title: Dead Presidents Society
description: THE SMITHSONIAN INSTITUTION

title: Show Revels in Innovative Use of Materials
description: THE Pelham Art Center here has conducted an yearly art competition since 1989. The first one lasted only three days and even admitted high school students. The next year the show ran for three weeks, and an entrant had to be at least in college. The requirements have progressively tightened, and this year for the first time the competition is national. An entrant still has to fit the category of emerging artist, and for the purposes of the competition this means not being represented by a gallery.

title: Business Best Sellers
description: HARD COVER

title: Don't Call Me 'Near Elderly'
description: Instead of ''senior,'' ''no spring chicken'' and the like, I prefer ''old.'' If it is acceptable to say ''young,'' why not ''old''?

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; What to Teach Our Daughters?
description: WHEN Brenda Barnes, president of Pepsi-Cola North America announced her resignation to be with her children, she caused quite a stir. Here was a woman who had reached a goal that most women don't even bother considering: a corporate position of power and wealth. She was playing with the big boys and succeeding when she left it all for hearth and home. And then everyone had something to say about it.

title: 'Birthday Letters'
description: 'Apprehensions'

title: Correction
description: The art column and a picture caption on Feb. 15 about a Smithtown Township exhibition misspelled the surname of a photographer. He is Louis Spitalnick, not Spilatnick.

title: February 22-28; A Defector Warns of Biological Threat
description: A defector from the former Soviet biological weapons program said in an interview that Moscow's cold-war plans for World War III included a doomsday plot of germ warfare.

title: Work That Elevates What's Found at the Feet
description: FROM the remnants of broken bottles and smashed car windshields, Bing Hu creates beauty. Ms. Bing, a native of Shanghai, produces sculptures from a studio in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, using mostly materials gathered nearby. Sixteen of her pieces (a detail of one is shown above) can be seen at the Brooklyn Museum of Art in the show ''Scattered Petals, Fallen Leaves, Shards of Glass,'' the latest in a series of exhibitions of work by emerging artists who live or work in Brooklyn.

title: 'Official Negligence'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZAGAT, ELEANOR PASNER
description: ZAGAT-Eleanor Pasner. February 28, 1959. A dearly loved sister who had great capacity, quality and feeling. Mathilde Christapos

title: And on the Next Slide...
description: Presentations: They're showtime for some people, the bane of many others. How have they gone for you? And what moments next to the overhead projector would you most like to forget? Or remember? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: A 'Nothing Sacred' Episode You Haven't Seen
description: FATHER RAY, the pastor of St. Thomas's parish, receives a troubling phone call about his good friend Father Jesse. Despite the usual chaos that characterizes his rectory (and any good Catholic rectory), Ray leaves his staff in charge and goes off to see Jesse, who, it turns out, has AIDS. Disgraced, humiliated and despairing, Jesse plans to leave the priesthood.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Vernon Jordan's Resume: Is Too Much Too Much?
description: AS the he-said, she-said donnybrook rages at the White House, the role of Vernon E. Jordan Jr. has been subject to some conjecture. Obviously, I do not have the remotest clue about what Mr. Jordan has done in the Clinton-Lewinsky morality play -- for whom, when or why. I am struck, however, by the series of critical comments about Mr. Jordan's actions on various corporate boards.

title: A Hats-Off Success in Fish Presentation
description: THE talented and ever restless Tom Schaudel has at one time or another been the chef and owner of the Downtown Grill in Montauk, 107 Forest Avenue in Locust Valley, Eli's Roadhouse in Plainview, 660 West in Garden City and Lemongrass in Roslyn. He has had his restaurant ups and downs but his latest venture, 107 Ocean Bistro in Locust Valley, is a winner all the way.

title: Betty Friedan's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Russell Reeder, 95, Leader In Invasion on D-Day, Dies
description: Col. Russell P. (Red) Reeder, who accumulated six demerits in his first two hours as a cadet at West Point, but went on to become one of its most beloved graduates and a highly decorated commander in the D-Day invasion of Normandy, died last Sunday at Inova Mount Vernon Hospital in Alexandria, Va. He was 95 and lived in a military retirement community adjacent to Fort Belvoir, Va.

title: Milken Is Gone, But Junk Still Reigns
description: The king is long gone, but the junk bond market has never looked more robust.

title: Lonely At The Top
description: Let us be clear about what happened in the recent confrontation with Saddam Hussein. It was not the use of force that brought about the agreement brokered by the United Nations; it was the threat of force. The difference is crucial, and therein lies an important lesson.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: High Crimes

title: Pink Makes You Think . . .
description: A children's fashion story

title: Starks Is Injured At Knicks Practice
description: The banged and bruised Knicks watched another player go down today when John Starks hyperextended his right elbow during a collision at practice. Starks left the floor for treatment and was listed as day to day, though he said he expected to play against the Los Angeles Lakers on Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

title: A Burst of Renewal Sweeps Old Beijing Into the Dumpsters
description: The neighborhood known as Willow Alley lives on in the watercolors of Deng Haifan, who lived there for 80 years, until last November, and he wants his grandchildren to remember what life in this once-typical corner of Beijing was like.

title: Baptist Group Ousts Church for Welcoming Gay People
description: A Texas church ostracized by other local Baptists in the 1940's for welcoming blacks has come under fire again, this time after ordaining a gay deacon and advertising an outreach program for gay people on its Web site.

title: Republicans End Silence On Troubles Of President
description: After weeks of largely collective restraint, many of the nation's most prominent Republicans unleashed scathing attacks on President Clinton this weekend, asserting that his relationship with a White House intern raised questions about his moral fitness for office.

title: Corrections
description: The New York on Line column on Dec. 14 about an exhibition of computer art at the School of Visual Arts misattributed two animated poems in the show, ''Self Reflexive #1'' and ''Ghost Train.'' They were written by B. P. Nichol. They were adapted for the World Wide Web by Tim McLaughlin, who pointed out the error in a letter dated Feb. 11.

title: In Spain, They Dance and Sing of Garcia Lorca
description: In commemoration of the 100th anniversary of Federico Garcia Lorca's birth, Spain will pay homage to its great poet and playwright with exhibitions and theatrical presentations throughout 1998.

title: Word & Image; The Unedited Air
description: One day early in the drama, i thought I had stumbled upon a recording of the silly sidewalk banter that is common among reporters idling away the time at some stakeout outside the home of a newsworthy personage. Some excerpts:

title: Maine Limits Fishing For Island's Lobster
description: For the first time in Maine history, the lobster grounds surrounding an island have been declared off limits to all who are not islanders.

title: New Tune for the Material Girl: I'm Neither
description: IMAGINE MADONNA in the most unlikely position she could take. Perhaps this: Alone in a silent room, lying face up on the floor in a yoga pose known as the corpse, crying uncontrollably. The 39-year-old singer, notorious for being the pre-eminent quick-change artist of her generation, found herself in this odd and vulnerable situation more than once in the two years that led up to the release of her new album, ''Ray of Light.'' She was not engaging in a kinky sex rite or a new performance style. She was doing what had not come naturally, she says -- confronting herself.

title: Balkanizing Homer
description: THE FILE ON H.

title: Another Comeback For Cone
description: David Cone was standing on a cruise ship with the wind pelting his body and other passengers clicking photographs of him the first time he lightly flipped a ball after shoulder surgery last October. The ship was breezing across the ocean and Cone was trying to prove his career was about another comeback, not one final farewell on a Yankee cruise.

title: Life-Jacket Rule Has Some Sailors Upset
description: A spate of drownings among sailors in the last few years has prompted United States yachting officials to come up with a rule that requires competitors to wear life jackets during offshore racing, even on big keelboats.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MELCER, DAVID
description: MELCER-David. Hail to thee dear Father, man of noble spirit. You live with me always. Herbert

title: Sold! To the Buyer With the Eclectic Taste
description: More than 1,000 buyers from 50 countries purchased pieces of one of the most celebrated love story of the 20th century, that of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, during a nine-day sale at Sotheby's that ended Friday.

title: A Family Channel That Even the Pets May Enjoy
description: DURING the opening credits, it looks and sounds like ''E.R.,'' with quick-cut flashing medical scenes, close-ups of doctors' anguished faces and a soundtrack with a powerful drumbeat. But you know this television series has a different twist as soon as the patients start rolling into the operating room: Faith the cat, whose dislocated jaw makes it difficult to eat her Meow Mix; Misty the Pekingese, who had a tussle with a Rottweiler; Spike, an iguana who's looking a bit pale (kidney trouble, it turns out).

title: Correction: International Funds
description: A table on Feb. 1 with an article about Fidelity Investments misstated some return figures for the flagship international stock funds of leading mutual fund companies. Here are corrected figures.

title: Moving to Semantical High Ground
description: The advertised price was $30 for an eighth of an ounce of ''Five Star Mexican Gold,'' and dollar bills were exchanged at a brisk clip today for plastic bags of marijuana. But, in deference to a new court ruling barring the sale of the drug by clubs, a hastily erected sign over the marijuana bar read: ''Remuneration Station.''

title: Car-Rental Offers Abroad
description: THIS is usually the month when Americans expecting to go to Europe in the summer can reserve a rental car and lock in a rate, often an advantageous one, in dollars.

title: Friends
description: THE QUAKERS Money and Morals. By James Walvin. Illustrated. 243 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.: John Murray/ Trafalgar Square. $45.

title: Needles Click to a Younger Beat
description: THEY are on the subway. Wherever lines form. In court. At the movies. Casually walking down the street. Knitters. All over New York, there seem to be more of them, feverishly working needles, their yarn discreetly tucked in a bag by their side, on their lap or even in a pocket.

title: Kohl's Rival Faces a Vote That's Make Or Break
description: About 6 million of Germany's 82 million people are eligible to vote on Sunday in a local election that, under normal circumstances, would have problems raising ripples, let alone waves. But this ballot is attracting unusual attention: It could well help determine who leads Europe's greatest economic power into the 21st century -- just as the continent's quest for elusive unity, and Germany's ability to lead it, face their greatest challenge.

title: Has Nonfiction Ever Lived Up to Its Name?
description: To the Editor:

title: Americans Abroad Learning Studies Now Offer a Bargain
description: Marie Claire Santos-Lim returned to Yale University this winter after a highly satisfying autumn semester in which she immersed herself in Spanish language and culture at the University of Seville.

title: Has Nonfiction Ever Lived Up to Its Name?; Liberties Are Justified
description: To the Editor:

title: Ah, the 15 Percent Bracket
description: Despite the ''kiddie tax,'' in which unearned -- that is, investment -- income of children under age 14 is taxed at their parents' marginal rate, taxpayers who plan wisely can still get some breaks when it comes to children and money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, JACQUELINE
description: FOSTER-Jacqueline. On February 27, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence Hausman. Loving mother of Lisa Haft Balter, Wendy Haft, Robin Abbott, Daniel Foster Haft and Jason Foster Scheinbart. Adoring grandmother of Lawrence, Emily, Samuel, William, Jane, Claire and Nora. We love you forever. Service Monday, 10 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: From Honeymoon to Last Hurrah
description: SOME MUSICIANS of the Houston Symphony Orchestra say they were shocked when Christoph Eschenbach told them, four months ago, that he would relinquish the orchestra's music directorship in 1999, when his contract ends. In his decade on the Houston podium, Mr. Eschenbach has transformed a demoralized regional orchestra with a respectable history but scant acclaim into a world-class touring and recording ensemble. Several of the players speak of his tenure as a honeymoon that never ended, and on the eve of his final tour with the orchestra, which includes a concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, Mr. Eschenbach did not dispute that characterization.

title: The Little Creepy Crawlers Who Will Eat You In The Night
description: There are two parts to this story, and the first, like most things in Silicon Valley, can be dispensed with quickly. It runs something like this: In the 1960's and 70's, the Santa Clara Valley got itself a new name by making silicon chips, personal computers and related goods. The sunshine, the absence of tradition, the willingness of Stanford University to do business with corporations and the presence of a counterculture intent on arming the masses with new technology all made the Valley the place to be for people with a knack for building new machines. Other things being equal, the new will arise where the old simply does not exist.

title: Stiletto Out, Sabrina In
description: For spring and summer, sexy, curvy, colorful shoes are everywhere -- and they are walkable. After last year's stiletto heel made it hard for many women to negotiate even a cocktail party, a lower, narrower style known as the Sabrina heel has become the new look. The style, worn by Audrey Hepburn in the 1954 film of the same name, is also known as the Louis heel, as Louis XIV favored it.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column on Feb. 8, about the renovation of a row house at 28 West 126th Street under the Cityhome program, misstated the address of another building being restored under the program. That house is at 74 East 127th Street, not 74 West. The article also misstated a financial requirement for prospective purchasers of that house. A buyer must have a minimum income of $41,000; the figure is not the income ceiling.

title: Meditation and Hard Work, Making Pottery and Making Music
description: FROM Brookfield Craft Center to Broadway stage, from making pottery to making music may sound like unlikely progressions, but, strangely, it all came together. Susan H. Schulman, director of a revival of ''The Sound of Music'' that opens on Broadway March 12, was intent on researching the lives of the nuns in Austria before World War II. Seeking to add depth to their characterizations, she traveled to Salzburg, Austria, to meet Mother Perpetua of the Nunnberg Abbey. There she gathered a historical perspective of the nuns in the days of Maria Von Trapp. She learned that in the atmosphere at Salzburg Abbey, carved into the side of a mountain in 1741, ''nuns were not solely concerned with quiet meditation, but also occupied themselves restoring frescoes in the abbey, making pottery on the kick-wheel and using hand building techniques with molds.''

title: Skeletons in the Family Closet
description: SLAVES IN THE FAMILY

title: Classics in Connecticut
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANYAEGBUNAM, AKOLISA M., M.D.
description: ANYAEGBUNAM - Akolisa M., M.D. The entire Albert Einstein College of Medicine community mourns the untimely passing of our distinguished Professor of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Women's Health and Clinical Chairman of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Women's Health at Jacobi Medical Center. A dedicated and caring physician, an outstanding teacher, a prolific author in the scientific literature, and an inspiring leader in the medical community, he exemplified all that is most highly revered in our profession. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D., Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Jones's Lawyer Likes Underdog Role
description: The law offices of Donovan Campbell Jr., the lead attorney for Paula Corbin Jones, consist of a small suite in an isolated high-rise off the Stemmons Freeway here looking out at Texas scrub and Dallas sprawl. It is tidy and, he says, sufficient for the six lawyers in his firm.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: NIGHT BEAT

title: It's Brand Over Bargain In the World of Cigars
description: LIKE stogies left out in the rain, the stocks of cigar companies are fizzling fast. Many are near their 52-week lows, and shares of the four largest public enterprises -- Swisher International Group, General Cigar Holdings, Consolidated Cigar Holdings and 800-JR Cigar -- have dropped 20 to 46 percent since October.

title: Nantz's Eloquence
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROFMAN, HENRY
description: BROFMAN-Henry. February 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Pearl for 64 years. Devoted father of Dr. Jerelyn Brofman and Faith Block. Loving grandfather of Debra Sue Goldberg and Heidi Levine, and great-grandfather of Barry Leonard Goldberg. Donations in his memory can be made to the Diabetes Association. Services Sunday 12:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amerstam Avenue.

title: How to Work With Types of Plastics
description: AT one time, plastics were considered to be cheap substitutes for quality materials like wood or metal. Now, however, many craftsmen recognize that plastics can be an attractive and durable material to work with.

title: Beach Replenishment Helps Few at Expense of Many
description: To the Editor:

title: Digging Up an Old Return
description: Divorces are often bitterly fought, and Julian Block, a tax lawyer in Larchmont, N.Y., notes one frequent consequence: Months or even years later, one ex-spouse is left with no record of the joint finances and possibly even trouble with the I.R.S. and no clue as to what he or she signed that caused it. In either case, a copy of the tax return can clear up the picture, and either signatory to a joint return can request a copy of it from the I.R.S. For details call the I.R.S. Tele-Tax number, (800) 829-4477, and press 1-5-6.

title: Memories of Moscow
description: These pictures, from an album found in a second-hand shop in Ardmore, Pa., were taken in 1896, part of a record of an extensive European tour. The captions are as clear as the images, which are still sharp after more than a century: ''Fresh bread and cakes,'' ''Junk stall -- Louse Market,'' ''Russian Tourists at Sparrow Hills,'' ''A noon-hour sleep,'' ''Our hotel room in Moscow'' and ''Mr. Lowell and the tattered drunkard.'' All else is mysterious. Who was the photographer? Who were the travelers? Specifically, who was Mr. Lowell, a member of the traveling party, or an acquaintance of the road? And, sadly, how did what must have been a family treasure end up in a secondhand shop in Ardmore, Pa.?

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: March Begins With Duke and UConn Roaring; Losing to Tar Heels by 17, Blue Devils Storm Back
description: The top-ranked team in the country was playing on its home court before a frenzied, full house today. Undisputed possession of first place in the Atlantic Coast Conference, and with it an excellent chance at the top seeding in the East Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, was on the line as the regular season drew to a close.

title: New Shape To Triangle Tying U.S. And Koreas
description: The United States and South Korea have always been a bit like spouses as well as allies, and Seoul's basic demand of Washington has been for diplomatic fidelity: thou shalt not commit adultery with North Korea.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Views of the City

title: Too Many Vehicles, Too Much Rage
description: DURING his 20 years as a Connecticut truck driver, Alan Green has watched some of his fellow truckers try to force motorists off the road. But he also reports being routinely cut off by aggressive drivers more interested in speed than safety.

title: Understated Asian, New in New Canaan
description: FOR its size, New Canaan may have more restaurants than any other Fairfield County town, and that was before the newest, Asie, opened, boosting the per capita total again.

title: New Coach, Same Team: Rangers Let Another Slip Away
description: It took exactly two games for the exciting, free-flowing Rangers of the new Coach John Muckler to look an awful lot like the ninth-place team that got Colin Campbell fired.

title: At Brookhaven, a New Charge That Radiation Threatens Water
description: Raising new questions about pollution at the Brookhaven National Laboratory, a former scientist there has charged that the lab has jeopardized local drinking water by draining millions of gallons of discarded water into basins near an old but still potent radioactive hot spot.

title: Plumbers' Lawsuit
description: Four Westchester plumbers have filed suit in United States District Court in White Plains, seeking to overturn the county plumber licensing law because it treats them differently from electricians. In the suit, filed last month, the plumbers charge that the law violates the 14th Amendment of the United States Constitution, which requires equal protection under the law.

title: Ms. Bingham, Mr. McAdams
description: Marian Bingham and Kenneth George McAdams were married yesterday at Woodbridge Farm, the bride's home in Salem, Conn. The Rev. Dale Pauls, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

title: Armour Surrounded By the Field
description: So many golfers have a chance to win the Nissan Open, perhaps they should call it the Nissan Wide Open.

title: The World; The Front-Runner in India Is Deep Doubt
description: NOT long ago, a villager outside New Delhi faced an unusual quandary. As voting day approached, the man was exploring freedoms denied him for years as a bonded laborer in a stone quarry outside the city. Like millions of other Indians in a similar plight, he had been a slave in all but name, working to defray debts his father had accumulated with the quarry owner.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Katell le Bourhis; A Windsor Rejoins the House of Dior
description: ON Wednesday, Katell le Bourhis was ready to buy a dress that was not her style, would cost too much and was the wrong color. And it most definitely would not fit.

title: British Officer Said to Give NATO Plans to Bosnian Serbs
description: The British Government is expected to charge an army major next month with providing classified NATO information and documents to the Bosnian Serb leadership during the last two years of the Balkan war, according to senior Western diplomats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGREE, BETTY
description: AGREE-Betty On February 25, 1998, in her 74th year. Daughter of the late Isadore and Mary Agree. Dear sister of George E. and Lee Agree, of Washington D.C. Beloved aunt of Andrew, Robert and Jonathan. Betty will be lovingly remembered by her many friends, colleagues and relatives. Memorial services Monday, March 2nd, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: It's Not Easy to Push Sex Into the Shadows
description: As early as the 1840's, dauntless pushcart vendors and stationery stores hawked lewd postcards of women in considerably less than full attire. It was only a matter of time before there was a topless shoeshine parlor in Times Square.

title: One Putts, the Other Gets Pampered
description: ON our trip to Florida last year we struck a deal. My husband, Bill, would play golf and I'd play spa slug. But where to go without breaking that all-important vacation rule, togetherness?

title: Israeli Learns Some Are More Israeli Than Others
description: Three years ago, Adel Kaadan saw an ad in the paper for lots on this hilltop near his village. The view was spectacular, the infrastructure modern, the school good and the price right.

title: Houston
description: In some part of Houston's soul, the oil boom will surely live forever. Even today, the city's tourism literature gushes about the 1970's: ''Multimillion-dollar corporations were invented on paper napkins in fast-food restaurants (Compaq Computer for one) and real estate prices tripled.''

title: No Invitation? No Problem!
description: NETTIE GEFFNER has talked her way into dozens of Broadway premieres, so there was no way she was going to miss opening night of ''The Lion King.'' She positioned herself outside the New Amsterdam Theater, on 42d Street, observant, patient, determined. With a winning smile and grandmotherly sweetness, she methodically queried the black-tie swells stepping out of their limos: ''Pardon me, any extra tickets?''

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Colorful backgrounds mark a cluster of choice films this week: long-ago Hollywood, the American frontier, the Sahara Desert and the diplomatic service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VISERTO, LOUISE, NEE FILIZZOLA
description: VISERTO-Louise, nee Filizzola. Passed on peacefully on February 22 at the age of 92. She is survived by her son Charles Bellissimo and many grandchildren and great grandchildren. Louise is buried at Pinelawn Cemetery, Long Island.

title: On Language; On the Lam, Who Made Thee?
description: ''Big-time Clinton-Gore donor Ted Sioeng,'' wrote The Wall Street Journal's crusading editorialist, ''poured some $250,000 into campaign coffers, and has recently been on the lam from nosy investigators.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFF, MARY CATHERINE (NEE TUOMEY)
description: HOFF-Mary Catherine (nee Tuomey), age 74, of Oradell, NJ, died Thursday, February 26, 1998. Beloved wife of the late George E. Hoff, wonderful mother of eight children, she is survived by seven: Mary Eileen Roos and Nancy Tishman, both of Arlington, VA.; Walter Hoff of Atlanta, Georgia; Vincent Hoff of Honolulu, Hawaii; Edward Hoff of Cambridge, MA.; Geri Havill of Packanack Lake, NJ; and Dr. James Hoff of Tulsa, OK. She is survived by her children's seven spouses, seventeen grandchildren and her brothers, Timothy Tuomey of Chicago, IL., and James Tuomey of Buffalo Grove, Illinois. A son, Thomas Hoff died in 1965 as a result of cerebral palsy. Throughout her life, she infused her extended family with her spirit of faith and strength and graced everyone who knew her with her charm and selfless generosity. A talented writer and speaker, she was valedictorian and president of her graduating class at Mundelein College in Chicago. Upon graduation, she became a policy representative of the American Library Association and later a certified teacher in Illinois and New Jersey. She was a devoted parishoner and Eurcharist minister in St. Joseph's R.C. Church in Oradell for thirty years, and a friend and member of the Women's Club of Haworth, N.J. Visiting will be Sunday, March 1, at the Volk-Leber Funeral Home, 268 Kinderkamack Road, Oradell, NJ from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. The Funeral Liturgy wil be celebrated Monday, March 2 at 9:30 AM in St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Oradell. Entombment will be at Holy Cross Mausoleum in North Arlington, New Jersey.

title: Exercises in Self-Discipline
description: THE last place I expected to have the insides of my ears massaged was in a New England Yankee town. And that wasn't the only surprise I had on a recent trip north to try out the spa facilities at two hotels in Vermont.

title: Culture Zone; Portrait of the Artist As a Focus Group
description: If you took a poll, what would America's best-loved painting look like? In their playful new book, ''Painting by Numbers,'' two Russian emigre conceptual artists decided to find out. With a little help from some polling experts, Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid queried 1,001 Americans about their tastes in color, form and style, and concluded that the most wanted painting in the country is a bluish landscape painting, populated by George Washington, a family of tourists and a pair of frolicking deer. The canvas is the size of a dishwasher and looks like something that might adorn the walls of a third-rate motel. It is the apotheosis of art created by consensus.

title: A Grandmother's Biological Clock
description: Wow! Are all New York intellectuals so conventional? Wedding presents from Tiffany? Crystal soup tureens? Are we in a Woody Allen movie? How about buying something more useful -- a shiny solar collector from Real Goods, perhaps.

title: Maria Steiner, Duccio Baldari
description: Maria Luz Steiner, the daughter of Mercedes Steiner and Dr. German Steiner of New York, and Dr. Duccio Baldari, the son of Anna Baldari and Dr. Giorgio Baldari of Livorno, Italy, were married yesterday in New York. Msgr. Michael J. Wrenn performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

title: Moment to Savor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mitsubishi Montero; A High-Riding Truck Tested in Timbuktu
description: MOST Americans, if you asked, would be hard pressed to find the city of Dakar, Senegal, on a map. So it seems unlikely that the Mitsubishi Montero's second consecutive sweep of the famously brutal Paris-to-Dakar rally will wow them in the heartland, where the farthest off-road that many sport utilities go is the drive-through at Dunkin' Donuts.

title: Blame for Bay of Pigs
description: To the Editor:

title: Refinancing Again? Take a Deduction
description: With interest rates dropping last year, many people refinanced mortgages to get the lower rate. Points paid on a home purchase can be deducted up front, but points paid in a refinancing must be amortized over the life of the loan for tax purposes. But here is a break that many taxpayers overlook in a second refinancing: The unamortized points remaining when the mortgage for the first refinancing is paid off are deductible in full.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NIVEN, DAVID
description: NIVEN-David. You would have been eighty-eight today. You gave so much to so many. It is so sad that you are gone. Jamie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, DAVE
description: COHEN-Dave. In loving memory. Dear friend, we will miss you. Harold Mintz and Family Ken Schwartz and Family

title: Devils Fall Behind, Squander a Lead and Wind Up Winning Anyway
description: Nothing seems to faze the Devils these days. They fell behind tonight for the third game in a row, squandering a two-goal lead, but came back in style for their sixth straight victory, a 4-3 decision over the Carolina Hurricanes.

title: The Egg Men
description: DR. RICHARD SCOTT is on the phone, hunched over his computer, studying the calendar on his screen. Many people have packed date books and stressful lives, but few are so tightly scheduled as Dr. Scott and his patients. When sperm and egg cannot be joined in the traditional way, it is Dr. Scott's job to unite them the high-tech way, a process that resembles launching a spaceship in its intricacy and timing.

title: THEATER; That Power-Mad Couple Seems So Familiar
description: WHY SO MANY Macbeths all of a sudden? Angela Bassett, worrying that famous ''damned spot'' in George C. Wolfe's new production (in previews at the Joseph Papp Public Theater and opening on March 15), brings to at least 17 the Lady Macbeths on stage in New York since last summer. From Lincoln Center to Off Off Off, these productions have run the gamut. Alec Baldwin, directed by Mr. Wolfe as a basically Scottish, basically medieval king (that is, the character Shakespeare wrote), follows hard upon renditions in which Macbeth has been, among others, a Zulu warrior, a Wall Street lawyer, a Japanese gangster, a baritone, and a woman.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Trolley Memento

title: Water Near L.I. Lab Reported in Jeopardy
description: Raising new questions about pollution at the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, a former scientist there has charged that the lab has jeopardized local drinking water by draining millions of gallons of waste water into basins near an old radioactive ''hot spot.'' He voiced fear that waste water may have caused the radioactivity to penetrate the underground water supply.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, HAROLD
description: GOLDSTEIN-Harold. Loving father of Dorian and Robert; devoted father-in-law of Harriet and Benita; cherished grandfather of Alan, Donald, Julie, and Seth; adored great-grandfather of Max, Emily, Leah, Jared, Miles, Hannah and Eli; dear friend of Carol Wigder. Services Monday 12 noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSHON, DOROTHY H.
description: HIRSHON-Dorothy H. The life of Dorothy H. Hirshon, who passed away on January 29, will be celebrated on Thursday, March 5, at 11:30 AM in the New School's Tishman Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street. Mrs. Hirshon had been on the Boards of the New School for Social Research, Phoenix House Foundation, Carnegie Hall, the National Urban League, the Taconic Foundation, and a number of other institutions and organizations. She also was a two-term member of the New York City Commission on Human Rights in the early 1960's, on the Planning Board of the City of Glen Cove, Long Island, where she lived, and was Chairman of the Hospitality Committee of the United Nations. Speakers will include her family members, friends, and representatives of the organizations she served.

title: A Decade Later, Star Status for the 80's
description: ADAM SANDLER is not the real star of the hit comedy ''The Wedding Singer.'' Neither is Drew Barrymore, nor even Ellen Albertini Dow, the grandmother whose Geritol version of ''Rapper's Delight'' provides the amiable film with its funniest moment. Top billing should go to the movie's spot-on re-creation of the 1980's, its fads and fashions, trends and taste lapses.

title: Lives; Nowhere Man
description: When I used to hear of lost souls who trekked to Nepal or New Zealand or some other distant land to ''find themselves,'' I scoffed. How did they expect to find themselves in a place they'd never been?

title: Iron Fists Along the Silk Road
description: FIFTEEN days in Uzbekistan! It is a prospect to delight the heart of any adventurous traveler. Here is an ancient Central Asian land of teeming bazaars and spectacular architecture, comprising domains once ruled by Alexander, Genghis Kahn and Tamerlane, most of it hidden from foreign eyes for centuries. Last October I traveled overland to nearly every part of the country, and like every traveler I found some images especially vivid.

title: Moving (Too Slowly for Some) to Fight Lead Poisoning
description: To the heartfelt cheers of doctors and community advocates, the City of Newark proudly opened two lead-free safe houses in the last few months, enabling it to move children with dangerously high lead levels and their families out of contaminated dwellings so that the chipping and peeling lead-based paint can be safely removed.

title: The World; In Drug War, America Barks but Fear of Bite Fades
description: THE driver was late, the aide had the directions all wrong, and as Colombia's Ambassador rode up Capitol Hill the other day to defend his country's drug-fighting record before one more skeptical audience, his only armor was two copies of a thin, boring-looking Government report. For the emissary of a country whose drug-enforcement efforts had failed the United States' certification test two years in a row, the Ambassador, Juan Carlos Esguerra, was looking remarkably unperturbed.

title: Editorial Notebook; One Scholar and the Matrix of the Past
description: In a city like New York the deep meaning of culture occasionally presents itself, not as a definition but as a web of unexpected entanglements. A good example is the modest exhibition of cylinder seals now on display at the Pierpont Morgan Library.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT/Page 6/

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 15 about blacks who migrated to Chicago misspelled the surname of an artist who designed a monument to them. She is Alison Saar, not Sarr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, SEYMOUR E.
description: WEINTRAUB-Seymour E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Seymour E. Weintraub, associated with The Times from 1973, until retiring in 1981.

title: INVESTING IT; Fixed Annuities: New Twists and Old Gnarls
description: UNHAPPY with static sales, the marketers of fixed annuities are jazzing them up. But financial planners say the twists come at a price and, anyway, do not correct the fundamental flaws of these investments.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Eating Chinese Food Naked

title: The Moment That Defines O'Neill
description: Don Larsen graced history with his World Series perfect game, and in turn, history graced Larsen. Baseball fans, and Yankees fans, in particular, will remember Larsen the same way they will remember the post-season heroics of Reggie Jackson, Bucky Dent and Chris Chambliss. The same way they will remember Paul O'Neill, for his play in the 1997 playoffs.

title: A Promising Clean Water Strategy
description: The 1972 Clean Water Act has been the most effective of all the landmark environmental measures enacted in the early 1970's. But while it has done a good job of controlling pollution from so-called ''point sources'' like factories and waste treatment plants, the act has failed to stem poisonous runoff from ''non-point'' sources like farms and city streets. This runoff is the main reason why nearly 40 percent of the nation's lakes and streams remain unfishable and unswimmable.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 9 about Lincoln's early years misstated the direction in which the writer traveled from Springfield, Ill., to Lincoln's roots on the Kentucky and Indiana prairie. It was southeast, not southwest.

title: Alcohol and Accidents
description: To the Editor:

title: February 22-28; A Grim Trade in Organs From Chinese Prisoners
description: Spurred by a prominent human-rights advocate, Federal authorities in New York City arrested two Chinese citizens for conspiring to sell kidneys, corneas and other organs from the bodies of prisoners executed in China.

title: Food; Pot of Gold
description: A good pot roast is the apogee of home cooking, offering, as it does, the specter of magic. Suddenly, after hours on the stove, the tough turns tender; the coarse becomes elegant, and the ordinary, irresistible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OYSTER, JIM
description: OYSTER-Jim, 67. Of New York City and Blairstown, N.J., on February 23, 1998 from acute, latestage alcholism. Veteran actor of seven Broadway plays, many tours and regional theater productions. Beloved ''unk'' of Missy Mellor and her siblings Jeffrey, Jenny and Jim. Also survived by cousin Muriel Blumenthal and many adoring friends. Cremation private. Burial in Easton, MD. Memorial service to be announced. Donations to The Actors Fund. Blessings.

title: What's New? A Lot; Beijing
description: Beijing visitors who find all the new Western-style shopping centers too tame can once again join the hordes of Chinese tourists who parade through the refurbished Mao Zedong Mausoleum, on the south side of Tiananmen Square. It reopened in January after being shut down for nine months for unspecified repairs.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Clintons Slip Away to Unlikely Haven
description: So what is a Baptist Democratic Arkansan golfer who does not ski doing in a state like this?

title: City Hall Memo; Is This Henry Higgins Playing to the Nation?
description: Perhaps there is need for pause when a big-city mayor's call for basic civility becomes national news. Then again, the city is New York, where anyone who smiles is regarded as mentally unbalanced. And the Mayor is Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose charms tend to be muted by a sometimes abrasive manner.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Shopping at Asia's Fire Sale: Can Managers Avoid Getting Burned?
description: SURE, the Asian markets took a kamikaze dive last quarter: the Morgan Stanley Emerging Markets Asia Index was down 33 percent, and fund managers suffered mightily.

title: Visions of Two-Edged Horde
description: Edward Morales, the manager of Fleet Auto Service at Second Avenue and 12th Street, was waiting out a Wednesday afternoon shift and thinking about the proposal to build a new mall and cinema complex across the street.

title: Backfield in Motion As Hampton Must Wait
description: Pro football has had plenty of two-back offenses. And one-back offenses. And offenses with no backs at all lined up behind the quarterback.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on Feb. 15 about trips through the Panama Canal misstated the toll-free telephone number of Panama Discovery Tours. It is (888) 726-2621.

title: SOAPBOX; Egg Roll Revenge
description: THERE'S only one digit of difference between my phone number and that of Tang Tang, a Chinese restaurant at Second Avenue and 88th Street. So every Sunday and often on Thursday (which seems to be the second most popular evening for takeout), starting about 3 P.M., my phone would ring.

title: In Giving, a Way to Avoid Capital Gains Tax
description: For the charitably inclined, gifts of appreciated securities are often a better way to meet a pledge than cash. Why? You can deduct the market value of the gift and avoid capital gains tax. The charity can sell the shares and is not liable for taxes.

title: Father of His Country
description: NELSON MANDELA A Biography. By Martin Meredith. Illustrated. 596 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $29.95.

title: Forgotten Costs In Refinancing
description: To the Editor:

title: February 22-28; New Report of Error By Israel's Spy Agency
description: The Mossad, Israel's foreign intelligence agency, was the subject of new embarrassing reports, with Israeli radio and television saying it had suffered a ''very serious'' failure in Europe. In Switzerland, authorities confirmed that five Mossad agents had been caught trying to bug a house in Bern, and that one was being held. Some Israeli reports spoke of an Iranian target of the operation, but Swiss officials denied that.

title: For Retirees, a New World of Complexities
description: JOHN H. STIVES says it takes him a little longer each year to get his taxes done. ''My calculator makes more mistakes every year,'' says Mr. Stives, 78, who nevertheless takes pride in preparing the forms himself.

title: Some Letters Inspire Nostalgia, Others Spell Trouble: A McDonald's Advertisement Raises Three Floors' Worth of Protests
description: A three-story sign advertising a local McDonald's has caught more than the eye of passing drivers hankering for Happy Meals. The Golden Arches, or, to be precise, red arches, have drawn the scorn of Jackson Heights civic leaders, and the attention of the city Department of Buildings, which says the sign doesn't belong there.

title: The American Way of Jail
description: Crime and Punishment in America By Elliott Currie. 230 pp. New York: Metropolitan Books/ Henry Holt & Company. $23.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMON, ANN R. (STOLL)
description: SIMON-Ann R. (Stoll). 3/5/33-5/8/96 In memory of a devoted daughter and sister. In our thoughts every day. Missed so very much. Mae Stoll and Ellen Pearlman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANYAEGBUNAM, DR. AKOLISA M.
description: ANYAEGBUNAM-Dr. Akolisa M. On February 27, 1998. The staff of Jacobi Medical Center and North Central Bronx Hospital deeply mourn the tragic and untimely passing of our Chairman of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Women's Health. As a professional, he will be remembered as a much admired, respected and renowned young physician whoe exceptional career spanned 17 outstanding years as a superb clinician, compassionate physician, dynamic teacher, prolific author, and able administrator. On a personal level, we will deeply miss ''Aki's'' warmth, wit and unique charm. We extned our deepest condolences to his family. Joseph S. Orland Seniro Vice President North Bronx Helathcare Network Jacobi Medical Center/ North Central Bronx Hospital

title: Q. & A.
description: Noise From Teen-agers' Basketball

title: 'Tis a Gift To Be Perfect. Or Is It?
description: ANOTHER STUDY on absolute -- or if you insist, perfect -- pitch appeared in these pages not long ago. A survey of 600 musicians showed pretty much the same results as past studies like it: namely, that the ability to identify the pitch names of notes plucked out of the air occurs mostly in people who begin music at an early age.

title: A Ride Back in Time: Pullman Cars Return
description: The return of luxury train travel in the United States will get a boost on Saturday, with the first of four transcontinental trips by two refurbished private cars from the 1920's, one built for Harold Vanderbilt, the son of Cornelius Vanderbilt. Pulled by regular Amtrak trains, the cars, operated by American Pullman Traditions of San Marino, Calif., offer accommodations for a total of 16 passengers on this week's seven-night trip, from New York to San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, KATHARINE (NEE BOSTON)
description: DALY-Katharine (nee Boston). Formerly of New York City, died at La Jolla, CA., on February 23, 1998 in her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late J. Holmes Daly and adored mother of Pamela Daly Vose. She was the daughter of the late Charles A. Boston and Ethel Lyon Boston of New York. Her father was president of the American Bar Association and an early partner of Hornblower & Boston, now Willkie Farr & Gallagher. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Chapin School, 100 East End Avenue, NYC 10028.

title: How to Manufacture a Best Seller
description: It was sold on a phrase and bought with the idea ''We can fix it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, EDWARD
description: LEWIS-Edward. The passing of Ed Lewis is noted with sorrow. A longtime associate, good friend and able consultant in the real estate field. He will surely be missed. With deep sympathy, Sarah Korein

title: New Benefits for Self-Employed, With Promise of More to Come
description: THE growing ranks of the self-employed are getting expanded tax breaks this year -- with more to come in the years ahead.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption last Sunday about multiple chemical sensitivity as a workers' compensation issue referred incorrectly to the case of Joann Taylor, an Ohio woman who sought such compensation from her employer, Centerior Energy. The Ohio Industrial Commission, which hears such cases, found in 1995 that the company should pay Ms. Taylor compensation while she was recovering from her illness; it did not award Ms. Taylor $400,000.

title: February 22-28; When You Call Me That, Smile!
description: He's the man who promised to chase bad guys away from New York. He's the one who predicted he'd improve the quality of life by driving out annoying squeegee men and pushing seedy sex shops into the remotest corners of the nation's largest city.

title: Susan Gordon, John Matheson
description: Susan Latimer Gordon, a daughter of Mary Gay Gordon and Richard Latimer Gordon of Omaha, was married there yesterday to John Murdoch Buchanan Matheson, a son of Bonnie Buchanan Matheson and Charles Thompkins Matheson of The Plains, Va. The Very Rev. Thomas Hurley performed the ceremony at Trinity Church.

title: Who Will Harvest The Nation's Bounty?
description: DEBATES about overhauling tax policy have never lacked vigor, but for the last 15 years they have been restrained by the huge Federal budget deficit, which has rendered talk of any sweeping tax reduction largely academic.

title: The World: Caveat Victor; At the End of the Rainbow, Ennui in the Pot of Gold
description: IF you've heard or read much at all about Tara Lipinski, you know about the piece of Tupperware, a prop as integral to her Lilliputian legend as the stone-bound sword was to Lancelot's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SIDNEY M.
description: MILLER-Sidney M. Of Pleasantville, NY, and Orleans, MA. Died February 26 at home at age 78. He is survived by his loving wife of 56 years, Barbara; his sister, Dorothy Bogdanoff; his brother, Hyman; his four sons, Paul, Bruce, Eric and Adam; four devoted daughters-inlaw; as well as four grandchildren, Luke, Max, Hannah and Alex. Sidney was Chairman of the Board of L. V. Myles, Inc., a manufacturer and importer of women's and children's sleepwear, robes and loungewear. In 1947, he joined a small business representing sewing contractors and over 50 years built the firm into one of the most respected companies in the field. In addition to his business career, Sidney was very active in community affairs, serving for many years as President of Usonia Homes, Inc., a cooperative residential community dedicated to the ideas and designs of Frank Lloyd Wright. In addition, he served for 12 years on the school boards of Bear Ridge and the Inaugural Board of Byram Hills. A memorial service will be held Sunday, March 1, at 10 AM, at Congregation B'nai Y'Israel. Contributions in Sidney's name may be made to Columbia College, Columbia University, Suite 917, 475 Riverside Dr., NY, NY 10115.

title: The View From/Torrington; Where Artists Meet And Share Their Work
description: TUCKED on a side street in Torrington's business district is a little storefront gallery -- a small, unimposing space that doesn't quite convey the momentum, the energy, the sheer numbers of artists who have made this place possible. Artwell, at 51 Water Street, barely three years old, is 100 members strong and churning out exhibitions and events. The nonprofit gallery was no more than a dream in the early spring of 1995. As Stewart Wilson tells it, he had been walking down Main Street with a friend late in 1994 when he casually mentioned that Torrington was a cute little town, but lacked a place where artists could meet and share their work. He put a classified advertisement in the local paper, got 10 people to come out for an initial meeting, and convinced a Water Street property owner that donating space for the group would be a good investment for the neighborhood.

title: Are Annoying Posters Illegal? Officials Say It's a Sticky Issue.
description: Like many New Yorkers, Gerard W. Purcell hates the handbills and posters for magazines and rock groups that bloom by the dozens or even the hundreds as soon as a building is torn down or becomes vacant. Mr. Purcell, the owner of Paparazzi, an Italian restaurant at 51st Street and Second Avenue, considers the posters that paper over the makeshift walls at a vacant lot at 52d Street and Second Avenue a blight on the East Side, where he grew up.

title: Competing Olympics; Hockey Embarrassment
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WE MUST LOVE ONE ANOTHER OR DIE

title: For Daisy Fuentes Fans and 'PR Food' Lovers
description: There are about 29 million Hispanic Americans, and surveys show that more than 80 percent of Hispanic American adults have access to computers at home or at work. But while few Web sites cater to this audience, the goal of Latina Magazine Online is to establish an on-line community for everyone interested in Latino culture.

title: The Nation: Monica and More; From Just Lurid To Truly Vile
description: FOR a while, the Monica Lewinsky story could not have seemed any more sensational and basic, built around allegations of sex and mendacity in the Oval Office. But now it may be getting even closer to the facts of life in Washington. It has begun peeling away at the dirty little secrets of how the capital scandal-hunting culture works, and with such a bare-knuckled vehemence on the part of the antagonists that the result may be even less uplifting for the nation than the original scandal story.

title: Voices Raised in Song Highlight Concerts
description: THE human voice is much in evidence this week, especially at concerts this afternoon.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: SOAPBOX; Rear and Center
description: LIKE Maria von Trapp scaling the Alps to hear the sound of music, I ascend the steps of Tier Four of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center to my seat in the center of Row L. It is the first night of my New Jersey Symphony Orchestra subscription series. I look at the people filling Row M behind my. There are no Rows N, O or P. There is no Tier Five. I elbow my husband: ''At least we don't have the worst seats in the house.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURT, MICHAEL E., M.D., PH.D.
description: BURT-Michael E., M.D., Ph.D. A memorial service will be held for Dr. Michael E. Burt on Monday, March 9th at 5 PM at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Rockefeller Research Laboratories, 430 East 67th Street. At the time of his death Dr. Burt was a thoracic surgeon and President of the Medical Staff at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. All are welcome to attend this service.

title: VIEWPOINT; An Accountable Process
description: GOOD accounting rules should be created in an open -- and accountable -- process. That is not how it works today, and that is why I have introduced the Financial Accounting Fairness Act. The legislation, now before the House Commerce Committee, calls for the Securities and Exchange Commission to vote on the pronouncements of the Financial Accounting Standards Board before companies are required to comply with them.

title: The Other Discoverer of the North Pole
description: WHEN Kevin Hooks was approached by TNT a year ago about making a movie on the Arctic explorers Robert E. Peary and Matthew Henson, his initial reaction was pretty much what you'd expect form someone who has spentmost of his life in Southern California. He recalls thinking to himself, in so many words: You're asking me to go to the North Pole to shoot a movie. You've got to be kidding.

title: What's New? A Lot; Moscow
description: If you want to understand what matters in Moscow today, skip Lenin's Tomb. Well, walk by if you like, but keep going another 200 yards until you come to the essential Russian shopping experience. No, not GUM, the huge department store that caters to czars and rich tourists, but the Okhotny Ryad mall in Manezh Square. Set near the Kremlin, where the world's most sustained assault on capitalism was carried out, this $350-million mall proves that nothing in Russia moves as fast as history.

title: Tax Offices Filling Up For Elder Exemption
description: THE assessors' office does not often draw a crowd in Southold, a haven for retired people on the North Fork. But lately the three assessors have been so sought after that they have opened their office on weekends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELMAN, MILTON H., M.D.
description: ADELMAN-Milton H., M.D. Died February 26, 1998. He was the cherished father of Samuel, grandfather of David and devoted husband of his late wife Sylvia. He is survived by his sister Lee, her husband Dr. Barnett A. Greene, nephew Dr. Stephen A. Rosenthal and wife Marilyn, nephew Dr. William H. Greene and wife Beverly, by nieces Mrs. Sherry Greene and Mrs. Jandy Blaine, five grandnieces and nephews. Dr. Adelman served with distinction at the Mt. Sinai Hospital for many years as Chief of the Department of Anesthesiology and as Chief of Anesthesiology at a general hospital in the U.S. Army in England during World War II, and finally as Clinical Professor of Anesthesiology at NYU School of Medicine. Interment is at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Mt. Pleasant, NY, on Sunday, March 1, at 12 noon.

title: Harvey C. Russell Jr., 79; Broke Ground for Blacks in Companies
description: Harvey C. Russell Jr., a retired Pepsico executive who was the first black man to become a vice president at a major American corporation, died on Feb. 20 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx.

title: Tests on Severed Foot Rule Out Missing Woman
description: Authorities trying to identify a severed foot that was found in the Hudson River two weeks ago have determined that it did not belong to a woman who disappeared with her boyfriend Nov. 7.

title: Sheffield Doubts He Will Be Ready
description: Gary Sheffield is unhappy with the medical treatment he is receiving from the Florida Marlins for a back ailment, and he doubts he will be ready to play opening day.

title: Where Bagels Are Just the Beginning
description: A dipperful of soup from the brown ceramic crockpot streams into a cardboard container. The plastic spoon delivers a sample. It's hearty, mellow, a soup that's almost a stew. The broth embraces the tastebuds and the chunks of chicken and vegetables offer the teeth a satisfying bite. The soup is incredibly good.

title: The Disappearance Of Awnings
description: To the Editor:

title: Emotions on the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Alcohol and Accidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Showing The Courage of Their Convictions
description: AT the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford two shows highlight women with the courage of their convictions. One is a buoyant yet elegant exhibition of paintings and sculpture from the collection of the astute Baroness Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza. The other show focuses on Lee Lozano and the beginnings of Conceptual art.

title: Our Towns; In This Town, Blight Is in Eye Of Inspector
description: MICHAEL MARGANSKI, anti-blight enforcement officer, set out from his newly sided white clapboard house overlooking the Naugatuck Valley, on the prowl for something ugly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTHROP, AMORY (ELIZABETH)
description: WINTHROP-Amory (Elizabeth). Of Millbrook, N.Y. Died Feb. 26, 1998. Daughter of Robert Winthrop and the late Theodora Ayer Randolph. Survived by her sisters Theodora Hooton and Cornelia Bonnie, and a niece and nephews. Ms. Winthrop was an accomplished horse-woman and a horse show judge. She was a director of The Fund for Animals & Founder and President of the Winley Foundation. A memorial service will be held at a future date. Contributions in her memory may be made to Winley Foundation, attention Anne Barone, R.R.1, Box 40, Millbrook, N.Y. 12545 or The Institute for Ecosystems Studies.

title: Stapleton Reprises 'Eleanor'
description: IN praise of ''Freak,'' John Leguizamo's new one-man play, as an exception to their own rule, many reviewers expressed discontent with the solo-show genre. For young actors, it is all too often a substitute for a vanity showcase. Older ones can be more like showoffs, with the writer's words serving the actor.

title: A Lifeline Runs From Upstairs to Down
description: He is almost 91, and has been in his rent-controlled, $145-a-month apartment on Greenwich Street for 53 years. He has seen the commodities brokers come and go, and watched as the homesteaders, the millionaires and the movie stars replaced them. ''I wouldn't be surprised if I were the longest-standing resident of TriBeCa,'' Marty Mayer said last week at the home of his upstairs neighbor and friend, Cheryl Moch.

title: Russian Immigrants At Home on East End
description: IN the summer of 1991, Leonid and Larissa Mouzykine and their two daughters packed their bags in their apartment in Russia for a trip to eastern Long Island. While they were excited about experiencing the American way of life, they did not realize that they were leaving Russia for good.

title: One Year Later, Iona Gets Past First Round
description: Iona figured out early that it did not have to defeat its past today, just Marist.

title: Immigrants in Prison Are There for a Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: Mausoleum Vandalism Hits Old Jewish Cemetery Again
description: The grounds of a Jewish cemetery have been violated again. Last weekend, vandals scattered bones inside a mausoleum that had been taken from a pried-open coffin at the Bayside Cemetery, the police said. Eight months ago, another mausoleum was broken into and a coffin was set on fire, incinerating the remains inside.

title: A February Without Snow
description: For the first time since Federal officials began keeping weather records in 1869, the month of February has passed without a trace of snow falling in Central Park.

title: Justice in the Military Has Its Reasons
description: It may seem easy to ridicule a justice system that can throw someone in jail for ''jumping from a vessel into the water'' or for ''straggling'' or for ''abusing a public animal.''

title: POSTINGS: A Survey Finds Tighter Financial Standards; Co-op Rejections Increased in '97
description: Prices for Manhattan co-ops rose last year, and so did the number of prospective buyers rejected by boards, according to a study by a large brokerage company.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Raiders of the Lost Codex
description: Patricia Finney's intricate novel, as carefully laid out as a Renaissance knot garden, tells a tale of intrigue, corruption and (occasional) true innocence at Queen Elizabeth I's roiling royal court. UNICORN'S BLOOD (Picador, $25) centers on a book whose blue velvet cover is wrought with a white-and-silver unicorn with a ruby for an eye. Rumored to be in the possession of a former nun, the so-called Book of the Unicorn is said to contain the 14-year-old future ''Virgin'' Queen's confession of her affair with Lord Admiral Thomas Seymour, her subsequent abortion and, most empire-upheavingly, her naming of Mary Queen of Scots as heir. Many courtiers and Roman Catholic foreign powers are lusting for the book, the better to unseat Elizabeth, and she herself is understandably desperate to recover it. The resulting scramble involves, among others, Sir Philip Sidney and his sword-master, an undercover priest, the Queen's secretary and her royal fool (a midget named Thomasina), and the chase unfolds in such varied precincts as the Tower of London, a bawdy house and even, most rankly, the royal sewage chambers. Swiftly moving and deftly woven, this courtly tale is as engrossing as it is improbable -- and thus all the more delightful. Julie Gray

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, RAY (NEE SCHREIBMAN)
description: GREENBAUM-Ray (nee Schreibman). Died February 28. Dear wife of the late Max Rozmarin and the late Noah Greenbaum. Beloved mother of Vivian and Donald Resnicoff, and Margie and Jerry Friedman. Dearest grandmother of Matt Resnicoff, Merryl and Jay Newler, and Nancy and Andrew Schwartz. Caring greatgrandmother of Jordana and Seth Newler. She lived a life of grace and beauty. Services Monday, March 1, 12:15 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Patterns in the Landscape and in the Eye
description: PHOTOGRAPHY and the American West have always maintained a sympathetic relationship,'' writes Toby Jurovics, assistant curator of photography at the Princeton University Art Museum, in the beautifully produced catalogue for ''Emmet Gowin: Aerial Photographs,'' one of the museum's three current photography exhibitions. The exhibitions by Mr. Gowin, Thomas Joshua Cooper and Robert Adams are separate and self-contained, but together they give a remarkable glimpse of transformations in a tradition rooted in the pioneering work of photographers like Timothy O'Sullivan and Carleton Watkins in the 19th century.

title: A Visit to 860 Broadway Bridged Four Generations
description: To the Editor:

title: A Smoker's Friend
description: Stylish ashtrays may not be too prevalent in public places these days: some restaurants furtively supply butter plates to diners who wish to smoke. But for those who long for a chic little place to tap ash, there is a repository: a silver-plated, snap-shut ashtray (left, $16) discreet enough to slip into pocket or purse.

title: Alcohol and Accidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. George H. Hitchings, 92; Won Nobel Prize in Medicine
description: Dr. George H. Hitchings, who won the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1988 for pharmaceutical research that led to the creation of drugs to treat leukemia, gout, malaria and disorders of the human immunity system and that eventually made organ transplants possible, died on Friday morning at his home. He was 92 and lived in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: Adventure; Beyond The Back Of Beyond
description: It was as if glacier national park had been plopped down in the middle of a West Texas prairie. Or the mountains of New Zealand had been dropped into the Australian outback. A lowercase landscape suddenly turned to uppercase ALPS. Some 12 million years ago, from deep in the earth, a huge fist of molten magma stuck upward, making peaks out of plains. And today those great geologic knuckles still pack a punch that can leave you almost breathless (especially if you are climbing). This towering landscape is all the more beautiful for being so unexpected in the middle of low-hilled, lumpy Patagonia.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARKER, SANFORD
description: PARKER-Sanford. In memory of my beloved brother, Sandy. So much a part of my life. Forever in my heart. Lil

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Lofland's Opens a Grill In the Financial District

title: Pastor to President Says Morality Includes Courage, Caring and Proportion
description: When the Rev. J. Philip Wogaman, a noted Christian ethicist, inherited the plum pulpit of Foundry United Methodist Church here six years ago, his predecessor bequeathed him a bombshell powerful enough to shatter the church.

title: Two Youths In Belarus Pay Dearly For Graffiti
description: Gaunt and pale, with his prison-shaven head just beginning to sprout hair, 16-year-old Vadim Labkovich seemed barely able to believe the modest comfort of being back home.

title: Vanessa Cooper and Richard Dampf
description: Vanessa Allison Cooper, a daughter of Isabel and Stanley B. Cooper of Rye Brook, N.Y., is to be married today to Richard Alan Dampf, a son of Carol Dampf of Hewlett, N.Y., and the late Martin M. Dampf. Rabbi Michael Ehrlich will officiate at Fox Hollow, a catering establishment in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Some Letters Inspire Nostalgia, Others Spell Trouble: From Pasta Plant Rubble, 6 Survivors
description: Other than a few gutted floors and a lot of rubble, little remains of the three-story brick building at 52-02 Northern Boulevard that for 48 years served as the bustling Ronzoni spaghetti factory. Yet 15 blocks away, in a storage room on the fourth floor of a funeral parlor, the legacy of the macaroni magnate Emanuele Ronzoni Sr. lives on.

title: BABAR GOES TO COLLEGE
description: Kent State University recently acquired some 3,600 items relating to Babar, the benign elephant king featured in more than 50 children's books by Jean and Laurent de Brunhoff. The collection, which includes 1,300 books, Babar dolls and marzipan, was donated by the late John L. Boonshaft of Las Vegas, Nev., a wealthy fan who once threw the fictional pachyderm a 50th birthday party. Ann Meinzen Hildebrand, a professor at Kent State and author of a study of the de Brunhoffs, sees the archive as an invaluable resource on a scholarly topic. After all, some leftist critics contend that Babar, Queen Celeste and their royal entourage symbolize European imperialism. (One angry book from this school is called ''Should We Burn Babar?) Hildebrand disagrees: ''The series has always struck me as a story about families,'' she says. Given those family values, could Babar work as a symbol of the Republican Party? ''I never thought of that,'' says Hildebrand, a Democrat. ''Maybe Dumbo would be more appropriate.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, ROBERT EMERY, M.D.
description: GOULD-Robert Emery, M.D. February 25, 1998. Psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, teacher and activist. Loving husband of Lois and father of Anthony and Roger. Memorial service on Sunday, March 1, 5 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Mirrors Within Mirrors
description: TALES OF THE NIGHT

title: A Time to Attack Next Summer's Insect Pests
description: THERE is no time like the present to get rid of many troubling insect pests. While the plants are still dormant, is the time to use horticultural oils.

title: A One-Woman Show, But What a Woman
description: ELEANOR ROOSEVELT is explaining it all for you: her disillusionment over finding her place in ''an ameliorating universe,'' and her determination to reclaim her innocence and idealism.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Jayne Sosland, David Swersky
description: IN the summer of 1989, David Swersky and Jayne Sosland met while working out at the Vertical Club in New York. His first line was a classic: As she was doing her stretches, he said, ''Are you a dancer?''

title: The Art of Managing a Motley Crew, and Keeping a Smile
description: IGNATIUS J. REILLY, the misfit hero of ''A Confederacy of Dunces,'' John Kennedy Toole's 1981 Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, winds up as a New Orleans hot-dog hawker. And as denizens of the French Quarter can tell you, Ignatius's eccentric, fictional employer -- Paradise Vendors -- has an eccentric, real-life counterpart: Lucky Dogs Inc.

title: Waving Audit Flags
description: Although only one out of 100 personal income tax returns is audited, certain characteristics, known as audit flags, greatly increase your odds of attracting Internal Revenue Service scrutiny. Claim anything to which you are entitled on your return, tax professionals say, but if your action raises an audit flag, be sure you have the records to defend it. Ten such flags are:

title: Has Nonfiction Ever Lived Up to Its Name?; 'Storm of the Century'
description: To the Editor:

title: Watchdog for Tobacco
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report last Sunday about the Fitness by Design exercise studio misstated its address. It is at 41 West 57th Street, not 51 West 57th.

title: Corrections Panel
description: County Executive Andrew J. Spano has appointed a task force to examine problems in the Department of Corrections and search for a new Corrections Commissioner, Susan Tolchin, a spokeswoman for the County Executive, said last week.

title: Sanctions an Indiscrete Harm to Iraqi Bourgeoisie
description: As Sami Kaftan, one of Iraq's most famous actors, strolled into a hotel this week, people stopped and smiled. Some rushed to shake his hand, quoting a funny line or two from a score of movies, plays and television shows he has starred in over three decades.

title: Liberties; Get Nice? Get Lost!
description: I ran away from Washington to escape a righteous, overzealous prosecutor who is threatening to toss all of us in jail if we don't do everything his way.

title: The Do-It-Yourself Society
description: A History of the American People

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGRERA HOLDEN, CAROLINA
description: SEGRERA HOLDEN - Carolina. February 8, 1998, at age 92, in New York City. Opera singer at La Scala of Milan during the 1930s and concert singer of ''lieder'' and art songs in leading concert halls in Europe in the 1950s. Ms. Segrera taught singing in her studio in Manhattan from 1960 to 1996. Contributions in her name can be made to a memorial fund at the New York City Opera, New York State Theater, 20 Lincoln Center, New York, NY 10023. attn: Sarah Foote Cohen, Development Manager of Funds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, DR. FRANCES C., ED.D.
description: REED-Dr. Frances C., Ed.D. Leaves behind her beloved husband Lionel and her four sons, Drs. Harold, Lawrence, Irving and Barry Reed. Daughter-in-laws Arlene and Jill, sisters Anna Yager and Pearl Brod. Grandchildren Staci, Michael, Joshua, Dahlia and Ilana. She devoted her life to the education of slow learners and was instrumental in the development of tests used to diagnose their problems. She will be missed. A graveside service will be held Sunday, March 1 in Miami, FL. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the National Center for Learning Disabilities Inc., 381 Park Ave. South, New York City 10016.

title: Big Investors Expect Gains In Europe's Financial Stocks
description: SOME mutual fund managers are counting on the emergence of an investing culture in Europe to make financial services stocks soar. The hope is that the Continent will follow the example of the United States, where bank and brokerage stocks have been among the top market performers of the last few years.

title: Tomorrowland Was Never Like This
description: DISNEY and reality do not usually occupy the same thought, much less the same television hour. After all, a company that calls its creative principals ''imagineers'' and makes animated films about mermaids and mythological heroes seems an odd choice for a documentary series devoted to the nitty-gritty lives of ordinary mortals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYNER, CHESBROUGH
description: RAYNER-Chesbrough On February 26, 1998. Beloved daughter of Chesbrough Patcevitch. Devoted sister of Minot Amory and his wife Victoria. Service Tuesday, March 3, 11 AM, St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd St, NYC. In lieu of flower,s contributions may be made in her name to Sloan Kettering, NYC.

title: The Homosexual Exception
description: As a lesbian with a partner living in suburbia and raising a child, now 3 years old, I have yet to experience the intolerance written about in Wolfe's article. I write this as a tribute to my suburban neighbors.

title: Condop: Part Co-op, Part Condo
description: WHEN Steven Zagoria and his wife, Beth, went looking for a Manhattan apartment several months ago, they found themselves in a building they were told was a ''condop.''

title: What's New? A Lot; Rome
description: It is hard to imagine Rome -- a city that has accumulated more than its fair share of great works of art -- needing another museum. And in a way, the Palazzo Altemps, which officially opened in December 1997, isn't even new, since the Greek and Roman sculptures it displays were once sprinkled around the city's other museums.

title: Film of Love and Desire and a Role for the Island
description: WAVES wash up gently on the shore. A young man and his dog amble along an empty beach. ''But let us say that this story began with the end of another, far, far from the surf of Long Island,'' intones a solemn, upper-crust British voice in the opening sequence of ''Love and Death on Long Island,'' a new film written and directed by Richard Kwietniowski.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEICH, LEE
description: TEICH-Lee. On February 27, 1998. Beloved son of Lynette. Devoted brother of Farrel. Loving uncle of Michael. Funeral service Sunday, 11AM, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, SYLVAN
description: ELIAS-Sylvan, on Feb. 25, 1998. Adored husband of Sylvia (Fidler). Cherished father of Roberta Krinick and Felice Miller and fatherin-law of Howard Krinick and Jordan Miller. Devoted grandfather to Nancy, Michael, Pamela, Amy, Ari, Gina and great-grandfather to Eric. Loving brother of Ruth Goldstein. Services on Sunday, 12:15, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Homosexual Exception
description: To a writer who has devoted most of his life to trying to change hearts and minds on the subject of homosexuality, Alan Wolfe's article ''The Homosexual Exception'' (Feb. 8), which concludes that prejudice against homosexuals still runs high in this country, was depressing. But then I wondered if the responses of 200 randomly chosen Americans from Tulsa, Atlanta, San Diego and Boston are enough to support Wolfe's argument. Still, I'm pleased that The Times felt the piece was of sufficient general interest to merit publication. After 30 years of beating the drum for understanding, I was pleased to see a coolheaded assessment of how far we have yet to go.

title: BENEFITS
description: Fostering Futures

title: What's New? A Lot; Mexico
description: Colonia juarez, tucked along the south side of Mexico City's main boulevard, Paseo de la Reforma, was once a lively bohemian enclave of cafes and galleries. But after the 1985 earthquake destroyed theaters and restaurants, affluent residents fled to sturdier ground.

title: Help Is Ahead for Middle-Class Families Planning for College
description: PARENTS who are saving for or paying their children's college costs are getting several tax breaks in the new tax law.

title: Word for Word / Henny Youngman; He Delivered Deftly and Carried A Big Catskill Shtick
description: WHAT better way to set up a selection of rib-ticklers and groaners from Henny Youngman, who died in New York last week at 91, than to simply steal some of the one-liner king's own introductory zingers, which he honed over a lifetime of Friars Club roasting and Borscht Belt skewering?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, ADELE
description: PERLMAN-Adele. On February 26, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Alfred Perlman. Beloved mother of Constance Spahn, Lee and Michael Perlman. Loving grandmother of Blake and Kirk Spahn, and Amy, Beth and Michael Perlman. Private burial in California. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Population Action International, 1120 19th St. N.W., Wash.,DC.20036

title: Which U.S. Team?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Homosexual Exception
description: Wolfe's article lost all credibility with me when he lumped the taking of Prozac with drunken revelry and marital infidelity. Although Prozac may be abused by some, it has relieved the suffering of many people. If Wolfe has such biases on this subject, one can only wonder how biased the rest of the article is about homosexuality.

title: Beauty and Danger on a Rally in Africa
description: THE 20th annual Paris-Dakar off-road rally began on New Year's Day in the shadow of Versailles and ended on the shores of Lac Rose in Senegal, near the ancient city of Dakar. During the intervening 18 days and 6,000 miles, a cruel itinerary of mountainous, wind-scalloped dunes and wheel-bending wadis -- as well as sandstorms, armed bandits, forge-like heat and a steel cable strung nastily across a road -- winnowed down the starting field of 349 cars, trucks and motorcycles to a mere 99.
