title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHEL, LOUIS
description: HIRSCHEL-Louis. Died February 25, 1998 in Sharon, CT, at the age of 83 years young. His brother Arthur Hirschel of Florida survives him. Additionally, his daughters Yvette and her husband David Smith of River Vale, N.J., Myrnaand Nat Yagoda of Fort Lee, N.J., and his son Marc and his wife Paula Hirschel of Sharon, CT. Lou also leaves behind his grandchildren Craig, Todd, Danielle and Seth, and his very best friend Mona King Myerson of Woodlands, Florida. After immigrating from Poland in 1929, Lou helped established Batterman and Hirschel Caterers of Rego Park, Queens and Yonkers, N.Y. He touched many people's lives with both his personality and his tremendous sense of humor and will be greatly missed by all. Graveside services will be held Friday, February 27, 1998 at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, New York at 10:30 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRO, LEON J. COMMANDER
description: CARRO-Leon J. Commander, USNR-Retired, age 103, of Brooklyn, NY, formerly of Revere, MA, on February 27, 1998. He graduated from Tufts University in 1917, left Harvard Law School to enlist in the US Navy in WW I, was commissioned an Ensign and served aboard the destroyer USS Paul Jones. Graduated from Boston University Law School in 1922, was a member of the MA, NY and Federal bars, and practiced in MA and NY. He served during WW II and was District Security Officer of the 15th Naval District (Panama Canal Zone) for two years. He also served on the Third Naval District permanent General Court Martial and was attached to the Judge Advocate General Corps. He is survived by his beloved wife Esther Epstein Carro, a son Melvin J. Carro (Carol), grandchildren Richard S. Carro (Laura) and Diane Carro, and two great-grandchildren Sabrina Evelyn and Amanda Rose Carro. Graveside services private.

title: French Church and Volkswagen Settle Suit
description: Volkswagen and the Roman Catholic Church of France have settled an unusual dispute about car advertisements, with the bishops forgiving the car maker, which agreed to pay for its sins.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: LAWYERS, MONEY, AND SUCCESS

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: At 90, a Party, Then Back to Work
description: WHEN Walter Taussig turned 90 this month, there was little time to celebrate. Mr. Taussig has served the Metropolitan Opera since 1949 as a chorus master, assistant conductor and vocal coach, and as the self-appointed guardian general of the German repertory, and this was a typically busy time. For the last several weeks, cast members from the coming productions of Wagner's ''Lohengrin'' and ''Meistersinger'' have been reporting to a tiny studio in a subterranean level of the Metropolitan Opera House for intensive coaching sessions.

title: In Sherman, Is It Politics or Personalities?
description: IN the 196 years since Sherman has been governed by a Board of Selectmen, there had never been a Democrat or a woman elected to serve as First Selectman.

title: Corrections
description: The air fares chart on page 3 of the Travel section today carries incorrect dates in some copies. The fares are valid March 29 to April 4, not March 22 to 28.

title: Liberal or Conservative, Both Are From L.I.
description: IN the shared world of Sean Hannity and Alan Colmes, the question of what came first was never the chicken or the egg. It was the liberal or the conservative. The conservative won. ''I was hired first,'' said Mr. Hannity, who grew up in Franklin Square and loved Ronald Reagan.

title: 'Madam, I'm Adam'
description: EVE SPOKE

title: Teamwork in School
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARD, MARY E.
description: RICHARD-Mary E. Of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., on February 25, 1998, age 33. Executive Director Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary, Oyster Bay Cove, LI. Beloved daughter of Dr. James and Elizabeth Richard of Riverhead, L.I. Dear sister of Peter, Robert, Christine and Ann. Fond aunt of five. Reposing 2-4, 7-9 PM, Sunday, Reginald H. Tuthill Funeral Home, 406 East Main Street, Riverhead. Funeral mass 10:30 AM, Monday, St. John's R.C. Church, Riverhead. Interment St. John's Church Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations requested to the Roosevelt Sanctuary.

title: The Homosexual Exception
description: We middle-class Americans are very tolerant of gay men and lesbians as individuals. What we don't tolerate is their political agenda as a group. It has two main thrusts: a demand for special rights in the workplace and a demand that public schools indoctrinate our children with the propaganda that abnormal behavior is healthy and moral.

title: 'Titanic's' Lovers
description: To the Editor:

title: Tinkering Perilously With Europe
description: With Washington preoccupied by other events, the Senate is rapidly moving toward a momentous decision on NATO expansion. Though the issue has stirred little passion outside the foreign policy fraternity, the eastward extension of NATO ought to concern every American because it may damage the country's paramount security interests for decades to come. There is still time for the Senate to weigh these risks and to reject a plan that is likely to undermine the very goals the White House insists it will achieve, including the advancement of democracy and unity in Europe.

title: The World: Good Deficit, Bad Deficit; The Fear Is Gone, Not the Danger
description: YOU'VE heard it before and you'll hear it again: Trade deficits are bad. So the 24 percent jump in America's deficit, to a whopping $10.8 billion in December, and the near-certainty of further increases this year add up to trouble for an otherwise blessed economy.

title: A Safety Net, An Extension
description: Can't find that 1099 from the bank? No cash on hand and you owe taxes? Don't guess at the amount, panic or hope that the I.R.S. won't notice if you're late in filing. Extensions are legal.

title: In a Departure, A Plunge Into Darkness
description: PAUL TAYLOR is not only a choreographer but a writer and an artist, an avid reader, a collector of objects and creatures found in the wild and a lover of all music, except perhaps contemporary jazz and Mozart (''too elegant'' for setting to dances). He likes physical work and has built, without a yardstick, a bungalow on Long Island using only driftwood and other flotsam. Yet, like many who occupy rarefied creative planes, he doesn't know, for example, which subway stops nearest his Manhattan residence.

title: Educational Program For Retirees
description: Your article [''Retirees, Refusing to Stand Pat, Infuse Communities,'' Jan. 25] omitted an excellent educational program that deserves mention. I am referring to the Adult Alternative University at Nassau Community College. To the best of my knowledge it is not a member of a Learning in Retirement Program, but it does offer a variety of intellectual stimulating courses for adults for a nominal fee. These courses are taught by N.C.C. faculty. I have attended several and have been excited by them all.

title: Corrections
description: A table on Feb. 1 with an article about the international mutual funds of Fidelity Investments misstated some three-year annualized returns for flagship international stock funds of leading mutual fund companies. A corrected chart appears today on page 8.

title: BAD BOY
description: *In his new autobiography ''The Long Hard Road out of Hell,'' the rocker named Marilyn Manson (born Brian Warner) tells all about how a former Ohio choirboy became ''the All-American Antichrist.'' * And then some: Manson claims he has 450 scars on his body and brags about onstage antics like simulated fornication and faked animal sacrifice. * Naturally, many Christians and parents hate the guy. Manson has been banned from South Carolina and offered $10,000 not to play in Salt Lake City. * Even his fans aren't sure what to make of him. Internet rumors have it that he's ''really'' a former Amish person, a priest or a star of ''The Wonder Years.'' * He's certainly cocky. ''What happens someday if more people own my record than the Bible?'' he writes. ''Will that make me God because more people believe in me than Him?''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It was a slap in the face. It was an earthquake for me. I work in a military hospital. They let me save their lives, but to live next to them, no.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, MIRIAM W.
description: WASSERMAN-Miriam W. At home, on February 26, 1998 in her 90th year. Loving wife of 65 years of the late John Wasserman. Devoted mother of Ann Kiggen and Jane Ferrar. Beloved grandmother (our Lulu) of Andrew, Carolyn, Linda, Derek and Jessica. Doting great-grandmother of Aaron, Daniel, Peter, Jessica, Danielle, Michael and Quinn. Former active volunteer at Hudson Guild, Fulton House and Sydenham Hospital. Her generous, lively spirit will be deeply missed. Private services.

title: February 22-28; You Can Go Home Again
description: Two years ago they were the royalty of the Republican Party, the telegenic husband and wife who met, wooed and wed as members of the House of Representatives.

title: Jimmy Hoffa's Revenge
description: In reading Jeffrey Goldberg's balanced article ''Jimmy Hoffa's Revenge'' (Feb. 8), I was struck by the teamsters' self-destructiveness. With their union threatened, they zero in on hating Government and Democrats. They forget that it was Government that enabled unions to thrive, through the National Labor Relations Act, and that it was Democrats who sustained the N.L.R.A. over the years. Now, needing Government and Democratic support more than ever, they want to bite the hands that feed them.

title: The Risks and Rituals of Doing Lunch
description: Food in the workplace can be many things: a statement, a sociological scan that reveals prosperity or poverty, a window into the psyche or an X-file on a midday ritual of sprouts and tofu. But every now and then, lunch, like the Freudian cigar that was just a cigar, is just a comforting tuna sandwich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMANN, GABOR
description: NEUMANN-Gabor. On Feb. 18, 1998. Beloved husband of Verica. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday evening March 4, 1998 at 6 P.M. Donations in his name may be made to Supportive Care Program, Palliative Care Services, Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021

title: Amy Bial, Adam Heavenrich
description: Amy Reinherz Bial, the daughter of Martha and Ernest Bial of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was married on Wednesday in Jerusalem to Adam Dov Heavenrich, the son of Elaine Heavenrich and Dr. Richard Heavenrich, both of Huntington Woods, Mich. Rabbi Yitzchak Shurin performed the ceremony at the Renaissance Jerusalem Hotel.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Feb. 15 included an outdated reference to United Airlines' frequent flier program. It no longer requires a Saturday night stay to qualify for a domestic coach ticket costing 25,000 miles. United changed the rule on Feb. 10, after the issue went to press.

title: Observing 150 Years Of Victorian House
description: JACOB ODELL built a house as a wedding gift for his bride, Harriet, 150 years ago. Unfortunately, Mr. Odell, who ran a successful lumberyard and became the first president of the village of Tarrytown when it was incorporated in 1870, neglected to provide storage and closet space, an error later rectified.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Perfect Vehicle

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMETT, JOHN A.
description: HAMMETT-John A. Retired Vice President of Douglas Gibbons, Holliday & Ives. On February 27, 1998, after a long illness. His many friends mourn the passing of this kind and generous man. Memorial mass 10 AM, Tuesday, March 3 at Saint John the Evangelist Church, 1st Ave. and 55 St., NY. Private interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Baghdad's Ability to Sell Oil Is Hurt by Poor Maintenance
description: Iraq's oil production system has deteriorated so badly during years of economic sanctions that it cannot take full advantage of a recent Security Council resolution allowing Baghdad to more than double its oil sales, Iraqi officials and independent experts say.

title: POSTINGS: Warhol's Old Factory: A Restaurant and Offices; 15 Minutes of Pasta?
description: A remnant of the Andy Warhol era can still be seen below a second-floor balcony in an industrial-sized lobby facing the building entrance at 22 East 33d Street.

title: Learning, the Hard Way, About Party Loyalties
description: ''Right down there,'' Representative Robert E. Andrews was saying as his black Ford crossed the Delaware River the other day, ''is where my grandfather and father worked.''

title: Don't Call Me 'Near Elderly'
description: At 63, I refer to myself as ''chronologically gifted.''

title: A Grandmother's Biological Clock
description: Katie Roiphe's comic and loving portrayal of her mother speaks to an important issue for feminist moms (Lives: ''A Grandmother's Biological Clock,'' Feb. 8). Like Roiphe's mother, I was married, a mother of two and divorced in my early 30's. Remarried now, I stand by silently when my husband (a bachelor until 48) proclaims the benefits of a mature union.

title: Coach and Godiva Riding In
description: The west side of Broadway between 84th and 85th Streets has been looking tired lately. Three of the seven stores on the block have been shuttered in the last few months, and scaffolding covered much of it during a year's worth of facade work.

title: Adventure; Yosemite: In the Footsteps of John Muir
description: Four thousand feet above yosemite valley, there's another, more secret Yosemite. Jagged peaks against azure skies, alpine meadows, water slides and waterfalls, glacial lakes and trout streams, granite so white you think it's snow, so polished by glaciers it shines like a dance floor, rock gardens so perfect you can't believe they weren't planted -- these are some of the attractions of Yosemite's high country.

title: A Retirement More Allegro Than Andante
description: AT the start of his 15 years as music director of the Utah Symphony, Joseph Silverstein joked that he would call his memoirs ''Maestro in Zion.'' Now, in the last full year of his tenure, memoirs still in the pipe-dream stage, he cuts back to a more diplomatic phrase: ''It's been a wonderful time.''

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Arts Appreciation Begins in School
description: After reading Larry Austin's opinion about the arts [''Keep Culture Vibrant, for Our Sake,'' Feb. 8], I quickly decided to share a sentiment. I agree that the arts are important to Long Island and we all are responsible for their preservation. Successfully instilling interest in future generations will help to continue the quality of arts on Long Island.

title: An Alley May Become a High Road for Film Buffs
description: When Anthology Film Archives bought a defunct city courthouse on Second Avenue between First and Second Streets in 1979, there were vague plans to construct a library in the little alley that runs along the museum's southern wall.

title: Competitors Are Shopping For Customers of Oxford
description: Cigna is promoting itself in newspaper advertisements as ''a big old stable health care company.'' Aetna U.S. Healthcare is running ads urging employers to apply the principles of ''preventive care'' when choosing an insurer.

title: Discord Grows Where Plants Once Did
description: For years, plants and trees grew on the small lot just south of Canal Street. Now controversy is blossoming there, because of a recently announced plan to build expensive condominiums where the Farm and Garden nursery once stood.

title: Ferreting Out Breaks That Affect '97 Returns
description: THE TAXPAYER Relief Act of 1997 not only added complexities to the tax code -- like multiple rates and holding periods for capital gains. But it also has confused some taxpayers who are looking for breaks now that do not take effect until 1998 or later.

title: Water Filtration Talks
description: The New York City Department of Environmental Protection held five public scoping hearings in Westchester last month to gauge public sentiment on a water filtration plant for the Croton Reservoir System. Cathy DelliCarpini, a spokeswoman for the department, said New York City is considering four locations in Westchester and three in the Bronx. She said the hearings gave Westchester residents an opportunity to comment on the sites and a draft environmental impact statement.

title: What's New? A Lot; Miami
description: Tucked away in a two-story Art Deco building in a Miami Beach residential neighborhood, Tantra opened last December as part of the latest trend in South Beach, the restaurant-lounge. This concept, also being tried at such new night spots as the Russia-inspired Red Square, offers a combination of restaurant, dance club and after-hours haunt.

title: The Homosexual Exception
description: That many Americans dislike us comes as no surprise to most gay people. It is, of course, their privilege. But those who base their antipathy on the notion of volition need to be clear about this: we do not choose whom we are attracted to. What we do choose is our response to that attraction. Celibacy, sublimation, invisibility, hypocrisy and self-hatred are no longer acceptable choices for the majority of us. Yet by and large, they remain the only ones society willingly offers us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAVER, JUNE S.
description: BEAVER-June S. On February 26, 1998 in State College, PA. Wife of Thomas. Mother of Millicent, Thomas and William. Grandmother of nine. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Tom and June Beaver Fund at The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802. Family service on Tuesday.

title: Specializing in Soul Food in Hempstead
description: STAN'S Soul Kitchen in Uniondale is a pipsqueak of a place, more a carry-out than a restaurant. The nine-month-old storefront, at 575 Uniondale Avenue (564-0922), not far from the Nassau Coliseum and Hofstra University, has seven molded plastic chairs and three wobbly uncovered tables. Nor is there any service except at a counter and virtually no decor (except for a few incongruously elegant French prints) in this bare bones mecca for meritorious down-home vittles.

title: Frisky Wink At Winter
description: Accessories with personality provide escape from the dominant utilitarian fashion look. One woman glanced back to the 1920's with her lacquer-toned red velvet cloche, far right. Others looked to the future with their molded backpacks. One backpack showed the Mona Lisa.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the recent performance of the Vanguard Windsor fund referred incorrectly to the fund's holdings of cyclical stocks, reflecting filings by the Vanguard Group with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The fund still owns 12.7 million shares of USX-Marathon Group, about even with its holdings at the end of October, and 261,000 shares of Continental Airlines class B, down from 1.3 million shares at the end of October; it did not sell all of its shares of either stock in the fourth quarter. Charles Freeman, the fund's manager, said last week that the fund has maintained its weightings in cyclical stocks since the end of October at about 45 percent of its assets.

title: Eyesore Out, Gallic Cafe In
description: It was vacant for nearly five years, boarded up and derelict. But the restaurant at 470 West 23d Street, on the southeast corner of 10th Avenue, has finally reopened, despite the opposition of some neighbors to its sidewalk cafe.

title: February 22-28; Dylan Got It Right. The Times They Did Change.
description: When Bob Dylan released his earthshaking albums ''Highway 61 Revisited'' and ''Blonde on Blonde'' in 1965 and 1966, the Grammy Awards for album of the year both went to Frank Sinatra. But at the 1998 awards, Mr. Dylan prevailed: ''Time Out of Mind,'' a haunted album of songs about lost love and intimations of death, was named album of the year. Meanwhile, his son Jakob Dylan ruled the rock category with two awards for the Wallflowers' song ''One Headlight.''

title: THE GUIDE
description: Silvermine Artists

title: Marian Helms, William Hewitt
description: Marian McGarrah Helms and William F. Hewitt were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. J. Barrie Shepherd, a Presbyterian minister, officiated, and the Lama Pema Wangdak, a Buddhist monk, took part in the ceremony.

title: Bayou Country
description: My idea of a good time used to involve, in one form or another, the acquisition of a really fabulous pair of shoes. But that was back when I was single, and living in New York City. Now that I live in Baton Rouge, La., I know better.

title: COURTS EXPANDING EFFORT TO BATTLE WATER POLLUTION
description: A wave of lawsuits brought by environmentalists is compelling state and Federal authorities to enforce a long-dormant provision of the Clean Water Act, opening a new front in the struggle over pollution and requiring the Government to make new assessments of whether water standards are being met.

title: The Nuke of the 90's
description: In july 1945, a group of scientists huddled in the new Mexico dawn to witness the first nuclear explosion. They had created a terrible power, but one that nations have successfully controlled for more than 50 years. Now we have unleashed a very different but similarly awesome force, one capable of overthrowing governments and their policies almost overnight. And there are no systems in place for controlling it.

title: Adventure; Climbing to the Gods
description: It stands a scant 9,570 feet above sea level, a mere third the height of Everest, a bump upon a topographical map of the planet's surface. Yet while Everest has teased the imagination of the Western world only since the mid-19th century, Olympus has cast its substantial shadow over Western mankind for at least the past 2,800 years.

title: Selling Europe on the Stock Market
description: TWO years ago, Boris Ogursky was working for the catering arm of Lufthansa, the German airline, when he saw the future and made a bet.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: WHERE THIS LAKE IS

title: Peering Into the Bell Jar
description: Birthday Letters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSSOFF, SHIRLEY R.
description: KOSSOFF-Shirley R. Age 96, on February 28. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Kossoff, loving mother of Richard and Arlene Kossoff, Janice and Irving Southern, and Terri and Stuart Taylor. Proud grandmother of Laura, Drew, Wendy, Ivan, Douglas, Pat, and Laurie. Funeral service Sunday, March 1, 10 AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St. at Amsterdam Ave., Manhattan.

title: For the Small Landlord, All Problems Are Big
description: THE walls seemed to move the first time Jeff Dunayer, a fledgling landlord, stepped into his first tenant's apartment that afternoon back in 1983.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIMAN, A. HARRY
description: KLEIMAN-A. Harry, MD. On Feb. 27, 1998. Dedicated physician, devoted husband of Micheline, loving father of Dena, Sam and Max. Adored stepfather and grandfather. Services Sunday, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Corporate Day-Care Centers Grow, but Cautiously
description: WHEN Symbol Technologies completes a 125,000-square-foot addition to its world headquarters in Holtsville later this year, 6,000 square feet will be set aside for a child day-care center. It will be able to accommodate 60 children, including infants as young as 6 weeks.

title: Dierker Decided He Could Manage, and the Astros Proved Him Very Right
description: As Larry Dierker waited to take his turn on a series of managers' conference calls with reporters in December, he asked the public relations person, ''Are you going to cue me?''

title: Successful Marriage, and How to Go About It
description: THEY speak to each other with all the rapt attention of newlyweds, but Drs. Paul and Evelyn Moschetta have been married for 22 years. Their conversation flows seamlessly back and forth like a well-orchestrated musical duet. There are no interruptions as each listens intently, waiting for the other to finish speaking before adding comments.

title: February 22-28; High Court Deals Credit Unions a Blow
description: Credit unions, aided by sympathetic Federal regulators and substantial tax breaks, have evolved into major financial institutions, far removed from their mom-and-pop origins. The banks are fighting back, and last week won an important Supreme Court victory when the Justices invalidated a 1982 regulation that had allowed credit unions to grow exponentially by absorbing unrelated employee groups.

title: Who Will Profit by Covering The Cards?
description: TWO of the biggest guns in American business are at war. They are calling each other names and slamming each other in lawsuits and newspaper ads.

title: Who We Are
description: To the Editor:

title: There Are No Losers Here
description: IT was more than a great sports moment. It was a great feel-good moment.

title: Roth I.R.A.'s Giving 401(k)'s a Run for the (Retirement) Money
description: THE new Roth I.R.A. is attracting so much interest -- because of its promise of tax-free retirement distributions -- that some company administrators of 401(k) plans are growing worried and taking steps to make their 401(k)'s more attractive, including giving more money to workers who participate.

title: February 22-28; Victory for Free Speech: Yes, Oprah Can Insult Beef
description: It wasn't quite how the Founding Fathers put it when the talk-show host Oprah Winfrey offered homage to the First Amendment last week. ''Free speech not only lives, it rocks!'' she exulted at the Federal Courthouse in Amarillo, Tex., where cattlemen had claimed she defamed American beef and cost them millions of dollars with a 1996 show on ''mad cow disease.'' The jury said she wasn't liable. SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

title: Competing Olympics
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Letters Inspire Nostalgia, Others Spell Trouble: Critics of Staples Win Half a Battle
description: About a year after Staples Express opened its store on Union Square West, the huge sign that drew protest from community watchdogs has been dismantled. Or most of it.

title: Shaken Indian City Votes as Election Ends
description: India's general election came to a tense end today as voters in this southern textile city joined 150 million others in choosing between Sonia Gandhi's vision of a secular India and a rival vision of a country dominated politically by the culture and preferences of its 700 million Hindus.

title: El Nino Is Blamed For Rio Beach Erosion
description: Chalk up another point for El Nino -- maybe. Portions of Rio's famous beaches, mainly at Copacabana, Ipanema and Leblon, are being nibbled away, and at least some scientists think El Nino is the culprit.

title: Syracuse Is the Only Favorite to Fall in Tournament's Opening Round
description: Only one favorite fell as the Big East women's basketball tournament opened at Rutgers today with five first-round games. In the evening session, sixth-seeded Syracuse lost for the second time in a week to Georgetown, which had dropped seven of its last eight games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARSON, ARTHUR
description: GARSON-Arthur. The Board of Directors and staff for Retired and Senior Volunteer Program, International deeply mourn the loss of our Founder and President, Arthur Garson. Arthur's many friends around the world join with us as we offer our sincere condolences and support to Arthur's wife and fellow board member Patricia Garson and to other family members. RSVP International, Board of Directors, Anne O'Sullivan Executive Director

title: With a Hit In One Hand, A 'Hamlet' In the Other
description: NEW YORK IS one of the last theater capitals to receive Yasmina Reza's international hit ''Art,'' which opens tonight on Broadway. And the city is coming relatively late as well to Matthew Warchus, the English director of the play's sellout London run and its current New York incarnation.

title: F.A.A. Inspectors Are Divided Over Safety Violations by Valujet
description: Valujet has broken numerous safety rules but there is ''no evidence of systematic safety problems,'' the Federal Aviation Administration said on Friday. But the agency also said its inspectors had had an unusual disagreement among themselves about the airline, which is now doing business as Airtran Airlines.

title: Style; Are You Game?
description: As far as can be determined, the drag-name game took root at an upstate artists' colony in the snowy winter of '96. Since then, I can confidently report, it has thoroughly infiltrated the culture at large. How am I sure? Well, a group of friends recently fell into it after a Super Bowl party, once they'd hauled out the empties and vacuumed up the Cheetos dust. It's a simple game: take the name of your first pet, add your mother's maiden surname and voila. A dog is preferred, but no prejudice is shown if, as a child, you happened to have kept amazing sea monkeys.

title: A Style Maven's Advice: 'Black Is Not Your Color'
description: THE SETTING -- Phillip Bloch, a Hollywood stylist, signing copies of his book ''Elements of Style'' (Warner Books, 1998) on the fourth floor of Saks Fifth Avenue Thursday night, where lower-priced designer clothes are sold.

title: His Father's Handiwork
description: There was one bed, a kitchenette and an electric warming plate in a bare, musty motel room tucked away in a frayed section of West Los Angeles.

title: Harding Wasn't a Slacker
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: March Begins With Duke and UConn Roaring; St. John's Title Hopes End Abruptly as Huskies Romp
description: St. John's came here to win a Big East championship, an unthinkable possibility when it was working to salvage its season at the start of the year. But what the Red Storm discovered tonight -- in the din of Gampel Pavilion -- was that the Connecticut Huskies were not prepared to share a spot at the top of the league.

title: Streetscapes/Readers' Questions; A Teddy Roosevelt House, a Calvert Vaux Design
description: 689 Madison Avenue

title: February 22-28; Civil Rights Charges In a Brooklyn Torture Case
description: Federal prosecutors took over the racially charged case of Abner Louima, a Haitian immigrant who has said he was tortured by police officers after he was arrested last summer in Brooklyn; the four police officers who have been implicated were indicted on a variety of civil rights charges, making them subject potentially to much stiffer sentences than they would have faced in state court.

title: Parents Test Skills on School Computers
description: JUST as immigrants often relied on their children to negotiate the sometimes unfathomable customs, ways and language of the New World, so too do many of today's parents depend on their computer-savvy offspring to help them decipher the complexities of the information superhighway.

title: CUTTINGS; Sheets of Snowdrops Expel the Winter Doldrums
description: MY first brush with snowdrops and their devotees occurred several years ago in East Hampton, N.Y., where a small garden planted with more than 35 galanthus species and cultivars was open for the day in late February. Rain was falling lightly; the temperature hovered just above freezing. Looking into the garden, I saw a dozen quivering humps of tan cloth. Tents? No, it was a collection of snowdrop worshipers, tightly wrapped in their raincoats, bent double over the tiny plants.

title: Break on Gains, but Not on Frustration
description: ONE certainty about taxes is that almost any break the Government decides to give comes at an uncomfortably high price.

title: Civil Servants Who Are More Than Just Civil
description: THE old scourge spiked like a fever chart.

title: Papers Make Debut in Two Communities
description: THE electronic-age pundits who daily predict the demise of newspapers have not met Robert Bonvento or Susan Arterian Chang, two stalwarts who believe that newspapers, not the Internet, are the favored medium. What is more, they both dug into their own savings to start community publications.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 34 of the Arts and Leisure section today about Madonna misspells the term for the totally prone corpse pose in yoga. It is shavasana, not sivasana.

title: Comparing the Scorecards in a Fidelity Shift
description: Watchers of Fidelity Investments are still reading the tea leaves over the significance of the announcement that George Vanderheiden, managing director and vice president, would be giving up some of his portfolio management duties. But what will the change mean for investors in his $3.8 billion Fidelity Destiny II fund, which will be handed over to Beth F. Terrana, the veteran manager of the Fidelity Fund?

title: In America; Cheap Justice
description: Ahh, the attorneys' fees. Let's see, in the post-O. J. universe we've had Oprah vs. the cattlemen in Texas, Bill Gates vs. the Justice Department in Washington, the endlessly blossoming tobacco litigation, and Bill Clinton and his cronies against the world. It's a fabulously prosperous time for lawyers who are at the top of their game. Sometimes you can calculate the fees in the millions; sometimes, incredibly, in the billions.

title: One Man's History Rings Proudly
description: At the age of 75, Charlie Sifford cannot forget the hardships he endured, and neither should anyone else.

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Office Market Surge Spurs Eastern Bergen Activity
description: OVER the last year the office market in eastern Bergen County has surged, giving rise to new investment -- and new ownership -- in older buildings and renewed interest in vacant development sites.

title: Boerum Hill Is Brightened By a Kinetic Sculpture
description: To the Editor:

title: February 22-28; A Court Drops Charges Of Biological Danger
description: All biological weapon charges were dropped against two men arrested by Federal authorities in Nevada last month in an anthrax scare. The two, William Leavitt Jr. and Larry Wayne Harris, had been accused of conspiracy to possess and possesion of a biological material for use as a weapon, but testing of the substance showed it to be a non-lethal form of anthrax that could be used in making a vaccine.

title: Ms. De Los Santos, Mr. Mascarello
description: Daphne De Los Santos, a daughter of Rosanna and Victor De Los Santos of Yonkers, was married yesterday to John Anthony Mascarello, a son of Hilda Rubio of Miami and Juan Mascarello of Mexico City. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: A Family's Survival In a Toyland Jungle
description: HARRY KISLEVITZ never planned on being a toy maker. He and his wife, Patricia, were artists in postwar Manhattan, living in a railroad apartment on the Upper West Side, when they acquired a roll of vinyl sheeting. Noticing how the vinyl stuck to the apartment's semigloss walls, they put it, along with some scissors, in the bathroom. Friends would spend hours playing Matisse, cutting out designs and sticking them to walls.

title: Fickle Weather
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: Hong Kong at Down-to-Earth Prices
description: ONE of the greatest deals I have ever seen was offered by Cathay Pacific Airlines last November -- five nights in Hong Kong for two, including accommodations, round-trip tickets and a Super Saver card (with discount coupons) for a breathtaking $999. At the time the airline's lowest one-way fare from New York to the Asian hub was $1,190. What is more, Hong Kong is legendary for being a pricey city, where you would be hard pressed to find a hotel room for less than $100 a night.

title: Q&A/Humphrey Tonkin; Back to the Classroom, Shakespeare in Tow
description: HUMPHREY TONKIN has served as a university president for 15 years, including a decade at the University of Hartford, a private 7,000-student liberal arts school. He will step down in June, spend a year on research as a visiting fellow at the Whitney Humanities Center at Yale, then return to Hartford and the classroom as University Professor of the Humanities, a new position in which he will teach courses relating to 16th- and 17th-century English, his field of expertise, as well as courses on language in society.

title: In the Region/Westchester; For Rye Brook, 429-Home Village in a Village
description: AN unusual residential project, designed to encourage interaction among neighbors and replicate some of the aspects of life in a small town, is scheduled to break ground next month on 140 acres along King Street, one of the last remaining parcels of land left in this village.

title: Egypt Captures Cup Title
description: Egypt grabbed two early goals and then defended superbly to defeat the defending champion, South Africa, 2-0, in the African Cup of Nations final in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, yesterday.

title: Hansel Mieth, 88, Magazine Photographer
description: Hansel Mieth Hagel, a photographer who documented the Great Depression and World War II for Time, Fortune and Life magazines, died on Feb. 14 at a friend's home in Santa Rosa, Calif. She was 88 and lived on a ranch nearby.

title: Making Over Mom: From Santa Fe Hippie to Comme des Garcons
description: IT was a bad hair day, a very bad hair day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, ROBERT
description: MEYER-Robert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert W. Meyer, associated with The Times from 1955, until retiring in 1993.

title: Where to Celebrate Women's History Month
description: Here is a sampling of Women's History Month activities.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: HAWAII RENEWED -- The Kapalua Bay Hotel on Maui, which recently reopened after a six-month renovation, is offering an introductory rate of $199 for an ocean-view room through July 31 (tax of 10.166 percent is extra). The resort, on 18 beachfront acres, has 191 rooms and 3 suites, all with new bathrooms; three golf courses; two tennis complexes; two swimming pools, and a new fitness center. For information or reservations, call (800) 367-8000 or (808) 669-5656; or look on the Internet at www.kapaluabay.com.

title: Make Mine Black
description: Gatorade, of all things, has gone punk. Its newest thirst quencher, Midnight Thunder, is the shade of black leather jackets, black jeans and black hair dye. The company hopes the shock value will appeal to customers, particularly young ones. ''This product has an in-your-face attitude that teens seem to love,'' said P. J. Sinopoli, Gatorade's director of marketing communications. ''It's important to stay hip with youth.''

title: Multiplex Heralded As Linchpin To Growth
description: SCENE 1. Take 1. Roll the cameras!''

title: Film Set in Yonkers Native's Locale
description: IN the age of the indie, the independent-film-making movement, a Yonkers native and film maker, Joe Lovero, has joined the ranks of young writer-directors who use familiar surroundings to convey their stories without the financial resources of major film studios.

title: Tempest in a Boccie Court
description: Oblivious to the clouds glowering above, 30 elderly men stared intently as a large green ball rolled down a rust-colored clay court at Dyker Beach Park and came to rest inches from a tiny metal ball.

title: The Homosexual Exception
description: If there's any upside to the news media's endless preoccupation with President Clinton's alleged affairs, it's that Americans are being forced to confront the complexities of human nature, especially where sexuality is concerned. This exercise in mind expansion can only benefit gay men and lesbians.

title: $15 Million for Bike Paths
description: What do you think of Governor Whitman's proposal to spend $15 million this year to build 200 miles of bike trails?

title: Backtalk; The Shot Heard Round The Wrangle
description: The crippling pain of a torn Achilles' tendon ended Nykesha Sales's brilliant college career and her chance to lead second-ranked Connecticut into the post-season. The injury also left her 1 bitter point short of the school's scoring record.

title: A Typeface as Symbol of National Pride
description: WRITING ABOUT what he called ''the awful German language,'' Mark Twain expressed bewilderment at its grammatical intricacies and lengthy compound nouns like Waffenstillstandsunterhandlungen (cease-fire negotiations) and Unabhangigkeitserklarungen (declarations of independence).

title: Make Crostini to Whet the Appetite and Add Panache
description: AMONG the simplest, most inviting concepts is the crostini. A plate of simple rounds of good bread, toasted and topped with some savory mixture can fuel the cocktail hour very nicely without destroying appetites. An assortment of crostini can also become an easy first course when the wine is poured.

title: Uneasy Renaissance on Harlem's Street of Dreams
description: On 125th Street in Harlem, where the stories and myths and frustrations of black urban America resonate with every step, a new economy is coming.

title: Sandra Vigano, Robert Bochicchio
description: Sandra Vigano, the daughter of Elena and Oscar Vigano of Falls Church, Va., was married yesterday to Robert Patrick Bochicchio, the son of Angela and William Bochicchio of Dumont, N.J. The Rev. Donald McLaughlin performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Dumont.

title: Life for Revlon Site
description: Vacant for more than a decade, the former site of the Revlon cosmetics company in Tuckahoe may have a new use and new tenants if the latest plans to convert it are approved.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLATBUSH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANHALT, EMANUEL
description: ANHALT-Emanuel. Age 89. On February 18, 1998. Beloved father of Steve and June and Alice and Gilbert Goldstein. Adored grandfather and great grandfather. Private services were held in Florida

title: Right From the Start
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami Has Enough Fight To Teach Nets A Hard Lesson
description: Win or lose, the Nets knew that today's meeting with the Miami Heat was going to be a learning experience. As they walked off the floor after the final buzzer, the Nets wore the signs of a most painful lesson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAKIN, SELMA
description: SHAKIN-Selma. In her 100th year. Survived by son Bernard Shakin of NYC, daughter Edith Katz of Somers, NY, granddaughters Jane Lebowitz and Terry Kleinberg, great-grandchildren Emily, Matthew, Sophie and Harry. Memorial service to be held at future date.

title: State of War
description: As the Civil War approached, New Jersey was itself divided; many of its politicians, citizens and newspapers were critical of Lincoln and the Union. This division was personified by the Halsey family of Rockaway: when war broke out Edmund, 22, a Princeton graduate, enlisted in the 15th New Jersey Volunteers of the Union Army. His brother Joseph, 38, also a Princeton graduate, had married into a slave-owning family and had moved to Virginia. He fought for the Confederacy. Joseph wrote many letters, as did Edmund, who also kept a diary. ''Brother Against Brother,'' edited by Bruce Chadwick, tells the war's story from both sides through these writings.

title: Get Me To the Gym On Time
description: ON a recent Friday afternoon, Halle Becker, clad only in a pair of white Manolo Blahnik pumps and a flesh-colored thong, stood before a three-sided mirror in the Bergdorf Goodman wedding salon. Discarded bridal gowns lay about her feet like enormous dollops of whipped cream. A gravel-voiced redhead who produces corporate events, Ms. Becker, 35, was quick to reject styles that didn't flatter her svelte physique, which, she admitted, she'd put through a two-hour work-out earlier that day.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Head for Heights
description: A kaleidoscopic panorama of sky, stone, glass and steel, striated with film noir shadows and the glint of sunlight: It's a view of New York City more familiar to first-time visitors than to harried locals, most of whom wouldn't be caught dead craning their necks in appreciation of what soars above them. With unabashed enthusiasm, the German photographer and Manhattan resident Horst Hamann celebrates New York's loftiest sphere in NEW YORK VERTICAL (Te Neues Publishing, $98). For Hamann -- with his panoramic camera tipped 90 degrees, his apparent fearlessness of heights and his infatuation with what the journalist Volker Skierka calls, in the book's introduction, the fifth compass point (''upwards, above and beyond'') -- the vertical perspective was an obvious one. Indeed, flipping through the 66 black-and-white depictions of the stark, distorted geometry of New York's upper regions, one wonders why such a collection hasn't been compiled before. Here are the famous landmarks -- the Empire State Building, the Chrysler Building, Trinity Church -- looking as if they have just been launched into ''vertical infinity.'' And here, also, are the anonymous places: the Brooklyn Bridge as viewed from a desolate corner; a nondescript building on Bond Street in Manhattan, sprayed with graffiti and accompanied by an artist's lonely words (''In the last 12 months, many of my friends have advised me to leave New York''). All the photographs are set off with observations from Woody Allen, E. B. White and other writers, artists and working people. Together, the quotations and photographs manage to convey with tension and eloquence the obvious but unavoidable metaphor inherent in such a thematic treatment of New York. The skyscrapers, the bridges, the not-so-grand buildings are nothing if not the architectural embodiment of the vertiginous passions that define life in the vertical city. Suzanne MacNeille

title: CUNY Proposes Stricter Rules On Students in Remedial Classes
description: Stung by criticism that it is wasting resources and lowering its standards in teaching students basic skills that they should have learned in high school, the City University of New York is proposing a sweeping overhaul of the way it handles students who are not ready for college-level work.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: February 22-28; Campaign Finance Reform: Keep Waiting
description: It was all over in a week.

title: Name That Zone
description: Los Angeles is not known as a hub of technology and new media. But city boosters, pointing to an expanding coastal L.A. cluster of businesses like Boxtop, Cybermedia and Activision, believe it should be -- right up there with Silicon Valley, New York's Silicon Alley and other tech hotbeds in Seattle, Austin and Boston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERERA, CHARLES ALLEN, M.D.
description: PERERA-Charles Allen, M.D. With deepest sympathy we announce the death on January 27, 1998 of our respected colleague, renowned physician and scholar Charles Allen Perera M.D. Dr. Perera joined the staff of Columbia University Department of Ophthalmology, The Edward S. Harkness Eye Institute in 1935 specializing in Ophthalmic Pathology. He was a founding member of the Verhoeff Society and Editor of the Collected Papers of Dr. John M. Wheeler. He was also the Editor of several editions of the Charles May Handbook of Ophthalmology. He served on the Scientific Board of Fight for Sight. He was active in the world-wide Society of Friends. He retired in 1971 and was appointed Consultant Emeritus at Columbia University. Dr. Perera was admired and respected by both his patients and colleagues. He made significant contributions to ophthalmology and in particular to the Edward S. Harkness Eye Institute. He will be sadly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Perera's family. A memorial service is scheduled for Saturday, March 7, 1998 at 2 PM. The address is: Kendal Auditorium, Kendal at Longwood Community, Route 1, Kennett Square, PA 19348. Telephone: 610-388-7001 Stanley Chang, M.D. Edward S. Harkness, Professor and Chairman

title: PULSE; Here's The Dirt
description: From Elvis Presley's slick pompadour to the rumpled locks of Pearl Jam's Eddie Vedder, rock-star hair has been copied by fans for years. But cultivating the unkempt look, with its accompanying dandruff and greasy scalp, takes time. Now, it is no longer necessary to wait for hair to become dirty for it to look that way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOCHNOWITZ, JEAN
description: JOCHNOWITZ - Jean. Beloved wife of the late Solomon. Beloved mother of Samson and Joe. Dear grandmother of Robin, Andrea, Daniel, Abbey, Nina, Gabriel, Douglas, Jennifer and Michael. Cherished and adored great-grandmother. Services Sunday, 12:30, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOWSETT, JACK
description: DOWSETT - Jack. 3/4/88 - 3/4/98. Ten years ago you were suddenly gone. Wishing with all my heart that you were here....But you are not. Your memory burns brighter each year, and the thought of you always brings a smile to my face. You sure were ONE SINGULAR SENSATION. Love, your sister Kathy

title: With the Telluride, Colo., Ski Patrol
description: After Michael Kennedy and Sonny Bono died in skiing accidents within a week of each other, industry spokespeople rushed forward to explain that the sport had not suddenly reached a new state of deadliness. True enough -- more people are killed every year boating and bicycling than skiing -- but the day-to-day risks of skiing (and snowboarding) are considerable. In a typical year, more than 30 people die at U.S. ski areas and another 130,000 are hurt bad enough to require medical assistance. In the grand ''You fall, we haul'' tradition of ski patrols everywhere, the 45 patrollers in Telluride, Colo., pick up after other people's mistakes, handling an average of 2.75 boo-boos per 1,000 skier-days. With March's spring-break skiing rush about to begin, here's a sample of typical slopeside woes.

title: Do You Know These Women?
description: ANNIE OAKLEY slept here -- in Nutley, where she settled for 10 years after touring Europe with Buffalo Bill.

title: Foreign Team in Mexico Warns of Growing Danger in Chiapas
description: After a two-week mission in southern Chiapas state, nearly 200 human rights observers from Europe and Canada left Mexico today calling the Government's campaign against foreigners ''a way of distracting from the conflict'' and warning that the polarization between pro- and anti-Government factions in the state is deepening dangerously.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, ZALDIN ETHEL
description: BIRNBAUM-Zaldin Ethel. Devoted wife of the late Stanley.Beloved companion of Jerry Litt. Beloved mother of Alfred and Meg, Marty and Nancy. Dear sister of Seymour and Harriet. Adored grandmother of Stephanie, Michelle, Shane, Samantha and Elizabeth. She will be sorely missed and loved by all. Services Sunday 12 noon, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd and 76th Rd, Forest Hills.

description: Painting Classes in Italy

title: Adventure; In Hot Pursuit
description: Brumby running! does the phrase quicken your heartbeat in anticipation of high adventure at breakneck speed? Are we talking river rapids or wild horses? If you have read the great Australian ballad ''The Man From Snowy River,'' by A. B. (Banjo) Paterson (or seen the movie with Kirk Douglas), you probably know exactly what brumby running means: chasing and roping wild horses in the high country of southeastern Australia.

title: Wrong Emphasis
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The East Side Looks Eastward
description: CAFE CENTRO ** [rating: two stars]

title: The World: Clueless; Tests Show Nobody's Smart About Intelligence
description: AFTER decades of agonizing over the fairness of S.A.T. scores, the differences between male and female mathematical skills and the gaps in I.Q. between various races and ethnic groups, the notion of intelligence and how to measure it remains more political than scientific, and as maddeningly elusive as ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, JOSEPH
description: ROTHSTEIN - Joseph. Sutton Place Synagogue records with sorrow the loss of our member and benefactor on February 21. Our condolences to his devoted wife Gale and the bereaved family. Robert W. Berend, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARMER, HENRY JR.
description: FARMER-Henry Jr. of Glen Ridge, NJ on February 20, 1998. Husband of Marianne (Aebli), father of Sue Belinger of CT, Mary Jay Mullowney and Henry Rudolpf Farmer, both of Burlington, VT and Peter Farmer of NYC. Grandfather of Eileen and Julie Mullowney, Lauren and Sabrina Farmer, brother of Janet Ackerly of Southport, CT. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 7, 12 PM at the Glen Ridge Congregational Church, 195 Ridgewood Ave., Glen Ridge, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Cancer Care, 1180 Ave. of the Americas, NY, NY 10036 or Hospice of Glen Ridge, 3 High St., Glen Ridge, NJ 07028.

title: Those Common Errors Can Be Costly
description: Taxpayers' errors fall into two broad categories. On the one hand are those that will raise the hackles of the I.R.S., resulting in correspondence, and possibly additional taxes, interest and penalties. On the other are oversights that may escape I.R.S. notice but may cause you to pay more tax than necessary. Following are examples of each type from Sidney Kess, a tax lawyer and accountant, and the American Express Tax Guide 1998 (Harper Business):

title: American Is Reducing Jet Service in Caribbean
description: American Airlines plans to end jet service in April between San Juan, P.R., and five Caribbean islands and cut it in half to another, substituting turboprop planes operated by American Eagle, American's commuter carrier. Caribbean officials are critical of American's decision, some saying that substituting the smaller prop planes will depress tourism, while others have called it a blow to the islands' status.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: DOROTHY DANDRIDGE: A Biography

title: Science Outpaces Near-Death, Saving Life
description: ELAINE HECKER stood in the hallway of her home, gazing at what she calls ''the shrine.'' It is a wall filled with pictures of her 3-year-old grandson, Mark Mattessich. She was beaming.

title: Disney Ship's Debut Is Delayed Again
description: If building a cruise ship were as easy as creating Mark Twain's Steamboat, the Disney Magic would have carried thousands of passengers by now. But as it is, even with magic from Aladdin's lamp, the first sailing of the Disney ship has again been postponed, to July 30 from April 30.

title: What's New? A Lot; Queens
description: For better or worse, Archie Bunker put Queens on the map. Now, an institution that is everything Mr. Bunker was not -- experimental, xenophilic, young and funky -- may be giving the perversely lovable bigot a run for his money. In October 1997, the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center reopened in Long Island City after a major three-year renovation. With its exhibition space expanded to 125,000 square feet, the Center may be one of the largest contemporary art institutions in the world. There is certainly nothing else in New York like it.

title: America in Watercolors
description: CAPTAIN WATSON'S TRAVELS IN AMERICA

title: Doing One Play Twice: Elizabethan or Modern
description: DEE O'BRIEN swept Sarah Mehlman's hair off her face, slipped a long beaded necklace over her head and studied the effect. ''Is that too 70's go-go?'' Ms. O'Brien wondered aloud. ''What should we do with her hair? And gloves. She definitely needs gloves.''

title: At Big Employers, Big Savings on 401(k) Fees
description: IT'S a difficult scene to envision: chief financial officers and their eye-shaded minions crunching numbers into the wee hours, not to cut corporate overhead or other costs, but to save their own employees' retirement money. But that's the gist of what more such officers of the largest corporations are trying to do as they negotiate lower fees for employee 401(k) plans.

title: Whence the Big Ideas?
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A/Mary T. Alfinito; Early Treatment Can Aid a Troubled Child
description: THE book ''Reviving Ophelia,'' on best-seller lists for more than three years, details the potential trauma of being a teen-age girl. News accounts tell of putting depressed children on Prozac and of an increasingly common practice of diagnosing children with attention disorders and putting them on drugs. It is enough to make you think that being a child can be a nightmare.

title: Jarrett Posner and Elana Waksal
description: Elana Waksal, a daughter of Cynthia F. Nash of Washington and Dr. Samuel D. Waksal of New York, was married last evening to Jarrett Blake Posner, a son of Susan and Steven Posner of Miami. Rabbi Howard Gorin performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel on the island of Nevis in the West Indies.

title: A Mother and Son's Divergent Paths And Contemporary Black Artists
description: Two Generations

title: Bill Eases Challenges to Land Regulation
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee, splitting along party lines, approved legislation on Thursday that would make it easier for property owners to challenge environmental regulations and local zoning decisions in Federal courts.

title: February 22-28; El Nino Takes a Toll On Both Coasts
description: Florida is as accustomed to tornadoes as Texas or Arkansas, but by the time at least six of them cut a wide swath between Tampa and Daytona Beach, packing winds of more than 200 miles per hour, Florida had recorded the deadliest such swarm of storms on the state's record books. At least 39 people were killed and nearly 300 others injured in four counties as the unusually powerful tornadoes caused devastation reminiscent of Hurricane Andrew in 1992. The weather was attributed to the climate-altering phenomenon known as El Nino, which last week was also blamed for torrential rains and rare tornadoes in California that caused mudslides, flash flooding and a death toll of at least nine. MIREYA NAVARRO

title: From Holy Men to Houses, a World of Tax Breaks
description: WHEN the Trinity Broadcasting Network of Tustin, Calif., hires a station manager, it can offer a benefit that ABC, NBC, CBS and Fox cannot match: a tax-free housing stipend.

title: Disappointed Kids
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Computing Returns the Feel-Good Way
description: NOT everyone who has a computer at home trusts it entirely. Lurking in the back of many a PC owner's mind is the nagging fear that the machine is booby-trapped to foul up unfixably for an unknowable reason at an unpredictable but crucial moment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, HENRIETTA (QUEENIE)
description: KATZ-Henrietta (Queenie), age 95 of Lauderhill, FL, formerly of New York. Beloved wife of the late Hyman (Kitty). Loving mother of Henry (Margaret), Richard (Judy), and Lucy (Ed) Weidman. Adored by eleven grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. Graveside services Sunday, March 1st, Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island 11 AM. Friends and family may call at the home of Lucy and Ed Weidman on Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday from 4:00 P.M. to 9:00 P.M.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Somebody's Child

title: Adventure; Choosing the Unmapped Route
description: An adventure is a transgression you don't regret. Your first came, surely, as a child. Perhaps, as in a fairy tale, your parents left you alone, in a hotel room, with your sister, while they went out to dinner. Room service was sheer delight -- the cart, the uniformed waiter, plates under silvery domes. But the adventure began only when you sneaked, pajama-clad, into a wedding reception. Strangers fed you canapes. In bed when your parents returned, you'd never forget the woman in the strapless gown.

title: A Star In Twilight Turns Reflective
description: IN A CAREER that has spanned 45 years, Paul Newman has come to embody the very word icon: his face is instantly recognizable, because of his motion pictures, of course, and because of the labels on the sauces and salad dressings that carry his name. It is a face that is almost delicate in its lines, mysteriously vulnerable, with a mouth that manages somehow to convey both sensuality and sorrow.

title: When Will Oscar Really Know the Score?
description: ONE OF the great, annoying paradoxes of movie music is that it works best when it's noticed least. That, unfortunately, gives the annual Academy Award nominations for best original dramatic score and best original musical or comedy score an air of Heisenbergian uncertainty. If film scoring, like film editing, is meant to be an invisible support system -- if, like a certain celebrated iceberg, this is an art that's more powerful when only a little bit shows above the surface -- which scores should be honored? The ones that stand out? Or the ones that without calling attention to themselves, make good movies seem magically better?

title: What's New? A Lot; Paris
description: A most unlikely complex has affected Parisians of late: The feeling that the gastronomic scene in London, of all places, may be livelier and more inventive than their own. The formulaic fare of certain brasseries, and the tired predictability of many menus, have become a subject of anxious, sometimes vitriolic, debate over the extent to which France should open its cuisine to greater international influence.

title: New Ways Of Exploring The Old West
description: OVER THE last 30 years, the telling of American history, especially the history of the American West, has undergone fundamental changes. In counterpoint to the traditional European-American tale of triumphant exploration and conquest, a complicated narrative has emerged: stories, told in many different voices, of threatened native cultures and displaced populations. And as ideas of history have changed, museums devoted to the West have had to reinvent themselves. The exhibition ''Powerful Images: Persistent Voices,'' at the Cowboy Hall of Fame in Oklahoma City, is, in effect, a show about this process of reassessment.

title: State G.O.P. Gives Pataki Fund Cushion
description: In the last year, New York's Republican Party raised campaign money at an unprecedented rate and gave most of it to Gov. George E. Pataki's re-election fund, allowing his campaign to circumvent laws that limit contributions from wealthy supporters, campaign documents show.

title: Dr. Bogart, Mr. Spiess Lubowski
description: Dr. Tara Anne Bogart, a periodontist in New York, is to be married today to Nelson David Spiess Lubowski, a senior vice president in private client services at Lehman Brothers in New York. Rabbi Yisroel Jungreis is to perform the ceremony at the Himeni Heritage Center in New York.

title: Mets Drop Exhibition Opener as Hundley Fidgets
description: Spring training began in earnest for the Mets today on a slightly ominous note: they had to sit through an hourlong rain delay. The game ended with a two-out, full-count, run-scoring single from a nonroster catcher named Fausto Tejero, who wears No. 86 on his Atlanta uniform.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUBBELL, DOROTHY TWYEFFORT
description: HUBBELL-Dorothy Twyeffort. A woman of elegant strength, died February 23, 1998 in Falmouth, Me. She was 89. Born in Paris, to American parents, Josephine and Louis Twyeffort, she lived there until she graduated from Vassar in 1930. A year later she married William Bradford Hubbell and moved to Bedford, N.Y. Captain W.B. Hubbell died in 1943, serving in the Army Air Corps in Alaska. She lived on Mianus River Road in Bedford for 63 years and retired to Me. in 1995. She is survived by their sons William B. Hubbell, Jr. of Cumberland Foreside, Me., John T. Hubbell of Asheville, NC., daughter Anne H. French of Bedford, NY and by 8 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Mrs. Hubbell was an Elder of the Bedford Presbyterian Church as well as a devoted supporter of the Mianus Gorge Preserve. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be sent to the Mianus Gorge Preserve, 167 Mianus River Road, Bedford, New York. 10506. A memorial service will be held in the spring in Bedford when the lilacs are in bloom.

title: Frequent Fliers
description: A PRIVATE STATE

title: Don't Call Me 'Near Elderly'
description: With regard to William Safire's On Language column ''Don't Call Me 'Near Elderly' '' (Feb. 8), I favor the euphemism ''upper-middle-aged.''

title: The View From/White Plains; As Kosher as Can Be, Deli Stresses Difference
description: ONE of Paul Sia's earliest memories is of ''the knish truck rolling through the mountains.'' The mountains were the Catskills; young Paul and his family ''used to schlep up to'' a rented cottage there every summer. The Sias were not Jewish, but Mr. Sia was in the garment business, and many of the family's friends were Jews who spent vacations in the Borscht Belt.

title: The World; America, the Lone Wolf With a Following
description: AMERICANS watching the military and diplomatic drama in Iraq might easily wonder why Washington seems to bear every burden and get so little gratitude or support, even from the countries most threatened by Saddam Hussein.

title: City of Gold
description: Through slippery, perilously steep cobblestone byways, slaves carried refined Portuguese ladies in ornate sedan chairs. Impassioned rebels plotted independence within sight of the rock where, if betrayed, they could be hanged. An artist whose nerves were ravaged by disease carved statues of laughing angels, while prospectors for gold changed the luck of a lifetime overnight.

title: Artists, In Paint and In Person
description: THE opening of the Museum of Modern Art's Chuck Close retrospective on Wednesday night was the biggest non-Grammy party of the week, and it attracted its own list of mega-stars. It was hard to know which to focus on -- the people or the pictures in the exhibition, since they were frequently identical. Apparently not everyone was riveted by the music-industry extravaganza taking place just a few blocks away.

title: Chinese Official's Visit Bolsters Mount Vernon
description: A RECENT visit by officials from China has members of the city administration here feeling more optimistic than ever about a proposed joint international development project.

title: Mud in the Data Stream
description: CODE-NAME BRIGHT LIGHT The Untold Story of U.S. POW Rescue Efforts During the Vietnam War. By George J. Veith. Illustrated. 408 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.

title: Rutgers Sports Programs Get 2 Sets of Suggestions
description: Rutgers University's football team had a 0-11 record last fall, but that didn't necessarily mean the players were studying instead of practicing. Rutgers athletes take more than two months longer on average to graduate than the student body overall, according to the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Backtalk; The 'Olympic' Moment Isn't What It Used to Be
description: The Olympics are over. Forever. If you don't agree, you have not been paying attention to the Nagano Games, a relic of the 19th century, or to the transvestite Thai kick boxer, Pirinya Kaibusaba, who will carry the torch into the 21st.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATTMAN, IRWIN
description: PLATTMAN-Irwin. On February 23, 1998. Devoted father of Miles (Christine) and Hal. Cherished grandfather of Victoria, Morgan and Devin. Loving brother of Flossy Leavy and Judy Denenberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINRIB, ARNOLD W.
description: WEINRIB-Arnold W. On February 27, 1998. Of New York City and Saltaire, NY. Graduate of Princeton University Class of 1955. Husband of Mary Ellen Weinrib. Father of Theodore Briggs Weinrib. Brotherin-law of Catherine Donovan and several nieces and one nephew. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Saltaire Fire Department, PO Box 5375, Bay Shore, NY 11706.

title: Documents From Cigarette Makers Show They Tested Methods to Enhance Nicotine
description: Two months after a top executive of the Philip Morris Companies testified in 1994 before Congress that the cigarette maker did not ''manipulate or independently control'' nicotine in its products, company scientists reported on human experiments that indicated that they could produce ''enhanced'' nicotine effects on a smoker's nervous system, an internal company document shows.

title: So Far, a Good Year in Europe
description: LOWER interest rates, corporate cost-cutting and a positive outlook for earnings have sent European stock indexes to more new highs this year than the leading American indexes have reached. And because the dollar, while volatile, has not changed much in value against European currencies, Americans who invested in Europe have done well so far.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISSELL, EDITH (NEE ROACH)
description: BISSELL-Edith (nee Roach). Age 62 of Chester Township, NJ, on Wednesday, February 25, 1998. Wife of Elliston Perot Bissell III of Morristown, NJ; mother of Elliston P. IV of Seattle, WA, Rolin P. of Chestnut Hill, PA and Ann P. of London, England. Sister of Lloyd B. Roach of West Chester, PA, Peter Roach of Chicago, IL and Ann Hoover of Coconut Grove, FL. She is also survived by her father, Isaac Roach, of Vero Beach, FL and five grandchildren. A memorial mass will be offered on Tuesday, March 3, at 11 AM at St. Denis Church, 2401 St. Denis Lane, Havertown, PA. Interment Old St. David's Cemetery. Memorial gifts may be made to Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, 325 Chestnut St., Philadelphia, PA 19106.

title: Confessions of a Reluctant Eco-Tourist
description: HEY! It is a jungle out there. People really do hack their way through the underbrush with machetes, sleep under mosquito netting and get bitten by scorpions. The jungle really is unimaginably hot and humid. Remember how Sidney Greenstreet and Ava Gardner used to sweat, in spite of the overhead fans? Even Tarzan had problems acclimating to jungle life. Had I given the matter sufficient thought, I might have realized that eight degrees from the Equator in the middle of a Costa Rican rain forest might not be the optimal vacation destination for a red-headed Caucasian, especially one whose ancestors actually did come from the Caucasus. I might also have figured out that every day is a bad hair day in Costa Rica.

title: INSIDE
description: Company Documents Show Nicotine Experiments

title: In Exile Wherever He Goes
description: Alexander Solzhenitsyn A Century in His Life. By D. M. Thomas. Illustrated. 583 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $29.95.

title: Skip Away Runs Away From Field by 2 1/4 Lengths
description: Skip Away won his fourth straight major race when he swept to victory today in the $500,000 Gulfstream Park Handicap and raced ever closer to his goal of becoming racing's richest horse.

title: Antipoverty Group Fighting to Keep Its Center Open
description: CEILING tiles are falling down and there is a puddle of water in the middle of the worn wooden floor in the Manhasset-Great Neck Economic Opportunity Commission center's gym. The antipoverty group's basketball team has no place to practice, the computer room is vacant and paint is peeling on the columned facade of the former schoolhouse, constructed in 1929 as the segregated Manhaaset Valley School.

title: Sampras Finally Able To Take Foe to School
description: Pete Sampras was just a hooky-playing teen-ager when he won his first ATP title here in 1990. That breakthrough convinced him he was right to shelve his high school career in favor of one that would make him a multimillionaire and lead him to the head of the class on the global tennis court.

title: Restoration by the Numbers Along a 19th-Century Barge Canal
description: MORE than 150 years after they were first set in place, blocks of stone weighing up to a ton each were maneuvered back into their numbered spots as restoration continued on the locks and a stretch of canal and towpath of the Delaware and Raritan Canal near Boyd Park in New Brunswick.

title: Q/A: Dr. Ted Horowitz; Help With Stresses of Single Parenthood
description: AT the request of many of his divorced clients, Dr. Ted Horowitz, a psychotherapist with a practice in Queens and Port Jefferson Station, was using hypnosis to help provide motivation to meet other singles and to cope with the stress of single parenthood.

title: For the Arts and Good Causes
description: From a Kitchen Caper for immunology to Brotherhood Awards.

title: Hampstead High
description: To listen to some londoners talk, hampstead, in the northwest corner of the city, deserves to be described entirely in italicized adjectives, each as double-edged and cutting as a dagger. Posh, trendy, snobbish, twee -- they sneer at this leafy, upscale neighborhood that has managed to preserve its villagey atmosphere a century after being swallowed by the surrounding metropolis. Crowded with cute shops, French cafes, Italian espresso bars, Hungarian bakeries and Arab teahouses, populated by A-list celebrities and represented in Parliament by the actress Glenda Jackson, Hampstead has come to be viewed as a precinct of preening yuppies, house-proud toffs and politically correct kooks. Recently, The Independent, a serious Labor-supporting broadsheet, ran a front-page article about rich Hampstead residents who buy tiger and lion manure from the London Zoo, then spread it over their lawns. Not that they believe jungle beasts produce the best fertilizer. No, their high-minded purpose, The Independent claimed, is to prevent foxes from burrowing in their gardens. The scent of predatory cats supposedly protects the property of enlightened folks who refuse to resort to traps, poisons or small-caliber pistols.

title: City With Plans Hires a Planner
description: EVER since Hartford's political and corporate leaders unveiled the MetroHartford Millennium Project in September, Kenneth Greenberg, a Toronto-based urban planner and consultant to the Trinity College president, Evan Dobelle, has watched as the officials embraced an ambitious plan for the economic revitalization of the capital region with an almost religious fervor.

title: Young Book Editors Looking for Dirt, Not Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: A Yankee Prospect Is Impressive in Debut
description: Mike Jerzembeck will turn 26 years old in three months, which is almost ancient for a minor league pitching prospect. So Jerzembeck must make the most of his chances, and that was exactly what he did with three scoreless innings today as the Yankees defeated the Pirates, 10-0, at Legends Field.

title: Finnish Modern: Defining a Nation By Its Designers
description: WHILE THE frozen streets here glistened with new-fallen snow, the entrances to galleries and museums were aglitter with the same curvilinear glass vase filled with tulips. More than a harbinger of spring, the recurring vase evoked the spirit of its designer, Alvar Aalto, whose centenary this year is the cause for the festive mood in this capital city.

title: Habitats/270 Union Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn; Former 'Colored School' Houses Artist and Studio
description: JAMES O. CLARK, a sculptor, eased his pickup into a parking space across the street from the onetime Colored School No. 3 in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn and thought back 15 years.

title: For Moviegoers, The Net's Not Yet An Easy Option
description: ANYONE WHO wonders what a full-length movie looks like on a computer screen at this moment of technological flux can go to the World Wide Web site called The Sync (http://www.thesync.com) and, provided one's machine and modem are of sufficient capacity, summon the silent classic ''Nosferatu.''

title: Sports of The Times; Why Won't N.H.L. Try European Coaches?
description: WHEN the Olympic men's hockey tournament was over, when Petr Svoboda had scored the gold-medal-winning goal for the Czech Republic in its 1-0 victory over Russia, he talked about how his coach, Ivan Hlinka, was the primary reason he had joined his nation's Olympic team.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: A Sumptuous Bouquet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REEDER, RUSSELL P. ''RED'' JR.
description: REEDER-Russell P. ''Red'' Jr., 96, United States Army, Retired, died of congestive heart failure on Sunday, February 22, 1998, at Mount Vernon INOVA Hospital in Alexandria, VA. Burial Service will be at 2 P.M. Friday, March 6, 1998 in the Cadet Chapel At West Point, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to the Red Reeder Memorial Fund, Association of Graduates, West Point, New York 10996.

title: On-Line Trade Fees Falling Off the Screen
description: THERE is no end in sight to the price war among on-line discount brokers.

title: The 'Eh?' Meter
description: Manhattanites must not be terribly concerned about loud noise, or they would move away and become, say, Dubuquers. But Dr. Paul A. Brown, a Harvard-trained physician and entrepreneur, thinks a little aural self-protection is in order. He's marketing a new palm-size device, the Hearing Alarm ($14.95; prototype pictured) that allows users to obtain instant racket readings, complete with warning lights that kick in at 80 decibels. (For comparison's sake, Brown says that more than four straight hours of exposure to noise levels between 80 and 110 decibels causes permanent damage that could eventually lead to significant hearing loss.) We recently asked him to tour the New York area to assess the threat. The results:

title: Live Music's Glory Days Pass It By; Suburbs Are Tuning Out, Even at Springsteen's Old Haunt
description: The band was jamming gleefully. The fans were dancing tirelessly. It was just like old times at the Stone Pony, the murky rock club where Bruce Springsteen got his start -- except for one thing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FIELDS, ESTHER R.
description: FIELDS-Esther R. March 3. A beautiful butterfly in life for a fleeting moment. Couldn't stay longer, always remembered. Your Daughter

title: Under a Cloud
description: As springlike rains beat down on New York, shoppers on Madison Avenue are popping open David Tang's brightly colored signature umbrellas. ''I carry mine everywhere because it's extra large, and it gives me a little more space than most umbrellas,'' said Louise Gray, an actress and waitress who owns two. ''I feel like people are dying to jump underneath with me.''

title: Clinton Staff Starts to Put Race Policy Into Practice
description: Back in December, Jon Jennings, a White House Fellow, was trying to figure out what he could do to further President Clinton's Initiative on Race. To get the message out to a broader audience, he decided to use his contacts in professional sports; before his White House Fellowship, Mr. Jennings had been an assistant coach with the Boston Celtics.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 15 about 19th-century yellow journalism misattributed a famous description of the Spanish-American War as ''a splendid little war begun with the highest motives.''
