It was written in an 1898 letter from John Hay, Ambassador to England and later Secretary of State, to Col. Theodore Roosevelt. Roosevelt did not coin the phrase.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Polish Lover

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ANNE (NEE SPRINZ)
description: SCHWARTZ-Anne (nee Sprinz). February 26, 1998. Your long and brave struggle against cancer has ended. Your lively wit and spirit will long be remembered by all those who loved you. Betty, Frank, Patti, Lisa and Andy

title: Building Unsinkable Boats That Lifeguards Clamor For
description: In 1955, to win a $10 bet, an Atlantic city lifeguard named Richard (Boomer) Blair rowed a rescue boat into a hurricane. Mr. Blair rowed the boat, which was entirely underwater but miraculously didn't sink, 1,000 feet to the end of Steel Pier, and back.

title: Yolanda Merchant, Courtney Haff
description: Yolanda Suarez Merchant and Courtney Alfred Haff were married yesterday at the Episcopal French Church of St. Esprit in New York. The Rev. Nigel Massey performed the ceremony.

title: Has Nonfiction Ever Lived Up to Its Name?; Unfamiliar Worlds
description: To the Editor:

title: New Group Enlists Montaukets in Drive for Gambling
description: A RECENTLY formed group has enlisted the Montaukets in a move that could bring legalized gambling to the former Northrop-Grumman airport complex in Calverton.

title: The Homosexual Exception
description: Wolfe tells us that the suburbs are populated by people who can't even get to ''tolerance'' of homosexuality, let alone to understanding. The reason, he says, is that they are stuck on the erroneous assumption that we choose to be gay; therefore, we should just unchoose it. What little is known about human sexuality indicates that genetics plays a strong role in determining everyone's sexuality. While I expect that the vast majority of heterosexuals believe they did not choose their sexual orientation, I puzzle daily over the fact that many of them believe gay people have selected theirs -- leading a small minority to use this as a basis to argue against equality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONG, MARY ELIZABETH, (LIZ)
description: LONG-Mary Elizabeth, (Liz) of New York, NY and Orlando, FL. on February 18, 1998 in Orlando. Survived by her sisters Patricia Landmann, and Kate Hennessey, as well as many nieces and nephews. Funeral service private. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the ASPCA.

title: What Do Voters Think Anyway?
description: EARLIER this month, a Connecticut voter was asked his opinions of candidates and of issues that may figure in elections later this year.

title: The Nation; It's The Economy, Genius
description: THE American economy is a behemoth, driven by forces so vast and unpredictable that they are difficult to track and impossible to control. In the short term, economists agree, Presidents have almost no influence over the ups and downs of the business cycle. What effect their economic policies do have is often felt long after they have left office.

title: Not a Clue
description: The Fortune Sellers

title: Adam Purple Stands His Ground in 184 Forsyth Standoff
description: It was a bad week for the man known as Adam Purple.

title: The Scary Guy
description: Earl Kenneth Kaufmann, a tattoo artist from Tucson, Ariz., recently persuaded a judge to let him legally change his name to The Scary Guy.

title: In Midst of Preservation Battle, 2 Claims to Montauket Chief
description: TWO men claiming to be the rightful leader of the Montauket Indians are vying for leadership as the tribe prepares to seek Federal recognition and thwart an attempt to build a golf course or recreational facility on its ''sacred'' grounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, ETHEL
description: BURNS-Ethel, died on February 27, 1998. For many years she was connected with educational broadcasting on WNYE-FM and WNYETV channel 25, with many of her program series winning Emmys for CBS-TV, where they were broadcast. Among the programs she produced for television and radio were American Musical Theater, Dial M For Music, Around The Corner, and It's Fun To Sing. She will be missed by her TV and radio friends. For information regarding funeral arrangements contact at Riverside 212-362-6600.

title: Dr. Rachmiel Levine, 87, Diabetes Expert, Dies
description: Dr. Rachmiel Levine, whose experiments on how insulin increases the body's use of blood sugars overturned conventional scientific belief and set new courses for diabetes research, died on Feb. 22 in Faulkner Hospital in Boston. He was 87 and lived in Newton, Mass.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 1, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Lassoing Your Inner Self
description: AS I stood in the bone-dry dust of the corral and approached an imposing brown gelding named Magic, I felt anything but magical. My task: to lift the hoofs of this 1,200 pound truth-detector, cleanse them of mud, manure and stones one at a time, and in so doing, confront a few of the demons that color my relationships with two-legged creatures packing more artifice but less kick.

title: Lyme Disease
description: If predictions prove correct, Lyme disease could rise precipitously next year. According to a study in the Feb. 13 issue of the journal Science, a bumper crop of acorns last fall has likely started a cycle beneficial to ticks, the carriers of the disease.

title: The Ultimate Moment, When Reason Fails
description: TAKE an analytical surgeon who would rather be a metaphysician. Add a prominent playwright who extracts drama from a doctor's private and professional dilemma. Pair him with a director for whom confronting audiences with the unspoken mysteries of life is more important than offering a real good time.

title: A Man Who Loved Women
description: TITIAN'S WOMEN

title: High-Octane Fund on a Roll
description: WHEN Michael J. Reilly, 33, was offered a job at Alliance Capital Management in 1992, he wrestled less with hours, pay and benefits than with an issue closer to home. Would he be able to cope with his older brother James, already his roommate, working as a portfolio manager in the same office?

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Riverdale, the Bronx; A Community Jealous of Its Open Space
description: RESIDENTS of the rambling Riverdale neighborhood in the northwest corner of the Bronx have long fought to retain its special character. And with good reason.

title: Postcard From Pinetop
description: NOBODY'S GIRL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEATTIE, EDWARD J., M.D.
description: BEATTIE-Edward J., M.D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent corporation, Greater Metropolitan Health Systems, Inc., in acknowledging with deep sadness the passing of our beloved colleague and friend, Ted Beattie, M.D. Beth Israel welcomed Dr. Beattie to its medical staff in 1985 following his years of distinguished service at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (where he was Chief of Staff and Chairman of Surgery) and other leading medical institutions. At Beth Israel, he served as the first Director of the David B. Kriser Lung Cancer Center and Chief of Thoracic Surgery, and, since 1995, provided outstanding leadership in the development of the Beth Israel Cancer Center. The rapid growth and expansion of our initiatives in the diagnosis and treatment of cancer stand as his legacy to the thousands of patients who turned to us for help. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and worked with him. To his wife Nicole, his son Bruce, his brother James, his grandson Edward, the entire Beattie family, and all who loved him, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman Chairman, Boards of Trustees, GMHS and BIMC Robert G. Newman, M.D. President and CEO, GMHS Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO, BIMC Jerome S. Breslaw, M.D. President, Medical Board, BIMC Sidney K. Stein, M.D. President, Doctors Alumni Assoc.

title: Semantics of Riley: Dirty Play? Hard Foul?
description: Keith Askins said Pat Riley has never encouraged him to take someone out of a basketball game. ''Not one single time, to any of us,'' Askins said yesterday afternoon. ''Sure, he wants us to be aggressive and not give up layups. But that's much different.''

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Your Taxes

title: Now Hiring
description: PATRICIA CLAGHORN originally wanted to call it the Mother of All Job Fairs. She changed her mind.

title: Putting the Moi Back in Memoir
description: After years of effort in the author trade, I've discovered an ideal topic, an inexhaustible subject of discourse, a literary inspiration -- me. I'm writing a memoir. I don't know why I didn't do this ages ago. It's so liberating to sit down at the keyboard and just be myself, as opposed to, say, being you, which I don't have the clothes for.

title: On Self-Help Shelf, Four Big Tomes on How to Face T-Day
description: MOST of us would probably prefer to deal with the Internal Revenue Service by rumor only. But, alas, every April 15 we must confront the beast and balance our financial lives according to the tax laws of the moment.

title: A Star in Europe And the Americas Takes On the U.S.
description: When Eros Ramazzotti was born, his father, an aspiring singer whose own dreams of stardom never materialized, named him after the Greek god of love. He thought the name would bring his son good luck. Thirty-four years and 25 million records later, Mr. Ramazzotti is a pop superstar in Europe and Central and South America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, IRWIN S.
description: RUBIN-Irwin S. On February 27, 1998, age 67, at home in Bear Creek, PA. A founder and former President of Trion Industries, passionate golfer and traveler, lover of life. Beloved father, grandfather, brother and friend. He is survived by his children, Jeffrey and Susan Rubin and Lita and Alan Saltzman; his grandchildren Justine, Ethan, Leigh and Kate; brother Warren Rubin; and sister Myrna Doerfler. Services Monday, March 2, 1 PM, at the Rosenberg Funeral Home, 348 South River St., Wilkes-Barre, PA. At Irwin's request, his life will be celebrated at a gathering following the services at the Woodlands Hotel. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center Fund, 622 West 168th St., New York, NY 10032.

title: What's New? A Lot; Houston
description: The famous French Quarter in New Orleans. Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco. Times Square in New York. Bayou Place in Houston.

title: Voices In Songs Sacred and Secular
description: VOCAL ensemble art is well in evidence this week. This afternoon at 4 the Fairfield County Chorale, augmented by the Fairfield County Children's Chorus, presents under the direction of Johannes Somary a sampling of sacred music from the romantic era at St. Mark's Church in New Canaan. One highlight is the juxtaposing of Jewish and Lutheran settings of Psalm 150; another is the pairing of Gounod's Missa Brevis and Liszt's Missa Choralis, the latter performed with the assistance of the organist Kent Tritle. The number to call for more information is (203) 254-1333.

title: Rowdy Crowd At a Roadhouse In Trendyville
description: It would stand to reason that a bar with a mural of gunfighters painted on its outside wall might have a few fisticuffs. And it especially makes sense when the music in the place is country, the bartenders breathe fire and two feuding staffs of journalists regularly drink there.

title: After the Wall
description: Rebuilding A House Divided

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILENKER, HINDA FISHER
description: BILENKER-Hinda Fisher. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the mother of its beloved member, Judith Rabinowitz. May her family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: A Sport for All, and Now for the Olympics
description: FOR decades, if not centuries, curling has suffered from the Rodney Dangerfield syndrome. It just didn't get any respect. ''In some sports circles this is a joke game,'' summed up Terry Olson, vice president of the Norfolk Curling Club.

title: IN BRIEF; Welfare Policy Study Lists State Near Bottom
description: A Tufts University study has given New Jersey low grades in its implementation of welfare reform. The study, released last week, ranks the state 43d nationally. It was among 14 states whose policies were deemed likely to worsen poor families' economic well-being.

title: Jets Escort Lost Plane to an Atlantic City Landing
description: Four jet fighters of the New Jersey and Massachusetts Air National Guards scrambled out over the Atlantic early yesterday and escorted a small civilian aircraft that had lost its way to a landing in Atlantic City, military authorities said.

title: Educational Program For Retirees
description: Your article, ''Retirees, Refusing to Stand Pat, Infuse Communities,'' provided an excellent overview of the educational and recreational services being offered to Long Island's older residents. I regret only that you failed to mention the program know as the Hutton House Lectures at Long Island University's C. W. Post campus in Brookville. This program, which opened in 1976, offers an array of lecture courses in history, philosophy, literature, the fine arts and current events, as well as field trips to points as close as SoHo and the Metropolitan Museum of Art and as distant as Egypt and Greece. The Hutton House Lectures attracted a record 2,094 registrants in 1997. Its students are just the sort you described in your article: mature in mind and years, active, involved and dedicated to the view that learning is a lifelong experience.

title: Not Exactly a Landlord's Dream Tenant
description: WILLIAM RUSSELL MOORE -- tall, broad-shouldered, handsome, pumped with the confident righteousness of those who are raised as beloved children to believe that the system is supposed to work for them -- moved into 230 East 167th Street in the Bronx two years ago. He says he felt he should be part of the community in which he worked. Also, he could walk to his office near Yankee Stadium.

title: Mastering The Form 1040: A Step-by-Step Guide
description: The Tax Game scarcely rivals the Super Bowl or the World Series as an American favorite. Still, give the matter even a bit of the attention many fans lavish on those contests, and you may be a winner, considerably reducing what you pay Uncle Sam.

title: Creeping Up on the Day When It's Legal to Drive 65 M.P.H.
description: As the date nears when drivers can legally go faster on some New Jersey roads, how do you actually go about the massive job of changing the 55's to 65's?

title: Stephanie Lawson, K. G. Muhammad
description: Stephanie Michelle Lawson, a daughter of Dr. Doris Jennings of Longwood, Fla., and Robert Lawson of Orlando, Fla., was married yesterday to Khalil Gibran Muhammad, the son of Dr. Kimberly Muhammad-Earl of Chicago and Ozier Muhammad of New York. The Rev. Dr. Claude A. Knight performed the ceremony at St. Stephen Lutheran Church in Longwood.

title: An Asian Oasis
description: TARO is the kind of restaurant that people wish would open in their towns, an inspiring space that serves satisfying Asian dishes for reasonable prices.

title: Church in Smithtown Seeks Bus Easement
description: WORRIED about buses that leave a a parochial school, church officials have asked the Smithtown Town Board to let the buses leave from the rear exit and travel through a quiet residential neighborhood.

title: Tapping Into the Singles Market in West Midtown
description: LAST Wednesday was move-in day for Anthony Brittan and his brother, Steven, at a new building in Midtown West.

title: Ah, Wilderness!
description: Wild Thoughts

title: Where Disney World Meets Camden
description: EVERYBODY does it, Elaine Bey had insisted. Stealing from the schools of Camden, a city whose children are the poorest in the country, was no big deal, she seemed to believe.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEDLIS, CYNTHIA M.
description: SEDLIS-Cynthia M. March 1, 1997. You've been gone one year, but you have never left our side. We miss you. Love, All of Us

title: Digging Up the Old Gas Tank Drains the Independent Station's Profits
description: For most of last week, the most recognizable feature of Ray Netschert's Texaco station in Short Hills has been a huge, muddy mound of rubble. A sign over the garage bays announces that the station is open for repair work. But Mr. Netschert's business has plummeted since excavators ripped open the front of his station on Feb. 16.

title: Neighborhood Spot for Pasta in Armonk
description: AFTER years of neglect that a string of short-lived tenancies inflicts, this roadhouse restaurant has been given an elegant face lift. Outside, floodlights illuminate fresh white stucco, a brick walk runs through small islands of charming gardens, pinlights shimmer in trees -- the entrance is a pleasant destination in itself. But Il Giardino!! is not just another pretty face.

title: Police Charge Two In Fatal Drug Bust
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office leveled drug charges yesterday against two suspects captured during a buy-and-bust operation that left a third suspect dead and an undercover officer wounded on Friday morning.

title: Retired Negotiator May Lead '98 Talks
description: WITH contracts between the countyr and some of its unions having been expired for two years, the county is poised to rehire as a consultant its longtime labor negotiator, who received $50,000 in accrued vacation and sick pay when he retired at the end of last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUCE, JOSEPH J.
description: BRUCE-Joseph J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph J. Bruce, associated with The Times from 1959, until retiring in 1984.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIEN, JOYCE A.
description: WIEN-Joyce A. Judge Bernard Newman and his staff at the US Court of International Trade are saddened by the passing of their faithful secretary, Joyce A. Wien, on February 26, 1998. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family members. Joyce was a lovely and gracious lady, and will be greatly missed by all at the court.

title: The Steep Price Of Climbing To the Top Of the World
description: MAYBE it's because of his grandfather, a wild-animal collector still unaccounted for after a trip to British Guyana in the late 1930's. Or because of his father, who sailed in the merchant marine. Or his childhood in Puerto Rico spent yearning for snow. For whatever reason, Rick Werner really wants to climb Mount Everest.

title: Ready, Set, Grammy!
description: ''I USUALLY go to four or five Grammy parties,'' the calm, composed and collected rock star Sting said as he sat at a table with Luciano Pavarotti at the Waldorf-Astoria two nights before the 40th annual Grammy Awards ceremony. ''Until I get too drunk and have to be taken home.''

title: New Tension for City and AIDS Group
description: Although the city and Housing Works, which provides shelter and other services to poor people with AIDS, have worked more closely in the eight years since Housing Works was spun off from the activist group Act Up, their relationship is far from harmonious. Housing Works is a vocal critic of some city AIDS policies, and it filed a lawsuit to stop the Giuliani administration's threatened dismantling of the Division of AIDS Services. The suit is pending; the agency has been restructured.

title: DIARY
description: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE

title: Stamford's Old Town Hall Faces Developers
description: IN Stamford, where landmark buildings have been demolished by the hundreds over the last two decade and replaced by an eclectic array of corporate office towers, the Old Town Hall in the heart of downtown has seemed sacrosanct: a striking Beaux Arts structure gracefully bespeaking the city's past and aparently exempt from unending urban renewal.

title: Little Men on Campus
description: On a winter afternoon, as the sun throws long shadows off the Gothic splendor of Princeton University, C. J. Chapman knows he is in for a tough scrimmage at Jadwin Gym. Wiry and light-footed, a prized freshman out of Denver, Chapman is averaging only eight minutes per game on a veteran Princeton basketball team that has only lost once this year. But with Mitch Henderson, the senior guard, resting a cranky ankle, Chapman has swapped his white practice jersey for the black one worn by the starters.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 1, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Metro Matters; A Dialogue On the Way To an Ideal
description: ''Does everybody remember Plato? Plato developed the notion of the ideal. You never reached it. But in striving to get there, you kept making improvements in society. The ideal republic, the ideal state of honesty, the ideal state of integrity, the ideal state of cleanliness or safety.'' Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Feb. 25, 1998

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEMESHNIK, BEATRICE SCHAPIRA
description: LEMESHNIK-Beatrice Schapira. Died on February 28, 1998. Beloved wife of William Lemeshnik and loving mother of Beryl Levinger, Mitchel Schapira, and JoNan Forman. Cherished grandmother and friend to many. Services at Park West, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St., Monday, 11 AM. Donations, in lieu of flowers, to Cancer Research Institute, 681 5th Ave., NY, NY 10022. Shiva at the Levinger residence.

title: Foote, Cone Combines 2 Toronto Agencies
description: Foote, Cone & Belding, a unit of True North Communications, has combined two agencies in Toronto -- Foote, Cone & Belding and Harrod & Mirlin Ltd. -- to form Harrod & Mirlin/FCB Toronto.

title: Tully Filmus, 94, Realist and Portrait Painter
description: Tully Filmus, a realist painter and portraitist, died on Wednesday at his home in Fern Hill, Mass. He was 94.

title: Dreamworks' lackluster start is putting pressure on the company to perform.
description: AFTER David Shim, an adviser to the Korean investors in Dreamworks SKG, saw 20 minutes of ''Prince of Egypt,'' the company's forthcoming animated movie about Moses, he proclaimed the film ''awesome.'' In a telephone interview from Seoul, South Korea, he said, ''I would bet my own money it will be a success.''

title: Once Under Attack, Company Managing Child Care Benefits Is Promised More Money by State
description: State officials decided on Friday to pay more money to a company in charge of a bold effort to privatize welfare services, four months after nearly terminating the company because the effort was faltering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, RAY (NEE SCHREIBMAN)
description: GREENBAUM-Ray (nee Schreibman). Died February 28. Dear wife of the late Max Rozmarin and the late Noah Greenbaum. Beloved mother of Vivian and Donald Resnicoff, and Margie and Jerry Friedman. Dearest grandmother of Matt Resnicoff, Merryl and Jay Newler, and Nancy and Andrew Schwartz. Caring greatgrandmother of Jordana and Seth Newler. She lived a life of grace and beauty. Services today, March 2, 12:15 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue

title: Coach's Act Shows Sport at Its Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Judy Garland Gets Happy Again and Cruel, Too
description: Don't play your Judy Garland CD's before seeing ''I Will Come Back.'' It puts Garland impersonators, even good ones like Tommy Femia, at an unfair disadvantage. Going with the illusion is easier if you haven't just heard ''The Man That Got Away'' on ''Judy at Carnegie Hall.''

title: Ignoring Odds, Mayfair Beats Woods in a Playoff
description: For Billy Mayfair, the challenge was enormous, the journey was memorable, and the outcome was extremely gratifying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARVEY, JOHN P.
description: GARVEY-John P., 71, New York City, died February 27, 1998, emphysema. USNR, 1944-1946, gradate of Yale University, 1952, BA. Survived by his children, John P., Jr., Lee (Lili) G. Carmel, Nathalie (Mimi) G. Mascolo, six grandchildren, and his sister, Natalie Scott Martin. Service will be private.

title: Pan Am Talks On Funds Stall
description: The Pan American Airways Corporation and Pan American World Airways Inc. said over the weekend that talks with a New York investment firm had stalled and that the earliest the discount carriers could begin flying again was the middle of this week.

title: To Social Security Critics, The Argument Is Simple
description: As the nation begins debating how to shore up Social Security for the aging baby-boom generation, advocates of fundamentally changing the system are honing their argument to a single theme: that as an investment Social Security is a bad deal.

title: Dance for Thee, at 33-1, Shocks the Favorites
description: Who would win the fierce homestretch duel at Gulfstream Park yesterday in Hallandale, Fla., involving the two filly favorites -- Escena, with Jerry Bailey riding, or Glitter Woman, with Mike Smith? Answer: Dance for Thee, a 33-1 longshot with Joe Bravo orchestrating a furious finish that upset the two dueling favorites by two lengths in the $200,000 Rampart Handicap.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a ruling on World Court jurisdiction in the case of two Libyan citizens accused of blowing up a Pan American jet over Scotland in 1988 referred incorrectly to the countries that argued against the Court's jurisdiction. They were Britain and the United States, not Britain and France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENTHAL, MILDRED W.
description: BLUMENTHAL-Mildred W. In Westport, CT. February 16, 1998. Wife of the late Andre Blumenthal. Mother of William P., Thomas A. and Elizabeth A. Blumenthal and grandmother of eight. Memorial services March 6, 1 PM, in the Greens Farms Congregational Church, Westport, CT.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Rough Road for Motorola As Wireless Goes Digital

title: Holding On in the Garment Center; Shops Struggle With Soaring Rents in a Shrinking District
description: For 55 years, Sam Guarneri has been a button man in the garment district. He has supplied millions of pearl, casein and covered abalone buttons to the sample rooms and sewing shops on the streets and avenues south of Times Square. Business has shrunk to about a quarter of the 29 million buttons that he once sold every year. Yet, even as many other garment businesses have closed or moved, Mr. Guarneri, who is 70, hangs on, proud to be one of the few high-quality, button-dyeing operations left in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, GLADYS
description: STONE-Gladys. On March 1, 1998, 87 years. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Loving mother of Judith Kaufman. Devoted grandmother of Carole A. Bloom. Services 1:30 PM, Monday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Independent Lawyer Relishes Another Shot at Independent Counsel
description: Francis T. Mandanici, a public defender in New Haven, can scarcely contain himself. He has been complaining about Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating President Clinton, for years, and for the most part, has taken his lumps.

title: Investment Banking Visions Are Fading for German Giant
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., which announced the ambition to build a top-tier Wall Street franchise two years ago, is quietly pulling in its horns as aggressive expansion has bogged down in rising costs and as it focuses more of its efforts in Europe.

title: Hindu Still Proud of Role In Killing the Father of India
description: If India's general election brings a Hindu nationalist government to power, the event will have a special resonance for a courteous but hard-eyed old man who has made his two-room walk-up apartment in this old garrison city a shrine to Hindu nationalism and to its role in one of history's most notorious assassinations.

title: Reagan's Intellect Suited Him for Presidency; 'Brutish' Redefined
description: To the Editor:

title: The Unintended Career Of TV's Prolific Writer; From Real Law Office to Two Fictional Ones
description: It's Monday in America. It's David E. Kelley night again on television.

title: Under the Hood
description: The Justice Department is seeking to prevent Microsoft from making computer manufacturers load Internet Explorer in new machines. Microsoft says, however, that without Explorer, its Windows 95 operating system and features of other software will not work.

title: Students From Two Lands Celebrate Shared Traditions
description: There is not only nothing new under the sun, there is also a past that ballet, more than other art form, consistently reveals, re-examines and renews.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in some copies yesterday about Dr. George H. Hitchings, who won the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1988, omitted a reference to his first wife. She was the former Beverly Reimer, who died in 1985. His children, Thomas Hitchings and Laramie H. Brown, are from that marriage. The obituary is reprinted today on page A14.

title: Police Award to Officer Shot in Station House
description: Though police officers are often wounded in the line of duty, it is not often that they receive the Purple Heart.

title: A Useful Balkan Firewall
description: Rising violence in the Kosovo province of Serbia has dangerous implications not only for Kosovo, but also for its neighbors. Ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of Kosovo's population, but they suffer severe repression at the hands of Serbia's Government. In the last six months a violent group of ethnic Albanians, the Kosovo Liberation Army, has stepped up its terrorist attacks in Kosovo, and claimed credit for two bombings in the neighboring country of Macedonia. That is why a Security Council resolution that cuts off the peacekeeping mission in Macedonia in August is a mistake.

title: HOCKEY: Hockey's Improvising Gold Glove; Hasek Has Redefined The Way to Play Goalie, But Don't Tell Him That
description: The question, it seems, is interesting to everyone but Dominik Hasek.

title: Isla de los Estados Journal; Dream Fulfilled at End of the World
description: It was the kind of wild, romantic adventure that only the French could dream up: a spectacular journey to this forbidding island at the end of the earth, between South America and Antarctica, to rebuild a famed lighthouse that had lain dormant for nearly a century.

title: Calipari Regrets Some of His Words to Fan
description: New Jersey Nets Coach John Calipari finds himself embroiled in another controversy.

title: After Concert Debacle, Paul Robeson Sang On
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VICTOR, ANNE
description: VICTOR-Anne. Loving mother of Sherry and Michele; dear grandmother of Neal and Tristan. She was a wonderful teacher and a devotee of French.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSSOFF, SHIRLEY R.
description: KOSSOFF-Shirley R. Age 96, on February 28. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Kossoff, loving mother of Richard and Arlene Kossoff, Janice and Irving Southern, and Terri and Stuart Taylor. Proud grandmother of Laura, Drew, Wendy, Ivan, Douglas, Pat, and Laurie. Funeral service Sunday, March 1, 10 AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St. at Amsterdam Ave., Manhattan.

title: I.Q.'s Rise, Yet Students Fall Back; A Simple Explanation
description: To the Editor:

title: A Young Nation Celebrates Art Built on Its Past
description: The ambitious ''Art of the State: Israel at 50'' festival at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here got off to a rollicking, thundering start on Saturday night with Ohad Naharin's eveninglong ''Anaphase,'' performed at the center's Eisenhower Theater by the Batsheva Dance Company of Tel Aviv. The festival will end on May 9 with fireworks from the Zik Group, performance artists from Jerusalem. In addition to the physical fireworks of ''Anaphase,'' Mr. Naharin created an audience-involving party atmosphere.

title: Van Gundy Produces Patchwork Surprise
description: The door to Jeff Van Gundy's office opens, and in bounds one of the only healthy bodies left in the Knicks family. His wife, Kim, follows behind their daughter and apologizes, ''She knows the way -- what can I do?''

title: Coach's Act Shows Sport at Its Best; Men Don't Cry?
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home; What Has Gone Wrong
description: If you look at it from the point of view of Kenneth Starr and his assistants, they are being unfairly abused. They believe that they are working in good faith to find out whether President Clinton and others committed what they regard as serious crimes. Yet they are besieged by criticism.

title: Piqued Huskey Feels Confined by Mets' Salary Structure
description: Butch Huskey is still steaming. And it has nothing to do with the Florida weather, which has been cool and damp lately.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Southern Republicans Pick Gov. Bush in Straw Poll
description: Republicans who converged on this coastal gambling town this weekend still haven't learned an important lesson from Presidential campaigns past: Straw polls taken to gauge the popularity of would-be Presidential contenders are about as revealing as Central Committee balloting in the old Soviet Union.

title: Paxon Tells Upstate Voters Why He Is Leaving Congress
description: It was 10 A.M., and the parking lot at Nick's Family Restaurant just down the road from Lake Ontario was filled with pickup trucks and mud-splattered utility vehicles. Inside, 40 people were sitting as quietly as parishioners in their pews when the room suddenly lighted up with the exuberant voice of today's guest of honor.

title: San Francisco Tries to Retain Its 'Multimedia Gulch'
description: On any given sunny afternoon, scores of workers pour out onto an oval stretch of scrappy grass known in San Francisco as South Park. The surrounding neighborhood, once home to immigrant families, printing plants and an occasional flophouse, now features a few high-end restaurants, coffeehouses and a lot of workers in the interactive media industry who come out for lunch from the renovated lofts surrounding the park.

title: Equity Offerings Set For Sale This Week
description: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULZER, ESSIE
description: SULZER-Essie. Age 95. Wife of the late Theodore D. Sulzer. Beloved mother of Helene Guarnaccia and Richard Sulzer. Grandmother of Peter and Steven Guarnaccia and Jill and Andrew Sulzer, and Carole Anne Friedman; greatgrandmother of Jasper, Jaime and Shara Guarnaccia and Jared Friedman. She died Saturday, February 28, 1998, in Cambridge Manor, Fairfield, CT. Funeral today, 1:30 PM, Boulevard Park West Chapels, Hewlett, LI.

title: I.Q.'s Rise, Yet Students Fall Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Pain-Free Outing Is Relief for Pettitte
description: Andy Pettitte still wonders about the spasms in his lower back that made it painful for him to follow through on pitches last October. Every time Pettitte finished his motion and wanted to push himself a little harder during two depressing losses to Cleveland in the division series, he felt a twinge. Something was awry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, G. PHILIP
description: LYNCH-G. Philip. Of Lawrence and Bridgehampton, NY, on February 28, 1998, at age 84. Loving husband of Sylvia Maitland and the late Gertrude Low. Father of George P. Lynch, Jr., Madelaine Reese Anagnostopoulos and Raymond C. Lynch. Stepfather of Petria H. Fossel, the late Sandy Baker, J. W. Maitland Horner and Martin Horner. Adored grandfather of nine grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Over 50 years a member of the New York Stock Exchange. Memorial service Wednesday 1 PM, Trinity-St. John's Church, Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send memorial donations to Need in Deed, 8616 Germantown Ave., Philadelphia, PA 19118 or South Nassau Communities Hospital, 2445 Oceanside Road, Oceanside, NY 11572.

title: Antonio Prohias, 77; Drew 'Spy vs. Spy' Cartoon
description: Antonio Prohias, the cartoonist who drew ''Spy vs. Spy'' for Mad magazine, died on Tuesday at Mercy Hospital in Miami. He was 77 and lived in Miami.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Recreating a Historic Forum for Innovative Works
description: In 1918, Schoenberg became so dismayed with the hostile reception to his radical music that he formed his own private performance society. The concerts, in small halls or people's homes, were open to society members only. The programs were mostly devoted to new and recent works by Schoenberg and other modernists. No one was allowed to applaud or demonstrate disapproval.

title: Sometimes the Eye of the Beholder Sees Too Clearly for Its Own Good
description: The art in ''Art,'' the short, slender and often very funny play by Yasmina Reza that opened last night at the Royale Theater, is a 4-by-5-foot white-on-white painting, unadorned by anything figurative. Though Ms. Reza's comedy is set in the Paris of today, the painting in it that causes such trouble is not what you would call cutting-edge contemporary.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The Education Minister of Singapore came here, and people said: 'What are you looking here for? Your kids consistently score on top of all international tests.' And he said something like, 'All that our kids can do is take tests.' He understood that we are nurturing more creativity here.''

title: Singer as Mediator Between Known and Unknown
description: ''It goes back to Elvis,'' the singer David Thomas said recently on the phone. ''Abstract thought was his big thing.'' Mr. Thomas, the leader of Pere Ubu, a self-consciously modernist pop group that formed in Cleveland in the mid-1970's, was talking about the role of abstraction in American art and life. I found myself measuring his theories against the exquisite 1996 western ''Dead Man,'' a film by one of Mr. Thomas's fellow Ohioans, the writer and director Jim Jarmusch.

title: A Right Way, a Wrong Way And a Better Way to Win
description: In the abstract, there is almost always a right and wrong way to play a suit combination. But there are some interesting exceptions, and the North-South diamond combination shown in the diagram is one of them. We need four tricks, and we shall assume that the suit does not split 5-0.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, SYDELL
description: SOLOMON-Sydell. Beloved wife of Martin. Devoted mother of Richard and (Amy), Lee and (Darlene), and Steven. Cherished grandmother of Joshua, David, Alex and Erik. Adored daughter of Sophie Block. Dear sister of Charlotte Novatt. Services today, 11:30 AM, at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Time to Make a Good Law Better
description: At a time when campaign finance has become a bipartisan scandal for the Federal Government, and the state is once again lurching into elections in which the dominant issue is who has the most money, New York City has a right to celebrate the 10th anniversary this week of its estimable campaign finance program.

title: Sports magazines are stepping up branding and promotion efforts.
description: THE Winter Olympics may finally be over, but the competition is still under way in the crowded field of sports magazines.

title: N.Y.U. Gets First-Round Bye
description: New York University will begin the defense of its women's Division III national basketball championship on Saturday with an East Region game at Coles Sports Center.

title: Treasury's Schedule of Auctions Offers Only Bills for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.17 percent and a six-month bill was 5.10 percent.

title: Milken Off the Hook
description: To the Editor:

title: Spyglass, a Pioneer, Learns Hard Lessons About Microsoft
description: Few people are more familiar with the real-world nature of Microsoft's market power than Douglas P. Colbeth, the 42-year-old chief executive of Spyglass Inc. His Internet software company has been a supplier to Microsoft, providing the software engine for its Internet Explorer browser. Spyglass has also been a Microsoft competitor, briefly, in the browser market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTHROP, AMORY (ELIZABETH)
description: WINTHROP-Amory (Elizabeth). Of Millbrook, N.Y. Died Feb. 26, 1998. Daughter of Robert Winthrop and the late Theodora Ayer Randolph. Survived by her sisters Theodora Hooton and Cornelia Bonnie, and a niece and nephews. Ms. Winthrop was an accomplished horse-woman and a horse show judge. She was a director of The Fund for Animals & Founder and President of the Winley Foundation. A memorial service will be held at a future date. Contributions in her memory may be made to Winley Foundation, attention Anne Barone, R.R.1, Box 40, Millbrook, N.Y. 12545 or The Institute for Ecosystems Studies.

title: Updates/Media and Technology; Enhancing Technology A Priority of Companies
description: Technology enhancement will be the top priority in 1998 as companies make investments to insure their future growth, according to a recent survey of chief financial officers.

title: Business Joins Call for Rise In Tax Credit
description: The state's leading business groups have joined organized labor and advocates for the poor in calling on Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders to use some of the state's surplus to expand a tax credit for the working poor.

title: Ramchandran Jaikumar, 53, Business Professor at Harvard
description: Ramchandran Jaikumar, a professor at the Harvard Business School who specialized in computer-aided manufacturing, died on Feb. 10 in Quito, Ecuador.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOFTUS, THOMAS P.
description: LOFTUS-Thomas P. On February 28, 1998. Beloved husband of Beth. Devoted father of Patrick, Martin, Gary, Kathaleen Mercer, Thomas, Jr., Sean, Carol Pedersen, Lynn Elliott, and Elizabeth. Dearest grandfather of 15. Brother of William, Helen Cerjan and Geraldine Deighan. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., on Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. and 84 St., on Wenesday evening, 6 PM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Memorial SloanKettering Research Center, 1275 York Ave, NYC 10021.

title: After Concert Debacle, Paul Robeson Sang On
description: To the Editor:

title: Low Scores Are No Disgrace
description: The dismal performance of American 12th graders on the Third International Mathematics and Science Study is naturally disheartening. Even in a pool that lacked the usual high-scoring Asian countries, American students managed to score near the bottom.

title: Iraqi Diplomat and U.N. Expert Differ Sharply on Terms of Pact
description: Iraq's envoy to the United Nations and the United Nations chief arms inspector disagreed sharply yesterday about a critical part of the arms inspection pact reached last week that helped avert American air strikes on Baghdad.

title: Longwood Journal; In Mobile Homes, Sitting Vulnerable to Tornadoes
description: At 91 years old, Martha Carney lives on a street of manicured lawns, decorative windmills and pink flamingos. It is the kind of neighborhood where people can mingle at their own private clubhouse and a stranger's car would be quickly noticed and even reported to the manager's office.

title: Israel Seeks Deal to Quit Buffer Zone In Lebanon
description: Sending out diplomatic feelers to end an increasingly costly military involvement in southern Lebanon, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said today that his country was ready to comply with a United Nations resolution calling on it to withdraw, if Lebanon cooperated in insuring security along the border.

title: Iona Can Almost Taste Tourney
description: The Iona Gaels are one victory away from shattering the barrier that has denied them entry into the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament the past two seasons.

title: INSIDE
description: A Challenger for Kohl

title: UConn Hits A Slump, But Saves A Victory
description: After the Connecticut women's basketball team played a good, up-tempo first half against West Virginia today, it went bad in the second half. Not bad enough to lose, but almost.

title: 2 Officers Suspended After Weekend Arrests
description: Two New York City police officers were arrested outside the city over the weekend in separate incidents involving drugs and alcohol, police officials said.

title: Charges of Incompetence and Laxity Are Leveled at Fragmented Forces : Belgian Police Face Growing Distrust
description: BRUSSELS  Passengers leaving the Anderlecht Metro station in Brussels on a recent evening were subjected to an unusually stringent ticket control.

title: Even the Air Was Black With Pain
description: The dust bowl found its place in American literature via ''The Grapes of Wrath,'' John Steinbeck's 1939 novel of the Joad family's troubled trek to California. But most of the farmers caught up in the decade of drought and dust storms that ravished America's southern plains stayed where they were. Their endurance is movingly recalled in ''Surviving the Dust Bowl.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLITS, GLENNY O.
description: WILLITS-Glenny O. Of Glen Gove, LI, on February 28, 1998. Wife of Frederick E. Mother of Karen W. Zentgraf, Fritz and Phebe W. Bergenheim. Also survived by one sister, two brothers, four grandchldren and one greatgrandchild. Service is private. Donations may be made to First Church of Christ, Scientist, Glen Cove, or North Country Garden Club, Laurel Hollow, NY.

title: Lessons From Afghanistan
description: Even as the Clinton Administration irons out the details of a possible accord with Iraq, Government officials have confirmed that the Central Intelligence Agency is continuing to draw up a blueprint for covert action there, including a major program of sabotage and subversion against Saddam Hussein.

title: Rupert Murdoch's Publishing Principles
description: In some ways, the latest Rupert Murdoch saga has the uncomfortable feel of the most recent James Bond movie: International media mogul learns that a book being published by one of the lesser arms of his communications empire might anger the Chinese Government, which allows him to broadcast in its massive country. So, what does the mogul do? Does he stand firm for a free press?

title: Author's Downward Spin Rivals Tragedies in Her Novels of Black America
description: In the late 1970's, before Gayl Jones all but vanished from a literary world that had applauded her novels about black America as pioneering, even brilliant, she wrote powerfully about the legacy of slavery, of racism, rape, incest and abuse, of violence between women and men, and other things hot to the touch.

title: Taking In the Sites; Corporate Intelligence: A Cloakhold On the Web
description: Competitive intelligence, known variously as CI and business intelligence, is more than just a buzzword thrown about by management consultants. Gathering information on rivals can be one key to success in the cutthroat corporate world. But some of the cloak-and-dagger may be giving way to the mouse and keyboard as an increasing number of resources become available on the World Wide Web.

title: Updates/Media and Technology; Judge Rules Against Law On Employees' Web Use
description: A Federal judge has struck down a Virginia law that barred state employees from using state-owned computers to peruse sexually explicit Internet sites.

title: Taxi Jumps Curb and Strikes 3 Pedestrians
description: A taxicab jumped a curb at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and East 71st Street yesterday, striking three pedestrians and injuring one of them critically, the police said.

title: Tchaikovsky By Masur, Making Case For Himself
description: It looks as though we can expect an interesting drama to play itself out at the New York Philharmonic's concerts for the time being. At the end of last week, the orchestra's board made it known that Kurt Masur's days on the podium were numbered, with the double bar coming in 2002. And from the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening, Mr. Masur and the orchestra offered a brilliantly conceived and spectacularly played performance of the Tchaikovsky ''Pathetique'' Symphony that argued forcefully that the board is out of its collective mind.

title: German Social Democrat Triumphs in Key State Election
description: Surfing a wave of voter acclaim that could carry him to the chancellor's office in Bonn, Gerhard Schroder, the Premier of Lower Saxony, triumphed in closely watched state elections today, sealing his bid to challenge Helmut Kohl for Europe's most powerful political position in September's national ballot.

title: Sports of The Times; Huskies Give Critics A Lesson in Heart
description: GENO AURIEMMA of the University of Connecticut coached his nationally ranked women's team to a victory in its first post-season game without the Big East player of the year, Nykesha Sales.

title: Congress Moving Quickly to Try to Curb Cell Phone Abuses
description: The movement to crack down on cellular phone fraud and eavesdropping is gaining ground in Congress. Last week, the House passed a bill that would outlaw so-called cloning devices, which make it possible to charge calls to someone else's account, and a House committee approved another bill that would make certain scanning equipment illegal.

title: In New Balkan Tinderbox, Ethnic Albanians Rebel Against Serbs
description: IN THE CICAVICA MOUNTAINS, Serbia -- A half dozen heavily armed rebels, who had taken cover in a copse of trees to evade a Serbian attack helicopter, scanned the bleak, moonlit horizon and set out swiftly toward the foothills of the Cicavica Mountains. The rebels, wearing camouflage uniforms and weighted down with AK-47 assault rifles and ammunition-packed vests, said little as they moved through darkened farm villages, their boots leaving waffle imprints in the snow and mud.

title: Reagan's Intellect Suited Him for Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Knowledge Adventure Inc., Los Angeles, a unit of the Cendant Corp., to McCann-Erickson Los Angeles, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., as the first agency to handle advertising for its Jump Start Learning System software series. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: Suharto Is Still Weighing a Drastic Economic Move
description: President Suharto said today that the austerity measures demanded by the International Monetary Fund to overcome Indonesia's economic crisis have not yet borne fruit and that the country must find its own formula for recovery, something he said might be called ''I.M.F.-plus.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLAR, SEYMOUR
description: GELLAR-Seymour. Beloved husband of Paula, devoted uncle of Natalie and Janice. Services March 3, 11 AM, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY.

title: Threat to Corporate Computers Is Often the Enemy Within
description: The computer supervisor at a Midwestern engine manufacturing company approached his bosses earlier this month and made them an offer they could not refuse. Either they gave him a big raise immediately and agreed to a list of other job demands, or he would shut the company down, according to Erik Thompson, a computer security consultant who was called in to help the company after the incident.

title: People
description: * Michele S. Fabrizi, senior vice president and director for client services at MARC Advertising, Pittsburgh, was promoted to president and chief operating officer, succeeding Anthony L. Bucci, who was promoted last year to chairman and chief executive. Also Tony Jaffe, senior vice president and creative director, was promoted to the new position of executive creative director.

title: I.Q.'s Rise, Yet Students Fall Back; New Testing Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: New Owner Raises Hope for Ski Area's Turnaround
description: Five inches of fresh snow fell in the mountains here last Wednesday, bending branches along the ski trails in picture-postcard scenes and providing this long-struggling resort area with some of the best skiing of the season. In a year when most mid-Atlantic ski areas have languished during a relatively snowless winter, this late February caress must have seemed to many here as a sign of better days to come.

title: Writer With Hybrid Past Burrows for the Facts
description: THE FACTORY OF FACTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWRY, PHILIP HOLT
description: LOWRY-Philip Holt. On February 28, 1998, at home in McLean, VA. He is survived by his daughters Georgia Harmony Lowry Orphan of Vienna, VA, and Marion Holt Lowry of Los Angeles, and his sister Marion L. Pennell of Washington Depot, CT. Services and interment will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the Margaret K. Lowry Book Fund, Potomac School, McLean, VA.

title: Coach's Act Shows Sport at Its Best; Given, Not Earned
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : A Bachelor Waits:Will She Leave N.Y. for Fairbanks?
description: Jay Ramras, a most eligible Jewish bachelor, went to New York City from Alaska four months ago in search of his dream woman, the Jewish population of Alaska being quite small. Now he has found what he wanted  if only he can sell her on Fairbanks.

title: Artists Arrested in Raucous Rally Against Sales Permits Near Museum
description: For years, a small plaza just south of the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art has doubled as a thriving outdoor art gallery, where on Saturday and Sunday mornings, tourists and passers-by strolled among works by Chinese portrait artists, Russian painters and photographers from Harlem, browsing and buying.

title: Williams Knew There'd Be Days Like This for Seton Hall; at Last, There Was
description: There were supposed to be a lot more days like this for Donnell Williams. When he was recruited five years ago, he was expected to pour in points and carry Seton Hall to important victories, but something always got in the way, whether it was injuries or classroom troubles. The Pirates waited, not so patiently, through three coaching regimes, for days like today.

title: Microsoft's Defense Is in Its Software Code
description: To the uninitiated, the clash between the Microsoft Corporation and the Department of Justice's Antitrust Division can seem a maddening exercise in semantics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERIN, SYLVIA
description: HALPERIN-Sylvia. Died February 24, in Florida. Formerly of the Bronx. Beloved aunt and great aunt. Devoted wife of the late Frank Halperin. Cherished sister of the late Sadie Held and Anna Kriegel. Survived by loving nieces and nephews, grand and great grand nieces and nephews. Burial was February 26 at Baron Hirch Cemetery, Staten Island, NY.

title: What Oafs Read
description: To the Editor:

title: Freedom in Math Class May Outweigh Tests
description: When the results of a major international mathematics and science test were made public last week, showing American 12th graders near the bottom of the industrialized world, leaders reacted with well-rehearsed alarm. They warned that Americans would not be able ''to continue to be global competitors in the new knowledge economy,'' as Education Secretary Richard W. Riley put it.

title: Theodore Schultz, 95, Winner Of a Key Prize in Economics
description: Theodore W. Schultz, an economist at the University of Chicago whose research on agriculture and education was honored with a Nobel Memorial Prize in 1979, died Thursday at a nursing home in Evanston, Ill.

title: Unlocking the Secrets Of the Digital Archive Left by East Germany
description: According to German national law, Dr. Michael Wettengel is supposed to preserve records and documents ''for the long term, to insure continuing accessibility and provide scientific research.'' The 40-year-old historian heads a highly specialized section at the German Federal Archives, or Bundesarchiv.

title: White House's All-Out Attack on Starr Is Paying Off, With His Help
description: From the moment that the name Monica S. Lewinsky began to dominate the national conversation, the White House determined that President Clinton's best survival strategy in the scandal was to mount an all-out attack on Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel.

title: Wheels and Deals; G.M. Executive Wields Enormous Influence With the Nation's Biggest Ad Budget
description: Standing among the shiny cars on display in the General Motors showroom on Fifth Avenue and wearing one of his signature designer suits -- a twinkle in his eye and a box of cigars tucked under his arm -- Philip Guarascio comes across as the kind of man who could easily sell you that moonstone Cadillac DeVille or the black Pontiac Grand Prix.

title: I.Q.'s Rise, Yet Students Fall Back; Prep School Helps
description: To the Editor:

title: As Tournament Founders, Sampras Floats
description: Another day, another $110,000.

title: Library Suit Becomes Key Test Of Freedom to Use the Internet
description: When patrons of the Loudoun County, Va., public library try to view sexually explicit material on any of nine computers newly connected to the Internet, a software program responds with an unambiguous message: ''Violation!! Violation!! Violation!! Access to this site has been blocked. Please click on your bookmark or go to some other Web site.''

title: Ranking Law Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLICK, MELVIN
description: WALLICK-Melvin. Died February 28, 1998, at 68 years. Dearest husband and best friend of Gloria. Devoted father of Michael (Gayle) Wallick, Claire (Kai) Moy, Larry Wallick and Carolyn Horn, Jim (Cathy) Wallick. Proud grandpa of Brian, Carrie, Jesse, Karina and Daniel. Dearest brother of Ruth (Ed) Lipson and Muriel (Jack) Polish. Cherished son-in-law of Blanche Rosenhirsch, brother-inlaw of Suzi (Martin) Oppenheimer. Special friend and loved by all, including his employees at Mercer Tool for his warmth, support and caring nature. Services Tuesday, March 3, 11 AM, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

title: Owens-Illinois Plans to Acquire London-Based Glass Business
description: Owens-Illinois Inc., a maker of glass bottles and plastic containers, said last night that it would acquire the worldwide glass and plastic packaging businesses of BTR P.L.C. of London for $3.6 billion in cash.

title: After the Oxford Debacle
description: Oxford Health Plans made the remarkable admission last week that its losses during the last months of last year exceeded the total of all its previous profits. Oxford's performance is more embarrassing than even its stunning losses indicate. Its management did not have a clue how much money it was paying out to doctors or collecting from members. In fact, Oxford has been losing money for some time, but no one knew. Late last year, its bookkeepers caught up to a sorry reality.

title: Essay; Saddam's Winning Strategy: 'Guerrilla Peace'
description: Having suffered a half-defeat at the hands of President Bush, Saddam Hussein scored a half-victory over President Clinton.

title: Peace Languishes as Another Angola Deadline Passes
description: Saturday was supposed to be the day when Angola's long-delayed countdown to peace was completed. The rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi -- presumably wearing his trademark double-breasted blue blazer with silk pocket swatch -- was supposed to leave his highlands stronghold to meet in Angola's capital with President Jose Eduardo dos Santos.

title: Dr. Samuel Corson, 88, Dies; Father of Pet-Assisted Therapy
description: Dr. Samuel A. Corson, who spent years using dogs to conduct valuable but arcane biophysical research only to have his career upstaged by his own laboratory subjects, died on Jan. 27 at the home of a daughter in Granger, Ind. He was 88 and known as the father of pet-assisted therapy.

title: I.Q.'s Rise, Yet Students Fall Back; Local Chauvinism
description: To the Editor:

title: Prize Winner Who Defies Stereotypes
description: It used to be said, sometimes unfairly, that musical competitions produce bland, cookie-cutter performers: musical athletes of proven technical skills who confine their interpretations to the middle of the road to avoid the risk of offending any judge.

title: John C. Malone vows to wire the world. Sound familiar? It should.
description: JOHN C. MALONE, the tough-talking chairman of the cable television giant Tele-Communications Inc., is back in the news again, and industry watchers who were around for the first ''interactive television'' debacle of the early 1990's are having flashbacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTYKA, MARGARET (NEE CHRISTIE)
description: KURTYKA-Margaret (nee Christie). Of Clifton, NJ, on February 26, 1998. Born Paterson, NJ, July 12, 1913. Beloved wife for 62 years of Henry, mother of daughter Ruthanne and son-in-law Harvey Corn and grandmother of Christie, Margaret and Olivia. She was a very special person who was dearly loved and who will be sorely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYNER, CHESBROUGH
description: RAYNER-Chesbrough On February 26, 1998. Beloved daughter of Chesbrough Patcevitch. Devoted sister of Minot Amory and his wife Victoria. Service Tuesday, March 3, 11 AM, St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd St, NYC. In lieu of flower,s contributions may be made in her name to Sloan Kettering, NYC.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, VALERIE D.
description: BAKER-Valerie D. Of New York City and Sea Cliff, NY, February 27, 1998. Beloved daughter of Enid; loving brother of Charles E. Baker. Visiting 3-5 and 7-9 PM, Wednesday, Whitting Funeral Home, Glen Head, NY. Funeral service 8:30 PM, Wednesday, at funeral home. Interment private. Contributions to American Cancer Society.

title: Rivalry Grows at Low End of Dial
description: Whatever reputation public radio has for polish and low-key aplomb, the rise of Public Radio International as a challenger to National Public Radio's programming dominance is making life in the nonprofit time-slot trenches as brutal as any scheduling fight between Fox and NBC.

title: Was It the Save That Wasn't?
description: It might be the most spectacular non-save in the history of hockey.

title: Market Place; Motorola, once a darling among technology stocks, has made some missteps in recent years.
description: AS the wireless communications industry transforms itself from analog to digital technology, Motorola Inc., whose reputation for innovation, high-quality products and smart strategic thinking flourished in the early 1990's, has looked surprisingly clumsy at times.

title: Todd Duncan, 95; Sang Porgy and Helped Desegregate Opera
description: Todd Duncan, the baritone who created the role of Porgy in Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess'' and was the first black singer to join the New York City Opera, died on Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, SR. MARY LAURA
description: DOYLE-Sr. Mary Laura. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity on March 1, 1998. Survived by nieces, grand-nieces and grandnephews. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark St., Yonkers, NY, on Tuesday, 1-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 9:30 AM, at the Convent. Interment at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Coach's Act Shows Sport at Its Best; The Violence Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Even Aides See Starr Wounding Himself
description: Ever since Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, expanded his investigation from the Arkansas land deal into reports of a liaison between President Clinton and a former White House intern, he has been the target of an effective barrage of negative characterizations from Mr. Clinton's defenders. But Mr. Starr's own miscalculations in his handling of the matter have helped erode his public approval rating -- 11 percent in a recent poll -- raising questions about the fairness of his investigation to the point that even members of his own staff are questioning the wisdom of some of his recent moves and wondering, in some instances, whether the inquiry is in danger of losing what little public confidence remains.

title: Restless Souls, Entangled in Emotions and Caught in a Whirlwind
description: Kevin O'Day's ''Open Strings'' demonstrates that lots of steps do not automatically add up to a choreographically rich ballet. There are plenty of steps, most of them restless ones, in this work, which Mr. O'Day created last year for the New York City Ballet. The impression of frenetic activity is enhanced by John King's throbbing score for electric guitars and bass guitars.

title: BALANCED BUDGET FACES A BIG TEST: TRANSIT SPENDING
description: In the first major test of whether Congress will abide by the self-imposed austerity of last year's budget agreement, the Senate is taking up one of the biggest public works bills in the nation's history, a multiyear plan laden with big-ticket highway and transit projects that are dear to every lawmaker's heart.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTER, LEAH
description: KESTER-Leah. Formerly of Bayside, New York, died February 27 in Hershey, PA. Surviving are her husband, Allen; two sons, Dr. Mark of Harrisburg, PA and Eric of Bayside; a sister, Lillian Fink of Rochester, and two grandchildren. Burial was Sunday in Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens. Shiva will be observed at 18-75 Corporal Kennedy Street, Apt. 5-G, Bayside, NY. Memorials to the Jewish National Fund, 42 East 69th Street, New York, NY 10021, or the American Heart Association.

title: Islanders Waste a Chance to Gain Ground
description: For a moment today, it seemed as if the Islanders would stop digging themselves a deeper hole in the Eastern Conference and start climbing. But in the span of 2 minutes 26 seconds in the third period, the Boston Bruins scored three times on Islanders goalie Tommy Salo, breaking a 2-2 tie and going on to win, 5-4.

title: The Safe-Driving Mayor Takes Umbrage
description: Days after announcing that he will enforce speed limits as part of a far-reaching campaign to make New York City more civil, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani angrily denounced a newspaper columnist yesterday who said he caught Mr. Giuliani speeding from City Hall to Staten Island.

title: Patents; Developing easier and more efficient ways to deliver a drug that enhances oxygen capacity.
description: THE recent Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan, drew attention to erythropoietin, a drug that stimulates the growth of red blood cells and is widely suspected of being used by some athletes to enhance performance.

title: Sports of The Times; Quiet Knick Insights From a Loud Victory
description: MOMENTS before yesterday's game with the wounded Knicks, Del Harris, the Lakers' coach, walked down to the Knicks' bench and shook hands with Jeff Van Gundy.

title: For One Day, Knicks Escape O'Neal's Shadow
description: There was Shaquille O'Neal, rising out of the orange paint like a submarine, massive and ominous. Driven by his faith or his foolishness, Charlie Ward just kept coming.

title: In Aide's Claim, Echoes of Watergate
description: Sidney Blumenthal, a senior White House press adviser, says he declined last week to answer several questions before a Federal grand jury investigating the relationship between President Clinton and a former intern, citing the disputed doctrine of executive privilege.

title: Partners & Shevack Is in Joint Venture
description: Partners & Shevack in New York, a unit of Mickelberry Communications, is expanding Partners & Frankfurt, a unit devoted to new media, entertainment and corporate branding, by forming a joint venture with Belk Mignogna Associates in New York, a corporate-identity and new-media agency. Terms were not disclosed. The joint venture, Partners & Frankfurt, Belk Mignogna, has six employees working for clients like the A & E cable television network. Partners & Frankfurt and Belk Mignogna will continue operating as separate agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, SYDNEY
description: NEWMAN-Sydney. Of Brooklyn and Delray Beach, FL. On February 24, 1998. Beloved husband of Shirley, loving father of Roger, cherished grandfather of Peter and Beth. He will be sorely missed.

title: George Hitchings, 92, Winner Of Nobel in Medicine, Is Dead
description: Dr. George H. Hitchings, who won the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1988 for pharmaceutical research that led to the creation of drugs to treat leukemia, gout, malaria and disorders of the human immunity system and that eventually made organ transplants possible, died on Friday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 92.

title: Unions Unite In a Campaign For Child Care
description: Hoping to make New York the first state to provide child-care benefits as generous as those in Europe, 10 New York City labor unions have begun lobbying state lawmakers to spend $200 million more on child care and pressing employers to create a multi-union child-care fund.

title: Nets Earn Some Respect, Not a Victory
description: As upset as Jayson Williams was at the end of tonight's game, he was surprised to look up and see Miami Heat center Alonzo Mourning consoling him.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Dr. Benjamin Spock misidentified the parent company of Pocket Books, the publisher of his book on baby care. It is part of the Simon & Schuster unit of Viacom Inc.; it is not a division of National Amusements Inc.

title: Arnold Starts Campaign Against Smoking
description: The Food and Drug Administration is introducing its first national multimedia campaign aimed at reducing the illegal sale of tobacco to minors.

title: Rochester Parents Fret, and Sue, Over Cancer
description: When Debbie Cusenz gets together with neighbors, she catches up on the activities of their children. Not just Little League and school plays, but brain scans, chemotherapy and surgery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, DAVID
description: COHEN-David. Age 72, of Aventura, FL, formerly of Riverdale and Ft. Lee, NJ. Passed away February 27. Beloved husband of Myra. Loving father of Alan (Joni) Cohen and Michael (Karen) Cohen. Dear brother of Celia Bornheim, Stanley (Mercy) Cohen, Paul (Sonya) Cohen and Barbara (Marvin) Morrison. Cherished grandfather of Ari, Adam, Daniel, Stephen, Jesse and Alyson. Former Director of Kingsbridge Center of Israel. Services will be held in Florida on Sunday, March 1. Contributions to U.J.A.

title: Italy's Hard Right Sheds Neo-Fascist Past for Respectability
description: Italy's hard right-wing political party, shedding its last loyalties to a lingering Fascist tradition, emerged from a three-day conference this weekend as the stable, indispensable and increasingly respectable member of the Italy's center-right opposition.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, LUCILLE H.
description: LOEB-Lucille H. Of La Quinta, California. Wife of the late Carl M. Loeb, Jr. Mother of Carl M. Loeb III and Peter K. Loeb of New York Cuty and Constance Cohn of Edmonds, WA. Grandmother of Catherine Benson, George Cohn, Jr., David Cohn, Jeffrey Cohn, Peter Loeb, Jr., Karen Loeb, James Loeb, Alexander Loeb, Dahlia Loeb and Alexandra Loeb. Also survived by 9 great-grandchildren. At Mrs. Loeb's request there will no funeral or memorial service but contributions to the National Crime Prevention Council, 1700 K St, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20006 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Home Trampoline Injuries Double
description: TRAMPOLINES have joined basketball hoops and swing sets as fixtures of many American backyards in recent years. But their popularity has come at a price: fractures, dislocations and other injuries to children. Those injuries doubled from 1990 to 1995 and show no signs of abating, according to new research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANYAEGBUNAM, DR. AKOLISA M.
description: ANYAEGBUNAM-Dr. Akolisa M. On February 27, 1998. The staff of Jacobi Medical Center and North Central Bronx Hospital deeply mourn the tragic and untimely passing of our Chairman of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Women's Health. As a professional, he will be remembered as a much admired, respected and renowned young physician whose exceptional career spanned 17 outstanding years as a superb clinician, compassionate physician, dynamic teacher, prolific author, and able administrator. On a personal level, we will deeply miss ''Aki's'' warmth, wit and unique charm. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Joseph S. Orlando Senior Vice President North Bronx Healthcare Network Jacobi Medical Center/ North Central Bronx Hospital

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Leash on Dog Owners
description: To the Editor:
