description: BRODY-Nathan. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Gail Billig, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOFTUS, THOMAS P.
description: LOFTUS-Thomas P. The residents of 1199 Park Avenue mourn the passing of our long-time neighbor and Board member. His genial personality and wise counsel will be sorely missed. To his wife Beth and all his loved ones, we offer our sincere condolences. Park Hill Tenants Corp.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar retreated for the third day against the yen on further signals that Tokyo might use public funds to stimulate the economy. The dollar settled at 125.35 yen, down from 126.10 yen Friday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP., Dallas, ended plans to sell two Canadian pulp mills and related woodlands to Harmac Pacific Inc., Vancouver, British Columbia, for $540 million, because Harmac did not secure financing.

title: Olivetti Sells Computer Services Unit to Wang
description: Olivetti S.p.A., the Italian electronics company that has been shedding assets to focus on telecommunications, will sell its computer services subsidiary to Wang Laboratories Inc. for a package of cash and securities worth more than $395 million.

title: 2 Regional Bells In Satellite Deal
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. signed agreements today with DirecTV and the United States Satellite Broadcasting Company to sell satellite-television services to their telephone customers.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Voice of Majority
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Reports Rape In Brooklyn Subway
description: A 19-year-old woman was raped on a Brooklyn subway platform yesterday morning during rush hour, the police said.

title: Appeals Court Finds in Favor Of Gay Scout
description: Holding that the Boy Scouts are essentially a public accommodation like a hotel or restaurant, a New Jersey appeals court ruled today that the organization violated the state's anti-discrimination law when it ousted an Eagle Scout because he is gay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPERT, ALBERT
description: LIPPERT-Albert. We note with sorrow the sudden passing of a Trustee whose personal involvement and philanthropic generosity reflected a selfless devotion to North Shore and the people it serves. Mr. Lippert's business acumen was respected by his fellow Trustees, as well as officials within the System who frequently sought his advice. The Lippert Pavilion, housing a number of important patient services stands as a tribute to the generous nature of this outstanding man. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Felice, and the rest of his family. Paul Karafiol, M.D. President Medical Staff Peter F.R. Walker, M.D. Chairman, Medical Board Lawrence Scherr, M.D. Senior Vice President Medical Affairs North Shore University Hospital

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISSNER, EDITH JUDY
description: WISSNER-Edith Judy. Of Somerset, N.J. On March 2, 1998. Beloved mother of Dr. Lawrence and Gail. Beloved grandmother, great grandmother and sister. Funeral services on Tuesday, at 12 Noon, Holcombe-Fisher Funeral Home, 147 Main Street, Flemington, NJ. Interment Mount Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, N.Y. Memorial contributions may be made to Flemington Jewish Community Center, 40 E. Main St, Flemington, N.J. 08822.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, G. PHILIP
description: LYNCH-G. Philip. Of Lawrence and Bridgehampton, New York, on February 28, 1998, at age 84. Loving husband of Sylvia Maitland and the late Gertrude Low. Father of George P. Lynch, Jr., Madelaine Reese Anagnostopoulos and Raymond C. Lynch. Stepfather of Petria H. Fossel, the late Sandy Baker, J. W. Maitland Horner and Martin Horner. Adored grandfather of nine grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Over 50 years a member of the New York Stock Exchange. Memorial service Wednesday 1 PM, Trinity-St. John's Church, Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send memorial donations to Need in Deed, 8616 Germantown Ave., Philadelphia, PA 19118 or South Nassau Communities Hospital, 2445 Oceanside Road, Oceanside, New York 11572.

title: Stop Get-Rich Mailings, Barbados Firms Are Told
description: A Federal judge has ordered four direct-mail companies based in Barbados to stop pitching fraudulent get-rich-quick schemes to elderly people in New Jersey and at least 10 other states, prosecutors announced yesterday.

title: Small-Town Feel, and Feud; Roosevelt Islanders Battle Government Over Cutbacks
description: Those with smallpox, the palsied, the paralytic, the utterly mad, the vagrant, the penniless, the sexually depraved, the criminally fiendish -- from the early 1800's until the early 1900's, that is whom the great city sent to the beautiful island.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 19 about romance in high places in South Africa referred incorrectly at one point to the age of former President P. W. Botha's fiancee, Reinette te Water Naude. She is 47, not 49.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBACK, ESTHER
description: TOBACK-Esther. On March 1, last surviving Koren sister, beloved wife of the late Benzion, cherished mother of Deborah Davis (Martin) and Selma Toback. Services on Tuesday, March 3, 10 A.M., at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 2nd Avenue and 10th Street.

title: Moynihan and D'Amato Back Rail Tunnel
description: A proposal to build a rail freight tunnel under New York Harbor received the crucial endorsements of Senators Daniel P. Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday as the city moved forward with a study of what could eventually become its biggest building project in decades.

title: Canada Concern In a Realty Deal
description: The Dundee Realty Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire two closely held real estate concerns -- the Camreal Corporation and the Lehndorff Tandem Group -- for stock that is valued at $246 million (Canadian), or $173 million (United States).

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about the Coney Island Boardwalk in winter misspelled the surname of Brooklyn's official historian. He is John Manbeck, not Mambek.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the newly installed Francis Cardinal George of Chicago misidentified the priest shown with him at Mass. It was the Rev. Robert E. McLaughlin, pastor of Holy Name Cathedral in Chicago, not Timothy Lyne, a retired bishop.

title: Now, Two $2.7 Billion Offers for Insurer
description: American International Group yesterday escalated the takeover battle for American Bankers Insurance Group, a little-known insurer based in Miami, raising its bid by 23 percent.

title: Gunsmoke in Space
description: Q. If I write a murder mystery set in space, can I have one of my characters kill another by firing a gun?

title: Supreme Court Will Consider Arbitration's Role at Work
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a clause in a labor contract requiring workplace disputes to be resolved by arbitration bars individual workers from suing their employer for discrimination.

title: UConn's Big Message: Rout Is Just First Step
description: Connecticut took a major step toward proving it remains the class of the Big East yesterday when it put together its most impressive victory of the post-Nykesha Sales era.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I want us to produce a document that can become law. I don't want to produce a report that gathers dust in a library.''

title: Russian Falls to Death in an Apparent Suicide
description: A 50-year-old Russian immigrant seeking to be deported by the Immigration and Naturalization Service because he had lost his job jumped to his death yesterday from a ninth-floor window at the Federal Office Building in lower Manhattan, officials said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Doubts About Slowdown Push Yields to 1998 High

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYD, WILLIAM T.P. SR.
description: BOYD-William T.P. Sr., in Plymouth, on March 1st, age 87. Beloved husband of the late Emily (Quartuccio) Boyd. Dear father of Richard B. Boyd of Kensington, MD., William T.P. Boyd Jr. of Duxbury, MA., Lawrence Boyd of Brooklyn, NY, Mary Elizabeth Boyd of Bethesda, MD and Barbara Warren of Harrisburg, NC. He is also survived by 13 grandchildren and 7 great grandchildren. Burial in the Mayflower Cemetery, Duxbury. Visitation at the Funeral Home will be on Tuesday from 58PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Mercy Haven Inc., 859 Connetquot Ave., Islip Terrace, NY 11752, Attn: Sister Pat Griffith, CSW.

title: Executive Says He's Uncertain About Tobacco's Harm
description: Everyone else may believe that cigarettes kill, the world's chief cigarette maker testified today, but he isn't sure. And he said he didn't want to know.

title: Mazda's campaign aims to clarify its image and reverse a persistent slump in car and truck sales.
description: DRIVERS have long responded to entreaties to buy Mazda vehicles with bored sighs that signaled ''Been there. Done that.'' How then will they react to ambitious appeals to ''Get in. Be moved''?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELTON, HELEN (NEE KESSLER)
description: FELTON-Helen (nee Kessler). Widow of the late Harold W. Felton. Died February 27, 1998 in Lenox, MA. She had resided in New York City and Lakeville, CT., and was a former actress and leading lady, performing under the stage name of Helen Kingsley. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: A Cultural Exchange Minus The Pomp
description: An exchange between musical capitals often resembles a state visit, with a grand and venerable institution taking up temporary residence in a palatial hall. The debut appearance of the Berlin Symphony Orchestra in the United States, at the Kaye Playhouse of Hunter College on Friday evening, was an altogether more modest and scrappy affair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, IRVING
description: HIRSCH-Irving. Devoted husband of the late Gene (nee Braunstein). Beloved father of Robert and Elinore Hirsch, Carl and Kim Hirsch and Gail and Jim Victorine. Loving grandfather of Karen, Elizabeth, Eric, Samantha, Ananda, Joseph and Jacob. Services Beth El Cemetery, Washington Township, NJ Tuesday, 2:30 PM. Should friends desire, donations to Community Chest of Englewood, 41 Brownes Terrace, Englewood, NJ 07631 would be appreciated. For information ''Gutterman - Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ 800-522-0588.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: School Spending Debate Returns to Court
description: The State Attorney General and lawyers representing students in urban districts argued before the New Jersey Supreme Court today about whether the state should spend more money for new education programs and improvements to school buildings to help students overcome the disadvantages of poverty.

title: Behind a Singer's Eyeglasses, Into Her Soul
description: The pop singer-songwriter Lisa Loeb has built a persona around her eyeglasses, the cat-eye kind that secretaries in old movies remove so their bosses will say, ''My God, you're beautiful!'' Ms. Loeb's music similarly hides its drama behind her deceptively artless voice and accessible melodies. But as her performance at Tramps on Friday night indicated, Lisa Loeb is really no plainer than Rosalind Russell was without spectacles off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, NATHAN
description: LEVINE-Nathan. Died peacefully at his home March 1. Beloved husband of the late Ide Gruber Levine and devoted father of Ellen, Mada Liebman, Dori Brenner, Burt Liebman and Anne Koedt, grandfather of Sara and Dan Liebman. In lieu of flowers donations to West Side Federation for Senior Housing, 2345 Broadway, NYC 10024. Funeral service Tuesday, 1 PM, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue corner West 91 Street.

title: Under-18 Crowd Doubles, Broadway Study Finds
description: Efforts in recent years to attract more young people to Broadway shows appear to be paying off, with the number of ticket holders under the age of 18 more than doubling from 1991 to 1997, according to an audience study by the League of American Theaters and Producers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, ALEXANDER
description: BIRNBAUM-Alexander. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a deeply respected member of the Jewish community and our cherished friend, the beloved brother of Dr. Jacob Birnbaum, who is a YU Guardian and founder of a Presidential Fellowship at the University's affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Birnbaum and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEATTIE, EDWARD J., M.D.
description: BEATTIE-Edward J., M.D. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and Staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center note with great sorrow the death of their dear colleague and friend, Dr. Edward J. Beattie. Dr. Beattie joined the staff of Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases as an Attending Surgeon & Chief of the Thoracic Service in 1965; he was appointed Chairman of the Department of Surgery in June of 1966. Later in 1966 Dr. Beattie was named Chief Medical Officer of Memorial Hospital. He held that position until his retirement in 1983. At the time of his death, Dr. Beattie was Chief Medical Officer Emeritus and member of the Board of Overseers Emeriti. As Chief Medical Officer, he pioneered a multi-disciplinary approach to the treatment of cancer, bringing surgeons, medical oncologists, and radiation oncologists together for patient care. Dr. Beattie also helped develop staging techniques which became the world's standard index of lung cancer. As a physician, he was a role model for generations of physicians. He will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Beattie family. Laurance S. Rockefeller, Honorary Co-Chairman Benno C. Schmidt, Honorary Co-Chairman James D. Robinson III, Chairman, Board of Overseers Douglas A. Warner III, Chairman, Board of Managers H. Virgil Sherrill, Vice Chairman Richard L. Gelb, Vice Chairman Paul A. Marks, M.D., President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Cabletron Profits Will Be Below Estimates
description: Cabletron Systems Inc. said late today that it expected to report fourth-quarter results below expectations because of sluggish sales and competitive pricing pressures.

description: HAVE GUN WILL TRAVEL

title: Sports of The Times; Blatant Fouls Need Stiffer Penalties
description: LOST somehow, so quickly, amid the spur and whip of the tumultuous National Basketball Association season, was the paltry punishment ladled by the league on Keith Askins, the Miami forward, who, as was described by some courtside reporters Saturday afternoon, ''nearly took the head off'' Keith Van Horn.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; The Value of Manners
description: To the Editor:

title: Albert Lippert, 72, a Founder Of Weight Watchers, Is Dead
description: Albert Lippert, a once pudgy garment executive who stumbled on a diet program that made him both svelte and rich, died on Saturday during a business trip to South Africa. He was 72 and a founder of Weight Watchers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNCAN, TODD
description: DUNCAN-Todd. New York City Opera mourns the passing of our colleague Todd Duncan. Best remembered as the creator of the role of Porgy in Gershwin's Porgy and Bess, he also sang Escamillo and Rigoletto with the City Opera. He was a pioneer in his field and an inspiration to generations of younger artists, both by his example and through his teaching. We are proud to have been part of his distinguished career. We extend our sympathies to his family and his many friends throughout the world. Paul Kellogg General Director

description: WALDMAN-Miriam, age 85, survived by her loving family, daughters Roberta (Dr. Kenneth) Bell and Elinor Waldman, Granddaughters Jessica, Carolyn (Bruce), Jessica (Shawn), and Suzanne and great-grandchildren Daniele and Jacob, pre-deceased by her beloved husband David.

title: Corning to Sell Most of Its Cookware Unit
description: Corning Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell most of its Corning cookware business to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the New York investment firm, for $583 million.

title: SBC Files to Sell Long Distance
description: SBC Communications Inc. filed an application today with the Texas Public Utilities Commission seeking permission to offer long-distance phone service to customers in the state.

title: Depressed Parent's Children at Risk
description: DEPRESSION is a family affair, in more ways than one. Not only does depression in one family member affect everyone else, depression in one or both parents greatly increases the risk that their children will also become depressed or develop other emotional disorders. This familial vulnerability may result from the inappropriate actions of a depressed parent or from an inherited abnormality in brain chemistry, or both. Regardless of the cause, physicians and families need to be alert to the possibility that depression and related mental illnesses will persist across generations and that failure to recognize and treat them can result in serious school, social and vocational problems.

title: Vote Set on Ordinance To Ban Ice Cream Jingles
description: The tinkly jingle of an ice cream truck as it meanders through a summer afternoon may be sweet music to some, but to others it's a public nuisance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MC NEILLY, HENRY BRANHAM, SR.
description: MC NEILLY-Henry Branham, Sr. Town of Newburgh, NY, formerly of Southold, L.I. He was the President of Micron Clean Uniform Service, Inc. and a resident of the area since 1960. He died Monday, March 2nd, at St. Lukes Hospital, Newburgh, NY. He was sixty-one. The son of the late Charles Mc Neilly and the late Josephine Branham. He was born November 12, 1936 in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was dedicated to his family, he is a member of the North Fork Country Club in Cuthoque, L.I. and a member of the Powelton Club, Newburgh, N.Y., and member of Ducks Unlimited. He graduated St. James Prep School, Hagerstown, MD and Virginia Military Institute, Lexington, VA. Survived by his wife, Barbara Ranges Mc Neilly of Town of Newburgh; one son, Henry Mc Neilly, Jr., Briarcliff Manor, NY; 2 daughters, Caroline Boyar of Scarsdale and Mary Gwynne Mc Neilly of Manhattan; one brother, Custis of Newburgh; several nieces and nephews. Donations to The Brain Tumor Society, 84 Seattle Street, Boston, Mass 02134-1245. For further information, contact Di Donato-Brooks Funeral Home, 914-561-8300.

title: Corrections
description: A report in Sunday Styles this week about the wedding of Dr. Tara Anne Bogart and Nelson David Spiess Lubowski misspelled the name of the Jewish studies center where it took place. It is the Hineni Heritage Center, not Himeni.

title: Ordonez Is Ready to Try It the Mets' Way
description: One of the major questions the Mets had coming into spring training was whether Rey Ordonez, their Gold Glove shortstop, would swallow his pride and make an adjustment at the plate or risk incurring Manager Bobby Valentine's wrath by not changing an approach to hitting that led to a .216 batting average last season.

title: Caray Family Is Touched by Fans Honoring Harry
description: When WGN-TV hired Chip Caray to call Chicago Cubs games this season, he approached family nirvana: working side by side with his grandfather, Harry.

title: Starr Inquiry Is Shifting Back to the Basics
description: The Federal grand jury investigating President Clinton's relationship with a former intern is returning to the heart of its inquiry on Tuesday, with some of Mr. Clinton's closest confidants having been summoned to answer questions about the relationship and any efforts to cover it up.

title: No Brakes for Universe
description: Over the last few years, astronomers have been searching for data to show that the outward rush that began in the explosive moment of cosmic creation in the theorized Big Bang is slowing. Instead, their preliminary results show that the expansion of the universe seems to be accelerating.

title: U.N. REBUFFS U.S. ON THREAT TO IRAQ IF IT BREAKS PACT
description: The Security Council tonight unanimously endorsed Secretary General Kofi Annan's agreement with Iraq on weapons inspections, but without authorizing an automatic military response if Baghdad fails to comply.

title: 2 Clinic Administrators Charged in Plastic Surgery Fraud
description: Two administrators of a midtown medical clinic were charged with mail fraud yesterday and accused in a scheme to perform plastic surgery on patients without a license in which insurance companies were billed at least $350,000, according to a complaint unsealed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, MAX
description: SHULMAN-Max. The Bialystoker Synagogue family mourns the passing of the beloved father of its devoted President, Hon. Martin Shulman. Max Shulman dedicated himself to the values of family, religious inspiration and avodas hashem. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Yitzhak Singer Ira M. Miller, Exec Vice President Benjamin Tuchman, Treasurer Daniel Adler, Financial Secretary Herman Gewanter, Ritual Dir

title: Coalition Finds Support For Tough Seat-Belt Laws
description: A statewide coalition of 30 safety-related groups yesterday released a survey that it said indicated widespread support for tougher seat-belt laws.

description: BRODSKY-Irving, 96, of N.Y.C., Sunday in Manhattan. Funeral services, 1PM Tuesday March 3, 1998 in the Mausoleum Chapel of the Beth Israel Cemetery, US #

title: Yesterday's Warnings, Still Timely
description: In 1961, it seemed appropriate to a group of German composers that they should react to the resurgent threat of anti-Semitism by writing a cautionary cantata. A generation before that, in the 1930's, the vast majority of composers worldwide were finding the demands of open political commitment inescapable. If that meant their music would become redundant when current conflicts had passed, they were probably content. There was an emergency. They had to speak now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOX, HARRY L.
description: KNOX-Harry L. On February 26, 1998, age 62. Men's Sportswear manufacturer. Memorial service on Tuesday, March 3, 6:30PM at Riverview Manor, Merritt 7, #

title: GE Capital Acquires Factoring Business
description: GE Capital Services said today that it had bought the First Factors Corporation, marking its entry into the factoring commercial finance business in the United States.

title: Postcards From Europa
description: LAST Dec. 16, the Galileo spacecraft passed just a few hundred miles from Jupiter's moon Europa and sent back the most detailed pictures that scientists will have of that icy moon until it is visited by a probe of its own, as it surely will be someday. Planetary scientists have long suspected that tidal forces from Jupiter's huge gravitational field could be heating Europa's interior and keeping it liquid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLICK, MELVIN
description: WALLICK-Melvin. Died Feb. 28, 1998, at 68 years. Dearest husband and best friend of Gloria. Devoted father of Michael (Gayle) Wallick, Claire (Kai) Moy, Larry Wallick and Carolyn Horn, Jim (Cathy) Wallick. Proud grandpa of Brian, Carrie, Jesse, Karina and Daniel. Dearest brother of Ruth (Ed) Lipson and Muriel (Jack) Polish. Cherished son-in-law of Blanche Rosenhirsch, brother-in-law of Suzi (Martin) Oppenheimer. Special friend and loved by all, including his employees at Mercer Tool for his warmth, support and caring nature. Services Tuesday, March 3, 11 AM, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre. Contributions may be made in his memory to Child Care Council of Nassau, 925 Hempstead Turnpike, Franklin Square, New York 11010.

title: New York Lottery Reviewing Account
description: The New York State Lottery said yesterday that it had begun a mandated review on its account, which had been handled for the last decade by DDB Needham New York. Billings were estimated at $50 million to $60 million.

title: The Devils Just Pass First Test In a While
description: The Devils have put together the best record in the Eastern Conference by piling up victories against the National Hockey League's weaker teams. But tonight's matchup with the Philadelphia Flyers was the Devils' first game in the last 10 against a team with a winning record, so it was as good a time as any for them to gauge how good they really are.

title: UNITRODE TO ACQUIRE BENCHMARQ, ANOTHER CHIP MAKER
description: The Unitrode Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Benchmarq Microelectronics Inc. of Dallas for $135 million in stock, adding semiconductors that control battery power to its line of chips. Shareholders of Benchmarq, whose chips are used in portable computers, cellular telephones and other electronics equipment, will get one share of Unitrode for each Benchmarq share. Unitrode, based in Merrimack, N.H., makes chips that control electric current in computers and industrial equipment. Its shares fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $18.1875. Shares of Benchmarq rose 87.5 cents, to $17.125.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Republicans in Assembly Select New Leader
description: The dominoes from Bill Paxon's departure from Congress continued to fall today as Republicans in the State Assembly elected John J. Faso their new minority leader, taking Mr. Faso out of the running for state comptroller.

title: White House Warns Congress Over Limiting Tobacco Ads
description: The White House warned today that some of the restrictions on tobacco advertising that Congress was considering could be unconstitutional.

title: Sprewell Involved In Auto Accident
description: Latrell Sprewell lost control of his car on a northern California freeway while changing lanes, causing another vehicle to flip onto its roof, authorities said yesterday.

title: After Raid in Error, Police to Pay for Damage
description: Acting on a tip from an informer, police narcotics officers raided an apartment in the Bronx last week, sparking a wild shootout with the frightened occupant, who apparently thought that the officers were burglars. But the address where the raid took place turned out to be wrong, and yesterday, chagrined police officials agreed to pay for the damage.

title: Boyds Wheels to Cease All Manufacturing
description: Boyds Wheels Inc. said today that it would cease all manufacturing operations and seek permission in Federal bankruptcy court to liquidate the company's assets.

title: With Shutout, Hasek Shows He's Still Olympian
description: During the Winter Olympics, Team USA's Gary Suter likened facing Dominik Hasek to playing against a wall with a mask.

description: To the Editor:

title: Court in Brawley Case Hears a Film Maker
description: A video archivist testified in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial yesterday about a film he made 10 years ago on the Brawley case, but he was unable to account for several discrepancies in his work.

title: Turning a Joplin Opera Into a School Project
description: IT was in the parlor of her grandmother's house in Village Springs, Ala., that Joan Burroughs first felt the tapping of Scott Joplin's steady left hand somewhere against her spine. Her uncles would drop by to play jazz and blues on the parlor piano, but when her grandmother sat down at the keyboard, it was usually the wistful hopscotch of ragtime that would fill the house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINS, ALEX A.
description: MARTINS-Alex A. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Alex A. Martins, associated with The Times from 1972, until retiring in 1976.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBUS, ELINOR HUGHES
description: JACOBUS-Elinor Hughes. Age 91. On February 28 at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital, Patchogue, New York. Wife of the late David D. Jacobus, she is survived by two stepsons, John H. Jacobus of New York City and Dr. David P. Jacobus of Princeton, New Jersey, five grandchildren, four great-grandchildren and two generations of nieces and nephews. Immediately after her graduation from Radcliffe College, under the name of Elinor Hughes, she began her career as a theater critic for the Boston Herald, a position she held for over 40 years. Her reviews, which included film and occasionally music, made her a preeminent voice in Boston and she reviewed hundreds of Broadway bound musicals and dramas. Her encyclopedic knowledge of English and American prose and poetry, especially Shakespeare, and her life-long enthusiasm for the theater made her writing both generous and erudite. Many pieces were collected in her book, ''Passing Through to Broadway''. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to: The Actors Fund, Radcliffe College, National Wildlife Federation.

title: Learning From Success of Smallpox Eradication
description: The eradication of smallpox 20 years ago was arguably medicine's greatest triumph because no other naturally occurring disease has ever been wiped out.

title: In Praise of Smaller Farms
description: Suburban sprawl looks like a natural product of American growth until one realizes that it was largely shaped by state and Federal policies affecting highway construction, lending and zoning. The same is true of farm country. The concentration of land in fewer and fewer hands, the steady demise of small farms, the vertical integration of food production -- all this looks like the inevitable result of economic forces. Actually it has been largely caused by a prolonged bias toward industrial farming in the Agriculture Department and the agricultural establishment that has led to the depopulation of farm towns, the loss of soil, the pollution of land and water, and the demoralization of America's small farmers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRELL, RUSSELL
description: CARRELL-Russell. The Board of Managers of East Side House Settlement expresses its deep sympathy at the death of Mr. Russell Carrell. As long-time manager of the Winter Antiques Show until his retirement, Mr. Carrell was instrumental to the Show's success. We are grateful for his many contributions. David L. Duffy, President East Side House Bd of Managers John A. Sanchez, Exec Director East Side House Settlement

title: 3 Acquisitions By Sunbeam in Separate Deals
description: The Sunbeam Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the Coleman Company Inc. and the makers of Mr. Coffee machines and First Alert smoke alarms in deals that will more than double the size of the $1 billion consumer appliance manufacturer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, ANN
description: MELTZER-Ann, 91, died on March 2nd, 1998. Sister of the late Celia Denton and Sadye Meltzer. Loving aunt. Graveside services Tuesday, March 3rd at the New Montefiore Cemetery, at 1 P.M.

title: Focus Is Put on Soldier's Accuser
description: Maj. Michelle Gunzelman, one of the six women to accuse Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney of sexual misconduct, frequently asked her male subordinates for advice on how to be more attractive to the opposite sex, according to testimony here today.

title: Prudential Profit Falls 43% On Life Insurance Problems
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America reported a 43.4 percent drop in profits for 1997 yesterday, as sales of its main product, life insurance, remained depressed and the company set aside more than $1.6 billion to pay policyholders who contend they were deceptively sold insurance they did not need.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD PLANS TO ACQUIRE 2 HOME BUILDERS
description: The Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation agreed yesterday to buy home builders in Texas and Colorado for a total of $115 million. Kaufman will pay $50 million for the Houston-based Hallmark Residential Group Inc., the parent company of Dover Homes and Ideal Builders, which has projected 1998 revenue of about $73 million. Kaufman said the deal would make it the largest home builder in Texas. The company also said it would pay $65 million for the assets of Pridemark Homes, a Denver-based home builder. Kaufman & Broad, based in Los Angeles, had revenue of $1.88 billion in the year ended Nov. 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, BERNADETTE
description: MURPHY-Bernadette. On March 1, 1998. Teacher IS187, NYC Board of Education. Beloved daughter of Timothy and Bridget (nee Flynn), loving sister of Mary Barbara and Tim, proud aunt of Arnan and Jana, cherished godmother of Nicole, also survived by many family members, a close circle of friends, colleagues and students. Visiting Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday 10:15 A.M. at Our Lady of Angels Church. The family requests in lieu of flowers, donations to Saint Jude's Childrens Hospital: 1-800822-6344 and/or National Cancer Institute: 1-800-4CANCER.

title: Echoes of 1798
description: Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel investigating President Clinton, had a novel defense for his recent decision to subpoena Sidney Blumenthal, a White House aide, for possible obstruction of justice. Mr. Starr claimed that Mr. Blumental might have been spreading ''misinformation'' to reporters and that ''the First Amendment is interested in the truth.''

title: Patterns
description: American Designers Abroad

title: Finding Cultural Roots in the Rhythms of Carnival
description: Martinique is celebrating the 150th anniversary of the abolition of slavery, and the subject, quietly, pervasively rippled through the four days of carnival this week. It was everywhere, in the women's gold necklaces that symbolized the chains of bondage to the rhythm of the drum choirs that rustle in the distance like a soft wind, then sweep through the streets furiously.

title: State Is Investigating Complaints on Oxford
description: State insurance regulators said yesterday they were investigating Oxford Health Plans of New Jersey in response to complaints of poor customer service and late payments to doctors.

title: Boys to Men: Boost For U.S.?
description: Project 40, a joint venture between the United States Soccer Federation and Major League Soccer to develop young American players, took a major step last week toward putting the youngsters in a professional environment almost year round.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, DOROTHY
description: DIAMOND-Dorothy. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Devoted mother of Marc and Linda Diamond, Drew and Diane Diamond, Debi and Michael Nelson, Robert and Jodi Diamond and Lanni and Eugene Sidoti. Cherished daughter of Anna Friedman. Loving grandmother of twelve. Services today 1:30 P.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Congress Is Urged to Defer Plan To Increase Medicare Eligibility
description: The Chairman of a new commission studying the future of Medicare called on Congress today to defer action this year on President Clinton's proposal to open Medicare to people 55 to 64 years old.

title: The Future of Credit Unions
description: The Supreme Court was not engaging in exotic legalisms last week when it struck down a Federal regulation that has allowed tax-exempt credit unions to evolve from their homey origins into large financial institutions that use their tax breaks to compete with regular banks for business. Rather, the Court's decision rests on a common-sense reading of the relevant law.

title: Accounts
description: * Renters Choice Inc., Dallas, to Levenson & Hill, Dallas, to handle advertising for the rent-to-own chain, previously handled by the Bagwell Agency, Dallas. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Jesse Jackson Jr. Is His Father's Son, But He Reaches Beyond the Rainbow
description: Tudor architecture and pricey boutiques line the broad sidewalks of Sterling Avenue in this elegant Chicago suburb, where a Land Rover slips into a parking lot near a micro-brewery.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Politicians in a Hurry
description: To the Editor:

title: By Design; Pants That Go Lightly
description: Shades of Audrey Hepburn. Cropped pants -- whether capris, pedal pushers or toreadors -- are back in force for spring.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Misplaced Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Forget Williams's Injury; Just Bring on the Knicks
description: Jayson Williams went to see the doctor this morning, letting the team's physicians take a look at his right wrist, which he injured at the end of Sunday night's tough loss at Miami. He underwent X-rays, which did not show anything unusual, so the doctors suggested a magnetic resonance imaging test.

title: Reaction Is Calm to CUNY Plan to Limit Remedial Courses
description: While remedial education at the City University of New York has long been a delicate issue because it raises the specter of admitting students who are not ready to do college-level work, reaction to CUNY's plan to limit remedial courses has been surprisingly calm.

title: Early Results in India Show Gains for Hindu Nationalists
description: Incomplete returns from India's general election early today indicated that an alliance of parties led by the Bharatiya Janata Party, a Hindu nationalist group known in India as the B.J.P., had far outstripped a rival alliance led by the Congress Party, but apparently not by enough seats to assure the nationalists an outright parliamentary majority.

title: Metro Business; Housewares Chain To Close Mall Stores
description: Lechters Inc. of Harrison, N.J., the nation's largest housewares chain, said yesterday that it expected to close 60 to 70 money-losing stores in malls by next Jan. 31 and open another 25 in strip malls and solo sites.

title: Gotti on Trial and Cutler for the Defense: Seems Just Like Old Times
description: Bruce Cutler, who achieved national notoriety as the lawyer who kept the mob boss John Gotti out of prison until a Federal judge disqualified him for being too close to La Cosa Nostra, joined the defense of John Gotti Jr. yesterday in a racketeering case in Westchester County, and it was just like old times.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL WEAKENS. Oil prices fell on expectations the U.N. would adopt a resolution warning Iraq of repercussions if it violates the arms-inspection accord. Light sweet crude for April delivery settled at $15.34 a barrel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Via Spain, a Jilted Gypsy and a Love Triangle
description: The National Ballet of Spain established its distinctive twofold nature with the opening work on its second program, presented on Friday night at City Center. The world premiere of Jose Antonio's ''Vida Breve'' drew on both the new and the old. And its cast was lead by an international Spanish dance star, Lola Greco.

title: Scudder Kemper Narrows Review
description: Scudder Kemper Investments Inc. in Boston, a unit of the Zurich Group, said yesterday that it had narrowed a review on its consolidated account to four agencies from eight. The account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million, had been handled by four agencies before Zurich combined Scudder, Stevens & Clark with Zurich Kemper Investments.

title: Coats of Ice
description: ''It's not a usual winter that we're having,'' said KRISTEN VANORSKI of the Ice Theater of New York, who skated in 48-degree weather at a fashion show for designers from Montreal last night. She swirled and twirled around the rink at Rockefeller Center while wearing coats by DINO GASPARI and HILARY RADLEY. ''Coats can be worn anywhere,'' she said, ''and what better way to show that they're warm than on ice?''

title: Rancorous Rivalry
description: In the latest episode in a long-running feud, MOHAMED AL-FAYED, the owner of the London department store Harrods and the father of Dodi al-Fayed, who was the companion of Diana, Princess of Wales, was arrested in London yesterday. He was released on bail after detectives questioned him about allegations of theft brought by a rival tycoon, ROWLAND W. ROWLAND. Mr. Rowland has alleged that Mr. al-Fayed and his security staff plundered his safe deposit box at Harrods. Mr. Al-Fayed has denied the allegations. . . . In the real-life legal thriller department, it's case closed for the novelist JOHN GRISHAM. Without comment, the Supreme Court let stand rulings that he did not copy from another book in ''The Chamber,'' his 1994 page-turner about a lawyer representing a death-row inmate. POLLY NELSON, who wrote ''Defending the Devil: My Story as Ted Bundy's Last Lawyer'' (William Morrow, 1994) was trying to revive her copyright-infringement lawsuit against him. JAMES BARRON

title: Adding Cumin to the Curry: A Matter of Life and Death
description: CHOOSE any and all correct statements: People living in hot climates eat lots of highly seasoned foods because --

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Fasten Your Seat Belt
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKIPPER, LENA B.
description: SKIPPER-Lena B. Formerly of Atlanta, Ga., and Weir, Miss. February 28. At home. Beloved wife of late Virgil D. Skipper. Beloved mother of Nancy Skipper Adams, Linda Skipper. Beloved grandmother of Charles and Lia Adams and sons-in-law David Adams and James Singelis. Memorial service at West End Collegiate Church, 368 West End Avenue at 77 Street, New York, March 6, 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be sent to West End Collegiate Church Memorial Fund for Lena B. Skipper.

title: F.A.A. Adding Controllers to Busy Center
description: Three years after the Federal Aviation Administration vowed to hire more air traffic controllers at a regional control center in Ronkonkoma, N.Y., the number of fully trained controllers has grown only slightly, managers and union officials say. But the agency has recently hired dozens of apprentices and says it has greatly increased its training efforts.

title: Sale Weighed As Takeover Fight Goes On
description: In its fight to fend off a hostile takeover by Computer Associates International Inc., the Computer Sciences Corporation said yesterday that it would go as far as selling itself to another company.

title: Low-Profile Coin
description: The Robert F. Kennedy silver dollar went on sale the day after MICHAEL L. KENNEDY, was killed while playing touch football on skis in Aspen, Colo. In announcing the coin in December, the mint had promised that Kennedy family members would do interviews, including two of Robert F. Kennedy's sons, Representative JOSEPH P. KENNEDY 2D and ROBERT F. KENNEDY JR., senior attorney with the Natural Resources Defense Council. After Michael Kennedy's death, officials of the mint said they were not available.

title: Cast That Rod, Hold That Shotgun
description: For many anglers, campers and boating enthusiasts, the annual World Fishing and Outdoor Exposition at the Rockland Community College Field House is a harbinger of happy times, a signal as evocative as crocuses blooming in the dooryard that winter's grip on the land has been broken.

title: Countess Szapary, 79; Led Newport Society
description: Countess Anthony Szapary, the doyenne of Newport society and the great-great-granddaughter of Cornelius Vanderbilt who lived a good part of the year on the upper floors of the Breakers, maintaining the family's presence in the 70-room mansion built by her grandparents, died on Sunday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWNE, BARTON
description: BROWNE-Barton. Loving and Beloved Partner. March 27, 1950-March 3, 1996. And so it is.

title: Hate Groups in U.S. Are Growing, Report Says
description: With a boost from the Internet, white power rock-and-roll music and even the approach of the millennium, the number of organized hate groups in the United States has continued to increase, a research group has concluded in a new report. The increase comes despite a robust economy, which experts contend typically discourages the proliferation of such organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANA, ELEANOR WATERS
description: DANA-Eleanor Waters, passed away Feb. 21, 1998 in Juno Beach, Florida. She was the daughter of Rossiter Lester Waters and Katherine Wilson Morrison Waters. She graduated from the Spence School in New York City and The Katherine Gibbs Secretarial School, and later became a member of The Albertina Rasch School of Ballet. She married John Langhorne in 1932 and had four sons. She was an active member of The Spring Valley Hounds in Harding Township, New Jersey, and she headed up The Red Cross Unit in New Vernon, New Jersey during World War II. Later, in 1951, she married Charles A. Dana, Jr. and had one daughter. They resided in New Canaan, Connecticut, where she was a member of the Country Club of New Canaan, The Garden Club, and the St. Marks Altar Guild Flower Committee. She also served as Chairman of Youth Consultation Service benefits and Chairman of Just One Break. She was active in The Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund, The New York Philharmonic Orchestra Society, and many other charities. Mrs. Dana also worked in the travel business for many years. Surviving are her brother, William R. Waters, her children, John Langhorne, Jr. of Miami, Florida, Edmund G. Langhorne of Winston Salem, North Carolina, Rossiter W. Langhorne of London, England, & Richard M. Langhorne of Miami, Florida and Vail, Colorado, Sandra Dana O'Donnell of Fairfield, Connecticut and eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Contributions may be made to The New York Philharmonic, Waveny Care Center or Americares. Memorial Service to be held at a later date.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the funeral of the comedian Henny Youngman referred incorrectly to a speaker, Robert Merrill. He is a baritone, not a tenor.

title: Democratic Donor Told Her to Destroy Documents, Aide Says
description: As a controversy over political fund-raising was blossoming into a scandal early in 1997, an Arkansas restaurant owner told an aide to destroy documents concerning his money-raising for the Democratic Party, the aide has told Federal investigators.

title: American Bidding War for a British Utility
description: A fierce bidding war broke out yesterday for control of the Energy Group P.L.C., a big British utility, with Pacificorp raising its offer for the company beyond a new bid made earlier in the day by Texas Utilities.

title: Wary Astronomers Ponder An Accelerating Universe
description: AT their telescopes in the last few years, astronomers have been searching the heavens for evidence that the expansion of the universe is slowing down. The mutual gravitational attraction of all matter in stars, planets and everything else known or hypothesized should be putting a gradual brake on the outward rush of space since the explosive moment of cosmic creation in the theorized Big Bang.

title: Prices Fall, With Yield at 6%, as Economy Looks Strong
description: Bond prices plunged yesterday, pushing the yield on the 30-year bond over 6 percent for the first time since mid-December, as investors began to doubt whether the economy would cooperate and slow down as hoped.

title: SCIENCE WATCH; A Stud or a Dud
description: THE love song plays itself out in the dark recesses of the murky ponds near Cape Town, South Africa. The first notes come from the male in a melodious trill. That is followed by the female, who emits a rapping noise that sounds like a Geiger counter after being exposed to uranium. The male responds, his trill now ardent and frantic as he realizes he has found a mate.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Ticket Litterbugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Kramnik Shows Subtlety In a Long-Range Gambit
description: Of the world's most prominent challengers, only Vladimir Kramnik was missing from the World Championship Knockout Matches organized by the International Chess Federation.

title: Sticking to the Formula; DuPont Insists Mundane and Exotic Products Mix Well
description: Charles O. Holliday Jr. knows that a lot of investors think he should break up DuPont, the $45 billion chemical industry giant where he was put in charge this year. He knows they think that mundane products like polyester and petroleum are a distraction from hot items like genetically altered corn or fancy new drugs.

title: Serbia's Police Crush Protest By Kosovo's Ethnic Albanians
description: The Serbian police used truncheons, water cannon and tear gas today to disperse some 30,000 ethnic Albanians who were marching to protest the killing over the weekend of more than 20 civilians by paramilitaries.

title: Cordero Won't Get Bronx Address
description: The Yankees have decided to not pursue Wil Cordero, the former Boston outfielder who received a suspended sentence for domestic battery last fall.

title: U.S. Holds First Test of Crash Between Sport Utility Vehicle and Car
description: Federal regulators conducted their first crash test pitting a sport utility vehicle against a car today, slamming a 1997 Ford Explorer into the side of a 1997 Honda Accord.

title: On My Mind; The Iraq-Palestine Axis
description: At the United Nations it is never mentioned, and around the world governments act as if it does not exist. But the alliance between Saddam Hussein and the Palestinians is a reality in the Mideast, growing in importance politically, emotionally and militarily, and not about to go away.

title: Mondale, Clinton's 2d Envoy, Urges Suharto to Press Reforms
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale said he had urged President Suharto today to press ahead with painful economic reforms demanded by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Abused Children First
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAINZER, RENATE
description: MAINZER-Renate. On March 2, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Alfred. Loving mother of Ronald and Sari. Cherished grandmother of Lynn and Brad, and Barry and Marci and great grandmother of Alison, Lauren, Lisa, Justin and Samuel. Service are today 10 A.M., at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer'', Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Clinton Attacks G.O.P. Tax Overhaul Plan
description: President Clinton took aim today at a Republican proposal to abolish the current Federal tax code by the end of 2001, calling it an irresponsible gimmick that could endanger the nation's prosperity.

title: Atom Chief Of Russia Is Removed From Post
description: Russia's powerful Atomic Energy Minister was abruptly relieved of his duties today in a move that startled Russian and Western experts.

title: Shrewd Politics, Sound Policy
description: Since President Clinton introduced his budget for the 1999 fiscal year, there has been much praise for -- and some grumbling about -- the political acuity of his pledge to ''reserve'' the looming budget surpluses until Social Security has been reformed. Yes, it looks like shrewd politics. But the more important question is, Is it also sound policy? I believe it is. Here's why.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Not Trivial at All
description: To the Editor:

title: Asia's Interest In U.S. Market Suddenly Cools
description: When Korea's Hyundai Electronics Industries acquired Symbios Inc. from the AT&T Corporation for more than $300 million in 1994, it marked the beginning of a spurt of investment by South Korea's ambitious companies in the American market.

title: Union Figures Take the Fifth Before Jury On Louima
description: Invoking their Fifth Amendment rights, three officials of a New York City police union refused to testify yesterday before a Federal grand jury investigating officers accused in the Abner Louima case. But later, at least one union official began testifying, lawyers and others familiar with the case said.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC ACQUIRES COBURN OPTICAL INDUSTRIES
description: Gerber Scientific Inc. said yesterday that it had bought Coburn Optical Industries for $41.5 million in cash and the assumption of $21.5 million of debt. In the latest fiscal year, the closely held Coburn, of Tulsa, Okla., had revenue of $74 million and Gerber had sales of $380.9 million. The Gerber Optical unit makes equipment used to shape lenses and fit them into frames. The company should be able to sell more lenses abroad by adding Coburn's operations in Canada, the Netherlands, Singapore, Australia and Britain. Gerber, based in South Windsor, Conn., also makes equipment used in sign, clothing and electronics factories. Its shares rose $1.625 yesterday, to $21.4375.

title: Irabu Loses His Control And His Cool
description: Merely by declining to criticize the erratic pitcher Hideki Irabu last year, Yankee catcher Joe Girardi lent his support. Girardi would watch Irabu disintegrate emotionally, yet say nothing about it.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Police Politeness
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Analysts Warn Investors March May Be Volatile Month
description: When March comes in like a lamb, it goes out like a lion, some stock market analysts cautioned after yesterday's rather gentle session.

title: Cashing In the City's Surplus
description: New York City's budget fortunes keep getting better. Barely a month after Mayor Rudolph Giuliani announced that the city would end this year with a $1.2 billion surplus, it now looks as if the number could rise to $1.5 billion or higher. As it should, the windfall has produced a vigorous debate about what to do with it. The city's ultimate approach will be a test of its vision and creativity as well as its fiscal responsibility. We believe that the wisest use of the hefty surplus is to help repair schools, water pipes and other dangerously crumbling pieces of the city's infrastructure, not to pay operating expenses as the Mayor proposes.

title: Indonesian Reserves Fell 14% in February
description: Indonesia's foreign exchange reserves plunged 14 percent in February to $16.33 billion, their lowest point since at least 1993, the Bank Indonesia said yesterday. The bank has bought rupiah in the foreign exchange market on a number of occasions in recent months to prop up the embattled currency. Reserves have now plunged 43 percent from the record high of $28.85 billion set at the end of June. The inflation rate was 32 percent in February -- its highest in 23 years.

title: Foreign Affairs; Ohio State II
description: Last week the Senate Foreign Relations Committee put on a shameful performance. Senators Jesse Helms, Joe Biden & Co. rolled over like puppies having their bellies rubbed when Clinton officials explained their plans for NATO expansion by dodging all the hard questions. It's too bad CNN couldn't entice the Clinton team to go out to Ohio State again and hold a town meeting on NATO expansion. If they had, it would sound like this:

title: INSIDE
description: A Puzzling Kremlin Move

title: Lopez's Long Journey Is Finally Bearing Fruit
description: For the first time in Felipe Lopez's playing career at St. John's, the students threw a pep rally for the team yesterday. The players later admitted they did not know what they were supposed to do, so they simply mingled with the other students.

title: Damsels in Distress (One's a Lawyer)
description: Fairy tale characters really don't have it any better than the rest of us. Take, for instance, the hapless virgin of ''The Handless Maiden,'' the Adobe Theater Company's farcical tweaking of the Brothers Grimm.

title: Birds' Design for Living Offers Clues to Polygamy
description: POOR Monica Lewinsky. She thought Linda Tripp was her best friend, but Ms. Tripp proved treacherous, a wiretapped Anne Baxter to her feckless Bette Davis in the Beltway farce, ''All About Eavesdropping.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZAPARY, SYLVIA S.
description: SZAPARY-Sylvia S. Wife of the late Count Anthony Szapary, daughter of the late Count and Countess Laszlo Szechenyi, and beloved mother of Paul and Gladys, died suddenly on March 1, 1998. The funeral will be held on Thursday, March 5 at noon, Saint Patrick's Roman Catholic Church, State Road, Bedford Village, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to The Preservation Society of Newport County.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA BUYING HAMBROS BOND BUSINESS
description: The Royal Bank of Canada said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the bond business of the British investment bank Hambros Bank Ltd. from Societe Generale, which recently acquired Hambros P.L.C. Financial terms were not disclosed. About 150 Hambros employees are expected to move with the bond division, which has its headquarters in London and offices in Sydney, Australia; Johannesburg; Toronto, and Tokyo. In the merger, expected to take effect April 1, Royal Bank's investment banking arm, RBC Dominion Securities, will combine with the Hambros bond business to become RBC Dominion Securities Global Markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RUTH
description: COHEN-Ruth. On March 1, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Rita Miller and Dr. Bernard Cohen, and mother-inlaw of Phoebe Cohen. Cherished grandmother to Margaret, Alexander, and Dr. Nathaniel Cohen, JoAnne Miller and Nina Miller Prill. Fond great grandmother of Samuel Klotz and Jack Prill. Dear sister of the late Dr. Jacob Rosenblum. The will for life was strong within her. Services on Tuesday, 1:30 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYNER, CHESBROUGH
description: RAYNER - Chesbrough. The Trustees and staff of The Parrish Art Museum regret the loss of Chessy Rayner, a longtime friend and supporter of the Museum. Mildred C. Brinn, Chairman, Board of Trustees Trudy C. Kramer, Director

title: Isles Need Salo to Play Big
description: It's going to take a Herculean effort by Tommy Salo this year if the Islanders are to end their four-year post-season drought. They are 8 points behind the Ottawa Senators for the final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference and have two teams to leapfrog with only 23 games to play.

title: Bailey Brushes Off Greene's Predicition
description: In track and field, jumpers jump, throwers throw, distance runners run and sprinters often trash-talk. Donovan Bailey did the latter yesterday in a telephone hookup with the weekly luncheon of the New York Track Writers Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORT, LAWRENCE
description: CORT-Lawrence. Temple Hillel, North Woodmere, L.I. records with profound sorrow the passing of a devoted congregant and extends sincere condolences to the entire family. Dr. Alan F. Lavin, Rabbi Arthur Singer, President Dr. Morris S. Friedman, Rabbi Emeritus

title: For Balloonists, Innovation And Daring. But Success?
description: IF at first you don't succeed, try, try again. . . . But what if your goal is simply unattainable?

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?
description: To the Editor:

title: Favoritism Is Found in Magnet School's Admissions
description: Political favoritism and nepotism have tainted the admissions practices at a Staten Island magnet school that had promised to select students only by random lottery, according to a report by an independent investigator that was released yesterday.

title: Imperial Bancorp To Spin Off Units
description: Imperial Bancorp said today that it had received Internal Revenue Service approval to spin off part of its entertainment and specialty-lending businesses to shareholders in a tax-free transaction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELMAN, MILTON H., M.D.
description: ADELMAN-Milton H., M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni records with sorrow the loss of their longtime colleague and friend. Dr. Adelman served the institution for over forty-five years, distinguished himself as an outstanding clinician and devoted teacher. A conscientious mentor who touched the lives of countless medical students and residents, Dr. Adelman will be remembered as a dedicated physician, teacher and friend. He will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Wayne S. Fuchs, M.D., President Avi Barbasch, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria Padilla, M.D., Secretary William G. Stein, M.D., Treasurer

title: Eat Out at Home
description: The chef DANIEL BOULUD is returning to a familiar place: the corner of Park Avenue and 65th Street. But this time, room service is part of the deal.

title: Senate Agrees To Give States More Money For Highways
description: Taking advantage of a booming economy and a balanced budget, Senate negotiators reached an agreement today on the broad outlines of a six-year, $173 billion transportation bill that would significantly increase spending on roads and bridges in every state.

title: Settlement Near in Technical Help-Line Suit
description: AS anyone who has spent hours on hold for bad advice can tell you, customer service is not exactly one of the computer industry's strengths. For the Iomega Corporation, it was such a sore point that the company singled it out as a problem in its 1996 annual report. After that came lawsuits and the Click of Death.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Go After the Trucks
description: To the Editor:

title: Deutsch to Open Office in Chicago
description: Deutsch Inc. said yesterday that it would expand by opening a full-service office next month in Chicago.

title: Two Restless Piano Works Come Home
description: Thursday evening's concert at Merkin Hall by Parnassus was a pleasant occasion and a short one, but long enough to include two ranging piano pieces by Stefan Wolpe, a salute to Ursula Mamlok in her 70th year and a couple of ensemble pieces by younger composers: David Crumb and Matthew Greenbaum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAKOWSKY, STANLEY JAY
description: MAKOWSKY-Stanley Jay. Beloved husband of Rose-Ila; devoted father of Kenneth, Hindy and Monroe; brother of Arline. Services Wednesday 10 A.M., ''Garlick's'', Coney Island Avenue at Avenue N, Brooklyn.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Government Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: A Star Built, Not Born
description: Richard Hamilton is pushed by slights, a motivation that seems fitting as he approaches the end of his sophomore season at the University of Connecticut. He was once overlooked by the star-making basketball industry, partly because of his frame. Even now, at 6 feet 6 inches and 180 pounds, he appears too fragile for the Big East Conference, with its lingering reputation of hard bodies and harder fouls. Night after night this winter, Hamilton, the Huskies' leading scorer, has demonstrated that his frame conceals what is inside.

title: Knicks Try to Shrug Off Nets' Infatuating Youth
description: The Knicks have been treated a little like models past their prime in this glamour market. They are not as photogenic these days and have fallen off the covers of magazines. A forgotten bunch. Youth, that's where it's at. And that's across the river in New Jersey, of all places.

title: With Prostitution Booming, Legalization Tempts Russia
description: When Lena, 20, arrived at a seedy hotel here after a call from the Amazonka escort service dispatcher, she felt fortunate. The client took one look at her waist-length, platinum-blond hair and chose her over the two other prostitutes the dispatcher had sent over for his inspection.

title: Archer Daniels Informant Repudiates His Allegations
description: The chief informant in a sweeping antitrust investigation has repudiated allegations he made last year that an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation ordered him to destroy evidence favorable to potential defendants in the case, according to a sworn affidavit filed yesterday by Federal prosecutors.

title: At Last, Gaels Earn A Trip To Tourney
description: They hugged. They cut down the net and wore portions of it like necklaces. While their supporters danced around them, some in face paint, some carrying banners, they even prayed.

title: Microsoft Offers To Change Deals
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to revise business deals with about 40 Internet service providers in the United States and Europe but denied the move was a reaction to continuing United States and European Union investigations into its business practices.

title: After Easy Semis, It's Connecticut Against Rutgers
description: The Connecticut women's basketball team had Nykesha Sales, its injured leader, in the stands tonight. It also had more immediate help, a 17-2 run at the start of the game and an 8-0 run at the start of the second half, and that propelled the Huskies to a 73-53 victory over Notre Dame.

title: Helmut Kohl Gets a Challenger
description: Germany's Social Democrats, out of power 16 years, now have an appealing candidate to run against Chancellor Helmut Kohl in September. Gerhard Schroder, pragmatic, telegenic and more than a decade younger than the 67-year-old Mr. Kohl, was chosen yesterday, shortly after winning re-election as Premier of Lower Saxony. But it will probably take more than personal appeal to lead the Social Democrats out of the wilderness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFER, MIRIAM H. (NEE HAMILTON)
description: SHAFER-Miriam H. (nee Hamilton). Beloved wife of Dr. Sid John Shafer. Dear mother of Philip H. (Antoinette Stewart) Shafer and Lea (Craig) Crawford. Loving grandmother of two. Fond sister of Joan Mantz, Cynthia (Donald) Malmquist and the late Bruce Hamilton. Private family services were held. For more information the Piser Chapel, 773-561-4740.

title: N.C.A.A. Drought Ends For Fairleigh Dickinson
description: There was a familiar script in the making at the old Brooklyn Paramount Theater last night, where the Long Island University Blackbirds were once again blowing out an opponent early in the second half.

title: To Battle Kohl, a Socialist Who's Pro-Business
description: In Gerhard Schroder, Germany's leading opposition party has chosen a relatively youthful, telegenic and combative politician whose story of poverty to power is a symbol of Germany's postwar rebirth.

title: Subway Line Repairs Start With Confusion
description: It was the kind of chaos that made people late for work, late for the doctor and late for job interviews.

title: North Korea Says Its Food Is Nearly Gone
description: North Korea said today that its official food stocks would run out by mid-March, adding to concerns about the risk of famine there.

title: Many in Sudan Tire of War Without End
description: Six days a week, Capt. Dewhi Mustafa bridges the gap between two worlds separated by religion, race and decades of civil war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, VALERIE D.
description: BAKER-Valerie D. Of New York City and Sea Cliff, NY, February 27, 1998. Beloved daughter of Enid; loving brother of Charles E. Baker. Visiting 3-5 and 7-9 PM, Wednesday, Whitting Funeral Home, Glen Head, NY. Funeral service 8:30 PM, Wednesday, at funeral home. Interment private. Contributions to American Cancer Society.

title: The Vienna Mirrors Yet Reshapes The Past
description: In three concerts with the Vienna Philharmonic last weekend, Riccardo Muti created original experiences from an old tradition. The only hint of current events was on Sunday, in Hindemith's E Flat Symphony from 1940. Mozart, Mahler, Brahms and Beethoven made up the rest.

title: In the Old Neighborhood With Monet and Manet; Displaying Impressions of Parisian Upheaval
description: In their portrayals of Haussmannian Paris, many Impressionists projected a mood of timeless comfort and security, as if horse-drawn carriages, men in top hats and women under parasols were merely the latest travelers through an urban landscape that had always looked, well, Haussmannian. Off canvas, however, things were very different: mid-19th-century Paris had become one giant construction site.

title: Baruch College President to Lead Adelphi
description: A year after Adelphi University's trustees and president were removed for mismanagement, the university's new board has named the president of Baruch College in Manhattan, Dr. Matthew Goldstein, to take charge of Adelphi and its recovery efforts.

title: The Marrying Kind: Till Divorce Do Them Part
description: It has been decades since sitcom families moved beyond the Nelsons and the Cleavers, those improbably cheerful 1950's ideals, and on to the Archie Bunker-Roseanne Conner types, families that fought together and stayed together. ''Something So Right'' (dropped from NBC last year and returning tonight on ABC) offers the next, long-overdue twist: the adults each trail a string of ex-spouses behind, along with children from their assorted marriages. Except for the opening title sequence, the revived series is exactly the same. It is an underachieving sitcom, far less daring than its up-to-the-minute premise.

title: Scientists Are Turning to Trees to Repair the Greenhouse
description: ON 80 acres of the wettest land in Catahoula Parish in Louisiana, an experimental crop of hardwood saplings is seizing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and locking it up in wooden cells.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, JOHN DALY
description: HART-John Daly. Died February 28 at age 51 after a brief battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife, Molly Butler Hart, children, Ted, Brian and Colin, mother, Ann Montgomery Hart, brother, Peter and sister, Deborah Hart Zitner. Jack was a loving uncle to Lauren, Jennifer and Jeremy Zitner and Katie and Megan Hart. He attended Brooklyn Prep and graduated from St. Francis College. He served in the Marines including a tour in Vietnam. After college he worked as an investment banker. He worked on Wall Street at Mutual of New York, Merrill Lynch, Paine Webber and Sandler O'Neill and Partners. His great wit endeared him to all who knew him. The deep sorrow at his loss is tempered by the warm memories of this very special man. Besides his family, he loved opera, art, sports, fine wines and cigars. He was also a gourmet cook and enjoyed a good political debate. Jack was much loved by his entire family and will be long remembered and sorely missed. Visitation Tuesday, March 3, from 3 to 5 PM and 6 to 9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral services Wed., March 4, 10:30 AM at St. Francis Xavier, 225 Sixth Ave between President and Carroll, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Donations should be directed to Christian Help in Park Slope (CHIPS).

title: Review/Fashion
description: How a masked man with a child in his lap and a woman with a dead lobster on her head found themselves seated side by side in the front row at Julien Macdonald's presentation was for 24 hours the most pressing question at the London shows last week. The question that lingers, however, after the women's collections here, which opened the international round of showings for fall, is, Can British designers survive the wave of foreign financing sweeping into their offbeat ateliers? Money, known to corrupt, can, in fashion, dull creativity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHURE, BEATRICE S.
description: SHURE-Beatrice S. Beloved wife of the late Jacob Silverberg. Devoted mother of Julian Silverberg. Dear mother-in-law of Jeanne Silverberg. Loving grandmother of Elizabeth Jaffe and Lucy Smith. Loving great-grandmother of five. Private services were held on Tuesday. For further information contact Gutterman-Musicant.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; In Search of a More Democratic Grapevine
description: In late 20th-century America, Wall Street celebrates great advances in computer technology and bids up the stocks of companies that are leading players in them. But when it comes to getting the news out to investors, most of corporate America uses a somewhat older technology: the telephone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANDARD, MARY
description: STANDARD-Mary. Formerly of Waco, Texas, graduate of Baylor University, longtime employee of Continental Can, artist, writer, mathematician, activist. Dog lover and true friend. Your strong, independent, caring spirit will always be missed by your many friends, neighbors, and your dear Sammy. Memorial service March 8, 12 noon at 220 West 16th Street.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Curious Civics Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: Diana's Two Sons Share the Bulk of Her $21.45 Million Estate
description: In a will stressing her concern that the upbringing of her two sons not be restricted to the royal family, Diana, Princess of Wales, left Prince William and Prince Harry the bulk of her $21.45 million estate.

title: Multiple Personalities, All of Them Eccentric
description: By the time Keith Thornton got to the story of his alien abduction on Thursday night at Tramps, he had already introduced several fantastically fractured personalities, from the pornographic stud of his nasty ''Sex Style'' album to the more futuristic, if equally perverse, Dr. Octagon. The little green men in the purple flying saucer fit right in with Mr. Thornton's own strange personae.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Henry Steele Commager, History Scholar and Defender of the Constitution, Is Dead at 95
description: Henry Steele Commager, one of the nation's most distinguished historians and teachers, a prolific author, editor and essayist, and an eloquent defender of the Constitution, died yesterday at his home in Amherst, Mass. He was 95.

title: In Stern City, Fun Is Out, Grim Is In
description: IT was a nice restaurant. The meal would have been more enjoyable, though, if the table wasn't right opposite the Heimlich Maneuver poster. Every bite came with this implicit warning that it might be your last unless your companion knew how to keep you from choking to death.

title: BTR Shares Climb on Owens-Illinois Deal
description: The shares of BTR P.L.C., Britain's biggest industrial holding company, climbed 16 percent today after it said on Sunday night that it was selling its glass and packaging businesses and would return $:2 billion ($3.32 billion) to shareholders.

title: Hints of Spring: Ballet Winter Ends As New Casts Bud
description: The New York City Ballet must surely believe that although dance seasons begin and end, dance as an art lives on eternally. The company closed its winter engagement at the New York State Theater this past weekend. Yet, as if to suggest that ballet never stops developing, it introduced new casts into several works at these final performances.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; A Cultural Hysteria
description: To the Editor:

title: Scientists Track the Process of Reading Through the Brain
description: SCIENTISTS studying the problem of dyslexia have found a neural pathway for reading. People who have great difficulty reading, they discovered, use that pathway only inefficiently as they struggle to make sense of written words.

title: Corrections
description: Headlines on Saturday with a front-page article about Eric Robert Rudolph, the man being investigated in connection with several bombings in the South, referred imprecisely to his status. He is an official suspect in the bombing of an Alabama abortion clinic, not in other attacks.

title: Is Mayor's Civility Drive a Platonic Pipe Dream?; Slow Down on Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: John L. Bissell, 66, Entrepreneur In Handloomed Textiles in India
description: John L. Bissell, an American businessman who ran a handloomed-textile export business in India for more than 30 years, died yesterday in New Delhi. He was 66 and lived in New Delhi. The cause was a cerebral hemorrhage, according to his cousin, Hector Prud'homme.

title: Metro Business; Battle Over I.B.M. Building
description: The 43-story I.B.M. Building, one of Manhattan's premier office towers, is the center of a struggle among owners seeking to take advantage of surging real estate prices that have pushed the property's value to about $500 million.

title: For Urban Wastelands, Tomatoes and Other Life
description: On an industrial strip in Buffalo, where just over a year ago the remains of a steel mill sagged on an oil-soaked lot, bumblebees now dance among the yellow blossoms of 170,000 tomato plants growing in artificial soil in a computer-controlled greenhouse. This month, 125 workers will start picking what the greenhouse company says will be at least seven million pounds of vine-ripened tomatoes each year.

title: Rumors of Gingrich in Presidential Race Lead to Jostling Over a Successor
description: For months the rumor ricocheted from office to office on Capitol Hill, but it never quite sank in. The buzz was that Representative Newt Gingrich, the first Republican Speaker of the House in 40 years, would step down early to run for President.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the decision by the New York State Court of Appeals to uphold a ban on sex shops in New York City referred incorrectly in some editions to the judge who wrote the opinion. He was Vito J. Titone, not Joseph W. Bellacosa.

title: Accounts
description: * Straight Arrow Products, Bethlehem, Pa., to McAdams, Richman & Ong Advertising and Design, Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., as the first agency to handle the account for its health and beauty product lines. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: Theater in Review
description: An Unwanted Pregnancy,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'URSO, DAVID FRANCIS
description: D'URSO-David Francis, March 3, 1998. Beloved husband of Michelle. Loving father of Michaela. Loving son of Florence and the late Camillo D'Urso. Devoted brother of Mark, Donna and Lisa. He was a graduate of Iona Grammar, Prep and College, London School of Economics and Carnegie Institute. He currently was the President of D'Urso Enterprises, Inc., and was active in Pelham Civics, and Board Member of the Iona Grammar School. Benefactor of Boys Town of Italy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10AM, St. Patrick's Cathedral, Principal Celebrant, His Eminence John Cardinal O'Connor. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Westchester. In lieu of flowers, a scholarship fund will be established in his name at Iona Prep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, DEUTSCH, REGINA
description: REINER-DEUTSCH-Regina, age 97, formerly of Brighton, MA., and Bayside, New York, on March 3. Beloved wife of the late William Reiner-Deutsch. Devoted mother of Philip Reiner-Deutsch of CA. Services private. Remembrances to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place S.W., Washington, D.C. 20024-2150. For more information, contact The Brezniak-Rodman Funeral Directors, Newton, MA.

title: Harlan Hatcher, 99, U. of Michigan President
description: Harlan H. Hatcher, who as the eighth president of the University of Michigan guided the institution through a time of growth that lifted it into the ranks of the nation's elite research universities, died on Wednesday at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 99.

title: Chrysler Sales Increased 3.1% in February
