description: The Chrysler Corporation reported today that domestic car and truck sales rose 3.1 percent in February, beating estimates, with a surge in truck sales offsetting a sharp drop in car sales.

title: Art Dealer Receives Prison Term Of 28 Months in Fraud Scheme
description: Todd Michael Volpe, a well-known Manhattan art dealer who built a reputation advising Hollywood celebrities, was sentenced yesterday to 28 months in prison for his convictions in a fraud scheme in which his clients lost about $1.9 million.

title: Strikes by German City Workers Frame Political Battle to Come
description: As Germany's political titans squared off for national elections later this year, Wilfried Klumski and about 130,000 other municipal workers gave them a hint today of what the winner's prize -- or burden -- will be.

title: Japanese Executive and Wife Found Dead
description: The president of a small picture frame manufacturer and his wife have committed suicide because of bad business conditions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, IRENE
description: SULLIVAN-Irene. On March 2, 1998. Beloved daughter of the late Frank and Jane. Loving sister of Loretta Long and the late Dr. Joseph, Frank, Mary and Catharine Sullivan. Dearest aunt of Dr. Andrew and Joseph K. Sullivan and Jane Burke. Also survived by ten grand nieces and nephews and one great-grand nephew. Funeral Thursday at 10AM, from the M. J. Smith Sons, Inc. Funeral Home, 248 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial 10:30AM St. Saviour Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, IRVING
description: STEIN-Irving. On February 27, 1998 at age 90. Caring husband of Evelyn. Devoted father of Robert and the late Martin Stein. Loving brother of Ruth Rice, Sidney and Simon Stein and grandchildren Barry Stein and Scott and Eric Landau. Services were held in NY.

title: Criticism of Basketball Record Is About Integrity, Not Gender
description: To the Editor:

title: Payton Scores When It Counts
description: SONICS 97, HEAT 91, OT

title: Roche Sets Cuts As It Revamps
description: Roche Holding A.G. said today that it would streamline its research, cutting jobs in the United States and Japan, and add a sixth research center in Germany as it integrates Corange Ltd. into its business.

title: Jordan Tells Federal Grand Jury Of Helping Lewinsky in Job Hunt
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the cool and elegant confidential adviser to President Clinton, spent the day before the Federal grand jury that is investigating the President's relationship with a former White House intern, Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: A Musical Voyage, Back on Course; Falling From Juilliard to the Streets, Then Conducting With a Conscience
description: On his way to Good Shepherd Presbyterian Church on the Upper West Side, the conductor Jens Nygaard often walks past the little park across the street from the Juilliard School where Broadway and Columbus Avenue intersect. Back in 1959, Mr. Nygaard, who founded and leads the orchestra called Jupiter Symphony, called that little park home.

title: 1,000 Unlikely Elbow-Rubbers Meet at a Time Gala
description: In the crowded lobby of Radio City Music Hall last night, the Rev. Jerry Falwell chuckled and whispered into Muhammad Ali's ear. A few feet away, Lee Iacocca and F. Lee Bailey smiled for a photo op. Staring down from the balcony above, the actress Sharon Stone posed in a zebra-striped dress, not far from Louis Farrakhan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUTH, BERTHA (NEE BERTLOCKELACKOWITZ)
description: KAUTH-Bertha (nee BertlockeLackowitz). Devoted wife of Dr. Benjamin Kauth, passed away March 2, 1998. A memorial service for family and friends will be scheduled in the near future.

title: The Grateful Dead Will Tour Again (Just Don't Call It a Reunion)
description: Although there are no huge stadium tours planned for the summer, there is big news: the surviving members of the Grateful Dead announced yesterday that they would reunite under a new name, the Other Ones, and play some 30 dates in June and July with Rusted Root and Hot Tuna.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A New Rule to Turn the Annual Report Into True Confessions
description: Dear shareholder,

title: Profit Up at Dayton Hudson and Federated
description: Two big department store companies, the Dayton Hudson Corporation and Federated Department Stores Inc., reported yesterday that fiscal fourth-quarter earnings rose, beating analysts' expectations, as the companies kept a tight rein on costs amid modest gains in holiday sales.

title: Saying He's No Isolationist, Gephardt Backs New Aid to I.M.F.
description: Declaring that he had been ''misunderstood and misrepresented'' as a protectionist and isolationist last year, the Democratic leader of the House, Richard A. Gephardt, yesterday threw his support behind the Clinton Administration's efforts to win $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund.

title: Witness in Brawley Case Rebuts Sharpton Remark
description: A Dutchess County woman took the witness stand in the Tawana Brawley defamation case yesterday to rebut statements the Rev. Al Sharpton made about her family 10 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Yah Lin Trie, who was indicted in January on charges of illegally funneling money to the Democratic Party in the 1996 Presidential campaign, referred incorrectly to his business history. He was a restaurant owner in Little Rock before becoming an international business consultant; he was not employed by the Lippo Group in Indonesia.

title: Prosecution Opens Case of Beating Outside a Westhampton Beach Nightclub
description: The prosecution opened its attempted murder case against Austin Offen today by telling the jury that he had brutally and sadistically used an iron bar to bludgeon Shane Daniels outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub nearly two years ago, creating a hole in his skull as big as a softball.

title: Vienna to Go Ahead With Holocaust Shrine
description: After two years of argument, mainly within the small Jewish community, the Mayor announced today that Vienna is going ahead with construction of a Holocaust memorial.

title: People
description: * Chris LaBonge, executive vice president and general manager at Grey Direct/West, Glendale, Calif., a division of Grey Advertising, was promoted to president, a new post.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAKEN, JOAN W.
description: BAKEN-Joan W. 1945-1995

title: U.S. Warns of Force If Iraq Breaks Word
description: The day after the United Nations Security Council stopped short of endorsing an explicit military threat against Iraq, the Clinton Administration contended that the United States has the authority to use force if Iraq does not comply with United Nations weapons inspections.

title: MID-CONTINENT
description: In Moline, Ill., Bill Jenkins scored 16 points and Valparaiso earned another trip to the N.C.A.A. tournament by beating Youngs-town State, 67-48, to win its fourth straight Mid-Continent Conference tourney title.

title: U.S. Is Linking Aid to Jakarta To Its Reforms
description: Hours after President Suharto of Indonesia met a special American envoy, top Administration officials told Congress today that the White House could not support additional emergency aid to Indonesia from the International Monetary Fund unless Mr. Suharto makes ''adequate progress'' toward economic reforms he agreed to in January.

title: Congress In China: No Teeth, Strong Jaws
description: The National People's Congress is an annual rite, bringing together nearly 3,000 delegates from all parts of China who ratify measures already approved by the Communist Party. This year's session, which starts Thursday, is drawing more interest than usual, because it is expected to endorse leadership changes that could herald new directions in Government policy.

title: Darcy O'Brien, 59, Author Of Fiction and 'True Crime'
description: Darcy O'Brien, who turned a Hollywood childhood into award-winning fiction, taught literature at two universities and became the best-selling author of several ''true-crime'' books, died on Monday at his home in Tulsa, Okla. He was 59.

title: As Life Ebbs, So Does Time To Elect Comforts of Hospice
description: After eight years of working in a nursing home, Alaine Dougherty was no stranger to death. When terminal cancer of the esophagus was diagnosed in her mother last April, she knew precisely what she wanted -- or, rather, did not want: ''I didn't want my mom to suffer, and I didn't want all the craziness.''

title: As Russia Seethes, NATO Prepares to Grow; Decades of Oppression
description: To the Editor:

title: Out and About
description: Turnabout is fair play, the saying goes, so IVANA TRUMP organized a birthday party for the man who organized one for her last month, COUNT ROFFREDO GAETANI D'ARAGONA. They celebrated his turning 43 at Sofia Fabulous Pizza, a restaurant on Madison Avenue, near 77th Street, and later danced in the lounge at Moomba, on Seventh Avenue South. Seen in the crowd were GIUSEPPI CIPRIANI, who runs the SoHo restaurant Downtown, and Mrs. Trump's teen-age daughter, IVANKA. Not seen was DONALD J. TRUMP, who attended Mrs. Trump's party last month. . . . JAMES CAAN, the hotheaded Sonny Corleone in ''The Godfather,'' walked into at Tapika, on Eighth Avenue at 56th Street, at 3:30 P.M. ''I'm hungry,'' he said. Told that the restaurant would not begin serving dinner until 5, he left, without giving an incendiary performance. . . . While filming a scene for the HBO series ''Sex and the City,'' the crew blocked the sidewalk on Fifth Avenue between 80th and 81st Streets. Cameras focused on SARAH JESSICA PARKER, who strolled down the avenue in a tan coat. Some pedestrians focused on getting where they had to go. ''I'm a doctor,'' a woman said as she barged past. ''I have patients waiting.'' JAMES BARRON with PHOEBE HOBAN

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE DROPS. Prices fell nearly 4 percent, to the lowest level in four months, amid an expected big crop in Brazil and weak demand. The May contract fell 5.8 cents, to $1.525 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.

title: As Russia Seethes, NATO Prepares to Grow; For a National Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWELL SELLS 8% BLACK & DECKER STAKE FOR $395 MILLION
description: The Newell Company said yesterday that it had sold its 7.862 million-share stake in the Black & Decker Corporation to the investment bank Goldman, Sachs & Company for $395 million. Newell, which realized a $200 million pretax gain from the sale, bought the shares on the open market in 1990 and through a private placement in 1991. The shares represent about 8 percent of Black & Decker's outstanding stock. Newell said it would use the proceeds to pay down debt. Black & Decker, based in Towson, Md., had revenue of $4.94 billion in 1997. Shares of Black & Decker fell $1.3125, to $48.5625. Newell fell 25 cents a share, to $45.

title: As Russia Seethes, NATO Prepares to Grow
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOFF, ROSLYN
description: LEIBOFF-Roslyn. Beloved wife of the late Murry. Devoted mother of Ellen Reichenberg and Michael Leiboff. Loving grandmother of Mitchell, Noah and Tess. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack on Thursday at 10 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSS, JOAN
description: GROSS-Joan. We keep on loving you.

title: Cary Reich, 48, Writer, Dies; A Biographer of Rockefeller
description: Cary Reich, a financial journalist and the author of a widely praised biography of Nelson A. Rockefeller, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York. He was 48, and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bits and Bytes
description: Wine Spectator Puts A Cellar on Line

title: Japan Bailout Agency Acting on Failed Bank
description: The Resolution and Collection Bank of Japan plans to hire roughly 500 employees of the failed Hokkaido Takushoku Bank to move forward with the liquidation of the bank's assets. Shigeru Mizuno, president of Resolution and Collection, said yesterday that his institution would take on some 300 Hokkaido Takushoku employees on Hokkaido and 200 on the main island of Honshu.

title: Near Miami, Arrests Test Free Speech For Students
description: The high school students say it was a prank. But a pamphlet titled ''First Amendment,'' with racist comments, obscene cartoons and a cover drawing of their black principal shot through the head with a dart has earned nine suburban Miami teen-agers a trip to jail and possible expulsion from school.

title: Islanders Make Big Fashion Statement
description: It has got to be the shirts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEYMAN, ISIDORE
description: HEYMAN-Isidore. Cherished husband of Yetta and loving father of Ellen Rachich and Barry Heyman, father-in-law of Ellen Heyman and Milian Rachich, and zaidy of Andrew, Marni, Adam, Danielle and Ethan. A graduate of NYU Law School. He successfully practiced law for 68 years. Graveside service at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J., 1:30 P.M., March 5. Donations may be made to Van Cortlandt Jewish Center, Bronx.

title: U.N. Chief Invites Iraqi to a Talk About Oil
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan today invited the Iraqi Foreign Minister to New York to talk about problems with the program that allows Iraq to sell limited quantities of oil to buy food and medicine.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINTRAUB, JEANNE
description: WEINTRAUB-Jeanne. Mother, on this first anniversary of your passing, we are thankful for the legacy of love that your life and Dad's has passed to us. Love from Charles and Ellie for all

title: Job Growth Last Year Was Highest Since '84
description: The State Department of Labor yesterday reported that, under revised 1997 employment figures, job gains for the year were the highest since 1984. A net of 87,500 new jobs were created, with the highest gains in the service sector, said Josh Rosenblum, a department spokesman. Revisions also brought the 1997 unemployment rate down to 5.1 percent from 5.4 percent, making it the lowest since 1990.

title: An 'Icon of Technology' Encounters Some Rude Political Realities
description: William H. Gates walked into the Senate hearing room today flanked by his two home state Senators, Slade Gorton and Patty Murray of Washington, like a couple of bodyguards ready to ward off the blows.

title: Sports of The Times; A Different Rivalry, With Respect
description: ON a Comedy Central television show not long ago, Jayson Williams, the Nets' full-court jester, was asked to define the ''toxic area'' that separates New York City from the rest of America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUGER, RICHARD H.
description: KRUGER-Richard H. Of Lawrence, NY, on March 3, 1998 at age 54. President of the former Kruger Millwork Co., Inc. of Lawrence. Beloved husband of Pamela (nee Browne). Dear father of Richard H., II and Carolyn B. Son of the late Henry L. and Pauline B. Kruger. Brother of Harry S. of FL and the late Joan D. The memorial service will be held Saturday, March 7, 10:30 AM at Trinity-St. John's Church, Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Memorial donations to ''The Memorial Fund of Trinity-St. John's Church'' will be appreciated.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK GAINS. The dollar fell against the mark on talk that the German opposition leader, Gerhard Schroder, might defeat Chancellor Helmut Kohl in September. In New York the dollar cost 1.8096 marks, down from 1.8142.

title: Criticism of Basketball Record Is About Integrity, Not Gender
description: To the Editor:

title: Wilson Triumphs, and Builds Confidence
description: Paul Wilson has a little advice for anybody who wants to play devil's advocate by suggesting that he might be better off starting the year in the minor leagues after missing a full major league season because of shoulder surgery: Don't do it.

title: Budget Surplus Nears, And Plans for It Appear
description: Just hours after the Congressional Budget Office predicted that the first Government surplus would appear this year, the chairman of the House Budget Committee said today that Congress should consider using part of the surplus to create Individual Retirement Accounts for workers paying into the Social Security system.

title: Light Touches In a Dark Tale
description: Herve Le Goff's tap dancing is part rococo embellishment and part sudden darting thrusts and bucklings of his long body. Unsurprisingly, Mr. Le Goff's new ''Bonsoir Mon Prince,'' performed on Sunday afternoon at Synchronicity Space, had some of the same oddball quality.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the scheduled appearance by Vernon E. Jordan Jr. before the grand jury investigating President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky referred incompletely to his account of his efforts to find her a job. While Mr. Jordan began helping Ms. Lewinsky before he knew that she had been subpoenaed as a witness in Paula Corbin Jones's lawsuit against Mr. Clinton, Mr. Jordan's lawyer said, eventually he was in fact told of the subpoena and continued to help her, on assurances from both the President and Ms. Lewinsky that there was no relationship.

title: $25 and Under; 20 Lashes With These Wet Noodles? Yes, Please!
description: WATER pours gently from a fountain into a little rock garden in the vestibule of Soba-ya, a small Japanese noodle restaurant that opened a month ago in the East Village. The fountain sounds a contemplative note that is almost out of place on this block of East Ninth Street, which already has several bustling Japanese restaurants, a raucous Japanese bar and a Japanese hair stylist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFER, FREDERICK Q.
description: SHAFER - Frederick Q. The trustees, faculty, administration, alumni/AE of Bard College mourn the passing of Frederick Quentin Shafer '36, former chaplain of the college and Bernard Iddings Bell Professor Emeritus of Philosophy and Religion. His life and work were closely bound together with Bard, a place to which he was deeply committed and to which he devoted nearly 60 years of his life. He exemplified the aspirations and spirit of this institution. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Margaret Creal Shafer and to his children and grandchildren. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab II, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Pynchon's Letters Nudge His Mask
description: In his private correspondence, Thomas Pynchon, a famously reclusive author, offers extraordinary insights into his creative process as well as his insecurities, angers, passions and his day-to-day life. At various times, he questions his talent as a writer and called one of his novels a potboiler. But on at least one occasion, he is struck by a surge of self-confidence, envisioning himself as the subject of a battle among publishers for rights to his fiction.

title: Business Travel; A Web site allows travelers to create an interactive guide based on data from Fodor's.
description: REVIEW TRAVEL INC., whose World Wide Web site has traditionally focused on vacationers, is now wooing business travelers. It is currently the only business travel Web site that allows users to create an interactive guide to destinations based on data from Fodor's Travel Publications' Gold Guide series of books.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOYD, J.A. (JOE)
description: FLOYD-J.A. (Joe) The Board of Directors and Staff of Christie's International, PLC, are deeply saddended by the loss of J.A. Floyd, former Chairman, friend and colleague who served the company with distinction for forty-five years. Joe played a pioneering role in Christie's North American operations, particularly the opening of Christie's New York Office in 1977. He will be greatly missed.

title: Fertility For Sale
description: As reproductive technology has advanced, the law of supply and demand has inevitably clicked in. Some clinics have had trouble finding women to donate their eggs for implantation in infertile women. That has led to a medical and ethical debate over whether donors should charge for their eggs and, if so, how much. The St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J., recently accelerated that debate by offering $5,000 for donors, double the rate of many clinics. A variety of experts were asked whether women should be permitted to sell their eggs on the open market:

title: MARCUS CABLE WEIGHS BUYOUT BIDS OR STOCK OFFERING
description: The Marcus Cable Company said yesterday that it had received unsolicited bids from two companies interested in buying the cable-television company. The closely held Marcus, which is 36 percent-owned by Goldman, Sachs & Company, is considering several options, including a sale of the entire company or a public stock offering, its chief executive, Jeff Marcus, said. He declined to name the interested parties. The company could fetch $3 billion in a sale, Mr. Marcus said. Marcus has about 1.1 million subscribers in six markets, including Fort Worth and Southern California. It is the nation's 11th-largest cable operator. Variety, the trade publication, and The Wall Street Journal reported the possibility of a sale.

title: Closed Jury Selection Is Sought in Capital Case
description: Defense lawyers in what is expected to be the state's first death-penalty trial in decades asked yesterday that the press and the public be excluded from jury selection when it begins March 16.

title: Working Very Hard at Business as Usual
description: For President Clinton, today was a fever ishly even an abnormally -- normal day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGER, SARAH ELIZABETH
description: LANGER-Sarah Elizabeth, of Watchung, NJ. Beloved daughter of Theresa M. and David H. Langer, sister of Joseph and Rachel Langer, granddaughter of Ryna and Bernard Langer and Maryanne and David Lambe. Funeral March 4 at 11:00 A.M. at Temple Har Shalom, Warren, New Jersey. Interment Fairview Cemetery Westfield, NJ. For information, Higgins Home for Funerals, Watchung, NJ. Memorial contributions to Overlook Hospital Foundation in Sarah Langer's memory P.O. Box 220, Summit, NJ 07901

title: Parcells Has Excused O'Donnell From Jets' Off-Season Workouts
description: When the Jets' off-season conditioning program begins next Monday, quarterback Neil O'Donnell, whose future with the team is uncertain, will be one of the few absentees.

title: Wine Talk; Flights of Fancy: Wine With Dinner Midair
description: ON a plane out west a few years back, the flight attendant had just begun the safety demonstration, acutely aware of how absurd some of the performance is. ''Now,'' she said, ''for those of you who haven't been in an automobile since 1954, I will show you how to fasten your safety belt.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAUBINGER, MILDRED SRULOWITZ
description: GLAUBINGER-Mildred Srulowitz. Of Alpine, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Harry J. Srulowitz and Martin Glaubinger. Devoted mother of Susie Schneeweiss and the late Joan Tina Finkelstein and Benno Stratton. Mother-in-law of Gary Schneeweiss, Chuck Finkelstein and Joyce Stratton. Step-mother of Bob and Daryl Glaubinger. Dear sister of the late Yvonne Fishman and Daniel Miller. Loving grandmother and many nieces and nephews. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, New Jersey, Wednesday at 12 noon.

title: Journal; Who's Biased Now?
description: Remember the biased ''mainstream media'' that would stop at nothing to protect the Clinton White House? Funny how you don't hear about that anymore. If there's one certain casualty of Monicagate so far, it's the notion that the likes of Newsweek, The Washington Post, The New York Times and the big three networks will suppress news out of loyalty to a supposed liberal comrade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, JOHN DALY
description: HART-John Daly. Died February 28 at age 51 after a brief battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife, Molly Butler Hart, children, Ted, Brian and Colin, mother, Ann Montgomery Hart, brother, Peter and sister, Deborah Hart Zitner. Jack was a loving uncle to Lauren, Jennifer and Jeremy Zitner and Katie and Meagan Hart. He attended Brooklyn Prep and graduated from St. Francis College. He served in the Marines including a tour in Viet Nam. After college he worked as an investment banker. He worked on Wall Street at Mutual of New York, Merrill Lynch, Paine Webber and Sandler O'Neill and Partners. His great wit endeared him to all who knew him. The deep sorrow at his loss is tempered by the warm memories of this very special man. Besides his family, he loved opera, art, sports, fine wines and cigars. He was also a gourmet cook and enjoyed a good political debate. Jack was much loved by his entire family and will be long remembered and sorely missed. Funeral services Wednesday, March 4th, 10:30AM at St. Francis Xavier, 225 6th Ave, bet. President and Carroll, Park Slope, Bklyn. Donations should be directed to Christian Help in Park Slope (CHIPS).

title: Green States Policy, and It Is on Health Care
description: Mark J. Green, New York City's Public Advocate, moved to stake out ground in the United States Senate race yesterday, decrying abuses by health maintenance organizations and advocating a hefty $1.50-per-pack increase in cigarette taxes to help discourage teen-agers from smoking.

title: Reluctantly, Williams Leaves Game in Pain
description: Jayson Williams came out of the locker room at halftime forcing a smile, as if he could fool the Nets' coaching staff and even himself. If he didn't show the pain, Williams seemed to think, he could continue to play. But when he tried to run up the floor, he could not hide the pain.

title: FINE HOST SHARES PLUNGE 64% ON ACCOUNTING PROBLEMS
description: The shares of the Fine Host Corporation plunged 64 percent yesterday in their first day of trading in two and a half months, after the company disclosed that it would restate results because of accounting problems. Shares of the food-concession company, based in Greenwich, Conn., plunged $6.50, to $3.625, in Nasdaq trading of 11.4 million shares. Fine Host's stock was halted on Dec. 12 after a weeklong plunge. The company dismissed its chief executive, Richard E. Kerley, and the treasurer, Nelson A. Barber, acknowledged that it recognized some income before it was earned and said it would restate results dating back to 1994. Fine Host runs concessions and cafeterias at football stadiums, prisons and health care operations.

title: Jockey tries to update the image of its underwear line.
description: A VENERABLE maker of underwear hopes to lift sales by encouraging customers to drop their pants.

title: As Russia Seethes, NATO Prepares to Grow; Mystery Price Tag
description: To the Editor:

title: The Minimalist; Simply Chicken And Rice
description: YOU can make a big deal out of chicken with rice -- at its zenith, it becomes paella -- but it is a dish that takes well to short cuts. And even at its simplest, it's a crowd-pleaser.

title: There's a Steady Rush To the Corporate Altar; Mergers and Acquisitions Continue At a Record Pace Across-the-Board
description: It is early morning on a recent Tuesday, and Gary Parr is hard at work. Since arriving four hours earlier at his 35th-floor office overlooking Times Square, Mr. Parr, the co-head of Morgan Stanley's global mergers-and-acquisitions group, has dispatched a banker to Asia to counsel a client on a corporate restructuring, weighed in on a bid for an insurance company and mapped out a London trip to meet a chief executive who wants to sell the company he runs.

title: U.S. Loans for Farmers Hurt by '97 Drought
description: As rain soaked the state for the third straight day yesterday, the United States Department of Agriculture announced a low-cost loan program for farmers hit by last summer's drought.

title: Charge Revived Against a Top Japan Aide
description: The yen declined today as traders worried about the economic impact of corruption charges leveled by an opposition party against the top Finance Ministry official in charge of international affairs.

title: Theater in Review
description: Mark and Shelly and Jill

title: Criticism of Basketball Record Is About Integrity, Not Gender
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTZ, LENNIE
description: KURTZ-Lennie. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Devoted father of Carol Bates. Cherished friend of Ruth Halle. Loving grandfather of Michael and Sarah. Services at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, on Wednesday, at 10 A.M. For information, 1-800-522-0588.

title: Mr. Gates Takes the Stand
description: Bill Gates's appearance yesterday before the Senate Judiciary Committee lacked the drama early in the century, when Congress hauled in J. P. Morgan to defend Wall Street's frightening reach into the sinews of the economy. Yesterday's hearings also lacked the impact of turn-of-the-century investigations of Standard Oil's manipulative stranglehold -- an inquiry that informed later antitrust law and court doctrines. Even so, it was a moment of no small importance -- the first confrontation between the information age's wealthiest and most gifted entrepreneur and a Congress that is trying to figure out whether Mr. Gates is the consumer's best friend or a crafty monopolist determined to crush all competitors.

title: Food Chain
description: Safe Egg Whites

title: Texas Utilities Raises Bid for Energy Group
description: A bidding war for the Energy Group P.L.C., Britain's largest utility, intensified yesterday as Texas Utilities raised its bid to $7.34 billion, slightly more than Pacificorp's offer of $7.2 million made on Monday.

title: Tobacco Chief 'Horrified' Over Evidence
description: Saying he was ''ashamed'' and ''horrified,'' the chief executive of Philip Morris was presented with a parade of internal documents showing that the company kept close tabs on smokers ages 12 to 18, handed out promotional T-shirts at beaches, and believed its future to be dependent on attracting young smokers.

title: New State Proposal For Special Education
description: In an effort to teach special education students more of the curriculum that mainstream students learn, the Department of Education will propose rule changes today that range from how students are classified to the kinds of staff that guide their education, officials said. The changes could go into effect as early as September if approved by the State Board of Education, said Barbara Gantwerk, director of the State Office of Special Education Programs.

title: Leonard/Monahan In Providence Shuts
description: Leonard/Monahan, a 20-year-old agency in Providence, R.I., has closed after losing important clients and top executives.

title: Liberties; Who, Me? Predatory?
description: We used to worry about S-E-X. Now we worry about U.R.L. We used to worry about a Middle East war. Now we worry about a browser war. We used to worry about soft money and coffees. Now we worry about software and Java.

title: Local Lawmakers Immune From Suits Too, Court Says
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that officials of city and county governments have absolute immunity from suits for damages for their legislative actions.

title: Availability Of Rent Aid Is Reduced
description: A little-noticed change in Federal housing rules announced late last month is likely to sharply reduce the number of poor people who receive help paying their rent in New York and other large cities across the country, city and state housing officials said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: As Russia Seethes, NATO Prepares to Grow; Shared Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAY, HELEN P.
description: MAY-Helen P. Of Mill Neck, LI on February 28, 1998. Beloved wife of the late George W., Jr. Devoted mother of Derrice C., Douglas H., Marshall D. and the late George W., III. Cherished sister of Marshall D. Payn. Loving Nana to Elizabeth Anne. Active in her church, in her community, in her life. Mom, we will miss your love, energy, strength and enthusiasm for life. Visitation Dodge Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, on Thursday, from 5-8 PM. Service at St. John's of Lattingtown, Friday, 11:30 AM. Donations may be made to Glen Cove Animal Lovers League, P.O. Box 389, Glen Cove, N.Y. 11542.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCK, BAYLI ATAMIAN
description: ZUCK-Bayli Atamian. Born in New York City on August 29, 1994. Died of Tay-Sachs disease on February 28th, 1998, at exactly 3-1/2 years of age in Santa Barbara, California. Beloved daughter of Jeffrey and Erin Zuck and sister of Oliver. Cherished granddaughter of Richard and Helen Atamian and Martin and Natalie Zuck. Adored niece of Barbra Zuck Locker and Penny Zuckerwise, Jill and Mark Hall, and Lori Atamian. First cousin of Ian Hall. Embraced and dearly loved by an extended family of cousins, caregivers and friends. Although her life was brief, Bayli had a profound impact on all who knew her. She will be remembered always. Memorial service Sunday, March 8, 5 P.M., the Plaza Memorial Chapels, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Bayli Atamian Zuck Memorial Fund of the National Tay-Sachs & Allied Diseases Assn, Brookline, Massachusetts.

title: Greening of the Forgotten Islets; Concrete Deserts Bloom as Parks Dept. Thinks Small
description: If New Yorkers notice a traffic island at all, they are likely to see a desolate patch of concrete or asphalt, awash in the fumes and din of passing traffic, littered with whatever the wind left behind.

title: The Chef
description: AS I start my series of eight columns, I want to turn to a dish that not only is one of the most popular in my restaurant during zucchini season but also illustrates a technique that I find invaluable: the toasting of pastas and grains, like pastina, barley or even rice.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Towers That Persist as Showrooms
description: In any given year, there are about 35 to 50 transactions at 1411 Broadway, the premier women's sportswear and swimwear building, involving either new leases, renewals of old leases or adjustments to existing leases.

title: Trash-Station Proposal Greeted by Protests
description: As it prepares to deal with the planned closing of the mammoth Staten Island landfill on Dec. 31, 2001, New York City appears to have reached at least one judgment: sex shops are more offensive than garbage.

title: Computer Sciences Sues to Halt Hostile Bid
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation filed suit yesterday, seeking an injunction against Computer Associates International Inc.'s hostile takeover bid.

title: They Soften Schroeder's Position : Social Democrats Talk Up the Euro
description: FRANKFURT  - A day after Germany's Social Democrats nominated a candidate for chancellor who once recommended that Europe consider a delay of its planned single currency, the party took pains Tuesday to portray itself as a supporter of the euro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHRMAN, HOWARD Z.
description: LEHRMAN-Howard Z. 75, of Fairfield, CT., died March 2, 1998 after a brief illness. He was the son of the late Dr. Philip R. Lehrman and Wanda Lehrman. Survived by his son Philip Charles Lehrman of Stamford, CT, his sister Lynne Lehrman Weiner of White Plains, NY, a nephew Meyer Weiner and two nieces Erica Weiner-Hanley and Dr. Sara Weiner. Graveside services Thursday,March 5, 11 A.M., Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York. Donations may be made to the Bridge Fund, 171 E. Post Road, White Plains, N.Y. 10601.

title: As Russia Seethes, NATO Prepares to Grow; Moving on Start 2
description: To the Editor:

title: Prudential's Policy Sales Off By 27% in U.S.
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, still feeling the effects of several years of criticism from millions of customers who contend they were deceptively sold insurance they did not need, saw sales of new policies in the United States plunge 27 percent last year, according to documents filed with regulators this week.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the grand jury investigation of the Monica Lewinsky question misstated the number of grand jury appearances by Nancy Hernreich, director of Oval Office operations. She has been called twice, not three times.

title: Baruch Is Pledged Record Cash Gift as President Departs
description: Matthew Goldstein, the Baruch College president who has had a magic touch when it comes to fund-raising, will leave behind one more major gift before he leaves for Adelphi University in June: an $18 million pledge from an alumnus, Lawrence Zicklin, and his wife, Carol.

title: Rangers' Wing Gunners Keep Shooting Blanks
description: A defining moment in Kevin Stevens's season occurred in the first period of the Rangers' 1-0 loss to the Buffalo Sabres at Madison Square Garden on Monday night.

title: Superior Is Great. Could Champlain Be, Too?
description: Some lakes are born Great, and some have greatness thrust upon them.

title: Metro Business; Jersey City Tower for Sale
description: Another of the Manhattan-style skyscrapers on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River has been put up for sale.

title: A Town's Last Word to the Ice Cream Man: Quiet!
description: It is as sure a sign of springtime as tulips or the sun itself: ice cream trucks lumbering down streets in towns and cities across America, crooning a mating call of carnival tunes that send anyone under the age of 12 (and, admit it, some older folks) scurrying to catch a creamy taste of heaven.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSHON, DOROTHY H.
description: HIRSHON-Dorothy H. The life of Dorothy H. Hirshon, who passed away on January 29, will be celebrated on Thursday, March 5, at 11:30 AM in the New School's Tishman Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street. Mrs. Hirshon had been on the Boards of the New School for Social Research, Phoenix House Foundation, Carnegie Hall, the National Urban League, the Taconic Foundation, and a number of other institutions and organizations. She also was a two-term member of the New York City Commission on Human Rights in the early 1960's, on the Planning Board of the City of Glen Cove, Long Island, where she lived, and was Chairman of the Hospitality Committee of the United Nations. Speakers will include her family members, friends, and representatives of the organizations she served.

title: So, This Is What the Top Looks Like?
description: THE Champagne was just beginning to work its magic when the maitre d'hotel, brimming with bonhomie, drifted over and delivered the perfect line. ''So, what are we celebrating tonight?'' he asked, spreading his arms expansively. ''Other than life, of course.''

title: About New York; Trying Charm To Tame A Surly City
description: SHAMED into civility by City Hall's harangues, where can a grouch catch some couth? Adults may be too old for the classes in classiness proposed for public school students. And despite its wholesome outpost on the once sleazy streets of Times Square, Disney's arrival has yet to spur people into acting like Chip and Dale in the subway. After you. Oh yeah? After this, buddy!

title: U.S. Insists It Retains Right to Punish Iraq
description: A day after the Security Council stopped short of endorsing an explicit military threat against Iraq, the Clinton Administration defended its stance that the United States has the authority to use force if Iraq does not comply with United Nations weapons inspections.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KENNEDY, ELIZABETH W.
description: KENNEDY-Elizabeth W. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 7 at 10 AM at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 316 East 88 Street. Contributions may be made to the Sarah Wright Atkins Fund, St. Bernard's School, 4 East 98 Street, NYC or St. Christopher's Episcopal Church, Chatham, MA.

title: Officer Was Shot By Police Firearm
description: A Brooklyn police sergeant who was wounded during an undercover drug arrest last week was shot either by an undercover officer trying to assist him or by his own handgun, which went off during a struggle with several suspects, the police said yesterday.

title: Prices Fall for 2d Day as Home Sales Surge
description: Prices of Treasury securities were hammered again yesterday after the Government reported the pace of new-home sales surged 10.3 percent in January, casting more doubt about whether the economy could slow enough to keep inflation benign.

title: Restaurants; Glamour, and a Luxurious New Menu
description: THE woman stands at the top of the stairs. She looks left and right, smiling dazzlingly, as if waiting for the flashbulbs to explode. Then with the deliberate sensuality of Marilyn Monroe, she makes the most of her moment and slowly descends the staircase.

title: Hudson's Bay Revamping
description: The Hudson's Bay Company will close 54 stores and dismiss 4,000 to 6,000 employees as it combines its Zellers chain of discount stores with the newly acquired Kmart Canada Company. Hudson's Bay will close 40 of 112 Kmart stores and 14 of 298 Zellers stores in the next six months. In addition, 59 other Kmarts will be converted to Zellers stores, and 11 Kmarts and one Zellers will be turned into specialty retail stores. Two Kmarts and one Zellers will become part of the Bay chain, Hudson's Bay's flagship stores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, LUCILLE H.
description: LOEB-Lucille H. Of La Quinta, CA. Wife of the late Carl M. Loeb, Jr. Mother of Carl M. Loeb III and Peter K. Loeb of New York City and Constance Cohn of Edmonds, WA. Grandmother of Catherine Benson, George Cohn, Jr., David Cohn, Jeffrey Cohn, Peter Loeb, Jr., Karen Loeb, James Loeb, Alexander Loeb, Dahlia Loeb and Alexandra Loeb. Also survived by nine great-grandchildren. At Mrs. Loeb's request there will no funeral or memorial service but contributions to the National Crime Prevention Council, 1700 K St, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20006 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Late-Day Rally Sends Dow to Fifth Consecutive Record
description: The stock market edged higher again yesterday, despite an early selloff in the technology sector and rising interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COESTER, BERNICE G.
description: COESTER-Bernice G. Of Short Hills. Widow of Colonel Emil H. Coester, on Monday, March 2nd, 1998. Graveside service Fairmount Cemetery, Central Avenue, Newark, New Jersey, on Thursday, March 5th, at 11:30AM. Relatives and friends are invited to attend.

title: Knicks Still Old, and Still in the Young Nets' Way
description: Jeff Van Gundy was asked before last night's game with the Nets whether we would rather coach five aging players short on skill and long on heart, or five young players with amazing athleticism. He smiled and said he was enjoying the group of players he is currently coaching.

title: Off the Menu
description: Sino-Franco-Deco

title: Looking the Macabre Side of Nature in the Eye
description: THE RED HOURGLASS

title: Princeton Surges, Stumbles, Prevails
description: No Ivy League team had stayed within 10 points of Princeton this season. None had weathered the Tigers' sharp shooting and crisp passing. None could contend with their switching defenses.

title: The Fight Over Street Art
description: In pleasant weather the plazas on either side of the Metropolitan Museum of Art fill with 50 or more artists, many of them with work for sale, lending a festive atmosphere to the area. The New York City Parks Department, which controls the spaces, wants to reduce that number to 24 artists. Each artist would pay $25 for a 30-day permit that would be surrendered at month's end to make room for other artists.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''With all due respect to my good friend Senator Leahy, I know the Great Lakes. I've traveled the Great Lakes. And Lake Champlain is not one of the Great Lakes.''

title: XLCONNECT SOARS ON REPORT OF TAKEOVER BY XEROX
description: The stock of Xlconnect Solutions Inc. surged 26 percent yesterday in the wake of a report that the Xerox Corporation could acquire the computer-services provider for as much as $25 a share, or $420 million. The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that a deal could be completed within days. Spokesmen for both companies declined to comment. The potential acquisition of Xlconnect, based in Exton, Pa., is seen as an opportunity for Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., to bolster its efforts to connect digital copiers into office computer networks. About 80 percent of XlConnect's shares are owned by Intelligent Electronics Inc. Shares of Xlconnect climbed $4.50 each, to $21.75. Xerox closed at $89.4375, up 87.5 cents.

title: Loeb Connection
description: Cast as a young woman testifying at the trial of Richard Loeb, who with Nathan Leopold confessed to killing a teen-ager for the thrill of it in Chicago in 1924, JURIAN HUGHES hit the books. Ms. Hughes appears in ''Never the Sinner'' at the John Houseman Theater at 450 West 42d Street; eventually, her producers came across the names of three women Mr. Loeb had gone out with: Sarah, Rachael and Gladys.

title: Heated Debate Is Expected Over Rate for Student Loans
description: Congress has delayed a vote scheduled for today on reauthorizing the $40 billion Higher Education Act, the most important piece of Federal assistance to students, colleges and universities, so that Congress may air intensely conflicting views on interest rates for federally guaranteed student loans.

title: A Cod's Swift Journey From Sea to Plate
description: IT was, as usual, a quiet Saturday afternoon. Sea gulls were gliding through the still air. Cars eased along the streets. People here do not hurry. Except down on the wharf, where all the town's energy seemed to be swirling around the Browne Trading Company. There, inside a small office, Rod Mitchell was feverishly working the phones like a trader on Wall Street.

title: Gilkey Arrested on Alcohol Charge
description: Bernard Gilkey, the Mets' starting left fielder, was arrested early this morning and charged with driving under the influence of alcohol.

title: Big Lead, Low Anxiety
description: There is a board on the wall just to the right of the entrance to the Devils' dressing room that updates the team's season in 10-game segments. In 1995-96, that board was carefully scrutinized every day by the team's personnel during the second half of a season in which the Devils missed the playoffs; the season before, they Devils had won the Stanley Cup. These days, hardly anyone, with the exception of Coach Jacques Lemaire, seems to pay attention to the bulletin board. There is no need for anxiety.

title: 4 Malaysian Institutions Need Financial Aid
description: Malaysia's central bank said yesterday that two of the nation's largest commercial banks -- Sime Bank Bhd. and Bank Bumiputra Bhd. -- and two finance companies needed capital injections to offset increases in bad loans. Sime Bank, the fifth-largest bank, needs 1.2 billion ringgit ($330 million) to meet minimum capital requirements. Another financial institution Rashid Hussain Bhd., said yesterday that it was in talks to buy Sime Bank and merge it with its bank, RHB Bank Bhd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNEILLY SR, HENRY BRANHAM
description: MCNEILLY SR-Henry Branham. Of the Town of Newburgh and Southold, Long Island, who was the President of Micron Clean Uniform Service Incorporated of Newburgh, died Monday, March 2, 1998, at St. Lukes Hospital, Newburgh. He was 61. Survivors include his wife Barbara Ranges McNeilly at home, son Henry B. McNeilly, Jr. of Briarcliff Manor, two daughters, Caroline Boyar of Scarsdale, and Mary Gwynne McNeilly of Manhattan and one brother Custis Wright McNeilly of Newburgh. He is also survived by several nieces and nephews. Visitation will be from 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. at the Coloni Funeral Home, Rt. 9W, New Windsor, New York on Wednesday, March 4, 1998. A funeral mass will be celebrated at St. Patrick's Church, Grand Street, Newburgh on Thursday, March 5, 1998 at 10:00 A.M.

title: Japanese Car Makers Set Cuts in Production
description: A number of Japanese auto makers said yesterday that they would cut domestic output in March because of weak sales in Japan, their biggest market. The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest auto maker after Toyota Motor, will cut output 10 percent compared with March 1997, while the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, Japan's fourth biggest, said it was considering a 9 percent cut.

title: Puddings: Still Microwaving After All These Years
description: FOR years, I championed the microwave oven, which remains one of the most underused and underappreciated appliances in the kitchen. And now, after all that fervent proselytizing, people often come up to me and ask if I'm still microwaving, as if I had had a momentary brain fever and surely, by now, must have recovered.

title: Critic's Notebook; Arresting Images of Innocence (or Perhaps Guilt)
description: The people who need defending on principle are not always the ones you would actually want to defend. They may not be the worthiest people, or the nicest or the wittiest. Often they are mediocre or gross or self-aggrandizing. Think of Larry Flynt, the publisher of Hustler. Or Karen Finley, the performance artist best known for smearing her body with chocolate. Just because they are under siege legally doesn't mean they are worth the trouble of defending on other grounds.

title: Deliverance Is Coming, if You Can Believe It
description: There is enough misunderstanding among five priests and three feminist acolytes of Amelia Earhart, as well as total misapprehensions of each group by the other, to keep you laughing through an hour and a half of Gip Hoppe's ''Savior of the Universe.'' But watch out for the last 20 minutes: the plot abruptly veers into violent recriminations, delusions, a car accident and a fatal misstep on a mountain path. (Or was that a murder?) Members of the audience may feel they are the ones who have slipped off a precipice.

title: UConn Men Riding High Into Tournament
description: Four teams will not have sweaty palms when they walk into Madison Square Garden for the Big East tournament -- they are assured of berths in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. But for other teams, like Miami, which is pressing against the N.C.A.A. bubble, and Seton Hall and Georgetown, which are looking at possible National Invitation Tournament bids, the pressure is on. Playing well is crucial for their post-season aspirations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIBSHUTZ, ESTHER
description: EIBSHUTZ-Esther. On March 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Meyer. Mother of Miriam and Milton Bieder, Naomi and the late Melvin Lazarus. Grandmother of Toby Lazarus and Allan Lichtenberg, Andrea Bieder, Marla and Joel Bieder. Great grandmother of Lauren and Jason Bieder. Funeral services private. Contributions may be made to the Ramaz School, 60 East 78 Street, NYC.

title: Metro Business; Bank in New Jersey To Close Branches
description: Hubco Inc., a banking company in Mahwah, N.J., said yesterday that it may close about 25 percent of the First Union Corporation branches it agreed to buy in New Jersey, Connecticut and New York.

title: Taiwanese Group Prepares to Meet God -- in Texas
description: The members of God's Salvation Church started moving in last summer. They have bought at least 30 houses, all with cash and all within a two-and-a-half-mile radius. At least 150 followers have arrived from Taiwan, with more on their way.

title: WESTERN AUSTRALIA SELLS GAS PIPELINE FOR $1.61 BILLION
description: The government of the state of Western Australia has sold a 930-mile natural-gas pipeline for $1.61 billion to Epic Energy Ltd., a joint venture of units of the United States energy companies the El Paso Energy Corporation and the Consolidated Natural Gas Corporation as well as various Australian interests. The pipeline is linked to offshore gas fields in the northern areas of the Carnarvon Basin.

title: Maybe It's an Ocean
description: When does a merely good lake become great? When Congress says so. In a recent bill reauthorizing the National Sea Grant College Program, Congress also redefined the Great Lakes to include Lake Champlain. The impulse to name a sixth Great Lake came from Senator Patrick Leahy of Vermont, which adjoins Lake Champlain and craves some of the Sea Grant funds that go only to states abutting the oceans or the Great Lakes.

title: Review/Fashion
description: Until just a few years ago, the fashion world looked to Milan not for creativity but for reliability. Paris was the source of inspiration, the style leader; Milan supplied beautifully made suits in fine fabrics, clothes that women would want to wear. Period.

title: Yes, Connecticut Won, But Rutgers Did, Too
description: Redemption.

title: Calendar
description: Cooks and Their Books

title: Releasing the Hidden Powers of Flavor
description: LATELY, we've been experimenting with what we call power packs. They're intensely flavored, inventive mixtures of spices, herbs, oils and other deeply flavored ingredients. Spooned over dishes just after they come off the stove, power packs are so potent that they provide multiple levels of deep flavor, elevating even the simplest dish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, BEATRICE (NEE DUBIN)
description: STEINBERG-Beatrice (nee Dubin). Of Forest Hills, on March 3, 1998, at 74. Attorney, wife, mother, grandmother, sister, friend and advocate for children and women, she will be deeply missed by those she left behind-Samuel, beloved husband of fifty-five years; sons, Lawrence, Paul and Richard; nine grandchildren; and Sylvia Pezas, her only sister. In 1972 she graduated cum laude from Queens College, then worked as Special Assistant to the Secretary of the NYC Board of Education where she was the first woman to be promoted to Assistant Secretary to the Board and retired from that position in 1988. At sixty-four she completed a law degree at Brooklyn Law School, passed the New York State bar, and devoted her practice to representing the ill and incompetent who had no voice of their own. She supported and sustained us all with her love and care. Funeral Thursday, March 5, noon Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Boulevard.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Gates Defends Microsoft In Congressional Testimony

title: This Time, Budget Plans Are Closer
description: Democratic legislators today gave the first firm evidence that as he runs for re-election this year, Gov. George E. Pataki may avoid the rancorous, protracted budget-making of recent years.

title: City Opera Plans 8 New Stagings in 1998-99
description: Twentieth-century opera figures prominently among both the new productions and revivals on the schedule for the New York City Opera's 1998-99 season, Paul Kellogg's second as the company's general and artistic director. Among the eight new productions, which the company announced yesterday, are Carlisle Floyd's ''Of Mice and Men,'' Jack Beeson's ''Lizzie Borden'' and Richard Strauss's ''Intermezzo'' in its first City Opera staging. Among the six returning programs are Janacek's ''Cunning Little Vixen'' and the double bills of Weill's ''Seven Deadly Sins'' and Orff's ''Carmina Burana,'' and Ravel's ''Heure Espagnole'' and ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges.''

title: Doby Again Follows Robinson
description: Larry Doby followed Jackie Robinson by only 11 weeks in helping to break baseball's color barrier, but it took him 36 years to join him in baseball's Hall of Fame. Lee MacPhail, on the other hand, needed only 20 years to join Larry MacPhail as the first father and son to make the Hall.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WALDEN RESIDENTIAL PROPERTIES INC., Dallas, a real estate investment trust, formed a joint venture with Grupe Co., of Stockton, Calif., a residential developer, to acquire two properties in the Sacramento, Calif., area for $47 million.

title: New York Is Tough Market for Magic Johnson's Quest for a Multiplex Site
description: During a 13-year career as a star point guard with the Los Angeles Lakers, Earvin (Magic) Johnson demonstrated time and again his ability to break down the opposing team's defense and score from anywhere on the basketball floor.

title: F.T.C. Votes to Halt Two Big Drug Mergers
description: The Federal Trade Commission voted yesterday to block a pair of proposed mergers among the nation's four largest drug wholesalers that would have created two of the most dominant players in any industry.

title: Plan to Put Crosswalks In Midblock Is Considered
description: In the latest attempt to ease gridlock in midtown Manhattan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was considering a plan that would add midblock crosswalks near two busy intersections and make permanent the pedestrian barricades that are already in place there.

title: As Russia Seethes, NATO Prepares to Grow; U.N.'s End Run
description: To the Editor:

title: AMYLIN PHARMACEUTICALS SHARES OFF 44% ON FAILED DEAL
description: Shares of Amylin Pharmaceuticals Inc. lost almost half their value yesterday after the company announced late on Monday that Johnson & Johnson was withdrawing from a collaborative agreement to develop a new diabetes drug, Pramlintide. Amylin, a biotechnology company based in San Diego, also reported yesterday a fourth-quarter loss that was greater than Wall Street expectations. The company plans to reduce its work force by about 25 percent to insure that it has sufficient cash to operate for another year. Shares of the company fell $2.25, or 44 percent, to $2.8125, in Nasdaq trading of almost 3.1 million shares.

title: Metro Business; Oxford in Medicare Talks
description: Oxford Health Plans of Norwalk, Conn., is talking with at least one hospital chain about changing the way it pays for services for Medicare patients, an official for North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System said yesterday.

title: As Russia Seethes, NATO Prepares to Grow; Worries About Germany
description: To the Editor:

title: Gates, on Capitol Hill, Presents Case for an Unfettered Microsoft
description: In his first testimony before Congress, William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, delivered a spirited defense of his company's business practices today and portrayed Microsoft as the standard- bearer of the nation's high-technology economy.

title: Woman Will Be Yankee Executive
description: Kim Ng, the director of waivers and records for the American League, has agreed to become assistant general manager of the Yankees, according to several A.L. officials.

title: Bond Takes Credit
description: Question: How did the actor who personified ''Bond, James Bond'' end up with a producer's credit for YASIMA REZA'S new play ''Art''?

title: KEY SENATE PANEL PASSES RESOLUTION TO EXPAND NATO
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted overwhelmingly today to reshape the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, founded in 1949 to stop the spread of Communism in Europe, by adding three former foes, Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about a concert by the Berlin Symphony Orchestra on Friday night at Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College misidentified the Beethoven piano concerto performed. It was the Third, not the Fourth.

title: Once a Fear Beyond Fear Itself
description: ''My name is virus poliomyelitis,'' intones a cultivated, sinister male voice, as a camera pans over fair-weather clouds from which a hollow shadow emerges carrying the silhouette of a crutch. ''I consider myself quite an artist, a sort of sculptor,'' the voice continues. ''I specialize in grotesques, twisting and deforming human bodies. That's why I'm called The Crippler.''

title: TV Notes; Life and Death In the Sweeps
description: In the special television ratings periods known as sweep periods, some verities never change.

title: Food Stuff
description: A Business Grows Up: Sarabeth's Moves to Chelsea

title: Temptation; Creamy Pasture-Fresh Tastes From the Old Sod
description: IRISH farmhouse cheeses, buttery and handmade, usually don't travel far off the island. But a collection of eight varieties arrived last week at Murray's Cheese Shop in Greenwich Village. Some are aged, and some are young. They are made from goat's, sheep's and cow's milk, and each one has a family history, as well as a distinctive taste. In all cases, the taste is clean and amiable, an Irish green pasture taste.

title: Martin Is Stunned By His Celebrity
description: Surveying the 150 news media representatives waiting to talk to him yesterday in Austin, Tex., Casey Martin considered his new-found celebrity and said: ''It's a zoo. I'm flattered and grateful, but all this attention is a bit overwhelming.''

title: Pre-Game Show Expands to 2 Hours
description: Is two hours too much for a football pre-game show? That used to be the length of Super Bowl pre-game shows, but ESPN, which expanded ''N.F.L. Countdown'' from one hour to 90 minutes in 1995, will stretch it to two hours starting Sept. 6 at 11 A.M.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: UConn Isn't Ready to Give Up Its Crown
description: It wasn't easy, and for much of the game it did not look as if it would happen. But Connecticut, a team that has been to the women's basketball wars year after year and has succeeded at the highest level, fought off a young, aggressive Rutgers team tonight and won, 67-58, for its fifth consecutive Big East championship.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: TV Notes; Beating the News
description: For the first time in Nielsen-recorded history, the most-watched program at 11 P.M. in the New York area was not a newscast.

title: A Dream of Glory. Penn Station's, That Is
description: PHILIP K. HOWARD grew up as a minister's son in the hills of Kentucky, which he says was a lot like living in the Bible. There were floods, there was typhoid, and in 1958, when he was bitten by a rabid cat, the vaccine had to be flown in by the state police. So he can still recall his wonder when he arrived at Pennsylvania Station, the glorious colossus then under destruction. It was 1963, and he was 14.

title: Man Accused of Keeping 2 Men Captive
description: A Harlem man was arrested yesterday on charges that he held two mentally retarded men in virtual captivity for several years, stole their government benefit checks and beat them into submission, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANYAEGBUNAM, AKOLISA M., M.D.
description: ANYAEGBUNAM - Akolisa M., M.D. The Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Women's Health of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine/Montefiore Medical Center is mourning the untimely passing of our beloved friend and colleague, Dr. Akolisa Anyaegbunam. ''Dr. Akolisa'' or ''Aki'', as he was affectionately known has been a member of our clinical family since 1981 when he first came to the Medical Center as a resident-in-training. Over the past sixteen years he advanced through his academic and scientific accomplishments culminating in his promotion to the rank of Full Professor at the Medical School. In 1997, he was appointed Clinical Chair of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Women's Health at the North Bronx Healthcare Network, encompassing Jacobi Medical Center and North Central Bronx Hospital. He was also the Co-Director of the Department's Division of Maternal-Fetal Medicine, PastPresident of the Bronx Ob/Gyn Society, an Officer in District II of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, and a member of many regional and national societies including the National Medical Association, the Society of Perinatal Obstetricians, and the Society for Gynecologic Investigation. Dr. Akolisa was a devoted and highly-skilled physician, a prominent educator, a prolific author, and a respected and inspiring leader of the medical community throughout the country. His students, residents and colleagues are his legacy. Aki had an uncanny ability to endear himself to everyone who had the privilege of working with him. Countless numbers will grieve his premature loss. Irwin R. Merkatz, M.D., Professor and Chairman, Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Women's Health

title: Executive Changes
description: CONSOLIDATED EDISON CO., New York, named J. Michael Evans president and chief operating officer. He was previously executive vice president for customer service.

title: Vernon Jordan's Testimony Is Expected to Hasten Close Of Inquiry Into Alleged Affair : Clinton's Friend Remains 'Cool' In Grand Jury Questioning
description: WASHINGTON  Vernon Jordan, one of President Bill Clinton's closest friends and a central figure in the allegations that Mr. Clinton sought to cover up a sexual relationship with a young woman, testified Tuesday before a grand jury here, and his lawyer said the powerful lobbyist was "fine, cool" and eager to tell the full truth.

title: Starr Subpoenas Notes and Case Files of Lewinsky's Former Lawyer
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, has subpoenaed the notes and case files of a former lawyer for Monica S. Lewinsky, an unusually aggressive move that is stirring alarm among some defense lawyers.

title: Ex-Top Soldier Takes Stand in Court-Martial
description: After a month of testimony at his court-martial here, Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney took the stand today, defending his relationship with his accusers as characteristic of his leadership style of intensely personal interaction with soldiers.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, RABBI PESACH
description: SOBEL-Rabbi Pesach. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. He served as educator in congregations in Cincinnati, OH and Spring Valley, NY. At the time of his death he was a teacher at the Prozdor of Boston Hebrew College and Rabbi of the South Area Solomon Schechter Day School in Stoughton, MA. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Suzanne, children Uri, Ilana, and Shira Mercado, and to his sister, Edith, and to his brotherin-law, our colleague, Rabbi Harold (Suzette) Kushner.

title: Smith Ponders Objectivity
description: Dean Smith said he was a nervous wreck before last Saturday's North Carolina-Duke rematch. Smith told Bill Guthridge, his successor as coach of North Carolina, that he might go to a matinee movie and watch the game on tape.

title: HINDU PARTY HAS A STRONG SHOWING IN INDIAN ELECTION
description: Leaders of the main Hindu nationalist party today demanded the right to form India's next Government after nearly complete returns showed the party had made its strongest electoral showing ever.

title: Criticism of Basketball Record Is About Integrity, Not Gender
description: To the Editor:

title: Trenton Alters School Aid For Districts
description: The Whitman administration told school districts today how much state aid they would get later this year, almost two weeks after discovering that millions of dollars in state aid had been assigned to the wrong school districts under a new formula.

title: Lucille Loeb, 92, Board Member Of the Crime Prevention Council
description: Lucille H. Loeb, a board member of the National Crime Prevention Council and a leading supporter of the Visiting Nurse Service, died on Sunday at her home in La Quinta, Calif., her family said. She was 92.

title: The Web That Widened From Whitewater
description: The mandate was relatively broad when Kenneth W. Starr, a former Solicitor General, took over as Whitewater independent counsel in August 1994: investigate the tangle of questions arising from the real estate and business dealings of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton in Arkansas in the 1980's. But that inquiry was expanded several times and came to include new areas of inquiry, some unrelated to Whitewater, each with its own parade of witnesses. After nearly three and a half years, two criminal trials and grand juries in Little Rock, Ark., and Washington, Mr. Starr has secured three convictions and 12 plea bargains. He has spent well over $25 million. Below is a summary of the Starr investigation so far. MONICA BORKOWSKI

title: BAKER HUGHES AGREES TO ACQUIRE ASSETS OF BIT COMPANY
description: Baker Hughes Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the assets of the Western Rock Bit Company, a privately held Canadian bit distributor, for $30.8 million. Baker Hughes, based in Houston, provides products and services for the oil, gas and process industries. Western Rock, based in Calgary, Alberta, has been the exclusive licensee and Canadian bit distributor for Baker Hughes's Hughes Christensen unit. Western Rock will be operated as a separate division of the Hughes Christensen Company, which supplies roller cone and drill bits, Baker Hughes said.

title: Budget Group Seen in $250 Million Deal for Ryder Trucks
description: Budget Group Inc., the owner of Budget rental cars, is expected to announce today that it is buying Ryder TRS Inc. for about $250 million in an effort to reduce its exposure to the price wars in the rental car industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUIGLEY, MARGARET (NEE BREHENY)
description: QUIGLEY-Margaret (nee Breheny). Beloved wife of Charles. Loving mother of Robert and Gerard. Dear sister of Mary and Helen. Loving grandmother of Jeanne, Michael and Caroline. Reposing at Castle Hill Funeral Home, 1528 Castle Hill Avenue, Bronx, New York, Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday, 9:30 AM, at St. Helena's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWNDES, JOSEPH R.
description: LOWNDES-Joseph R. Of Forest Hills, N.Y. On March 2, 1998 at age 96. Devoted husband of the late Rose Newman. Beloved son of the late Thomas F. Lowndes and Mary G. Renn. Dear uncle of Charles F. Mansfield, Sr. and Charles Lowndes. Cherished by Mary Glass, Patricia Phelan, Stewart Newman, Joseph Goldman and many grand nieces and grand nephews. Worked, for many years, for Republic Aviation and for the New York City Board of Education. Friends may call Thursday, 9-10AM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Avenue, New Hyde Park, New York. Funeral Mass Thursday, 10:45AM at Saint Anne's R.C. Church, Garden City, New York. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: As Russia Seethes, NATO Prepares to Grow; Fuel for Nationalism
description: To the Editor:

title: St. Bruno Journal; The Babies of Quintland Now: Broke, and Bitter
description: They are no longer as hard to tell apart as when they were children, dressed in different colors and forced to wear name tags so tourists at Quintland could identify them. Cecile Dionne's face is now a bit fuller than her sisters'; Annette's is somewhat sharper and Yvonne's more drawn.

title: Judge Says Police Can Set Ticket Quota
description: A state judge on Monday upheld the right of police departments to set quotas for the number of tickets officers must write, if the numbers are reasonable, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, WALTER
description: LEVY-Walter. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Walter Levy, a generous and ardent supporter of UJA-Federation. He was a dedicated leader and cherished friend of the Long Island Jewish community who served as Chair of our Rockville Centre Community Campaign, and as a member of our South Nassau Cabinet. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife, Beatrice; his 2 sons, Peter and Ronald; and his 2 grandsons, Jacob and Benjamin. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Martin Rosenman, Chair, Long Island Cabinet Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICH, LEGIA
description: REICH-Legia. Congregation Kol Ami of White Plains records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member, and conveys sincere condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Mark Hershey, President

title: Bronx Man Recounts Abuse By Police in Mistaken Raid
description: Sitting amid shards of glass in his bullet-ridden apartment, a Bronx man whose home was mistakenly raided by the police accused officers yesterday of kicking and beating him and using a racial epithet as they shouted, ''Where are the drugs?''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: New Peril in India
description: India is once again entering a delicate and dangerous political period. After another tumultuous campaign, the main Hindu nationalist party has fallen just short of a parliamentary majority, but still won more seats than any other party. Whether it will be able to form a government, or even be invited to do so by President K. R. Narayanan, is an open question. As competing factions seek to round up majorities, the clash of ideologies and jockeying over spoils in the next few days will probably test India's stability and cohesion.

title: Critic's Notebook; Cauliflower: From Dowager to Debutante
description: I HAVE always thought of cauliflower as something in the ''eat your vegetables'' category, the sort of fodder that makes you feel virtuous. You eat it only because it's so good for you.

title: As Russia Seethes, NATO Prepares to Grow; Balkan Collapse?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICH, CARY
description: REICH-Cary. On March 3rd. Beloved husband of the late Karen Eisenstadt. Son of Etta and the late Marvin. Father of Jeremy. Brother of Michael and Wayne. Services Thursday 12:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations can be made in Cary's name to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, NY, NY 10021.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the listing of new equity issues in Business Day on Monday, by MCM Corporatewatch, included an outdated reference to Brylane Inc. The company, which filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Feb. 18 to offer seven million shares, dropped those plans after Pinault-Printemps-Redoute S.A. of France agreed on Feb. 20 to buy 40 percent of the company.

title: Albanians Bury 24 Villagers Slain by the Serbs
description: A red Mercedes truck rumbled today past a yard that was filled with distraught women sitting on wooden planks set on concrete blocks and unloaded its cargo of 14 mutilated corpses in a farm shed.

title: Balance Throughout The Land
description: Northeastern's two victories over No. 4 New Hampshire last week give credence to the premise that many of these teams are interchangeable this season: if they played one another 10 times, the accounting would be 5-5.

title: INSIDE
description: Accused Soldier Testifies

title: A First for Michelin Guide: One Chef Wins Six Stars
description: LAST year at this time, the cynics were smiling their smug smiles and saying, ''I told you so,'' when the red Michelin Guide, France's restaurant report card, was published. It punished Alain Ducasse for his supposed hubris in opening an elaborate Paris restaurant bearing his name while still trying to run another three-star establishment, Louis XV in the Hotel de Paris in Monte Carlo.

title: Daiwa Unit in U.S. Settles Stock Charges
description: Daiwa Securities' United States unit agreed today to pay a $100,000 fine and $590,000 in restitution to settle allegations it overcharged American customers trading Japanese securities on the Tokyo and Osaka Stock Exchanges.

title: Social Workers Evaluate Victimized Retarded Men
description: Two mentally retarded men who the police say had been held in virtual captivity over the last several years by a roommate were assessed by city social workers yesterday as the man accused of tormenting them sat in jail awaiting trial.

title: Ex-Nazi Is Seized; Accused of Gunning Down 500 at Maidanek
description: German prosecutors today announced the arrest of a suspected Nazi war criminal accused of a catalogue of murders, including his killing of 500 camp prisoners, mostly Jews, during a systematic massacre gruesomely code-named ''Operation Harvest Festival.''

title: In Software Sleight of Hand, Video Ghosts Rise
description: I HAVE the original arcade version of Atari Missile Command playing on my PC. It is running on Mame (multiple arcade machine emulator), a piece of software that mimics the operating system of a coin-operated cabinet so old arcade games will play on your computer like ragtime scrolls through a player piano. The games think that they are running on a refrigerator-size machine in 1982, even though they are stored on your hard drive in 1998.

title: Dow Ends Hot Streak and Fears About Asia Reappear
description: The stock market took a break from its record-setting run yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 45.59 points, to 8,539.24. The Dow had set five highs in a row.

title: Income Holds Steady At Cadbury Schweppes
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C.'s implied second-half profit was little changed as a surge in United States sales of Dr Pepper soft drinks offset a slowdown in revenue from chocolate. Net income was $:219 million ($350 million), compared with $:220 million a year earlier, based on extrapolation from Cadbury's annual and first-half figures.

title: Spring Directions; Striking Gold With Grand Economy
description: GREAT style never comes on like gangbusters. This spring, more than ever, subtle refinement is the key to fresh interiors.

title: First Union to Acquire Money Store for $2.1 Billion
description: The First Union Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Money Store Inc. in a $2.1 billion stock swap that creates the largest home-equity lender in the country. The deal also promised to bring a measure of conservativism to the lower end of the consumer finance industry, which had been hammered over the last year by earnings problems related to overly optimistic accounting practices.

title: Spring Directions; Out of the Blues, New Cool Rooms
description: Nothing reveals vistas like a voyage.

title: Stumble on the Road to Market; Haste Makes Problems for Creator of Alzheimer's Test
description: For the last two years, a small Maryland company has been holding out hope that its simple test can help doctors rule out Alzheimer's disease in their patients.

title: Shanghai Journal; Behind a Great Wall of Reticence, Some Sex Toys
description: In China, the guiding principle on sex has long been a studied discretion. But Liu Dalin says it is just plain silly that most Chinese are uncomfortable with public discussion of such a vital part of life. So he opened the Shanghai Sex Museum, where he displays his private collection of several thousand sex-related historical objects.

title: Drunken-Driving Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip Johnson Geometry In an Advertising Wrapper
description: Philip Johnson is back, with yet another plan for Times Square. This is the fifth proposal Mr. Johnson has prepared for this location since 1983, when he unveiled his scheme for four gigantic towers designed to straddle what was then a bedraggled Crossroads of the World.

title: House Panel Passes Constitutional Amendment on School Prayer
description: The House Judiciary Committee today approved an amendment to the Constitution that would explicitly allow prayer in public schools, religious symbols on Government property and tax dollars for private religious schools.

title: Gregoris Staktopoulos, 88; Imprisoned in Death of George Polk, a Reporter in Greece
description: Gregoris Staktopoulos, a Greek journalist who spent a decade in prison in connection with the murder of George Polk, the distinguished CBS news correspondent, in northern Greece in 1948, died on Saturday while being taken to the Evangelismos Hospital in Athens.
