He was 88 and had lived in Athens since being released from prison in 1961.

title: HARSCO TO BUY FABER PREST FOR $95 MILLION IN CASH
description: The Harsco Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Faber Prest P.L.C., which handles waste for the steel industry, for $95 million in cash as it continues to expand its international industrial businesses. Harsco, an industrial-services and manufacturing company in Camp Hill, Pa., said its Heckett Multiserv subsidiary would pay about $8.20 for each Faber Prest share. Harsco has announced two other acquisitions in the last three months: the Chemi-Trol Chemical Company for $46 million, to build its steel pressure tank business, and the EFI Corporation, a composite-cylinder business, for $7.23 million.

title: DNA Test Absolves Sam Sheppard of Murder, Lawyer Says
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Harassment Law Under Siege
description: For centuries, sexual harassment was considered ''just life.'' That changed in 1986, when the Supreme Court recognized sexual harassment in the workplace to be a form of sex discrimination. In 1992, the Court extended this recognition to sexual harassment in schools. Since then, this law has intervened in the traditional male prerogative of sexual access to women who are men's subordinates in a hierarchy, as most women are. Yesterday, the Court held that male victims have the same rights against male perpetrators as women have.

title: Excommunicated Priest Is Reunited With Vatican
description: It was a year ago that the Vatican announced its remarkable judgment in the case of the Rev. Tissa Balasuriya, finding the Sri Lankan priest, then 72, guilty of heresy for his radical views on salvation and the Virgin Mary, and declared him excommunicated from the Roman Catholic church.

title: Public Eye; New $50 Bill: Grant's Tomb
description: ''IT looks like Monopoly money,'' said Rosemarie Robinson, a clerk at Hudson United Bank in Montclair, N.J. ''It just doesn't look real.''

title: Profit at Thomson-CSF Soars as Exports Surge
description: Thomson-CSF, Europe's largest military electronics company, said second-half profit almost quintupled as it benefited from a capital gain and as exports outpaced sales within France for the first time. Second-half profit rose to 1.66 billion francs ($276 million) from 349 million francs while full-year net almost tripled, to 2.12 billion francs.The company raised its dividend 30 percent, and its stock jumped 15.8 francs, to 229.3 francs.

title: It Takes a Child to Raze a Village
description: DEEP in the dungeons beneath the medieval village of Tristram, a digital alter ego -- a pumped-up ax-wielding warrior that the player has named Deathmaker -- is in peril. A pair of horned, fire-breathing demons are in hot pursuit. But as Deathmaker runs down a passageway, he wheels suddenly and -- swook! swak! -- deftly lops off the heads of the cyber demons. Cool! Another 100 points for Deathmaker.

title: 'Cute Little Girl' Who Likes to Blow Things Up
description: BRIDGET FITZGERALD prides herself on three carefully acquired skills: Japanese, which she taught herself before entering college; the viola, which she has mastered sufficiently to earn a full scholarship to Juilliard, and Quake, a computer game in which she expertly blows things up.

title: As Long as Money Talks, Justice Won't Be Equal; Defenders' Hands Tied
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Battle, Israel President Is Re-elected
description: The Israeli Parliament re-elected Ezer Weizman today to a second five-year term as President after an unexpectedly charged campaign for a largely ceremonial office that is supposed to be above the political fray.

title: Plugging a Leak
description: To House & Home:

title: Clinton Hinted Jones's Motive In Visit at Hotel
description: In a deposition he gave in January in the Paula Corbin Jones sexual misconduct case, President Clinton seemed to suggest that if Ms. Jones visited him in his hotel room in 1991, it could have been at her request.

title: C.I.A. Tutors Palestinians in Tricks of Trade
description: With Israel's knowledge, the Central Intelligence Agency has been training the security forces of the Palestinian Authority in the arts of espionage, information-gathering, interrogation and other techniques of the trade, American officials say.

title: Suit Charges Ford Profited By Nazi-Era Forced Labor
description: A lawsuit filed yesterday in Federal court in Newark accuses the Ford Motor Company of having profited from the forced labor of thousands of civilians at a truck factory of its German subsidiary during World War II.

title: Metro Matters; Principles, Privacy, Cameras in the Park
description: EVER since the co-op board installed the video cameras in his building on Central Park West, Norman Siegel has been an unhappy man. Not only is there the indignity of being watched while you pick your nose waiting for the elevator, the board has also put a camera in the laundry room.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Making Books; Common Sense: No Offense
description: Why is anyone blown away with surprise by what Rupert Murdoch does? Why the rage on both sides of the Atlantic that HarperCollins, the book publishing company owned by Mr. Murdoch, canceled publication of a book that would offend China? Indeed, when did book publishing become a symbol of moral luminescence?

title: Pataki Urges New Sanctions For Workfare
description: Seeking to further tighten the state's welfare laws, Gov. George E. Pataki is pushing for new rules to allow local governments to cut cash grants to entire families, including children, when a parent refuses to work in exchange for benefits.

title: Dream Pond Reverie
description: To House & Home:

title: Mets' Yoshii, in Debut, Leaves the Gate Smartly
description: Masato Yoshii used a horse racing metaphor today to describe how he hoped his first major league season in the United States would turn out. The metaphor may well be fitting, even if his translator, Kota Ishijima, could not help laughing at the difficulty he was having in translating it into English.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Feb. 17 about Dewi Sukarno, the widow of President Sukarno of Indonesia, described her years with him and her life since then. It said that at the time she met him, in Japan in 1959, she was a geisha. That description was based on British and American newspaper reports over the last decade, which accord with accounts in two Indonesian books. Those references describe her as a geisha or a nightclub hostess.

title: Ruination Of a Prefix
description: IN the past, computer experts have taken a kind of perverse pride in their ''monitor tan,'' a pallor that comes from staying inside and staring at the screen. Not a skin tone that would seem likely to appeal to cosmetics makers. But cyberspace, cybersex and, in fact, the prefix ''cyber'' itself are apparently now bankable, at least as far as Chanel is concerned.

title: Court-Martial Shows Calls By Sergeant and an Accuser
description: Under cross-examination in his court-martial, Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney did not falter today in insisting that he had not made sexual advances toward subordinates.

title: In Trenton, Progress on Special Education Code
description: The State Board of Education today moved closer to a final version of new rules defining which students will be included in special education programs, which now cover 15 percent of all students in the state. State officials vowed that the new rules, expected to be completed next month, will not exclude any children now served by the program.

title: As Long as Money Talks, Justice Won't Be Equal; Middle-Class Inequity
description: To the Editor:

title: Seton Hall Falls Short by 5 Extra Minutes
description: Seton Hall had enough to send the game into overtime, but the Pirates did not have enough to close the door on Boston College. The Eagles survived an endurance test that began last night and ended early this morning at Madison Square Garden, defeating Seton Hall, 97-87, in the first round of the Big East tournament.

title: $3,000 Reward Offered For Information in Death
description: On Jan. 24, as many as 200 people were at a birthday party at the Holiday Inn here when a gun battle erupted, killing one young man and wounding three others. But among the scores of partygoers interviewed by the police, including the victims, none admitted seeing what happened.

title: Arts Abroad; Cuban Jazz on the March, but With a Canadian Beat
description: As the snow piles up on the streets of Toronto, billboards that show off the beaches and sun-swept plazas of Cuba suddenly seem to be everywhere. Hundreds of thousands of Canadians visit Fidel Castro's island fortress every year, and some do business there, even if it means risking the wrath of Uncle Sam.

title: In the Service of a Warrior Princess
description: THE syndicated television show ''Xena: Warrior Princess'' had its debut on the airwaves in the fall of 1995, arguably about the same time the popularity of the Internet began to explode across America, and the two entities have been intertwined ever since.

title: HIGH COURT WIDENS WORKPLACE CLAIMS IN SEX HARASSMENT
description: In an important sex discrimination case, the Supreme Court ruled today that Federal law protects employees from being sexually harassed in the workplace by people of the same sex.

title: A Computer Chip Gives a Globe a Digital Voice
description: SOME things are improved by digital technology. Some are just gussied up. Arguably, global-positioning software in car dashboards and 3-D atlases on desktop computers are leaps and bounds ahead of flat paper maps. But then there is the globe, that multicolored sphere that you can hold, grasping the shape of the world.

title: Russia Names Atomic Chief, And the U.S. Is a Little Wary
description: Even before he was appointed Russia's Minister for Atomic Energy today, Yevgeny Adamov had caught Washington's attention.

title: Where to Check That Plato Quotation
description: ANTHONY BEAVERS recently went searching on the Internet for punditry on Plato. The result proved all too daunting: 44,000 related Web sites, including numerous references to ''a suburb of Chicago and the Spanish word for plate,'' Professor Beavers lamented.

title: Tony Blair's Millennium Dome
description: Last week Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain unveiled plans for some of the contents of the $1.24 billion Millennium Dome, now being built on the site of an abandoned gas plant in Greenwich. The Dome is scheduled to open on Dec. 31, 1999 -- one day or 366 days before the new millennium begins, depending on your calendrical point of view. The location was chosen partly because it straddles the prime meridian -- zero degrees longitude. Never mind that the primacy of the prime meridian has nothing to do with when the day begins or that the millennium will have spread over half the globe before it reaches Greenwich.

title: Filling a Technology Need
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Recognizing Same-Sex Harassment
description: Congress may not have been thinking about workplace harassment involving people of the same sex when it approved Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. But as a unanimous Supreme Court held yesterday, the statute's wording that outlaws discrimination ''because of sex'' is broad enough to cover such cases.

title: Replacing Stolen Data
description: To the Editor:

title: ITT INDUSTRIES TO SELL ITS FLUID MEASUREMENT DIVISION
description: ITT Industries agreed yesterday to sell its Barton fluid measurement unit to Barton Instrument Systems L.L.C., as it focuses on making pumps and valves. Terms were not disclosed. The Barton unit, which makes devices that measure liquids and gases, was put up for sale in October by ITT Industries, based in White Plains. Barton Instrument Systems, which makes process measurement instruments and systems mainly for the oil and gas industry, and is an affiliate of American Commercial Holdings Inc. of Lexington, Ky., had $78 million in sales last year.

title: Garden Notebook; Flower Show: Panoramas From France
description: ''IS there a place from which we can look down?'' Michel Racine of the French National School of Landscape at Versailles asked, as he entered the 1998 Philadelphia Flower Show, where the theme is ''La Passion du Jardin.'' It was a very French question, since classically French gardens are meant to be viewed from above. But then this year's Philadelphia Flower Show is a very French affair.

title: Israel Urges U.S. to Keep Peace Plan Quiet, but It's Already Out
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has begun an intense campaign, deploying Israeli officials and lobbyists to prevent the Clinton Administration from announcing a specific proposal for reviving peace talks with the Palestinians.

title: As Long as Money Talks, Justice Won't Be Equal; The Snoozing Bar
description: To the Editor:

title: Underdogs' Day As Georgetown And Rutgers Win
description: Eric Clark gathered his teammates around him before Rutgers started the second half against West Virginia yesterday and shouted ''We can win this thing'' over and over in the huddle. With his bald head gleaming and his voice booming, Clark looked more like a preacher than a player. Actually, he proved to be a prophet.

title: ASYLUMS BEHIND BARS: A special report.; Prisons Replace Hospitals for the Nation's Mentally Ill
description: Michael H. had not had a shave or haircut in months when he was found one recent morning sleeping on the floor of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in suburban Lancaster, next to empty cans of tuna and soup from the church pantry.

title: U.S. Says Man's Death Occurred During Illicit Surgery at a Clinic
description: A patient died during a common liposuction procedure at a Manhattan medical clinic run by a woman who is accused of performing cosmetic surgery without a license, Federal prosecutors said in court yesterday.

title: Briton Wins $1.2 Million Prize for Promoting Interfaith Dialogue
description: Sir Sigmund Sternberg, a British businessman and philanthropist who is a prominent proponent of dialogue between people of different faiths, was named yesterday as the recipient of the world's largest monetary award, the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion.

title: For a Safer New York, Penalize Speeding Taxis
description: To the Editor:

title: Ol' Aches and Pains Has a Satisfying Outing
description: David Cone appeared at the entrance to Joe Torre's office at 8 o'clock this morning, saying that his right ankle felt fine and that he was ready to pitch today.

title: Browser Software Brings the Web Home
description: For computer users devoted to the World Wide Web, their browser -- Netscape or Microsoft Explorer, for instance -- may seem magical, a quick route through mysterious cyberspace to Web sites around the world. Or the browser may be an annoyance at times, clunky and slow, providing frustration instead of instant gratification. But few users have any idea how a browser works. Even though the user seems to be transported to distant locations, the home pages flow into the user's computer. Here is a look at how it really works.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 24 about Mancur Olson, an economist, misidentified the North Dakota hometown of a surviving brother, Gaylord. It is Buxton.

title: Repeat Performer
description: LEONARDO DICAPRIO has become a household name in households that go to the movies, which is a lot of households, considering the billion-dollar success of ''Titanic.'' And this week, he has been a regular at Asia de Cuba, the restaurant on Madison Avenue near 38th Street where the drinks come with little plastic trees sprouting between the ice cubes -- he had dinner there Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. ''The first night, everyone was like, 'Wow, look who walked in,' '' said JEFFREY CHODOROW, an owner of the restaurant. ''The second night, we were saying, 'Look, he's here again.' '' The third night, someone else connected with the restaurant said the feeling was, ''What? He's here again?'' But Mr. Chodorow said, ''Hey, he must really like this place.'' . . . ANTHONY QUINN and his wife of four months, KATHY BENVIN, had lunch at Bellini, the restaurant on East 52d Street. ''She was like, 'You want to make me happy? I want another child,' '' another customer said. ''He said, 'O.K., we'll go home and start tonight.' She was serious, he was laughing.''

title: Noticed and Now Net-Savvy
description: WWW.SLATE.COM

title: Economic Scene; China's good intentions in banking may fall short of goal.
description: NEWS from China confirms that Zhu Rongji, the country's top economy policy maker, is in a hurry to restructure its insolvent state-owned banking system. While China may be partly insulated from the financial chaos sweeping Asia, the crisis has apparently increased Beijing's resolve to deal with the contradictions in its half-socialist, half-capitalist economy before they cause it to stumble.

title: To Save Waterways, E.P.A. Will Tighten Regulation of Big Farms
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will announce on Thursday plans to significantly increase the regulation of some of the nation's biggest farms, treating them much like factories and other industrial sites that produce waste, a Government official said tonight.

title: For the Mayor by the Bay, the Honeymoon Is Over
description: For a while now, San Franciscans have been griping that Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. is taking on imperial airs.

title: Calendar; Exhibits, Lectures
description: Expanding a Museum

title: For a Safer New York, Penalize Speeding Taxis
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Look to Afghanistan for Lessons on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Montgomerie Is Looking For Important Trophies
description: He is one of the world's best golfers, yet Colin Montgomerie is acutely aware of the remaining holes in his resume. He has never won a major. He has never won a PGA Tour event. And while he has dominated the European PGA Tour, Montgomerie looks at his impressive career and still sees unfinished business.

title: N.B.A. Star Who Choked Coach Wins Reinstatement of Contract
description: An arbitrator sharply reduced the landmark punishment of Latrell Sprewell yesterday, ruling that the Golden State Warriors must reinstate the All-Star guard's multimillion-dollar contract and that the National Basketball Association must shorten the one-year suspension he received for choking his coach last December.

title: How to Engage Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: As Long as Money Talks, Justice Won't Be Equal; Affordable Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RICHFOOD HOLDINGS INC., Richmond, will close its frozen foods distribution plant in West Point, Pa., resulting in a fourth-quarter charge, as it reorganizes its frozen foods operations in Pennsylvania.

title: Sports of The Times; Undoing A Reasonable Punishment
description: IT is not open season on employers, as the decision by John D. Feerick in the National Basketball Association-Latrell Sprewell case might lead some to believe. Commenting on Feerick's ruling yesterday, David Stern, the commissioner of the league, was correct in saying that ''you cannot choke your boss and hold your job unless you play in the N.B.A.''

title: Study Issued In Bid to Halt Medicare Cut
description: A new study by the American Association of Retired Persons says that elderly people spend nearly one-fifth of their income on medical care and prescription drugs, even though most have Medicare and some type of private health insurance as well.

title: A Profit Forecast Raises Doubts
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, which is fighting a takeover bid by Computer Associates International Inc., disclosed a forecast of big increases in earnings yesterday in an effort to show that the hostile offer was too low.

title: 2 Ex-Baron Brokers Get Prison Terms
description: Two former brokers at the defunct brokerage firm A. R. Baron & Company were sentenced yesterday to 3 1/3 to 10 years in prison for their role in a stock-fraud scheme that cost investors $75 million.

title: Sprewell Fallout: Support Below, Dismay on High
description: The ruling by an arbitrator to reduce a one-year suspension and reinstate the contract of Latrell Sprewell yesterday intensified the debate over how much authority the league has when deciding the punishment for National Basketball Association players.

title: Report Shows a Strong and Diverse Job Growth for New York City
description: The New York City economy added more new jobs in 1997 than in any year since 1984, the New York State Department of Labor said yesterday.

title: Residential Resales
description: Manhattan

title: LIBRARY; Web Zines: An Immediacy Beyond Paper
description: WHATEVER else it has wrought, the Internet kindles all-or-nothing debates: Are books dead? Is pornography stalking us? Is on-line news responsible or laughable? Does the Net foster literacy or decimate it? The fervor of umpteen public and private exchanges on these meaty topics is perhaps the most telling indicator of the remarkable social force the Net has become in a scant three years.

title: 14 Facing Charges In First U.S. Action On Internet Betting
description: Pursuing the first Federal prosecution of Internet sports gambling, the authorities in Manhattan charged 14 owners and managers of 6 offshore companies yesterday with illegally using interstate phone lines to attract and take on-line wagers from Americans who placed their bets with the click of a mouse.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The answer is now well established: you cannot choke your boss and hold your job unless you play in the N.B.A.''

title: United Natural Foods Deal
description: United Natural Foods Inc. has agreed to acquire the Hershey Import Company, a packager of nuts, seeds, dried fruit and snack items. Terms were not disclosed. United Natural Foods, based in Dayville, distributes natural foods. It had sales of $421.7 million for the year that ended on July 31. Hershey Import, based in Rahway, N.J., had fiscal-year sales of $20.8 million as of June 30.

title: Big Deal; Where 3 Who Held the Stage Once Dressed
description: WHAT becomes a diva most?

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Do It Themselves Garden

title: Corrections
description: Several recent articles about Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern, including one on Friday, misidentified the job once held by Andrew J. Bleiler, who says he had an affair with her. He was a theater technician at the California high school Ms. Lewinsky attended; he was not her drama teacher.

title: Accounts
description: * Bavarian Village International Ski and Golf, Troy, Mich., to W. B. Doner & Co., Southfield, Mich., to handle its account, previously handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $1.5 million to $2 million.

title: At On-Line Auctions, Good, and Raw, Deals
description: IN need of a new personal computer, William Porter decided to deal for one at auction. So he surfed over to eBay, one of more than 150 live auction sites on the World Wide Web where consumers can bid against one another for PC's, stereo systems, collectibles, antiques and just about anything else that if one person wants, another person might want even more.

title: E. J. Beattie, 79, A Specialist In Lung Cancer
description: Dr. Edward James Beattie, a leading chest surgeon, lung cancer specialist and medical educator who was long affiliated with Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and Beth Israel Medical Center, died last Friday at Beth Israel. He was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: NATO Myopia
description: NATO expansion received a strong endorsement this week from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, but the most interesting thing about the Senate's handling of this issue is the ambivalence so many members express. Rarely has such an important matter seemed headed for approval with so little enthusiasm or attention. That should indicate that something is amiss. The United States ought not to take such a fateful step without a compelling justification and fervent conviction.

title: Indonesia's Chief Undercuts Vow to Reform the Economy
description: As a decision nears over whether to infuse billions of dollars in international aid, a close look at the performance of President Suharto shows a pattern of evasions and half-measures on the economic reforms he agreed to six weeks ago.

title: An Envoy to Time
description: What was it like to be the guy from the No. 3 news magazine at the 75th anniversary celebration for the one that pioneered the weekly way, Time?

title: Don't Look to Afghanistan for Lessons on Iraq; Insult to Our Values
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS SELLS STAKE IN VENTURE WITH ACER
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its 33 percent stake in a money-losing joint venture making computer memory chips with Acer Inc., ending a nine-year tie with Taiwan's largest computer maker. Texas Instruments, based in Dallas, sold its stake in Texas Instruments-Acer Inc. to Acer. The companies did not disclose the terms of the sale. Texas Instruments said only that it had recouped its investment. The move is part of Texas Instruments' effort to shed a reliance on memory chips, which have plummeted in price. Texas Instruments-Acer estimated it would post a record loss of $156 million last year. The stock of Texas Instruments rose $1.9375 a share yesterday, to $55.

title: Controversial Decision Costs Judge His Post
description: A Superior Court judge who has been on the bench for 17 years will not be reappointed after his handling of a sexual assault case spurred controversy.

title: People
description: * Mariano Favetto, creative director at Lautrec Nazca Saatchi & Saatchi, Buenos Aires, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., was named chief creative officer of a sibling agency, Conill Advertising, New York, succeeding Luz de Armas, who left.

title: The Search for Truth in the Killing of Newborns
description: To prosecutors, as one of them says on tonight's ''48 Hours,'' it's ''a simple case of murder.'' To defense lawyers, the clients charged with killing their newborn babies are mentally ill. Viewers who see the young women on news and magazine programs, telling of secret pregnancies with deadly consequences, may find it hard to decide whether they are victims or monsters.

title: Gilkey Both Contrite and Effective
description: Bernard Gilkey drove in five runs this afternoon against the Los Angeles Dodgers, a little more than 24 hours after he had been released from an overnight stay in the county jail after his arrest on a charge of driving under the influence of alcohol.

title: Kmart Profits Rose by 14% In 4th Quarter
description: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that earnings before a charge rose 14 percent in the latest quarter as the discount retailer cut costs and sold more Martha Stewart home fashions, Sesame Street children's apparel and other higher-profit goods.

title: Park-Ohio to Spin Off Unit
description: Park-Ohio Industries, a manufacturing and logistics company, said today that it would spin off its logistics unit to shareholders through an initial public offering of stock. Shares of Park-Ohio, based in Cleveland, rose $1.375 each, to $19.75, in Nasdaq trading. The unit will become a separate public company called Integrated Logistics Solutions Inc. Park-Ohio said it planned to file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the spring.

title: New York to Teach Deaf in Sign Language, Then English
description: In what is being hailed as a landmark change in the education of deaf students, the city's only public school for the deaf will be overhauled so that all teachers will teach primarily in a sign language based on symbols and gestures, rather than an English-like sign language based on sounds, or other methods like lip-reading and pointing.

title: Israeli Judges Put Security Above Rights
description: A three-judge panel of the Supreme Court today ended the secrecy of a four-month-old ruling in which it acknowledged and condoned the fact that Israel was holding Lebanese men, some for as long as a decade, solely as a ''bargaining card.''

title: UAL Buys 30 Jets for United From Airbus
description: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, said today that it had ordered 30 planes from Airbus Industrie, giving Airbus a bigger piece of the United fleet and momentum in its battle with the Boeing Company to be the world's largest airplane suppler.

title: Whitaker Fails Drug Test
description: Pernell Whitaker, a former three-time world champion, apparently has failed one stage of a drug test he took last week in New York, putting in jeopardy his fight against Ike Quartey, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, on April 25 in Las Vegas.

title: Deputy Marshal Is Cleared in Shooting of Queens Teen-Ager
description: A Federal agent who shot a teen-ager in the leg last November after mistaking the youth's foil-wrapped candy bar for a gun will not face criminal charges, the Queens District Attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Buys Car Insurer
description: The buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and management of the privately held Bristol West Group said yesterday that they had agreed to acquire Bristol West Group, a nonstandard auto insurer.

title: Spare Look, Thoughtful Style
description: WWW.FEEDMAG.COM

title: Just One Guy Named Moe, and He Ain't Even Here
description: Poor Moe Green. In 1972 this mobster modeled on Bugsy Siegel was rubbed out by the Corleones in ''The Godfather'' with a memorable gunshot through the eye that left his eyeglass lens shattered and bloody. In 1991 Anthony DiMurro resurrected Moe in name only as the titular hook for ''Moe Green Gets It in the Eye,'' a one-act play about a small-time mob guy and his two nephews.

title: Home Theater: Rival Sound Formats Mean Consumer Static
description: THE goal is the clarity of digital sound. So why has the simple -- if expensive -- concept of home theater become so distorted?

title: Tapes and Skeptics
description: To the Editor:

title: Hindu Nationalists Gain Support of Key Regional Parties
description: India's main Hindu nationalist party, Bharatiya Janata, edged closer to forming a new government today as key regional parties began rallying to the nationalists, bringing them closer to a majority in the newly elected Parliament.

title: Stop Protecting Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets' Williams May Be Hurting, but He Won't Tell
description: When Jayson Williams limped off the floor at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, the Nets wondered how they would get along if their All-Star center was forced out of the lineup for a long period.

title: Agency Scales Back Plan To Cut Housing Subsidies
description: Officials at the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development announced a partial retreat yesterday from a budget-cutting plan that officials in New York and other large cities said would have drastically cut the amount of Federal rental help available to poor families.

title: Corrections
description: Several recent articles about Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern, including one on Friday, misidentified the job once held by Andrew J. Bleiler, who says he had an affair with her. He was a theater technician at the California high school Ms. Lewinsky attended; he was not her drama teacher.

title: Our Towns; A Boulevard Leads to Drugs And Death
description: AFTER all that's happened, the petty drug dealers are still hanging out on West Runyon Street and Irvine Turner Boulevard, waiting for the suburban junkies.

title: A Male Muse Lacking Only a Name
description: SPENDING

title: Bound Once More for the Moon, Without the Stressful 60's Cargo; Mini-Series Casts the Mission as the Defining Spirit of a Decade
description: Tom Hanks was just 12 years old in the crucial, difficult year of 1968, but at least one portion of his memories of those times is crystal clear. ''Our world was very, very polarized,'' Mr. Hanks said in a recent interview. ''If you had long hair, you were a good guy; if you had short hair, you were a bad guy. We mistrusted just about anything that had to do with the Government.''

title: Of a New Generation of Guitarists
description: Fans of the classic guitar look back at the late 1970's as a notably more exciting time than the present, and not entirely without reason. Young players worked hard to bring technical standards up to levels listeners expected of keyboardists and violinists; the repertory was bursting with both newly discovered 19th-century works and freshly composed pieces, and concerts and recordings were plentiful. A decade later, when the pace at which guitarists reinvented their style and repertory began to slow, the novelty-seekers in the audience drifted away, and the boom came to an end.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the 1998-99 season at the New York City Opera referred incorrectly at one point to the composer of the opera ''Lizzie Borden,'' one of eight new stagings by the company, and gave an incorrect date for its world premiere. The composer is Jack Beeson, not Carlisle Floyd. The premiere, by the City Opera, was in 1965, not 1976.

title: Press Agent Is Charged With Harassing Trump Family
description: Chuck Jones, who worked as a press agent for Marla Maples Trump and is awaiting a second trial on charges that he stole her lingerie and more than 200 pairs of her shoes in 1994, was arrested yesterday and accused of faxing lewd material to Trump family members and their friends, the authorities said.

title: A Welcome Explanation
description: To the Editor:

title: EVI to Buy Weatherford in Oil-Gear Deal
description: EVI Inc. will buy Weatherford Enterra Inc. for $2.6 billion in stock, they said yesterday in another move by oil-services companies to combine, cut costs and better meet the strong demand for exploration equipment. That demand has persisted despite lower prices for crude oil.

title: Metro Business; Trump to Refinance Debt
description: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts will refinance some of its debt this year in an attempt to reduce its annual interest costs by at least $20 million, Nicholas L. Ribis, the chief executive, said yesterday.

title: Macy's and Bloomingdale's Turn Out the Lights
description: THE lights are dimming, bulb by bulb, in the lamp departments at Macy's and Bloomingdale's.

title: Microsoft, Accused of Trademark Violations, Is Sued in Europe
description: In a lawsuit that raises new questions about the Microsoft Corporation's market power, Palm Computing Inc., a pioneering Silicon Valley maker of a hand-held electronic organizer called the Palm Pilot, is suing Microsoft in Europe, accusing it of trademark violations.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Treasuries End 2-Day Slide as Traders Await Jobless Report
description: The Treasury market managed a mild rebound from its two-day slide yesterday, even as traders remained focused on the February employment report, which will be announced tomorrow.

title: High Stakes In Divorce Case
description: But not a penny for plastic surgery.

title: In America; Meet Mayor Manners
description: Politicians by definition are hypocritical, some more than others. But hypocrisy soars to astonishing new heights when Rudolph Giuliani, the snarling, bullying, hot-tempered Mayor of New York, starts lecturing people on the need to be more civil, more polite, more considerate of one another.

title: As Long as Money Talks, Justice Won't Be Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: The Threats to Mass Transit
description: In agreeing to provide an extra $26 billion for the nation's highways this week without a commensurate increase for mass transit, the Senate has thumbed its nose at a majority of the American population, the nearly 55 percent of all Americans who live and work in more than 40 major metropolitan areas. Boosting the share of spending for roads and bridges without providing a reasonable increase in aid for commuter trains, subways and buses ignores the complexity of mobility in metropolitan America. Moving workers to their jobs depends on a network of decent roads and reliable mass transit. Without rapid transit, many of these metropolises would be parking lots at rush hour.

title: Applause for WebTV
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts and Ideas pages on Saturday about recent scholarly interest in manners referred incorrectly to the role of P. M. Forni in starting the civility project at Johns Hopkins University. He was one organizer; he shared that role with Giulia Sissa, a classics professor.

title: U.N. Chief to Name Special Envoy to Improve Links to Baghdad
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan has decided to assign a special political representative to Iraq to improve lines of communication between Baghdad and the United Nations, the organization's spokesman said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Ease Slightly But Bonds Rebound

title: Gretzky Revives, And So Do Rangers
description: Playing in the Winter Olympics apparently has rejuvenated Wayne Gretzky.

title: Checkmate Line Excels
description: On Monday night it was Eric Lindros. Tonight it is Jason Allison and the hottest line in the National Hockey League. Saturday night it will be Wayne Gretzky and whatever peashooters the Rangers line up with him.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL SEESAWS, ENDS HIGHER. Prices rebounded after initially tumbling on news that Venezuela's oil minister will not attend a March 16 OPEC meeting. April contracts settled at $15.32 a barrel, up 5 cents, after hitting an intraday low of $15.07, the weakest in nearly four years.

title: An Old Barn's Soul Inhabits Twin Peaks
description: THE GOAL -- To design a small family house in San Francisco's hilly Twin Peaks neighborhood as a homage to light and memory: the owner fondly recalled a farm, especially a barn, on this spot in the 1950's, when he and his sister were growing up in a wood-frame house nearby. The quarter-acre site has been in his family since 1937.

title: Panel Rejects Adding Markers to Explosives
description: Because of the large amount of explosives used in this country, it is impractical to put chemical markers into explosive material to deter terrorist bombings, a National Research Council committee said today.

title: Serial Attacks Case Goes to the Jury
description: Closing arguments in the John Royster trial were heard late yesterday afternoon, leaving the jury to decide whether the defendant was a calculating, cold-blooded killer or a man suffering from an uncontrollable mental illness.

title: Bridge; Was It Brilliant or Foolish?
description: Some hands leave a defender bewildered. Did the declarer do something brilliant? Or did he do something foolish that happened to work? The diagramed deal from the Flight A Regional Swiss Team Championship in Hauppauge, N.Y., on Sunday is an example.

title: SARA LEE TO BUY INTIMATE APPAREL UNIT FROM ARISTOTLE
description: The Aristotle Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Strouse, Adler Company women's intimate apparel unit to the Sara Lee Corporation for $21.5 million. Aristotle, based in New Haven, , had sales of $14.4 million in the six months that ended on Dec. 31. Strouse, Adler is Aristotle's sole operating unit. Sara Lee, based in Chicago, is a food and consumer products giant with revenue of $10.2 billion for the six months that ended on Dec. 27. Strouse, Adler will become part of the Sara Lee Intimates division after the transaction closes, which is expected to occur in late spring.

title: L.I. Man Is Seized in Scheme To Smuggle Jet Parts to Iran
description: Federal agents seeking to stop the smuggling of embargoed military hardware to Iran have arrested a Long Island man after they said he tried to ship F-14 engine parts to that country by way of the Netherlands.

title: Silicon Graphics Selects McCann
description: Silicon Graphics in San Jose, Calif., yesterday named McCann-Erickson San Francisco as the first agency to handle advertising for its new Visual PC Group, which will introduce a line of computers. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: Metro Business; Restaurant to Alter Name
description: The Sign of the Dove restaurant, which closed last month on the Upper East Side of Manhattan to make room for an apartment tower, will reopen in mid-Manhattan next year under a slightly different name.

title: Essay; Privilege Proliferation
description: ''He was born to privilege,'' said President Clinton about Franklin Roosevelt, at the anniversary gala for Time magazine, which has been defending him against Newsweek in the Monica wars. But it took Bill Clinton to make ''executive privilege'' a pernicious habit.

title: Matchmaking, or How Conductors and Orchestras Get Together
description: Symphonic matrimony is rarely for life and not always for love. Odd couples abound in the relationships between conductors and the orchestras they direct. Some are marriages of convenience. Others involve a dowry of sorts. For every good coupling there are others one can't quite understand.

title: House Approves Measure on Self-Determination for Puerto Rico
description: In a cliffhanger roll-call, the House tonight passed a bill by only one vote, 209 to 208, that would let Puerto Ricans vote on their island's destiny -- statehood, independence or continued commonwealth status -- a delicate and hotly debated question on the Caribbean island.

title: Libya Partners Dismiss Talk of 'Military' Pipe
description: LONDON  Libya and its British engineering partner dismissed as "fantasy" Wednesday the suggestions of some Western security experts that a huge water pipeline project had secret military uses.

title: Merrill Chief Paid $11 Million for 1997
description: Merrill Lynch & Company paid its chairman and chief executive, David H. Komansky, $11 million in 1997, his first year at the helm.

title: Building Girls Cyber Rooms Of Their Own
description: BRENDA LAUREL says that there was little in her Indianapolis upbringing in the 1950's and 60's to prepare her to create multimedia software for today's techno-savyy, media-literate child.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in Business Day yesterday about an appearance by William H. Gates before a Senate hearing referred incorrectly to comments by James L. Barksdale, president of the Netscape Communications Corporation. In calling for a show of hands to demonstrate that Microsoft had a monopoly, he asked how many of those with personal computers used Microsoft's Windows operating system -- not the company's Web software, Microsoft Explorer.

title: Ham Radio, Version 2.0, for the Silicon Era
description: LIKE millions of people these days, Keith Baker thinks nothing of sending E-mail from his home computer to friends who may live halfway around the world. But his E-mail does not always travel the usual route, down a telephone line and out into that vast maze of glass and copper cables called the Internet.

title: Your Honor, I'm Bored: Let's Change Channels To 'The People's Court'
description: Judge Judy was giving a man on the wrong side of an assault suit her ''if looks could kill, brother, you'd be underground'' stare: ''You were wrong, Mr. Jones. You were angry at the wrong person. You should have been angry at yourself.''

title: Murdoch Blames Staff for Embarrassment Over Hong Kong Book
description: Rupert Murdoch blamed HarperCollins executives today for having ''screwed it up'' by the clumsy way they dropped the publication of a book by Chris Patten, the last British Governor of Hong Kong.

title: Harper's Bazaar is moving to increase ad pages with a new Web site and television campaign.
description: TO stimulate advertising sales and to promote itself and its advertisers, Harper's Bazaar has put up a new World Wide Web site and started its first television campaign since Elizabeth Tilberis was appointed editor in 1992.

title: Fiery Tango, Boiling Dancers
description: The genius of Paul Taylor lies in part in his seeming transparency. On the surface, Mr. Taylor's new ''Piazzolla Caldera,'' the centerpiece of the opening night program presented by the Paul Taylor Dance Company on Tuesday at City Center, is an exploration of the tango as a popular dance form, as cultural history and as music. Even more, however, ''Piazzolla Caldera,'' set to music by Astor Piazzolla and Jerzy Peterburshsky, is a work whose complexities suggest why Mr. Taylor remains such a fresh and important artist after more than four decades.

title: Fraud Ruling Invalidates Miami Mayoral Election
description: Citing ''a pattern of fraudulent, intentional and criminal conduct'' in the casting of absentee ballots, a Florida judge voided Miami's mayoral election today and ordered a new vote to be held in 60 days.

title: MACK-CALI REALTY TO EXPAND OFFICE PROPERTY HOLDINGS
description: The Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, based in Cranford, N.J., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy $450 million of office properties and had secured about $650 million in financing through the sale of stock and debt. The moves will increase Mack-Cali's real estate holdings by about 12 percent and provide it with capital as it seeks to acquire more properties. The acquisitions include the purchase of the Prudential Business Campus in Parsippany, N.J., and the Developer Pacifica Holding Company in Denver. When completed, the transactions will raise Mack-Cali's holdings to 240 properties with 25.8 million square feet, mainly in New Jersey, New York and the Southwest.

title: Veba Chemicals Unit To Acquire Degussa
description: The German electricity supplier Veba A.G. said yesterday that its Huels A.G. chemicals unit would acquire the specialty chemicals maker Degussa A.G., extending Huels's international reach, in a stock swap estimated at more than 5 billion marks ($2.8 billion). Veba paid 2.9 billion marks for a 36.4 percent Degussa stake last May. Degussa's shares rose 4.5 marks, to 99.5, amid expectations that shareholders would be offered a premium.

title: Clinton Aides Spread Data Critical of Starr as Lawyer for G.M.
description: A week after the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, ordered a White House official before a grand jury to account for accusations spread about prosecutors, President Clinton's aides today circulated a batch of material critical of Mr. Starr's performance as a lawyer for the General Motors Corporation in the early 1990's.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Intel Goes, So Goes the Rise in Stocks?
description: Shooting a warning across the bow of the recently revived stock market, the Intel Corporation said yesterday that first-quarter sales would fall about 10 percent below modest predictions it had made less than two months ago.

title: Feerick Comfortable Making Key Decisions
description: He has taught mediation techniques to community leaders from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, and he once asked the former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo where his campaign financing came from.

title: Auto Sales Fell In February, Hurt by G.M.
description: Auto sales dipped slightly in the United States last month, as very weak car sales at the General Motors Corporation offset flat or rising sales at other companies, particularly the Chrysler Corporation and the Korean auto makers, which offered big rebates and other deals on small cars.

title: Formula One Team Revs Up the Computers to Speed Up Race Cars
description: MAGNY-COURS, France  In a sport where the technical regulations change yearly and the cars develop almost daily, there is little mystery why technology has taken a front seat in the manufacture of race cars.

title: New Breed: Snowshoers In Search Of Fitness
description: A different breed of mountain maven has invaded Alpine slopes usually the domain of skiers and snowboarders. The newcomers tend to be individualists, but are known to run in packs. They eschew lift rides, and wear strange clothing, sometimes Lycra tights and thin shirts in the middle of winter. And most noticeable of all, they tend to come out mostly at dusk.

title: State Improves Its Record of Disciplining Doctors
description: New York State has steadily improved the rate at which it disciplines doctors found to be incompetent, negligent, who have been convicted of a criminal offense or have performed other misdeeds, according to a report released yesterday by Public Citizen's Health Research Group, a consumer advocacy group.

title: Pain-Free Computing
description: To the Editor:

title: Barbed and Timely Essays That Call for Seconds
description: WWW.SALONMAG.COM

title: Court Clears Driver Detained for Four Hours
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday overturned the 1994 conviction of a driver who was detained by the state police for four hours before cocaine was found in his car and he was formally charged.

title: Global Efficiency
description: To House & Home:

title: U.S. Rulings Support Plan to Break Up Lilco
description: The breakup of the Long Island Lighting Company took two important steps forward late last night.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Violinists' Insights, Present and Past
description: . . . Formerly Known as Nigel Kennedy

title: Personal Shopper; Opulence Arrives on Orchard Street
description: IT'S not the Orchard Street your grandmother knew. Until a few weeks ago, fabric shopping there was like an adventure in the wilds of a textile jungle, in warehouses strewn with bolts and mill ends. Three new stores have upgraded the area to first class -- would you believe valet parking?

title: Applause for WebTV
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Look to Afghanistan for Lessons on Iraq; Soviet Reformers Won
description: To the Editor:

title: To Avoid Tariffs, Pasta Makers Come to U.S.
description: Edwin L. Artzt drives a Mercedes-Benz sport utility vehicle built in Alabama. So he doesn't see any reason Americans wouldn't eat Barilla pasta made in Iowa.

title: An Uphill Fight for the Life of a Loved One
description: THE doctor met the Moy family at the hospital on New Year's Eve and gave them the bad news: Cindy Moy, 27, the youngest of the three accomplished Moy sisters, had a very aggressive form of leukemia. The disease might be beaten back with chemotherapy, but for Ms. Moy's life to be saved, she would need a bone marrow transplant.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR STRENGTHENS. The dollar rose on optimism that the Government's February jobs report due tomorrow would show further strength, while German joblessness was expected to worsen. In New York the dollar cost 1.8184 marks, up from 1.8096.

title: Virtual Unreality at Urban School; Gates Goes to a Carefully Prepared 6th-Grade Classroom
description: A day after he was hauled before a United States Senate panel and all but accused of plotting to take over the world, the country's richest man had to settle yesterday for commandeering a sixth-grade classroom at a middle school in Washington Heights.

title: Information Potholes
description: Q. When I connect with my 28.8 modem to my Internet service provider or America Online, my computer sometimes says I'm connected at a slower speed. Why does that happen?

title: Animation And Audio Enliven Text
description: WWW.WORD.COM

title: From Metaphors to Miracles
description: The agitated dreamlike pieces of Ginette Laurin for O Vertigo, her experimental dance company in Montreal, are on the untidy side. ''La Bete,'' with which O Vertigo returned to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night, is typical. It is a glorious mess, an outpouring of energetic images whose Goya-esque metaphors take flight toward the fantastic, away from the rational.

title: Archer Daniels Informant Receives a 9-Year Sentence
description: Mark E. Whitacre, the former executive of the Archer Daniels Midland Company who worked as a Government informant in a huge investigation of price-fixing by the company, was sentenced today to nine years in prison for stealing millions of dollars from his former employer.

title: Fred W. Friendly, CBS Executive and Pioneer in TV News Coverage, Dies at 82
description: Fred W. Friendly, the former CBS News executive who was a towering figure in the evolution of news coverage on television, died Tuesday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 82.

title: Newsweek Getting A New Publisher
description: Carolyn Wall, a longtime media executive, is joining Newsweek magazine in New York as publisher -- part of a restructuring of top management announced yesterday.

title: MARCUS CABLE TO DIVEST ITSELF OF TV ASSETS IN 2 STATES
description: The Marcus Cable Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its cable television assets in Connecticut and Virginia to TMC Holdings Inc. for $150 million. The systems serve about 46,000 customers in Connecticut and about 17,000 customers in Virginia. The sale is part of Marcus Cable's plan to divest itself of certain nonclustered cable television systems. Marcus Cable, based in Dallas, is the nation's largest closely held cable-television company and the ninth largest over all, with 1.1 million customers in six United States markets. On Tuesday, the company said it had received offers from potential purchasers. It gave no information about TMC Holdings.

title: Get Them Rewrite
description: Now it's the script that has Chinatown leaders complaining about ''The Corruptor,'' an OLIVER STONE film. Some scenes are scheduled to be filmed there in May. Yesterday, 30 Chinatown leaders gathered at the Fifth Precinct station house to denounce the script, which focuses on a corrupt Chinese officer who patronizes prostitutes, accepts bribes from underworld bosses and gives them advance notice of gambling raids. They also objected to descriptions of gang wars in the script.

title: Betting Money on the Web
description: ''If you can use a mouse, you can place a wager.''

title: C.I.A. Officers, With Israel's Knowledge, Teach Palestinians the Tricks of the Trade
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has been training the security forces of the Palestinian Authority in the arts of espionage, information-gathering, interrogation and other techniques of the trade, United States Government officials say.

title: Daniel Crowley Is Dead at 76; Anthropologist and Partygoer
description: Daniel J. Crowley, an anthropologist who loved parties so much that he devoted his life to attending carnivals, festivals and other folk celebrations in every corner of the globe, died on Feb. 24 while in Oruro, Bolivia, for a Mardi Gras carnival.

title: Deal Will Give A Grand Space To Penn Station
description: Thirty-five years after the old Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan was leveled, Federal officials announced an agreement yesterday to begin converting the landmark General Post Office building on Eighth Avenue into a new train station. They said work could start this summer.

title: Tough Standard on Drunken Driving Is Backed
description: The Senate voted today, 62 to 32, to force states to adopt a stricter definition of drunken driving or risk losing part of their Federal highway aid.

title: Exploring The Soul With Columbus
description: Lust for gold and religious fervor have always been the conflicting primary urges behind human exploration. In Nikos Kazantzakis's play ''Christopher Columbus,'' the Genoan weaver's son has enough of both to discover a dozen new worlds.

title: Jury Weighs Charges Against Jail Guards
description: A jury began deliberations yesterday in the trial of three Union County correction officers charged with abusing and assaulting more than a dozen immigrants seeking asylum who were taken to the county jail after a 1995 melee at a Federal detention center nearby. It marked the end of the eight-week trial and the conclusion of two days of summations.

title: INSIDE
description: A Choice on Puerto Rico

title: Severing Ties to a Second Home; Woman Finds Strength in Family After Her Nightmare at Nebraska
description: Kathy Redmond's dad sobbed as she left for college in late August 1991, in two cars loaded with stereo equipment, stuffed animals and lacrosse sticks. It was the first time she had seen her dad, a former Air Force officer, actually cry, but she was not surprised; Kathy was the baby of the family and among its fourth generation to attend the University of Nebraska. At 50, Bill Redmond still wore his varsity letterman's ring on the same finger as his wedding band.

title: Who Bucks Tide And Chooses Mac?
description: MY list of Insane Temptations to Resist:

title: Administration Decides to Reduce G.I. Force in Bosnia Slightly
description: The Clinton Administration has decided to reduce the number of American troops in Bosnia slightly, even as the NATO peacekeeping force overall remains at 35,000 troops, officials said today.

title: Parenting Pitfalls
description: To House & Home:

title: Closed-Captioning Opposed for 'Springer'
description: Two senators known for crusading against what they call trash television are urging the Secretary of Education to stop using Federal money to underwrite closed-captioning on ''The Jerry Springer Show.''

title: GLOBAL INDUSTRIAL TO ACQUIRE A. P. GREEN INDUSTRIES
description: Global Industrial Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire A. P. Green Industries for $22 a share, or $195 million. Global Industrial, based in Dallas, makes industrial products and operates refractory plants. Global Industrial said that it had purchased A. P. Green, based in Mexico, Mo., in an effort to become a dominant player in the refractory business, which involves the production of heat-resistant ceramic material. Shares of A. P. Green rose $4, or 23 percent, to $21.6875. Global Industrial rose 75 cents, to $16.3125. Global Industrial also said that it would receive $217.5 million from the previously announced sale of its Industrial Tool unit to Cooper Industries.

title: Metro Business; New Food Service for Open
description: The United States Tennis Association said yesterday that it had hired Restaurant Associates, a Manhattan food-service and consulting group, to be the new food service provider at the United States Open tournament in August at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAGODA, STELLA
description: JAGODA-Stella. On March 3, 1998 after an illness borne with courage, dignity and grace. Adored mother of Nita and Sy Savitz and Bette and Fred Weil. Beloved grandmother, great-grandmother and friend. Services Friday, March 6, 11:30AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Thousand-Year-Old Silks, Virtually Gold and Really So
description: A millennium ago, the great chain of caravan cities and shrines called the silk road looped its way across Central Asia, linking China and the Roman Empire. Pilgrims, potentates and artists alike traveled the route. So did material goods, plain and precious, including porcelain, spice and silk.

title: Physical Imagery From a Self-Effacing Poet
description: THE recent announcement that Gov. George E. Pataki has named Sharon Olds the official New York State Poet might be amusing, if one could only summon the image of the Governor sinking into an easy chair to read one of her poems. Human bodies are not welcome this year in American politics, and Ms. Olds has become one of the country's best-known poets by writing about life inside a physical body: the pleasures, the sufferings, the various life-giving angles and fluids.

title: China's Paragon of Corruption; Meet Mr. Chu, a Hero to Some, an Embezzler to Others
description: Chu Shijian is still a hero in this ramshackle town, even though he stands accused of diverting more than $145 million from state coffers, one of the most spectacular cases of corruption in China since the Communist Party came to power nearly 50 years ago.

title: Nurse Contradicts Testimony Of Defendant in Brawley Case
description: The first nurse to treat Tawana Brawley testified today that the teen-ager was normal, healthy and very likely conscious when she was brought by ambulance to a hospital emergency room in 1987.

title: CAMPBELL IN NEGOTIATIONS TO SELL CONTINENTAL SWEETS
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that it was negotiating to sell its European confectionery and distribution business, Continental Sweets, to the Gilde Buy-Out Fund, a Dutch venture capital firm. A possible purchase price was not disclosed. Continental Sweets makes and distributes sugar and chocolate confectionery in Western Europe. In May 1997, Gilde purchased Campbell's Beeck Feinkost gourmet salad and deli products business. Campbell, the food and soup giant, said the proposed sale was part of its 1996 plan to divest itself of $500 million of nonstrategic businesses over two years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROTHSCHILD, JUDITH
description: ROTHSCHILD-Judith. Five years. H

title: S.E.C. pressure on 3Com signals that it might be time to tighten the accounting rules in mergers.
description: WHEN the 3Com Corporation acquired US Robotics last year, the accounting wizardry was at least as impressive as any high-technology product ever produced by either company. When the books of the two companies were combined, two very bad months in the history of US Robotics, a maker of computer modems, vanished into thin air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'URSO, DAVID FRANCIS
description: D'URSO-David Francis. On March 3, 1998. The Boards of Calvary Hospital and Calvary Fund and the Administration of the Hospital express sorrow on the death of the son of their esteemed Fund Director, benefactor and friend, Florence D'Urso. To the entire family, we extend deepest sympathies. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD, Chairman, Calvary Hospital Dennis E. Berberich, Chairman, Calvary Fund Frank A. Calamari, Executive Director/President Michael J. Brescia, MD, Medical Director

title: Politics Aside, Students Still Need Skills; New Math Debacle
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertisers Find a Formula They Like in Auto Racing
description: LONDON  They are sleek and fast. They travel the globe from Melbourne to Monte Carlo, surrounded by models and princes, actors and corporate moguls, and watched by some 460 million avid television spectators. And there are only 22 in each race.

title: A Round of Championship Bantering, Senior Division
description: ''Twilight,'' a class act in a classic genre, finds Paul Newman playing detective amid some uncommonly soigne Los Angeles settings. The film's sleek, unusual locations, including an unfinished Frank Lloyd Wright project in the hills above Malibu, have been artfully chosen, but of course it's the guy in the gumshoes who is the real monument here. At 73, Mr. Newman still has the wisecracking vigor and panache that have always shaped his screen roles. He inhabits his shrewd, world-weary character with the ease that only lifelong movie stardom can bring.

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'Notes From Underground'

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR SURGES. The dollar jumped 1 percent against the mark after a member of the Bundesbank indicated it would not raise interest rates this year. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.8335 marks, up from 1.8184.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Shipwrecked And Loving It

title: Metro Business; Incubators for Long Island
description: New York State officials announced $22 million in financing yesterday for four business incubators on Long Island aimed at nurturing entrepreneurs in biotechnology and software.

title: Democratic National Party to Share Wealth With States
description: Moving to quiet complaints from New York Democrats that President Clinton's aggressive fund-raising has undercut contributions for local candidates, the Democratic National Committee announced today that it would begin to share some of its proceeds with state Democratic organizations across the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIFFORD, SAMUEL A.
description: GIFFORD-Samuel A. On March 5, 1998, in his 91st year. Beloved husband of Harriette. Devoted father of Gail and Stephen Rudin. Adored grandfather of Deborah and Stephen Verp, Kenneth Rudin, and the late Andrew Rudin. Cherished great-grandfather of Alison Verp. A longtime leader in the paper industry. A caring, generous and loving family man, he will be deeply missed by many. Service will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, at 12 noon, on Sunday, March 8, 1998.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Agent Irked by Yanks' Negotiating Tactics
description: Player agents have long complained about the Yankees' way of doing business, but they have always made their comments privately. No need to antagonize the man in the best booth at the free-agent market.

title: Cap Gemini Shares Fall On News of Stock Issue
description: The shares of Cap Gemini S.A. fell 5 percent yesterday after the Paris-based company, Europe's biggest computer services concern, said it planned to sell up to 4 billion francs ($666.7 million) of new shares to finance acquisitions.

title: An Unsuspecting Traveler Loses His Illusions, Step by Harrowing Step
description: To the extent that artists are defined by their goals, John Sayles is the most courageous and decent storyteller working in American films today. He proves that again in ''Men With Guns,'' which brings the quiet integrity of Mr. Sayles's ''Lone Star'' to bear upon even more uncompromising material. Set in a nameless Latin American country, this is an allegory about war and responsibility, confronting the burden of history as hauntingly as this director's films so often have. With extraordinary assurance, Mr. Sayles directs this story in Spanish, English, Nahuatl, Tzotzil, Maya and Kuna, and does it so exactingly that there is no true language barrier at all.

title: Campaign Inquiry Stays Partisan to the End
description: Sharply partisan until the bitter end, a Senate committee investigating campaign financing voted along party lines today to approve a final report finding that President Clinton's re-election campaign ''eviscerated Federal fund-raising laws'' and reduced the Presidency itself to a fund-raising tool.

title: Indonesia's Crisis Deepens Over Reform Rift
description: The Indonesian crisis deepened as the rupiah plummeted 10 percent today on concern that the International Monetary Fund would suspend a $3 billion loan due on March 15 unless President Suharto stops backtracking on promised economic reforms.

title: Daimler-Benz Earnings May Rise Above 60%
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. indicated yesterday that its second-half profit rose at least 60 percent, helped by its aerospace business and a turnaround at its truck unit. Second-half profit at the German car maker was more than 3.2 billion marks ($1.8 billion), based on figures released by the company. Daimler also said it would raise its dividend to 1.6 marks from 1.1 marks, more than expected.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER HIGHER. Copper prices jumped as manufacturers stepped up purchases to take advantage of recent low prices. Mine production is also being cut. Copper for May delivery rose 1.70 cents, to 80.45 cents a pound.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Michael Ashkin

title: Indiana School Days: Reading, Writing and Murder
description: ''Then we went to McDonald's.'' This sentence is uttered by four teen-age girls describing the end to an evening of revelry in ''Hazelwood Junior High,'' Rob Urbinati's less-than-sensational play about a highly sensational crime. Of course, many adolescent outings, like proms and ball games, are topped off with visits to fast-food restaurants, where gossip, complaints and casual insults are swapped, along with a post-mortem of the night's earlier events.

title: Gun Battles in Serbia Raise Fear of 'Another Bosnia'
description: Serbian police and paramilitary units today unleashed helicopter gunships and armored personnel carriers against armed Albanian separatists in Kosovo Province, forcing dozens of Serbian families and Albanian women and children to leave and cordoning off scores of villages to keep outsiders away.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: After Rocky Run, 'Capeman' to Close
description: ''The Capeman,'' the $11 million Paul Simon musical that went through five directors on its rocky road to Broadway and opened to generally scathing reviews on Jan. 29, will close on March 28, after 59 previews and 68 regular performances at the Marquis Theater.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: George Sugarman

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DISCREET LOGIC INC. Montreal, said the Intel Corp., Santa Clara, Calif., had bought 2.2 percent of the company for about $13.5 million and would work with it to make special-effects software that runs on Intel's next-generation Merced chip.

title: Senate Is Lukewarm, but Some Seek Vote on Puerto Rico
description: Although the one-vote majority on a House bill to give Puerto Rico a say on the issue of statehood gave the measure only a modest boost, pressure began building in the Senate today to try to stir up interest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, ALEXANDER
description: JACKSON-Alexander. The Fresh Air Fund mourns the loss of its beloved member of the Board of Directors Alexander Jackson. Sandy was a dedicated Board member for over twenty years. As our Treasurer, he worked tirelessly on behalf of our Fresh Air children. He was admired for his leadership, strength and good humor. We extend our deepest sympanthy to his family. Sandy wil be greatly missed. Susan Newhouse, Chairman C. Stephen Heard, Jr., President Jenny Morgenthau, Exec Director

title: Thinking Big and Designing Small: Finnish Grace in Everyday Objects
description: A cup shaped to fit the hand or a chair that coddles the bottom may not seem like crucial considerations. But in 20th-century Finnish design, a concern for comfort has been as much a part of the game as simplicity, elegance of form and ease of production. It goes with the distinctly Finnish development of modernism evolving from the progressive design movement that swept Europe after World War I.

title: Metro Business; F.A.A. Picks Queens As Headquarters Site
description: The Federal Aviation Administration will move its Northeast regional headquarters from a building on the grounds of Kennedy International Airport to a newly constructed complex on city-owned property near the Nassau County border in Queens, city and Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about voting in the southern Indian city of Coimbatore misstated the election record of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party in the four southern states. The party has won parliamentary seats in previous elections in two of the states, Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka; it had not been shut out in parliamentary elections in the south.

title: Accounts
description: -- Yoo-hoo Chocolate Beverage Corp., New York, the soft drink division of the Austin, Nichols & Co. unit of Pernod-Ricard, to Mad Dogs and Englishmen, New York, to handle its account, previously handled by Compton Partners, New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $6 million.

title: Shades of Gray in an All-White Canvas
description: The prop in Yasmina Reza's snappy play ''Art'' at the Royale is an all-white painting that a smug character named Serge, a der

title: A New Penn Station
description: Negotiators for the United States Postal Service and a city-state development agency have finally reached a tentative peace agreement that would transform part of the James A. Farley Post Office on Eighth Avenue in Manhattan into a railroad station. One big question is how much the Postal Service is willing to part with. But the news that both sides are now willing to get started is welcome. New Yorkers need and tourists deserve a new terminal on the West Side that is not only comfortable and efficient but evokes the grandeur lost when New York City foolishly dismantled the old Penn Station in 1963.

title: Polygraph Test Results Offered in Baby Death Case
description: Defense lawyers today took Amy S. Grossberg another legal step away from her former high school sweetheart, Brian Peterson, two months before their scheduled trial in the death of their baby at a Delaware motel in 1996.

title: Pregnant Women's Fight Winds Up in Court
description: A pregnant woman accused of pulling another pregnant woman out of her car and beating her for taking a parking space was convicted of aggravated assault yesterday, despite the defense's argument that the woman was suffering ''road rage,'' prosecutors said.

title: France Limits Legislative Inquiry on Rwanda Role
description: A decision to hold a limited parliamentary inquiry into how French military aid to the Hutu-dominated Government in Rwanda in the early 1990's may have contributed to the killing of hundreds of thousands of Tutsi and moderate Hutu in 1994 has drawn sharp criticism here for not going far enough.

title: Car Makers Slow to Use New Power Over Prices
description: RION HANES is turning down $60,000 offers for the solitary Plymouth Prowler on the lot at Northgate Chrysler Plymouth in Cincinnati. The rare, retro-style hot rods are in such demand that Mr. Hanes, the dealership's sales manager, is not accepting any bids below $70,000 -- almost twice the manufacturer's suggested retail price of $39,000.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCGUIRE, MURIEL MARGARET
description: McGuire-Muriel Margaret. Dearest Mom, Happy 95th Birthday! Trudy and I will be celebrating your day, thinking of you every moment and toasting the most special of moms. Love, Sissy

title: Victory for Pataki in Effort To Take Over L.I. Utility
description: With a major ruling from the Internal Revenue Service in hand, Gov. George E. Pataki has almost reached a goal that has eluded public officials for a quarter of a century: cutting Long Island's high electricity bills.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the brother of Mohandas K. Gandhi's assassin misstated the duration of the banning of Hindu nationalist organizations in India after the killing on Jan. 30, 1948. The main nationalist group, the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, was banned for 17 months, beginning in February 1948, not ''for more than a decade.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, MURIEL
description: HOROWITZ-Muriel. The Board of Directors and membership of Glen Head Country Club announce with profound sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member, Muriel Horowitz. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Martin Scheman, President

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Hindu Bloc Moves Closer To Power
description: With its opponents in growing disarray, India's main Hindu nationalist party grew increasingly confident today that it would form the country's new government, although probably not for another week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEINEMAN, RUTH (KRESS)
description: HEINEMAN-Ruth (Kress). Age 75. She passed away peacefully in her sleep at home after a long illness born with courage and dignity. She is survived by her loving husband Bernard (Jack) Heineman, Jr. Her devoted children Deborah Heineman (Scaglione) and Ralph Scaglione, Matthew and Katherine (Phillips) Heineman and Stephen and Katherine (Lingg) Heineman and by her adoring grandchildren Joshua, Benjamin, Nicholas, Emily, Tyler and Scott. She is also survived by her brothers George and Kenneth and her sister Nancy Armstrong and many nieces and nephews. She will be greatly missed by her brothers-in-law William Heineman, and his family, and Andrew Heineman. The family will receive friends at The Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Sunday March 8 from 6-9 PM and on Monday March 9 from 6-9 PM. The funeral service will be held Tuesday, March 10 at 4 PM at The First Presbyterian Church, 12th St and 5th Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The College of Wooster, Wooster, OH, The Public Education Association, 39 W. 32nd Street, New York City or the charity of your choice.

title: The Rot in Indonesia
description: Indonesia faces an immediate financial crisis that the International Monetary Fund can help fix, and a longer-term political crisis that can be remedied only by reforms that President Suharto seems incapable of adopting. Though the monetary fund is right to be concerned about corruption and financial favoritism in Indonesia, it should be concentrating on the economic problems that threaten to bankrupt that country. The other problems, including the business manipulations of the Suharto family, will require sustained American pressure.

title: Ardent Donor To Democrats Faces Charges
description: Johnny Chung, a struggling businessman whose eager giving to national Democratic candidates turned him into a leading figure in the investigation of campaign finance abuses, was charged here today with four counts of bank fraud, tax evasion and conspiracy and will plead guilty and cooperate with the authorities.

title: A Waiter? Who Needs It? On the Streets, It's a Movable Feast
description: Why, I often wonder, is New York's symbol a wholesome red apple, when the more obvious choice would be the blue and yellow umbrella of a Sabrett hot-dog stand, an irresistible beacon shimmering in the wind?

title: Callaway Golf to Open Performance Center on Madison Ave.
description: The Callaway Golf Company, which makes the oversized Big Bertha drivers, is bringing its clubs and computers to Madison Avenue.

title: Politics Aside, Students Still Need Skills
description: To the Editor:

title: A Writerly Approach to the Hopelessness That Is Cuba
description: Cultural repression often sends people in two opposite directions, and in Cuba musicians either create a dance world of pleasure, or carefully, and with melancholy, describe the fate that has befallen the island.

title: From a Vanished Cooperative, Nature in Abstract
description: Of the groups formed by American photographers who shared common interests, the least known is the short-lived Association of Heliographers. Named after the sun-imagery process invented by Joseph Nicephore Niepce in 1829, the Heliographers opened a Manhattan gallery in July 1963 with a group show. That exhibition was followed in August by a larger one in the lobby of the Lever House in Manhattan, which, by all accounts, was a stunner. With its 101 superbly printed photographs, including many abstract studies of nature, it attracted a lot of attention.

title: Back Close To Signing Giants Deal
description: Negotiations between the Giants and the free-agent running back LeShon Johnson are nearing a close, with Johnson expected to sign a multiyear contract with the team perhaps today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; International Headaches Follow a Modern Midas
description: SHADOW WARSBy Clyde Farnsworth419 pages. Donald I. Fine Books/Penguin. $24.95.

title: New Serbia Fighting Recalls Bosnia War
