description: Serbia sent helicopter gunships and armored personnel carriers against Albanian separatists in the south, leaving 22 dead, and some see parallels in Kosovo Province to the actions of Serbian forces during the Bosnian war. An Albanian political leader said ''massacres'' were being carried out.

title: U.S. Aid to Help Train People on Welfare as Child Care Workers
description: Officials in the South Bronx and Harlem plan to use Federal economic development aid to train welfare recipients as child care workers, helping them find work while creating thousands of sorely needed day care openings for children, thus making it possible for even more jobless parents to work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LODGE, FRANCESCA
description: LODGE-Francesca. The Women's National Repubican Club mourns the passing of Francesca Lodge, wife of former Congressman, Connecticut Governor and Ambassador to Spain and Argentina, John Davis Lodge. A devoted and valued member of the WNRC Board of Governors from 1964 to 1967, she served as Vice President of the Board of Governors, Chairman of the 1966 Annual Luncheon and Chairman of the International Affairs Committee. We extend our sincerest condolences to her daughters and grandchildren. Lila Prounis, President, Women's National Repubican Club

title: UNICO AMERICAN SAYS IT IS IN TALKS ABOUT A MERGER
description: The Unico American Corporation said yesterday that it was in preliminary talks to merge with another company. The announcement sent Unico's shares up $2.50, to $17.50. Unico, a Woodland Hills, Calif., insurance company, is up 33 percent this week and 67 percent in the last 12 months. No information was provided about the prospective partner, and Unico said ''significant issues'' must be resolved before any deal was struck. Unico sells property, casualty, life and health insurance, and it makes loans to cover premium payments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, BERNARD H.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Bernard H. Age 90, of Port Washington, Long Island, March 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Edith I. (nee Spivack). Devoted father of Rita G. Christopher and Amy G. Bass. Father-in-law of Geoffrey A. Bass and the late Robert C. Christopher. Adoring grandfather of Alistair D. and Gordon F.B. Christopher, Jonathon E. and Susanna E. Bass. A partner in Tenzer, Greenblatt L.L.P. Funeral Services are private. Memorial service to be announced. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to Columbia Law School.

title: Harry Stanley Dies at 100; Master of Erudite Nonsense
description: Harry Stanley, a vaudevillian turned lecturer who was such a subtle master of philolillogical orotundity and frammatical linguistation that when he got wound up it took a while before it became apparent that nobody had the foggiest idea what he was talking about, died on Feb. 15 at the Actors Fund Home in Englewood, N.J. He was 100 and had been a leading exponent of double talk for the better part of a century.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WARE, EDYTHE
description: WARE-Edythe. In our hearts you will always be remembered. Mac and Our Sons Lewis, Stephen and Robert

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a proposed sale of the computer services subsidiary of Olivetti S.p.A. referred incorrectly to the company's plans for another subsidiary, Lexikon, which specializes in copiers and printers. Olivetti plans to seek a commercial alliance for Lexikon; it is not in negotiations to sell it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, JACOB (JACK)
description: RUBINSTEIN-Jacob (Jack), 87, on March 4, of West Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Sarah. Devoted brother of Betty Glasser and the late Raye Mallin, Max Robert and Sam Rubinstein. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Graveside services Sunday, March 8, 1998, 11 AM at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY, under the direction of ''Park West Riverside Chapels'' 212-362-3600.

title: Mexican Army Whistle-Blower on Trial
description: After a decade-long legal battle, the Mexican armed forces have opened the court-martial of a general who once accused the military of human rights abuses.

title: Giuliani Fund-Raising Points To Running for Higher Office
description: Just two months into his second term, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his aides sent a strong signal yesterday that he plans to seek higher office, saying they would hold a series of fund-raising events this year, including a $1,000-a-plate dinner in May.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARRACK, JAMES T.
description: WARRACK-James T. The Department of Psychiatry at Long Island College Hospital mourns the sudden passing of Mr. James T. Warrack, C.S.W., CASAC, Clinical Director of our Duffield Street Alcoholism Treatment Program in downtown Brooklyn. Mr. Warrack was a distinguished colleague, friend, mentor, and clinician who over his 12 year career with us made important contributions to improving services to high risk patient populations. He was a man of compassion and integrity, who never looked down on anyone unless it was to lend a helping hand. We are grateful for Mr. Warrack's tenure and extend our sincere condolences to his family

title: THE BIG EAST: CONFERENCE TOURNAMENT -- Mighty Leap for Rutgers, a Steady Rise for St. John's; Red Storm Breezes Past Boston College
description: After three years of struggling to get out of the first round in the Big East tournament, St. John's seniors finally found out last night what it was like for those teams that get to move directly into the second round: nice and smooth.

title: Six Degrees Of 'Footloose'
description: With the imminent transfer of ''The Beauty Queen of Leenane'' to the last available Broadway theater, the season is complete. Time to kick back and relax. Had enough? Good. Let's talk about next season.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: DIAMOND OFFSHORE DRILLING INC., Houston, a deep-water drilling services company, said its president and chief executive, Robert E. Rose, had resigned effective March 31. The chief financial officer, Lawrence R. Dickerson, will become president and chief operating officer. The chairman, James S. Tisch, will add the title of chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADESON, AUSTEN
description: MADESON-Austen. Died March 5th. We will always miss you. You were a truly wonderful, loving brother-in-law, uncle, great uncle. Miriam and Stanley, Mitchell, Sarah, Heather, Roberta, Nancy, Bobby, Jessica, Andie, Danielle

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HREACHMACK, ROSEMARY LASORSA
description: HREACHMACK-Rosemary LaSorsa, on March 4, 1998 after a courageous battle with cancer. Her spirit, love of life, humor, compassion and Christianity carries on with all the many people whose lives she has touched. Rosemary was a law firm administrator in both Delaware and New York. Beloved wife of Dan. Loving daughter of Angela and Domenick. Dear sister of Frank. Reposing Towers Funeral Home Inc Long Beach and Foxhurst Roads Oceanside, LI Friday 7-9pm and Saturday 9-10:30am. Funeral mass on Saturday 11 A.M., St. Anthonys RC Church Oceanside, LI. In lieu of flowers, Rosemary requested donations be made in her name to The Delaware Humane Society at 701 A Street Wilmington, DE 19801 where she volunteered for several years and served as a board member.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Two Warhols, Together Again

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOWITZ, ELAINE
description: MARKOWITZ-Elaine. On March 5, 1998. Beloved wife of Walter, loving mother of Sheree, motherin-law of Marc, grandmother of Adam and Daniel, sister of Wilma Goldsmith. Services 12 noon, Sun. March 8th. at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy., Flushing.

title: 2 Laws Signed to Step Up Efforts for Child Support
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed two bills into law yesterday intended to help officials collect some of the $1.4 billion that parents owe for child support.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABBINER, LILLIAN C.
description: RABBINER-Lillian C. Age 83. On March 3, 1998. Cherished mother of Elaine and Meyer Eisenberg, Stanley and Eve Rabbiner, Arthur Rabbiner and Richard Gluckman. Beloved grandmother of Judith Eisenberg, and Mark Oberman, Jonathan Eisenberg and Jessica Rabbiner. Delighted great-grandmother of Michelle and Nicole Oberman. Caring aunt of Wendy Lazarus. Loving wife of the late Jacob Leo Rabbiner. Devoted sister of the late Deborah Deletiner. A memorial service was held in Florida, on March 4, 1998.

title: Tyson Alleges Massive Fraud in Suit Against King
description: Mike Tyson yesterday filed a lawsuit against the boxing promoter Don King in United States District Court in Manhattan, alleging a brazen and vast decade-long pattern of financial fraud and abuse that robbed the troubled former heavyweight boxing champion of tens of millions of dollars.

title: Extortion and Protection Rackets Grow Into a Threat to Business : Organized Crime Strangles Slovakia
description: BANSKA BYSTRICA, Slovakia  When the mob came calling in August at his office in this provincial capital, Frantisek Mojzis had a good idea what it was after: his business.

title: MDU RESOURCES ACQUIRES MORSE BROS. FOR $93 MILLION
description: MDU Resources Group Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held Morse Brothers Inc. for $93 million in stock and cash to bolster its construction materials business in the Pacific Northwest. MDU Resources will also assume some Morse Brothers liabilities. The companies did not disclose terms. MDU Resources, an energy and building materials company based in Bismarck, N.D., had 1997 sales of $607 million. Morse Brothers is the largest construction materials supplier in Oregon, with 1997 sales of $100 million. MDU's shares closed at $32.8125, up 43.75 cents, before the acquisition was announced.

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: Everest'

title: On My Mind; The Secret Council
description: Once in a while newspapers and television carry pictures of diplomats raising their hands to vote at meetings of the U.N. Security Council. They are political frauds -- both meetings and pictures.

title: Observer; Comfort for the Afflicted
description: Despite Monica Lewinsky and Stonewall Clinton, there is good news for Democrats. Newt Gingrich may be the Republicans' next Presidential candidate.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Brooklyn Couple Held In Scalding of Baby
description: A couple from Coney Island were arrested last night after their 3-month-old suffered major burns in her bath, the police said.

title: Life Among the Scenic Wonders, Where the Qings Beat the Heat
description: CHENGDE, China  Spring has reached Beijing, bringing the year's first crop of foreign tourists in search of a 5,000-year-old civilization. As they trudge from one site to the next, do their spirits sag?

title: Public Relations Fee Income a Record
description: Fee income for the nation's 50 largest public relations agencies rose 10.3 percent in 1997 to a record $1.71 billion from $1.55 billion in 1996, according to an annual survey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, JAMES
description: GREGORY-James, 77. On Feb. 4, 1998. Broadway musical theater coach and composer. He will be missed by his family and many devoted students. A memorial will be held later this spring.

title: A Legend, Continued
description: Terrence Malick has legendary status here for two things: the movies he has made, and the movies he has not made.

title: 21 Big Japanese Banks Apply for a Piece of the Bailout Pie
description: In a smoothly scripted bailout of Japan's financial system, 21 big banks submitted applications for public funds today, a move the Government hopes will ultimately help restore worldwide confidence in Japanese banks.

title: Service for Friendly Today
description: A funeral for Fred W. Friendly, the broadcast news pioneer and former CBS news executive, will be held at 11:30 A.M. today in Riverdale Temple, West 246th Street at Independence Avenue in Riverdale, the Bronx. Speakers will include family and friends as well as former colleagues of Mr. Friendly, who died on Tuesday at age 82.

title: Jack Micheline, 68, a Beat Poet With an Ear Tuned to the Streets
description: Jack Micheline, a Beat poet who wrote about the downtrodden using the rhythms and sounds of street speech, died on Friday on a commuter train leaving San Francisco. He was 68 and, friends said, lived near poverty in a San Francisco hotel.

title: Name That Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Once a Nemesis, Jackson Has Become the President's Spiritual Adviser
description: In hushed tones in the inner sanctum of the White House, President Clinton's new spiritual adviser said he offered counsel that is steeped as much in practical politics as in the Bible: ''Keep your eyes open and your mouth shut. And don't panic.''

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption on Wednesday about the Big East women's basketball final referred incorrectly in some editions to the University of Connecticut player shown. She was Rita Williams, not Marci Czel.

title: Sharpton Says He Won't Be a Political Candidate This Year
description: After months of flirting with the idea of running for Congress, the Rev. Al Sharpton announced yesterday that he would not seek office this year, saying he wanted to spend more time on civil rights issues than on his political career.

title: An Encyclopedic Mind Flips From C (for Conscious) to U (for Unconscious)
description: ''Live in Your Head,'' the exhortative title of the first large survey of Conceptual art, in Zurich in 1969, has probably inspired all kinds of artists. But it may have elicited particular devotion from Matt Mullican, who arrived in New York City in 1973, armed with a degree from the California Institute of the Arts, in Valencia.

title: Television in Review
description: 'The Fixer'

title: Loss of Gas Pressure Affects 4,000 Customers
description: A gas main lost pressure on Wednesday while being repaired, leaving more than 4,000 homes and businesses without heat and hot water for up to three days.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DWYER, MIKE
description: DWYER-Mike. I remember and love. A.

title: Television in Review
description: With made-for-television films flooding the channels, there is room for everything from hidden gems to flash-and-trash. Here are some of the more distinctive television movies being shown this weekend.

title: It's All Semantics
description: Luke and Laura of ''General Hospital'' became daytime television's most popular couple after what was described as Luke's ''seduction'' of Laura.

title: Jones Lawyers Seek New Talk With Accuser
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones want to reinterview another woman who says President Clinton made sexual advances toward her, lawyers with knowledge of Ms. Jones's sexual-misconduct lawsuit against Mr. Clinton said.

title: It's Futurist Step Dancing, Bouncy and Extravagant
description: Sean Curran's ''Folk Dance for the Future (Traditional Methods/Post-Modern Techniques)'' is a witty and exuberant modern-dance piece set to irresistible traditional Irish mouth music and based in the technique of Irish step dancing, which Mr. Curran performed as a child.

title: Two Banks Agree to Merge in Berlin Deal
description: Bankgesellschaft Berlin A.G. agreed today to buy Norddeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale for 6.47 billion marks ($3.54 billion) in cash and stock, after breaking a 10-month deadlock over the sale by compensating its own majority shareholder, the city-state of Berlin, for loss of control.

title: Second-Half Profit Doubled at French Bank
description: Banque Nationale de Paris S.A. said yesterday that its profit doubled in the second half of 1997 as buoyant markets, a higher dollar and an increase in international business more than offset an unexpectedly large charge for Asian loans.

title: Korean Stocks Fall After Panic Selling
description: Korean stocks tumbled Thursday by their largest margin so far this year, underscoring the economic uncertainties facing the new President, Kim Dae Jung, as he tries to reorganize the nation's economy.

title: Pfizer to Join With UConn on Research Lab
description: As part of an effort to increase collaboration between university researchers and its company scientists, Pfizer Inc. announced today that it would build a $19 million research laboratory on the campus of the University of Connecticut in Storrs.

title: Pollution by Factory Farms Inspires Industrial Approach to Regulation
description: The winds that blow across Premium Standard Farms' long barns here carry the stench from hundreds of thousands of confined hogs for miles over the northern Missouri hills, enraging many neighbors.

title: CHART TO PAY $34 MILLION FOR AN IMI INDUSTRIAL DIVISION
description: Chart Industries, an industrial equipment maker based in Mayfield Heights, Ohio, agreed yesterday to buy the Industrial Heat Exchanger division of IMI Marston, a unit of the British engineering company IMI P.L.C., for $:21 million

title: A Foe of Starr Goes to Court, but Makes Little Headway
description: A Connecticut lawyer came here today to argue before a Federal appeals court that Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating President Clinton, should himself be investigated, for conflict of interest.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 16.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Starr Is Right to Question White House Aide; Don't Look to Jefferson
description: To the Editor:

title: Reciprocation
description: ''New York is going through a renaissance -- I want to give something back,'' said ALEX GARFIELD, a manufacturer of women's apparel and the chairman of Fashion Helps '98. The $1,000-a-person benefit at Avery Fisher Hall raised $365,000 for the Community Literacy Research Project. . . . ''I'll wind down first and figure out what I want to do next,'' said MAGGIE LEAR, who is leaving the city's Administration for Children's Services today after two years as press secretary. Reporters covering the Giuliani administration found her uncharacteristically open with the press. . . . ''My father taught me the value of creativity, and now I'm making something new with his music,'' said JEN CHAPIN, the daughter of HARRY CHAPIN, who has been rehearsing for tonight's concert at Town Hall with children of other 70's idols.

title: Mark Hollis, 89; Raised Early Pollution Alarm
description: Dr. Mark Dexter Hollis, a public health official who raised the alarm about air and water pollution nearly 50 years ago and led efforts against malaria as chief of a precursor of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, died on Feb. 24 at the Lakeland Regional Medical Center in Lakeland, Fla. He was 89 and lived in Lakeland.

title: For the Love of B Movies: Scorsese's Cinematic Tour
description: ''A Personal Journey With Martin Scorsese Through American Movies'' has been shown as part of a museum retrospective. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's Critics Notebook article, which appeared in The New York Times on Feb. 23, 1996. The documentary opens today for one week at the Gotham Cinema, Third Avenue at 58th Street, Manhattan.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Hedda Sterne

title: Sanctions for Men's Team?
description: A top official of the United States Olympic Committee yesterday called for tough penalties for the members of the United States men's hockey team in connection with the vandalism at the Olympic village last month in Nagano, Japan.

title: Sex, Suspicion and Silliness
description: If comedy is hard, Feydeau is harder.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Residential Real Estate; Unsold Apartments to Yield Larger, Fancier Units
description: A developer is renovating 80 apartments that it bought in January in a 208-unit building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and combining at least 15 units.

title: Judge Reinstates a Union Activist in Syracuse
description: A woman who is often called the Norma Rae of Syracuse won her job back after a judge ruled that a plastics factory fired her because of her pro-union activities, not because of sexual harassment charges the company brought against her.

title: Review/Fashion; Sander Finds the Gentle Side of Sensuality
description: Fashion is moving into an era in which sensual pleasure is as important to style as the cut and color of a garment. This may be unprecedented in modern fashion, but it is a natural outgrowth of women's interest in comfort and spiritual fulfillment. This yearning shone out in the collection Jil Sander presented today, a gentle exposition that showed that modernity need not be harsh.

title: Putting Pizazz Back in Public Works
description: New York has had a good week in Washington. Yesterday, a bipartisan group of senators announced that the Budget Committee had found another $5 billion for transit, boosting the total under the new Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act (Istea 2, in Congressional parlance) to $41.3 billion. If enacted, it would be the largest amount ever devoted to transit in a six-year authorization. More than $6.6 billion for New York!

title: Strange Ends Long Wait For a Lead at the Doral
description: While having dinner with his wife last Christmas Eve, Curtis Strange realized he could not close his left eye. He spent Christmas Day in the hospital, diagnosed with Bell's palsy, a malady that can cause temporary paralysis in the face.

title: Politics Aside, Students Still Need Skills; Jobs Go Unfilled
description: To the Editor:

title: Warming Up to Snowshoeing
description: ''Follow moi!'' said Sophie, struggling to herringbone up a snowy trail at High Point Cross Country Ski Center in highest New Jersey. We had come to try the newest-oldest thing in winter recreation: snowshoeing. You know: tennis rackets on the feet, fur trappers, the Yukon. Only today, after at least 6,000 years of gear evolution, it's jogging snowshoes, step-in bindings, anodized aluminum and titanium, ArcTec and Hypalon.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Y. Z. Kami

title: A Pillbox Hat For the Lady
description: Did you ever wonder where the term ''personal shopper'' came from? It seems as if it's been around forever, but it may have been coined by Jacqueline Kennedy, in a letter she wrote in 1960 to her favorite hat saleswoman at Bergdorf Goodman. Busy with the preparations for Inauguration Day, Mrs. Kennedy wrote to Marita O'Connor at Bergdorf's Custom Hat Department to ask for help in choosing the accessories for her White House ensembles.

title: Mexico's Overtures to the Zapatistas Bring Tensions in Chiapas to a New Boiling Point
description: The soldiers arrived in a column of armored vehicles intending to bring the Government's peace to a valley where many Indian farmers support the Zapatista rebels. But instead of peace, the troops who camped in a school soccer field five days ago brought the hamlet to the brink of bloodshed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDGRAB, ANDREE
description: GOLDGRAB-Andree. The employees of Bass & Limer extend their condolences to Harry, Sheilah and Shelby Goldgrab upon the passing of their wife and mother.

title: Landmark Status
description: ''Twilight,'' a class act in a classic genre, reunites the ''Nobody's Fool'' team and finds 73-year-old Paul Newman playing detective amid striking Los Angeles settings. The backdrops may be architecturally distinguished, but it's the guy in the gumshoes who's the real monument here. In this sleek, nostalgic film noir, it's a pleasure to watch him sparring stylishly with Susan Sarandon, Gene Hackman, James Garner and Stockard Channing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, JESSE
description: ROSS-Jesse. In New York, on February 25, 1998. At age 91. Supervisor, Adult Education, City School District, Syracuse, 1964-70. Principal, North High School, Syracuse, 1951-64. Ordained rabbi, Hebrew Union College, Cincinnati, 1931. U.S. Army Chaplain, Pacific Theatre, World War II. Survived by wife, Beatrice S. Ross, son, Clyde H. Ross, of West Hollywood, California, sisters, Golda Levine, of New Haven, Berta Graffman and Lottie Graffman of Skowhegan, Maine, Marcia Rothstein, of Rochester, New York, and two grandsons. Interment is in Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Starr Is Right to Question White House Aide; Having It Both Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets' Latest Problem: A Surplus of Pitching
description: If this were three weeks from now, the Mets might be staring at a serious numbers problem, simply because five pitchers with uncertain outlooks for making the team can no longer be sent to the minors.

title: A 50-Year Run, Onstage and Off
description: Onstage, ELI WALLACH has been playing a curmudgeonly 86-year-old widower in the two-character play ''Visiting Mr. Green.''

title: People
description: -- Matthew W. Lake was named to the new position of executive vice president and new business director at Gotham Inc., New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos. He had been senior vice president and managing director at Hampel/Stefanides, New York.

title: Ex-Top Soldier Is Contradicted By An Accuser
description: Contradicting Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, Sgt. Christina Roy swore today that she had never considered an abortion, even though her 1996 pregnancy was unwanted and precluded the job ''opportunity of a lifetime'' on Sergeant Major McKinney's staff.

title: Casino Plans Ferry From Chelsea Piers
description: Foxwoods Casino in Connecticut, owned by the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, has leased docking space at Chelsea Piers for a high-speed ferry that is to begin transporting gamblers later this month between New York City and the tribe's casino near New London.

title: Club Kids: Starry Eyes and Blurry Minds
description: ''Shampoo Horns,'' a glossy, sensationalistic group portrait of New York City ''club kids,'' makes you long for those good old days when Andy Warhol's self-appointed superstars brought a certain humor and bohemian sense of style to his semi-improvised films. But nearly three decades after cross-dressers like Candy Darling and Holly Woodlawn paraded their personal fantasies of Hollywood stardom across the screen, being an underground legend isn't what it used to be.

title: Quebec Liberal Quits, Unsettling Canadian Politics
description: A surprise resignation in Quebec unleashed political turmoil across Canada this week, raising questions about the country's oldest political party, the national fight for right-wing voters and the possibility of a third referendum on Quebec separation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEAVY, ESTHER
description: LEAVY-Esther. March 6, 1976. Lovingly remembered forever. Your children and grandchildren

title: Busting out of the Straitjacket With Paul Taylor
description: In ''The Word,'' Paul Taylor gives us one of his beware-of-conformity pieces. Eleven dancers, men and women dressed alike as schoolboys, regroup into regimented lines. Only Lisa Viola wears a scaly green leotard. She is not a member of the club.

title: Starr Is Right to Question White House Aide
description: To the Editor:

title: Computer Associates Drops Bid To Acquire Computer Sciences
description: In the face of ever-increasing resistance, Computer Associates backed off yesterday from its hostile $9.8 billion bid to buy the Computer Sciences Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLER, EBERHARD, HANS J.
description: MULLER-EBERHARD-Hans J. One of the world's leading molecular immunologists, died March 3, 1998. Director of the Institute of Molecular Medicine for the Prevention of Human Diseases at the University of Texas-Houston, his research contribution dominated an era in immunology and biomedical research. From 1988-1995 he led the world-renowned Bernhard Nocht Institute for Tropical Medicine in Germany. He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences and Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Irma Gigli-Muller-Eberhard, and daughters Kristina and Monika Muller-Eberhard. A memorial service will be held 4:00PM, Monday, March 16, at Palmer Memorial Episcopal Church, 6221 Main St. Houston, TX. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Institute of Molecular Medicine, the University of Texas-Houston Health Science Center, 2121 W. Holcombe Blvd, Houston, TX 77030

title: F.A.A. Falls Behind Schedule In Air-Traffic System Changes
description: The Federal Aviation Administration's slimmed-down, simplified modernization of the air-traffic control system is behind schedule and may be over budget, Congressional auditors told a House subcommittee today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, LOIS (BILLIG)
description: EDELSTEIN-Lois (Billig), unexpectedly, on Monday, March 2, 1998, of Andover, MA. Beloved wife of Joel J. Loving mother of Anne Edelstein and her husband Roy Moskowitz of Manhattan, Dr. Bernard M. Edelstein and his wife Ann Epstein of Brookline, MA, and the late Daniel A. Edelstein. Adored grandmother of Henry, Charlotte, Eli and Eva. Dear sister of Nathan Billig of Chevy Chase, MD., and the late Cecile Dunn and Jacob Billig. Services at Temple Emanuel, Andover on Sunday, March 8. Memorial observance through Tuesday evening at her late residence. Remembrances may be made to the Lois Edelstein Educators' Fund, C/O Union of American Hebrew Congregations, 75 Second Avenue, Suite 550, Needham, MA 02194 or the Daniel A. Edelstein Scholarship Fund, C/O Temple Emanuel, 7 Haggetts Pond Rd., Andover, MA 01810. For further information, please call the Levine Chapel at 617-277-8300.

title: Craft Sees Signs Of Water as Ice In Moon Craters
description: An American spacecraft has found evidence that relatively large amounts of frozen water exist on the Moon, scattered in craters over vast spans of the north and south poles, scientists announced today.

title: Give Parents a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: Gentlemen, Silver Charm in Showdown
description: As far as Gary Stevens is concerned, it was a ''win-win situation.'' No matter which horse he chose to ride in Saturday's $1 million Santa Anita Handicap, Gentlemen or Silver Charm, he would wind up on one of the three best older horses in the country.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Vernon E. Jordan Jr.'s appearance before the Federal grand jury investigating the Monica Lewinsky question referred incorrectly to his conferences with his lawyer, William G. Hundley. They occurred during breaks; Mr. Jordan did not leave the room during questioning.

title: Miami Delays the Naming of an Interim Mayor
description: The question of who is the mayor of Miami remained up in the air today after the City Commission postponed making an interim appointment in response to a court ruling that voided the last election because of ballot fraud.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Alain Kirili

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKLAR, JUDITH TARSHIS
description: SKLAR-Judith Tarshis. Formerly of Greenwich. Died February 27 in Miami. Devoted wife of Burton J. Sklar, loving mother of Stanley Sklar, Stacey Goldweitz, Susan Mahar and Sandra Thompson. Adored grandmother of eight. A Memorial service at 3 P.M., on Sunday, March 8, Temple Shalom, Greenwich. Donations may be made to Greenwich Council, Boy Scouts of America.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Lee Lozano

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: New Role for Jesse Jackson
description: Since the start of the furor over Monica S. Lewinsky, President Clinton and his family have frequently turned to the Baptist minister for private sessions of prayer. Page A20.

title: AT&T Is Seeking Cable-TV Alliances
description: A top official of the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that the company was talking to a number of cable-television companies about alliances, which could help it offer local telephone and high-speed Internet access using cable wires.

title: N.B.A. Violence
description: An arbitrator's decision to reinstate Latrell Sprewell's contract with the Golden State Warriors seems overly accommodating to a player who choked, punched and threatened his coach. In a game where violent acts on and off the court are not unusual, this decision may make it harder for teams to dismiss players for bad conduct.

title: Again: A Fugitive, Wild Stunts and Tommy Lee Jones
description: When a movie, like an old rock-and-roll record, ''has a good beat,'' as teen-age rock fans used to put it in their impromptu one-sentence record reviews on ''American Bandstand,'' what more does it really need? ''U.S. Marshals,'' the action-crammed sequel to ''The Fugitive,'' doesn't have a coherent story. Nor does it have the implacably righteous Harrison Ford as a good guy nearly hounded to death by the law. What it does have that its forerunner possessed in equal measure is an unceasingly infectious beat, as it picks up the rhythm of the chase and sustains it for more than two hours in a mad dash from swanky high-rise offices in Chicago through the swamps of Kentucky to the streets of New York.

title: Plan to Assist Mass Transit Moves Ahead
description: Declaring a victory for urbanized states, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Senate leaders said today that they had agreed on a plan to increase Federal spending on mass transportation by $5 billion over the next five years, including about $200 million a year in new funds for New York and New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHLE, MARGARET LURTON
description: KAHLE-Margaret Lurton. Of Madison, CT. Formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Mother of Brewster Lurton Kahle of Seatle, WA., and Alison Lurton Kahle of Delaware, Oh. Sister of Grace Lurton Miller of Madison, CT. Services Friday 11AM Swan Funeral Home Madison, CT.

title: TRIZECHAHN CONSIDERS SELLING ITS 25 SHOPPING CENTERS
description: The TrizecHahn Corporation said yesterday that it was considering the sale of its operating portfolio of 25 regional shopping centers after being approached by several parties. TrizecHahn, based in Toronto, is a real estate company with interests in 96 properties consisting of 66 million square feet. It had revenue of $713.7 million in 1997. TrizecHahn said it had not made a final decision on whether to sell. It said any sale would not include its portfolio of development projects. Without elaborating, the company said the value and ''strategic attractiveness'' of its retail properties had been confirmed by recent transactions in the market. TrizecHahn's shares were unchanged at $24.375.

title: Giant Rec Room, River View; Chelsea Piers Surmounts Its Financial Growing Pains
description: In 1912, the Titanic should have completed its maiden voyage with a celebratory arrival at Pier 59 in Manhattan. It did not work out that way.

title: Bill Gates is Tiger Woods? Well, he's doing a commercial.
description: BILL GATES, you've just testified before a Senate committee, paid tribute to the Wright brothers at the Time magazine 75th anniversary party, presented the New York Public Library with a $640,000 grant and visited a sixth-grade classroom. What are you going to do?

title: Washington Post Magazine Editor to Be Named Managing Editor
description: Steve Coll, the 39-year-old editor and publisher of The Washington Post Sunday magazine, is expected to be named managing editor of The Washington Post, an editor of the newspaper said yesterday evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAYKIN, ROSE
description: SHAYKIN-Rose. Lincoln Square Synagogue records with sorrow the passing of Mrs. Rose Shaykin, beloved mother of our esteemed Board member, Leonard Shaykin. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Richard Kestenbaum, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, THOMAS F.
description: CASEY-Thomas F. of Larchmont, NY, on March 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Terry, devoted father of Andrea O'Neill and Christina Webers of Larchmont, loving father-in-law of Tim O'Neill and Frank Webers, loving grandfather of Caroline O'Neill, April, May, June, Frank and Caitlin Webers. Also survived by his sister, Ann Ayre of Hampton Bays, his nieces, Susan Turner and Betsy Saccone of Montclair, New Jersey, his niece, Patricia Jacobsen of Hampton Bays and his nephew, Michael Lawrie of Manhattan. Visitation Friday, March 6, 2-5 and 7-9PM, Fox Funeral Home 2080 Post Road, Larchmont. Funeral Mass on Saturday, March 7th at 9:30AM Sts. John and Paul Church, Larchmont, New York. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, New York. Contributions may be made to United Hospital Hospice, 406 Boston Post Road, Portchester, New York 10573.

title: CLEAR CHANNEL IN DEAL FOR BRITISH AD COMPANY
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the British outdoor advertising company More Group P.L.C. for $:446 million ($727 million) in cash. Clear Channel is expected to use More Group, one of the world's largest outdoor advertising companies, as a platform for more acquisitions overseas. Shares of Clear Channel rose $2, to $94.125. More Group's shares rose 190 pence, to 1,024 in London. The offer was for 1,042.5 pence a share. In December, Clear Channel bought 46 radio stations and 348 billboards from Paxson Communications for $629 million. The company is awaiting regulatory approval of its $1.7 billion acquisition of Universal Outdoor Inc., another billboard company.

title: Sports of The Times; A Real Key For the Guy In the Cart
description: LIMPING slightly, Casey Martin was on his way to his 8:33 A.M. tee time at The Hills Country Club yesterday when he slid into the seat of a beige golf cart without a roof and stepped on the accelerator. When nothing happened, he looked around and uttered the words that no other PGA Tour or Nike Tour golfer has been allowed to say.

title: ANTIQUE FORTRESS: A special report.; Park Ave. Armory Is Losing the Battle Within
description: The Seventh Regiment Armory stands like a fortress overlooking Park Avenue, a crenelated, red-brick landmark with a formidable presence that befits its role as the premier showplace in New York City for internationally renowned art, antiques and crafts shows.

title: Bill Could Force Owners Of Pit Bulls to Pay $500
description: Less than a month after three pit bulls attacked first and second graders at an elementary school, injuring 15, an ordinance has been introduced in the City Council to force the owners of pit bulls to pay a $500 registration fee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBY, MARK J.
description: JACOBY-Mark J. With the sudden passing of Mark Jacoby, the insurance industry, City College, UJA Federation and the Jacoby-Levick families have lost an invaluable supporter, friend and patriarch. A life-time member of the Million Dollar Roundtable, his contributions will long be remembered by the countless families who he helped to protect and provide for. A graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School, City College and Columbia School of Social Work, he founded Jacoby Associates, a flourishing insurance agency in 1949. Beloved husband of Miriam for 56 years, loving brother of Elsie (Murray) Somerfield devoted father of Joan, Billy, Kenneth, Alice, Jon and Maggie, and dedicated grandfather of Jordan, Geoff, Jocelyn, Michael, Rachel, Steven and Jennie Rose. Without him, our world will never be the same. Funeral services will be at Schwartz Brothers Funeral Home, Queens Boulevard, Friday, March 6, at 10 AM.

title: The Arbitrator Ruled With Stern in Mind
description: On the surface, the scoreboard reads Latrell Sprewell 1, David Stern 0.

title: Ministers Lead Rally For Precinct Under Fire
description: It had almost all the trappings of a spiritual revival. The ministers praised God. Shouts of ''Amen'' and ''Hallelujah'' punctuated melodious hymns that were sung in perfect harmony.

title: Strong Sales Are Reported For February by Retailers
description: Underscoring a principal shift in the way Americans now shop -- that is, when they feel like it, not simply when merchants want them to -- retailers yesterday reported strong sales for February, usually a quiet shopping month.

title: Court Orders Update on Desegregating of Hartford's Schools
description: A Superior Court judge ordered the state today to show that it had adequately responded to a 1996 ruling by Connecticut's highest court demanding that Gov. John G. Rowland and the General Assembly take swift action to desegregate the public schools in the Hartford area.

title: An Author Wakes Up To the Age And a Boy
description: ''Love and Death on Long Island'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 27, 1997. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Fall Sharply Following Intel Warning

title: Augusta B. Baker, 86, Storyteller, Editor and Children's Librarian
description: Augusta Braxston Baker, a spellbinding storyteller, editor and former custodian of the children's section at the New York Public Library, died on Feb. 23 at Baptist Medical Center in Columbia, S.C. A Columbia resident since 1980, she was 86 and formerly lived in St. Albans, Queens.

title: Prosecutor Refuses to Reopen Sheppard Inquiry
description: Cleveland's chief prosecutor refused yesterday to reopen the criminal investigation into the 1954 murder of the wife of Dr. Sam Sheppard, dismissing new DNA evidence that Dr. Sheppard's supporters say exonerates him.

title: Il Cortile: A Taste of Italy in the Middle of Paris
description: PARIS  Despite a universal love affair with Italian cuisine, the very gastronomic Paris remains a wasteland for authentic pastas, breads, risottos and traditional Italian grilled fare. Leave it to Alain Ducasse, Michelin's new six-star chef and lover of all things Mediterranean, to bail us out here.

title: N.C. State Takes a Step Toward Repeating Feat
description: Last year, North Carolina State became the first eighth-seeded team to reach the final of the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament. Tonight, led by a season-high 25 points from guard Ishua Benjamin, the Wolfpack took the first step toward a repeat voyage, outlasting Florida State, 65-63, in the opening round of the 45th A.C.C. tournament.

title: China to Prime Economic Pump With Mammoth Building Outlay
description: China's leaders plan to spend $1 trillion on a huge range of public works projects in the next three years, in an ambitious effort to stop the Asian financial crisis from derailing the country's economic growth.

title: Television in Review
description: 'The Con'

title: Collision Ahead For Disk Players
description: Anyone considering buying a digital video disk, or DVD, player at $600 and up might be interested to learn that a format war is developing between two delivery systems that might limit the number of movies available to one system or the other.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANASTER, SYLVIA MOLDAW
description: MANASTER-Sylvia Moldaw, 76, of Queens, NY. Beloved wife of Norman Manaster. Formerly of Highland Park, IL, Brookline and Beverly, MA. Loving mother of Faye (Artur) Eldar, Joan (Scott) Ramos, and Beth Manaster. Grandmother of Maya Eldar, Lia and Jesse Ramos. Also survived by her caregiver of eleven years, Grace Poteau. Contributions to Alzheimer's Association, 212 983-0700. For Shiva information call 718-263-7600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIENDLY, FRED W.
description: FRIENDLY-Fred W. 82. Died March 3, 1998. Beloved and cherished husband of Ruth W. Friendly; devoted father of Andrew, Lisa, David, Jon, Michael and Richard; proud grandfather of Noah, Christopher, Emily, James, Ramona, Alice, Sandor, Hannah, Madeleine and Andrew. Funeral service Fri,. March 6, 1998, 11:30 AM, Riverdale Temple, W. 246th St and Independence Ave, Riverdale, NY. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations to the Fred W. Friendly Fund at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism would be greatly appreciated.

title: The Oscar Chase: Power and Dollars
description: Forget Saddam Hussein. Forget Kenneth W. Starr and Bill Clinton.

title: OSCAR-NOMINATED FILMS
description: The following Oscar nominees are on video or will be available this month. Oscar nomination categories are in parentheses.

title: Doctor Held in Sale Of Nine Prescriptions
description: A doctor was arrested yesterday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan after he had illegally sold prescriptions to an undercover officer, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, LOUIS
description: GOLDBERG-Louis. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear and caring friend. We have shared much in the celebrations of life, with family, our anniversaries and the fun of golf and bridge. We shall miss you, Lou. Irma and Stanley, Reggie and Marty, Emily and Jerry

title: Politics Aside, Students Still Need Skills; Winning by Losing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIKE, HARRY
description: PIKE-Harry. On March 4, 1998 in Laurel, MD. Beloved husband of Tess Pike (Nee Nadler). Loving father of Mrs. Susan Blackman of Columbia, MD., and Mrs. Phyllis Berk of Birmingham, Alabama. Devoted brother of the late Mollie Gogel and Anna Lifton. Loving grandfather of Michael and Rayna Blackman, Michael, Barry and Rachel Berk. Services were held. For more information contact Sol Levinson & Bros., Inc., Baltimore, Maryland 800-338-1701.

title: Thucydides' Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a lawsuit accusing the Ford Motor Company of profiting from forced labor in Nazi Germany misstated the number of B-24 bombers that Ford built for the United States during World War II. It was 8,685, not 86,865. The company mentioned the higher figure in a statement in response to the lawsuit on Wednesday, but corrected the number yesterday.

title: Uninvited Guests
description: MARK VANDERLOO, who was VH1's male model of the year in 1996, was scheduled to ride down Broadway in a taxi for a DKNY jeans promotion at Macy's. He is the kind of guy who models of the opposite sex want to be around. Four who had not been scheduled to ride with him climbed in.

title: Williams Sidelined as Nets' Woes Mount
description: Shortly after his teammates took the floor at the Nets' practice facility today, Jayson Williams walked out the back door of the locker room. There was a pained look on his face, as much from frustration as from the pulled abdominal muscle that will sideline him for the next two games and possibly much longer.

title: Starr Is Right to Question White House Aide; The Silent Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Charged In Plot to Sell Apartments
description: A fire at Gouverneur Gardens Apartments last August appeared to be a straightforward high-rise blaze, until firefighters found traces of kerosene leading to a file cabinet in the management office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, AUGUSTA
description: BAKER-Augusta, who died on February 22, was a great children's librarian and storyteller, and a champion of African-American culture in children's books. We are proud to have been her colleagues. Barbara Bader Jean St. Clair

title: A GUIDE TO FILMS WITH NOMINATIONS
description: Here is a listing by critics of The Times of the films that have received major Oscar nominations and are playing this weekend in New York City. + denotes a best picture nomination. * denotes a highly recommended film. Oscar nomination categories, ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We want to sell cars and build an image, but I want to feel like I'm living the truth.''

title: Discipline Fails; So Do The Knicks
description: It was not easy to follow the bouncing Rod Strickland as he bounded inside the paint and slithered his way underneath the Knicks' skin tonight.

title: Many at the Saturn Auto Factory Are Finding Less to Smile About
description: Every week, hundreds of curious tourists make pilgrimages to this small town to take a tour of the Saturn factory. They watch yellow and orange conveyors flow through it like veins carrying car parts to the heart of the assembly line.

title: CHESAPEAKE ENERGY TO ACQUIRE AN OCCIDENTAL UNIT
description: The Chesapeake Energy Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's MC Panhandle Corporation unit for $105 million. MC Panhandle has estimated proven reserves of 100 billion cubic feet of natural gas in the West Panhandle field in Carson, Gray, Hutchinson and Moore Counties of the Texas Panhandle. The wells produced about 13 billion cubic feet of natural gas a day in 1997. Discovered in 1918, the West Panhandle field has produced more than 3.3 trillion cubic feet of natural gas and is expected to produce for at least 50 years more. Chesapeake Energy is based in Oklahoma City. Occidental is based in Los Angeles.

title: Intel Warning Touches Off Flight From Technology Shares
description: They sold first and asked questions later.

title: No Verdict Yet in Manhattan Murder Trial
description: After a full day of deliberations, the jury in the first-degree murder trial of John J. Royster adjourned last night without reaching a verdict. Deliberations are expected to resume this morning in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Goree Island Journal; The Evil That Was Done Senegal: A Guided Tour
description: With a slight wince nowadays, Joseph Ndiaye hoists a rusty cast-iron ball above his head in the courtyard of this island's most famous former slave-trading house, and in a voice as smooth as riverbed stone begins his recital of the banal facts behind one of humanity's greatest crimes.

title: Starr Is Right to Question White House Aide; Grand Jury Secrets
description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Another Jolt For Investors In Technology
description: Motorola Inc. warned late today that earnings during the current quarter would fall well below Wall Street's expectations, another jolt for investors in technology stocks who were already alarmed by the Intel Corporation's similar announcement on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARR, HUGH D. ''RED
description: BARR-Hugh D. ''Red, 71, Erie, PA. On February 15, 1998. Extraordinary musician and consummate newspaperman. Survived by sons Jeff and David, Daughter-in-Law Theresa and grandson Liam. Memorial celebration, Sat. March 7, 1PM, Siebenbuerger Club, Erie, PA. Remembered with special affection by friend Arthur Coake.

title: CLINTON REPORTED TO CALL SECRETARY MAIN TIE TO INTERN
description: In his deposition defending himself against a sexual misconduct lawsuit, President Clinton repeatedly portrayed his secretary, Betty Currie, and not himself, as the principal who dealt with Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern, said lawyers who have reviewed a transcript of the President's testimony.

title: U.S. Files Charge Against Man Found Not Guilty in '94 Fire
description: Signaling a belief that a Manhattan jury erred two years ago when it found a man not guilty of setting a warehouse fire in TriBeCa that killed a firefighter, United States prosecutors took the unusual step yesterday of filing a Federal charge in the case.

title: Editorial Observer; News That Fred Friendly Wouldn't Recognize
description: For all the loving obituaries and on-air panegyrics to the former president of CBS News, Fred Friendly, his death forces us to realize what thin soup television news has become after the hearty stuff Mr. Friendly and his minions served their audiences 30 years ago.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Works on Paper'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVACK, SAUL
description: NOVACK - Saul. Extraordinary, compassionate, brilliant, much loved human being, professor emeritus, former dean of humanities and chairman of the Music Department, Queens College. Adored by wife, Phyllis, and daughter, Carol. Gather to honor our beloved at the Ceremonial Room, Ethical Cultural Society, 2 W. 64 St., Saturday, March 7, 3-5 PM. A memorial celebration will be held on a later date at the Aaron Copland School of Music, Queens College. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Saul Novack Scholarship at the Aaron Copland School of Music.

title: Beleaguered Labor Board Counsel Is Bowing Out
description: Facing opposition from Congressional Republicans, Fred Feinstein, the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, announced yesterday that he was asking President Clinton not to renominate him for the post.

title: Mere Mortals, Don't Try This at Work
description: MEMO to the boss:

title: New Video Releases
description: The Full Monty

title: Whoever That Man May Be, He's Really Enjoying Himself
description: Most of the time, David Neumann had fun in the program he presented on Wednesday night at Dance Theater Workshop. But his one serious piece was scary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRYWES, PROF. MOSHE
description: PRYWES-Prof. Moshe. The American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev mourn the passing of the first President of our University and Founding Dean of the ''Beer-Sheva Experiment'' the Joyce and Irving Goldman Medical School, Ben-Gurion University's innovative, world-renowned medical school. We will sorely miss this brilliant and compassionate man. Kenneth L. Tucker, President Harold L. Oshry, Chairman of the Board Kenneth M. Farber, Executive Vice President

title: Politics Aside, Students Still Need Skills; Language Study Helps
description: To the Editor:

title: DeLorean Jury Rules Against Arthur Andersen
description: Sixteen years after John Z. DeLorean's car company went bankrupt, a Manhattan jury decided yesterday that Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm, should pay as much as $110 million to the company's creditors and investors for not disclosing the company's questionable financial practices.

title: INSIDE
description: Mexican Rebels Unappeased

title: FIRST DATA DIVISION TO DISMISS 10% OF ITS EMPLOYEES
description: The First Data Corporation's merchant services division said yesterday that it would dismiss 10 percent of its staff, or 500 people, as the company reduces costs to improve performance. The division, First Data Merchant Services, based in Englewood, Colo., said the move would help lower the price that merchants pay for charge transactions. The unit processes mostly retail store charge card transactions. First Data said expenses from the job cuts would be offset by a gain on the recent sale of its transportation services unit. Shares of First Data fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $33.6875.

title: A Bowling Ball's-Eye View of Reality
description: Soaking in a bubble bath, smoking a joint and listening to whale sounds, Jeff Lebowski (Jeff Bridges) is surely a happy man. And he keeps his funny, enviable cool throughout ''The Big Lebowski,'' despite the nonstop difficulties (like an attack ferret tossed into that bathtub) that the Coen brothers throw his way. In their latest crazy fable, the Coens send their shaggy hero into turmoil after strangers break into his apartment and grievously insult his rug. It's hard to resist a guy who turns up at the bowling alley with his buddies, grousing, ''Man, it really tied the room together!'' because the rug is gone.

title: Across State, Schools Show Big Strides in Reading Scores
description: Schools across New York State, including those in New York City, posted substantial gains in third-grade and sixth-grade reading last year. School officials praised the results, but educational experts suggested yesterday that improvements came from changes in the tests or student preparation rather than in policies of individual school districts.

title: Rivera And Jeter To Make $750,000
description: Mariano Rivera admitted with a wry smile that he has a specific contract figure he would consider fair. The Yankees did not meet that today, or the one that Derek Jeter had in mind. Unable to come to an agreement with their No. 1 closer and their starting shortstop, the Yankees renewed their contracts, as they may do under the collective bargaining agreement.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Buffy Johnson

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jack Featherly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPERT, ALBERT
description: LIPPERT-Albert. Al, you gave me the chance to follow my dream and make a career of it. You were truly one of a kind. H. Robert Greenbaum

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Some restaurants hang pictures of their rich and famous customers on the walls. Mr. K's doesn't do anything so obvious. When you walk into the high-ceilinged, well-carpeted room, you see two discreet display cases of chopsticks embossed with the names of famous patrons of his Washington restaurant -- Ms. Jane Fonda, Mr. Robert De Niro.

title: Collision Sends Gilmour Out With a Knee Injury
description: The Devils allowed the Boston Bruins to get a third-period goal tonight to forge a 1-1 tie that snapped a seven-game winning streak, but that was the least of their misfortunes.

title: Southeast Asian Fare
description: Restaurants from Southeast Asia range from the familiar to the exotic. Thai ingredients are now commonplace in the kitchens of French restaurants, and Vietnamese restaurants seem to have opened every few blocks, but you can count New York's Cambodian and Indonesian restaurants on the fingers of one hand and still have room for more. As for Laotian restaurants: if you find one, let us know. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLANT, RICHARD, DR.
description: PLANT-Richard, Dr. died at his home in Greenwich Village on March 3, 1998 at age of 87. Dr. Plant was a prominent academic and scholar of the Holocaust and the author of ''The Pink Triangle, The Nazi War Against Homosexuals''. He is survived by his close friend and companion, Michael Sasse. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to The New York City Gay and Lesbian Anti-Violence Project, 647 Hudson St, NY NY 10014. Arrangements for a memorial service will be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLTOFF, KAY
description: COLTOFF-Kay. The Officers, Trustees and Staff of The Children's Aid Society join with the children of New York City and extend their heartfelt condolences and deepest sympathy to Philip Coltoff, the Society's Executive Director, and family upon the death of Kay Coltoff, beloved wife and mother, and cherished colleague. She was a friend of all children and families in the city. She touched each of us and tens of thousands in need with her courage, compassion and abiding humor. She is mourned, will be deeply missed and always remembered. Mrs. Stowe C. Phelps, Honorary Chairman John S. Griswold, Honarary Chairman Edward M. Lamont, Chairman Edgar R. Koerner, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDERMAN, ANNE TULLY
description: RUDERMAN-Anne Tully. We, the Board of Directors of the New York Milton H. Erickson Society, express our deepest sadness and profound loss of our beloved and loving friend, colleague, teacher and former president who died February 28, 1998. A memorial service will be held in late June.

title: In the Garden of Art, Structure Tempts
description: ''Fabrications,'' the new architecture show at the Museum of Modern Art, takes a mortal blow from curatorial overkill. Here is a show of four garden follies, all of them more or less playful in spirit. But these slight, whimsical structures have been burdened with the trappings of a major exhibition: portentous catalog essays, interactive computer programs, blown-up video projections, etc. The bloated grandiosity is more than the work on view can bear.

title: I.M.F. Delays Indonesian Aid; Reforms Seem to Be Stalled
description: As criticism grew of President Suharto's failure to press ahead with the International Monetary Fund's economic program, the fund said Friday that it was delaying the release of further financing for Indonesia.

title: Be Civil, He Growled
description: When Mayor Rudolph Giuliani appeared onstage as part of the Inner Circle journalists' review last year, he was supposed to be a beauty of sorts. ''Rudy Rudia'' was a Marilyn Monroe character with a cigar. This year, playing off his press clippings, Mr. Giuliani agreed to be the Beast. As any parent or publicity agent knows these days, the Beast is more than meets the ear or eye. The Disney creature growls a lot and goes into rages now and then, but underneath all that hair and those big teeth and the oversized Prince Charming outfit, he's not such a bad guy after all.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Job Creation Surges, Confounding Expectations

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUPA, VITO M.
description: ZUPA-Vito M. On March 6, 1998. Devoted father of Victor. Loving father-in-law of Mary. Dear grandfather of Evelyn and Paul Shyposh, Ann and Mary Beth. Also surviving are many family members and his longtime beloved friend Janina Haba. Mass of Christian Burial was celebrated today at 10 A.M., at Our Lady of Solace Church and entombment followed at St. Raymond's Cemetery. The family has requested that donations be made in the memory of Vito to Visiting Nurse Services of New York, 981 Morris Park Avenue, Bronx, New York 10462.

title: What the C.I.A. Can Teach the P.L.O.
description: Having pressed the Palestine Liberation Organization to crack down on terrorism, the United States cannot turn away from the sometimes ugly and unjust results. Palestinian security services regularly torture detainees, and 18 people have died in their custody in the past four years. So it is reasonable for the Central Intelligence Agency to be training Palestinian forces in more acceptable, and more effective, interrogation techniques and other aspects of intelligence gathering.

title: Expansive Technique In Intimate Setting
description: Andre Watts does not often turn his formidable pianistic technique to contemporary music, and it was interesting that he chose Tobias Picker's ''Old and Lost Rivers'' on which to do so in his recital on Tuesday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This little piece, from 1986, is disarmingly simple, with widely separated melodies evidently representing the high bridge and the winding bayous Mr. Picker describes in the program notes. Mr. Watts could probably have played it with one hand if only the lines were not so far apart.

title: Sports of The Times; Good Plays And Better Memories
description: AS Syracuse took on Villanova in a quarterfinal game of the conference tournament at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, three Ghosts of Big Easts Past settled behind the Orangemen's bench: Rony Seikaly, class of 1988; Sherman Douglas, class of 1989, and Derrick Coleman, class of 1990.

title: A Nurse's Account Is Attacked In the Brawley Defamation Trial
description: The defense in the Tawana Brawley defamation case raised questions today about the competence and compassion of the first nurse to treat Ms. Brawley upon her arrival in a hospital emergency room in 1987.

title: Starr's Three Silent Chaperons
description: The extension of Kenneth Starr's investigation from Whitewater into the perpetually expanding Monica Lewinsky case has proved to be a bad decision -- a triple failure by Mr. Starr, Attorney General Janet Reno and the three-judge panel that is meant to supervise Mr. Starr. It threatens the survival of the independent counsel law. The heart of the problem is a single, unsexy word: jurisdiction. It's not too late for the three-judge panel to set things right.

title: Couple in Baby Death Case Appear Estranged in Court
description: For the first time since they were released on bail 14 months ago, the two teen-agers charged with murdering their baby and leaving his body in a motel trash bin appeared in the same courtroom today.

title: Late Surge by Martin Leaves Him 3 Back
description: Walking to his 20-foot birdie putt on his last hole, Casey Martin glanced at the Greater Austin Open scoreboard. His name wasn't on it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALTROWITZ, HELEN
description: PALTROWITZ-Helen. Of Danbury, Connecticut, died March 6, 1998, peacefully at The Hebrew Home For The Aged. Born on December 11, 1908. Wife of the late Leroy Paltrowitz. Devoted mother of Michael, Carolyn, Ronald and Anne. Cherished grandmother of Geoffrey, Kathryn, Melissa, Nanci and Jason. Great grandmother of Esther and Naomi. Services will be held on Sunday, March 8, at 2:00 P.M., at The United Jewish Center, Danbury, Connecticut.

title: Business Group Leader Arraigned in Drug Case
description: The leader of the Zoo Crew was arraigned on Federal drug charges yesterday after his arrest the day before. He was indicted on Aug. 29 with other members of the Newark-based group, who billed themselves as community-minded entrepreneurs but who prosecutors say were drug dealers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are open to the restitution of everything given to the museum in an immoral trade. This should have been done 30 or 40 years ago. We have to fulfill a specific moral debt.''

title: After 'Capeman,' A Chill in a Thriving Broadway Season
description: The rapid collapse of Paul Simon's $11 million Broadway musical, ''The Capeman,'' just under two months after opening, was only the largest in a string of failures that has made this one of the costliest Broadway seasons in memory.

title: Man Is Guilty in 3 Attacks, Including a Woman's Murder
description: After a six-week trial, John J. Royster was convicted yesterday of murdering Evelyn Alvarez, who was beaten to death as she opened her Park Avenue dry-cleaning shop. He was convicted of smashing Shelby Evans Schrader's head against the blacktop so savagely that her nose was flattened. And he was convicted of attempting to rape a young piano teacher as she strolled through Central Park, beating her so severely that her own father could not recognize her.

title: Theater History, Moved
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Changes Expected in the Sale of Mutual Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to adopt sweeping changes next week in the way that mutual fund companies sell their shares to investors.

title: Celestine Tate Harrington, 42, Quadriplegic Street Musician
description: Celestine Tate Harrington, a quadriplegic street musician whose buoyant personality and unremitting chutzpah brought astounded smiles to everyone who watched her play the keyboard with her lips and tongue on Atlantic City's Boardwalk, died on Feb. 25 at the Atlantic City Medical Center. She was 42.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANASTER, SYLVIA
description: MANASTER-Sylvia, 76. March 2, 1998. Beloved wife of Norman. Also survived by daughters Faye, Joan, Beth, sister Raquel (Gary) Schwalb and three grandchildren.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKYE, WILLIAM
description: SKYE-William. On March 5, 1998 at age 84. Husband of Norma. Father of Stephen, Jeffrey and Richard. Loving grandfather of Allison, Stephanie and Danielle. Loving great-grandfather of Jason. Services New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. Sunday, March 8, 2PM. Should friends desire, donations may be made to Alzheimer's Assoc., 20 Lexington Avenue, Suite 610, NY, NY 10070.

title: The Country Club: The Good Life or a Greedy One?
description: In ''The Theory of the Leisure Class,'' the economist Thorstein Veblen said: ''In order to gain and to hold the esteem of men, it is not sufficient merely to possess wealth or power. The wealth or power must be put in evidence, for esteem is awarded only in evidence.'' In a book being published this month, ''The American Country Club: Its Origins and Development'' (Rutgers University Press), James M. Mayo, a professor at the school of architecture and urban design at the University of Kansas, quotes various writers on this suburban oasis.

title: DIAMOND HOME SERVICES TO ACQUIRE REEVES SOUTHEASTERN
description: Diamond Home Services Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Reeves Southeastern Corporation for $42 million in cash and notes to expand its home-improvement business. Diamond Home, based in Woodstock, Ill., sells roofing, doors and fencing, primarily under the Sears brand, and had 1997 sales of $161 million. Reeves, a Tampa, Fla., maker of fencing and outdoor-security products with 1997 revenue of $122 million, operates 31 distribution centers in 20 states. Diamond Home rose 75 cents, to $6.75.

title: Serbs Pound Kosovo To Repel Separatists
description: Serbian policemen cracked down on a separatist movement in the province of Kosovo yesterday, firing mortar rounds at villages, setting fire to homes and appearing to shoot at men indiscriminately, according to those who fled the zone.

title: Nets Suffer Hard Loss Without Williams
description: While they were on the floor tonight, the Nets listened to the loud applause that rewarded a courageous effort. But in the locker room afterward, there was hardly a sound, just whispered might-have-beens.

title: A Small War to Control a Crumbling Armory and Its Art
description: With questions arising over the upkeep and management of the landmark Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue, a struggle has erupted over who will control the building and the millions of dollars of paintings and artifacts it contains.

title: BIG EAST CONFERENCE TOURNAMENT: Last-Chance Shot Lifts the Orangemen in Overtime; Connecticut Bursts The Rutgers Balloon
description: Rutgers kept altering the expected and kept breathing. One day, two days. Back for a third day at Madison Square Garden, the Scarlet Knights were not just short-term guests at the Big East Conference tournament anymore. They were trying to become one of the two guests of honor in tonight's title game if they could accomplish the unexpected one more time against Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ETHEL BLANCK.
description: WEINSTEIN-Ethel Blanck. West Orange, NJ. Beloved wife of Sidney. Endearing mother of David, Daniel and Michael. Adoring grandmother of Zoe, Stevie, Simon, Hannah and Max. Devoted sister of Semon Blanck. Admiring mother-in-law of Laura Foner and Martha Matlaw, and loving friend. Services will be held on Sunday morning, March 8, at 9:30 AM, at Temple Sholom of West Essex, 760 Pompton Avenue, Cedar Grove, New Jersey. A private family burial will take place on March 10 at Sharon Memorial Park, Sharon, MA. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice or to the Sister Rose Thering Endowment Fund, Seton Hall University, South Orange, NJ.

title: Welfare Miracle, Or Mirage?
description: Both Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki have taken recent steps to change the welfare system of New York, city and state. The Governor this week proposed cutting the cash grants to entire families if a parent refuses ''workfare'' assignments. And the Mayor sent a strong signal in January by making Jason A. Turner the head of the city's Human Resources Administration.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Guilty Plea by Ex-Official of Archer Daniels
description: A former executive with the Archer Daniels Midland Company pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy and tax fraud charges stemming from a scheme to steal money from the giant grain company, Justice Department officials said.

title: Tamil Guerrillas in Sri Lanka: Deadly and Armed to the Teeth
description: These are some of the weapons in the arsenal of the Tamil Tigers, the guerrilla army waging a bloody war for an independent state on the tiny island nation of Sri Lanka: surface-to-air missiles from Cambodia, assault rifles from Afghanistan, mortar shells from the former Yugoslavia and Zimbabwe, 60 tons of explosives from Ukraine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEBARD, UNA T.
description: HEBARD-Una T. (Retired School Teacher). On Mar. 6, 1998. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving friend to many. Visiting Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M., McLaughlin & Sons, Third Avenue at 97th Street. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday at 9:30 AM at St. Patrick's Church.

title: Starr's Inquiry Of President Tries Patience Of Trent Lott
description: Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, expressed impatience today with the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr, declaring that it is time for Mr. Starr ''to show his cards'' or close his operation if he cannot win any more convictions.

title: Austria Is Set to Return Artworks Confiscated From Jews by Nazis
description: Sixty years after the Nazis marched into Austria to cheering crowds, Austrian officials say they are prepared to return to their owners artworks confiscated by the Nazis and then kept here in museums as national treasures.

title: Soldier's Evidence for Alibi Is Described as Suspicious
description: A critical piece of evidence at the court-martial of Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, his entry on a sign-in sheet at a self-service auto repair shop, was called suspicious today by a forensic document examiner.

title: Astra Chief Says He Would Like Merger Partner
description: Igniting the latest outbreak of acquisition fever, the chief executive of Astra A.B., the Swedish pharmaceutical giant, said yesterday that he would like to merge his company with a drug maker of similar size.

title: Spin Control:Opel and VW In a Flip Flap
description: FRANKFURT  The "elk test" is turning the German auto industry upside down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLER, EBERHARD, HANS J.
description: MULLER-EBERHARD-Hans J. One of the world's leading molecular immunologists, died March 3, 1998. Director of the Institute of Molecular Medicine for the Prevention of Human Diseases at the University of Texas-Houston, his research contribution dominated an era in immunology and biomedical research. From 1988-1995 he led the world-renowned Bernhard Nocht Institute for Tropical Medicine in Germany. He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences and Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Irma Gigli-Muller-Eberhard, and daughters Kristina and Monika Muller-Eberhard. A memorial service will be held 4:00PM, Monday, March 16, at Palmer Memorial Episcopal Church, 6221 Main St. Houston, TX. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Institute of Molecular Medicine, the University of Texas-Houston Health Science Center, 2121 W. Holcombe Blvd, Houston, TX 77030

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: Defector From Cuba Will Join The Yanks
description: Orlando Hernandez, a Cuban defector and the older brother of the World Series star Livan Hernandez, agreed last night to a four-year, $6.6 million contract with the Yankees.

title: Senate Stops Bid to End Road-Work Set-Asides
description: In the year's first major test of Federal affirmative action policies, the Senate strongly rejected an effort today to end a two-decade-old program that seeks to give 10 percent of all Federally financed highway contracts to companies owned by minorities and women.

title: Study Panel On Medicare Begins Work, In Conflict
description: A Federal advisory commission that will study the future of Medicare kicked off a year of work today with members declaring a desire for bipartisan agreement but skirmishing over President Clinton's proposal to open the program to millions of people 55 to 64 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANAS DE MULLER, ISABEL
description: MANAS de MULLER-Isabel. On March 5, 1998. Age 98. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Loving mother of Eduarda and Eugene Raul. Cherished grandmother of Alan Charles and Mary Raul. Adored great-grandmother of Caroline Raul and William Eduardo. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:45 A.M., St. Margaret of Cortona R.C. Church. Interment Mount Hope Cemetery.

title: Coach Was Out of Line; A Lesser Crime?
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Prison Guards Guilty of Abuse Of Immigrants
description: Three Union County prison guards were convicted today of assaulting and abusing more than a dozen asylum-seeking immigrants who had been brought to the county jail on the night of June 18, 1995, after the nearby Federal detention center was shut down in a disturbance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, DONALD ALAN,
description: MORRISON-Donald Alan, 66, of Milford, Connecticut. Beloved son of Henry Morrison and the late Betty Sejeck Morrison. Mr. Morrison was a resident of Moodus, Connecticut, for 20 years before moving to Milford a year ago. He was a U.S. Navy Veteran of the Korean Conflict. Mr. Morrison was the Owner and President of Direct Color Systems of Milford. Previously, he was the Owner and President of Rowland, Inc of Kensington, Connecticut. He was a member of Y.P.O. (Young Presidents Organization) and was on the Board of Directors for Practical Systems, Inc of Odessa, Florida. In addition to his father, Mr. Morrison is survived by his companion, Carol Shyer; three sons, David Morrison of Glastonbury, Connecticut, Scott Morrison of Newtown Square, Pennsylvania, and Todd Morrison of New York City; four grandchildren, Phoebe, Natalie, Julia, and Kim Morrison. Friends are invited to attend a Memorial Service on Saturday at 12 Noon in the First United Church of Christ Congregational, 34 West Main Street, Milford, Connecticut. Committal will be private. Donations are being accepted in Donald's name to the World Wildlife Fund, 1250 24th Street, NW, Washington, D.C. 20037.

title: HASBRO TO CLOSE PLANT THAT MAKES SCRABBLE LETTERS
description: Hasbro Inc. plans to close a Fairfax, Vt., plant that makes letter tiles for the Scrabble board game and dismiss 87 workers. Hasbro, which is based in Pawtucket, R.I., acquired the plant when it bought the Scrabble line in 1989. In addition to the letter tiles, the factory makes the wooden racks that hold them and houses and hotels used in the deluxe version of Monopoly. The plant will shut down in September. The announcement marked the fifth plant closing since Hasbro, the nation's second-largest toy maker, announced in December that it would slash 2,500 jobs, or 20 percent of its work force, and exit some markets to bolster profit. Hasbro took a fourth-quarter charge of $92.4 million, or 68 cents a share, to pay for the restructuring moves. Shares of Hasbro rose 12.5 cents, to $35.375.

title: FORSTMANN PLANS LAYOFFS AT 2 GEORGIA PLANTS
