description: The wool textile manufacturer Forstmann & Company said yesterday that it would lay off 730 workers at two Georgia plants that produce worsted fabrics after completing orders for the fall season. The job cuts, which will occur in late summer, will affect 650 workers at a plant in Milledgeville and 80 at a plant in Louisville, the company said. Forstmann, which emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy-law protection last July, said it would stop producing men's suitings and government top-dye worsted fabrics. It plans to continue producing fancy worsted fabrics and worsted piece-dyed fabric. Top-dye worsteds accounted for $18 million in 1997 sales. Last year, Forstmann, based in New York, lost $7 million on sales of $199 million.

title: Judge To Lift Curb on Sex-Shop Law
description: A Federal District judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that as early as Wednesday night the Giuliani administration could begin enforcing a zoning law that would ban X-rated businesses from residential neighborhoods in New York City.

title: LEARNING COMPANY SETS DEAL FOR MINDSCAPE
description: The Learning Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Mindscape Inc. from the British media conglomerate Pearson P.L.C. for $150 million in cash and stock. The Learning Company, of Cambridge, Mass., makes educational software. It had sales of $392.4 million in 1997. Mindscape, of Novato, Calif., publishes educational and entertainment software, including Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing and Lego Island. It had revenue of $130 million in 1997. Separately, the Learning Company said its Softkey Software Products Inc. unit had raised $104 million in a private placement of 6.25 million special warrants exchangeable for Learning Company stock on a 1-for-1 basis.

title: Police Say Patient Raped A Catatonic Woman
description: A patient at a Brooklyn hospital was arrested yesterday and accused of raping a woman as she lay in a catatonic state, the police said.

title: A Pair Accepts a Mutual Bid For a Permanent Partnership
description: The number of husband-and-wife combinations each of whom owns a major world title recently doubled, from one to two. Mike Passell of Dallas won the Bermuda Bowl in 1979 and his wife, Nancy, was a Venice Cup winner in 1993. They are now joined by Bob Levin, a Bermuda Bowl winner in 1981, and Jillian Blanchard, who won the Venice Cup in 1995 and the Women's Team Olympiad title a year later. They were married in January, and live primarily in Riverdale, the Bronx

title: Privatizing Social Security Wouldn't Pay Off; Wizardry Not Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers' Next Test? Devils
description: The Rangers are on cusp of a home-and-home series with the Devils that will, they say, define their improvement under their new coach, John Muckler. They have more pressing things to think about than the threat of sanctions by the United States Olympic Committee against the American men's hockey team. Ranger Captain Brian Leetch said yesterday he thought the U.S.O.C's punitive stand was laughable.

title: Publisher Apologizes to Hong Kong Chief for Canceled Book
description: After a week of relentlessly bad publicity over its abrupt decision to cancel a book by Chris Patten, Hong Kong's last British Governor, HarperCollins today took the highly unusual step of issuing a full apology to Mr. Patten and agreed to pay him an unspecified amount of money.

title: S.& P. 500 Jumps 2% as Bargain Buyers Fuel Trading
description: If the market is lower, it must be a buying opportunity.

title: HILTON SAID TO HOLD MERGER TALKS WITH CIRCUS CIRCUS
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation has held talks with Circus Circus Enterprises Inc. about buying the casino operator, the Bear, Stearns & Company analyst Jason Ader said, citing conversations with executives at both companies. The discussions are at a very early stage and may not yield an agreement, he said. Hilton declined to comment and Circus Circus officials could not be reached. A purchase would be the biggest in a wave of casino industry acquisitions in recent months. Shares of Circus Circus shares rose $1.6875, to $23.9375. Shares of Hilton jumped 31.25 cents, to $32.375.

title: Richard F. Shepard, 75, Editor And a Writer for The Times
description: Richard F. Shepard, a retired New York Times writer who was also a former cultural news editor of The Times and was known for his amiably down-to-earth manner, which included meeting friends at a Theater District cafe he called ''the Polish Tea Room,'' died last night at his home in Fresh Meadows, Queens. He was 75 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 30 about William Wood Prince, a prominent Chicago businessman and philanthropist, referred imprecisely to the way in which he became heir to Frederick H. Prince, a distant cousin who legally adopted him. Frederick Prince indeed had offspring, but one son, Frederick H. Prince, was not interested in the family business and the other, Norman Prince, died in World War I. A reader's letter postmarked Feb. 25 pointed out the error.

title: D.C. Ennui
description: A new axiom on domestic affairs seems to have taken hold in Washington this year. It is, simply, the less you do, the more popular you become. Take the Republicans in the House, who once vowed to make history by remaking government. This year they seem content with mini-measures on school vouchers, drugs and crime. Indeed, House members are much more involved in palace intrigue than in any item on their agenda. Yet the approval ratings of Congress, like those of a President Clinton who offered his own list of sound-bite policies in the State of the Union speech, have soared to record levels.

title: Serbs Bombed Ethnic Albanians; Many are Feared Dead
description: Hundreds of Serbian policemen pounded villages in central Kosovo with mortar rounds today, set fire to homes and appeared to shoot at men indiscriminately in a sweep to stamp out a separatist movement of ethnic Albanians, according to those who fled the zone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWCOMB, WILLIAM K.
description: NEWCOMB-William K. on March 4, 1998 age 68, of Palermo, NJ. Former V.P., Johnson & Higgins, NYC. Husband of Ezit (nee Wooster) also survived by three children and four grandchildren. Services and burial are private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVACK, SAUL
description: NOVACK-Saul. Gather to honor our beloved at the Ceremonial Room, Ethical Cultural Society, 2 W. 64 St., Saturday, Mar. 7, 3-5 PM.

title: Equality and Civility
description: To the Editor:

title: Journal; Love That Bill
description: This side of Hollywood no one has done more to further America's modern cult of celebrity than the house that Luce built: Time, Life, People. And so it only followed that at the 75th anniversary bash for Time at Radio City this week, fame, not goodness, determined the guest list: Joe DiMaggio and Louis Farrakhan, Anita Hill and Imelda Marcos, Mel Brooks and the actual Nazi propagandist he evoked in ''Springtime for Hitler,'' Leni Riefenstahl. Celebrity uber alles, indeed: as in Luce journalism, star-sized personalities guaranteed entree more than intellectual or moral attainment.

title: Connecticut Lottery Worker Kills 4 Bosses, Then Himself
description: Angered about a salary dispute and his failure to win a promotion, a Connecticut Lottery accountant reported promptly to his job this morning, hung up his coat and then methodically stabbed and gunned down four of his bosses, one of whom he chased through a parking lot, before turning the gun on himself.

title: STATE AUTO FINANCIAL PLANS 2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT
description: The State Auto Financial Corporation said yesterday that it planned to split its shares 2 for 1 and purchase an insurance unit from its mutual, or policyholder-owned, parent company. Investors would get one new State Auto Financial share for each common share held on June 18, the company said. The split, set for July 8, hinges on shareholder approval of a measure increasing State Auto's stock authorization to 100 million shares from 30 million. State Auto Financial will buy the Milbank Insurance Company, a South Dakota auto and homeowners insurer, from State Automobile Mutual on July 1. The price is now about $79 million, according to the chief investment officer, James Duemey. State Auto Financial shares rose $1.75, to $32.75.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the court-martial of Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney referred incorrectly to part of the testimony of Richard Roy, the husband of one of the women who have accused the sergeant major of sexual misconduct. Mr. Roy said he shouted obscenities while his wife, Sgt. Christina Roy, was on the telephone with Sergeant Major McKinney. Mr. Roy did not tell of talking directly to the sergeant major.

title: About New York; Action Fans Glimpse the Spirit of Kung Fu
description: RIGHT, then. If you spent too many Saturdays watching kung fu flicks on Channel 5, those words are as certain to spur memories of face-saving kicks and leaps as surely as a perfume's scent reminds others of a first love's face. The phrase really meant nothing, inserted by dubbers in a gloriously cheesy attempt to make sure the words didn't end before the Chinese actors' lips stopped moving.

title: Democrats Lead G.O.P. In an Early Money Race
description: Democrats have taken a surprising, strong early lead over Republicans in raising money to contest open Congressional seats, the House seats most likely to change hands, Federal Election Commission records show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, ABRAHAM
description: SUSSMAN-Abraham. On March 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Pearl; loving father of Eleanor and Norman; adoring grandfather of Carol, Robert, Rebecca and Zachary; great-grandfather of Shlomi, Yasmin and Sarah. He will always be remembered by his family. Service on Sunday, at 9:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Beliefs
description: A little more than a week ago, the State of Oregon took the historic step of deciding that it would pay to help dying poor people kill themselves. The state's Health Services Commission voted, 10 to 1, to include doctor-assisted suicide on the list of ''treatments'' covered for Medicaid patients. It joined doctor-assisted suicide to other forms of ''comfort care'' for any ''terminal illness, regardless of diagnosis.''

title: Hudson River Cleanup
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL FALLS FURTHER. Crude oil fell below $15 a barrel for the first time in four years on rising supply and declining demand, dropping 42 cents, to $14.91, for April delivery. Heating oil hit its lowest price in more than nine years.

title: Op-Art
Friendly Is Recalled as Loud Voice of Integrity
description: Broadcast pioneer Fred W. Friendly was laid to rest yesterday, with warm tributes from family, friends and former colleagues -- and with a well-thumbed copy of the United States Constitution in his suit pocket.

title: Four People Devoted to Work and Family
description: With his retiring demeanor and sparse words, Otho R. Brown could easily blend into almost any background. But he stood at the forefront of the state lottery industry, because he had navigated the potentially turbulent transition of Connecticut's game from what was essentially a government agency to its own quasi-public entity.

title: Corrections
description: An architecture review on Thursday about Philip Johnson's proposal for two new towers in Times Square referred incorrectly to the status of Mr. Johnson's firm while he recovered from heart surgery two years ago. The firm, Philip Johnson/Alan Ritchie Architects, did not close; it continued to work on projects designed by Mr. Johnson and new designs under Mr. Ritchie's direction.

title: Furyk Shoots Himself Into Contention
description: When the day started, Jim Furyk was in danger of missing the cut. When the day ended, he was in the record book.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASS, DR. MORTON.
description: KASS-Dr. Morton. All of us at the East Midwood Jewish Center mourn the passing of the brother of our distinguished and beloved rabbi, Dr. Alvin Kass. Rabbi Kass' brother was an eminent physician in Paterson, New Jersey, who dispensed his medical skills with humaneness and spiritual sensitivity. We pray that God will comfort Rabbi Kass and all the members of the bereaved family. Marsha Shlefstein, President Harvey Marks, Executive Director

title: Fewer Children Per Care Provider Is Good for All, Study Finds
description: At a time when policy makers are discussing ways to improve the quality of child care, a new study by the Families and Work Institute has found that children fared better in day care when the teacher-to-child ratios were lowered.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR STEADY. The dollar rallied yesterday against the yen and the mark after the February jobs report. But it finished up only slightly, at 127.93 yen, from 127.81 on Thursday. It was off slightly against the mark.

title: Tijuana Journal; After a Murder Attempt, An Editor Is Unbowed
description: Jesus Blancornelas is hunched in a bulletproof vest in a car moving through the grit and fear of East Tijuana, approaching the intersection where traffickers opened fire on him in an ambush in November, critically wounding him and killing his bodyguard.

title: Zapping the Way to Better Police Marksmanship
description: The staticky radio call warned of a girl being beaten by her stepfather. When the police arrived, they found a shirtless man pummeling a girl.

title: Klezmer Keeps Growing: Was That Beethoven?
description: Klezmer's long journey has not ended yet. The music that arrived in America with Jewish immigrants from Eastern Europe, having already absorbed elements of Balkan, Gypsy and Middle-Eastern music, is still expanding. For the ''New Sounds Live'' concert at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night, which was broadcast on WNYC-FM, two groups played music with klezmer roots and New York cosmopolitanism. John Zorn's music for the Masada String Trio carried klezmer across styles and continents, and the fiddler Alicia Svigals led a traditionalist group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIERNAN, RAYMOND J.
description: KIERNAN-Raymond J. Of Bronxville, NY on March 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Jeanne Sillery Kiernan. Cousin of Patricia Kiernan O'Sullivan. Survived by several nieces and nephews. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville betw the hours of 2-4 and 7-9pm Saturday and Sunday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Monday, March 9 at 11am. Masses preferred or contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: 3 Dionne Survivors Accept A $28 Million Settlement
description: After suffering a public relations nightmare that made Ontario appear unresponsive to the plight of the three surviving Dionne quintuplets, the Government announced a settlement for them today worth $2.8 million. It also offered to open an inquiry into the nine-and-a-half years the sisters were wards of the state.

title: Knicks Join In Watching Sixers' Show
description: An irritated John Starks stalked off the court late in the game, with hecklers' calls escorting him to the bench. He glared but moved on in silence to take his seat.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the expected appointment of a managing editor at The Washington Post referred incorrectly in some copies to the plans of the current one, Robert G. Kaiser. He plans to resume writing and reporting; he is not retiring.

title: MCKESSON AND AMERISOURCE SAY THEY MAY SUE F.T.C.
description: The McKesson Corporation and the Amerisource Health Corporation said in a joint news release that they were ''evaluating litigation'' with the Federal Trade Commission over the commission's March 3 decision to file a complaint to block the companies' merger. The companies said they believed the F.T.C.'s analysis of the wholesale drug industry and its conclusion that the McKesson-Amerisource merger would lead to higher prices was inaccurate. The companies said industry data showed that wholesaler consolidation had reduced the cost of health care, and argued that the $1.79 billion merger would yield cost savings and expanded services.

title: Russia Plans to Sell Reactors to Iran Despite U.S. Protests
description: In a rebuff to the United States, Russia's Atomic Energy Ministry said today that it plans to sell several more nuclear reactors to Iran.

title: House Arrest for Suspect In Iran Embargo Case
description: A New Jersey businessman charged with trying to sell military aircraft parts to Iran was was released yesterday on a $2.5 million bond and placed under house arrest.

title: GE CAPITAL TO BUY BARCOM FOR $67 MILLION
description: The GE Capital Corporation agreed to buy Barcom P.L.C., which provides fleet management for the mining, engineering and construction industries, for $:41.4 million ($67 million). GE Capital, a unit of the General Electric Company based in Fairfield, Conn., would pay 72 pence for each Barcom share. The offer represents a premium of 47 percent over Barcom's closing share price yesterday. Shares of Barcom, which is based in Wellingborough, Northamptonshire, soared 19.5 pence, or 40 percent, to 68.50 pence. Barcom also offers medium- and long-term contracts for fleet management and distributes equipment to the engineering, agriculture, forestry and other industries.

title: At Least The Horses Are Sane
description: If ''Hush'' is any indication of the future path of Jessica Lange's movie career, it won't be long before she is wielding a bloody ax and bellowing like a lunatic in the kind of psycho-killer romp associated with the cinematic twilights of Bette Davis and Tallulah Bankhead. To give those Grand Guignol camp fests their due, at least they exuded a certain raw energy. But ''Hush'' is much too ''nice'' a movie to take off its white gloves and get down and dirty in the barnyard droppings that its characters refer to regularly. The movie, which opened yesterday, hasn't the foggiest notion whether it's a soap opera or a horror film, and wanders around in a generic fog.

title: One Lake Too Many
description: To the Editor:

title: The Curse of a Civil Society
description: Oh, what a fire the savages of New York must light for their supper! Christopher Morley

title: BIG EAST CONFERENCE TOURNAMENT: Last-Chance Shot Lifts the Orangemen in Overtime; Artest Can Rescue St. John's Just Once
description: St. John's went the distance and then some against Syracuse last night in the semifinals of the Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden, but the Red Storm was knocked out by a blow at the buzzer as Orangemen forward Ryan Blackwell nailed a 15-foot jumper in overtime to give Syracuse a 69-67 victory.

title: INSIDE
description: Book Publisher Apologizes

title: Not to Bury Homer but to Update Him
description: Who killed Homer?

title: EF Education Quits Fifth Leg
description: Becalmed and bedeviled, EF Education, the all-female team in the Whitbread Round the World Race, retired yesterday from Leg 5 after 33 days 11 hours at sea.

title: Q & A / Lamberto Dini, Italy's Foreign Minister : Nudging Iran to Back Its Words With Deeds Against Terrorism
description: Italy's foreign minister, Lamberto Dini, was to hold wide-ranging talks Saturday with the U.S. secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, in Rome. Mr. Dini was expected to brief his U.S. counterpart on his meeting in Tehran this week with President Mohammed Khatami of Iran. Mr. Dini discussed Iran's new position on terrorism with Alan Friedman of the International Herald Tribune.

title: Could the Old South Be Resurrected?; Cherished Ideas of the Confederacy (Not Slavery) Find New Backers
description: Few things in American intellectual life would seem quite so terminally discredited as the politics and culture of the white, slaveholding, antebellum South.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIENDLY, FRED W.
description: FRIENDLY-Fred W. My condolences to David F. on the loss of his great Dad. David List, Sydney Australia

title: Privatizing Social Security Wouldn't Pay Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Privatizing Social Security Wouldn't Pay Off; Benefits for Survivors
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Appoints 2 Editors
description: Appointments to two senior editing positions at The New York Times Magazine have been announced by Adam Moss, who takes over in April as the magazine's editor. Katherine Bouton will be deputy editor and Gerald Marzorati will be editorial director.

title: Senators Back Extra Military Spending but Fault Gulf Allies
description: The Senate committee that controls spending bills grudgingly signaled its support today for the Clinton Administration's request to pay for military missions in Bosnia and the Persian Gulf, but criticized gulf allies for not helping defray the cost of the recent force buildup in the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, ALEXANDER
description: JACKSON-Alexander. Of East Hampton, NY, of a stroke on March 5, 1998. Beloved brother of Richard M. Jackson (Lloyd Harbor, NY) and Joan Jackson Forte (Marion, MA and Naples, FL) and the late Katharine Jackson Bass and Danforth Jackson. Beloved uncle of 11 nieces and nephews and 19 great-nieces and nephews. He attended St. Mark's School and was a graduate of Phillips Academy, Andover, MA. Following his graduation from Harvard in 1950, he attended Columbia Law School until he joined the US Air Force, attaining the rank of captain. He later received his MBA from the Harvard Business School in 1955. Mr. Jackson joined the First National City Bank in NYC and served as Vice President in the Trust Department until his retirement. He was a Director of the William Waldorf Astor Foundation, Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation in Stratford, VA, Edward S. Moore Foundation and the Fresh Air Fund. In East Hampton he was a member of the Board of Managers of the East Hampton Library and a Director of the East Hampton Historical Society. In February he was elected to the Board of the East Hampton Neighborhood House Association. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, East Hampton, Saturday, March 14, 2 PM. Interment will be in Dublin, NH. In lieu of flowers, contributions to any of the above organizations would be appreciated.

title: For Lewinsky, Fame Aplenty But at the Price of Freedom
description: In a two-bedroom apartment on the banks of the Potomac River, Monica S. Lewinsky, the object of seven weeks of sudden celebrity, is struggling to adjust to what her friends describe as an increasingly cloistered and sometimes suffocating daily existence.

title: Another Wilson May Bloom Soon as a Met
description: Preston Wilson sees a lot of similarity in his playing style and that of his adopted father, the celebrated ex-Met Mookie Wilson. Yet there is one distinct difference.

title: Hans Muller-Eberhard, 70, Immunologist, Dies
description: Dr. Hans J. Muller-Eberhard, an immunologist who made crucial discoveries about the workings of the body's immune system, died on Tuesday at the University of Texas M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. He was 70 and lived in Houston.

title: Sifting Through Divergent Stories For the Truth About a Relationship
description: Like witnesses at a crime scene, the four central players in the unfolding story of President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky have offered differing versions of what they saw and said and did.

title: Russia Seeking Senior Role On Inspection Teams in Iraq
description: In an effort to expand its influence on the special commission charged with disarming Iraq, Russia has asked Secretary General Kofi Annan to name a Russian as co-deputy chairman of the panel, United Nations officials said today.

title: Privatizing Social Security Wouldn't Pay Off; What Higher Returns?
description: To the Editor:

title: 300,000 FIND WORK
description: After seven years of economic growth, the American job juggernaut has not even begun to slow down.

title: Privatizing Social Security Wouldn't Pay Off; Distorted Analyses
description: To the Editor:

title: Interest Groups Run Own Race in California
description: Californians are long used to the televised cut-and-thrust of political advertising in a state where distances are huge and civic discourse muted. But in the special election to fill a vacant seat in the 22d Congressional District here next Tuesday, many of the commercials are not even the work of the candidates, and local issues sometimes seem all but lost.

title: A Warning About Sales By Compaq
description: In another spectacular stumble by a technology company, the Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that it would not make any profit in the first quarter because of a unexpected falloff in sales.

title: A Tighter Drunken-Driving Standard
description: It is always worth applauding when elected lawmakers resist pressure from well-heeled special interests in order to do right by the public. That happened this week when the Senate, resisting lobbyists from the liquor industry and restaurant chains, voted 62 to 32 to establish a uniform national standard for drunken driving. Currently, New York and 34 other states set the blood alcohol limit for drivers at .10 percent. Under the new measure, an amendment to the giant Federal highway bill, states would have to adopt a stricter and more realistic .08 percent limit by Oct. 1, 2001, or lose a portion of their highway construction aid.

title: G.O.P. May Cede Race to McCall To Reduce Black Voter Turnout
description: New York's top Republicans are considering mounting only a token challenge to State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a black Democrat, partly out of fear that a serious run at him would raise black voter turnout in November and harm Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's and Gov. George E. Pataki's re-election bids, several prominent Republicans say.

title: Prices Rise Despite Strength In February's Report on Jobs
description: Treasury prices rose yesterday despite a strong February employment report. Investors, resigned to the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will not lower interest rates anytime soon, took advantage of the slide in bond prices earlier in the week and bought.

title: Sorrowful Outlaw Radical Abandons Bid for Parole
description: In turning herself in nearly five years ago, one of the last Vietnam-era outlaw radicals to come up from the underground, Katherine Ann Power performed an act of contrition, relinquishing a homey life in Oregon to face responsibility for her role in a 1970 bank robbery that had left a police officer dead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEINEMAN, RUTH (KRESS).
description: HEINEMAN-Ruth (Kress). Age 75. She passed away peacefully in her sleep at home after a long illness borne with courage and dignity. She is survived by her loving husband Bernard (Jack) Heineman, Jr. Her devoted children Deborah Heineman (Scaglione) and Ralph Scaglione, Matthew and Katherine (Phillips) Heineman and StephenHeineman and Katherine Lingg, and by her adoring grandchildren Joshua, Benjamin, Nicholas, Emily, Tyler and Scott. She is also survived by her brothers George and Kenneth and her sister Nancy Armstrong and many nieces and nephews. She will be greatly missed by her brothers-in-law William Heineman, and his family, and Andrew Heineman. The family will receive friends at The Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Sunday March 8 from 6-9 PM and on Monday March 9 from 6-9 PM. The funeral service will be held Tuesday, March 10 at 4 PM at The First Presbyterian Church, 12th St and 5th Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The College of Wooster, Wooster, OH, The Public Education Association, 39 W. 32nd Street, New York City or the charity of your choice.

title: 2 Nations, Even in School
description: To the Editor:

title: Garner E. Shriver, 85, Kansas Congressman
description: Garner Edward Shriver, a former Republican Congressman from south-central Kansas, died on Sunday at Via Christi-St. Francis Hospital in Wichita, Kan. A resident of Wichita, he was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, LILI
description: NEWMAN-Lili. A woman with a love of life, people, and a spirit of adventure who gave that gift to all who knew her. Her courage, wisdom, honesty, strength and generosity survived through those who loved her. She died peacfully on March 6, 1998 and will be mourned by many: her husband Abraham, her daughters Vicki and Jessica, her sons-in-law Walter and Roger, her granddaughters and grandson-in-law Karen, Scott, Catherine, Amy and Rebecca, her greatgranddaughter Julie and her friends Lee, Ruthie, Jason, Eva and Grace. She touched many lives through her work at United Service for New Americans and there are some who live in freedom because of her individual efforts. In her way, she made the world a smaller place and she will be missed by her family and friends in Sweden, Hungary and Israel who enriched her life and whose lives were enriched by her. Services Sunday, March 8 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street at Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASS, GWEN
description: BASS-Gwen. On March 5, 1998, suddenly and unexpectedly in Minneapolis, Minn. Beloved daughter of Ruth and Leon. Loving sister of Debbie. Dear cousin of Jill and Jeffrey. She will be profoundly missed by her family, friends, and colleagues. Service on Sunday 11:15 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Coach Was Out of Line; Get Another Job
description: To the Editor:

title: German Company to Leave China Over Sales of Organs
description: A German company has abruptly announced that it is abandoning its half-interest in a kidney dialysis center in Guangzhou, China, admitting that Chinese military officials had probably made it an unintentional accomplice in the selling of organs from executed prisoners to wealthy foreigners.

title: UNITED DENTAL DISCLOSES TALKS ON POSSIBLE MERGER
description: United Dental Care Inc. said it was in talks with an unidentified third party about a possible sale or merger that could value the Dallas-based provider of managed dental care at about $19 a share, or $170 million. United Dental said a potential agreement could be in stock, cash or a combination. A $19 price would represent a 17 percent premium over yesterday's close. United Dental shares rose 62.5 cents, to $16.875. Last year, United Dental, which covers about 1.9 million people, lost $2.8 million, or 32 cents a share, on revenue of $174.7 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, GOLDIE
description: BRENNER-Goldie. On March 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Elias. Loving mother of Edith Everett, Gladys Praigrod and the late Fred Brenner. Adored grandmother of Frances, Sharon, David and Carolyn. Dearest great grandmother of Elias, Ethan and Hannelora. Service Sunday, 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: University of Phoenix Seeks Roseland Campus
description: The University of Phoenix, the nation's largest private university and a pioneer in for-profit higher education, has applied to open a campus in Roseland, officials said yesterday.

title: Coach Was Out of Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Links a Death at Plastic Surgery Clinic to Anesthesia
description: The Medical Examiner of New York concluded yesterday that the death of a patient in a West Side medical clinic after recent cosmetic surgery was the result of complications from general anesthesia..

title: Islanders Keep Shooting And Find Hasek's Seam
description: No goalie could maintain the level of play Dominik Hasek had for so long, Tommy Salo insisted. He was speaking about the player whose goaltending had helped the Czech Republic win an Olympic gold medal and the Buffalo Sabres surge through 13 straight games without a loss.

title: Good News for Columbia/HCA Investors
description: Shares of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation climbed almost 9 percent in value yesterday after the company announced that it expected its first-quarter earnings to exceed Wall Street estimates.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Party's Over
description: Ever since Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia went into economic meltdown, the biggest foreign policy question hanging over Asia has been this: Do the Chinese get it? Do China's leaders understand that their own economy suffers many of the same ills as their neighbors' -- bankrupt banks, real estate speculation, underregulated markets -- and that the only thing saving China from being stampeded was the fact that it did not have a convertible currency, so the electronic herd couldn't really get inside its economy?

title: To Celebrate the Millennium, Wales Erects World's Biggest Greenhouse : A U.K. Building Spree Funded by the Lottery
description: LLANARTHNE, Wales  The broken-down stone walls and the silted-up lakes bear witness to a century of neglect that has turned the 18th century landscaped gardens of the Middleton Hall estate into a square mile of scrub and marshland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, MURIEL
description: HOROWITZ-Muriel. You were always there for us. We love you. Dolly and Dick Brickman

title: Neighbors Who Recall Quiet Teen-Ager Cannot Fathom the Rampage
description: Along the twisting country road here where Matthew Beck grew up, few of the neighbors who remembered him as a bright, shy teen-ager with a knack for math were aware that he had quietly moved back in with his parents last fall, at the age of 35.

title: The Dawn Raids Of the Park Racers; Cyclists Are Hitting a Finish Line Before Most of Us Hit the Floor
description: It was 5 A.M. last Sunday in Central Park, and it was dark, lonely and eerily silent. There were no joggers. No Rollerbladers. No dog walkers. Not a soul.

title: Tar Heels Bounce Back And Breeze Into Semis
description: Teams that finish the regular season with 27 victories, as did fourth-ranked North Carolina, are expected to play with confidence. But when they lost at Duke last week after squandering a 17-point lead, the Tar Heels wondered about the efficiency of their defense.

title: Injured Silver Charm to Skip His Race With Gentlemen
description: Silver Charm, last year's champion 3-year-old colt, suffered a bruised right front foot while galloping here this morning and was scratched from Saturday's $1 million Santa Anita Handicap, dashing a highly anticipated matchup with Gentlemen.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: West Africa's New Oil Barons; Equatorial Guinea Joins the Region's Bonanza
description: Like many officials in this tiny West African country, Cristobal Manana Ela of the mining ministry here is still having a hard time coming to terms with Equatorial Guinea's fantastic oil windfall.

title: TRANSWORLD OFFERS $96 MILLION FOR HEALTHCALL
description: Transworld Healthcare Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to acquire Healthcall Group P.L.C., a British health care services concern, for $96 million. Healthcall provides primary physician care, nursing and optical services, as well as temporary placement of medical professionals. Transworld Healthcare, based in New York, provides health care services. Its British subsidiary, Transworld Healthcare Ltd., operates 72 offices throughout Britain that offer respiratory therapy, medical supplies and nursing services. For the three months ended Dec. 31, it had revenue of $37.8 million. Transworld offered 105 pence ($1.73) for each Healthcall share outstanding. Shares of Transworld rose 37.5 cents, to $6.75, yesterday.

title: Supremacists Had Hit List, F.B.I. Agent Says
description: Members of an Illinois white-supremacist group planned to assassinate a lawyer who has battled hate groups, bomb the lawyer's Southern Poverty Law Center and public buildings, kill a judge, rob banks and poison water supplies, an F.B.I. agent testified today at a Federal court hearing.

title: State Lottery Puts Off Drawing
description: The Connecticut Lottery postponed yesterday's drawings of the midday and nightly games. All of yesterday's drawings will take place between 10 and 10:30 P.M. tonight, followed by the drawings for tonight at the scheduled time.

title: 2 Nations, Even in School
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRY, PHILIP J., JR.
description: CURRY-Philip J., Jr. Of Bristol, RI. Formerly of New Canaan, CT. On Friday, March 6, 1998. Survived by his wife Maureen Cohalan Curry; six sons, Philip of Easton, Conn., Michael of Barrington, R.I., Christopher of Orlando, FL., Sean of Boston, MA., Edward of New York City, and David of Charlottesville, VA; a daughter Margaret Curry of New Canaan, CT; and four grandchildren. Funeral mass Monday, March 9 at 10:30 AM, St. Aloysius Church, Cherry St, New Canaan. Interment, Calvary Cemetery, Queens. Visitation, Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main Street, New Canaan, Saturday 7-9 PM, and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Contributions may be made to the Canterbury School, New Milford, CT. 06776.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend yesterday about ''U.S. Marshals'' misstated the movie's rating. It is PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned), not R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian).

title: Bill Would Govern Use of Dead Men's Sperm
description: In what appears to be the first bill of its kind in the nation, a state senator from Manhattan has proposed legislation governing a rare but increasingly frequent request: that doctors remove and preserve the sperm from men who have just died.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIFFORD, SAMUEL A.
description: GIFFORD-Samuel A. On March 5, 1998, in his 91st year. Beloved husband of Harriette. Devoted father of Gail and Stephen Rudin. Adored grandfather of Deborah and Stephen Verp, Kenneth Rudin, and the late Andrew Rudin. Cherished great-grandfather of Alison Verp. A longtime leader in the paper industry. A caring, generous and loving family man, he will be deeply missed by many. Service will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, at 12 noon, on Sunday, March 8, 1998.

title: Incentive of Sweden Seals Shift of Focus
description: Incentive A.B. of Sweden, announcing a trebling in fourth-quarter profit, said it would assume the name of its dialysis equipment unit, Gambro, on July 1, sealing its shift to a medical technology company from a holding company.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SMART AND FINAL INC., Los Angeles, agreed to acquire United Grocers Inc.'s 39 Cash and Carry grocery warehouse stores to enter the Northwest. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Devils Will Lose Gilmour For the Next Two Weeks
description: Doug Gilmour will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his right knee Saturday and will be lost to the Devils for at least two weeks. A magnetic resonance imaging test on Gilmour's knee this morning showed damage, but the Devils declined to disclose the nature of the injury.

title: BASEBALL: Meet the Next Junior; A Teen-Ager Called Little Rock Sets His Sights on the Majors
description: Tim Raines Jr. started running, not walking, when he was 8 months old. He perfected sliding across the living room carpet when he was a year old. He began accompanying his father to major league clubhouses and stadiums at the age of 2. Little Raines was there to play, not chase autographs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLTOFF, KAY S.
description: COLTOFF-Kay S. Died peacefully at 2:45PM on Thursday, March 5, 1998 at the age of 61. She was, to the very last moment of her life, a loving, caring, beautiful woman whose last breaths were for her husband Phil, children Julie and Peter, her grandchild Noah and her two step-children Michael and Robert. She loved living and life and did so with gusto. She was a social worker, teacher, artist and folk singer. She saw only the best in people and had a love for all. Her family, friends, colleagues and students will remember her as a person who helped to make their world better. Contributions may be made to The Children's Aid Society, or the Hunter College Graduate School of Social Work Scholarship Fund, in her name. Services will be held at 11:30AM Sunday, March 8, 1998 at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave and 81 St, New York City. Phil, Julie and Peter

title: In Case That's Fit for Fiction, Writer Brothers Face Trial
description: In his latest book, ''Bob the Gambler,'' the author Frederick Barthelme tells the story of an ordinary man reeled in by the lure of the casinos that glitter like jewels along this state's gulf coast. But now the life of Mr. Barthelme, who has written 11 books and whose stylish prose has drawn comparisons to Ernest Hemingway, has taken a turn that could have come from his own pages.

title: A New Image With Very Few Missteps
description: OUR eyes popped when we pulled up to the Chalet on a recent evening. The Roslyn landmark, which dates from the middle of the last century, had always resembled a quaint Swiss ski lodge. Now it is bathed in a red glow, is outlined in white flashing Christmas lights and sports a 20-foot American flag hanging from the side of the building.

title: Backtalk; Upholding Society's Standards
description: Imagine P. J. Carlesimo, struggling to feel less like a victim and more like a survivor, calling up the National Coalition Against Violent Athletes and asking to speak with some other coach who has been assaulted by a disgruntled player.

title: The World; Hero to U.S., Yawn to Russia
description: WHEN Russia's Prime Minister summed up his accomplishments for the past five years, he was a little weak on what former President George Bush liked to call the vision thing.

title: Carolyn Slovis, Leonard Golub
description: Carolyn Zina Slovis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold J. Slovis of New York, was married last evening to Leonard Alan Golub, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin S. Golub of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Fred Hyman performed the ceremony at the New York Palace Hotel.

title: Turned Off by 'Stupid'
description: To the Editor:

title: Loading Up at Scudder
description: The walls between no-load and no-load funds keep crumbling. Scudder Kemper Investments will close three of its hottest funds to new no-load investors on April 15 and begin offering shares on a load basis exclusively, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Flight Plans
description: BILL THAYER lives in a beachfront condo, but he hasn't complained much about the storms, flooding and other extreme weather conditions in Atlantic City this winter.

title: Matters of Scale, and of Nostalgia Too
description: WHEN the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield advertises that it's showing large-scale drawings, it's not kidding. Ten belonging to Wynn Kramarsky, a major New York collector of works on paper, challenge the traditional notion of drawing as a cozy medium. Many are mural size.

title: Very Risky Business
description: The last phone call Peter Zarate, an ex-Navy SEAL from California, made was to his wife. A commercial real-estate broker working in Mexico City, Zarate stayed late at the office one night in mid-December to close several big deals. Around 8 o'clock, he picked up his cell phone, called his wife and told her that he would be home soon. Ten minutes later, carrying a briefcase and dressed in a dark blue pin-stripe suit, he walked out of the three-story building on Galileo Street where his employer, the American company Cushman & Wakefield, has its offices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, ABRAHAM
description: SUSSMAN-Abraham. On March 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Pearl; loving father of Eleanor and Norman; adoring grandfather of Carol, Robert, Rebecca and Zachary; great-grandfather of Shlomi, Yasmin and Sarah. He will always be remembered by his family. Service on Sunday, at 9:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Wilbur Cross High, Another View
description: Thank you for your excellent tribute to our friend and classmate, Oral Jones (''Trying to Make Peace With an Untimely Death,'' Feb. 15).

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: JOHN SLOAN: Painter and Rebel

title: Albright Warns Serbs on Kosovo Violence
description: Blaming President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia for the bloodshed in Kosovo, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that the United States is ''not going to stand by and watch'' Serbian authorities crush political freedoms in the province.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Otherworldly Stories
description: In ''The Brew,'' a powerful story from Karen Joy Fowler's new collection, BLACK GLASS (Marian Wood/Holt, $23), a woman stands in a hotel lobby staring at an aquarium. ''Sometimes,'' she tells herself, ''we can find a smaller world where we can live, inside the bigger world where we cannot.'' Other worlds, worlds within worlds, shifting realities -- all these inform Fowler's highly imaginative short fiction. In the title story, a zombie terrorizes the United States in the form of Carry Nation, and this gigantic hatchet-wielding Amazon becomes the obsession of Patrick Harris, an undercover Federal drug agent. A Christ story involving a 15-year-old boy unfolds in 17th-century Japan in ''Shimabara.'' ''The Elizabeth Complex'' assembles a composite life story from those of formidable figures like Lizzie Borden, Elizabeth Taylor and Elizabeth I. In ''Duplicity,'' two American women are taken captive by noseless aliens in the Brazilian rain forest. And in ''The View From Venus: A Case Study,'' Venusians analyze the romantic practices of college-age students in Berkeley in the late 1960's. More earthly but equally inventive narratives include ''Contention,'' which describes a housewife's loneliness; ''Go Back,'' in which a young girl discovers her father's infidelity; and ''Letters From Home,'' an affecting meditation on what became of the narrator's boyfriend in Vietnam. There is much that is fantastical about Fowler's fiction, but also much that is rooted in a solid emotional reality; in fine-edged and discerning prose, she manages to re-create both life's extraordinary and its ordinary magic. Jenny McPhee

title: F.Y.I.
description: Road Code

title: SOAPBOX: Models for Life; . . . And a Mother Who Sees Value in Everyone
description: MY mother, Heleena Van Raan, works every day to improve human rights and is always trying to help improve women's rights. She works with all kinds of people every day to help improve their lives.

title: Boy Loses 3 Fingers Lighting Firecracker
description: A 5-year-old boy who was visiting his uncle's apartment in the Bronx on Friday night lost three fingers when an M-80 firecracker exploded in his hand, the police said.

title: Daytona Beach Journal; Bikers Flash Chrome, and Gold Card
description: In the black leather, exhaust pipe extravaganza known as Bike Week, close to half a million motorcycle enthusiasts descended on this city of about 63,000 residents to partake of the engine revving, beer drinking and girlfriend flaunting of biker lore.

title: An Island of Southern Hospitality
description: FOR a couple of New Yorkers in search of a weekend destination, the Cloister, a famously traditional old Southern resort off the coast of Georgia, does not immediately leap to mind. So why did my wife, Nancy, and I choose it, and why in February? For years, our family has spent time each August on the South Carolina coast, a couple of hundred miles north of Sea Island, where the Cloister is situated. We love that part of the South, but it is usually sweltering when we're there. So we've often talked of traveling back down in cooler weather, and trying someplace different.

title: Comedy in the Conference Room
description: Presentations: They're showtime for some people, the bane of many others. How have they gone for you? And what moments next to the overhead projector would you most like to forget? Or remember? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be repub-lished in any medium.

title: In a Province of Winners, Worker Who Lost Out Takes Revenge
description: It is an ordinary beige building with a warehouse in the back, but to many people, the headquarters of the Connecticut Lottery is a place of fantasy where the big winners go to pose with the big cardboard check. They follow the bright yellow ''Prize Claim Center'' sign into a special reception area and collect jackpots, from $600 to hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: A Long, Solo Voyage Awaits a Brand-New Yacht
description: Jean-Pierre Mouligne was in a rush. He had just come from his office where he works as sales manager for a $25 million fiberglass products company. He had a dinner engagement within the hour, and he still needed to look at his ''baby.''

title: The Con Artist
description: The Picasso Papers

title: Teaching With a Twist but No Magic Formula
description: ''PUT that hat away, before I stuff it in your ear.''

title: BENEFITS
description: Musical Finds, Now and Then

title: Facade Law Is Being Tightened
description: RESPONDING to concerns about hazards posed by aging masonry on high-rise buildings, the New York City Council voted unanimously last month to expand the scope of Local Law 10, which mandates the inspection of the facades of buildings taller than six stories every five years.

title: Bear Facts
description: In BEARS!, a National Geographic Explorer special, the veteran host of the series, Boyd Matson, introduces three separate stories of the fearsome beasts while Coco, a brown bear, toys with his hand like a domestic pet. The first story, ''Lights! Camera! Bears!,'' focuses on the Seus family , who train animals for television and movies -- most famously, that scene stealer Bart (above with Doug Seus), who upstaged his co-stars Alec Baldwin and Anthony Hopkins in the 1997 film ''The Edge.'' The second story, ''Realm of the Great White Bear,'' is David Wright's paeon to polar bears, from the moment twin cubs emerge from their den to blink in the icy glare until they're almost ready to face life alone at age two. Narrated by Keith David, the story was filmed on the island of Svalbard, halfway between Norway and the North Pole, and captures surprisingly tender maternal moments as the mother teaches the cubs to observe their icy world. But don't be fooled by the apparent docile nature of a bear, warn the rangers at Montana's Glacier National Park; they can run 35 miles an hour and kill within seconds if they are scared or surprised. This is made chillingly clear in the final story, ''Bear Attack,'' through accounts of survivors and filming of grizzlies in the wild -- SUNDAY at 7 and 11:05 P.M. and SATURDAY at 10 A.M. on TBS. Suzanne O'Connor

title: Overall, Reading Scores Increase
description: DURING the first parent-teachers meeting at Public School 8 in Yonkers more than a century ago, the pressing issue was why the stagecoach transporting children to school was running late. In 1997, the buses were running on time but irate parents were still demanding answers -- because reading scores on the state's report cards a year ago were low.

title: March 1-7; A Pepper a Day Keeps Germs Away
description: Variety may be the spice of life, but spice may be, in part, what makes life possible in the tropics. The flavorful folklore that surrounds the abundant and creative use of spices in hot climates ranges from the persistent notion that the hot stuff triggers a cooling sweat to the intriguing thought that heavy seasonings disguise the odor and flavor of spoiled food.

title: An Incumbent Is Challenged by Shifts In His District's Population Makeup
description: Since his election to Congress 10 years ago, Representative Eliot L. Engel has seen his middle-class district, which covers the northern Bronx and portions of Westchester County, gradually grow more black and Hispanic.

title: Those Hidden, Sometimes Hefty Transaction Costs Can Be a Drag
description: THAT'S eating your fund's returns?

description: ACRICHE-Fanny. Bienenfeld & Wertman expresses its sympathies to the family of Debra Bienenfeld, wife of Saul Bienenfeld, and to the entire Acriche family on the passing of Fanny Acriche.

title: What Now? Piercing The Credit Union Haze
description: IT took seven years, but late last month the nation's bankers won a significant legal victory in their battle against credit unions: The Supreme Court invalidated a 1982 regulation that had let credit unions absorb unrelated employee groups, a move that had propelled exponential growth.

title: Backtalk; 10 Is a Crowd, So Change the Game
description: Along with about a billion other people on this planet, I've had a lifelong love affair with basketball. I've known the game as a player (Princeton), as a coach (Hollywood Y.M.C.A. 5- to 8-year-olds), and as a basketball supervisor for the movies (''White Men Can't Jump,'' ''Blue Chips'' and ''Eddie,'' among others).

title: Africans Resentful as Asia Rakes In Aid
description: There was a slightly forced quality to the smiles of officials from the International Monetary Fund and the Ivory Coast Government when they met here last month to sign a major pact on restructuring this country's ailing economy.

title: March 1-7; Guerrilla Bombing
description: The Tamil Tigers, who have been waging a 15-year war for an independent Tamil state on the Indian Ocean island of Sri Lanka, have demonstrated again why they have the reputation as one of the most ruthless and sophisticated terrorist organizations in the world. A suicide bomber detonated explosives on the bus he was driving on the busy streets of the capital, Colombo, killing 36 and wounding hundreds, including schoolchildren. RAYMOND BONNER

title: Down Mean Alleys With John Goodman
description: JOHN GOODMAN cradles the make-believe bowling ball in his hands as if contemplating Yorick's skull. Standing in the middle of a midtown Manhattan intersection, he takes four careful steps, curls the ball behind him and flapjacks it down 55th Street. With Mr. Goodman's goading, the ball bellies out precariously toward the taxi on the right, then grips the asphalt and shimmies back toward the center of the street. The burly Mr. Goodman stops at the make-believe foul line and poises nimbly on his left foot like a ballet dancer. When the make-believe pins go down, he does a little jitterbug cakewalk.

title: A Plan to Halt Mistreatment Of the Elderly
description: MARGARET BRIGHAM looks like a dream of a grandmother. Petite, with beautiful white hair and wearing a blue suit and a fresh coat of lipstick, the 89-year-old woman walked slowly to the podium, where she trembled a bit before beginning her story.

title: The Microsoft We Deserve
description: The world's strongest government is fighting its most formidable corporation in a spectacle enthralling to a citizenry unaccustomed to such superpower confrontations.

title: Students Lose on Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on page 36 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the new ABC series ''Two Guys, a Girl and a Pizza Place'' misidentifies the company that signed agreements with seven comedy writer-producers, including Danny Jacobson, the creator of the series. It was 20th Century Fox Television, not Fox Broadcasting. The article also refers incorrectly to the destination of the programs to be developed. They may be sold to any network, not only to Fox.

description: To the Editor:

title: Playing It Sweet, If She Needs To, Or Sexy-Funny
description: THERE SHE WAS, almost four years ago, on the top deck of the Cotton Blossom, singing her heart out to Gaylord Ravenal in the moonlight in ''Show Boat.'' Had there ever been a sweeter, purer Magnolia who deserved her miserable fate less? The critics adored her voice, a bell-like soprano, but found her acting on the wooden side.

title: Battle Leaves Regents Board Without Ally For Teachers
description: An unusual struggle to fill a vacancy on the New York State Board of Regents has highlighted the board's growing importance and the political concerns of a teachers' union that sees itself under attack.

title: What Europe Should Hear
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, PETER
description: ADAMS-Peter. In Paris, peacefully at home, March 3, 1998. Buried in Montmartre. Salut et bon voyage.

title: In the Blink Of a Screen
description: Some weeks ago, my neighbor's computer self-destructed in a blaze of burnt-orange streaks (Lives: ''In the Blink of a Screen,'' by Tom McNichol, Feb. 15). Its brain had been the repository for, along with the usual daily essentials, all of her letters and journals dating from the early 1980's. She wandered around for days, bereft. ''I have no past,'' was all she could say.

title: Health Care Union Votes To Merge, Creating Giant
description: In a move that will create the biggest union in New York City, workers in a 30,000-member local of New York health care workers have voted overwhelmingly to merge with 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union.

title: The View From/North White Plains; Group Helps Open Homes to Belfast Children to Further Peace
description: A SUMMER without bullets or bombs. A summer when the only explosions are the fireworks on the Fourth of July. This is the goal of the Northern Ireland Children's Enterprise, a nonprofit organization, which from its offices here and in Belfast, places young people in American homes for five weeks in July and August.

title: March 1-7; No One's Choked Up
description: An arbitrator's ruling sharply curtailed the landmark punishment of Latrell Sprewell, the All-Star guard of the Golden State Warriors who choked, punched and threatened his coach, P.J. Carlesimo, last December.

title: March 1-7; The First Friend
description: Central casting provided the star witness for last week's installment of the Monica Chronicles in the person of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., President Clinton's golfing partner and backroom adviser.

title: Even Worse Than We Remember
description: SHOW TIME

title: Snowdrop, Spring Sign Wrapped in Delicacy
description: THEY are truly nature's pop-ups -- the snowdrops. Their delightful early blooms have been appearing suddenly, casting aside last fall's remaining detritus in sunny corners, for several weeks, confirming that spring truly is on its way.

title: 128 Pages, 200 Photographs and Decades of History
description: Shoppers at Smiley's Country Deli and Gervin's Sport Shop on Main Street in Woodbridge wouldn't know that the spot was once occupied by Blum's Grocery Store, where the proprietor stacked the canned goods in neat pyramids a century ago. Or that the Woodbridge Sons of Veterans' Drum Corps and Firing Squad used to practice out front, dressed in Civil War-era uniforms, in ragtag formation, with fife, drums and bayonets in hand. Unless, of course, they had seen a copy of ''Woodbridge,'' by Robert J. McEwen and Virginia Bergen Troeger.

title: U.S. Measure Reduces Medicare Home Care
description: ROY GREENBERG,49, barely makes a dent under a neatly tucked blue-and-tan quilt. Six-feet tall and a mere 110 pounds, the former social worker lies motionless on his back in the bedroom of his Huntington home. On a nearby mantel, a photograph of Mr. Greenberg striking a sportive pose while on vacation on Block Island stands in stark contrast to the father of two sons whose limbs have since stiffened from multiple sclerosis. The voice that counseled teen-agers on the dangers of drug and alcohol abuse now only sputters slurred phrases. Dependent upon home-care aides to bathe, dress and feed him -- a routine that takes up to two hours -- Mr. Greenberg, who is enrolled in Medicare's home health program, was told recently that his home-care assistance had been reduced from seven days to three days a week.

title: Cigarette Makers Ordered To Relinquish Documents
description: A Minnesota state judge yesterday ordered cigarette makers to release about 39,000 internal documents to lawyers for the state after a finding last month that the records may contain evidence of fraud and other crimes by tobacco company officials and their lawyers.

title: Ronald Johnson, 62, Poet Of Critically Acclaimed 'Ark'
description: Ronald Johnson, a visionary poet who wanted to take his God out of church and find Him, say, in the exploding light of dawn as it rose across the prairie of his native Kansas, died on Wednesday at his father's home in Topeka. He was 62.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15
