description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Q&A: Mark Pettie; Keeping Alive 100 Years of Cheese Making
description: WHEN Giuseppe Pollio passed through Ellis Island in 1899, he left much behind in his native Italy. But one prized possession he took with him was his skill as a cheese maker, and he became one of the first to introduce ricotta and mozzarella on a large scale to the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKHAM, LINDA (CONANT)
description: MARKHAM-Linda (Conant). 64, of Barnstable, MA, died March 5 of lung cancer. Born in NYC, she lived with her lifelong friend and husband Emerson in Chappaqua and Bronxville, NY before moving to Cape Cod in 1994. Also surviving are her two children, Leslie and Jeffrey and three grandchildren, Cyrus Brown and True and Finlay Markham. Visiting hours Sunday, March 8, 3-6 PM, Doane, Beal & Ames Funeral Home, 160 W. Main St., Hyannis. Memorial service St. Mary's Church, Barnstable, Saturday, March 21, 3:30 PM. Donations to Friends of Sturgis Library, P.O. Box 606, Barnstable, MA 02630.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SAM
description: KAPLAN-Sam. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Sam Kaplan, associated with The Times from 1946, until retiring in 1988.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAYKIN, ROSE
description: SHAYKIN-Rose. The National Jewish Outreach Program mourns the passing of Rose Shaykin, beloved mother of Leonard Shaykin, a founding Board member of NJOP. His support of NJOP has played a crucial role in NJOP's efforts to assure a Jewish future for American Jewry. Condolences to the family. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: March 1-7; Hate Groups in Boom Times
description: At least since Hitler's rise from the depths of the Great Depresssion, historians have found a correlation between hard economic times and the emergence of hate groups. But the Intelligence Project of the Southern Poverty Law Center, an Alabama group that monitors hate activities, issued a report finding a 20 percent increase in the number of American hate groups between 1996 and 1997, despite the robust health of the economy.

title: A Bigger NATO Is Good for Europe; Win-Win Scenario
description: To the Editor:

title: Rediscovering Balsam and Other Unfashionables
description: IN a garden center a few years ago, I chanced across a flat of blooming plants that at first I didn't recognize. They looked a bit like stocks, but very short ones, with lightly scented double blossoms in shades of pink and white.

title: Celestial Glow: New Beauty Strikes an Angelic Pose
description: OVERHEARD at the corner newsstand, as a small boy gazed up at Vanity Fair's current cover girl, then turned to his mother in saucer-eyed surprise: ''That's Madonna? She looks about 13.'' The object of his wonder really did seem to have shed a few years, and along with them, more than a few layers of artifice. Her eyes large and lambent, her lips and nails tinted a sheer rose, her skin translucent as a child's, she looked lighted from within, like nothing so much as Eve before the Fall.

title: For Sweepstakes 'Winners,' Millions Are a Mirage
description: For one moment Ina Brown thought that she had become a millionaire. After spending years subscribing to American Family Publishers magazines in the hope of eventually winning the sweepstakes, in January she received a mailing that read: ''INA BROWN, YOU STAND ALONE AT THE TOP -- YOU'VE SWEPT PAST 200,000+ OTHER WINNERS WITH OUR FIRST $11,075,000 PRIZE IN HISTORY!''

title: Once and Future Stuff
description: It's hard to imagine doing business today without handy, powerful gadgets that make communicating speedier and more versatile, but it was only in the 1980's that tools like laptop computers and cell phones surfaced and started evolving at a dizzying clip. A century ago, business travelers were amazed that they could even place a call from their hotels, thanks to telephone service, which first became available in 1879. Today's hotel room is wired to be a fully functioning office, and future trends point to a tech-driven business landscape that has fewer boundaries of time and place.

title: Narrow Escapes for Duke and North Carolina
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference has been at this post-season tournament business for 45 years now, and the league rightly prides itself on the intensity of the competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFIELD, BARBARA MUNSON
description: GARFIELD-Barbara Munson, 85, died at her home in Sarasota, FL, Feb. 20, 1998. Widow of Edward Garfield, former Manhattan attorney. Mother of Gail Garfield Schwartz of Mamaroneck, New York, Susan Garfield of Oakland, CA, Wendy G. Palliser of London, England. Grandmother of five and great-grandmother of four. Remembrances may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: O'Donnell's Status on Jets: A Secret Kept by Parcells
description: National Football League teams are wondering what exactly is going on inside the head of Jets Coach Bill Parcells when it comes to quarterback Neil O'Donnell. Few people know, because Parcells is doing something smart: keeping his mouth shut.

title: A New Concept In Layouts
description: To the Editor:

title: Frank Racial Dialogue Thrives on the Web
description: A father wrings his hands over the on-again, off-again relationship that his daughter, who is white, is having with a black man. ''I would be more accepting of interracial relationships if there was evidence of society's acceptance of it,'' he said recently, noting that he had never considered himself prejudiced.

title: A Priest Who Finds Messages in His Meals
description: During Lent, traditionally a time of spiritual reflection, a teacher might expound on the virtues of fasting, while a preacher might excoriate the self-absorbed preoccupations of the times. The Rev. James Cafone does both -- and makes a heavenly pasta in shrimp sauce.

title: Boston's Tourists Taxed For Convention Center
description: Since Jan. 1, visitors to Boston have been in for a surprise: higher taxes on hotels, rental cars and sightseeing tours. But unlike taxes on tourists in many cities and states, which have helped finance stadiums, arenas and other projects with tenuous connections to tourism, the new Boston taxes are earmarked to help pay for a 600,000-square-foot convention center near the waterfront.

title: Scarsdale Woman Steps Up Game for Duke
description: THERE is another basketball star from Westchester County besides Elton Brand who will play a major role in Duke University's fortunes in the coming National Collegiate Athletic Association championships.

title: When One Isn't Enough
description: Tell us about interesting things that are collected by you, or by someone you know.

title: Music Radio Replayed
description: To the Editor:

title: East 76th Street Worries: One Tall Building Too Many?
description: East 76th Street, between York Avenue and the F.D.R. Drive, is a fairly typical Upper East Side block. There is a fancy bagel place on a corner, two large apartment buildings, a private school, a small park and nannies who shout: ''Rachel! No running!''

title: Office Life
description: A WORKING GIRL CAN'T WIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTLER, ADOLPHE GEORGE
description: RUTLER-Adolphe George. Born 1915. Husband of Dorothy Elaine Albertson, father of the Rev. George Rutler and Dorothy Elaine Rapp, died March 6, 1998. Reposing at McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville, Monday evening 7-9 PM. Requiem mass Tuesday, 10 AM, St. Agnes Church, 143 East 43 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers: gifts to the St. Agnes Memorial Fund.

title: Groups Sue G.E.
description: A proposed General Electric hangar for company jets at the County Airport -- 1,000 feet from the Kensico Reservoir -- could damage the water supply, according to a lawsuit filed in State Supreme Court in White Plains by a coalition of eight environmental and housing groups.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: TOURS

title: Irabu, Part II: Yankees Hope He Gets With Their Program
description: Channel your emotions, they say to Hideki Irabu. Channel your talent. But in reality, the Yankees pitcher is channel surfing this spring, searching for his identity. It's as if Irabu were enclosed in pitch black and blindly reaching for a circuit breaker.

title: America's Treadmill Economy
description: THE caller insisted that a telephone number must exist for the Kimberly-Clark Corporation in Voorhees, N.J. He had called there once, and now he demanded that Sandra Singh find the number. His voice rose in anger when she said that only one New Jersey listing for Kimberly-Clark popped up on her computer screen -- in the town of Spotswood, not Voorhees. ''Perhaps they moved,'' Ms. Singh offered, sympathetically. Only gradually did he give in, finally accepting the Spotswood number she proferred so amiably.

title: Norwich Plan Yields To Burial Ground
description: TRIBAL members' concerns about the further desecration of the Mohegan Indians' Royal Burial Ground have ended plans to use Norwich's turn-of-the-century Masonic Temple building for a $9 million communications and technology learning center.

title: POSTINGS: Board Leadership Conference Seminars; About Co-ops And Condos
description: Habitat Magazine's annual Board Leadership Conference for apartment owners, board members and management personnel, being held from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. today at the Sheraton New York, Seventh Avenue and 52d Street, will include 16 seminars on such subjects as sponsors, loans, annual meetings and owner occupancy.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Conversations with Joseph Brodsky A Poet's Journey Through the Twentieth Century. By Solomon Volkov. Free Press, $25.

title: A look at Baseball, 'the Way It Ought to be'
description: Andrew E. Braunstein, who administers a pension fund for the fur industry out of an office building in Chelsea, can't really tell you why one game -- a New York Mets game sometime in the 1988 season -- changed his life. But Mr. Braunstein, 46, who was at best a lukewarm baseball fan before that game, now spends some 70 to 80 hours a week reporting on minor-league baseball.

title: When the Tables Are Turned in Adultery's Secret Rooms
description: SO, BRIGITTE ROUAN was asked over tea and biscuits in her Fifth Arrondissement apartment, where did she get the idea for ''Post Coitum,'' a new film she wrote and directed that is about a married woman who falls passionately -- and disastrously -- in love with a tall, dark and handsome man 20 years her junior?

title: SHOPPING WITH: Sandy Dalal; Scissors Mightier Than a Saber
description: SANDY DALAL, the newest next big thing in men's fashion, was once a shy young man who, upon meeting a stranger, would stare at the ground. ''Three years ago, I wouldn't have been able to look you in the eye,'' he told a shopping companion.

title: City Plans to Cast Dormant Theater in a New Role
description: Jason Chen and Ralph Fong were chatting on East Broadway beneath the Manhattan Bridge on Wednesday afternoon when a visitor asked them about the vacant two-story building behind them.

title: Photos With Individuals' Bent, and Landscapes
description: The East End: Photographer's Favorites

title: Women See Key Gains Since Talks In Beijing
description: Two and a half years after the United Nations international conference on women in Beijing put forward proposals for government action on women's rights, representatives of organizations from around the world are meeting here for two weeks to take stock of progress.

title: Heckscher to Acquire Home of Arthur Dove
description: IN the wake of a hurricane that had many other Long Islanders wishing they lived upstate, the painter Arthur Dove assured his dealer, Alfred Stieglitz, that after five dreary years in Geneva, N.Y., he was glad to be back where his art could flourish.

title: Elephants Go To Grad School
description: THOUGH the ''Elephant Crossing'' sign is posted prominently along Highway 107 in northern Thailand, the main entrance to the Chiang Dao Elephant Training Center is not. My husband, Brad, and I zoomed past it and onto a ceaseless stretch of hairpin curves. Fearing we'd end up in Myanmar, we braved a frightening three-point blind turnaround and steered our rented Jeep into a wide patch of dirt that, to our relief, delivered us to a shack selling tickets. The first show had already begun.

title: Bishop John Maury Allin, 77, Former Leader of Episcopal Church, Dies
description: Bishop John Maury Allin, the 23rd presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church, who was a pivotal supporter of Mississippi's effort to rebuild burned black churches in the 1960's but was an ardent critic of the ordination of women, died on Friday in Jackson, Miss.

title: Reading Your Rights
description: FOR THE PEOPLE

title: The Wearing Of the Plaid
description: The classic Scottish tartan, which fades in and out of popularity, has new enthusiasts. The distinctive Stewart clan colors are appearing in whimsical mixtures for sportswear, center, and in classic suits. But the most interesting versions come from a Scottish-born designer, Alexander McQueen, who crossbred a bias-cut jacket with kimono sleeves, far left, and embellished it with satin and lace. One can almost hear the skirl of bagpipes on Fifth Avenue.

title: March 1-7; High-Tech Showdown
description: William H. Gates, chairman of Microsoft, defended his company's aggressive style of competition during a four-hour grilling before the Senate Judiciary Committee. The questions fired at him were often pointed and acerbic, especially from the chairman, Orrin Hatch, who proved deft on high-tech subjects.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS; INVESTING WITH: Rimas M. Milaitis
description: SURE, Rimas M. Milaitis has the kind of degrees that a lot of other money managers do: a B.S. in economics and an M.B.A. But what he really needs to know to run his two funds for Strong Capital Management came from growing up on the south side of Chicago, where a generation of dispossessed Lithuanians rebuilt lost fortunes one hard-earned dollar at a time.

title: Tradition Isn't All Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bus Stops Here
description: ''The Java Bus coffee is like the nectar of the gods,'' David Waters, a production assistant, said one night while working on the set of the movie ''Blast From the Past'' at Union Station in Los Angeles. What's the Java Bus? It's a coffee shop on wheels -- a delivery-style truck with a staff that cruises around Los Angeles day and night selling light snacks and coffees to actors and members of film crews who aren't content with the refreshments provided on the set.

title: Fierce Bidding Expected on 2 Sites in Times Square
description: The dilapidated storefronts and pornographic theaters in Times Square have given way in recent years to two musical theaters, a giant music and entertainment store, splashy theme restaurants, and soon, Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum and 50 movie screens.

title: Sarah Calame, Timothy Grosskopf
description: Sarah Peale Calame, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard J. Calame of Vero Beach, Fla., was married there yesterday to Timothy Edward Grosskopf, a son of Bobbie Grosskopf of New Canaan, Conn., and Theodore E. Grosskopf of Orange Beach, Ala. Msgr. Irvine Nugent performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Helen.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 8, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Senators Keep Gay Nominee for Luxembourg Post in Limbo
description: When the State Department announced last year that James C. Hormel, who is gay, had been nominated to be an ambassador, there was jubilation here, and not just among the city's homosexuals.

title: Behind the Horse of the Year
description: WHO -- Malvern Burroughs, 57, of Raritan Township in Hunterdon County. He is the owner, breeder, and driver of Malabar Man, voted horse of the year in 1997 in a poll conducted by the United States Trotting Association. This horse has the highest winnings among standardbreds in North America, the first time in 20 years that a male trotter has led the way.

title: Female Practitioner Of Circumcision In a Male World
description: ''WE'RE here to share a life cycle event,'' Dr. Dorothy Greenbaum announced, in full volume, to more than 100 family and friends of Michael and Marni Barone who had assembled at Bruzell's restaurant in Great Neck on a recent Friday morning.

title: Serbs Claim Victory Over a Separatist Militia
description: The sweep in central Kosovo province by hundreds of Serbian police and paramilitary units appears to have failed to capture or kill most of the ethnic Albanian rebels operating in the area, senior Serbian officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: Liberties
description: The President's deposition is a classic. It is so very Clinton.

title: Lucas Will Be Around the Jets, Somewhere, if Not Everywhere
description: As the Jets prepare for the start of their voluntary off-season workout program tomorrow, Ray Lucas could be the only quarterback who knows what his role will be. He knows he won't be the starter.

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report article last Sunday, about the Carlton Hotel in Johannesburg, included an outdated reference to the hotel's application for a casino license. After the section went to press, the provincial government of Gauteng awarded four licenses, but the Carlton, one of 23 applicants in the Johannesburg area, did not get one. The province said it would award two more licenses ''in the next few months.''

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Yes, There Is Life in Old Technologies
description: ''DO you still play vinyl?'' the salesman asked, with a slight air of bemusement. The fact that I did meant adding a turntable to the list of components that I was buying for my new stereo system.

title: A Night to Remember for a Thousand Years
description: AS A MARKETING concept, it is a thing of beauty -- the ultimate anniversary tie-in. What could be more rare, transcendent and noncontroversial than a celebration honoring not a great figure or a signal event but the once-in-1,000-years blooming of time itself? For demographic appeal, the millennium is hard to beat.

title: I Sing the Meadowlands!
description: I spent my early years in a town near what we called simply ''the meadows,'' so I certainly enjoyed Robert Sullivan's article ''I Sing the Meadowlands!'' (Feb. 15). Those who are less adventuresome than Sullivan can still visit the meadows today at the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission Environment Center in Lyndhurst. Standing on the edge of the marsh, you can feel the strange lure of this land, in the absolute quiet, in the beauty of the many birds and in the movement of the graceful grasses. It is a place in two time frames -- the tiny trucks race along the turnpike in front of the Manhattan skyline, yet there is a natural peace that is centuries old.

title: Of Beads, in an Evolving American Fashion
description: BEADS, usually small objects pierced for stringing, have long been used as playthings, in jewelry, prayer and trade. But the subject becomes more focused in ''Art In Motion: Native American Beadwork,'' an exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, on view through May 24.

title: Boost From a Bull
description: Red Bull, a caffeinated soft drink, is charging into Los Angeles by the back door. The drink, which is sold in a short 8.3-ounce can and has a little more than half as much caffeine as coffee, is catching on not because of any big ad campaign but by word of mouth -- from people who buy it in health clubs, health-food stores and nightclubs, where it is even used as a mixer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZAGAT, ELEANOR PASNER
description: ZAGAT-Eleanor Pasner. February 28, 1959. A dearly loved sister who had great capacity, quality and feeling. Mathilde Christatos

title: Showcasing 7 Photographers From Heyday of Life Magazine
description: IT is tempting to say that the photographs now at the Candace Perich Gallery here make up a motley exhibition. Though the work is all black and white, the content varies widely. But because the pictures were all published in Life magazine in its heyday, from the 1930's through the early 1960's, they make a dynamic fraternity.

title: A French Twist On the Bridal Store
description: A French no-frills bridal chain is coming to the United States on April 16 when Tati: the Bridal Superstore opens at 475 Fifth Avenue between 41st and 42d Streets. Tati is a French discount department store that has spun off a chain of bridal stores; this is the first in the United States.

title: When the Bottom Line Affects Health Care
description: Re: the article entitled ''Slow H.M.O. Bill Payments Strain Hospitals'' (Feb. 8), there is a much larger forest not being seen for all the trees that get in the way. The case of a local patient might help offer a bird's-eye view of the magnitude of the problem. An 85-year-old woman known to some as the ''mother'' of her neighborhood (because of the many foster children she had nurtured over the years) required hospitalization on Christmas day, and after many tests and much treatment, needed major surgery on Jan. 6. Her postoperative course was rocky because of her very frail condition, but, finally, near the end of January, it looked as if she might be able to go home, something she really needed for her emotional well-being after almost six weeks in the hospital.

title: A Font of Good Fortune for a Business Printer
description: AT first glance, some investors may conclude that the staid commercial printing business lacks appeal. But Consolidated Graphics Inc. may be proving those investors wrong.

title: In Opera, a Few Conductors Still Wield Clout and Control
description: IN OPERA TODAY, singers are generally in control. Although many of them might complain about the encroaching power of stage directors, it still takes star singers to draw the public into the opera house and to sell recordings.

title: For 2 Mets Hurlers, Normalcy Is Becoming
description: Two pitchers once considered cornerstones of a promising Mets pitching staff quietly continued their comeback bids today.

title: Tips From a Traveling Compulsive
description: On my best days, as I head toward La Guardia, I pretend that I'm heir to a literary tradition. Richard Rovere chronicled Washington for The New Yorker, from Harry Truman to Jimmy Carter, while periodically commuting from his Hyde Park, N.Y., home. Rovere described his genteel travel rituals in his final memoir: ''Once every three or four weeks, I would leave Hyde Park -- generally on a Sunday evening -- and arrive, by sleeper, in Washington Monday morning.''

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Hartford redevelopment plans misidentified the organizaton of which Robert Santy is vice president. It is the Connecticut Capitol Region Growth Council, not the Hartford Downtown Council.

title: The World; Another Victory For Death in Serbia
description: OF all the tinderboxes in the Balkans, Kosovo may be the nastiest. It is the place where an armed rebellion by the ethnic Albanian majority against their Serb rulers could easily draw in restive Albanian minorities in neighboring Macedonia and Montenegro. Perhaps it could then draw in Albania itself, then Turkey and Greece. That would produce the true nightmare: an international conflict that would pit the region's Orthodox Christians against its Muslims on a large scale.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: In her essay, Anne Bernays tells us blithely that ''only five out of every thousand travelers submit official missing luggage claims.'' What this means is that on a typical international jet flight with, say, 400 passengers, two will submit a claim.

title: From a Stunted Career, a Concerto in Search of a Context
description: THERE WERE so many, Jew and non-Jew alike, whose lives were shattered by Hitler's rise to power that it may be hard to read of any more. By now, this litany of woe has a ring of numbing familiarity. Yet it is only by turning from the immensity of the whole to the experience of the individual that the tale can regain its potency and become, once again, all too real.

title: Pricey Fare but Save Room for Dessert
description: OVER the past 20 years, the two-story white frame house in Greenwich that now accommodates Magnolias has had more occupants than most of us can recall, beginning with Cinquante Cinq, and most recently Bali of Greenwich.

title: Gentlemen Runs Last In a Four-Horse Field
description: A week full of plot twists and turns saved its most startling surprise for today when Gentlemen, racing without Silver Charm and seemingly without competition, struggled home last behind three undistinguished long shots in the $1 million Santa Anita Handicap.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: TIMES SQUARE

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the problems of small landlords misstated the year in which Pari Dulac, a building owner, decided against renewing the leases of her tenants. It was 1988, not 1998.

title: Yes, I'll Take a Seat, And the Job Offer, Too
description: MARIE PUSATERI was six months pregnant when she walked into an interview a few weeks ago for a job as an Internet communications manager in Manhattan. ''I declined the receptionist's offer to take my coat, preferring to carry it in front of me,'' Ms. Pusateri said. ''If I had a house plant I would have carried that, too.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURT, MICHAEL E., M.D.
description: BURT-Michael E., M.D., Ph.D. A memorial service will be held for Dr. Michael E. Burt on Monday, March 9th at 5 PM at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Rockefeller Research Laboratories, 430 East 67th Street. At the time of his death Dr. Burt was a thoracic surgeon and President of the Medical Staff at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. All are welcome to attend this service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPILMAN, ELEANOR DAVIS
description: SPILMAN-Eleanor Davis, of Duxbury, MA., formerly of Indianapolis, Ind., and Rye, NY, on March 4, after a brief illness. Devoted wife of the late Claude M. Spilman and the late G. Barron Mallory. Beloved mother of Elizabeth P. Mallory, Mary R. Mallory, George B. Mallory, and Peter D. Mallory, and six grandchildren. Donations may be made to the NRDC, 40 W. 20 St., NY, NY 10011; American Lung Association, 1 Abbey Lane, Middleboro, MA 02346, or the Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Ave., Montgomery, AL. 36104.

title: The View From/New Haven; Wanted: Director for the Symphony. Gregarious Nature a Plus.
description: IN the symphony orchestra world, the rumor mill is very active. And it churns frenetically when a spot opens up on a podium. ''At this point in time we have not placed an ad,'' said Cindy Kissin, executive director of the New Haven Symphony Orchestra. But, she added, ''We've had hundreds of resumes pour in.''

title: Nowhere, U.S.A.
description: In the United Airlines first-class lounge at O'Hare International Airport, there's sushi for lunch and only two travelers in evidence. One is on the floor, waving his legs in the air, doing yoga. The other is a grouchy-looking middle-aged guy in tasseled loafers, slacks and a duffel coat he hasn't bothered to take off. He sits hunched, moodily sipping red wine, quite oblivious to the serene first-class space, with its subdued motif of the Orient. He's trying to control his temper.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 8, 1998
description: Weeks

title: A Suitcase Full of Guilt
description: 4:45 A.M. It's pitch black out as Eileen Oswald, like a thief in the night, wheels a carry-on bag out the front door and heaves it into the trunk of her silver 1989 BMW. Moments later, her car steals down the drive while upstairs, in the spacious two-story brick colonial, her husband and two children sleep.

title: Who Built Perot's Ship?
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Memories, Our Selves
description: Stephen S. Hall's ''Our Memories, Our Selves'' (Feb. 15) was a fine and fascinating article. This decade's dynamic memory research is fueled -- beyond boomers' growing terror of Alzheimer's and memory loss -- by a specific social urgency: the ''recovered-memory wars,'' which have pulled memory science into its vortex. As the wars have split the fields of psychiatry and psychology into hostile camps, and left thousands of families destroyed by allegations of incest, the race to identify false from true memories has given scientists a sense of national purpose absent, some say, since the space race.

title: The United States Department of Lost and Found
description: GETTING RID of everything and starting out new is part of many American stories. The act is liberating, but there's also a nagging feeling that the very thing you throw away is the next thing you'll need. When such anxieties strike, it might be comforting to realize that only a short distance from the Capitol Building here, there's a cultural safety net.

title: March 1-7; Workplace Protection Widens In Sexual Harassment
description: The Supreme Court is divided over many issues these days, but sexual harassment is not one of them.

title: Report Card: How the City's Third Graders Measured Up
description: Except where noted, these data are from New York City's school report cards, released last week. Alternative schools are not broken out separately.

title: Uncle Sam, Policeman
description: Unwinnable Wars American Power and Ethnic Conflict. By David Callahan. 273 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $24.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There are times when I wished that I could magically go through the computer and tell someone just how ignorant they really are, but you can't. You just have to listen and type something back, and hope you can change the person's mind.''

title: A Tense Pas de Deux Between Head and Heart
description: LIKE LITERATURE, dance has had its quarrels between the ancients and the moderns; emotion -- or the lack thereof -- is at the core of the debate.

title: Questions Following a Former Mayor
description: Two years ago, East Orange awarded about $300,000 in Federal housing money to a small nonprofit group to buy five rundown buildings. Last year, Federal officials found that the group had failed to properly account for the money, and ordered the city to repay it.

title: Five for the Money in Banff
description: THEY say two can live as cheaply as one, and my wife, Miriam, and I have often proved it. But now we are five, including two teen-agers and one 12-year-old. The challenge, as we approached a weekend on a fixed budget, was finding a way for five to get by as cheaply as two. We knew it would not be easy, but a weak Canadian dollar and a taut strategic plan encouraged us to give it a try.

title: Ousted Union Chief's Theft Trial Centers on Lavish Life Style
description: In his teens, Frederick W. Devine dropped out of high school and landed a rough-and-tumble job building and repairing docks on the city's waterfront. A union activist, he ultimately rose to become the $410,000-a-year head of the nation's largest regional carpenters' union and a powerful labor official whose support was courted by city and state politicians.

title: A Bigger NATO Is Good for Europe; E.U. Membership
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKEND; Se Habla Ingles
description: War has quietly broken out in England once again over the thing we mind about perhaps as much as the monarchy or our natural rights: the English language. The trouble started late last year, when the Collins dictionary people published a list of 100 key words, one for each year of the century (''bikini'' for 1946, ''Scrabble'' for 1948, ''miniskirt'' for 1965, ''clone'' for 1992, and so on). Not to be upstaged, the Oxford dictionaries then produced an alternative list, electing their own most important words from the last two decades (''Reaganomics'' for 1980, ''AIDS'' for 1984, and -- an intriguing pair -- ''Whitewater'' and ''Bobbitt'' for 1993).

title: School 'Report Cards' Upset L.I. Districts
description: JUST as students anxiously wait for their report cards at the end of each term, Long Island school districts have been awaiting the second yearly report cards for each of their schools.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Princeton Borough, N.J.; A Historic, Prototypical College Town
description: SURROUNDED by Princeton Township, Princeton Borough is the epitome of a college town. Its downtown grew up north of Nassau Hall, a massive structure with 26-inch-thick brown sandstone walls built in 1756 to house the College of New Jersey, later renamed Princeton University.

title: The Turning Point
description: CONCEIVED IN LIBERTY

title: Introduction
description: Stephen S. Hall's article ''Our Memories, Our Selves'' elicited a powerful response from readers who are leery of manipulation through medication. Many feel that bad memories are as intrinsic to their sense of self as good ones.

title: Younger Performers On Stage At Palace
description: THREE ensembles of the Young Artists Philharmonic are giving a 7 P.M. concert at the Palace Theater in Stamford. The youngest players, a string group led by Polly Keane, will tackle a Handel hornpipe, one of Dvorak's Bohemian Dances and a movement of a Mozart symphony, while the Young People's Symphony, under John Mastroianni, performs works by Saint-Saens and Tchaikovsky.

title: N.Y.U. Takes Step on the Road to Another National Title
description: William Smith College would have preferred that yesterday's women's basketball game against New York University had been played at its upstate campus in Oneida, N.Y., where it has won 59 straight games. But Coach Glenn Begly said it would not have mattered.

title: Player's Saga: Success, Loss And a Season Redeemed
description: ELTON BRAND almost suffered a lost season. Now he is trying to win it all before it is over.

title: A Painter Hopes to Draw Buyers of Art in Williamsburg
description: Artists for years have flocked to Williamsburg to fashion unused warehouses and factories into studios and lofts, but few galleries have sprung up in the neighborhood. Now Richard Timperio, a painter who has lived there since 1979, has opened the Sideshow gallery at 195 Bedford Avenue between North 6th and North 7th Streets, capitalizing on what he sees as a growing interest among Williamsburgers and Manhattanites to buy art in the neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, JANE
description: PETERS-Jane. On March 6, 1998. Widow of the late C. Brooks Peters and known to many and Dr. Jane Farley Templeton. Jane received a doctorate in psychology at the University of Chicago in an era when few women had such credentials, and she was awarded a National Institutes of Mental Health grant to study psychic factors in hearing loss, a field in which she became a leading expert. Later, she pursued a career in advertising and is author of the pioneering text on focus groups ''Focus Goups: A Guide for Marketing & Advertising Professionals,'' 1987. It is to this day a standard reference text and has been translated into a number of other languages. In addition, Jane was a psychotherapist in private practice. She touched the lives of many people in the course of her various professional roles as well as the lives of those who were part of her personal life. She will be long rememberd and sorely missed. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: What Is a Concentration Camp? Ellis Island Exhibit Prompts a Debate
description: An exhibit opening on Ellis Island next month will revisit an ugly chapter of modern history: the story of tens of thousands of families who, because of their ancestry, were forced from their homes during World War II and corralled into camps, encircled by barbed wire and guarded by armed sentries.

title: EARNING IT; The Hunt for Bias in Hiring
description: FOR managers learning the basics of employment law, there are the usual methods. Reading. Taking notes.

title: Bending and Joining Pieces of Plastic
description: LAST week, this column focused on cutting and drilling plastics. It is also important to know how to fasten pieces together, and how to bend them into different shapes.

title: Listen to the Public
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Day of Humiliation
description: Ellis Elliott was awakened suddenly by an insane pounding on the metal door of his Bronx apartment. It was clear that someone was trying to break the door down.

title: Schools Challenge Students' Internet Talk
description: Aaron Smith's troubles grew out of a drawing that he made in the school computer lab, one that his friend said looked like a chihuahua being killed. That remark, hilarious to a group of 13-year-old boys, became a kind of standing joke that led Aaron and his computer-nerd pals to go home and create a ''C.H.O.W.'' Web page -- a place for Chihuahua Haters of the World to share tidbits like the tale of the seven-foot boa constrictor that ate a chihuahua.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, MAY S.
description: ROSENBERG-May S. On March 7, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Jerome R. and Norton A., and daughtersin-law Julia D. and the late Selma L. Adoring grandmother of Linda Franciscovich, Elisabeth Saxe, Louise Rosenberg and Daniel Rosenberg. Dear great-grandmother of Caroline Saxe. Services 12:15 PM, Monday, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Clang, Clang, Clang, And Connecticut Wins
description: On Thursday night, after his team had beaten Villanova in the quarterfinals of the Big East tournament, Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim said he could not recall the last time the Orangemen had shot so poorly from the field and still won a game.

title: A Big-Hearted Kitchen
description: SOMEONE has to tell you about the White Deer Restaurant. Otherwise, you'd probably pass it on your way to the Lake Mohawk Country Club and prettier Lake Mohawk beyond it.

title: Yolanda Merchant and Courtney Haff
description: WHEN she was 5 years old, Yolanda Suarez Merchant and her family fled Cuba and moved to Miami, then to rural Iowa, and then to Southampton, N.Y. Miss Merchant described her childhood in Southampton this way: ''It was mostly farmers and my mother in her Chanel suit.''

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Airheads
description: Maybe it's the depleted oxygen ration, maybe it's the sense of anonymity or maybe it's a side effect of eating too many salted almonds, but there is something about airline travel that causes otherwise discerning readers to lower their standards and binge on pulp. Like literary adulterers, even the snobbiest readers, once airborne, will abandon their beloved classics and embrace the cheap and easy.

title: The Hand Behind the Hands
description: IT was an emergency. Early on a Sunday morning last June, the Minerva and the Bell Ringers clock at Herald Square, near 34th Street and Broadway, went wild, bong bong bonging without stop. Marvin Schneider, the man responsible for the city's most important clocks, was called in. He dashed from his home in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, clambered up the clock tower and disabled the striking mechanism, the best he could do on short notice.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; For Stamford, a New Way to Preserve Greenspace
description: OVER the last 20 years, Stamford residents have witnessed considerable redevelopment at the cost of a substantial loss of greenspace.

title: Pipeline Review
description: Westchester has applied to the Federal Energy Regulation Commission for intervenor status in the review of the proposed Millennium Pipeline Project, County Executive Andrew J. Spano said last week.

title: Correction
description: A front-page reference last Sunday to an article about a wave of productions of ''Macbeth'' in New York carried an erroneous byline in some copies. The writer was Eileen Blumenthal, not Deborah.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOFFMANN, JOHN R.
description: HOFFMANN-John R. Past forever! Renee, David and Aileen, Peter and Lizzie, Allison and Danielle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARVEY, JOHN P.
description: GARVEY-John P., 71, New York City, died February 27, 1998, emphysema. USNR, 1944-1946, graduate of Yale University, 1952, BA. Survived by his children, John P., Jr., Lee (Lili) G. Carmel, Nathalie (Mimi) G. Mascolo, six grandchildren, and his sister, Natalie Scott Martin. Service will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIFFORD, SAMUEL A.
description: GIFFORD-Samuel A. On March 5, 1998, in his 91st year. Beloved husband of Harriette. Devoted father of Gail and Stephen Rudin. Adored grandfather of Deborah and Stephen Verp, Kenneth Rudin, and the late Andrew Rudin. Cherished great-grandfather of Alison Verp. A longtime leader in the paper industry. A caring, generous and loving family man, he will be deeply missed by many. Service will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, at 12 noon, on Sunday, March 8, 1998.

title: Life After the Poppy
description: ON a remote mountain ridge in northern Thailand, I stood with my wife, Nancy, before a spirit gate that heralded the entrance to a small village inhabited by members of the Akha hill tribe. The contrast with modern, congested Bangkok, from which we had flown north the day before, could not have been more extreme. A bamboo lintel on tall posts, the ceremonial gate is erected each year outside an Akha village to bar malevolent spirits from entering. The traditional supplication for a productive year -- a pair of wooden fertility statues differentiated only by exaggerated sex organs -- was propped against one post. Careful not to antagonize the spirits, we stepped around the gate and into the village.

title: Sally Cohen and Brian Kaplan
description: Sally Marie Cohen, the daughter of Joy Yudofsky Behr and Louis Cohen, both of Louisville, Ky., is to be married this afternoon to Dr. Brian Jay Kaplan, the son of Ida and Arthur Kaplan of Douglaston, Queens. Rabbi Irving P. Glickman is to officiate at the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago.

title: Invention, in All Its Beguiling Varieties
description: WHAT powers the life of an inventor like Robert E. Fulton Jr.? An all-weather curiosity fueled by an unabating desire to create that which is useful. Throughout his 89 years, the Newtown resident has approached the impossible and proved it otherwise. Case in point: his federally approved flying automobile.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about lead poisoning in Newark included two erroneous figure from the state Department of Health and Senior Services for cases reported. Last year there were 363, not 222; in 1996, there were 415, not 419.

title: A Sport Devalued
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Tourism Slipping, Along With Asian Economies
description: THE long-awaited new Hong Kong airport at Chek Lap Kok is scheduled to open July 6, but the opening ceremony could resemble a funeral unless the Asian economic crisis moderates soon. Tourism has fallen steadily since July, to Hong Kong as well as to other Asian cities for which the new airport is expected to become a major hub. And the World Travel and Tourism Council recently forecast that the drop in tourism to Asia will continue through 1998, at a cost of more than 500,000 jobs.

title: Feminists' Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: When the White House Visits Westport
description: WILLIAM J. LOPATA JR. didn't want to serve just beef. True, beef was what the White House had requested, but the executive chef of the Restaurant at National Hall in Westport wanted to serve something more, something befitting a visit from the President of the United States.

title: Motherhood for All, at a Price; Think of the Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MIRIAM MELIN (NEE JAYE)
description: COHEN-Miriam Melin (nee Jaye) on March 1, 1998, in Philadelphia. Wife of the late Dr. Julius Cohen and the late Arthur Melin. Mother of Valerie (Dr. Jack) Cutler and Samuel Melin. Sister of May Chase and the late Harry, Eli and Stanley Jaye. Grandmother of Dr. Andrew Cutler, Peter and Joy Cutler, Dr. Blayne Cutler. Great grandmother of Michael Arthur Cutler and Katie Gabrielle Cutler. A special aunt to all her nieces and nephews. Services were held.

title: Adventures in the Search for Physical Fitness
description: MY physique is not what it used to be, and it never was anything to boast about. When two flights of stairs began to feel like the Himalayas, I resolved to get back in shape.

title: Operation Poison Pill
description: Six Westchester pharmacists were among 16 arrested after an 18-month investigation -- Operation Poison Pill -- by the State Attorney General into a black market operation of prescription drugs.

title: Stylish or Simple, The Asian Bounty Of Washington
description: THOUGH Washington and its suburbs are surprisingly short on consistently worthy top-of-the-line restaurants, it is amazingly blessed with dozens of less expensive places, particularly Asian and Asian style, that are worth the more-moderate tab. The suburbs, in particular, are teeming with Southeast Asian places, particularly Vietnamese, because Washington was one of the places refugees settled after the Vietnam War.

title: Corrections
description: An illustration on page 18 of the Long Island section today with the Home Clinic column, about bending and joining pieces of plastic, is printed in error. It relates to last Sunday's column, about cutting and drilling plastics.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Fit for Spring

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, DRUSCILLA
description: EVANS-Druscilla. 85, on February 28, 1998. Beloved daughter of the late John and Aimee Evans, loving sister of Judith E. Boyd, dear aunt of Gavin Bruce, Timothy Tomma and Andrew Boyd. Services March 10 at 4 PM, Green Funeral Home, 721 Elden St., Herdon VA 20172

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; What? No Werewolves?
description: Americans ''twixt 12 and 20'' have been driving their parents crazy since the days of George Washington -- in the 1770's, according to Michael Barson and Steven Heller, unmarried couples were criticized for ''irregular night walking, frolicking and keeping bad company.'' With color images as in-your-face as the average adolescent, TEENAGE CONFIDENTIAL: An Illustrated History of the American Teen (Chronicle, paper, $16.95) takes a multimedia look at the teen-age subculture since World War II. Examining advertising artwork, magazine articles, paperback book covers, movie posters and romance comics, this lively and well-researched retrospective suggests that ''the more things change, the more they remain the same.'' For American teen-agers, music (from Frank Sinatra to Elvis Presley and the Beatles) has always been a catalyst, the opposite sex an often heart-wrenching mystery, and parents there to rebel against. In ''a masterful display of bifurcated vision,'' the mass media promoted the ''Kleen Teen,'' as embodied by the redheaded, bow-tied comic book hero Archie Andrews and immortalized on movie screens by Mickey Rooney and Judy Garland, even while sounding the alarm with dire warnings of juvenile delinquents on the rampage. Magazine exposes, dime novels and low-budget films fanned the flames of parental panic side by side with their coverage of saddle shoes, sock hops and slumber parties. Magazines like Teen Life addressed ''Kissing . . . Petting . . . Going Steady'' while instructional films tackled subjects like ''What to Do on a Date.'' Love comics flourished throughout the 50's and 60's, ''offering pithy lessons on dating behavior that teens could ignore at their own peril.'' ''Teenage Confidential'' is a wryly nostalgic trip back to the future, a tribute to ''the way we were . . . when we weren't in detention, that is.'' Leslie Chess Feller

title: A Collection of 1,500 Plants and Growing
description: FOR those people who don't know a philodendron from a Philadelphian, Mark Mishanie's hobby will seem peculiar. Even those who do appreciate their flora and fauna may question the zealous commitment that Mr. Mishanie has to house plants.

title: Violinists Playing for Various Good Causes
description: FOUR internationally admired violinists will play for love in North Jersey, three of them this week. Their concerts will reveal that love has several meanings: it can be for a certain piece of music, a family member, a colleague, a child or a cause.

title: Sports of The Times; El-Amin Fostering Great Expectations
description: KHALID El-Amin has keen instincts and a good heart. Good attribute for a point guard, great qualities for a human being. In the middle of his junior year of high school, when he was 16, El-Amin decided to get married. His wife-to-be was a college sophomore. El-Amin was being faithful to a religious creed as he understood it.

title: Gingrich Defends Starr as Lott Urges Him to 'Show His Cards'
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich staunchly defended Kenneth W. Starr today after Senator Trent Lott said it was time for the Whitewater independent counsel to wrap up his investigation and ''show his cards.''

title: TELEVISION; Of Two Networks, a Sitcom and a Place of Its Own
description: SO FAR, Danny Jacobson's $20 million sitcom deal with Fox hasn't gone exactly as expected. The first comedy to come from that arrangement, ''Two Guys, a Girl and a Pizza Place,'' will have its premiere Wednesday night at 9:30. But it will be on ABC.

title: Hunter Overcomes Ragged Play to Advance
description: Hunter College, the band of basketball nomads with realistic aspirations of winning a national championship, took a wobbly step toward that goal last night.

title: A Battlefield Shifts
description: A New Jersey court's ruling last week against excluding openly gay young men from the Boy Scouts of America was significant in a number of ways, but perhaps none more than this:

title: An Apothecary With a Past, Including the Underground Railroad
description: High Street in Burlington City runs through the center of town and dead-ends at the Delaware River. Old-fashioned stores -- some predating the Revolutionary War -- line the street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLTOFF, KAY
description: COLTOFF-Kay. We mourn our loving, spirited friend and colleague. Roberta Graziano Ellyn Schiff Berman

title: In the Region/Long Island; For the Young at Heart, the Choice Is a Mix of Ages
description: ONE of the signs greeting visitors to Summerfield, a subdivision under construction here on 221 acres, describes the development of detached single-family houses as a ''total family environment.''

title: VIEWPOINT; One Set of Rules, Please
description: THE argument over whether to bail out ailing Asian economies has diverted attention from more basic, if less seductive, issues: the need for transparency in international transactions and the crucial role that financial accounting standards play in meeting that goal.

title: In the Flea Market of the Mind
description: THE FACTORY OF FACTS By Luc Sante. 307 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ BATZ, MURIEL
description: HOROWITZ BATZ-Muriel. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Muriel Horowitz Batz, a very generous supporter who embraced Tzedakah through her passionate commitment to the Jewish community. She was a Lion of Judah contributor, and a beloved leader in our Long Island Women's Campaign. She will be greatly missed. We extend our sincerest condolences to her son, Sanford, and Robert Batz. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Diane Wohl, Chair, Long Island Women's Campaign Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: A Word for the Spring of El Nino: Cashmere
description: ONE of fashion's trickier puzzles comes up when spring clothes hit the stores in late February and early March -- and spring itself has not sprung. Those with the fervor to appear as soon as possible in the latest spring things run the danger of looking silly traipsing down frozen streets in lightweight coats and sandals, not to mention the threat of catching a cold that even the most costly chicken soup can't cure.

title: Cellular Tower Is Opposed in Muttontown
description: A PROPOSAL to build a cellular-telephone tower in Muttontown has prompted members of a civic group to call for a moratorium on all microwave towers to study their effects and to create planning and zoning guidelines.

title: Substance, Spirit Endure in 'Mass Appeal'
description: ''MASS APPEAL'' is too much with us, in professional, in stock and in community theaters. Even the movies have had their colorless way with Bill C. Davis's two-character play, which moved from Off Broadway to Broadway in 1981. One does not expect to find Fleetwood Stage in New Rochelle, N.Y., whose mission is mightier than a ride on a war horse, with such an overcooked item on its bill of fare. And yet. And yet.

title: Knockout Punch Toughens St. John's
description: Ron Artest looked up at the basket, shook his head and pulled his uniform jersey halfway up his back on Friday night. He was frustrated and exasperated. Ryan Blackwell had just buried a soft 16-foot jumper with no time remaining to push Syracuse to a 69-67 victory over St. John's and allow the Orangemen to march into the championship game of the Big East Conference tournament and Artest felt responsible. Blackwell was his man.

title: The On-the-Record Flap About Off the Record
description: WASHINGTON'S unwritten rules for writing could use a rewrite.

title: Heppner as Lohengrin: A Test for a Tenor With Heroic Prospects
description: HELDENTENORS MAY not be the operatic equivalent of dodos, but they are rare birds. Although once spotted with some regularity, singers possessed of dramatic-tenor voices -- loud, ringing and indefatigable -- have assumed mythic stature in recent years. But despite exaggerated reports of the extinction of the voice type, a concern for the future extends well beyond the lofty heights of Bayreuth, the Wagnerian shrine and thus the favored habitat of such singers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTEIN, MINERVA
description: GERSTEIN-Minerva, of Aventura, FL, on March 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted Mother of Marion and Lee Slosberg, Jane and Richard Shapiro. Cherished Grandmother of Elise and Robert Holtzman, Laurie Slosberg, Lauren and Jonathan Shapiro, and Andrew Shapiro. Loving Greatgrandmother of Rachel Danielle Holtzman. Dear Sister of Matilda Lesser. Graveside services on Sunday, March 8, 1 P.M., at New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Unified Pressure on Kosovo
description: Bosnia collapsed in upon itself, but the violence in Kosovo could ignite the Balkans beyond the former Yugoslavia. The guerrilla terrorism and state massacres of the past week are finally forcing American and European officials to take the danger seriously. When top diplomats from the United States and five European nations meet in London tomorrow, they should affirm Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's strong warning yesterday to the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, to stop the killings of Kosovo's Albanians.

title: Our Memories, Our Selves
description: The question that actors find most irritating is, ''How did you learn all those lines?'' It's irritating because memorizing, for the actor, is the most pedestrian of all the acting tasks, and certainly no indicator of talent. But acting is the one profession in which rather incredible feats of memory are all in a day's work. In reading Hall's article, it occurred to me that quite a few of the actor's challenges offer a perfect canvas for scientific study. For example, Hall writes that in 1885 a German psychologist ''discovered that he could memorize a list of nonsense syllables much better if he spaced out the learning sessions with a rest interval'' rather than ''repeating the drill over and over without a break.'' This is something that actors know, too. Also, memorizing happens even faster if the lines are learned in tandem with the physical blocking of the play. (Why is it that kinetic memory so affects word memory?)

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Watching Tuberculosis
description: The incidence of tuberculosis in Westchester increased almost 60 percent last year, but there is no cause for alarm, the county's Health Commissioner, Harold N. Adel, said.

title: Jordan Is Still Growing Into Greatness at Garden
description: Michael Jordan will wind his way through the corridors beneath Madison Square Garden today before strolling onto the floor, a stage he has taken with as much electricity as Frank Sinatra or the Grateful Dead and with as much grace as Muhammad Ali.

title: Motherhood for All, at a Price; Hardly the Slave Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Architectural Order Graces a Chaotic Hub
description: The design for the new Reuters Building is a 30-story equivalent of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's civility campaign. It is decent, well mannered and deferential, and if you were a gentleman, you would tip your hat.

title: Feasts for Ears
description: To the Editor: Susan Barron's amusing article reminded me of an experience my wife and I had.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: WITHIN THESE WALLS

title: Depression-Era New York, Captured in Photos
description: WHEN Berenice Abbott returned to New York City from Paris in 1929, it was not the city she had left in 1921. Confronting the building boom taking over New York, she began to photograph the city's changing face. From 1935 to 1939, she did so with the support of the Museum of the City of New York and the Federal Art Project. From that period, 126 of her photos will be shown at the museum until June 21.

title: Unprepared for Death; Caring for Survivors
description: To the Editor:

title: The Road Behind
description: The Ground Round in Jackson, Mich., sits at the top of Exit 138 off Highway 94, next to a strip mall. ''I've eaten here quite a bit, coming through,'' says John Maxwell, who for 42 years has sold automotive and machine parts, traveling the country by car and by plane. ''It's convenient, right on the highway.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDBERG, MARTHA E.
description: FELDBERG-Martha E. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Rhodes. Devoted mother of Samuel, Celeste and Naomi. Caring motherin-law of Hiroko and Carl. Cherished grandmother of David, Adam, Jason, Amy, Harumi and Shana. Loving great-grandmother of Jacob and Matthew. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Program for the Exceptionally Gifted, Mary Baldwin College, Staunton, VA 24401. Services 12 noon, Monday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Feb. 22, about travel by grandparents and grandchildren, misstated the telephone number of Special Expeditions and rendered the surname of a company spokeswoman incorrectly. The phone number is (800) 397-3348; the spokeswoman is Maria Brunesson Lindblad, not Burnesson-Lindblad.

title: A Benz for the Wrist
description: ON a Tuesday night last month, a Swiss watchmaker named Franck Muller held a party at the Plaza Athenee Hotel on East 64th Street to introduce his new line of timepieces to a group of about 50 nattily dressed watch enthusiasts -- pardon, horologists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAPPER, FRANCES (NEE RITTER)
description: KLAPPER-Frances (nee Ritter). On March 6, 1998. Widow of Jerome. Loving mother of Carol. Dear sister of the late Teresa Halpern, Helen Glassberg, Benjamin, Henry and Edward Ritter. Service Monday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, JACQUELINE
description: MENDELSON - Jacqueline. Of Aventura, FL. Formerly of New York City. Passed Away February 28, 1998. Beloved wife of Herbert. Loving mother of Nancy (Thomas Scott) Mendelson, Manny Mendelson and Anthony (Jane) Mendelson. Cherished grandmother of Benjamin Michael Mendelson. Dear sister of Thomas Woolf. Services were held in Florida.

title: Brooklyn to Display Romanov Treasures
description: The Brooklyn Museum of Art is the last stop for ''Jewels of the Romanovs: Treasures of the Russian Imperial Court'' before the popular show goes back to Russia, where its opulent objects will again be dispersed among five museums there.

title: Shroud of Turin Exhibit To Open in Cathedral
description: For the first time in 20 years, the Shroud of Turin will be on display in the Turin Cathedral this spring.

title: Republican Leaders Are Split Over Starr
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich defended Kenneth W. Starr yesterday, even as the Republican leader of the Senate said it was time for the Whitewater independent counsel to wrap up his investigation and ''show his cards.''

title: $100,000 Reward in Deli Mystery
description: It has been two years since Abe Lebewohl went to the bank and never came back. On the morning of March 4, 1996, Mr. Lebewohl, the founder of the Second Avenue Deli at Second Avenue and 10th Street, was gunned down on a busy corner six blocks south by two men who then fled. Mr. Lebewohl, who was 64, was left to die on the sidewalk.

title: Study Sheds Light on Drug Traffic, Viewing Markets in 6 Cities
description: When it comes to getting busted by the police, crack cocaine is the riskiest drug because crack smokers tend to buy it outdoors, in their own neighborhoods and from a variety of dealers, making them more conspicuous. But powder cocaine can be bought more discreetly, often indoors from a single dealer who caters to his regular customers.

title: Quick Sip/Edgewater; Where the Hudson River Flows Into the Caribbean Sea
description: The reconstruction of River Road left an oddly preserved tiny strip of Old River Road that is home to a charming year-old restaurant called Rebecca's.

title: Devils, Buoyed by News About Gilmour, Bruise Rangers on Power Play
description: This was a day of good news all around for the Devils. First, they learned that the damage to Doug Gilmour's right knee was minor. Then, they went out on the ice at Continental Arena and posted a 6-3 triumph over the Rangers on the strength of three power-play goals, a victory that put the Devils atop the National Hockey League.

title: Corrections
description: The Choice Tables column on page 6 of the Travel section today, about Asian restaurants in Washington, referred imprecisely to the photographs in Germaine's. Many of them, but not all, are by Dick Swanson, the husband of the owner.

title: Are Rangers Still in Race? Devils Don't Know It
description: The Rangers were hoping to learn how close they have come to the Devils today. Instead, they confirmed what they must have feared most.

description: AFRICA IN CHAOS

title: Back to the Calculator, Once Again, on School Aid
description: For Adam E. Drapczuk, the school superintendent in Jamesburg, Middlesex County, the numbers simply did not add up.

title: Two Cultures and How They Converged in a Timeless Folk Form
description: A MASK can be one person's simple Halloween disguise and another's metaphor for life. The actors of ancient Greece wore masks to transform themselves into gods or heroes; pop culture figures like the Lone Ranger and Zorro wear them to escape identification. From Venice to New Orleans, or anywhere else Carnival is celebrated, a mask can free the wearer to enjoy that one last fling before Lent without fear of discovery and embarrassment.

title: Is There a Doctor On the Plane?
description: William Abranowicz, a photographer who racks up around 200,000 miles on airplanes every year, is living proof that frequent fliers face other dangers than plane crashes and the American Airlines dinner calzone: ''I can get off a plane and have giant red marks on each side of my nose, develop a dry scalp, my skin will be inflamed. My skin freaks out.''

title: Quotidian Treasures
description: ART AND LIFE IN BANGLADESH By Henry Glassie. Illustrated. 511 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $49.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, NETTIE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Nettie. Beloved wife of the late Norman. Beloved mother of Elinor Stampler, Merrilyn Kadison and Dr. Michael. Devoted grandmother of Andy (Lisa), Steven and Dr. Alan (Susan) Kadison, Janet and Michael Stampler and Jennifer and Jonathan Goldstein. Great-grandmother of Rebecca and Rachel Kadison. Active member of Workmens Circle and City of Hope. Services Sunday, March 8, Parkside, 167th Street and Jerome Avenue, Bronx.

title: Our Memories, Our Selves
description: A drug that prevents forming memories of traumatic events would do more than obstruct the legal process: it would interfere with one of the important psychological tasks of the trauma survivor -- to make sense of the experience. We are the species that strives to understand what happens to us, and recovery from trauma is made more difficult when memories are missing. We see this when physical injury interferes with long-term memory formation. (Remember the bodyguard in Diana's crash?)

title: Irked Irabu Grabs Film In Fracas
description: The contentious relationship between Hideki Irabu and the Japanese news media boiled over today when, according to reporters from Japan, he angrily took film from photographers and then stomped on the foot of one cameraman and battered his videotape.

title: Spare the Rod, and Then What?
description: THE sophomore and junior girls hanging out at the mini-market near Eastside High in Paterson were bubbling with commentary about life in the classroom.

title: 'Raging on Park Avenue' Did Subject a Disservice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hunkered Presidency
description: ''I've proved I can take a punch,'' Bill Clinton said after surviving the bimbo eruption that threatened his candidacy in 1992. Almost exactly six years later, President Clinton is still embroiled in one of the scruffy, self-inflicted scandals that have been a chronic feature of his career. Once again, the boxing metaphor applies. The man can still take a punch. Moreover, the old rope-a-dope is working in his favor. But the rope-a-dope's originator, Muhammad Ali, also demonstrated the flaw of that strategy. It is agonizing to watch and exacts hidden, long-term costs on the winner.

title: Nets Aim To Reverse A Losing Trend
description: The excuses for the Nets' four-game losing streak could come easily:

title: Hard Lessons In Teen-Age Drinking
description: UNDERAGE drinking has long been thought of as a rite of passage for teen-agers and college students, and largely tolerated by the public.

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: I do not think it appropriate to carry an article complaining about the unreliability of airline baggage checking. As every airline passenger can observe, passengers bring too much carry-on luggage into the cabin, filling the overhead bins, leaving no room for a late arrival's briefcase or even hat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIERNAN, RAYMOND J.
description: KIERNAN-Raymond J. Of Bronxville, NY on March 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Jeanne Sillery Kiernan. Cousin of Patricia Kiernan O'Sullivan. Survived by several nieces and nephews. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville betw the hours of 2-4 and 7-9pm Saturday and Sunday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Monday, March 9 at 11am. Masses preferred or contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Little Rock Growing Weary Of the 4-Year Siege by Starr
description: Skip Rutherford, one of this city's most faithful Friends of Bill, and William H. Kennedy 3d, a former associate White House counsel, were sharing lunch a few months ago at La Scala, an Italian restaurant in Little Rock's Hillcrest neighborhood, when an acquaintance stopped by their table.

title: Court to Examine Sex Harassment
description: The Supreme Court's ruling this week that Federal discrimination law covers sexual harassment between people of the same sex was only the start of a wide-ranging examination of sexual harassment law now under way at the Court.

title: Long Before Murdoch, There Was Ted Turner
description: Rupert Murdoch already had a $14 billion media conglomerate when he decided that his Fox Television group should buy the Los Angeles Dodgers. But Ted Turner was not a cable news titan or America's Cup winner when he bought the Atlanta Braves in 1976. He was just a brash Southern dervish with a billboard business and a small UHF station.

title: Motherhood for All, at a Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Cancun
description: From the moment it began beckoning to visitors less than 25 years ago, Cancun has been defined by contradictions. In a part of Mexico dominated by ancient Maya temples, it was envisioned as a modern creation, all glass and concrete and steel. In an area surrounded by nature at its most raw and unspoiled in the form of beaches and jungle, it is a purely man-made place.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUSSELL, MAURICE V.
description: RUSSELL-Maurice V. A memorial service for Dr. Maurice V. Russell will be held at the Community Church of New York, 40 East 35 Street, NYC, Thursday, March 12, 4 P.M. Reception to follow.

title: Lizards and Snakes Star in San Diego
description: Dinosaurs continue to be a star attraction of natural history and science museum shows. But other reptiles still around to bask in the glory are finally getting their own exhibition. ''Reptiles!'' started a national tour at the San Diego Natural History Museum Feb. 21. The exhibit includes live reptiles and six robotic creatures much larger than life.

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: I got a big chuckle from Anne Bernays's ''Carrying On About Carry-Ons,'' (Jan. 25), and I count myself among sufferers of Baggage Separation Anxiety. However, delayed luggage can sometimes afford the traveler an enriching experience.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; Thoughts of Bamboo and My Dad
description: IN Chinese gardens, bamboo symbolizes the honorable person, resilient in adversity, who bends without breaking. I learned this after my father's death, too late to offer it. Just as well, maybe. Praise always embarrassed him.

Fellow in the Maternal Fetal Medicine. Beloved father of Ndidi and Ike. Reposing at Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Ave., Bronx, NY on Tuesday, March 10, 1998 from 4-9 PM. Interment Onitsha, Nigeria.
