description: IN the midst of California's biblical downpour last month, The San Francisco Chronicle dispatched a reporter to Seattle to figure out how people here live with the wet, the gloom -- the horror! -- of perpetual precipitation.

title: Three N.Y. Preps Star in State Meet
description: Keyon Soley of Uniondale High School in Long Island, Sashanie Simpson of Campus Magnet High School in Queens and Sean Wright of Rice High School in Manhattan turned in strong performances yesterday in the New York State intersectional indoor track and field indoor championships in the Carrier Dome in Syracuse.

title: Laura Williams And Christian Gal
description: Laura Susan Williams and Christian Blair Gal were married yesterday at King's Chapel in Boston. The Rev. Arlene Sutherland, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: On Time and Change: Mouthing the Blues
description: BEFORE the opening-night performance of ''A Jersey Cantata,'' Jacqueline Knox talked to the audience about the pleasures of belonging to an audience-friendly and friendly neighborhood playhouse, 12 Miles West. ''There is a lot of hope for the theater,'' said Ms. Knox, who, as producing artistic director, resident actress and founding member of the theater collective, is ever in search of new plays. ''I won't believe this is a dying art form.''

title: Vandals Slash 114 Tires on Cars Near Station House in Brooklyn
description: Vandals punctured 114 tires, including some on New York City Police Department vehicles and officers' personal cars, early yesterday outside the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn, the site of the alleged torture of Abner Louima.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: A FLOATING LIFE

title: What It All Boils Down To
description: THE hills of Vermont swell with spring thaw. When the ice and the snow and the underground frost melt, the dirt roads turn to chocolate mousse and the maples fill with sweet water.

title: Bard and the Beatles On Maps in Britain
description: The British Tourist Authority is offering two new maps for visitors interested in sites linked to popular music and literature.

title: Same Old, Same Old For Two Top Teams
description: The French say it, ''Plus ca change, plus c'est la meme chose.'' The Atlanta Braves and the Cleveland Indians might not be able to translate that saying into the language of balls and strikes, but it fits these two teams perfectly: the more they change, the more they stay the same.

title: Musical Fares
description: The first rule of the airline business is that an empty seat is as worthless as a piece of rotten fruit. Last year, the carriers succeeded in filling more than 70 percent of their seats, the highest level since the end of World War II and a rate that, before deregulation, was considered technically unattainable by most experts.

title: Giving Some T.L.C. To an S & M Restaurant
description: The adult high chairs are drenched, the black patent leather boots are soggy, and the spikes are rusty. The sado-masochism-themed restaurant La Nouvelle Justine is closed to repair water damage from a fire. It broke out on Feb. 23 in an apartment above the restaurant, which is at 206 West 23d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

title: In the Shoes (Five Pairs) of Women Seeking Solace
description: THE FIVE women Tyne Daly portrays in her new one-woman play ''Mystery School'' would probably never be drawn to one another. Certainly not long enough to discover that they have a need in common: a hunger for religion, something spiritual to hold onto as the millennium nears.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUBA, MARGRET JOY FLINSCH
description: BUBA-Margret Joy Flinsch. Internationally known sculptor, aged 93, died in Black Mountain, North Carolina, February 11, 1998. She and her husband Peter, lived in her studio in New York City for many years. Her contributions to the city are on public display in fifteen locations. Among these are a bust of Pope John Paul II (Saint Patrick's Cathedral), a bas-relief of John D. Rockefeller Jr. (Rockefeller Plaza), a bust of Henry Fairfield Osborne (American Museum of Natural History). A passionate ornithologist and life member of the Audubon Society, her sculptures of John James and Lucy Audubon reside at the Society's headquarters. In Washington DC one can see her over life-size figure of Dr. Florence R. Sabin in Statuary Hall and a bust of Justice Stanley Matthews in the U.S. Supreme Court. In Europe her works there include a bust of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer (Bonn, Germany) and a bust of Pope Paul VI at the Vatican Library (Italy). Her artistry was prolific, characterized by tireless attention to detail. Sketchbook in hand, she observed and recorded everything. She also illustrated several children's books, painted scenes and portraits with oils and water color. She is survived by a brother Roland Flinsch in California and a sister Dr. Cora Flinsch in Switzerland, as well as many nieces and nephews.

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Feb. 15, about New York hotels, misspelled the name of a discount hotel reservation service. It is Quikbook, not Quickbook.

title: Into Halls of Fame and Second Centuries
description: HALL OF FAMERS, NO. 1 -- It's been more than 50 years since Larry Doby broke the color barrier in the American League, joining the Cleveland Indians on July 5, 1947.

title: Post Office Murals, at 50, Get Face Lift
description: ''I've waited a long time for this,'' said Joe Cohen, the curator of the New York Museum of Postal History, from his cramped quarters in the General Post Office, also known as the James A. Farley Building, on Eighth Avenue and 33d Street.

title: The Nation; The Dark Side of Optimism
description: ONE of the things that is supposed to be so wonderful about the economic expansion of the 1990's is that it has made people feel so good about themselves. Remember the pitiful, helpless American giant of the 1980's, with its butterfingered, inept work force? That is not the national self-image anymore. Now America's triumphant economy breeds the sort of optimism that even has some people saying there can't be hard times again.

title: Testing the Tasteless
description: Did The Times really fail to pursue the Gennifer Flowers and Paula Jones stories because to do so would have been to pander to prurient interests (Word & Image: ''Testing the Tasteless,'' by Max Frankel, Feb. 15)? I doubt it. Here's a more plausible explanation: The Times preferred Clinton to Bush and Dole, and knew that adding the weight of its prestige to the coverage of Clinton's ''bimbo eruptions'' might have doomed his election and re-election. Thus, by playing down the Flowers and Jones stories, The Times abetted the election of a man whose personal behavior clearly forewarned us of his scandal-ridden Presidency.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on page 4 of the Travel section today, about inheriting frequent flier accounts, includes an interview with Cary Reich, a biographer of Nelson A. Rockefeller. Mr. Reich died on Wednesday, after the section had gone to press.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TOWNSEND, ROBERT CHASE
description: TOWNSEND-Robert Chase. A memorial service will be held for Robert C. Townsend on Tuesday March 17 at 11 AM at All Saints Church, 855 Middle Neck Rd., Great Neck, Long Island, N.Y. Mr. Townsend, who died on the island of Anguilla on January 12, 1998 had been a Senior Vice President of American Express for many years and Chairman and CEO of Avis Rent a Car. His books on management and leadership were international best sellers. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the Midnight Mission, 396 S. Los Angeles St., Los Angeles, CA 90013, attn: Clancy.

title: Hugh Jones 4th and Christine Yoo
description: Christine J. Yoo, the daughter of Leslie and Ronald Yoo of New York, was married yesterday in New York to Hugh McKean Jones 4th, the son of Mr. Jones 3d of Buffalo and the late Lee Randall Jones. Justice Leslie Crocker Snyder of State Supreme Court in New York officiated at the Plaza.

title: First the Schoolhouse, Then the Home
description: IT is more important, the parents say, than the town or borough, the street or neighborhood; more important, they insist, than the style of house or size of apartment. It is the school their children will attend -- and for many families it has become the deciding factor determining where they will live.

title: Fighting Water Pollution in Pound Ridge
description: AN oily film on the dog's water bowl was the only real clue that George and Ann Thom had that something was wrong with their water.

title: Nobody Is Likely to Starve Around La Guardia College
description: If progress can be measured by cups of coffee, then Long Island City seems to be turning around. Seven years ago, when Big Apple Deli and Pizza opened on the corner of Queens Boulevard and Van Dam Street, there wasn't much competition. Now, said Big Apple's manager, Les Raftis, ''It's beginning to be a tough area to do a food business.''

title: Prisoner's Accusations of Police Beating Are Under Investigation
description: The Police Department and the Queens District Attorney's office are investigating allegations that a handcuffed prisoner was beaten in a Queens police station house, law enforcement officials said yesterday. Among those being questioned, they said, is an officer who reportedly saw the beating and notified the department's Internal Affairs Bureau.

title: Murals at Co-op Are Irreplaceable Treasure
description: To the Editor:

title: Case Studies
description: Yes, it is possible to fly 3,000 miles from home and not check any luggage. The secret (as in all things) is organization and planning. It also helps if you have a wardrobe like a Chinese menu. Here's how it's done.

title: A Different West Side Story
description: ON THE OUTSIDE LOOKING IN

title: Detainees In Nigeria Pin Hopes On the Pope
description: Human rights campaigners are expressing the hope that Pope John Paul II will use his visit here this month to seek clemency for Nigeria's political prisoners. The issue has gained urgency, they say, with the worsening health of one of country's best-known detainees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIT, ALICE
description: LEVIT-Alice. Loving sister of Jacob and Edith ''Lilly'' Chalik. Adored aunt of Naomi Alpert, Bernard, Alan, William, Hiram Levit, Noah and Leon Fuhrman. Beloved great-aunt and great-great aunt. Private services Sunday.

title: The Nation: I Bill, Therefore I Am; Philosophers Ponder a Therapy Gold Mine
description: WHEN he was starting out as a standup comedian in the 1960's, Woody Allen joked about being expelled from college for cheating on a philosophy exam: ''I looked within the soul of the boy sitting next to me,'' he said.

title: The World: The Power Stops Here; Annan Makes His Bid to Make His Job Count
description: HE has no political power base, no army, not even a private plane. He may be at the pinnacle of world diplomacy, but the throne he occupies is really a hollow box. The job description of the Secretary General of the United Nations is contained in eight short paragraphs of the organization's Charter -- and most of those are devoted to circumscribing his authority. On Capitol Hill, he is portrayed as a mere foreigner meddling in American affairs.

title: Motherhood for All, at a Price; Taboo for Women Only
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUPPER, JOEL H.
description: HUPPER-Joel H. On February 28, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Joan T. Hupper. Loving father of Anne and David. IBM retiree. Computer consultant and teacher and music critic. Survived by his 2 children and 3 grandchildren. Services Mar. 10, 2PM, Prestyberian Church, New Canaan, Connecticut.

title: A Friend Who Can Never Be Replaced
description: THE rain came down cold and steady. A gust of wind scattered some torn coin wrappers and fast-food debris across a lot in the Inlet neighborhood of Atlantic City. In the mist, you could barely make out the silhouettes of the casino skyscrapers piled against the sea.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Lecture on Photo Collecting

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, GOLDIE
description: BRENNER-Goldie. On March 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Elias. Loving mother of Edith Everett, Gladys Praigrod and the late Fred Brenner. Adored grandmother of Frances, Sharon, David and Carolyn. Dearest great grandmother of Elias, Ethan and Hannelora. Service Sunday, 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Long Reach In Intel's Slide
description: The plunge in the stock price of the Intel Corporation last week, after the company warned that its first-quarter profits would be disappointing, hit mutual fund investors harder than any other one-day decline by a stock in recent history.

title: A Regal Four Days In Paris
description: SOMETIMES I worry that I was Marie-Antoinette in a previous life. I have always dreamed, for example, of having a pied-a-terre in Paris, to pop over as blithely as some people drive to the country, catch up with friends, visit a few favorite museums and shops and return refreshed on Monday. When off-season rates put such extravagant fantasies within a real person's grasp, you have to indulge those Marie-Antoinette whims. What could be better (or more obnoxious) than announcing, ''I'm going to Paris for the weekend''?

title: Q&A/Evelyn Mareth; Coaxing Meaning From Strings of Digits
description: EVELYN MARETH is in the business of improving accuracy: teaching employees how to make fewer errors with data. The vehicle is her company, the Accuracy Company, based in Fairfield.

title: Patrons Root for the Return of the 'Cheers' of Clinton Street
description: Jan. 5 was a black day for the regulars at the Cafe on Clinton. A fire broke out in the kitchen of the popular restaurant at 268 Clinton Street, and the damage was so extensive it has been closed ever since.

title: Snowdrop, A Sign of Spring Wrapped in Delicacy
description: SNOWDROPS are truly nature's pop-ups. Their delightful early blooms have been appearing suddenly for several weeks, casting aside last fall's remaining detritus in sunny corners and confirming that spring is on its way.

description: Monika Morris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Morris of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Marwan Kreidie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Munir R. Kreidie of King of Prussia, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Thomas L. Steirs performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Greenwich in Old Greenwich, Conn.

description: HOOPER-Barbara, of Philadelphia, formerly of New York City on March 2, 1998. Beloved wife of Alfred Hooper, mother of Thomas Hooper and Mary Del Bono, sister of Olga Coren and the late Martin L. Scheiner, grandmother of Ginnie Hutchinson. Services private.

title: Huskies, as Teams And Crowd Pleasers
description: FOLLOWING practice at the Gampel Pavilion on Friday afternoon Feb. 27, the sixth-ranked University of Connecticut men's basketball team and its coaches boarded a bus that took them to the Hartford Marriott Hotel in Farmington, about 35 miles west of the Storrs campus.

title: Mack-Cali, Growing, Reports Soaring Profits
description: The Mack-Cali Realty Corp., one of the fastest-growing office property companies in the country, said last week that fourth-quarter profits more than doubled on the strength of about $1.8 billion in acquisitions.

title: Giants Add Johnson At Running Back
description: The Giants and the free agent running back LeShon Johnson have agreed to terms on a two-year contract, another sign that Rodney Hampton, the team's career rushing leader, is unlikely to remain with the team.

title: Duke to Adopt a Code to Prevent Apparel From Being Made in Sweatshops
description: With the Duke basketball team riding high and consumers snapping up apparel bearing the university's name, Duke plans to announce a far-reaching code of conduct tomorrow to insure that products bearing its name are not made in sweatshops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBY, MARK J.
description: JACOBY-Mark J. Community Advocates has lost a loyal friend and generous supporter. Our heartfelt condolences to Miriam and the entire family. Marge Rogatz, President

title: Linked By Strings Of a Guitar
description: They met about four years ago. Jeff Epstein, a sales and marketing manager by day and, by night, a singer, songwriter and guitarist for an ''alternative power pop'' band called Plaid. And Joe Pickerelli, a guitar repairman.

title: India, Eager for Stability, Frets at Another Indecisive Vote
description: As India's election results flowed in this week, a television advertisement captured a widespread apprehension that this huge, impoverished nation may be headed for another period of revolving-door governments that lack the political clout to tackle the country's problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLER, EBERHARD, HANS J.
description: MULLER-EBERHARD-Hans J. One of the world's leading molecular immunologists, died March 3, 1998. Director of the Institute of Molecular Medicine for the Prevention of Human Diseases at the University of Texas-Houston, his research contribution dominated an era in immunology and biomedical research. From 1988-1995 he led the world-renowned Bernhard Nocht Institute for Tropical Medicine in Germany. He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences and Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Irma Gigli-Muller-Eberhard, and daughters Kristina and Monika Muller-Eberhard. A memorial service will be held 4:00PM, Monday, March 16, at Palmer Memorial Episcopal Church, 6221 Main St. Houston, TX. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Institute of Molecular Medicine, the University of Texas-Houston Health Science Center, 2121 W. Holcombe Blvd, Houston, TX 77030

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, MIRIAM
description: WASSERMAN - Miriam. The Board of Directors, council, staff and friends of the Hudson Guild note, with deep sorrow, the passing of our generous and devoted friend. A member of the Board of Trustees from 1962 to 1998, Mrs. Wasserman showed her devotion to the Guild in countless ways. Her commitment to the mission of the Hudson Guild will continue to inspire us long after her passing. She will be greatly missed.

title: New Prosperity Brings New Conflict to Indian Country
description: Not long after the Goshute Indians stopped resisting the Mormons who had poured into the sun-cracked bowl of the Great Basin, the tribe seemed to disappear, gone like most natives into sepia tones of the past, their poses ever frozen -- noble, doomed, vanquished.

title: INSIDE
description: Aftermath of a Massacre

description: To the Editor:

title: Repairs in Florida May Be Delayed as Labor Market Tightens
description: Shortages of construction workers, particularly roofers, could slow the rebuilding and repair of the 1,600 homes and apartments ravaged by a series of tornadoes that ripped through central Florida last week.

title: A Bigger NATO Is Good for Europe; Solid Czech Majority
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILLS, POLLY STRONG
description: SILLS-Polly Strong. At 79 on March 2, 1998. Beloved wife of Morton, mother of Rockwell and Charles Tenney. Daughter of the Society of Mayflower Decendents, Patron of the Brecht Forum, she will be in our hearts forever. Memorial service in Cold Spring Harbor, 72 Shore Rd., April 19 at noon. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Alzheimer's Association, 420 Lexington Avenue.

title: The Road Crew
description: Ceri Mort, manager, Virgin Limobike ''The way it works is, I meet you at the limo desk at the airport. Then I dress you in whatever I think is appropriate for the weather. If it's cold, a motorbike jacket, a scarf, heavy-duty gloves and a sort of granny blanket from your feet up to your waist. It's kind of funny when you get a 50-year-old high-flier banker type and you're basically dressing him or her. We have a phone plugged into the bike and an intercom. I recently had a chap talking to a colleague in Manhattan who was talking on his cell phone from a New York taxi.''; Norman Bukofzer, bartender at the Westin Central Park South in New York ''There's nothing like a hotel bar. We serve very upscale business travelers. We have very intellectual drinkers. Our guests like old fashioneds and martinis. I always introduce the guests to each other at the bar because everybody in the world has something in common. They had a bad day, they missed their plane, the weather was bad, they hate their boss. And business: What's your business? What's my business? They find something to talk about. For a couple of days it was the Clinton affair, but everyone just figures, it's his business. I've been here 16 years, and businesspeople still love their gin martinis.''; Donald J. Eadie, Captain, Delta Shuttle Business travelers are type A. You can empty a shuttle in 3 1/2 minutes. Most are very experienced travelers. They play the middle-seat game. They'll turn and pretend to be talking to the seat next to them so that nobody fills the middle seat.; Paul Filippini,manager, Hudson News, LaGuardia Airport ''They buy The Times and The Wall Street Journal. If they buy one, then 50 percent of the time they buy the other. The men also buy pornographic magazines to take on the flight. Playboy, Penthouse and Club are the three most popular ones. Then they also buy Sudafed, dramamine, Pepto-Bismol, Tums and Rolaids.''; Roy Mingo, manager of special services, American Airlines; decides who gets first-class upgrades ''I've heard everything. People find out my name and know I can upgrade them. Six months ago, one of my reps on a flight to Miami had a passenger claim to be a good friend of mine. She asked if the passenger knew my wife and two sons, and the passenger said yes. But I've got daughters. Another passenger came right up to me and said, 'I'm a friend of Ray Mingo.' Didn't quite get my name right. I've heard, 'I have to ride first class because I suffer from claustrophobia.' And the worst: 'I have to ride first class because I have my period.' The PMS angle.''; R.D. Spear, chaplain at Atlanta airport; member of International Association of Civil Aviation Chaplains ''All the human needs and emotions can occur in an airport. Some treat it almost like a sort of confessional because they're just passing through and they won't meet me again. Maybe they're going to be fired or they have to deal with some supervisor or manager. One man stopped by and said he was going to interview for a new job. When he was on his way back he stopped by again and said the salary was $1,000 more than he expected. But don't tell anyone or I'll be swamped with prayer requests.''; Carol Grove, chiropractor with practice in Denver International Airport ''I should really thank the airlines, because airplane seats are not exactly conducive to back health. For female business travelers especially -- airline seats, like office furniture, are designed for men. But for men, too, they're constantly in those little seats, they're sleeping in a different hotel every night, on a different mattress -- and most people don't carry their cervical pillows with them when they travel. We've got people who reroute through Denver from Chicago just to have an appointment with us. I have one guy who sits in the massage chair with his laptop.''; Danny Showers, the Bobby Short of the West, lounge singer at the Westin Tabor Center in Denver ''You learn to read the business week like a good book. Generally, early in the week people are feeling their way around. They're still getting used to the climate, the food, the booze, the hotel. You tailor the music to their mood and play something soothing, like 'Misty.' Once they get over the middle of the week, they're winding up their business. That's when you play 'New York, New York' or 'Kansas City' -- upbeat music. I can tell by the way they walk through the lobby what kind of day they had. I can see if they've had a stressful day. You can tell if they're smiling that they just closed a business deal, and you know that pretty soon the Champagne corks are going to start popping. Sometimes you might see someone looking lonely. I'll invite them over to the piano and sometimes a crowd will gather around and they'll exchange business cards. I'm like the mortar between the bricks. The busiest times are happy hour -- 4:30 to 6:30. Then they'll come back after dinner and get their spreadsheets out right there in the bar.''

title: Floats Like a Butterfly, But Stings Like a Bee
description: I HAVE never been smitten by the king-sized Mercedes Benz S-Class sedans. They've seemed too imposing, too boxy and too slab-sided, with a heavy, almost armored look. They will be replaced this fall and I, for one, will welcome the change.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: TONTO'S REVENGE

title: High Heels to Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: SPENDING IT; It's How You Play the Game
description: COSULTANTS say almost all parents can obtain college financial aid -- if they know how.

title: Three Share Lead
description: Gene Sauers, who won two PGA Tour events in 14 years, tied a course record with a 65 yesterday to claim a share of the lead after three rounds of the Nike Greater Austin Open in Texas.

title: Sports of The Times; The Ride of a Lifetime for a Fan of Casey Martin's
description: HE's not Tiger Woods. He doesn't attract thousands. In his golf cart, Casey Martin is still more of a curio than an icon. His gallery here at the Greater Austin Open on the Nike Tour has never had more than 500 spectators at one time.

title: Clergy to Meet With Mubarak About Attacks On Christians
description: In a sign of growing concern among some religious leaders over political troubles facing Christian minorities abroad, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, said he and a group of other members of the New York clergy will meet this week with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to discuss reported attacks by terrorist groups against Egyptian Christians.

title: From Swagger to Statecraft: Hussein's Newfound Elan
description: From the onset of the latest gulf crisis, Iraq has had four goals: avoiding a military attack; casting doubt on the objectivity of Richard Butler, the Australian who heads the United Nations special commission charged with weapons inspections; drawing the United Nations into more active involvement, and insuring that the principle of easing economic sanctions on Iraq be accepted before President Saddam Hussein cooperates with inspections.

title: Eric Breindel, 42, Commentator and New York Post Columnist
description: Eric M. Breindel, the former editorial page editor for The New York Post and the conservative moderator of a weekly news show on public affairs on the Fox News Channel, died yesterday afternoon. He was 42.

title: A Path Fast Beaten
description: A restaurant where tables are hard to come by and the chicness barometer is high is exemplary of a new trend in Los Angeles: hot spots in smaller places off the beaten path.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, EDWARD G.
description: COLLINS-Edward G. On March 1, 1998. Retired F.D.N.Y. Beloved husband of the late Catherine (Nee Nolan). Loving father of Nancy, Philip and Cathy. Proud grandfather of Kristina Wiig.

title: Song of the Earth
description: MAHLER

title: Dialing for Dollars in Brazil's Telephone Privatization
description: BRAZIL is blessed with lush jungles, the samba and joie de vivre. The country's telephone service, however, is another matter. Getting a dial tone and holding a conversation free of static are minor miracles, and the waiting list for lines, now 13 million potential customers long, moves more slowly than an Amazonian swamp.

title: After Her Ph.D., the Scavenger's Life; Trying to Turn a Patchwork of Part-Time Jobs Into an Academic Career
description: Wendy Scribner spent 10 years writing her dissertation, typing it at night in a railroad flat on East Ninth Street while her two small boys were growing up in a windowless middle room. It was the pinched, obsessed life of an underground character in a novel by Dostoyevsky, one of her favorite authors.

title: Holders Left Holding the Bag
description: SOMETIMES fund shareholders get stuck, even when management does the right thing.

title: The Cheating Kind
description: A quarter of a mile down North Conduit Avenue from John F. Kennedy airfield in Jamaica, N.Y., the Holiday Inn is a gleaming, dreaming spire of utilitarianism, 12 stories tall, 582 beds full. For several years now, Anthony C., an executive at an aviation company, has been a regular at the hotel bar. It is, he surmises, ''a good place to have an affair.''

title: How to Bend and Fasten Pieces of Plastic
description: PLASTICS can be joined with many of the same fasteners that are used to join wood and metal together. Avoid overtightening fasteners -- apply torque only until resistance is felt -- and use wide washers under bolt or screw heads and nuts to distribute the pressure beyond the fastener.

title: Two Reminders of What Theater Is All About
description: TWO PLAYS, three playwrights, a total of seven actors -- and the New York theater seems suddenly bursting with possibilities.

title: Hakkinen Wins Formula One Opener
description: Mika Hakkinen and David Coulthard finished 1-2 in the Australian Grand Prix in Melbourne today as McLaren dominated in the season's first Formula One race.

title: Health Work Training With a Special Focus
description: MORE than 40 students -- half of them victors over mental illness, the rest without psychiatric histories -- are learning to be mental health workers in an unusual program at Housatonic Community-Technical College in Bridgeport.

title: Buck's Boy Wins Pan American
description: Buck's Boy, a 5-year-old gelding whose star has been rising as a racer on turf, led all the way yesterday as he buried the favored Flag Down and Awad to win the $250,000 Pan American Handicap and set a Gulfstream Park track record for a mile and a half.

title: A Role She Would Rather Not Have Played
description: SOMETIMES the 15 minutes of fame that you get are not the 15 minutes you want. Mary L. Anastasio has spent a lot longer than 15 minutes wondering why that is so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOLL, ROBERT HARGEST
description: SCHOLL-Robert Hargest. Of Philadelphia, PA., former Director of Public Relations for Standard Oil Company (NJ) died February 9, 1998 at the age of 97. He was born in Jersey City, NJ, graduated from Princeton University in 1922 and Columbia Law School in 1925. He joined the law firm of Kellogg Emery Innis-Brown in New York City. In 1935 he joined Esso Standard Oil Company as Associate General Counsel & later became Executive Vice-President and General Counsel of the company. He ultimately served the parent organization Standard Oil Company (NJ) as Director of Public Relations retiring in 1965. As a result of his lifelong interest in education he served on the Tenafly, NJ, Board of Education. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of Vermont Academy for many years. He served on the Board of Voorhees Technical Institute in New York City. He also taught at the Saltzburg Seminar and held every class office of the Princeton class of 1922 and its foundation. He was proud to have ''marched in the Princeton ''P-Rade'' of 1997 leading his 75th class reunion. In 1980 Bob and his wife Kitty moved to Cathedral Village in Philadelphia after 33 years in New Canaan, CT. He was the initial President of the Residence Association and served as a member of the village Board of Directors from which he retired in 1993. Mr. Scholl was pre-deceased in 1985 by his wife of 60 years Katherine Parker Scholl. He is survived by a brother Julian S. Scholl of Kendall, Hanover, NH and two sons and daughters-in-law, Robert P. and Carolyn Barton-Scholl of Westport, CT and Donald B. and Margaret Justice Scholl of West Chester, PA, eight grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to the Katherine P. and Robert H. Scholl Fund at Vermont Academy, Saxtons River, Vermont or the Katherine P. Scholl Library Fund at Goucher College, Baltimore, Maryland.

title: Warily, Baseball Prepares to Make Murdoch Owner of the Dodgers
description: On Feb. 5, on the Fox studio lot in Los Angeles, three baseball executives, including the sport's acting commissioner, Bud Selig, conducted one of the more critical interviews the game had ever undertaken. The topic was the proposed $320 million sale of the Dodgers, one of the game's fabled franchises, to the buyer seated across the lunch table: Rupert Murdoch.

title: Biker vs. Hiker on Greenbelt
description: There is a battle over the Greenbelt, the 4.5 square miles of glacially sculptured park land that runs from Todt Hill in the north to Richmond Creek in the south. Environmentalists, many of whom were active in consolidating this rugged spine of forests into a park in 1984, are fighting to ban a relatively young and recent wave of mountain bikers from the area's nature trails.

title: Correction
description: A table on Jan. 18 with an article about small-claims cases in United States Tax Court referred incorrectly to a court policy toward payments submitted while taxes are in dispute. The Internal Revenue Service reported to The Times in February that if a taxpayer's petition is accompanied by a check for the disputed taxes, the check will be cashed, not held until the case is resolved. This correction was delayed by a reporting lapse.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with the Streetscapes column misstated the date of a photograph of the former Theodore Roosevelt house that once stood at 689 Madison Avenue. It was 1901, not 1950. The picture was also credited incorrectly. It was from Corbis-Bettmann.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: The World: Living Dangerously; Indonesian Faceoff: Drawing Blood Without Bombs
description: AS the United States geared up last month for an intensive bombing campaign over Iraq, the Clinton Administration weighed its chances of crippling Saddam Hussein's chemical and biological war-making abilities against the certainty that the attack would kill hundreds or thousands of Iraqis. Years of sanctions had already brought suffering to Iraqi civilians; the prospect of killing many more, on camera no less, eroded the international enthusiasm for a military solution.

title: All-Brahms Salute in New Rochelle
description: THE 100th anniversary of the death of Brahms was last year, but that is not stopping faculty artists at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Mid-Westchester in New Rochelle from offering a Salute to Brahms today at 3 P.M. in the Bendheim Performing Arts Center.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Chairman Is Under Fire Over a Board Renomination
description: Recent criticism of Julian Bond, the newly elected board chairman of the N.A.A.C.P., for his renomination of a convicted embezzler to a crucial position in the organization suggests that the troubled civil rights group is still struggling with infighting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEDGWICK, FANNIE P.
description: SEDGWICK-Fannie P. Of 2500 Q Street, NW, Washington, D.C., died unexpectedly, Thursday, February 26, 1998 at her apartment. She was 66. During her life Ms. Sedgwick worked for a variety of public and not-for-profit organizations, including the Peace Corps, NYC Planning Commission, the NYC Human Resources Administration, the Institute for World Order and the Citizens Democracy Corps. Most recently she was director of executive search for the Citizens Democracy Corps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METCALF, THOMAS NEWELL, JR
description: METCALF-Thomas Newell, Jr, 75, of South Dartmouth, Massachusetts, died Thursday, March 5, 1998, in Beaufort Memorial Hospital, Beaufort, South Carolina. Mr. Metcalf was born June 10, 1922, in Brookline, Massachusetts to the late Thomas Newell Metcalf and Elizabeth Paine Metcalf. He was a 1940 graduate of Groton School. He graduated in 1944 from Harvard University and in 1950 Mr. Metcalf graduated from Harvard Law School. While at Harvard, he was President of the Spee Club. From 1951 until 1969 he was a Foreign Service Officer for the Department of State. He became an investment and financial advisor at Charles A. Collins, Inc in Boston, Massachusetts. He was a US Army veteran. Surviving are his wife, Patricia Thompson Metcalf, South Dartmouth, Massachusetts; Three sons; Thomas N. Metcalf III, Fairport, New York, Jonathan M. Metcalf, Boston, Massachusetts; Patrick R. Metcalf, Memphis, Tennessee; One brother; Robert T.P. Metcalf, Beverly Farms, Massachusetts; Two sisters; Joan Lee, Boston, Massachusetts; Diana Stainow, London, England; Six granchildren. Memorial Services will be at 2:00 PM Thursday, March 12 in the Church of the Redeemer, 379 Hammond Street, Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts. Those wishing may make Memorial contributions to The Thomas N. Metcalf, Jr. Fund c/o Brooks School, 1160 Great Pond Road, North Andover, Massachusetts 01845 or Beaufort Memorial Hospital, Post Office Box 1068, Beaufort, South Carolina 29901. Copeland Funeral Home of Beaufort, South Carolina is in charge of arrangements.

title: Rings by the Handful
description: These colorful rings could pass for prizes in a Cracker Jack box or trinkets in a gum-ball machine. Made in Italy of Lucite, they are being collected by fashionable women in Southern California, who sometimes wear more than one on the same finger.

title: All for Fun
description: In the entertaining ''Four Musketeers'' (1975), the British director Richard Lester somewhat modifies his unorthodox go at the venerable Dumas adventure of Old France. This handsomely produced feature is part two of his ''Three Musketeers,'' a bold slapstick that moved at a dizzying pace. There's less clowning around in the sequel, though the fine cast keeps hopping and the end result, briskly salted with sex, is fast and flavorsome. Tumbling in and out of royal intrigue and treachery are Oliver Reed (above), Richard Chamberlain, Michael York, Christopher Lee, Raquel Welch and Geraldine Chapin. Charlton Heston makes a wily Richelieu and Fay Dunnaway a worthy aide -- Wednesday at 8 A.M., Wed/ Early Thursday at 2:05 A.M. and Thursday at 3:30 P.M. on AMC Howard Thompson

title: The Newest Phone War
description: CONSUMERS looking for the cheapest long-distance telephone rates need only log onto the Internet, the newest arena of intense competition, where companies are offering special prices from 5 to 10 cents a minute.

title: At Rutgers Fraternities, an End to the Age of Big Wild Parties?
description: First came the rule about no kegs, reducing the free flow of beer at fraternity parties.

title: Erosion Project For Lighthouse Nears Completion
description: WHEN George Washington commissioned construction of Long Island's Montauk Point lighthouse in 1792, the early planners took into consideration the erosive impact of North Atlantic winds and water, setting the navigational structure 300 feet back from the bluff.

title: Featuring Itself
description: Time magazine's 75th anniversary party at Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday night brought together 1,200 of the century's news makers. It was hard to imagine a more extraordinary mix. The mammoth auditorium was turned into a six-tiered banquet hall; dancing was on the stage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRY, PHILIP J., JR.
description: CURRY-Philip J., Jr. Of Bristol, RI. Formerly of New Canaan, CT. On Friday, March 6, 1998. Survived by his wife Maureen Cohalan Curry; six sons, Philip of Easton, Conn., Michael of Barrington, R.I., Christopher of Orlando, FL., Sean of Boston, MA., Edward of New York City, and David of Charlottesville, VA; a daughter Margaret Curry of New Canaan, CT; and four grandchildren. Funeral mass Monday, March 9 at 10:30 AM, St. Aloysius Church, Cherry St, New Canaan. Interment, Calvary Cemetery, Queens. Visitation, Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main Street, New Canaan, Saturday 7-9 PM, and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Contributions may be made to the Canterbury School, New Milford, CT. 06776.

title: Hey, It's on the Company!
description: At Sotheby's, the international auction house, annual travel and entertainment expenses during the glitzy 1980's sometimes ran to $200,000 a year -- for a single senior employee. But in these days of downsized management and Scrooge-like budgeting, purse strings everywhere are a lot tighter. Filing an expense report can call for creative gamesmanship. The dollar bill handed to a baggage handler mysteriously becomes $2. The entertainment bill for $78, split down the middle with your lunch partner, goes on the expense report as yours alone. However petty the sum, the cost of travel and entertainment, or T and E, still adds up -- to more than $156 billion annually, according to American Express Travel-Related Services, with almost half going to hotels, meals, entertainment and ''other.'' With an attitude of ''they owe it to me,'' expense-report novelists will try to cover the costs of a hairdresser, golf game, kennel and traffic ticket. The I.R.S. has raised the ceiling for undocumented expenses to $75, but as one corporate travel manager puts it, ''we're still at $25 because the minute we make it higher, we'll get taxi fares for $74.65 -- with no receipts. Even now, when we see $24.97 for a fake taxi, they must think we're really stupid.''

title: Dusting Off The Dreams In the Attic
description: Despite the 122-degree summer heat, 10,000 people flocked to the Civic Center in downtown Phoenix last year bearing the contents of dusty attics and dank basements, recently inherited heirlooms or flea market finds.

title: What Do They Really Want Up There?
description: ''To travel hopefully is a better thing than to arrive,'' wrote Robert Louis Stevenson in his 1877 essay ''An Apology for Idlers.'' To get a sense of what today's business travelers hope for, we distributed a questionnaire to an informal sample of Delta Shuttle passengers traveling in the Boston-Washington-New-York corridor. A total of 213 people graciously took time to respond -- including 124 who admitted they should have been doing office work instead.

title: A Cart Nearly Hits Martin, Who Slips to a 72 and a Tie for 11th Place
description: After three bogeys and three birdies, Casey Martin said he was glad to shoot par 72 today in the Greater Austin Open on the Nike Tour. Especially after narrowly missing possible injury near the 18th green when the driver of a Golf Channel cart inadvertently took off in reverse as Martin stood nearby.

title: Expanding Japanese Menu in Pleasantville
description: BEYOND a small garden, the even smaller, narrow entrance to Hanada is easy to overlook. Inside, the lavender-hued dining room expands somewhat, leaving enough room for a sushi counter seating not more than five. But few lovers of sushi are shut out. An additional dining space on the second floor accommodates those who crowd into this restaurant, especially on weekends.

title: A Welfare Success Story
description: UNAFRAID OF THE DARK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ETHEL BLANCK
description: WEINSTEIN-Ethel Blanck. West Orange, NJ. Beloved wife of Sidney. Endearing mother of David, Daniel and Michael. Adoring grandmother of Zoe, Stevie, Simon, Hannah and Max. Devoted sister of Semon Blanck. Admiring mother-in-law of Laura Foner and Martha Matlaw, and loving friend. Services will be held on Sunday morning, March 8, at 9:30 AM, at Temple Sholom of West Essex, 760 Pompton Avenue, Cedar Grove, New Jersey. A private family burial will take place on March 10 at Sharon Memorial Park, Sharon, MA. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice or to the Sister Rose Thering Endowment Fund, Seton Hall University, South Orange, NJ.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article in the Long Island section today describes Gov. George E. Pataki's plan for a partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company and the obstacles it faces. On Thursday, after the section had gone to press, the Governor announced that the Internal Revenue Service had granted a tax exemption, a key element that will let the plan go forward.

title: Feasts for Ears
description: To the Editor: I had to laugh -- in recognition -- at the understated British weather descriptions in Susan Barron's ''A Feast for the Ears'' (Jan. 11).

title: The Coast Guard Gathers Its Forces in New London
description: AFTER the Coast Guard opens its Leadership Development Center in New London later this year, every officer and senior enlisted person in the service will have to go through Connecticut at some point.

title: Gainful Way To Splitsville
description: IT is the refrain of accountants, financial planners and tax-savvy lawyers: If couples would only treat divorce more like a business proposition than an emotional cataclysm, they might actually profit.

title: Q&A/David Butler; When Magic Takes the Form of Therapy
description: TO some of the Alzheimer patients he works with, he is Sammy Davis Jr., this man who entertains them with magic and music. Around the Greenburgh elementary schools, he is the man who has a talking slate and waves scarves and has various other things in his bag of tricks.

title: Richard F. Shepard, 75, Times Writer, Dies
description: Richard F. Shepard, a cigar-biting, storytelling, retired New York Times writer and former cultural news editor whose gentle wit and down-to-earth manner often masked an eclectic learning that embraced languages, literature, the theater from Yiddish to Broadway, and the neighborhoods of New York, died Friday night at his home in Fresh Meadows, Queens. He was 75 years old.

title: Feerick Was Fair
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Exploring a Time of Life When Choices Are No Longer Made by Chance
description: AMY LIPPMAN is just 34, but she grows nostalgic when talking about her 20's, when she was a writer fresh out of Harvard, living in New York, and a cab ride was the gateway to adventure. The purest reflection of those happy times, recalled Ms. Lippman, the co-creator of ''Party of Five,'' was a late night dinner at which she impulsively ordered lamb chops at a restaurant without even checking the price, a symbol that freedom and responsibility could taste pretty good. By contrast, Christopher Keyser, 37, her writing partner, was insistent that he did not miss those difficult times, when his career and personal life were in flux.

title: Ideas & Trends: Self-Starters; Learning to Go Against Japan's Corporate Grain
description: A JAPANESE executive was describing his company's efforts to spin off a smaller unit when he suddenly leaned forward and asked that his name not be used.

title: 4:43 A.M.: Do You Know Where Your Broker Is?
description: LATE in the day on Feb. 18, the Dell Computer Corporation announced its quarterly earnings. They were up 52 percent over the period a year earlier, and Gerry Krayenhagen very much liked what he heard.

title: Hiding Extra Pounds
description: To the Editor:

title: In Three Revivals, the Goose Stepping Is Louder
description: WHEN ''The Sound of Music'' first opened on Broadway in 1959, the Nazi officers onstage in Rodgers and Hammerstein's pre-World War II Austria did not wear swastikas.

title: For the American Century, A Party Just as Grandiose
description: IT promised to be the 1990's version of Truman Capote's Black and White Ball -- a party so exclusive in its selective inclusivity that it becomes an instant social index -- an A-list of an era. And Time magazine's lavish 75th anniversary gala didn't disappoint. Forget the last so-called party of the decade -- the Versace event at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This was the bash of the pre-millennium.

title: Sports of The Times; As Good as He Was, Doby Might Have Been Better
description: WHEN Larry Doby was 22 years old, he was called up to the big leagues, to the Cleveland Indians, in the summer of 1947. For most young men, this might have been make-believe, a lad's most precious dream come true. Doby, an all-round athlete from Paterson, N.J., approached it that way.

title: For Marine Mammals, a New Home Is a Matter of Money
description: Move 50 feet east and lose $3 million. It sounds like a wrong turn in the Monopoly game, but for Robert Schoelkopf, director of the Marine Mammal Stranding Center in Brigantine, it's politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERBERG, JOSEPH O.
description: SILVERBERG-Joseph O. March 2, 1998. In his 86th year. Pre-deceased by his beloved wife Ann. Survived by his devoted daughter Ellen. A fiercely independent man who fought the good fight. He was a hero to all who knew him. He will be sorely missed. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Q & A
description: Abatement Linked to Rent Rules

title: Editorial Observer; Why Colleges Shower Their Students With A's
description: The economist Milton Friedman taught that superior products flourished and shabby ones died out when consumers voted emphatically with their dollars. But the truth of the marketplace is that shabby products can do just fine if they sustain the veneer of quality while slipping downhill, as has much of higher education. Faced with demanding consumers and stiff competition, colleges have simply issued more and more A's, stoking grade inflation and devaluing degrees.

title: Who Cares What Owners Think?
description: Who owns American companies?

title: March 1-7; 'Capeman' Fails to Fly
description: Paul Simon, author of some of the most enduring pop songs of the last quarter century, has found Broadway a harder nut to crack. His first musical, ''The Capeman,'' based on a 30-year-old tabloid murder case that stuck in the songwriter's mind, closes March 28 after fewer than 125 performances and at a cost of at least $11 million. Even in an industry that has seen some colossal collapses, that's a staggering figure.

title: In the New South, an Heir to Motown
description: THREE FIDGETY young men from Greenwood, Miss., are slouched in brown leather chairs in the sleek reception area at LaFace Records, waiting for their moment to hand a demo tape to one of the company's talent scouts. A nearby television is tuned to BET, and Boyz II Men, the kings of 1990's rhythm-and-blues, are crooning their hit ''Song for Mama,'' in harmonies as silken as a cashmere sweater.

title: Substance and Spirit Shine in 'Mass Appeal'
description: ''MASS APPEAL'' is too much with us, in professional, in stock and in community theaters. Even the movies have had their colorless way with Bill C. Davis's two-character play, which moved from Off Broadway to Broadway in 1981. One does not expect to find Fleetwood Stage in New Rochelle, N.Y., whose mission is mightier than a ride on a war horse, with such an overcooked item on its bill of fare. And yet. And yet.

title: Ramon Ramos Continues to Rebound
description: Ramon Ramos looks people in the eyes when he meets them, shakes their hands strongly and warmly, and with an engaging smile assures them that he is doing ''great'' more than eight years after a devastating car crash almost killed him. He offers a thumbs up to punctuate his comments.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: POLITE LIES

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Lexus LS 400 and Mercedes-Benz E430; Altered Chrysalis, The Same Cocoon
description: SCHEDULE dental appointments for the children. Take the cat to the vet. Prepare taxes.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Martha on Martha

title: A Bigger NATO Is Good for Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Fish Fillets Take Well to Searing, Then Baking in a Hot Oven
description: ONE of the simplest and most foolproof ways of cooking fish fillets is to bake them. In restaurants chefs often sear the fish first on the top of the stove in a nonstick pan to give it a little color, and then finish it in a hot oven. Grouper, a firm-fleshed fish (it is almost like chicken) is wonderful prepared this way, roasted with capers and thyme leaves. This method also works well with sea bass, which is more delicate, and I like to serve the fillets on individual plates on a mound of slivered artichokes, which have finished cooking alongside it.

title: Crime
description: Ian Rutledge, the Scotland Yard detective who emerged from World War I with a shattered mind and a haunted soul in Charles Todd's stunning first novel, ''A Test of Wills,'' returns in WINGS OF FIRE (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $23.95) to face another fierce assault on his belief in human goodness. Dispatched to Cornwall to investigate the suicide of Olivia Marlowe and the sudden deaths of two of her stepbrothers, Inspector Rutledge is reluctant to find evidence that would damage Olivia's literary reputation as ''O. A. Manning,'' whose poetry gave him comfort during his four years of misery in the trenches of France. The sharp sense of loss he feels in the country (where dead sons and missing limbs lend a ghostly presence to the landscape) also makes him hesitant. But the more he learns of the family's unsettling history, the more troubled he becomes by the factual discrepancies and moral ambiguities of the case.

title: Eat Well. Drink Lots. Expense It.
description: When a restaurateur daydreams, what does he imagine? ''I used to tease Wolf that if I dressed up as a baby carrot, he'd pay more attention to me,'' says Barbara Lazaroff, who is the wife and business partner of Wolfgang Puck. ''I would joke with him in bed: 'What are you thinking of now? A new chicken recipe?''' As alluring as a new chicken recipe may be, a chef-proprietor is likelier to be imagining something even more delectable: the customer who eats fast, drinks well and brandishes a corporate credit card. Every restaurateur's dreamboat is the business traveler.

title: Museum Plans Capital Drive To Offset Decline in Aid
description: TO offset a steep decline in Federal and state support, the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College here has sponsored house and garden tours, auctioned off plates made by artists and held elegant fund-raising soirees like last November's masked ball honoring Edward Albee and Kitty Carlisle Hart. Now the museum is gearing up to conduct the first capital campaign in its nearly 24-year history.

title: One Last Hurrah for the Bulls? Reinsdorf Isn't Quite Saying
description: On the desk in the office of Jerry Reinsdorf, Reinsdorf is quick to remind, is this framed axiom, ''Nothing is written in stone.''

title: The Reluctant Hero
description: He has never sought the spotlight, yet somehow it has always seemed to find him. On the January night that Chris Drury became the leading goal scorer in the history of Boston University hockey, when he returned to center ice and leaned forward for the face-off, the referee, Jim Fitzgerald, remained upright and held the puck to allow a tribute to continue. Reluctantly, Drury lifted a stick to acknowledge the noise. Softly, he tapped the blade of his stick against the referee's leg to say thanks.

title: Portugal, Here and There
description: Throughout this century, families have said goodbye to the fishing ports and villages of Portugal and come to the United States to start new lives.

title: 'Moral Turpitude'? Just What Is It?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Authentic Spanish Dining Provides a Bounty
description: SPANISH restaurants create dishes that are hearty and refined, soothing and spicy, yet despite the variety and appeal of this cuisine, it has never been especially popular on Long Island.

title: Which Conductors Will End Up Where?
description: THE INTERNATIONAL conducting business, already a seller's market, becomes an even bigger one with the news that Kurt Masur, now 70, will apparently be departing from the New York Philharmonic in the year 2002. Some Philharmonic musicians are puzzled why this issue is being raised so far in advance, but it makes perfect sense to me.

title: Love Bug: The Sequel -- Still Friends With the Beetle
description: The Volkswagen Beetle is back, and Los Angeles -- where cars are as common as air kisses -- is swept up in Beetlemania. At the Volkswagen dealership in Santa Monica, hundreds of interested buyers have put their names on a waiting list for 1998 Beetles, expected to arrive any day, said Jeff La Plant, the general manager.

title: Russia's Tax Police Press Media Message: Pay Up
description: When medieval Russian villagers savagely beat Prince Igor for trying to make them pay taxes, bad things happen: His redoubtable wife, Princess Olga, rides up to their wooden fortress with a posse of soldiers, then sets a flock of sparrows on fire and releases them to burn down the village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, ALICE E.
description: JOSEPH-Alice E. Of New York and Florida on March 2nd after a brief illness at the age of 85. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Devoted Mother of Rochelle Finfer, Michael Joseph and Lynne Kahn. Loving Grandmother of Stephen Finfer, Robert Finfer, Lainee Steinberg, Leslie Gilinson, Kori Karpus. Great-Grandmother of Sidney and Chelsea Finfer. Graveside services were held at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey. Donations may be made to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation.

title: Ladies Sing the Blues
description: BLUES LEGACIES

title: The Frequent-Flier Economy
description: Jeff Pollak doesn't spend much time in the air, but that hasn't stopped him from accumulating an impressive pile of frequent-flier miles. Pollak, 28, has earned about 600,000 miles in the last six years, 80 percent of them without leaving the ground. ''A lot of people collect coins and stamps,'' says Pollak, who lives in Washington. ''I collect frequent-flier miles.'' An equal opportunity deal-hunter, he now has 180,000 miles to his credit with British Airways, 60,000 with American, 25,000 with United and 10,000 with Alaska, though he has never flown on a revenue ticket with any of those airlines.

title: On Language; Broaching the Telltale Brooch
description: Let us now broach the sensitive subject of Monica's brooch.

title: Even a Penalty Shot Can't Help the Isles
description: Not even the gift of a penalty shot helped the Islanders keep pace with the Colorado Avalanche tonight as they lost, 4-2, on four power-play goals at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Ideas & Trends; Once Upon a Time, There Was a Big Bang Theory
description: THE idea once seemed so elegant and simple: The universe began with a bang. Wherever astronomers pointed their telescopes, the distant galaxies were shooting away like stellar shrapnel. And permeating the space in between was a uniform glow of radiation -- surely the afterflash of an ancient explosion.

title: Sprightly 77-Year-Old Is Charged in Armed Robbery
description: The Teaneck police say James Chester didn't let his age keep him from doing the kinds of things usually associated with someone much younger: things like pulling a gun on an elderly couple and robbing them of cash and credit cards.

title: Living It Up In the East 80's
description: BUTTERFIELD 81* [rating: one star]

title: Streetscapes/70 Pine Street; An Art Deco Tower With Double-Deck Elevators
description: THE American International Group is completing a multiyear restoration of the elevators in its 1932 skyscraper, at 70 Pine Street in downtown Manhattan. The cabs are dazzling, in the Art Deco style of the spectacular marble lobby. It seems unlikely anyone will notice, but the most unusual element is missing. Although they are now run conventionally, the originals were the first double-deck elevators, conceived as office developers squeezed the last square feet of space from the sky.

title: Near Philadelphia's Chinatown, 51 New Homes
description: RED-paper scraps from firecrackers heralding the Chinese New Year had barely been swept up from the streets last month when the first of 51 families moved into a new town-house complex that expands Chinatown beyond its traditional seven blocks.

title: Commercial Property; Are Big Retailers Waking Up to a Chelsea Morning?
description: WHEN art galleries started moving from SoHo to Chelsea a few years ago the owners said they were driven by two factors: the influx of retailers in their old neighborhood who could pay higher rents and the availability of old industrial buildings and garages that could easily be converted into galleries.

title: Habitats/128 West 82d Street; Designer Finds There's No Place Like the Office
description: IRWIN FELD was looking for an office. What he found was a home away from home on the Upper West Side.

title: Bradley Is Steady In Wind At Doral
description: Sooner or later, today's windy conditions at the Doral-Ryder Open gave everyone fits. Shooting a 62, as Jim Furyk did on Friday, was out of the question. In fact, anything under par was excellent.

title: Getting the Bugs Out
description: THE LIFE OF INSECTS

title: Ms. Lasnier de Lavalette, Mr. Loo
description: Valerie Lasnier de Lavalette, the daughter of Florence Lasnier de Lavalette of New York and Bernard Lasnier de Lavalette of Paris, was married yesterday to David Jon Loo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eddie Loo of Yuma, Ariz. The Rev. Don Flickinger performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Inheriting Miles: Not Clear Skies
description: THE inheritance of frequent flier miles is not something most lawyers have experience with. A search of literature on trusts and estates at a major New York law firm disclosed nothing. Nor did anyone respond to an inquiry at a lawyers' round-table lunch where emerging issues were discussed.

title: Feminists' Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Revitalizing Jersey City's Depressed Journal Square
description: A $7.5 MILLION effort now under way to spruce up the Journal Square area of Jersey City is among the latest signs that, after years of decline, the business center of the state's second largest city is slowly rebounding.

title: DIARY
description: MARKETS

title: Not Alpha or Omega: Risk, Small Caps and Beta
description: FIRST it was the market drop in October. Next came the Asian financial crisis. Then, last week, Intel delivered its gloomy revenue predictions. The market never lacks for traumas, and when they come it is small-capitalization stocks that often have the wildest fluctuations.

title: Marjorie Adams, Noah Franzblau
description: Marjorie Ann Adams and Noah Franzblau, both lawyers, were married yesterday at the Hudson River Club in New York by Associate Justice Angela M. Mazzarelli of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in New York.

title: POSTINGS: Renovating the Rectory of St. Mark's in-the-Bowery; Home for a Rector, and More
description: St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery in the East Village has in recent decades been on the cutting edge of social, artistic and political change -- and, paradoxically, preservation as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROST, SYLVIA SLIPYAN
description: FROST-Sylvia Slipyan. Age 84, a resident of Albuquerque since 1992, passed away Friday, March 6, 1998. Born in Brooklyn, NY, April 10, 1913, where she spent her early years. She was preceded in death by her first husband Dr. Alvin Slipyan, who practiced medicine in Queens, NY, and by her son Dr. Philip Slipyan, who practiced medicine in Cherry Hill, NJ. She is survived by her husband Dr. David Frost, whose Public Health work brought him to Washington, DC, and New York. She is also survived by her daughter Pam Slipyan and husband, Villy Newton; two grandsons, Andrew Slipyan of Cherry Hill, NJ, and Scott Martin of Penn Valley, PA, and cousin Shirley Metz of NY. Mrs. Frost was an associate of PBS KNME TV, a member of the President's Council of The New School of Social Research, Congregation Albert and Hadassah. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Albert, 3800 Louisiana NE, Albuquerque, NM 87110, on Tuesday, March 10, 1998, at 2:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Congregation Albert.

title: Getting a Leg Up on Spring
description: THE SETTING -- The Festive End of Winter, a private party held Thursday night in the candlelit disco-soaked environs of Wax, the SoHo nightspot at 113 Mercer Street. Some guests seemed to think the party was being given by Vogue magazine, by Krug champagne, by Skyy vodka or by the designer Tocca, which provided free dish, drink, and perfume.

title: Word for Word / Jane's Fighting Germs; The Grim Do's and Deadly Don'ts Of Handling Chemical Attacks
description: MILITARY buffs know all about ''Jane's Fighting Ships'' and ''Jane's All the World's Aircraft.'' Now how about ''Jane's Fighting Germs''?

title: Tobacco Industry Steps Up Flow of Campaign Money
description: In a bid to win support for sweeping tobacco legislation, the major cigarette producers have showered lawmakers with record campaign contributions, even as some old allies are now swearing off tobacco money.

title: Testing the Tasteless
description: Max Frankel states succinctly and correctly that the Lewinsky affair is newsworthy because the conduct is ''reckless and disrespectful of our highest office.''

title: No to Sales Tax Plea
description: State lawmakers have told Westchester that the state will not reimburse the county for the $20 million it expects to lose if it abolishes the sales tax on clothing costing less than $100 next year.

title: TELEVISION; It's the Sitcom Cartoons That Have Character
description: IF YOU'VE seen ''Ally McBeal,'' you may have caught these moments: Ally says something embarrassing, then imagines her foot in her mouth. A guy breaks up with Ally, and she sees herself fall into a Dumpster. Ally, with obvious reluctance, agrees to meet a client for drinks, then thinks, ''I'd rather have a root canal.''

title: Miriam Solomon And John Clarke
description: Dr. Miriam Solomon, an associate professor of philosophy at Temple University, and Dr. John Rodney Clarke, a professor of surgery at Allegheny University of the Health Sciences, both in Philadelphia, are to be married this afternoon in Thompson Hall at the College of Physicians of Philadelphia. Rabbi Leonard Gordon is to officiate, and Rabbi Norman Solomon, the bride's father, is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ISADORE H.
description: COHEN-Isadore H. Died on February 27, at age 90. He is survived by his sons James of Rhinebeck, NY, John of Shelburne Falls, MA, and David of Chelsea, MI; by his daughters-in-law Linda Putnam and Magdalene Lampert, his grandchildren Lisa and Sarah Cohen, Amy, Rachel and Eli Putnam, his great-grandsons Abraham Tapia and Jacob Putnam Hill, and his longtime friend and advisor, Kalman D. Rothman. Isadore Cohen's life mixed great ability, hard work, and professional accomplishment with family difficulties. He was born on the lower East Side of Manhattan to poor Russian immigrant parents, and moved with them to Connecticut when he was a young child, where his father owned and operated a series of small dairy farms. He attended the Norwich Free Academy where he was a gifted student, and won several scholarships to Yale. He graduated Yale College in 1929 Phi Beta Kappa and summa cum laude, and the Yale Law School in 1932, second in his class and a member of the Yale Law Review. Mr. Cohen took a position with Austrian and Lance in New York City after graduation, and worked for more than ten years on bank liquidations and other matters related to the Great Depression. In the course of that decade he published more than a dozen scholarly articles in the Columbia, Yale and other law reviews, while carrying on a full-time legal practice. He married the late Eleanor Kastner in 1932. They moved to Valley Cottage in Rockland County for a year in 1938, and then to West Nyack in 1939. He continued to practice law in New York City for several decades, moving to private practice in Rockland County in the late 60's. His marriage and family life grew increasingly troubled, and Isadore and Eleanor Cohen separated permanently in 1962, which began a long estrangement from his family. But in recent years Mr. Cohen was reconciled with his sons and their families, and greatly enjoyed their company and love. He moved to Grandview-on-Hudson in 1962, and lived there until a few weeks before his death.

title: Killer's Friend Says He Was Shocked, but Not Surprised, by Rampage
description: Perhaps the best measure of the distance Matthew Beck had descended over the last year -- as anger and depression consumed him -- can be found in the simple reflexive reaction of his closest friend to the news of Friday morning's killings.

title: Music Radio Replayed
description: To the Editor:

title: Ryan to Leave CBS For Fox and NBC
description: Tim Ryan, whose contract is expiring after 20 years at CBS, is joining Fox and NBC Sports. His final CBS assignment will come this week when he calls first-round games at the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament.

title: SOAPBOX: Models for Life; A Hispanic Educator Who Never Gives Up . . .
description: ''Working for Human Rights: Women Light the Way'' was the subject of an essay contest for New Jersey students as part of the International Women's Day Celebration, a project of the Y.W.C.A. of the U.S.A. The top two winners, Jennifer Orlando and Rachel Van Raan, are being honored today at a forum at Town Hall in Manhattan. Here are excerpts from their essays.

title: March 1-7; No Introductions Were Necessary
description: A pyschiatrist might consider prescribing anti-psychotics if someone confessed to a dream like this: You were in a huge room, and the Rev. Jerry Falwell was chasing Muhammed Ali as David Copperfield and Claudia Schiffer arrived a few steps behind Sophia Loren. You saw Sharon Stone, Arthur Schlesinger Jr., Louis Farrakhan, Norman Mailer, Mikhail Gorbachev, Raquel Welch, Tom Cruise and Betty Friedan. Everyone wore black, including Dr. Jack Kevorkian. President Clinton arrived late. Everyone ate caviar. The band played ''I Feel Like a Sex Machine.''

title: Neo-Noir's a Fashion That Fits Only a Few
description: IN HOLLYWOOD NOWADAYS, the color of hip is noir. Coined by French movie critics who attached it to the word film to describe a crime genre that gurgled up like a glistening black sludge into the faucet of 1940's American culture, it has never been more in vogue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, MARTHA (HIRSCH)
description: GORDON-Martha (Hirsch), 79. 1940 Hunter graduate. Ran Queens Paperbound Book Shop in 1960s and '70s. For 57 years, adored wife of Louis. Mother of Joseph and Marc. Grandmother of Amy, James and David. Sister of Anne Schulman. Beloved aunt, greataunt and friend. Services today, 4 PM, Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy., Fresh Meadows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEINEMAN, RUTH (KRESS)
description: HEINEMAN-Ruth (Kress). Age 75, passed away peacefully in her sleep, at home, after a long illness borne with courage and dignity. She is survived by her loving husband Bernard (Jack) Heineman, Jr, her devoted chiildren Deb and Ralph, Matt and Katie, Steve and Kathy and by her six adoring grandchildren. The family will receive friends at The Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue on Sunday March 8 from 6-9 PM, Monday March 9 from 6-9 PM. The funeral service will be Tuesday, March 10 at 4 PM at The First Presbyterian Church, 12th St and 5th Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The College of Wooster, Wooster, OH, The Public Education Association, 39 W. 32nd Street, or the charity of your choice.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A slam-bang musical of period Americana, a universal fable, a dark Victorian melodrama and a prison story hoist the week's film fare on television.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DECONSTRUCTION ACRES

title: Sorry, It's a Private Party
description: AT 2 A.M. last Wednesday, Leonardo DiCaprio approached the navy velvet rope and gesturing behind him, asked: ''Is it O.K.? They're with me.''

title: Unprepared for Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Board Still in Harmony With Democrat in Lead
description: TWO months after the Democrats took control of the Westchester County Board of Legislators, members of the Board say the honeymoon is not over -- they are all getting along rather well. And perhaps, just perhaps, the Board chairman, George Latimer, said, some Legislators (but not himself) should be getting more money.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SNOW

title: SPENDING IT; Guess Who Didn't Save For College
description: THE REV. PATRICK FIORE knew that sending his two children to college would be expensive. A senior pastor at the Christian Life Center, an Assemblies of God church in West Milford, N.J., Mr. Fiore had read articles that suggested socking away $200 or more a month into a college fund.

title: Food; The Spicing On the Cake
description: When freshly grated, nutmeg smells like a little old lady's house -- piney and camphorlike with undertones of French lavender and wilting roses. But like a matriarch who connects past and present by dint of her longevity, nutmeg connects one flavor to another while adding the warmth of history.

title: 'The Web Made Me Do It'
description: In '''The Web Made Me Do It''' (Feb. 15), Jack Shafer implies that raw reportage via the Internet is somehow more truthful than information processed by editors bent on protecting ''corporate America.'' He attributes this purification of Internet data to ''disintermediation,'' suggesting, for instance, that Matt Drudge's reports are somehow credible because they are ''straightforward'' and that Drudge has ''something original to say.''

title: Taking a Seat in TriBeCa
description: ABOUT four years ago, Patrick Marchand, a specialist in 1940's and 50's French furniture, started looking for a place to open a store. Downtown appealed.

title: Vendorville
description: In late January, Chris Burch hopped a commuter plane from Dallas to Bentonville, Ark. -- or, more precisely, to Fayetteville, since Bentonville doesn't have a movie theater, much less an airport. Although the flight covers only 269 miles, it costs nearly $500, and Burch complains that he can fly to London for less. But Wal-Mart isn't in London; it's in Bentonville, which explains why Burch has visited about 200 times. And to do business with Wal-Mart, first you have to get there. Just when Burch's flight should have been touching down, the pilot pulled into a sudden climb. It had been so foggy that Burch couldn't see the runway. Neither, apparently, could the pilot. ''After the third miss,'' Burch says the flight attendant told him, ''we go back to Dallas.'' Fortunately, the plane landed safely, averting not only a crash but also another unpleasant possibility -- that Burch would miss his morning appointment.

title: March 1-7; Fraud and the Ballot
description: Struggling to recover from budget deficits and political scandals, Miami sank into deeper turmoil when it suddenly found itself without a Mayor. A state judge threw out the results of last November's mayoral election because of ballot fraud and ordered a new vote in early May.

title: 'Teachers Don't Salute'
description: AT 48, Michael Castania is a licensed pilot and has what in military parlance is called command presence. It's just that he sometimes forgets to salute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, FANNIE
description: HABER-Fannie. The entire ORT world mourns the passing of Fannie Haber of Ann Arbor, MI., wife of the late Dr. William Haber, a past president of both American ORT and World ORT. She would have been 99 years old later this month. She was, in her own quiet way, most helpful to ORT as she visited most of the ORT schools and other operations on all five continents. In addition, she was the organizer of the UJA of Ann Arbor, a founder of Delta Phi Epsilon Sorority at the University of Michigan, an active member of League of Women Voters. We extend our condolences to her sons, Professor Ralph Haber and Allen. American ORT Paul Borman, President Brian J. Strum, Executive Vice-President Paul I. Bernick, Executive Director Emeritus Women's American ORT Ruth S. Taffel. President Pepi Dunay, First Vice President Rosina K. Abramson, Esq., Executive Director World ORT Union Justice Richard Goldstone, President Dr. Ellen Isler, Director General

title: The New Business Class
description: In Hong Kong recently, I spent a layover with one of my closest friends from school in England. The guest room in his modest, functional apartment was furnished almost entirely with suitcases. On the desk sat a Hewlett-Packard Desk Jet printer, a box of Chinese Standard Version 3.2 diskettes and some personalized stationery (for someone I'd never heard of) from the Oberoi hotel, Bombay. Against the wall were a travel iron, a worldwide power adapter and a timetable for Dragonair Systems, a Hong Kong airline. In the bathroom I found a bottle of Thai Air hair treatment, a Delta Airlines business-class toilet kit and a British Airways towelette. Some toothpaste from an Imperial Hotel, a bottle of conditioner from the Westin Tai Ping Yang, Shanghai, and some Princess Cruises French formula shampoo. Otherwise, nothing.

title: The Wartburg Alters Its Health Care
description: CHANGE, change, change. Those three words account for the longevity of the Wartburg, a Mount Vernon fixture for 132 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTTI, LEWIS C.
description: BUTTI-Lewis C. Of Douglaston on March 6, 1998. Retired school administrator and a veteran of World War II. Mr. Butti was a principal and Director of Instruction in District 28 in Forest Hills and he ismentioned in ''Who's Who in the East''. He leaves his wife Mary, two children, Lawrence and Claire Myers, two grandsons, David Myers and Christopher Butti, and a sister Josephine Cornacchio. Visitation at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Sunday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass on Monday at 9:45 A.M., St. Anastasia's R.C. Church, Douglaston. Interment following at Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to the charity of one's choice.

Husband of Paola Maranesi Mele. Father of Paola De Vita, Michael, Peter A. Jr., and Christopher Mele, M.D. Brother of Frank M. Mele. Grandfather of Frank P. and Cristina Anne De Vita. Funeral Mass at Mt. Carmel RC Church, Tenafly, NJ, on Wednesday at 11 AM. Visiting at Riewerts Memorial Home, 187 South Washington Ave, Bergenfield, NJ, on Monday and Tuesday, 2-4 and 6:30-9:30 PM.

title: Hudson Park Plan Turns Friends Into Foes
description: In part, yesterday's gathering on the Hudson River was a carefully staged media event. There were people pretending to fish, a kayaker bouncing in the chilly Hudson and a soulful folk singer providing earnest inspiration. But it was also the sort of wild and woolly political event typical of Manhattan's West Side, as supporters and opponents of the Hudson River Park screamed at one another and waved awesomely conflicting signs.

title: Irabu Accepts (Some) Blame in Dispute
description: His manager, coaches and teammates all say Hideki Irabu is more relaxed this spring. Reporters from New York who covered him last year agree he is more open in his interviews.

title: Sheriff Provokes Furor On Abortion in Florida
description: Sheriff John J. McDougall of Lee County is not one to mince words. A year ago, when Florida set free hundreds of prisoners under an early-release program, Sheriff McDougall warned a national television audience that the state was too dangerous to visit.
