description: Telefonica de Espana Planning New U.S. Alliance

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, FANNIE
description: BERKOWITZ-Fannie. Age 89. March 8, 1998, at North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, NY. Wife of the late Joseph Berkowitz. Beloved mother of Rita and Moe Pasternack and Alan and Carol Berkowitz. Adored grandmother of Barry and Andrew Berkowitz, Gail and Joel Leder, Jan and Fern Pasternack, Barry and Amelia Pasternack, and nine great-grandchildren. Her family was her life. Services today, 1 PM, at Sinai Chapel, Fresh Meadows, NY.

description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

description: The hulking remains of burned houses, most with gaping holes in the walls from huge explosions, stood empty and silent this afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, SIDNEY P.
description: HARRIS-Sidney P. Entered into rest March 7. Of Waltham, MA, formerly of Bayside, NY. Beloved husband of Muriel (Touster). Loving father of Suzanne Harris of Bedford, MA. Adored grandfather of Jeffrey Campagna. An inspiring and beloved teacher. For information, Stanetsky Chapels, Brookline, MA, 1-800-842-4280.

title: Real Estate Trusts Plan $2 Billion Merger
description: Bay Apartment Communities Inc., a real estate investment trust based in San Jose, Calif., announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Avalon Properties Inc. in a stock exchange worth about $2 billion. The new company will be called Avalon Bay Communities and will be one of the largest developers of luxury apartment communities in the United States.

title: Energizing The Future Of Black Theater
description: In an intensive marathon of talks and panel discussions on Saturday at Dartmouth College here, a wide cross section of theater artists and business and foundation executives confronted a crisis in black theater and searched for new ways to carry that theater past the millennium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANFIELD, HOPE BROWN
description: CANFIELD-Hope Brown. Died on March 7, 1998. Beloved wife of Franklin O. Canfield and mother of Hope Canfield Tetrault. Memorial service in Southampton, NY in June.

description: Graham Chapman died in 1989, but he was nonetheless present on Saturday at the reunion of his former colleagues, collectively known as the comedy troupe Monty Python's Flying Circus. At an afternoon rehearsal for an evening tribute to the group at the Wheeler Opera House here, Chapman was the center of attention.

title: Rivalry Sure to Exit When Jordan Does
description: So Michael Jordan never found an equal the way Magic Johnson and Larry Bird found one in each other. So what. Patrick Ewing's tired old bones usually made do. His flawed team of laborers was the most antagonistic thing to happen to Chicago in the 1990's.

title: For Bradley, Six Feet Easier Than Six Inches
description: The outcome of the Doral-Ryder Open was not settled until the final putt on the final hole, a six-footer that Michael Bradley needed for victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEINEMAN, RUTH (KRESS)
description: HEINEMAN-Ruth (Kress). Age 75, passed away peacefully in her sleep, at home, after a long illness borne with courage and dignity. She is survived by her loving husband Bernard (Jack) Heineman, Jr, her devoted chiildren Deb and Ralph, Matt and Katie, Steve and Kathy and by her six adoring grandchildren. The family will receive friends at The Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue on Sunday March 8 from 6-9 PM, Monday March 9 from 6-9 PM. The funeral service will be Tuesday, March 10 at 4 PM at The First Presbyterian Church, 12th St and 5th Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The College of Wooster, Wooster, OH, The Public Education Association, 39 W. 32nd Street, or the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOWENSTEIN, BOB
description: LOWENSTEIN-Bob. March 9, 1995 The impulse that never fades away to pick up the phone and call, to share our ups and downs and disarray, to hear your voice when we fall. Just 3 years since you've been away-the emptiness of it all, the joy you brought to everyday, and now this endless pall. Love, Dad and Hank

title: Conductor Explores His Heritage
description: The Russian conductor Yuri Temirkanov came to the New York Philharmonic over the weekend with a program he could lay claim to, particularly Shostakovich's Symphony No. 10. This vast, anguished and enthralling work was given its premiere in 1953 by the orchestra Mr. Temirkanov now directs, the St. Petersburg (then the Leningrad) Philharmonic, under the direction of Mr. Temirkanov's predecessor, and the composer's colleague, Yevgeny Mravinsky. So this symphony is part of Mr. Temirkanov's musical heritage, and the performance he led on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall was authoritative and involving.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREINDEL, ERIC MARC
description: BREINDEL-Eric Marc. Loving son of Joseph and Sonia. Dearest brother of Monique Breindel and Jonathan Oberman. Most tender and caring uncle of Hannah, Naomi and Sarah Rose. Service Monday, 11 AM, at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th St and Madison Ave.

title: Officer Says He Didn't See His Colleagues Beat Prisoner
description: A police officer who tipped off his superiors to alleged mistreatment of a suspect at a Queens precinct station house said yesterday that he did not witness the suspect, Walter Avila, being beaten and kicked by fellow officers, as Mr. Avila has claimed. Instead, Officer Thomas Bennett said he called investigators to report only that Mr. Avila had been needlessly stripped after a struggle with officers.

description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; Giving away money, even quite a bit of money, to support inventors turns out to be not so easy.
description: HOW hard can it be to give away $100,000? Very hard, as it turns out, if you are trying to give it to an inventor.

title: Cry of Muslim Women for Equal Rights Is Rising
description: The day Rashida was called to family court, she found herself in a scene that nearly stopped her heart. There, before the judge, was her husband of 10 years, father of her two children, the man she thought so enlightened when they first met at the university.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Collectors Flocking To Dutch Fine Art Fair
description: Just as auction house experts are moaning about the dwindling supply of great art and objects to sell this spring, the European Fine Art Fair comes along with some $3 billion worth of the best of nearly every collecting category: paintings and drawings, decorative arts and sculpture, textiles, antiquities, books and manuscripts, jewelry and 20th-century art.

title: Let the Charter Be
description: Charter revision, which involves changing the basic rules under which local government does business, is one of the most important activities a city can undertake. It is also one of the most difficult and least glamorous. For both reasons, New York City tackles Charter revision very seldom. It is a tribute to the surreal atmosphere in City Hall lately that the City Council and the Mayor are creating competing Charter revision commissions. That is two too many.

title: For Mentally Ill, Freedom Often Leads to Jail; Revolving Door at Rikers
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILLECK, SIDNEY B. JR.
description: SILLECK-Sidney B. Jr. Of Scarsdale, NY, on March 6, 1998, at the age of 83. Loving husband of Katherine Wallace. Also survived by his four children: Katherine, Bayley, and Thomas of NYC and Gordon of Irvington, NY; three grandchildren, Sean, Siri, and Elizabeth; and three great-grandchildren. He was a graduate of Deerfield Academy (1932) and Princeton University (1936) and served as a warrant officer in the Merchant Marine during World War II. He was a well known advertising and marketing executive who specialized in innovative cereal product premiums and sponsorship of early television shows such as Ed Sullivan's ''Toast of the Town,'' ''Howdy Doody,'' and ''Rin Tin Tin.'' A lifelong rail fan, he led a successful campaign to save several NYC trolleys from demolition. Sid will be deeply missed by all his friends and family. A memorial service will be held at the Church of St. James the Less, Scarsdale, NY, on Thursday, March 12, at 3 PM. Contributions in his name may be made to the church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YORIO, WILLIAM M.
description: YORIO-William M. On March 7, 1998, of Ridge, formerly of Manhasset. Beloved husband of Lucille. Loving father of William T. and the late Anthony M. Also survived by his daughter-in-law Jacqueline and three grandchildren Dana, Regina and Paul. Brother of Michael, Micheline, Anne, Nancy and Yolanda. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Monday and Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10:45 AM, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: St. John's Seniors Finally Get Their Wish: A Chance at the Tournament
description: The St. John's players and coaches, gathered in Manhattan yesterday, sat rapt as the first announcements of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament pairings were broadcast. There was silent anticipation as the East Regional was unveiled, followed by the West. No trip to Sacramento. Good. A few cheers went up after the bracket for Boise, Idaho, was completed and the Red Storm was not mentioned.

title: Abroad at Home; After Kenneth Starr
description: Kenneth Starr's ever-widening investigation of President Clinton, however it may end, has many Americans worried about his prosecutorial methods. So the polls show. But the fundamental problem is not Mr. Starr. It is the Independent Counsel Act.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 1 about Carl Gorman, a Navajo code talker in World War II, listed his survivors incompletely. They also included a son from a previous marriage, Donald Mitchell of Chinle, Ariz.; a daughter, Karletta Anderson of Shonto, Ariz., and 12 great-grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, HELEN
description: HERTZ-Helen. Age 91, beloved mother of Leona Duffy and Martin J. Hertz; mother-in-law of Judith M. Hertz. Grandmother of Marian Sue Keltz, Ricki Martin Kline and Herbert Ray. Greatgrandmother of Daniel Keltz, David Keltz, Liana Ray, Melina Kline and Harry Kline. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York, Tuesday, March 10, at 9:45 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Central Synagogue, New York City.

title: 10 Are Hurt As Gunman Sprays Club With Bullets
description: Ten people were shot in a crowded Brooklyn nightclub early yesterday morning after a man who had been ejected from the club returned with a semiautomatic handgun and opened fire, the police said.

description: In a shocking move last night, Connecticut, the nation's third-ranked team, was denied a No. 1 seeding in the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

description: A European Union

title: A Poet's Words Echo, Tempering Evil in the Old West
description: I've gone back to Jim Jarmusch's l996 film ''Dead Man'' again and again over the last weeks. The reason isn't unrelated to the false drama that since January has enveloped a possibly real scandal: the explosion produced by the confluence of the Paula Corbin Jones and Monica Lewinsky matters. Mr. Jarmusch has his connection to all this. A previous movie, his 1989 ''Mystery Train,'' featured one Steve Jones, now Paula Corbin's husband, as the ghost of Elvis Presley.

title: On the Road to Destruction, With an Edge
description: What flows like molasses and is marinated in wit? Answer: Paul Taylor's choreography, as seen on a perfect program presented on Friday night at City Center.

title: Of Languages and Math
description: To the Editor:

title: The Other Battle Over Browsers; Barnes & Noble and Other On-Line Booksellers Are Poised to Challenge Amazon.com
description: A focus group of book buyers was asked a pointed question last week about the leading Internet booksellers, which are locked in a battle for dominance, market share, strategic alliances and customer loyalty.

title: What Is Inside Still Counts the Most, but the Packaging Has Its Merits, Too
description: At the 1996 annual Pugwash, a planning retreat for senior editors of The Washington Post, a special team first disclosed its early ideas for redesigning the newspaper.

title: Essay; My Monica Moment
description: I ran into Monica Lewinsky in a bar the other night but more about that later.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about restaurant ratings in this year's Michelin red guide to France referred incorrectly to the guide's first award of a total of six stars to a single chef. The distinction went to Eugenie Brazier, a chef with two restaurants in the Lyons area that held three stars each from 1933 to 1938; Alain Ducasse, a chef with two restaurants that were awarded three stars each in the 1998 guide, is not the first. The article also misstated the ownership of the restaurant Hotel de France in Auch. Andre Daguin sold it to Roland Garreau last fall.

title: Coalition Assails the City's Decision to Withhold Money for Brooklyn Housing
description: A plan to build hundreds of homes for low-income families on abandoned land in Brooklyn has stalled because city officials have decided to withhold $5 million from the project, community leaders in charge of the construction said yesterday.

title: Weekly Schedule of Offerings Of Equity and Convertible Debt
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Recounting Angst and Joy In a Melodic Midlife Crisis
description: Midway through Loudon Wainwright 3d's show on Friday night at the Bottom Line, he hit an apex of self-awareness. Mr. Wainwright, the singer and songwriter, was performing ''Livin' Alone,'' a diary of bachelor life after yet another botched relationship. Amusing details did not lessen the tension built up by his frantic guitar strumming and wiry vocals.

title: At Work and at Play, Time's Editor Seeks to Keep Magazine Vigorous at 75
description: For Walter Isaacson, it was perhaps the ultimate dinner party.

title: A New Lesson for Ostriches: Good Defense Will Prevail
description: For intermediate players who own a computer (with Windows and three megabytes available on the hard disk) and want to improve their bridge skills, there is a clear choice: Mike Lawrence's ''Private Bridge Lessons, Volume I.'' It is a sequel to ''Counting at Bridge,'' both produced in collaboration with Fred Gitelman, a bridge software designer, and more are to come. Either disk is available from the author at 131 Alvarado Road, Berkeley, Calif. 94705, for $37.95, including mailing.

title: Refusing to Say the M-Word
description: William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, was rhetorically bobbing and weaving in the face of the combative questioning of the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Orrin G. Hatch, at last Tuesday's committee hearings. The steely Republican from Utah kept trying to pin the software entrepreneur down, repeatedly, on just one word.

title: Take the Slow Train
description: To the Editor:

title: Hundreds Lose Food Stamps in Error Under U.S. Welfare Change
description: Since sweeping Federal welfare changes went into effect in New York more than six months ago, hundreds of the city's poorest immigrants have seen their food stamps cut off or sharply reduced because they were mistakenly ruled ineligible, according to welfare officials, immigrants and advocates for the poor.

title: Roommates Who Resist Growing Up
description: You're not seeing double. This week there are two new sitcoms about a group of old friends in their 20's, two men and a woman, who live in the same house and are self-consciously Peter Panish about growing up. Several more with similar themes will appear in the next weeks. (It seems married people share real estate and have trouble growing up, too.) Before you can say, ''Goodbye, Seinfeld,'' you are witnessing the copycat boomlet that defines this year's midseason replacement shows.

title: Clinton Partner In Whitewater Dies in Prison
description: James B. McDougal, whose accounts of business dealings with Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton ultimately led to the sprawling Whitewater investigations that continue to haunt the Clintons, died today in Fort Worth, where he was imprisoned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAPPER, FRANCES (NEE RITTER)
description: KLAPPER-Frances (nee Ritter). On March 6, 1998. Widow of Jerome. Loving mother of Carol. Dear sister of the late Teresa Halpern, Helen Glassberg, Benjamin, Henry and Edward Ritter. Service Monday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Heirs Try to Keep A Black Press Heritage Alive
description: When John Sengstacke, the longtime chairman of Sengstacke Enterprises, died last spring, he left behind three things. First, a chain of black-owned newspapers, most notably The Chicago Defender, which is closely linked to 20th-century black history. Second, a family trust, the legal owner of the estate's assets, including the newspapers. And third, six grandchildren, the beneficiaries of the trust.

title: Immigrants Aren't the Problem. We Are.
description: In the next few weeks, the half million members of the Sierra Club will vote to set the club's policy on the issue of immigration. Since the Sierra Club does not exactly control Congress, the final count won't much matter, but the debate, which has already been spirited, represents an invaluable chance to raise the issue of how many people this country can and should contain.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: A Pedestrian in Queens Is Hurt by Falling Bricks
description: A 37-year-old woman was struck by bricks plummeting from the facade of a three-story apartment building in Jamaica, Queens, last night. The woman, whom the police did not identify, was in stable condition at Mary Immaculate Hospital last night.

title: Finalists Are Set for P.S.A.L.
description: The Public Schools Athletic League finalists were determined yesterday as 12 teams battled at St. John's University for the right to play for titles in three divisions at Madison Square Garden on Sunday.

title: U.S. Awakes to Epidemic of Sexual Diseases
description: The burly man from the city Health Department who showed up at Gina G.'s apartment in early February brought unpleasant news: A blood test had revealed that Gina, a soft-spoken, bookish woman of 38, had been swept up in a raging local epidemic of a sometimes forgotten disease, syphilis.

title: Russian Prostitution
description: To the Editor:

title: A Suicide Tape on TV Inflames the Issue in Spain
description: Ramon Sampedro's struggle to be allowed to end his life after an accident 29 years ago left him paralyzed from the neck down made him a cause celebre in the campaign to legalize assisted suicide. For years, he fought unsuccessfully in the courts to be helped to die and even wrote a book about it, using his teeth to hold the pen.

title: Despite Controversy, Wadleigh in P.S.A.L. Final
description: Amid all the off-the-court controversy that swirled around the Wadleigh Tigers leading up to yesterday's game, Coach Steve Romagnoli relied on the maxim, ''That which does not kill us, makes us stronger.' ''

title: Once Again, Nets Squander a Lead
description: In the locker room after today's game, the Nets chose their words carefully. ''Effort'' and ''blame'' kept slipping out, but for today, at least, they all agreed that they needed a better effort and they would not blame their teammates.

title: Sydney Gruson, 81, Correspondent, Editor and Executive for The New York Times, Dies
description: Sydney Gruson, a former hotel bellboy who became a foreign correspondent, the foreign editor of The New York Times and then a corporate executive of The Times Company, died yesterday evening at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Backlash Growing as Indians Make a Stand for Sovereignty
description: Come south along the Little Bighorn River to a rise in the Montana hills, where the ghosts of Crazy Horse and George Armstrong Custer have taken up a permanent perch in American mythology. No blood has been shed here in well over a century, but the Little Bighorn is a battleground again.

title: Educating the Deaf
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Names Electronic Media Editor
description: Richard J. Meislin has been appointed editor in chief of The New York Times Electronic Media Company. The appointment, which takes effect today, was announced by Martin A. Nisenholtz, president of the media company.

title: Seedings Are Sown, And 64 Dreams Born
description: The names of the selected basketball teams pop up on the television screen during an anxious Sunday evening in March, like so many lottery winners. The teams learn who they will oppose, where they will travel and what it is like to be one of the chosen 64 in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. And so, the madness that is this month begins again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSIN, SHIRLEY
description: BOSIN-Shirley. 75, of Miami, FL, formerly of NYC, passed away Saturday, March 7, 1998. Beloved wife of George, loving mother of Charles (Laurie) Bosin of Raleigh, NC, Adele (Dr. Kenneth) Hertz of Miami, cherished grandmother of Michael, Nicole, Joshua and Zachary, dear sister of Solomon Levine of Miami. Loving aunt and greataunt and loving sister-in law. Mrs. Bosin was former Sisterhood President Town and Village Cons. Synagogue NYC, member of JCC, JWV Auxillary and leaving many cherished friends and family. Services were held on Sunday, March 8, 1998.

title: An Omitted Passage In Article on Dodger Sale
description: A front-page article yesterday about Rupert Murdoch's purchase of the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team omitted several paragraphs in some copies. Following is the omitted passage, which should have appeared at the beginning of the continuation page:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UMANS, RUTH R.
description: UMANS-Ruth R. March 7, 1998, of Great Neck, LI. Beloved sister of Helen Taub, George S. Goldberg and Joseph H. Goldberg. Services private.

title: Sports of The Times; Jordan Reprises His Oldies At Garden
description: FAR more than a basketball game, this had the feel of a rock concert, a musical salute. Michael Jordan against the Knicks at Madison Square Garden, live, the occasion heightened by uncertainty, the specter of retirement, the possibility that he would never return.

title: Trial Starting in Brooklyn Is First Under State's New Death Penalty
description: Nearly three years after New York State reinstated capital punishment, jury selection is to begin this week in the first trial in which a murder defendant faces a possible death sentence under the new law.

title: Father of Lottery Killer Says Son 'Not a Monster'
description: After learning that his son had overdosed on pills, Donald Beck rushed over to the apartment, dragged him out of bed and to an emergency room and had his stomach pumped, a move that may well have saved the young man's life.

title: Clinton to Reappoint Levitt as S.E.C. Chief
description: President Clinton said over the weekend that he intended to nominate Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to another term as the top United States securities regulator.

title: For Graf in Comeback, a Test of Will
description: Once a champion, always a champion? That's what Steffi Graf, back in business after eight awkward months in limbo following a radical surgical makeover of her left knee, aims to discover.

title: Seeded Players All Advance
description: All six seeded players who saw action in the second round of the Evert Cup in Indian Wells, Calif., advanced to the next round yesterday.

title: Ethnic Chinese Try to Keep Out of Harm's Way
description: JAKARTA  Amid the puddles and crumbling walls of Jakarta's morning market is the city's Chinatown, a labyrinth of shops, warehouses and narrow alleys navigated by stooped old women.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KHAZIN, ALEXANDER
description: KHAZIN-Alexander. Unexpectedly passed away on March 6, 1998. Mr. Khazin was born on February 26, 1947, in St. Petersburg, Russia, but spent the last 20 years of his life in New York City where he was a successful entrepreneur working in international trade. Alexander will always be remember as a high-spirited, life-loving man by his friends, and a wonderful and caring father by his daughter, Masha. Viewing Thursday 1011:15 AM, at FranK E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral service will commence at 11:30 AM. Interment to follow Southampton Cemetery, Southampton, NY.

title: A Choice for Puerto Rico
description: In a historic move, the House narrowly passed a bill last week to give 3.8 million Puerto Ricans the right to vote on whether the island should retain its current commonwealth status, seek statehood or become independent. The United States-Puerto Rico Political Status Act, sponsored by Representative Don Young of Alaska, requires that a vote be held on the three options by the end of this year. If either statehood or independence receives a majority, the President and Congress would be asked to develop a transition plan, and give final approval to a status change within 10 years. If none of the options receive a majority vote, the current status would be unchanged and another referendum would be held within 10 years.

title: A Year Before the Millennium Bug, There's the Euro Problem
description: Amid the rush to reprogram the world's computers so that they will function after Jan. 1, 2000, a little-known computer problem looms as large with a deadline that is even earlier.

title: Yankees Proceed With Few Openings
description: Jim Converse, a pitcher who is 26 years old and coming back from rotator cuff surgery, drove here from California with his wife and three very young children last month for a shot at making the Yankees. He is hoping he will fly back to the West Coast next month as part of the team.

title: Mets' New Reliever Is Toughest on Lefties
description: For the casual Mets fan, the team's January trade for a 35-year-old left-handed pitcher named Dennis Cook did not generate much excitement.

title: Yes, Close Associates of Clinton Say, He Privately Vents Anger on Inquiry
description: It is generally in his most private mo ments with his wife, his personal lawyers, a couple of his closest aides and friends -- that President Clinton allows himself to display the anger he harbors toward the prosecutors and investigators digging into his relationship with a former White House intern, associates of Mr. Clinton said.

title: Calm and Exoticism In the Hovering Clouds
description: Brian Eno didn't compose ''Music for Airports'' for concert performance. It is a recording-studio assemblage, made from tape loops and synthesizer tones and never written as a conventional score. It was also the first of what Mr. Eno designated as ''ambient'' works, background music that would repay attention but could also be ignored, akin to soundtracks and elevator music. The album ''Ambient 1: Music for Airports'' (EG/Caroline), released in 1978, named and spawned a genre of half-heard, amorphous music.

title: Taking In the Sites; Desktop Coaches for the Final Four
description: It is normally considered bad form for people to strip to the waist, paint their bodies in bright colors, wag their index fingers and scream ''We're No. 1'' in triple-digit decibels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREEN, CATHERINE P.
description: BREEN-Catherine P. ''Kitty,'' 78. Of Chicago, IL, on March 2, 1998, in Chicago. Devoted sister of Fr. John F. and Walter E. Breen. Family will receive friends Monday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Quackenbush Funeral Home, 117 Maple Avenue, Monroe, NY. Funeral Mass on Tuesday at 10:30 AM, at St. Francis Chapel at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Interment will be in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne.

title: Albright Tours Europe to Whip Up Resolve to Punish Serbia
description: The foreign ministers of the United States, France and Germany agreed today on the need for ''firm and clear measures'' to stop the violence in the Serbian province of Kosovo before it spreads to other nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANYAEGBUNAM, AKOLISA M.
description: ANYAEGBUNAM - Akolisa M., M.D. On February 27, 1998. Professor and Chairman of Obstetrics and Gynecology. Fellow in the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Fellow in the Maternal Fetal Medicine. Beloved father of Ndidi and Ike. Reposing at Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Ave., Bronx, NY on Tuesday, March 10, 1998 from 4-9 PM. Interment Onitsha, Nigeria.

title: The Money Groupie
description: Among the high rollers and influence peddlers involved in the dark side of Democratic Party fund-raising during the mid-1990's, Johnny Chung is a fairly small fry. But Mr. Chung, who has now agreed to plead guilty to violating the Federal campaign finance law, is an example of a very big problem. A struggling entrepreneur with no personal fortune, Mr. Chung headed no organization, belonged to no political group. Yet he donated nearly $400,000 to the Democratic Party and made about 50 trips to the White House before people began to ask serious questions about where he was getting the money and what his motives were in giving it.

title: The Unpaid Bill That's Crippling the U.N.
description: I will be traveling to Washington on Wednesday to meet with President Clinton and members of his Administration, to discuss not only Iraq but also the debilitating problem of the $1.3 billion in back dues that the United States owes to the United Nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, GOLDIE
description: BRENNER-Goldie. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of the mother of Edith Everett, a cherished member of our extended family. Edith, together with her husband Henry, a valued member of our Board of Directors and its Executive Committee, are Chai Founders and have established a major scholarship endowment enabling Boys Town to fulfill its mission of turning young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures. True giants of philanthropy, the Everetts' generous support of a myriad of Jewish, civic and humanitarian causes enhances the quality of life for countless individuals. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Josh S. Weston, Chairman Rabbi Ronald L. Gray Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITTEN, CORA
description: WITTEN-Cora. We mourn the loss of our beloved Cora. She was always ''up'' and found humor despite life's adversities. Condolences to her family. The Sandpiper at Westhampton Beach, Inc. Judy Rosenblum, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: GOLDSTEIN-Sylvia. Of Miami Beach, FL, and New York City, passed away March 6, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Abraham, loving mother of Jonathan (Jennifer), and a devoted sister of Ralph (Sandra) Holod and Phyllis Holod. Graveside services Monday, March 9, at 1:30 PM, at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: The Market Rules, but Can It Edit a Book?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A map on Friday with an article about a former slave-trading house in Senegal misspelled the name of the island and the bay where the house is situated. It is Goree, not Gore.

title: Health Panel at Standstill On Enforcing Bill of Rights
description: A Presidential commission that recommended a bill of rights for patients is now deadlocked on the important question of how to enforce those rights.

title: Iona's Excitement Tempered By Its Opponent: Syracuse
description: It was the moment Iona Coach Tim Welsh had waited for his entire career. It was also a moment he had dreaded.

title: Talks Assess U.S. Relations With Turkey
description: Turks and their American friends maintained at a recent conference here that the alliance between their countries is more vital than ever, but will not develop fully until Turkey improves its human rights record and presents its case more forcefully to Congress.

title: Tar Heels Hit Peak That Duke Can't Meet
description: The character of North Carolina's veteran Tar Heels has been consistent this season. They play to the level of their competition. The higher the level, the better they play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPARD, RICHARD F.
description: SHEPARD-Richard F. The Sholom Aleichem Memorial Foundation deeply mourns the passing of our member and devoted family friend. His sweetness and gentleness will be sorely missed. Sidney J. Gluck and Bel Kaufman

title: Another Setback in Quest To Marry TV and Phones
description: The much-heralded but still-unfulfilled convergence of television and telephone took another step back toward the drawing board last week as Stephen A. Weiswasser, a former senior executive at Capital Cities/ ABC, announced that he would step down from his job running Americast, a television venture of four big local phone companies and the Walt Disney Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, RUTH
description: SMITH-Ruth. On March 7, leaving family members Leigh, Dale, Sue and others.

title: A Strange Little World With a Barrel That Flirts
description: Linda Austin's ''Pig,'' presented by the Danspace Project on Thursday night at St. Mark's Church, has only a minor porcine presence. Much of the dancing looks as if Ms. Austin had selected moves and gestures from contact improvisation, a distinctively intimate form of physical improvisation, and then isolated, slowed and slightly formalized them. What is important, however, is the strange little world in which ''Pig'' unfolds.

title: What's the Rush on NATO?
description: As more members of the Senate realize a vote on NATO expansion is barreling toward them, they are understandably asking for more time to consider a decision that is likely to be among the most important they make as lawmakers. For all the talk about using NATO to consolidate democracy and unity in Europe, the issue before the Senate is the enlargement of a military alliance and the commitment that carries to use American soldiers and weapons, including nuclear arms, to defend new members in Eastern Europe.

title: Bishop John Allin, Who Led Episcopalians, Is Dead at 77
description: Bishop John Maury Allin, the 23d presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church, who was a pivotal supporter of Mississippi's effort to rebuild burned black churches in the 1960's but was an ardent critic of the ordination of women, died on Friday in Jackson, Miss. He was 77 and lived in Jackson and Sewanee, Tenn..

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: BUDGET SURPLUS SOWS DISSENSION ON CAPITOL HILL
description: Congress will begin work in earnest this week on its tax and spending plans for next year, energized by the prospect of big budget surpluses but deeply unsettled about politically charged issues like taxes and Social Security.

title: Market Place; After taking some recent lumps, Texas Instruments may be poised for an upturn.
description: THOMAS J. ENGIBOUS, the chief executive of Texas Instruments, wasted no time Thursday in putting an upbeat chip industry forecast delivered by his economist, Vladi Catto, in the right perspective.

title: Under Water, to Under Construction
description: To the five Huderle children of 22 Polk Street, where ancient elm trees seemed to soar to heaven, the old two-story bungalow was always home, even after they were grown and gone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, WITTEN, CORA
description: TURNER-WITTEN-Cora. March 7. Beloved wife of the late Erwin Turner and the late Lawrence Witten. Loving mother of Cissy and Gene Armour and the late Alan and Harry Turner. Grandmother of Lori Roth and Jill McAlpine. Graveside services at Temple Israel's Mount Hope, Ardsley, NY, leaves Riverside Chapel, NYC, Monday, March 9, 12:30 PM. Friends may contact Cissy at 212427-5584.

title: Bill Would Require Cabbies To Take Special Driving Test
description: Eleven days after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani asked the state to create a special driving test for taxi drivers, the chairman of the City Council Transportation Committee, Noach Dear, proposed yesterday that such a test be administered by the city instead.

title: Key Executives Shuffle at 3 Agencies
description: Three agencies made changes in top management late last week.

title: Suharto Faults I.M.F. on Family Principles
description: President Suharto said on Sunday that the open economic system being promoted by the International Monetary Fund may not be right for Indonesia, where the economy is based on ''family principles,'' an Indonesian political leader said.

title: MCI and Worldcom Set For Telefonica Alliance
description: Telefonica de Espana S.A. just can't seem to get comfortable.

title: City's Budget Surplus
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 New Yorkers Make Top 10 in Science Competition
description: Parker Rouse Conrad, 17, has spent nearly a year studying the brain cells of a creature called aplysia, known more commonly as the sea snail. Yesterday, his research won him third place and a $20,000 scholarship in the 57th annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search, the nation's top contest for aspiring scientists.

title: The bottom-line publisher of The Los Angeles Times faces the hard-line skeptics.
description: THE ideal of journalism met the emerging reality at the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism recently. Mark H. Willes, the publisher of The Los Angeles Times and chairman of the Times Mirror Company, had been invited to defend his bottom-line-oriented newsroom policies before a skeptical crowd of journalism students and former Times Mirror employees, and peace did not break out between the two points of view.

title: Martin Finishes 8 Strokes Back
description: Casey Martin finished in a tie for 16th place at the Nike Greater Austin Open today in his first tournament since a Federal court ruled that he could use a golf cart in PGA competition.

title: Ray Nitschke, 61, Linebacker During Packers' Glory Years
description: Ray Nitschke, one of the most fearsome middle linebackers in the history of professional football and an anchor of the championship Green Bay Packer teams of the 1960's, died yesterday in Venice, Fla. He was 61.

title: For Mentally Ill, Freedom Often Leads to Jail; A Costly Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools' Report-Card Grade: Incomplete
description: For parents who have longed for a way to measure the quality of their children's schools, the school-by-school reports released by the state last week for the second year seem like a treasure trove of data.

title: Alarmed by Meningitis, Rhode Island Tries Mass Inoculation
description: Happily licking a lollipop, Gabrielle Gentile, 8, said her injection was not all that bad. ''They told me at school that it wouldn't hurt,'' she said.

title: It's not just numbers or advanced science, it's also knowing how to think.
description: WHEN the depressing results of the Third International Mathematics and Science Study were announced two weeks ago, technology became the great alibi of the United States. American 12th graders may score near the bottom of the industrialized world in their knowledge of advanced mathematics and science. The elite of United States students may score nowhere near the elite of France or Russia or Switzerland.

title: News on the Web by Time and Saatchi offers a way to change on-line banners instantly.
description: AN innovative effort to make banner ads more closely resemble the constantly changing content of the World Wide Web sites on which they appear -- and thereby increase their appeal -- is scheduled to be introduced today by cyberspace divisions of two media and agency giants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTLER, ADOLPHE GEORGE
description: RUTLER-Adolphe George. Born 1915. Husband of Dorothy Elaine Albertson, father of the Rev. George Rutler and Dorothy Elaine Rapp, died March 6, 1998. Reposing at McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville, Monday evening 7-9 PM. Requiem mass Tuesday, 10 AM, St. Agnes Church, 143 East 43 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers: gifts to the St. Agnes Memorial Fund.

title: Ashford Journal; Ah, Britain! The Light at the End of the Tunnel
description: Parisians who shrug in Gallic disdain at the parochial contentedness of life in England could have Ashford in mind. By day, the streets of this tidy market town are filled with shoppers in their patterned flat caps going about their chores at a measured gait. By night the place falls into shuttered stillness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESSELMAN, LEO W.
description: HESSELMAN-Leo W. Retired partner Haskins & Sells, predecessor firm of Deloitte & Touche LLP, died at home February 13, 1998 after a long illness. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy, nee Kittell, five daughters Barbara Dodson, Judith Lawson, Linda Hesselman, Nicolys D'Agostino and Jean Bohr, and 12 grandchildren. Burial service will be at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 253 Glen Ave, Sea Cliff, NY, March 21, 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Lehigh University, Bethlehem, PA 18015.

title: Budding Artists for City Opera Spring
description: The New York City Opera has some unusual works in store for the second half of its current season, including the New York premiere of Tobias Picker's ''Emmeline'' and Britten's first opera, ''Paul Bunyan.''

title: Jordan Provides Look, and Result, of Old
description: Michael Jordan stood on the floor at Madison Square Garden in his original Air Jordan sneakers, a vintage look straight from the days early in his career when he used to soar in search of the ultimate dunk.

title: An Iraqi Is Home, at Last, From the War of Long Ago
description: Majida al-Zubaida vividly recalls the morning in 1982 when her husband kissed her goodbye and left for the front to fight in Iraq's bitter war against Iran.

title: Rangers Look Down For Help
description: After yielding three power-play goals to the Devils and allowing Krzysztof Oliwa to score the decisive goal on Saturday, the last thing the Rangers need in tonight's return game with the Devils at Madison Square Garden is another slap in the face.

title: Worker Dies in Accident At Brooklyn Navy Yard
description: A worker using a blow torch at the Brooklyn Navy Yard was killed yesterday morning after he accidentally cut a hole in a fuel tank of the ship he was working on, the police said. The worker, whom the police did not identify, was overcome by diesel fumes from the tank and pronounced dead at the scene.

title: 4 Marketers Switch Advertising Agencies
description: Four big marketers have changed advertising agencies.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a front-page article yesterday about Rupert Murdoch's purchase of the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team omitted several paragraphs in some copies. The passage is reprinted today on page C6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARCHER, ROBERT SAMUEL JR.
description: ARCHER-Robert Samuel Jr. On March 3, 1998 after a long illness. Adoring father of Sarah Katherine Archer. Devoted son of Virginia Catharine of Del Ray Beach, FL., and the late Robert Samuel Archer. Loving brother of Elizabeth Archer-Carter, and devoted uncle of Michelle and Michael Carter of Belmont, MA. A memorial service will be held Wed. March 11, 1998 10 a.m.,at Rye Presbyterian Church, 882 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY.

title: Metro Matters; April Budget? Hey, You Never Know
description: MAYBE they were caught off guard. Or maybe it was just the giddy prospect of spring in Albany. But last week, with less than a month to go before the deadline, virtually all the key players in the Capitol made the same extraordinary admission about this year's state budget: there is absolutely no excuse for not passing it on time.

title: Caring for Poor, and for Profit; Bronx Hospital Shakes Up the Medical Establishment
description: St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx was founded in 1866 as the Home for the Incurables, a place where people with cataclysmic strokes or crippling heart disease went to die. By the early 1980's, this anachronism of a hospital might have expired itself, but for its ambitious and enigmatic young president, Dr. Ronald Gade.

title: A New Palm Pilot By 3Com Today
description: The 3Com Corporation plans to introduce an enhanced version of its Palm Pilot hand-held electronic organizer today as it prepares for Microsoft's entry into the market for such devices later this year.

title: Waldo Howland, 89, Builder of Yachts
description: Waldo Howland, a yacht builder and preservationist, died Feb. 26 at his home in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 89.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGULAS, DAVID
description: MORGULAS-David. 94, of Scarsdale, NY, died Friday at the Forrestal Nursing Center in Princeton, NJ. Born in Paterson, NJ, he was a lifelong area resident. He had graduated from New York University with a law degree in 1922. He helped found the M. Carl Levine, Morgulas, and Foreman law firm in 1927. He was active in the firm until his retirement in 1989. He was a former member of the bar association. He is survived by his wife Carolyn Morgulas, a son and daughter-in-law Jerrold and Susan Morgulas of Scarsdale, NY, a daughter and son-in-law Karen and Ronald Schotland of Skillman, NJ, six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Graveside services were held Sunday. Memorial contributions may be made to the National Council of Jewish Women, Morgulas Scholarship Fund, c/o Ann Levy, 29 Howard Ave, Eastchester, NY 10709. Riverside Memorial Chapels, Ewing Twp.

title: Notes From the Hearing Room
description: Last week, the Microsoft Corporations's founder and chief executive, William H. Gates, went to Congress to testify about his company's business practices.

title: Mawae Is Eager to Work, No Matter Who Is at Quarterback for the Jets
description: Kevin Mawae, the Jets' newest starter and most expensive off-season acquisition, will miss the opening of the team's conditioning program today. After all, even a $5 million signing bonus does not mean he has to skip his son's first birthday on Wednesday.

title: The Market Rules, but Can It Edit a Book?
description: To the Editor:

title: Housing Worker Raped While Working in Bronx
description: An employee of the New York City Housing Authority was raped while on duty early yesterday after she was followed into the boiler room of a Bronx housing project, the police said.

title: Briefcase of Rare Coins Is Snatched on Street
description: It sounded, at first, like a dime-a-dozen robbery: A man getting out of a cab in front of his Manhattan apartment at 2:30 A.M. drops a briefcase and a suitcase on the sidewalk. Two men then materialize out of nowhere to grab the cases.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   EDDINS, BENJAMIN
description: EDDINS-Benjamin Dearly loved, sorely missed. Mom and Dad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIMEL, DONALD
description: SHIMEL-Donald. Beloved husband of Helaine. Devoted father of Lauren and Michael. Dear brother of Janet Shimel. Cherished son of the late Benjamin and Rosalie Shimel. President of J-S Sales Company of Mount Vernon and President of Billiard Congress of America. Service today, 10 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St, Mount Vernon, NY. Memorials may be made to Coallition for the Homeless and Midnight Run, 97 Main St, Dobbs Ferry, NY.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You see the word 'liberte' on every public building in France, but I wasn't free

title: Slave Ship to Be Rebuilt as a School
description: In June 1839, the only successful rebellion in the 400-year history of the slave trade took place off Cuba aboard the Spanish schooner Amistad. Fifty-three enslaved Africans, kidnapped from what is now Sierra Leone, seized the ship and tried to sail it back to Africa. They were captured off Montauk, Long Island, put on trial and ultimately won their freedom after John Quincy Adams argued their case before the United States Supreme Court.

title: For Mentally Ill, Freedom Often Leads to Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: An Offer to Replace Tires Slashed at a Station House
description: A neighborhood tire repair shop offered yesterday to provide replacement tires at cost to the victims of a tire-slashing spree early Saturday outside the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn. More than 100 tires on 44 vehicles, including 16 police vehicles, were punctured.

title: U.S. Is Pressing Moscow on Iran And Missile Aid
description: The United States is offering Russia an opportunity to expand its lucrative business launching foreign satellites if it clamps down on the sale of missile technology to Iran, senior American officials say.

title: BASEBALL: SPRING TRAINING
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELTZ, MARGARET A.
description: PELTZ-Margaret A. Wife of Dr. William L. Peltz died on January 23, 1998 on Martha's Vineyard. Her memorial service will be held at the Federated Church in Edgartown, MA. at 1PM on March 28th.

title: Make Room for Daddies
description: EVOLUTION is usually viewed as pushing women toward monogamy. The idea is that a man who is sure he is the father of a child will be more likely to help out around the jungle, or the house. But a study of the Bari people of Venezuela shows that promiscuity sometimes works better than fidelity.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Rev. Tissa Balasuriya, a Sri Lankan priest who was reconciled with the Roman Catholic Church after facing charges of heresy, misidentified his Rome-based order. It is the Missionary Oblates of Mary Immaculate, not the Oblates of the Immaculate Conception. The article also misspelled the surname of an editor of The Tablet, a British Catholic weekly newspaper that has followed the controversy. She is Margaret Hebblethwaite, not Hepplethwaite.

title: A $2.8 Billion Deal by Alcoa For Alumax
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, announced yesterday that it was buying the No. 3 aluminum maker, Alumax Inc., for $2.8 billion in cash and stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIEFFENBERG, LEON
description: TIEFFENBERG-Leon, 86, died March 8, 1998 at his apartment in Manhattan after a long illness. He is survived by his wife Josefina Rubinstein Tieffenberg; his daughter Magdalena Tieffenberg Tosteson of Boston and her husband Daniel Tosteson and their two children Joshua and Ingrid; and his son Jacobo Tieffenberg of Buenos Aires and his wife Irene Woods Tieffenberg and his children Gustavo, Jorge, Raul, Veronica and Ilan. In his memory, please send contributions to the Leon and Josefina Tieffenberg Fellowship Fund, Harvard Medical School, 25 Shattuck St., Boston, Ma. 02115.

title: LOTT SHIFTS BLAME ON INQUIRY'S PACE TO THE PRESIDENT
description: Recalibrating his views on the inquiry into President Clinton, Senator Trent Lott today called for the President to come forward and tell ''the whole truth'' about his relationship with a former White House intern. He said the issue ''is beginning to have an impact on his Presidency.''

title: Snow, Floods and Bitter Cold: Storm Rakes Much of Nation
description: A vast storm system over the weekend caused deadly flooding in the South and heavy rain and high winds in the New York region, and hurled a bitter onslaught of snow, ice and frigid temperatures from Wisconsin through Nebraska that blasted Midwesterners out of their smugness over a winter that almost wasn't.

title: Firstplus Buys Texas Unit
description: Firstplus Financial Group Inc. said today that it had bought the Regional Management Corporation's Texas consumer finance business, increasing lending in its home state. Firstplus, a home equity lender based in Dallas, bought Regional Management's 20 Texas branches and its $6.4 million Texas consumer loan portfolio. Terms were not disclosed. The purchase brings Firstplus's branch network in Texas to 53, all operating under its Texas subsidiary, Covington Credit of Texas.

title: School's Out Today; Parents in Scramble
description: Through notes in backpacks, the mom-and-dad grapevine and the children themselves, parents throughout New York City have got the kind of surprise that normally would come with a blizzard in March: school has been canceled today. And many parents and teachers learned about it only a few days ago, or even yesterday.

title: Editorial Observer; The House Is Not a Home, Until You Move In
description: One of the hot new trends in Congressional races is the term-limits pledge, in which a candidate signs a promise to step down after three terms. Some people regard this as a dumb idea, akin to vowing to resign as soon as you get the hang of the job.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A 2-Way Contest to Pick Up Philadelphia's Options
description: The American Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange have each approached the Philadelphia Stock Exchange about combining their options businesses, according to exchange officials.

title: The Hudson Needs the Mayor
description: Each day brings the proposed Hudson River Park on Manhattan's West Side closer to reality. The park has been broadly endorsed by the Governor, the Mayor, every West Side community board save one and every New Yorker with the vision to see the difference a restored waterfront could make to the city's quality of life. Yet the history of this enterprise is fragile, its future still uncertain.

title: Wilson Sidelined by Sore Shoulder
description: After being limited to five minor league appearances in 1997 while trying to come back from shoulder surgery, Paul Wilson arrived in camp intent on defying the odds.

title: 'Hostile' Speech May Be Protected
description: To the Editor:

title: Gretzky's Fluky Late Goal Helps Rangers Salvage Tie
description: This was just one of those nights when Wayne Gretzky of the Rangers banks the tying goal off two Devils and some lout douses Gretzky's wife and the Devils' general manager, Lou Lamoriello, with the same cup of beer while Brian Leetch, the mild-mannered Ranger captain, loses his helmet, literally, and his head, figuratively, before hacking the legs of two Devils with his stick.

title: Nothing Phantom About Affection
description: MICHAEL CRAWFORD, the former Phantom of the Opera, has been making his way across the country, appearing on public-television pledge drives when stations broadcast ''Michael Crawford in Concert.''

title: Test at Onset of Menopause Can Avert Bone Loss
description: LAST month my friend Carole and I paid a long overdue visit to the Osteoporosis Prevention Center at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York to have the density of our bones measured. Carole is 59 and I am approaching 57, and we both should have had this test done for the first time when we entered menopause around age 50, repeating it, if warranted by the initial results and our risk factors, a few years later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLITZ, RUTH PRIEST
description: POLLITZ-Ruth Priest. On March 9, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Edward Alan Pollitz and Henry Paul Hirst. Loving mother of Audrey Rosenfield and the late Samuel Priest Hirst. Adoring grandmother of Dr. Patricia Rosenfield, Thomas Rosenfield, David Hirst, Michael Hirst, Robert Hirst-Cohen and great grandmother of thirteen. Daughter of the late Samuel and Pearl Priest of Providence, Rhode Island. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Bowater-Avenor Deal to Create 2d-Largest Newsprint Maker
description: Bowater Inc. will acquire Avenor Inc. for $2.47 billion, the companies announced today, a combination that will create the second-largest newsprint manufacturer in North America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELE, PETER A. MD.
description: MELE-Peter A. MD. The Medical Staff of Englewood Hospital and Medical Center is saddened by the passing of Dr. Peter A. Mele. Dr. Mele was a loyal member of the medical staff for over 30 years. Peter played a vital role in the Department of Surgery serving as director of the residency program for many years. His surgical career culminated with his being elected as the first president of the American Society of Abdominal Surgeons. His dedication and service to the hospital and to his patients was only surpassed by his love of his family. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Paola, his daughter Paola, his sons Michael, Peter, and Christopher. Barry Sussman, MD, President Richard Salzer, MD, Vice President Kenneth Rubin, MD, Secretary Treasurer Medical Staff Englewood Hospital and Medical Center

title: Technology Earning Reports Finally Drive Down Markets
description: The stock market was haunted yesterday by warnings of disappointing earnings from some of the largest technology companies late last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, GEORGE W.
description: CAMPBELL-George W. Of Lloyd Neck, New York, on March 8, 1998. Mr. Campbell was the former President and CEO of the George Campbell Corporations of Flushing, NY. Beloved husband of Valerie. Loving father of George III, Eric, Gregory, Colleen, Celeste and Amy. Cherished son of Elizabeth and the late George Campbell. Dear brother of Anita Bergquist, Jane Jesinsky, Marian Rizzi and Barbara Dougherty. Also survived by five grandchildren. Memorial Mass Wednesday 9:45 AM at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Huntington, NY. Cremation was private. Funeral information contact the Vernon C. Wagner Funeral Homes, Inc. of Huntington.

title: Erin Go Brawl: Feuds And Fussing in Queens
description: Queens, at least as seen through the eyes of the creators of ''That's Life,'' an affable car wreck of a sitcom that has its premiere tonight at 9:30 on ABC, turns out to be a fairly bloodless and generic Everytown, where they have to wear Jets T-shirts to remind us what city we're in and put ''Erin Go Bragh'' pillows on the sofa to help us understand that the family is Irish-American.

title: Words for Suffering
description: Like many horrifying expressions in the 20th century, the term ''concentration camp'' started out as a ghastly euphemism. British authorities first coined it to describe their encampments for Afrikaner civilians during the Boer War in South Africa. During the Third Reich, the Nazis applied the phrase ''concentration camp'' to the places where millions of Jews and other prisoners were starved, tortured and eventually sent to the gas chambers at nearby ''killing centers.'' In a grim irony of history, the United States used the term to describe the camps in which tens of thousands of Japanese-Americans were incarcerated during the hysteria over the war in the Pacific.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, SARAH
description: FELDMAN-Sarah. Sweetest, kindest, most generous, mother of Phyllis and Gail, mother-in-law of Ed and Steve, grandmother of Melissa, Craig and Renny. Service at Parkside Memorial, 98-60 Queens Blvd., March 11 at 1 P.M.

title: Sport Utility Licenses
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, AARON FRED
description: SNYDER-Aaron Fred. Died on February 9, 1998 from natural causes. He was a member of the American and New York State Psychological Association. He was a retired psychologist and surviving is a sister Rita Glickman and Arnold Handman, a nephew.

title: Keeping Classics Alive
description: To the Editor:

title: Obsessed Nation Obsesses
description: With Brazil's World Cup team in poor form after ties with Jamaica and Guatemala and a loss to the United States, there was outrage in the country for more than two weeks. As a result, officials of the Brazilian Football Confederation, the governing body of soccer in the country, turned for help last week to two former national heroes. They appointed Zico, a star for Brazil in the 1980's, as the deputy to Coach Mario Zagallo, who then announced that he would include Rai on the squad for the World Cup in France.

title: Sports of The Times; Hockey's Concussion Concern
description: AT 6 feet 4 inches and 236 pounds, Eric Lindros is one of hockey's biggest and strongest players. He's not easy to knock off the puck, much less off his skates. But last Saturday, the Philadelphia Flyers' center crumpled to the ice, literally knocked out when slammed on the chin with a legal shoulder check by Darius Kasparaitis, a Pittsburgh Penguin defenseman.

title: Immigration Trouble-Shooter Lands in Inquiry's Cross Hairs
description: When Attorney General Janet Reno dispatched Robert K. Bratt last April to straighten out the Government's beleaguered citizenship program, he faced a daunting task.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASIN, DR. EDWIN
description: KASIN-Dr. Edwin. Devoted father of Deborah Benz and Paula Clark. Loving grandfather of Jennifer Benfaida, Samuel Clark and Eliana Clark. Services 12 noon, Wednesday, March 11, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 W. Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Mason Gives a Blood Sample
description: Anthony Mason gave a blood sample to Queens prosecutors yesterday morning, and a hearing on charges that he had sex with an under-age girl last month was delayed until April 7 to allow DNA testing to be conducted, the prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, DONALD W.
description: ROBERTS-Donald W., 88, a resident of Sand Castle Road, Sanibel Island, Florida and Cape Porpoise, Maine, formerly of Port Washington, Long Island, New York died Saturday in Kennebunk, Maine. Husband of Mary Lee (Kilthau) Roberts. Owner of Law practice, Taylor and Roberts in Flushing, New York for many years. Funeral services for Mr. Roberts will be held at 2 PM on Tuesday at Bibber Memorial Chapel, Kennebunk, Maine. Should friends desire, memorial contributions can be made to the Audubon Society of Maine, 118 US Route One, Falmouth, ME 04105 in Mr. Roberts memory.

title: Surprise! Take Some of Duke's Millions
description: In death, Doris Duke became a creature of the tabloids, the subject of countless colorful articles about her vast estate, the butler whom she had named as her executor and an angry suit brought by distant relatives, friends and questionable hangers-on. Much more quietly, the legal battles were settled, three years after Ms. Duke's death in 1993, and a foundation was formed to distribute the money the tobacco heiress had bequeathed to philanthropic causes.

title: Fashion Nation
description: EMME, the world's leading plus-size model, which means size 12 and above, is in New York for three days to videotape episodes of her ''Fashion Emergency'' program for the E! Entertainment cable network, a compendium of dos and don'ts that usually originates in Los Angeles. This raises a question: how does a New York fashion emergency differ from a Los Angeles one?

title: 30-Year Yield Falls Below 6% as Low Oil Prices Spur Rally
description: The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday amid lower oil prices and expectations that concerns about Indonesia's economy would drive foreign investors to seek the relative safety of the American bond market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANG, HERSH
description: LANG-Hersh. Of Pembroke Pines, FL. Formerly of Jackson Heights, NY. Passed away March 8, 1998. Beloved husband of Rose; loving father of Dr. Arnold (Dr. Gale) Lang; cherished grandfather of Jonathan, David and Samantha. Graveside services Tuesday, 11 A.M., at Mt. Hebron Cemetery. Levitt Weinstein 1-800-343-5400

title: Swaggering Through the Backdoor
description: There was an unmistakable swagger about the Princeton basketball team as the players performed routine drills after answering routine questions today at Jadwin Gymnasium. This Princeton team plays a little differently and chats a little differently than previous successful teams here have. Save thesis questions for Harvard. The Tigers would rather talk about possibly opposing North Carolina again. Seriously.

title: In a Plea Deal, Youth to Testify In Baby's Death
description: Breaking his long silence on charges that he helped his sweetheart kill their newborn son in a Delaware motel 16 months ago, Brian C. Peterson pleaded guilty to manslaughter today and agreed to become a central witness against his former girlfriend in her murder trial.

title: Generale des Eaux to Buy Remaining 70% of Havas
description: Generale des Eaux S.A., the diversified French water utility company, has agreed to buy the 70 percent of Havas S.A. it does not own for $5.6 billion, another step in Generale's effort to transform itself into a focused industrial concern with a major stake in telecommunications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, JOHN T., JR.
description: EDWARDS-John T., Jr. Of Massapequa, NY, on March 9, 1998. Mr. Edwards was a 1955 graduate of Manhattan College and First Lieutenant in the USAF. He began his twenty-eight year career at NYNEX as an Electrical Engineer and progressed to a division level Executive in their corporate planning and marketing division. John was the beloved husband of Mary. Devoted father of Susan, Brian, Mark, and Paul. Loving grandfather of Emily, Bobby, and Stephanie. Reposing at Massapequa Funeral Home Inc. 1050 Park Boulevard (at Clark), Massapequa Park, NY on Tuesday 7-9:30 PM & Wednesday 2-4:30 & 7-9:30 PM. Mass Thursday 10 A.M., St. Rose of Lima RC Church, Massapequa. Interment in Grace Church Cemetery.

title: On a Garage Floor in Kosovo, A Gruesome Serbian Harvest
description: The bodies of 51 ethnic Albanians, their lower torsos wrapped in white sheets, lay stretched out in two rows on the cement floor of an old garage today as a steady drizzle pelted the tiled roof.

title: Ruling Aids 'Gray Market' In U.S. Goods
description: In a decision that virtually insures the continued flourishing of the multibillion-dollar ''gray market'' in unauthorized imports, the Supreme Court ruled today that American manufacturers cannot invoke the protection of copyright law to block the domestic sale of products they originally sold at a discount overseas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAVRAN, MORRIS
description: HAVRAN-Morris. Congregation Orach Chaim deeply mourns the loss of our beloved senior member and daily and Sabbath congregant. A Holocaust survivor, his devotion and service to our Congregation will be eternally remembered and honored. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Sylvia, and sons, Leo and Jack. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Michael D. Shmidman, Rabbi Wolf Scheck, President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEFFEN, BATYA (SANDLER)
description: GEFFEN-Batya (Sandler). 10 years gone, still greatly missed by Mitchell, David, Deena, Sam, Julianne, Vivian, and Elaine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, PAT H. JR.
description: JACKSON-Pat H. Jr. Age 81. A retired state employee. Formerly of the Bronx. Residing at Northern Manor Nursing Home, Nanuet, NY. Passed Friday, March 6 after a prolonged illness. He was a WW II veteran stationed in the Pacific. Survived by his loving wife of 54 years Genevieve Carmen Jackson of Nanuet, NY. Beloved father of Mrs. Harolgen L. Chestnut of Maryland and Theresa P. Jackson, MD of Rockland County, NY. Also survived by two grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren. Reposing at Sniffen-Sagala Funeral Home, 235 Route 59, Spring Valley, New York, Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 11AM at St. Joseph's Church, 333 Sneden Place West, Spring Valley. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Northern Manor Geriatrics Center, 199 North Middletown Road, Nanuet, NY 10954 or United Hospice of Rockland, 18 Thiells Mt Ivy Road, Pomona, NY 10970. Dad, we know you are in God's grace, farewell.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Circuits section on Thursday about ham radio misstated the legal maximum for transmitter power. Radio operators may use up to 1,500 watts, not 4,000.

title: A Primer for Reporters: Gray's Interview of King
description: Memo: To all courtside, sideline, rink-prowling and ringside reporters.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Same-Sex Harassment Issue Furrows Court Brow
description: The Supreme Court took action today in two more sexual harassment cases, disposing of them in a way that underscored how unsettled the law remains after last week's ruling that brought same-sex harassment within the coverage of Federal discrimination law.

title: Coach Watson Brings Some Fab to Detroit
description: Perry Watson, a Detroit native, said he used to sit in the stands for University of Detroit basketball games and watch Dave DeBusschere and Spencer Haywood play. A few years later, he brought elementary school children to watch the Titans teams that were coached by Dick Vitale, now a college basketball analyst with ESPN.

title: Eric M. Breindel, 42, a New York Post Columnist
description: Eric M. Breindel, the former editorial page editor for The New York Post and the conservative moderator of a weekly public affairs program on the Fox News Channel, died Saturday afternoon. He was 42.

title: 'X-Files': Adventure for Directors; Stronger Roles Than Usual in the Shaping of a Series
description: It was a deliciously ominous day on the set of ''The X-Files'' at a studio here, and Kim Manners was busy doing what he excels at: breaking most of the rules of television directing.

title: Wild and Wacky Tax Laws
description: ''March Pledge '98'' has arrived on PBS, which means a heavy dose of television lite to sweeten the excruciating exhortations to give. Bolstered by the recent showing of ''Love and Survival With Dr. Dean Ornish: The Healing Power of Love and Intimacy,'' viewers should be in shape to make the most of ''Jonathan Pond's Tax Party.''

title: Record for Big Board Seat
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange, the entry ticket for trading on the world's biggest stock market, sold yesterday for a record $2 million. Owning one of the 1,366 stock exchange seats gives the holder the right to trade stocks and vote at exchange meetings. The seats trade at auction much the same as member stocks. The highest bid right now for an exchange seat is $1.4 million. The lowest price at which an exchange member is willing to sell is $3 million.

title: Edward T. Canby, 85, Choral Director and Writer
description: Edward Tatnall Canby, a choral director, teacher and writer whose conducting specialty was Renaissance and Baroque music but whose wide interests led him to work as a folklorist and as an advocate of electronic music, died on Feb. 21 at his home in Cornwall, Conn. He was 85 and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: Starr to Investigate Contacts With Witness
description: The independent counsel's office is investigating whether any efforts were made to discourage a witness in the Paula Jones case from testifying about an encounter she had with President Clinton, a lawyer involved in the case confirmed tonight.

title: Who Needs Jokes? Brain Has a Ticklish Spot
description: LIFE, it seems, imitates humor as well as art.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Federal Action Is Urged on Tainted Food
description: Illness caused by contaminated foods will increase unless the Government undertakes new and comprehensive public health efforts to detect cases and prevent outbreaks, leading experts said at a scientific meeting here today.

title: Old-South Ideologues
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Moses' and 'Susannah' On Met's New Schedule
description: The Metropolitan Opera is to present its first productions of Arnold Schoenberg's ''Moses und Aron'' and Carlisle Floyd's ''Susannah,'' as well as new productions of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' Verdi's ''Traviata,'' and Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' during its 1998-9 season.

title: Strike Vote Tonight on Broadway
description: With its contract expiring yesterday, the board of the union representing Broadway's pit musicians is to vote tonight on whether to authorize a strike that could begin as early as Sunday.

title: City Stunned to Lose Ex-Mayor in Lottery Attack
description: Linda Blogoslawski Mlynarczyk would probably have liked her service to be a more typical New Britain political wake, with people talking in a side room and politicians gossiping about the next election.

title: Norman E. Isaacs, 89, Journalist And Expert on Newspaper Issues
description: Norman E. Isaacs, a prominent newspaper editor and expert on press matters, died on Saturday in a residence for people with Alzheimer's disease in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 89 and formerly lived in Katonah, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ANN R.
description: MILLER-Ann R., Mar. 6. Survived by her beloved friend Phyllis Austopchuk and her sister-in-law Joan Miller. We will miss her dearly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIZAR, LEON
description: BIZAR-Leon. Beloved husband of Sylvia, devoted father of Andrea Schneebaum, Jodi Bizar-Wilcox and Scott B. Bizar. Cherished grandfather of Rachel and Rebecca Schneebaum, Sam and Victoria Wilcox and Kevin Bizar. Loving brother of Irving and Jack. Graveside services Wednesday 11 AM, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, LI. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Lupus Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Man Guilty of Murdering Girlfriend and Her Aunt
description: More than eight years after a Hackensack man was charged with killing his former girlfriend and her aunt following his release from prison, a jury convicted him of both murders yesterday.

title: An Ex-Bosnian Serb Commander Admits Rape of Muslims in War
description: A former Bosnian Serb paramilitary commander admitted before an international tribunal today that he had raped Muslim women during the Bosnian war in 1992. The confession makes him the first person to plead guilty to rape as a war crime.

title: Bilingual Education Facing Toughest Test
description: Rose Espinoza and Alice Callaghan spend much of their lives nurturing the American Dreams of poor and working class Latino immigrant children by tutoring them after school in English, math and faith in themselves and in their new country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTER, JULIUS
description: PASTER-Julius. On March 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Helen, loving father of Meryl P. Sherwood, Laurie R. Teitelbaum, Wendy P. Katz, and Sharon M. Paster. Cherished grandfather of Aaron, Rachel, Jonathan, Max, and Bonnie. Dear uncle. Services Tuesday, 1:30 PM at Park-West Riverside, 333 Amsterdam Ave.

title: Oxford's Plea To Raise Rates Stirs Anxiety
description: Ruth Edelman, a Manhattan real estate agent, has always paid her health insurance premiums on time. She even continued to send checks to Oxford Health Plans when the company, crippled by computer problems, failed to mail her bills. Nearly two weeks ago, the company sent her its own unsolicited piece of mail: it notified her that her premiums may rise to $547 a month from $324 a month, a 69 percent increase.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: FUEL TUMBLES. Prices of fuels plunged after Saudi Arabia suggested that it would not cut oil output. The unleaded gasoline contract for April delivery fell 2.02 cents, to 46.28 cents a gallon, the lowest since October 1994.

title: In Boston, It's a Broadway Away From Broadway
description: The opening of ''Wait Until Dark'' on Thursday is the latest in a string of recent pre-Broadway tryouts here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIMINE, PHILIP JOSEPH
description: CIMINE-Philip Joseph on Sunday, March 8, in his sleep of natural causes. Devoted husband of Isabel. Beloved father of Mary Ellen of Tampa and Diane of Irvington, N.Y. Loving grandfather of Cara, Ian and Dana. Recipient of the Bronze Star Medal for service to his country during WWII, 1941-1945. Retired from Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in 1975 after 25 years of employment. A wake is being held at La Bella Funeral Chapel, 2625 Harway Avenue, Bklyn, N.Y., Monday and Tuesday, 2-5PM and 7-9:30PM. Burial will take place March 11th at Veterans Memorial Cemetery in Calverton following a 9:30 mass at Most Precious Blood Church, Bklyn. NY.

title: New Tinderbox, Same Fuse: A Serb Comes Full Circle
description: Kosovo is a sacred place for Serbs, and for Serbian politicians. The Ottoman Turks defeated an army of Serbian knights on a barren field here more than six centuries ago, and Serbs have commemorated their martyrdom ever since in poetry and song.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Merger of Weapons Giants Faces Unexpected Hurdle

title: Debate on Camps Goes Back to War; Japanese Atrocities
description: To the Editor:

title: Debate on Camps Goes Back to War
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTMENT FIRM TO ACQUIRE STAKE IN EYE CARE CENTERS
description: Eye Care Centers of America Inc. said yesterday that the Thomas H. Lee Company, an investment firm, and its affiliates would acquire 90 percent of the company for $300 million. Thomas H. Lee's purchase will provide expansion capital for the 243-store San Antonio-based Eye Care Centers chain. The current majority owner, Desai Capital Management Inc., a New York-based private investment firm, and the management of Eye Care Centers, the country's third-largest optical retailer, will hold the remaining 10 percent. Thomas H. Lee, based in Boston, has about $5 billion under management.

title: Americans Take a Dim View Of the Government, Survey Finds
description: Most Americans still deeply distrust the Federal Government, despite the end of the cold war, the robust economy and the highest level of satisfaction in their own lives in 30 years, a new national survey has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YORIO, WILLIAM M.
description: YORIO-William M. On March 7, 1998, of Ridge, formerly of Manhasset. Beloved husband of Lucille. Loving father of William T. and the late Anthony M. Also survived by his daughter-in-law Jacqueline and three grandchildren Dana, Regina and Paul. Brother of Michael, Micheline, Anne, Nancy and Yolanda. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Monday and Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10:45 AM, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WEPRIN, JACK
description: WEPRIN-JACK. 1930-1996. A dear friend is always remembered with love. Martin

title: Glimpse of Abnormal Nuclei Alters Views on Atomic Structure
description: PHYSICISTS at Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois say they believe they have created some freakish atomic nuclei that are shaped like footballs and eject protons during their death throes to produce a very rare form of radioactivity.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- Be True to Your Cola, Rah! Rah!; Battle for Soft-Drink Loyalties Moves to Public Schools
description: The Jefferson County school district in Colorado needed a new football stadium. The Lebanon, Ohio, school district had a crumbling outdoor track. The Keller Independent School District, outside Fort Worth, wanted to make sure its value as one of the state's fastest-growing and best-performing school systems did not go unrecognized.
