title: Decision to Cancel School Today Sends Many Parents Scrambling
description: Through notes in backpacks, through the mom-and-dad grapevine and through their children themselves, parents across New York City got the kind of surprise that normally would come with a blizzard in March. School has been canceled today. And many parents, principals and teachers learned about it only a few days ago -- or even just yesterday.

title: E.P.A. Delays Study of Hudson River PCB's
description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency released a revised schedule for its study of PCB contamination in the Hudson River today, saying it would issue a final decision on a cleanup strategy in June 2001, 16 months later than previously planned.

title: Another Superstar? But He's So Modest, So Earnest
description: Eros Ramazzotti's female fans picked up all their cues at his sold-out show on Friday night at Radio City Music Hall. They tossed flowers onstage, pressed forward for kisses, gasped when he dropped his voice to a whisper, sang along on old hits and squealed when he tossed his tie into the crowd. ''Estoy enamorado de ti,'' he said -- Spanish for ''I'm in love with you'' -- and pointed to one woman after another: ''de ti, de ti, de ti.'' Yet Mr. Ramazzotti, a superstar in his native Italy, didn't act cocky or overbearing; he had an air of modesty, singing love songs in an earnest, reedy voice. Like Julio Iglesias, he's a gentleman, grateful for love and dreaming of bliss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACCHIA, JOHN J.
description: MACCHIA-John J., 84. Died March 9, 1998 in Fort Lauderdale, FL. He was born January 29, 1914 in Bronx, New York. Mr. Macchia attended St. John's College and Fordham Law School. He was admitted to the New York Bar in 1942 and enlisted in the US Army that same year. In 1950 he married Katheryn Satterfield of Galletin, TN, and moved to Chappaqua, NY. They remained married until her death in 1984. Mr. Macchia practiced Law in New York City for over 30 years and was a senior partner with the firm of Townley, Updike, Carter, and Rogers. He retired to Reading, Vermont in 1979. In 1990 he moved to Fort Lauderdale, Florida where he lived until his death. He is survived by a son, John J. Macchia, Jr., Fort Lauderdale, FL, a daughter, Mary K. Macchia, Tequesta, FL, a sister, Marion Raimondi, Hopewell Jct, NY, Nieces and Nephews. He was pre-deceased by three brothers, James, Joseph, and Tony Macchia. Services: Saturday, March 14, 1998, at 11:00 A.M., at Our Lady of the Snows Catholic Church in Woodstock, Vermont. Visiting hours will be Friday evening from 6 to 8 PM at the Cabot Funeral Home in Woodstock, Vermont. Memorial donations to the Ottuaquechee Health Center, 32 Pleasant Str., Woodstock, VT 05091.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEECHMAN, LAURIE
description: BEECHMAN-Laurie. She has been a special and extraordinary friend over the years. Our deepest sympathy to Neil, Dolly, Nat, Claudia, Jane and the rest of the family. Warren, Sally and Amanda Baker

title: New Tax Will Be Sought To Pay Off Trash Bonds
description: The Atlantic County Board of Freeholders is to vote tonight on a special tax to pay off $84 million in bonds issued by the Atlantic County Utility Authority years ago to build trash hauling facilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, EDITH
description: MORSE-Edith. Beloved wife of Charles. Super-fantastic mother of Alison and Matthew. Loving aunt, treasured friend. Services Wednesday, 1 P.M. at Schwartz Bros., 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: Move to Let Remediation Into Religious Schools
description: Public school districts that provide remedial and special education programs to private school students would be able to hold classes inside religious schools under a bill that cleared the Assembly Education Committee yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEFFERSON, FLOYD WELLMAN III
description: JEFFERSON-Floyd Wellman III, 44, of Oak Bend St., Orlando, died on March 6, 1998. A professional golfer, he was born in New York, New York and moved to Orlando in 1974. He was Episcopalian. He was a past member of the Walt Disney World Classic Country Club, Bay Hill Country Club, Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, Meadow Club of Southampton, Southampton Bathing Organization, Cypress Creek Country Club. He is survived by his daughters Kelly June of Orlando, Florida, and Morgan Elizabeth of New York, NY; Son Ian Wellman of New York, NY; stepdaughter Kristin M. Zornow of Winter Park, FL; Stepson Warin L. Epstein of New York, NY; Sisters Joan J. Stott of North Palm Beach, FL., and Marina J. Sutro of New Jersey. Funeral Services will be held Tuesday, March 10 at 3:00 PM from the Chapel of the Dobbs Funeral Home, 430 North Kirkman Road, Orlando.

title: PARADIGM TECHNOLOGY TO BUY SEMICONDUCTOR MAKER
description: Paradigm Technology Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the IXYS Corporation, a closely held semiconductor maker, for about $150 million. IXYS, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., had net income of $4.4 million on revenues of $55.3 million for the 1997 fiscal year. Paradigm, based in Milpitas, Calif., makes memory chips for computer networks, modems and military equipment. The company had a net loss of $8.9 million on sales of $12.4 million in 1997.

title: Harrowing Choices Accompany Advancements in Fertility
description: ON Oct. 15, Diane S., a 30-year-old woman who lives in Grand Rapids, Mich., faced what might be her last chance to become pregnant. In two and a half years, she had spent tens of thousands of dollars on fertility treatments and could not afford to try much longer. Her doctor had created five healthy embryos by mixing Diane's eggs with her husband's sperm. The doctor could put two or three embryos into her uterus, freezing the rest for later, or he could put them all in.

title: Forget Mousetraps! Build Us a Better Web Phone
description: THE much-heralded information appliance has been an unkept promise for years. The promise is that we will one day see cheap self-contained electronic devices that can perform many of the important functions of computers without their stupefying complexity and instability. The reality is that the simplest and most dependable information appliance has been around for more than a century. It is called a telephone, and only its relative the fax machine has managed to come close.

title: Bill Advances to Set Drug-Testing Guidelines
description: A bill that would establish the first state guidelines for employee drug testing in private companies was approved by the Assembly Judiciary Committee yesterday.

title: 1997 Profit Fell 30% At Big Singapore Bank
description: United Overseas Bank Ltd., one of Singapore's four largest banks, said yesterday that its profit fell 30 percent in 1997 as it set aside money for bad loans in Southeast Asia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RILEY, WINIFRED CECILIA
description: RILEY-Winifred Cecilia. On March 8, 1998. Beloved sister of Rita M. Potter. Survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th Street), New York City, on Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial 10AM, Wednesday at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Sunbeam Chairman Gets New Contract
description: The chairman of the Sunbeam Corporation, Albert J. Dunlap, has received a three-year contract extension that includes a doubling of his salary and stock and options currently worth about $68 million to him.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 59 of the Television section on Sunday about the series ''Antiques Road Show'' referred incompletely to its broadcast schedule. While the show is normally broadcast on Mondays at 8 on Channel 13, it was not seen last night and will not be seen next Monday because of pledge week programming.

title: Crisis Aside, What Pains Indonesia Is the Humiliation
description: Nearly two months later, Indonesians still shudder at the image. Their President sits hunched at a table, signing what amounts to an economic surrender agreement, as the head of the International Monetary Fund glares sternly at him with his arms folded.

title: Warning and Wooing on Patient Bill of Rights
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that Congress would probably pass health care legislation to protect the rights of patients this year, but he declared that the bill would not solve the problems of doctors and patients fed up with insurance companies.

title: Clinton Attending Fund-Raiser With Lawyer Behind Tobacco Deal
description: As President Clinton intensifies his call for comprehensive tobacco legislation, he will attend a big fund-raising event at the home of a prominent lawyer who stands to reap a windfall from enactment of such laws.

title: The Royal Ripple Effect
description: The recent announcement here of a Government measure to give princesses the same rights of succession to the throne as princes has caused few waves. Yet its implications may be immeasurable.

title: Seoul Leader, Ex-Inmate Himself, Is Slow to Free Political Prisoners
description: The world of Prisoner No. 3514 is a closet-size space with three brick walls and one solid steel door with a flap that opens to deliver his meals. His only ''furniture'' is one blanket that he lays on the floor as a mattress and another that he wraps around himself to fight the winter cold.

title: Treasures of Science Offered at Auction
description: Treasures from the Haskell F. Norman Library of Science and Medicine, hailed as the finest private collection of its kind, will be auctioned beginning at 10 A.M. on March 18 at Christie's in New York, Dr. Norman, right, a San Francisco area psychiatrist who died in 1996, collected some 2,500 science books worth an estimated $10 million to $12 million. Other parts of the collection will be auctioned in June and November.

title: Workouts Begin, Minus O'Donnell
description: With Neil O'Donnell presumably working out on his own, the Jets yesterday began their voluntary workouts at the training complex in Hempstead, L.I.

title: COMMERCIAL FEDERAL PLANS TO ADD FIRST COLORADO
description: The Commercial Federal Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the First Colorado Bancorp, a bank holding company, for $525 million. First Colorado, based in Lakewood, Colo., is the parent of First Federal Bank of Colorado, which has 27 branches in the state. Under the deal, Commercial Federal, a holding company based in Omaha, will exchange a share for each First Colorado share outstanding. The exchange ratio will be 0.9677 if the average price of Commercial Federal stock falls below $31 and 0.7895 if the average price is above $38. Shares of Commercial Federal closed at $33.6875 yesterday, down 37.5 cents. First Colorado shares were at $28.50, up 25 cents.

title: Delta Woodside To Shed Units
description: Delta Woodside Industries said today that it would sell or close its three Stevecoknit fabric plants and sell its fitness unit, Nautilus International, to focus on textiles and apparel.

title: Lose 1 to and Gain 1 From Thompson
description: What did BBDO South do after J. Walter Thompson swiped a top executive? It hired one from Thompson.

title: Just a Hearing On Landmark, But City Balks
description: WALKING along Third Avenue in the East 70's, you could easily overlook an unusual -- some might even say quirky -- enclave of apartments and stores known as the Cottages. They were built in the 1930's, in the shadow of elevated trains that once upon a time, children, rattled by on Third Avenue.

title: Report Says VW Profit Doubled Last Year
description: Der Spiegel, the German weekly, reported yesterday that the profit of Volkswagen A.G. more than doubled in 1997 as new and updated vehicle models resulted in higher sales across the company's product line. VW's shares rose after the magazine said, without citing its source of information, that profit had risen a greater-than-expected 120 percent, to 1.5 billion marks ($820 million). Officials of VW declined to comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUSON, SYDNEY
description: GRUSON-Sydney. The Board of Directors and staff of The Rogosin Institute express heartfelt sympathy to family and friends of Mr. Sydney Gruson. Mr. Gruson was deeply committed to the advancement of the programs of RI as a benefactor and member of The Institute's Honor Guard.

title: Mitsubishi Roster Belongs to Deutsch
description: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America said yesterday that it had reduced the roster of agencies available to its local dealer associations from two to one. The decision leaves Deutsch Inc. in New York as the sole agency to handle the dealer accounts, with combined billings estimated at $65 million to $80 million.

title: With New Inspection Setup, a New Annan-Iraq Link
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan forged another direct link with Iraq today by unveiling procedures for Iraqi presidential sites to be inspected under the watchful eyes of diplomats. He also sent a new commissioner to Baghdad tonight to oversee the operation.

title: SYNETIC TO EXPAND LINE WITH PURCHASE OF POINT PLASTICS
description: Synetic Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Point Plastics Inc. for $86 million in cash and stock as it seeks to expand its plastics business. Synetic, which makes health care products and provides health care communications, will pay $51.6 million in stock and $34.4 million in cash for Point Plastics, a seller of high-volume disposable plastic products. Point Plastics, which is based in Petaluma, Calif., will become part of Synetic's Porex plastics filtration unit. As a result of this acquisition, Synetic said it would cancel its proposed initial public offering of Porex. Shares of Synetic, based in Elmwood Park, N.J., rose 75 cents yesterday, to $50.50.

title: 'Hostile' Speech May Be Protected; Basketball Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSIN, SHIRLEY
description: BOSIN-Shirley. Tifereth IsraelTown and Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its beloved member of long standing and past Sisterhood president and extends its heartfelt condolences to her husband George and the entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Fred Karp, President

title: Hartford Legislators Threaten to Block a Takeover Bid
description: Connecticut's State Legislature made a rare foray into board-room politics yesterday, threatening to block a hostile takeover by a Muskegon, Mich., auto parts maker against Echlin Inc., the only Fortune 500 company in New Haven County.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLOWAY, ROBERT E.
description: HOLLOWAY-Robert E. Of Lincolndale, New York, cherished husband of Sondra (nee Youner), devoted father of Christine Barnett, Diane Haug, Malissa, Tyler, and Robin. Loving grandfather of Jeffrey, Michael, Brandon, Bret, and Kyle. Visitation Wednesday 24 and 7-9 P.M. at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, Mount Kisco, New York. Requiem Mass Thursday 10 A.M. at Good Shepherd Episcopal Church, Granite Springs, New York. Interment to follow at Ivandale Cemetery, Somers, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations preferred to Somers Volunteer Fire Department, Somers, New York 10589.

title: IRI INTERNATIONAL IN STOCK DEAL FOR HITEC OF NORWAY
description: The IRI International Corporation, a drilling-equipment maker based in Houston, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Norwegian drilling-equipment company Hitec A.S.A. for $280 million in stock. Under the agreement, which is expected to close in the spring, Hitec's stockholders will receive 0.575 of a newly issued IRI share for each Hitec share. Hitec will retain a 35 percent stake in the combined company, which will be called IRI Hitec Inc. IRI, which had full-year net income of $11 million, said combined revenue in 1997 was $300 million. Shares of IRI fell 56.25 cents yesterday, to $12.4375.

title: INSIDE
description: 'Gray Market' Upheld

title: Texas Lenders Pledge $1.4 Billion in Housing Case
description: Three Texas mortgage lenders have agreed to make nearly $1.4 billion available to low-income and minority home buyers over the next three years in a settlement of housing discrimination complaints.

title: Yankee Bullpen Tailor-Made for Success
description: Tom Glavine won a Cy Young award for the Atlanta Braves and is among the game's best pitchers, Mike Stanton said today, prefacing an answer to a larger question. ''But,'' Stanton added, ''there's absolutely no way he could be a reliever.''

title: Bronx Police Seek Link Between Rapes and Death of Teen-Ager
description: The police are investigating a possible link between recent rapes of two women in the Tremont section of the Bronx and the body of an unidentified slain teen-age girl that was found in the neighborhood two weeks ago, investigators said.

title: Foreign Affairs; It Takes a Village
description: I've come to China to follow an observer team, led by the Carter Center in Atlanta, to monitor village elections in northeast China. This column is the first of a series on the trip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, NORMAN E.
description: ISAACS-Norman E. For all of the students, faculty and alumni who knew and respected Norman Isaacs, we note his death with sadness. As an outstanding newspaper editor, president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, and chairman of the National News Council, he was a leading figure in American journalism. As editor-in-residence and associate dean at the Journalism School, he infused us with his passion for high standards in the pursuit of truth, especially in the face of political intimidation. We extend our condolences to our colleague, Prof. Stephen D. Isaacs, and his family. Tom Goldstein, Dean Joan Konner, Dean Emerita Sandy Padwe, Associate Dean and the Faculty of the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism

title: Ryanair to Buy 45 Boeing Jets
description: Ryanair Holdings P.L.C. said today that it would buy as many as 45 single-aisle 737 jetliners worth $2 billion from the Boeing Company, giving the United States plane maker a victory in Europe after losing several orders to its rival, Airbus Industrie, in recent months.

title: AT&T Unit Adds $1.1 Billion in Business
description: The AT&T Corporation's outsourcing unit, known as AT&T Solutions, brought in $1.1 billion in new business in the first two months of the year, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: A Broken Toe Won't Sideline Nets' Van Horn
description: Keith Van Horn walked gingerly through the parking lot of the Nets' practice facility today, his toes sticking out of his sandals. But he revealed no limp in his gait, no signs that the Nets had just received another dose of bad news.

title: Song and Dance Reign Over Russian History
description: The Red Star Red Army Chorus and Dance Ensemble, which appeared at Lincoln Center in 1992, returned in somewhat different form on Sunday afternoon at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts.

title: As March 9's Go, It Was the Soggiest Ever in New York
description: A storm system that whipped up wicked weather across the nation cut a wet and windy swath through the metropolitan region yesterday, bringing 1.8 inches of rain to Central Park in 15 hours, toppling scaffolding with 50-mile-an-hour winds and flooding parts of Queens and New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPF, PAUL C.
description: KOPF-Paul C. Age 87. Beloved husband of Estel and father of Kathy. Formerly of New York City, Hillsdale, N.Y. and Lake Worth, FL. Passed away Friday, March 6.

title: Fines Asked for Problems At Brookhaven Labs
description: The United States Environmental Protection Agency yesterday proposed $80,000 in fines for safety violations uncovered last year at the Brookhaven National Laboratory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRY, PHILIP J JR.
description: CURRY-Philip J Jr. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Philip J. Curry, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Review/Fashion; Milan Hears 'Basta'; But 'Viva' What?
description: Where are the jackets of yesteryear? In short supply in Milan, that's for sure.

title: Code-Sharing Deal Reached By All Nippon
description: In the latest round of musical chairs that has world airlines joining forces, All Nippon Airways, Japan's second-largest carrier, announced yesterday that it had reached separate alliances with United Airlines and Lufthansa of Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEINEMAN, RUTH (KRESS)
description: HEINEMAN-Ruth (Kress). Age 75, passed away peacefully in her sleep, at home, after a long illness borne with courage and dignity. She is survived by her loving husband Bernard (Jack) Heineman, Jr, her devoted chiildren Deb and Ralph, Matt and Katie, Steve and Kathy and by her six adoring grandchildren. The family will receive friends at The Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue on Sunday March 8 from 6-9 PM, Monday March 9 from 6-9 PM. The funeral service will be Tuesday, March 10 at 4 PM at The First Presbyterian Church, 12th St and 5th Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The College of Wooster, Wooster, OH, The Public Education Association, 39 W. 32nd Street, or the charity of your choice.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Sunday incorrectly said that a meeting between Bill Richardson, the American delegate to the United Nations, and Monica Lewinsky took place in Mr. Richardson's home. It took place in the office of his rental suite in the Watergate Hotel in Washington.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Seeks New Agency
description: The Dunkin' Donuts unit of Allied Domecq is talking to two agencies about handling its account after dismissing Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, the incumbent since October 1995. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: This Time, Starks Labors To Pull Out of His Slump
description: When John Starks is playing badly, it usually takes two possessions to straighten everything out. Whether his jump shot veers too much to the left or he forgets about any offensive option inside the 3-point arc, it is Starks's nature to go through slumps and then pull out of them.

title: Textron Is Promoting President to Chief
description: Textron Inc., the auto parts and aerospace company, said last week that Lewis B. Campbell, its president and chief operating officer, would become chief executive this summer, replacing James F. Hardymon.

title: U.S. and Allies Set Sanctions on Yugoslavia
description: The United States and its Western allies decided today to impose modest diplomatic and economic sanctions on Yugoslavia for President Slobodan Milosevic's ''unacceptable use of force'' against the ethnic Albanian majority in the province of Kosovo.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The time is not yet ripe for the release of all prisoners of conscience. But I have a strong commitment to democracy, and I will make sure that they are freed gradually.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, GOLDIE
description: BRENNER-Goldie. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Goldie Brenner, beloved mother of Edith Everett, a cherished philanthropist and humanitarian. Edith and her husband, Henry J. Everett, are distinguished members of our Board of Directors. They are enormously admired and respected throughout the community for their extraordinary leadership, commitment and generosity on behalf of UJAFederation and many other organizations in New York, and throughout the world. We extend our deepest sympathies to Edith and Henry Everett; Mrs. Brenner's daughter, Gladys Praigrod; her grandchildren; and her greatgrandchildren. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, SAMUEL A.
description: WEISS-Samuel A. Of Great Neck. Beloved husband of the late Melvina. Devoted father of Seth Weiss and Naomi DeMuth. Loving father-in-law of Roger DeMuth. Cherished grandfather of Adam and Aaron DeMuth. Devoted uncle. Services Wednesday 12 noon at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: National News Briefs; Reno Urged to Continue Look at Herman Inquiry
description: Attorney General Janet Reno's aides have urged her to keep open an inquiry about the possible need for an independent prosecutor to investigate whether Labor Secretary Alexis Herman improperly used her influence to help an African businessman, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: For a Popular School, Parents Spend a Night in Line in the Rain
description: It is not unusual for parents to line up overnight for a chance to get their children admitted to a popular magnet school in Queens, but this year the wait was capped by a driving rain.

title: The Desk Set
description: That was no mannequin at the John F. Kennedy desk in the window at Barneys, on Madison Avenue at 61st Street -- it was TRACY KIDDER, a freelance advertising specialist. ''I've always been fascinated with the whole Kennedy thing,'' he said, and asked to try out the desk, a reproduction of the one in the Oval Office. There has been talk that it could go for $400,000 when it is auctioned next week at Guernsey's -- too much for Mr. Kidder.

title: British Mortgage Lender Has a Second Suitor
description: Halifax P.L.C., Britain's largest mortgage lender, offered to buy Birmingham Midshires Building Society, a mortgage lender owned by its customers, for $:780 million ($1.3 billion), topping an offer by Royal Bank of Scotland P.L.C. Last summer, the board of Midshires agreed to be bought for $:630 million by Royal Bank; its members are to vote on the proposal this summer.

title: Metro Business; Duane Reade Leases Site
description: Duane Reade, the drugstore chain with more than 70 New York City stores, will move its principal warehouse from Long Island City to a distribution center in Maspeth, Queens, that is owned by Federated Department Stores, the two companies said yesterday.

title: U.N. Should Be Grateful
description: To the Editor:

title: A Matter of Scout's Honor, Gay Victor Says
description: GREAT lunch at a restaurant downtown, where the desserts are so good you want to jump in the dish with them, but the gay Boy Scout keeps looking at his watch. It's his first week at a new job and he's been off doing all these interviews about his court victory, and he's feeling guilty.

title: Metro Business; Vornado Buys Building
description: Vornado Realty Trust, a real estate investment trust in Saddle Brook, N.J., said yesterday that it acquired an office building at 150 East 58th Street for about $118 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALPERN, WILLIAM
description: ALPERN-William. Dear Daddy, Happy Birthday. Miss you as much as ever. Time doesn't heal. Your loving daughter.

title: The New and Improved Agassi Is Working Harder to Succeed
description: Stasis has never interested Andre Agassi. Blue hair, blond hair, Mohawk hair, no hair, he has taken every hair on his head to extremes. On the tennis court, he has pretty much gone in the same direction. A dedicated recycler of himself, Agassi has performed every way but predictably in his 13 years on the stump, but this latest reincarnation, one that has him leading the pack with a 17-2 record and an 11-match winning spree after doing a dead man's float in 1997, may be his most ingenious.

title: The Universe, Explained
description: To the Editor:

title: Omdurman Journal; The Koran as a Cure-All? Listen to the Sufi Sheik
description: A crowd starts gathering in the dusty warehouse yard an hour before he appears. They come from all over the Sudan, the diseased and the disabled, the blind and the melancholy. They sit cross-legged in long rows in the dirt under a desert sky and wait for the healer, each wrapped in a private pain.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MEDALLION FINANCIAL CORP., New York, agreed to acquire the privately held financing company Capital Dimensions Inc., Minneapolis, for $30 million in stock.

title: 3 Times Mirror Officials Retiring From Board
description: The core of the Times Mirror Company's leadership before the arrival of Mark H. Willes as chief executive in 1995 will retire from the board in May, the company disclosed yesterday.

title: Get Inside Data On Any Broker
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers will put brokers' employment histories on line starting on March 26, as the first step in a $50 million project to make it easier for investors to find out about the backgrounds and disciplinary histories of United States brokers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, BARNEY
description: SIEGEL-Barney. Adored husband of the late Ruth B., beloved father of Martin Jay and Phyllis S. Zilkha, fond father-in-law of Laura M. and Jalall. Adored grandfather of Stephanie, Genan, Tamar, and Philip. Services today, 12 N, Kingsbridge Center of Israel, 3115 Corlear Avenue, Bronx. Interment Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, N.J.

title: Sanctions on Yugoslavia
description: The United States and its Western allies agreed in an emergency meeting to impose modest sanctions on Yugoslavia over its use of force against the ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo. Page A10.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: British Bookseller to Buy Operator of Newsstands
description: The British bookseller W. H. Smith Group said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire John Menzies P.L.C., a seller of magazines, newspapers and books, for $:68 million, ($112 million). The acquisition includes 232 Menzies stores, which had operating profit of $:5 million on sales of $:284 million for the year that ended on April 30, 1997.

title: Q&A
description: Hungry Plants

title: A Job Left Unfinished Disappoints the Devils
description: Fighting for a share of respect from Ranger fans has been the story of the Devils from their first day in New Jersey. Even though they challenged the Rangers in recent years -- and even won a Stanley Cup three years ago -- the Devils always seemed to lose to the Rangers when it counted, most strikingly in playoff series in 1994 and last season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, LILLIAN
description: KAPLAN-Lillian. On March 9, 1998 in Delray Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of Herman Kaplan. Loving mother of Rhoda Schachter, Annette Littman, and Carol Gardner. Dear sister of Moe Goldner, Helen Feldman, Sidney Goldner and Raymond Goldner. Cherished grandmother of Ilene Mirkine, Lauren Crandall, Michael Littman, Gary Littman, Cori Gardner and Evan Gardner. Great-grandmother of Kelsey, Matthew, Adam and Emily. She will always be remembered by her family. Services will be held Wednesday, March 11, at 12 noon at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYSANEK, LEONIE
description: RYSANEK-Leonie. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of one of our most highly-revered and deeply-loved artists, Leonie Rysanek. A thrilling and moving performer, she seared her roles into our memories with her glorious, gleaming soprano and heartstopping dramatic intensity. From her triumphant debut as Lady Macbeth in 1959 when she overcame the Herculean odds of substituting for Maria Callas, she gained the respect and adoration of the public and her colleagues alike. Standing ovations were a well-deserved commonplace at her performances. At the Met she was the first artist to sing the roles of Lady Macbeth in Verdi's ''Macbeth,'' Abigaille in Verdi's ''Nabucco,'' Ariadne in Strauss's ''Ariadne auf Naxos,'' the Empress in Strauss's ''Die Frau ohne Schatten,'' and Kabanicha in Janacek's ''Katya Kabanova.'' She had a special affinity for the operas of Wagner and Strauss, and her Senta, Sieglinde, Marschallin, Elisabeth, Chrysothemis, Elsa, Salome, Kundry, Ortrud, and Klytaemnestra were magnificent protrayals. In all she sang 299 performances of 24 roles over a period of 31 seasons at the Met. She sang in 12 new production premieres, including Leonore in the Beethoven Bicentennial year production of ''Fidelio.'' Her farewell performance here was just over two years ago, as the Countess in ''The Queen of Spades,'' making her Met career an amazing 37 years long. In addition to the immense respect her artistic achievements demanded, Leonie was much loved by her colleagues and company members at the Met. Her professionalism and hard work were total, and her easy smile, winning sense of humor, and open-hearted warmth made her every engagement here a delightful occasion. Her death has struck an unexpected and severe blow to this company's heart. We offer our sincerest condolences to her husband, Elu, who is also a great friend of many of our company, and to all her family. Joseph Volpe General Manager James Levine Artistic Director

title: Qwest Set to Acquire LCI For $4.4 Billion in Stock
description: Making a major leap into the consumer long-distance telephone business, Qwest Communications International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire LCI International Inc. for $4.4 billion in stock.

title: Adams Closes In on a Place Among the Elite of the Elite
description: It has been known for some time that after Garry Kasparov, the strongest players are Vladimir Kramnik of Russia and Viswanathan Anand of India. In the International Chess Federation's rankings on Jan. 1, they were Nos. 2 and 3 in the world. But the English grandmaster Michael Adams is soon likely to be following close behind.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL HOSPITALITY BUYING 14 HOTELS
description: The American General Hospitality Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire 14 hotels from the privately held Financial Security Assurance Holdings Ltd. for $270 million. American General is a Dallas-based real estate investment trust that owns 66 hotels including pending purchases. It had revenue of $61.9 million in 1997. Financial Security Assurance, based in New York, is a bond insurer that also manages hotel REIT's. The purchase comprises seven ocean-front resorts and seven commercial hotels, with a total of 3,229 rooms. Seven of the properties are in Florida, two are in California and the others are in Connecticut, Minnesota, Missouri, New York and Virginia.

title: Worldcom and MCI In Telefonica Link
description: As expected, Worldcom Inc. and its partner, the MCI Communications Corporation, announced today that they had formed an alliance with Telefonica de Espana S.A. of Spain to expand in the Spanish-speaking world and in Europe.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: INDONESIAN CURRENCY PLUMMETS. The rupiah fell 8 percent to the lowest level in five weeks, dragging down other Asian currencies, after the I.M.F. delayed an aid installment. In New York it cost 10,900 rupiah to buy a dollar.

title: Patterns
description: Versace Not Hiring

title: The Struggle to Decipher Human Genes
description: IN a drab gray building in the industrial outskirts of St. Louis, a team of some 200 people is working 19 hours a day in pursuit of the ultimate self-knowledge. They are spearheading the effort to sequence the human genome by 2005.

title: Judge Rejects Request to Exclude Reporters in Death Penalty Case
description: On the eve of New York State's first death penalty trial since capital punishment was reinstated in September 1995, Acting Justice Anne G. Feldman of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn ruled yesterday against a request by the defense to exclude the press during the questioning of prospective jurors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWSER, BERTIN
description: ROWSER-Bertin. With children and a stage Bertin made magic. We shall miss him. Died Thursday, March 5 at home in Buffalo. Shirley Ubell, Artistic Director Center,Modern Dance Education

title: 2 European Publishing Giants Cancel Their Plans for Merger
description: Reed Elsevier P.L.C., the British-Dutch publishing giant, and Wolters Kluwer N.V., a Dutch rival, said today that they had canceled plans to merge after they were unable to renegotiate their agreement, which had encountered regulatory objections.

title: Botulinum Toxin's Promise as Drug May Rival Its Potential as Weapon
description: WHILE concern grows about the possible use of botulinum toxin for biological warfare, medical uses of this deadliest of poisons are expanding. Injections of tiny amounts of the same toxin that bacteria produce to cause botulism, a food-borne disease that paralyzes breathing muscles and kills by suffocation, can heal by producing a local paralysis. The toxin reduces excessive muscle contractions without causing significant functional weakness or diminishing sensation, safely turning several largely untreatable conditions into manageable ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, HELEN
description: HERTZ-Helen. Age 91, beloved mother of Leona Duffy and Martin J. Hertz; mother-in-law of Judith M. Hertz. Grandmother of Marian Sue Keltz, Ricki Martin Kline and Herbert Ray. Greatgrandmother of Daniel Keltz, David Keltz, Liana Ray, Melina Kline and Harry Kline. Funeral services are at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York, on Tuesday, March 10, at 9:45 A.M. Contributions in her memory may be made to Central Synagogue, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, MIRIAM
description: WASSERMAN - Miriam. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Miriam Wasserman. We extend our deepest sympathy to her entire family. William Ettelson, President Michael Roth, Secretary

title: 2 Banks in Italian City Are Close to Merger Deal
description: Banca Popolare di Brescia S.p.A. said yesterday that it was close to an agreement for a merger with a crosstown rival, Banca San Paolo di Brescia S.p.A., in a transaction that would be worth at least 2.2 trillion lire ($1.3 billion). The Italian banks, which said in December that they were in negotiations that could lead to a merger, may announce details of an agreement as soon as this week, according to an official of Popolare Brescia.

title: Giuliani Visits Michigan for a Fund-Raiser
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Mayor of New York City, endured a turbulent flight to Detroit this afternoon that included a mother soothing her crying child with a loud rendition of ''Mary Had a Little Lamb.'' Then he sat, buckled in the coach section, as the airplane toured the tarmac for 15 minutes. Then he took a 20-mile limousine ride to the Novi Hilton, which looms over a highway intersection and a Big Boy restaurant.

title: Ailing Lipinski to Skip World Championships
description: The Olympic figure skating champion Tara Lipinski, feeling fatigued and suffering from swollen glands in her neck, has withdrawn from the world figure skating championships that will be held early next month in Minneapolis, her agent said last night.

title: Laurie Beechman Dies at 44; Played Grizabella in 'Cats'
description: Laurie Beechman, the throbbing-voiced singer and actress who played Grizabella in the Broadway musical ''Cats'' for more than five years, died on Sunday at her home in White Plains, N.Y. She was 44.

title: The 'Butterfly' Puccini Wanted
description: In recent seasons, the New York City Opera has lured novelty seekers to its ''Madama Butterfly'' by presenting Puccini's original version, which foundered at its La Scala premiere in 1904. That edition had a certain scholarly appeal, and for listeners who had sat through countless ''Butterfly'' stagings, it offered a few surprises. It also, with the help of some deft scenic touch-ups, extended the life of Frank Corsaro's mid-1960's production, which is to be replaced next season.

title: By Design; A Handbag That's a Full Loaf
description: The handbag as status symbol is far from a new phenomenon, with some bags attaining classic status and others suddenly catching on. The bag that fashionable women have been snapping up in recent weeks is called the ''baguette'' and it is made by Fendi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREINDEL, ERIC
description: BREINDEL-Eric. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Eric Breindel: brilliant commentator on current events, passionate attorney, renowned correspondent, and a charismatic champion of Jewish causes. His dedication to those who needed help was as passionate as his devotion to communal service. He served with distinction in our Entertainment, Media & Communications Division, most recently as a major leader of the Humanitarian of the Year Award Dinner honoring Rupert Murdoch. To his parents Sonia and Dr. Joseph Breindel; to his sister, Dr. Monique Breindel; to his entire family; and the world of friends who will miss his caring voice, we extend our deepest sympathies. May you be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Edward Bleier/Marty Pompadur, Co-Chairs, Entertainment, Media & Communications Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: It Takes a Computer to Decode DNA
description: THE lumbering caterpillar, the strutting peacock, the little girl on a swing -- like all living creatures they are the antithesis of a machine. Yet at the core of their bodies' cells is an instruction tape, written in cold code, as precise and elegant as that in any machine tool or computer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUNCK, WILLIAM D.
description: STRUNCK-William D. Of Norwalk, Conn., on March 8, 1998. Survived by a daughter June Schultz, of Westbury, LI, two sons, Gary A. Strunck, and W. Gregg Strunck, six grandchildren and one great grandchild also survives. Funeral service 11 A.M. March 12 at First Presbyterian Church, Oenoke Ridge Road, New Canaan, Conn. Visitation F. Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main Street, New Canaan, CT, Wednesday from 3 to 8 P.M. Contributions may be made to The American Cancer Society.

title: Clinton Is Entree At City Hall Roast
description: Oh, what pleasure is a scandal for reporters putting on a spoof -- when the scandal is 200 miles away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOVER, GERTRUDE (HARRISON)
description: GOVER-Gertrude (Harrison). Formerly of Brooklyn, New York, on March 9, beloved wife of the late Alfred. Devoted mother of Eugene and Daniel. Dear sister of Eleanor Spingarn, dear grandmother of Jennifer, Michael and Adam. Services are at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey, Wednesday, March 11 at 2:00 PM.

title: Teach English to Deaf
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the conviction of John J. Royster for four violent attacks in 1996 referred incorrectly in some editions to the precedents. Mr. Royster was the second person in Manhattan -- not the first -- to be convicted of first-degree murder since capital punishment was reinstated in 1995.

title: Antitrust Concerns May Scuttle Merger Of 2 Arms Makers
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said today that the Government ''fundamentally opposed'' its planned purchase of the Northrop Grumman Corporation, suggesting that Federal regulators may believe that the consolidation among military suppliers has gone too far to maintain competition.

title: Students at Key School Rally Against Suharto : '60s-Style Campus Protesters
description: BANDUNG, Indonesia  Every day last week, hundreds of students of an elite university here assembled on an outdoor basketball court and demanded that the man who has ruled their country for more than 30 years step down.

title: Prosecutor Seeks to Reinstate Au Pair's Murder Conviction
description: Invoking the sanctity of the jury system, a prosecutor today asked the highest court in Massachusetts to reinstate the second-degree murder conviction of Louise Woodward, the 20-year-old former au pair who was found guilty of killing a baby boy in her care.

title: Metro Business; Planet Hollywood Plans Hotel Complex
description: Planet Hollywood International, confirming months of speculation, said yesterday that it and two partners would build a hotel and restaurant complex in Times Square.

title: As the Climate Shifts, Trees Can Take Flight
description: TIME and again in the remote past, entire forests and other ecological communities have migrated hundreds of miles over the landscape in response to big warmings and coolings of the earth's climate. For example, sugar maples, beeches, firs and spruces that flourished in the Middle Atlantic states moved farther north as the world warmed after the last ice age, while oaks and hickories from farther south moved up to take their place.

title: Accord on Term 'Concentration Camp'
description: Cooling a debate about using ''concentration camps'' in the title of an exhibition about the incarceration of Japanese-Americans in World War II, curators of the show and their critics agreed yesterday to display a prominent footnote to explain the term's origins and its shades of meaning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINLAN, THOMAS
description: QUINLAN-Thomas. Board President & driving force for Village East Towers, Inc. Died suddenly February 17, 1998. Tom was an Adjunct Professor at Baruch College and Pace University. Funeral services will take place at 9AM Thursday, March 12, 1998 at St. Emeric's R.C. Church (East 12 St) between Szold Place and Ave D.

title: WESTERN ATLAS BUYING 2 OILFIELD-SERVICE COMPANIES
description: Western Atlas Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Wedge Dia-Log Inc. and 3-D Geophysical Inc. for a total of $333 million, the latest in a string of deals in the oilfield services industry. Wedge Dia-Log, a unit of the Houston-based investment company Wedge Group Inc., helps energy companies gather information about rock structures. 3-D Geophysical, based in Littleton, Colo., provides seismic data for oil and gas companies and has annual revenue of about $100 million. Western Atlas will buy Wedge Dia-Log for $218 million in cash and 3-D Geophysical for $9.65 a share in cash, or about $115 million. Shares of 3-D Geophysical rose 50 cents yesterday, to $9.375. Shares of Western Atlas, which is based in Houston, fell $1.8125, to $77.9375.

title: Full of Sympathy for Women, His Heroines at Least
description: ANTON CHEKHOV

title: More Copies of U.S. Strategy Are Missing in Mob Stock Case
description: When a Federal district judge in Manhattan was told last December that the Government had accidentally made public a confidential document outlining its strategy in a case involving the Mafia's infiltration of Wall Street, he ordered defense lawyers who had obtained several copies to send them to his chambers immediately. They were returned.

title: It's Risky to Talk Tough on Kosovo
description: The Clinton Administration does not hesitate to express its moral outrage when a crisis unfolds in a place like Kosovo, a province of Serbia where 90 percent of the residents are ethnic Albanians.

title: Debate on Camps Goes Back to War; Before the Boer War
description: To the Editor:

title: Congressman Sues a Colleague Over Disclosing G.O.P. Talks
description: Representative John A. Boehner filed suit today against Representative Jim McDermott, accusing him of publicly disclosing an intercepted conference call involving Republican leaders.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Stalking the Video Pirates; A Special Squad Moves In on the Movie Counterfeiters
description: The tip came from a Manhattan movie theater usher. The detectives quickly put a tail on the culprit, a tall man with a backpack, tracking him to Brooklyn. They surreptitiously watched his house for days. Then, the detectives said, they made a series of undercover buys, building evidence to obtain a search warrant.

title: Mentally Ill in Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Blue Devils Are Ready For a Rude Welcome
description: The game was among the most memorable in modern National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament history, and helped catapult Duke to a second consecutive national championship. Six years later, Mike Krzyzewski expects the memory to haunt his current squad.

title: Hildegarde Does A New Number: 92
description: ''She's 92 and she ain't through,'' declared the cabaret singer known as HILDEGARDE, celebrating yet another birthday with a crowd at Arci's Place on Park Avenue South near 31st Street that included MARGARET WHITING, FRAN WARREN and MERCEDES ELLINGTON. DON DELLAIR, her manager, quoted Irving Berlin as saying he wrote dances for Fred Astaire but songs for Hildegarde and ALICE FAYE. And JULIE WILSON told about the first time she saw Hildegarde at the Persian Room at the Plaza.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'AGUANNO, ANTHONY
description: D'AGUANNO-Anthony. Age 60, died in Scottsdale, Arizona, on March 7, 1998. He was born in Queens, New York. He was a retired Managing Director with Smith Barney. Survivors include his wife, Mary Louise; sons, Anthony, Louis and Joseph: mother, Elizabeth and 2 grandchildren. Funeral Services will be held Wednesday, March 11, at 9:00 AM, at Our Lady of Joy Church, Carefree, AZ.

title: The Furies, Tamed by the Soloist
description: How often does a concert program annotator get an opportunity like this? Here was Orpheus, the conductorless chamber orchestra, at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, and the centerpiece of the concert was Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto, with its supposed connection to the Orpheus myth. Yet the program notes said nothing of that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPARD, RICHARD F.
description: SHEPARD-Richard F., Folksbiene Yiddish Theater mourns the passing of Richard F. Shepard, retired New York Times Cultural News Editor. Harold Platt Corey Breier Zypora Spaisman Elyse Frymer

title: Lucent to Offer A Network Tool
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. expanded its offerings in one of the telecommunications equipment industry's hottest areas yesterday as it announced that it would begin shipping a new product that can manage connections to different sorts of networks later this year.

title: 70,000 Neglect to File For Federal Tax Credit
description: More than 70,000 New Jerseyans who qualified for an Earned Income Tax Credit in their Federal returns last year passed up a total of $100 million in rebates, officials said yesterday. The credit, which is available to working families that earn less than $30,000, amounts to an average of $1,400 per eligible household, said Jayne O'Connor, a spokeswoman for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. Some families may not have known about the credit, Ms. O'Connor said, while others had incomes so low they were not required to file returns.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of Fred W. Friendly on Thursday reversed the sequence of the Presidential nominating conventions that figured in his 1964 decisions, as president of CBS News, about Walter Cronkite's role as anchor. After Mr. Cronkite had served as anchor for the Republican Convention, Mr. Cronkite removed him for the Democratic one. Mr. Cronkite was reinstated as anchor of both conventions in 1968.

title: Legislating a Patient's Rights
description: President Clinton went before the American Medical Association yesterday to ask its help in pushing his ''patient's bill of rights'' through Congress. The doctors should support the President's plea because it helps patients. Even better, they will probably support it because it helps them regain some of the prerogatives they have ceded to powerful insurance companies.

title: On My Mind; What Suharto Knew
description: Being a simple sort of man, I sometimes wonder: When the emissaries of President Clinton visit the President of Indonesia to talk about his country's economic disasters and how we can bail it out, do they ever ask him if he knows that his sons, daughters, in-laws and dearest friends stole the country bare and blind?

title: Sprewell Says He Had to Stand Up to Carlesimo
description: It was the portrayal of P. J. Carlesimo as a helpless victim at the mercy of a deranged basketball player that bothered Latrell Sprewell the most.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the blackout in Auckland, New Zealand, referred to the city incorrectly. Although it is New Zealand's largest city, it is not the capital; Wellington is.

title: Foster Mother Is Charged In Beating of a 2-Year-Old
description: By state law, child welfare workers cannot check the criminal records of people who want to become foster parents. So when Diana Cash, 34, applied to become a foster mother last year, case workers accepted her word and her signed, notarized statement that she had never been in trouble with the law.

title: Spotlighting Argentine Distinctiveness (and Sameness)
description: ''Sonidos de las Americas'' kept asking two questions last week: Is this Argentine music we are hearing, or is this music from Argentina? There is a difference.

title: Japanese Map A Plan to Aid An Ill Economy
description: Bowing to pressure from Washington and other Western governments, officials in Japan's ruling party strongly suggested this week that they are putting together a package of $80 billion or more to stimulate the nation's economy.

title: Commercial Real Estate; With Major Tenant Lost, Upgrading Plan Pays Off
description: In the summer of 1996, when Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield vacated 308,000 square feet of office space on 14 floors at 3 Park Avenue, Charles Steven Cohen was left with a half-empty building. Now, with the leasing of almost 162,000 square feet to a group of engineering associations, and with three leases awaiting signing, Mr. Cohen's building is almost fully booked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLDORF, JULIAN MARK
description: WALLDORF-Julian Mark. On March 10, 1998, beloved husband of Marion (nee Bernstein), loving father of Suzanne and Steven, father-in-law of Maryann, grandfather of Jenny and Karen Walldorf, Ann, Megan, and Nicholas Fountain, Charlotte and Jane Wiesenberg. A CPA for over 50 years, he was a former Senior Partner of H.J. Behrman & Co, and a native New Yorker. Funeral services Thursday 1 P.M. Westchester Reformed Temple, Scarsdale, NY. Please omit flowers.

title: Review/Fashion; At Hermes and Vuitton, the Outsider's Delicate Touch
description: What is a consultant's role, really? Martin Margiela and Marc Jacobs may have forever changed the expectations for designers brought in to energize static labels.

title: At the End of Life, A Blind Bureaucracy
description: In the growing debate on improving care of the dying, hospices are often viewed as a model solution. But an antiquated provision of the Medicare law and the Government's aggressive enforcement of it are preventing many people from getting hospice care and, essentially, driving others to die by the clock.

title: For New Sports, ESPN Rules as the X-treme Gatekeeper
description: AS of early January, Mike Nick was an unknown, just a stocky 21-year-old who could do crazy tricks like aerial spins and flips on short, fat planks that resemble miniature snowboards. Then he won the first-ever skiboarding contest at the winter X Games in Crested Butte, Colo., and he was mobbed by reporters. A dozen ringed him slopeside, and the announcer for ESPN -- which produces the X Games and broadcasts the alternative-sports Olympics on its two cable television channels -- informed a million-plus viewers that Nick, a junior at the State University of New York at Plattsburgh, was now ''the sensation of rotation.''

title: Hispanic Film Audience Grows Fastest
description: Hispanic moviegoers are the fastest-growing ethnic group among film audiences, an industry report says, and Hollywood studios have begun -- some say perhaps too slowly -- to make movies that appeal to them.

title: High Schools Fear Telling Colleges All About Johnny
description: The reports are coming in piecemeal: parents threatening high school counselors with lawsuits if their children fail to gain college acceptance; counselors taking out liability insurance; admissions officers complaining that a student's disciplinary or criminal past is not being reported to them.

title: Patients Evacuated After Hospital Fire
description: More than a dozen patients at Shore Memorial Hospital in Somers Point were evacuated yesterday after a fire in the hospital's rooftop air-conditioning system sent smoke pouring through the upper floors, hospital officials said.

title: CLINTON TESTIMONY BEFORE GRAND JURY IS BEING DISCUSSED
description: President Clinton's top lawyer and prosecutors investigating the Monica S. Lewinsky matter have recently opened discussions over whether Mr. Clinton would provide grand jury testimony, a senior Administration official and a lawyer involved in the inquiry said today.

title: Prime Time: Starting Out In L.A. at 25
description: Oh, to be 25 again, right? If you're any distance beyond that age of infinite possibility, ''Significant Others,'' a new drama that has its premiere tonight on Fox, will leave you with a twinge of envy. But you'll surely savor what you've gained with experience as well.

title: The Thrill of Risk, and Other Reasons Why
description: THE one time I almost died on a bicycle ride -- well, ''almost'' is a relative term -- I was on the road from A Luoi to Hue, in central Vietnam. This was three years ago, so there was no shrapnel involved or anything. I was just a guy on a bike, alone, riding a 60-mile stretch of lonely road that winds through mountains eastward to the seacoast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESNIKOFF, WENDY
description: MESNIKOFF-Wendy. Of Hastings on Hudson, NY. Beloved wife of Alvin. Devoted mother and mother-in-law of Nathaniel (deceased), Rachel and Steven, Joel, and Ann and Howard. Cherished grandmother of Jeremy, Aaron, Jacob and Sheina. Wendy received her M.A. in Human Development from the University of Chicago and her Ph.D. in Environmental Psychology from the Graduate Center of C.U.N.Y. Loving, kind, stalwart and courageous, she was loyal to her family and friends and loyal to the environmental causes to which she was devoted, both in her community of Hastings on Hudson, NY and beyond. Funeral 12 noon, Thurs., Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., (Saw Mill Exit 17), Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorials in support of environmental conservation may be made to the Nathaniel A. Mesnikoff Foundation, 35 Scenic Drive, Hastings on Hudson, N.Y. 10706.

title: Fraschilla Sees Bountiful Era Ahead for St. John's
description: St. John's is off to Chicago this morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOMRATH, DOROTHY GOADBY
description: WOMRATH - Dorothy Goadby died March 9. Wife of the late Robert Snyder Womrath. Mother of Seldon Sutton, Linda Palmer, Robert Womrath, Jr. and Mary Olson. Memorial service Essex Meadows, Essex, CT., March 14, 11:30 AM. Contributions may be made to St. John's Episcopal Church, Essex, CT 06426 or Lighthouse for the Blind.

title: Food Chain
description: Shelf Life of Soy Milk

title: Making Sure It's an Excellent Adventure
description: NOBODY seems exactly sure what ''adventure travel'' means -- bicycling through Provence? Dog sledding through the Yukon? But it has moved away from the fringe to become a travel industry mainstay. According to a recent Travel Industry Association of America report, 98 million Americans took an adventure-travel trip within the last five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ELIZABETH M.
description: WHITE-Elizabeth M., 83. Of Hilton Head Island and formerly of Darien died on Saturday, March 7th, at the Hilton Head Medical Center and Clinics. She was born in Pittsburgh, PA and was the daughter of the late J.D. and Elizabeth Schillenberg McGinnis. She moved to Hilton Head Island in 1997 from Darien, CT. She retired as President of Leahy Archives in New York. She was active in national archive associations. She was a member of Weeburn Country Club in Darien and Country Club of Hilton Head. She was a previous owner of the world famous yacht ''Bolero'' which held the record for the Bermuda Race for many years. She is survived by her husband of 33 years, Charles M. White and a brother, Joseph McGinnis of Bradenton, FL. Her first husband Emmett Leahy died in 1964. Services will be held later in Darien, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Heart Association. For more information, contact the Island Funeral Home of Hilton Head Island, S.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSE, KOONG, KAI
description: TSE-Koong-Kai, of New York City passed away peacefully on Monday, March 9, 1998, at the age of 91. Born in China and educated at the University of Shanghai, K.K. Tse was hired in 1927 by C.V. Starr, founder of the American International companies, as an accountant in Shanghai. Over a 70-year career with the group that became American International Group, Inc. (AIG), he was an extraordinarily dedicated and talented executive. At his death, he still held positions as Honorary Director of AIG and Chairman of American International Underwriters, Limited of Hong Kong. He will be greatly missed by his many friends and admirers at AIG, where his many accomplishments are a part of the company's history. We, the management and employees of AIG companies around the world, extend our deepest condolences to K.K.'s family, his wife Teh Ying Tse; son Stephen; daughters Cecelia, Angelina, Virginia and Helena; nine grandchildren; and 14 great-grandchildren. The family will receive friends on Wednesday, March 11 from 2:00-5:00 p.m. and 7:00 to 9:00 p.m. at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. The funeral will be held on Thursday, March 12 at the Campbell Funeral Home at 9:45 a.m., with the burial immediately following at Ferncliff Cemetery, Secor Road, Hartsdale, NY. The family has suggested donations may be made in K.K.'s name to Watchtower Bible & Tract Society, Inc., 25 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, NY 11201. M.R. Greenberg, Chairman American International Group, Inc. and the worldwide staff of AIG

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FILLAT, SYLVIA
description: FILLAT-Sylvia. On March 10, 1998 at age 83. Beloved mother of Andy and Patti. Cherished grandmother of Alex and Tori. Dear aunt of Arlene, Ruth Anne and Richard. Services private.

title: Tobacco Strikes Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Lloyd Bridges Is Dead at 85; Actor Starred in 'Sea Hunt'
description: Lloyd Bridges, whose acting career spanned more than five decades and whose sons, Jeff and Beau, also became well-known actors, died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COVINGTON, RUTH HAYNES
description: COVINGTON-Ruth Haynes. Beloved aunt of Betty Flint, Joseph Hayes, John Haynes and Denise Weaver. Passed away Feb 16, 1998

title: Russia's NATO Fears
description: To the Editor:

title: Ward Turns the Knicks Around
description: Charlie Ward has the whisper-soft voice of a librarian, and an everyman appearance that allows him to blend in on a city street.

title: $25 and Under; The Tastes of Armenia With a French Accent
description: KARRN PETROSIAN has a singular vision, at least as far as New York restaurants go. He wants to combine traditional Armenian ingredients and recipes with the discipline and techniques of French cooking. The result is Bistro Monk, a handsome little restaurant that opened about three months ago on East Fifth Street near Second Avenue.

title: The Maverick Who Sent America Outdoors
description: EL NINO visited Ventura, Calif., one evening recently, turning the legendary Pacific surf the color of cappuccino. The Ventura River had washed over and claimed Highway 101. Rain and gravity had their way with chunks of the coastal range. A wild air had enveloped Surfers' Point, known for its waist-high swells, transforming the beach into a chaotic tangle of driftwood beneath which displaced rattlesnakes lurked.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Profit Warnings Shrugged Off as Dow Climbs Over 8,600
description: Dismissing the previous day's selloff as an overreaction to the first-quarter profit warnings of some high-profile technology companies, investors pushed stocks back up into record territory yesterday and gave the Dow Jones industrial average its first close above 8,600.

title: TRANSWORLD ENDS ACQUISITION TALKS WITH HEALTHCALL
description: Transworld Healthcare Inc. said yesterday that it had ended talks on a possible acquisition of Healthcall Group P.L.C., a British health care services provider, valued at about $:58.5 million ($96.5 million). The New York-based Transworld, a home health care services company, which said last week that it was considering a bid for the British company, says it ''has no present intention'' to make a bid. Healthcall shares fell 12 pence, to 87.5, while shares of Transworld fell 50 cents, to $6, in Nasdaq trading. The acquisition would have bolstered Transworld's operations in Britain, where it provides medical services and supplies through 72 locations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRISCHMAN, BERNARD L. (BEN)
description: FRISCHMAN-Bernard L. (Ben). Beloved husband of the late Doris. Cherished and loving father of Judy Saunders and Laura Weisbrod. Caring grandfather of Irene, Randi, Mindi and Steven. Great grandfather of Tyler, Hanna, Ilana, Noah and Brittany. Devoted brother-in-law of Bernard Gartlir. Services Friday, March 13 10AM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn (Avenue J). 718-377-7300.

title: PG&E Lands Big Contract To Manage Refiner's Needs
description: The PG&E Corporation said yesterday that it had landed a wide-ranging, multimillion-dollar contract under which it will manage most of the energy needs of the Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corporation, one of the largest independent refiners in the nation.

title: TV Notes; Sports Magazine
description: Many a television show has sprung from a magazine -- Playboy, National Geographic and Sports Illustrated come to mind. What happens when a television show -- indeed, an entire network -- spawns a magazine?

title: Hindu Party in India Chosen for Coalition
description: The President of India asked the main Hindu nationalist party yesterday to form a coalition Government, stirring fears among many Indians, particularly the Muslim minority, that the party would dismantle the country's historical commitment to equality for people of all faiths.

title: How Cliches Get That Way: They're True and Nobody Listens
description: Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it. The more things change, the more they remain the same. For as you sow, ye are like to reap.

title: Magazine to Police Media Hires a Watchdog for Itself
description: In describing his new magazine, Content, as an aggressive mass market watchdog of the media industry, Steven Brill kept encountering the question, ''But who will be watching you?''

title: If You've Got the Nerve, South Africa Has the Test
description: SOUTH AFRICA is an extremist's paradise. That has been said before, but in this case, it's meant in the sporting sense. Nearly getting killed is big fun here. And big business.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, ROSA
description: ISRAEL - Rosa. The Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design and the Board of Directors of the Friends of Bezalel express profound sympathy to our esteemed founders Romie and Blanche Shapiro on the death of his sister, Rosa Israel, London, England. An Aishet Chayil, she was devoted to her family and Israel. We extend condolences to her children Elise and Shirley and the entire family. Harry Bauer, President Eillene Leistner, Executive V.P. Dr. Ran Sapoznik, Head of the Academy

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUNSCHWEIG, RICHARD
description: BRAUNSCHWEIG - Richard, 62. Died March 9, 1998, Greenport, NY. He will be greatly missed by his friends and family, especially his loving brother Robert, sister-inlaw Willi; niece Diana and nephews Julius and Marc; Aunts Muriel and Ruth; and his dear long time friend Frank Lawrence. Memorial arrangements pending.

title: The Chef
description: SOMETIMES when you start fooling around with a classic dish, all sorts of unexpected possibilities open up. This dish began when I wanted to make a different kind of risotto to serve with fish, one that wasn't weighed down with a lot of eggs, butter and cream. I wanted a lemony rice, with a little bit of body. Instead of merely flavoring it with lemon, I aimed for a saucelike base to hold the rice together.

title: Traditions Through Modern Filters
description: The National Song and Dance Company of Mozambique billed its program as dancing that makes the earth move. The company, which performed tonight at the Victoria Theater at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here, certainly received an impassioned standing ovation from the audience that packed this new dance space.

title: Bike Racing Was Rage in Old New York
description: To the Editor:

title: With Prayer, Chants and Rock-and-Roll
description: Art makes unlikely alliances, especially at the annual Tibet House benefit concerts. Punk-rock, Tibetan folk songs, Minimalism, Buddhist chants, gospel, protest songs and Beat poetry shared the stage at Carnegie Hall on Monday night for the 10th annual Monlam Great Prayer Festival, which is named after a traditional Tibetan New Year celebration.

title: Metro Business; Broadcast Company Moving to New York
description: Adding a new wrinkle to Manhattan's position as a center of broadcasting, a radio company in Washington that plans to use satellites to broadcast to motorists across the nation will move its staff and studios to 1221 Avenue of the Americas, at 48th Street, in a deal backed by tax breaks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEAHAN, MARGARET C. (NEE MCGUIRE)
description: SHEAHAN-Margaret C. (nee McGuire). On March 9th, 1998. Formerly of New York City. Beloved wife of Malachi, mother of Kathleen M., Malachi G., Margaret M., and Constance M. Sister of Mary Curran. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Memorial mass 10 A.M. Wednesday, March 11, 1998, at St Catherine of Sienna Church, Mountain Lakes, N.J.

title: Kovalev Appreciates Communication With Coach About Benching
description: There sat Aleksei Kovalev, head down and shoulders slumped, stewing at the end of the Rangers' bench.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, HENRY A.
description: POLLACK-Henry A. On March 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Loving uncle of Marcia Chartow and Dorothy Fishman. Services Wednesday 12:15pm at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 6 Iraqis Who Aided C.I.A. Are Ordered Deported From U.S.
description: Six Iraqis who worked in concert with the Central Intelligence Agency in failed plots against Saddam Hussein have been declared threats to American national security in a court ruling so secret that their lawyers cannot read it.

title: A Century Marked
description: MADAME CHIANG KAISHEK, the American-educated woman who used her English and her charm to rally Western nations in her husband's fight against the Communists, celebrated her 100th birthday yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, WILLIAM S.
description: THOMAS-William S. On March 7th, 1998. Died peacefully in the presence of family, at age 85, at the Sherwood Oaks hospice unit in Wexford, PA. Mr. Thomas, who previously resided in Garden City, New York and Alachua, Florida, was a graduate and Trustee Emeritus of Dickinson College. Mr. Thomas had specialized in actuarial work throughout a 39 year career with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. He retired from Metropolitan Life in 1977 as a Senior Vice President (Group Insurance and Pension Operations) and as a member of the corporate executive office. Mr. Thomas was a fellow of the Society of Actuaries. He held memberships in The Union League Club of New York and The Cherry Valley Club in Garden City. He is survived by his three sons and daughters-in-law Anthony and Marcia Thomas of Evanston, IL, William and Kathryn Thomas of Rochester, N.Y., and Richard and Sarah Thomas of Pittsburgh, PA; 7 grandchildren: Adam, Andrew, William III, David, Matthew, Ian and Kathleen, and two great grandchildren, Brandon and Jackie. Calling hours will be on Friday, March 13, from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, Inc., 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, N.Y. 11530. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated St. Anne's Church, 35 Dartmouth Street, Garden City, on Saturday, March 14, 9:15 A.M. Interment will follow at Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Mr. Thomas' name to Dickinson College, Alumni Fund, Carlisle, PA. 17013.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERSON, HAROLD
description: BERSON-Harold. It is with great sadness that we extend our condolences to our Partner and Friend, Barry Berson, his wife Roni, his mother Marion and his sister and brother-in-law Mindy and Sandy on the loss of their beloved husband and father. Harold Berson was a man of uncommon grace, wisdom, charm and genuine warmth. It was a privilege to have known him. We feel enriched that he touched our lives. Doctors and Staff Daniel Maklansky, MD Howard Grunther, MD Jerold Kurzban, MD Burton Cohen, MD Jerald Zimmer, MD Alain Hyman, MD
