description: THIS is a true story that Dr. John W. Rowe, the president of Mount Sinai Medical Center, likes to tell friends:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNEGAN, FRANK E. JR.
description: FINNEGAN-Frank E. Jr. of Port Washington, Mar. 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Dorothy (nee Nuss). Loving father of Timothy, Michael and his wife Margaret, and Patrick. Cherished grandfather of Christopher, Daniel and Matthew. Dear brother of Elizabeth Frederick of Cincinnati, Ohio. Survived also by a niece and two nephews and many friends. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Thursday from 3 to 5 and 7 to 9pm. Mass of Christian burial will be held on Friday at 9:45 am in St. Aloysius RC Church, Great Neck with interment to follow in Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Covenant House, PO Box 731, Times Square Station, NYC, 10108 appreciated.

title: Liquefied Roads to Chocolate Heaven
description: A LANGUID hot-chocolate break was once distinctly European, a mainstay of French, Belgian, Austrian and Spanish pastry shops and coffeehouses. But now, New Yorkers have taken this civilized treat and made it their own.

title: Eating Well; Puffing the Claims, if Not the Cereal
description: BREAKFAST cereals take up both sides of the aisle in many supermarkets these days, and the array can be bewildering.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Cozy Familiarity Dissolves Into an Unsettling Future
description: It was a risk, beginning the lovely new film of Virginia Woolf's ''Mrs. Dalloway'' in a World War I foxhole. Woolf began more fragrantly, with the heroine blissfully going out for a walk on a heavenly spring day to buy massive bouquets, anticipating her evening party and recalling her childhood.

title: Hindu Party Asked to Form A Government For India
description: The President of India asked the main Hindu nationalist party yesterday to form a coalition Government, stirring fears among many Indians, particularly the Muslim minority, that the party would dismantle the country's historic commitment to equality for people of all faiths.

title: Government Paved Way for Microsoft's Success; Tools That We Need
description: To the Editor:

title: House G.O.P. Content to Make Ripples
description: Three years after sweeping into office on their Contract With America, House Republicans are acting as if they now have a contract with their campaign consultants: to keep the revolution on hold.

title: For Some Parents, Day Of Crisis Management
description: For some unwitting parents who showed up at public schools throughout New York City yesterday with youngster in tow, it was the kind of morning that their children love but they hate: a canceled day of school.

title: At Long Last, Love
description: The man sat alone on a sofa for two at the Waldorf-Astoria. The pianist and singer DARYL SHERMAN was singing love songs. Champagne and caviar were waiting.

title: Restaurants; Where the Romantic Decor Is the Draw
description: THE last time The Times looked at the Box Tree it was a pretentious place serving fancy, not very good Continental food for $78 a person, prix fixe. That was six years ago. Since then there has been a lengthy strike, which ended last month in a victory for the workers. You might think that would have improved the restaurant.

title: Man With Past Speculates on Future; Without Renters in Place, Macklowe Plans a Manhattan Office Tower
description: Two weeks after wrestling away a property on Madison Avenue near 42d Street from a pack of rival developers, Harry Macklowe was on his knees, poring over sketches for a new skyscraper.

title: Philosophy Isn't Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Retro Look To Madness: Amateurism
description: AS we prepare for one of the truly fun days in American sport, the first Thursday of the annual March Madness, we must give thanks to the National Basketball Association for its contribution to the merriment.

title: Everyone Wants to Do Something About Tobacco, but Few Agree on What
description: Normally, when Congress considers legislation that would bring on big changes in society, there are two main sides: those who want the bill to pass because they favor change, and those who hope to block the measure to preserve the status quo.

title: Multicultural Reading List Considered in San Francisco
description: To increase the cultural diversity of the curriculum, the San Francisco school board is considering a plan to require that at least half the books assigned to every high school student in the district be by authors of color.

title: The Minimalist; A Great Vinaigrette Goes Beyond Acid and Oil
description: IT'S hard to imagine five minutes better spent in the kitchen than those making vinaigrette, the closest thing to an all-purpose sauce. At its most basic, vinaigrette is acid and oil, salt and pepper, plus additional flavors as desired. But behind this apparent simplicity lies a web of questions. Which acid? Which oil? What else should be added? How to combine it all?

title: Before Getting Psyched, Try Getting Prepped
description: AS extreme sports like snowboarding have gained visibility and even Olympic credentials, more and more neophytes are taking to the slopes, the cliffs and the water to test their mettle.

title: In Welfare Reform, Smaller Is Better
description: Gov. George Pataki is moving too fast in his drive to root out welfare abuse in New York. His proposal to phase out cash aid for an entire family when a parent fails to participate in workfare does not adequately protect innocent children. The ability of county welfare agencies to administer such potentially harsh sanctions is unproven. The best way to find out is to scale down the Governor's plan, limiting it initially to a few counties that would be closely monitored and evaluated.

title: Simms and Parcells May Reunite
description: Channel 2 is close to announcing that Phil Simms and Bill Parcells will reprise their roles as the co-stars of a Sunday morning Jets program that will be shown before CBS's hourlong National Football League pre-game show. A Channel 2 spokeswoman said Simms and Parcells had yet to sign their contracts.

title: Her Dog Can Surf, All Right, but What About Her Students?
description: AMERICANS love the notion of surfing far more than they actually love to surf, which is how it is possible for the sport to occupy a central place in the mythology of popular culture. In reality, it's less popular than jumping out of airplanes or having paint shot at you by co-workers toting assault weapons.

title: Moab's Natives Struggle With an Overabundance of Wildlife
description: IT is called a sky anchor, and when folded is about the size and heft of a silk handkerchief. Will Oxx throws one skyward as he runs and leaps off an orange sandstone cliff, free falling toward the rocky canyon bottom, a quick 440 feet below.

title: Immigrants Cast Shadow Over the Danish Election
description: From cradle to grave, welfare beckons here, and so do the tax collectors. From maternity leave on full pay to subsidized day care, from hospital beds to classrooms, the Danish compact endures: Europe's highest taxes in return for Europe's most vaunted welfare state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEECHMAN, LAURIE
description: BEECHMAN-Laurie. The brilliance of her voice and the beauty of her soul will be forever cherished by those of us who were blessed to have known her. Janis and Alan Menken

title: Sports of The Times; Players' Stonewalling Is Childlike Behavior
description: THE rampaging National Hockey League players and their shut-my-mouth teammates who represented, if that's the word, the United States in the Winter Olympics last month in Japan may on occasion understandably possess a skewed view of right and wrong.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Counselors are becoming afraid of telling the full truth. They'll write that Johnny took these courses and was a great student but they won't tell you that Johnny burned down the gym.''

title: $488 Million Extension Of E-Z Pass Is Approved
description: State transportation authorities agreed yesterday to approve a $488 million contract to install the E-Z Pass toll collection service on the New Jersey Turnpike, the Garden State Parkway and the Atlantic City Expressway.

title: Hilliard's Return From Neck Surgery Buoys Giants Camp
description: The big-play receiver the Giants have wanted to lure to Giants Stadium all winter finally arrived today. Giants fans will recognize the name: Ike Hilliard, last year's top draft pick.

title: Public TV's 'Arthur' again cavorts with the commercial realm.
description: IT almost sounds like a riddle a child would ask: What do you get when you cross an aardvark with a beverage brand, a television network and a magazine?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, NATHAN
description: OWEN-Nathan. Formerly of Greenwich, Connecticut and Basin Harbor, Vermont, Mr. Owen died at home in Palm City, Florida on March 9, 1998. Devoted husband of Janet, beloved father of Patricia, David and Lorinda, and adoring grandfather of nine, great grandfather of one. Mr. Owen was the Founding Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of General Signal Corporation, before which he was a pioneering venture capitalist with J.H. Whitney and Co. Donations to Hospice.

title: Court-Martial Ends With Talk of Character
description: Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney is an Army recruiting poster come to life, a modern Horatio Alger story and an embodiment of Martin Luther King Jr.'s dream, his lawyer said today, pleading for acquittal at a court-martial that illuminated the military's awkward integration of female soldiers.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day yesterday about the growth of the AT&T Corporation's outsourcing business, AT&T Solutions, misstated the unit's revenue. It had revenue of about $650 million last year, not $3.1 billion, and expects revenue of about $1 billion this year, not $5 billion.

title: When Manners Offend
description: To the Editor:

title: SPECIAL TODAY: Adventure Sports
description: Whether cliff-diving in Moab, Utah, or biking in Vietnam, Americans are leaving the beaten path in search of something extra. A look at the sports, the risks and the reasons.

title: Clinton Make Plea for Congress To Use Its (Short) Time Wisely
description: President Clinton took a poke at Congress today, noting seven times in a brief speech that in the schedule set by Republicans, legislators have just 70 working days left this year, even though it is only March.

title: A Good Policy: Check Your Insurance Coverage Before You Leap
description: BILLY BASCHNAGEL, an insurance broker in Austin, Tex., who specializes in coverage for high-risk activities, has a very clear idea of the wrong time for participants in adventure sports to start thinking about insurance.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Atlanta at Crossroads Of Gas Price Paradise
description: From a distance it seems a mirage, like the gauzy image of a Saharan oasis in one of those French Foreign Legion films. But as one drives closer, the letters and numbers on the sign at the Crown gas station near the intersection of Buford Highway and Interstate 285 sharpen into focus, making it clear that this is no illusion: ''Regular -- .79 9//10 .''

title: Consumed by a Blaze He Set, McDougal Grasped His Fate
description: The Whitewater investigation might never have come to life had James B. McDougal not been burning trash outside his cabin in rural Arkansas on a day when he was also burning with anger at Bill and Hillary Clinton.

title: At Pivotal Time, Suharto Gets a 7th Term
description: With shouts of ''Agree! Agree!'' electoral delegates leapt from their seats on Tuesday and acclaimed President Suharto as their leader for a seventh term, after 32 years of near-absolute power here in the world's fourth-most-populous nation.

title: Newark Ends a Program to Buy Back Guns
description: The Newark Police Department concluded its monthlong program to buy back weapons from local gun owners today, announcing that it had collected a total of 653 firearms at a cost of $47,725.

title: Business Travel; Flying may get more complicated as airlines continue to tighten restrictions for carry-on bags.
description: FOLLOWING changes by Northwest Airlines and Southwest Airlines, Delta has tightened its carry-on baggage rules, which may make flying more complicated for business travelers.

title: Safety-Kleen Ends Accord
description: After failing to receive enough shareholder support on Monday, the Safety-Kleen Corporation said today that it had ended an agreement to be acquired for $1.58 billion by a group led by the Philip Services Corporation and would begin talks with Laidlaw Environmental Services Inc., a rival bidder.

title: U.S.O.C. Backs Off Threats in Vandalism Case
description: The United States Olympic Committee is not ready to announce specific punishment for the room-trashing episode involving American hockey players and appears to be moving away from threats, hoping for a settlement in the form of a group apology and a significant payment by team members.

title: Trying for the Top of the World One Last Time
description: TOM WHITTAKER, a 49-year-old Welshman who now lives and teaches in Prescott, Ariz., has set world-altitude records twice for amputees in the Himalayas. In 1989, he hiked and climbed 220 miles, reaching an altitude of 24,000 feet on Everest. In 1995, he got to 27,500 feet, only 1,528 feet from the top of the world. He has never reached the summit.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Overcoming Obstacles by Learning to Cook Well
description: TENDER AT THE BONEGrowing Up at the TableBy Ruth Reichl282 pages. Random House. $23.

title: Food Stuff
description: Recipes From Cyberspace And Other Food Matters

title: Apprentices Sample Life Of Doctors In Villages
description: Dr. Stephen Genereaux, a doctor in this remote village, listened to Doris Berry's heartbeat. He instructed his young assistant, Jessie Reynolds, to put up her stethoscope and do the same. Mrs. Berry, who is 90, did not mind the extra set of hands; the examination room was so tiny that the three were already crowded together.

title: Yale Gets The Top Seeding
description: Having finished the regular season with a flourish with victories at Union and Rensselaer, Yale gained the first seeding in the ECAC playoffs for the first time since the tournament began 36 years ago. Yale will be host to No. 10 St. Lawrence in a two-of-three-game series beginning Friday.

title: Belgrade TV Makes Serbs Furious At Albanians
description: With images of the widows of four Serbian policemen weeping inconsolably at the funerals of their husbands broadcast repeatedly on Government television, President Slobodan Milosevic has stirred the deep anti-Albanian feelings in Serbia.

title: Smallpox Vaccine Urged to Fight Terrorist Attacks
description: In a major turnaround, the scientist who led the campaign that eradicated smallpox and eliminated the need for vaccination worldwide now says the United States should resume making the vaccine to deal with the threat of biological warfare.

title: At Work and Funeral, Lottery Workers Struggle With Their Grief
description: Dozens of state employees returned tentatively to the scene of a nightmare that none wished to relive, arriving for work this morning at the Connecticut Lottery for the first time since an angry colleague stabbed and shot to death four of the lottery's top managers.

title: The Cleansing Power of Free TV
description: Blocking campaign finance reform seems to be the Senate's sport of choice these days. Just a few weeks ago the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, succeeded in scuttling -- temporarily, we hope -- a strong reform bill sponsored by Senators John McCain of Arizona and Russell Feingold of Wisconsin. Now, in a perverse sequel, the Senate Appropriations Committee is expected to approve legislation prohibiting the Federal Communications Commission from adopting a rule that would require radio and television stations to provide political candidates with free air time.

title: Chicago Fights Off the Elbows
description: BULLS 106, HEAT 91

title: Lawmaker Votes in Congress After Conviction for a Crime
description: Representative Jay C. Kim, the California Republican sentenced on Monday for accepting illegal campaign contributions, walked onto the House floor today and, to the surprise of his colleagues, cast his first vote as a man convicted of a Federal crime.

title: Big Acquisition In South Africa
description: RMB Holdings Ltd. said today that it would buy the financial services units of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa Ltd. for 46 billion rand ($9.2 billion) in stock, creating South Africa's largest company by market value.

title: Justice Department Names 'Point Man' on Microsoft Case
description: The Justice Department has hired Jeffrey Blattner, a former chief counsel of the Senate Judiciary Committee, as special counsel for information technology, a sign that the department's confrontation with Microsoft may be escalating.

title: Clinton Accepts Apology From Maker of First Sex Life Inquiry
description: It was a brief and mild statement that underscored but left unspoken a thousand could-have-beens about the Clinton Presidency.

title: Corrections
description: A credit for an illustration in Sunday Styles this week with an article about luxury Swiss watches was omitted. The artist was Susan Saas.

title: Government Paved Way for Microsoft's Success; Robber-Baron Image
description: To the Editor:

title: Eleanor Shuman, 87, Passenger on the Titanic
description: Eleanor Shuman, who was too young to remember more than the screams but recalled them vividly for more than 85 years, died on Saturday at a hospital near her home in Elgin, Ill. She was 87 and one of the last half-dozen survivors of the sinking of the Titanic.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a March 7 letter on Social Security incorrectly said that the system pays a monthly death benefit of $255 to a surviving spouse. The spouse receives a one-time payment of $255.

title: TV Notes; Little Screen For Nymphet?
description: Depending on the outcome of negotiations between the French film studio Pathe and the premium cable network Showtime, ''Lolita,'' the big-budget, high-profile remake of the Vladimir Nabokov novel and the Stanley Kubrick film may get its first American exposure on television, not in theaters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNAPP, GEORGE LEO, LTC, USAAFR, RET.
description: KNAPP - George Leo, LTC, USAAFR, Ret. Of Bristol, CT died on March 8, 1998. Born in the Bronx on September 25, 1919, he served as a navigator during WWII & was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross among other citations. He is survived by his loving wife, Rosemary Shavel Knapp; his daughter, Kathi of Canyon Lake, CA; his sons, G. David of Goffstown, NH and Jason of NYC and his sister, Dorothea Cooney of Somers; his brothers, V. Edward, Sr. and John and other sister, Muriel are deceased. A mass of Christian burial will be held at 10A.M. on Thursday at the Church of St. Matthew, Bristol, CT. The family will receive visitors at O'Brien Funeral Home, Forestville, CT., on Wednesday evening from 5 to 8P.M.

title: When Manners Offend
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; Sympathy for the Devil
description: Time's cover story this week on ''Primary Colors'' offers an incendiary hypothesis about the movie's Bill Clinton clone, Jack Stanton.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: TV Notes; Curfew in 'South Park'?
description: Tomorrow the Federal Communications Commission is expected to put its stamp of approval on the ratings system being used by most television networks to alert parents to sex, violence or foul language and on plans to enable parents eventually to block out offensive programs by using a V-chip.

title: Treasuries Rise Slightly as Investors Await Retail Sales Report
description: The prices of Treasury securities were only slightly higher yesterday, as oil prices stemmed their downward slide, removing one of the bond market's most recent sources of support. Trading volume was again light.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, TRUDE
description: GRUBER-Trude. Loyal friend, astute social worker and family therapist, adoring and devoted caretaker of Bianca, Daisy, Jason, Muffie and Maggie; with a passionate joie de vivre. Died on March 5, 1998 in Easthampton, New York. Memorial contributions may be made to the Animal Rescue Fund (ARF) of Easthampton, New York. A Memorial Service will be held Tuesday, March 31 at 1 PM at Congregation Ansche Chesed, 251 W. 100th St., New York, NY. With all our love, your family of friends.

title: Arkady N. Shevchenko, 67, A Key Soviet Defector, Dies
description: Arkady N. Shevchenko, who stunned the world two decades ago when he became the highest-ranking Soviet diplomat to defect to the United States, died on Feb. 28 in obscurity in his suburban home in Bethesda, Md. He was 67.

title: School Boards Trying To Block Charter Schools
description: Local school boards are trying to block the opening of more than half of the 23 charter schools around the state that are scheduled to begin operating in September, state education officials said yesterday.

title: Robert Wilson Adds Theater To 'Lohengrin'
description: Robert Wilson's theatrical reach, so varied and eclectic, has in recent years turned to standard operatic repertory. Here he applies (or imposes, according to your taste) the magical images and glacial time continuums so memorable in ''Einstein on the Beach'' or ''Time Rocker'' to the likes of ''Pelleas et Melisande'' and ''Madama Butterfly.'' On Monday, it was ''Lohengrin'' at the Metropolitan Opera, and in Wagner Mr. Wilson seems to have met his match.

title: Newspapers End Network For Web Sites
description: The New Century Network, a consortium of newspaper sites on the World Wide Web that was created less than three years ago by the newspaper industry as a bulwark against potential on-line competitors like Microsoft, America Online and the phone companies, was dissolved on Monday,

title: A New Finalist For Little Caesars
description: As one finalist withdrew from a review for the account of the Little Caesars pizza chain, with billings estimated at $30 million to $40 million, another was added.

title: Israeli Troops Kill 3 Arabs at Checkpoint, Setting Off New Clashes
description: Israeli soldiers shot and killed three Palestinians at a checkpoint between the West Bank and Israel today, setting off street clashes in Hebron and raising fears of a new round of violence that could further set back peace efforts.

title: Pataki Seeks Stricter Limits On Drinking And Driving
description: Gov. George E. Pataki proposed legislation today that would toughen the state's drunken-driving standards, lowering the blood-alcohol level at which a driver is considered legally drunk to 0.08 percent from 0.10 percent.

title: INSIDE
description: Crude Burial in Kosovo

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREWS, PHILADELPHIA
description: ANDREWS-Philadelphia Masters Carpenter, 76, of Cambridge, Massachusetts, died of complications of cancer on March 7, 1998. Born in Fargo, N.D., she was a graduate of Radcliffe College, of which she was an active alumna. She was active also in civic and community affairs until her death. She is survived by her two sons, Richard Hale, Jr. and David Gage, a daughter, Philadelphia AndrewsBroughton; a brother, Harry Gage Carpenter, and five grandchildren. A memorial gathering will be held March 14 at the Episcopal Divinity School chapel in Cambridge. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe College, 10 Garden Street, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02138 or to the VISION Foundation, Inc., 818 Mount Auburn Street, Watertown, Massachusetts 02172.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: For Adventures of the Mind, Establish Base Camp in an Easy Chair
description: I HAVE a thrilling early memory of nearly freezing to death and then falling off a mountain. It happened on a hot, humid day in Heidelberg, Germany, in mid-summer of 1947. I was 13, on my way north with my father and younger brother from a vacation in the Austrian Alps. We had had an adventurous time. With two local guides, I had climbed high enough in the Alps to pick edelweiss, the flower that grows only above a certain altitude. Leaving the mountain resort we had stayed at, our Studebaker's brakes failed at a hairpin turn. We got out in time, but the car went bouncing down the side of a steep ravine and came to rest at the bottom. A farmer dragged it out with his steam tractor and arranged to have it towed across the border to the German town of Garmisch-Partenkirchen. While waiting in Garmisch, we rode a cable car to the top of the Zugspitze, at nearly 10,000 feet the highest peak in Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, BRIAN
description: O'NEILL-Brian. On March 10, 1998. Survived by loving nieces and nephews and a brother-in-law. Friends may call at the Riley Mortuary, Inc. 110 Division St, Amsterdam, N.Y. today, 5-8 P.M. Mass of Christian burial, 9:15 A.M. Thursday, St Mary's Church, 158 E. Main St, Amsterdam. Interment St Mary's Cemetery.

title: DAVOX TO BUY ANSWERSOFT FOR $85.4 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The Davox Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Answersoft Inc. for about $85.4 million in stock to expand in the call-center software market. Davox, which had 1997 revenue of $76.8 million, provides call-center software and services for telemarketing and other companies, while Answersoft, based in Richardson, Tex., specializes in inbound call-center software for customers, including Compaq Computer and Gateway 2000. Davox said it expected to take a charge in the second quarter of 1998 related to the transaction, which will be accounted for as a tax-free pooling-of-interests. Shares of Davox fell $1.25, to $33.625.

title: Icon Shuts 2 On-Line Magazines And Dismisses 12 Staff Members
description: After failing to find a buyer for its two electronic magazines, Word and Charged, Icon CMT shut down both publications on Monday and dismissed their 12 full-time editorial staff members.

title: Officially, Ha-Ha
description: Gov. GEORGE E. PATAKI may regret having asked for a meeting with reporters and editors from The Christian Science Monitor.

title: Stepdaughter Accuses Sandinista Chief of Sex Abuse
description: Twenty years ago, Daniel Ortega Saavedra was already an international icon of the left, leading the Sandinista revolution that brought him to power in 1979. At the same time, Mr. Ortega's stepdaughter says now, he began sexually abusing her, then 11, in a pattern of mistreatment that she says continued until this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERSON, SALLY (NEE SCHACKMAN)
description: MEYERSON-Sally (nee Schackman). Age 97, at the VA Care Unit in West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. Veteran of naval service in World War I. Beloved wife of the late Jesse Meyerson, loving mother of Marilyn Goodman and Florence and Jack Scheinman, adored grandmother of Susan Scheinman, William Goodman, David Scheinman, Marjorie and Stewart Johnson, Elizabeth and John Lock. Great grandmother of Lawrence Jordan Johnson. Services are on Friday, March 13, at 11 A.M. at Old Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Gardens, Queens. Donations may be made to The Autism Society of America.

title: By The Book; New World Fare: Yuca to Paw Paw Slaw
description: AFTER reading ''Norman's New World Cuisine'' (Random House, $50), I still don't have a grasp of exactly what New World cuisine is. Yes, it includes ingredients found in the New World like yuca, coconuts and shrimp. Yes, there are heavy Latin and Caribbean influences. And yes, the cuisine is geared toward a tropical climate. But where did dishes like Vietnamese soft spring rolls with paw paw slaw and peanut dipping sauce come from? Is that Norman's part?

title: Gliding Serenely Across a Pond, or Paddling for Your Life
description: I GET a little fatigued listening to some of my adventuring pals -- whether daredevil whitewater kayakers, strong-armed polar women or round-the-world sailors -- mock sea kayaking as boring. A quasi-sport, they call it, requiring fitness levels equivalent to what's needed for riding a rocking chair on the front porch.

title: USA NETWORKS RAISES ITS BID FOR TICKETMASTER BY 17%
description: USA Networks Inc. agreed to buy Ticketmaster Group for about $29.70 a share in stock, or $400 million, raising its bid 17 percent after Ticketmaster executives and investors protested that the first offer was too low. In October, USA Networks chairman, Barry Diller, offered $25.30 a share, or $340 million, in an unsolicited bid for the half of Ticketmaster that USA Networks does not own. Under the new agreement, USA Networks will swap 0.563 share for each Ticketmaster share, up from 0.506 share. Mr. Diller wants to use Ticketmaster, the nation's largest seller of tickets to concerts and other events, to help his expansion into on-line shopping. Shares of Ticketmaster rose $1.625, to $28, while USA Networks shares fell $1.50, to $51.25.

title: 1998 N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT -- Team No. 64, Who Are You?; With Unlikely Upset, Prairie View (13-16) Finds Itself in the N.C.A.A.'s
description: It is the second-oldest institution of higher learning in the Lone Star State, and for 128 years has lived up to its motto of ''Proud Producers of Productive People.'' It has turned out more African-American three-star generals than any other school in the country and is renowned for its engineering school.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOPPELMAN, MORRIS
description: KOPPELMAN - Morris. Eight years since you left us. So dearly remembered, so sadly missed. Nina

title: These Days, Every Shoe Is a Specialist
description: For every sport, every terrain and virtually every season, there is a shoe. You'll find running shoes for sunny days, rainy days and muddy, rocky or paved roads; bicycling shoes for indoors and out, and shoes for rock jocks and aquatic athletes, even for grinders. (Don't ask, you'll find out.) Sport shoes come in a variety of colors and shapes, and with varying degrees of coolness, depending on the eye, and the activity, of the beholder. Here is a sampling of the latest. Elaine Louie

title: G.O.P. Pushes To Overhaul Finance Law
description: Republican leaders in the House proposed a compromise today to break a long stalemate over how to update the legislation governing the financial services industry, offering a bill that would eliminate many of the barriers that separate banks, securities firms and insurers.

title: Unhappy Campers Invent Cool Stuff
description: MICHAEL HOLMAN'S first invention, after he quit making precision parts for the space shuttle, was a method to redeem coupons from television advertisements by using a remote control and a grocery-store smart card. It flopped because it was just too complicated.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ADVANCE AUTO PARTS, Roanoke, Va., an auto parts retailer, agreed to sell a majority stake to Freeman Spogli & Co., New York, a private investment firm, for undisclosed terms.

title: Chile's Rightist Ex-Dictator Retires as Army Chief
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, whose 17 years as dictator of Chile were marked by widespread political killings, disappearances and torture, stepped down today as commander in chief of the country's armed forces.

title: Devils' Unbeaten Streak Hits 12 in a Defensive Deadlock
description: After ending their season series with the Rangers without losing a game, the Devils are now a game away from going unbeaten against the Flyers. The Devils surmounted the emotion arising from Roger Neilson's coaching debut with Philadelphia and fought the Flyers to a 2-2 deadlock tonight at Core States Center.

title: NATIONAL CITY BANCSHARES IN $56 MILLION DEAL FOR BANK
description: National City Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Community First Financial Inc., a bank holding company, for more than $56 million in stock. National City, based in Evansville, Ind., is a banking company with assets of $1.5 billion and 44 sites in Indiana, Illinois and Kentucky. Community First, based in Maysville, Ky., has assets of about $150 million. It is the parent company of Community First Bank N.A. in Maysville, Ky., and Community First Bank in Warsaw, Ky. Under the agreement, National City will pay 1.44 million shares of its common stock. Shares of National City Bankshares rose $1, to $40.

title: Op-Art
Paid Notice: Deaths  JERNIGAN, RAYMOND
description: JERNIGAN-Raymond. The Intimate Apparel Square Club members deeply mourn the loss and smile of Ray, our one-time Santa Claus for our children at the Rusk Institute. His personality and love will remain forever in our hearts. Barry Ross, President IASC

title: It's a Control Thing: Vermont vs. Cell Phone Towers
description: As new towers for cellular phone traffic have cropped up by the thousands from coast to coast, so have the spats, the lawsuits and the local rebellions, from California to New Jersey to Florida.

title: Comeback Version of Graf Appears as Dominant as Ever
description: She is back with a vengeance and without mercy. It is business as usual for Steffi Graf, who has not lost her touch when the time comes to dissect her opponent.

title: Vallone, Attacking Pataki, Begins Race for Governor
description: Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the New York City Council, declared his candidacy for governor yesterday, portraying Gov. George E. Pataki as an ambitious yet drifting chief executive who has overseen a stagnant economy, deteriorating schools and a troubled health care system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, MARY L.
description: MURPHY-Mary L. Of West Hempstead, NY, on March 7, 1998. She was involved in various organizations in the community and very active with the Democratic Party for more than fifty years. She held the position of Leader of the 18th Assembly District. For information, call Carl C. Burnett Funeral Home: 516-489-4492.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUBILET, FLORENCE BAERWALD ''BOBBIE''
description: DOUBILET-Florence Baerwald ''Bobbie''. Died peacefully in her home in Elberon, New Jersey, in her 82nd year, after a brave battle with cancer. She will be missed by her family and friends and the entire golfing community. She is survived by her daughter, Jane Kramer, and her son David Doubilet and his wife Anne. Also her son-inlaw Jose Alves and her granddaughters Rain Kramer and Emily Doubilet, her sister, Pauline Falk and her many nieces and nephews. Services will be held at Temple Beth Miriam, Elberon, NJ today 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Camp Oakhurst, New York Services for the Handicapped, 853 Broadway Suite 605, New York, N.Y. 10003.

title: Vote Allows Strike in Theater Pit
description: The executive board of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians voted yesterday to allow negotiators to call a strike, if necessary, against all but two of the theaters on Broadway.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- A Stock Crusader In a Short-Seller Suit; He Says Blunt Talk Fights Fraud, But Critics Say He Talks Too Much
description: Satanism has a better reputation in financial circles than does short-selling -- the practice of betting that stocks will fall.

title: About New York; Championing Lady Justice In the Bronx
description: LADY JUSTICE presides over the entrance to the old Bronx County Courthouse, her sandblasted robes fairly gleaming in contrast to the fenced-in hulk's soot-encrusted walls. She casts her gaze beyond Third Avenue, over a vista of newly built homes that have slowly brought this section of Melrose back to life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLOSSBERG, BARBARA
description: SCHLOSSBERG-Barbara. Of New York City. Sister of Debra Rainville, Richard and Douglas Schlossberg. Niece of Wanda Provost. Survived by four nieces and one nephew. Funeral from the Houghton Funeral Home, 976 Summit Ave., Jersey City, on Friday, March 13, 1998 at 12:00 noon.

title: Government Paved Way for Microsoft's Success

title: Talk Partners
description: At a party at ''21'' for Literacy Partners, a coalition of volunteers that has provided literacy instruction for 25 years, hardly anyone was talking about reading. But there was plenty of talk about talk. ARNOLD SCAASI had an animated conversation with AMANDA BURDEN about his conversation with SOPHIA LOREN at the Time magazine anniversary celebration.

title: The Word on Wilson: No Damage to Shoulder
description: For once, some good news for the Mets' young pitchers: magnetic resonance imaging tests on Paul Wilson's right shoulder taken today in Manhattan revealed no structural damage to his rotator cuff or labrum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASSARELLA, P. FRANCIS, COLONEL UNITED STATES ARMY RETIRED
description: PASSARELLA-P. Francis, Colonel United States Army Retired. On Friday, March 6, 1998, of Arlington, Virginia. Beloved husband of 63 years to Marion S. Passarella; loving father of Patrick F. Passarella and Anthony Passarella. He is also survived by three grandchildren, two great grandchildren, and a brother, Monsignor Anthony Passarella of New York. Friends may call at the Murphy Funeral Home of Arlington, 4510 Wilson Boulevard, Arlington, VA, Wednesday from 2-3 and 6-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Thursday, March 19 at 12:45 PM at the Ft. Myer Old Post Chapel. Interment to follow with full military honors at Arlington National Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society or the American Diabetes Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREIG, MARGARET BALTZELL MCAFEE
description: KREIG-Margaret Baltzell McAfee. On January 12, 1998, in her home of cancer. Survived by loving mother, Gladys Jennings, sons, Ray, Andrew, and Lawrence, sister Frances, husband William. title: Argentina to Hasten End of Phone Monopoly
description: In a move that could significantly expand the presence of United States companies in Argentina's $10 billion telephone market, President Carlos Saul Menem announced today that the monopolies held by two Argentine telephone companies would end in 1999.

title: Deutsche Telekom Fees For Rivals Are Set
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. must charge rivals less than it wanted for use of local phone lines, Germany's regulator said yesterday, opening the way for competition in local service. The former monopoly can charge no more than 20.65 marks ($11.30) a month for connections to homes and businesses, below the 28.80 marks Telekom sought, but above what competitors wanted to pay.

title: As Climbers Die, The Allure of Everest Keeps on Growing
description: AFTER reaching the top of Mount Everest five times, Ed Viesturs has had enough of the roof of the world and has formed Everest Anonymous, a group of elite mountaineers who have sworn off the 29,028-foot-high obsession.

title: Witness Disputes Brutality Claim, Police Say
description: The Police Department said yesterday that it had found a witness who ''completely discredited'' the accusations made by a Queens man who said he had been beaten and humiliated by officers in a Queens precinct station house in January. The witness, a robbery suspect, also contradicted statements by a police officer who said he had seen part of the incident and had reported it to department investigators.

title: Metro Business; Another Bank for Stamford
description: A Dutch merchant bank, Mees Pierson Holdings, is relocating its corporate headquarters and 60 jobs from Manhattan to Stamford, Conn.

title: Mitsubishi Sees First Loss Since 1974-75
description: The evaporation of markets in Southeast Asia and increased frugality by consumers at home forced the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation to sharply lower sales estimates today and project its first annual loss in 24 years.

title: Government Paved Way for Microsoft's Success; Consumers Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ANNABELLE
description: MILLER-Annabelle, age 95. A lifelong resident of Port Chester, N.Y. died Tuesday, March 10, 1996. She was the daughter of the late David and Etta Silver Miller. She was a graduate of Port Chester High School and Merrill Business School. She was an Executive Legal Secretary for the law firm of Peck & Schmidt, Esqs. in Port Chester, N.Y. and later for Edgar J. Bitz Esq. Her career lasted over fifty years. She was the sister of the late Harry, Charles and Yvette Miller, and Lillian Kahn. She is survived by nephews, David Kahn of Palm Beach Gardens, FL., and Andre Rodainsky of Stamford, CT, and nieces, Elsie Hafford of Plantation, FL., and Ethel Lencheck of Stamford, CT. She was a lifelong member of the KTI Synagogue in Port Chester, NY. Graveside service today March 11, 1998 at 3:00 PM at the Riversville Cemetery, Memory Lane, Greenwich, CT. For more information, contact Craft Memorial Home, Inc., 40 Leicester St., Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHAEFER, KENNETH J.
description: SCHAEFER-Kenneth J. March 11, 1969. Lovingly remembered today and always. The Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASIN, EDWIN, MD.
description: KASIN-Edwin, MD. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute and the William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Society note with irreparable sorrow, the death of a much revered graduate and member. As a Training and Supervising Analyst, and a Faculty member, Dr. Kasin inspired generations of psychoanalysts to whom he imparted the essentials of their profession. His erudite and scholarly teachings were more than matched by the grace, gentility, gladness, and tender humanity which Dr. Kasin demonstrated by example. Our heartfelt condolences to the family that he adored. We shall all miss him. Marylou Lionells, Ph.D., Director, White Institute Allison Stern Rosen, Ph.D., President, White Society

title: Help Kosovo Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Corporate Cultures Meet in MCI-Worldcom Merger
description: When the directors of the MCI Communications Corporation and of Worldcom Inc. dined together last Tuesday evening, the contrast between the two boards was stark.

Kelly, Jr., Marana, Az., six grandchildren, five greatgrandchildren. Funeral Mass in Az. Memorial service at later date.

title: Wine Talk; Why New Jersey Loves Pennsylvania And Other Strange Liquor Law Tales
description: IN Chicago, it's now O.K. to feed wine to a dog. Or so one must assume, as a city law that banned serving Champagne to Skippy has been repealed. There is no way of telling how the dogs feel about this, but among connoisseurs of ludicrous wine legislation, the dog law will be missed.

title: Microsoft Adding to Java and to Sun Rift
description: The Microsoft Corporation plans to announce new capabilities Wednesday for its version of the Java programming language that are certain to deepen a bitter rift with Sun Microsystems Inc., Java's inventor.

title: NORTEK AGREES TO BUY NUTONE FROM WILLIAMS
description: The building-products manufacturer Nortek Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Nutone Inc. from the British industrial company Williams P.L.C. for $242.5 million in cash. The Cincinnati-based Nutone makes products for use in residential construction and remodeling, including exhaust fans, range hoods, door chimes, intercoms, central vacuum cleaners and bathroom cabinets and accessories. It had full-year sales of $199 million. The company sells primarily to the North American market, operating in Canada through its subsidiary, Nutone Canada. Williams is pursuing a plan to exit the home-improvement sector. Shares of Nortek, based in Providence, R.I., rose $3.0625, to $34.0625.

title: Sips; Tequila Tastes, Champagne Purse
description: WOULD you make sangria with a bottle of Chateau Latour? Of course not.

title: Temptation; Cupcakes That May Require A Knife and Fork
description: ''YOU'VE got to have a glass of milk with this cupcake,'' the baker Mitchel London said of his ample creation with its dense, dark chocolate icing. ''A cupcake brings out the little kid in people.''

title: 600 Scraps in Camelot's Attic For Kennedy Dreamers' Bids
description: Prancing out of the recesses of history come the big and the small, the Presidential bust and the President's plastic Ace comb. Here are his scribblings on the Cuban missile crisis as well as his Bell System phone card. Notice the Oval Office flags, his shoehorn, a picture of the President with Roger Maris, a Jackie Gleason record album he liked to listen to, his racing sloop, even two pairs of his long johns. (Bear in mind, one pair is missing two buttons.)

title: An Exploration (He Explains) of Reactions to Torture
description: Many pundits have speculated that the mass audience has become so inured to movie and television violence that we've begun to lose our capacity for horror and empathy. But have we really?

title: Good Thing Gets Away From Isles
description: Once again the Islanders found a way to beat the best goalie in the National Hockey League. But they could not find a way to beat the Buffalo Sabres at Nassau Coliseum tonight, skating to a sloppy 2-2 tie that left Coach Rick Bowness frustrated and fuming.

title: Serbs Force a Crude Burial For 51 Left Dead in Kosovo
description: The Serbian police today seized the bodies of 51 ethnic Albanians killed in a sweep of separatists in Kosovo province, loaded them onto trucks, dumped them into graves and bulldozed the earth, witnesses said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ZACHARY D.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER UNIT IN DEAL FOR IP TIMBERLANDS
description: The IP Forest Resources Company agreed yesterday to buy all the publicly traded depository units of IP Timberlands Ltd. for $13.6325 each, or about $99.5 million. IP Forest, a subsidiary of the International Paper Company, is the managing partner for IP Timberlands. The company said buying IP Timberlands would significantly reduce administrative costs. Shares of IP Timberlands rose 32 percent, gaining $3.3125 each to close at $13.5625. IP Timberlands, based in Purchase, N.Y., is a limited partnership that owns timberlands and markets timber products.

He began his twenty-eight year career at NYNEX as an Electrical Engineer and progressed to a division level Executive in their corporate planning and marketing division. John was the beloved husband of Mary. Devoted father of Susan, Brian, Mark, and Paul. Loving grandfather of Emily, Bobby, and Stephanie. Mass Thursday 10 A.M., St. Rose of Lima RC Church, Massapequa. Interment in Grace Church Cemetery.

title: The Old Masters? They're the Ones Inspecting the Art; At the Maastricht Fair, Security Teams Come Armed With Magnifying Glasses
description: For two days last week, the scene at the Exhibition and Congress Center here, where the European Fine Art Fair was about to begin, could only be described as peculiar. Art was everywhere: thousands of paintings, sculptures, antiquities, antiques, icons, you name it. But no dealers were in sight.

title: Korean Air Says Losses Nearly Doubled in 1997
description: Korean Airlines, South Korea's largest airline, said yesterday that losses almost doubled last year as the currency turmoil slowed passenger traffic and inflated its costs. The airline lost 397.4 billion won ($252 million) compared with a loss of 210.5 billion won in 1996, a Korean Air spokesman said. Revenue rose to 4.29 trillion won, from 3.67 trillion won a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, GOLDIE
description: BRENNER-Goldie. Thomas J. Hubbard, Chairman Gregory Long, President

title: The Brightest, Seventh Star: Ducasse Himself
description: Alain Ducasse, the first chef in 60 years to win six of the coveted Michelin stars at once -- three apiece for two luxury restaurants separated by nearly 600 miles -- thought when he got the news last week that it was no less than what he deserved.

title: Subscribers Urge Regulators To Oppose Increase for Oxford
description: Oxford Health Plans made its case to state regulators yesterday that it needed a large increase in the rates it charges people who buy their own insurance. But those same Oxford customers, armed with stories of sickness and fear of not being able to afford insurance, fired back in a public hearing, charging that the request was exorbitant.

title: Soft-Dollar Case Filed by S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil fraud charges yesterday against a California investment advisory firm, its owner and a portfolio manager, saying they had misappropriated commission income through the use of so-called soft-dollar commissions.

Carroll and Meredith Lane. Dear brother of Nina Heldt. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday at 11am. Interment private. Please omit flowers.

title: Officer Says Man Hurled Firecrackers
description: A New York City police officer has stated under oath that he saw a man light a string of firecrackers on the steps of City Hall last month and throw them into a crowd of people, though photographs and a videotape would appear to contradict that statement.

title: Rules to Simplify Mutual Fund Documents
description: Mutual fund investors are likely to begin seeing shorter, easier-to-understand disclosure documents this summer under new rules adopted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, HELENE YESHILIAN
description: FREEDMAN-Helene Yeshilian. Died Tuesday, March 10, 1998 at home in Montclair, New Jersey, after facing acute leukemia with great courage and fortitude for nearly three years. She was born in Chelsea, Mass., October 5, 1939, the daughter of Martin Yeshilian and Flora Harvey Yeshilian. She attended public schools in Chelsea and graduated from Jackson College, Tufts University in 1961 with a B.A. in English, Magna Cum Laude and a teaching certification. Ms. Freedman began her teaching career in Medford, Massachusetts and following her marriage in 1962 taught in upstate New York for two years while her husband attended law school at Cornell. After his graduation they moved to Montclair because she was offered a teaching position in the Montclair schools. She was a reading specialist at Nishuane School until 1967 when she left because of the birth of her first child Susan. Her son John followed in 1970. When he reached school age in 1976, Ms. Freedman returned to teaching at Montclair High School, in the English Department, where she remained until her illness forced her retirement, in March of last year. In 1977, Ms. Freedman received a Master of Arts degree in reading from Montclair State College and was elected to the Phi Kappa Phi Honor society. Ms. Freedman was very active at Montclair High School. Among her positions she was a long time member of the Faculty Council, served on the Language Arts Curriculum Review Committee, conducted English Award Programs, served on various scholarship committees, was an advisor for the ESL Club and served as an officer of the PTSO. Ms. Freedman was singled out at the high school by the Montclair Board of Education in December 1992 to receive a Service Excellence Award for ''...dedication, commitment and outstanding service to the students in the Montclair Public Schools.'' Ms. Freedman was an avid reader and crossword puzzler. Prior to her illness she was very active in aerobic dancing. She is survived by her husband, Philip Freedman, who is a Judge of the Superior Court of New Jersey in Newark, her daughter Susan who is an attorney with the Office of the Public Defender and her son John who is a graphic designer. She is also survived by her father, of Chelsea, her sister Susan Manaras and her husband John and their daughters Katie and Jane of Brookline, Massachusetts and her sister-in-law Dr. Marsha Freedman of Bayonne, New Jersey. Funeral arrangements are private. The family will be receiving visitors at home, 35 Cambridge Road, Montclair, New Jersey on Wednesday, March 11 and Thursday, March 12 from 4:00 to 8:00 P.M. Ms. Freedman's family is establishing a charitable foundation in her memory. Anyone wishing to make a tax deductible donation may do so by sending a check payable to the Helene Freedman Foundation at the Cambridge Road address.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUSON, SYDNEY
description: GRUSON-Sydney. The funeral service for Sydney Gruson will be held today. The service is private. Memorial services will be at 11 A.M., on Thursday, March 26, in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Please use the main entrance at 82nd Street and 5th Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the family would prefer contributions be made to the Rogosin Institute of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center or the Sydney Gruson Fellowship of the Chaim Herzog Center at Trinity College Dublin, C/O Mr. Kingsley Aikins, Executive Director, The American Ireland Fund, 211 Congress Street, 10th Floor, Boston, MA. 02110.

description: Unfinished business? After 10 years of concerts?

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK WEAKENS. The mark fell against the dollar for the first time in three days, hurt by expectations that German interest rates would not be rising soon. In New York, the dollar cost 1.8287 marks, up from 1.8274 Monday.

title: Oval Office, Too?
description: It's President JOHN F. KENNEDY JR. now.

title: Gear: A Costly Affliction With No Known Cure
description: COMING soon to the Eastern Mountain Sports store in downtown Manhattan is a bit of gear that quickens even the gadget-weary hearts of the salespeople there. It is a camping stove called the Dragonfly, and it has all the hallmarks of truly seductive gear. It solves a real problem. It costs a lot of money. It can be described well only in the blessedly secret code of enthusiasts.

title: Calendar
description: Microbrew Tasting

title: Off the Menu
description: Heartland Brewery II

title: At the Big Table, Intimate Strangers
description: HARVEY S. SHIPLEY MILLER had not liked the looks of Le Pain Quotidien, a homey restaurant on the Upper East Side whose trademark is a big table where strangers sit next to each other, sharing conversation, trading plates and bumping elbows.

title: To Ease Delays, Balm at Subway Platforms
description: Liz Helmrich had just taken the blood pressure of a dizzy woman who stumbled off the No. 7 train onto a crowded platform at Grand Central Station when the next call came in: a pregnant woman, also dizzy, on a Lexington Avenue train. Ms. Helmrich ran upstairs and gave the woman some water and orange juice.

title: To Go; Treasure in a Brown Bag: Classiest Takeouts in Town
description: NEW YORK, racing to the jackhammer beat of life on the go, has embraced the takeout meal as a necessary stress reducer, like a jog in the park or a trip to the therapist. But while pizza joints and Chinese dumpling purveyors fill the streets with out-of-control delivery people, something quieter is going on at the same time: many of the city's most accomplished restaurants, some tentatively, almost secretively, are finding themselves drawn into the takeout business, too.

title: BASEBALL: SPRING TRAINING

title: D'Amato Defends $41 Billion Transit Measure
description: The senators from Minnesota and Colorado wanted more mass transit money to relieve choking traffic around Minneapolis and Denver. The senators from South Dakota and Wyoming came hat in hand for rural transit. And the senators from Illinois and Pennsylvania were looking for a few dollars more to transport the urban poor to suburban jobs.

title: VW Shares Surge As Stock Plan Is Cut
description: Shares of Volkswagen A.G. surged yesterday after the company said that it had canceled half of a planned 6-billion-mark ($3.3 billion) share sale and indicated fourth-quarter profit more than doubled. Shares rose 83 marks, to 1,345 marks, after VW said on Monday that it would sell three million new shares instead of six million. VW also indicated fourth-quarter profit rose to 508 million marks from 213 million, beating expectations.

title: For Motorcycle Gang Without Motorcycles, Even More Bad News
description: These are hard times for the Harlem Cowboys motorcycle gang.

title: Scandals Ignite Outrage That Could Topple a Mexican Governor
description: A wave of grass-roots protest has erupted against a prominent state governor after his highest justice and police officials were implicated in torture, kidnapping and protecting drug traffickers.

title: Role Has Changed, But Sveum Accepts It
description: Nothing pleases Dale Sveum as much as his time outdoors, the days spent waiting for pheasants to burst from cover, or for the distinct pull of a bass. In those hours, his mind occasionally wanders, and he wonders how much one pop-up changed his life.

title: Journal; Comedy After Monica
description: If oral sex in the Oval Office is now the stuff of the nightly news, what joke can possibly top it?

title: Today, Guides Need More Than Duct Tape
description: I ONCE guided a couple, a nurse named Wendy and her doctor husband, Neil, who had called out of the blue saying that they wanted an Alaskan wilderness experience and that money was no object. I was a graduate student making $4,900 a year. I had been a white-water rafting guide in the lower 48 and a dall sheep-hunting guide in Alaska, but had given it up because I rarely got paid. The phone call from Wendy was a gift from the universe, and I planned the best trip I could imagine: 10 days of fly-in backpacking in a remote section of the Alaska Range, then a 14-day trip down the Tatshenshini and Alsek rivers, some of the wildest back country in the world.

title: Pataki Renews His Push For Charter Schools
description: Gov. George E. Pataki renewed his push yesterday to create charter schools in New York State by having representatives of minority groups praise the schools, which are publicly financed but operate independently.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about sanctions against Serbia for its crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo Province misstated the timing of the measures. The sanctions, imposed by the United States and its allies, take effect immediately. (There is a 10-day period for a review, after which the sanctions may be revised.)

title: SYKES AGREES TO PAY $50 MILLION FOR PRUDENTIAL UNIT
description: Sykes Healthplan Services Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Prudential Insurance Company of America's Prudential Service Bureau unit for $50 million in cash to expand its employee-benefits program administration business. Prudential Service, based in Louisville, Ky., is a company that manages employee health and welfare benefits for more than 600 major employers. The acquisition and others pending will create a company with combined annual revenue of $80 million and after-tax earnings of $3.3 million. Sykes Healthplan is a joint venture of Sykes Enterprises Inc. and the Healthplan Services Corporation, formed to make acquisitions in the employee-benefits administration business.

title: Call to Halt Mixed-Sex Training Is Opposed by 3 Armed Services
description: The Army, Navy and Air Force are expected to reject a committee's recommendations that the nation's armed services separate men and women for much of basic and advanced training, officials said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARON, DAVID
description: ZARON-David. Age 76. Of Slingerlands, New York. On Sunday, March 8th, 1998. In Naples, Florida. Mr. Zaron was born in Brooklyn, NY, and has resided in the Capitol district for many years. He graduated from the Univ. of Michigan & received his Master's Degree in Public Administration from the Maxwell School at Syracuse University. He served 35 years with New York State in the Departments of Health, Mental Health, Civil Service & Labor. He retired as Assistant Commissioner with the Transportation Department. He was also employed by Suffolk County revamping its civil service system. He was a former Executive Director of OMCE and performed labor arbitration mediation and fact finding. He is survived by his wife Barbara Karlstein Zaron, a son Steven and his wife Patty of Albany, two sisters Judith Donow & Bernice Freiman, both of Delray Beach, Florida, a grand-daughter Katelyn Zaron, several nieces, nephews and great-nieces and nephews. Services at Congregation Beth Emeth, Albany, N.Y., Wednesday, 12 noon. Burial Beth Emeth Cemetery, Loudonville, N.Y. Mourning will be observed at the Zaron residence, Slingerlands, N.Y. through Friday. Contributions to a charity of one's choice. For information call Levine Memorial Chapel, Albany. New York at 1-800-427-0280.

title: Disclosure of a Conversation
description: In a vindictive political move, Representative John Boehner of Ohio has filed suit against Representative Jim McDermott of Washington accusing him of leaking to reporters the contents of a cellular phone conversation illegally taped by a Florida couple, John and Alice Martin. Mr. Boehner is suing for $30,000 and punitive damages under the Electronic Communications Privacy Act. The act, which bars interception of cellular calls, also prohibits anyone from intentionally disclosing the contents of such taping. But surely any Congressman has the right to release truthful information of substantial public interest without fear of legal reprisal.

title: Prosecutors Say Nikko Paid Off Politician
description: Tokyo prosecutors filed charges yesterday against the Nikko Securities Company and two former executives on suspicion that they violated the Securities and Exchange Act by paying off a Liberal Democratic Party legislator, Shokei Arai. A former vice president, Yumio Hiraishi, 61, and a former director, Hiroyuki Hamahira, 48, were charged with providing payoffs to Mr. Arai in the guise of profits from stock trading. Mr. Arai committed suicide last month, hours before he was to be arrested in connection with the case.

title: Regulatory Bill Seeks Cost-Benefit Testing
description: Reviving efforts to overhaul the Federal regulatory system, a Senate committee today approved a bill that would subject future health, safety and environmental rules to new cost-benefit tests, limiting regulators' discretion and potentially opening their decisions to new legal challenges.

title: The Thrill of Bouldering: It Doesn't Have to Be High to Be Hairy
description: ON a cold, sunny Saturday in February -- Valentine's Day -- Jonathan Reichbach is clinging to a crack in an overhanging wall of schist. Reichbach is 6 feet 2 inches and 205 pounds, and his thick chest and thighs make him look more like a linebacker than the climbing instructor he is at the Manhattan Plaza Health Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANCUSO, ALFRED
description: MANCUSO-Alfred, 84. Of Tinton Falls, NJ, March 10, 1998. Husband of the late Beatrice. Beloved father of Richard and Ellen. He gave most of his life to the cause of world peace and human rights. Funeral service at The WordenHoidal Funeral Home, 60 E. Front Street, Red Bank, NJ, Thursday, March 12 at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions to charity of choice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, SELMA
description: ROBBINS-Selma, 76. Of Singer Island, FL, passed away Sunday in West Palm Beach, FL. Survived by her loving husband Norman. Beloved mother of Curtis, Leslie, Rochelle Newman and Merrill Rachowin. Devoted grandmother of Benjamin, Lindsay, Rebecca, Blake and Todd. Graveside services Fri., Mar. 13, 11 AM, Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. For info contact Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1-800-947-4256.

title: Shot at Buzzer Caps Nets' Painful Day
description: John Calipari, a coach of volatile emotions and hysterical outbursts, quietly walked off the court tonight, went into his office in the back of the locker room and, after a long pause, opened the doors and invited reporters in. He turned on a videocassette recorder and replayed the final, decisive play, over and over and over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, DOROTHY SAFIR
description: GOODMAN-Dorothy Safir. On March 9, 1998. Beloved mother of Sue Morris and son-in-law Alan. Loving grandmother of David and Jonathan. Services private. Family will be receiving Wednesday and Thursday, 7:30PM-10PM, at the home of Sue and Alan Morris. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Home Healthcare Services at Mt. Sinai Hospital.

title: Passengers Rebel Over Tower Air's 12-Hour Flight Delay
description: Tower Air Flight 30 from Kennedy International Airport to Tel Aviv was delayed on Sunday night by mechanical difficulties.

title: China's Economic Battle Plan
description: China's National People's Congress would never be mistaken for a democratic legislature, but this month's meeting provides a revealing look at China's response to the Asian financial crisis, which threatens Beijing's hopes for continued rapid growth. The meetings have been dominated by the ideas of Zhu Rongji, an energetic reformer who has run the economy in recent years and is now to become prime minister. Mr. Zhu would rescue the banks, consolidate state industry, shrink the bureaucracy and accelerate public works. But his agenda may not be ambitious enough.

title: Cone's Goal Is 100 Good Pitches
description: His days of throwing 150 pitches in a game are over, David Cone said today, and given his splinter-thin smile and his self-deprecating tone when he uttered those words, he might have been speaking of wine and roses.

title: Currents; HOME FURNISHINGS -- Froufrou to Vintage: Adding Quirky Touches
description: Corinne Roberts, a painter and textile designer, has opened a home furnishings shop in an unlikely space: Chelsea's meat-packing district. June Bug features vintage furniture finds retouched in spring hues, Pop-era fabrics, froufrou accessories and unique furniture for unique children (she has two). Stripped to raw metal, an industrial-looking dresser, circa 1920, re-emerges as a child's chest ($2,200), and a mint-green, 1950's-era bed is $250. A new patchwork quilt, above, is made from polyester remnants from the 1960's, and her throw pillows are hand-embroidered with ribbon flowers (above, $180 each). The shop is at 433 West 14th Street; (212) 206-7676.

title: Trenton Gets Grant For Urban Renewal
description: Federal housing officials awarded a $3.8 million grant to Trenton yesterday to help turn a 212-acre area of abandoned buildings and deteriorating homes into a residential neighborhood of single-family houses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLANCY, JOHN J.
description: CLANCY-John J. On March 11, 1998. Beloved uncle of Noreen O'Neill, Catherine McKenzie, and Ann Baumann. Funeral Saturday, 9 A.M., from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn. Mass at St. Columba R.C. Church, 10 A.M. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Family will receive friends 7-10 PM Thursday, 2-5 and 7-10 P.M. Friday.

title: A Change of Heart, a Work Reborn
description: So identified is the music of Sir Edward Elgar with this land that a chord from the Romantic composer can bring a heave to the bemedaled chest of the most stoic Briton. Not for nothing does the Oxford Dictionary of Music call his ''Pomp and Circumstance'' March No. 1 ''an alternative national anthem,'' and tampering with his memory could be considered defacing a public monument.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELOFF, SONYA
description: ABELOFF-Sonya. The Board of Governors, members and staff of The Falls Country Club wish to express their sincere condolences to Sonya Abeloff's family on the passing of our friend and fellow member.

title: In America; Reprise Of Terror
description: The police invaded Shaunsia Patterson's apartment about 4:30 P.M. on Friday, Feb. 27. Ms. Patterson, who is eight months pregnant, and her two children, a boy, 3, and a girl, 2, were napping in the bedroom at the rear of the small second-floor apartment on Hull Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Arts Abroad; Gallic Hauteur Toward British Creativity Goes Poof
description: For many centuries until World War II, France and Britain competed over the pre-eminence of their respective versions of Western civilization. But when the United States took over leadership of what the French call the Anglo-Saxon world, the balance of power shifted. American movies, visual arts, popular music, fast food, even clothes invaded France, and British culture was largely forgotten here.

title: CLINTON MOVES UP HIS TRIP TO CHINA TO LATE IN JUNE
description: Eager to prevent any deterioration of relations between the United States and China over human rights and other issues, the Clinton Administration has decided to move up this year's Presidential trip to Beijing to late June, from November, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, ROSA
description: ISRAEL-Rosa. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of London's Jewish community and dedicated Zionist, beloved sister of Romie (and Blanche) Shapiro, member, Board of Directors, of YU's Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. Mr. and Mrs. Shapiro are longtime devoted leaders of YU and its schools, YU Guardians who also established CSL's Romie Shapiro Program in International Law and Human Rights. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Turf; When Banks Step Back, Middlemen Rush In
description: WHEN Lorraine Altman arrived for her first meeting with a mortgage broker, she came armed. From her perusal of the Internet the night before, she knew the current interest rates. From discussions with her real estate agent, she knew what type of loan she wanted. And from talking with her accountant, she knew exactly how much she wanted to spend on the monthly mortgage payment for the new $165,000 Upper East Side one-bedroom apartment she had picked out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAKE, STEPHEN N.
description: DRAKE-Stephen N. On March 11th, 1998. Beloved husband of Ann. Devoted father of Christopher, Valerie and the late Stephen N. Jr. Father-in-law of Mercedes Drake. Dear brother of Nicholas Tsardakas, Angelo Drake and Katherine Pergantis. Family will receive friends Thursday from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M., at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232nd Street, Bronx. Funeral service Prophet Elias Greek Orthodox Church (15 Leroy Ave, Yonkers, NY), Friday at 11 AM. Interment Mount Hope Cemetery. Evening service Thursday at 8 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLIE, ELIZABETH S.
description: COLIE-Elizabeth S. Of Haverford, PA, formerly of South Orange, NJ, on March 9, 1998, at the age of 84 after a short illness. Graduate of Bryn Mawr, Class of 1935, and retired teacher from The Chapin School in New York, she is survived by her sister-in-law Frances Colie of Mystic, CT, and her nieces and nephews: Edward M. Colie IV of Columbia, S.C., Laura Kuhlmann of Carmel, CA., Matthew Colie of Belleville, MI., Marguerite Schnepel of Providence, RI, and Ellen Schnepel of Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Bryn Mawr College.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RAPHAEL
description: COHEN-Raphael. The Officers and Directors of The Mental Health Association of New York City, Inc., note with sorrow the passing of Raphael Cohen, father of our esteemed Executive Director Giselle Stolper. We offer her mother Frances and her family our heartfelt condolences.

title: CBS Spices Up A Staid Sport
description: Bowling will loosen its respectful, conservative restraints in its first season on CBS, in an attempt to lure a young audience. Crowds sitting in horseshoe configurations around the lanes will be encouraged to be loud, and bowlers will be urged to display emotion. Coaches will sit beside their bowlers.

title: 12 New York Hospitals Receive Surprise Visits From State Inspectors
description: Without warning, State Health Department officials descended on 12 hospitals in New York last Thursday and spent the weekend poring over charts and interviewing staff members in an effort to determine whether young doctors are inadequately supervised and overworked in violation of state laws intended to protect patients.

title: Girl Pleads Guilty to Manslaughter in Central Park Killing
description: Daphne Abdela, a 15-year-old girl born to wealth and privilege on the Upper West Side, admitted yesterday that she had participated in one of the city's most gruesome slayings, the killing of a man whom she and a friend had been drinking with in Central Park.

title: Japanese Seize Central Banker In Leak of Data
description: Japan's financial scandals deepened on Wednesday as prosecutors raided the central bank and arrested an influential official suspected of leaking secrets to Japanese banks. Within hours the central bank's governor offered to resign.

title: Tighten Belts, Suharto Tells His People, It's All Over
description: President Suharto called on Indonesians today to tighten their belts, saying the rapid growth in prosperity they had enjoyed over the last 25 years was gone for good.

title: Rangers Do Little but Fatten Scoring Totals in a Victory
description: Two bad teams played one relatively important game last night at Madison Square Garden. Both had something at stake in this long season, and the Rangers rallied twice to beat the San Jose Sharks, 5-3, in a sloppy affair that had its entertaining moments and local standouts.

title: Currents; FLAMBOYANT FABRIC -- South Beach's Allure
description: The hot colors of South Beach in Miami have inspired 152 fabrics arriving this month in Kravet showrooms nationwide. Ripples carved in the sand by the surf and a harlequin taken from a tile floor of an Ocean Drive restaurant inspired the two Jacquards shown above, said Beth Greene, collections director for the Beth Page, L.I., company. ''We turned to Miami because our customers are no longer simplifying,'' she said. ''They want to immerse themselves in fabulous color.'' The fabrics, which sell for $60 to $90 a yard, include solids and velvets as well as elaborate patterns. Kravet is to the trade, but has a designer referral service, (888) 457-2838.

title: Apple Computer Hiring Compaq Executive
description: Apple Computer said today that it had named Timothy D. Cook, the No. 2 manufacturing executive at the Compaq Computer Corporation, as its senior vice president for worldwide manufacturing operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, JEAN HOWELL
description: DALY-Jean Howell. Of Short Hills, NJ, 76, on March 10, at home. Wife of the late Thomas C. Daly and mother of Ann Daly Printon and Catherine Daly. Also survived by three grandchildren, Stacie Printon, Melissa Printon and Gillian Printon and by two great grandchildren, Ben and Eliza. Mrs. Daly will be interred in Salt Lake City and a memorial service has been set for Thursday, March 19 at 11:00AM at Christ Church, in Short Hills, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations to New Eyes for the Needy, Short Hills, N.J. 07078 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONIG, LOUIS
description: HONIG-Louis. March 11. Beloved husband of Edith. Father of Fred. Graveside services 1 P.M., today at Mount Lebanon Cemetery.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have plenty of time -- 30 years, in fact -- to

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Installation of E-Z Pass System on Turnpike and Parkway Is Expected to Take 2 Years
description: State transportation officials said today that the E-Z Pass toll system would be in operation on the Garden State Parkway and the New Jersey Turnpike in about two years. They said they would finance the system by fining motorists who speed through the tolls without paying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORNERO, LEO
description: FORNERO-Leo. On March 11, 1998, of Springfield, NJ. Husband of Kathleen McGrath and the late Barbara Fornero. Father of Pamela and her husband Robert Kulesh and Timothy Fornero. Survived by four step-children and four step-grandchildren. Funeral Mass at St. Teresa of Avila Church, Summit, Saturday, March 14 at 9 AM. Visitation at Brough Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Avenue, Summit, NJ from 7-9 PM Friday. Entombment is in Saint Teresa's Chapel Mausoleum. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Madison First Aid Squad or C/O Dr. Robyn Barst, Director of the Pulmonary Hypertension Center, Columbia Medical Center, 3959 Broadway, NY, NY 10032.

title: Final Four Or Fade? Huskies Face Test
description: There is a tendency to consider any Connecticut team in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament as a flickering flame. There is this idea out there that Connecticut gives you goosebumps in the regular season and a rash in the post-season.

title: INSIDE
description: Single-Sex School No Better

title: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's; Report the Median
description: To the Editor:

title: Van Horn Hinting He May Sit to Heal Toe
description: After the Nets ended practice at an upscale facility today, Sam Cassell dragged his teammates and his coach to the sports bar upstairs to see what he called ''the Sammy statue.''

title: Russia Vows To Push Pact Cutting Arms
description: Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia said today that his Government would push to ratify the second strategic arms reduction treaty in order to prepare the way for President Clinton to visit Moscow for a summit meeting by the middle of the year.

title: Tower Travelers Tell of Another Ordeal
description: This time, it was an eight-hour delay; and then no running water for an 11-hour flight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, JANET
description: LEEDS-Janet. To the most wonderful mother and grandmother, you will always be in our hearts and our thoughts. We will miss you and always love you. Steven, Sheri, Jessica, Danielle and Zachary

title: For Mundane and Exotic, a Guide
description: OVERLOOKING a picturesque riverbank in Rhode Island sits a modest two-story clapboard building with high, narrow windows. Like many houses and shops in Warren, which was a whaling town when many of its oldest maples and birch trees were not yet pollen on the wind, this former general store exudes a palpable sense of an era when time seemed more likely to take its time.

title: Fading Concern Over Asia and Earnings Sustains Shares
description: Stock investors, apparently having overcome their anxiety about Asia and corporate earnings, went on another buying spree yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEECHMAN, LAURIE
description: BEECHMAN-Laurie. Your voice, the sound of your soul, was as bibilical as honey from the rock. For all these years, you have inspired us, but we have been most grateful for your simple friendship. Your great spirit was equaled only by your quiet strength. To Neil, Dolly, Nate, Claudia, and Janeour hearts are with you, even as we shall always remain in Laurie's audience. Rabbi Ben, Cathy, Sari, and Debra Kamin

title: Paris Journal; Beyond the Grave, DNA Haunts Yves Montand
description: In a country where people tell the story of a President, Felix Faure, who died after making love to a younger woman, few fingers wagged when Yves Montand was named by a minor actress as a defendant in a paternity suit in 1989.

title: Searching for Truth, but Finding Only Politics; Parent-Child Immunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Resales
description: Manhattan
