title: Seeking Harmonic Connections to Surrealism
description: Every few months the pianist and chamber musician Sarah Rothenberg comes to the Walter Reade Theater with her group Da Camera of Houston to present programs with music playing around literature and the other arts. Monday evening's concert, devoted to Surrealism, was probably her least successful enterprise so far, partly because the theme offered no focus.

title: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's; Grades and Ratings
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dangerous Plutonium Problem
description: Russia and the United States have dismantled thousands of nuclear warheads since the end of the cold war. But all the plutonium from those warheads is still stored in bomb-ready form. Washington and Moscow must move quickly to reduce the risks that some of that plutonium could end up in the wrong hands, for example through diversion to rogue states like Iraq or Libya.

title: People
description: * Bob Sarlin was named to the new position of senior vice president and creative director at Charron, Schwartz & Partners, New York. He had been president at Sarlin & Sarlin Ink, New York.

title: Study Finds Signs of Elusive Pheromones in Humans
description: They may be odorless and colorless and their purpose mysterious, but human pheromones at last have the zest of scientific truth.

title: Saturn Union Votes to Retain Its Cooperative Company Pact
description: After weeks of dissension in a workplace known for harmony, two-thirds of the workers at the Saturn car factory here voted down a measure that would have asked the company to jettison their current union contract, corporate America's most prominent continuing experiment in labor-management cooperation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUBILET, BOBBIE
description: DOUBILET-Bobbie. The Elberon Voters and Property Owners Association mourns the loss of Bobbie Doubilet, a member of our Board of Trustees and Executive Committee for more years than any living member can recall. Her death deprives our Association and community of a respected and clear voice. We will miss her friendship and counsel. Paul Martin Weltz, President Leila Poch, Secretary

title: Z's Beat X Ratings
description: When lawyers for sex shops went to a Federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday in their effort to block the Giuliani administration from enforcing a law banning sexually oriented businesses in residential neighborhoods, EMMA HAROULES BADINI was there.

title: Searching for Truth, but Finding Only Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Derby Field Is Smallest in 22 Years
description: Doug Bredar remembers it well. It was last December, when he was the stakes coordinator at Hollywood Park, presiding over the Bayakoa for fillies. But only one horse ran in the race: Sharp Cat, who naturally won in the racing rarity known as a walkover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCULLOUGH, FRANK S.
description: McCULLOUGH-Frank S. On March 11, 1998 of Rye, New York. Husband of the late Lovedy. Father of Frank S. McCullough Jr of Rye, James E. McCullough of Brooklyn Heights and Judith Ellis of Winder, GA. Grandfather of seven grandchildren and one great grandchild. The family will receive friends Friday 5-9PM at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye. Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of the Resurrection, Saturday 9:45am. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Skilled Nursing Pavillion at United Hospital, 406 Boston Post Rd, Port Chester, N.Y. 10573, would be appreciated.

title: Events; On Display, Art and New York's Past
description: Patterns in Folk Art

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, LILLIAN
description: WEXLER-Lillian. Died February 20, 1998 in New York City. A Memorial will be held on Sunday, March 15 at 3 P.M., in the Warburg Lounge of the 92nd St.Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York.

title: 2 Officers Are Accused Of Taking a Handgun
description: Two Newark police officers have been suspended after an internal sting operation showed that they took a handgun planted in a cache of weapons collected by the department's program to buy back guns, a police spokesman said yesterday.

title: Waste-Hauling Companies Announce $13 Billion Merger
description: Waste Management Inc., the troubled market leader in the garbage business, and USA Waste Services Inc., a rapidly growing rival, announced an unusual merger today that values Waste Management at more than $13 billion and leaves its shareholders owning a majority of the stock but USA Waste's top management in charge.

title: Accounts
description: * I.B.M. Corp., Armonk, N.Y., to Ogilvy One Worldwide, New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group, to handle worldwide direct marketing strategy and program development for small and midsize businesses, which had been handled by 12 agencies including Ogilvy One. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million. Ogilvy One also handles direct marketing for I.B.M's software, servers and services businesses.

title: Fast, and Convenient, Repairs
description: The New York State Thruway Authority has demonstrated that not all construction projects need to proceed at a snail's pace.

title: Currents; FOR THE OFFICE -- Is it a Sculpture or a Chair?
description: Vitra, the German manufacturer of office furniture, has introduced its latest desk chair as if it were a new sports car. The sleek, award-winning chair, called Meda after its designer Alberto Meda, is ergonomic, but has all its spring and knobs hidden. Meda's frame is made of cast aluminum, and recalls an esoteric piece of windsurfing gear. Sculpturally beautiful from every angle, the chair ($1,500 to $2,200) arrived in the Vitra showroom in New York last month. The optional translucent mesh seat and back add to the effect of floating on air. Vitra is at 149 Fifth Avenue (21st Street); (212) 539-1900.

title: Singer With Cold Greeted Warmly
description: Right now, everyone everywhere seems to be fighting off a cold, including Wolfgang Holzmair, the fine lyric baritone from Austria, who gave a recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday night with the pianist Russell Ryan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILEY, JOHN E.
description: WILEY-John E. On March 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Ida L. Wiley. Father of Thomas Wiley and Lucinda Williams. Grandfather of Marcia, Kristen, Todd, Maxene, Edward and Bairn. Great-grandfather of James. Brother of Douglas, Gordon, David, Alan Wiley and the late ''Bud'' and Barbara. Memorial service at Christ Church, Franklin Avenue, Cottage Ridge, Ridgewood, New Jersey on March 12 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to The Parkinson Desease Foundation at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 640650 West 168 St, NYC 10032-9982.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASIN, EDWIN
description: KASIN-Edwin. The faculty, graduates and candidates of Westchester Center for the Study of Psychoanalysis & Psychotherapy mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague Dr. Edwin Kasin. Harold Galef, M.D., Director

title: Hardy Newcomers With Strong Roots
description: PBS seems bent on proving that immigrant families are all alike, in their own ways. Having brought us warm reminiscences of Italian-Americans, Irish-Americans and Jewish-Americans, WLIW, Channel 21, comes through tonight with Polish-Americans. Once again we hear about poor, hard-working newcomers to a strange land and about close families, celebrations and accomplishments.

title: S.E.C. Sues 9 in an Insider Trading Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit today against nine people, charging they made illegal profits of more than $200,000 by trading on insider information about three companies.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of Fred W. Friendly last Thursday reversed the sequence of the Presidential nominating conventions that figured in his 1964 decisions, as president of CBS News, on Walter Cronkite's role as anchor. And a correction in this space on Tuesday misstated a name in the revised account. After Mr. Cronkite had served as anchor for the Republican Convention, Mr. Friendly (not Mr. Cronkite) removed him for the Democratic one. Mr. Cronkite was reinstated as anchor of both conventions in 1968.

title: More Unfamiliar Works in a Series At Lincoln Center
description: Peter Sellars, Bill T. Jones and Sir Edward Elgar are among the artists whose work will be part of the 33d season of Lincoln Center's Great Performers series, starting in October. The series schedule, announced at a news conference yesterday, will offer more than 80 performances at 8 sites, including one as far afield from Lincoln Center as the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue at 84th Street.

title: LIBRARY/WINE; A Database Manager Keeps an Eye on the Cellar
description: ROBERT PARKER'S WINE ADVISOR AND CELLAR MANAGER(Wine Technologies; $139 for deluxe version, $99 for standard; Windows 95 and 3.1.)

title: Cancer Rate Declined From 1992 to 1995
description: The overall cancer rate among state residents fell significantly from 1992 to 1995, largely due to healthier life styles and efforts to control tobacco use, according to a report released yesterday.

title: How to Build a Game's Rooms
description: As early as 1984, teen-agers inhabiting strip-mall arcades around the country eagerly awaited the release of Dragon's Lair. The game had been rumored to have the lushest animations ever.

title: 2 Chinese Steelmakers Weighing Merger
description: China's two most profitable steel companies may merge as the country strives to cut overlapping and increase efficiency. The proposed merger, initiated by Wuhan Iron and Steel Works, or Wugang, has been accepted tentatively by the Baoshan Iron and Steel Corporation, Bi Chenshu, director of Wugang's securities department, said yesterday. A preliminary proposal has been proffered to Chinese leaders at the National People's Congress.

title: Mayor Lays Down the Law On the Steps of City Hall
description: For generations of the righteous and the proud, the ambitious and the wronged, the steps of City Hall have served as a people's pulpit set in stone.

title: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's; Quality Over Quantity
description: To the Editor;

title: Jones Will Probably Start the Opener
description: The Mets are expected to announce on Thursday that Bobby Jones will most likely be their starting pitcher on opening day, March 31 at Shea Stadium.

title: Standing Up for Mac
description: To the Editor:

title: $100 MILLION MERGER BY MAKERS OF PRIVATE-LABEL FOODS
description: International Home Foods Inc. agreed to buy the Grist Mill Company for $14.50 a share, or about $100 million, to expand its private-label food products business. It will also assume $5 million in Grist Mill's debt. The buyer, based in Parsippany, N.J., makes Chef Boyardee pastas and Polaner fruit spreads. Grist Mill, based in Lakeville, Minn., makes and markets private-label cereal bars, fruit snacks and ready-to-eat cereals. It had sales of $108.5 million for the year that ended on May 31. Grist will become a wholly owned unit of International Home Foods. Shares of Grist rose $2.03125, to $14.28125. International Home Food rose 37.5 cents, to $31.125.

title: XEROX TO SELL CRUM & FORSTER UNIT
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell Crum & Forster Holdings Inc. to Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd. for $565 million in cash, completing its withdrawal from the financial services industry. Fairfax, a Canadian insurance and investment management company, will also assume $115 million in debt of Crum & Forster, which provides commercial property and casualty insurance. Xerox said it expected about $75 million in costs from the sale. Xerox said it would take a charge of less than $200 million in the first quarter related to the earlier sales of three units. The Crum & Forster sale will be Xerox's seventh since a 1993 decision to get out of the financial business.

title: On Line and Personal: Wanna Make a Baby?
description: ON-LINE sex is one thing, but how about on-line conception?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLODNY, DOROTHY S.
description: COLODNY-Dorothy S., 92. Of Longboat Key, Florida, died on March 9, 1998 in Sarasota, Florida. She was born on August 26, 1905 in Philadelphia, PA. She moved to Florida thirty years ago from Bronxville, NY. She is survived by 2 sons; Mark J. Colodny of Boca Raton, FL., and Peter I. Colodny of Port Chester, NY; 5 grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: California, taking a cue from other regions, plans a specialized promotion for cultural tourism.
description: A NEW campaign promoting California as a destination for cultural tourism goes beyond the obvious beacons like the Getty Center in Los Angeles. One suggested stop is the Thai Plaza on Hollywood Boulevard, where a Thai Elvis performs on Tuesday nights for throngs of Asian regulars.

title: Beware: These People Want to Take Over the World While You Laugh
description: Like most other acts in the U.S. Comedy Arts Festival here, the Upright Citizens Brigade, a young sketch-comedy group from Manhattan, came with an agenda. ''We just have one goal,'' said one group member, the wiry, curly-haired, dry-witted Matt Besser. ''We want a sketch show on television.''

title: Italian Banks to Combine In a Stock Swap
description: Banca Popolare di Brescia S.p.A. and Banca San Paolo di Brescia S.p.A. reached an agreement yesterday to merge in a stock swap worth about 2.3 trillion lire ($1.28 billion), creating one of the largest regional banks in the wealthy north of Italy in preparation for the single European currency. The stock of both companies has been rising amid reports that a deal was close.

title: For Human Rights
description: ''The code of silence must be cracked from the outside,'' said VAN JONES, a founder of police-abuse databases, as he received a Reebok Human Rights Award at Columbia University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, HENRY T.S.
description: LEE-Henry T.S. On March 10, 1998, of Scarsdale, New York. Husband of Julia T., father of Josette and Stanley. Father-inlaw of Pentti Niiranen and Jeanie Lee. Grandfather of Jennifer and Jonathan Greechan. Family will receive friends at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale, NY Friday 4:30PM-7PM. Funeral at the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, Saturday 9:30AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his memory to the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, 6 Greenacres Avenue, Scarsdale, New York 10583.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: $175 MILLION DEAL FOR 3D-LARGEST DENTAL CARE COMPANY
description: The Protective Life Corporation agreed to acquire United Dental Care Inc. for about $175 million in cash and stock, becoming the third-largest dental managed-care company. Protective Life, a life and health insurer based in Birmingham, Ala., will pay $9.31 in cash and 0.14465 share of its stock for each share of United Dental, which is based in Dallas and provides dental coverage to about 1.8 million members. The transaction gives Protective Life a coast-to-coast network; the combined company will have 2.9 million members in its dental health plans and about $1.3 billion in revenue. Protective Life's shares fell $1.1875, to $69.4375; United Dental Care's rose $1, to $17.9375.

title: On a Border, Tuition War Roils Family; Quirk of Geography Creates School Ordeal
description: Ajmal Zadran was in the middle of a final exam in organic chemistry in the spring of his senior year of high school when a voice came over the loudspeaker.

title: Every Day's a Music Festival on the Web
description: THE Web is alive with the sound of music.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MANHEIMER, BRUCE
description: MANHEIMER-Bruce. The world was a better place when you were here. I miss you. Always loved and never forgotten, Ellen

title: The Japanese Embrace Hip-Hop, and Parappa Is Born
description: PARAPPA the Rapper is what happens when pop culture plays the telephone game. Released as a Sony Playstation title in Japan, Parappa is selling at a steady clip on Main Street, U.S.A., despite the fact that it has no explosions, acrobatic combat or anything in the way of cinematic violence. It is a video game about hip-hop starring a cartoon puppy dog, the eponymous hero. Parappa wears baggy jeans and a stocking cap. He raps in English. His world is spangled with elements of hip-hop culture. But somewhere over the Pacific, everything was warped in translation. And rap, which left our shores as a glorification of the gangsta high life, has returned as something distinctly Japanese: something shiny and round and saturated with color. An animated playground filled with whimsical cartoon characters. A game of Simon Says.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, SAMUEL
description: GROSSMAN-Samuel, 93, March 10, 1998. Funeral services will be held today 10:15 AM, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I.

title: Searching for Truth, but Finding Only Politics; Once a Liar?
description: To the Editor:

title: Searching for Truth, but Finding Only Politics; Cornered by the Media
description: To the Editor:

title: William F. Farah Dies at 78; Led Family Clothing Business
description: William F. Farah, whose men's apparel business was the object of one of the most bitter labor disputes in the history of the apparel industry, died Monday in a private nursing home in El Paso. He was 78.

title: As Thousands Protest, Pinochet Assumes Chilean Senate Seat
description: As thousands protested violently outside the Congress here, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, Chile's former dictator, assumed a much-disputed Senate seat today that protects him from prosecution for crimes committed during his 17 years in power.

title: Red Cross, Under Threat, Pulls Its Workers Out of Kosovo
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross withdrew its staff from the troubled province of Kosovo today because of death threats, removing the only outside aid workers from an area where scores of people have been killed and thousands have fled to the winter wilderness.

title: In Northwest, Computer Security Is a Private-Public Effort
description: IT has no office, no officers, no Web site, no stationery and not even a phone number. It has ''security by obscurity'' and an unusual role in protecting the integrity of networks, databases and computers in public and private offices throughout the Pacific Northwest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENMAN, JESSIE
description: ROSENMAN - Jessie. Devoted wife of the late David. Beloved mother of Howard and Gilbert. Dear sister of Phyllis Saroka. Cherished grandmother of Robin, Jamie, Frederick, Matthew and Eric. Loving great-grandmother of Caroline. Graveside services Fri. 11 A.M., at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: A Bank and an Insurer In Talks in South Africa
description: The Liberty Life Group and the Standard Bank Group, both of South Africa, said yesterday that they were discussing a merger that could be worth at least 35 billion rand ($7 billion). Such a merger would create South Africa's largest company. Neither Liberty Life, South Africa's biggest publicly traded insurance company, nor Standard Bank, its largest bank by assets, disclosed terms.

title: Bridge; A Captain Whose Team Was Caught Cheating
description: A memorable episode in bridge history that made headlines around the world was recalled by the death of Ralph Swimer two weeks ago in London at the age of 83. He was the nonplaying captain of the British team at the 1965 World Team Championships in Buenos Aires and was thrust into controversy near the end of the tournament.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN TUMBLES. The Japanese yen fell to a seven-week low against the dollar on news that financial scandal had spread to Japan's central bank. In New York the dollar settled at 129.32 yen, up 1.45 percent from 127.47 Tuesday.

title: Louima Case Tugs at a Prosecutor's Mask
description: THERE is a cinder-block exterior that many Federal prosecutors develop, an affectless armor that keeps the world from their emotions and hides the sweat from the defense attorneys. There are exceptions to this tendency -- the current occupant of City Hall was one -- but anyone who has spent the last five years looking for wellsprings of emotion from Zachary W. Carter has been disappointed.

title: National News Briefs; I.N.S. Planning to Raise Foreign Adoption Fees
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service plans to raise fees for foreign adoption by more than 160 percent, a move that has drawn sharp criticism from officials of American adoption agencies, who say the increase is unfair and unjustified.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Feb. 28 with an article about Europe's preparations for a single currency misstated Denmark's budget balance for 1997. The country finished the year with a budget surplus -- not a deficit -- equal to 0.7 percent of its gross domestic product.

title: L.I. Health Clinic Mobbed In Wake of Hepatitis Scare
description: A hepatitis warning issued by the Nassau County Health Department on Tuesday induced hundreds of people to converge on a county health clinic yesterday, causing a two-hour traffic jam and depleting the clinic's supply of blood serum, authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLIRON, SHEILA M.
description: MILLIRON-Sheila M., 55. Died Tuesday evening at home. Born October 29, 1942 in New York City, daughter of late Dr. William and Anne O'Dea Horan. Graduate St. Mary's High School, Manhasset, NY. Received B.A. in Home Economics, Marywood University in Scranton, Pennsylvania. Taught school in Syosset, New York, and Jersey City, NJ. Substitute taught in Oakland, New Jersey. Active in family and civic duties including Our Lady of Perpetual Help. Moved to Upper St. Clair, PA., where she was a collector of stuffed animals and dolls. She is survived by her husband of over 21 years, William; a son Stephen Materazzi Jr., Nashville, TN, a daughter Kathryn Materazzi, Carbondale, PA, a step-son Mark Milliron, Marietta, GA, and 4 sisters; Maureen Horan, Poughkeepsie, NY, Mrs. Jeanne Swick, Highland Mills, NY, Mrs. Anita Germano, Clifton, VA., & Mrs. Marian Kropa, Clarks Summit, PA, a grandchild & 12 nephews and nieces. Funeral Sat., Jennings-Calvey Funeral Home, Clarks Summit, PA., with a Mass at 11:00AM, Our Lady of the Snow's Church. Visitation Friday, 2-4, 7-9 PM. Contributions Mercy Hospice, 746 Jefferson Ave, Scranton, PA. 18501 or The American Cancer Society, 700 James Way, Scranton, PA. 18510.

title: Center-Left Danish Coalition Leads in Close Vote
description: With 11 parties in the field, and voters spread from Copenhagen's Little Mermaid to ice-bound Greenland 2,500 miles from here, no one ever said Denmark's general election today would be easy to call. And it wasn't.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOUDREAU, LAURENCE ALLAN GILES
description: BOUDREAU - Laurence Allan Giles. Of Ridgefield, CT formerly of Greenwich Village, New York at the age of 62. Survived by his wife; Carol (nee Emerling) Boudreau. He was the son in law of the late Ernest and Helen Louise Emerling of Great Neck, New York, and Dayton, Ohio. A memorial mass of Christian Burial will take place Saturday at 12 noon in St. Mary's R.C. Church, Ridgefield, Conn. Contributions in Mr. Boudreau's memory may be made to the Ridgefield Library, 472 Main Street, Ridgefield, CT. 06877.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTIKYAN, GRANGER
description: COSTIKYAN-Granger. Count Costikyan died on March 10, 1998, in York, Maine at the age of 90. He made his home in York Harbor and Rancho Mirage, California. A 1929 graduate of Yale College, he was a life long banker, becoming President of First Bank System, Inc. in Minneapolis and a partner of Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. in Chicago and Philadelphia. He is survived by his wife, the former Margaret Lawrence Taylor, 3 daughters: Gail Lawrence Costikyan of Chicago, Joan Ransom Jarvis of York Harbor, Maine, and Wendy Warren Costikyan Smith of London, England; five grandchildren and one great grandson. Memorial services will be held at the First Parish Congregational Church in York, Maine on Sunday, March 15, 1998 at 4 P.M. Interment at a later date in Buffalo, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the First Parish Congregational Church, York Street, York, Maine 03909.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Amex and Nasdaq Reported To Be Discussing Merger

title: Joys of Ham Radio
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about James B. McDougal and the beginning of the Whitewater investigation referred incorrectly to Curtis Wilkie, who helped Mr. McDougal write his memoirs. Mr. Wilkie is a current political reporter for The Boston Globe, not a former one.

title: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's; Life After a Ph.D.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, WILLIAM S.
description: THOMAS-William S. On March 7th, 1998. Died peacefully in the presence of family, at age 85, at the Sherwood Oaks hospice unit in Wexford, PA. Mr. Thomas, who previously resided in Garden City, New York and Alachua, Florida, was a graduate and Trustee Emeritus of Dickinson College. Mr. Thomas had specialized in actuarial work throughout a 39 year career with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. He retired from Metropolitan Life in 1977 as a Senior Vice President (Group Insurance and Pension Operations) and as a member of the corporate executive office. Mr. Thomas was a fellow of the Society of Actuaries. He held memberships in The Union League Club of New York and The Cherry Valley Club in Garden City. He is survived by his three sons and daughters-in-law Anthony and Marcia Thomas of Evanston, IL, William and Kathryn Thomas of Rochester, N.Y., and Richard and Sarah Thomas of Pittsburgh, PA; 7 grandchildren: Adam, Andrew, William III, David, Matthew, Ian and Kathleen, and two great grandchildren, Brandon and Jackie. Calling hours will be on Friday, March 13, from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, Inc., 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, N.Y. 11530. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated St. Anne's Church, 35 Dartmouth Street, Garden City, on Saturday, March 14, 9:15 A.M. Interment will follow at Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Mr. Thomas' name to Dickinson College, Alumni Fund, Carlisle, PA. 17013.

title: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's
description: To the Editor:

title: Shareholders Vote to Approve Merger of MCI and Worldcom
description: The shareholders of the MCI Communications Corporation and of Worldcom Inc. overwhelmingly approved their companies' pending $37 billion merger yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BING, ILSE
description: BING-Ilse. Konrad and Ilse. Precious lives. We loved her photographs. She loved roses. We shall miss them. Cornell Capa, Founder Willis Hartshorn, Director International Center of Photography

title: House G.O.P. Puts Brakes on I.M.F. Funds
description: House Republican leaders said today that they would hold up financing for the International Monetary Fund and back dues owed to the United Nations until the White House agreed to an anti-abortion provision.

title: 75 Crates Could Not Confine An Architect's Imagination
description: THE great age of the metropolitan mansion in New York is long over. But anyone who enjoys its after-echoes will soon have a treat in store at No. 972 Fifth Avenue, where the so-called Venetian Room by Stanford White has been restored and reintegrated into the enormous house that was designed for Payne and Helen Hay Whitney and completed in 1906.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHEL, JEAN (RACUSIN)
description: FISHEL-Jean (Racusin). Age 99, on March 11, 1998, in Hollywood, FL. Beloved aunt of Aaron and Sydney Racusin, Ruth Dattner, Carolyn Gaines and Suzanne Talmadge. Funeral service at Levitt Weinstein, Hollywood, Florida, at 12 noon Friday, March 13.

title: A $4 Billion Global Issue by the World Bank Sells Quickly
description: The World Bank priced its largest dollar-denominated global bond issue ever yesterday, as solid demand from investors insured its quick sale and oversubscription.

title: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's; Low Adjunct Salaries
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents; WALL SCONCES -- Pass The Baton
description: Benjamin Noriega-Ortiz left Puerto Rico in 1982 to study architecture at Columbia University, was John Saladino's head designer and finally went solo. He follows his neo-classical bent with lamps for Nessen Lighting of Mamaroneck, N.Y., including Baton, a 1940's-style, 17-inch wall sconce with a frosted shade that resembles a relay baton. In several finishes, including brushed chrome (right, $225). Nessen Lighting, (914) 698-5577.

title: F.A.A. Report Says Commercial Aviation Grew Strongly in 1997
description: Commercial aviation grew strongly last year and will do so again this year, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HONEYWELL INC., Minneapolis, the maker of automation and control systems, bought Hughey & Phillips Inc., Simi Valley, Calif., a closely held company that makes airfield lighting systems, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, TRUDE
description: GRUBER-Trude. The Division of Social Work & Behavorial Science of the Department of Community and Preventive Medicine of The Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and the Social Work Department of The Mount Sinai Hospital note with deep sadness the passing of our valued colleague, Trude Gruber. Ms. Gruber joined the staff of The Mount Sinai Hospital Department of Social Work in 1970 and was appointed to the faculty of Mount Sinai School of Medicine in 1979. An expert in, and gifted teacher of, family treatment and short-term psychotherapy, she imparted valuable knowledge to both our staff and numerous other healthcare professionals. Her extraordinary talent and generous spirit enriched us all and she will be sorely missed. Gary Rosenberg, Ph.D. Edith J. Baerwald Professor Community and Preventive Medicine Chair, Division of Social Work and Behavioral Science Mount Sinai School of Medicine Susan Blumenfield, D.S.W. Director Department of Social Work The Mount Sinai Hospital

title: Clinton Refuses to Discuss Independent Counsel's Request That He Testify Before Grand Jury
description: President Clinton today refused to discuss whether he would comply with a request from prosecutors to provide grand jury testimony in the investigation of his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Public Eye; The Family Room Hits the Road
description: IN 1972, Michael Webb, a member of the British experimental architecture collaborative Archigram, commented on what he saw as the American car's similarity to the house. ''What with TV, cigarette lighter, quadraphonic sound-around, front seats sliding up and down,'' he wrote, ''the car is better appointed and certainly more admired than its owner's own living room.''

title: Let Us Entertain You
description: At his death last week, time may or may not have passed Fred Friendly by; Time most certainly had. The pioneering newsman's final hours coincided with Time magazine's 75th anniversary blowout at Radio City Music Hall, where newsmakers like Mikhail Gorbachev and Billy Graham rubbed shoulders with Donald Trump, Jack Kevorkian and Sharon Stone. Nearing the end of a century during which the pursuit of fame has often ended in infamy, it was good to hear President Clinton pay tribute to Franklin Roosevelt, and Toni Morrison render homage to Martin Luther King Jr.

title: German Airline Sees '97 Net Soaring 45%
description: Lufthansa, Germany's dominant airline, said yesterday that its net income rose 45 percent in 1997, at the high end of analysts' forecasts. The company said net income rose to 800 million marks ($436.7 million), based on preliminary figures. The airline does not disclose quarterly net income.

title: The Invisible Victory
description: The Boy Scouts would never have known if James Dale hadn't told them. That has always been the difference about the movement for gay rights. Homosexuals aren't visible. They have to stand up and identify themselves in order to be discriminated against. Half a century after one man in Los Angeles began to encourage his friends to do that, many people are still reluctant. For some of them, it is because they have this yearning to do the regular thing: to work hard, to go to church, to be faithful to their friends and good to their parents. They may be monogamous by nature. They may want to fall in love and marry. There are plenty of such people in the United States. They are all the things their critics wish that homosexuals were. They are good Scouts.

title: Democrat's Widow Wins California House Race
description: Lois Capps, a former teacher and school nurse from Santa Barbara, Calif., turned back an aggressive challenge from her Republican opponent to hold onto the Democratic Congressional seat vacated by the death of her husband, Walter, last fall, boosting her party's morale in the first Congressional contest of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, CLEMENT H.
description: MORSE-Clement H. March 11, 1998. Beloved husband and best friend of Ruth. Survived by nieces, nephews, grandnieces, grandnephews and great-grandnieces. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Friday at 11 A.M.

title: Personal Shopper; Pedestals That Turn the Tables
description: A PEDESTAL is permanently in a supporting role. That's its job. Classically, it was simply a single column holding up a statue or an urn rather than a building. But today, there is often a thin line between a table and a pedestal. It all depends on what's on top.

title: L.I. Man Blows Up His Boat, Then Stabs Himself to Death
description: A 45-year-old Long Island man free on $30,000 bail in a drunken-driving case committed suicide early this morning, blowing up his boat and then stabbing himself in the chest rather than surrender title to the craft to a bail bondsmen, law enforcement officials said.

title: Currents; FAST WORK -- Adroit and Comfortable Upholstering
description: Behind every great interior designer is a hand-in-glove relationship with a workroom, where draperies and upholstery are made. The faster and more fastidious the work, the better the designer looks. Kevin Fitzpatrick's City Workroom in the Button District has drawn David Bowie and Polo Ralph Lauren, but he serves retail clients, too. Fast? ''Four weeks is normal, two if you need it,'' he promised. Inventive? Try a Roman bathroom shade sewn from a yellow rain slicker. Or an armchair covered with Indian silk shreds that resemble feathers (right): 270 West 38th Street at Eighth Avenue, Suite 1500; (212) 944-4200.

title: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's; Cum Laude, Inflated
description: To the Editor:

title: 2/30ths of $100,000 For a Party Site
description: The 52d-floor condominium at One Columbus Circle that DONALD J. TRUMP and MARLA MAPLES TRUMP did not move into (they divorced instead) can be rented for $100,000 a month. So how much did Sub-Zero, the manufacturer of designer refrigerators that can be hidden under counters like file drawers for food, pay for a mere two days there? ''I haven't looked at the bill,'' said STEVE DUNLAP, a Sub-Zero vice president.

title: Martyrs' Rites in West Bank Town for Men Israelis Killed
description: Three Palestinian laborers killed by Israeli soldiers were buried as martyrs in this town near Hebron today as violent protests spread in the West Bank and senior Israeli officers struggled to prevent the unrest from spinning out of control.

title: Students and Laptops
description: To the Editor:

title: Searching for Truth, but Finding Only Politics; McDougal's Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's; No Time to Mentor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bowling's Fast Lane Of Slang
description: THEY call it the Information Superhighway, that vast storehouse of important knowledge for the Greater Good of Humankind. Sometimes, of course, the highway can be a low road, a vast storehouse of the most mundane knowledge imaginable, just another tool to help you appear to be more than you are.

title: House Proud; Stanford White, By Memory
description: WOULD it be possible to come out and see the house? ''I see no obstacle,'' the professionally gracious Dick Cavett said, ''since I would be that obstacle.''

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 2 about Theodore W. Schultz, an economist whose research on agriculture and education was honored with a Nobel Memorial Prize, referred incorrectly to his efforts, while on the faculty of Iowa State, to hire the economist John Kenneth Galbraith. Though he recruited Mr. Galbraith, Mr. Galbraith chose to go to Harvard.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Lottery Personnel File Shows Killer Came Back to Work Early From a Leave
description: The lottery employee who went on a deadly rampage last Friday, killing four of his bosses and then himself, had chosen to return to work earlier than he had to, eight days before his leave of absence for stress-related problems ran out, according to his personnel file released today by the State Office of Labor Relations.

title: George Bush Joins Author's Fan Club
description: '' 'To George and Barbara' would be wonderful,'' the man said.

title: Limiting Help at City's 4-Year Colleges
description: Trustees of the City University of New York appear to be leaning toward a plan to ban nearly all students who need remedial work from its four-year colleges, a proposal that goes well beyond a plan put forth 10 days ago and that comes close to what Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been seeking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAZIER, MARY (TINA)
description: FRAZIER-Mary (Tina). On March 10, 1998. Beloved wife of Wilbert. Devoted mother of Wayne, Myrna Perkins and Kathy. Cherished grandmother of Lauren. Services Friday 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Mary Artenna Frazier Fund, c/o Figure Skating in Harlem, 2 Horatio St., NYC 10014.

title: Federal Judge Delays Sex-Shop Enforcement
description: The Giuliani administration will have to wait at least until next week to begin enforcing a zoning law that would ban sexually oriented businesses from residential neighborhoods in New York City.

title: HANSON TO SELL CRANE UNIT FOR $605 MILLION
description: Hanson P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it had agreed to sell Grove Worldwide, its crane manufacturing unit in Shady Grove, Pa., to Keystone Inc. for $605 million. Keystone is the investment arm of Robert M. Bass, the Texas investor, and his associates. Grove, with full-year sales of more than $890 million, is the largest crane maker in the United States and has about a 50 percent share of the North American crane market. Hanson, which said the sale would virtually complete its transformation into a building-materials concern, has been spinning off its manufacturing, chemicals, energy and tobacco businesses since 1995. Proceeds from this sale will be used to eliminate debt.

title: U.S.O.C. Seeks Apology And $3,000 for Incident
description: Faced with limited options, the United States Olympic Committee sounded a conciliatory tone yesterday, saying that it may be willing to settle the room-trashing incident involving the men's hockey team for what amounts to a minimal show of contrition by the players.

title: Settlement By Exchange Is Questioned
description: An administrative law judge said yesterday that an agreement arranged between officials of the New York Mercantile Exchange and a Manhattan lawyer who was suing the exchange was ''certainly unethical'' and violated Federal regulations.

title: Question Lingers as F.C.C. Prepares V-Chip Standards
description: Today, the Federal Communications Commission will formally approve the much-debated television rating codes, and will issue technical standards for manufacturing the microchip inside new television sets, known as a V-chip, that will let parents block programs with violence, sex or vulgar language from screens.

title: The Final Word
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Are in the Running For Liberty Mutual
description: The Liberty Mutual Insurance Company has narrowed a review on its account to four agencies from nine. The account, with billings estimated at $27 million, had been handled for 11 years by Wells BDDP in New York, part of GGT Group, until that agency was dismissed as the review began in January.

title: Review Narrowed At Bell Atlantic
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation has named four finalists to compete for its consolidated media services account, with billings estimated at $200 million. The account has been divided among several agencies.

title: Making Books; A Life Purpose For Biographies
description: Intimidating. Even menacing. They are the serious biographies that sit like plump odalisques on bookstore shelves, seductive yet terrifying. ''Victor Hugo,'' nearly 700 pages with notes. ''Napoleon Bonaparte,'' nearly 800 pages, and a spine two and a half inches wide. One stands and looks and wonders just who is going to buy them. One editor calls them ''summer reading,'' and by that he means it takes an entire summer to read one.

title: Blue Notes, Plenty of Them, for A Jazzman
description: Among the many wonderful moments in ''Side Man,'' Warren Leight's lovely, eye-opening new memory play about a jazz trumpeter, his alcoholic wife and the son who is parent to them both, is a moving second-act tableau that tells you all you need to know about what goes on between a man and his music.

title: All-Girl Schools Questioned As a Way to Attain Equity
description: The American Association of University Women, whose 1992 report asserting that public schools shortchange girls led to increased interest in girls' schools and experiments with girls-only math and science classes, now says that single-sex education is not a good solution to the problems of sex equity.

title: Color Ink-Jet Printers: Looking Beyond Price
description: Q. When I bought my printer, the salesman showed me three different color ink-jet printers in my price range. Although they were drastically different in price, they seemed to have the same features. Is there really any difference in printers for home PC's?

title: Gluttons for Campaign Funds
description: With the election season barely begun, Gov. George Pataki already has an obscenely well-stocked campaign larder -- courtesy of New York's flimsy campaign finance laws and a state Republican Party that shares most of its contributions with the Governor, thus circumventing limits on direct contributions to him. With more than $12 million readied for his re-election race this year, Mr. Pataki has almost four times what Mario Cuomo had collected by this time in the last campaign cycle. Even the better-heeled among the Democrats, who face an expensive primary contest before one of them takes on Governor Pataki, have barely nudged the $3 million mark in the competition for contributions.

title: 3 Slain Palestinians Given Martyrs' Rites
description: Three Palestinian laborers killed by Israeli soldiers were buried as martyrs yesterday as violent protests spread through the West Bank. The killings at an army checkpoint on Tuesday ignited simmering anger among Palestinians over a long deadlock in peace negotiations. Israeli Army officers met with counterparts in the Palestinian police to keep the unrest from spinning out of control.

title: Violent Games Don't Help
description: To the Editor:

title: J RICHARD INDUSTRIES TO BUY PORTEC FOR $76 MILLION
description: Portec Inc. agreed to be acquired by J Richard Industries for $16 a share, or $76 million. Portec shares rose 68.75 cents, to $15.375. J Richard Industries, a unit of the private equity firm Code Hennessy & Simmons of Chicago, makes components used in materials handling, sports and automotive markets. Portec, in Lake Forest, Ill., makes engineered materials handling equipment, such as conveyor-belt systems. It had revenue of $25.5 million in 1997. Portec sold its construction equipment division to Astec Industries in October and its rail products division to the Rail Products Acquisition Corporation in November.

title: Publicis in Talks With Casadevall
description: Publicis S. A. and Casadevall Pedreno & Prg. have begun negotiations for Publicis to acquire Casadevall Pedreno. Further details were not disclosed. The two agencies said the talks would probably last through May.

title: CELLULAR PHONE STAKES IN CAROLINAS GO FOR $190 MILLION
description: Vanguard Cellular Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its cellular telephone operations in North and South Carolina for $190 million. Its operations in Myrtle Beach, S.C., serving a population of 250,000, will go to Triton PCS Inc. for $160 million. The company's 48 percent stake in the cellular operations of Wilmington and Jacksonville, N.C., serving 170,000 people, will be sold for $30 million to the United States Cellular Corporation. Vanguard, based in Greensboro, N.C., will use the proceeds to reduce long-term debt and to finance an extended stock repurchase program. Its stock rose $1 a share, to $17.125. United States Cellular's shares rose 56.25 cents, to $31.875.

title: When Love Turns to Obsession, Games Are No Game
description: A MIDDLE-AGED man recently sat in his high-rise apartment in Manhattan and commanded ancient Grecian fields to bring forth hunters, miners, builders and soldiers. Soon there were fortresses and armies to storm them. A short time later came the inevitable carnage -- flaming ramparts and rotting bodies -- that wars have wrought through the ages.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 2 Exchanges Discuss Merger In a Challenge to Big Board
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers is discussing a merger with the American Stock Exchange that would create a bigger and more formidable competitor to the giant New York Stock Exchange, according to several Wall Street executives.

title: Where Do Computers Go When They Die?; Into the Attic, Under the Ping-Pong Table -- but Hardly Ever Into the Trash
description: IF Americans treated dead people the way they treat dead computers, their basements and closets would be cluttered with family corpses. Under many a desk, there would be a cadaver crammed into the arch meant for knees. Whole warehouses and offices would function as ad hoc mausoleums.

title: Gossip Guru Stars in 2 Roles at Courthouse
description: The first question in the air as Matt Drudge, cyber-gossip extraordinaire, sidled up to the pack of news workers camped endlessly outside the Federal courthouse was whether Mr. Drudge even belonged in their midst.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPARD, RICHARD F.
description: SHEPARD-Richard F. The Workmen's Circle mourns a good friend and a gentleman who respected and supported our cultural Jewish traditions and programs. Condolences to his family and honor to his memory. Robert A. Kaplan, Exec. Director Mark Mlotek, President

title: Big Plan Driven by the Rising Power of the Little Investor
description: Average amateur American investors, pouring their money into mutual funds and retirement accounts, pay little attention to exactly where stocks trade, or how.

title: Asteroid Is Expected to Make A Pass Close to Earth in 2028
description: An asteroid is likely to pass within 30,000 miles of Earth on Oct. 26, 2028, a Thursday, and there is a possibility that it would hit Earth, the international astronomical agency that tallies the orbits of asteroids and comets announced yesterday.

title: Authority With a Sense of Fun
description: OZ CLARKE'S WINE GUIDE

title: Prosecution in Baby's Death Seeks Test Data on Accused
description: Delaware prosecutors have subpoenaed three of Amy S. Grossberg's former lawyers, demanding to know if she underwent lie detector tests other than the two in which she denied ever plotting to kill her newborn son in 1996.

title: Senator Sets Priorities for Tobacco Legislation
description: After a session that illuminated sharp disagreements, Senator John McCain, the pivotal Senator on the tobacco issue, said today that he could now separate the central questions from the more secondary ones.

title: Garden Notebook; Paradise Is a Place Called Wilderness
description: THEY didn't know a thing when they started. The first house they built blew down in a hurricane. They planted the wrong kind of trees -- common slash pines instead of longleaf pines. They halted the deliberate setting of brush fires, not realizing that certain plants and animals thrive after a fire. Still, the tortoise came back.

title: Relocations for China Dam Are Found to Lag
description: The relocation of at least 1.2 million people to make way for the Three Gorges Dam in central China is off to a poor start, calling into question the official timetable for filling the dam's reservoir five years from now, a Chinese social scientist who toured five of the most heavily affected counties in January says.

title: Weary Knicks Misfire Against Hornets
description: John Starks stood in front of a mirror after the game, fidgeting with his tie for 10 minutes or more. He was twisting it and tightening it over and over in search of the perfect knot.

title: And Don't Forget . . .
description: THE World Wide Web site of the Wine Spectator (www.winespectator.com) is an impressive starting point for on-line wine resources. The magazine's text is only one issue behind the newsstand, and there is a free searchable database of 15,000 reviews, with tasting notes and ratings, covering the previous two years. There is a Wine Basics section with essays on tasting and varietals, country-by-country descriptions of wines and more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MILDRED
description: MILLER-Mildred. On March 11, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Arthur Miller. Dear sister of William and Selma Tucker. Loving mother of Jay and Robin; Howard and Linda; and Bob and Phyllis Miller. Beloved Nana of Amy and Scott Horowitz, Lauren, Michelle, Debra, Josh, Andy, Matthew and Lily Miller. Services are today, March 12, 1998 at 10 AM, at Gutterman's (in the Parkside Building) 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY.

title: In the Beginning, There Was Kaypro
description: The Pulitzer-prize-winning writer Justin Kaplan, left, and his wife, the author Anne Bernays, right, have taken a Noah's Ark approach to computer ownership over the years, buying them in pairs. Some have died. Some have become obsolete. Some they have given away. Most just hang around their Cambridge, Mass., home.

title: Economic Scene; The Chinese way: spend out of trouble like Keynesians.
description: JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES may be out of fashion in the West. But in one of the odder twists to the unfolding Asian crisis, his prophets have resurfaced in Beijing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITTMAN, ANNETTE. (NEE BARNETT)
description: HITTMAN-Annette. (nee Barnett). Of Brooklyn, New York on March 7th, 1998 at age 95. The Sternklar and Honig families mourn the loss of their mother, grandmother and great grandmother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSE, KOONG, KAI
description: TSE-Koong-Kai, of New York City passed away peacefully Monday, March 9, 1998, at the age of 91. Born in China and educated at the University of Shanghai, K.K. Tse was hired in 1927 by C.V. Starr, founder of the American International companies, as an accountant in Shanghai. Over a 70-year career with the group that became American International Group, Inc. (AIG), he was an extraordinarily dedicated and talented executive. At his death, he still held positions as Honorary Director of AIG and Chairman of American International Underwriters, Limited of Hong Kong. He will be greatly missed by his many friends and admirers at AIG, where his many accomplishments are a part of the company's history. We, the management and employees of AIG companies around the world, extend our deepest condolences to K.K.'s family, his wife Teh Ying Tse; son Stephen; daughters Cecelia, Angelina, Virginia and Helena; nine grandchildren; and fourteen great-grandchildren. The family will receive friends on Wednesday, March 11 from 2:005:00 P.M. and 7:00 to 9:00 P.M. at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. The funeral will be held on Thursday, March 12 at the Campbell Funeral Home at 9:45 A.M., with the burial immediately following at Ferncliff Cemetery, Secor Road, Hartsdale, N.Y. The family has suggested donations may be made in K.K.'s name to Watchtower Bible & Tract Society, Inc., 25 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, New York 11201. M.R. Greenberg, Chairman American International Group, Inc. and the worldwide staff of AIG

title: Metro Business; Brown Harris Unit Buys Feathered Nest
description: Feathered Nest, a real estate brokerage firm in Manhattan, has been acquired by a new holding company formed by Brown Harris Stevens, a Manhattan brokerage and management firm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, MURRAY
description: PERLMAN-Murray. On March 11, 1998. Husband of Helen. Loving father of Kim and Neva. Brother of Charlotte and the late Julian. Cherished grandfather. Beloved companion and friend of Sy Cassorla. Service Thursday 10:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Searching for Truth, but Finding Only Politics; Counsel Law's Target
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Appeals Court Returns Defeated Mayor of Miami to Post
description: A state appeals court today returned Joe Carollo to the mayor's post he lost in contested balloting four months ago and ruled there was no need to rerun the mayoral election that a judge overturned last week.

title: Masco Acquires Vasco
description: The Masco Corporation said today that it had bought the closely held Vasco Corporation, a European maker of residential decorative radiators, for an undisclosed price as it seeks to bolster European sales. Vasco, based in Dilsen, Belgium, had more than $60 million in 1997 sales, Masco said. Its radiators are used in European heating systems. Vasco will operate as a wholly owned subsidiary of Masco, which is based in Taylor, Mich.

title: State Senator Enters Race for Attorney General
description: Standing before a crowd of 200 jubilant supporters yesterday, State Senator Catherine M. Abate officially entered what is certain to turn into a crowded, contentious race to become the State Attorney General.

title: Sports of The Times; How Much More Time For Milbury?
description: LIKE every other sport in a bottom-line world, hockey is more and more a numbers game.

title: British Giant Reports 4th-Quarter Loss
description: B.A.T. Industries posted a loss in the fourth quarter after taking heavy one-time charges to pay for the sale of its financial services businesses to the Zurich Insurance Company and the costs of a United States tobacco settlement.

title: Transformation as the Key To the Art of Survival
description: Although second-rate Butoh, ''Nocturne,'' the dance-theater piece currently at the Joyce Theater, is not to be written off entirely.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOSEPH, BERENICE HARRIS
description: JOSEPH-Berenice Harris. Ma, on your 19th Birthday and Wedding Anniversary in Heaven. Always in our hearts, and missed so very much. In loving memory. Van, Steve, and Family

title: Computing; Eye to Eye With a Wily Virus
description: I HAD promised to take my husband somewhere new for lunch, so I was on the Web checking out restaurants when I came across an intriguing menu for a Turkish cafe called Istanbul. The place served mantarli borek, manti and, curiously, eggplant salad with wazzu yogurt.

title: Mayor Starts Campaign Over School Financing
description: It was not enough for Mayor Anthony E. Just Sr. of Secaucus to write a letter to his state legislator announcing his opposition to New Jersey's longstanding policy of using property taxes to finance local school budgets. To express his feelings fully, he wrote nearly 1,500 letters, one to every legislator, mayor and school superintendent in the state.

title: Agassi Breezes By Bruguera and Eagerly Awaits Rafter
description: Now in the mood for a rematch with anybody and everybody who has ever played a pertinent role in his tennis travails, Andre Agassi today revisited Sergi Bruguera, the opponent he defeated for an Olympic gold medal in 1996.

title: Many Jobs on Web, but Not All of Them
description: WHEN it comes to on-line job searching, you could say that Rex Ballard is a veteran. Since 1993 -- a year when most employment Web sites were just beginning -- Mr. Ballard, a systems consultant, has been using the Internet to advance his career.

title: Act II: Milbury Again Behind Islanders' Bench
description: Mike Milbury still holds out hope the Islanders can make the National Hockey League playoffs. This morning, in an effort to jump-start the team for its last 19 regular-season games, he fired Coach Rick Bowness and once again took on dual roles as the Islanders' coach and general manager.

title: Coaches Share A Strong Bond After 25 Years
description: Not long after the Rutgers women's basketball team had advanced to the finals of the Big East tournament last week, Coach C. Vivian Stringer joked that she was going to rush a videotape of the game to her friend John Chaney of Temple. After all, she said, it was Chaney's defense, adopted by Stringer, that Rutgers used to win the day.

title: About New York; His Crime? Tardiness. Call the Police.
description: BENNY TORRES was sorting through the mail inside his insurance office in Red Hook two weeks ago when he noticed the official-looking envelope from the police. It was from the 72d Precinct, which he thought odd, since he lived and worked in the 76th. Then he opened the letter, and things got bizarre.

title: Searching for Truth, but Finding Only Politics; Blumenthal Subpoena
description: To the Editor:

title: C. E. Hall, 36, AIDS Patient Who Sued to Die
description: Charles Edward Hall, the AIDS patient who fought in the Florida courts for the right to die with the help of a doctor, died on Monday at his home in Beverly Hills, Fla. He was 36.

title: 1993 Immigrant Smuggling Case Ends in Organizer's Guilty Plea
description: The mastermind of the 1993 Golden Venture voyage, an ill-fated effort to smuggle hundreds of Chinese immigrants into the United States on a decrepit freighter, pleaded guilty in a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday to Federal charges of manslaughter and alien smuggling.

title: Diary of a Wordsmith, Or Is That Wordjones?
description: LAUGHING MATTERS

title: A Taste of Justice System for 4 Teen-Age Suspects
description: In two cases in recent days, teen-agers pleaded guilty to killings that took the public's breath away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, AIDA
description: LEWIS-Aida. Devoted mother of Diane Kozack and Michael Lewis. Dear sister of Herb Crane. Loving sister-in-law of Ruth. Adored grandmother of Dana. Also survived by the caring neices and nephews of the Crane family. Services Thursday, 12 Noon at Schwartz Brothers Chapels, 76th Road & Queens Blvd., Forest Hills.

title: Judgment for Terrorism Is $248 Million
description: In the largest judgment under a 1996 antiterrorism law, a Federal district judge ordered the Government of Iran today to pay $247.5 million in damages to the family of a 20-year-old New Jersey exchange student who was killed in a terrorist bombing in Israel three years ago.

title: Saul Novack, 79; Nurtured Queens College Music
description: Saul Novack, the former dean of arts and humanities at Queens College and a professor emeritus at the college's Aaron Copland School of Music, died on March 4 at New York Hospital. He was 79 and lived in Belle Harbor, N.Y.

title: Nice Videos Can't Hide Flaws
description: WINES OF THE WORLD GOLD EDITION

title: National News Briefs; Jury Considers Case Against Sergeant Major
description: A jury of four officers and four soldiers retired to a deliberation room here today to consider the testimony of 119 witnesses, the credibility of six female accusers and the character of Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, who is on trial here for sexual misconduct and obstruction of justice.

title: PHONE COMPANIES CANCEL $63 MILLION MERGER PLANS
description: The ACC Corporation has scrapped its proposed $63 million acquisition of US Wats Inc. because of delays, the two long-distance phone companies said yesterday. Shares of US Wats, which is based in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., fell 93.75 cents, to $1.15625. ACC's shares rose 59.375 cents, to $51.25. The companies said reasons ''beyond their control'' had made it impossible to complete the deal before March 31. ACC, based in Rochester, decided not to extend the agreement because it would delay its $1 billion acquisition by Teleport Communications Group. Teleport agreed in November to acquire ACC. In turn, Teleport agreed in January to be acquired by the AT&T Corporation for $11.3 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPELMAN, FANNIE
description: KOPPELMAN-Fannie. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Frank and Cynthia Koppelman, Paul and the late Doris Rosenblum. Adored grandmother of Mitchell, Paul and Kenneth Koppelman, Beth and the late Peter Rosenblum. Grandmother-inlaw of Debbie and Marie. Cherished great - grandmother of Adam, Maryn, Noa, Tani, Dara and the late Kelly. This extraordinary lady will be sorely missed. Services are on Thursday, at 1 P.M., Gutterman's (The Parkside Building), 98-60 Queens Boulvevard, corner 66th Ave., Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARPENSTEIN, ROSE
description: KARPENSTEIN-Rose. We mourn the passing of the mother of our esteemed member Israel Karpenstein and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Saying No in the Land of Yes; Japanese Rail Executive Stands Up for Shareholders
description: Never in his wildest dreams did Masatake Matsuda imagine he would tell the Prime Minister no.

title: COLUMBUS MCKINNON TO BUY LICO INC. FOR $155 MILLION
description: The Columbus McKinnon Corporation agreed to buy the closely held Lico Inc. for $155 million in cash to expand its materials handling equipment business. Columbus McKinnon, of Amherst, N.Y., makes lift tables, chain and wire rope hoists, alloy and high-strength carbon steel chain and forged accessories. Lico, through its operating subsidiary, Automatic Systems Inc., makes and designs conveyors, electric monorails, robotic indexing systems and automatic transfer systems primarily for the auto industry. Lico, based in Kansas City, Mo., with about 275 employees, had sales last year of $137.5 million. Columbus McKinnon's shares rose 56.25 cents, to $24.6875.

title: Bright Students Reaping Rewards on Slopes
description: When it comes to Loveland, Colo., nature seemed to have young skiers and snowboarders in mind. Teen-agers flock to the rolls, pitches, cliffs and occasional low-lying shrubs in the above-treeline slopes of Loveland the way their parents seek the manicured trails of, say, Deer Valley, Utah, or Stowe, Vt.

title: Currents; INDIAN MUSEUM -- Southampton Cabin Built
description: Just a log's roll from some of the poshest homes in Southampton is an eloquent reminder that this prime acreage once belonged to the Shinnecock Indians. A modest pine log structure, bleached salty white, is the new Cultural Museum for the 500-member Shinnecock nation, built with a $200,000 grant from the casino-enriched Connecticut Pequots. It was designed by Beaver Creek Log Homes, a business of the Oneida Indian nation. Logs were built in the traditional method, planed to fit snugly without joinery or mortar, and assembled on the Montauk Highway site, just west of Southampton. The museum, opening this summer, will be the hub of activities on the 800-acre reservation, with an amphitheater and a ''living museum'' for wigwam- and canoe-building. An additional $400,000 fund-raising drive is under way for an indigenous school. The architect Campion A. Platt contributed time to the project.

title: A Growing Headache: Ease in Faking Currency
description: As technology transforms the art of counterfeiting, rogue artisans who toil over printing presses are yielding to criminals with personal computers, mousepads and inkjet printers. On Thursday, the guardians of the nation's currency will call for changes to counter the revolution.

title: Crucial Call Is Disclosed in Teamster Case
description: Ron Carey's main accuser testified against the teamsters' president for the first time in public today, and told about a short, sketchy telephone conversation that could determine Mr. Carey's fate: whether he is expelled from the union or indicted.

title: Experts See Need to Control Antibiotics and Hospital Infections
description: Stricter control of antibiotic use and more stringent prevention measures are needed to stop the growing and related problems of drug-resistant and hospital-acquired infections, experts said today at a scientific meeting here.

title: Pentagon Blames Jet's Crew For Ski-Lift Disaster in Italy
description: The Pentagon has concluded that the American pilot and crew were responsible for the accident last month that killed 20 people when a Marine Corps jet struck a ski lift's cable in Italy, and they should face disciplinary charges, officials said today.

title: Ramp Project Will Close Some F.D.R. Drive Lanes
description: A $10.2 million project to reopen an on ramp onto the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive is expected to close the southbound lanes of the drive for four weekends from 63d to 42d Streets over the next nine months, state officials announced yesterday. The work is to begin on Friday at 10 P.M. to reopen an on ramp onto the northbound side of the drive at East 48th Street that has been closed for a decade. The southbound side will be reopened at 5 A.M. on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRATEL, JOSEPH
description: DRATEL-Joseph. Beloved husband of Heidi. Devoted father of Louise, Patti, Billy and Joshua; devoted brother of the late Bella Mishaan. Adored grandfather of Daniel, Mark, Charles, Robert, Asher, Julia, Jonathan and Sidney. Died March 10, 1998 in Jupiter, Florida. He was a lawyer and CPA, and Chairman of the Board of the Dratel Group, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange Member firm that he co-founded in 1980. He will be missed. Funeral services at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave., 10:45AM Friday.

title: The World of Paula Jones: A Lonely Place Amid Clamor
description: Paula Corbin Jones has a personal hairdresser, who traveled with her here recently, providing touch-ups as needed while she signed autographs. But she has no car in freeway-laced Los Angeles, and during her husband's work day is all but housebound with two preschool-age children in their one-bedroom apartment.

title: After Eight Turbulent Years, Former President of the Board of Education Loses Seat
description: Carol A. Gresser, who as New York City Board of Education president helped name schools chancellors and shape policy for the country's largest school system for eight frequently turbulent years, was ousted yesterday by the Queens Borough President, Claire Shulman, a one-time ally who is now a political supporter of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Currents; WRIGHT COPY -- Shedding Light
description: Frank Lloyd Wright designed it as a table lamp for Taliesin, his home in Wisconsin; now, the Japanese manufacturer Yamagiwa has reconfigured it as a 49-inch-tall floor lamp. While an altered Wright design may inspire debate, the lamp was made under the auspices of the Wright Foundation. The $1,150 lamp (cherry or ash) comes with a rice paper diffuser. Yamagiwa catalogues, (888) 879-8611.

title: Report Says Crime Is Rampant At Hotels for People With AIDS
description: A report commissioned by the Giuliani administration on conditions in the city's single-room-occupancy hotels for people with AIDS has found that criminal activity is rampant in the hotels, with the full knowledge of some of the city workers stationed in the hotels to assist residents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADIN, ALVIN JAY BERT
description: RADIN-Alvin Jay Bert. On Tuesday, March 10, 1998, of Glen Ridge, husband of Doris, father of Roy, Robin and Andrew, grandfather of Katie and Eric. Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, NJ, Friday, March 13, 1998 at 11:30AM. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to the Hospice Care, Inc., of Glen Ridge, NJ.

title: Currents; ART DECO -- Beholding Lysistrata: Masterpiece on Block
description: This curly-haired vixen is ''Lysistrata.'' And even if you can't afford her -- at $50,000 to $70,000 -- she's worth seeing before the gavel falls at Phillips Fine Art Auctioneers and Appraisers next Friday, March 20. In 1930, Donald Desky abstracted her profile in lacquered wood and inlaid chrome on a three-panel screen designed for Gilbert Seldes, the drama critic, who was then adapting the Aristophanes comedy. This American Art Deco masterpiece inspired many of Mr. Desky's graphics and textiles for Radio City Music Hall, said Usha Subramanian, Phillips's director of 20th-century decorative arts. Phillips Fine Art is at 406 East 79th Street; (212) 570-4830.

title: Searching for Truth, but Finding Only Politics; Starr's Empty Boat
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT SURGES. Wheat rose 2 percent to a three-month high on fear that snow and freezing cold have imperiled Midwest crops. May soft red winter wheat rose 6.75 cents, to $3.48 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Essay; Dear Mr. Master
description: The following appeal was issued today by Buddy, the First Dog:

title: Calendar; Shows on Art And Letters
description: Not Your Traditional Boxes

title: Judge Tries to Save Nomination Before Senate
description: Frederica Massiah-Jackson, a local judge in Philadelphia, tried today to salvage her troubled nomination to be a Federal judge at an extraordinary Senate hearing. But it appeared that she failed to change many minds.

title: Take Your Pick, Running Rebels or Cunning Tigers
description: Princeton will whip the basketball around the perimeter a dozen times. The Tigers will make aggressive cuts through the pivot and they will often spend 30 seconds in search of an open 3-point field goal or an easy layup. It is the Princeton way. It sounds basic, but defending the Tigers is difficult.

title: Kofi Annan and Washington Smooth Some Rough Edges
description: President Clinton met today with Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations and assured him that the United States would consult with the Security Council before taking any military action against Iraq.

title: State Grant Money to Spur Bronx Housing Development
description: After languishing for several years, a plan to build Melrose Commons, a 1,700-unit housing development in the heart of the Bronx suddenly seems to be gaining momentum.

title: What's Trendy on Campus? Adjunct Faculty and Easy A's; Reverse Seniority
description: To the Editor:

title: For Seconds, Air Force One Disappeared From Radar
description: Air Force One disappeared from an air traffic controller's radar screen for at least 12 seconds on Tuesday morning while the plane was carrying President Clinton over the New York metropolitan area, apparently because of a recurring problem with a new radar in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOWERS, JAMES PAUL, JR.
description: FLOWERS-James Paul, Jr. On March 9th, 1998. Dearly beloved husband of Helen Flowers. Loving father of Margaret Lane of Wayne, Maine, and adoring grandfather of Lt. Carroll and Meredith Lane. Dear brother of Nina Heldt. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday at 11am. Interment private. Please omit flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MOE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Moe. Age 90, of New York, died Tuesday, March 10, 1998. He is survived by devoted wife Anna Goldstein.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: The Slow Ways of Wisteria

title: Mexican Officer, Critic of Army, Is Sentenced to 14 Years in Theft
description: A military tribunal, waving aside contradictory testimony and inconclusive evidence, convicted a dissident general on two counts of criminal corruption today and sentenced him to 14 years and 8 months in jail.

title: LIBRARY/WINE; Tasting Wine Lore Via Computer
description: THE body of knowledge that wine enthusiasts must confront can be described, with understatement, as encyclopedic. Oenophiles face a lifetime of education in history, geography, microclimatology, viticulture, microbiology and marketing, to say nothing of the mighty arsenal of evocative descriptors -- from cedar, straw and grapefruit to bubble gum and road tar -- they must be ready to deploy at tastings.

title: Lemaire Shifts Devils' Centers
description: The Devils refuse to lose even if they play without Doug Gilmour and Bob Carpenter, their top centers. They have enough players to fill the void and keep their undefeated streak (9-0-3) going.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLDORF, JULIAN MARK
description: WALLDORF-Julian Mark. On March 10, 1998, beloved husband of Marion (nee Bernstein), loving father of Suzanne and Steven, father-in-law of Maryann, grandfather of Jenny and Karen Walldorf, Ann, Megan, and Nicholas Fountain, Charlotte and Jane Wiesenberg. A CPA for over 50 years, he was a former Senior Partner of H.J. Behrman & Co, and a native New Yorker. Funeral services Thursday 1 P.M. Westchester Reformed Temple, Scarsdale, NY. Please omit flowers.

title: Searching for Truth, but Finding Only Politics; A Revealing Moment
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVACK, MEYER
description: LEVACK-Meyer. We mourn the loss of our member and extend heartfelt sympathy to his family. Temple Sinai of Long Island Paula Jayne Winnig, Rabbi Evelyn Maltman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIFFORD, SAMUEL A.
description: GIFFORD-Samuel A. When a human being is born the journey of life begins and our purpose for this life that the Almighty has granted us has been charted. Sam Gifford's life was a beacon to us all. His memory is a blessing to all who were touched by his guidance and grace. We mourn his passing for he was an esteemed member of the paper industry as well as loved and cherished by his family and friends. He was a personification of a mensch. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Millmar Paper Sales

title: Officer Cleared in Kicking Incident
description: A police officer found guilty by a departmental judge of kicking a Bronx teen-ager in the groin during a 1993 traffic stop -- so hard that the youth ultimately lost a testicle -- was acquitted of criminal charges in State Supreme Court in the Bronx on Tuesday.

title: Many Serbs Would Just Rather Not Fight to Keep Kosovo
description: Few Serbs announce any qualms in the first moments of conversation, but not far beneath the surface outrage over the turmoil in Kosovo lurks opposition to any notion of fighting to keep the southern province.

title: HDTV: Not Heart-Stopping, but a Bit Too Close
description: WHEN engineers at WFAA-TV in Dallas recently flipped a switch to become one of the nation's first regular digital broadcasters, a dozen wireless heart monitors stopped working at the heart-surgery recovery center at the Baylor University Medical Center. When the problems vanished suddenly, clinical engineers were baffled -- it turns out that all was well as soon as WFAA turned off its transmitters for the night.

title: Searching for Truth, but Finding Only Politics; Spending Gone Berserk
description: To the Editor:

title: Battle Cry of the Technorealists
description: ANDREW SHAPIRO, a 29-year-old writer, was commiserating over lunch in Greenwich Village one day last summer with a fellow author, David Shenk. Their problem: in writing and speaking, they spend a lot of time in linguistic contortions, trying to explain that they neither love nor hate technology. Unlike previous generations, they have grown up with technology. They don't expect it to bring about utopia, nor do they demonize it.

title: Sterner Measures Sought for Violent Criminals
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today renewed his attack on first-time violent offenders with a revised proposal to keep them in prison for fixed terms, limit their parole and extend their supervision after release. Although a similar bill failed last year, this time even the critics say the idea has a real chance of passing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVACK, SAUL
description: NOVACK-Saul. Faculty, friends, and students past and present of the Aaron Copland School of Music at Queens College, City Univerity of New York, mourn the death on March 4, at age 79, of the visionary teacher, scholar of musical structure, former chairman and later Dean of the Arts, who conceived and brought to reality so many of our educational programs. His abiding concern to foster the best in each of us, and untiring labors to create the means to achieve the best, marked him as a leader most rare. His crowning work was the creation of the School of Music and the beautiful new music building that houses it. ''Si monumentum requiris, circumspice.'' Contributions in his memory may be made to the Saul Novack Scholarship Fund, School of Music, Queens College, Flushing, New York 11367. A memorial concert will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, NATHAN
description: OWEN-Nathan. Formerly of Greenwich, Connecticut and Basin Harbor, Vermont, Mr. Owen died at home in Palm City, Florida on March 9, 1998. Devoted husband of Janet, beloved father of Patricia, David and Lorinda, and adoring grandfather of nine, great grandfather of one. Mr. Owen was the Founding Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of General Signal Corporation, before which he was a pioneering venture capitalist with J.H. Whitney and Co. Donations to Hospice.

title: Carefully, Molinari To Meet the Press
description: SUSAN MOLINARI may not have the run of the talk shows when Doubleday publishes her autobiography next month.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FOX, PAUL
description: FOX-Paul. Our birthday. Thinking of you always. Miss you. Love, Lynn

title: Swedish Outlet Chain Gambles It Can Change Consumer Tastes : Will Cheap Chic Win Over Stylish French?
description: PARIS  "Paris, here we are!" gushed gigantic billboards as the Swedish cut-price clothing firm, H&M, brought its wear for the first time to a global fashion capital.

title: Talk About Obsession: Ahab Is Back
description: Before the lowly sailor Ishmael sets foot on the whaling ship the Pequod, or sets eyes on Captain Ahab, another character in Melville's ''Moby-Dick'' prepares him for the meeting: ''He's a grand, ungodly, godlike man, Captain Ahab; doesn't speak much; but, when he does speak, then you may well listen.''

title: Wiggling, Jiggling, Giggling: Fun With Blobs
