description: Simple, colorful fun bobs around the stage of the New Victory Theater and spills into the audience in ''Air Time,'' the relaxing, giggle-inducing show that will finish its run this week with five weekend performances beginning today.

title: First-Round Upsets
description: Top-ranked North Carolina was an easy winner and highly seeded South Carolina was a surprise loser. Xavier was also an upset victim, and for Temple it was hardly a day at the beach. But for Princeton, with a 27-1 record this season, it was just another day at the office in a 69-57 victory in the first round of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

title: Into the Abstract, With Color and Caution
description: Early modernist abstraction is having a bit of a moment in and around New York City these days. Some of its first stirrings are visible in three museum shows, all devoted to artists who started pushing Cubism in new directions in 1909 and 1910, just as it was emerging from the studios of Picasso and Braque into the competitive esthetic light of Paris.

title: Quarterly Profit Falls Short At National Semiconductor
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation today reported earnings slightly below analysts' estimates for its most recent quarter, after warning last month that results would fall short of expectations. National said it expected a loss for the current quarter, after a further decline in revenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, ROSA
description: ISRAEL-Rosa. The overseers and staff of Brookdale Center on Aging, Hunter College mourn the death of Rosa Israel, sister of our Overseer, Romie Shapiro, and we extend our sympathies to Romi and Blanche and the family.

title: On My Mind; A Tour of China
description: In October 1994, when President Clinton was packing for a trip to Syria, I prepared and printed a proposed tour for him, in Damascus or an easy limousine ride away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, BENEDICT
description: GINSBERG-Benedict, 1908-1998. On March 12th. Beloved husband for 63 years of Adele Wall Ginsberg, father of Phillip and Judith Ginsberg, father-in-law of Paul LeClerc and Janice Stanich. A 1929 graduate of Fordham Law School, then founded the firm of Ginsberg, Sommerfield & Weiss. Funeral services will be on March 13th at 1 PM at Larchmont Temple. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Larchmont Temple and to the Dorot Jewish Division of The New York Public Library.

title: Mrs. Gresser Moves On
description: New York City's Board of Education is a highly politicized forum where the Mayor and the five Borough Presidents play out their alliances and antipathies through their appointees. The political nature of the enterprise was underscored this week when Queens Borough President Claire Shulman ditched Carol Gresser, one of the board's most seasoned and independent members, in favor of a little-known bank executive regarded as acceptable to Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, although the Mayor denies being involved.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Toy Biz Says Marvel Creditors Back Plan
description: Toy Biz Inc. officials said yesterday that they had won the support of the Marvel Entertainment Group's unsecured creditors for a plan to combine the companies and bring the struggling comic book publisher out of bankruptcy.

title: F.C.C. Approves Ratings System for TV; Sets With Blockers Will Be on Market Within a Year
description: Two years after Congress passed a measure requiring the television industry to enable parents to block objectionable programs from their homes, the Federal Communications Commission today approved the ratings system hammered out last year by broadcasters, parent advocacy groups and the Motion Picture Association of America.

title: Matthew Benedict
description: Alexander and Bonin

title: With the Way to Power Open, Hindu Nationalists Falter
description: India's quest for a new government faltered today when the main Hindu nationalist party fell into dispute with a major ally, leaving the door open for a possible rival bid for power by the Congress Party.

title: Jack Davies, 74, an Innovator In the Sparkling Wine Industry
description: Jack Davies, a businessman turned winemaker who, with his wife, Jamie, transformed Schramsberg Vineyards in the Napa Valley of California into one of the country's pre-eminent producers of sparkling wine, died on Tuesday at his home at the winery near Calistoga. He was 74.

title: Kosovo Leader Urges Resistance, but to Violence
description: Ibrahim Rugova, the President of the self-declared Republic of Kosovo, who comes close to being revered among the ethnic Albanian majority here, sat behind his desk in his small office today and talked of literature. Across town, a Serbian Government delegation waited, professing a desire to negotiate a solution to the violence here.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Manuel Pineiro, Spymaster For Castro, Is Dead at 63
description: Manuel Pineiro, the ruthless but urbane spymaster who for more than 30 years led Cuba's intelligence apparatus and directed its efforts to export revolution to the third world, died in a car crash in Havana early today, the Cuban state news agency Prensa Latina reported. He was 63.

title: Assembly Speaker Proposes State Oversight of School Construction Authority
description: Saying he was fed up with a school construction process in New York City that has been notoriously inefficient and sometimes hazardous to students, the Speaker of the State Assembly, Sheldon Silver, called yesterday for stringent state monitoring of the agency responsible for building and repairing city schools.

title: Public Schools, Redefined
description: There are days when, tired of arguing in favor of Gov. George Pataki's proposed charter-school legislation, I fantasize about moving to Scarsdale. How uncomplicated it would be to send my daughter off to a well-financed, energetic, successful local school while I, in good conscience, talked up the benefits of her public school education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGULAS, DAVID
description: MORGULAS-David. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family of the late David Morgulas, a founder of the law firm of M. Carl Levine, Morgulas and Foreman. Dave was a keen scholar and practitioner for more than 60 years. He truly loved the law. Judy and Edwin Efros

title: The Vietnam War's Costs, Shown Fearlessly by a Gentle Casualty
description: The photographer who is perhaps most identified with the Vietnam War, and who showed the tortured, heartbreaking face of that conflict on the pages of Life magazine, is the British-born Larry Burrows. Like the legendary photographer Robert Capa, Mr. Burrows too lost his life while covering that distant war.

title: Courts Should Allow Parental Immunity; Presidential Pastors
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Possible Wall St. Winners

title: Japan to Give Sick Banks $11 Billion More
description: The Government agreed today to pump 1.42 trillion yen, or nearly $11 billion, into 17 Japanese banks as part of a program to replenish their capital and try to restore public confidence in the debt-burdened financial system.

title: Man in the News; A Cheery Herald of Fear: Brian Geoffrey Marsden
description: If Earth must have an astronomical bugler, a herald for the trackers of comets and asteroids who sounds the alarm when one might hit, it helps if it can be a scientist so sanguine, so droll that he can make possible global catastrophe sound like good news.

title: IN THE BRONX WITH: Billy Crystal; Facing 50 With Memories of the Mick
description: Billy Crystal stood in the middle of center field and looked at the great curving grandstand of Yankee Stadium looming up and all around him, an embracing wall of empty blue seats. A slow smile spread across his face. ''Look at that throw to the plate,'' he said. ''Look how far that is.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, ERIC
description: WASSERMAN-Eric. Beloved son of Samuel and Sandra Wasserman. Adored brother of Robert and Cary. Beloved grandson of Ethel Carmel Wasserman. Also son of Pat LaPedus. Your friends and your family love you and miss you. We welcome friends to our home to celebrate your life. Services Sunday, March 15th, 10 AM, at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue at 55th Street.

title: Light From Tiny Galaxy Reveals Most Distant Object Ever Seen From Earth
description: Light from a tiny, misshapen galaxy on the other side of the universe indicates that it is the most distant object ever seen from Earth, astronomers said today.

title: Observer; A Dog, a Bible, a Kiss
description: I have just made the annual late-winter movie rounds. Here are my five nominations for Academy Awards for best moments in films seen during the tour:

title: Strong Retail Sales Report Pushes Share Prices Higher
description: Most major stock indexes reversed early losses yesterday and ended higher, helped by more good news on the economy and further indications that the robust demand for shares is showing few signs of slowing down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOEHNING, JOHN A., SR.
description: BOEHNING-John A., Sr. Of Baldwin on March 12, 1998. Retired Assistant Traffic Manager, J.C. Penney & Co. Beloved father of Rev. John A. Boehning, Jr. and Mary Anne Boehning. Reposing at Weigand Bros Funeral Home, 2283 Grand Ave., Baldwin. Visiting hours Friday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Saturday 9:45 AM at Queen of the Most Holy Rosary RC Church, Roosevelt, LI.

title: Following His Troubadour Lineage, but Cutting a New Path
description: ''I'll never be Irving Berlin,'' Rufus Wainwright lamented Wednesday night at the Fez. He probably won't be the next Verdi, either, although he said he identified with the master of elephant ine opera. Mr. Wainwright need not cultivate such chimeras. With a forthcoming debut album on the well-financed Dreamworks label and a growing fan base of cosmopolitan hipsters, this youthful composer of beguiling serenades is already becoming pop's favorite new artiste.

title: Annan Tries to Untangle U.N. Dues From Abortion
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan asked House Republican leaders today to justify their decision to hold up payment of back dues to the United Nations until the Administration agrees to a provision cutting off aid to groups that support abortion.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: From Fantasy To Opening Day

title: Good News on Transit
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokihiro Sato
description: Leslie Tonkonow

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTIKYAN, GRANGER
description: COSTIKYAN-Granger. Count Costikyan died on March 10, 1998, in York, Maine at the age of 90. He made his home in York Harbor and Rancho Mirage, California. A 1929 graduate of Yale College, he was a life long banker, becoming President of First Bank System, Inc. in Minneapolis and a partner of Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. in Chicago and Philadelphia. He is survived by his wife, the former Margaret Lawrence Taylor, 3 daughters: Gail Lawrence Costikyan of Chicago, Joan Ransom Jarvis of York Harbor, Maine, and Wendy Warren Costikyan Smith of London, England; five grandchildren and one great grandson. Memorial services will be held at the First Parish Congregational Church in York, Maine on Sunday, March 15, 1998 at 4 P.M. Interment at a later date in Buffalo, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the First Parish Congregational Church, York Street, York, Maine 03909.

title: Exhibition on Camps
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Was Told How Nicotine Was Raised For 'Oomph'
description: A former top manager at the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company secretly told Federal regulators in 1994 that the company manipulated nicotine levels in some products to give them more ''oomph'' and ''pizazz,'' according to a transcript of the conversation obtained by The New York Times.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Do the recent reports that spice plants contain powerful chemicals that suppress bacteria have anything to do with the current surge in New York's Indian restaurant population? I don't know. I do know that Pondicherry opened late last year, Tabla is to open in the summer and Chola has just opened on East 58th Street.

title: Getting the Right Beat:The Behind-the-Runway Music Masters
description: PARIS  Runway music is a savvy mix of old and new but never quite what you heard on the radio, thanks to fashion's sound wizards  whether it is Catherine Deneuve, to the tune of Erik Satie, explaining her craft for Martin Margiela's at Hermes, or whether it is a mix of the greatest hits from the group Stereolab for Marc Jacobs's modernism at Louis Vuitton.

title: Aiming for Business Readers This Time, Gates Plans 2d Book
description: William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, intends to write a new book in an effort to showcase his talents as a technologist and burnish an image tarnished by a Government lawsuit charging his company with monopolistic practices.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: Attack of the Giant Rock
description: Those early and alarming claims that a huge asteroid might be headed for a collision with Earth undoubtedly elicited the same initial response from most readers. But once they got done calculating exactly how old they would be on Oct. 26, 2028, their reactions were more diffuse. People who are middle-aged now may have been taken with the idea of going out with a bang. Generation-X'ers probably nodded grimly at yet more proof that they were never going to get to collect Social Security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASS, FLORENCE
description: BASS-Florence. On March 12, 1998. Loving mother of Matthew and Roger, grandmother of Michael, Gregory, Julia and Allison. Services Sunday, 9 AM, ''The Riverside,'' 180 W. 76th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, THOMAS M.
description: WYMAN-Thomas M. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 19, 1998 at 5:00PM at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street, New York. Contributions may be made to the Panwy Foundation, 10 Valley Drive-9 Greenwich Office Park, Greenwich, CT. 06831.

title: London Journal; What, P.R. at the Palace? A Royal Bother, but . . . .
description: When they saw how angry the public was after the death of Diana, the Princess of Wales, members of the British royal family realized with an altogether unpleasant jolt that their own behavior was at issue. All of a sudden, they were out of touch. They were unloved. They were Stoics in the age of Oprah.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD HOME TO BUY ESTES HOMEBUILDING
description: The Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Estes Homebuilding Company and its affiliated companies for $47 million. Estes, based in Tucson, Ariz., is expected to deliver about 850 homes in Tucson and Phoenix in 1998, and provide revenue of about $100 million. Kaufman expects the combined operations to deliver about 2,000 homes in 1999. Kaufman, a residential construction company based in Los Angeles, said it expected the acquisition to add modestly to its earnings per share in 1998 and to add significantly in 1999. Its shares rose 31.25 cents, to $31.875.

title: Camping in the Cold: A Game of Survival
description: Everyone who has camped in the winter has a story to tell. Here's mine: 10 years ago, my brother and I drove from Brooklyn to the Adirondacks to watch a sled-dog race in Saranac Lake, N.Y. The call of the wild (and the scarcity of cheap motels) inspired us to spend the night in a lean-to in the very snowy woods.

title: Metro Business; Group Surveys Nightclubs
description: The New York nightclub industry pumped $2.8 billion into the city's economy last year and accounted for 27,040 jobs and $800 million in wages, according to a study that was released yesterday.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Plan on Immigration Misses Point; Thinking Globally
description: To the Editor:

title: Feng Mengbo
description: Holly Solomon

title: '97 Current-Account Deficit Took a Jump
description: The deficit in the United States current account, the broadest measure of foreign trade, jumped to its highest level in 10 years in 1997, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Clinton Again Presses Congress To Act on Tobacco Legislation
description: Continuing to beat the drums for an anti-smoking measure, President Clinton declared today that ''Congress should not go home until it passes comprehensive tobacco legislation,'' and he said he could support a bipartisan bill that was introduced today in the Senate.

title: Swan Song for Valparaiso Coach
description: This tournament will mark a bittersweet end for Valparaiso Coach Homer Drew. His son and team leader, Bryce Drew, will be playing his last game sooner or later in the N.C.A.A.'s.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLODNY, DOROTHY
description: COLODNY-Dorothy. The Board of Governors and Members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime former member, Dorothy Colodny and extend to the members of her family our sincere condolences. Joel Langer, President Marvin Leffler, Secretary

title: Exhibition on Camps; Citizen Prisoners
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Destroys School; Student Is Charged
description: One of the metropolitan region's oldest and largest private high schools for teen-agers with learning disabilities was destroyed by fire early today, and one of the school's students has been charged with setting the blaze, the authorities said.

title: A Night of Horrors as Rangers Fade
description: The Rangers might have had enough trouble with the Canadiens even if they had brought their A-game to the rink.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, GEORGE
description: HECHT-George. The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art mourns the death of George Hecht, inventor, manufacturing executive and philanthropist. A 1930 electrical engineering graduate, Mr. Hecht was a lifelong friend of the college and one of its most generous benefactors. As an engineer at Bell Labs during W.W. II, he invented components of the Navy's first radar system and held sixteen patents on electronic switching systems. A public-spirited citizen, Mr. Hecht was a patron of a number of city organizations, including the New York Zoological Society, Central Park Conservancy, the Horticultural Society of NY, and WNET/ Channel 13. A major gift from Mr. Hecht made it possible for Cooper Union and various city agencies to collaborate on the creation of a public viewing garden in the East Village to be completed this summer. Mr. Hecht loved the city, its parks and gardens, and his alma mater. A memorial service-to celebrate Mr. Hecht's life and his contributions to humankind-will be held at the Cooper Union at a date to be announced. We shall miss his friendship, generosity and spirit. John Jay Iselin, President The Cooper Union Mark Epstein, President The Cooper Union Alumni Assoc.

title: NEW CANCER CASES DECREASING IN U.S. AS DEATHS DO, TOO
description: For the first time since the 1930's, the number of new cancer cases in the United States is declining, Federal officials said today in announcing a sharp reversal in the incidence of diseases that kill more than 1,500 Americans each day.

title: 'Double Kitsch'
description: 'Painters From China'

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Shopper's Walk on the Wild Side
description: PARIS  Entering the furniture designer Michel Haillard's atelier is rather like accepting a walk-on part in Tarzan. Furry pelts swing from the ceiling, horns and antlers are locked in static combat and wild boar tusks protrude from shelves. Seating is provided on one of his neo-baroque-meets-1950s-panther skin sofas, just mind the tail as you sit down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASIN, EDWIN, M.D.
description: KASIN-Edwin, M.D. The Institute for Contemporary Psychotherapy notes with great sadness the passing of one of our dearest and most treasured teachers. Although he has enriched our students with his knowledge and wisdom for the past twenty-five years, it is for his humanity and gentleness of spirit that he will be most deeply remembered. Our sympathy goes out to his loving family. He will be greatly missed by all.

title: Renee Cox
description: Cristinerose Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHAL, ARTHUR B.
description: BEHAL-Arthur B. On March 12, of Manhasset, New York. Loving husband of the late Sylvia. Dear father of Arthur Jr. Funeral from the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, on Friday, 1:30 PM. Interment, Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Sports of The Times; Princeton Adds a New Believer
description: THESE guys?

title: French Films for (and About) Grown-Ups
description: What could be more mundane than the cautious romance between a rough-hewn middle-aged guard (Gerard Meylan) at a Marseilles cement factory and a high-strung woman (Ariane Ascaride) with two children who works as a supermarket checker? Robert Guediguian's film ''Marius and Jeannette,'' one of the opening-day movies in the annual series ''Rendez-Vous With French Cinema Today,'' at the Walter Reade Theater, is so warm-hearted and respectful of its working-class characters that it radiates a glow.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Taking the Arts To Teen-Agers

title: For Terps, First Step Is No Stumble This Year
description: That first step of the tournament had proved treacherous the last two years for Maryland, but today the Terrapins maintained a steady and true course in defeating Utah State by 82-68 in a first-round West Regional game at the Arco Arena.

title: Jets Extend Foley's Contract
description: With Neil O'Donnell at home, uninvited as the Jets go through their off-season conditioning program, the team solidified the position of quarterback Glenn Foley yesterday by extending his contract through 1999.

title: Courts Should Allow Parental Immunity; The Mood in Little Rock
description: To the Editor:

title: Shedding Dark, Minimalist Look, Fashion Puts On a Happy Face
description: WASHINGTON  The fashion industry had a lot to be sad about. The makeup palette was filled with dark and muddy shades of brown and plum. Minimalism was a pessimistic, gloomy aesthetic. Designers were giving women charcoal gray business uniforms, power suits for corporate warfare, sheer clothes they couldn't wear and stiletto heels in which they couldn't walk.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: The Awkward Growth Stage At J. P. Morgan
description: You have a storied brand name recognized around the globe and you once reigned supreme in your business. But times have changed and now stock analysts and investors are concerned that you may not be able to regain your lost luster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  USSAK, EILEEN
description: USSAK-Eileen. Seventy-eight, of West Davenport, NY. Died on Wed., March 11, 1998 at the A.O. Fox Memorial Hospital, Oneonta, NY. She was born Dec. 24, 1919 in Norwich England, the daughter of Max and Louise (Lang) Brenner. Eileen married Robert Ussak Feb. 4, 1945, in Norwich England. She is survived by her husband of 53 years, Robert Ussak of West Davenport, 2 sons and a daughterin-law, Richard Ussak of Tucson AZ, and Michael and AnnMarie Ussak of Edison, New Jersey.

title: Tubbs Supports Indiana's Knight
description: Texas Christian Coach Billy Tubbs bemoaned the loss of ''characters'' in the coaching ranks yesterday and cast his lot with Bobby Knight.

title: With Sharpton Not Running, Party Seeks House Candidate
description: The decision by the Rev. Al Sharpton to forgo a Congressional race this year may have removed him as a candidate, but it has left opponents of Representative Edolphus Towns working mightily to produce another challenger to Mr. Towns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTGER, MILTON
description: BUTGER-Milton. The Board of Trustees of YAI National Institute for People with Disabilities is greatly saddened by the passing of Milton Butger. As a distinguished member of our Board, he was a tireless and passionate advocate on behalf of people with disabilities. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Marcella Fava, Chair Dr. Thomss-Robert Ames, Dr. Paul Levitz, Vice-Chairman Board fo Trustees, Dr. Joel M. Levy, CEO Dr. Philip H. Levy, COO YAI National Institute for People with Disabilities 460 West 34th Street, New York, NY 10001-2382

title: A No-Apologies, Sometimes No-Name Author
description: EIGHTEEN months after his novel ''Primary Colors'' turned his life upside down, and now on the eve of the opening of the movie it inspired, Joe Klein understands enough about the intricacies of human character to know that he himself would be rich material for a novel.

title: Hamstring Strain Forces Graf to End Match Early
description: Too old to qualify as a comeback kid, but too young to walk away from her sport without pushing herself and her rebuilt knee one last time, 28-year-old Steffi Graf slammed into a brick wall tonight in the semifinals of the Evert Cup, just her second tournament back after a hiatus of nearly a year for reconstructive knee surgery.

title: Brodeur Posts 7th Shutout
description: Although once again missing their two injured centers, Doug Gilmour and Bob Carpenter, the Devils hardly missed a beat tonight at Greensboro Coliseum. With Martin Brodeur earning his seventh shutout of the season, they skated to a 2-0 victory over the Carolina Hurricanes.

title: Jones Will Pitch Season Opener
description: Manager Bobby Valentine informed Bobby Jones that he would be the Mets' starter on opening day March 31 at Shea Stadium against the Phillies. ''I think it sets up our rotation best,'' Valentine said, before the Mets defeated the Montreal Expos, 4-1, tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, DAVID C.
description: COHEN-David C. Devoted husband of the late Bertha. Beloved father of Richard and Barbara Anne. Dear brother of Dr. Arthur Cohen of Falls Church, VA. Cherished grandfather of Donna, Jill, Stephen and Cristina. Mr. Cohen was responsible for Cohen Associates of Long Island, industrial and commerical real estate developer dating back fifty plus years and a progressive, moving force in the present development of the Long Shore Brewery, Garden City, Long Island. Services Sunday, 1 P.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: A Mature Voice That Holds A Young Heart's Sensibility
description: ''It is so still, so secret here: the sun has gone down, the day disappeared. How quickly now the evening grays!''

title: Boy, 16, Is Stabbed By Group Outside Mall
description: A teen-ager who was stabbed outside the Queens Center shopping mall on Wednesday died yesterday. Investigators said the stabbing might have been a case of mistaken identity.

title: Thais Expected to End $392 Million Boeing Deal
description: The United States has agreed to allow Thailand to cancel its purchase of eight F/A-18 fighter jets because of Thailand's economic crisis, Administration officials said today.

title: St. John's Seniors United To the End
description: A speech Coach Fran Fraschilla made to his team at the end of the 1997 season was one of the first things that crossed the mind of St. John's guard Felipe Lopez on Sunday when the Red Storm's selection in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament was announced.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; Treasured Memories For 89 Cents and Up
description: IF motors could speak, we wouldn't need to advertise.'' So, unable to rely on engines' volubility, the Oilzum Oil Company put that slogan on porcelain enamel signs in the 1920's. Once a part of a gas station's promotional displays, such a sign now brings $5,000 or more from collectors.

title: Plan on Immigration Misses Point; Strain on Resources
description: To the Editor:

title: French Employment Rose in 4th Quarter
description: French employment rose half a percent in the fourth quarter from the third as service-related jobs swelled and industry stopped cutting jobs, providing further evidence that France has turned the corner in its fight against unemployment.

title: But Middle-Level Retailers Hard Hit by Crisis : Luxury Goods Still Strong in Asia
description: HONG KONG  A year and half ago it seemed that Asia's retail boom would never stop. Each new designer entry into the market was greeted by enthusiastic consumers eager to sport the latest international labels. Few anticipated that the party would come to such an abrupt halt.

title: Police Let a Celebrated Jaywalker Walk
description: Brenda Barnes, the city's most famous (and possibly only) jaywalking scofflaw, is off the hook.

title: New South Korea Leader Grants Sweeping Amnesty to 5.5 Million
description: President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea today approved the most sweeping amnesty in the history of his country, clearing the police and personnel records of 5.5 million people and freeing scores of political prisoners.

title: Kosovo's Peaceful Activists
description: Although it is violence that makes headlines in Kosovo, the remarkable thing about this province of Serbia is that for years most of its ethnic Albanians have responded to Serbian repression with nonviolent resistance. As the world follows the bombings and killings of a new Albanian guerrilla movement and Serbia's disproportionate response, the peaceful efforts of students and independent journalists deserve attention and support.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONZON, REGINE
description: ARONZON-Regine. On March 11, 1998. Beloved mother of Daniel and Nancy Aronzon, Nina Aronzon and Karl Rizzo. Grandmother of Denise, Nicole and Stephanie Aronzon, and Adam Rizzo. Services Friday, 11am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: A Fluke No More: Princeton Shuts Down U.N.L.V.
description: The Princeton Tigers wanted to prove that they belonged, wanted to prove that their glossy record and national ranking were legitimate. They wanted to prove that this would be the season when Princeton would do more than simply scare a school in the first round and trudge home. The Tigers did it, so they are not going back to New Jersey yet. No way.

title: Don't Blame Fred Friendly for 'Person to Person'
description: To the Editor:

title: Cosmic Quest by an Orchestra, Two Choirs and Bells
description: Tan Dun's ''Symphony 1997'' bears the parenthetical subtitle ''Heaven Earth Mankind'' (lack of punctuation his). Representing three such exalted items is a tall order for a single piece of music running 70 minutes. The forces for Wednesday's performance at Avery Fisher Hall were indeed big: a full symphony orchestra, two treble choirs, a cello soloist and, at the center, the recently unearthed bronze bells from the Hubei province of China, dating from almost 500 years B.C.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Now you know you can come here and sit in Disney's lap and shop and check out New York and it's all safe and happy. But it's a real short-sell policy, because in the long run there will be nothing here to buy anymore and it'll be a wasteland and the yuppies of the world will move on to some other new avant-garde spot.''

title: 2 Polk Awards for Journalism To New York Times Reporters
description: Reporters for The New York Times have won two 1997 George Polk Awards for excellence in journalism for their articles on allegations of corruption at the nation's largest private hospital chain and safety concerns surrounding light trucks and sport utility vehicles.

title: Turkish Court Clears 10 Policemen in Torture Case Cited Abroad
description: In one of Turkey's most closely watched human rights cases, a provincial court has acquitted 10 police officers accused of torturing a group of young people who were arrested for political crimes in 1995.

title: PEGASUS IN $50 MILLION DEAL FOR 12 PROVIDERS OF DIRECTV
description: Pegasus Communications said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 12 independent providers of DirecTV for about $49.8 million to expand its territory in rural areas. Pegasus, a provider of satellite, broadcast and cable services, would have about 317,000 subscribers in 38 states after the acquisition. It is the largest independent provider of DirecTV, a satellite service, and would reach about 48 percent of subscribers after the acquisition. The company said it would pay $48.9 million in cash and $850,000 in class A shares for the independents. Shares of Pegasus Communications rose $1.625, to $23.375.

title: Defending Jews' Lexicon Of Anguish
description: ONE by one, emotion-laden words that Jews have thought of as special to them are slipping from their grasp.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: POUND RALLIES. The British pound rose for the third day on speculation that the Bank of England might soon raise interest rates to limit inflation. In New York sterling cost $1.6576, up from $1.6483 and the highest in seven weeks.

title: Malaysia May Relax Limits for Foreigners
description: Malaysia's Securities Commission signaled yesterday that the country was willing to give foreign brokerage firms and investment banks a larger slice of its securities and financial services industry. The Securities Commission -- the main securities watchdog -- proposed in a discussion paper that foreign stock brokerage firms and investment banks be allowed to set up international dealing desks to enable them to solicit local business under three circumstances.

title: U.S. Officials Lay Out Concerns About Lockheed-Northrop Deal
description: The Pentagon and Justice Department raised serious concerns about the Lockheed Martin Corporation's plan to buy the Northrop Grumman Corporation because the deal would all but eliminate competition in the manufacturing of certain radar and electronic warfare systems, senior officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARANIK, RUDOLF
description: BARANIK-Rudolf. Died March 6, 1998 in Santa Fe, N.M. The world is smaller without his presence. On rare occasions, a great artist is also a great man. Mr. Baranik is missed and revered. A memorial will be held at a later date.

title: Tears That Tailgate Laughter
description: When Dixie Carter, the cabaret world's most elegantly funny cutup, comes to the line ''they just like to kick it around'' in ''Most Gentlemen Don't Like Love,'' Cole Porter's incisive analysis of the fickle male libido, the singer begins kicking the air with a vehement, hilarious comic fury. It is a typically expressive gesture for Ms. Carter, a performer who inhabits a song totally while singing it, veering from madcap playfulness one minute to intense, teary-eyed romanticism the next.

title: Irene Hardwicke
description: 'To Have and to Hold: Paintings of Love, Courtship and Marriage'

title: Girl Scouts Seek To Update Image
description: The Girl Scouts of the United States of America said yesterday that it had named Siegel & Gale in New York to help update its image by creating a brand identification program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHER, MOLLY W.
description: FLEISCHER-Molly W., age 85, died peacefully on March 10, 1998 after a brief illness. Born in Hartford, CT, Mrs. Fleischer was the beloved mother of Robert S. Fleischer of NY and Susan Axelrod of Atlanta, special mother-in-law of Susan Raanan and Larry Axelrod, and deeply loved grandmother of David, Deborah, Matthew and Victoria. We will all cherish her memory. She is preceded in death by her loving husband, Harry. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to Hadassah in NY, Hospice of Palm Beach County, Inc., or the Southern Poverty Law Center, Birmingham, AL.

title: New Video Releases
description: In the Company of Men

title: Volkswagen and Arnold Communications pitch a Beetle with 'more power' and 'less flower.'
description: IT may be more difficult in advertising than in nature for lightning to strike twice in the same place. But when the lightning involves a bug loved by millions as the Beetle, the second time around may well prove to be as affecting -- and effective -- as the first.

title: Nissan Says Profits Will Be Disappointing
description: The Nissan Motor Company, which was slow to start selling sport utility vehicles, said yesterday that it probably would not reach its profit target of 100 billion yen ($775 million) for the year ending March 31. While Toyota and Honda prepare to report double-digit profit growth for the year, Nissan, Japan's second-largest car company, will report profit fell more than 20 percent below its forecast because of slumping sales in the United States and Japan.

title: Courts Should Allow Parental Immunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERSON, HAROLD
description: BERSON-Harold. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Men's Club and Couple's Club mourn the passing of the beloved father of our devoted member, Dr. Barry Berson. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about state efforts to gauge whether young doctors are overworked in New York hospitals referred incompletely to the legal actions involving Libby Zion, whose death in 1984 led to changes in the training of doctors. After a professional disciplinary board had censured the residents who treated Ms. Zion at New York Hospital, a state appeals court exonerated them. In a separate civil case, a jury found the doctors involved were negligent.

title: Taking the New Tango Further From Home
description: Tango is living in the aftermath of a revolution. The composer Astor Piazzolla, who died in 1992, almost single-handedly carried the tango from the dance floor to the concert hall; his tango nuevo melded sultry melodies and impetuous dynamics of tango tradition with the polyphony and dissonance of European classical music, bringing the music the bustle and structural complexity of modernism.

title: UMass Worries About Injuries
description: Massachusetts Coach Bruiser Flint noted that the Georgia Dome has changed since the team's last trip to Atlanta in 1996, leading to an appearance in the Final Four.

title: The Puzzling Road Maps Of a Philosopher's Mind
description: Among many art trends hovering in the air is an interest in visual systems, from the exhaustive cosmologies of the Buddhist mandalas seen at the Asia Society last fall, to the computer-generated flow charts with which Peter Halley recently papered a gallery at the Museum of Modern Art. A gallery show in SoHo by Matt Mullican (at Brooke Alexander through March 28) follows a similar thread.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the completion of Sir Edward Elgar's Third Symphony by the British composer Anthony Payne misstated the year of the scheduled March performances in Washington and New York. It is next year, not this year.

title: Review/Fashion; McQueen Pilots Givenchy Boldly Into the Late 90's
description: When Robert Browning wrote ''a man's reach should exceed his grasp,'' he might have been referring to a young designer trying to bring greatness back to an old-line fashion house. Seldom does such a designer actually grasp what he or she is reaching for. But the effort to achieve it is what ultimately counts.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Economic Projection

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; The Aftershock Lingers As 'Mean Streets' Turns 25
description: The arrival of ''Jaws'' in 1975 marked a well-noted turning point in American film, but now it's time to celebrate another, quieter earthquake of the same era. Twenty-five years ago, Robert De Niro's Johnny Boy dropped a Molotov cocktail into a mailbox at the start of ''Mean Streets,'' and the explosion can still be felt.

title: Cornell Plans to Rescue Pumpkin Stuck on Tower
description: In an unexpected change of heart, Cornell University officials have decided to take down the mysterious pumpkin that has been perched atop the school's 173-foot bell tower since early October.

title: For Smith, It's 'We' Before 'I' for Now
description: North Carolina was playing Navy in Hartford, but Dean Smith was 150 miles away in CBS's 57th Street studio watching on television.

title: Professor Named to Lead St. Louis Fed
description: A Brown University economics professor was named president of the St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank today and indicated he had particularly tough views on inflation.

title: Transit Union Overturns Election After a Dispute Over Campaign
description: The recent election victory by the incumbent president of New York City's largest transit union has been overturned by its parent union on the ground that his opponents were not given equal access to a list of the union's 32,000 members that was used for campaigning.

title: Olden Goldies Burnished Up
description: Old movies in one stage of revival or another are always in the video pipeline. This month, ''Touch of Evil'' (1958), Orson Welles's noir classic about a murderous police chief (Welles) in a Texas border town, is beginning a long trip to reissue on videocassette while other films -- ''Come Back, Little Sheba,'' ''Morning Glory,'' ''The Quiet Man,'' ''The Bridge on the River Kwai'' and ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind'' -- are arriving or here. ''Touch of Evil'' is being restored by Universal for redistribution in theaters this fall. As with other Welles films, the original editing ended up in the hands of others. Now the movie is essentially being reworked into a ''director's edition'' in accordance with a 58-page memo of instructions that Welles wrote at the time but that was largely ignored.

title: Irabu Hurls 4 Flawless Innings
description: In his first exhibition outing since an outburst against Japanese reporters and since he was severely chastised by a Yankee coach, Hideki Irabu last night had perhaps his best performance with the Yankees, dominating the Atlanta Braves at Kissimmee, Fla., during a 14-2 Yankee victory.

title: Mannesmann Planning To Issue New Shares
description: Mannesmann A.G. said yesterday that it planned to issue new shares to raise around 3 billion marks ($1.63 billion) to finance expansion, particularly in its telecommunications division. Analysts praised the capital increase, especially the plan to use most of the new cash to beef up telecommunications, which provided most of the engineering, auto parts and telecom group's 1997 net profit of 600 million marks.

title: Memorabilia From Camelot Under Government Scrutiny
description: The National Archives said it believes that some of the John F. Kennedy materials scheduled to be auctioned in New York City next week actually belong to the United States, including:

title: Balky Conservatives Block House Vote on Republican Anti-Abortion Measure
description: Fighting dissension in their own ranks, House Republican leaders today abruptly postponed a vote on legislation that was designed to display their resolve to link an anti-abortion provision to some of the President's chief foreign policy priorities.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. APPROVES MERGER OF 2 ACCOUNTING GIANTS
description: The United States Justice Department cleared the merger of Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand L.L.P. yesterday, and the two accounting giants said they hoped for approval soon by European antitrust regulators. The Justice Department, which began reviewing the transaction several months ago, did not find evidence that the combination would reduce competition in the accounting business, a spokesman, Michael Gordon, said. The antitrust regulatory agency of the European Union is scheduled to announce its decision on the merger on Monday.

title: Cathay Pacific Shares Plunge on Forecasts
description: The stock of Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. plunged yesterday as analysts slashed their 1998 profit forecasts because last year's earnings fell 55.5 percent. An analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, Wendy Wong, slashed this year's forecast by 82 percent, to 300 million Hong Kong dollars, after Cathay said on Wednesday that it earned 1.69 billion Hong Kong dollars last year and added that business could get worse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMATTEO, PAUL JOSEPH
description: DeMATTEO-Paul Joseph. 76. Of New Port Richey, FL., died on Tuesday, March 10, in Hudson, FL. He was born in NYC and moved to New Port Richey from L.I., in 1983. He was a retired electronics technician with the Sperry Corporation of Lake Success, NY after forty years service and most recently was an independent travel agent and world traveler. He was an army veteran W.W. II-VFW ChinaBurma-India theater. Survivors include son Joseph of NYC, daughters: the Reverend Brunetta DeMatteo Winthers of Lees Summit, MO, Christine Nagy of Lantana, FL, and Donna DeMatteo of Woodside, CA., and four grandchildren. Services will be held Saturday March 14, Dobies Funeral Home, New Port Richey, FL.

title: The Comparable Tony Blair
description: Tony Blair has pulled off a startling coup. After less than a year as Britain's Prime Minister, he has become a buzzword. More than any other world leader today, he is the yardstick for aspiring statesmen. People are already using phrases like ''the Blair effect,'' ''Blairification'' and ''laissez-Blair.''

title: Asteroid, the Films, Heading to Theaters
description: The news that an asteroid is expected to pass close to Earth in 2028 hardly caught Hollywood by surprise. Two upcoming films, ''Deep Impact'' and ''Armageddon,'' bear a striking resemblance to real possibilities.

title: Stock Mutual Funds Attracted Yet More Money in February
description: American stock mutual funds attracted a higher level of net new investments in February than January, helping spur the market to record levels, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NIKE INC., Beaverton, Ore., the athletic shoes and sports apparel company, will cut 300 temporary workers this week in the first step in a larger round of layoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANFIELD, HOPE BROWN
description: CANFIELD-Hope Brown. The Trustees of St. Andrew's Dune Church mourn the death of Hope Brown Canfield, beloved and wonderful wife of our Trustee of 21 years and Trustee Emeritus, Franklin O. Canfield. We look forward to rejoicing in the gift of her life and praying for her soul at a memorial service at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, Saturday, June 13, 1998 at 5 P.M.

title: Sweetness, Light and Lederhosen
description: You do realize what you'll be in for, don't you? Musical nuns, mischievous children longing for love, a frosty father who melts into cuddliness through the powers of song, and a virginal heroine who knows just what ditty to break into when she's feeling sad. Plus lilting melodies that saw at the heartstrings and that, whether you admit it or not, you have probably found yourself humming from time to time.

title: I.R.S. Has Sent Out More in Tax Refunds
description: The Treasury Department has sent out 11.3 percent more in tax refunds this year than in the corresponding time last year, providing a potential push for the economy in the first quarter.

title: Shipment of Hepatitis Serum Arrives on L.I.
description: An emergency cross-country delivery of anti-hepatitis serum arrived at the Nassau County Health Center shortly after noon today as scores of people who recently ate food bought at a delicatessen in Wantagh waited to be inoculated against the hepatitis A virus.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER STRENGTHENS. Copper rose nearly 4 percent, to the highest level since November, on news that warehouse stockpiles were declining. May delivery contracts rose 3.15 cents to settle at 83.70 cents a pound.

title: Good Looks Quickly Fade for Islanders
description: Two trades. Different owners. Now, a new coach.

title: Indian Success Story
description: To the Editor:

title: After Much Time Off, UConn Is Ready for Run
description: How does a high-ranking team prepare for the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament? If you are Connecticut, you don't practice -- or at least you don't practice too much.

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE TO BUY 19 AMERITECH EXCHANGES
description: Century Telephone Enterprises Inc. agreed yesterday to buy 19 local telephone exchanges and directory publishing operations in Wisconsin from the Ameritech Corporation for $225 million in cash, making Century the third-largest local phone company in the state. The transaction includes property and equipment that serves 85,000 telephone lines in 21 towns in northern and central Wisconsin, as well as the publishing operations for nine telephone directories. Century already serves 245,000 telephone lines in 96 exchanges in Wisconsin, it said. The stock of Century, which is based in Monroe, La., rose $1.4375, to $60.375.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Fast-Food Alternatives
description: You can find fast food on almost any block in New York City: a burger, a street hot dog, a sandwich from a deli display case. Why settle for these? Here are a dozen alternatives that serve food fast and tasty. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: UConn Escapes, but 2 Favorites Fall
description: Any team that strolled onto the floor at the MCI Center here tonight could fully expect that its opponent was not only prepared for thrills, for competitive games, but also for an upset or two.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Sprucing Up The Delacorte

title: Judge Rejects Polygraph Tests In Baby's Death
description: The presiding judge in Delaware's murder case against Amy S. Grossberg refused yesterday to admit lie-detector evidence in which Ms. Grossberg denied planning to kill her newborn son in November 1996.

title: The Dangers of a Smile, Curls and a Loincloth
description: ''Post Coitum'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 27. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Heads Still In the Clouds
description: South Carolina State players have already had a memorable trip to Atlanta regardless of the outcome of today's game against Kentucky: they have taken their first plane ride of the season.

title: Review/Fashion; The Deconstructivists: Summing Up the Parts
description: The Japanese designers who showed here this week lived up to their reputation as the most experimental in the world. There was hardly a conventional cut or an ordinary coat or dress in the fall collections of Junya Watanabe, Issey Miyake or Rei Kawakubo for Comme des Garcons.

title: Fleeting Beasts Collected in a Fantasy Heaven
description: Fiery dragons and horny-toed demons, a mountainous boulder that turns into a giant, lords of death and destruction and a gigantic spider that for many Halloweens danced merrily on the facade of the Jefferson Market Library in Greenwich Village as the arachnidan version of King Kong -- these and other fantastical creatures fill the main gallery of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. This phantasmagoric cavalcade, which runs through May 2, is the invention of Ralph Lee, for more than 35 years a master mask maker in the American theater.

title: Crew of Jet That Sliced Ski Lift Cable Facing Criminal Inquiry
description: The military equivalent of a grand jury hearing was ordered today to determine whether the crew of a United States jet that sheared ski lift cables in Italy, killing 20 people, should be prosecuted on charges including involuntary manslaughter and negligent homicide.

title: Norwegian Oil Concern To Buy U.S. Company
description: Nopec International, a Norwegian oil services company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Houston-based TGS Calibre Geophysical from its private owners for $153 million to expand its seismic surveying business. Nopec will issue 11 million shares to TGS's owners, giving them 47 percent of the combined company. Nopec's acquisition would be the fourth United States-Norwegian oil service linkup in the last six months.

title: Most Distant Object Ever Found Is Sighted
description: Light from a ''miserable looking piece of a galaxy'' on the far side of the universe is showing that the tiny, misshapen object is the most distant ever seen from Earth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUR, DR. HELEN (KRAUS)
description: SCHUR-Dr. Helen (Kraus). On March 11. Wife of the late Max; mother of Dr. Peter Schur and Eva Milofsky; survived by four grand and 3 great grandchildren. Services on Friday, 9:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to the James Weldon Johnson Counseling Center, New York, NY 10029.

title: 7 I.N.S. Employees and 26 Others Are Charged With Selling False Immigration Papers
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan announced yesterday that seven employees of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service and 26 others had been charged with selling fraudulent immigration papers for more than $100,000 in bribes.

title: Tar Heels and Charlotte Set Up a Carolina Day
description: Antawn Jamison wanted the basketball and North Carolina wanted to get it to him because that is when the Tar Heels are most explosive. But Navy's Hassan Booker manhandled Jamison, treating him as if he was a plebe from Army. The best player in college basketball had a bloody nose before the game was five minutes old. Welcome to Wrestlemania.

title: MUTUAL LIFE OF CANADA IN $850 MILLION DEAL
description: Mutual Life of Canada agreed yesterday to acquire the Canadian operations of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for $850 million. The acquisition would consist of Met Life Canada's retail life insurance, savings and group insurance operations. Mutual Life said it would cut 1,100 of the 1,800 Met Life Canada nonsales jobs as the operations were integrated. Mutual Life said its market share of premium income would increase to 16 percent from 10 percent in individual life insurance and to more than 10 percent from 7 percent in group insurance. Over all, the combined company would rank second in Canadian individual and group insurance, after the Great West Life Company. Mutual Life announced plans in December to become a shareholder-owned company. It is now owned by policyholders.

title: Debate and Recalculation On an Asteroid's Progress
description: The prediction on Wednesday that a one-mile-wide asteroid would pass dangerously close to Earth in the year 2028 sparked bitter debate yesterday about the extent of the danger, but also prompted calls for action to deal with any future menace from space, including the possibility of intercepting it.

title: Favorite Trick Favored
description: The Horse of the Year may not be running in the race of the day, but he will be the star of the show on Saturday.

title: Plan on Immigration Misses Point; Time to Act Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Author, Author
description: There were two Irish playwrights at the opening preview of ''St. Nicholas'' at Primary Stages, on West 45th Street near Ninth Avenue -- CONOR McPHERSON, who wrote the show, and MARTIN McDONAGH, whose own play ''The Beauty Queen of Leenane'' is scheduled to open on Broadway next month.

title: Short-Term Korean Debt Converted by Bank Plan
description: South Korea and international banks have successfully converted enough of the country's short-term foreign debt into long-term debt to ease the liquidity crisis that has been threatening to topple the economy since late last year.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Kentucky Players Are 'Probable'
description: Two Kentucky players, guard Jeff Sheppard and center Nazr Mohammed, are recovering from injuries but were listed as probable starters for today's game against South Carolina State in South Regional games in Atlanta.

title: In Poll, Americans Find New York More Disneyland Than Gangland
description: Terry Harper is a lifelong resident of the Middle West, one of the nation's supposed seething hotbeds of anti-''big city East Coast liberal establishment'' sentiment, and she holds nothing back in talking about New York.

title: Plan on Immigration Misses Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMERSHLAG, STELLA DUFF
description: HAMERSHLAG-Stella Duff. On March 10. She was an actor and painter, loved her garden, people and her dogs. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Jacob Perlow Hospice or Beth Israel Medical Center North. Memorial Friday March 20, 4-7 p.m. at home.

title: New President Is Named For the Sports Authority
description: The chief operating officer of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, Dennis R. Robinson, was named president of the authority yesterday. Mr. Robinson will succeed Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, who resigned last month to become the Rutgers University sports director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, NATHAN
description: OWEN-Nathan. Formerly of Greenwich, Connecticut and Basin Harbor, Vermont, Mr. Owen died at home in Palm City, Florida on March 9, 1998. Devoted husband of Janet, beloved father of Patricia, David and Lorinda, and adoring grandfather of nine, great grandfather of one. Mr. Owen was the Founding Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of General Signal Corporation, before which he was a pioneering venture capitalist with J.H. Whitney and Co. Donations to Hospice.

title: U.S. Says It Might Consider Attacking Serbs
description: Clinton Administration officials raised the possibility today that the United States would consider a military attack on Serbian forces if diplomatic efforts failed to stop human rights abuses in the province of Kosovo.

title: Vito Acconci
description: Barbara Gladstone Gallery

title: Diana Cooper
description: Postmasters Gallery

title: Viewing Solzhenitsyn Through a Freudian Lens
description: ALEXANDER SOLZHENITSYN

title: Experiment in Private Fire Protection Fails for a Westchester Village
description: Two years ago, this prosperous village in Westchester County drew national attention when it became the first municipality in the heavily unionized Northeast to hire a private company to provide fire protection.

title: Taking Stock
description: The possible merger between two of the country's largest stock markets is an eye-catching development that will bring tangible benefits to the participants, The American Stock Exchange (Amex) and Nasdaq. It could even lead to bold reforms that might shake up the securities industry. But the immediate gains for ordinary investors, such as lower trading costs or innovative trading opportunities, appear speculative and modest.

title: Jewelry Reflects Desire for Femininity and Fantasy : Gems Again Have a Cool Edge
description: PARIS  "Sooner or later every woman wakes up wanting diamonds," said the London jewelry designer Solange Azagury-Partridge as she popped a spider ring, a plump three-carat rock in a web of filigree red gold, on her finger. The ring was from her current collection of uncut, faceted and Golconda diamond rings.

title: GROUP 1 AUTOMOTIVE SAYS IT WILL BUY FIVE DEALERSHIPS
description: Group 1 Automotive Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy five automobile dealerships in four states for about $37 million in cash and stock in a transaction that would increase its annual revenue to about $1.6 billion. Group 1 is to buy the dealerships for $25 million in cash and 1.22 million shares of Group 1 stock. The dealerships, which have annual revenue of $300 million and sell more than 11,000 cars and trucks a year, are Johns Automotive Group, with two dealerships in Albuquerque, N.M.; Flamingo Ford in Homestead, Fla.; Highland Chrysler in Austin, Tex., and Luby Chevrolet in Denver. Group 1 shares rose 68.75 cents, to $10.4375.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN ELIMINATES AN OBSTACLE TO LAIDLAW BID
description: The Safety-Kleen Corporation, a waste-management company, said yesterday that it had removed a shareholder-rights plan that had barred Laidlaw Environmental Services Inc.'s $1.57 billion cash-and-stock takeover bid. But Safety-Kleen said it still had concerns about the stock component of Laidlaw's offer and would make no recommendation to its shareholders about whether to support the bid. Safety-Kleen began talks with Laidlaw after its shareholders failed to approve a competing bid by the Philip Services Corporation. Under its offer, Laidlaw must receive at least two-thirds of Safety-Kleen shares.

title: Paris Turns to the East for Ethnic Mix and Youthful Hip
description: PARIS  The French have a phrase for it: "Ca bouge"  things are on the move. In the urgent, angry new-generation music, in the multiethnic restaurants and bars and in quirky new shops, a fresh energy is bursting out in a city where people had been claiming that the cultural lights were out.

title: The Latest Wrinkles in the Battle to Look Young
description: PARIS  An obsession with youth and a stigmatization of age dominate today's world. And it has become big business for those professionals who depend on making women feel good  plastic surgeons, skin specialists and cosmetic companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLMER, DR. IRA
description: WOLMER-Dr. Ira. The Officers, Trustees and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to his wife Beth, daughter Danielle and the family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Alan Levine, Ch. of the Board Robert P. Antler, President

title: Where Landlords Learn; Some Property Owners Choose School Over Fines
description: The teacher raised his hands and pleaded for calm: ''Hold on! Let's catch our breath here, people!''

title: Reed Elsevier Profit Rises Just 1.4%
description: Reed Elsevier's implied second-half profit before charges rose only 1.4 percent, battered by the strong pound and a decline in earnings at the Reed Travel Group. Second-half profit at the company, which publishes Variety and New Scientist, rose to $:296 million ($488 million) before charges, from $:292 million a year earlier.

title: These Cats Can't Display Triskaidekaphobia
description: At noon today, Harrah's casino will conduct a beauty contest for black cats. The categories will include attitude, appearance and talent, a spokeswoman, Linda Valente, said. The winner of the pageant will receive $130 and a giant scratching post, Ms. Valente added.

title: 'Paper + Finland = Art'
description: American Craft Museum

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, JANET
description: LEEDS-Janet. To the most wonderful mother and grandmother, you will always be in our hearts and our thoughts. We will miss you and always love you. Steven, Sheri, Jessica, Danielle and Zachary

title: De Klerk's Party to Challenge Wide Amnesty for Mandela Allies
description: Officials of the opposition National Party announced today that they would challenge South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission in court over the validity of a blanket amnesty the panel gave to 37 members of the country's ruling party.

title: Netanyahu Apologizes for Killing of 3 Palestinians by Soldiers
description: In an unusually conciliatory gesture, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu went on Arabic-language Israeli television today to describe the shooting of three Palestinians at an Israeli roadblock as a ''tragic mistake'' and to express sympathy for their families.

title: Trial Opens for Methodist Minister Who United 2 Women
description: A United Methodist Church minister, the defendant in a highly unusual ecclesiastical trial, said today that he was not guilty of a charge of violating his denomination's laws by performing a ceremony of same-sex union for two women at his church last year.

title: Nasdaq and Amex May Prove a Hard Fit but Could Make a Strong Rival
description: The possible takeover of the American Stock Exchange by the parent of the Nasdaq stock market reflects both the tide of changing technologies and the growing power of big Wall Street brokerage houses to force changes that will save them money. And it follows stock market reforms that have diminished the power of insiders at both markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEL, RITA
description: SEIDEL-Rita. Plainsboro, N.J., formerly of Rego Park, N.Y. died March 11, 1998, after a courageous battle with cancer. Prominent graphic designer. A memorable friend and personality. Mother of Barry and Brian Seidel; grandmother of Robin, Emilie and Rebecca; sister of Michael Besser.

title: Clinton's Closest Aide Testifies a Third Time Before Grand Jury
description: Bruce R. Lindsey, the White House deputy counsel and President Clinton's closest confidant, returned today to the grand jury investigating the relationship between the President and a former intern, Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Grand Tour Heirlooms And Illusions
description: One of the attractions of collecting miniature Roman temples and other ''souvenirs of the Grand Tour'' is imagining that you inherited them. V. S. Pritchett understood this perfectly. Of all the literary works about the antiques trade, his short story ''The Camberwell Beauty'' may well be the most insightful. Writing about the buying and selling of antiques, the late British writer mused: ''It is a trade that feeds illusions. For example, if you go after Georgian silver you catch the illusion, while you are bidding, that you are related to the rich families who owned it. You acquire imaginary ancestors.''

title: Witness in Beating Case Failed To Identify Defendant Initially
description: The first trial witness to identify Austin Offen as the person who nearly bludgeoned Shane Daniels to death at a Westhampton Beach nightclub two years ago said under cross-examination today that he had failed to make a similar identification shortly after the brawl.

title: Warming Up With a Washington Visit
description: Offering a glimpse into how he might campaign for national office, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani told an audience of Republican leaders today that Republican policies had produced the reductions in crime, welfare and graffiti that had lifted the reputation and health of his city.

title: If Nominated, Janet Jackson . . .
description: No one was running for President in the public hearing room at City Hall -- not Gen. COLIN L. POWELL, not Mayor RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI, not JANET JACKSON.

title: Putting the Downtown Element Back Into O'Neill
description: ''An uncommonly powerful and imaginative performance, in several respects unsurpassed this season,'' wrote Alexander Woollcott in the fall of 1920 in The New York Times. The object of praise was a then little-known actor named Charles S. Gilpin, who was appearing in a strange, bruising new play that had uptown cosmopolites swarming to a small theater in Greenwich Village.

title: Residential Real Estate; Greenwich Condo Resuming Sales
description: Originally designed as luxury condominiums, Old Greenwich Gables became a rental complex when the building boom of the 80's soured. Now the 167-unit development named for its area of Greenwich, Conn., has come full circle.

title: Metro Business; Anti-Takeover Bill Gains in Connecticut
description: A committee of the Connecticut Legislature in Hartford yesterday passed a tough anti-takeover bill in an effort to block the SPX Corporation's $3 billion hostile bid for Echlin Inc., an auto parts manufacturer in Branford, Conn.

title: Every Town Is One for the Books
description: The phone rang at 8:55 on a wintry morning at the Merriams, whose 18th-century home in the hills above the village of Conway, in northwestern Massachusetts, doubles as a bed and breakfast. It was Mary Merriam on the line. As my wife and I lingered over an extra cup of coffee, served by her husband, Robert, she'd hurried into town to teach a quilting class. Mary wanted to alert us to a flock of wild turkeys down the road, a sight sure to delight a pair of Upper West Siders.

title: Metro Business; Vornado Earnings Jump
description: Vornado Realty Trust, a real estate investment trust in Saddle Brook, N.J., said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose more than 80 percent on the strength of about $3 billion in acquisitions since the start of 1997.

title: L'Etat, It's DiCaprio: C'est le Brat-King
description: In the aftermath of ''Titanic,'' Leonardo DiCaprio is arrogant, spoiled, vain and regal. He's also shy, decent and noble, a pinup-ready vision of angel-faced purity. And this isn't even in real life; it's in an amusingly ludicrous new version of ''The Man in the Iron Mask,'' which dusts off the Dumas story and gives it a definite 90's spin. This time, when the mask comes off, the story's glowing young hero appears to have undergone a seaweed wrap at that exceptionally punishing spa, the Bastille. And he later delivers this self-help credo: ''I wear the mask. It does not wear me.''

title: Presidential Panel Sees No Need for a Law on Patients' Rights
description: In a setback for the White House, a Presidential advisory commission declined today to endorse the use of legislation to define and enforce the rights of patients who have been improperly denied health care benefits promised by insurance companies and employers.

title: Anne Truitt
description: Danese Gallery

title: CMG INFORMATION ACQUIRES ACCIPITER FOR $35 MILLION
description: CMG Information Services Inc. said yesterday that it had bought closely held Accipiter Inc. for $35 million in stock, adding technology that tracks on-line users to its Internet ventures. CMG, a direct marketer that invests in Internet companies, will combine Accipiter with its Engage Technologies unit, which sells market research on how people use the World Wide Web. CMG intends to use Accipiter's technology to increase advertising revenue at its ventures. The technology lets on-line advertisers change the ads that Web surfers see based on user profiles. Shares of CMG, which is based in Andover, Mass., fell 81.25 cents, to $57.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Courts Should Allow Parental Immunity; Grand Jury Secrecy
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Cosy Paris Boutiques That Dare to Be Different : Off the Beaten Shopping Path
description: PARIS  Mega boutiques for mega names have been monopolizing the main shopping axis of Paris, from the just opened Louis Vuitton on the Champs Elysees and the Emporio Armani on the Left Bank's Boulevard St. Germain to the madly multiplying Gap stores, but a handful of smaller boutiques are daring to be different.

title: A Debut Delayed for Centuries
description: It's hard to fathom, but the first exhibition in the United States of the Florentine Mannerist sculptor Giambologna (1529-1608) is happening now, a mere 390 years after his death -- and at a gallery yet, rather than a museum.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Some Stock Indexes Set Records, but Dow Slips

title: McGreevey Protests Shift Of Newark Flight Paths
description: Three days before Federal officials plan to reroute some departures from Newark International Airport away from Staten Island and over this township, residents and officials conducted a protest. In a news conference yesterday at Town Hall, Mayor James E. McGreevey and members of the New Jersey Coalition Against Aircraft Noise condemned the change and suggested directing planes at high altitudes over the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SMALL, JIM
description: SMALL-Jim. 3/13/83 to 3/13/98 15 years Missed more each day

title: Traders Waiting For the Fine Print
description: Worry, optimism and a whole lot of bafflement swept over Wall Street yesterday as talks continued on the possible merger of the American Stock Exchange and the parent company of the Nasdaq stock market.

title: A Front-Runner Fades and Some See Race Playing a Role
description: The folding chairs were full in the New Greater Mount Eagle Church basement, and Roland Burris, candidate for governor of Illinois, was churning up the South Side crowd.

title: Nets Keep Clawing Back, but Can't Halt Free Fall
description: John Calipari was gyrating and howling as he tried to prod the Nets to victory tonight. But even Calipari knew he was asking too much.

title: Dogs' Night Out
description: The photographer WILLIAM WEGMAN and his party animals were out last night. Mr. Wegman took his famous troupe of Weimaraners on a four-block walk up Madison Avenue. They went from the Pace Wildenstein MacGill Gallery on 57th Street (where they had attended the opening of a show of his Polaroids of themselves) to Shanghai Tang, the palace of lime-green and lemon-yellow fashion at 61st Street.

title: Not So Fast, Archives Say About Auction
description: The squabbling over next week's auction of John F. Kennedy memorabilia took another bizarre twist yesterday as the National Archives and Records Administration dispatched experts to New York to examine the artifacts because officials believe some of them belong to the United States Government.

title: Tyne Daly Re-Emerges as a New Age Totem Pole
description: In ''Mystery School,'' Tyne Daly plays an outcast five times over. The women in Paul Selig's quintet of spiritually inclined monologues are misfits and cuckoos of various sorts, exiles of the mind and soul who embrace highly personalized theologies in hopes of filling the cracks in their lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNELL, GEORGE R.
description: BROWNELL-George R., 83. An international corporate attorney and lifelong resident of Westfield, NJ, died March 8, 1998. A graduate of Cornell Law School, Mr. Brownell was a partner of Mudge Rose Guthrie and Alexander, NYC until 1965. Thereafter he served as special counsel and Vice President of the Legal Department at D. K. Ludwig's National Bulk Carriers. He currently served as a director of Intercat, Inc., Alfred Karcher, Inc. and Brady-Palmer Label Corp.

title: The Standard Road Menu, Minus the Rhythm Section (Plus a Meaty New Dessert)
description: Louis Armstrong, in later years, would perform concerts drawn from a predictable reservoir of tunes, bestowing on them a mere brushing of freshness. Not that the songs or the set list couldn't have used more attention, but Armstrong was originality itself. I'm not the first one to notice that Willie Nelson follows the same profile.

title: Queens Girl Is Injured When Truck Strikes Her
description: A 6-year-old Queens girl on her way to school was critically injured yesterday morning when a truck hit her while she was crossing a street in the Jackson Heights section with her mother and two brothers, the police said.

title: Prices Up Sharply Despite 2 Strong Reports
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday as investors apparently shrugged off concerns of inflation after several Government reports of economic strength.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Connecticut lottery workers who returned to their jobs after a shooting misstated the gun control plans of two state legislators. The two are looking into legislation that would make it easier to enforce a current law that prohibits gun permits for anyone who has been involuntarily committed to a psychiatric hospital. They have not formally proposed such legislation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRATEL, JOSEPH
description: DRATEL-Joseph. Beloved husband of Heidi. Devoted father of Louise, Patti, Billy and Joshua; devoted brother of the late Bella Mishaan. Adored grandfather of Daniel, Mark, Charles, Robert, Asher, Julia, Jonathan and Sidney. Died March 10, 1998 in Jupiter, Florida. He was a lawyer and CPA, and Chairman of the Board of the Dratel Group, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange Member firm that he co-founded in 1980. He will be missed. Funeral services at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave., 10:45AM Friday.

title: Democratic Leaders Formulate Tax Rebate Plans of Their Own
description: A Democratic State Senator has come up with a variation on Gov. John G. Rowland's plan to send rebate checks to taxpayers two weeks before Election Day: ''Perhaps they could be left at voting places,'' said the Democrat, Martin M. Looney.

title: Customer Is Shot in Bank Robbery on Upper East Side
description: The police said two armed men robbed a bank on the Upper East Side of Manhattan yesterday afternoon, shooting a customer in the leg, fleeing with an undetermined amount of cash and ruffling an upscale slice of the city dotted by hushed, thickly carpeted shops with buzzers and gates.

title: Oracle Reports Sharp Rebound That Beats Analysts' Estimates
description: The Oracle Corporation reported a sharp rebound in its third fiscal quarter today with record results that exceeded analysts' estimates.

title: FIRSTPLUS FINANCIAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE LIFE FINANCIAL
description: Firstplus Financial Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Life Financial Corporation, a mortgage-loan company, for $138 million in stock. Firstplus, based in Dallas, is a consumer-finance company with revenue of $591.4 million for the year ended Sept. 30. Life Financial, based in Riverside, Calif., is the holding company for Life Bank, a federally chartered savings and loan. Under the agreement, Firstplus will pay $20 for each share of Life Financial, provided that Firstplus shares trade between $30 and $40. Firstplus gained $3.9375 a share, to $43.0625. Life Financial rose $2.1875, to $20.1875.

title: Canada No Safe Haven for Birds or Bears
description: The venerable yellow cedars near here hold one of the world's great concentrations of nesting sites for the marbled murrelet, a secretive bird equally at home in the old-growth forest and on the sea.

title: Maynard Amerine, 87, California Wine Expert
description: Maynard A. Amerine, the elegant and erudite plant physiologist whose pioneering research helped revive the California wine industry after the repeal of Prohibition, died on Wednesday at his home in St. Helena, Calif. He was 87 and was widely acclaimed as the father of American wine.

title: Tips on Being a Good Landlord
description: Tips from Kevin Ryan, a tenant advocate who teaches a class for landlords cited for violations:

title: Court Tells HIP to Give Details of Partnership
