description: A state appeals court ordered a nonprofit health maintenance organization in North Brunswick yesterday to make public the details of its relationship with a for-profit partner.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JACOBS, LEE
description: JACOBS-Lee. Time does not heal all wounds. We miss you and love you. Aimee

title: Man Arrested in Shooting At Brooklyn Nightclub
description: The police arrested a man yesterday on charges that he shot 10 people outside a Brooklyn nightclub earlier this week, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOWITZ, RUTH
description: KANTOWITZ-Ruth. Wife of Solomon, mother of Joyce and Marvin Hartstein, Barbara and Michael Kalvert. Sister of Mary Hasnas, Helen Frieder. Grandmother of Elise, Seth and Peter. High school biology teacher and guidance counsellor in the NYC school system for 25 years. Services Friday, 10 AM at Schwartz Bros-Jeffers Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard and 76 Road, Forest Hills.

title: A Balance Of Naughty And Nice
description: It is probably a mixed blessing for any artist to go down in history as Josephine Bonaparte's favorite painter, but that's what Pierre-Paul Prud'hon (1758-1823) was. Why he was is evident in a survey of his work at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a languidly paced, mercurial show with unexpected shadows and jolts.

title: Agassi and Gambill Post Upsets
description: One is a star in the making, the other a star bent on renovating.

title: SENATE'S MEASURE OFFERS COMMUTERS A BREAK IN TAXES
description: A little-noticed provision of a sweeping transportation bill adopted by the United States Senate yesterday would let employers give workers up to $65 a month in tax-free mass-transit benefits instead of salary. Experts said the plan could sharply cut the cost of train, bus and subway travel in the New York metropolitan region and across the country and possibly bring new surges in ridership and transit revenues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, IDA
description: WEINTRAUB-Ida. On March 10, 1998. Beloved wife of Benjamin. Loving mother of Daniel and Joel. Dear sister of Sophie Blecker and Ruth Grosshandler. Adoring grandmother of David, Anita, Jeremy and Jody. Graveside service Friday, 1 P.M., at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEGGS, MARJORIE M.
description: MEGGS-Marjorie M. Of Scarsdale, New York. Wife of Hugh Meggs. Mother of Hugh C. and Dr. Leonard G. Meggs and Dr. Marcia R. Meggs. Mother-in-law of Dr. Kenneth Williams, Renee and Roberta Meggs. Sister of Dr. Carl C. Reid and Atty. Hudson H. Reid. Grandmother of two. Great-grandmother of one. Funeral service Sunday, 2 PM, at Grace Episcopal Church, White Plains, New York.

title: Jets' Douglas, Deemed an Ill Fit, Is Traded to the Eagles for Picks
description: Less than three years ago, Hugh Douglas was the National Football League's rookie defensive player of the year, a sensational pass rusher and something most rare for the Jets: an impact player on defense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEE, MAJ. GEN. SAMUEL E. ''NED''
description: GEE-Maj. Gen. Samuel E. ''Ned'', 89, died March 8, 1998 in Vero Beach, FL. Graveside services Monday, March 16, 1998 1:30pm at Post Cemetery, West Point, NY. Contributions to the Association of Graduates, USMA, West Point, New York 10996.

title: Religion Journal; A Religious Standpoint: Looking Back at Movies
description: The 70th annual Academy Awards may be less than two weeks away, but most critics decided long ago what they thought best about last year's movies. That group would include people who, from a professional or personal interest, look at the cinema from a religious perspective, for what films have to say about the complexities of human character, as well as for the ethical and moral questions a movie may raise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTELS, PAUL W.
description: BARTELS-Paul W. March 12, 1998 of Rockville Centre, LI. Beloved husband of Marjorie and father of Paul, Jr., George and Patricia, and William. Adored grandfather of Elizabeth. Friends may call at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel, 20 Lincoln Avenue, Rockville Centre, LI, Sunday 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Funeral service on Monday 10:00 AM. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington.

title: Sports of The Times; Turner Gets Best Lessons Off the Court
description: THE day before St. John's faced Detroit in the N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional last night, Tarik Turner and a few of his Red Storm teammates took a brief, unscheduled tour of the United Center.

title: The Incoming Enemy
description: Like the prospect of being executed, the sudden appearance of asteroid 1997 XF11, which scientists say is hurtling toward Earth at a speed of up to 45,000 miles an hour, has transformed astronomy, normally the most esoteric of sciences, into a matter of life and death.

title: New York's Specialty Shops Bounce Back With Trendy Lines
description: NEW YORK  If you find yourself in New York in need of an Armani suit, chances are you'll hit one of the many department stores uptown.

title: Hurtling and Floating, At the Jungle Frontier
description: The boundary between live and canned music has been breached regularly, and Roni Size and Reprazent mounted a full-scale assault on it at Irving Plaza on Thursday night. Mr. Size is a producer, programmer and disk jockey from Bristol, England, which has been an incubator for futuristic funk. For the moment, he is at the vanguard of jungle, a style that rides on a combination of deep, leisurely bass lines and jittery, shifting double-time drum tracks. It's music that simultaneously hurtles and floats, with a dizzying perceptual whiplash as a listener makes the quantum leap between rhythms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, DAVID S.
description: FISCHMAN-David S. March 12, 1998. In fond memory of David S. Fischman. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. He will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, MARSHA
description: EHRLICH-Marsha. Camp Greylock mourns the passing of Marsha Ehrlich and sends deepest sympathy to her husband Bernard and her beloved family.

title: Statement by Lawyers for Jones
description: Following is the statement issued today by lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones as documents in her lawsuit against President Clinton were made public:

title: Token Sanctions Won't Help Kosovo
description: Those villages in Kosovo, a province of ''Yugoslavia,'' that were attacked recently by the Serbian police and paramilitary troops are still under siege. The Serbs hastily buried the dead, some 80 people, including many women and children, to hide the evidence of the massacre. Those left in these villages have no food, medicine and electricity, and they are vulnerable to new attacks. Every day somebody is struck by police sniper fire.

title: Lerik Journal; Yogurt? Caucasus Centenarians 'Never Eat It'
description: Something appears to be keeping people in this breathtaking mountain village alive longer than anywhere else on earth. It could be the clean water, the bracing air or a life of back-breaking labor.

title: Japanese Economy Shrank in Quarter
description: Japan's economy contracted at an annual rate of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1997, and the Government conceded that even its minimal growth target for the current fiscal year might be too optimistic.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR WEAKENS. The dollar fell on United States stock and bond losses and on hope that Japan would stimulate its economy. In New York the dollar cost 1.8185 marks and 128.15 yen, down from 1.8272 marks and 129.32 yen.

title: Women's Role in Islam
description: To the Editor:

title: Hingis Proves to Williams That She's Still No. 1
description: It was an unusual day in the desert: the stadium lights flicked on in midafternoon and raindrops spattered on the top gun Martina Hingis and eighth-seeded Venus Williams today as they tortured each other in the tense second-set tie breaker of their Evert Cup semifinal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASS, FLORENCE
description: BASS-Florence. On March 12, 1998. Loving wife of the late Sol Bass. Loving mother of Matthew and Roger, grandmother of Michael, Gregory, Julia and Allison. Services Sunday, 9 AM, ''The Riverside,'' 180 W. 76th Street.

title: Feeding the Next Generation; Food Industry Caters to Teen-Age Eating Habits
description: Christina Green, a 17-year-old high school student in Delaware, Ohio, considers herself old-fashioned when she shops for groceries. Most of her friends buy meals to go, she said -- ''stuff they can eat right away or zap.'' She, on the other hand, picks up frozen pot pies and breaded chicken, fish sticks and pizza, boxed macaroni and cheese.

title: Praise for Irabu
description: Hideki Irabu's first fastball Thursday night thumped into the mitt of catcher Jorge Posada, whizzing past Atlanta's leadoff hitter, Andruw Jones. ''Wooo, he's throwing hard,'' Jones said breathlessly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUR, HELEN, M.D.
description: SCHUR-Helen, M.D., former Medical Director of the James Weldon Johnson Counseling Center of Union Settlement Association. Loved and respected by her staff and disciples, grateful for the many, many years of devoted service to the East Harlem community. An outstanding clinician and teacher, Dr. Schur left her indelible print on community based mental health services. Staff of JWJ

title: To Sounds of Dixieland, James McDougal of Whitewater Notoriety Is Buried
description: James B. McDougal, the banker whose corrupt Whitewater real estate development tainted a Presidency and landed him in prison, was the center of attention for one last hour today, something his old friends say he would have appreciated.

title: Senate Urges U.N. to Try Iraqi as a War Criminal
description: After weeks of criticizing the United Nations, the Senate voted 93 to 0 today to urge the creation of a United Nations tribunal to try President Saddam Hussein of Iraq as a war criminal.

title: Tigers' Looks Are Deceiving
description: On the eve of Princeton's game against Michigan State in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, the Tigers continued to try to stress basketball over books today. Even after the Tigers dismantled Nevada-Las Vegas, 69-57, on Thursday, they still lamented that the stereotype about them as unathletic geniuses will probably persist.

title: Knicks' Injury List Grows
description: The Knicks added Brooks Thompson and Chris Mills to their ever-growing list of injured players today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHNER, IVA KAPLAN
description: ASHNER-Iva Kaplan, 54. New York City and Provincetown, MA. After a long illness bravely born, displaying nobility and unusual courage in difficult times. Beloved wife of Leon D. Ashner. Precious daughter of Eleanor and Nathan Kaplan, Pittsfield, MA. Dear sister of David Kaplan. Darling niece and cousin. Loving aunt. Dear friend. She was a 30-year employee of W.W. Norton Publishing Company where she was Editor and Director of Advertising. Funeral Services, Sunday, March 15, at 11 A.M., Gramercy Park (Sigmund Schwartz) Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, NYC. Burial Mount Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Shiva Surrey Hotel, 20 East 76 Street, NYC thru Tuesday, afterward in Pittsfield to Friday Noon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Iva Kaplan Ashner Writing Fellowship, Fine Arts Work Center, 24 Pearl Street, Provincetown, MA. 02657.

title: Small to Replace Ng
description: Brian Small, a former American League employee, was named yesterday to replace Kim Ng as the league's director of waivers and records. Ng (pronounced Ang) is leaving to become the Yankees' assistant general manager.

title: Woman Is Given Probation In Death of Baby Born in Secret
description: After telling a judge that she was ''truly sorry'' for her ''terrible mistake,'' a 20-year-old Brooklyn woman was sentenced yesterday to probation and community service for manslaughter in the asphyxiation of her baby minutes after she secretly gave birth.

title: Sega Enterprises Pulls Its Saturn Video Console From the U.S. Market
description: In a stunning retreat, Sega Enterprises Ltd., the company that gave wings to the high-flying video-game business with the success of its Sega Genesis console, announced today that it was pulling its Sega Saturn console from the United States market in the face of stiff competition from Sony and Nintendo.

title: Makers of Pistol Are Sued In Brooklyn Bridge Attack
description: In 1995, a Lebanese immigrant named Rashid Baz was sentenced to spend the rest of his life in prison for killing 16-year-old Aaron Halberstam on the Brooklyn Bridge. Yesterday, Aaron's parents and a survivor of the shooting went to court to convince a jury that the manufacturer of the gun was just as responsible for the attack.

title: Atlantic City Track Sets Fewer Horse Races in '98
description: In keeping with a study that recommends less horse racing in the state, the Atlantic City Race Course plans to ask the State Racing Commission for approval to operate only five live racing dates this season, rather than the 30 it had originally applied for, a move that probably means this will be the last season for live racing at the 53-year-old track.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, DAVID C.
description: COHEN-David C. The entire Nassau Association for the Help of Retarded Children family mourns the death of David C. Cohen. A lifemember of Nassau AHRC, he was a very generous benefactor and a strong advocate for protecting the rights of all individuals with mental retardation and other developmental disabilities and their families. Our deepest sympathy to his family and friends. Jack Garofalo, President Michael Mascari, Exec Director Association for the Help of Retarded Children, Nassau County Chapter

title: Label Reports Signing Snoop Doggy Dogg
description: No Limit Records, the label run by Master P, one of hip-hop's most successful self-made executives, rappers and filmmakers, announced yesterday that it had signed Snoop Doggy Dogg to the label. It said that on Aug. 4 it would release Snoop Doggy Dogg's long-awaited third album, ''Da Game Is to Be Sold Not to Be Told.''

title: Plea Deal Is Sought for Ex-Doctor Accused of Hiding Dark Past
description: The lawyer for a former doctor accused of lying about his criminal record to get a job at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Northport said today that she was trying to negotiate a plea deal and did not expect the trial to begin on Monday as scheduled.

title: LIFE BY DESIGN; Arguing Ethics, Forfeiting Progress
description: A startling new treatment is found that allows people with heart failure to live almost normal lives. It is risky, but without it the patients will certainly die. Do you use it?

title: A Challenge for a Cellist: More Notes Per Octave
description: Ted Mook specializes in contemporary cello music and has a particular interest in microtonality, a language in which composers replace the conventional 12-note octave with one that is more finely subdivided. Stringed instruments are ideally suited to this music because they present the notes of the octave as a seamless continuum, but the difficulty of finding the right pitches in a microtonal scale should not be underestimated. The challenge is magnified when a performer plays works using several microtonal scales, as Mr. Mook did at his recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Stocks Rally, But Market Finishes Mixed

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PHILIP SERVICES INC., Hamilton, Ontario, a scrap metal and industrial waste processor, plans to buy back as much as 6.56 million of its shares in the next year.

title: Kim's Decree Benefits Millions; Some Dissidents Are Left Out : South Korea Grants Sweeping Amnesty
description: SEOUL  President Kim Dae Jung granted amnesty to more than 5.5 million of his countrymen on Friday  for everything from traffic tickets to spying  and freed 2,304 people from jail, including some of the nation's best-known political prisoners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MOLLIE L.
description: COHEN-Mollie L. On March 13, after a brilliant 17year battle against breast cancer. Mollie was a woman of rare wisdom, good-naturedness, inner strength and caring, always patient and forbearing and always concerned about the other person. Her example is almost impossible to match. She is survived by her husband, Dan Harrison; her mother, Ruth S. Cohen; and her sister, Janis L. Vallely. Service Monday, March 16, 12:30 P.M., at Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, New York (two blks. from Pleasantville R.R. station. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Derby Hopefuls Gather in Florida
description: In two races nearly four hours apart, leading 3-year-old colts will take strides toward the Kentucky Derby today at Gulfstream Park in Hallandale, Fla. Six will run in the Florida Derby and nine others in the Swale Stakes, led by Favorite Trick, the juvenile champion and Horse of the Year in 1997.

title: Jones Adds Detail to Account Of Her Meeting With Clinton
description: In court papers filed by her lawyers today, Paula Corbin Jones gave new detail to her account of her 1991 encounter with then-Governor Clinton that creates a more threatening portrait of their alleged meeting at the Excelsior Hotel in Little Rock, Ark.

title: Plotting Against Reform
description: In order to quell a rebellion by Democrats and reform-minded Republicans, House Speaker Newt Gingrich promised that there would be a vote by the end of March on campaign finance reform. Now that the deadline is approaching, Mr. Gingrich is working hard to make sure the vote is rigged to come out the way he wants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEYERSDORF, MATHILDE
description: BEYERSDORF - Mathilde. Of Scarsdale, NY on March 13, 1998. Wife of the late Rene Beyersdorf. Mother of Frances Sutherland and John P. Beyersdorf. Also survived by six grandchildren and seven great-grandchilden. Memorial service to be held at Ferncliff Chapel, Ferncliff Cemetery, Secor Road, Hartsdale, New York, Wednesday at 12 Noon.

title: Longtime Dissident Still Held by Seoul
description: Officials and human rights groups said that Woo Yong Gak, a North Korean who may be the world's longest-serving political prisoner, was not included in today's amnesty of traffic offenders and prisoners in South Korea.

title: Kremlin Says Yeltsin Has a Cold, but This Time No One Panics
description: Three days after President Boris N. Yeltsin jubilantly proclaimed that ''the subject of the President's health should be closed -- it does not exist,'' the Kremlin announced today that Mr. Yeltsin had caught a bad cold and had canceled his Friday appointments.

title: Jones Files Generate Coverage, but Far From a Frenzy
description: The developments yesterday in the Paula Corbin Jones suit against President Clinton drew extensive, daylong coverage on television's all-news cable channels, but did not stir the all-encompassing media frenzy that accompanied some of the earlier developments in the two-month-long investigation into accusations of misconduct by the President.

title: Veterans Fear a Budget Squeeze Will Hamper Hospital Care
description: It is hard to tell in the gnarled faces and hobbled steps of the men who come to Lyons Veterans Hospital here that they were once vigorous enough to fight at infernal places like Omaha Beach and the Ardennes Forest. Increasingly, they find themselves having to remind people of what they have been through and of the country's promise to provide them with decent medical care.

title: U.C.L.A.'s Veterans Finally Halt Miami
description: U.C.L.A. has won the national championship 11 times since Miami last played in the tournament, and the Bruins needed a couple of experienced hands at the end to survive a challenge from the Hurricanes tonight.

title: Deal Expected For Cellular Phone Carrier
description: The Alltel Corporation was close to reaching an agreement last night to acquire the 360 Communications Company, a wireless telephone carrier, for more than $4 billion in stock, executives close to the companies said.

title: YACHTING: WHITBREAD; Gearing Up for Leg 6
description: The nine boats in the 31,600-nautical-mile Whitbread Round the World Race have been in Sao Sebastiao, Brazil, making final preparations before the start of Leg 6 today. The 4,750-nautical-mile journey to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., comes after Leg 5 left several teams in the fleet with technical or ethical problems. In the current points standing, EF Language, skippered by Paul Cayard, has a formidable lead. Katie Pettibone, an American on the all-female crew of EF Education, which stands last, has been filing periodic updates. This is her 15th report.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, CHARLES W.
description: ANDERSON-Charles W. Of Westfield, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Linnea Anderson. Father of Charlotte A. Abell. Also survived by three grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren. Former Chairman of the Board of Amatek Inc, New York City. Memorial services will be held on May 9, 1998 at the Chapel of the Presbyterian Church in Westfield at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Children's Specialized Hospital, Mountainside, NJ or the Presbyterian Church in Westfield.

title: Lonrho Unit to Buy Tavistock Collieries
description: Lonrho P.L.C. said yesterday that its Duiker Mining Ltd. subsidiary had agreed to acquire Tavistock Collieries Ltd. of South Africa from JCI Ltd. for $277 million. Lonrho also said it would seek shareholder approval to buy back up to $293 million in shares outstanding.

title: An Inventor and Heir Nonapparent
description: To get an idea of Carrot Top's brand of humor, observe the gray cat (which may or may not have been dead before it was frozen) that falls out when the landlady opens the refrigerator that belongs to his character, Edison. Or the cigarette ashes, complete with butts, that Edison combines with the crematory ashes of a recently deceased friend. Or consider the line, ''This must be the boardroom; you guys look pretty bored.''

title: Review/Fashion; Time Travel's Rewards and Perils
description: When Karl Lagerfeld was juggling four collections, no one expressed any doubt, at least not publicly, that he was up to the task, like a polygamist claiming to service four wives ably. But it is clear Mr. Lagerfeld can serve two better. The Chanel collection he showed Friday was breathtaking in its elegant insouciance. It was a splendid follow-up to the masterly Fendi collection he presented last week in Milan, one of the strongest Fendi shows in years.

title: Fordham Names O'Keefe as Coach
description: Fordham has selected Ken O'Keefe to replace Nick Quartaro and become the 16th head coach in the school's 98-year football history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEE, GLADYS (NEE CLARKE)
description: GEE-Gladys (nee Clarke), 86, died March 11, 1998 in Vero Beach, Florida. Graveside services on Monday, March 16, 1998 1:30PM, at Post Cemetery, West Point, NY. Contributions to the Association of Graduates, USMA, West Point, New York 10996.

title: UConn Shakes Off The Rust And Rolls
description: Ten days ago, the Connecticut women's basketball team won the Big East tournament. Thirteen days ago, Fairfield won the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament. Neither team had played since, so their game tonight in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament was understandably not always classic basketball.

title: Late Goal by Giroux Salvages a Tie
description: St. Lawrence 3, Yale 3

title: Icahn Climbs Into Cockpit Of Pan Am (But Why?)
description: Carl C. Icahn is back in the airline business.

title: Investigation of Ron Brown Leads to Other Indictments
description: In a vivid example of how an investigation can outlive its target, an inquiry into the financial affairs of a late Cabinet officer led today to the indictment of a Texas entrepreneur and her top financial officer, both accused of defrauding the Federal Government out of hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: From President's Defenders, Fierce Attack on the Accusers
description: President Clinton and his defenders responded to the latest filing in the Paula Corbin Jones lawsuit today with a blistering attack on the credibility and motives of Ms. Jones, her lawyers and her financial supporters.

title: No Hiding on the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Safir Sues TV Station, Saying Report Libeled Him
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir has filed a lawsuit against WCBS-TV, claiming that the station falsely reported that he had used city funds to pay for a meal at a restaurant in Littly Italy. The suit seeks $20 million in punitive damages.

title: Clinton Urges Asia Investors To Aid Lands Like Thailand
description: Offering Thailand as an example of proper economic management, President Clinton warned today that investors could throw Southeast Asia ''into a long-term recession'' if they fail to reward the countries that are effectively grappling with the financial crisis there.

title: KOHLBERG KRAVIS AND WELSH CARSON ACQUIRING MEDCATH
description: A joint venture of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe agreed yesterday to buy Medcath Inc., a physician-management and cardiology-hospital concern, for $19 a share, or $240 million. Shares of Medcath rose $1.625 yesterday, to $18.125, in Nasdaq trading. Medcath, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., said the merger would be financed by equity investments by Kohlberg Kravis, Welsh Carson and Medcath's management, as well as borrowings under a new $75 million revolving credit loan. Kohlberg Kravis and Welsh Carson, both New York-based investment firms, would each make a $105 million equity investment. Medcath's management would make a $17 million equity investment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORBETT, AMY (NEE SEINKNECT)
description: CORBETT-Amy (nee Seinknect). Aged 86, of Sarasota, Florida, died Mar. 12. Former longtime resident of East Williston and Huletts Landing, NY, she attended NYC School of Design and was an artist and homemaker. She is survived by her husband of 62 years James D. Corbett, two daughters Martha C. Leith of Michigan, Jane CorbettFloyd of Oregon, 5 grandchildren and 1 great grandson. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Albanian Rebel Bands Take to the Hills in Kosovo
description: A short burst of automatic weapons fire today sent villagers scurrying for cover down a narrow dirt street. There they gathered behind a wall of red cinder blocks and scanned the hilltops nervously.

title: Putting Some Order To All the Dali Prints, Both Real and Fake
description: ''Le more confusion is more better,'' said Salvador Dali, charming his devotees and laying down a formidable challenge to posterity. His dizzying output of nearly 2,000 graphics, often executed with workshop artisans and widely faked by a flourishing counterfeiting industry, has left art dealers, collectors and law enforcement agents agonizing over what is an authentic Dali print.

title: F.D.A. Advisory Panel Deadlocks on a Diet Drug
description: A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel deadlocked 5 to 5 today over whether to recommend agency approval of a diet drug.

title: Renegade Cleric Guilty Of Molesting Altar Boys
description: A cleric who broke from his Episcopal parish to form his own religious order in 1992 was convicted Thursday of sexually assaulting two altar boys, a boy he sought to adopt and a young man under his religious tutelage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, JANET
description: LEEDS-Janet. Bar-Ilan University in Israel and its American Friends extend sincerest condolences to Mrs. Diane Belfer upon the loss of her beloved sister Janet Leeds. Diane has been a generous benefactress of Bar-Ilan University and of many other important Jewish causes. We pray that she will derive comfort from inspiring memories. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor Bar-Ilan University Melvin Stein, Esq. President, American Friends Brig. Gen.(Res) Yehuda Halevy Executive Vice President Bar-Ilan University

title: A Limited Playing Schedule, But Still Beating the Best
description: It is not easy for young players with great talent to strike a proper balance between bridge and more serious occupations. Many have achieved fame in the game at the cost of neglecting their studies or 9-to-5 employment. One who has avoided that trap is Gregory Robbins of Manhattan, who recently graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and now works long hours in merchant banking. From his high school days he has shown that he can play bridge on a limited schedule and beat the best in the New York area.

title: Food and Population
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Top Sergeant of Army Is Acquitted of All Sex Charges
description: As his accusers sat stone-faced in a military courtroom, Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, once the top enlisted soldier in the Army, was exonerated of all sexual misconduct charges tonight and convicted of just one count of obstructing justice at his closely watched court martial here.

title: Corrections
description: A pop music review in Weekend yesterday about Rufus Wainwright, who performed songs at Fez in the East Village, misstated the given name of his mother, who is a singer and songwriter. She is Kate McGarrigle, not Anna.

title: Lagerfeld's 'Cosmovision' a Winner for Long-Line Chanel(folo)
description: PARIS  The British designer Deborah Milner confirmed Friday that she had signed a contract to work with Versace.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There are times when you have to get your priorities right.''

title: Setback for Street: Broken Left Leg
description: The same fear of falling that made Picabo Street overcautious in her specialty last month at the Nagano Olympics appeared to surface again yesterday, with painful consequences. She broke her left leg after crashing in the final women's downhill run of the World Cup season.

title: Messinger, City Fixture, Looks to Suburbs for Job
description: Ruth W. Messinger, the defeated candidate for New York City mayor, is looking for work in the more suburban pastures of Westchester County, interviewing this week for the job of the county's social services commissioner after answering a newspaper help-wanted ad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPHAEL, IRMA
description: RAPHAEL-Irma. On March 13, 1998. A loving, kind and generous person-and very special to all who knew her. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Devoted mother of the late Walter. She is survived by her granddaughter Robin Hemmingsen and great-grandchildren Anders Arthur and Emma Lindgren, sister-in-law Evelyn Zwick, nieces Renee Rubin and Ruth Landauer and their children. Many thanks to Florence Waight, her loving, kind caregiver and Dr. Weisenseel. Services Sunday, 1 PM, at Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Donations in her memory can be made to Dr. Meier, Palliative Care Program, Mt. Sinai Hospital Medical Center, 1 Gustave Levy Place, PO Box 1070, NYC 10029. For information, contact Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 212-288-3500.

title: City Owes Community Hearing on the Cottages
description: To the Editor:

title: ANNUAL U.N. RITUAL CONDEMNING CHINA LOSES U.S. SUPPORT
description: Only days after deciding to move up a Presidential trip to Beijing, the Administration has given China another important boost by dropping American sponsorship of an annual United Nations resolution condemning China's record on human rights.

title: Women's Role in Islam
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking the Bond Between Social Concern and Everyday Life
description: Call miracle self-healing:

title: Don't Rush on DNA
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMBERLIN, ROBERT H.
description: CHAMBERLIN-Robert H., 93. Of Ghent, NY. Died Tuesday, March 10, 1998. Born in Dayton, OH. He was a graduate and devoted alumnus of Williams College. He was a longtime resident of Scarsdale, NY active in civic, church affairs and community theater groups and a retired manager of Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. He is survived by his wife Anita of Ghent, NY; his children Robert, Ann, Jean and Thomas; 11 grand children & 2 great-grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held at the convenience of the family. Charitable contributions may be made to the Chatham Rescue Squad, 11 Moore Avenue, Chatham, New York 12037.

title: CLEAR CHANNEL TO BUY 40% OF MEXICAN BROADCASTER
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to buy 40 percent of a leading Mexican radio broadcaster, Grupo Acir Comunicaciones S.A., for $57.5 million in cash to expand outside the United States and add to its Spanish-language holdings. The San Antonio-based radio and television group also filed to sell 5.5 million shares of its common stock and a total of $500 million of senior convertible notes. Shares of Clear Channel rose $4.5625, to $95.6875. The closely held Acir owns 164 radio stations in 72 Mexican cities. Clear Channel owns 177 radio stations and 18 TV stations. It also owns one-third of the biggest Spanish-language radio broadcaster in the United States.

title: Pastor Found Innocent in Lesbian Ceremony
description: In a decision likely to reverberate through America's major Protestant churches, a jury of United Methodists clergy members voted tonight to acquit a fellow minister of a charge that he violated church law by performing a same-sex union for two women in his congregation last September.

title: INSIDE
description: Sighs of Relief

title: JONES LAWYERS ISSUE FILES ALLEGING CLINTON PATTERN OF HARASSMENT OF WOMEN
description: Trying to bolster their sexual misconduct suit against President Clinton, lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones today released more than 600 pages of sometimes graphic court documents in which they sought to portray Mr. Clinton as repeatedly engaging in sexual harassment of female underlings from his executive positions in government.

title: Trying to Weigh Safety and Tourism
description: In a normal winter dry season, the only time water rushes from the St. Lucie locks is when the mechanized gates crank open to release pleasure vessels entering or leaving the long man-made canal leading to Lake Okeechobee 25 miles to the west.

title: Hunter Wins in 2 Overtimes
description: George Brown, Hunter's outstanding guard, has confessed at times that he misses the drama of Division I basketball.

title: EQUITY RESIDENTIAL SAYS IT BOUGHT 12 PROPERTIES
description: Equity Residential Properties Trust, the nation's largest apartment owner, said yesterday that it had bought 12 properties in six states for $158.2 million. The properties have a total of 2,542 units. With the acquisition, the company owns a portfolio of 501 properties. The real estate investment trust, based in Chicago, said it had bought apartments in Florida, Maine, Minnesota, New Jersey, Texas and Virginia. Shares of Equity fell 18.75 cents yesterday, to $48.8125.

title: Pulsipher Sparkles In 5 Innings
description: Bill Pulsipher again did everything he could to up the ante in his bid to make the Mets' rotation. Armando Reynoso may have opened some eyes in what may have been an audition for the opposing general manager. Carl Everett criticized his former team and the New York media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, BENEDICT
description: GINSBERG-Benedict. The Jewish Education Service of North America mourns the passing of Benedict Ginsberg and extends its deepest sympathy to his daughter and our colleague, Judith Ginsberg, Executive Director of the Covenant Foundation, his wife, Adele, his son, Phillip, and the entire family. May the bereaved find comfort among the other mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mark Lainer, President Jonathan Woocher, Executive VP

title: Lawsuit Over Taped Call Goes Beyond Politics; Clinton Is the Winner
description: To the Editor:

title: From a Life of Rural Poverty, To a Life of Army Leadership
description: Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney gave life to the Army television commercial -- the one that urges recruits to ''be all that you can be,'' his lawyer told jurors at the court-martial this week.

title: Foreign Affairs; Here Comes The Sun
description: After several days of following village elections in northeast China with an international observer team, two lessons stand out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, SAM
description: GOLDMAN-Sam. The Board of Governors and the members of The Seawane Club records with sorrow the loss of our beloved member Sam Goldman. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Bea and family. Robert Roman, President

title: France Meshes Old and New to Create a Super-School
description: PARIS  The days when budding designers in France learned their trade picking up pins in the couture house atelier are over. Faced with increasingly stiff European and international competition, French schools are beefing up their curriculums. Internationalization, multi-disciplinary study and fashion business are the new mantras.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTERMAN, EDGAR ALLEN
description: KANTERMAN-Edgar Allen. Devoted and loving husband of Phyllis. Dear brother-in-law of Jerry Schwartz. Loving uncle of Anne Levitan and Fran Wheeler. Also survived by four great-nieces and nephews. He was a greatly admired dentist in Bayside, Queens, since 1949. Graveside services Sunday 11:30 A.M., at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Comments to Reporters by the President's Lawyer
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference in Los Angeles yesterday by President Clinton's lawyer, Robert S. Bennett, as recorded by Federal News Service, a private transcription company:

title: WARNER BOOKS AND GATES REACH A TENTATIVE BOOK DEAL
description: William H. Gates, the chairman and chief executive of Microsoft, has reached a tentative agreement with Warner Books, part of Time Warner Inc., to publish his second book, which will focus on how the Microsoft Corporation applies its technology to running its business. Microsoft executives said yesterday that Mr. Gates had an agreement in principle with Time Warner, but said that a final contract had not yet been signed. The new book, which does not yet have a title or a publication date, is intended to reach the company's millions of business customers -- in contrast with his first book, ''The Road Ahead,'' which was aimed at general readers. Mr. Gates originally proposed the idea of showing how personal computing technology could be used to make businesses work more effectively early last year. The roots of the project lay in Mr. Gates's eagerness to reach a broad business audience with his understanding of how the Internet was changing business, said Collins Hemingway, a Microsoft marketing executive.

title: Renault Shares Soar On Rebound From Loss
description: The shares of Renault S.A. soared yesterday to a record after the company said on Thursday that it had returned to profit in the second half of 1997. Shares rose 22.5 francs, to 248.5, their highest level since the French state first sold a stake in 1994. Renault earned 3.76 billion francs, rebounding from a loss of 5.41 billion francs a year earlier.

title: Suharto's New Cabinet Expected to Set Back Hopes for Indonesian Reform
description: As Indonesia enters one of its most difficult years, President Suharto announced today a Cabinet marked by loyalty and family connections rather than economic expertise.

title: Calipari's Options Dwindle
description: During his two seasons as Nets coach, John Calipari has had to look down and wonder if it was worth inserting the player sitting with a hopeful expression at the end of the bench. But he knew times were tough during the Nets' 115-104 loss to the Houston Rockets on Thursday night, when he looked down there and had no choice to make.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, MARELA
description: RUBEN-Marela. Mother of Fran, Maier and Betsey. Grandmother of seven, great grandmother of 11. Funeral 10:30 Sunday March 15, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry.

title: Militant Jews Start Melee By Marching In Hebron
description: A group of Jewish militants marched into a Palestinian-controlled area of Hebron tonight, touching off a melee in which 12 Palestinians, including several journalists, were wounded.

title: Rookie Upstages Agassi
description: With the throat of his racquet cracked from the battering it took from trying to field sonic serves, and with a lump in his throat as he pondered fending off the juggernaut across the net, Andre Agassi let himself become discombobulated and let his rookie opponent become a semifinalist for the first time.

title: Two Czechs Are Charged In Sex Ring Near Times Sq.
description: Two Czech nationals were indicted yesterday on charges of running an international prostitution ring that brought scores of women from Eastern Europe to work in sex shops on the edge of Times Square.

title: Excerpts From Deposition by Jones in Harassment Suit Against Clinton
description: Following are excerpts of testimony by Paula Corbin Jones when she was questioned on Nov. 12, 1997, by President Clinton's lawyer, Robert S. Bennett, in Federal District Court in Arkansas:

title: Chief U.N. Inspector Says Iraq Is Granting Much Wider Access
description: Iraq has given United Nations weapons inspectors unusually free access in the first test since Secretary General Kofi Annan reached his memorandum of understanding with President Saddam Hussein last month, the director of the inspection teams reported today.

title: New Look at an Unsolved Murder
description: From the day JonBenet Ramsey was murdered, the pieces never seemed to fit together: the bizarre ransom note, the discovery of the body in the basement, the killing that may have occurred while several people were in the house, the refusal of her parents to cooperate with police. The death of the pretty 6-year-old who paraded in beauty pageants captivated the nation, if only because a child of privilege had been found strangled in her own mansion. Her family's wealth and social standing may have flummoxed the Boulder, Colo., police, who did not press the grieving parents during the initial phases of the investigation.

title: GROUP MAKES AN $81 MILLION OFFER FOR POLLO TROPICAL
description: Pollo Tropical Inc. said yesterday that a group led by its chief executive and co-founder, Larry J. Harris, had offered to buy the fast-food chain for $10 a share. The offer values the company, which owns 36 restaurants featuring grilled chicken, at $81.8 million. Mr. Harris owns about 17.5 percent of the shares outstanding. The stock rose $1.3125, to $9.25. The board of Pollo Tropical formed a special committee to consider the proposal.

title: In Deposition, Former White House Volunteer Tells of Unwanted Advance by Clinton
description: In a deposition that provides some of the most potentially damaging evidence in a sexual harassment case against Bill Clinton, a former White House volunteer, Kathleen E. Willey, has described how an unwanted sexual encounter with the President began with a hug that was ''more than just a platonic hug.''

title: In New York, Forming Young Talent to Feed a Booming Industry
description: NEW YORK  It is a distinguished list of alumni. Donna Karan. Calvin Klein. Betsy Johnson. Isaac Mizrahi. Norma Kamali. Everyone of these prominent fashion designers  along with several others  attended one of New York City's three leading fashion schools, the Fashion Institute of Technology, Parsons School of Design and the Pratt Institute.

title: VALUE CITY IN DEAL WITH SCHOTTENSTEIN STORES
description: Value City Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy certain assets from the Schottenstein Stores Corporation for $110 million. Value City, an off-price department store chain based in Columbus, Ohio, said it had agreed to buy Schottenstein's Shonac Corporation and Nacht Management Inc. units as well as the store operations of the Valley Fair Corporation. Schottenstein Stores, also based in Columbus, is a discount retailer. Shonac has been the shoe licensee in all of Value City's stores since 1969 and also operates 40 DSW shoe warehouse stores. Valley Fair operates two department stores in Irvington and Little Ferry, N.J. Value City has been a licensee of certain departments in the stores for 18 years.

title: Price Dip Ends Weeklong Rally
description: The prices of Treasury securities turned lower yesterday for the first time in six days, as the market encountered buyer reluctance to pay more for Government bonds without seeing further evidence of slowing economic growth.

title: Senate's Proposal for Mass-Transit Vouchers Is Met With Wary Optimism
description: To Fred J. Levine, president of a Park Avenue printing company, ''it looks like a terrific opportunity.'' To Sonia Henry, human resources coordinator at the Battery Park City Authority, it ''seems workable, but then we'll have to see.''

title: The Texts: A Detailed Report
description: Key sections from President Clinton's deposition, with Paula Jones and Kathleen Willey excerpts, appear on pages A9 through A12. Text and depositions also appear on the Internet at www.nytimes.com.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: Linking Ancient to Modern, 1300's to Gertrude Stein
description: This season the Anthology Film Archives (32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village) began doing its part to encourage new music with a commissioning program and concert series, Music at the Anthology. Its program books list Philip Glass as executive producer, with Lisa Bielawa and Eleanor Sandresky as artistic directors, and in its first season it presented four concerts, the last of which was on Tuesday evening. A fifth, planned for May, has been postponed until September.

title: Police Admit Minority Officers Are Punished More Often
description: The New York City Police Department has released a study acknowledging that minority officers are more likely to face punishment for transgressions at internal disciplinary hearings than their white colleagues, as critics have repeatedly asserted.

title: Syracuse Thwarts Iona On Janulis's 3-Pointer
description: Syracuse had been in these situations as recently as the Big East tournament and more than a dozen times over the course of the season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNERT, CHARLES W.
description: TANNERT-Charles W. A devoted husband, loving father and grandfather, and avid fisherman, Charlie passed quietly on the morning of March 12, 1998 at the age of fifty-nine. His wry wit, quiet nature, and strong character will be sorely missed by all that knew and loved him, especially his wife, Noreen, and two children, Lisa and Chuck. Charlie is also survived by his son-in-law, John, and three adorable grand kids, Ben, Nick, and Sam. No matter how hectic life got around him, Charlie always found solace out on the water aboard his 18-foot runabout. With a fishing rod in hand and the sun on his face, Charlie always said, ''I love to go fishing. Catching something is just a bonus.'' I'll always treasure our Alaskan adventure, my friend. We'll see you on the other side. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. Visiting hours on Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass Monday 9:30AM, St. Peter of Alcantara Church. Interment Private.

title: Counties Clash Over the Lilco Takeover Plan
description: It was neighbor against neighbor as lawyers for Suffolk and Nassau County legislators clashed today in court over whether Gov. George E. Pataki's plan for a partial public takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company was legal.

title: A Year Later, N.Y.U. Women Fall Short
description: Trailing by 29-12 at halftime after making only 5 of 24 shots, New York University, the defending champion, looked hopelessly beaten tonight against Rowan University in a round-of-16 game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III women's basketball tournament.

title: Lawsuit Over Taped Call Goes Beyond Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEFFREYS, DR. LEONARD C., JR.
description: JEFFREYS-Dr. Leonard C., Jr. of Convent Station, NJ, formally of Livingston, NJ, on Thursday, March 12, 1998. Beloved father of Kristi L. Bristol of Middlesex, NJ and Timothy C. Jeffreys of Hoboken, NJ. Son of the late Mabel Crawford. Also survived by his three grandchildren, Jennifer, Steven and Matthew Bristol. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Monday, March 16, 1998 at the St. Thomas More Church, Convent Station, NJ at 10:30 am. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Morris Township, NJ. Hours of visitation at the Doyle Funeral Home, 106 Maple Avenue, Morristown, NJ on Sunday 1-4 and 7-9pm

title: Gore Proposes Video Channel To Show Earth, All the Time
description: The idea hit Al Gore one night at 3 A.M., and he sat bolt upright in bed: Let's send a satellite into space that would beam back sun-washed images of the whole Earth -- something more majestic than the tight shots seen on the Weather Channel, something that would show storm systems and forest fires and cloud formations in real time, a channel devoted to all Earth, all the time.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Circuits section on Thursday about the Agora computer security group misstated the location of the Regence Group, the organization's sponsor. It is in Portland, Ore., not in Washington State.

title: Colleges, Too, Often Hide Disciplinary History
description: To the Editor:

title: Beatrice Wood, 105, Potter And Mama of Dada, Is Dead
description: Beatrice Wood, a ceramic artist known as much for her irreverent quips, beauty, bohemian life style and famous lovers as for her luminous luster-glaze chalices, and who inspired at least two movie characters, died on Thursday at her home in Ojai, Calif. She had celebrated her 105th birthday on March 3.

title: Park Slope, Reshaped by Money; As Rents and Prices Rise, Some Fear for Neighborhood's Soul
description: In fits and starts over several decades, Park Slope has become a laboratory for both assimilation and gentrification. The Irish and the Italians once brawled on Fifth Avenue, followed by the Puerto Ricans, who elbowed into the mix. There were Jamaicans, and by the 1970's, the hippies had arrived, enticed by the lure of stately but inexpensive brownstones in need of repair.

title: Lagerfeld's 'Cosmovision' a Winner for Long-Line Chanel
description: PARIS  A powerful collection from Chanel on Friday, spanning the divide between Coco in the 1920s and the year 2000, has laid to rest one of fashion's most persistent myths: that a designer can serve two masters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, ERIC
description: WASSERMAN-Eric. Beloved son of Samuel and Sandra Wasserman. Adored brother of Robert and Cary. Beloved grandson of Ethel Carmel Wasserman. Also son of Pat LaPedus. Your friends and your family love you and miss you. We welcome friends to our home to celebrate your life. Services Sunday, March 15th, 10 AM, at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue at 55th Street. Contributions may be made to the Eric Wasserman Fund for Community Outreach c/o Central Synagogue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALPERT, BENJAMIN
description: ALPERT-Benjamin. It's three long years since you left us!!! WE'RE LONELY, WE MISS YOU. LOVE YOU, June, Richard and Peter

title: Little Valparaiso Turns Into a Titan Against Ole Miss
description: The play is called Pacer: go the length of the court and score in 2.5 seconds. The Valparaiso Crusaders practice it every day, but it seldom works. Now they had to make it work before a national television audience.

title: Journal; Deaf Comedy Jam
description: ''It will be fun to read,'' promised one of Paula Jones's advocates before 700 pages of sexual Clintonalia were dumped on the public yesterday. It will be ''the mother of all mudslides,'' added NBC's crack newsman Geraldo Rivera. The only question: Can we finish devouring all 700 fun pages before tomorrow night, when ''60 Minutes'' offers Kathleen Willey in the flesh, presumably to expand upon her vivid account, already reported by Newsweek, of all the President's manhood?

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of the Arts section on Thursday about Susan Lucci's nomination for a Daytime Emmy misstated the date of this year's awards. It is May 15, not April 15.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWMAN, ETHEL L.
description: BOWMAN-Ethel L. Widow of Supreme Court Justice Amos E. Bowman and mother of Supreme Court Justice Janice L. Bowman, passed away peacefully in her sleep on March 12, 1998. Viewing Benta Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Avenue at 141st Street, on Sunday, March 15, 4-6 PM. Funeral St. Philip's Episcopal Church, 204 West 134th Street at 7th Avenue, Monday, March 16, at 11 A.M.

title: City Owes Community Hearing on the Cottages
description: To the Editor:

title: St. John's Fights to the End, and Falls Just Short
description: This was not the way that St. John's three seniors, Zendon Hamilton, Felipe Lopez and guard Tarik Turner, wanted to go out. In their first and only appearance in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, the trio suffered a meltdown.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN DROPS. Corn fell 2.5 percent after the Sparks Companies, an influential commodity consultant, predicted the biggest planting in 16 years. The May contract lost 7 cents a bushel, to $2.7475, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Shares Are Mixed as Dow Retreats and Nasdaq Advances
description: The stock market ended mixed yesterday, pushed down by declines in consumer company shares that were led by a plunge in Kimberly-Clark but buoyed by strength in technology stocks that extended their rebound from last week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  APRIL, CYNTHIA SUE KASS
description: APRIL-Cynthia Sue Kass. Happy 50th Birthday! The ''forcynthia'' are blooming. I miss you. Love, Lois.

title: Frantic Hunt Found Photos That Deflated Asteroid Fears
description: It pays to save old photographs.

title: An Unlikely Pair of Senators Oppose Expansion of NATO
description: Bob Smith and Tom Harkin don't agree on much.

title: Cultural Issues Pose Obstacles In Cancer Fight
description: The Breast Examination Center of Harlem was designed as a cheery place, with toys to entertain patients' children and a billing policy as inviting as the atmosphere: mammograms, free of charge. But when the newly expanded center opened four years ago, its doctors were dismayed to discover that the women of Harlem were not banging down the doors to take advantage of their offer.

title: Europe Refuses to Drop Ban on U.S. Beef
description: The European Union said today that it would not drop a ban on hormone-treated beef even though two international panels have ruled against it.

title: Abe Ajay, 78, Artist of Relief; Known for Boxlike Constructions
description: Abe Ajay, an artist best known for his shallow, boxlike wall constructions and collages, died on Monday in a hospital near Bethel, Pa., where he lived. He was 78.

title: Colleges, Too, Often Hide Disciplinary History
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Kennedy 2d Will Quit Congress; Family Needs Cited
description: Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, the leading politician in the dynasty's younger generation, announced today that he planned to retire from Congress, prompted by a year of family tumult and tragedy that brought ''a new recognition of our own vulnerabilities and the vagaries of life.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: BANKBOSTON ACQUIRING URUGUAYAN CREDIT CARD COMPANY
description: The BankBoston Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire a Uruguayan credit card and consumer finance business. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. The Boston-based bank said it would buy OCA, Uruguay's largest credit card company, which has a loan portfolio of $50 million. BankBoston has 14 branches and $700 million in assets in Uruguay. BankBoston earmarked $100 million for investment this year in Latin America, which is expected to generate almost one-third of its revenue by 2001.

title: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success
description: LONDON  To outsiders, it might seem like a conspiracy  two London fashion colleges intent on world domination infiltrate their students into the prime jobs in international fashion.

title: Hilton Hotels Considers Split Into Two Parts
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that it was considering splitting its hotel and casino businesses into two separate publicly traded companies, with the gambling company then merging with Circus Circus Enterprises in a stock transaction.

title: Linda Tripp's Security Form Draws Inquiry
description: Pentagon officials said today that they would investigate whether Linda R. Tripp, the Defense Department employee who secretly tape recorded phone conversations of Monica S. Lewinsky, lied on a security clearance form and should be penalized.

title: Election Victory Upheld Despite Faulty Machine
description: A judge has upheld a State Assembly candidate's 74-vote margin of victory in November even after a faulty polling machine failed to record 160 votes, ruling that most of the unrecorded votes probably would have been cast for the victor anyway.

title: Analysts Get Together for a Synthesis
description: In the early history of every field, there are traumatic events. In psychoanalysis, one of the biggest was the creation and destruction of the seduction theory. In 1896, Freud said he had found the key to hysteria: all hysterics were seduced as children. The next year he took it back. He decided that the key to hysteria was not the actual seduction of children but their sexual fantasies. It is not physical reality but psychic reality that counts.

title: When Convenience Calls
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawsuit Over Taped Call Goes Beyond Politics; Equal Standard for All
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLEGHENY TELEDYNE EARNINGS TO FALL BELOW ESTIMATES
description: Allegheny Teledyne Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings before special items were unlikely to reach analysts' estimates. In a statement late yesterday, Allegheny Teledyne also said it expected nonrecurring revamping charges and transaction costs from its recently announced acquisitions. The charges were not specified. A First Call Inc. survey of seven analysts found they were expecting Allegheny Teledyne to earn 46 cents a share for the first quarter. In the first quarter last year, the company reported net income of 35 cents a share before a one-time gain. The Pittsburgh-based company cited continuing weakness in commodity stainless steel prices, combined with a shortfall in aerospace-related metals shipments.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 26 about Manhattanites' reliance on mini-storage referred incorrectly to the doves used in the act of Arnie Kolodner, a magician. While he keeps costumes in mini-storage, the doves live in his home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALMIRON, HUGO
description: ALMIRON-Hugo. Loving husband of Alma. Dear father of Fabiana. Beloved son of Severina. Reposing at the Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, New York, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 710PM. Graveside service Monday 11AM at Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: Huskies Face A Familiar Foe
description: Because Connecticut has played Indiana in each of the last two seasons -- first a 30-point victory in the Great Alaska Shootout and then a 10-point loss at Indiana last year -- the Huskies say they have a feel for the Hoosiers.

title: Officials Seek Building for Students Displaced by Fire at a School
description: Officials from the private high school in Westwood gutted by arson on Thursday began the search today for a new school for its learning-disabled students.

title: About New York; Grandmother Hits the Road In Soul Search
description: JOAN MISTER jumped up from her kitchen table, abandoning her coffee and buttered toast in mid-sentence. She had been talking about her car trip from her Brooklyn home to the West Coast and back when she realized that she couldn't always count on sunny skies to guide her. ''Oh,'' she said, jotting a reminder in a note pad. ''I have got to get a compass.''

title: Yale Brozen, 80, Economist And Advocate of Free Markets
description: Yale Brozen, a retired professor of business economics who was a vocal critic of government regulation, died on March 4 at his home in San Diego. He was 80.

title: A Kennedy Drops Out
description: The decision by Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d not to seek re-election runs counter to the family's combative never-say-die image. The eldest son of Robert Kennedy now becomes perhaps the only member of the Kennedy dynasty ever to give up politics voluntarily, even if only temporarily. But in the context of a disastrous year, the decision makes sense. An embarrassing furor over a book by Mr. Kennedy's former wife and charges of improper sexual relations with a teen-age baby sitter against his brother Michael had already forced the Congressman to drop out of the Massachusetts governor's race last year, a harbinger of the withdrawal announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, GOLDIE
description: BRENNER-Goldie. The Trustees of the American Friends of the Tel Aviv Museum of Art mourn the passing of Goldie Brenner. Our sincere sympathies to her daughters Edith Everett and Gladys Praigard. Uzi Zucker, Chairman Professor Mordechai Omer, Director and Chief Curator Tel Aviv Museum of Art

title: A Collaboration of Organ And Reverent Movement
description: American modern dance and French Baroque and modern music harmonized well on Thursday night at the Church of the Holy Trinity when a choreographer and an organist collaborated on ''A Dance and Organ Extravaganza.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITT, MICHAEL WILLIAM
description: LITT-Michael William. On March 11, 1998, age 51. Survived by his mother Florence, sister Caren, brother Scott, and many friends and relatives who will greatly miss him. Visitation: Saturday, March 14 from 7-9PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th St. Service to remember and celebrate his life: Sunday, March 15 at 3 PM, Philosophy Hall, Columbia University. For details, call Riverside Memorial at 212-362-6600.

title: Did a Barnyard Schism Lead to a Religious One?; Scholars Trace Christian-Jewish Hostilities To the Pig, Laden With Symbolism
description: Throughout history, the pig has been an animal with a deeply fraught significance for Christians and Jews as well as Muslims. Why, for example, are Jews forbidden to eat pig meat at the same time Christians happily serve up ham for Easter?

title: RANGERS
description: Aleksandr Karpovtsev's season-ending wrist surgery has been postponed until March 26, his agent said yesterday, because the wrist was inflamed following a tuberculosis test.

title: State Exceeds a Goal For New Welfare Laws
description: Less than one month shy of the one-year anniversary of New Jersey's welfare revision legislation, slightly more than half of the able-bodied people receiving public assistance have obtained part-time jobs or are in work training, which is substantially more than the goal of 30 percent set for this point in the program, state officials said.

title: Excerpts from Deposition Detail a Potentially Compromising Hug
description: Following are excerpts of a deposition of Kathleen E. Willey, a former White House volunteer, given on Jan. 10 in the sexual harassment case of Paula Corbin Jones against President Clinton and Danny Ferguson, a former Arkansas state trooper. Ms. Willey was questioned by Robert S. Bennett, the President's lawyer, and Daniel Gecker, her lawyer. The deposition was made public today by lawyers for Ms. Jones.

title: Excerpts From Clinton Testimony for Deposition in Jones Lawsuit
description: Following are excerpts from the testimony of President Clinton when he was questioned on Jan. 17 at the Washington offices of his lawyer, Robert S. Bennett, for a deposition by lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones. The first 40 minutes of the session were taken up with arguments among the lawyers and the questioning does not begin until page 25 of the transcript. The text was made public today by lawyers for Ms. Jones.

title: FORD SETS DISTRIBUTION FOR ASSOCIATES FIRST SPINOFF
description: Stockholders of the Ford Motor Company would receive 0.262085 share of the Associates First Capital Corporation for each class B or common Ford share they own as part of the auto maker's spinoff of the consumer-finance company. Ford expects to spin off its 80.7 percent stake in Associates First to shareholders April 7. The total distribution is valued at about $25 billion, including $3 billion in corporate cash given to employees. Ford employee savings plan enrollees would receive the same distribution in cash rather than stock. Ford's shares rose $1.91, to $59.28, while Associates fell 37.5 cents, to $78.9375.

title: Fighting Sexual Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pumpkin and Hoopla at Cornell Go Splat
description: The Great Pumpkin Mystery at Cornell University reached a bizarre anticlimax yesterday, after five months of speculation, hoopla and some ingenious amateur sleuthing to identify the huge orange thing that someone had somehow impaled before Halloween on a lightning rod atop a 173-foot campus bell tower.

title: Arkansas Nears Another Title
description: Kenny Evans, an Arkansas freshman, cleared a personal best of 7 feet 6 inches and won the high jump at the National Collegiate Athletic Association indoor track and field championships tonight.

title: Cancer Retreats, Slightly
description: It is a testament to the remarkable intractability of the cancer problem that a relatively small decline in new cancer cases is being hailed as a major turnaround. Yet any final victory over this most dreaded of human diseases must start somewhere, so it is indeed cheering that, after decades of inexorable rises, the incidence of cancer in the American population has started to dip, ever so slightly, and so has the death rate from cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, THOMAS M.
description: WYMAN-Thomas M. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 19, 1998 at 5:00PM at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street, New York. Contributions may be made to the Panwy Foundation, 10 Valley Drive-9 Greenwich Office Park, Greenwich, CT. 06831.

title: Meadowlands Plan Means More North Jersey Billboards
description: The Meadowlands sports complex in East Rutherford has already sold the naming rights to one of its arenas to Continental Airlines. As early as this summer Meadowlands officials will begin selling billboard space as well.

title: Susan Rausen, Alfred Drewes
description: Susan Watkins Rausen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron R. Rausen of New York, was married yesterday to Alfred Herman Ahrens Drewes, the son of Marjorie E. Morgan of Englewood, N.J., and the late Alfred H. Drewes. The Rev. Arnold Wettstein, the dean of religious studies at Rollins College, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: A Long Island Bank Grows on Manhattan Island
description: Ho hum: one bank's branch closes to be replaced by another bank's branch. Still, the corner of 72d Street and Amsterdam is a puzzle. As the giant posters proclaim, the bank moving into the spot where Citibank had been since 1936 is North Fork Bank. Who?

title: A Reunion, Of Sorts, Goes Bad
description: CANUCKS 6, ISLANDERS 2

title: The Troubles
description: BEHIND THE MASK

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Everest

title: Outsmarting the Plants to Grow a Great Salad
description: HUGE heads of escarole and endive with deep, wide, well-blanched hearts are a favored salad green in Europe, but they tend to receive low ratings in the United States, where they are considered a minor crop.

title: Queens Leaders Back Bookkeeper for Assembly
description: Pauline R. Cummings, a 52-year-old former bookkeeper, sat quietly at a fund-raising breakfast at a Forest Hills restaurant on a recent morning, surrounded by the firmament of Queens Democratic leaders. As the parade of politicians passed by, she seemed more than a little in awe -- more like a guest than the guest of honor.

title: Clinton May Veto Funds Bill on Abortion Issue
description: President Clinton hinted today that he might veto emergency spending legislation if Congress attached a ban on financial aid to groups that offer abortion services overseas.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 15, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Show of Work Resembling Items at Hand
description: ART made of nontraditional materials is nothing new; it is a staple of the 20th century. But those materials are always new, always being updated, and that is why the genre does not wear out. At the College of New Rochelle's Castle Gallery, ''Alternative Measures'' presents a lively and varied selection of recent manifestations.

title: Sunday: March 15, 1998; ROAD BILL
description: Good news, West Virginians: you can now shop for meat while driving! Recently in the State Legislature, Paul Prunty, a Democrat, proposed a bill making it legal for hunters to preserve and keep, year-round, the meat they bag. (In part to discourage poaching, state law had it that game meat could be kept for only 90 days after hunting season.) But then a state senator got into the act by adding the so-called ''road-kill provision,'' a rider that would also permit drivers to keep the carcass of any animal they hit. The bill became law in early March, despite the fact, says Prunty, that many legislators were uncomfortable with the idea of promoting stop-and-go shopping on the highway.

title: Go Slow on NATO Expansion Vote; Push on Start 2
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: What Is It About Those Old Bones?
description: THE pace was swift at the annual Dinosaur Days held recently by the Peabody Museum of Natural History in New Haven. Children were tearing about, dragging along parents and grandparents from exhibit to exhibit, picture to picture, bones to bones. Sometimes they would stop short, nearly causing the adults to tumble over them, to stare upward in fascination at a huge skeleton that once had been a great creature roaming the earth.

title: A Vietnamese Restaurant Finds a New Home
description: When the New Jersey section last set out to visit Saigon, we ended up in Cresskill, at a Vietnamese restaurant run by a talented chef named Khanh Tran. At that time, January 1997, Fran Schumer, the restaurant critic, praised the intriguing flavors of Saigon's spring rolls and its careful way with salmon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, MARC ALAN
description: WEISS-Marc Alan. Suddenly on March 12, 1998. Loving and devoted father of Allison Rachel Weiss, beloved son of Helene Rothstein and Arthur Weiss, cherished brother of Stephen and Lauren Weiss, dear uncle of Lindsay and Shelby. Services Sunday, 12 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A style column on March 1, about a game played to figure out the names that participants would use if they were drag performers, misspelled the name of a literary magazine that published a poem by one player. It is Sewanee Review, not Suwannee.

title: Spectacles Of Rock
description: Music lore has it that when a young Buddy Holly shared billing with Elvis Presley in Lubbock, Tex., in 1956, Presley encouraged him to keep his black-framed glasses on. Holly (above) went on to become one of rock's most enduring influences. So did his glasses.

title: Hotel Restaurants Shine in East 50's
description: AL BUSTAN ++

title: As Ewing Heals, Doctor Faces Decision
description: The aging superstar crashed down on his shooting wrist with a thud. Within 24 hours, everyone would discover the details of his predawn surgery and the bleak prognosis.

title: Nets Snap Loss Streak As Gatling Scores 24
description: It was only fitting that in the moments after Chris Gatling had helped end the Nets' seven-game losing streak, while his teammates breathed a sigh of relief, he was in another room having his right shin X-rayed.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Examining Medical History

title: A Look at How Mets and Braves Care for Pitchers' Arms
description: Brian Edmondson is neither an orthopedist nor a physiotherapist. He is not a member of the Professional Baseball Athletic Trainers Society. But he is a pitcher who spent three years in the Mets' minor league system and now is trying to win a spot in the Atlanta Braves' bullpen.

title: Fast Forward; The Intercranial Internet
description: History has been punctuated by inventions with the potential to change everything. The technology of language made civilization possible while the atomic bomb gave us our first big shot (you should excuse the expression) at self-extinction.

title: The Wrong Time To Go Clamming
description: I read ''Digging for Clams and Finding Life'' [Feb. 1] and found it interesting. Unfortunately, it is illegal to take clams after sunset in any waters within the town of Southold. If Mr. Berson is, in fact, a ''sailing captain,'' whatever that means, and lives in Greenport he should know better. It is a shame that someone whose livelihood comes from the water is not aware of the regulations in his own town and is not more concerned with how our resources are managed.

title: On the Market Again: A Seasickness Patch
description: Transderm Scop, a seasickness treatment in the form of a patch worn behind the ear, is again available. Production difficulties kept it off the market from 1994 until January. Studies reported by the Journal of Travel Medicine have found the patches to be as effective as antihistamine pills.

title: Children's Books
description: MEANWHILE . . .

title: Supreme Court Was Right on Jones Lawsuit; Pity the Pundits
description: To the Editor:

title: Indian Congress Party Picks Sonia Gandhi
description: Sonia Gandhi was elected president of India's Congress Party today, defying Indians who have said that Mrs. Gandhi, Italian-born and until recently immersed in domestic life, is not fit to head the organization that led India to independence 50 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALPERT, BENJAMIN
description: ALPERT-Benjamin. It's three long years since you left us!!! WE'RE LONELY, WE MISS YOU. LOVE YOU, June, Richard and Peter

title: 'Casual Friday' Dress Becoming Everyday Thing
description: SIX members of the engineering department at the Northrop Grumman Corporation in Bethpage sat around a cafeteria table on a recent Friday eating lunch and talking about old-timers who were retiring.

title: Illustrations That Breathed Life Into Rubaiyat
description: Elihu Vedder's Drawings for the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam

title: Supreme Court Was Right on Jones Lawsuit; Good Liberal Dog
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/New Jersey; First Town Houses for a Detached-Home Township
description: THE residential landscape is about to change in the affluent Essex County suburb of Livingston, a 13.7-square-mile community of detached homes ranging from modest Cape Cods to rambling ranches and just one rental apartment building.

title: Sunday: March 15, 1998; EAT YOUR GREENS
description: * Starting in the 18th century, oppressed Irish citizens wore green as an act of defiance. Today, we swallow our green. * Every March, Hostess sells a bright green (rather than bright pink) line of Sno Balls snack cakes. The greenies boost sales over a typical month by 15 percent to 20 percent. * If you lined up all the green Shamrock Shakes sold by McDonald's in the last 27 years -- in cups laid end-to-end -- you could cover the distance, twice, between Chicago and Limerick, Ireland. * Not quite so popular: the green bagels sold at New York City's Bagel Buffet. * Green beer may be more trouble than it's worth. The dye stays in draft lines and produces sickly looking beer for days. ''A lot of places will do it once,'' says Joe DeNardo, marketing director for several Houlihan's restaurants in New York City, ''and they learn their lesson.''

title: Schools Try To Expand Two Arenas
description: C.W. POST and the State University at Stony Brook have been planning to expand their athletics complexes, but both plans have met resistance.

title: When a Friend Needs a Legal Stand-In
description: Q. I'm in my early 60's and two friends want to give me power of attorney. I'd like to help but am wondering exactly what my responsibilities would be and how I would know enough to carry them out.

title: Food; The Pineapple Parable
description: This is a story about battery acid, pineapple and the end of innocence, all of which are intimately connected, at least in my life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORWITZ, SIDNEY
description: HORWITZ-Sidney. On March 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Joyce Cummings Horwitz. Devoted father of Michael S. Horwitz. Loving grandfather of Jesse and Alec. Dear sister of Estelle Kessler. Funeral service Monday, 10 AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Six Iraqis, Unfairly Judged
description: Imagine a trial in which the prosecution secretly presents evidence that the defendants and their lawyers have no right to see. The judge's ruling against the defendants is disclosed, but the details are kept classified. The government will only say that the men are considered a danger to national security and must leave the country. It sounds like the former Soviet Union, but the rough equivalent of this case just happened in the United States.

title: A Lounge Inspired By Czechoslovakia
description: On a recent trip to Czechoslovakia, John Barounis was impressed by the rolling hills outside Prague, by the city's grungy but picturesque lounges, and by the city of Brno, which he described as a giant's playground of concrete blocks.

title: At Hair Salons, It's Feet First
description: FREUD would have had a field day with today's hairstylists and colorists, whose obsessions confirm his theory of fetishism: that the classic objects of displaced desire are hair, shoes and feet. For hairdressers, clothes are often beside the point. Solid white or black shirts are the uniforms of choice. What really gets their blood going -- besides hair, of course -- is shoes.

title: On Their Own in the Big Screen Land
description: LEE VOGEL, of Branford, has been in love with movies since childhood and can remember spending entire days in luxurious theaters with grand-sounding names -- the Palace, Royal, Grand and Ritz -- near her home in Albany, N.Y.

title: March 8-14; A Victory for McKinney
description: For the Army's former highest-ranking enlisted soldier, the verdict in Fort Belvoir, Virginia, was just short of a triumph. A military jury acquitted Sgt. Maj. Gene McKinney of all sexual misconduct charges, and found him guilty of only one of the 19 charges he faced: obstructing justice.

title: In Masks and Diamonds
description: Inspired by Purim, youth, art and science.

title: Style; Ah, Spring
