description: Call me a stretch snob, but I was never a stretch enthusiast. To me, stretch meant either disco-stretch, as in Lurex, Lycra, spandex, or cheesy-stretch, as in shiny, pilling, baggy knees -- neither look a terribly attractive one.

title: Some Clarifications On Brookhaven Memorial
description: The article ''Slow H.M.O. Bill Payments Strain Hospitals'' in the Feb. 8, section incorrectly reported vital information concerning Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center.

title: Jeanette Wakin, 69, Columbia Lecturer and Expert on Medieval Islamic Law
description: Jeanette Wakin, an expert in the arcane world of medieval Islamic law, died on Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 69 and a senior lecturer at Columbia University, where she had long been a mainstay in the department of Middle East and Asia Language and Culture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCE, LESLIE
description: DRUCE-Leslie. March 13, 1998. Beloved sister of Jeffry Druce. Dear friend of Lyn Meehan. Her generosity, sense of humor and wonderful love of life will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral private.

title: Children's Books
description: ''ALWAYS WEAR

title: Love, Italian-Style
description: NOT everyone loves Mangia Questa, which I've heard derided as ''New Jersey Italian,'' but I do. A former delicatessen disguised with white gauze and green plants, it is a source of always-satisfying and often first-rate Italian dishes.

title: Blacks Carry Load of Care for Their Elderly
description: Eldora Mitchell is nearly as old as the century, and for her it has been a life of love and service, starting at the age of 12, when she went to work scrubbing white people's floors to help her family. Later, she cleaned hospital rooms to feed her own children and cared for her grandchildren while their parents were working. In her 60's, she nursed her dying husband and her elderly mother.

title: Working Vacation Takes Volunteers to India
description: MENTION vacation and what probably comes to mind for most people is turquoise seas and swaying palm trees, or snow-covered slopes waiting to be skied. But for those who want something different, something akin to a mini-stint with the Peace Corps, there is Cross-Cultural Solutions.

title: There'll Always Be . . .
description: A SCIENTIFIC ROMANCE

title: London's National Theater Holds Sway
description: THE National Theater had a change of director last fall, with Trevor Nunn replacing Sir Richard Eyre, but it shows no sign of yielding the dominance it has achieved in recent years. True, the months ahead bring London plenty of appetizing stuff elsewhere, from Harold Pinter in a revival of one of his best short plays to Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Whistle Down the Wind,'' from Kevin Spacey as the gladhanding protagonist of O'Neill's ''Iceman Cometh'' to ''The Merchant of Venice'' in Shakespeare's Globe. But with the Royal Shakespeare Company deserting the Barbican in early May for its annual redoubt in Stratford, there's no concerted challenge this summer to the wizardries in Mr. Nunn's concrete Oz on the South Bank of the Thames.

title: INVESTING IT; Baseball and Beyond
description: THE most promising name in sporting goods this year may also be one of the most venerable: 111-year-old Rawlings Sporting Goods.

title: Ingram Finishes 2d In the Pentathlon
description: Bridgette Ingram of Maplewood, N.J., finished second in the girls' pentathlon last night at the National Scholastic Indoor Track and Field in Boston. Loren Leaverton of Garland, Tex., was the winner with 3,711 points, and Ingram, a junior at Columbia High School, had 3,411.

title: Word for Word / The Justices and Paula Jones; The Ruling That Entangled the President
description: WHATEVER the Justices of the Supreme Court were thinking last May 27, when they ruled unanimously that Paula Jones could proceed with her sexual harassment suit against President Clinton, it is safe to say they never imagined developments like the one last week in Little Rock, Ark., where lawyers for Ms. Jones made public a foot-high stack of pretrial documents filled with lurid allegations about Mr. Clinton's sex life.

title: When Character Counts
description: When military jurors here considered the sexual misconduct charges against Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, they were caught in the same muddle that often complicates such harassment cases, whether civilian or military: Whom to believe when a woman says one thing and a man says another.

title: Making Small Successful
description: THE Balleto di Toscana, which started its first North and South American tour on Friday, is in many ways an Italian cultural anomaly. The company is private, it is small, its repertory is modern, and its success is greater abroad than at home, where contemporary dance is often forgotten in the institutional bias for the big splashy productions of Italy's state-financed opera houses.

title: Mortgage ABC's in a Borrower's Market
description: TRADITIONALLY, the biggest challenge faced by first-time home buyers, typically a young couple or family, was coming up with a big-enough down payment to qualify for a mortgage. After that, they would need the right combination of confidence, brashness and humility to be able to walk into a lender's office, ask for a huge amount of money and wait nervously for an answer.

title: March 8-14; Maybe Boys Aren't So Yucky After All
description: Six years after setting off a national debate about how public schools shortchange girls, the American Association of University Women has a new message: All-girls' schools don't solve the problem.

title: Through Turkey, With Toddler in Tow
description: MY husband, Duke, looked at the stack of suitcases and scowled. ''We can't take this much stuff,'' he said, shuddering. ''Lose two bags.''

title: Sharp Resigns At Manhattan
description: Michele Sharp, the basketball coach of Manhattan's Lady Jaspers the past six seasons, said yesterday that she has been forced to resign. ''They asked me to resign, so I resigned,'' she said. ''I wouldn't want to stay in a job where I was no longer wanted.''

title: Historic Buildings in Houston Getting New Roles
description: THE homeless people who once congregated under the cast-iron portico of an abandoned old downtown hotel have been replaced by construction crews working to transform the historic, red-brick 18-story Rice Hotel into 312 rental apartments.

title: Promoting the Joys of Selfishness
description: WHO was Ayn Rand anyway? If the power of television immortalizes her as the brazen older woman in a long-running adulterous affair, the author, philosopher and self-declared ''radical for capitalism'' may be forgotten.

title: How the Andersens Turned Into the Bickersons
description: ON a recent Wednesday evening, white stretch limousines crowded the parking lot at Andersen Consulting's headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif. The drivers waited to take the firm's top partners and their counterparts at Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm, to dinner at Spago, an elegant restaurant downtown.

title: In His Own Way, Olerud Bulks Up
description: Charles Atlas, he is not. But John Olerud did work this winter to bulk up ever so little in preparation for this spring.

title: The World: In Its Dreams; Russia Solves Its Crime Problem
description: THE new, unlikeable boss of the Moscow police insists that a string of seven grisly murders is the work of one vicious serial killer. Nastya Kamenskaya, a top detective, is less sure. Slowly, surely, working her way through murky evidence, powerful mafia informants and a daily pack of menthol cigarettes, she cracks the case: The seven victims were killed by secret service trainees for practice. It was all part of a plot by rich businessmen and corrupt officials to rig the presidential elections in the year 2000 and take control of the country. Her boss, she discovers, was part of the conspiracy.

title: The World; The Not-So-Superpower Society
description: I GREW up with history, and I learned that since the 16th century, France and Russia have almost continuously been allies and friends,'' the late President Francois Mitterrand of France wrote in 1985 to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, then President of the Soviet Union. ''History and geography dictate some things that are constant.''

title: Sign Language: It's the Talk of the Town
description: DEAF people aren't the ones Pat Massey worries about; she is convinced they can take care of themselves.

title: Report Cards for Alternative Middle Schools
description: New York's alternative schools are either free-standing or schools within larger neighborhood schools. Some highlights from the city's report card on alternative elementary schools:

title: Lincoln's Youth
description: To the Editor: I must take some issue with Harold Holzer.

title: Keeping a Sense of Mission Alive for 300 Years
description: The Puritan farmers of southern Connecticut were already running out of room as the turn of the century approached 300 years ago. With the Dutch holding New York and the Hudson River Valley, anyone looking for new land to settle had to choose between facing the Mohawk tribes inland or skipping down to Long Island or, eventually, moving to the wilds of New Jersey.

title: Q&A;: Joan Tanenhaus; Computer as Ally for Learning Disabled
description: TWELVE years ago, when computers were first being incorporated for home and school use, Joan Tanenhaus, a speech-language pathologist since 1962, was asked to procure and develop a computer program for use at a Head Start program, where she was a consultant.

title: POSTINGS: Municipal Art Society Walks; Tours Discover Old New York
description: Architectural historians will be marching into the city's past this week in five afternoon ''Discover New York'' tours sponsored by the Municipal Art Society.

title: Valparaiso Keeps It All in the Family
description: Her husband the coach told of their son's courage. Of how every day since he was 8 years old, Bryce Drew counted down the final seconds of imaginary games and fired the winning shot from beyond the 3-point line. Janet Drew closed her eyes and heard the ball bouncing off the blacktop in her backyard as she has most days in the past 20 years.

title: A Quebecer Trumpets The Case For Canada
description: When the phone line to Montreal suddenly went dead, Stephane Dion's usual sang-froid disappeared. The host of a French-language talk show had asked about Quebec secession and Mr. Dion, Canada's official crusader for national unity, did not want to look like he was avoiding the question.

title: Arkansas Men Soar to Victory
description: Arkansas won its 14th men's team championship in 15 years yesterday, scoring 56 points to Stanford's 36. Clemson and Washington State tied for third at 26.

title: Finally, City Sees 3 Minutes Of Snow
description: The New York City winter has been such a lost cause in the snow department that meteorologists have taken to giving their tally in minutes rather than inches.

title: Children's Books; Frazzled and Bombazzled
description: One rainy day a little girl named Iggie finds herself trapped in the house with a bad case of the fidgets, which come to life as the Krazees, a gaggle of wild things playing havoc with Iggie's head, her house and her cat. Rooms are shredded one by one in a crescendo of chaos. Finally -- poof! -- the Krazees vanish. Out comes the sun, and Iggie is free. It's really O.K., cool, cathartic even, that in THE KRAZEES (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16; ages 3 to 6), there are undercurrents of transactional analysis. It's popular psychology for the preschool set. The text is so charmingly wrought by Sam Swope and envisioned by Eric Brace that the therapeutic instruction rests easily upon it. Seussian wordplay abounds: ''Do you ever get the Krazees? / Do they make your razzle tig? / Do they frazzle your bombazzle / Till you shilly up your shig?'' And my favorite: ''Do they biggle your bumdiggle? / Do they make you wriggle red?'' These are marvelous lines to read -- or squeak or growl or rumble -- aloud. Brace's illustrations have the fully realized, 3-D quality of Claymation, as well as that medium's rather funky esthetic and Taos palette. What a short film this book would make! Krazees are, variously, snouted or striped or snaggletoothed. There are Krazees like little beans, or winged piglets; there are plaid Krazees and Krazees with polka dots. Iggie's like a brunette Penny from the old ''Pee-wee's Playhouse.'' And the manic kitty is just terrific. Penelope Green

title: March 8-14; Thanks, But No Thanks
description: In a court ruling so secret that their lawyers cannot read it, six Iraqis were ordered deported by a Federal immigration judge. They had worked in concert with the Central Intelligence Agency in failed operations against Saddam Hussein and have been declared threats to American national security. Offered refuge by the United States, they were thrown into Immigration and Naturalization Service detention centers after arriving in California last year. TIM WEINER

title: Ideas & Trends; In Cold Facts, Some Books Falter
description: THE Clutters, a Kansas farm family, were all murdered during a botched robbery one day in 1959. Truman Capote spent several years investigating the crime, and emerged with ''In Cold Blood,'' which was published in the New Yorker in 1965 and then in a book Mr. Capote called a nonfiction novel.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOFFMAN, WALLACE R.
description: HOFFMAN-Wallace R. September 7, 1920-March 16, 1997. So sadly missed, so deeply loved. Charlotte, children and grandchildren

title: Go Slow on NATO Expansion Vote; Plenty of Hearings
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Would Create Lottery To Preserve Open Spaces
description: State lawmakers have introduced a bill that would create a new $1 lottery game to raise money for the preservation of farmland and open space.

title: A Bakery-Bistro-Bar With Big Portions
description: CUISINE Cucina is one of those 1990's hybrids. It calls itself a bakery-bistro-bar-market. Diners on their way to tables in the rear of this long, narrow, high-ceilinged Rockville Centre storefront first encounter shelves loaded with imported olive oils, pastas, biscotti and other specialty groceries. Most patrons then pause to make mental choices from the display cases of pastries, cakes and pies. A deli counter, presenting a colorful mosaic of fancy salads, prepared entrees and bowls of olives, is next.

title: Spencer Barnes, Rhys Moore Jr.
description: Spencer Kathryn Barnes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse N. Barnes 3d of Winston-Salem, N.C., was married yesterday to Rhys Llewellyn Moore Jr., the son of Mrs. Ernest E. Guerney Jr. of Clinton Township, Mich., and Mr. Moore of Clearwater, Fla.

title: Honoring a Theater With 'My Fair Lady'
description: THE Julie Harris Theater of the Clear View School here has a long and colorful history. First known as the Beechwood Playhouse of the former Scarborough School, the theater was dedicated in 1917 by the pianist Ignace Jan Paderewski, whose opening-night performance was only slightly marred by an enormous explosion across the river. (The automatic fire doors opened above listeners' heads, but Paderewski kept playing.) Charles Coburn, Isadora Duncan, Sarah Bernhardt and H. G. Wells were among those who trod the theater's stage. Audiences through the years included Franklin D. Roosevelt, John D. Rockefeller Jr., Henry Ford and the last King of Poland.

title: The View From/Westport; For Music in All Its Guises (but Not Its Fads), It's Sally's Place
description: THE secret behind the success of Sally's Place, Sally White's popular Westport music store, can best be described through an exchange that occurred between her and a customer late last summer.

title: To Help a Nightclub Get a Lease, Trump Works the Phones
description: Ingrid Casares is pulling out some big guns, including Donald Trump, in her fight to open a branch of her Miami nightclub, Liquid, on West 22d Street near Fifth Avenue. But the landlord, David Yagoda, says the artillery does not faze him.

title: Setting the Sadness in Willy Loman's Mind
description: IF the Paper Mill Playhouse has the stuff that musical theater dreams are made of, the devotees of drama need not be shortchanged. When winter comes, the musical showplace here turns to the non-musical, all too often a dotty English farce or an interim booking from the road. The more useful examples of Paper Mill's January-to-March tradition (''Inherit the Wind,'' ''You Can't Take It With You'') suggest that the preservation of important American plays in first-class productions can be an intrinsic part of the season rather than an interruption. When the play is ''Death of a Salesman,'' no one can talk of filler. For it comes with the territory of great theater.

title: Sunday: March 15, 1998; PLANTING POETRY
description: Early next month, Andrew Carroll, the 28-year-old executive director of the American Poetry and Literacy Project, hits the road on a solo cross-country spree. He'll be handing out books of poetry wherever readers are found -- at truck stops, supermarkets, even jury waiting rooms. To match local tastes, Carroll has special books in store for some chosen cities. For example, residents of Roswell, N.M., a U.F.O. hotspot, will get Mina Loy's ''The Lost Lunar Baedeker,'' while patrons of an all-night Chicago diner will receive Hayden Carruth's ''Scrambled Eggs & Whiskey.'' Carroll shoves off April 1 from New York City, after a public reading whose lineup caters to Manhattan's variegated local tastes: the choreographer Bill T. Jones, Laurie Anderson and Mike Wallace.

title: Il Ritorno: Young Find Arthur Ave. Is Home
description: GROWING up, Salvatore Biancardi spent holidays in Biancardi's, the family butcher shop on Arthur Avenue, known throughout the city as the Little Italy of the Bronx. As he wrapped homemade sausage and baby-lamb roasts, he daydreamed, and the dreams were always the same. He would become a banker, impeccably dressed and worldly. He would fly to foreign capitals, to meet with powerful people and lend them money for monumental projects.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER EAST SIDE

title: A West Side Story
description: For three years, Olive & Bette's has been one of the few purveyors of Daryl K and other hip designers on the Upper West Side. The success of the store, at 252 Columbus Avenue (72d Street), has prompted its owners, Stacey Pecor and Karen Greenberg, to come up with a mail-order catalogue to fill what they see as a void in that market.

title: A National Chain Arrives With Hoopla
description: TYPICAL Long Island shoppers, Fran and Elliot Levine of Malverne have visited many a store's parking lot. But last Sunday was the first time that they happened upon 18 women in brief gold lame outfits and large ostrich-plume helmets, kicking alongside their car. ''I hope it's the Rockettes,'' Mrs. Levine said as she pushed her shopping cart out of the new Target store in Westbury. Sometimes one never knows. But it was the dancing women from Radio City. As they kicked, Mr. Levine stared. ''I've been a New Yorker all my life,'' he said. ''But I never saw the Rockettes. I had to come to a Target store to see them.''

title: Finding the Puerto Vallarta Liz Taylor Knew
description: MAZATLAN, Puerto Vallarta, Manzanillo, Ixtapa, Acapulco, Huatulco. To my ear, these main resort havens on the 1,300-mile Mexican Riviera are beautiful words -- promising long margarita afternoons and the giddy sense of flushness that stems from a favorable rate of exchange (about 7.8 pesos to the dollar recently). In early February, I was planning to visit Southern California, so they would all be within easy reach.

title: End of the Line for L.I.R.R.'s 10 Loneliest Stops
description: It was 5:45 on a bone-chilling Thursday afternoon. In the fading daylight, a bookkeeper from Wantagh, a bank clerk from Valley Stream and a devout Islanders fan from around the corner stood in their customary spots at the edge of a desolate railroad track on the back side of a 145-year-old graveyard in Glendale, Queens.

title: Ruth F. Young, 94, Founded An Academy to Promote Peace
description: Ruth Forbes Young, who founded the International Peace Academy, an organization that trains negotiators, diplomats and military personnel in peacekeeping and provides meeting grounds for diplomats involved in efforts to prevent hostilities, died on March 5 at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 94.

title: World Bank Vs. Reformers on How to Still Feed Russia When It's 64
description: When one of Russia's most ardent reformers set out to convert the state-run pension system into a program of private individual retirement accounts, he never imagined that the unabashedly capitalist idea would be rebuffed by the World Bank.

title: Sunday: March 15, 1998; QUESTIONS FOR:; James Nashold
description: James Nashold, a writer and neurosurgeon, co-wrote ''The Death of Dylan Thomas'' with George Tremlett.

title: Q. & A.
description: Replacing Air Coolers In a Condo

title: Continental Divide
description: LADY MOSES By Lucinda Roy. 382 pp. New York: Harper Flamingo/ HarperCollins Publishers. $24

title: Once Upon a Time, When DiCaprio Was King . . .
description: The Man in the Iron Mask

title: In Costa Rica, Studying Endangered Turtles
description: SAM SADOVE, a marine biologist, was last in Playa Grande, Costa Rica, more than a decade ago. There was no electricity, telephones, running water or roads in the remote lowland jungle.

title: The Religious Tyranny Amendment
description: Once again, the separation of church and state essential to American liberty is under assault in Congress. In a radical move that attracted little public notice, the House Judiciary Committee has approved a constitutional amendment that would effectively strip the promise of religious neutrality by government from the Bill of Rights.

title: Sunday: March 15, 1998; PUBLICATIONS; The Anti-Wired
description: It's not exactly Howard Beale, the mad anchor in Network,'' deciding he's opposed to corporate news operations, but a group of Silicon Valley wonks has taken the daring step of going public with an equally heretical notion. The cyber-future can wait.

title: From the Barricades, an Outcry Against Fascism
description: IN the first half of the 20th century, revolutionary posters became rallying points for political protests in Spain and Russia. With bold lettering and vivid images of bombed cities and strident workers, these posters proved to be effective weapons of war.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EISNER, ROSLYN
description: EISNER-Roslyn. ''A TRUE NEW YORKER'' ''A True Charitable Person'' B. Nov 8, 1920. D. Mar 13, 1997 IN LOVING MEMORY Your brother, Mel Mond

title: Closed-End Funds Play A New Kind of Defense
description: OVER the last year, investors in closed-end funds have been pushing successfully for measures like stock buybacks and dividend increases to bolster the market value of their holdings. But in what critics say is a move to thwart the conversion of such funds to open-end status, several closed-end funds have developed a novel kind of takeover defense: issuing preferred stock.

title: Passive, Aggressive
description: While conservatives remain largely silent, Bill Clinton's defenders have become the vocal partisans in the Paula Jones furor. Page A29.

title: Catherine Hakim, Adam Brodsky
description: Catherine Rose Hakim, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kamran Hakim of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Adam M. Brodsky, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jules Brodsky of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Chaim Stern officiated at the Plaza in New York.

title: Castle Hotel: From Notoriety to Propriety
description: Since the Castle Hotel, once notorious for drug use and prostitution on 106th Street west of Central Park, was sold under court order last summer, neighbors have nervously awaited word of what the new owners planned. Nearby residents cheered reports that it might be used for student housing. When that plan seemed to fall through, they organized to fight a proposal to use the building for a residence for people with AIDS.

title: Into the Outside World
description: ACCOMPANIED by vituperative community meetings, bitter lawsuits, angry protests, hopeful state reports and heart-wrenching tales of individual suffering, New Jersey is entering a phase most states began and finished long ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLMAN, FRANCES MERRON
description: HILLMAN-Frances Merron. In Westport, CT. March 13, 1998. Wife of the late Henry Hillman and mother of Patrick M. Hillman of NYC. Retired Broadway columunist for both The New York Journal American and The New York Mirror. Services Monday 10 AM, St. Luke Church, Westport, CT. Interment Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Charles F. Phillips, 87, President Of Bates College for 23 Years
description: Charles F. Phillips, a former president of Bates College in Lewiston, Me., who helped oversee the Government's rationing of goods during World War II, died at the Central Maine Medical Center in Auburn on Tuesday. He was 87 and lived in Auburn.

title: Schizophrenia's Most Zealous Foe
description: As the moderator of the E. Fuller Torrey-Thomas Szasz debate at Towson University, I must strongly object to Michael Winerip's depiction of the debate assurreal'' and of Szasz as ''once influential'' (''Schizophrenia's Most Zealous Foe,'' Feb. 22). Szasz is the most quoted and respected critic of psychiatry, and he continues his prolificacy to this very day.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIEBERFARB, BETTYE
description: LIEBERFARB-Bettye. 27 years remembered always with love. Warren, Bonnie, Monte and Jim

title: March 8-14; The High Price of Love
description: When it comes to investing in political influence, the tobacco giant Philip Morris has set a record. No single company has ever spent more in one year on campaign contributions and lobbying in Washington than the staggering $53.8 million spent by Philip Morris in 1997. And never has so much money bought so little love.

title: In a Wheelchair
description: To the Editor: I would like to add to Betsy Wade's comments about facilities on cruise ships (''Practical Traveler: Smoother Seas for Wheelchairs,'' Feb. 1).

title: The Winter That Wasn't Means Woe For Many
description: The cherry blossoms are blossoming here in Branch Brook Park. The shad have started swimming up the Delaware to spawn. Pollen floats through the air, irritating noses, making eyes burn red. Yes, spring is here and it is early, very early.

title: Supreme Court Was Right on Jones Lawsuit; Asteroid Scenario
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: AN adventure milestone, a delightful salute to dance partners, a jagged western and a memorable portrait of a playwright's family lead this week's film roster.

title: The Gore Guide To The Future
description: Al Gore would no doubt be a fine President, but if he has no more sense than to sip his tea directly over the computer keyboard, I fear for the nation.

title: The Last Neon Light by The Side of The Road
description: One hundred and ninety-two years ago, an increasingly weary Meriwether Lewis, separated from his colleague William Clark and confounded by fog, stopped on these lonely plains at a place he called Camp Disappointment. Sounds like the great explorer could have done with a real good night's sleep about then, on a firm but plush mattress, preferably one equipped with a coin-op Magic Fingers massager.

title: Rangers Can Find Solace in Just One Thing: The Future
description: Ranger fans can find much to be encouraged about after today's demoralizing 5-1 loss to the Boston Bruins at Fleet Center. The positive thoughts have nothing to do with the way the Rangers played.

title: For Boeheim and Bliss, Rivalry Lives on Bench
description: Syracuse and New Mexico, who will meet here Sunday afternoon in the second round of the South Regional, are hardly traditional rivals. They have met only twice, and not since 1977. Their coaches, however, are longtime acquaintances who often sit together in the stands to watch the Final Four.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: MAJOR WASHINGTON

title: Correction
description: An entry in a time line on Jan. 25 in New York Then and Now, a special section on New York City's centennial, omitted the surname of a public relations pioneer in the decade of 1898-1907. He was Ivy Ledbetter Lee. This correction was delayed because a letter from his son Ivy Lee Jr., dated Feb. 5, was initially misdirected at The Times.

title: Sports of The Times; One Boy's Eye-Opening Initiation To the N.H.L.
description: AN 8-year-old boy went to Madison Square Garden recently for his first live hockey game, with his father and 4-year-old brother, the New Jersey Devils fan. The 8-year-old, much more a basketball enthusiast, was tagging along with no rooting preference, but nonetheless was in for the awakening of his brief and simplistic professional sports fan's life.

title: March 8-14; For Whitewater Witness, A Lonely Passing
description: The death of James B. McDougal while in solitary confinement was a setback to Whitewater prosecutors, but not a monumental blow.

title: Renaissance Man
description: LONG LIFEBy Nigel Nicolson. Illustrated. 294 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $29.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAMPSEY, HELEN R.
description: DAMPSEY-Helen R. Age 91, died on March 8, 1998, in Carmel, NY. She was a gifted musician who played the piano around the world. A memorial gathering will be held at her home in April. For information, contact Beecher Funeral Home in Brewster, NY.

title: How The Album Got Played Out
description: Marzorati's lament for the lost art of the rock album strikes many a poignant chord, but unless he grew up in England, he has chosen a poor example of an album that showed him, back in the eighth grade, the value of a carefully assembled sequence of songs.

title: Bridging Two Worlds: Elite and El Barrio
description: ON a chilly Sunday morning, James de la Vega walked down the three flights from his East Harlem apartment and went outside to make art. Using white masking tape, he laid down the outlines of a woman releasing a bird, a figure extending two or three car lengths, in the middle of hilly 102d Street between Park and Lexington Avenues. Then he taped the words: ''Be free my son, be free.''

title: Even an Arch-Individualist Can Get Lonely
description: MENTION the name Ayn Rand, the combative Russian-born writer and philosopher who died in 1982, and chances are a passionate femme fatale isn't the first image that comes to mind.

title: Losing His Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: U.S. Marshals

title: Arcade Protest
description: Opposition is mounting to a $1 million proposal by Trans World Entertainment of Albany to build an electronics superstore and arcade in the Galleria mall in White Plains.

title: The Nation; East Wins and Loses A Race in the West
description: LOIS CAPPS, a former school nurse from Santa Barbara, handily defeated State Assemblyman Tom Bordonaro last week in a hard-fought special election to serve out the Congressional term of her late husband, Walter, a Democrat who died last fall.

title: Mr. Clinton's Dangerous Friends
description: The White House line was that President Clinton left early for Camp David on Friday afternoon to show that he was not distracted by the new filings in the Paula Jones suit. The timing of the departure from the South Lawn meant that Mr. Clinton missed his lawyer's rambling press conference. Robert Bennett, looking weary and rattled, said he was right to file the motion to dismiss that allowed Ms. Jones's lawyers to file a 700-page examination of the President's sexual conduct. ''I think the President's reputation is pretty darn good in the eyes of the American people,'' Mr. Bennett said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASEN, DOROTHY
description: ASEN-Dorothy. Devoted, beloved wife of Emanuel; loving mother, grandmother, daughter, sister, aunt, friend. Funeral today 12:30 PM, I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Freedom Riders
description: THE CHILDREN

title: Go Slow on NATO Expansion Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Mail
description: P.R. Bauble Of the Week

title: DIARY
description: EXCHANGES

title: How The Album Got Played Out
description: While Gerald Marzorati makes an excellent point about the effects of technology on album listeners, he forgets the other side of the problem: the effects of technology on musicians (''How the Album Got Played Out,'' Feb. 22). The long-playing record was about 40 minutes long; today's compact disk can drone on for up to 74 minutes. Bands can't resist the temptation to fill all the vacant space on a disk, and the listeners suffer. How can you expect the kids to sit through 10 good songs interspersed with another 10 pieces of padding and overindulgence without reaching for the skip button?

title: Hudson Valley Featured in Concerts
description: THREE Hudson Valley composers are represented in concerts today. The Yonkers Philharmonic plays the first movement of Stanley Wolfe's Third Symphony at 3 P.M. at the Saunders School in Yonkers. At 4 P.M. David Amram and his Trio take listeners at Briarcliff Congregational Church on a trip ''Around the World in 80 Minutes,'' and at 7 P.M. the music of Herman Luri is featured in a special tribute concert at the Tarrytown Music Hall.

title: Possibilities, Real and Surreal
description: LIFE is a dream. Or perhaps it isn't. After the first act of ''Sueno,'' a new adaptation of an old epic at Hartford Stage, a woman said that she didn't understand the play's title.

title: Growth Pains on Breast Cancer
description: NOWHERE in the country has breast cancer activism been so influential as on Long Island in enlisting volunteers, gaining political support and obtaining government and private funds, even leading to the issuing of a breast-cancer postage stamp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYSANEK, LEONIE
description: RYSANEK - Leonie. Beloved opera singer on March 7, 1998 in Vienna. Funeral Tuesday, March 17, at 3:30 PM at Dr. Karl LuegerGedachtniskirsche, Wiener Zentralfriedhof. Donations may be made to Leonie Rysanek Fund, c/o The George London Foundation, 515 East 79th St, NY 10021, to be used to help young singers.

title: The Reticent High Priest of Munich
description: SUDDENLY, Sergiu Celibidache is everywhere. Relatively speaking, that is.

title: Commuters See Gain At I-95 Rest Areas
description: RUSH hour, especially along Interstate 95 in southwestern Connecticut, is a tooth-grinding experience. ''It takes you an hour and a half to get to work in rush hour,'' said Ed Gentile, who only covers 18 miles from his home in Fairfield to his job at Pitney-Bowes in Stamford, where he is a customer assistance supervisor.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: YESTERDAY WILL MAKE YOU CRY

title: THEATER; The Cheerful Past O'Neill Had to Invent
description: ''AH, WILDERNESS!'' Eugene O'Neill's ''comedy of recollection,'' opening on Wednesday at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center, would seem to be a natural musical.

title: Cost of Staying In Touch Abroad
description: MATT SMEDLEY, 24, was nearing the end of a year spent exploring Europe last June when he spotted a pay phone in Tromso, a Norwegian harbor town above the Arctic Circle, and decided to call his parents in Malvern, Pa. ''I thought it would cost a fortune, but I wanted to call so I did,'' said Mr. Smedley.

title: Smoke-Free Zones At 35,000 Feet
description: This month Air France joins most of its European counterparts in banning smoking on all trans-Atlantic flights. Flights to and from the United States and Canada will be completely smoke-free as of March 29, as will flights between Los Angeles and Tahiti. (Flights from Miami to the Caribbean will still have smoking sections.) Last month Air France eliminated smoking sections on all flights within Europe. Flights to Africa, Asia and South America will still offer ''air pur,'' its enclosed and ventilated smoking bars.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Feb. 22 about the Chobe River in Botswana misidentified the buffaloes shown. They were Cape buffaloes, not water buffaloes.

title: Elizabeth Carr, Denis Leverson
description: Elizabeth Whitney Carr and Denis Keith Leverson were married yesterday at St. Christopher's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Key Biscayne, Fla. The Rev. Robert M. G. Libby performed the ceremony.

title: We'll Have The Chateau Cuervo
description: A VOLKSWAGEN BEETLE sold for about $1,700 in the early 1960's. The new model about to appear will cost as much as $20,000. So perhaps it's not so startling that someone has just introduced a $1,000 bottle of tequila.

title: An Appreciation Of Ward Melville Article
description: The recently renamed Ward Melville Heritage Organization, known for many years as the Stony Brook Community Fund [Letters, Feb. 8], has a carefully crafted aura of sanctity about it to which everyone does not subscribe. Under its original name newcomers might have believed that it was a charitable organization and made donations accordingly. Its new name, and the fact that it has been broken up into separate organizations, have helped to rectify that misunderstanding.

title: When Rage Is All the Rage
description: ON a rainy Friday afternoon, about 20 employees of Makovsky & Company, a Manhattan public relations agency, were crowded into a small seminar room, sipping soft drinks and chatting amiably while waiting for the program to begin. They were hardly a pack of pit bulls, but they were there for one reason: to get a better grip on managing their anger at work.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; How Two Companies Dressed for Success
description: I WISH I had a nickel for every hour that companies spend debating casual dress. Short on facts, long on emotion, the suits-vs.-slacks debate is tailor-made for metaphor.

title: Clash of 'Facts' Intensifies in Jones Suit
description: It was fitting that President Clinton's lawyer, Robert S. Bennett, was in Los Angeles on Friday while lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones were in Washington. In every sense, the two camps were thousands of miles apart.

title: Liberties; Sticky Cotton Candy
description: Ozone Man woke up in the middle of the night and wanted a world view.

title: The Best Part
description: To the Editor: The illustrator of the article on the $200 cantaloupe (''Forbidding Fruit,'' Jan. 18) has unwittingly destroyed the value of the fruit. A fancy muskmelon becomes valueless if a stem is not attached.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Tube Stations

title: Decades of Life in Harlem As Recorded by VanDerZee
description: RIGHT now the A train is not necessarily the fastest way to get to Harlem. ''VanDerZee,'' at the New Britain Museum of American Art is a raft of richly evocative photographs by James VanDerZee (1886-1983) whose career spanned 80 years. Most of them were spent as a commercial portrait and street photographer in Harlem.

title: Tar Heels Wrest Overtime Victory From Charlotte
description: There was a classic game between North Carolina and North Carolina-Charlotte this afternoon, a game that actually deserved an overtime and did not seem as if it would climax until there was one final twist to make it even more memorable. It was a basketball junkie's nirvana, especially if you reside in the hoop-crazed state of North Carolina.

title: The View From/Scarsdale; Where Toddlers Learn To Say 'Yuck' in French
description: DR. LINDA BENISH has big plans for her daughter, Arianna. Dr. Benish, a dentist, said Arianna is ''already pretty amazing,'' an articulate conversationalist. Arianna also ''constantly craves new experiences'' and, her mother said, she hopes her daughter will grow up to be healthy, happy, accomplished and well traveled. Which is why, at the age of a year and a month, Arianna is studying French.

title: Echoes of the Gold Rush and the Cry of 'Eureka!'
description: One hundred and fifty years after James Marshall plucked a shiny nugget of gold from the American River, the Oakland Museum of California has mounted a major exhibition devoted to the mass migration of fortune seekers caused by Marshall's discovery. ''Gold Rush! California's Untold Stories'' consists of three shows that explore the history and legacy of the event that transformed the state.

title: The Freelance Approach To Personal Training
description: Ken Fitzgerald has opened Lift Gym, which he promotes as a haven for independent personal trainers. And that, he says, translates into lower prices and better service for customers. The gym, which he opened in January on two floors of 139 East 57th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, does not charge the trainers a fee.

title: Back Home in Dixie
description: CAVEDWELLER

title: Firing Shots Across the Bow Of Charter School Dreams
description: Governor Whitman gushes about charter schools. So do lawmakers from both parties, who say the independent public schools are a more palatable educational experiment than voucher programs, which use tax dollars to send children to private schools.

title: Nice Guys Finish Dead
description: TWILIGHT ON THE LINE

title: In Master's Room, a Chill Creeps In
description: Born 100 years ago, the Finnish Modernist architect Alvar Aalto is hot again. All over town, exhibitions and lectures have been celebrating his work, from ''Finnish Modern Design'' at the Bard Graduate Center to a high-profile retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. But not far from the museum, and unknown to many people, is the real thing: a large, furnished conference room complex that Aalto designed with his wife, Elissa, in 1964, for the Institute of International Education at 809 United Nations Plaza, near 45th Street.

title: In Stratford, the Return of Shakespeare
description: The shuttered American Festival Theater in Stratford, Conn., which introduced tens of thousands of schoolchildren in the Northeast to Shakespeare, is being resurrected after years of dormancy and decline.

title: EXPERTS SAY SUIT AGAINST PRESIDENT FACES BIG HURDLES
description: In her 700-page court filing, Paula Corbin Jones may have presented enough evidence to have her sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton heard by a judge and jury in Little Rock, Ark., in May. But many lawyers and law professors say her case still has significant flaws and weaknesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCKMAN, ISAAC
description: GLUCKMAN-Isaac. Age 93, of Boca Raton, FL, March 9, 1998. Survived by wife, Annette and daughter, Linda Berman.

title: The Grande Dame Of Jazz, but Don't Tell Her That
description: EVEN if the only noteworthy thing Marian McPartland had done in her long life was play jazz piano outstandingly well, she would still be deserving of the all-star concert being given in honor of her birthday on Saturday at Town Hall. But Ms. McPartland, who was born in Windsor, England, 80 years ago Friday, is far more than just a pianist. She is also a strikingly individual composer, an excellent writer, the host of one of the longest-running jazz programs in the history of network radio and, as if all that weren't enough for one lifetime, the widow of Jimmy McPartland, the tough-talking cornet player from Chicago who replaced Bix Beiderbecke in the Wolverines when his wife-to-be was only 6 years old.

title: Is a Death Benefit Worth the Price?
description: SunAmerica, the variable annuity giant, has added a twist to its family of 19 mutual funds: a death benefit. Not for the fund managers, mind you, but for the investors. And like a lot of insurance products, this one is not for everybody.

title: March 8-14; $30 Billion Later, Cancer Begins a Decline
description: The United States has spent more than $30 billion on cancer research since 1971, when President Richard M. Nixon declared war on cancer.

title: A Spontaneous Kind of Guy
description: During a late comeback to help his team upset Clemson on Friday afternoon, Rashod Johnson, the Western Michigan guard, hit a 3-point basket. He ran to the sideline and took two deep bows as applause rained down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILHAUPT, CHARLES
description: MILHAUPT-Charles. March 13, 1998. Son of Mary Thomas and the late Arthur Milhaupt, Jr. Brother of Gretchen Milhaupt, Merimee Moffitt, Tony Milhaupt and Ann Bottinelli. Memorial service Saturday, March 21, 1998, 2 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street). Reception immediately following at Gansevoort Gallery, 72 Gansevoort St. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, N.Y.C. 10013.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILLS, POLLY STRONG
description: SILLS-Polly Strong. At seventy-nine, on March 2, 1998. Beloved wife of Morton, mother of Rockwell and Charles Tenney. Daughter of the Society of Mayflower Descendants, Patron of the Brecht Forum, she will be in our hearts forever. Memorial service in Cold Spring Harbor, 72 Shore Road, on April 19 at noon. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Alzheimer's Association, 420 Lexington Avenue.

title: 'Wenceslas Square' At the Schoolhouse
description: IT is easy to understand why the director Cara Caldwell Watson was drawn to the content of ''Wenceslas Square'' by Larry Shue. But where is style? Where is the essence of the play? Where's the play?

title: Return to Basics
description: EVERYBODY can relax. Most of the marathon summer art shows (Documenta, the Venice Biennale) that periodically send crowds scurrying across Europe like mice in a maze came and went last year. This season, quieter fare prevails: stately museum surveys and the small-scale delicacies that make travel abroad both a rest and a surprise.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is Mom. I don't have but one. She brought me up and looked after me; I feel I should do the same.''

title: Soaps on the Ropes
description: THE writers of ''One Life to Live'' were cooking up something big. Laptops were open around a conference table in the ABC building on West 66th Street. Fingers clicked keyboards. It was Tuesday afternoon and a shocking plot was being written that spelled doom for a certain character.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: TO DANCE WITH THE DEVIL: The New War on Breast Cancer

title: To a Boss, Disability Is No Barrier
description: Ask Priscilla Daniels, head of volunteer services at Bellevue Hospital Center, why she hired Sharada Veerubhotla, and she answers without hesitation.

title: Farmers Hear From Young Members of Their Fan Club
description: This is National Agriculture Week, an annual celebration of the farmers who provided food and fiber to consumers worldwide. This year the New Jersey Agriculture Society sponsored an essay contest, asking students from the 6th grade to the 11th grade to write on this theme: ''New Jersey Agriculture -- How It Makes My Life Better.'' Here are the first-place winners, who will be honored this week at a ceremony in Trenton.

title: Young, Yet Composed, Rutgers Hangs On
description: The emotion-wrenching nature of this National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament victory had Rutgers Coach C. Vivian Stringer thinking of the proper superlatives. In some ways, she said, it may have even eclipsed the school's wildly celebrated late-season victory over UConn.

title: Fear, Apathy, Regret: A Happy Combination
description: DOUBTLESS you have heard of Juliette Binoche. After all, the French actress won an Academy Award for the sensitivity she brought to the task of nursing a charbroiled Ralph Fiennes in ''The English Patient.''

title: Great White Way
description: TERRA INCOGNITA

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Women Devoted to the Chant, Serving as Stewards of the Land
description: EIGHT times a day, every day, bells chime to summon the nuns of the Abbey of Regina Laudis to prayer. The cloistered Benedictine nuns have lived in Bethlehem, among the wooded hills and pastures of Litchfield County, in tranquillity and relative obscurity for most of the past half century.

title: Pop and Jazz Briefs
description: STEVE COLEMAN: 'GENESIS AND THE OPENING OF THE WAY'

title: SOAPBOX; Just Give 'Em the Money
description: SINCE my daughter entered elementary school six years ago, I have lived through countless fund-raising activities. Several times a semester, I am called upon for combinations of donating, selling and buying. Bake sales, for instance, require that I do all three. Bake sales are one of my favorite fund-raisers, since they also involve eating, but I must report that they have declined appallingly. Not only do parents no longer bake the goods they send in, they no longer even send in baked goods. At one ''bake'' sale last year canned soda was offered. ''Did you bake that?'' I asked the fifth grader standing behind the table. ''No,'' he said blankly, ''I think my friend's mother did.'' But even canned soda sales have a kind of homemade charm when compared with the (much more profitable) fund-raisers run by professional companies hired by the Parent Teacher Organization. About twice each year, Lindsay brings home a shiny catalogue full of pictures of the wrapping paper or chocolate or plants or magazines that she is selling, and sometimes another shiny catalogue picturing the incredibly cheap prizes that will be bestowed on the juvenile salespeople. I am not against P.T.O. fund-raising per se. I realize that public school budgets in even the richest districts do not extend as far as one might hope. I want my daughter to have the benefit of the field trips and assemblies and playground equipment that these funds provide. The problem is in the sales process. The instructions sent home by the school sensibly discourage the children from selling door to door. My daughter does have nine households of grandparents, aunts and uncles, so for the first year or two she fared pretty well on telephone sales to them. Over time, though, the appeal of a 6- or 7- or 8-year-old niece peddling $10 cans of peanut brittle began to wear off, not to mention the fact that her (mostly younger) cousins are fast maturing and entering the fund-raising market themselves. If my sisters buy Lindsay's pear-shaped, vanilla-scented candles, then sooner or later I will have to buy their children's kosher-for-Passover coconut patties. The combination of guilt and self-interest produced by this situation leaves me a less than eager salesperson; I have been known to stand behind my daughter when she is giving a sales pitch and shout, ''Don't feel you have to buy any!'' into the phone. Not all of the products my daughter is instructed to peddle are hopelessly overpriced; one fund-raiser of which I was rather fond was a magazine subscription sale run by her school. Magazines strike me as more genuinely desirable than, say, a tiny ceramic coin bank shaped like a baseball mitt, and the magazines are reasonably priced. The problem is that the deadline for the magazine sales forces me to write a check to the school to cover the sales my daughter makes by telephone, and then wait for the purchasers to reimburse me. Mom has always paid promptly, but we've had trouble with some of the other customers. Last year my sister's husband ordered a subscription to Consumer Reports from Lindsay in October, but then, despite a touching dunning letter written in my daughter's childish hand, failed to follow up with a check. I had to recoup the $22 by giving the subscription to him as a Christmas present. Lindsay made a telephone sale to my ex in Philadelphia, who gave his new girlfriend's address and then never sent me the $14.95. So when the envelope came home last semester, I put an end to the sales. Over my daughter's protests, I sent $2O to the organizers, which I suspect is more than they would have netted from $50 worth of sales. And I still had enough money left to buy my daughter the 75-cent flashlight she would have won as a sales incentive.

title: Thurmans All Come Out to Play
description: THINK of them as the Trapp family of Buddhism, although they don't sing. The Trapp family had its annual Christmas sing-along, and the Thurman family (Robert, Uma, et al.) is known in a certain circle for its involvement with Tibet House, which held its annual Tibetan New Year's concert at Carnegie Hall on Monday night. There was more than the sound of one hand clapping by the end of the concert, which began with chanting monks and ended with Patti Smith.

title: Yale Held To a Tie
description: With 52 seconds remaining in regulation time Yale's Jay Quenville scored the tying goal in the Bulldogs' 3-3 tie with St. Lawrence last night at New Haven, Conn. It was the second consecutive 3-3 tie between the two teams in a contest matching the top-seeded club in the ECAC tournament, the Bulldogs, and the 10th or last one, the Saints.

title: Adrian Marks, 81, War Pilot Who Led Rescue of 56, Is Dead
description: Adrian Marks, a Navy pilot who rescued 56 sailors struggling in the shark-filled Philippine Sea after the cruiser Indianapolis was sunk by Japanese torpedoes in July 1945, died on March 7 at Clinton County Hospital in his hometown of Frankfort, Ind. He was 81.

title: Correction
description: Because of a computer programming error, the Largest Stock Funds table that has appeared monthly in this section since 1995 has consistently misstated percentage returns of the average stock mutual fund -- for the most recent four weeks, for the year to date, and for one year, three years and five years. The Vanguard Group detected the error and alerted the table's compiler, Morningstar Inc., last month; Morningstar confirmed the error on March 3. The computers had been basing their calculation on figures for the average mutual fund of all asset types -- not just stock funds. Correct figures are shown in today's table, on page 8.

title: And, in Conclusion ...
description: Presentations: They're showtime for some people, the bane of many others. How have they gone for you? And what moments next to the overhead projector would you most like to forget? Or remember? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Good Vibes in Gotham
description: New Yorkers have historically taken a perverse pride from living in a city that scared the rest of the country to death. It let them mythologize their own lives and feel superior to folks from the soft and uneventful provinces. But now waves of tourists are crowding the streets, and a New York Times poll released last week showed that Americans from the heartland who once feared the city claim to love it and want to visit.

title: Drug Suspensions Decrease in N.F.L.
description: Within the next several months, a small group of about three or four National Football League players will receive notices from the league that they have failed drug tests. One of those players, since he has failed at least one drug test before, will be suspended by the league without pay for at least four weeks. He is a player whose name fans will know.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; Reaching 60, I Can't Take It Easy
description: NOW that I'm 60, I understand why people retire. It's not so much that they don't want to work. They just don't have time for it. For many of us, basic maintenance chews up a good part of each day. Trust me, I know.

title: Kristine Mellina, Marc Weinstein
description: Kristine Michelle Mellina and Dr. Marc Andrew Weinstein were married last evening at the Pleasantdale Chateau in West Orange, N.J. Msgr. Thomas Byrnes officiated with Rabbi Dennis Tobin.

title: Island Mainstays With Manhattan Outposts
description: PAGGIO, Pacific East, Mare Mare, Nick and Toni's, Ben's Kosher Deli, Pomodoro and Bobby Van's have two things in common. They are restaurants in Manhattan and are owned by Long Island restaurateurs. The flow of restaurants from Manhattan to the Island has been reversed in recent years. Most of the momentum is now in a westerly direction as more and more successful entrepreneurs establish Big Apple beachheads.

title: Soul Mates
description: CAUCASIA By Danzy Senna. 353 pp. New York: Riverhead Books. $24.95.

title: Butterfly Flutter
description: After butterfly designs popped up on Dolce & Gabbana dresses, bags and shoes for spring, butterflies are suddenly everywhere, even in hair. ''Butterflies are becoming huge,'' said John Barrett, whose salon at Bergdorf Goodman weaves fake ones into tresses. ''We work them into the hair in a looser way, so they are almost lost,'' he said. Popular with long, loosely curled pre-Raphaelite-style hair (witness Madonna on her ''Ray of Light'' album), they cost $25 each. Choices for do-it-yourselfers: ponytail ties and clips with enamel butterflies (above, $40), at Barneys New York from Frou by Paige Novick; Colette Malouf's Austrian crystal butterflies on combs and sticks ($68) at Henri Bendel and Saks Fifth Avenue, and brown leather sweeps ($10) at Urban Outfitters, 127 East 59th Street. Butterflies are almost free at Reminiscence, 74 Fifth Avenue (13th Street), where clips with enamel butterflies sell for $1.

title: The World: When Bad Things Happen to German People; Where a Lawsuit Can't Get Any Respect
description: FOR those who wonder what life might be like if American lawyers had their wings clipped, a visit to almost any German playground or swimming pool is instructive.

title: Washing Our Dishes
description: I was surprised that William Safire missed the ''dish the dirt'' reference that comes immediately to my mind (''Washing Our Dishes,'' Feb. 22). The lyrics to ''The Lady Is a Tramp,'' by Lorenz Hart (copyright 1937), from the musical ''Babes in Arms,'' include the following:

title: Darjeeling
description: To the Editor: There's another marvelous scene at Darjeeling.

title: The World; It's Chevalier Lewis, If You Don't Mind
description: SURELY it is satisfying enough just to be rich, famous, photographed and admired, to possess the mysterious status of celebrity that turns heads at restaurants and gives weight to even the lightest of opinions. But, no, there can be more. Thanks to Europe's bountiful honors systems, celebrities can also aspire to ancient titles, medals and ribbons as more solemn recognition of their talent than, say, harassment by paparazzi.

title: Already Accountable
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Giuliani, The Candidate, Play in Peoria?; G.O.P. Leaders Doubt His Chances in 2000
description: The chairman of the California Republican Party, Michael J. Schroeder, was talking about Presidential politics the other day when the name of the Mayor of New York City came up. How, Mr. Schroeder was asked, would he assess the national prospects of Rudolph W. Giuliani in the year 2000?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPARD, RICHARD
description: SHEPARD-Richard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Richard Shepard, associated with The Times from 1946, until retiring in 1991.

title: Ever So Lively, Even if Gone
description: JUDY GARLAND is alive and well and performing in Greenwich Village. Freddie Mercury was last seen rhapsodizing Bohemian-style in Chelsea, not far from Dinah Washington's new gig on 23d Street. Tallulah Bankhead is giving a party on West 54th almost nightly. And now that her ''Master Class'' is no longer in session, Maria Callas is selling computers in Times Square.
