description: To the Editor:

title: Cobble Hill as Baden-Baden
description: For the stressed, the achy and the gnarled, Cobble Hill is turning into a place to go to be rubbed, scrubbed, masked, steamed and aromatherapized without leaving the comfort of the neighborhood.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the former Cities Service Building, referred incorrectly to the home of its developer, Henry Doherty. The building where he lived and worked, at 24 State Street, was at the corner of Bridge Street, not Liberty Street.

title: China Keeps Murdoch And His TV On Hiatus
description: One of the paradoxes of Rupert Murdoch's bend-over-backward efforts to keep good relations with China is that he has been so badly frustrated here.

title: ABC's of Choreography: Teaching the Unteachable?
description: A CHOREOGRAPHER told about a dozen people gathered in a studio that he was about to show an excerpt from a work in progress. Then two women standing side by side made agitated gestures while bending and turning in unison. Comments were invited from others present, all of them members of a choreographic workshop.

title: For Caribbean Chicken Cooks, Steel Drum Disharmony
description: Lulu (Mama) Pitterson was apoplectic. ''They're going to have to lock me up every week,'' she shouted, her voice ricocheting off the walls of her tiny restaurant, Badoo's International, on Church Avenue. ''I'll still do my chicken.''

title: A Delicate Touch
description: This spring there exist a category of dress so soft and fragile that it blurs the line between day and evening.

title: Michigan State Brings Princeton's Magical Ride to a Jarring Halt
description: There were some moist eyes, some flushed cheeks and some bitter memories scattered throughout a quiet Princeton locker room. The tears will eventually subside, but the memories of this 63-56 defeat to Michigan State will not fade too soon for the Tigers because of the aching way in which it unraveled. Those memories will linger. Things that people could have easily changed tend to stick.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Great Big River
description: You're on the Amazon. Suddenly you come upon five blindfolded, pot-bellied American businessmen, dressed in war paint and loincloths, their wrists loosely tied to trees, the river's muddy water lapping at their knees. You turn to your tour guide for some insight into this bizarre ritual. All he says is, ''North American salesmen celebrating the year's successes.'' Such are the frustrations of AMAZON: From the Floodplains to the Clouds (Monacelli, $60), a book of photographs of the world's most mysterious river. Alex Webb presents readers with a jumbled variety of images from the entire 4,000-mile length of the Amazon -- from its mouth on the Brazilian coast to its source in the mountains of Peru -- but his captions fail to provide any context for them. Though many of the photographs are arresting, too many others are incapable of communicating their message without adequate text. Worse, the layout is a disservice to Webb's work: each photograph has an overwhelming white border, diminishing the verisimilitude of the entire you-are-there experience. That said, there is much work of merit here, from the photograph of an overheated gentleman who escapes the sun in the shadows of a satellite dish in backwater Tapia, Brazil, to a shot of a Peruvian militia whose uniforms seem to consist of white headbands, hand-me-down soccer shirts, bare feet and primitive firearms. Webb's best images capture the fluidity not only of the river but of the life along its banks. Lance Gould

title: March 8-14; Revenge of Forgotten Bugs
description: Remember herpes, syphilis and gonorrhea? Since the arrival of AIDS, most people have forgotten.

title: On the Auction Block, the Yacht of Camelot
description: As the Federal Government and an auction house continue to haggle over who owns some of the John F. Kennedy memorabilia to be sold this week, more items have been added to the for-sale list.

title: Calling a Cab, Out of Thin Air
description: DON'T ask a magician how he makes magic. He just might try to tell you. But if you understand or explain the technicalities, where's the magic?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, A
description: MYERS-A. Howard. On March 6, 1998, after a long illness in Boca Raton, FL., at age 93. Formerly of Boston, and worked for the Department of Labor during the Roosevelt years, was Professor Emeritus of Industrial Relations at Northeastern University (1948-1978). Held faculty posts at Boston College, Harvard University, the University of Michigan, and Florida Atlantic University. Married Ethel Myers who predeceased him in 1977. Devoted husband of Elisa M. Myers. Father of Natalie B. Kalette of Syracuse, NY; Joy M. Silverman of Tenafly, NJ; and Howard N. Myers of Milwaukee, WI. Grandfather of nine and great-grandfather of ten.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Local Protests Changing the Course of Development
description: TO a casual passer-by, the patch of woods hidden behind a King Kullen supermarket and the Wantagh Lanes bowling alley on Wantagh Avenue might look like a neglected vacant lot. Litter is everywhere; bordering it to the rear is a public school complex and some housing.

title: Darjeeling
description: To the Editor: Because my own experience in Darjeeling almost paralleled David Pinault's, I particularly enjoyed ''Where Faiths Meet at a Peaceful Summit'' (Feb. 1). My wife, son and I were there in 1990. Two footnotes to his account:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, DONALD
description: JOYCE-Donald. On Tuesday, March 10, 1998, at age 45, of cancer. Extraordinary musician, brilliant organist, imaginative and curious intellect, international organ ambassador of old and new music, beloved son and brother, loving and loyal friend to many. In addition to his Juilliard degrees, he held the Premier Prix de Virtuosite (with Distinction) from the Geneva Conservatory where he worked with Lionel Rogg, as well as other international competition prizes. During the Bach tercentenary year 1985 he performed all the organ works of Bach to great acclaim in thirteen recitals in New York, and was scheduled to repeat this series at the Lincoln Center Festival '98. Many performances and two CD's grew out of another great interest, in Iberian and Mexican organ music; at his death he was writing a monograph on Mexican historic organs. All his life he was a strong advocate for contemporary organ music, performing and recording many new works. He was Music Director and Organist at the Church of the Holy Apostles in Chelsea; Organist at the Central Synagogue and taught organ at Queens College. As winner of a Fulbright-Garcia Robles grant from the U.S. and Mexican governments, he established a class in organ studies at the University of Guanajuato, Mexico last summer. Survivors include his mother, Anne Rose; his father, Walter Joyce; brother Kenneth Joyce; and sisters Carol Bochner and Virginia Keil. A service will be held Saturday, March 28 at 1 P.M. at the Church of the Holy Apostles, 9th Avenue, at 28th., NYC 10001. In lieu of flowers donations may be made either to the Organ Fund at the above church or to the Donald Joyce Scholarship Fund at the Copland School of Music, Queens College, Flushing, N.Y. 11367.

title: The Big Chill
description: I May Be Some Time

title: Fiorucci Encore
description: In the 1970's and early 80's, if you wore clothes by Fiorucci, you were cool. The jeans, signature T-shirts and wacky accessories were must-haves for whiling away boogie nights. But in 1988, the stores disappeared nationwide, as Fiorucci, based in Milan, pulled out of the American market. But now that all things 70's are back, so is Fiorucci. Stephen Budd, whose company, Bennini Fashions in Manhattan, is the new American licensee for Fiorucci, is manufacturing and distributing the clothes across the country. ''I grew up in New York City and spent my childhood Saturdays hanging out in the Fiorucci store on 59th Street, so I grew up attached to this brand,'' Mr. Budd said. The clothes, including logo T-shirts still bearing the same two cherubs (above, $28), will be in Macy's and Bloomingdales in April.

title: The High-Return Evangelist of Valueland
description: ROBERT A. OLSTEIN has an opinion about the market. And are you going to hear about it.

title: Corn Emerges as a 'Weed and Feed' Product
description: IT may sound a bit odd, but now is the time to apply corn gluten meal as a pre-emergent treatment for the control of weeds and a nitrogen boosting substance to spur initial spring green up in the lawn or garden.

title: Crossing the Line, and Living With It
description: It took a slim 10-second slip-up for the 64-foot sailboat, Toshiba, to break a basic rule of the Whitbread Round the World Race. By running the boat's engine to clear seaweed, the yacht was disqualified recently from an otherwise stellar third-place finish in Leg 5 from Auckland, New Zealand to Sao Sebastiao, Brazil.

title: Young Chess Nuts Learn the Right Moves
description: ADAM WESER is contemplating his next chess move with all the concentration of Garry Kasparov facing the I.B.M. Deep Blue supercomputer. But his opponent is not a computer, and Adam is many years younger than the champion. Adam, 6, of Jericho, is practicing tactical moves with Chris Petrullo, 7, at the Chess Nuts, the largest organization on Long Island where children can advance chess skills.

title: 'Always in Pursuit'
description: To the Editor:

title: Hingis Gets Revenge Against Davenport
description: Martina Hingis, making herself right at home in this desert oasis on her first visit to the State Farm Evert Cup, had given fair warning that she intended to mop up the court with the event's defending champion, Lindsay Davenport.

title: The Expectations Are Rising After UConn Downs Indiana
description: ''That's us!'' yelled Khalid El-Amin. ''That's got to be us!''

title: Knicks Come Unraveled and Lose in Overtime
description: When you are Allan Houston, and you are all the Knicks have on some nights, you have a weighty burden to haul around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERTER, MURIEL
description: WERTER-Muriel. Devoted wife of Nathan M.D. Dear mother of Ronni, Allen, and James; grandmother; dear friend to all who knew her. Passed away on March 11th. in St. Joseph's Hospital. She will always be a bearer of love and kindness.

title: Q and A
description: Venetian Vows

title: Red Sunset
description: FROM WEST TO EAST California and the Making of the American Mind. By Stephen Schwartz. 566 pp. New York: The Free Press. $30.

title: Made to Explain a Career Move
description: IN accepting the title of music director of the Munich Philharmonic as of autumn 1999, James Levine has taken a professional turn that may well alter his future at the Metropolitan Opera. But none of this should come as a surprise.

title: Bringing the Battery Before the Orchestra
description: THE orchestral percussionist tends to be a gentle, laid-back type, usually male. Dressed formally for his pummeling duties in performance, he is more often in shirt sleeves and chinos for appearances with small ensembles. If he were not wearing shoes, it would probably be because he forgot them.

title: Midsized. Outperforming. Underappreciated?
description: LIKE pointer dogs fixed on their targets, investors just can't seem to let go of the stocks of large, brand-name companies.

title: Maier Clinches No. 3
description: In his first full season on the World Cup circuit, Hermann Maier left yesterday's final giant slalom race at Crans Montana, Switzerland, with a third crystal globe in his collection, assuring Austria's claim to all five men's Alpine titles.

title: Moynihan Offers Proposal To Preserve Social Security
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan moved today to reshape the national debate on Social Security by offering a comprehensive proposal to cut payroll taxes, reduce the annual cost-of-living adjustment and encourage workers to establish personal savings accounts for retirement.

title: In the Afterlight of Bloodshed, Smoldering Images
description: SINCE the late 1980's, after studying sculpture at New York University, Doris Salcedo has become one of the most-watched emerging talents on the international survey-exhibition circuit. Her rise and her provocative art have been compared to the memory- and history-tinged work of Christian Boltanski and the Beirut-born artist Mona Hatoum.

title: Tentative Deal for Musicians Averts Broadway Strike Vote
description: The union representing Broadway's musicians canceled a planned strike vote yesterday after negotiations with producers and theater owners produced a tentative agreement to replace the union contract that expired a week ago.

title: Perspective; Sit Back, Fans, It's Rupertball
description: Under cover of March Madness, the Fox is expected to move into the chicken coop this week. Rupert Murdoch will buy the Los Angeles Dodgers, assuring his takeover of the national pastime, which will accelerate his domination of international sports and, if he is not stopped by Disney or Time-Warner, his eventual domination of the world.

title: Painting Shadows
description: AMAZING GRACE

title: Lincoln's Youth
description: To the Editor: In ''Lincoln's Early Years'' (Feb. 8) Harold Holzer paints a grim picture of Abraham Lincoln's boyhood in Kentucky and Indiana, emphasizing how harsh and poverty-stricken that boyhood was and how crude were the living conditions. In particular, he uses the cabins in which the Lincolns lived as evidence of their way of life.

title: Stockholm
description: ''What is culture?'' the organizers of Stockholm 98, the celebration that marks the city's choice as the 1998 European Capital of Culture, asked themselves. And they proceeded to arrange 1,020 events that might answer that question.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOEL, ARIEL
description: NOEL-Ariel. Born January 1, 1945 died with the sinking of the ship Clecia Cruise Line in the seawaters of Haiti on the 27th of February 1998, and was buried in CAP Haitien, Haiti.

title: Habitats/154 Clinton Street; A Brooklyn Native Finds You Can Go Home Again
description: MICHAEL LONDON returned to Brooklyn last year after an absence of 31 years, he said, ''to find the place I always wanted to live in New York more beautiful than I remembered it.'' For Mr. London, a native of Crown Heights who had spent his recent years in Lexington, Mass., that place was Brooklyn Heights.

title: High-Tech Firefighting Gear Reaches Some Small Towns
description: Firefighters in Plainsboro and Elmwood Park now have a little help when a person is trapped in a burning building.

title: New Times Square Needs Pedestrian-Friendly Spots
description: To the Editor:

title: When Seating Can Make a Difference
description: QUATTRO'S, an Italian restaurant in Guilford, is an example of why it is important, in evaluating a restaurant, to visit at least twice, preferably at both lunch and dinner.

title: At Shanghai Tang, a Three-Dog Night on Madison Avenue
description: THE SETTING -- A private party Thursday night at Shanghai Tang, the Madison Avenue emporium that opened across the street from Barneys four months ago. William Wegman, the photographer known for his portraits of his silvery-gray Weimaraners, was signing copies of his new book ''Puppies'' (Hyperion).

title: In the Region/Westchester; A Makeover for a Vast Onetime I.B.M. Building
description: A SPRAWLING three-story office building with a total of 320,000 square feet, once occupied exclusively by I.B.M., is undergoing a total makeover to transform a single-tenant building into a contemporary corporate campus that can attract a variety of businesses under one immense roof.

title: Text of Monica Lewinsky's Affidavit in Paula Jones's Suit Against the President
description: Following is the affidavit by Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern at the center of accusations of sexual misconduct by President Clinton, which was filed in connection with Paula Corbin Jones's lawsuit against the President. The affidavit was included by Ms. Jones's lawyers in their filing on Friday in response to a motion by Mr. Clinton's lawyers to have the suit dismissed. Although it is standard procedure to describe it as an ''affidavit of Jane Doe,'' it is signed by Ms. Lewinsky.

title: Karen Murphy and Marvin Weitz
description: BEFORE their wedding, Marvin B. Weitz and Karen Murphy described themselves as the perfect mismatch -- the quintessential odd couple who are nothing alike.

title: Ilse Bing, 98, 1930's Pioneer Of Avant-Garde Photography
description: Ilse Bing, one of the few surviving members of the fabled group of avant-garde artists who gathered in Paris in the early 1930's and produced brilliantly unorthodox and inventive photography, died Tuesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. She was 98 and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 15, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Equality of the Sexes
description: Have women reached full equality with men?

title: Softer Side of Lincoln Comes To Light in a Trove of Papers
description: In the last hours of his life, just before going to Ford's Theater on April 14, 1865, President Abraham Lincoln reviewed the court-martial of Pvt. Patrick Murphy, who had been characterized as ''idiotic and insane.'' Lincoln decided that the soldier should be pardoned and released from the military.

title: Children's Books
description: MOMMY GO AWAY! By Lynne Jonell. Illustrated by Petra Mathers. Unpaged. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $12.95. (Ages 2 to 7)

title: Friends of Clocks Are Pleased by Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: IRISH REBEL

title: French Pop Discovers Its Hip to Be Cheesy
description: FRANCE has spent decades on the sidelines of popular music. French rock is a long-running joke. French pop singing hasn't counted for much since the heydays of chanteuses and chanteurs like Edith Piaf, Jacques Brel and Serge Gainsbourg. French jazz has produced a scattered handful of luminaries, not all of them born in France. For world music, France has been where performers from Africa and the Caribbean go to get their music tricked up and sweetened in Paris studios. And France has come up with exactly one internationally known rapper, M. C. Solaar.

title: Teachers Reject Bilingual Education; Each Student's Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: The Serious Side of Japan's Favorite Nuisance
description: SOMEDAY Takeshi Kitano may win an award for being the world's most productive split personality. In Japan, he's best known as Beat Takeshi, a scabrous, wisecracking television comedian; in the West, his reputation as the director and star of iconoclastic films that probe the tender spots of Japanese society is growing. He's a ruthless critic of his culture, but is also its most admired media celebrity. He appears in seven television shows and writes six weekly newspaper columns, and he's the author of 55 books of poetry, essays and fiction. (His book ''Why They All Hate Me,'' an invective against contemporary Japan, sold more than a million copies.)

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: State of Mind

title: On Language; Paddling Your Own Canoodle
description: Senate judiciary chairman orrin Hatch told The New York Times that if allegations concerning the President and the former White House intern Monica Lewinsky prove to be true, ''we have perhaps the first Presidential canoodler in history.''

title: In Paraguay Border Town, Almost Anything Goes
description: Although brand names and slogans scream out from every avenue in this gritty bazaar where three countries meet, Nike's stands out as supremely appropriate: ''Just Do It.''

title: Sports of The Times; Always Mr. Green Bay Packer
description: NO matter what the sport, when the best players finally take their uniform off for the last time, most desert the area where they played and get a job in another business. Maybe a few try to coach or manage, usually somewhere else. But with Ray Nitschke, whose funeral was in Green Bay yesterday, it was as if he never stopped wearing his green-and-gold Packers No. 66 jersey.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Pitfalls Of Effortless Virtuosity
description: FLUENCY, facility, ease of technique or whatever you want to call it is sorely envied by strugglers in the arts. If only I had that gift of naturalness, if only I could make the struggles go away, they say, how successful I would be. Such people should be careful of their wishes. In music and, I suppose, elsewhere, the old saw holds true: getting what we want most can be the worst thing to befall us.

title: Puccini's Stage: All of Lucca
description: ON a halcyon evening last July, I found myself sitting at an outdoor cafe across from Lucca's icing-white church of San Michele, listening to ''Che Gelida Manina'' from ''La Boheme'' by Puccini.

title: March 8-14; Earth Gets a Bit of Future Shock
description: From the time of its birth four billion years ago, Earth has been hammered by solar system flotsam, mostly in the form of dust or small chunks, but sometimes by projectiles the size of cities. On Wednesday, the respected Central Bureau for Astronomical Telegrams in Cambridge, Mass. made the chilling announcement that 30 years from now, a mile-wide asteroid called 1997 XF11 might hit Earth.

title: The South in Bloom: Tours and Oysters
description: It must be spring: Virginia's 65th annual Historic Garden Week will be held April 18 to 25. The statewide house and garden tour, sponsored by the Garden Club of Virginia, includes more than 250 properties and features seasonal flowers and plants native to Virginia. Participants can visit houses ranging from 17th-century Colonial manors to present-day houses, in settings from urban to rural. A guidebook is available for $4 from Historic Garden Week, 12 East Franklin Street, Richmond, Va. 23219. Admission to individual houses or gardens costs $3 to $5. Tours with five or six properties cost $10 to $20. Information: (804) 644-7776.

title: Playwright Sees Work Produced
description: FOR Norman Chaitin, it is a miracle more than 40 years in the making.

title: Handling With Care
description: To the Editor:

title: A Smorgasbord of Nonstop Dance
description: AMERICAN dance and performance art will be popping up in new settings throughout Europe this spring, summer and fall. The New York City Ballet dances at the Harrogate International Festival in England, the Pacific Northwest Ballet at the Edinburgh Festival and Lou Conte's Hubbard Street Dance Chicago at the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy. The Merce Cunningham Dance Company will perform in Lyons and at London's Dance Umbrella festival. And Savion Glover will singlefootedly hold the fort for dance at the Holland Festival in Amsterdam.

title: Mt. Vernon Enclave Attracts Upwardly Mobile
description: IN Westchester, where the name of one's town may elicit an approving smile or merely cool acknowledgment, Mount Vernon has not always been the most sought-after address. Noted more often for bitter racial politics than its quiet tree-lined streets, this small city has long labored under a stigma that kept many from taking a closer look.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE PETTICOAT AFFAIR

title: UConn's Potent Offense To Face Added Pressure
description: Forgive an oversimplification, but it will be Connecticut's offense against George Washington's defense here Sunday night in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNSEND, ROBERT CHASE
description: TOWNSEND-Robert Chase. A memorial service will be held for Robert C. Townsend on Tuesday March 17 at 11 AM at All Saints Church, 855 Middle Neck Rd., Great Neck, Long Island, N.Y. Mr. Townsend, who died on the island of Anguilla on January 12, 1998 had been a Senior Vice President of American Express for many years and Chairman and CEO of Avis Rent a Car. His books on management and leadership were international best sellers. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the Midnight Mission, 396 S. Los Angeles St., Los Angeles, CA 90013, attn: Clancy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, SAMUEL
description: GOLDMAN-Samuel. Beloved husband of Bea. Devoted father of Eileen and Robert Roman, Elizabeth and Lawrence Goldman. Loving grandfather of Lisa and Paul, Mindy and Jonathan, Abra and Todd, and Meredith. Adored great grandfather of Max, Jake, Amanda, Alec and Carly. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Sunday 11:30A.M.

title: Some Opportunities For Bird-Watching
description: Your excellent article on Long Island bird-watching opportunities [''L.I. Rates High for Fast-Growing Bird-Watching,'' Feb. 15] was long overdue. In the 20 years of our experience, we have seen this hobby grow to amazing proportions. Although the article listed several excellent sites and activities, here are a few more:

title: Absecon to Zarephath: An Encyclopedia for New Jersey
description: No, Marc Mappen, a Rutgers University associate dean, didn't get the idea for a New Jersey encyclopedia when a tomato fell on his head.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: New Kid on the Block

title: Rios Ends Gambill's Champions Cup Ride
description: Jan-Michael Gambill, the boy wonder who shocked the bald wonder, Andre Agassi, on Friday, received a large dose of comeuppance tonight from the brazen wonder, Marcelo Rios.

title: Marketing Video Like Dumplings
description: They named it for their favorite character on ''Seinfeld'' and for a kind of drink (the cosmopolitan) favored by the company's president, Joseph Park. And the six young founding partners of the Internet video rental service kozmo.com are convinced they have discovered a special niche in the business of serving time-deprived and convenience-obsessed New Yorkers.

title: Tenets Are Binding
description: To the Editor:

title: Backlash on Insurance
description: WHEN he heard that insurers planned to raise liability rates for sport utility vehicles, David Gregorino was incensed.

title: First Date Was Great, but This One Counts
description: ONE effect of the New York Philharmonic's recent announcement that Kurt Masur's tenure as music director may end in 2002 is that every talented maestro who appears with the orchestra will be subjected to a new kind of scrutiny and speculation: is this a desirable or likely candidate to succeed Mr. Masur?

title: More on Environment
description: Governo Pataki, State Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver have announced an agreement to finance more than 100 environmental projects across the state with $50 million from the Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act. The projects will preserve open space, improve and expand state and municipal parks, close polluted landfills, bolster recycling and upgrade the environmental performance of state properties.

title: Millennium Means County Must Correct Computers
description: SOMETIME last year computers at the State Liquor Authority had their first encounter with the new millennium, and they came through without a blip. Government officials throughout Westchester are hoping their computers can do as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONOM, CLARICE J.
description: BONOM-Clarice J. On March 10, 1998, in Lauderhill, FL. Wife of Samuel (deceased); beloved mother of Neil and Miles, loved by her daughters-in-law Maryanne and Sandy and granddaughters Samantha and Sydney. Services at Riverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, March 16 2 PM. Donations to UOTS, Inc. Loyalty 31, C/O M. Meskin, 1900 Quentin Rd, Apt D6, Brooklyn, NY 11235.

title: Creative Analysis
description: To the Editor:

title: From Mystic Novel to Manifest Spectacle
description: THAR she blows. Again. The terrifying Great White is back on the screen, thrashing, splashing and causing all manner of high-seas mayhem. Ships are upended and torn to shreds. Experienced sailors are throttled and dispatched to watery graves.

description: To the Editor:

title: In Wilton, on the Trail of American Antiques
description: WHEN the Wilton Historical Society held its first antiques show, in the spring of 1967, the event consisted of a few local dealers selling out of their station wagons in the parking lot behind Town Hall. Over the past 31 years the show has grown consistently, and when it opens next weekend 104 exhibitors will be displaying antiques ranging in price from less than $100 to ones for five- and six-digit figures.

title: How to contact the museums and concert halls
description: Where to write or call for more information about the festivals mentioned by the critics. A listing of jazz festivals appears on page 29.

title: Litter Fluctuates With Workfare
description: Twice a month, city inspectors do a litter count, compiling scorecards that evaluate the cleanliness of streets in the 59 community board districts. When Willie Scott, the district manager for Community Board 17 in East Flatbush, saw his score fall to 71 percent in February from 78 percent in January, he wanted to know why.

title: The Global Ambitions That Drive A Merger
description: The urge to merge that has suddenly swept two of the nation's largest stock markets is fueled, in large part, by a lust for listings, as Wall Street calls the stocks that trade on a particular exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYRE, ANNE
description: SAYRE-Anne. Beloved wife of David Sayre; writer, justice, and beloved friend of many others. Funeral service Tuesday, 11 AM at St. James Episcopal Church, St. James, Long Island.

title: Historic Houston Neighborhood Falls to Renewal
description: In its headlong rush to become the nation's fourth-largest city, Houston has never been particularly noted for preserving its past. ''Growth'' is a civic mantra, and public angst over whether the place is getting ''too big'' or ''losing its character'' is virtually nonexistent. For good and for bad, Houston is a city that mostly seems to look ahead.

title: Musician's Love for Ireland in Song
description: FOR Jane Murphy, St. Patrick's Day means much more than just shamrocks and leprechauns. It is a time to pick up her guitar and celebrate her Irish heritage by performing the airs and ballads she loves best.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Your Old House

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, RENE ERNEST
description: WOLFF-Rene Ernest. On March 9, 1998 in Strasbourg, France. Lifelong resident of Kolbsheim. Born there August 11, 1911. Paula and Elaine Wolff sadly announce the death of cherished Leon, Sylvia, Achille and Raymonde's brother. He is survived by Marthe, his wise and radiant wife of 60 years, their daughters Liane (Marco) Meyer of St. Louis, France and Josette (Alain) Kaufman of Bne-Brak, Israel. 18 grandchildren and many great-grandchildren. Rene was a french soldier and prisoner of war, liberated by the American Army in 1945. We have all been touched by his sense of freedom, his great wit and intelligence, his devotion to country and homestead and love of our family's rich history. We miss him enormously. Our hearts go out to Marthe and all who loved him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAZIER, FRANCES
description: FRAZIER-Frances. Of New York City. On March 10, 1998. Beloved to all who knew her. A non denominational memorial service will be held at West End Synagogue, 69th Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC, 1 PM, Sunday, March 22, 1998. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Beth Israel Medical Center in Memory of Frances Frazier, 1st Ave. and 16 Street, New York, NY 10003, Attention: Development Office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MAY C.
description: BERNSTEIN-May C. Age 88. Died in the loving arms of her beloved family after a valiant fight. Loving wife of the late Henry. Cherished mother of Barbara and Norman Libman. Adored grandmother to David, Peter and Michele. A very special Aunt May to Carol and Joel Sheinbaum and Jerry Cohen. She will be greatly missed.

title: Finally, His Day in Court; Man Wrongly Accused in Brawley Case Will Be Heard
description: Steven A. Pagones remembers his wedding as a festive, storybook affair. There were more than 200 guests, a nine-piece Greek band, bouquets of flowers everywhere and more food than anyone could possibly eat.

description: To the Editor:

description: Solo Variations

title: Schizophrenia's Most Zealous Foe
description: I was shocked by E. Fuller Torrey's assertion that a cure for schizophrenia might be found in the next 5 to 10 years. My younger brother has suffered from this illness for two decades, and the prospect of a cure redeeming him from this devastating disease is something I've grown not to expect. Although Torrey may be overly optimistic in his belief, I'm grateful for his dedication in pursuit of it. His talent and determination provide what schizophrenics and their families need most: hope.

title: Republicans See Jones Case As a Double-Edged Sword
description: At the Conservative Political Action Conference here four years ago, many participants could barely contain their delight when a woman from Arkansas named Paula Corbin Jones nervously stepped up to a lectern and accused President Clinton of making sexual advances toward her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAHEY, RICHARD WILLIAM, JR.
description: LAHEY-Richard William, Jr., age 78, March 11, 1998, in Boulder, CO. Formerly of New Rochelle, NY. Beloved husband of Barbara and father of Richard W. Lahey III of Kentfield, CA, Corning Lahey of Boulder, CO, Avis Bridgers of Pittsboro, NC, Frederic M. Lahey of Boulder, CO. Also survived by sister, Avis Beckler of San Clemente, CA; five grandchildren. Contributions to Children's Hospital, 1056 E. 19th Ave., Denver, CO 80218

title: 'Happy Birthday' and Variations
description: TWO new concert halls grace Europe this season, one in Baden-Baden, Germany, the other in Lucerne, Switzerland. The World Orchestra for Peace, a legacy of the late conductor Georg Solti, gives the first performance in the 2,500-seat Festspielhaus on April 18, initiating the International Festival Baden-Baden, dedicated to Solti, who provided its inspiration. On Aug. 19, Claudio Abbado and the Berlin Philharmonic open the 60th Lucerne Festival in the 1,840-seat concert hall on the shore of Lake Lucerne, the first auditorium to be completed in the city's new Culture and Congress Center.

title: A Good Fight: For an Elder Shelter
description: In the traditionally staid world of charity fund-raisers, participants meet over cocktails and earnest party talk. They rarely come to blows.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: MR. BUMBLE. By Kim Kennedy. Illustrated by Doug Kennedy. Hyperion. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8) Here's the fanciful story of a clumsy bumblebee -- the one who always stumbles and spills. He gets trapped in a distant patch of clover, is rescued and tutored by the fairies who live there and becomes a fine racing bee. Very pretty illustrations, in which the flowers have faces and the fairies have instruction books.

title: Teachers Reject Bilingual Education; What's Best for Deaf?
description: To the Editor:

title: On Sunday; Nomenclature, Thy Name Is Henry
description: PARKS Commissioner Henry J. Stern has drawn the line. He will not give trees individual names like Fred or Dorothy. ''You don't know if they'd appreciate it,'' he said. ''You can't get informed consent.''

description: MONDAY

title: Hail (and Watch Your Back)
description: LIKE the historical Julius Caesar whom he portrays, Dan Circle, the only full-time Roman emperor on the Boardwalk, expects today, the Ides of March, to pass without incident.

title: Illinois State Wilts After Arizona Applies Second-Half Pressure
description: Jason Terry says Arizona's players can feel it. The pressure gets turned up, the other team begins to wobble, then crack, and the Wildcats pounce with feral intensity.

title: Class Consciousness
description: The Dower House

title: Sunday: March 15, 1998; VACATIONS; Let's Go: Manhunting
description: As adventure holidays go, Ted Oliver's new idea may put even big-game hunting in the sissy category. This summer, Oliver, a 47-year-old British-born bounty hunter who now lives in Bonney Lake, Wash., plans to offer British tourists the chance to participate in a real live manhunt. Oliver (pictured) is a 10-year bounty-hunt veteran and author of a fugitive-recovery guidebook called ''You Can Run but You Can't Hide.'' His idea is to charge intrepid countrymen $1,600 to train with him in martial arts and handcuffing techniques. Then the newly minted tough guys and gals will accompany Oliver on a weeklong hunt for bail jumpers of all stripes, from petty criminals to armed robbers, in Washington State.

title: A Voice for the Irish
description: No shamrocks or leprechauns here.

title: Untying Cellular Phones From Those Annual Contracts
description: DESPITE its name, the wireless phone often comes with strings attached.

title: Revisiting the Refugee 'Problem'
description: A couple of months ago, this column described a spectacle of abuse that some guards at the Union County Jail in Elizabeth inflicted on a group of terrified asylum-seekers who were transferred temporarily to the jail on June 18, 1995.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on the Travel Advisory page on Feb. 22, about a guidebook to Tokyo subway exits, misstated the telephone number of Phoenix Books, the distributor. It is (602) 840-3276. The number given, (602) 840-8948, is the fax number.

title: Study Finds That Youngest U.S. Children Are Poorest
description: While the number of American children living in poverty has declined from the peak of 1993, children younger than 6 remain the poorest age group in the nation, according to a study by the National Center for Children in Poverty.

title: Q&A/John A. Connelly; Tough Prosecutor Leading the State Police
description: JOHN A. CONNELLY is not easily intimidated. Not after 14 years as Waterbury State's Attorney, pointing his finger at accused killers, including three of the five men on death row in Connecticut. He once prosecuted members of his own Democratic party for absentee-ballot fraud. His courtroom presence was formidable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, MARY M. ''MOLLY'' (MCGEE)
description: McMAHON-Mary M. ''Molly'' (McGee). Of Brockton, MA, formerly of NYC. March 5. Wife of the late John D. McMahon. Mother of Regina C. McMahon of San Francisco, Patricia K. Wood of West Islip, NY, and Mary M. O'Toole of Brockton, MA. Funeral was held last Saturday in MA. Donations in Molly's memory may be sent to Easter Seals, 460 Totten Pond Rd., Waltham, MA 02154.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: ON THE ROAD SANS COMPUTER

title: Children's Books
description: MAILING MAY

title: Melissa Brown and Michael Brown
description: Melissa Anne Brown, the daughter of Susan K. Baker of New York and Owen J. Brown 3d of New Canaan, Conn., was married last evening to Dr. Michael Charles Brown, a son of Nancy and Frederic D. Brown of Fairfield, Conn.

title: The Wheel Turns
description: It's not a major performing arts center, but perhaps it is a small sign of rebirth in Newark: bike racing in Branch Brook Park. In this case the construction requirements were just a coat of asphalt on a 2.2-mile loop of road. The Montclair Cyclists, a club of racers and bicycling enthusiasts, rolled out to Newark last fall to check out the new surface and found a smooth-riding, flat course in green surroundings, optimal for criteriums - races over a repeated set of laps. Next Saturday and March 28, the club and the Essex County Department of parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs are co-sponosring a series of training races there, for beginning to experienced competitors.

title: The Stores That Cross Class Lines
description: COLLEEN McQUISTON is an upper-middle-class homemaker, and she likes to shop accordingly. She buys cosmetics at Foley's, a department store near her home outside Houston, and clothes at Lord & Taylor. She hits Neiman Marcus each year at Christmas. But when she needs a lipstick or guest towels or socks for her children, she is likely to go to Target.

title: Linda Tripp, Elusive Keeper Of Secrets, Mainly Her Own
description: As a senior at Hanover Park High School in New Jersey, she listed a ''pet peeve'' next to her smiling portrait in the 1967 yearbook. ''A certain fair-weather friend,'' it read.

title: For Britain and Ireland, One Goal: Peace in Ulster Now, Imposed if Necessary
description: Fearful of losing the best chance in three decades to forge a settlement of the conflict in Northern Ireland, the Governments of Britain and Ireland have decided on the risky strategy of driving the lagging peace talks to an early conclusion.

title: Irvington Waterfront
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has chosen Irvington's polluted waterfront as the first so-called brownfield to be transformed into a park using the 1996 Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act. The village will receive $2.9 million from the state for the project, which entails capping a 12-acre former industrial site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRODIN, FRED
description: GRODIN-Fred. Beloved husband of Lillian, devoted father of Jewel Prince and Norine Grodin. Cherished grandfather and greatgrandfather. Services Tuesday 11:15 A.M. at Riverside-Nassau North, Great Neck, New York.

title: Design Buildings Are Back From Dead, Though Less Tony
description: Twelve years ago, guests from Manhattan's design and decorating world were ferried by a fleet of black vans over the East River to the foot of the Queensboro Bridge. There, the International Design Center of New York, with its vaulting atriums and sleek showrooms designed by I. M. Pei, had been carved out of two old factory buildings on Thomson Avenue.

title: After All, They're Only Humanoid
description: The dream of building mechanical humanoids was already many centuries old when the Czech playwright Karel Capek coined the word ''robot'' in his 1921 play ''R.U.R.'' Starting with the medieval invention of clockwork engines, the construction of ''automatons,'' machines made to look human and engineered to play music or dance, gained enormous popularity. The idea of building an automaton so perfect that it could fool people into thinking it was human came to inspire not only the mechanics who experimented with these machines but the artists who fictionalized them; a seductive female automaton named Olympia became an important character in the 1880 tragicomic opera by Jacques Offenbach, ''The Tales of Hoffman.''

title: About the Excerpts
description: Because of technical problems, excerpts from President Clinton's deposition in the Paula Jones lawsuit were incomplete or contained duplications in yesterday's editions. The excerpts will be reprinted in fuller form on Monday.

title: Children's Books
description: Charles A. Lindbergh

title: A Darling of the Critics Who Doesn't Flatter Them
description: EVEN if ''St. Nicholas'' were not about a drama critic, Conor McPherson's one-man play would command more than passing interest. Here is a 26-year-old Dubliner whose love of language has brought prominence and awards on the basis of only three professionally produced plays and, most recently, one film.

title: Jason Duckworth, Angela Lee
description: Angela Susan Lee, who teaches seventh-grade mathematics at the Learning Project, an alternative public school in New York, was married yesterday to Jason Matthew Duckworth, a management consultant in New York for McKinsey & Company. Pastor Paul Neff officiated at the Lutheran Church of the Holy Communion in Philadelphia. The Rev. David Albert Jones, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: The Gore Guide To The Future
description: As the first Fulbright Scholar teaching in Kyrgyzstan, I had the opportunity to meet Vice President Al Gore as he conducted a town meeting hosted by the Kyrgyz-American School (''The Gore Guide to the Future,'' by Richard L. Berke, Feb. 22). He was witty. . .yes, witty. . . charming, intelligent, gracious and diplomatic as he randomly fielded questions from the Kyrgyz students. He was diplomatically adept and culturally astute. Without a doubt, the Vice President won the respect and admiration of this large, packed hall of Central Asian citizens, many of whom, only two years before, were members of a Communist system.

title: March 8-14; Monica, Shmonica. What About Me?
description: There's an unwritten protocol governing Presidential photo opportunities with foreign leaders. When the American press peppers the President with questions about uncomfortable domestic matters -- like, say, his relationship with a certain former intern -- the foreign dignitary is supposed to appear interested, but not too interested. Most leaders adopt a wry detachment, a look that translates as ''Better you than me,'' or ''These people should have been shot long ago.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, SIDNEY P.
description: HARRIS-Sidney P. Entered into rest March 7. Of Waltham, MA, formerly of Bayside, NY. Beloved husband of Muriel (Touster). Loving father of Suzanne Harris of Bedford, MA. Adored grandfather of Jeffrey Campagna. An inspiring and beloved teacher. For information, Stanetsky Chapels, Brookline, Massachusetts, 1-800-842-4280.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, SHARI
description: WOLFSON-Shari Former jewelry designer and wife of Victor Wolfson, of Hollis, New York, died March 1, 1998.

title: The Passion of Anton
description: ANTON CHEKHOV

title: Science Fiction
description: Like all her work, Gwyneth Jones's PHOENIX CAFE (Tom Doherty/Tor, $24.95) eschews the storytelling devices we usually find in science fiction: well-defined settings, clear-cut predicaments, unequivocal resolutions. There are no hard edges in her books. Not only are we often in doubt about her characters' motivations, we are not always sure what is happening. Yet we never doubt that something of great importance is at stake, because all the people to whom Jones directs our attention are suffering so intensely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWMAN, ETHEL L.
description: BOWMAN-Ethel L. Widow of Supreme Court Justice Amos E. Bowman and mother of Supreme Court Justice Janice L. Bowman, passed away peacefully in her sleep on March 12, 1998. Viewing Benta Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Avenue at 141st Street, on Sunday, March 15, 4-6 PM. Funeral St. Philip's Episcopal Church, 204 West 134th Street at 7th Avenue, Monday, March 16, at 11 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POTTER, HAROLD (HAL)
description: POTTER-Harold (Hal). January 23, 1932 to March 17, 1992. Dear husband and father. We miss you. Love, Joyce, Seth, Robert and Warren.

title: Pox Americana; A World Made Safe For, Uh, Whatever
description: THE end of the cold war was supposed to bring not only a peace dividend, with less money spent on defense, but a sort of moral dividend, too. The United States, which had suppressed its ethical standards in the higher battle against godless Communism, was now supposed to be able to pick its friends with a little more discretion.

title: Discrediting Reported Confession Is Major Defense Strategy in a Capital Case
description: On the night of Dec. 20, 1996, in the 79th Precinct station house in Brooklyn, a former New York City correction officer, Darrel K. Harris, confessed to killing three people while robbing patrons of a social club two weeks earlier, police detectives say.

title: Assembling Pieces With a Surprise Quotient
description: THE art of assemblage differs from its immediate ancestors, the Cubist or Dada collage and constructivist sculpture, mainly by way of its three-dimensionality on the one hand, and the heterogeneity of its component materials on the other. One of the pleasures of this art -- for the viewer and, I suppose, for the artist -- is its potential for surprising combinations of objects and materials. So the mere observation that ''Terry Adkins: Distant Mirrors'' is the kind of exhibition that can include works made of ''steel, enamel, owl,'' or ''steel, iron, apples'' is enough to indicate the presence of an assemblagist whose surprise quotient can be high indeed.

title: School Janitor Is Arrested In '74 Killing of Mobster
description: It was a cold case for more than two decades. The body of a mobster found stuffed in the blood-soaked trunk of a car in Coney Island, the second such discovery by the police in less than a week. Suspicion for both killings focused on organized crime.

title: Sunday: March 15, 1998; YOU ARE THERE; It's a Dog's Life: The Flea Circus
description: Maria Fernanda Cardoso had never seen a flea circus when she decided to resuscitate the lost art of insect performance. For the past three years, Cardoso -- a 34-year-old Colombian-born, Yale-educated conceptual artist -- has painstakingly trained hundreds of fleas, using a variety of techniques that were popularized in 19th-century Europe. Now, in ''The Cardoso Flea Circus Video,'' an installation showing at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in New York City from March 19 to April 19, Cardoso can be seen prodding her tiny charges (each flea is 1 millimeters long, or slightly bigger than a pinhead) into stunts like walking a tightrope, swinging from a trapeze, even sword fighting. ''The show is hilarious,'' she says, ''but it is a serious artwork.'' Here's a look.

title: Results of Promotion Exams Are Nullifed for 13 Firefighters
description: Exam scores for 13 firefighters who returned from medical leave and took a makeup examination for promotion to lieutenant will be nullified because the firefighters may have received advance notice of the exam's content, Fire Commissioner Thomas Von Essen said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANBY, EDWARD TATNALL
description: CANBY-Edward Tatnall. On February 21, 1998 in Cornwall, CT., at age 85. The original members of the Canby Singers will ever be grateful for his musical nourishment and good fellowship and for the life-long friendships made as we sang together. Natalie Jaffe Richard Bodig Alison Kallman Herbert Steiner

title: Julie Kosann And Richard Troy
description: Julie Lisa Kosann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Kosann of New York, was married last evening to Richard Lawrence Troy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Troy of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Reuven Siegel officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: Lord Peter's Last Case
description: THRONES, DOMINATIONS

title: Computers That Tend The Home
description: WHAT time is it?'' Tim Shriver asked his computer. ''The time is 12:32 P.M.,'' it said.

title: The Many New Shades of Gray
description: IN trying to attract the attention, and subscriptions, of aging baby boomers, most personal-finance magazines overwork the theme of retirement. Worth's April issue, though, has six articles on the subject that are informative and entertaining and espouse fairly unconventional -- some might say quirky -- wisdom that doesn't sound like it's parroting the mutual fund industry.

title: A Young Performer With a Few Tricks of His Own
description: IT was Michael (Shade) Turco's uncle, just plain Michael Turco of Smithville, who tipped him off about Joseph Gabriel's auditions for young magicians. Last year, Michael learned about the opportunity two days late. This year, on Feb. 17, he showed up an hour early, the first of 25 who tried out for an intermission spot onstage during ''Magic '98.''

title: No Incest, and Only a Little Drink
description: ARE YOU SOMEBODY

title: $200,000 in Gems Stolen
description: Four men drove a sledgehammer into the window of a Madison Avenue jewelry store yesterday and stole $200,000 in gems, the police said.

title: Not Just for Salad, Arugula Can Also Season Sauce or Risotto
description: IN the 10 or so years since arugula has become a supermarket staple and a yuppie cliche, its use is nearly always in salad. But these bitter-tasting greens have other uses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, BESS
description: KLEINMAN-Bess, 89, formerly of New York and Los Angeles, spent her last years in Kibbutz Saar, Israel; died peacefully in her sleep on November 14, 1997. Survived by husband George; daughter, Nora and husband Rafi; son, Danny and wife, Nicole; grandchildren Ariel, Naava, Itai, Stephanie.

title: Behind the Sidewalk Book Bargains: A Manhattan Mystery
description: Frazer Pennebaker, a documentary film producer, spotted an irresistible bargain while heading for Zabar's one recent Sunday afternoon. He bought a copy of the Merck Manual from a street vendor for $20, about $9 less than he would have paid at the Barnes & Noble a couple of blocks away.

title: Radical Pragmatist
description: GENUINE REALITY

title: Jazz: Born in America, and a Citizen of the World
description: Jazz shares the European music scene from about June to November, but the most popular month for festivals that concentrate primarily on jazz is July, when all but three of the following events take place. The popularity of jazz is undiminished abroad, as shown by this sampling of festivals, listed chronologically.

title: Having It Their Way Means Keeping Out Burger King
description: In most neighborhoods, a sign staked on a lawn means the house is for sale or someone wants your vote. But along Bard Avenue, the hundreds of signs planted in front yards, and even outside a Lutheran church, convey a different message: ''No Burger King.''

title: Old Apartments and the Fear of Fire
description: CROUCHING in the dark smoke-filled hallway, Carlos Nique quickly bundled his tiny daughter in his overcoat and fled with her down several flights of stairs into the cold February morning. Unscathed but homeless, the self-employed carpenter and 15-month-old Daniela huddled outside on the White Plains street with the other victims of the fourth fire to strike a Westchester apartment house in less than two months.

title: March 8-14; Rocks, Bullets and Words
description: Another round of bloodshed and recriminations clouded the prospects for progress toward peace between Israel and the Palestinians. But by the end of the week their leaders were speaking as if they wanted to calm the passions and get on with the business of talking to each other, in advance of an expected American effort to restart peace talks.

title: Teachers Reject Bilingual Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHNER, IVA KAPLAN
description: ASHNER-Iva Kaplan, 54. New York City and Provincetown, MA. After a long illness bravely borne, displaying nobility and unusual courage in difficult times. Beloved wife of Leon D. Ashner. Precious daughter of Eleanor and Nathan Kaplan, Pittsfield, MA. Dear sister of David Kaplan. Darling niece and cousin. Loving aunt. Dear friend. She was a 30-year employee of W.W. Norton Publishing Company where she was Editor and Director of Advertising. Funeral Services, Sunday, March 15, at 11 A.M., Gramercy Park (Sigmund Schwartz) Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, NYC. Burial Mount Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Shiva Surrey Hotel, 20 East 76 Street, NYC thru Tuesday, afterward in Pittsfield to Friday Noon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Iva Kaplan Ashner Writing Fellowship, Fine Arts Work Center, 24 Pearl Street, Provincetown, MA. 02657.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Towering Ambition
description: DELIRIUM By Douglas Cooper. 232 pp. New York: Hyperion. $21.95.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BITTER HARVEST

title: March 8-14; But They Still Wouldn't Want To Live There
description: With its rich traditions of trash, crime and attitude, New York City has long been regarded with dread across much of America. But a new national poll by The New York Times found those attitudes to be changing. More than 60 percent of people questioned around the country had a good image of the city up from 40 percent just two years ago.

title: A Movie America Can't See
description: JEREMY IRONS has a look of anguished despair on his face, which is splattered with droplets of blood. He slumps against the window as he drives an old wooden-sided station wagon, swerving on and off a country road. In one bloodied hand he holds a bobby pin as if it were the greatest treasure on earth; on the seat beside him is a gun. Then Humbert Humbert, the man who has loved a 12-year-old girl, begins his long confession. In voice-over, Mr. Irons offers the most famous lines from one of the most poetic, romantic novels ever written: ''Lolita, light of my life, fire of my loins. My sin, my soul, Lo-lee-ta.''

title: Maker of Software That Pinpoints Problems
description: LESS than a year ago, when America Online, one of the largest internet service providers, crashed, making it impossible for subscribers on the Eastern Seaboard to gain access to the Internet, chaos reigned for eight hours.

title: Paris Will Be Brimming During World Cup
description: THE World Cup, which is to soccer what the World Series is to baseball, will bring players and fans to France from all over the world from June 10 to July 12. The French Government sees the event as a welcome shot in the arm, and has gone all out to make it a success even though Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's favorite sport is rugby. Hotel rooms in the 10 French cities playing host to the games are heavily booked through most of the period, and train and air reservations may also be harder than usual to come by.

title: Renovation Has Tenants Looking Skyward
description: Steven Mayer, a concert pianist who lives in a rent-stabilized apartment at the Cambridge House Hotel on 86th Street near Riverside Drive, has a chunk of concrete from the facade of the building, which is undergoing renovation. It is a piece of the masonry that fell from the 16th floor on Tuesday, he said, bouncing off the scaffolding and onto the street, where it broke apart.

title: Mozart to Messiaen's Monks
description: I KNOW one festival city I want to visit this season: Bergen, in the latter part of May. I don't know much about Bergen. According to the atlas, it's some way up the Norwegian coast, around the corner from Oslo. It probably has a quaint district of old timbered houses going down to the quayside, where an early morning fish market takes place. No doubt it has fjords nearby. But none of that really matters, because the main reason to be there would be for the music.

title: Bookend; www.claptrap.com
description: Shortly after personal computers and word-processing programs became commonplace tools for writers, a brave new future for fiction was trumpeted. In 1992, Robert Coover informed the readers of the Book Review that the novel, ''as we know it, has come to its end.'' Hypertext, ''writing done in the nonlinear or nonsequential space made possible by the computer,'' would at last enable the reader to amble through a network of linked text blocks, or ''lexias.'' Instead of following a linear story dictated by the author, the reader could now navigate at will through an ''endless expansion'' of words.

title: Students Pursue Past In Oral History Project
description: FOR most Metro-North commuters, the Croton-Harmon train station is little more than a backdrop to their daily routine. Nor do most Croton residents give more than a passing thought to the Croton Dam -- which, like the Hudson River, seems to be a timeless feature of the landscape.

title: U.S. Warned Serb Leader Not to Crack Down on Kosovo Albanians
description: Several weeks before the Serbian police killed scores of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo province, President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia was warned by Washington's top Balkans negotiator not to carry out the widely expected crackdown.

title: Mira Citron, B. H. Bernstein
description: Mira Citron, a daughter of Virginia B. Citron of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Dr. Henry Citron of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Bradford H. Bernstein, the son of Marianne and Harvey Bernstein of Old Westbury, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, ROSA
description: ISRAEL-Rosa. We extend our sincerest condolences to Romie Shapiro on the passing of his beloved sister, Rosa Israel. Romie, together with his wife Blanche, are Diamond Founders of the ''Hospital with a Heart'' and have dedicated themselves in a most extraordinary manner to many charitable endeavors. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Lee Weinbach, President National Women's Division Sidney Adler, Treasurer Dr. Stuart Tauber, Exec. Dir.

title: The Gap
description: THE WEALTH AND POVERTY OF NATIONS

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Hunter Falls Just Short Of Realizing Its Dream
description: Hunter Coach Mike Brown plucked his recruits from a playground, a restaurant and wherever else he could unearth a player who needed a second chance.

title: Trump's Revised Plan
description: Donald Trump, in response to concern raised at public hearings last year, has revised his plans for Briar Hall Country Club, calling the new proposal less intensive.

title: Buckled Up? It's Pilot Season in Hollywood
description: A FEW weeks ago, on the drive between her home in West Hollywood and a Fox television casting office in Santa Monica, Heidi Schanz decided she would take her shoes off at her audition.

title: Schizophrenia's Most Zealous Foe
description: Michael Winerip's profile of E. Fuller Torrey comments misleadingly on the theory of schizophrenia developed in 50 years of research by our father, Theodore Lidz. He has not claimed that ''bad parenting'' is linked to schizophrenia. He has argued that the family environment in which a person is raised appears to be a major (not the only) cause of schizophrenia. Lidz has not blamed parents for their children's disorders, as some psychiatrists of a past generation did. Lidz's view of schizophrenia has carefully distanced itself from moralism.

title: BENEFITS
description: In League

title: In the 90's, Take-Out Becomes Take-In
description: WHAT does a molecular biologist have in common with a 73-year-old widow, a restaurant chef, two dentists, a police detective and a teacher of gifted children? They all want to enjoy hot, fresh, healthy dinners in the comfort of their own home. They want to eat the kind of food they would prepare themselves if only they had the time. None have the time. Instead, they are becoming happily addicted to different forms of gourmet takeout, an option that puts dinner on the table efficiently, creatively and perhaps most importantly, guilt-free.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, BENEDICT
description: GINSBERG-Benedict. 1908-1998. Mr. and Mrs Herbert R. Weissberg and Family mourn the passing of the greatest lawyer and loyal friend for more than forty years. We will miss him every day.

title: Overkill Is Not Dead
description: The B-61-11, the latest addition to America's nuclear arsenal, is known as an earth penetrator. The new nose and steel casings add weight and strength, and the fuse has been changed to delay detonation until seconds after impact. The result is a bomb that burrows several feet before exploding, enabling it to obliterate targets like command bunkers and chemical-weapons factories several hundred feet beneath the surface. All in all, it represents a significant leap in bomb design, and that's precisely the problem. Pentagon officials deny that the B-61-11 is a new weapon.

title: Kirsten Schiefler, Norman Ernst Jr.
description: Kirsten M. Schiefler, a daughter of Dr. Donald Schiefler of Calgary, Alberta, and the late Doreen Schiefler, was married on Feb. 17 to Dr. Norman A. Ernst Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernst of Dunedin, Fla. The Rev. Frank Mak of the Joyful Christian Ministries officiated at the Royal Hawaiian Hotel in Waikiki.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, GEORGE
description: HECHT-George. Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund is saddened by the death of our long time supporter. George was deeply committed to our mission of protecting the rights of lesbians and gay men. His warmth, generosity and friendship will be deeply missed. Kevin M. Cathcart, Exec. Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, ERIC
description: WASSERMAN-Eric. Beloved son of Samuel and Sandra Wasserman. Adored brother of Robert and Cary. Beloved grandson of Ethel Carmel Wasserman. Also son of Pat LaPedus. Your friends and your family love you and miss you. We welcome friends to our home to celebrate your life. Services Sunday, March 15th, 10 AM, at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue at 55th Street. Contributions may be made to the Eric Wasserman Fund for Community Outreach c/o Central Synagogue.

title: Corrections
description: The Gazetteer chart last Sunday with the article about living in Princeton, N.J., misidentified the author of the phrase ''Ivy League.'' It was Caswell Adams, a sportswriter for The New York Herald Tribune, not Stanley Woodward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHLER, EDNA
description: KAHLER-Edna. On March 13, 1998, of Manhasset, NY. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Dear mother of Ann Lovett and Susan Carboine. Loving mother-in-law of Thomas Lovett. Adored grandmother of nine and two granddaughters in heaven. Also survived by 13 great-grandchildren. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Sunday, 2-5 PM. Entombment private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to North Shore Center for Extended Care and Rehabilitation, 330 Community Dr., Manhasset, NY 11030.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THUNE, ANDERSEN, WILLIAM
description: THUNE - ANDERSEN - William. Thanks to Scandinavia records with profound sorrow the death of a very special human being and expresses heartfelt sympathy to his beloved family, his wife Gitte and his children Thomas, Karen, Nicolas and Michael and to his countless friends. His vast friendships in the United States, while Danish Consul General in New York between 1977 and 1984 continued throughout the ensuing years while he served as Danish Ambassador to Japan, Egypt and Italy. He will be missed and he will never be forgotten. Victor Borge, National Chairman Richard Netter, President

title: March 8-14; Young Love, a Baby's Death, Courtroom Recriminations
description: In the end, the blissful teen-age romance of Brian Peterson and Amy Grossberg crumbled in icy recrimination over the charges that they killed their newborn son 16 months ago. At a hearing in a Delaware courtroom, her lawyers argued that the baby had been stillborn and blamed Mr. Peterson for leaving the body in a motel trash bin.

title: Free Candidate Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Can E.D.S. Remove That Frown From a Big Investor's Face?
description: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS has landed on the list of worst corporate performers that is compiled annually by one of the nation's largest institutional investors. The contentions: poor financial showings, poor shareholder returns and poor corporate governance.

title: In Recital, Handbells and Brass
description: THE Gloriae Dei Brass and the Gloriae Dei Ringers, from Orleans, Mass., are giving a recital at 3 P.M. this afternoon in the Church of Christ, Congregational in Newington. On the program are pieces by Holst and Debussy, arrangements of music by Saint-Saens and Donald Allured as well as ''The Great Gate of Kiev'' from Moussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition.''

title: The Nation: Military Maneuvers; Operation Be Fit Goes for the Gut
description: OVER the decades the United States armed forces have taken on and conquered some mighty foes: the redcoats, the Nazis, Saddam Hussein. Now they have sighted a new enemy and it is fat.

title: Box Cutter Crackdown
description: District Attorney Jeanine Pirro reported last week that a recent sting operation found 48 stores in the county selling box cutters and that 44 percent illegally displayed the knives for sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AJAY, ABE
description: AJAY-Abe. We mourn the loss of a fine artist, a fine person, a fine friend. We will miss your good humor, vision and perception as we cherish your memory in art. Sincere condolences to Betty and all the Ajay family. John Driscoll, Jeanne Baker Driscoll, and Babcock Galleries

title: Uncas, Still Among Postal Service Rejects
description: IF the United States Postal Service won't honor an Indian chief renowned as the friend of Connecticut's early settlers, who will it honor?

title: Rancho SoHo
description: Whoa, pardner, look what's back in town: cowboy hats have been spotted again in the canyons of Manhattan. ''These hats are less about cowboy and more about cool,'' said Terri Gillis, the owner of TG-170, at 170 Ludlow Street (Stanton Street). Colorful straw hats by Tracy Watts sell for about $120 there and at Barneys New York; Variazioni, 37 West 57th Street, and Bond 07, 7 Bond Street (Lafayette Street), where they were modeled by Mina Khelifa (left), a saleswoman, and Alexandre Sauvageot, an owner. What inspired Ms. Watts? ''I saw a gal down in SoHo last year in a cowboy hat, and it really struck me how great she looked,'' she said. Like her, Lola Ehrlich was inspired by cowboy clothes on the street; her straw hats are $275 at Bergdorf Goodman. And at Steven Alan, 60 Wooster Street (Broome Street), colorful straw hats by Paxton are $165. MARYELLEN GORDON

title: The Way We Are In the Era Of Clinton
description: FROM the opening shot of ''Primary Colors,'' in which the camera pans slowly from a beefy politician's hand to what turns out to be John Travolta's full face -- half smiling, half pouting in an unmistakable mix under silver-gray hair -- there is no doubt about just whose handshake, and face, and flaws this movie is meant to evoke.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Pawling, N.Y.; Growing Town, Rich Past
description: THE Village of Pawling is a microcosm of the town as a whole -- struggling to build on the best of its illustrious past while grappling with the effects of growth.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SILVER, BERTHA
description: SILVER-Bertha. Your 100th birthday today-March 15. How I miss our Sunday morning calls-but mostly I miss you. Love, Pam

title: SOAPBOX; O Park, We Hardly Knew Ye
description: IN Brooklyn there sits a nine-acre piece of East River waterfront, neglected and unprepossessing except for its spectacular possibility. Much-needed open space for all New Yorkers, this land is a state park and has been since 1979, when we the people bought and paid for it, a future green haven from the city's pressures.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Krippendorf's Tribe

title: Couch Potato Politics
description: The American political system seems to work best when the American economy is performing at its worst. Compare the Great Depression with the go-go years after World War II. Throughout the economic crises of the 1930's, political passions ran high, innovative policies were fashioned, people listened to their radios and campaigns were intense. And ultimately, Franklin Roosevelt came to be considered one of our greatest Presidents.

title: A Drought Halts Ghana On Its Road To Success
description: With temperatures climbing most days into the high 90's, Jesper B. Jeppesen, managing director of Fan Milk, Ghana's largest dairy company, is facing a serious problem.

title: Commercial Property/Florham Park, N.J.; Once Sleepy Hamlet Now Bustling Corporate Haven
description: A GENERATION ago, Florham Park, N.J., was a sleepy residential hamlet nestled along the Columbia Turnpike between Morristown and South Orange, known largely for its bowling alley and roller skating rink. But due to a combination of improved transportation and accidents of history, the borough has become a corporate haven, with over a million square feet of office space completed in the last decade, and more on the way.

title: Report on Homeless Man Omitted Some History
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: The Lone Ranger
description: HIS was a death that has evoked the legend and the mystery of a James Dean.

title: The Nation; 800-Pound Guests At the Pentagon
description: WITH the cold war over and Pentagon spending on weapons slashed, the military-industrial complex isn't what it used to be. The nation's defense contractors, hurting for business, have gone through an eat-or-be-eaten merger wave so sweeping that only three major military contractors are left standing today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUCKER, GERTRUDE
description: KUCKER-Gertrude. Beloved wife of Joseph. Loving mother of Miles and Michele, and Stuart and Jacalyn. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Stephanie, Jason and Lauren. Devoted sister of Estelle. Services today, 2:30 PM, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, (Avenue J).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKIN, ALBERT
description: ELKIN-Albert. Husband of Pearl. Roberta, Edward, Meredith, and Jed mourn the loss of their father and grandfather. Friends are welcome at home on Tuesday evening and Wednesday. Private interment Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALMIRON, HUGO
description: ALMIRON-Hugo. Loving husband of Alma. Dear father of Fabiana. Beloved son of Severina. Reposing at the Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, New York, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 710PM. Graveside service Monday 11AM at Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: In America; A Cop's View
description: The police officer called late in the afternoon. He spoke hesitantly, afraid that his identity would be revealed. I assured him that it would not.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Family Honor
description: Despite the near-microscopic scrutiny to which our politicians' love lives are currently subjected, we may still be astonished to encounter a culture in which ordinary girls' sexual intimacies are known by every neighbor, mothers probe their sleeping daughters' private parts to confirm the ''family honor,'' and a girl's first menstruation is announced from the rooftops. Dorit Rabinyan, an Israeli journalist, poet and playwright, has conjured precisely such a society in PERSIAN BRIDES (Braziller, $22.50), her lush, lyrical and disturbing first novel. Set in a Jewish community in a village in turn-of-the-century Persia, the story contrasts the experiences and aspirations of two young women: Flora, a 15-year-old pining for her deadbeat husband, a cloth merchant who ditched her with ''a baby in her belly and lice in her hair,'' and Flora's 11-year-old cousin, Nazie, desperate to achieve her menses so she can be wed to Flora's brother. Nazie and Flora's frantic longing for married life is artfully contrasted with the reality of what's in store for them: wives and mothers in their world are violently mistreated by their husbands, spat upon, even threatened with death for bearing female children. With unwaveringly authentic period detail, Rabinyan grounds her themes of sexual politics in scenes mingling exotic beauty and gritty horror. Only 23 when her book was published in Hebrew, she writes with the wise and leisurely assurance of a town bard recounting communal myths. In this translation by Yael Lotan, Rabinyan's marvelously digressive style and rich prose give the story the feel of a nightlong wedding feast. ''Persian Brides'' is an auspicious debut. Michael Lowenthal

title: Attention Must Be Paid For
description: TRUTH GAMES Lies, Money, and Psychoanalysis. By John Forrester. 210 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $22.95.

title: Town of the Lottery Killings
description: THE blood that stained the offices and parking lot at the state's Lottery Corporation headquarters in Newington had all been washed away by the time employees began returning to work last week.

title: Lynn Jollivette, Jamal N. Simmons
description: Lynn Monique Jollivette and Jamal Nkosi Simmons were married yesterday at St. Hugh's Roman Catholic Church in Coconut Grove, Fla. Bishop Lawson Howze of Biloxi, Miss., performed the ceremony.

title: Sports of The Times; Heading in a New, Unknown Direction
description: IN different parts of the losers' somber locker room on Friday night, St. John's players absorbed the misery of a 2-point loss in their own fashion. Most of the crying had been in private, before the horde of reporters rushed in. Now the players sat and stared and tried to speak in measured tones.

title: March 8-14; A Kennedy Drops Out
description: For half a century, Kennedys have made news by entering politics. Now the leading politician of the family's younger generation has become the first Kennedy to make news by leaving politics.

title: Lives; Last Communion
description: My mother knew she had alzheimer's disease long before it was diagnosed, her symptoms an eerie reprise of my father's dementia a scant decade earlier.

title: Lopez's Career Finishes On a Metaphorical Miss
description: This was not the way the Red Storm envisioned its season ending, not with Felipe Lopez's 3-pointer hitting the front of the rim and center Zendon Hamilton clutching the rebound, unable to get another shot off before time expired. St. John's had lost to Detroit, 66-64, in the first round of the Midwest Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament at the United Center here.

title: Streetscapes/42 West 72d Street, 118 West 72d Street and 126 West 73d Street; 3 Identical Buildings, With a 'Daddy' as Their Father
description: A walk through the blocks around 72d Street and Columbus Avenue may lead a pedestrian to think he is seeing a mirage or experiencing deja vu -- ''Didn't I just see that building?'' But the architectural legacy of Edward W. (Daddy) Browning is no hallucination -- it is three identical white terra-cotta apartment buildings put up in 1915 within a block of one another. Exterior work on two of the buildings indicates that their identical character is not just skin deep.

title: Supreme Court Was Right on Jones Lawsuit
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTGER, MILTON
description: BUTGER-Milton. Died March 12, 1998, aged 77. Beloved husband of Beatrice Butger; father of Harold and the late Alan Butger. Also survived by two sisters Ruth Magrab and Thelma Kirshenbaum, and by grandchildren Bari and Jodi Blair, and Beau Butger.

title: Stifling the Steam Rids City of Atmosphere
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Colorblind: Just Blind
description: The inclusion of two articles on Feb. 22 dealing with race was either supremely ironic or brilliantly purposeful. ''Not Colorblind: Just Blind,'' by Nicholas deB. Katzenbach and Burke Marshall, commented on the importance of affirmative action as a method of remediating past racial discrimination and pursuing the policy of diversity in society. ''This Is a Player,'' by John Feinstein, expressed surprise that a white man could play successfully in the National Basketball Association, and stated that among this year's All-Stars, only 1 player of 24 is white. By Katzenbach and Marshall's reasoning, the N.B.A. must be the most racist institution in America.
