title: Tennessee Governor Talks of Revolt on E.P.A. Smog Rules
description: The battle over new clean air requirements has turned nasty here in the South.

title: Supreme Court Was Right on Jones Lawsuit; Zone of Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITT, MICHAEL WILLIAM
description: LITT-Michael William. On March 11, 1998, age 51. Survived by his mother Florence, sister Caren, brother Scott, and many friends and relatives who will greatly miss him. Service to remember and celebrate his life: Sunday, March 15 at 3PM, Philosophy Hall, Columbia University. For details, call Riverside Memorial at 212-362-6600.

title: Word & Image; The Next Great Story
description: I have been burrowing for a scoop far removed from Monica Lewinsky, for a discovery that might ignite entirely new curiosities and emotions. If jingo is an even greater passion than libido, I have found it, at least in dim outline: get ready for the collapse of nationhood.

title: Correction: Averages for All Stock Funds
description: Because of a computer programming error, this table, which has appeared monthly in this section since 1995, has consistently misstated percentage returns of the average stock mutual fund -- for the most recent four weeks, for the year to date, and for one year, three years and five years. The Vanguard Group detected the error and alerted the table's compiler, Morningstar Inc., last month; Morningstar confirmed the error on March 3. The computers had been basing their calculation on figures for the average mutual fund of all asset types, not just stock funds. Correct figures are shown in the table listed.

title: Rudolf Baranik Dies at 77; Artist and a Political Force
description: Rudolf Baranik, a painter, writer and teacher well known in the art world for his political advocacy, died March 6 at his home in El Dorado, N.M., outside Santa Fe. He was 77.

title: Modern Yoga: Om to the Beat
description: IT was a typical Monday night at the Jivamukti Yoga Center on Lafayette Street.

title: VIEWPOINT; 10 Steps to a Happy Merger
description: THE feeding frenzy that is flattening the business food chain seems to have taken on a life of its own. The value of mergers and acquisitions among American-based companies hit a record $1 trillion in 1997, up 50 percent from 1996, and recent deals only signal that the pace is accelerating.

title: The Courtly Contrarian
description: Though a journalist himself, Paul Johnson is famously hostile to members of the press. Reporters, he recently wrote, ''tend to be ugly, stunted -- or, if tall, uncouth -- poor, because they spend their money on drink or in the betting shop, with bedraggled wives and unwelcoming homes.'' It is with some trepidation, then, that one puts one's finger to the bell of the Georgian town house, in the London neighborhood of Bayswater, where Johnson lives and works.

title: INSIDE
description: Unity on Ulster Peace

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, STEPHEN
description: GARDNER-Stephen. Steve Gardner, ''Shy'', born Christmas 1908 in New York; a Brooklynite for life, though he lived there only from 1915 to 1936; intellectual, raconteur, bibliophile, gourmet; a powerful presence in the lives of all those he touched, young and old; died March 10, 1998 in Santa Monica, CA, with his wife, Diana Gardner, his children, Joel Gardner and Andrea Fellows, and his best friend, Leo Melzer, by his side throughout his last struggle. His face is now amid a crowd of stars. Or, in his words, ''my compliments to the chef.''

title: In Ardsley, Italian Dishes and Film Decor
description: THE movie posters decorating the walls recall i primi of the Italian cinema -- ''Amacord,'' ''Cinema Paradiso,'' ''La Dolce Vita'' -- along with a few American epics. In her iconic stance, Marilyn Monroe guards the entrance; a more formal rendering graces the bar, over which a marquee continues the theme, which, however, stops at popcorn and previews. This clientele comes here for substantial food.

title: Report Cards: How the Middle and High Schools Fared
description: Here are some key measures released by New York City and New York State this month.

title: Favorite Trick Stars on Difficult Day in Florida
description: In the wildest finish in 30 years, Cape Town was declared the winner of the Florida Derby today when the favored Lil's Lad, with Jerry Bailey aboard, was disqualified for interference in the deep homestretch. But the star of the show at Gulfstream Park was the Horse of the Year, the undefeated Favorite Trick, who swept to victory in the Swale Stakes in his first race in four months and asserted himself as a powerful presence on the road to the Kentucky Derby.

title: A Cooler, More Self-Aware Sally Bowles
description: IT was during a recent Broadway preview of ''Cabaret,'' a dark revival set in a cabaret itself, that Natasha Richardson realized that a man in the front row had a splendid view straight up her dress. It is not as if the 34-year-old Ms. Richardson is an innocent -- she has had her share of sex scenes in movies -- but the rawness of playing Sally Bowles up so close was overpowering. ''My legs started to shake,'' she said.

title: His Job Title Is Elusive, But His Taste Is Impeccable
description: WHO is Robert Verdi? When the designer Cynthia Rowley wanted the freshest and yellowest sunflowers for her wedding reception in an airplane hangar in Brooklyn, Mr. Verdi knew just the right florist, and he also hired one of New York's hippest deejays, Johnny Dynell.

title: United Asset Hopes Its First-Aid Plan Will Stop the Bleeding
description: IF Norton H. Reamer, chief executive of the United Asset Management Corporation, sounds a mite defensive these days, it is understandable. Although his giant money management company is leaching assets, he is adamant that he has the plan to turn the outfit around.

title: SKIPPING THE RACE -- A special report.; Run for Congress? Parties Find Rising Stars Are Just Saying No
description: Darla Wexstten was soaking in the bathtub one Saturday morning in December when her husband, Jim, raced up the stairs and summoned her to the phone. The White House was on the line. Wrapped in a towel and dripping wet, Ms. Wexstten listened intently as President Clinton gently tried to persuade her to seek the House seat from the 20th Congressional District in south central Illinois.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Using Taps and Dies to Cut Threads
description: MANY appliances are held together with threaded fasteners. If you work on any of these machines, you will find that it is handy to have an assortment of taps and dies in your tool kit. Taps and dies are tools for cutting threads. They can be useful if you have to fashion a new part, or if you want to repair threads on damaged or corroded fasteners.

title: POSTINGS: Redeveloping the Hammerstein Estate in Queens; Wildflower to Blossom Again in Beechurst
description: For the last decade, there have been several proposals to develop the Tudor-style mansion built in 1924 for Arthur Hammerstein, the Broadway producer and uncle of lyricist Oscar Hammerstein 2d. The two-story, 15-room house called Wildflower, for Arthur Hammerstein's 1923 hit play, sits abandoned along the waterfront in Beechurst, Queens, a victim of arson, vandalism and time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MOLLIE L.
description: COHEN-Mollie L. On March 13, after a brilliant 17year battle against breast cancer. Mollie was a woman of rare wisdom, good-naturedness, inner strength and caring, always patient and forbearing and always concerned about the other person. Her example is almost impossible to match. She is survived by her husband, Dan Harrison; her mother, Ruth S. Cohen; and her sister, Janis L. Vallely. Service Monday, March 16, 12:30 P.M., at Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, New York (two blks. from Pleasantville R.R. station. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Too Complicated To Categorize
description: David Wells is finished talking about his personal life, he says. He will talk baseball only. From now on, all business. The Yankees pitcher is weary of newspaper biographers running amok through the bits and pieces of his life and interpreting him, tired of the chaos it creates.

title: Planting the Seeds for a Crop of Lean, Green Machines
description: GASOLINE costs far less than designer water, and while Americans say in surveys that they want cleaner, more fuel-efficient vehicles, they are buying record numbers of gas-chugging trucks, which pollute more than cars do.. So is there any reason to fear for the future of the internal-combustion vehicle?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, THOMAS M.
description: WYMAN-Thomas M. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 19, 1998 at 5:00PM at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street, New York. Contributions may be made to the Panwy Foundation, 10 Valley Drive-9 Greenwich Office Park, Greenwich, CT. 06831.

title: There All Along
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: LOST LANDSCAPES In Search of Isaac Bashevis Singer and the Jews of Poland. By Agata Tuszynska. Morrow, $23.

title: The Ski Mogul's Risky Run
description: The cheap champagne is chilling in the brisk Vermont air as the new $5 million enclosed-cab gondola lift at Killington -- the largest ski area in New England -- gets prepped for its first run with a load of skiers. The guy who owns the place is waiting on the lift deck, but he's not holding court. No, Les Otten, skiing's most audacious deal maker, is smack in the middle of an impromptu bucket brigade, grunting and grinning as he humps sandbags -- stand-ins for live bodies during the lift's final safety check -- in front of a crowd of 200 anxious skiers chanting the lift's name, ''K-1, K-1, K-1!''

title: Welcome Mat Is Out at Home of Atlantic City's Founding Father
description: In 1820, Jonathan Pitney graduated from Columbia Medical School and moved into a 1799 house in the village of Absecon, hoping to establish a medical practice among the local fishermen and farmers.

title: Awakenings
description: CONQUERING SCHIZOPHRENIA

title: Surprises in Fur
description: Blond fur coats, left, seemed perfectly timed for the mild winter. The honey color is achieved through fur farmers' crossbreeding and bleaching their pelts. Even the stable black cloth coat, far right, is lavishly lined in honey-colored Mongolian lamb. Some of the coats, like the ones at far left and right, are styled with a 1920's silhouette, deep shawl collar, buttonless wrap closing and low calf length. A second surprise was the revival of costly Russian broadtail, below, a perishable fur pelt suitable for mild climates.

title: Sports of The Times; The 30-Second Weave Is Not for Everybody
description: YESTERDAY, John Rogers rooted from afar as his alma mater, Princeton, extended Michigan State before losing, 63-56. Last weekend, Rogers played Princeton-style basketball for himself.

title: The Hill Where Elitists and Populists Meet
description: IT takes too long to get up the hill. There isn't enough parking for everyone. People are confused about the layout. There is no contemporary art. The white is too white. The complaints you hear around the J. Paul Getty Center are complaints about elitism, the inherent snobbishness of a big white compound high above the grit and smog of Los Angeles.

title: If Squirrels Hibernate, What's in My Backyard?
description: I was both astonished and very puzzled to read David Boucher's Feb. 8 article [''A Step for World Peace, Breakfast for All'']. According to him, sensible creatures, such as squirrels, hibernate in the cold months.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Feb. 22 with an article about Saratoga Springs showed the city's library at an outdated location. It is now at 49 Henry Street, north of Phila Street. (The location given, 320 Broadway, is now the Saratoga Arts Center.)

title: Theft Silences a Sitar Player
description: The thief who broke into Daisy Paradis's van did not make off with anything famous. But Ms. Paradis hopes that someone will remember that thief because of the eye-catching color, size and shape of what was stolen: a chocolate-brown case the size of a coffee table but shaped like a barbell. Inside was the sitar that Ms. Paradis bought 30 years ago for $175 and that she estimates is worth $3,000. She is offering a $400 reward for its return.

title: Q&A/Steven Schiff; Up Front and Personal With the Homeless
description: THERE was a time in his life when Steven Schiff was occasionally involved with evicting people from their homes. But today he makes his money when people buy homes. Together, those facts explain why Mr. Schiff now gets great satisfaction in helping the homeless, or people at risk of becoming so.

title: Nature Groups Support Farmers' Bid to Raise Milk Prices
description: For years, environmentalists have been among the most ardent critics of New York's dairy farmers, accusing them of fouling the state's rivers and streams with pesticides, manure and other waste.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, RICHARD WARREN
description: LEWIS-Richard Warren, 65. Of Hancock, NH, formerly of Bel Air, CA, and NYC, on March 12th, 1998. Loving husband of Glenda Edwards Lewis, brother of Dr. Valerie Lewis Mankoff of Kinnelon, NJ, uncle of James Lewis, Richard Wiener and Jennifer Lynn. Contributions to the ALS Foundation, Donations Dept., Suite 200, 100 N. Brand Blvd., Glendale, CA. 91203.

title: No One Rushing in Oregon To Use a New Suicide Law
description: Five months after becoming the only place in the world to have legal doctor-assisted suicide, Oregon has produced a detailed manual on how doctors can end a life, and the state has decided that taxpayers should pay for it when the patient is poor.

title: Brooklyn Faces Resurface In Photos From The Eagles
description: THE old Brooklyn Eagle is gone, and so are Ebbets Field and the Dodgers. But all of them resurface in a photography show titled ''The Weird, the Wonderful and the Merely Mundane'' at the Brooklyn Public Library.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, MARELA
description: RUBEN-Marela. Mother of Fran, Maier and Betsey. Grandmother of seven, great grandmother of 11. Funeral 10:30 Sunday March 15, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry.

title: How to Complain
description: To the Editor: Speaking of ''How to Argue With Airlines'' (Practical Traveler, Feb. 8), I had two unpleasant airline experiences that took perseverance to resolve:

title: Thieves Methodically Strip Iraq Of Treasures From a Storied Past
description: A little over a year ago, in a brazen act of vandalism becoming very familiar here, thieves struck the ruins of this ancient temple city, once the capital of a mysterious kingdom whose people worshiped the Sun, the Moon and Mars. The thieves were discriminating. They lopped off the head from a priceless, recently restored statue of a king 18 centuries old.

title: Where Jugglers of All Ages Practice
description: THE balls whirled in front of 12-year-old Michael Fleder as if they had a life of their own, but in fact, Michael's deft hands controlled their orbit.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORWITZ, SIDNEY
description: HORWITZ-Sidney. On March 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Joyce Cummings Horwitz. Devoted father of Michael S. Horwitz. Loving grandfather of Jesse and Alec. Dear brother of Estelle Kessler. Funeral service Monday, 10 AM, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : California Bar Owner Becomes Butt Of the State's No-Smoking Statute
description: A bar owner in Auburn, California, has been convicted of two infractions for allowing patrons to light up in violation of the new state anti-smoking law. It was apparently the first such trial under the law that bans smoking in more than 35,000 bars and casinos. The owner, Bill Ostrander, was fined a total of $300

title: William Goodrich, 82, Lawyer And Advocate for Food Safety
description: William W. Goodrich, a lawyer and pioneering advocate of food and pharmaceutical safety procedures died Tuesday at Arlington Hospital in Arlington, Va., of complications from lymphoma. He was 82 and lived in Arlington.

title: Political Briefing; From Stars and Bars To Straights and Pairs
description: Facing re-election this year, Gov. David Beasley of South Carolina figures his most pressing need is to heal the political divisions that linger from his widely noted but unsuccessful 1996 crusade to remove the Confederate flag flying atop the capitol in Columbia. So he has embarked on a new crusade.

title: Mets Search for Ideal One-Two Punch in Order
description: Bobby Valentine blanches when he is asked who the top two hitters in his batting order are going to be this season.

title: INSIDE
description: A Mall for the Meadowlands

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENGARDEN, RALPH
description: ROSENGARDEN - Ralph. The Board of Governors and Members of the Boca Rio Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Mr. Ralph Rosengarden, beloved husband of Ardath. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family. Boca Rio Golf Club Norman Ricken, President

title: Wait Till Next Year? Not, Sadly, for Princeton
description: The numbing realization enveloped Princeton's players after Michigan State dribbled away the final, awful seconds of the Spartans' 63-56 victory on Saturday. Steve Goodrich put his hands on his knees, bent over and closed his eyes. Mitch Henderson, stone-faced until the end, stared long and hard at the bitter result on the scoreboard. James Mastaglio untucked his uniform jersey for the last time and marched to the locker room, smiling Spartans beside him.

title: United Nations Bill Is Bargain for U.S.; Eroded Credibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKIN, ALBERT
description: ELKIN-Albert. Beloved husband of Pearl. Roberta, Edward, Meredith, and Jed Weiner mourn the loss of their father and grandfather. Friends are welcome at home on Tuesday evening and Wednesday. Private interment Tuesday.

title: Treasury's Schedule Offers Bill Auction
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Peterka Prevails
description: Primoz Peterka of Slovenia won the World Cup ski jump at Holmenkollen, Norway, yesterday with a 0.02 point margin over Bruno Reuteler of Switzerland.

title: A Brooklyn Man Is Missing, And a Family's Search Begins
description: Family, friends and neighbors have taken to the streets to search for a 21-year-old Brooklyn man who went to work last Tuesday, went out for drinks afterward at a neighborhood bar, stopped at a friend's house and then never made it home.

title: The Value of History
description: When John F. Kennedy worked in the White House, doodling on notepads and dictating questions, there was no system set up to capture the flow of paper that recorded the President's state of mind. There was only his devoted secretary, Evelyn Lincoln. She squirreled things away, obsessively. But no one from the National Archives followed around. When Kennedy was murdered, the Oval Office files were sealed for a time. Two years later, the President's widow and trustees issued a deed of trust for his estate, donating to the archives and the Kennedy Presidential Library the paper and effects ''which he intended should be deposited,'' and retaining for the family ''such items as John Fitzgerald Kennedy had not intended to be deposited. . . .''

title: The Simpsons and their progeny colonize television in a golden era for animation.
description: AS everyone knows, television viewers are growing increasingly sophisticated and are demanding ever more thoughtful shows from an expanding number of channels. And so, as the networks look for ways to appeal to our high-mindedness, they have latched on to a new tool: a flood of animated shows.

title: Documentaries Are Jumping From the Small Screen to Bookstores
description: Although the TV-watching public has long been familiar with shows based on high-quality books, few readers have looked to television to produce good written works.

title: Patents; An inexpensive way to regenerate arthritis-damaged cartilage in knees and hips.
description: ARTHRITIS can irreversibly damage joints, causing such deterioration in knees and hips that they have to be replaced with artificial ones.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Metro Matters; Public Toilets: Finding Relief Is Still a Quest
description: ''I know that I am in distress when I walk the streets of New York. Wondering constantly where the next stop will be and if I can hold out that long.''

title: Jeanette Wakin, 69; Taught Mideastern Culture
description: Jeanette Wakin, an expert in the arcane world of medieval Islamic law, died on Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 69 and was a senior lecturer at Columbia University, where she had long been a mainstay in the department of Middle Eastern and Asian language and culture.

title: Haitians Striving to Muster Political Clout
description: Meeting recently in a private home in Uniondale on Long Island, a group of Haitian clergy members, radio personalities and grass-roots organizers set for themselves a simple but momentous goal: electing the first Haitian-American to political office.

title: Brooklyn Team Sets Record
description: Boys and Girls High School of Brooklyn set a national indoor record in the boys' 3,200-meter relay today to highlight the National Scholastic Indoor Track and Field Championships here.

title: Fighting Over the Ugliest Wilderness; Developer's Megamall Plan Forces Decision on Meadowlands' Future
description: For generations, travelers have usually rushed past the Meadowlands, barely acknowledging its long, flat marshes, the acres and acres of tall, brown reeds bowing low in the wind, the murky waters and, more recently, the unnatural peaks of former garbage dumps, the squat warehouses and vapid office parks.

title: Administration Cuts Affirmative Action While Defending It
description: While it continues to defend Federal affirmative action programs in Congress and the courts, the Clinton Administration has, during the last two years, conducted the most sweeping reduction of those measures since they were instituted during the Nixon Administration.

title: Memories, Most Bitter, Of a Lane In Limerick
description: You've read the book? Now see the television program. Inspired by ''Angela's Ashes,'' his Uncle Frank's account of growing up in Depression Ireland, which has become entrenched high on best-seller lists, Conor McCourt brings together the four McCourt brothers in an hour of reminiscence and reflection, sing-along and gab about growing up in the lanes of Limerick.

title: Donald Joyce, 45, Organist and Music Director
description: Donald Joyce, an organist whose expansive repertory ranged from Renaissance and Baroque works by Spanish, Portuguese and Mexican composers to recent scores by Philip Glass, died on Tuesday at the home of his sister, Virginia Keil, in North Brunswick, N.J. Mr. Joyce was 45 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Official's Arrest Puzzles South Africa
description: The big mystery in South Africa these days is: What was Robert McBride really doing in Mozambique?

title: Ogilvy One Takes Marketing Honors
description: Ogilvy One Worldwide took top honors, winning the most awards, at the 20th annual presentation of the John Caples International Awards for direct marketing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JOEL H.
description: GOLDMAN-Joel H. On March 13, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Isabelle; devoted father of Carol and Dr. Michael Slippen, Ronni and Peter Rosenberg. Dear brother of Florence and Murray Duitz and Edward and the late Muriel Segall; loving grandfather of Jeffrey, Marc, Daniel and Aimee. Services and interment were held March 15, 1998.

title: Abroad at Home; Remember 1991
description: One of the worst mistakes of United States foreign policy in recent years was the failure to stand up to Slobodan Milosevic in 1991, when the Serbian tyrant began his brutal military adventures. Croats, Bosnians and the Serbs themselves paid a terrible price.

title: Walters, and His Brother's Memory, Lead Wadleigh to P.S.A.L. Championship
description: After every basket he scored in yesterday's Public Schools Athletic League B championship game at Madison Square Garden, Marc Walters of Wadleigh patted down his white shorts.

title: Excerpts From the Clinton Deposition in Jones Sexual Misconduct Suit
description: Following are excerpts from the deposition of President Clinton in connection with Paula Corbin Jones's lawsuit against him. He was questioned on Jan. 17 at the Washington offices of his lawyer, Robert S. Bennett; the transcript was made public on Friday by lawyers for Ms. Jones.

title: United Nations Bill Is Bargain for U.S.; A Plan on Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Aetna Deal for New York Life's Health Unit Is Expected Today
description: Aetna Inc., the giant health insurer, is expected to announce today that it is buying the health care business of the New York Life Insurance Company for $1.05 billion in cash.

title: 1998 N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: SECOND ROUND -- WEST; Bit of History for Harvard: 16th-Seeded Club Advances
description: There were no words. Not for the winner, and certainly not for the loser.

title: After Staggering for a Bit, Duke Swaggers Into Round 3
description: For only the third time, Duke is a No. 1-seeded team in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Yet the Blue Devils are neither a veteran unit nor a finished product. They rely heavily on four underclassmen among their top seven players, and remain very much a work in progress.

title: Sports of The Times; Interim Coach Hopes To Survive El Nino
description: THE national tournament may be great for fans, but these games are absolute murder on coaches. Pressures of all sorts descend on winners and losers alike, as 20-year-olds reach unpredictable highs and lows with each possession.

title: French Leftists Surge in Regional Elections
description: The leftist parties of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's nine-month-old Government coalition knocked the conservative opposition out of power in about half of France's 22 regional assemblies in light voting today across the country, computer projections based on exit polls indicated.

title: To Avoid Floods, Let Wetlands Return
description: To the Editor:

title: Royalty in Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORF, PAULA
description: KORF-Paula. Beloved wife of the late Norman. Loving mother of Gene and the late Gary. Kind mother-in-law to Madeline. Cherished grandmother of Scott and Neil. Devoted sister of Max Heller.

title: Bill to Push Africa Trade Is Approved
description: In approving a broad trade bill with Africa last week, the House gave President Clinton an important carrot to bring on his trip to the continent later this month.

title: SOUTH'S EMBRACE OF G.O.P. IS NEAR A TURNING POINT
description: One by one, they have fallen. During the last three decades, each of the once solidly Democratic states of the old Confederacy have elected Republican governors; each, that is, except Georgia.

title: Israel Calls British Aide's Visit To Disputed Site Unacceptable
description: The Israeli Government declared today that the British Foreign Secretary's intention to visit the site of a disputed new Jewish settlement in eastern Jerusalem this week was ''unacceptable,'' raising the possibility that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu would refuse to see him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERDELL, JOHN B.
description: ERDELL-John B. On March 9, 1998. Professor of Design and Photography at State University of New York, Farmingdale Division. Beloved husband of Paquita. Loving brother of Lillian Erdell and Evelyn Reagan. Services at the Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street, NYC, Thursday, March 19, 1998, 11AM.

title: While Its Offense Struggles, Syracuse Wins With Defense
description: At first glance, a team adept at making 3-pointers should have a field day against a team that insists on employing a zone defense.

title: Connecticut Holds Off Colonials To Advance
description: Of the four No. 1-seeded teams in the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament, two have lost -- Stanford to Harvard on Saturday night and Texas Tech to Notre Dame tonight. Meanwhile, Connecticut, a No. 2-seeded team that thought it should have been a No. 1, kept winning tonight. But the Huskies made it difficult for themselves.

title: When Rutgers Pleaded, Young Came Through
description: Tomora Young could feel her back stiffening after she slammed into a courtside table while going for a loose ball on Saturday. The Rutgers junior guard limped around for about a minute, then had to leave the game against Oregon.

title: Political Briefing; Battle Over Abortion Fought in the States
description: While Congress struggles over what to do about abortions -- when they should be authorized, what procedures should be allowed, what role a mother's health should play -- out in the states abortion opponents continue their efforts to persuade legislatures to chip away at abortion rights. And defenders of those rights are pushing back with equal vigor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYSANEK, LEONIE
description: RYSANEK - Leonie. Beloved opera singer on March 7, 1998 in Vienna. Funeral Tuesday, March 17, at 3:30 PM at Dr. Karl LuegerGedachtniskirsche, Wiener Zentralfriedhof. Donations may be made to Leonie Rysanek Fund, c/o The George London Foundation, 515 East 79th St, NY 10021, to be used to help young singers.

title: HINDU BLOC GAINS WEAK GRIP ON HELM
description: The long wait for power by India's main Hindu nationalist party ended today with a formal invitation to establish a Government, but the circumstances appeared to leave the party little room for the Hindu supremacist policies that are anathema to the country's 120 million Muslims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAKIN, JEANETTE ANN
description: WAKIN-Jeanette Ann. On March 13, 1998, at 69. Professor of Arabic and Islamic Studies at Columbia University and renowned expert on Islamic law. Dedicated to her field, to scholarship, to her students, to her friends, she gave unstintingly to all. Those who knew her were touched by her warmth and vitality. She was a central figure in the scholarly activity of Arabist and Islamicist throughout the United States and abroad in her roles, for twenty years, as editor of the Islamic section of the Journal of the American Oriental Society and chair of the Columbia University Seminar on Arabic studies. Known for her intellectual rigor and high academic standards, she trained generations of scholars around the world and overflowed with humanity for the people around her. She was a strong advocate of social justice and worked to protect the victims of war in Lebanon and, most recently, Bosnia. She loved New York City, where she lived for nearly 50 years, and made an eternal mark on the hearts of her loving family, son Daniel Wakin and daughter-in-law Vera Haller of Rome, Italy; sister Mary Lou Wakin of Manhattan; brother Joseph Wakin and sister-in-law Louise Wakin of Stamford, CT. She lived to embrace and love her two grandchildren, Thomas, 4, and Michael, 7 months. Family will be receiving on March 18, 2-5 PM, and 7-9 PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral March 19, 10 AM, Church of the Virgin Mary, Brooklyn, 8th Avenue and 2nd Street. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Community of Bosnia Foundation, c/o Michael Sells, Department of Religion, Haverford College, Haverford, PA 19041-1392.

title: Excerpts From Interview Of Willey on '60 Minutes'
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Kathleen E. Willey by Ed Bradley on the CBS News program ''60 Minutes,'' which was broadcast last night. After Ms. Willey repeated her account of an encounter with President Clinton at the White House in 1993, in which she says that Mr. Clinton made an unwanted sexual advance, she went on to talk about her state of mind and about what has happened to her subsequently. A transcript of the interview was provided by CBS News.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: 3 Agencies Form Specialized Divisions
description: Three agencies have formed new divisions in health care advertising, product development and strategic consulting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPONE, THERESA (TESS)
description: CAPONE-Theresa (Tess). On March 14, 1998. Dearest wife of Dino. Sister of Mary Elizabeth Garren and her niece Janet of El Cajon, CA. Rest in peace. Reposing Albert R. Conner-Colonial Funeral Home, 4955 Broadway (at West 207th St), Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Elizabeth's, Wednesday, 10 AM.

title: Stevens for the Defense
description: It is an old debate in hockey circles.

title: No Winners in Gay Scout Case; Missed Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Desert Nomads Changed The World With the Word
description: THE GIFTS OF THE JEWS

title: With Goto.com's Search Engine, the Highest Bidder Shall Be Ranked First
description: In the world of Internet search services, finding just the right business model is proving as elusive as finding an entirely relevant list of search results. But the effort can be seen on the Web sites of all the industry's most familiar names.

title: Bach's Life in Six Suites As Presented by Yo-Yo Ma
description: If the greatest music ever written is not ''St. Matthew Passion'' by Bach, then it must be his works for unaccompanied string instruments. (But stay tuned for whatever Bach happens to come along next week.) Just as the ''St. Matthew,'' for all its monumentality, can seem the most personal and quietly touching of utterances, so the cello suites, in the hands of a master, can seem the grandest and most eloquent of statements without losing any of their intimacy.

title: Priest Kicks Intruder From Apartment Window
description: A retired priest caught a thief trying to climb into a window of his second-floor apartment in upper Manhattan early yesterday morning and kicked the man back out the window, causing him to fall to the pavement and break his ankle, the police said.

title: The Knicks Find Some Energy, but Can't Keep Up With Jackson at the End
description: It had been such a perfect setting for the return of the old, colorful John Starks, the one who seemed to have been prodded out of his recent trance by the appearance of Reggie Miller in front of him and the Garden crowd behind him. But Mark Jackson stepped into Starks's scene last night.

title: Decades After Midlife Mark, A Frontier for Mental Health
description: In 1905, when Sigmund Freud was 49, he declared that people over 50 could gain little from psychoanalysis. ''Near or above the age of 50, the elasticity of the mental processes on which treatment depends is, as a rule, lacking,'' he wrote. ''Old people are no longer educable.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPLER, BERTHA A.
description: KEMPLER-Bertha A. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Harriet Rosenberg and Michael Kempler. Cherished grandmother of George, Jamie, Robert, Ricky and Amanda. Adored great-grandmother of Jeffrey, Rachel and Andrew. Dear mother-in-law of Dr. Barry Rosenberg and Lois Kempler. We will miss you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, SUSANNE WILLIAMS
description: CLARK-Susanne Williams. Born July 21, 1935, in Kansas City, MO. Died peacefully after a courageous battle with esophageal cancer at Calvary Hospital on Friday, March 13. She graduated from Randolph-Macon Women's College in Lynchburg, VA in 1957. Since then she has lived in Manhattan where she had a career in advertising and airline sales. Following a laryngectomy operation in 1986, she devoted much of her life to the rehabilitation of those who had lost their voices. She was an active volunteer in Memorial Sloan-Kettering's patient-to-patient program and currently served as Secretary of the International Association of Laryngectomies. She was preceded in death by her loving husband, James G. Clark. She will be sorely missed by her family and her many devoted friends all over the country who were uplifted by her lively artistry on the piano and her warm and unique humor. She is survived by her brother, Dr. Tom Williams and his wife, Elizabeth, of Etowah, TN. Survived also by a niece, Alison Coulson and three nephews, Murray Williams, Stephen K. Williams and Tommy Williams. There will be a memorial service at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, at 2 PM, on Thursday, March 19, with the Rev. John A. Calhoun officiating. Friends are welcome at Rita Bell's immediately following the service. Interment will be the following day at Moravian Cemetery on Staten Island.

title: Boeing and Lockheed Have a Pact On Supplies
description: A month before the Government expressed opposition to the merger of the Lockheed Martin Corporation and the Northrop Grumman Corporation, Lockheed signed an agreement with the Boeing Company intended to prevent the problems the Government is worried about.

title: Racial Reading List Would Deprive Students
description: To the Editor:

title: An Exciting If Little Noticed A.B.L. Finals
description: The Columbus Quest defeated the Long Beach StingRays, 86-81, to win a second American Basketball League title tonight, concluding a tournament in which March madness had more to do with scheduling than with anticipation.

title: 300 Concerts Are Planned At New York Jazz Festival
description: The Knitting Factory announced the schedule for the Texaco New York Jazz Festival for 1998 today, and, as has been the trend, it is larger and more ambitious than ever, with over 300 concerts between June 1 and June 14.

title: Purdue Blasts Detroit And Roars Into St. Louis
description: After his team beat Western Michigan in the Midwest Regional this afternoon, Stanford Coach Mike Montgomery said he was going to stick around the United Center and watch the second game between Purdue and Detroit. The Cardinal would face the winner of that game on Friday in St. Louis.

title: United Nations Bill Is Bargain for U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: DiCaprio, Charismatic Star, Balks at the Idol Image
description: Ask the top talent agents or studio executives or producers for the name of the biggest star in town. It's not Tom Cruise or Mel Gibson or Harrison Ford. The answer is one word: Leo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILHAUPT, CHARLES
description: MILHAUPT-Charles. March 13, 1998. Son of Mary Thomas and the late Arthur Milhaupt, Jr. Brother of Gretchen Milhaupt, Merimee Moffitt, Tony Milhaupt and Ann Bottinelli. Memorial service Saturday, March 21, 1998, 2 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street). Reception immediately following at Gansevoort Gallery, 72 Gansevoort St. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, N.Y.C. 10013.

title: Network of Volunteers Acts as Tornado Alarm
description: When Patricia Cooper, a meteorologist, wants to get the attention of her audience of volunteer weather spotters, she shows them a videotape made by two men from the National Weather Service who chased a tornado through a town in Texas.

title: Updates: Media and Technology; For Variety, A New York State of Mind
description: Two new faces in journalism will have their debuts this week.

title: Taking In the Sites; Tuning Into the Music of Developing Nations
description: Once upon a time, before the Internet had pictures and was all the rage, Quincy Jones, the music impresario, sat with William H. Gates, the computer magnate, at a technology conference, talking about the future. The year was 1992, and the conversation was a melding of the two titans' respective passions: the preservation of musical cultures and the nascent on-line universe that would become cyberspace.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I thought, 'Well, maybe I ought to just give him a good slap across the face.' And then I thought, 'Well, I don't think you can slap the President of the United States like that.' And -- and I just decided it was just time to get out of there.''

title: My Lai, And Its Omens
description: Thirty years ago today the 100 men of Charlie Company, assigned to Task Force Barker of the Americal Division's 11th Infantry Brigade, were flown by helicopters to the edge of a small Vietnamese hamlet named My Lai 4. There was no enemy there and, over the next few hours, the G.I.'s, including William L. Calley Jr., a platoon leader, systematically murdered all the women, children and old men they could find. At least 350 civilians were slain.

title: Study Finds Less Traditional News as Outlets Seek More 'Relevant' Content
description: For some time, media watchdogs have complained that the news media have become more interested in human interest and celebrity journalism than in news about politics, international affairs and social policy. Now a study of news coverage over the last 20 years has documented this shift but says it is not entirely a bad thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELLER, PETER
description: FELLER-Peter. Died March 13, 1998, in Melbourne, FL, at age 78. Loving husband of Katherine. Devoted brother to Dr. Elizabeth Feller and Mrs. Dorothy Lohmann. Loving father of Peter Feller and daughter-in-law Lynn Feller, Philip Feller and daughter-in-law Gail Feller, and proud grandfather of Katherine, Sky, and Simone. Peter Feller was production supervisor and builder of scenery for thousands of Broadway shows, industrial projects, and arena tours over the last five decades. He became a valued friend to many of the leading designers, directors, playwrights and producers in the theatre industry. He will be remembered with great love by his family, friends and colleagues. Plans for a memorial service at Broadway's Winter Garden Theatre will be announced soon. For those who wish to make a contribution in memory of Peter Feller, the family suggests the Henegar Theatre Center, 625 East New Haven, Melbourne, FL 32901.

title: Charter Schools Said to Raise Pupils' Performance on Tests
description: A report to be released today by a group that supports charter schools says that most of the best such schools it surveyed met, and sometimes surpassed, their promises to raise academic achievement.

title: Political Briefing; A Biting Battle On Paramilitary Groups
description: Roughly half the states now have laws governing the private paramilitary groups that have proliferated in recent years, sometimes violently. But not Colorado.

title: Market Place; Buffett, in his annual message to investors, says the fishing was tough in stocks last year.
description: WARREN BUFFETT, a man who built his reputation by buying stocks that were destined to soar, says he is having a hard time finding new investments that look cheap. So he has been selling some of the huge stock portfolio he built over the decades.

title: Editorial Observer; 'Primary Colors': Hollywood Offers an Apology
description: When the book ''Primary Colors'' appeared in early 1996, it seemed like a sleazy parody of President Clinton's 1992 campaign. Now, here comes the movie ''Primary Colors,'' and suddenly it feels like an apology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYRE, ANNE
description: SAYRE-Anne. Beloved wife of David Sayre; writer, justice, and beloved friend of many others. Funeral service Tuesday, 11 AM at St. James Episcopal Church, St. James, Long Island.

title: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings Scheduled
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Desperate Times
description: It has come to this for the Rangers: beat the Ottawa Senators tonight at Madison Square Garden or forget about the playoffs.

title: No Winners in Gay Scout Case; Seeking Inclusion
description: To the Editor:

title: So Steeped In Blood: A Couple On the Edge
description: The Macbeths, tragedy's most popular partners in regicide, have never been what you would call a laid-back couple. Killing a king requires energy and focus, and it certainly takes its toll on a marriage, not to mention good sleeping habits. Still, you may be unprepared for the dizzy heights of anxiety scaled by the power-lusting spouses in George C. Wolfe's new take on Shakespeare's Scottish play. As portrayed by Alec Baldwin and Angela Bassett, the marquee-glamorizing stars of the production that opened last night at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, Macbeth and his highly motivated lady are never close to being cool conspirators. Their nerves are hamburger before any ghastly deed is done, and hamburger they remain.

title: Valparaiso and Rhode Island Make Upsets a Family Business
description: A grown son hopping onto a basketball court into the joyous arms of his father. That scene was played out twice here in the Midwest Region, barely three hours apart. The transformation into National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament Cinderella was strictly family business.

title: I.N.S. Fee Increases
description: To the Editor:

title: Shifting Winds Upstage New Flight Pattern at Newark Airport
description: Day One of the new flight pattern at Newark International Airport began much as any other. In the Arlington section of Staten Island, which was supposed to see a drop in aircraft noise, Peg Cebula got what she refers to as her usual morning wake-up call: The bottles on her windowsills rattled and banged when a jet passed overhead.

title: China's New Premier: Fast Riser Who Tamed Economy in Chaos
description: Zhu Rongji, who is expected to be chosen as Prime Minister of China on Tuesday, is a career Communist planner whose meteoric rise to power has been driven largely by the sheer force of his achievements.

title: Pitfalls Loom in Possible Merger of Two Exchanges
description: The announcement of the prospective merger of the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq stock market makes it sound so alluring.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NORTON, THOMAS E.
description: NORTON-Thomas E. Friends of Tom are invited to gather in the Main Auction Room at Sotheby's, 1334 York Avenue, at 72nd St., on Wednesday, March 18, 6:30PM to celebrate his life and contributions to the art world. This informal gathering will be followed by a reception at the Galleries. All who knew him are welcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, JACOB
description: EPSTEIN-Jacob. 94, at home. Jake left us March 10, to join Ruth, his beloved wife, companion, and comrade. Nieces, nephews, and countless friends will miss him always. A lifelong social activist, Jake went to Spain with the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. He was a translator, talented designer, lover of the arts, and loyal friend. To the end, Jake remained himselfsharp and smart, talking politics and quoting Shakespeare. Goodbye Jake, we love you.

title: A Warm Marriage of Art and Athletics on Ice
description: Madison Square Garden was packed on Saturday night for ''Discover Stars on Ice,'' now in its 12th touring season. It is a hybrid show, accenting both the athletic and the artistic and as such, one of the best on the rink.

title: Racial Reading List Would Deprive Students; Battle of the Colas
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Cleric Among nominees to Replace Newark Bishop
description: An openly gay cleric has been chosen as one of five nominees to succeed the Rt. Rev. John S. Spong as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, diocesan officials said yesterday. If elected eventually, he would be the first openly homosexual bishop of the 2.5 million-member Episcopal Church in America.

title: Fringe Figure in Case Takes Center Stage, and Some Question Her Story
description: With her testimony in the Paula Jones case and appearance tonight on the CBS News program ''60 Minutes,'' Kathleen E. Willey has suddenly become a pivotal figure in the controversies swirling around President Clinton.

title: The Aftermath of a Wild Derby Day
description: Lil's Lad was tired but sound; Cape Town was tired but redeemed. Mike Smith was hurting; Jerry Bailey was angry. And all of them, leading players on the wildest Florida Derby day in decades, were hoping to play leading roles on the grandest day of the racing year: May 2, the day of the Kentucky Derby.

title: No Winners in Gay Scout Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Policy Held Hostage
description: House Republican leaders flaunt their disregard for America's broader interests by letting anti-abortion crusaders hold up funding for the International Monetary Fund and the United Nations. The money is being held hostage to an obnoxious amendment by Representative Christopher Smith of New Jersey that would block American financing of any foreign group lobbying for less restrictive abortion laws abroad. President Clinton rightly threatens to veto any bill with the Smith language.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Giuliani Says Extra Police Are Not Needed for Parade
description: Expressing confidence that drunken St. Patrick's Day revelers can be kept under control tomorrow, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and city police officials said yesterday that there were no plans to increase the number of officers policing the annual cavalcade up Fifth Avenue, which was marred last year by fighting that left a high-school student dead.

title: Taxing Sales on the Internet: Many Governors vs. Congressional Legislation
description: Buoyed by White House support and facing only tepid opposition from the nation's governors, Silicon Valley has state and local tax collectors on the defensive: Congress is on the verge of passing legislation that would effectively bar sales taxes on Internet transactions until 2004.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Public Radio Hosts Drop In and Maybe Stay Too Long
description: For almost 20 years, since its debut in 1979, Bob Edwards has presided over the National Public Radio news magazine ''Morning Edition.'' But from the start, the soothing, avuncular tone that is Mr. Edwards's trademark raised certain questions.

title: Highway Link Opposed By Environmentalists
description: A Federal District Court judge is scheduled to hear arguments today from a coalition of environmental groups seeking to block the construction of a 1.7-mile-long highway along the city's last section of riverfront parkland.

title: Essay; The Real NATO Issue
description: An irresponsible Harvard astronomer (who could not be bothered to check out his cockamamie calculations with other scientists) last week fed media appetites for stories of impending doom. Alarmists had a one-day field day.

title: Classic Contest for G.O.P.: Conservative vs. Moderate
description: For a Republican Party mapping a strategy to unseat United States Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, it seemed that Loleta Didrickson, a moderate who supports abortion rights, had come straight from political central casting.

title: Richard Plant, Holocaust Scholar, Critic and Literature Professor, 87
description: Richard Plant, a teacher, a writer and a scholar of the Holocaust, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMBERLIN, W. MACY
description: CHAMBERLIN-W. Macy. On March 13, in Florida, in his 98th year. Beloved husband of Irma Morell. Father of Kate deForest Johnson and Judith Macy Stroud. He is also survived by six grandchildren and 15 great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to All Souls Church, Onteora Park, Tannersville, NY 12485, or the Irma and Macy Chamberlin Scholarship Fund, c/o W. Macy Johnson, 90 Park Ave, NYC 10016.

title: States Appear Ready to Raise Their Spending on Education
description: Lawmakers in many states are negotiating budgets that include substantial increases in education spending in response to a strong economy, widespread concern about the quality of public schools and, in some cases, court decisions requiring new systems of school financing.

title: Critics Gather to Say Uniforms Shouldn't Be Forced on Pupils
description: A small group of parents, students and civil libertarians gathered yesterday in front of Stuyvesant High School in TriBeCa to denounce the Board of Education's proposal to require uniforms for elementary school students. They called the plan sexist and un-American, and said it was a costly ploy to divert attention from the more pressing ills of the city's schools.

title: Jeter Makes An Adjustment In His Swing
description: Believe it or not, there has been more to Derek Jeter's spring training than contract talks and dinner with Mariah Carey. Teen-age girls who coo his name each time he comes to bat may not care, but he has made a major alteration to his swing, and he is driving the ball more.

title: The Clinton Testimony
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones, who has accused President Clinton of sexual harassment when he was Governor of Arkansas, filed 700 pages of court documents in Little Rock on Friday. Included was a transcript of the President's Jan. 17 deposition in the case. Because of technical problems, excerpts from this testimony in The Times on Saturday were truncated or duplicated; a corrected transcript appears on pages A18-A20.

title: Digital Film Restoration Raises Questions About Fixing Flaws
description: If one looks closely at the opening credits of ''Gone With The Wind,'' one might see a flagpole that is not really attached to the building from which it is jutting. The flaw results from a crude 1930's special effect, combining a real flagpole with a painting of a building.

title: Giuliani and Council Want to Cut a Tax, but Not the Same One
description: With New York City government awash in cash for the second year in a row, the talk in City Hall revolves around cutting taxes. The question is which one to cut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOWITZ, PAULINE
description: MOSKOWITZ-Pauline. 90. Loving wife of the late Jack Moskowitz. Devoted mother of Eugene Morse, wife Gladys, Sherril Ambinder Sussman, husband Jay, Seymour Morse, Sue Ross, husband Dr. Sonny Ross. Dearest sister of Edna Sweder, brother-in-law Dr. William Sweder, sister-in-law of Rae Greenberg, and sister of late Harry Greenberg. Loving grandmother, adored great-grandmother, and cherished aunt. Pauline will be sadly missed for the love and understanding of her Jewish heritage. Her favorite ''Yiddishisms'' will be forever remembered. Always in our hearts, ''Ayshes Chayil.'' Services held Tuesday, 1:30 PM, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIER, SARA (UDISKY)
description: BRIER-Sara (Udisky). March 14, 1998. Wife of late Benjamin Brier and late Judge Maurice Robinson. Resident of Providence, RI. Mother of Dottie Brier, NYC; Phyllis Berry, Providence, RI; Milton Brier, Saunderstown, RI; and late Shirley Brier Lewis. Sister of Mina Rosen, Providence, RI. Grandmother of nine grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.

title: Sergeant Major's Accusers Fault Excess Army Loyalty
description: Until a few days ago, Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney's accusers had never seen one another except in the blurry sketches of courtroom artists.

title: Musicians on Broadway To Vote on a Contract
description: Officials of the union representing Broadway's musicians are to meet with negotiators for producers and theater owners tomorrow to continue working out the final language of a tentative agreement on a new five-year contract. The agreement could be put to a vote of the members as early as next week, the officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACLEAN, ALEXANDER G., JR.
description: MacLEAN-Alexander G., Jr. Age 73, died Friday, March 13, 1998, after a short illness. He was born in Chicago and lived in Ridgewood, NJ, for 26 years. He attended the Illinois Institute of Technology and began a lifelong career in the textile industry and retired from his position as National Sales Manager for Stonecutter Mills Corp. of NYC in 1994. Prior to his working at Stonecutter he was the General Manager for Textile Piece Dye of Paterson, NJ, and before that he was the Vice President of Sales for Rayflex, Inc., of NYC, and subsequently the President of the Rayflex Division of the Wyomissing Corp. of Reading, PA. He began his textile career at Ansonia O & C Co. of Connecticut. He had served as a member of the 503rd Airborne Division in the Pacific during World War II and he was a Trustee of the Ross Foundation of NYC for many years. His survivors are a daughter, Nancy Carver Truesdell and a granddaughter, Katharine, both of Upper Montclair, NJ; two brothers, Gerald of Illinois and Donald of Florida. Visiting hours are Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at The Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Ave, Wyckoff, NJ. Services will be private. Memorial contributions may be sent to Ross Foundation, Inc, 6 E. 45 St, Suite 209, NY, NY 10017.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENTLE, PHYLLIS (MARSHALL)
description: GENTLE-Phyllis (Marshall). Beloved wife of George. Devoted mother of Carolyn Mustopa, Jonathan Mernyk, Paul Mernyk and Suzanne Mernyk. Loving sister of Judith Forusz. Cherished grandmother of Yusuf, Laila, Annisa, Hannah, Joseph and Ella. Services 6:30 PM, Tuesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Neighborhood Nurtures Its Vibrant Culture; Pride of Place for Art and Artists in the Barrio
description: The neighborhood around 106th Street and Lexington Avenue is usually called East Harlem. But to its Spanish-speaking, largely Puerto Rican-born residents it is El Barrio, and it offers the best and worst of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, SAUL
description: MENDELSON-Saul. Died March 13, 1998, age 80, in Chicago. Beloved husband of Jennie Mendelson. Father of Neal, Paul, Jack (Carole). Loving Grandfather of Emma. Memorial services pending. For details please call the family.

title: Accounts
description: * Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $8 million: Clif Bar Inc., Berkeley, Calif., a maker of energy bars whose account had been handled by Gilmour & Associates, San Rafael, Calif., and Marmot Mountain Ltd., Santa Rosa, Calif., a maker of apparel and equipment whose account had been handled by agencies on a project basis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMEAL, MARY JEAN
description: SMEAL-Mary Jean. The National Center for Disability Services mourns the passing of Mary Jean Smeal, a much respected supporter of programs for people with disabilities. Her efforts leave a lasting legacy that will improve the lives of countless future generations. The National Center for Disability Services expresses their heartfelt condolences to her husband Frank, her children, grandchildren, family and friends. Edmund L. Cortez, President and CEO and the Board of Directors, National Center for Disability Services

title: Tomba Wins Season's Final Race
description: Alberto Tomba of Italy won his 50th World Cup race when he took the final slalom of the season yesterday in Crans Montana, Switzerland.

title: When Caution Is Justified
description: Thousands of players will converge on Reno, Nev., at the end of the week to compete in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring National Championship. A small group will arrive early because they have qualified for the playoffs in the North American Pair Championship.

title: Hevesi's Son Announces at a Politically Weighty Breakfast
description: By any standard, it was a fund-raising breakfast of unusual heft. More than 150 people -- politicians, Democratic Party foot soldiers and union leaders from Queens and throughout the city -- paid $100 a plate or more yesterday to see a candidate announce his official entry into a State Senate race.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Buffett Says Cheap Stocks Were Tough to Find in '97

title: Nathan R. Owen, 78, Chairman Of an Industrial Conglomerate
description: Nathan R. Owen, the longtime chairman and chief executive of the General Signal Corporation who helped build it into a major industrial company, died March 9 at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 78.

title: Cellular Carriers Set $4.1 Billion Merger
description: The Alltel Corporation and the 360 Communications Company reached a $4.1 billion merger agreement last night in a deal aimed at creating a new force in the cellular telephone industry, according to executives close to the companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, ROSA
description: ISRAEL-Rosa. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the sister of our esteemed member, Mr. Romie Shapiro, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres David Yagoda, Chairman Dr. William Schwartz, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, SISTER ANTOINE
description: CAMPBELL-Sister Antoine. The entire Marymount School community mourns the death of Sister Antoine Campbell, RSHM, a beloved educator and friend. She served our students, parents and alumnae for more than 40 years as a dedicated Teacher of Latin and speech, Headmistress, and Director Alumnae Relations. In addition to her sincere fondness for each student, she will be lovingly remembered for her quiet humor and gentle elegance. Her legacy lives on at Marymount through the alumnae established Sister Antoine Campbell Faculty Endowment Fund and the commencement award given each year to the graduate who exemplifies her values of kindness, generosity and genuine concern for others. She will remain in our hearts and minds as a woman of faith who served her God and shared her gifts with others. A memorial service will be held at Marymount School, 1026 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY, in April.

title: Forensic Team Requests Visas To Visit Kosovo
description: A group of international forensic experts have applied for Serbian visas so they can examine the bodies of ethnic Albanians killed by Serbian police officers in Kosovo Province.

title: Political Briefing; Assessing the Length Of a Texan's Reach
description: With Gov. George W. Bush of Texas seemingly assured of re-election this fall -- he won last week's Republican primary with 97 percent of the vote and has a 3-to-1 lead in the polls over the Democrat's nominee, Garry Mauro, the land commissioner -- speculation is again centering on the more intriguing question of the Presidential prospects of the former President's son.

title: Second Chance at Defiance For a British Newspaper
description: The Independent, the newspaper that defiantly challenged the partisan practices of Britain's press at its founding in 1986 but has been losing money, staff and readers in recent years, has been given a new start.

title: After Beating Rusedski, Rios Sets Sights Higher
description: With a symphony of shotmaking from the baseline, Marcelo Rios, the first Chilean to crash the top 10 and the only player to revel in a worldwide reputation for irascibility, captured the Newsweek Champions Cup final this afternoon. He did it by defying and denying the big serve of Britain's Greg Rusedski.

title: No Winners in Gay Scout Case; Religion Isn't Culpable
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSH, SAMUEL
description: MARSH-Samuel. September 16, 1912-March 13, 1998. Age 85. Retired physician. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Devoted father of Jonathan and David. Loving grandfather of Jeremey. Cherished brother of Lee and Laurel. He will be sorely missed. Service today, 11 AM, at ''Schwartz BrosJeffer,'' Queens Blvd at 76th Rd, in Forest Hills. Interment will be held in Salem, MA.

title: Decision Deferred on Control of Key Bosnian Town
description: With tensions spreading in the region, an arbiter postponed a decision today on which ethnic grouping will control a strategically important Bosnian city for at least nine months.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Likable Showoff's Aw-Shucks Grin
description: Michael Flatley's ''Lord of the Dance'' burst into the Radio City Music Hall on Friday night with plenty of brash cheer. Although Mr. Flatley remains the show's artistic director, the Chicago-born specialist in Irish dancing is not appearing with this touring production. The star is now Mr. Flatley's former understudy, John Carey, who made a fine impression indeed.

title: Woman Subpoenaed in Lewinsky Case
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, has issued a subpoena compelling a young New York woman to testify on Tuesday before a grand jury investigating President Clinton, lawyers involved in the case said today.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a 1995 settlement agreement between the New York Mercantile Exchange and a Manhattan lawyer who had sued the exchange on behalf of a trader referred incorrectly to the circumstances under which the lawyer, Scott M. Brenner, parted ways with another client, Michael Clark.

title: After 32 years and some of the most successful campaigns ever, Wells BDDP will close its doors.
description: TIME has run out for the besieged Wells BDDP, the onetime Madison Avenue powerhouse that had recently stumbled into a stunning free fall as large clients left amid executive turmoil and ownership changes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTOR, DR. KAREL
description: MONTOR-Dr. Karel. On March 13, 1998, of Severna Park, MD. Services March 19, at U.S. Naval Academy Chapel. Contributions to Karel Montor Memorial Fund, 71 Brooks Road, Arnold, MD 21012.

title: White House Volunteer, on TV, Details Encounter With President
description: Kathleen E. Willey put a vulnerable face and an emotional voice tonight on a story that has so far been told in dry court documents and secondhand accounts, saying in a television interview that President Clinton sexually forced himself on her in an Oval Office encounter in late 1993.

title: The Law Where There Is No Land; A Legal System Built on Precedents Has Few of Them in the Digital World
description: Cyberspace, only yesterday the proud Wild West of the information age, is rapidly being settled and tamed. The best evidence is a sudden -- and some might say alarming -- infestation by a new species, the cyberlawyers.

title: The vision of General Magic buttressed by Microsoft. Now that's an interface!
description: WHEN the Microsoft Corporation announced earlier this month that it had bought a minority stake in the financially struggling General Magic Inc., the investment refocused the industry's attention on one of Silicon Valley's most acutely visionary companies -- and one that had over the years become synonymous with high-technology hubris.

title: Carleton Putnam Dies at 96; Led Delta and Wrote on Race
description: Carleton Putnam, who helped create a major airline, wrote an acclaimed biography of Theodore Roosevelt, and then, driven by opposition to the Supreme Court's 1954 school desegregation decision, turned out a classic defense of racial segregation, died on March 5 at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 96 and a former chairman of Delta Air Lines.

title: Updates: Media and Technology; Critiques of Microsoft (With a Wink to Pogo)
description: Competition and innovation go hand in hand. It is one of life's truisms, accepted in economic circles, enshrined in antitrust doctrine. And recently, the competition-innovation link has become a central tenet of the critique of Microsoft -- that the company is a monopolist that stifles competition and thus innovation.

title: Seoul Journal; Korea Deflated, but a Diplomat's Hopes Are High
description: Last year, Stephen W. Bosworth agreed to be the American Ambassador to a booming industrialized nation with a single dominant political party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, BENEDICT
description: GINSBERG-Benedict. 1908-1998. Mr. and Mrs Herbert R. Weissberg and Family mourn the passing of the greatest lawyer and loyal friend for more than forty years. We will miss him every day.

title: A Director Who Dares, And Takes The Heat
description: The day after his production of ''Lohengrin'' received a hostile reception at the Metropolitan Opera, Robert Wilson, with commitments to keep, flew to Europe. On the telephone from Geneva, the director expressed his surprise at the reaction, and tried to explain the reason behind it.

title: Filtering the Internet
description: Less than a year after the Supreme Court struck down the 1996 Communications Decency Act, which banned distribution of indecent material to minors on the Internet, Congress is again considering legislation that would harm free speech in the name of protecting children. A bill sponsored by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, would require schools and libraries to install anti-pornography filters on their computers in order to receive Federal funds for Internet hook-ups. But recognizing potential opposition from educators and librarians, Mr. McCain kept open the possibility that a compromise would be offered when the bill reached the Senate floor.

title: Fatigue Is a Factor For Nets In Victory
description: At halftime on Saturday night, the scoreboard showed that the Nets were trailing the Dallas Mavericks by just 1 point. But looking around, Coach John Calipari figured things were not quite as close as the score would indicate.

title: U.C.L.A.'s Foul Shots Undercut Michigan
description: Time after time, a desperate Michigan sent U.C.L.A.'s Kris Johnson to the free-throw line, hoping for a miss that would enable the Wolverines to pull out the South Regional game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOESER, URSULA.
description: MOESER-Ursula. Died March 14, 1998, after a short illness. A cultured lady, always cheerful, who will be much missed by her many friends in her Seaford and Massapequa communities, and also by her Church community of our Redeemer Lutheran Church. She was a Scientific Translator who spoke many languages. She had a lively, literary talent. She was a lover of animals, particularly her cats. She survived by seven years, her late husband, Otto Moeser. Ursula's death is a terrible loss. Reposing at the Charles G. Schmitt Funeral Home, 3863 Merrick Rd, Seaford (2 traffic lights east of Route 135). Religious Service on Wednesday 10 AM, our Redeemer Lutheran Church, Seaford. Cremation Private. Hours Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M.

title: Jury Selection Begins in First Death Penalty Case Since 1983
description: For the first time in 15 years in New York State, a group of potential jurors was bluntly asked a life-or-death question yesterday: If they convicted a man of murdering three people during a robbery, could they sentence him to die?

title: White House Attacks Credibility Of Aide Who Accused Clinton
description: In the four years since she said she endured an unwanted sexual encounter in the Oval Office with President Clinton, Kathleen E. Willey seemed to maintain a cordial relationship with the President, according to correspondence released by the White House today. She wrote him a series of friendly notes and asked him for help getting jobs, the letters show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KABOT, ABRAHAM (SKIBBY)
description: KABOT-Abraham (Skibby). Beloved husband of the late Esther Kabot, cherished brother of Belle Scher, Eva Kabachnick, Natie Kabot and the late Al, Ray, Ben and Phil. Adored and caring father of Philip and Ellen, Charlotte and Mortimer Lowenfeld, Frances and Sandy Silver. Cherished grandfather of Allison, Andrew and Leslie, Edward and Natalie, Elizabeth, Ellen and Bob, Eric and Brooke, Eileen and Bill. Proud great-grandfather. Graveside services on Wednesday, March 18, at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, 2:30 PM.

title: Elizabeth Barnes, Volunteer, 90
description: Elizabeth Barnes, a volunteer for national organizations including the Y.W.C.A. and National Council of Negro Women, died on Thursday at the Health Clinic of Westminster Shores in St. Petersburg, Fla. She was 90 and a resident of St. Petersburg.

title: Foreign Affairs; Get a Job
description: While monitoring village elections in northeastern China with a U.S. observer team, I wandered through the hamlet of Heng Dao, dropping in on a farmer-turned-mechanic who had geese and pigs in the front yard but a stereo and color television inside his brick hut. Our interpreter asked him what had happened to the loudspeaker that the Communist Party had in his ''brigade,'' as small villages were known in Mao's day. The loudspeakers were used to blare out instructions and propaganda from the party. ''We took it down last year,'' the villager said. ''No one wanted to listen to it anymore. We have stereo and TV now.''

title: Benjamin Spock, World's Pediatrician, Dies at 94
description: Dr. Benjamin Spock, the pediatrician who gently coached anxious postwar parents to trust their ''own common sense,'' only to be blamed by some critics for the self-indulgence of those parents' children, the 60's generation, died on Sunday at his home in San Diego. He was 94.

title: PLATINUM TECHNOLOGY AGREES TO PURCHASE LOGIC WORKS
description: Platinum Technology Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Logic Works Inc. for $174.8 million in stock. Logic Works, based in Princeton, N.J., provides software to manage data bases. It had revenue of $50.5 million in 1997. Platinum Technology, based in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., makes computer-system management software. In 1997, it lost $117.8 million on revenue of $623.5 million. In the transaction, expected to close by midyear, Logic Works stockholders will receive 0.5769 Platinum share for each Logic Works share. Logic Works' stock fell 31.25 cents a share, to $13.25, while Platinum Technology fell $2.0625 a share, to $24.50.

title: User Challenge: Getting Modems Up to Speed
description: HOORAY! A new international standard for so-called 56K modems will eventually eliminate much confusion. Hooray? In the short run, users are likely to be more bewildered than ever.

title: Court Refuses to Intervene in Andersen Feud
description: A Federal District Court judge denied yesterday a request by the consulting firm Andersen Consulting to have the court intervene in its feud with its sister accounting firm, Arthur Andersen.

title: On Cloning, Ethicists Don't Stand in the Way; Ethicists Aren't Censors
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, DOROTHY
description: GOLD-Dorothy. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Sidney Freedman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEAVER, JOHN H.
description: WEAVER-John H. Former husband of Nancy Weaver, cherished brother of James D. and Charles G. Weaver, dear friend of Ruth Merrill, loving uncle of Anne Weaver and also survived by one uncle, Dr. Neil Lebhar. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Nets Humble Jordan, But It Doesn't Last Long
description: It will go down as one of David Vaughn's fondest playing memories, the moment he sent Michael Jordan's attempted dunk back to the floor in the first quarter tonight.

title: Law Firm Finds No Link to Kennedy
description: The clients of Lawrence X. Cusack Jr. were the sort to make a devout Irish Catholic lawyer proud: the Archdiocese of New York and Mother Teresa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPLER, BERTHA A.
description: KEMPLER-Bertha A. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Harriet Rosenberg and Michael Kempler. Cherished grandmother of George, Jamie, Robert, Ricky and Amanda. Adored great-grandmother of Jeffrey, Rachel and Andrew. Dear mother-in-law of Dr. Barry Rosenberg and Lois Kempler. We will miss you.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen hit a two-month low after Japan's Finance Minister said there were no plans for a supplementary budget to stimulate the economy. In New York, the dollar cost 129.64 yen, up from 128.15 Friday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 26 about Manhattanites' reliance on mini-storage referred incorrectly to doves and a rabbit used in the act of Arnie Kolodner, a magician. While he keeps costumes in mini-storage, the rabbit and doves live in his home. A correction in this space on Saturday omitted mention of the rabbit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLONSKY, HENRIETTA
description: POLONSKY-Henrietta. On March 11, 1998 died peacefully at her home in West Palm Beach, Florida at the age of 89. Survived by her husband Nathan, her sister-inlaw Ruth Blume of Plainview, N.Y. and ten loving nieces and nephews. Tenderly cared for by Chris and Beata Skowronski. Formerly of 283 Avenue C in Manhattan. She was a dedicated teacher at Charles Evans Hughes High School. Henrietta lived life with passion, with tenacity and with a twinkle. Fond memories of this strong woman will endure in the hearts of all who knew her.

title: Cheaper Commutes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODER, ADELE KITTREDGE BRODER
description: BRODER-Adele Kittredge Broder. Of Short Hills, New Jersey, on Monday, March 16, 1998; beloved wife of Robert H. Broder; loving mother of Michael K. and Mary Lee Broder of Dallas, Texas, Thomas K. Broder of Hoboken and James K. Broder of NYC; adoring grandmother of Katherine K. and Brian H. Broder; she is survived by her seven devoted brothers: Ralph G. Webber, Charles Kittredge, George Kittredge and Barry Kittredge, all of Longmeadow, MA, Sidney Kittredge of Enfield, CT, Edward Kittredge of NYC, Dr. Robert L. Kittredge of Cummaquid, MA and her late brothers, Alfred H. Webber and John Robinson. Funeral Service Wednesday, March 18, 11 AM in Congregation B'Nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Ave., Short Hills, NJ. Interment B'Nai Jeshurun Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Bertha Kittredge Scholarship Fund of the National Council of Jewish Women, 1160 Dickinson Street, Springfield, MA 01108. A native of Longmeadow, MA., and long time resident of Short Hills, New Jersey, Adele was active in local and state democratic politics, The League of Women Voters, The American Jewish Committee and many other civic and philanthropic organizations.

title: Argentine Labor Code Largely Intact
description: In an uncharacteristic rebuff to big business, President Carlos Saul Menem plans this week to propose a package of labor regulations that leaves intact most Government-mandated severance benefits and limits companies' right to hire part-time workers.

title: Rangers, Clinging to Life, Survive Injuries and Rally
description: Despite an important victory in a crucial game, last night was not a completely happy or healthy one for the Rangers. Injuries sidelined two key players, center Pat LaFontaine and defenseman Jeff Beukeboom, as New York hung on to defeat the Ottawa Senators, 5-4, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Out of Need or Desire, a Collector's Happy Obsession
description: Most English collectors are terribly discreet about the art they buy. Few even like to admit they collect at all. But when Janet de Botton speaks about her 20-year love affair with contemporary art, her eyes grow wide and her voice fills with passion.

title: A 'Better' Theme For Burger King
