description: The Burger King Corporation unit of Diageo P.L.C. is changing themes in its advertising for the first time since awarding its account to the Ammirati Puris Lintas unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, BERTHA (BERTIE)
description: LEVINE-Bertha (Bertie). On March 16, 1998, of New Rochelle, beloved wife of the late Samuel, dearest mother of Rosalie Woodrow, Laney Davis, and Bette Rutman. Cherished grandmother of Franci, Robert, Wendy, Jodi, Steven, Michael, Debbie, Jimmy, and Alison. Also survived by eleven great grandchildren. Services at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, on Wednesday at 1 P.M. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Battling Junk E-Mail May Become Easier
description: Sendmail, the most popular software used to deliver E-mail on the Internet, is getting a powerful set of tools to fight the junk mail known as spam, which is increasingly clogging cyberspace and filling mailboxes of Internet users with unwanted promotions on subjects as diverse as get-rich-quick schemes and pornography.

title: HIGH RATES HOBBLE LAW TO GUARANTEE HEALTH INSURANCE
description: A 1996 law hailed as a way to guarantee health insurance for millions of Americans when they change jobs or lose coverage is not working as Congress intended, Federal investigators say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, BENEDICT
description: GINSBERG-Benedict. 1908-1998. Mr. and Mrs Herbert R. Weissberg and Family mourn the passing of the greatest lawyer and loyal friend for more than forty years. We will miss him every day.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Buoyant Investors Push Dow Above 8,700 for First Time
description: In the psychology of the stock market, buying begets buying.

title: Capital Matters
description: It has already been a busy week at the Ziegfeld Theater, the grandiose movie house on West 54th Street. On Sunday, an invitation-only crowd watched the premiere of ''Wide Awake,'' starring ROSIE O'DONNELL and DENNIS LEARY. VICE PRESIDENT AL GORE was on hand (he slipped out a side door as the lights were going down).

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the St. Patrick's Day Parade, which starts at 11 A.M. today, the following streets will be closed:

title: SCIENCE WATCH; A Vampire Bat's Burden
description: DR. WILLIAM A. SCHUTT Jr. went looking in the tropical forests of Trinidad to prove that not all vampire bats are equal. A professor at Bloomfield College in New Jersey, Dr. Schutt knew that nearly all vampire bat research had focused on the genus Desmodus, which makes up 99 percent of the vampire bat population.

title: By Design; Embracing Long, Lean Skirts
description: Trend-spotting at the fall collections in Milan and Paris made one thing perfectly clear. Dresses and skirts have almost totally eclipsed pants. Most hemlines fall well below the knee, some daytime skirts even scraping the floor. The skirts are narrow, with a slight flare or pleats for movement, and are shown with short-fitted jackets or sweaters. The sweaters may be long and lean in chunky knits, or lightweight and layered. Long cardigan sweaters, anywhere from fingertip to floor length, are often shown with the long skirts for both day and evening.

title: Cat Scratch Disease
description: Q. What is cat scratch fever?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SAMUEL S.
description: MILLER-Samuel S. On March 16, 1998, in Boca Raton, FL. Funeral service on Wednesday, 11 A.M., Temple Beth El, 350 Roxbury Road, Stamford, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JOEL
description: GOLDMAN-Joel. The Members of The Seventh Manhattan District of Masons deeply regrets the demise of its beloved Brother, friend and Past President. We benefited from his friendships, advice and counsel, and will deeply miss him. Jay Stuart Dankberg

title: Scientist at Work: Wallace S. Broecker; Iconoclastic Guru of the Climate Debate
description: IF there is a great guru among the relatively small group of scientists who try to fathom the present and future behavior of the earth's climate by studying how it has behaved in the past, it has to be 66-year-old Wallace S. Broecker: part crusty curmudgeon and blunt-spoken iconoclast, part imp and practical joker -- but all intellect.

title: 2 Groups Race to Take Celestial Census
description: IN the quest to map the structure of the universe, the Sloan Digital Sky Survey has company. Sloan will first use its digital camera to take a census of 200 million objects in the heavens, and then measure the distances of the million brightest galaxies. But there is a quicker way: Working from an earlier photographic census, a team based at a telescope in New South Wales, Australia, has already nailed down red-shift distances for more than 8,000 galaxies.

title: Mets Held Rapt By a Master Of the Mound
description: Socrates could not have asked for a more receptive audience than the one that turned out today for the 62-year-old left-hander from Brooklyn who paid the Mets a visit.

title: Omaha Tribe Turns to Cigarettes for a Better Life
description: The thrumming green machines in the new factory here are the hope of the Omaha Indian tribe. Early sales are encouraging, and soon the tribe will be tripling production.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, DONALD
description: JOYCE-Donald. On Tuesday, March 10, 1998, age 45, of cancer. Musician, organist, choir director, teacher. A service will be held on Saturday, March 28, at 1 P.M., at the Church of the Holy Apostles, 9th Ave at 28th St., NYC 10001. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made either to the Organ Fund at the above church or to the Donald Joyce Scholarship Fund at the Copland School of Music, Queens College, Flushing, N.Y. 11367.

title: The McKinney Verdict
description: After being acquitted of 18 sexual-misconduct charges, Sgt. Maj. Gene McKinney now faces an end to what was a distinguished military career. Once the top enlisted soldier in the Army, he was found guilty of a single count of obstructing justice by the court-martial jury. The panel reprimanded him and reduced his rank by one grade, but he escaped prison and a dishonorable discharge that would have stripped him of a military pension. He has announced that he plans to retire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVECK, CAROLYN SCHNURER
description: NOVECK-Carolyn Schnurer. Mrs. Noveck, of Palm Beach, Florida died in Palm Beach on Sunday, March 15, 1998 with her son, Tony, at her bedside. Mrs. Noveck was born and educated in New York City, and moved to Palm Beach over twenty years ago. In New York, she taught at New York University and the Fashion Institute of Technology. Carolyn Schnurer was instrumental in changing women's fashions in beachwear and sportswear, designing complete outfits, and adapting the two-piece bathing suit for the United States market. For these innovations her designs appeared in the pages of ''Vogue'', ''Harper's Bazaar'' and ''Life'' magazines, as well as on the covers. The Awards presented to her from Coty, The Cotton Council, International Sportswear, Miami Sportswear, and Boston Sportswear were among other special recognitions for her achievements. Her sense of humor was often chronicled in newspaper columns. The oft-told tale was the time when she was cautioned in traveling from India to Paris to be sure not to be routed via Iran, as her passport was stamped as having visited Israel, and that was reason enough to be taken from the plane, detained in Iran, and perhaps the cause of an international situation. Announcement was made by the Captain of the plane that they would make an unscheduled stop in Iran, before proceeding on with the itinerary. Immediately a landing card was distributed to each passanger to be filled out, including ''Religion''. In a panic and fear that she would be in trouble on landing in Iran, she thought of her headquarters in New York on Seventh Avenue, and wrote under ''Religion'' Seventh Avenue Adventist, and all was well. In essence, Carolyn Schnurer had flair and style and grace, and devoted herself to her family, and to the successful development of a catering service with her late husband, Lawrence Noveck. Survivors include her son, Anthony T. Schnurer, M.D., her sister, Selma Frank, and her step-children, Jane Strompf and Ralph Noveck. Funeral Services will be private. Interment will take place in Forest Lawn Memorial Park, Glendale, California. A memorial Service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers the family requests contributions In Memory of Carolyn Schnurer to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 3300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida. For further information, please contact Quattlebaum-Holleman-Burse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach.

title: A Tough Town, on Screen Anyway; Despite Drop in Crime, New York's Gritty Image Prevails
description: Even on the station house set, reality can no longer be denied: crime is continuing its precipitous decline in New York City. And as they hung out in their famously scruffy squad room between takes, Detectives Leonard W. Briscoe and Reynaldo Curtis, New York's quintessential crime stoppers, were pondering what it meant when truth was safer than fiction.

title: Laureate's Mission Is to Give Voice to a Nation of Poets
description: If there is a more lyrical way to celebrate the approaching millennium than by letting an average American recite T. S. Eliot's ''The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock'' in Saul Bellow's Yiddish translation, then Robert Pinsky, poet laureate of the United States, is dedicated to finding it.

title: A Peace Sprint in Northern Ireland
description: The parties negotiating peace in Northern Ireland are in Washington this week, in what has somehow become a yearly St. Patrick's Day politicians' pilgrimage. This year the ritual is particularly useful. The parties are due to resume formal negotiations next Monday, and have only until about Easter, April 12, to reach an agreement on a peace plan that can be put to British and Irish voters in May -- before the summer marching season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONK, THEODORE GLENN
description: MONK-Theodore Glenn, 88. Of Rancho Mirage, CA, died March 14 of natural causes. A graduate of NYU, he served in the Navy Seebees on Guam in W.W. II. He was President of Square Lumber and Supply Co.-President of the NY Lumber & Trade Assn. Mr. Monk was a volunteer for the Veterans Bedside Network. He was a longtime resident of Stamford, CT before moving west. He leaves his beloved wife of 62 years Audrey Marsh Monk, 2 devoted daughters Meredith Monk of NYC, Tracy Monk Durland of Sante Fe, NM, a sister Marylyn Beclwith of Locust, NJ, a brother Gilbert F. Monk of Roslyn, LI. Adoring grandfather of Phoebe, Corinna, Laurel, and William Durland. A memorial service will be held in NYC in May.

title: Ex-Police Chief and His Son Plead Guilty in Corruption
description: The former chief of police in West New York, N.J., and his son, who was a lieutenant and supervisor of detectives, pleaded guilty today to Federal racketeering and extortion charges, admitting that they and other officers demanded and accepted bribes for protecting illegal gambling, prostitution and after-hours liquor sales.

title: Harvard Falls to Earth
description: ARKANSAS 82, HARVARD 64

title: Icahn Retracts Offer to Rescue Ailing Pan Am
description: The financier Carl C. Icahn withdrew his $43 million bid yesterday to bail out the Pan Am Corporation, leaving the airline one step closer to closing its doors permanently.

title: Alltel to Buy Big Carrier of Cellular Calls
description: The Alltel Corporation announced an agreement yesterday to acquire the 360 Communications Company, a big cellular telephone carrier, for more than $4 billion in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, ALEX
description: BRODSKY-Alex. On March 10, 1998 in Boca Raton, Fla. Beloved husband of Anita, devoted father of Leslie and Jerry Caruso and Jeffrey and Kim Brodsky; proud grandfather of Megan. He will be missed and remembered always. Contributions in his memory may be made to American Assoc. of Kidney Patients, 6801 Lake Worth Rd., #

title: Researcher Links Reduction in Cholesterol With Violent Death
description: JUST when cardiologists and lipid experts thought they had convinced fat-loving Americans of the need to lower their cholesterol, a lone researcher has stepped forward to reopen a hornet's nest of an old question on the safety of that advice.

title: Pearson Profits Fell 12% in 2d Half
description: Pearson P.L.C.'s second-half profit from operations fell an indicated 12 percent as the company, a British media concern, sold some businesses to focus on its higher-growth broadcast units. Second-half net before charges fell to $:136.5 million ($228.0 million) from $:155.7 million a year earlier, according to calculations based on first-half figures. The company did not break out second-half profit. Pearson owns The Financial Times, Penguin Group books and half of The Economist.

title: Battered Women Face Pit Bulls and Cobras
description: THE cobra is a real snake in the grass, quiet and focused before striking its victim with little or no warning. The pit bull's fury smolders and builds, and once its teeth are sunk into its victim it won't let go. Men who batter women are either like cobras or pit bulls, say two professors of psychology at the University of Washington who have spent a decade studying violent marriages, and the distinction can make a difference in the severity of the harm they inflict, the ability of women to escape a relationship and the risks the women face if they do leave.

title: NORWOOD TO BE SOLD IN MANAGEMENT BUYOUT
description: Norwood Promotional Products Inc. said yesterday that it would be acquired by FPK L.L.C., a company formed by Norwood's chairman and chief executive, Frank Krasovec, in an $85 million management buyout. Norwood Promotional Products, based in Austin, Tex., a supplier of advertising specialty products, said that outsiders hold 4.1 million of the company's 5.2 million shares outstanding and would receive $20.70 in cash for each share. An executive at Norwood Promotional said the move to become a closely held company reflected pessimism about the stock price. Norwood's shares rose $2.375 each yesterday, to $19.75.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Trains Suharto Forces

title: Briton Settles Dispute Over Visit to Israeli Site
description: Israel and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook of Britain resolved a dispute today over his plan to visit the site of a disputed new Jewish neighborhood in eastern Jerusalem by agreeing that he would go there with Israeli officials, not Palestinians.

title: Charter School Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, ROSA
description: ISRAEL-Rosa. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Rosa Israel, beloved sister of our devoted members and benefactors, Romie and Blanche Shapiro. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Defense Chief Rejects Advice To Separate Sexes in Training
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen today rejected a special panel's recommendation that the Army, Navy and Air Force segregate men and women for much of basic training, but he ordered changes in recruiting, training and housing for new recruits in all services.

title: Sitcom News Program Vs. Real Life: Good Luck
description: After we've seen Monica Lewinsky's lawyer, William Ginsburg, chortling with Geraldo Rivera, after we've the seen the Internet gossip Matt Drudge appear on ''Meet the Press,'' how can a political satire top reality? ''Lateline,'' Al Franken's mild new sitcom set behind the scenes of a program like ''Nightline,'' doesn't come close.

title: 1998 N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: The Little School That Could; In This Tournament, Valparaiso Has Made a Big Name for Itself
description: For two hours today, Merel Nelson waited in the cold for the bus carrying the town's new heroes to roll down Union Street. He wasn't alone. There were students, professors and retirees, more than 2,000 people who just wanted to celebrate where they lived. Shivering, Nelson clutched a cord and got ready to salute Valparaiso's basketball team with a cannon shot from Crusader II.

title: Essay; Asteroid Expert's Voice Is Missing, but His Legacy Is Felt
description: IN all the discussion about Asteroid 1997 XF11 and its chances of hitting Earth, and what to do about it, one voice badly missing was Dr. Eugene M. Shoemaker's. He was the geologist who first brought the study of rocks into space and whose work, first with impact craters and then with the asteroids and comets that blasted them, has made most people accept the notion -- revolutionary in the 1950's and 60's -- that big rocks from space can make big holes in planets, with catastrophic results.

title: Seller Charged With Faking Scandalous Kennedy Papers
description: Months after doubts were first raised about the authenticity of hundreds of documents said to be in the handwriting of John F. Kennedy, Federal prosecutors charged a Connecticut man yesterday in a scheme to forge the papers and sell them for more than $7 million to unsuspecting investors.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW: POP
description: Getting a Little Help But Still Heartbroken

title: Do Sanctions Really Work? Debate Is On In Burma
description: RANGOON  Burma's economy, squeezed for years by Western sanctions and weakened by the economic crisis affecting much of Asia, is in tatters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CESA, ALDO
description: CESA-Aldo. On March 15th, 1998, formerly of New Rochelle, NY. Husband of Louise, father of Christine Affronti, Robert Cesa and Jane Pedigree. Brother of Nick Cesa. Also survived by six grandchildren. Family will receive friends at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services will be held at the St. Francis of Assisi Chapel, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Thursday, 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to The Alzheimer's Association.

title: Ex-Doctor Admits Lying About Poisonings
description: Michael J. Swango, a former doctor who went to prison in the 1980's for poisoning several co-workers in Illinois, pleaded guilty here today to a Federal charge of fraudulently obtaining a medical position at a veterans' hospital.

title: Cab Service Is Called Mask For Drug Ring
description: It had a dispatcher and two drivers, cars equipped with two-way radios and a reputation for speedy service. But the business that called itself the Metro Cab Company made its money not by ferrying passengers, but by delivering $20 bags of cocaine and heroin to the doorsteps of drug users all over the Bronx, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESNER, BERNARD
description: CHESNER - Bernard. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Presidential Character
description: This is a peculiar moment in what will surely be remembered as one of the oddest modern Presidencies. Part of what makes it peculiar is that we have so much information and yet still know so little about what kind of man Bill Clinton really is. It is certainly possible, as Mr. Clinton said again yesterday, that he never made sexual overtures to Kathleen Willey and that he never propositioned Paula Jones or seduced Monica Lewinsky. But it is also true that the American people would not be surprised if Mr. Clinton turned out to be lying in all three cases.

title: Corrections
description: The One Step Back column yesterday about National Public Radio hosts misstated the surname of an author who was interviewed about his true-crime novel ''Another Day in Paradise.'' He is Eddie Little, not Miller.

title: Now Practicing What He Preaches; Jewish Museum in Berlin Is a Noted Architect's First Building
description: During his first two decades as an architect, Daniel Libeskind had no interest in building anything. Instead he concentrated on drawing, writing and teaching, earning accolades as an avant-garde theorist. Finally, 11 years ago, he entered his first competition. Now, at the age of 51, the Polish-born American is completing his first building, the new Jewish Museum in Berlin.

title: Armenians Turn Out To Elect New Leader
description: Armenian voters turned out in large numbers today for presidential elections that Western political analysts say could profoundly affect stability in the oil-producing Caucasus region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DITTELMAN, HAROLD J.
description: DITTELMAN-Harold J. On March 15th, devoted husband of Jean, loving fahter of Lawrence (Sharon) and the late Stephen (Fay). Judge Dittelman was an Ossining Town Justice for 21 years. He practiced law in Westchester County for 60 years. Services will be held at The Congregation Sons of Israel, 1666 Pleasantville Rd, Briarcliff Manor, on Tuesday at 1 P.M. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Garlick Hellman FH: 914-237-3300 for information.

title: Gore Brings a Little Fire to Kennelly's Race for Governor
description: The Democratic Party's most famous wooden figure came to Connecticut today to bring life and light to Barbara B. Kennelly's sluggish campaign for Governor.

title: ST. PAUL BANCORP TO BUY RIVAL IN ILLINOIS
description: St. Paul Bancorp agreed yesterday to buy an Illinois rival, Beverly Bancorporation, for $170 million in stock, as the bank expands around the southern Chicago region. Shareholders of Beverly Bancorporation, which has $669 million in assets and 13 branches and is based in Tinley Park, Ill., will receive 1.063 shares of stock in St. Paul Bancorp. The stock of St. Paul Bancorp, which is based in Chicago, closed at $25.8125, down 62.5 cents, while Beverly Bancorp's stock rose $1.375, to $27.625. St. Paul Bancorp, the parent company of St. Paul Federal Bank for Savings, expects to cut 19 percent of Beverly Bancorp's operating expenses, or about $4.8 million pretax.

title: The View From Space Won't Teach Us Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTINGER, FLORICA, M.D.
description: ETTINGER-Florica, M.D. On Mar. 15, 1998. Services Wednesday 11:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours Tuesday 6-9 P.M., at the funeral home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAKIN, JEANETTE
description: WAKIN-Jeanette. The Arabic Seminar of Columbia University expresses its profound grief at the passing of its Chair, Jeanette Wakin, and extends condolences to her family. It was a great honor to be associated with her and she will always be remembered with respect and affection.

title: Accounts
description: * AT&T Corp., Basking Ridge, N.J., to Foote, Cone & Belding Direct, New York, part of True North Communications, to handle its consolidated college market account, which had been divided between Foote, Cone Direct and Bronner Slosberg Humphrey, Boston. Though total billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated them at $50 millon.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Extra Resonance In the Encores

title: Studies Find Brain Grows New Cells
description: FOR years, neurobiologists clung to a fundamental truth: once animals, or people, reach adulthood, they may lose brain cells but they can never grow new ones. There were a couple of exceptions -- in birds and rats -- but the thought was that these were peculiarities of nature and not evidence of a general principle.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES TO BUY INTERNATIONAL MUREX
description: Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the diagnostic-products maker International Murex Technologies Corporation for $13 a share, or $234 million. The tender offer, made directly to shareholders, was approved by the boards of both companies. International Murex, based in Toronto, had 1997 revenues of $106 million. Shares of International Murex rose nearly 19 percent, gaining $2 each, to $12.6875 in Nasdaq trading. Abbott, a medical products company based in Abbott Park, Ill., had 1997 sales of $11.9 billion.

title: Here and There
description: The byline said MANUEL A. NORIEGA. But did the ex-dictator of Panama really write ''How to Become a Strongman'' for Men's Health magazine? Apparently not. ''He did approve all the copy,'' said CATHERINE BROPHY of Men's Health. But the editors collaborated with his daughter, SANDRA, for a pagelong look at keeping fit in a jail cell. ''He's not that funny, I guess,'' Ms. Brophy said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about Steven A. Pagones, the former Dutchess County prosecutor who is suing Tawana Brawley's former advisers for defamation, misstated the occupation of his colleague Scott D. Snell. Mr. Snell operates video equipment at the trial for Mr. Pagones's legal team. He is not a lawyer.

title: Oil Prices Tumble as Producers Give No Signal of Restraint
description: Futures contracts for crude oil fell 5.6 percent to the lowest level in more than nine years yesterday on skepticism that OPEC, which supplies a third of the world's oil, would cut production to reduce a glut.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The life expectancy isn't high enough for there to be a lot of cancer.''

title: List of Favorite Stocks Is Updated Today
description: The New York Times today updates its list of favorite stocks, which are defined as the 16 stocks owned by the most accounts at Merrill Lynch. The new list is based on holdings at the end of 1997, replacing a list that was based on holdings on May 31, 1996.

title: Sports of The Times; An Unlikely But Alluring Comeback
description: A COUPLE of hours before Mark Jackson tormented the Knicks on Sunday night by defiantly infiltrating what normally is Patrick Ewing's lair, Ewing lurked outside the Indiana locker room, poking his head in, reminding Jackson that he was still very much alive, and around.

title: A Power Broker With Blarney in His Pen
description: MOST New Yorkers would be unable to distinguish James F. Gill from the countless other men of pomegranate complexion and profane good cheer celebrating themselves in today's St. Patrick's Day parade. But the state's most powerful politicians know exactly who he is.

title: Moore Finds a Niche at Connecticut
description: The scouting report says that Ricky Moore is not a wicked shooter, not a supreme scorer, that you can back off and give him room and let him hang on each release. It is true that Moore averaged 7.7 points a game this season, the fourth-lowest total among Connecticut's starters. But there is much more to his scoring story, so many other intangibles, much like the nature of this Huskies team.

title: Indonesia's New Cabinet Takes Office
description: A new nationalist-oriented Cabinet took office today facing tough negotiations with international lenders over how best to dig Indonesia out of its deepening economic crisis.

title: KERR-MCGEE TO BUY GULF CANADA'S NORTH SEA OPERATIONS
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire all of Gulf Canada Resources Ltd.'s operations in the British North Sea for $418 million. Gulf Canada Resources, based in Calgary, Alberta, is an oil and gas company. It had revenue of $888 million in 1997. Kerr-McGee, based in Oklahoma City, is an energy and chemical company. In 1997, it had sales of $1.71 billion. Gulf Canada will use the proceeds from the sale, expected to close in May, to repay debt. Kerr-McGee said that the acquisition would add oil and natural gas reserves equivalent to 100 million barrels of oil.

title: The Cerebral Approach
description: It would be an exaggeration to say that Richard Goode has a cult following among New York concertgoers. But it is likely that much of the audience for his Carnegie Hall recital on Saturday evening has followed Mr. Goode's work for the last 25 years, from his days as an early member of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, through his first recordings on the venturesome Delos label to his later ones for Nonesuch, and through annual recitals that have been consistently eloquent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AMSTERDAM, SAMUEL N.
description: AMSTERDAM-Samuel N. March 17, 1898-April 13, 1954. Happy 100th, daddy. Missed and loved all these years. Arline and Rhoda

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELLER, PETER
description: FELLER-Peter. Died March 13, 1998, in Melbourne, FL, at age 78. Loving husband of Katherine. Devoted brother to Dr. Elizabeth Feller and Mrs. Dorothy Lohmann. Loving father of Peter Feller and daughter-in-law Lynn Feller, Philip Feller and daughter-in-law Gail Feller, and proud grandfather of Katherine, Sky, and Simone. Peter Feller was production supervisor and builder of scenery for thousands of Broadway shows, industrial projects, and arena tours over the last five decades. He became a valued friend to many of the leading designers, directors, playwrights and producers in the theatre industry. He will be remembered with great love by his family, friends and colleagues. Plans for a memorial service at Broadway's Winter Garden Theatre will be announced soon. For those who wish to make a contribution in memory of Peter Feller, the family suggests the Henegar Theatre Center, 625 East New Haven, Melbourne, FL 32901.

title: Arizona, No. 1 Underdog, Aims to Repeat
description: Simon says: ''We don't care about last year. All we care about is Thursday.''

title: Patterns
description: Galliano Starts a Fur Line

title: 65 and Counting
description: A nine-piece band was playing Broadway standards when MARTY RICHARDS, the producer of hits like ''Chicago,'' dashed upstairs. ''I was working on the sound,'' he said when he returned. ''I think I fixed it.'' To which DONNA HANOVER, the television personality and wife of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whom Mr. Richards is considering casting in the film version of ''Chicago,'' said: ''Once a producer, always a producer.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORBES, GLENN D.
description: FORBES-Glenn D. March 12, 1998. Beloved brother of Myron and Bruce Forbes. An accomplished actor and dancer, passed away at the Actors Fund Home in Englewood, NJ. Service Wednesday, March 18, 8PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment Hamilton, Ohio.

title: It's Mott and Bailey Again at Gulfstream
description: Even though he lived 90 miles away and commuted to races with his stable of horses, Bill Mott won the trainers' title at Gulfstream Park today for the sixth year in a row. And Jerry Bailey, who rides many of Mott's horses, won three races on closing day today and cruised to the jockeys' title for the third time in four years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOURTY, LAWRENCE E.
description: McGOURTY-Lawrence E., 76. Of Woodstock, Vermont, formerly of Placida, Florida, and Bolton, Massachusetts, died March 15 in Linden Lodge at the Brattleboro Retreat, Brattleboro, Vermont. Survived by his wife, Philomene (Gilman) McGourty; two sons, Lawrence E. McGourty, Jr. of Meredith, NJ, Eric T. McGourty of Grafton, MA; 2 daughters, Maura Coulter of Telluride, CO, Martha Kelleher of Worcester, MA; seven grandchildren; brothers, John G. McGourty of Arlington, MA, William G. McGourty of Melrose, MA; sister, Ellen Anderson Belden of Belmont, MA. His sister, Dorothy Goslin predeceased him. Born in Malden, MA., son of Lawrence E. and Clara (Kiley) McGourty. WWII Navy veteran. Graduate Harvard University. Former President of Thom McAn Shoe Co. and Vice President of Marketing and Development for Melville Corp. Funeral Mass 10 AM Wed., March 18, Immaculate Conception Church, 353 Grove St, Worcester, MA. Calling hours Tuesday 5 to 8 PM Callahan Brothers Funeral Home, 61 Myrtle St, Worcester, Mass. A Memorial Mass on Saturday, March 21 in Our Lady of the Snow Church, Woodstock, VT followed by reception in church undercroft. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to Lawrence E. McGourty Memorial Stroll-Garden Fund at Brattleboro Retreat, PO Box 803, Brattleboro, VT. 05302 or to Lawrence E. and Philomene Gilman McGourty Endowment Fund for Neurological & Psychiatric Research, University of Mass. Medical Center, 55 Lake Avenue, North Worcester, MA. 01655 or to Old Sturbridge Village, 1 Old Sturbridge Village Road, Sturbridge, Massachusetts 01566.

title: Spain Expands Inquiry Into Argentine State Terror
description: The names of 9,000 people, many of them Spaniards and their decendants, who disappeared during the Argentine military dictatorship were presented to a Spanish judge today, sharply widening his inquiry into Argentine-sponsored terrorism. Until recently the inquiry listed a much smaller fraction of the estimated 30,000 people who died.

title: Exel to Buy Rest of Mid Ocean In a Deal by Bermuda Insurers
description: The insurer Exel Ltd. said yesterday that it would pay about $2.1 billion in stock for the 75 percent of Mid Ocean Ltd. it does not own to increase its size and help attract larger clients.

title: Scandal Erodes the Power of Japan's Bastion of Fiscal Austerity
description: Yoichi Otsuki seemed to be enjoying a life of power and prestige, until he fastened a noose to a curtain rod in his apartment and looped it around his neck.

title: Willey Interview Shakes Clinton's Support Among Women
description: Prominent female politicians, including Democrats, broke months of silence today about the White House sex scandal, expressing deep concern about the accusations by Kathleen E. Willey that President Clinton forced himself on her near the Oval Office.

title: For Bidding, Ever After, It's Camelot
description: JUST in case you were dense and couldn't guess what mood the auctioneers expected of you while viewing Kennedy doodads on display at the New-York Historical Society, they piped in songs from the musical ''Camelot.''

title: A Manhattan-to-Queens Ferry Is Planned for Mets Fans
description: The Giuliani administration is poised to give Mets fans a chance to travel from Manhattan to Shea Stadium by ferry, city officials said yesterday.

title: Japan Names New Governor of Central Bank
description: Breaking with tradition, the Government tapped a relative outsider on Monday to head the central bank and help steer the nation's troubled economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMBERLIN, W. MACY
description: CHAMBERLIN-W. Macy. On March 13, 1998. The entire family of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center mourns the passing of Honorary Trustee W. Macy Chamberlin. A member of our Board of Trustees for two decades, he was a beloved and revered leader of St. Luke's Hospital. His dedication and committment will be sorely missed. To his wife, Irma Morell, his daughters, Kate DeForest Johnson and Judith Macy Stroud, and his entire family, we offer our profound condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman of the Board Ronald C. Ablow, MD President Richard P. Fried, MD President of the Medical Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, LORRAINE
description: FRIEDMAN-Lorraine. A void has been created in our hearts with the untimely loss of our past President and dear friend. Lorraine shared with us her unparalleled zest for life, unflagging optimism, radiant charm, and warm sense of humor. Her kindness and generosity towards others was boundless and she was a model of virtue for all to follow. Her spirit will endure within us. Our heartfelt condolences to Sidney, Cara, and Glen and the entire Blumenthal family. Emek Hanahar, Riverdale Chapter of Amit Women

title: Ruling by Federal Judge on Leasing Planes Worries Airline Industry
description: An unexpected ruling by a Federal judge in Colorado last week sharply increases the risks associated with financing and leasing airplanes, threatening to depress the value of billions of dollars worth of deals and to make it much harder for new and financially troubled airlines to get airplanes, said lawyers and an airline industry analyst.

title: Westchester Republicans Doom Messinger Bid
description: Calling Ruth W. Messinger ''too extreme'' for Westchester County, a coalition of Republican legislators today doomed her effort to become commissioner of the county's Social Services Department.

title: Crazy for Songs With That Certain Feeling
description: Long after the larger body of American classical music is forgotten, sophisticated ears will settle fondly, I suspect, on two decades of the 20th century, a brief time when music and literacy were allowed to meet.

title: Review/Fashion; Breezy Gaultier And Yamamoto
description: It is easy to overlook the genius of Jean Paul Gaultier in the passage of time and as more designers adopt the mix of street style, ethnic traditions and couture references that have long been a part of his oeuvre.

title: A Walter Trampler Tribute
description: A musical tribute to the violist Walter Trampler is to be held on Thursday at 10:30 A.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Among those scheduled to take part are the Juilliard String Quartet, past and current members of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and other musicians who worked or studied with him.

title: Boy's Death in Surgery Is Lesson on Nonprescription Drugs
description: A CHILD'S death during surgery is frightening and rare, and if any good can come from it it is to prevent further tragedies.

title: Ewing Set To Discuss Status Of Wrist
description: Patrick Ewing will hold a news conference Tuesday night before the Knicks' home game with the 76ers, fielding questions on his rehabilitation and issuing ''I told you so's'' to those who immediately scratched him out of the lineup until next season when he went crashing to the floor in Milwaukee on Dec. 20.

title: Texas Utilities Offers Details of Energy Bid
description: The Texas Utilities Company said today that it might issue as much as $2.8 billion in stock and debt to help finance its $10.4 billion offer for Energy Group P.L.C., adding details that flesh out its bid for the company.

title: Loss at Micron Technology Much Steeper Than Expected
description: Stung by pricing pressure from Asian competitors, Micron Technology Inc. yesterday reported a steeper-than-expected loss for its second fiscal quarter. A major maker of memory chips for personal computers, Micron said it had been hard hit in recent quarters by Asian manufacturers' sales of chips below cost.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Community-Service Plan For Suspended Students
description: The Old Bridge Board of Education is expected to approve a program that would force students who are suspended from school to perform community service rather than stay home.

title: Istanbul Journal; A Woman, Her Scarf and a Storm Over Secularism
description: A bright-eyed medical student hardly seems the sort to touch off a national crisis, but Tuloy Erdogan and her friends are at the heart of an intense new conflict between secularism and conservative Islam in Turkey.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Do Blinders Become Bulls On a Run?; Wall Street Searches For a Silver Lining In Lower Earnings
description: They call it the ''confessional season,'' the period when corporate America begins to warn Wall Street of the troubles that lie ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORF, PAULA
description: KORF-Paula. Beloved wife of the late Norman. Loving mother of Gene and the late Gary. Kind mother-in-law to Madeline. Cherished grandmother of Scott and Neil. Devoted sister of Max Heller.

title: Founder Of a Center For New Art Steps Aside
description: After years of tumult and controversy, Marcia Tucker has announced that she will step aside as director of the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo, which she founded 21 years ago as a focus for recent work by living artists.

title: THERMO ELECTRON TO PURCHASE 6 BRITISH BUSINESSES
description: The Thermo Electron Corporation agreed yesterday to buy six units from Smiths Industries P.L.C. of Britain for $73 million in cash to expand its food-inspection and emissions-monitoring equipment businesses. Thermo Electron, which is based in Waltham, Mass., and makes industrial quality-control monitoring devices, said that its Thermo Sentron Inc. and Thermo Instrument Systems Inc. units would buy the businesses from Smiths Industries' Graseby P.L.C. division. The six Smiths units had combined revenue of about $78 million in 1997.

title: Close Calls and Classic Contests: 16 Survivors
description: The field of 64 teams in the N.C.A.A. tournament has quickly shriveled to 16, and it will shrink to a final four teams by the weekend. There have been buzzer beaters, classic games, amazing upsets, and as always, dark horses. Here is a look at the who, the why, the what and the where of the teams still trying to make it to the Final Four in San Antonio. By JACK CURRY

title: Thomas F. O'Neil, 82, Ex-Chief of RKO, Dies
description: Thomas F. O'Neil, the former chairman of RKO General studios who brought movies to television and experimented -- unsuccessfully -- with an early coin-operated pay-TV system, died Saturday night at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 82, and the cause of death was heart failure complicated by pneumonia, said his son Shane.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HASBRO INC., Pawtucket, R.I., bought the Atari video game division of JTS Corp. of San Jose, Calif., for $5 million in cash.

title: Let Doctors Sleep
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMEAL, MARY JEAN
description: SMEAL-Mary Jean. On Thursday, March 12th, Mary Jean Smeal went home to a loving God. The 'music of her years' was a most splendid symphony of caring. Long ago, with her beloved Frank by her side, she responded to the Pauline invitation to the Corinthians-of-old: ''. . .but the greatest of these is Charity.'' And in the wide circle of the suffering whose pain was measurably eased by her caring concern were the legions of 'lost children' charged to the care of Daytop Village. And she shall long be remembered in our grateful prayers. Wordsworth's apostrophe to such a splendid life remains as vivid: ''The music in my heart I bore; long after it was heard no more!'' Our deep sympathies to Frank and the Smeal Family. (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien President Daytop Village, Inc.

title: Sergeant Major Gets One-Step Demotion But No Time in Jail
description: A military jury imposed a mild sentence today on Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, ordering that the Army's former top enlisted soldier be reprimanded and demoted for obstructing justice, the lone conviction resulting from the high-profile court-martial in which he was cleared of sexually harassing six servicewomen.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COSTANZO, RICHARD
description: COSTANZO-Richard. Those of us, whose lives you touched, mourn and miss you. Jean Sun Shaw

title: The View From Space Won't Teach Us Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HUGHES, MISS KITTY (KATHERINE VERONICA MCHUGH)
description: HUGHES-Miss Kitty (Katherine Veronica McHugh). 6 December 1895-17 March 1918. Wait for the Lord, take courage. Peter Byrne, Queens Historical Society

title: Sonia Gandhi Consolidates Her Control Of India Party
description: Sonia Gandhi, Italian-born standard-bearer for India's most famous political family, moved today to take full control of the Congress Party, setting up an intriguing battle between her as the leader of the chief opposition party and the Hindu nationalist Government that is due to be sworn into office on Thursday.

title: Marianne Burge, 64, Expert on Tax Issues
description: Marianne Burge, the first woman to become a partner in the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse, died Feb. 25 at Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 64.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 27 described a lawsuit in which J. P. Morgan & Company is suing several South Korean companies over contracts involving the complex financial products known as derivatives.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about sales of stock by Berkshire Hathaway Inc., omitted one stock in which Berkshire sold a big stake last year, according to its annual report. Berkshire sold at least 48 percent of its holdings in the McDonald's Corporation in 1997.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Tunes of a Different Time: Piano Rags and Parlor Songs

title: Scouting's Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRECKIR, ALBERT YALE
description: BRECKIR-Albert Yale. Happy Birthday, Bill Bailey. Your Loving Family

title: Dr. Spock's Children
description: Babies do not arrive with owner's manuals. But for three generations of American parents, the next best thing was ''Baby and Child Care,'' which has sold nearly 50 million copies since it was first published in 1946. Dr. Benjamin Spock, who died yesterday, was a quiet revolutionary who breathed humanity and common sense into child-rearing, and passionately extended his concerns to the cause of peace. At the height of the Vietnam War, he saw the tragedy of all those children raised under the guidance of his book going off to fight in a senseless war.

title: On Cloning, Ethicists Don't Stand in the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Olivetti Shares Surge On Takeover Rumors
description: The shares of Olivetti S.p.A. surged again yesterday after adding 11.5 percent on Friday amid talk that the company, which controls one of Italy's two cellular phone networks, may be taken over. The stock was also helped by news of a cooperation agreement with the Xerox Corporation. Olivetti's Omnitel Pronto Italia S.p.A. unit holds 21 percent of Italy's fast-growing 12 trillion lire ($6.6 billion) market for mobile telecommunications. Its stock climbed 215 lire yesterday, to 2,490.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, OZZIE
description: RAPPAPORT-Ozzie. Lido Beach Synagogue mourns the passing of our esteemed Board of Directors member. Our sincerest condolences to his beloved wife Rose and family. May God console the family in their hour of bereavement. Dr. Daniel H. Mehlman, Rabbi Herman Berger, Pres. Rose Brumberg, Pres. of Sisterhood

title: Several Voices: A Stand Bold and Cautious at Once
description: The Vatican's statement on the Holocaust, released yesterday after 11 years in the works, seems to speak with more than one voice. It opens with a ringing declaration that the ''unspeakable tragedy'' must never be forgotten, follows with a cautious look at historic Christian attitudes toward Jews, adds a defense of Pope Pius XII and closes with a call to repentance.

title: UConn's Latest Center Draws Attention
description: Paige Sauer is not as quick or as slick as Rebecca Lobo. She is quicker than Kara Wolters, but she does not have Wolters's soft baby hook or the determination to shoot every time the ball comes into the low post.

title: Metro Business; I.B.M. to Purchase Tarrytown Company
description: The International Business Machines Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Chem Systems Group of Tarrytown, N.Y., for an undisclosed amount as it expands its chemical and petroleum industry consulting services.

title: Wells BDDP's post-mortem begins, looking to Darwin and snowballs by clients and employees.
description: AS once-mighty Wells BDDP in New York prepares to close, it joins a growing list of problem-plagued agencies that have dissolved faster than cookies in hot tea.

title: What Else Lurks Out There? New Census of the Heavens Aims to Find Out
description: PERCHED on a platform that extends like a diving board from this wind-whipped ridge 9,200 feet above sea level, between the foothills of the Sacramento Mountains and the close night sky, the new Sloan Telescope hardly looks imposing.

title: Review/Fashion; American Sportswear, French Elan
description: Despite the globalization of fashion, the American and French esthetics remain an ocean apart. Americans favor sportswear and simplicity, while the French, with few exceptions, still like to dress up.

title: U.S. Official Asks Restraint By Albanians
description: In an effort to shore up the forbearance of the Albanians as they watch Serbian violence against their ethnic kin in neighboring Kosovo, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, Strobe Talbott, dropped into this out-of-the-way capital for two hours today.

title: On My Mind; Risking the Presidency
description: This country is awash in the muck of the White House nastiness. We are dirty with the cynicism that flows from it. We are stinking from TV comic shticks inspired by graffiti on the walls of barroom toilets. We gag at the spectacle of America devoting more attention to oral sex than to Iraqi biological weapons.

title: Feisty Spirits in Freezing Temperatures
description: TERRA INCOGNITA

title: Team of the Americas Wins Match Against Europeans
description: Two pick-up teams, one from the Americas and one from Europe, contested a Scheveningen System match on 10 boards at the Mermaid Beach Club in Bermuda last month. In this type of confrontation, in which each player faces each player on the opposing team, the Americas won by 53 1/2 to 46 1/2.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Ex-Moscow Atom Chief Still in the Fray
description: When the Russian Government announced this month that Viktor Mikhailov was leaving his post as Minister of Atomic Energy, many American officials breathed a sigh of relief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAISLEY, LILLIAN E.
description: PAISLEY-Lillian E. Of Bronxville, New York, on March 13, 1998. Aunt of Joan Paisley. Sister of the late Sr. Mary Bertrand Paisley S.H.C.J. Calling hours are at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 26 PM Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Wed., March 18, at 11 AM.

title: Iraqi Deportation Order
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GOODGOLD, MURRAY
description: GOODGOLD-Murray BELOVED ADORED Sally, Iris, Jay

title: 1969 Tripp Charge Reduced, Papers Say
description: A 1969 grand larceny charge lodged against Linda R. Tripp, the Pentagon employee whose tape-recordings of Monica S. Lewinsky started a perjury investigation of President Clinton, was reduced to a charge of loitering, according to court dockets in Greenwood Lake, N.Y.

title: Remedial Limits for CUNY Are Attacked
description: As the trustees of the City University of New York prepared to vote on a proposal to overhaul the way the university handles remedial education, educators and elected officials angrily contended yesterday that the board was moving too fast to pass what many of them described as an ill-conceived reversal of nearly 30 years of open admissions.

title: On Cloning, Ethicists Don't Stand in the Way; Absent Frankenstein
description: To the Editor:

title: Promotion Honors For Packard Bell
description: A promotion marketing campaign for Packard Bell NEC in Sacramento, Calif., took top honors at the 15th annual Reggie Awards competition sponsored by the Promotion Marketing Association. The promotion that won the ''Super Reggie'' award, which was presented at a recent ceremony in Chicago, was created by B. Little & Company in New York and featured CD-ROM's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEYMAN, SYLVIA
description: HEYMAN-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Sidney, devoted mother of Gerard and Jay, sister of Leonard Gladstone. Cherished grandmother of Rachel and Sage. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: The View From Space Won't Teach Us Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYSANEK, LEONIE
description: RYSANEK - Leonie. Beloved opera singer on March 7, 1998 in Vienna. Funeral Tuesday, March 17, at 3:30 PM at Dr. Karl LuegerGedachtniskirsche, Wiener Zentralfriedhof. Donations may be made to Leonie Rysanek Fund, c/o The George London Foundation, 515 East 79th St, NY 10021, to be used to help young singers.

title: Metro Business; Short Hills Building Is Sold
description: The Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville, N.Y., has agreed to purchase a New Jersey office building from a joint venture of the Prudential Insurance Company and the Mitsui Fudosan Company of Japan for $67 million.

title: Cone Gets Thumbs Up To Start in Week One
description: For the first time, at least one Yankee official is saying that David Cone will be part of the rotation at the season's start in two weeks. General Manager Brian Cashman watched Cone pitch five and two-thirds good innings today and said he could not see any reason Cone would not start in the first week of the season.

title: John Paul's Plea: 'Never Again'
description: Following is the text of Pope John Paul II's cover letter, dated last Thursday and issued today, accompanying the Vatican statement about the Holocaust, addressed to the president of the Commission for Religious Relations With the Jews:

title: Russo to Do a Double Take on N.F.L.
description: Suddenly, Sunday mornings will be filled with pre-game shows for the networks' pre-game football shows. Blame it on Channel 4, which last season paired Bill Parcells, the Jets' coach, with Phil Simms, for an 11:30 A.M. show.

title: Attack That Began on Internet Is Described
description: Opening the kidnapping and sexual assault case against a Columbia University graduate student yesterday, the prosecution described the defendant as a kind of folk monster of the information highway, a sophisticated man who used the anonymity of computer communications to entrap an unsuspecting victim.

title: Fila and Arnell Are Parting Ways
description: Fila USA and its agency, Arnell Group Brand Consulting in New York, said yesterday that they had agreed to part ways on the footwear company's account, which has billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSCHARK, ARTHUR ''BUDDY''
description: MARSCHARK-Arthur ''Buddy''. Formerly of NYC, in Tucson, AZ on March 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Blossom. Devoted father of Peter Marschark and Ronald and Anne (Marschark) Paltrowitz. Cherished grandfather of Jason, Nanci, Max and Lucas. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, March 18, 10:30 AM at the Plaza Funeral Home, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Letters to the President
description: Following are excerpts from letters to President Clinton from Kathleen E. Willey after the time she said he tried to sexually force himself on her on Nov. 29, 1993:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARVEY, GEORGE EDWARD
description: HARVEY-George Edward. Beloved husband of the late Nancy. Devoted father of George and Joyce Harvey, Clare and Barry Feldman, Joan and Manny Fonseca and John and Cathy Harvey. Loving grandfather of 11. He was a veteran of WW II, President of Harvey-Geary Assocs. Visitation Tuesday, March 17 at Barrett and Sons FH, 422 West 51 Street, NY, 7 to 9PM. Services at Holy Cross Church, 329 W. 42 St, NY, NY 10AM Wed., Mar 18. In lieu of flowers contributions to St. Mary Home Resident Fund, 2021 Albany Avenue, West Hartford, CT. 06117.

title: The Fans Turn Out In Florida
description: The Miami Fusion, Major League Soccer's new team in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., opened the league's third season with a 2-0 loss to the defending champion, D.C. United, on Sunday, but the Fusion was a huge winner with its fans.

title: Kennedy's Children Assail Auction and Father's Secretary
description: Two days before a bitterly contested auction of John F. Kennedy memorabilia, his two children broke their public silence about the event yesterday and released a statement that harshly criticized their father's longtime secretary, Evelyn Lincoln, for taking many of the personal items being put up for sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, JEAN C.
description: CAMERON-Jean C. On Saturday, March 14, 1998 at the Washington Home. Wife of the late Dr. D. Ewen Cameron. Mother of Airlie Lennon, Duncan, Stuart, and James Cameron. Grandmother of eight. Services private. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests memorial contributions to Alzheimer's Assn, 919 N. Michigan Ave, #

title: Thomas H. Johnson, 98, Cosmic Ray Physicist
description: Dr. Thomas H. Johnson, a cosmic ray physicist whose findings were part of the foundation for the field of high energy physics, died on Feb. 25 at his home in Denmark, Me. He was 98.

title: Buyer of Used Car at Auction Finds Woman's Body in Trunk
description: A man who had purchased a used car at a recent government auction in Brooklyn discovered the body of a woman in the trunk of the car when he returned to pick it up, the police said yesterday.

title: Jurors Seem Unfazed by Photos of Brawley
description: Jurors in the defamation trial of Tawana Brawley's former advisers exhibited little reaction today as they looked at what one lawyer called ''horrendous'' photographs of Ms. Brawley covered in feces and with racial slurs scrawled on her body.

title: Tighter Rules Proposed On Casino Contributions
description: Casino executives, the holders of casino licenses and companies that do a major part of their business with the casino industry cannot contribute to most political candidates in New Jersey. The prohibition, part of the original 1977 state legislation that allowed casinos, was passed to prevent the casino industry from having undue influence on politicians and state law. Now, the Assembly has passed two bills that would expand that prohibition.

title: TRACE INTERNATIONAL OFFERS TO BUY ALL FOAMEX SHARES
description: Trace International Holdings Inc., which owns 46 percent of Foamex International Inc.'s common shares outstanding, offered to buy all outstanding Foamex shares it does not already own, for $17 a share. In response to Trace's unsolicited buyout offer, Foamex's board named a special committee to study the proposal. Trace, a private holding company based in New York, owns about 11.5 million Foamex shares. The Trace offer came yesterday evening after Foamex's stock gained 87.5 cents a share, to $14.75. Foamex, based in Linwood, Pa., makes flexible polyurethane and advanced polymer foam products.

title: Free Throws Lift Rutgers, But the Vols Are Up Next
description: C. Vivian Stringer did not need long to realize how big tonight's victory was for her team. Over 26 seasons and 566 victories, Stringer, the Rutgers women's basketball coach has taken two teams to the Final Four and four to a regional final. But tonight's victory clearly earned a special place in her heart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTANGELO, BETTY L.
description: SANTANGELO-Betty L. Beloved wife of the late Congressman Alfred E., devoted mother of Mary Jo Nocero, Eileen Hult, Betty J. Santangelo, Patricia A. Santangelo, Charles Alfred Santangelo, dear sister of Rose Santangelo, survived by 7 loving grandchildren. Reposing Farenga Brothers Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Ave, Bronx, NY, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Lucy's Church, Wednesday 9:45 A.M. Contributions to the Congressman Alfred E. Santangelo and Betty Santangelo Scholarship Fund, C/O The National Italian American Foundation, 1860 19th Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20009/Attn: Dr. Maria Lombardo, would be greatly appreciated by the Santangelo Family.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEINWAND, JAMES L.
description: LEINWAND-James L. Five years today. We hold you close. Family and friends

title: Gordon Cochran, 74, Ski Coach And Operator of a Vermont Lift
description: Gordon S. (Mickey) Cochran, a skiing coach whose four children became world-class skiers by heeding his instruction for years using the family rope tow in their Vermont back yard, died last Saturday at Respite House, a hospice in Williston, Vt. He was 74.

title: Deposition Might Be His Last Word on Matter
description: President Clinton suggested today that he might have nothing more to say about the numerous accusations of personal and legal misconduct that have emerged in recent weeks.

title: Metro Business; Ethiopia Mission Buys Site
description: The Mission of Ethiopia has paid $3 million for two floors at 2 Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, making it the latest United Nations member to invest in condominium space in the building as an alternative to renting Manhattan offices.

title: Still Laughing
description: The punch lines linger on. Henny Youngman's death last month did not prevent a dozen other comedians from trading reminiscences (and a few jokes) yesterday, on what would have been his 92d birthday.

title: From Capstar And a Rival, A New-Breed Hotel REIT
description: The Capstar Hotel Company and the American General Hospitality Corporation said today that they had agreed to merge in a transaction valued around $530 million, combining fast-growing companies with premium hotels in big cities including Los Angeles and Dallas.

title: Solemn Words Offered by the Vatican: A Call to Penitence
description: Following is the text of the Vatican document about the Holocaust, ''We Remember: A Reflection on the Shoah.'' The statement was issued today by the Commission for Religious Relations With the Jews. The source of each quotation not identified in the text was cited in a footnote.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Surges 116 Points, As Market Sets Records

title: Texaco-Chevron Venture
description: Texaco Inc. and the Chevron Corporation will spend $185 million to develop a natural-gas site nearly two-thirds of a mile below the surface of the Gulf of Mexico. Drilling at the Gemini project in 3,400 feet of water will begin later this year, with first production in mid-1999, Texaco said. Texaco owns 60 percent and Chevron 40 percent of the reserve.

title: Kodak Tries to Improve Morale With Stock Options and Promises
description: Nearly three months after telling employees that it would discharge more than 19,000 of them, the Eastman Kodak Company began an all-out attempt yesterday to raise the morale of workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, DR. IRVING
description: RUBIN-Dr. Irving. April 7th, 1916March 13th, 1998. Distinguished pharmaceutical publisher, editor, writer, and educator. Caring husband to Florence, very loving father to Joanne and Saul, and devoted Grandpa to Jenny, Alex, Adina, and Sylvie. Irv will be missed dearly by his family, friends and the pharmaceutical community.

title: Clinton Proposes Testing
description: Alarmed by the dismal performance of American high school seniors on math and science tests, President Clinton called on states today to require teachers of those subjects to pass ''high-level competency tests'' before receiving licenses.

title: Hunting the Heft Amid the Delicacy
description: A California orchestra playing a Mahler symphony on one day and a mixed program on another: next weekend, it is the Los Angeles Philharmonic, led by Esa-Pekka Salonen at Avery Fisher Hall; last Thursday and Friday evenings, it was the San Francisco Symphony, conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas at Carnegie Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANT, MARTIN B. (MARTY)
description: GANT-Martin B. (Marty), 77. Of Boca Raton, FL. Passed away in peace at his home Sunday, March 15, 1998. He was born in Brooklyn, New York, Jan. 19, 1921, the son of the late Bernard and Rebecca Gantmacher. He was a University of Connecticut graduate and a U.S. Army Air Corp. B-17 pilot in World War II. He was co-founder and President of Gant Shirtmakers of New Haven, CT. He was active in numerous political, community and civic organizations including the New Haven Jewish Federation. He is survived by his loving wife, Rene, son, Benjamin S. Gant of St. Croix, U.S.V.I., daughter and son-in-law, Elise G. and Joseph W. Mooney of Branford, CT., son and daughter-in-law, Mark L.S. and Lisa A.B. Gant of Guilford, CT., grandchildren, Jacob and Aaron Gant of Guilford, CT., and brother, Elliot B. Gant of Barnard, VT. He was pre-deceased by his sister, Frances Gantmacher. A private memorial service was held with his family in Boca Raton, FL. Contributions may be made to Hospice By The Sea, 1531 W. Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL. 33432.

title: A Store Owner Pleads Guilty To Selling Skulls of Indians
description: The owner of a baroque SoHo boutique specializing in human and animal bones pleaded guilty yesterday to selling the skulls of Native Americans illegally and operating what law enforcement officials said was one of the largest rings in the Northeast involved in smuggling the remains of endangered species.

title: Montana Freemen Disrupt Their Trial as Jury Is Picked
description: Angry Montana Freemen were carried, dragged and pushed in wheelchairs into Federal court here, shouting threats and expletives and knocking over furniture as jury selection began for their trial on charges both leading to and stemming from an 81-day standoff with Federal agents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, SIGMUND
description: WEISS-Sigmund. On March 15, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Beulah B. Weiss. Survived by two stepsons, Charles R. and Donald Weil and brother-in-law Leo Bluhm Jr. and nine step-grandchildren. Interment privated.

title: Wide Layoffs Proposed to Cut Hospital Costs
description: Faced with a looming budget shortfall, New York City's public hospital system is seeking to cut hundreds of jobs, and officials are raising the specter of the first large layoffs of hospital workers in nearly two years, city and union officials said yesterday.

title: An Armistice in the Clash Of 2 City Hall Superpowers
description: In recent weeks the two most powerful figures in city government have taunted each other with plans to create their own charter revision commissions. It seems that only in City Hall is the term charter revision considered to be a threat.

title: Judge Limits Disclosures Under 'Megan's Law' in New York
description: Saying New York State needs to rethink how it classifies sex offenders under ''Megan's Law,'' a Federal judge in Manhattan issued a temporary restraining order yesterday that limited the public release of detailed information on such offenders.

title: VATICAN REPENTS FAILURE TO SAVE JEWS FROM NAZIS
description: The Vatican issued a document today that it described as an ''act of repentance'' for the failure of Roman Catholics to deter the mass killing of Europe's Jews during World War II. But the document skirted the painful issue of the Vatican's long silences during the Nazi reign of terror.

title: County Hospital Leased To For-Profit Operators
description: After several years of review and public debate, Bergen Pines County Hospital was officially leased to private operators on Sunday and renamed the Bergen Regional Medical Center. The transaction turned over what was once the state's largest public hospital to a consortium of for-profit managers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDENBAUM, ANNE (ZEIGER)
description: LINDENBAUM-Anne (Zeiger). On March 15, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Sidney, loving sister of Jeanne Schoenberg and Bernice Robinson, dear sister-in-law of Gertrude Lehrhaupt and Elsie Novick. Loved by all whose lives she touched. Service on Wednesday at 12 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Internet Is Expanding Arms Race With Junk E-Mail
description: The Internet's most popular software for routing and delivering E-mail on the Internet is being armed with a powerful set of tools to fight the unsolicited junk electronic mail known as spam, which is increasingly bedeviling cyberspace.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Dancing Up a Storm Of Potpourri

title: Port Authority Won't Increase Tolls on Bridges and Tunnels
description: Tolls on the Port Authority's bridges and tunnels will not go up next year, the authority said yesterday as it announced record profits for 1997 resulting from higher traffic at its bridges, tunnels, airports and rail line.

title: Scouting's Values
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Struggles of the Spirit On an Exotic World Tour

title: China Nears Completion of Leadership Moves
description: China's new leadership lineup was partly completed today as the National People's Congress, the national legislature, elected the man who has been Prime Minister for 10 years, Li Peng, as its next chairman.

title: Democratic Fund-Raiser Pleads Guilty to Fraud and Conspiracy
description: In a deal with Government prosecutors, Johnny Chung, a California businessman and Democratic fund-raiser, pleaded guilty today to bank fraud, tax evasion and conspiracy in connection with $20,000 in illegal contributions to the Clinton-Gore re-election campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCEVOY, BRIAN
description: McEVOY-Brian. March 17, 1967June 20, 1970. Remembered and missed today and always. Love, Meema

title: Planning to Escape From an Abusive Relationship
description: A COMMON response of people who learn that a woman is being battered by the man she lives with is: ''Why doesn't she leave? What kind of woman is she to stay with a man who beats her?'' But experts on domestic violence and the women who are its victims say these questions, though well-meaning, reflect profound ignorance of the tenacious hold abusive men can have on their partners and the often-limited options available to women in abusive relationships.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW: CABARET
description: Fashion Victims, Married Men And Kurt Weill, Take Note

title: U.S. Training of Indonesia Troops Goes On Despite Ban
description: The Pentagon has been training Indonesian military forces in specialized arts of warfare since 1992, despite a Congressional ban intended to curb human rights abuses by those soldiers, Defense Department documents show.

title: TV's Debt to the Public
description: To the Editor:

title: The Moral Weight Of Leadership
description: Regardless of the outcome of the present investigations into President Clinton's alleged misconduct, the controversy swirling around him has raised one question that must not go unanswered: should those in positions of leadership be held to a higher standard of moral and ethical conduct than ordinary citizens?

title: Cendant Lifts Bid for Insurer To $67 a Share
description: Investors in a little-known Miami insurance company awoke yesterday morning to a pleasant if not totally unexpected surprise: the Cendant Corporation, which has been vying for control of the company, had just increased its bid 15.5 percent, to $67 a share.

title: Connecticut Man Guilty Of Internet Indecency
description: A 57-year-old unemployed sales consultant was convicted in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday of sending indecent materials over the Internet to a person he thought was a 13-year-old girl and trying to coax her into having sex.

title: The Loose Cannons At the Arms Factory
description: At the outset of ''BAFO,'' a new play by Tom Strelich, one of the blowhards at the Omega Aerospace Industries enters a conference room and demands of no one in particular, ''What's the threat?'' A colleague plunges into a long litany of dangers to the American way of life as perceived by aging white men, beginning with ''young black males with baseball caps turned backward'' and including ''disgruntled post office workers.'' That turns out to be a preview of what's in store.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEQUEIRA, JACK
description: SEQUEIRA-Jack. Husband of Juanita, father of Albert and Patricia Blum, Poppy to Mark and Randi. Service 11 A.M. Tuesday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Developer Seeks to Build Another Hotel in (Where Else) Times Square
description: The developer Bruce C. Ratner is negotiating with city and state officials to build a 450-room hotel behind his entertainment center now rising on 42d Street in what would be a major revision of the redevelopment plan for Times Square.

title: Food Chain
description: Still Wary of Pork

title: Sports of The Times; LaFontaine Should Not Come Back
description: THE management of Madison Square Garden faces a hard decision, but not the one it had expected. At least Patrick Ewing can walk into a news conference and make jokes and handle questions about his surgically repaired wrist.

title: 'Seinfeld' Reruns
description: In a coup that may prove costly, New York's Fox affiliate, WNYW/ Channel 5, has snatched the rights to ''Seinfeld'' reruns away from WPIX/ Channel 11, which has been showing them since September 1995.

title: Getting a Head Start on Some Garden Gems
description: IT will be several weeks before the spading fork can be added to the list of kitchen utensils. But after such a peculiarly warm winter, with the buds bursting before their time all over the region, the gardening itch can become insistent: Need to plant something, need to get going.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEAVER, DOROTHY DOBBS
description: WEAVER-Dorothy Dobbs. January 12, 1932 - March 14, 1998. Emmy award-winning costume designer. Owner and proprietor of Source III Theatrical Costumes. Member United Scenic Artists since 1970. We mourn the loss of our beloved Dotty, our truly beautiful friend. Her elegance, kindness, wit and courage will be remembered always. Her impeccable taste and exquisite eye were an inspiration to her many admirers, as was her love of the arts, music and animals. Our deepest sympathies to Harry and the Dobbs Family. Fritz Weaver, Rochelle Oliver, Dan Weaver, Blanche Greenstein, Tom Woodard, Roberta Gaal, Linda Stone, Jane Yusko, Charlotte Hobart, Candace Chase, Victoria Grecki, Martin Pakledinaz.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Did Sunbeam go too far to keep Dunlap in its corner office?
description: ALBERT J. DUNLAP does not have much to lose in his new contract as chairman and chief executive of Sunbeam.

title: Women's Groups in a Bind Over Willey
description: She stepped forward, grudgingly, to tell the nation of unwanted sexual advances by a powerful man who was something of a mentor to her. Still, she had gone to work for him. Only after years of silence did she speak out about his behavior. And her first big interview was with Ed Bradley on ''60 Minutes.''

title: Cincinnati Tests Restrictions On Financing of Campaigns
description: At the old Federal Courthouse here, a legal drama began unfolding today that could alter the way political campaigns are conducted throughout the country at all levels of government.

title: A Carnival, of Sorts, With Clowns
description: The long-running adolescent tradition of the gross-out reaches some kind of peak with the Insane Clown Posse, a rap duo from Detroit that performed at Irving Plaza on Saturday night. Cannibalism, torture, nose-picking and hating homework are all fodder for the raps of Violent J and Shaggy 2 Dope, who spend a lot of time thinking about murder and bodily fluids. For them, the escape from teen-age male frustrations -- rejection by women, coercion and hypocrisy from adults -- is fantasies of mayhem as slapstick. Wearing clown makeup, the Insane Clown Posse is proud to be a sick joke.

title: Restaurants; Korean Cuisine, Uniquely Rustic
description: THE soft white custard has the texture of overwhipped cream. It gives, gently, when you dip your spoon into the bowl, allowing a bit of fragrant steam to escape. In the mouth it is warm and savory, not sweet, with the comforting character of chicken soup. It is the most lovable food you can imagine. At least until you hear its name: ''bean curd dregs'' hardly conveys the utter deliciousness of this amiable fare. And ''bean curd restaurant'' cannot adequately express how exciting the eight-month-old Cho Dang Gol can be.

title: Et Cetera
description: A follow-up: MARTHA STEWART says that she was wide awake after the New York premiere of the film ''Wide Awake.'' But her eyes were not open the whole time that VICE PRESIDENT AL GORE was speaking at the dinner that she attended. ''I'm going through eye exercise therapy, strengthening my eyes,'' she said yesterday. ''I'm supposed to sort of, like, rest them, and they get very dry, especially in crowds.'' Her ears were working fine. ''Probably I could repeat the Vice President's speech quite closely,'' she said. . . . BARBARA FELDON, who played Agent 99 on the 1960's sitcom ''Get Smart,'' has been hired as the host of a public-television cooking show. ''I'm looking forward to exploring what in my life has been neglected, which is food, one of life's great daily raptures,'' she said. She will have help, and not from Maxwell Smart: ROBERT SHAPIRO of the French Culinary Institute and ANITA JACOBSON of Peter Kump's cooking school will join her on ''Golden Kitchen.'' JAMES BARRON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, THOMAS M.
description: WYMAN-Thomas M. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 19, 1998 at 5:00PM at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street, New York. Contributions may be made to the Panwy Foundation, 10 Valley Drive-9 Greenwich Office Park, Greenwich, CT. 06831.

title: 21 Items to Go to Archives, but Kennedys Still Seethe Over Auction
description: The 49-year-old collector whose auction of John F. Kennedy memorabilia has invoked the wrath of Kennedy's children agreed yesterday to turn over 21 Kennedy items of historical importance to the National Archives.

title: Knicks Reach Deep To Salvage a Victory
description: Before last night's game, Patrick Ewing spoke self-assuredly of his belief that he would be back in action when the playoffs begin. But his determined words were the only contribution he could make, leaving the day-to-day grind of getting the Knicks to the playoffs in the hands of people like Anthony Bowie.

title: TWINLAB TO PAY $55 MILLION FOR JONES MEDICAL UNIT
description: The Twinlab Corporation of Ronkonkoma, N.Y., said it would buy the Bronson Nutritional division of Jones Medical Industries for $55 million in cash, adding new vitamin and beauty-aid products and mail-order sales to its business. Twinlab sells a line of minerals, fish oils, herbal teas and sports-nutrition supplements through supermarkets, drugstores and specialty retailers. Jones Medical, which is based in St. Louis, said the deal would allow it to spend on acquisitions to expand its line of pharmaceuticals. The Bronson unit had sales of about $31 million last year, Twinlab said. Twinlab shares rose $2 each, to $35.6875, and Jones Medical gained 43.25 cents, to $37.8125.

title: The Chef
description: THIS is a dish from my childhood, one of those home-entertaining concoctions from the 1960's, but I tweaked it. When my mother used to serve a rolled souffle -- a rectangle of airy, baked egg that is formed into the shape of a jellyroll -- it was filled with chopped spinach and ricotta cheese.

title: NBC Hires Collins As N.B.A. Analyst
description: Doug Collins returned to sportscasting yesterday, signing with NBC Sports through 2002 six weeks after being fired as the Detroit Pistons' coach.

title: Mississippi Reveals Dark Secrets of a Racist Time
description: After a 21-year court fight, the state of Mississippi today unsealed more than 124,000 pages of secret files from a state agency that used spy tactics, intimidation, false imprisonment, jury tampering and other illegal methods to thwart the activities of civil rights workers during the 1950's, 60's and early 70's.

title: EDUCATION SOFTWARE RIVALS PLAN $131 MILLION MERGER
description: CBT Group P.L.C., a maker of education software for information-technology professionals, agreed yesterday to acquire a smaller rival, Forefront Group, for $131 million in stock. CBT, which was founded in Dublin and is now based in Menlo Park, Calif., had full-year revenue of $188.6 million. Forefront, based in Houston, had full-year revenue of $18.4 million.
