Under the deal, CBT will issue 0.3137 of an American depository share for each Forefront share. The deal values each Forefront share at $15.685, based on Monday's closing price. Forefront shares rose $1.1875 yesterday, to $14.5625, and the American depository shares of CBT Group fell $1.625 to close at $48.375.

title: Sudan Hinders U.N. Aid as South Faces Famine
description: Buzzards circled the Adet airstrip on a recent morning while Adheil Tong waited with 3,500 other hungry people under the thorn and tamarind trees for aid workers to distribute the food piled at the end of the runway.

title: Even With More Jobs, Unemployment Rises
description: New Jersey's unemployment rate rose a tenth of a percentage point in February -- to 5 percent -- even as the number of jobs in the state increased by 12,500, the State Department of Labor announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHENBERG, EDWARD
description: SCHENBERG-Edward. On March 17th, 1998. Beloved husband of Thedis. Dear brother of Norma Davis. Service on Wednesday 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODER, ADELE KITTREDGE BRODER
description: BRODER-Adele Kittredge Broder. Of Short Hills, N.J., on Monday, March 16, 1998, beloved wife of Robert H. Broder, loving mother of Michael K. and Mary Lee Broder of Dallas, Texas, Thomas K. Broder of Hoboken and James K. Broder of NYC, adoring grandmother of Katherine K. and Brian H. Broder. She is survived by her seven devoted brothers, Ralph G. Webber, Charles Kittredge, George Kittredge and Barry Kittredge, all of Longmeadow, MA, Sidney Kittredge of Enfield, CT, Edward Kittredge of NYC, Dr. Robert L. Kittredge of Cummaquid, MA. She was also the sister of the late Alfred H. Webber and John Robinson. Funeral Service Wednesday, March 18, 11 AM in Congregation B'Nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Ave., Short Hills, NJ. Interment B'Nai Jeshurun Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jewish Communal Fund for the Adele Kittredge Memorial Fund, 130 East 59 St, Suite 1204, New York, NY 10022. A native of Longmeadow, MA., and long time resident of Short Hills, New Jersey, Adele was active in local and state democratic politics, The League of Women Voters, The American Jewish Committee and many other civic and philanthropic organizations.

title: Proficiency of English Declines as Schools Switch to Teaching It as a Second Language : Tongue-Tied in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  A recent telephone call to a major stock brokerage, asking when the manager would be available, produced a confusing reply: "He will call you after the phone."

title: About New York; A Comeback: Add Fortitude To Irish Song
description: THE first pipers had yet to hit Fifth Avenue, but the parade had already started at Adrian Flannelly's midtown studio on Madison Avenue. Nineteen members of the Artane Boys Band, a vision in red and blue from Dublin, wedged themselves into the studio and broke into ''When Irish Eyes Are Smiling.'' In the reception area outside, Irish eyes were scanning the room for sight of Mr. Flannelly, who swept in a few minutes late to preside over the day's festivities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTDIENER, DR. ARTHUR
description: GOTTDIENER-Dr. Arthur. Of Ridgewood, N.J. Beloved husband of Ruth nee Harper. Devoted father of Charles and William, dear brother of Adele Fiddle, loving grandfather of Benjamin. Services were held on Tuesday. For further information Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, N.J. 1-800-522-0588.

title: Little White Dress
description: The New-York Historical Society owns a painting that supposedly shows Viscount Cornbury, a Colonial governor of New York and New Jersey, in a white dress.

title: A Groundbreaking Run For Harvard and the Ivy
description: It was fun while it lasted for the Harvard women's basketball team.

title: Only Patients' Rights Laws Can Rein In Insurers; Small-Claims Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Plea Backfires As Fine Is Raised
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which had agreed to review a $50,000 fine against Howard Miller, a Los Angeles broker, has increased the penalty to $600,000.

title: Thompson Detroit To Stay Downtown
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company, a unit of WPP Group, has decided to keep its Detroit-area office in downtown Detroit rather than move to a suburban site. Blaise Newman, a spokesman for Thompson Detroit, said that the decision had come without any monetary incentives being offered to the agency.

title: SUN MICROSYSTEMS TO PROVIDE DATA IN MICROSOFT INQUIRY
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., enmeshed in a court battle over its Java software language with the Microsoft Corporation, has been asked to provide information to the Justice Department in a continuing antitrust investigation of Microsoft's business practices. A spokeswoman, Anne Little, confirmed yesterday that Sun, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., had received various civil subpoenas from the Justice Department ''several months ago'' as well as from some states that are conducting their own inquiries into Microsoft.

title: INTERNATIONAL GAME BUYS SLOT UNIT FOR $70 MILLION
description: International Game Technology bought the slot machine business of Bass P.L.C. of London yesterday for about $70 million. The unit, called Barcrest Ltd., is the biggest maker of slot machines and has a 40 percent share of the British slot machine market. It sold 36,000 machines in the year that ended last September, generating about $100 million in revenue. The purchase will help International Game Technology sell slot machines in international markets, its president, G. Thomas Baker, said. In December, International Game Technology, based in Reno, agreed to buy an Australian company for $114 million to help it expand in that country's gambling market.

title: Italian Military Concern To Sell More Stock
description: The shares of Finmeccanica S.p.A. soared yesterday after its board approved details of a 1.9 trillion lire ($960 million) stock sale, a key part of the Italian Government's reorganization of the company, a state-owned military and engineering concern. Finmeccanica shares rose 187 lire, to 2,075 ($1.15); trading was suspended after the rise exceeded 10 percent.

title: 'Ally' Commercials
description: One big reason for both NBC's and CBS's Monday problems is the popularity of ''Ally McBeal.'' But if you were one of the 15.4 million fans who tuned into ''Ally McBeal'' this week, you may have felt you weren't seeing as much Ally as you like. This week's episode included an extra-heavy dose of commercials, with the biggest concentration coming in the first commercial break in the show.

title: Mr. Giuliani and the 'L' Word
description: New York's Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, has been testing the waters for a national political career. As far as Republican leaders are concerned, the temperature so far is decidedly icy. Professional politicians could not be expected to fling out the welcome mat for the man who endorsed Mario Cuomo for governor over his own party's candidate. But Mr. Giuliani's chief sin seems to be that he fails to meet the ideological litmus tests that have continually crippled the Republican Party's national ambitions.

title: Crude Oil Falls Further; Some Gasoline Near $1 a Gallon
description: Crude oil sold below $13 for the first time in nine years yesterday, and gasoline declined to the lowest level since 1995, flirting with an average price of $1 a gallon.

title: Only Patients' Rights Laws Can Rein In Insurers; Wrong Conclusion
description: To the Editor:

title: CUNY Trustee Seeks Delay Of Vote on Remedial Classes
description: With less than a week until the trustees of the City University of New York are to vote on banning remedial courses at the senior colleges, John J. Calandra, the primary architect of the proposal, called yesterday for the vote to be postponed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANKOVICH, RICHARD
description: DANKOVICH-Richard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Richard Dankovich, associated with The Times from 1986.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 2 Top S.&L.'s Will Merge, Creating Formidable Giant

title: What Fountain of Youth?
description: To the Editor:

title: Indictments in Death of Girl, 16, Hit by Brick
description: A construction company and one of its supervisors were charged yesterday with manslaughter and other crimes in the death of a 16-year-old girl who was fatally injured in January when a brick fell from the top of a Brooklyn elementary school that was being repaired.

title: Conservative Wins Republican State Primary In Illinois
description: Rejecting the advice of party leaders to pick a centrist woman to run against Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, voters in the Illinois Republican primary today nominated a conservative man, Peter Fitzgerald, who is a strong opponent of abortion and gun control.

title: Topics of The Times; Sentenced to Time in Congress
description: Representative Jay Kim has given new meaning to the term ''serving in Congress.'' Last week the California Republican became the first member convicted of a Federal crime to cast a vote in the House. He is also to become the first member to wander the halls of Congress wearing a court-ordered monitoring bracelet.

title: A Goalie and a Defenseman Are Isles' Trade Priorities
description: The Islanders, who are on the verge of missing the playoffs for the fourth consecutive season, also might be on the verge of more changes as the March 24 trade deadline approaches.

title: 'Good Vibes' for Tourists, Not for New Yorkers; Warrant for Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, CATHERINE P.
description: DAVIDSON-Catherine P. Beloved wife of Frederick Q. Davidson, mother of Joanne Klein and Ginny Hansburg, grandmother of David and Alexander Klein and Jon and David Hansburg.

title: Not Even McBach?
description: Two classical music record labels spent St. Patrick's Day celebrating music that was definitely not Irish. Deutsche Grammophon had a lunch at Firebird, a restaurant on West 46th Street with a lavish air of czarist aristocracy, to salute MIKHAIL PLETNEV and his Russian National Orchestra, which was founded as the Soviet Union was breaking up.

title: A Firebrand Suffragist Who Challenged Her Era
description: OTHER POWERS

title: The Vatican's Holocaust Report
description: At the direction of Pope John Paul II, the Vatican has labored for 11 years to address its behavior during the Holocaust. That study has now yielded a carefully crafted statement that goes further than the Roman Catholic Church has ever gone in reckoning honestly with its passivity during the Nazi era and its historic antipathy toward Jews. This breaking of new political and theological ground by the Vatican is important and welcome. Yet the document disappointingly stops well short of the unflinching acknowledgments of responsibility that Catholic bishops in France and other European countries have produced in recent years.

title: Hearings Focus on Union Pacific Rail Safety
description: After Union Pacific bought Southern Pacific in 1996, snarled rail traffic cost shippers billions of dollars and a series of crashes last year left 11 people dead. Federal authorities hardly glanced at whether this $5.4 billion deal, the industry's largest, would compromise safety.

title: Whitney Museum Chief Is Leaving for New Job
description: David A. Ross, the director of the Whitney Museum of American Art since 1991, said yesterday that he would leave the Whitney to become director of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art on July 1.

title: Woman in Internet Case Says Accused Beat Her
description: A strange first date between Internet pen pals turned sinister after the conversation turned from philosophy and politics to the nature of evil, the primary witness against Oliver Jovanovic testified yesterday.

title: Phillips Will Not Give Cook Extension
description: Mets General Manager Steve Phillips has said this spring that he will entertain requests for contract extensions on a one-by-one basis. So far, though, left-handed relievers are 0 for 2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEIL, THOMAS F.
description: O'NEIL-Thomas F. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board, and members of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City note the passing of Thomas F. O'Neil, former Chairman of RKO General. Tom was a staunch supporter of people with cerebral palsy and related disabilities over many, many years. Through his efforts RKO sponsored UCP's annual telethon broadcasts over its New York station WWOR-TV (Channel 9). For this and for his many other generous contributions, he was awarded UCP's Humanitarian Award in 1984. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Claire and all the family. Leo Hausman, President Jack Hausman, Founder UCP of NYC, Inc.

title: Briggs Is Confident For Lewis Bout
description: Shannon Briggs is not ashamed to have defeated George Foreman in a majority decision last November that was so controversial that Foreman protested the outcome. He hopes to channel the self-confidence into a victory over Lennox Lewis in their World Boxing Council heavyweight title bout in Atlantic City on March 28.

title: Family Planning Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, SAMUEL
description: GOLDMAN-Samuel. The Rabbi, Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Beth-El, Cedarhurst, New York, and its Affiliates express deepest sympathy on the passing of its member. We grieve with the family on its loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Allan Kroningold, President

title: Metro Business; S.E.C. Files Lawsuit Against Radio Host
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a suit yesterday against the host of an investment-advice radio show in New York, saying he had not fully disclosed that he was being paid by the companies whose stocks he was promoting on the air.

title: Bellini's Version of a Classic
description: Given how vast the catalogue of operatic rarities is, the efforts by music schools to revive lost works is usually rewarding. But what could the Mannes College of Music Opera have been thinking when it dusted off Bellini's version of the Romeo and Juliet story, ''I Capuleti e i Montecchi,'' for a performance at the Dicapo Opera Theater (184 East 76th Street) on Sunday evening, with repeats last night, tomorrow night and Saturday?

title: Population Of New York Rises Slightly
description: More than a million New Yorkers moved out of the city during the 1990's, but new immigrants and children born to them have more than replaced those who left, according to Federal Census figures released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOVES, PHILLIP M.
description: SLOVES-Phillip M. On March 16, 1998. Of Briarcliff Manor, NY. Formerly of New York City. Survived by son John Glickman, brother Marvin Sloves, sister Flora Sloves, aunt Estelle Aster and two grandchildren. Memorial services to be announced at a later time. For further information, contact Waterbury and Kelly Funeral Home, 914-941-0838.

title: Sports of The Times; In the Meadowlands, The Moment of Truth
description: THE weary, bedraggled New Jersey Nets, appearing as though they had been plucked out of a hamper for the game Monday night, had just suffered another defeat, their eighth in nine games, this one to the Bulls, 88-72, in the United Center in Chicago. It was their fourth road game in seven days -- to the Nets, the seven days felt like seven weeks. It was the first time in months the team had dropped below the eighth -- and last playoff -- spot in the Eastern Conference, a half-game behind Washington.

title: Old Allies Part Ways On Opening Files of Hate
description: The wrongness of the Mississippi Sovereignty Commission, like the worry lines in an old man's face, has deepened over time.

title: Like Watching Al Gore
description: Vice President Al Gore has a dream -- a 24-hour Earth Channel that people could tune in to anytime, day or night, to watch high-definition satellite pictures of their planet. Mr. Gore's Presidential aspirations are no secret, and some critics say the channel would be nothing more than a round-the-clock promotion to remind voters that the environment is his signature policy concern.

title: Test Kitchen; Clever Designs for Kitchen or Table
description: A Disk for the Crisper

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It will probably bring forth some memories of a bad time in the state, which we all acknowledge was a bad time now. I hope it'll be the basis for understanding that we can't ever lapse back into the kind of intolerance we once had in this state.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SAMUEL S.
description: MILLER-Samuel S. The members of Rockrimmon Country Club are saddened by the passing of their longtime member and good friend and extend sincere sympathy to his wife and family. Leonard Danon, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANEL, RALPH I.
description: FLANEL-Ralph I. March 17, 1998, after a valiant struggle against ALS. Beloved husband of Renee, loving father of Ted & Diane Piniaris. Services Thursday, 11:30 Garlick-Hellman F.H., Yonkers, NY.

title: Operating Profit Up 58% At Credit Suisse Group
description: Credit Suisse Group said yesterday that its profit before charges rose 58 percent in 1997, helped by rising trading income at its investment bank, Credit Suisse First Boston. The bank's 1997 profit before charges for acquisitions and provisions for various risks rose to 3.4 billion Swiss francs ($2.3 billion), compared with 2.15 billion francs in 1996.

title: Polls Are Split On Credibility Of Key Figures
description: In the aftermath of newly detailed accusations of sexual misconduct against President Clinton, the American public continues to approve of his job performance, but is divided on whether to believe Mr. Clinton or his latest accuser, Kathleen E. Willey, three national polls have found.

title: Calendar
description: What We Ate 100 Years Ago

title: No. 1 Rating For '60 Minutes'
description: For the first time in more than four years, ''60 Minutes'' finished No. 1 in the weekly Nielsen ratings, as about 28.75 million people on Sunday night watched Ed Bradley's interview with Kathleen E. Willey, the former White House volunteer who has accused President Clinton of making an unwelcome sexual advance to her.

title: Credit Card Delinquency
description: The percentage of credit card holders behind on their payments fell at the end of last year to a three-year low, the American Bankers Association said today. The association said 3.04 percent of credit card accounts were delinquent in the fourth quarter, down from 3.53 percent in the third quarter. The report defines credit card accounts more than 30 days overdue as delinquent.

title: S.E.C. Charges Executives in Pyramid Scheme
description: International Heritage Inc., a North Carolina company that describes itself as a direct sales organization, and three of its founders were charged Monday with luring 155,000 investors into a giant pyramid scheme that raised $150 million.

title: Republicans Clashing on Impeachment
description: With the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, going full throttle on his investigation of President Clinton, House Republicans are starting to ponder privately, and disagree, on how best to handle the possibility of an impeachment inquiry.

title: Two Drug Wholesalers Plan to Fight F.T.C.
description: Two pharmaceutical wholesalers Cardinal Health Inc. and the Bergen Brunswig Corporation -- plan to contest the Federal Trade Commission's attempt to block their proposed $2.62 billion merger, Cardinal Health said today.

title: Injuries to LaFontaine and Beukeboom Are Serious
description: As their playoff hopes flicker, as the trade deadline approaches and as their disappointing season wobbles toward its conclusion, the Rangers' medical crises grew considerably worse today. Two key players who were injured Monday night in a 5-4 victory over the Ottawa Senators at Madison Square Garden were hurt more severely than first thought, the team announced after practice at Playland Ice Casino.

title: All Sorts of Sweetness for Harrick
description: Jim Harrick walked into the small press room at Mackal Field House yesterday with box of chocolates. How fitting.

title: Op-Art; 9 REASONS THAT ASTEROID 1997 XF11 CHANGED ITS MIND
Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the reaction to the director Robert Wilson's staging of Wagner's ''Lohengrin'' at the Metropolitan Opera House misstated the date of an earlier Wilson collaboration there. His staging of Philip Glass's ''Einstein on the Beach'' was in 1976, not 1986.

title: Business Travel: Open Skies, Closed Markets?; Growing Debate Over Keeping Airlines Competitive
description: When the bankrupt Western Pacific Airlines stopped flying last month, Frontier Airlines, one of its rivals at Denver's sprawling new airport, offered to honor its outstanding tickets, splitting the revenue 50-50. But just when Frontier thought it had sealed the deal, United Airlines, which controls more than 70 percent of the seats flown in and out of Denver, swooped in and reached its own agreement.

title: Managed Care Is Found To Grow in Popularity
description: The number of businesses in New Jersey offering managed care insurance plans to their employees has doubled over the last four years, according to a survey released yesterday.

title: Of Star-Crossed Lovers, In Art, Not Real Life
description: The house was sold out for the return of the tenor Roberto Alagna and the soprano Angela Gheorghiu to the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night as the star-crossed lovers in Gounod's ''Romeo et Juliette.'' And there was a palpable sense all evening that the audience was rooting for them.

title: Gift Shop Owner Dies After Beating at Store
description: A 61-year-old shopkeeper died early this morning from head wounds he suffered while attempting to stop a teen-ager he thought was shoplifting, the authorities said.

title: British Company Is Acquiring Inland Steel
description: Ispat International N.V. said today that it plans to buy the Inland Steel Company of Chicago for $888.2 million plus $538.6 million in assumed debt to expand in the United States, where construction and manufacturing growth has fueled steel demand.

title: Chase Will Lay Off 2,250 in Latest Cuts
description: Chase Manhattan, the nation's largest bank, said yesterday that it planned to lay off 2,250 employees, or about 3 percent of the work force.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Sonia Gandhi's consolidation of her control of the Congress Party in India referred incorrectly in some editions to her new role. She has agreed to become the parliamentary leader of the party, but has not said whether she will seek a seat in Parliament. (Under a new amendment to the party's constitution, the parliamentary chairman does not have to be a member of Parliament.)

title: Bridge to Pay $510 Million For Dow Jones Data Business
description: Capping weeks of negotiations, Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its troubled financial information business to Bridge Information Systems for $360 million in cash and $150 million in Bridge preferred stock.

title: Eating Out in Moscow: Theme-Park Cuisine
description: Unruly and almost lawless, Russia today is often compared to Chicago in the roaring 20's -- a free-market jungle where businessmen settle scores with gun blasts, bureaucrats line their pockets and vast fortunes are amassed overnight. But when it comes to the novel pursuit of fine dining, Moscow is closer to Los Angeles in the 30's.

title: 'Good Vibes' for Tourists, Not for New Yorkers
description: To the Editor:

title: Rutgers Women Take Confident Aim At Bringing Down the Best: Tennessee
description: In her first two years as the women's basketball coach at Rutgers, C. Vivian Stringer struggled. Her team lost more games than it won. Some players missed their old coach and left the team.

title: Rally Fades on Mixed Economic Signs
description: An early bond market rally quickly faded yesterday and prices finished lower, hurt by mixed signals on the economy's strength.

title: S. J. Makowsky, 68, Sports Announcer
description: Stanley Jay Makowsky, a prominent figure in radio sports broadcasting under the name Stan Martyn for decades, died on March 1 at Temple University hospital in Philadelphia. He was 68.

title: Apple Executives To Receive Stock
description: Apple Computer Inc. has set aside 17 million shares, or 13 percent of its total shares outstanding, to be awarded to executives in an effort to prevent the loss of top talent.

title: SEED COMPANY SELLS BIOTECHNOLOGY STAKE TO DOW UNIT
description: Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its remaining two million shares of the Mycogen Corporation to Dow Agrosciences for $20.06 a share, or $40.12 million total. With the purchase, Dow AgroSciences owns 69 percent of Mycogen, a biotechnology company in San Diego that develops seeds and valued-added traits for genetically enhanced crops. Pioneer, based in Des Moines, supplies genetically engineered agricultural products and markets seeds and microbial products to farmers and grain processors. Dow Agrosciences, in Indianapolis, is a unit of the Dow Chemical Company. In 1995, Pioneer bought three million shares of Mycogen as part of a $51 million deal. It later sold a million shares to Dow AgroSciences.

title: Off the Menu
description: French Star Chefs Unite

title: Calipari Denies a Report That He Will Leave the Nets
description: John Calipari has endured a hard month, struggling to survive his team's worst stretch of the season. But the Nets' coach said yesterday that, no matter how he may yell and scream on the sideline, he has no intention of leaving New Jersey any time soon.

title: Movements From Lips To Feet
description: Every now and then a dance comes along that one would like to abscond with to a desert island. It is not necessarily that the work is better done than most, but simply that it is a fascinating world unto itself. ''(Voice Tells) 14 Tiny Pictures, No More No Less,'' presented by Jennifer Lacey and Zeena Parkins on Saturday night at Performance Space 122, was such a piece.

title: Netanyahu Angrily Cancels Dinner With Visiting Briton
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu angrily canceled a dinner today with the British Foreign Secretary, charging that the visiting official had violated an agreement by meeting with Palestinians at the planned site of a disputed Jewish settlement.

title: Vigilant Eyes Fill Skies Over Los Angeles
description: When the sun sinks over the Pacific and the freeways fill with cars, when the nightly newscasts start and the bad guys begin to cruise, the big birds rise -- two, three, five, a dozen helicopters hovering in the California twilight, trolling for trouble, ready to televise it live.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, ELLEN
description: WOLFSON-Ellen. On Tuesday March 17, 1998 at age 73. Survived by her husband Irving, daughter Nora, son Adam and sister Marlies. We miss her, and she will be with us always. Funeral services at Kol Ami Chapel in the Woods, Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York, on Wednesday, March 18 at 1 P.M. For more information: Ballard Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, New York.

title: Michelin Falls Short Of Profit Expectations
description: Michelin, the world's largest tire maker, said yesterday that its second-half profit rose a lower-than-expected 24 percent, as a drop in Asian sales partly offset gains in Europe and the United States. The company earned 2.01 billion French francs ($330 million), up from 1.62 billion francs a year earlier. Earnings for the last six months of 1997 were calculated by subtracting first-half profit from full-year profit.

title: Gay Rights Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic's Notebook; A Taste of What the Early Bird Caught
description: THE waiter looks worried. He makes a gesture with his hands, searching for words.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIERRA, MARCELINO F.
description: SIERRA-Marcelino F. (Ph.D.) Of Rockville Centre. Succumbed on March 16 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, at age 54 following a long, noble, hard fought battle against cancer. His family, friends and colleagues deeply mourn his passing. He was a loving husband to Lorraine; beloved son of Natalie; a devoted father to Michael and Kevin; dear brother of Elisa Guttierez; cherished uncle of Miguel Guttierez and a caring and loyal friend to all who were touched by him, and a leader in his chosen field of microbiology. He received his Ph.D. in microbiology from St. John's University and since 1974, had been the Director of Microbiology at King's County Hospital Center and the University Hospital of Brooklyn and Associate Professor of Pathology at the SUNY Health Science Center at Brooklyn. He was a member of the American Society for Microbiology, the New York Society of Infectious Diseases, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the Infectious Diseases Society of America, the Pan American Group for Rapid Viral Diagnosis, and he was the Chairman of the Microbiology Division of the New York Academy of Science (from 1984-1986) and Codirector of Workshop in Clinical Laboratory Sciences. He is the author of numerous scientific publications and was especially recognized for his contributions to the development of methods for the laboratory diagnosis of mycobacterial infections. In 1997 he received the bio Merieux Vitek Distinguished Achievements in Clinical Microbiology Award for his contributions to the NYC branch of the American Society for Microbiology. Visiting Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at the Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial, Saturday, 10:15 A.M. at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bklyn. In lieu of flowers or donations to charities, contributions may be sent to: The Dr. Marcelino F. Sierra Memorial Fund. Kindly make checks payable to: The NYC Branch of the ASM and mail them to: P.O. Box 736, Westbury, New York 11590. His impact was profound, both personal and professional. Goodness, generosity, compassion, wisdom and strength are his legacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ONGLEY, PATRICK A.
description: ONGLEY-Patrick A. The Trustees, Officers and staff of the China Medical Board of New York, Inc., mourn the passing of a former President, Dr. Patrick Ongley. We extend our sincere condolences to his beloved wife, daughter, son and grandchildren. Dr. Ongley served as President and Trustee from January 1, 1970 until June 30, 1989. He led the China Medical Board's return in 1980 to the support of medical educational institutions in China. Furthermore, his unique understanding of the complex social, economic and political problems in Asia contributed much to the rapid progress of the China Medical Board's programs in various countries. The Board will miss him.

title: You Want to Slap Ally McBeal, but Do You Like Her?
description: All those quarrels about the true nature of ''Ally McBeal,'' that television comedy filled with bright young women and men, every one of them successful corporate lawyers with attractively complicated private lives. (''Ally'' is the writer David E. Kelley's right-side-of-the-Boston-tracks comedy on Fox. ''The Practice,'' on ABC, is his wrong-side-of-the-Boston-tracks drama, filled with smart, exhausted, not always young defense lawyers, whose lives are as grueling as the legal system they try to outmaneuver.)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ETKIN, SUSAN BODNER
description: ETKIN-Susan Bodner. Remembered today and every day. Forever loved and missed. Mother

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTINGER, FLORICA, M.D.
description: ETTINGER-Florica, M.D. On Mar. 15, 1998. Services Wednesday 11:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Koong-Kai Tse, 91, Insurance Executive
description: Koong-Kai Tse, a former senior executive of the American International Group, one of the nation's largest insurers, died March 9 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 91 and lived in New York and Miami.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRINET CORPORATE REALTY TRUST, San Francisco, and Whitehall Street Real Estate, an affiliate of Goldman Sachs & Co., bought a New Orleans office complex from Koll/Bren Realty Advisors for $114.3 million.

title: Anne Sayre, 74, Whose Book Credited a DNA Scientist, Dies
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENENBERG, HARRY
description: DENENBERG - Harry. Devoted husband of the late Tessie. Beloved father of Fern DenenbergFriedman and Alan. Dear brother of Beatrice Hoberman and the late Morris Denenberg. Services today 1 P.M. at ''Weinstein-West End Chapel,'' 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Murder Victim's Photo Is Banned From Trial
description: A picture of a 16-year-old murder victim cannot be displayed in the courtroom during the trial of the youth accused of killing her, a state judge ruled yesterday.

title: Novartis Posts 76% Rise In Net for Half-Year
description: Novartis A.G. of Switzerland said yesterday that its net income increased 76 percent in the second half of 1997 as profit margins over all widened for the company, which was created through the $36 billion combination of Ciba-Geigy A.G. and Sandoz A.G. The earnings of Novartis, the largest health care company in the world, climbed to 2.09 billion Swiss francs ($1.4 billion) from 1.19 billion francs in the period a year earlier.

title: 'Good Vibes' for Tourists, Not for New Yorkers; Futile Drug War
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Hurt by Falling Bricks at Brooklyn School
description: A 100-foot-long brick parapet that was being renovated at a Brooklyn elementary school collapsed onto the school's roof yesterday afternoon, critically injuring a construction worker, injuring two students and closing the school at least until tomorrow, school officials said.

title: Vornado Reported to Be in Talks for Barney's
description: Vornado Realty Trust, the aggressive real estate investment trust that appears to pride itself on flashy deals, is in talks with Barney's Inc., people close to the retail company said yesterday.

title: Topics of The Times; Mixed Military Training
description: By declining to segregate women during basic training, Defense Secretary William Cohen sends the right message that gender integration is vital to the modern military. After several military sex scandals, a special advisory panel convened by Mr. Cohen and headed by former Senator Nancy Kassebaum Baker recommended last December that the Army, Navy and Air Force separate new recruits into single-sex training units and house them in single-sex barracks. The Marines already segregate training by sex.

title: Biggest S.& L.'s In Merger Deal Of $9.9 Billion
description: The nation's two largest savings and loan companies, once intense rivals in the takeover game, agreed yesterday to merge in a $9.9 billion stock swap that would create a West Coast behemoth capable of competing with the new giants of consumer banking.

title: Albany Democrats Urge $100 Million to House Homeless
description: The Democrats who control the State Assembly proposed spending $100 million today to renew a program that had created housing for thousands of mentally ill homeless people in New York City.

title: Liberties; Libido Games
description: When The Washington Star folded in 1981, it was hard for me to find another job. I got a little desperate.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSE, MAUD
description: ROSE-Maud. Honoring the memory of this remarkable woman on her one hundredth birthday. Her family; Adele, Belinda, Allison, Bret, Derek, Daphne, Taryn, Jed

title: Sips; Vodka With a Savory, Herbal Edge
description: MANY of the newly popular infused vodkas seem to have borrowed their flavorings from scented candles or hard candy. So it is refreshing to taste one with soul.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the Government's concerns about the Lockheed Martin Corporation's proposed purchase of the Northrop Grumman Corporation misidentified the maker of the B-2 ''stealth'' bomber. It is Northrop, not Lockheed.

title: 2,250 Layoffs Set at Chase, Or 3% of Staff
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's largest bank, said yesterday that it planned to lay off about 2,250 employees, or about 3 percent of its work force, as it consolidates administrative and business functions.

title: INSIDE
description: Willey Talks Acknowledged

title: Adventurer With Brightly Colored Stories
description: It is possible that photojournalists are our modern-day Gypsies, arriving in town on the wind with their charm and brightly colored stories, stealing what is most precious. Then gone, leaving everyone with the feeling that their lives are more adventurous, more fun than our own.

title: No White House Attack
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about used-book shops in northwestern Massachusetts misstated the name of the restaurant on the floor below the Book Mill in Montague. It is the Blue Heron, not the Blue Pheasant.

title: Wine Talk; Bordeaux Tour, by Invitation, Bus or Book
description: SOME years ago, curious to see the Bordeaux wine country through the eyes of a tourist, I took a chateau tour, just for a day. Actually, I hooked onto a tour group that had arrived from New York the day before. It was a chilly spring morning as the visitors boarded their bus in downtown Bordeaux, excited at the prospect of experiencing, even briefly, life in the fabled wine chateaus.

title: Daniel Katz, 94, Professor of Psychology
description: Daniel Katz, a retired University of Michigan psychology professor who was an expert on organizational psychology, died on Feb. 28. He was 94 and lived in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDERSON, JANE, NEE MOVERY
description: HENDERSON-Jane, nee Movery, 87. Died Mar. 16, 1998 at Chandler Hall Nursing Home, Newtown, PA. Beloved mother of Ward Thomas Henderson of NYC and Richard Clark Henderson of Baltimore, MD. Predeceased by her husband, Thomas Wayne Henderson. Service on March 20, at 11 A.M., St. Andrew's Church, Newtown, PA.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Residential Real Estate; Insignia Financial Announces Plans for a Corporate Restructuring
description: Insignia Financial Group, a real estate investment and services company, announced a financial restructuring yesterday that would create a separate company based in New York that conducts real estate sales and service operations nationally and internationally and manages 57,000 cooperative apartments and condominiums in the metropolitan area.

title: Payson Wild, 92, Retired University Provost
description: Payson Sibley Wild, a retired professor of international relations and provost emeritus of Northwestern University, died on Feb. 23 at his home in Evanston, Ill. He was 92.

title: Mayors Thought Big, Nation Said 'No!'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, LEONARD
description: APPEL-Leonard. On March 16, 1998. Beloved son of the late Jack and Emma Appel. Cherished brother of Nanette Appel Bloom. Loving uncle of Joshua and Thomas Bloom. Service Thursday 11 A.M. at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Spike Lee's joint venture with DDB Needham seeks to grow beyond 'urban marketing.'
description: AFTER a year in business, the joint venture agency formed by the director Spike Lee and DDB Needham Worldwide is making progress as it makes organizational and management changes. But challenges continue to confront the partners in Spike DDB, as the fledgling New York agency is called, in seeking to forge a distinctive identity in an overcrowded industry.

title: Changing Parenthood With 8 Words
description: I was born in Trinidad in 1958; my father was doing a year of anthropological fieldwork, and my parents were living in a small East Indian village.

title: Shot-Putting's Little Big Man
description: On a recent blustery afternoon at Bayonne Park, Kevin DiGiorgio pushed his father's car across the parking lot, sprinted down a field while pulling a sled carrying 300 pounds and raced up a hill with 140 pounds of extra weight on his torso.

title: Industrial Production Is Unchanged; Housing Soars
description: Industrial production was unchanged in February even as the nation's housing market boomed, signs that domestic demand was offsetting whatever ill effects the economy was feeling from Asia's crisis.

title: Junked Car's Owner Found at Last
description: The police are no longer looking for the owner of a junked and abandoned car in which a body was discovered on Tuesday after the car was sold at a sheriff's auction in Brooklyn. He was the man in the trunk, investigators said.

title: Costs Are Seen On Target To Meet Goals In Curriculum
description: State education officials said today that estimates on the amount of financing needed to meet new curriculum standards adopted in 1996 were largely on target and that only a slight increase in spending would be necessary to continue to meet those standards in the next few years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFRAN, MELVIN H.
description: SAFRAN-Melvin H. On March 16 at home. Age 85. Born in South Amboy, New Jersey, and graduated from Rutgers University. He served in the Pacific during World War II. He was a founder of the real estate firm Safran Brothers, together with his late brother, Ira. He served as President of the Middlesex County Board of Realtors, the N.J. YMHA-YWHA Camps and Hollywood Golf Club. He was a longtime Director of Amboy Bancorporation. He is survived by his beloved wife of 47 years, Nan, two sons and their wives, Andrew and Linda of N.Y.C., Charles and Donna of Boston, and a daughter, Barbara Esrig of Gainesville, FL. He is also survived by six adored grandchildren, Rachel, Julie, Caroline, and Lily Safran, and Aaron and Ariel Esrig, and two great grandchildren, Jacob and Molly. Services will be held Wednesday, March 18, 11 AM, at Temple Beth Mordecai 224 High Street, Perth Amboy, New Jersey. The family will be receiving friends on Wednesday and Thursday evening at their home in N.Y.C. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Monmouth Medical Center Health Care Foundation or the Lighthouse, Inc.

title: Food Stuff
description: A Radicchio By Another Name

title: Senate Panel Tries to Get I.M.F. to Tighten Its Lending Process
description: A Senate panel approved $18 billion in financing for the International Monetary Fund today, but only if the fund formally votes to make major changes in the way it lends money to nations in distress.

title: After a Plea Deal, Youth Has Monitor Taken Off
description: Except for awaiting sentence in the death of his newborn baby, Brian C. Peterson can now live almost like any other teen-ager.

title: Beating Barnes & Noble
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. FISCAL PLAN REJECTS PROGRAMS SOUGHT BY CLINTON
description: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee today proposed a Republican fiscal blueprint for next year that rejects nearly all of President Clinton's calls for increased domestic spending but provides smaller tax cuts than sought by many Republicans.

title: Putting a Voice Through Its Paces
description: On Sunday afternoon, just 38 hours after finishing a Friday night performance at the Metropolitan Opera in the daunting role of Wagner's Lohengrin, the Canadian tenor Ben Heppner was across the plaza in Avery Fisher Hall, singing a substantive program of arias with the Orchestra of St. Luke's, conducted by Julius Rudel. And this may explain why Mr. Heppner had an off day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, BENEDICT
description: GINSBERG-Benedict. 1908-1998. Mr. and Mrs Herbert R. Weissberg and Family mourn the passing of the greatest lawyer and loyal friend for more than forty years. We will miss him every day.

title: Frank McCullough, Politician and Judge, 92
description: Frank S. McCullough, a former New York State lawmaker and justice in State Supreme Court in Westchester, died last Wednesday at the United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 92 and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Be It Wharton or Darla Moore, Not for Nothing Is a B-School So Named
description: Darla Moore really does have it all: After growing up on a small South Carolina farm, she goes to Wall Street and becomes a queen of capitalism. She marries a fellow deal maker worth around $1.5 billion and has a career so meteoric that it propels her onto the cover of Fortune magazine, which terms her the ''toughest babe'' in business.

title: WPP Group Buys Smith & Jones
description: WPP Group P.L.C. in London said yesterday that it had acquired Smith & Jones Communications Ltd., a business-to-business agency in Henley, England, that specializes in high-technology accounts. Terms were not disclosed. Smith & Jones, which will join WPP's Specialist Communications Group, has billings estimated at $13.3 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBART, PHILIP P.
description: LUBART-Philip P. Attorney-atLaw and Captain of the NYU 1930 Fencing Team. Beloved father of Mark. Dear brother of Jessie Levey. Adored uncle and great uncle. Cherished brother-in-law of Gertrude Elkind. Services Thursday, 1PM, at ''The Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', Brooklyn, 312 Coney island Avenue at Prospect Park.

title: As Czech Skinheads Escalate Attacks, Gypsies Start to Put Up a Fight
description: PRAGUE  Helena Bihariova, 26, did not deserve to die on the night of Feb. 17. Her only crime was to be a dark-skinned Czech citizen of Gypsy origin in the northern Czech town of Vrchlabi.

title: 'Got Milk?' Gets Hot Wheels Truck
description: The Hot Wheels line of miniature vehicles, best known for souped-up sports cars, is adding something different to its lineup: a dairy delivery truck named for the popular ''Got milk?'' campaign by the Goodby, Silverstein & Partners unit of Omnicom Group in San Francisco.

title: U.S. Budges at U.N. Talks on a Permanent War-Crimes Court
description: The final planning session for the first permanent International Criminal Court began here today with legal experts saying that the United States is drawing closer to many other nations on how to define the roles of the Security Council and Governments in deciding what cases are heard.

title: Merrimack In a Shocker
description: Merrimack College's veteran coach, Ron Anderson, had been told his contract would not be renewed for next year. The team had won only nine games and had finished eighth, next to last, in the Hockey East standing. And its last regular-season game was a 9-1 loss to Boston University, the Warriors' 24th defeat of the season.

title: Defendant Described Beating Man With Bar, Witness Says
description: Within hours of a brawl outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub two years ago, a white man admitted during a conversation with a group of friends that he had beaten a black man in the head with an iron bar, a key prosecution witness testified in Suffolk County Criminal Court today.

title: No Evidence Of Sex Assault On Brawley, Nurse Testifies
description: An emergency room nurse who treated and bathed Tawana Brawley in the hours after the teen-ager arrived at the hospital testified in the defamation case against her former advisers today that Ms. Brawley showed no signs of having been sexually assaulted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGUT, BETTY G.
description: COGUT-Betty G. Dear wife of Edgar. Devoted mother of Rick and Judy, Alan and Dana, Steve and Rachelle, Michael and Nancy, Casey and Ellen. Cherished grandmother of Gary, Michelle, Sipora and Avi, Ariel, Aaron, Sarah, Matthew, Noah, Hedy, Sheryl, Pamela and Rachel. Great grandmother of Avraham Moshe and Akiva. Loving sister of Monroe and Naomi Gordon. Services Thursday 12 noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, Long Island.

title: The Heat Is On; Hot sauces are burning their way across America.
description: SPANISH moss hangs lightly from ancient oaks. The bird sanctuaries are alive with brilliant white egrets building their nests. The view of Vermilion Bay from the family manse is breathtaking. Such a privileged and bucolic setting is an unlikely place for a factory of any kind.

title: Woods Confident His 'Slump' Will End
description: For the next month, Tiger Woods will face even more scrutiny than he usually does.

title: Newly Translated, Still Kafkaesque; A Comic Style Emerges in 'The Castle'
description: By the winter of 1922, Franz Kafka was a figure pitiful in his suffering. He had tuberculosis, boils, hemorrhoids and headaches. But there was also something distinctly modern about this writer's pain, in the neurotic way it emanated from his unquiet spirit. His circumstances were for the most part comfortable. He was from an assimilated middle-class Jewish family in Prague. He had a law degree. But so great was his inner turmoil that he could not bear loud voices or to eat in front of others. And it was because of his own hesitations that his love relationships, with Felice Bauer, with Julie Wohryzek, with Milena Jesenska-Polak, had failed.

title: Japan Banks to Increase Loan Write-Offs
description: Fuji Bank Ltd. and six other Japanese lenders will increase their write-offs for bad loans by more than 950 billion yen, or $7.3 billion, in the first wave of banks taking advantage of Government measures to increase capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, HELEN
description: LIEBERMAN-Helen, age 85. Loving wife of Henry. Beloved mother of Amy Bursky and Jacob. Adored grandmother of Sarah and David. Services Wednesday, March 18, 11:30 AM, Kirschenbaum Brothers, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Bklyn.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURANCE TO TALK WITH CENDANT
description: The American Bankers Insurance Group Inc., a Miami-based insurer that covers credit card debts when borrowers become disabled, unemployed or die, said yesterday that it would start talks with the Cendant Corporation over Cendant's tender offer of $67 a share, or $3.1 billion. That tops the $58-a-share that American International Group Inc. agreed to pay. ''Cendant is now in the driver's seat, and the pressure is on A.I.G. to counter fast or lose out,'' said Patrick McGurn, director of corporate programs at Institutional Shareholders Services in Bethesda, Md. American Bankers has been at the center of a bidding war between Cendant, a direct marketing and franchising company whose brands include Avis car rentals and Howard Johnson hotels, and A.I.G. since Jan. 27, when Cendant offered $58 a share to wrest the company from its agreement to be acquired by A.I.G. for $47 a share.

title: Curious Cook; Shock in the Refrigerator
description: ONE recent morning, I opened the refrigerator and found that some barbecued chicken from the previous evening had already etched ragged holes in its aluminum foil wrapping. True, the sauce had been salty and pungent with vinegar and chilies. But corrosive? I marveled at the resilience of the human digestive system -- and at what I took to be my good luck in having kept the leftovers in a leakproof stainless steel dish.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: POUND GAINS. The British pound strengthened to its best level against the dollar this year on heightened expectations that the Bank of England would raise interest rates. In New York, the pound cost $1.6692, up from $1.6686.

title: A Most Dramatic Drama Critic
description: There was life before the vampires, and life after the vampires. Such is the way the unnamed narrator of ''St. Nicholas,'' a delectably droll celebration of storytelling as striptease by the young Irish playwright Conor McPherson, divides his personal history. But early in this account of human weariness and inhuman encounters, it becomes clear that the teller of the tale would himself have qualified as a sort of vampire long before he ever met the real thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, VIRGINIA B.
description: WARD-Virginia B. Retired Manager for American Airlines died March 16, 1998 in Sloan-Kettering, NYC. Her career with American began in 1944. She trained reservations agents when computers were introduced. She retired in 1974. She graduated from the University of Michigan with a B.A. in Music in 1934. She founded a preschool with her brother MacKenzie in Chicago in 1934. She was born in Chicago March 22, 1913. Survivors include sister, Barbara Pare of Chicago and ten nieces and nephews. Family and friends will gather at Davis Pk., Fire Is. to celebrate Ginny's life in June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESNER, BERNARD
description: CHESNER-Bernard. It is with deep sorrow that we record the untimely passing of our esteemed member, Bernard Chesner, and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Evelyn and children Arlene, Cliff, Dana and Jeffrey. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Jeffrey Sands, President Barry Swidler, Secretary

title: Melville Fans
description: The USA Network's production of ''Moby Dick,'' starring Patrick Stewart as Captain Ahab, drew the highest basic-cable audience ever for any program other than news or sports, and the network's chief said she was especially pleased that it seems to have been a hit with families.

title: Excerpts From Mississippi File on a Black
description: Following are excerpts from a 1958 report to the Mississippi Sovereignty Commission about Clyde Kennard, a black man who was trying to become the first black student at what was then called Mississippi Southern College, now the University of Southern Mississippi, in Hattiesburg. The report was written by a commission investigator, Zack J. VanLandingham, and was also filed to the Governor and the Attorney General of Mississippi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEER, ALICE S.
description: BEER-Alice S. Of Coral Springs, FL. Passed away Monday, March 16. Alice is survived by her husband Burt, two sons Alan and wife Jamie, and Jeremy and wife Amy; grandson Bradley; brother Robert and wife Judy Samet; sister Jane Samet; sister-in-law Sara Beer and nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be conducted on Wednesday, March 18, 1:00 P.M. at the Star of David Memorial Chapel, North Lauderdale. Interment will follow in Star of David.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOPAL, LOUIS
description: TOPAL-Louis. On March 17, 1998. Beloved husband of Fannie. Devoted father of Emanuel and Samuel. Cherished grandfather of Alan, Franklin, Jeffrey, Simone, Rachel, Claire and great grandfather of Rowen. Service is on Wednesday at 1 P.M., at Beth El Cemetery, New Jersey.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, BERNARD E.
description: BARON-Bernard E. On March 16, 1998, beloved husband of Frieda, adored father of Dr. Judy BaronStone (Steven), Rhonda Karp (Jack), and Cheryl Tasciotti (Lou), Ellen, Marc, and Jamie Rosenberg, devoted brother of Esther Schoenfeld, Edith Warshovsky, and Stanley Baron, cherished grandfather. Services Thursday at 10 A.M. at ''I.J. Morris Inc'', 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, DR. IRWIN
description: KAPLAN-Dr. Irwin. March 16, 1998. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of Dr. Ilene Kaplan, Jodi and Alan Kaplan. Proud grandfather of Adam, Jonathan and Alicia. Loving brother of Sandra Seidman and Roslyn Gottesman. Funeral services are on Wednesday, March 18, 11 A.M. at the Riverdale Temple, 246 Street and Independence Avenue.

title: Hong Kong Frees A Former Broker
description: Hong Kong unexpectedly dropped all criminal money-laundering charges today against a former Merrill Lynch & Company private-client banker, leaving him free to leave.

title: Willey Has Pursued $100,000 Book Deal
description: Kathleen E. Willey, the former White House aide, has been pursuing a $100,000 book deal in recent months, but her lawyer and a prospective publisher differ on how closely those negotiations were linked to her decision to go public with her accusation against President Clinton on Sunday night.

title: A Haven for Lawsuits
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Arts and Leisure Guide on Sunday misstated the telephone number for ''Legends and Visionaries,'' a New York Theater Ballet program that starts tomorrow at the Danny Kaye Theater. The number is (212) 772-4448.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KABOT, ABRAHAM (SKIBBY)
description: KABOT-Abraham (Skibby). Beloved husband of the late Esther Kabot, cherished brother of Belle Scher, Eva Kabachnick, Natie Kabot and the late Al, Ray, Ben and Phil. Adored and caring father of Philip and Ellen, Charlotte and Mortimer Lowenfeld, Frances and Sandy Silver. Cherished grandfather of Allison, Andrew and Leslie, Edward and Natalie, Elizabeth, Ellen and Bob, Eric and Brooke, Ilene and Bill. Proud great-grandfather. Graveside services on Wednesday, March 18, at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, at 2:30 P.M.

title: 2 State Mental Hospitals Are Providing Medical Staff Who Speak Chinese and Korean
description: Faced with the threat of a lawsuit, the State Office of Mental Health has agreed to set up a special system for treating patients with mental illness who speak only Chinese or Korean.

title: Senate Abruptly Opens Debate on NATO
description: The Senate unexpectedly opened debate today on expanding NATO with an awkward first step toward one of its most important foreign policy decisions in decades.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the architect Daniel Libeskind misstated the status of the design competition for a contemporary arts museum in Cincinnati. The competition is over; the architect Zaha Hadid was chosen to design the museum. Mr. Libeskind was a finalist.

title: Only Patients' Rights Laws Can Rein In Insurers; Men at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Log Keeper Goes Before Grand Jury
description: Ellen W. McCathran, the keeper of detailed accounts of President Clinton's activities and visitors for historical purposes, appeared today before the Federal grand jury investigating the President's relationship with a former White House intern, Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Board to Vote on a Less Rigid Plan for School Uniforms
description: The Board of Education is scheduled to vote today on a school uniform policy that is considerably less stringent than originally proposed, but that would still require most elementary schoolchildren in the country's largest district to wear uniforms beginning in fall 1999.

title: Suburbs' Mass-Market Mansions; Baby Boom Luxury: Huge Home, Often on a Tiny Lot
description: When Evan and Susan Ratner were shopping for a new home, they looked for a community like the one where they grew up in Smithtown, N.Y.: a development with young families, where children skated on cul-de-sacs and called to neighbors over backyard fences. They also wanted, and could afford, more luxury than their parents would have dreamed possible.

title: From Pot To Plank: Polenta Eaten Off The Table
description: ARTHUR ZAMPAGLIONE takes a perverse delight in his polenta. The dish itself, coarse ground cornmeal topped with a meaty tomato ragu, is perfectly rendered. But it's his manner of serving it -- spreading the soft-cooked polenta in an even layer onto raw pine planks -- that fills him with mischievous glee. No plates, just wood.

title: Temptation; An Italian Entr'acte, Translated From the Latin
description: THE printed menu doesn't count for too much at Manducatis, an Italian restaurant in Long Island City, Queens. Regulars simply ask for whatever's cooking in the kitchen, have a brief consultation with the owner, a scholarly looking Neapolitan named Vincenzo Cerbone, and eat what his wife, Ida, turns out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, DONALD
description: JOYCE-Donald. With profound sorrow Central Synagogue mourns the loss of its esteemed organist Donald Joyce. His gentle and caring personality combined with his extraordinary musical talents will be sorely missed. May his memory serve us always as a blessing. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Sarah H. Reines, Rabbi Joshua M. Davidson, Rabbi Richard Botton, Cantor Martin I. Klein, President

title: Oil and Technology Are Off in Mixed Performance Over All
description: After soaring on Monday, stock prices were mixed yesterday.

title: 'Must She TV'
description: Last fall, NBC called its Monday lineup of all-female-lead comedies ''Must She TV.''

title: Only Patients' Rights Laws Can Rein In Insurers
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Clinton Urges Irish to Grab 'The Chance of a Lifetime'
description: All the parties to the Northern Ireland peace negotiations paraded through the Oval Office today to hear President Clinton admonish them not to squander ''the chance of a lifetime for peace.''

title: The Pop Life; Change of Story In Shakur Case
description: A man who at one time was listed as a suspect in the killing of Tupac Shakur has changed significant elements of his story in a six-hour deposition, his most extensive interview since the slaying in Las Vegas, Nev., 18 months ago.

title: New Dose of Anxiety At Ever-Changing Bank
description: From outward appearances, it was a normal day at the Park Avenue headquarters of Chase Manhattan, except perhaps for the spectacle next door on 48th Street, where St. Patrick's Day marchers gave an oddly festive air to one of New York City's most bankerly addresses.

title: Clinton Pushes Plan for Medicare at Age 55
description: President Clinton went to Capitol Hill today and, at a rally with three dozen Democratic members of Congress, pushed his proposal to open Medicare to millions of people 55 to 64 years old.

title: A Shortstop for a Shortstop: Baseball's Code of Revenge
description: Baseball's beanball code is almost as established as British common law, unwritten and yet completely understood. When Derek Jeter stepped into the batter's box in the fifth inning of today's exhibition against Toronto's Roger Clemens, the Yankees' shortstop knew Clemens would throw a fastball at him.

title: TWO TESTERS OF COMMUNICATIONS GEAR AGREE TO MERGE
description: Wandel & Goltermann Management Holding G.m.b.H. of Germany and the Wavetek Corporation of San Diego, both private concerns, have agreed to merge. The company they will form will have annual revenue of more than $400 million and will be the second-largest company in the world, after Hewlett-Packard, that focuses on testing communications equipment like wireless phones and cable television. The merger must be approved by the companies' owners and regulators. The combined company, employing more than 2,400 people in 87 countries, will have corporate offices in both Germany and the United States. It will be incorporated in the United States.

title: Redemption to Rostenkowski Can Include Fun and Profit
description: The television teasers came every few minutes: ''And coming up. . . . We'll hear what political analyst Dan Rostenkowski thinks about this election.''

title: Ewing Still a Firm Believer He Will Return for Playoffs
description: Patrick Ewing met with reporters last night for the first time since Jan. 1 and he remained true to the theme that he has hummed since sustaining what everyone but Ewing believed was a season-ending injury: he is hoping to be back in action when the playoffs arrive.

title: $25 and Under; A Charming Bistro With Food to Match
description: FROM Le Tableau in the East Village to Mono in Greenwich Village, little bistros have deluged downtown Manhattan in the last few months. Restaurant Boughalem, which opened about a month ago in a former social club on Bedford Street, may be the most charming of them all, and the food is pretty terrific as well.

title: Turner's Plan: Stop Murdoch
description: Ted Turner, whose intense dislike for his rival Rupert Murdoch has prompted him to compare Murdoch to ''the late Fuhrer,'' plans to make a rare appearance at a baseball owners meeting on Thursday to try to block Murdoch's $311 million purchase of the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: London Journal; Britain's Man in the Wings Has a Day Center-Stage
description: Once described as a man who could brighten a room just by leaving it, Gordon Brown, the dark and brooding Chancellor of the Exchequer, would seem to have no place in the luminous center ring of the image-conscious New Labor Government.

title: Boy, 2, Lives After Being Thrown From 8th Floor
description: With the branches of a crab-apple tree and sheer providence breaking his fall, a 2-year-old boy who the police said was thrown by his grandmother from the eighth floor of a Brooklyn housing complex managed to survive with only minor injuries after landing in the fallow soil of a lone flower bed.

title: 5 Enter Guilty Pleas In Smuggling Cases
description: In two actions attacking the flow of illegal aliens into West Texas from Mexico, the Immigration and Naturalization Service today said five members of a ring had pleaded guilty to smuggling charges and 13 members of another ring had been indicted by a grand jury in El Paso.

title: Ideas Onstage and Bombs Offstage
description: Terrorism with a human face has not always been quite the oxymoron it might seem by today's standards of indiscriminate killing. Before there were airplanes to hijack and blow up or mass-produced cars to turn into bombs or even hand-carried machine guns to spray a mall or schoolyard, terrorism was regarded as a legitimate weapon in the struggle for justice, and assassins argued over the morality of spilling innocent blood.

title: A Mysterious Presence, And Absence
description: This was not a song recital. What was happening was not singing but being. Ian Bostridge came onto the platform at the Frick on Sunday afternoon, took a quick bow with just the upper part of his lanky body, and then Ian Bostridge disappeared. What remained was the soul of Schumann's ''Dichterliebe.''

title: LAFARGE IN $690 MILLION DEAL WITH SHAREHOLDER
description: The Lafarge Corporation, a construction-products supplier, agreed yesterday to buy three construction-materials businesses in North America from its major shareholder, Lafarge S.A. of France, for $690 million. The company, based in Reston, Va., had total sales of $1.8 billion last year. The operations being acquired -- Western-Mobile Inc. of Denver, Redland Genstar Inc. of Towson, Md., and Redland Quarries Inc. of Hamilton, Ontario -- posted combined 1997 revenue of more than $520 million. Lafarge S.A. took control of the operations last year when it acquired the British company Redland P.L.C.

title: A Procession of Noise, Festivity and Green Dye
description: On a fine blue day almost hinting of spring, the St. Patrick's Day Parade rolled up Fifth Avenue yesterday, a noisy, joyous and peaceful procession of wailing bagpipes and pounding drums, of green hats and green everything, all of it witnessed by hundreds of thousands of onlookers lining the route.

title: Journal; Pulp Nonfiction
description: It was one of those through-the-looking-glass moments that sum up an era in which the boundaries between reality and entertainment have disappeared. When ''60 Minutes'' ended its segment on Kathleen Willey's tale of a White House sexual assault, CBS cut directly to an upbeat commercial for ''Primary Colors,'' the new movie starring John Travolta as a barely fictionalized Bill Clinton who endures equally harsh accusations only to triumph by the final credits.

title: Jazz Festival Company Being Sold To BET Network
description: George Wein, the head of Festival Productions and impresario of the annual JVC Jazz Festival, said yesterday that he had agreed to sell 80 percent of his company to Black Entertainment Television. The 71-year-old Mr. Wein, the patriarch of the jazz concert business, will stay on indefinitely with an open-ended contract, but the sale means that the most important concert organization in the jazz world will get new leaders.

title: Court Blocks Zoning Law on Sex Shops
description: A Federal appeals court temporarily stopped the Giuliani administration yesterday from beginning to enforce a zoning law that would ban X-rated businesses from residential neighborhoods in New York City. The court said that it wanted several ''sufficiently troublesome'' questions addressed.

title: The Minimalist; With Sausage, Just a Little Does a Lot
description: PASTA and sausage are a combination that usually suggests a dense, heavy tomato sauce. But it can also mean the very opposite. Sausage, used in small amounts, can contribute to a relatively light, almost delicate pasta sauce.

title: Changes In Board Proposed
description: In executive meetings of the governing board of women's tennis this week in Miami, Bart McGuire, the new chief executive of the Corel WTA Tour, has proposed major overhauls to the tour's board of directors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EVELYN
description: COHEN-Evelyn. On March 18, 1998. Loving mother of David Cohen and Harriet Geller. Grandmother of Deborah Cohen and Lisa Parisi. Great grandmother of Alixandra. Sister of Edna Feirstein, Jules and Ida Shorr. Services Thursday 12:30 PM, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 11403 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: Excerpts From Affidavit
description: Following are excerpts from an affidavit of Julie Hiatt Steele in which Ms. Steele describes both her encounter with Kathleen E. Willey after the death of Ms. Willey's husband and later conversations with Ms. Willey:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, BENJAMIN J.
description: BLOOM-Benjamin J. On March 17, 1998, beloved husband for 58 years of Maxine, loving brother of Oscar, dear uncle and great uncle. Services private.

title: Freedom for Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Seinfeld' Writers Plot Their Busy Afterlife
description: For almost everyone connected with ''Seinfeld,'' the NBC hit comedy heading for one of the most celebrated, most publicized sendoffs in television history, these are days of gelt by association.

title: NEW YORK PUPILS TO NEED UNIFORMS IN GRADE SCHOOLS
description: For the first time in its 156-year history, the New York City Board of Education voted last night to require its half-million elementary-school children to wear uniforms. Under the policy, approved unanimously, pupils must comply with the dress code beginning in 1999 unless their school or parents are granted special exemptions.

title: Personal Shopper; Following a Master Of Light
description: ''ALL that you require to start a home are a room, a tatami and Akari,'' Isamu Noguchi once wrote about his paper light sculptures, which have found their ways into countless rooms as lamps.

title: Merrill Wins the Toss
description: The flip of a coin yesterday decided which underwriting syndicate won the right to sell $450 million in municipal bonds being issued by the State of North Carolina.

title: Illegal Trade in Homemade Computers Thrives : Beijing's 'Backyard' Industry
description: BEIJING  Swinging their truncheons, a dozen "intellectual property police" strode into action along Beijing's Zhongguancun street. At the sight of them, the hawkers of pirated compact discs and CD-Roms hurriedly gathered their wares and decamped.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Flying the Swoosh and Stripes; In Footwear Wars, Nike Lags, Adidas and Others Surge
description: The swoosh worn around the world is wearing thin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANEL, RALPH I.
description: FLANEL-Ralph I. We note with profound sorrow the passing of our colleague and valued friend. Ralph has been associated with our family for more than 45 years and we are grateful for all his efforts in our behalf. We offer our sincere sympathy to Renee, Diane and Ted. The John Civetta Family

title: In Bayside, the Night Looked Like War
description: For several hours last night, Bayside, Queens, did not resemble its usual, tidy self. It looked more like the set for an episode of ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.''

title: Senate Struggles to Pay Attention to the Remapping of NATO
description: Some Senators said they would rather be debating education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVERY, PETER RUTHERFORD RANDOLPH
description: LAVERY-Peter Rutherford Randolph. An accomplished OffBroadway stage manager, director and multimedia producer, died of a heart attack March 12. He was 60 years old. A former council member of Actors Equity from 1971 to 1977. He is survived by his sister, Sarah Fach of Newton, MA, and a daughter, Gwendolyn Berland-Lavery. A memorial service will be held Friday, March 20 at noon, in the chapel at St. George's Episcopal Church, 209 East 16th St. In lieu of flowers, the Lavery family would like donations to be made in his name to United Action for Animals, PO Box 635, Lenox Hill Station, NY, NY 10021.

title: Reading Experts Suggest Teachers Mix 2 Methods
description: The seemingly simple question has divided parents, teachers, schools and communities across the country: What is the best way to teach children how to read? Old-fashioned phonics? Or the newer whole-language method that emphasizes the meaning of words? Yesterday, after two years of study, a panel of national experts offered an answer: Use some of both.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Families, care givers and early childhood educators can help our youngest children develop strong language skills by talking to them, singing nursery rhymes and reading to them beginning at birth. Each of us can apply this report in our daily lives.''

title: Debut of Windows 98 Is Moved to Summer
description: AFTER several delays, the Microsoft Corporation last week announced that Windows 98 would be available in retail stores on June 25. Code-named Memphis, the new software -- the first major upgrade to Windows 95 in nearly three years -- was first scheduled to appear in 1997, but it was renamed Windows 98 when the shipping date moved to January. That slipped to April or May, and now to June.

title: Forget Big Brother
description: SURVEILLANCE cameras followed the attractive young blond woman through the lobby of the midtown Manhattan hotel, kept a glassy eye on her as she rode the elevator up to the 23d floor and peered discreetly down the hall as she knocked at the door to my room.

title: No Rush on Cloning
description: To the Editor:

title: Few Answers on Monster of All Cyberbugs
description: With only 653 days to go, it is too late for Federal agencies to fix all of the year 2000 bugs in their critical computer systems, and some Government functions are likely to be disrupted, high-ranking Government auditors warned a House hearing today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a Spanish judge's inquiry into deaths and disappearances during the Argentine military dictatorship from 1976 to 1983 misstated the legal status of about 100 active and former Argentine military and police officers named in the case. They are listed as suspects; they have not been formally charged.

title: Charlie Milhaupt, 48; Rallied Arts Support
description: Charlie Milhaupt, vice president of the Gilman Paper Company and a former film producer, died on March 13 at his home in Manhattan. He was 48.

title: From Medieval to Bernstein: Lincoln Center Festival '98
description: Lincoln Center Festival '98, which runs from July 7 to 26, will present theater and dance companies from Israel, Germany, Spain and Britain, as well as music ranging from a 12th-century work by Hildegard von Bingen to a 400-year-old Chinese opera to a celebration of Leonard Bernstein.

title: Despite U.N. Role, Serbs Find No Peace in Croatia
description: Some $450 million in international aid and two years of United Nations administration have failed in their goal: to turn this forlorn corner of the Balkans into the first example of how a minority ethnic population could be successfully integrated into one of the nationalist states in the former Yugoslavia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, FLORENCE
description: WILSON-Florence. Wife of the late Harold Wilson. Mother of Herbert, Fred and the late Irving Wilson. Grandmother and greatgrandmother. Graveside services, Thursday, March 19, 1998 at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery at 1 P.M.

title: Essay; The Death of Outrage
description: The gripping interview on CBS's ''60 Minutes'' came as a sad snowfall over the landscape of Clinton scandals. Here was no slick Willey. The public reaction is more of sorrowful consternation than of outrage.

title: Filling That Rectangle Above the Sofa
description: HMMM . . . What should we hang over the couch? It used to be easy to answer that question. You hung up a painting -- and then congratulated yourself for having the taste to choose a work that was more adventurous than the moonlit landscape selected by your next-door neighbor.

title: View From Minnesota; A Civil Asteroid
description: To the Editor:

title: Puerto Rico, U.S.A.
description: The Senate may soon be debating a bill that would permit Puerto Ricans living on the island to vote for statehood or independence or to become an enhanced commonwealth that would eventually evolve toward sovereignty. Feeling on the island is divided almost equally between statehood and commonwealth, with independence favored by less than 4 percent of the voters.

title: When Citizenship Is Leadership; Two-Party Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMBINDER, ROSE (NEE TALIANOFF)
description: AMBINDER-Rose (nee Talianoff). On March 18, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Nathan Ambinder, M.D., dearest mother of Edward, Lynn and Roy, cherished grandmother of Evan, Jennifer, Amanda, Julie, Marc, Michael, Eric and Jessica; devoted sister to Augusta and Laura, and her late brothers, David and George. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Friday, March 20 at 10 A.M.

title: Ex-Treasurer of Drew U. Faces New Theft Charges
description: Prosecutors have filed new charges against a former treasurer of Drew University, accusing her of stealing $598,000 more than the amount she was originally accused of taking from the university.

title: Microchips Are Latest Addition To Gear for London's Marathon
description: When runners in the London Marathon lace on their sneakers and pin on their numbers on April 26, they will also have to use a new accessory. Each of the 31,000 racers will be required to attach a small microchip to a shoelace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEIL, THOMAS F.
description: O'NEIL-Thomas F. The officers, Board of Directors and members of The American Ireland Fund have learned with profound regret of the death of Thomas F. O'Neil, a founding member of the American Irish Foundation (subsequently merged with the Ireland Fund to become The American Ireland Fund.) Since its inception in 1972, the O'Neil Family has annually funded the AIF Literary Award, designed to enable young Irish writers to devote time to develop his or her work. It honors, too, appropriate authors, poets and playwrights whose lifetime contributions have so enriched Ireland's cultural heritage. We extend our deepest sympathy to Mrs. Claire O'Neil, to our fellow Board Member, Shane, and to all the O'Neil Family. The American Ireland Fund

title: Lockheed Seeking a Way To Save Its Northrop Deal
