description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation is scrambling to salvage its proposed acquisition of Northrop Grumman, now that the Government has rejected a new proposal the company made in an effort to allay antitrust concerns.

title: My Lai Question Mark
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, GEORGE, IV
description: CAMPBELL-George, IV. Known as Duffy. Killed accidentally on Friday the 13th in Bakersfield, CA. He will be buried from St. John's Episcopal Church, Pleasantville, NY, Saturday, March 21, 1998 at 11 AM. For info: Beecher Funeral Home, Inc. Pleasantville, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 27 about Leonardo Nole, who posed for the statue of Prometheus at Rockefeller Center, misspelled the surname of one of the assistants who worked with the sculptor, Paul Manship. He was Henry G. Kreis, not Krist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELDIN, BERTRAM J.
description: ZELDIN-Bertram J. Of Greenwich, CT., on March 18, 1998 at the Greenwich Hospital. Son of Sarah Kaufman Zeldin, husband of Cheryl Beecher Zeldin, father of Tami Zeldin, Ruddy and Peter Zeldin, brother of Sanford Zeldin, Adelle Goldstein, Estelle Grundstein and Robert Zeldin and one granddaughter. Funeral Service today 11:30AM at the Greenwich Reform Synagogue, 257 Stanwich Road, Greenwich, Conn. Burial Putnam Cemetery, Greenwich. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions to the Bendheim Cancer Center, C/O Greenwich Hospital Development Center, Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT. 06830.

title: Part of Union Of Principals Says It Favors End to Tenure
description: A dissident group of high school principals wants to break away from its parent union and give up tenure protection, the group's president said yesterday.

title: BASF Plans to Buy Korean Lysine Business
description: BASF A.G., Germany's largest chemical and pharmaceutical company, said yesterday that it would pay $600 million for the lysine unit of Daesang Group of South Korea to get more than a fifth of the lysine market. Daesang supplies 21 percent of the world's lysine and had sales of $250 million last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBELL, JEANETTE
description: GIBELL-Jeanette. March 17, 1998, in Stamford, CT. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving sister of the late Joseph Yarchower. Cherished aunt of Harriet and Stan Simon and Karil Daniels, devoted great-aunt of Emily and Jessica. Proud member of the Monderer/ Ebner family. Born and educated in Bronx, NY, Jeanette enjoyed a long and satisfying career as Assistant Controller of the SSC & B/Lintas Advertising Agency until her retirement. Pride in her professional accomplishments, independence and a love of family and travel were an inspiration to all who knew her. Her sweet and loving nature will be deeply missed. Graveside services Friday, March 20, 11 A.M., Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Smiles and Anger Mix For Man in the Spy Files
description: As Lee Dilworth got his first glimpse today of the secret file accumulated on him 34 years ago by the Mississippi State Sovereignty Commission, his reactions alternated between hysterical laughter and seething anger.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions in House & Home last Thursday, with the continuation of an article about the restoration of Stanford White's Venetian Room at the headquarters of the French Cultural Services in New York, omitted the credit. The picture of workmen reinstalling a fireplace wall in the room and the picture of the front porch of a stable where panels for the room had been in storage were supplied by the project's architecture firm, John G. Waite Associates.

title: Presbyterians' Ban on Gay Ministers Is Retained
description: An effort to overturn a year-old church law that effectively bars ordination of openly gay men and lesbians within the nation's largest Presbyterian denomination has failed, church officials and people on both sides of the effort say.

title: CONTINENTAL TO BUY 15 BOEING 737-900'S FOR $810 MILLION
description: Continental Airlines Inc. will buy 15 Boeing 737-900 planes worth about $810 million as it replaces older aircraft and tries to cut costs. The new planes, which carry 170 passengers, are to be delivered between May 2001 and July 2002, the Houston-based carrier said. Continental, which had previously acquired options to buy the aircraft, also said it had arranged new options on another 25 planes. Like other airlines, Continental has reaped strong profits in recent years and is now looking to plow money into expanding and improving the airline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEGGS, MARJORIE (REID)
description: MEGGS-Marjorie (Reid). Died on March 12, 1998 at her home in Scarsdale, N.Y. after a long illness, she was 77. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y. Mrs. Meggs was an accomplished concert pianist, having studied at the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music. During the 1940's, she gave numerous piano recitals and concerts in Brooklyn accompanying such opera singers as Gloria Davies and Gertrude Turby. In later years, in addition to giving private piano lessons, Mrs. Meggs served as music teacher & choral director for several junior high schools in the New York City school system. She is survived by her husband of 51 years, Hugh C. Meggs, two sons Hugh C. Meggs, Jr. and Dr. Leonard G. Meggs of Westchester, a daughter Dr. Marcia Meggs of Chicago, two brothers Hudson H. Reid and Dr. Carl C. Reid, 3 grandchildren and one great grandson.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Zhu Rongji, China's new Prime Minister, referred to his children incorrectly, based on erroneous information in an official biography. He has a son and a daughter, not two daughters, according to a new official biography.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNOFSKY, RUTH
description: CHERNOFSKY-Ruth. The Leadership of EMUNAH of America mourns the untimely loss of its Honorary National President, Ruth Chernofsky. Her devotion and philanthropic endeavors enabled our organization to expand its network of educational facilities which enriched the lives of thousands of children in Israel. She will be greatly missed by the entire EMUNAH family. We express our sincerest condolences to her husband, Morris and her children, Philip and Toni, Neil and Ilona, Benett and Nancy, her grandchildren, and her nieces and nephews who she embraced so warmly. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Dr. Sylvia Schonfeld National President Shirley Singer,Exec Vice President Melanie Oelbaum, Honorary National President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, ELIZABETH L.
description: MILLS-Elizabeth L. The Kildonan School Board of Trustees, faculty, staff, students and alumni mourn the passing of our friend, colleague and Chairman of the Board, Elizabeth L. Mills. Her dedication, generosity, kindness and warm sense of humor will be deeply missed. We express our profound condolences to her family.

title: A Medici of Modern Arts In Tune With Composers; Betty Freeman, Long a Patron of Americans, Shifts Her Maverick Focus to Europeans
description: The political battles and attendant bitterness over government financing of the arts is enough to make one long for the days of enlightened private patronage.

title: Friend Accuses Willey of Plea For Her to Lie
description: Julie Hiatt Steele, a friend of Kathleen E. Willey, released a sworn affidavit tonight, accusing the former White House aide of asking her to lie to corroborate Ms. Willey's account of being sexually groped by President Clinton in the Oval Office.

title: Oil Rebounds 8% Amid Talk of a Producers' Supply Meeting Soon
description: Crude oil prices rebounded 8.6 percent yesterday as the market was encouraged by news that there might soon be a special meeting of big oil-producing countries to discuss reductions in output.

title: Transportation Authority Is to Control Airport
description: The South Jersey Transportation Authority will assume full control of Atlantic City International Airport from the Federal Government next month, making the airport eligible for millions of dollars in fees and Federal funds to complete a large-scale renovation, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSHNIT, MAX A.
description: KIRSHNIT-Max A. Of West Hartford, CT., died March 17, 1998. Beloved father of Susan Woodall of West Lafayette, IN., and Kathe Sherman of Westport and NYC, known professionally as Sunny Leigh. Also survived by two grandchildren. Funeral service and burial today in Hartford, CT. For information call Weinstein Mortuary of Hartford, CT.

title: A Suspect's Confession Fits the Crimes, but He's the Wrong Man
description: On Valentine's Day morning, this struggling small city enveloped by farmland and malls awoke to the most frightening crime spree it had witnessed in years.

title: Garden Currents; FERTILIZER -- Nature's Helper
description: Wonder why the neighbors' ivy geraniums flower so luxuriantly from their window box down to the apartments below? They probably use liquid fertilizer. Instead of fish emulsion, try Fox Farm's Big Bloom, scent-free though it teems with bat guano and earthworm castings: $10 for 32 ounces at Smith & Hawken, 394 West Broadway (Spring Street), (212) 925-0687.

title: Bridge; A Tricky Transfer Contract, And a Tricky Recovery
description: Two New York experts, Margie Gwozdzinsky and Susan Wexler, won the National Women's Pairs in Dallas a year ago. They will defend that title in Reno, Nev., next week and will represent the United States in the world championships in Lille, France, in August.

title: Garden Currents; PLANTINGS -- A Season for Chartreuse
description: The cool, chartreuse Ammi visnaga will be this year's hot annual, says Brian McGowan of Blue Meadow Farm in Montague, Mass. Chartreuse has always lurked in the garden (think Zinnia Envy), but never so lacy. Six plants, $2.25, from May 15 at Blue Meadow, (413) 367-2394; or seed packet, $1.50, Flowery Branch Seed Company, (770) 536-8380.

title: French Jobless Find the World Is Harsher
description: Like the more than three million other French workers who cannot find a job, Yves Hell is angry. He lost his job as a clerk in Marseilles in December, and now, at age 35, he has had to give up his small apartment there and move in with his retired parents.

title: Why Your Computer Needs Cache on Hand
description: Q. What is ''cache memory''?

title: Rangers' Standing Improves In Overtime
description: Rarely do the Rangers root for the rival Islanders, but last night was one of those times. An Islander victory at Ottawa coupled with a Ranger victory over Montreal at Madison Square Garden would help the Rangers' playoff prospects tremendously.

title: My Lai Question Mark
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Nullifies Most of California Immigrant Law
description: A Federal judge has struck down virtually all remaining provisions of Proposition 187, driving one more nail into the coffin of the California ballot initiative, which was passed in 1994 to deny social services to illegal immigrants but has been blocked by court challenges ever since.

title: A Matter of Definition
description: Several months ago when President Clinton called for a national conversation on race, he became the first President since the passage of the civil rights acts of the 1960's to try to focus our attention on race relations and the problems of discrimination in this country.

title: When Citizenship Is Leadership; Our Celebrity President
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; Murder Trial Is a Hard Case For Audience
description: OVER the last several days, Carlos Cevallos's relatives have come to realize that his life is quite a hard sell.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; At Occidental, So-So Results But Big Pay For the Boss
description: Last year, the directors of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation acknowledged that the employment contract of their chairman and chief executive, Ray R. Irani, needed an overhaul.

title: Suitor Sweetens Offer for Kansas City Utility
description: Western Resources Inc., a major Midwest utility, announced last night that it had raised its $32-a-share bid for the Kansas City Power and Light Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNION, EDNA C. (NEE CURLEY)
description: CUNNION-Edna C. (nee Curley). On March 17, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Devoted mother of Patricia C. Smith, Edna Clare O'Neill and the late Paul A. Dear mother-in-law of Kathleen (Muffin) Cunnion, Thomas J. Smith and Edward J. O'Neill. Loving second mother of John D., Helen Corrigan, Robert, Sister Dorothy Cunnion, S.H.C.J., the late Francis P., the late Arthur Jr., and the late Mary. Also cherished by nineteen grandchildren, seventeen greatgrandchildren, one great-greatgrandchild, four nieces and two nephews. Friends may visit on Thursday 2-5PM and 7-10PM at R. Stutzmann & Son Funeral Home, 224-39 Jamaica Avenue, Queens Village, NY. Funeral Mass Friday at 12:00 Noon, at Immaculate Conception Monastery (Jamaica Estates). Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Rose Stamler, 75, Expert on Blood Pressure
description: Rose Steinberg Stamler, a pioneer in the prevention and treatment of high blood pressure and a professor emeritus of preventive medicine at the Northwestern University Medical School, died on Feb. 28 at Scottsdale Memorial Hospital in Arizona. She was 75 and lived in Chicago.

title: Inspector in Bribery Case Pleads Not Guilty
description: An East Orange health inspector pleaded not guilty yesterday to accusations of soliciting a bribe to overlook a possible lead paint violation, a day after police found 10 bags of heroin in his car when they went to arrest him, prosecutors said.

title: Market Continues Its Climb, With Indexes Hitting Highs
description: The stock market soared further into record territory yesterday, sending all the major indexes to all-time highs.

title: 28 Charged With Links to Mob-Run Gambling
description: Twenty-eight people, including a New York City police officer, were arrested in Queens yesterday and charged with involvement in a gambling ring led by a well-known member of the Genovese crime family, prosecutors said.

title: PRESIDENT DERIDES G.O.P. BUDGET PLAN AS ILL-CONCEIVED
description: President Clinton today firmly rejected the current Republican budget proposal, declaring that it ''shortchanges our nation's future'' by eliminating nearly all of his planned Federal programs for education, job training and child care.

title: AT HOME WITH: R.B. Kitaj; A Second Exile, His Rage Intact
description: The American painter R.B. Kitaj did not go quietly when he quit London six months ago for Los Angeles. He was enraged at the venomous reviews of his retrospective at the Tate Gallery in 1994 and bereft at the death of his wife, Sandra Fisher, a week after the show closed (neurologists told him that her aneurysm could well have been caused by the stress). So he painted the imaginary execution of a monstrous, multi-eyed critic by a firing squad composed of Edouard Manet, savaged by critics in his own time, and himself.

title: U.S. Military Draws Up Battle Plans on How to Win an 'Info War'
description: PARIS  Information warfare was born with hackers, anarchistic whiz-kids who got so bored waiting for their turn running a big IBM mainframe at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology that they turned to pranks such as taking a piano apart, then reassembling it atop the chapel spire.

title: Hotelier Forms Partnership With an Investment Company
description: Ian Schrager, the former host of Studio 54 who created the chic Royalton and Paramount hotels, announced yesterday that he had formed a partnership with the Northstar Capital Investment Corporation of Maryland to consolidate his properties and expand rapidly in the United States and Europe.

title: France Telecom Returns To Profitability
description: France Telecom S.A. said yesterday that it returned to profitability in the second half of 1997. The company earned 6 billion francs ($980 million) in the latest six-month period, compared with a loss of 4.2 billion francs in the corresponding period of 1996.

title: 'Flawed' Armenian Election Forces Runoff
description: The senior foreign monitor of the presidential elections here on Monday said today that the vote had been ''deeply flawed,'' and the monitors urged changes to strengthen Armenia's democratic image.

title: Freedom for Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: PROFILE; Aiming Camera at Web, and Himself
description: AS a documentary filmmaker, Doug Block is accustomed to being on the safe side of the viewfinder. So it comes as a surprise that the lead character emerging reluctantly from the footage of his current film-in-progress turns out to be Mr. Block himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, ANNE P.
description: O'CONNOR-Anne P. March 16 in Exeter, NH, formerly of Bay Shore, NY. Beloved wife of the late Dr. John J. O'Connor, Jr, devoted mother of the late John J. O'Connor III, and mother of Tim O'Connor of Boston, MA, Jane O'Connor of Durham, NH, Anne O. Rock of Bay Shore, N.Y. Anne leaves 3 sisters, one brother and five grandchildren. Services to be held at a later date. Expressions of sympathy may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: JEFFERIES GROUP TO SPLIT ITSELF INTO 2 PARTS
description: Jefferies Group Inc. said yesterday that it would separate its two units, Investment Technology Group Inc., which provides equity trading and research services, and Jefferies & Company, an investment bank serving small to medium-sized corporations, into separate companies. A new holding company, Jefco, will be created for Jefferies & Company. Current shareholders will end up holding all Jefco shares and 82.3 percent of Investment Technology Group's shares. The two will operate as unrelated companies and Jefferies Group, which is based in Los Angeles, will cease to exist. The Jefferies stock rose 81.25 cents yesterday, to $52.125.

title: Seattle Businessman Pleads Guilty in Campaign Finance Case
description: The owner of one of the nation's largest privately held companies pleaded guilty today to violating Federal campaign finance and disclosure laws, admitting that he had employees use thousands of dollars in bonuses as political contributions.

title: In Six Markets, I-Link Offers 4.9-Cent Calls
description: How low can they go? Try 4.9 cents a minute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABRANCHE, GEORGE M.L. III
description: LaBRANCHE-George M.L. III. Age 72. Born in New York City on November 11, 1925. Died March 17 after a valiant struggle against cancer. George joined the Marine Corps in 1942 at the age of 17 and later fought in the battle of Iwo Jima. He retired as the President of Roy B. Rendle Company, a Boston marine construction contractor. He is survived by his wife Patricia Munro LaBranche of Marblehead, MA., and Amagansett, NY; a daughter, Eugenie Damon of Darien, CT; a son, George IV of Cold Spring Harbor, NY; a daughter, Nicole LaBranche of New York; and ten grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City, Friday, April 3, 1998, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th Street, New York, NY 10003.

title: Incentives Lured Bus and Subway Riders in January, Officials Say
description: New York City subway and bus passengers, attracted by the new 11-fares-for-the-price-of-10 deal as well as free bus-to-subway transfers, took about 12 million more rides in January than they did the previous January, according to transit figures to be released today.

title: People
description: * Donald R. Allman, executive vice president and general manager at TDI, New York, the out-of-home media company owned by the CBS Corp., was named to the new position of chief operating officer.

title: 3 at U S West Will Split $45.1 Million
description: U S West Inc. said today that Richard D. McCormick, the company's chairman, and two other senior executives would receive $45.1 million in severance when it splits into separate telephone and cable-television companies later this year.

title: Political Memo; In Washington, Impolitic Sex Is Talk of the Day, Every Day
description: After eight weeks, the furor over President Clinton's relationships with Monica S. Lewinsky and other women has become the stuff of daily Washington life -- the political context for every White House event, the subject of almost every question put publicly to the President, and the preoccupation of both his top aides and Federal Washington's three major classes: those who govern, those who report, and those who lobby and lawyer.

title: Southdown and Rival Set $1 Billion Merger
description: The cement producer Southdown Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire the Medusa Corporation, a smaller rival, for $1 billion in stock in a deal that will create the nation's second-largest cement producer.

title: Slain Shop Owner's Generosity Is Remembered
description: During James Lee's eight years as the owner of a gift shop on St. Marks Place, his tireless work habits and outgoing demeanor made him a popular fixture in the East Village trinket market.

title: India's Hindu Government
description: India has embarked on a perilous course with the installation of its first potentially durable Hindu nationalist Government. Two years ago the Hindu nationalists lasted only 13 days in power, unable to find any other party to support them. This time, party leaders claim enough coalition votes to survive, though with a minuscule majority. The weak margin may turn out to be a blessing, because party leaders lack the votes to carry out their inflammatory anti-Muslim agenda. Their Government will be judged on whether it eases the country's poverty and preserves national unity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTDIENER, ARTHUR, PH.D.
description: GOTTDIENER-Arthur, Ph.D. The Institute for Contemporary Psychotherapy notes with great sadness the passing of a much esteemed training and supervising analyst. Dr. Gottdiener was a revered supervisor who imparted his skill and knowledge to many students. His perceptiveness and wit will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences to his family.

title: Knicks' Bowie Has a Job to Do, and It's Not Dodging Lira
description: It was time for Anthony Bowie to take cover on a basketball court in a country where fans didn't just hurl insults, they flung coins the size of doorknobs at the referees. A few bad calls and it was raining lira.

title: Almost Healthy, Nets Look for Final Push
description: After dragging their way home from an eight-day odyssey, and after struggling through eight losses in nine games that put them on the edge of the playoff picture, the Nets returned to their practice facility today and suddenly all was well again.

title: Garden Currents; ORCHIDAMANIA -- A Lovely Obsession Blooms in a Rooftop Greenhouse
description: Oncidiums are the little yellow, brown-speckled butterflylike orchids found at any corner deli. But they also come in mahogany, maroon, lemon and orange, more the size of butter plates than butterflies. Upward of 1,000 oncidiums grow in Harry Zelenko's rooftop greenhouse on 61st Street in Manhattan, below. Mr. Zelenko, a graphic designer who fell for oncidium 13 years ago, has produced the definitive book on the subject, ''The Pictorial Encyclopedia of the Oncidium'' (ZAI Publications, $150 until April 15 and then $185). He and his wife, Betsy Dillard Zelenko, and a colleague, Johanna Warshaw, painted more than 700 taxonomically correct head shots of single flowers and 71 renderings of complete plants, like the Cochlioda noezliana shown here.

title: Whitman Shows Support for Criticized Charter Schools
description: In a campaignlike appearance to deflect criticism of the growing number of charter schools in New Jersey, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman toured one of the schools today and heard dozens of children proclaim it more rewarding than traditional public schools.

title: Coast Guard Joins Search
description: The Coast Guard yesterday joined the search for four Cuban baseball players and a coach, who have been missing at sea since they defected from Cuba eight days earlier.

title: NORTEL BUYING APTIS COMMUNICATIONS FOR $290 MILLION
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Aptis Communications Inc. for $290 million in cash and stock. Aptis, based in Chelmsford, Mass., is a remote-access data networking company. It develops carrier-class access switches, including the CVX 1800. Nortel, based in Brampton, Ontario, is a telecommunications equipment company. It had revenue of $15.5 billion in 1997. The CVX 1800, now in trials, is the only access switch designed to fully support multiple services including dial-up, leased lines and high-speed access, Nortel said. Nortel's stock rose $1.125, to $62.25.

title: Computers in U.S. Do Far More and Are Cheaper : Why Europeans Lag in Using PCs
description: PARIS  In the computer industry, where there are buzzwords for everything, the catch phrase is "the technology gap."

title: Central Park Attackers Rob Curator of $2,000
description: A woman walking through Central Park on her way to a bank was assaulted and robbed yesterday morning by two men who fled with $2,000, the police said.

title: Brodeur Brilliant Again in Devils' Shutout
description: Jacques Lemaire's neutral-zone trap has been a key for the Devils having yielded the fewest goals of any National Hockey League team this season. But Martin Brodeur has perhaps been the prime factor, and he was superb again tonight in a 3-0 victory over the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim.

title: Power Struggles Under the Sun
description: Balletto di Toscana, an Italian company that mixes ballet training with a modern-dance style, made its problematic debut in New York on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFRAN, MELVIN
description: SAFRAN-Melvin. The Board of Trustees and members of the Ocean Beach Club note with sadness the loss of longtime friend and member Mel Safran. Our sincere condolences to his wife Nan, his children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Sandy Paskin, President Laurie Lowenstein, Secretary

title: Metro Business; Head of Pensions Resigns
description: New York City's Deputy Comptroller for Pensions, who manages the $80 billion pension fund for the city, has resigned to take a position with a private investment management company.

title: Deal Between 2 Stock Markets Moves Forward
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers promised yesterday to invest at least $110 million in new technology and other improvements if it takes control of the American Stock Exchange.

title: An Assault on Open Admissions
description: The City University of New York is in an uproar over a proposal to eliminate remedial courses at the public senior colleges, making it more difficult for new immigrants and minority students to get the education they need to succeed. Complaints from State Comptroller Carl McCall and members of the State Legislature have forced the trustees to delay a vote on the plan until its potential impact can be examined. Meanwhile, CUNY's own experts have released data suggesting that abolishing remedial courses at the four-year colleges might depress graduation rates for all ethnic groups, including whites and Asians.

title: THOMSON TO SPIN OFF ITS BRITISH TRAVEL BUSINESS
description: The Thomson Corporation will sell its British travel business in an initial public offering to focus on providing business and legal information, a transaction that analysts said could raise as much as $:1.5 billion ($2.5 billion) for the company. Thomson, based in Toronto, is the owner of the newspaper The Globe and Mail. Thomson Travel Group P.L.C., Britain's leading seller of package vacations, has benefited from the growth in British tourism that has resulted from rising personal incomes, more leisure time and the strength of the British pound. Thomson said it would use proceeds from the sale to pay down some of the $4 billion in debt that has piled up from acquisitions. It bought the West Publishing Company in 1996 for $3.4 billion.

title: Unsealing Mississippi's Past
description: One of the great lessons of history is that truth, imprisoned, festers and seeks release. When it emerges, however ugly, it must be served.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPOCK, DR. BENJAMIN
description: SPOCK-Dr. Benjamin. Thank you for your good work on behalf of parents and children. Amie Gross, a Grateful Mother

title: Program Soft-Pedals Hindu Supremacy
description: The National Agenda for Governance issued today by India's new Hindu nationalist-led Government appeared to have been designed to draw wide support from groups that have traditionally opposed the nationalists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAZE, RUTH (NEE KLYDE)
description: RAZE-Ruth (nee Klyde). Died on March 17 after a long battle with Alzheimer's. Loving wife of David for 64 years, devoted mother of the late Joseph, grandmother of Jennifer Adams and Laura Williams, great-grandmother of Dylan and Hayden Adams, dear mother-in-law of Carole Friedman. Services private at grave site. Donations in her memory to Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Bklyn will be appreciated.

title: Just One Little Problem . . .
description: Touring orchestras put great faith in the mechanisms of modern travel, and for the sake of efficiency and cost-effectiveness, they often schedule concerts in distant cities on consecutive evenings. This is usually a safe gamble: orchestra managers tell white-knuckle tales of players, instruments or scores gone astray, but usually everything falls into place at curtain time, and the audience never guesses that disaster was narrowly averted.

title: Accra Journal; African Hospitality No Match for Clinton's Hordes
description: The last time this country received a visitor of such note, it was nearly four decades ago, and the guest was a young Queen Elizabeth. Newly independent and lacking the kinds of accommodations typically reserved for royalty, the Government hurriedly built an extension to a whitewashed old fort that still serves today as State House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTE, JOHN
description: CHRISTE-John. On Monday March 16, 1998, age 46, of a brain tumor. Beloved son of Marguerite and Clarence. Dear brother of James, Thomas, Peter, Andrew, Philip and Margaret. Brother-inlaw of Atsuko, Regina and Wayne. Cherished nephew, uncle, cousin and friend. Valued teacher. Received BFA degree with honors, Pratt Institute, MA in Education, Stonybrook University. Reposing Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street, NY, 212877-9700, Friday 2-9 P.M. Funeral Mass, Holy Name of Jesus RC Church, 207 W. 96 Street, Saturday 10 A.M. Interment private.

title: Let There Be Lighting
description: THERE are numerous reasons for marital strife. Sex. Money. Children. Lamps.

title: House Accord on Starr Evidence
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich and Representative Henry J. Hyde, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, have reached a basic agreement on how to sift evidence that might be used in an impeachment of President Clinton, a Republican Congressional aide said tonight.

title: View From Minnesota
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEN, KUAN, CHENG
description: CHEN-Kuan-Cheng. March 17, 1998. Devoted husband of Una Yuin Tann. Loving father of Elaine, Tina, Sana and Harold. Cherished grandfather of Mya, Aaron, YiLing, YiPei, Selena, Jennifer and Christina. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Saturday, March 21, 3-5 and 7-9PM. Service Sunday, March 22, 1:30PM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREEBEN, MIRIAM
description: DREEBEN-Miriam. March 18. Survived by loving nieces and nephews. Graveside services Thursday, 10 AM, Mt. Carmel Cemetery.

title: Trusts and Estates Give To Neediest Cases Fund
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has issued a list of trusts and estates that contributed to its 86th annual campaign, which ended Feb. 28. Donations from those sources totaled $1,445,060.83, compared with $1,171,229.09 a year ago. Following are the trusts and estates that took part.

title: Calendar; Hats, Gems, Blossoms, Disneytown
description: Millinery and Finery

title: Mobil-Hoechst Venture
description: The Mobil Corporation and Hoechst A.G. have agreed to merge their polypropylene flexible films businesses. Financial terms were not disclosed. The companies plan to combine the operations of Mobil's films unit, based in Pittsford, N.Y., with Hoechst's polypropylene films business, based in Neunkirchen, Germany. Each company will hold a 50 percent stake in the joint venture. It will have about 4,000 employees.

title: Finding Serenity, a Bit Belatedly
description: Selena Goodall is not your average head case. No sirree, not by a long shot. Her motto seems to be, don't get mad, get rat poison. Whenever she reaches the end of her rope, she spoons heaping tablespoons of it into the teacups, coffee mugs and baby bottles of parents, boyfriends and other assorted loved ones.

title: 'Hoosiers' No More, but Heroes All the Same
description: The rituals of high school basketball, celebrated in Indiana as perhaps nowhere else, were all there and alive for the regional title game here in Shelby County: a screaming, sweaty Friday night crowd of 2,600, a rural gym surrounded by stubbly winter cornfields, a parade for the victors headed by the town fire truck.

title: Computer Obsessions
description: To the Editor:

title: Memorial to Honor Gruson
description: A memorial gathering for Sydney Gruson, a former executive of The New York Times Company, who died on March 8, will be held at 11 A.M. next Thursday in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Those attending are asked to use the museum's main entrance on Fifth Avenue at 82d Street.

title: Manhattan Traffic Barricades Are to Get More Permanent Cast
description: The city's pilot program to ease gridlock in midtown Manhattan took another step toward permanence yesterday when transportation officials announced that wrought-iron barricades would replace temporary ones at two intersections and that two midblock crosswalks would be added to help ease traffic.

title: No Rush on Cloning
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRIS, ROBERT L.
description: FERRIS-Robert L. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Stanley and Patty. Cherished brother of Alan and the late Philip. Adored grandfather of Brandon. Dear step-father of Stephanie, Sharon and Sandy Losee and stepgrandfather of Olivia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, BENEDICT
description: GINSBERG-Benedict. 1908-1998. Mr. and Mrs Herbert R. Weissberg and Family mourn the passing of the greatest lawyer and loyal friend for more than forty years. We will miss him every day.

title: Derek H. R. Barton, Nobel Laureate in Chemistry, Dies at 79
description: Dr. Derek H. R. Barton, who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for adding a third dimension to chemical analysis, which has been central to research on new drugs and chemicals for decades, died on Monday at his home in College Station, Tex. He was 79.

title: Talented Couples Is Regaining Momentum
description: Fred Couples does not have to play often to play well.

title: Broken Mast Ends Attempt at Record
description: A huge wave swept under the stern of the 92-foot catamaran Royal & Sun Alliance yesterday, pitching both bows into the sea so forcefully that the sailboat came to a shuddering halt and broke its mast. None of the crew members was injured, but the incident put an end to the attempt by 10 women at a round-the-world sailing record.

title: For Fanatics, Sports Webcasts
description: IT'S not quite like being there. It does not even approximate television. But if you are in Fresno, Calif., or Chippewa Falls, Wis., and your favorite team is in Chicago or Denver, it's the next best thing. And for some sports junkies, that is a great leap forward.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, JOHN E.
description: KAUFMAN-John E., 71. A noted lighting engineer and long-time resident of Stamford, died at home Monday morning, March 16. The cause of death was cardiac arrest. Mr. Kaufman, who retired in 1992, was formerly technical director of the Illuminating Engineering Society of North America, and editor of ''The Lighting Handbook''. During his lengthy service to the IESNA, he was the recipient of many society awards: Marks Fellow, Distinguished Service, and Presidential Award. He was also an elected officer of the Commission Internationale de l'Eclairage, the worldwide lighting organization, and a member of the New York Academy of Science. Mr. Kaufman graduated from Cornell University in 1949. He was a director of Camillus Cutlery Co, a member of the ZBT fraternity, the Cornell Society of Engineers, the Senior Men's Association of Stamford, and the Retired Men's Club at the JCC. His wife, Betsy B. Kaufman of Stamford, died in 1986. He is survived by his mother, Fannye G. Kaufman, of Briarcliff, NY; his brother, Harold B. Kaufman Jr, of Somers, NY; his daughter, Gail K. Furgal of New York City; his son, J. Gilbert of Coral Gables, Fla; and three grandchildren. Plans for a memorial service have not yet been announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Stamford Hospital and Memorial SloanKettering Hospital, New York City.

title: Osteoporosis Linked to Vitamin D Deficiency
description: A new study strongly suggests that widespread deficiencies of vitamin D may play a big role in causing the bone-wasting disease osteoporosis among older Americans.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Name That Tomato Yourself

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy Remains Strong, Fed Says in 'Beige Book'

title: Crew Overrides Board In Picking School Chief
description: Seeking to rein in what he described as a recalcitrant school board, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew temporarily unseated the members of Community School Board 23 in Brooklyn yesterday because they had refused to appoint his first-choice candidate for district superintendent.

title: Gambler Learns She Can't Beat the House in Court
description: Late one August evening in 1991, Sheila King, a recent widow, was playing $25 slot machines at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., when she impulsively decided to try her luck at a nearby machine that cost $500 for each pull of the handle. Five times she dropped in the precious tokens and came up empty. But on her sixth pull all three reels stopped on blue sevens.

title: Public Eye; Big Sound, Little Boxes
description: WHETHER it signifies retro Art Deco decor or the return of the biomorphic shape, the table-top radio is back. This time, however, it comes in inoffensive colors (forget aqua and pink) and aspires to the height of taste (or failing that, nostalgia).

title: Metro Business; Accountant Is Guilty In Real Estate Fraud
description: A former partner of Arthur Andersen & Company has been convicted by a Federal jury of helping to mislead more than 700 investors about the value of real-estate limited partnerships they bought for $30 million, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JACOB M.
description: GOLDMAN-Jacob M. March 17. Beloved husband of Lucille. Loving father of Janice and David Cepler, Richard and Sylvia Goldman; cherished grandfather of five. Services Thursday, March 19, 1:30PM, at Gutterman's, Woodbury, LI.

description: To the Editor:

title: Behind a Huge S.& L. Empire, a Low-Key Superstar
description: Kerry K. Killinger.

title: Food for Bubbas
description: Some supporting roles are decided by auditions, others on the casting couch. All MIKE CECIL did was to answer the telephone. Soon he was shipping doughnuts to Hollywood -- dozens and dozens of doughnuts for ''Primary Colors,'' the barely fictionialized comedy-drama about the 1992 campaign that, if nothing else, captures BILL CLINTON'S high-calorie eating habits.

title: No Rush on Cloning
description: To the Editor:

title: China Names New Foreign Minister
description: The Government announced a new Cabinet today that includes a new Foreign Minister and places several pragmatic allies of the new Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji, in key economic posts.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SCHUFF STEEL CO., Phoenix, agreed to acquire the privately held Addison Structural Services Inc., Albany, Ga., another steel company, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Making Books; One Publisher, Two Faces
description: Nerves jangled, and there was some consternation and even perhaps a moment of second thought when it recently dawned at Random House Inc. that one arm of the publishing company was about to trash Disney as a sinister force while another was preparing an acclamatory autobiography of Michael Eisner, Disney's chief.

title: To the Mayor, He's a Friend and Impresario
description: Elliot Cuker is a City Hall courtier who deals in classic cars, fine cigars and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's new-found acting passions. ''I have literally created a monster,'' Mr. Cuker said of his unofficial role as the Mayor's acting coach. ''I think he would love for me to create a musical for 'The Godfather.' ''

title: Design Notebook; A Star To Swing On
description: SOMEWHERE there's music. At the Grey Art Gallery and Study Center on Washington Square, to be precise, where a beautiful show of work by the Japanese designer Shiro Kuramata is now on view.

title: McKinney Verdict Reveals an Injustice
description: To the Editor:

title: Snowboarders Back in Their Element
description: It has been 20 years since Jake Burton began turning out snowboards from his small shop in Londonderry, Vt. He is the largest snowboard manufacturer in the world now, but a lot of good that did him at the Winter Games in Nagano, Japan.

title: Freedom for Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Resales
description: Manhattan

title: Insurer Rivals Reach a Pact In Miami Fight
description: After seven weeks of battling for control of a little-known Miami insurance company, Maurice R. Greenberg, the chief executive of American International Group, one of the country's largest insurers, indicated yesterday that he was giving way to a rival bidder.

title: McKinney Verdict Reveals an Injustice; Military Misses Point
description: To the Editor:

title: When Citizenship Is Leadership; Misplaced Nostalgia
description: To the Editor:

title: In Cameras' Glare, A Man About Town
description: Dodging taxis and bicycle messengers while driving the congested streets of Manhattan is hard. Avoiding surveillance cameras is probably impossible.

title: Lawmakers in Albany Propose 2 Plans to Ease Cost of College
description: Three years after lawmakers enacted large tuition increases for public colleges, the Democrats who control the State Assembly proposed cutting tuition today by $250 a year.

title: Sports of The Times; Once Again, It's Dean's Tournament
description: THE Indiana University men's basketball coach said in a national magazine last week how ''badly'' he feels that Dean Smith may have ''stepped down a year too soon.'' Smith, Bob Knight lamented, had another chance to go to the Final Four, to win it all, to turn out the lights on the grand stage as he descended it one last time.

title: Bidding on Pieces of Mystique; After Disputes Are Settled, Kennedy Auction Proceeds
description: Displayed around the worn hardwood floors were the bits and pieces of an Administration that prided itself on taste and glamour. Potential buyers scrutinized the Presidential long johns, hanging next to a bolero jacket once worn by the First Lady, as the music of ''Camelot'' echoed through the cavernous armory on the Upper East Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINCKERHOFF, FLORENCE ANDREEN
description: BRINCKERHOFF-Florence Andreen. Born on August 27, 1904, died on March 17, 1998 at her home in New York City after a long illness. Widow of Charles M. Brinckerhoff who was a recipient of the Hoover Medal and CEO of Anaconda Copper Mining Company. Private family service at Greenfield Cemetery, Long Island. Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JOYCE ARNOFF
description: COHEN-Joyce Arnoff. Beloved wife of Murray; devoted mother to Holly, Tom and Amy; loving mother-in-law to Richard Osman and Elisa Singer; adored grandmother to Sarah, Eric, Jessie and Eli. Died peacefully on March 18, 1998 after a long and valiant fight from a brain tumor. Joyce dedicated her life to Tzedakah and helping others. She served on numerous boards including The Jewish Theological Seminary, The United Jewish Appeal, Congregation Or Zarua, The National C.J.F. Woman's Division and The National Foundation for Jewish Culture. Throughout her life she demonstrated incredible strength, generosity, courage and love for all who knew her. Her devotion to the State of Israel, Jewish history and Jewish tradition guided her in her effort to spread joy, compassion and understanding. Her thoughts were constantly about helping others and she was led by her motto ''I cared and so I tried.'' She will always be remembered by her kind and thoughtful deeds to others, her great humor and grace and her beautiful smile. Funeral services will be held 10 A.M. Friday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Jewish Theological Seminary.

title: 15 Accused of Dealing Drugs At Midtown Manhattan Club
description: Federal prosecutors charged 15 men yesterday, including a man they called the head bouncer at the Sound Factory, a midtown nightclub, in a scheme to sell thousands of dollars worth of Ecstasy and other drugs inside the Manhattan club and at other locations.

title: 12 Municipalities Sue State Over Its Support of Public Education
description: Twelve cities and towns in Connecticut announced today that they were filing a joint lawsuit asserting that the state has not met its constitutional obligations to finance public education adequately.

title: Syracuse Is on Top In the Poll
description: The dynasty continues. Syracuse prevailed during the difficult early part of the season and the Orangemen (3-0) are on top with the nominated player of the year, attackman Casey Powell, meeting and perhaps exceeding expectations.

title: As Big as Microsoft: Ribbing Gates
description: CALL them Gates gags: the digitized barbs flung playfully across cyberspace at the expense of the billionaire computer icon Bill Gates and the ubiquitous goods of his software company, Microsoft. Or call them tasteless examples of sour grapes, these jokes popping up on countless computers at the expense of William H. Gates, a great American entrepreneur whose Windows handiwork runs most of the computers on the planet.

title: Hindu Party Says It Will Reconsider Its Nuclear Policy
description: India's new Hindu nationalist Government said on Wednesday that it would review the country's nuclear policy and ''induct nuclear weapons'' into its military arsenal, a declaration that seemed likely to set off new anxiety about an arms race between India and Pakistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMERSON, KITTY
description: KRAMERSON - Kitty. Loving mother of Phyllis Brunelle and children Kim, Chris, Daniel. Best grandmother of Jeff, Adam and Audra Berkowitz and friend of Corby Chemists. Funeral services today, 10 A.M., at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapels, 2nd Ave. and 10th Street, New York City.

title: What Do They Mean by Digital, Anyhow?
description: The digital age, they call it -- this era in which information increasingly gets stored, retrieved and transmitted in an electronic form that computers can handle. But what does ''digital'' mean, anyhow?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELAMED, MOISES
description: MELAMED-Moises. On March 17, 1998. Devoted father of Deborah Melamed and the late Steven Melamed, and like a father to Vicki Passman. A uniquely kind and generous man with boundless energy and love, who took such good care of all of us. We are indescribably sad at losing him. Services Thursday, March 19th, 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: For All the Matador Types Out There
description: STANLEY CONRAD admits that bullfighting is not a subject near and dear to the average American. But he thinks that this is exactly why his three-year-old Web site, Mundo Taurino (mundo-taurino.org), has become so popular.

title: Ex-Governor Of Arkansas Talks to Jury
description: Jim Guy Tucker, the former Governor of Arkansas, who agreed to cooperate with Whitewater investigators in exchange for leniency, appeared today before a Federal grand jury in Arkansas.

title: Why Not Valparaiso?
description: There are those who believe that the annual N.C.A.A. basketball tournament inspires more interest and emotion among armchair fans than any other of our season-ending sports festivals, the World Series and the Super Bowl included. If that is so, it is due to the tournament's geographical reach (64 teams drawn from all over the country), a competitive intensity arising from the knowledge that each game could be a team's last, and the Cinderella factor -- the tournament's flair for producing dramatic endings and spectacular upsets.

title: When Citizenship Is Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Ugly Tie For Artful Losers
description: ISLANDERS 4, SENATORS 4

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORAPURE, CORNELIUS E.
description: SORAPURE-Cornelius E. Of Morris Township, NJ, formerly of New York City, Saturday, March 14, 1998. Mr. Sorapure was a former attorney with AlliedSignal Corp., W.R. Grace & Co., and Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen, and Hamilton. Husband of Ellen, father of Madeline and the late Gabrielle. Brother of Irene. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday March 21, 1998 at the Church of the Assumption, Morristown, NJ at 10:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the New York Philharmonic, Avery Fisher Hall, 10 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023. Contact Doyle Funeral Home, 106 Maple Avenue, Morristown, NJ.

title: Once Behind the Pack, Adidas Vies for the Lead
description: When Robert Louis-Dreyfus was tapped five years ago to run Adidas A. G., he was taking over the weakest franchise in the global sporting goods league.

title: Arts in America; A Visual Radio Show With Birds and Guilty Psychics
description: ''Chickens and turkeys,'' says Ira Glass, ''more than other animals, are a mirror of ourselves, of our desires, of our needs.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MARTIN
description: KAUFMAN-Martin. Loving father of Ellin and Samuel Heilman, Gail and Jeffrey Summit, Mark and Sarah Kaufman. Adoring grandfather to Adam, Uriel, Avi, Yoni, Aleza, Ariela, Zachary, David and Daniel. Beloved companion of Bunny Rosenberg and beloved friend to her children, Steven and Robin. Service today, 1 P.M. at Riverside 21 W. Broad St, Mount Vernon, NY

title: Garden Currents; RUSTIC WARE -- Garden Prints of the 1800's Return As Plates and Paperweights
description: Shoppers yearning for a bit of the country garden can find it at John Derian's shop. Mr. Derian reprints 19th-century images of flowers, birds and butterflies and turns them by decoupage into plates, paperweights and even bistro tables. On a quiet East Village street, he and his staff of 10 cut and paste prints under tempered or handblown glass. He paints the borders, and then they back the glass with felt or seal it with paint. The objects are functional as well as decorative; some can be submerged in water, but none are dishwasher safe.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a hearing on remedial education at the City University of New York referred incorrectly in some editions to the three trustees who are pressing hardest for cutbacks in remedial programs. The three, Anne A. Paolucci, Herman Badillo and John J. Calandra, were not present at the hearing. The article also misstated the given name of a professor who attended. She is Lenore Beaky, not Lorraine.

title: Study Faults U.S. Military Aid Sent to Mexico's Anti-Drug Effort
description: After years in which American officials have bitterly criticized Mexico's cooperation in the battle against drug trafficking, Government inspectors suggested today that the United States may bear a greater share of the blame.

title: Household Savings Rate Declines in Japan
description: Japan's average household savings fell in 1997 for the first time in four years, signaling that the nation's slump has spread to one of the pillars of the economy.

title: Ah, Wholesomeness! O'Neill With a Smile
description: An era of good feeling has descended on the Vivian Beaumont Theater. Illuminated by a summer sky of lavender and lime, and warmed by the words of Eugene O'Neill at his most wistful and serene, Lincoln Center Theater's revival of ''Ah, Wilderness!'' opened last night, in a production as smooth as a moonlit lake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADICOFF, ESTHER
description: ADICOFF-Esther. Beloved wife of the late Aaron (Harry) Adicoff. Loving aunt, cousin and friend. Services Friday 11AM at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Cedar Park-Bethel, Paramus, NJ.

title: N.F.L.: Giants; Hampton's Time With the Giants Appears Short
description: Rodney Hampton was back inside Giants Stadium today, his place of work since the team's Super Bowl season of 1990.

title: 3 Top Cabinet Members Lobby Congress for I.M.F. and U.N.
description: Three senior Cabinet members warned today that American economic and security interests would suffer badly if Congress failed to approve new financing for the International Monetary Fund and pay its back dues to the United Nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUTERBAUGH, ELAINE KEATS
description: PUTERBAUGH-Elaine Keats. Beloved wife of Dr. Rex Puterbaugh. Devoted mother of Mary Lee Morris, Nancy Jane Benson and Kathleen Ellen Beaulieu. Dear sister of Rawley Silver. Adored grandmother of Danielle Keats Citron, Jeanine Keats Morris, Eli Benson, Ezra Benson, Daniel Beaulieu and Lukas Beaulieu. Services are private. Shiva to be observed on Thursday 7 to 9 P.M., and Friday 1 to 5 P.M.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: PAN AM DROPS TALKS WITH POTENTIAL INVESTOR
description: The Pan Am Corporation, the start-up airline that is in bankruptcy proceedings, said yesterday that it had ended talks with a potential investor, Milan Mandaric. But Pan Am, which carries the name of its once-great forebear, said it and its creditors' committee would continue to talk with other possible investors. Mr. Mandaric, who has gained a reputation for turning around several troubled electronics companies, was the only investor known to be interested in Pan Am after the financier Carl C. Icahn withdrew an offer on Monday.

title: Bank Employee Charged in Theft
description: The F.B.I. is seeking to arrest an employee of the BankBoston Corporation who has been charged with embezzling money from the bank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEIGER, DOROTHY
description: SCHWEIGER-Dorothy. With great sadness we mourn the passing of Dorothy Schweiger, beloved wife of Erwin. We share his loss and extend sincerest sympathies. Dorothy, always her book in hand, her wit, and smile graced our premises every summer day. Her active drive for charities like Westhampton Hospice-Save the Children Association-and ALS Foundation was constant-with dignity. We at Lacoquille-our family-and Dorothy was an integral part. Lacoquille-Westhampton Board of Directors Harry Ruchman, Pres.

title: City Hospitals Are Targets For Layoffs
description: The Giuliani administration said yesterday that it would immediately seek to eliminate 800 workers in the public hospital system in what would be the second large layoff of unionized city workers during the Mayor's tenure. In addition, the officials said they plan to whittle another 700 hospital workers in the coming months, in part through attrition.

title: Foreign Investors Start Return to Thailand
description: Fresh investment has begun flowing into Thai companies and banks for the first time since the financial system started to crumble eight months ago, raising hope that foreign investors are starting to acquire assets made cheap by severe currency and market losses.

title: NEXTEL BUYS 21% STAKE IN JAPANESE WIRELESS PROVIDER
description: Nextel Telecommunications Inc., the mobile communications company backed by the McCaw family, has purchased a 21 percent stake in the J-Com Company from Nippon Motorola, the Japanese subsidiary of Motorola Inc. Nextel, based in McLean, Va., paid $32 million for the shares and extended a substantial loan to J-Com, which was formed in December by Nippon Motorola, the Nichimen Corporation and the Orix Corporation, a leasing and finance company. J-Com specializes in marketing digital wireless service for companies that must communicate frequently with employees outside the office.

title: Lawyer Questions Woman In a Sexual Attack Trial
description: A woman who said she was tortured and kidnapped by a Columbia University graduate student she met through the Internet came under withering cross-examination yesterday as a defense lawyer questioned how she managed to free herself, get dressed and fight off her attacker simultaneously.

title: Lobbyists' Spending in Albany Increases 31%
description: Lobbying the Legislature continues as one of New York's most dependable growth industries, with spending up almost a third during the last three years, according to a state lobbying commission report released today.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The dollar reached a two-month high against the yen, which weakened after a senior policy maker in Japan ruled out tax cuts to stimulate the economy. In New York the dollar cost 130.11 yen, up from 129.64.

title: User's Guide; Hunting the Elusive Spammer
description: APPARENTLY no one informed the sparrow.mooncrater.net postmaster that there are only two kinds of ''personal'' E-mail I really like to get: a short note from my literary agent promising to send a check right away or a quick line from my husband announcing his intent to come home early to cook dinner.

title: Diminishing Draw For Olympic Games
description: Viewers of the Olympic Winter Games in Nagano, Japan, watched on average one full day less of coverage than viewers watched of the 1996 Summer Games in Atlanta.

title: Union Leaders Say Railroad Resists Change
description: Union Pacific's plans to avoid accidents like those that killed 11 people last year are foundering on resistance from the railroad's middle managers and field supervisors, union leaders contended at a Federal safety hearing today.

title: Teaching Doctors How to Act
description: DR. MARK H. SWARTZ'S diagnosis of tonight's episode of ''Seinfeld'' is upbeat. ''I was concerned about what kind of mockery they might make of our program,'' he said, ''but the script sounds pretty good.''

title: Top-Level Lazard Executive Will Join Goldman, Sachs
description: Kendrick R. Wilson, one of Wall Street's best-regarded investment bankers, will be leaving Lazard Freres & Company on March 30 to join the financial institutions group at Goldman, Sachs & Company as a managing director.

title: Turner Has His Say as Owners Weigh Sale
description: Ted Turner, the irrepressible leader of the Atlanta Braves, came to his first baseball owners meeting in nine years today not to praise Rupert Murdoch but to try to bury his chances of buying the Los Angeles Dodgers for $311 million.

title: Girardi Sees His Future As a General Manager
description: Joe Girardi used to joke with Brian Cashman, then the Yankees' assistant general manager, about his dream of becoming general manager of a major league team. You'll be general manager of the Yankees one day, Cashman would tell the catcher, and I'll be your assistant.

title: Hill That Broke Bodies and Hearts
description: The horrors of Vietnam stay with us. Tomorrow night ''A Few Good Men'' returns to 1967 and a place called Hill 881 that marines were ordered to take. Thirty-six of them, mostly teen-agers from Hotel Company, walked into an ambush; four were killed, 23 wounded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMEAL, MARY JEAN
description: SMEAL-Mary Jean, March 12, 1998. The Trustees and staff of the Citizens Budget Commission mourn the passing of Mary Jean Smeal, beloved wife of our esteemed former Chairman, beneficent Trustee and dear friend, Frank P. Smeal, and beloved mother of our colleague and dear friend Hank Smeal. Our deep sympathies to the Smeal family. Lawrence B. Buttenwieser, Chair, Citizens Budget Commission Raymond D. Horton, President, Citizens Budget Commission

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIERRA, MARCELINO F. (PH.D.)
description: SIERRA-Marcelino F. (Ph.D.) Of Rockville Centre. Succumbed on March 16 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, at age 54 following a long, noble, hard fought battle against cancer. His family, friends and colleagues deeply mourn his passing. He was a loving husband to Lorraine; beloved son of Natalie; a devoted father to Michael and Kevin; dear brother of Elisa Guttierez; cherished uncle of Miguel Guttierez and a caring and loyal friend to all who were touched by him, and a leader in his chosen field of microbiology. He received his Ph.D. in microbiology from St. John's University and since 1974, had been the Director of Microbiology at King's County Hospital Center and the University Hospital of Brooklyn and Associate Professor of Pathology at the SUNY Health Science Center at Brooklyn. He was a member of the American Society for Microbiology, the New York Society of Infectious Diseases, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the Infectious Diseases Society of America, the Pan American Group for Rapid Viral Diagnosis, and he was the Chairman of the Microbiology Division of the New York Academy of Science (from 1984-1986) and Codirector of Workshop in Clinical Laboratory Sciences. He is the author of numerous scientific publications and was especially recognized for his contributions to the development of methods for the laboratory diagnosis of mycobacterial infections. In 1997 he received the bio Merieux Vitek Distinguished Achievements in Clinical Microbiology Award for his contributions to the NYC branch of the American Society for Microbiology. Visiting Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at the Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial, Saturday, 10:15 A.M. at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bklyn. In lieu of flowers or donations to charities, contributions may be sent to: The Dr. Marcelino F. Sierra Memorial Fund. Kindly make checks payable to: The NYC Branch of the ASM and mail them to: P.O. Box 736, Westbury, New York 11590. His impact was profound, both personal and professional. Goodness, generosity, compassion, wisdom and strength are his legacy.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 3COM TO CUT 380 JOBS AND REPLACE A TOP EXECUTIVE
description: The 3Com Corporation said yesterday that it would lay off 380 workers at two Chicago-area plants and replace a top Illinois executive as the company struggles with product lines acquired in its 1997 purchase of the U.S. Robotics Corporation. 3Com, the No. 2 maker of networking equipment, said the employees worked at former U.S. Robotics plants that made desktop computer modems and remote access servers, used by businesses to route telephone calls to the Internet. The dismissed workers represent about 7 percent of 3Com's Illinois work force. The company also said John McCartney, president of 3Com's client access business unit, which includes modems and remote access products, would leave the company next week.

title: U.S. Weighs Deal to Halt Missile-Gear Sales by China
description: The United States is weighing whether to allow American satellite manufacturers to buy launching services from China, a senior Government official said today. In exchange, China would have to create a system to stop sales of Chinese missile technology to nations like Iran.

title: Recycling Cybercarcasses
description: To the Editor:

title: George Humphreys, 65, Adviser To Politicians Since Rockefeller
description: George W. Humphreys, a political adviser who worked in more than 80 election campaigns, all Republican except for his final one in Georgia, died on Monday at Piedmont Hospital in Atlanta. He was 65 and had lived in Atlanta since moving from Manhattan about a dozen years ago.

title: Think History's Dull? Not Mrs. Grover Cleveland
description: THE SMITHSONIAN INSTITUTION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRENT, ESTELLE
description: TRENT-Estelle. Beloved wife of Philip Trent (aka Clifford Jones) at The Actors' Fund Home, on March 17, 1998. Mother of Rev. William Komstedt and Robert Fohrmeister. Memorial service to be announced. Donations to The Actor's Fund Home, 175 West Hudson Avenue, Englewood, NJ 07631.

title: Clerics Hopeful on Chinese Religious Freedom
description: Three American religious leaders who toured China last month on a fact-finding mission issued a cautiously optimistic report yesterday: Religious freedom has improved in China over the last 20 years, they said, but the country still needs to make significant changes in order to meet acceptable international standards.

title: SIEMENS DEAL COULD BRING MCI $2.1 BILLION IN BUSINESS
description: A Siemens A.G. unit and the MCI Communications Corporation signed a five-year agreement yesterday that could bring $2.1 billion in business to MCI, the No. 2 United States long-distance company. Under the agreement, Siemens Business Communication Systems Inc. and MCI will conduct joint sales activities, and Siemens will deliver customers for MCI's long-distance, data and Internet services. Siemens Business Communication Systems is the United States affiliate of Siemens Private Communications Systems, the world's largest supplier of private telecommunications systems.

title: Wallace Could Use Audience With Cone
description: A conversation between David Cone and the Mets reliever Derek Wallace might sound more like an episode of ''E.R.'' than ''This Week in Baseball.''

title: Irish Hearts Are Happy, but Not Too Happy
description: A famous advertisement for the national brew of Ireland shows a foaming pint above the adage ''Guinness Is Good for You.'' The common American view of Irish culture reflects this playful union of recreation and edification. The country's history presents potent themes of exile and religious conflict from a perspective that is emotionally immediate. Yet for most people, it remains safely distant, historically and geographically.

title: Technology Gives Circus A Mighty Roar
description: OUTWARDLY, the circus is still the circus. Jim Ragona, the lord of the ring known as the Voice, still struts the arena in the classic tail-coated equestrian outfit that has been the grand affectation of ringmasters through the generations. Arrayed about him is the full complement of elephants, tigers and humans, gathering in celebration of this ancient spectacle of artistry and smell and sweat.

title: LIBRARY/HOME DESIGN; Dreams on Screen, Including Kitchen Sink
description: DO we still need architects? Not according to some of the companies behind some of the CD-ROM home-design programs that allow you to build your dream house on screen.

title: No More Free Drinks: System Keeps Tabs on Bartenders
description: THERE'S an old story about the tavern owner who suspects his bartender of playing a little loose with the receipts. One night he watches through a ceiling trapdoor as his man divides the take into two stacks.

title: INSIDE
description: Warning on Computer Glitch

title: Garden Currents; OUTDOOR DESIGN -- Landscape as Living Room
description: Boxwoods for chairs, bamboo for curtains? Can the outdoors be designed as easily as the indoors? In straightforward language, and with gorgeous photographs of her garden and the gardens of others, Bunny Williams takes the terror out of garden making. Not a how-to book, or a cultivation guide, ''On Garden Style'' (Simon & Schuster, $35), written with Nancy Drew, will prove indispensable for garden design. Ms. Williams, who is best known as an interior designer, preaches fearless wall color on one page (inset), exhorts us to put pots of blooming flowers out in the kitchen garden, and amid the prints and drawings, throws in chunks of unexpected prose and poetry (Robert Frost, Anne Bradstreet, John Steinbeck, Robert Penn Warren and Mary McCarthy). Though Ms. Williams includes wide open spaces, her bottom line is: ''It takes walls to make a room.''

title: Sports of The Times; Devils Have Old Habit: Just Keep On Winning
description: QUIETLY and systematically, the Devils know the opportunity for another Stanley Cup is approaching. But it is almost as if the Devils were playing all their games up there in Canada somewhere. Moose Jaw or Medicine Hat.

title: More Doctors
description: There were shrieks, high-fives and relief after waiting and wondering. It was ''match day'' at the New York University Medical School, a kind of reckoning for the 168 fourth-year students who learned where they had been accepted as medical residents, the next step toward becoming full-fledged doctors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, SAMUEL
description: WALLACH-Samuel. Devoted husband of the late Blanche. Adored father of Alfred, Richard and Samoa Joan; cherished grandfather of Pamela, Jennifer, Jodie, Clifford, Joshua and David. Service Friday 11:30AM at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Economic Scene; It works in Bulgaria, but will it be a disaster for Indonesia?
description: THE similarities between Bulgaria in 1997 and Indonesia today are striking. Bulgaria was struggling to cope with insolvent banks, hold the lid on inflation and restore confidence in its currency. And as Indonesia is now, Bulgaria was tempted by a radical fix -- a ''currency board'' system that removes all discretion in monetary policy and fixes the currency's value to that of its rich trading partners.

title: 1998 N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: A Coach in Search of His Destiny; Connecticut's Calhoun Is Missing a Final Four Line on His Resume
description: Jim Calhoun keeps a crude wooden box on the desk in his office. Just a block of wood with hinges on the back, a few words across the lid and a few more inside. But this relic offers a peek into who the intense basketball coach at the University of Connecticut is, and why he is who he is.

title: Puzzling Over the Allure of Virtual Barbie
description: WHAT, exactly, are you doing when you play with a doll on a computer?

title: Garden Currents; RETAINING WALLS -- Basic as Piaf's Black Dress
description: ''They're an old tradition, rising out of the ground yet again,'' Douglas Reed, a landscape architect in Cambridge, Mass., said of the stone retaining walls in his garden designs, like this one in East Hampton, N.Y. Like the little black dress, the retaining wall is a basic. This year's version has no frills and can run as low as six inches. ''Even a single wide stone step can add a retaining-wall look,'' Mr. Reed said. And no plants tumbling down the rock face means that today's garden is calming down and sharpening up. Retaining walls can be added to restore crispness to sagging middle-aged gardens. They don't come cheap, however. A three-foot-high wall will run between $90 and $120 a linear foot. Douglas Reed Landscape Architecture: (617) 354-0554.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, DONALD
description: JOYCE-Donald. On Tuesday, March 10, 1998, age 45, of cancer. Musician, organist, choir director, teacher. A service will be held on Saturday, March 28, at 1 P.M., at the Church of the Holy Apostles, 9th Ave at 28th St., NYC 10001. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made either to the Organ Fund at the above church or to the Donald Joyce Scholarship Fund at the Copland School of Music, Queens College, Flushing, N.Y. 11367.

title: Federal Charges for Juvenile In a Case of Computer Crime
description: Prosecutors announced today that, apparently for the first time, they were bringing Federal computer crime charges against a juvenile -- a Massachusetts teen-ager whose modem mischief temporarily knocked out phone service to about 600 homes and a small airport's control tower last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSIG, CARRIE
description: LIPSIG-Carrie. Died at age 91, March 15, in Coconut Creek, FL. Beloved mother of Dr. Stephen and Susan Lipsig of Roslyn Estates, and Joseph and Maryann Lipsig of Sunnyvale, California. Adored grandmother of Diana, David and Scott. Sister of Sara Edelson of FL. Former Director of Food Services for the Board of Jewish Education, City of New York. She was a true pathfinder.

title: BMW Earnings Climb; Stock Payout Is Set
description: BMW A.G. said yesterday that it would sell new shares to raise about 2.1 billion marks ($1.15 billion) and pay a share dividend after second-half profit rose a surprising 67 percent, amid demand for its highest-priced models. Profit at the company, which makes BMW and Rover cars, rose to 811 million marks in the second half from 485 million marks a year earlier. BMW will raise its 1997 dividend to 20 marks a common share from 15 and to 21 marks a preferred share from 16 marks, also above expectations. BMW's common shares jumped 115 marks, to 2,015.

title: Blazers Outmuscle Stumbling Knicks
description: The Knicks were looking into the belly of the Portland Trail Blazers. This was a team as oversized and as hard to pass for the injured and undersized Knicks as a Winnebago on the highway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, ELIZABETH L.
description: MILLS-Elizabeth L. The Kildonan School Board of Trustees, faculty, staff, students and alumni mourn the passing of our friend, colleague and Chairman of the Board, Elizabeth L. Mills. Her dedication, generosity, kindness and warm sense of humor will be deeply missed. We express our profound condolences to her family.

description: A soupcon of plot touches off a carnival of chases in Jackie Chan's latest adventure, ''Mr. Nice Guy.''

description: Legislative leaders said today that they hoped to vote next week on a bill to reduce automobile insurance rates, but they conceded that they still had no idea what the bill would say.

title: FE HOLDINGS IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE MARBEL ENERGY OF OHIO
description: The Firstenergy Corporation and the Belden & Blake Corporation said yesterday that FE Holdings L.L.C., a joint venture they formed to buy natural gas properties, had agreed to buy the Marbel Energy Corporation for an undisclosed amount. Firstenergy, based in Akron, Ohio, is the 12th-largest United States electric utility, with $5 billion in annual revenue and 2.2 million power customers in Ohio and Pennsylvania. The closely held Belden & Blake, based in North Canton, Ohio, is an independent natural gas company with $160 million in annual revenues. Marbel Energy, a closely held natural gas company in Canton, Ohio, had sales of $125 million in 1997.

title: Prosecutors Ask Judge to Dismiss Lawyers in Baby Death Case
description: Repeating a tactic that they used successfully last year, prosecutors in Delaware have asked a judge to dismiss Amy S. Grossberg's defense lawyers from her trial on charges that she murdered her newborn son in 1996.

description: ROGOW-Selma Prince (nee Schlesinger), 89. Formerly of Fort Lee, died March 18 at the Allendale Nursing Home where she was a resident this past year. Mrs. Rogow was a member of Congregation Sons of Israel, Leonia. She is survived by her daughters and sons-in-law, Tara and Warren Goldman of River Vale and Joan and Howard Ackerman of Mahwah, a stepdaughter, Ritalou and Robert Harris and a stepson, Stephen and Joan Rogow, a sister, Josephine Schlesinger. And a sister-in-law, Joyce Schlesinger. Other survivors include 16 grandchildren and three great grandchildren. She was the widow of Dr. Harold A. Prince and Dr. Arthur A. Rogow. Another daughter, Susan Prince died last year. Services were held at ''Gutterman-Musicant''. Donations to Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

description: Nine-year-old Mendel Trotzig, the title character of Alexander Rosler's psychologically acute film ''Mendel,'' is the kind of aggressively curious child who always senses when his parents are hiding things from him. When their backs are turned, the little boy furtively sleuths about in search of clues to a past that is being kept from him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENCHER, ALEXANDER
description: MENCHER-Alexander. At the age of 95. Patent lawyer. Devoted husband of Mildred, loving father of Bonnie (Frank) Aliazzo of Lloyd's Neck, Long Island, and Howard (Roberta) Mencher of CA. Also survived by five grandchildren. Funeral services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOW, ELAINE Y.
description: LOW-Elaine Y. Bellmore, New York. March 14, 1998. Beloved and loving wife of Martin, mother of Douglas and Steven, grandmother of Veronica, sister of Harriet, aunt of Suzanne, Adam and Jeffrey. She will be missed be her many friends in and around Bellmore, New York and Delray Beach, FL. All will miss this lady who cared so much for and about others, someone who has truly made a difference in so many lives and so many ways. Elaine engaged in a wide range of professional activities. For over twenty-five years she was a preschool director, a daycamp director, as well as a public school teacher. She was very involved with the PTA, holding the post of president. She also developed and taught a training program for volunteers to teach reading in the public schools. Elaine's family was always at the top of her list leading her to be a pack leader of the Cub Scouts, an assistant Little League coach and a second mother to many who had need. There will be a memorial service which will be announced in the near future. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Elaine's memory to the Suburban Temple, 516-221-2370.

description: Kathleen E. Willey's severe financial problems were closing in on her last summer. Since her husband committed suicide in 1993, Ms. Willey has inherited many of his debts, including a $274,500 judgment that she was ordered to pay last June, court records show.
