description: Sketch comedy, driven by caricature, is different from situation comedy, which is driven by character. Sketch comedy is a lot easier. The comedians who come out of America's sketch shows, ''Saturday Night Live'' and its clones, should have that needle-pointed and hung on their dressing room wall.

title: Jardine Matheson Profits Tumbled 21% in 1997
description: Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd., Hong Kong's biggest trading company and a symbol of its colonial past, said yesterday that its profits tumbled in 1997 as the collapse of Asian currencies took a heavy toll on its far-flung operations. The company, with interests ranging from pastry making to construction to stock brokerage, said profits, excluding exceptional items, fell 21 percent, to $292 million. Analysts had expected a 50 percent rise in profit. (Bloomberg News)

title: Migrating to Movieland, Where Outsiders Fit In
description: Dorothy sings ''Over the Rainbow,'' still in her black-and-white Kansas. Judy Garland's voice keeps going while the images on screen change: there are immigrants flooding through Ellis Island, ragtag families crowded together and smiling at the future; an overhead view of pushcarts on the streets of New York gives way to searchlights outside a Hollywood movie premiere and a burst of color, as if these immigrants had arrived in Oz. And in the background Garland is singing, ''The dreams that we dare to dream really do come true.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, HOWARD BECK
description: WEISBERG-Howard Beck, 77. Died on Thursday, March 12, 1998. Born on November 21st, 1920, in Buffalo, New York. He was preceded in death by his wife of 44 years, Lillian Poltorak Weisberg, parents, Nathan and Cecilia Weisberg, brother Sheldon Weisberg, and sister, Sally Weisberg Alperin. He is survived by his 3 children, Caryl Ben Basat of Weston, FL., Barbara Weisberg Tennison of Austin, TX., Jonathan Howard Weisberg of Dallas, TX., grandson Avi Ben Basat of Weston, FL, and sister Barbara Whiting of New York, NY. Dr. Weisberg graduated from the Nichols School in Buffalo, N.Y. in 1937. After attending the University of Michigan for two years, he enlisted in the American Field Service in 1940 and served with the British Eighth Army under General Montgomery in North Africa until 1942. He then joined the U.S. Air Force and served as a gunnery drill instructor until the end of W.W. II. At the conclusion of the war, he returned to Buffalo, where he married Lillian Poltorak on Dec. 26, 1953. He attended the University of Buffalo, earning a Bachelor's and a Master's Degree in Physiology. In 1960, he earned a PhD. in Physiology from the University of Buffalo. He devoted his life to medical research and helping others. He worked first for the University of Chicago Medical School from 1960 until 1965, and then joined the American Heart Association at their national headquarters in New York. He moved to Dallas in 1975, when the Heart Association relocated its headquarters there. He served as Director of Research with the American Heart Association from 1975 until he retired in 1985. Following his retirement from the American Heart Association, he returned to the University of Chicago Medical School until 1986. He had a quick wit and a keen intelligence, and loved people, art and literature. He was a loving and devoted father, husband, brother and friend and will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held at Temple Emanu-El in Dallas on Friday, March 20, 1998. Condolences can be sent to 7215 Royal Lane, Dallas, Texas 75230. Donations may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABRANCHE, GEORGE M.L. III.
description: LaBRANCHE-George M.L. III. Age 72. Born in New York City on November 11, 1925. Died March 17 after a valiant struggle against cancer. George joined the Marine Corps in 1942 at the age of 17 and later fought in the battle of Iwo Jima. He retired as the President of Roy B. Rendle Company, a Boston marine construction contractor. He is survived by his wife Patricia Munro LaBranche of Marblehead, MA., and Amagansett, N.Y.; a daughter, Eugenie Damon of Darien, CT; a son, George IV of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y.; a daughter, Nicole LaBranche of New York; and 10 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City, Friday, April 3, 1998, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th Street, New York, New York 10003.

description: Indonesian officials began meetings today with officials of the International Monetary Fund, with both sides offering signals of flexibility on the deadlock that has caused a halt in disbursements of international aid.

title: Democrats Stall Bill on Education Tax Breaks
description: In the first confrontation over the education agenda in an election year, Democrats blocked the Republicans' centerpiece proposal today, with each party questioning the other's commitment to schoolchildren.

title: Motorola and Astronomers Agree to a Time Share in Space
description: Faced with the possibility that a new galaxy of communications satellites could hobble the science of radio astronomy, a compromise time-sharing agreement has been struck between radio astronomers in the United States and Motorola Inc., the satellite operator,

title: Trade Pact Brings Drug Searches and Traffic Jams
description: It was a trip of four and a half miles, to haul a trailer of Mexican-made air-conditioner parts from a warehouse in Nuevo Laredo, Mexico, to a freight forwarder just across the border in Texas. For Salvador Romero, the driver, the journey took 29 hours, door to door.

title: Sports of The Times; Celebration! A Boss We Can Cherish
description: IT was just a mom-and-pop business. Of course, Mom was Jane Fonda and Pop was Ted Turner. Pop owned a television superstation and a baseball team. Those were the good old days of personal baseball ownership, fast going out of style.

title: Kennedy Family Member Buys Diaries and Photos at Auction
description: An immediate relative of John F. Kennedy Jr. and Caroline B. Kennedy spent $51,000 yesterday to purchase two diaries and a photo album at the auction of John F. Kennedy memorabilia, an official of the auction house said.

title: City Hall Worker Is Injured in Stabbing
description: A member of the Giuliani administration suffered a small cut to her right hand yesterday morning when a stranger stabbed her inside a subway station on the Upper East Side.

title: The 'New' New Museum, With a Tableau of Wrenching Reality
description: The New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo is living up to its name, making itself new again. Its renovated quarters, a result of nearly two years of construction, are bigger, better-looking and more efficient than before. Outstanding features include more than twice the gallery space, a generous bookstore, improved offices and a new elevator.

title: FORD AFFILIATE TO BUY 90% OF DAIEI FINANCIAL UNIT
description: The Associates First Capital Corporation, an affiliate of the Ford Motor Company, said yesterday that it would pay 80 billion yen ($615 million) for 90 percent of DIC Finance, a financial unit of Daiei Inc., Japan's largest supermarket operator. Associates Capital is the most recent foreign company to gain a foothold in Japan before the Government deregulates financial markets. Associates, based in Irving, Tex., will operate DIC Finance as a separate company, keeping its name, management and branch offices, a spokesman said. Associates, which will be spun off from Ford this year, has 429 consumer-finance branches in Japan, 75 of which were added in the fourth quarter of last year.

title: NEW CHINA LEADER PROMISES REFORMS FOR EVERY SECTOR
description: Zhu Rongji, the new Prime Minister of China, laid down ambitious benchmarks today for sweeping social change, pledging to make ailing state-owned industries solvent, overhaul the country's banking system and redesign the Government, cutting its staff by half -- all within three years.

title: New Video Releases
description: Ulee's Gold

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK WEAKENS. The mark fell on surprising declines in German business confidence and money supply growth, diminishing prospects for higher interest rates. The dollar cost 1.8341 marks in New York, up from 1.8252.

title: Treasury Prices Mixed as Economic Signals Remain Unclear
description: The prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, after several economic reports provided no clear signals for investors.

title: Bill Clinton's African Odyssey
description: The White House hopes that Bill Clinton's 11-day African trip, which begins Sunday, will show off his diplomatic skills and provide a respite from his troubles at home. But a true test of statesmanship on this first African visit by an American President in 20 years is whether Mr. Clinton defends threatened human rights and calls for strengthening democratic freedoms.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Ellen Gallagher

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; Job Takes Priority
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil-Price Drop Threatens to Squelch Russia's Economic Rebound
description: Just as Russia appears to have weathered the economic turmoil that has battered Asia it is facing a new threat: falling oil prices.

title: Rowland Asks $350 Million In Aid to Rebuild Hartford
description: In a step toward delivering on the urban agenda he promised two years ago, Gov. John G. Rowland today proposed a $350 million package to revive downtown Hartford.

title: Handheld Computer Starts to Come of Age
description: PARIS  This year should see the handheld computer graduating from a costly gadget to a relatively inexpensive and productive tool.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKMAN, H. DAVID, M.D.
description: MARKMAN-H. David, M.D. Of Pembroke Pines, FL. Passed away March 19, 1998, formerly of Yonkers, NY. Cherished husband of the late Betty W. Markman. Survived by loving children Michael, Judy, and devoted care giver Barbara Wellington. Practiced medicine in the Bronx for more than 50 years and was associated with The Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Graveside services Friday, at 2:30 P.M., at Menorah Gardens and Funeral Chapels, Fort Lauderdale, Florida.

title: Alumni to Give Brooklyn Tech Huge Donation
description: A group of alumni led by the chairmen of Barnes & Noble booksellers and the Red Apple supermarket chain committed itself yesterday to raising $10 million in the next five years for Brooklyn Technical High School, one of the city's most selective and prestigious public schools.

title: Led by Compaq, Short Sales Rise by 2.3% on Big Board
description: During that month, Compaq reported that it was likely to break even in the first quarter, stunning analysts who had forecast solid profits. The shares closed at $25.375 on March 10, more than $10 below where they were a month earlier. They have since fallen to $23.81.

title: Clash Between Lawyers Delays Brawley Trial
description: The Tawana Brawley defamation trial stalled again yesterday as opposing lawyers and their supporters engaged in another verbal sparring match.

title: If Gingrich Goes, Louisiana Colleague Is Ready
description: Representative Robert L. Livingston said today that he had the votes to become Speaker of the House should the current Speaker, Newt Gingrich, relinquish the job.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Amy Sillman

title: And the Prince Visits the Rolls
description: It was just another stop for PRINCE PHILIP on his three-day visit to New York: the unveiling of a $216,400 Rolls-Royce with DEBORAH BULL, a principal ballerina with the Royal Ballet. (Her costume made her look like the hood ornament.)

title: U.S. TO EASE CURBS ON RELIEF TO CUBA AND MONEY TO KIN
description: At the urging of Pope John Paul II, President Clinton will ease American restrictions on aid to Cuba, direct flights to the country and money sent to relatives by Cuban-Americans, senior American officials said today.

title: Princeton Defeats Defending Champ
description: Princeton, a seventh seeded team which had knocked No. 4 Brown out of the ECAC tournament last weekend, defeated Cornell, 6-2, in last night's game. The Big Red, a team that in turn had eliminated No. 3 Rensselaer, had been the tournament champion the last two seasons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPUTO, LEONARDO (LEO)
description: CAPUTO-Leonardo (Leo). Devoted husband of Santa (nee Delfino). Beloved father of Maryann Longo, Charles, and Nicholas. Loving grandfather of Charles Caputo Jr, Sandra Benedicto, Michael Caputo, Michael Benedicto, Michelle Caputo, Nicholas Caputo, Joanna Caputo, and Joseph Caputo. Loving great-grandfather. Dear brother of Mary Scanapico and Frances Trivisano. Mass at Saint Stephen's at 9:30 A.M., on Monday. In repose, Raccuglia & Son F.H., 321-323 Court Street, Brooklyn, 718-855-7737.

title: Labor Asks Members to Fund $13 Million Political Effort
description: Although the focus of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. meeting here is how to go on the offensive to recruit new members to unions, the labor leaders spent much of today playing defense, seeking to counter attacks by their opponents.

title: New York Taxes Poor Whom U.S. and State Exempt
description: In a discrepancy affecting almost 100,000 poor New York families, the city is assessing income tax on people whose incomes are low enough to exempt them from Federal and state taxes, according to a study by the city's Independent Budget Office.

title: January Trade Deficit Soared, as the Asia Crisis Hit Home
description: The nation's trade deficit surged in January to its highest level in a decade as the financial crises in Asia depressed demand for American goods in that part of the world, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Reading, Writing and Dressing
description: The New York City Board of Education made a splash this week by requiring the city's 550,000 elementary school students to wear uniforms next year. The idea is hardly new, since 229 schools in the city already have voluntary uniform policies, and individuals and schools will still be able to opt out of the plan. The board's unanimous support for uniforms is not so much about improving education as it is a a showy, inexpensive gesture to gain more control over a troubled system. But while uniforms were in the headlines, there was more important news having to do with school principals and the highly charged national debate over how best to teach reading.

title: A Real Mouse With a 90's Edge
description: Where do you go with children's video after you've virtually invented the genre at Disney? On May 5, Dreamworks SKG will release the critically acclaimed ''Mouse Hunt,'' the first big family film to be issued on videocassette by people who made and sold them by the bucket in their former lives at Disney. By the looks, expect a course correction at Dreamworks.

title: Boats Tightly Grouped in Leg 6
description: After 1,200 nautical miles of Leg 6 in the Whitbread Round the World Race, only 43 nautical miles separated the leader, Silk Cut, and the ninth, and last, yacht, Swedish Match.

title: A Family Circle Breaks: Murdoch Owns Dodgers
description: The father yanked them out of Brooklyn 40 years ago to capture the wealth of the West. Now the son has severed them from the family for the wealth $311 million will bring.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Export Laws Challenged by Sale Of Encryption Software Abroad
description: An American maker of data-scrambling software said today that it would circumvent United States export policies by allowing its Dutch subsidiary to begin selling an international version of Pretty Good Privacy, a strong encryption program that does not provide a back door for law enforcement surveillance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JOSEPHINE
description: MILLER-Josephine. The Sanders, Katz and Fischl families of Midwood, Brooklyn, note with deep sadness the passing of our close friend, Josephine. Her warmth and good humor will be missed by all of us, and we send our sincerest condolences to her family.

title: Bibby Inspires Arizona (As if It Needs a Boost)
description: It figures that a guy with a mouse tattoo on his leg would thrive in the shadow of Disneyland.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Norway Raises Rates To Stabilize Currency
description: Norges Bank, the central bank of Norway, raised official interest rates a quarter of a percentage point yesterday, bringing the deposit rate to 3.75 percent and the overnight lending rate to 5.75 percent, effective immediately. The rate rise is in line with the goal of keeping the Norwegian krone stable against other European currencies, the bank said.

title: MOTOROLA MAKES A BID TO INCREASE ITS STAKE IN NETSPEAK
description: Motorola Inc. is offering to pay $90 million to increase its stake in the Netspeak Corporation, a network software developer. Motorola, the electronics giant based in Schaumburg, Ill., will take a $30-a-share cash offer directly to Netspeak shareholders in an effort to acquire 3 million additional shares. Motorola now owns 1.22 million shares, or 10.1 percent of Netspeak's outstanding shares. If successful, Motorola would increase its stake to 34.5 percent. Netspeak's stock gained $1.875, to $30.75. Motorola rose 31.25 cents, to $54.875. Netspeak, based in Boca Raton, Fla., produces software for delivering voice, fax and multimedia over the Internet. Under an agreement, Motorola committed to purchase $30 million worth of Netspeak products.

title: Give Us a Fair Chance to Compete
description: Two decades ago, the banking, insurance and securities industries were bitter rivals, each jealously guarding its legally defined turf.

title: With Bach Resounding and History Repeating
description: With 20 years' hindsight, the idea seems self-evidently simple: Allan Miller and Isaiah Sheffer wanted to move the focus of the music world's attention from midtown Manhattan to the Upper West Side for a day, so they rented the Symphony Theater, a crumbling movie house that doubled as a boxing ring, and presented a free daylong concert. Mr. Miller, who conducted the American Symphony Orchestra in special programs, had access to orchestral musicians, and he and Mr. Sheffer knew plenty of young soloists and singers who lived in the neighborhood of the theater and who volunteered to pitch in. For good measure, they let it be known that competent amateurs could join in as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, MARY ARCHER LORD (POLLY)
description: REED-Mary Archer Lord (Polly), Of Bedford, MA, formerly of Stonington, CT and NYC, March 13, 1998. Loving mother of Abijah of Putney, VT, Anne (Prager) of Sarasota, FL, and Bill of Concord, MA. Also a devoted aunt, grandmother, great grandmother, and friend of countless people who loved her.

title: In Deal to Sell Bus Depot, The Post Would Get a Plant
description: A committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to make a bus depot in the South Bronx available to The New York Post for a new color printing plant, in a move that critics say could cause service disruptions and force scores of buses to be quartered in residential neighborhoods.

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; Jefferson's Turn?
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Basically, they explode things down there. They blow up cars. They blow up safes. They blow stuff up.''

title: Grand Juries Hear Witnesses on 2 Fronts in Clinton Inquiries
description: As a grand jury here continued its examination today of the Monica S. Lewinsky case, another in Arkansas was looking at the finances of Bill Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton in the years before they arrived at the White House, illustrating the sprawling nature of the investigations of the First Family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTERNACK, MOSES
description: PASTERNACK-Moses. Beloved husband of Rita. Loving father of Gail and Joel Leder, Jan and Fern Pasternack, Barry and Emilia Pasternack. Dear grandfather of Marci, Amy, Dana, Adam, Trisha, Brooke, Lindsay, Emanuel, Jessica and Jonathan. Devoted son of Louis. Services at Schwartz Bros.Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard at 76th Rd., Forest Hills, New York, Friday at 12 noon.

title: An Orchestra of Students From Nonmusical Fields
description: The Waseda Symphony Orchestra Tokyo, an ensemble from the University of Waseda, is made up not of aspiring musicians but of students in other academic disciplines. They could, of course, change their minds and pursue musical careers: the orchestra's conductor, Chikara Iwamura, graduated from the university with a degree in engineering and science, but continued his studies in Japan's best-known conservatory, the Toho-Gakuen School. He has won prizes in several international competitions, and has conducted the Waseda ensemble since 1992.

title: With Housing as Theme, Mayor Opens Campaign
description: Mayor Sharpe James officially announced his intention to seek a fourth term yesterday.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JOYCE ARNOFF
description: COHEN-Joyce Arnoff. Congregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member Joyce Arnoff Cohen. Joyce was not only a Founder of Or Zarua, but a constant inspiration for our growth and progress. A woman of extraordinary charm and sublime courage, Joyce was a perpetual student, dedicating her life to her family, to the pursuit of higher Jewish education and to the welfare of the Jewish People. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to her bereaved family. Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, Rabbi Dr. Samuel C. Klagsbrun, Pres.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANK OF OHIO AGREES TO BUY W. LYMAN CASE
description: The Fifth Third Bank agreed yesterday to buy the privately held W. Lyman Case & Company for an undisclosed amount as it expands its real estate financing business. Fifth Third, which is based in Cincinnati, is buying a company that originates, underwrites, places and services commercial real estate. Case originated more than $800 million of financing and equity transactions in 1997. Fifth Third, which has $21.4 billion in assets, has three pending purchases in Ohio: the Ohio Company, a broker and dealer based in Columbus; the State Savings Company, a savings association in Columbus, and Citizens Federal, another savings institution, based in Dayton.

title: Utah Advances on a Wing and a Towel
description: Utah nearly became the latest high-seeded team to be felled by upstart West Virginia tonight, but the Utes desperately hung on and survived when West Virginia's Jerrod West missed a 3-point shot as time expired.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Raymond Saunders

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANEL, RALPH I.
description: FLANEL-Ralph I. We note with profound sorrow the passing of our colleague and valued friend. Ralph has been associated with our family for more than 45 years and we are grateful for all his efforts in our behalf. We offer our sincere sympathy to Renee, Diane and Ted. The John Civetta Family

title: Clancy Closes In on Vikings
description: The best-selling author Tom Clancy, who wrote ''The Hunt for Red October,'' now has a National Football League franchise dead in his sights.

title: Esther Bubley, Photographer With a Sober, Poetic Eye, 76
description: Esther Bubley, a documentary photographer who was noted for her sober, no-frills portrayal of post-World War II middle America, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 76 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Kidney-Drug Trials Halve Alteon Stock
description: Shares of Alteon Inc., a biotechnology company based in Ramsey, N.J., lost half their value yesterday after the company announced it might halt a clinical trial of its drug for treating kidney disease in diabetics because of concern about side effects.

title: Uniforms Policy Could Resist Challenges
description: The Board of Education's new policy requiring most elementary school pupils to wear uniforms by the fall of 1999 would most likely withstand legal challenges, legal experts said yesterday, because hours before it voted, the board effectively took the ''mandatory'' out of the policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, ROSE (NEE KINBERG)
description: WEIL-Rose (nee Kinberg). On March 18, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Weil. Cherished mother of Lee Birdoff, Ruth Stark, Robert Weil and the late Edward Weil. Adored mother-in-law, grandmother and great grandmother. Graveside service Sunday March 22, 1998, 11 AM, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE TUMBLES. Coffee prices fell 2.5 percent to the lowest level since January 1997 after Brazilian exporters forecast their biggest crop in 11 years. Contracts for May delivery fell 3.6 cents, to $1.4225 a pound.

title: German Trade Surplus Was Lower in January
description: Germany's merchandise trade surplus almost halved in January, to a two-year low, as export growth slowed and booming production increased demand for imports. Germany exported goods worth 6.3 billion marks ($3.4 billion) more than its imports in January, the Federal Statistics Office said yesterday, down from a surplus of 12.3 billion marks in December and also considerably lower than forecasts.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Ricci Albenda

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Nostalgia Cocktails

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: H. C. Westermann

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; As Journalists Drool
description: To the Editor:

title: Muttering, Whimpering And Headed for Trouble
description: ''Niagara, Niagara'' has the dubious distinction of dragging the lovers-on-the-rampage genre inspired by ''Bonnie and Clyde'' to the bottom of the food chain. That's not to say that this depressing story of geeky teen-age lovers on a spree from upstate New York to Canada via a pretentiously symbolic Niagara Falls isn't well made. The film, directed by Bob Gosse, won Robin Tunney a best-actress award at the Venice Film Festival for her portrayal of Marcy, a teen-ager afflicted with Tourette's syndrome. Her brutally repellent performance is a tour de force so uncompromising that your sympathy for the character periodically gives way to a sickening sense of disgust.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Animal Art From Eurasia

title: Asia Hurts Gucci Profit, But Less Than Expected
description: The Gucci Group, the Italian designer of luxury goods, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 20 percent as Asia's economic and currency problems hurt sales less than expected. Gucci, based in Florence, said profit fell to $42.1 million, or 69 cents a share, in the three months ended Jan. 31, from $52.5 million, or 86 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday, about Western Resources Inc.'s offer to buy the Kansas City Power and Light Company, reversed the identities of the companies' legal advisers. Sullivan & Cromwell advised Western Resources; Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom advised Kansas City Power and Light.

title: TESORO SAYS IT WILL BUY BHP PETROLEUM AMERICAS
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy BHP Petroleum Americas Refining Inc. from the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia for $275 million in cash plus a promissory note of $50 million. The move would nearly double Tesoro's annual revenue, which was $943.4 million last year. Tesoro, based in San Antonio, is a refining and marketing company. Broken Hill is a mineral concern. The agreement is expected to close by the end of May.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EISENBERG, LARRY
description: EISENBERG-Larry. 1952-1993. He did it all in a short time, because a short time is all he had. Love you. Mother and Arlene

title: Alcatel Alsthom Says Profits Rose 74% in '97
description: Alcatel Alsthom S.A. of France reported yesterday that its net income rose 74 percent in 1997, to 4.7 billion francs ($768 million), primarily because of the strength of the telecommunications business. Revenue rose 15 percent, to 185.9 billion francs.

title: Desperate Dance at Oblivion's Brink
description: Sally Bowles has just stepped into the spotlight, which is, you would imagine, her very favorite place to be. Yet this avidly ambitious chanteuse recoils when the glare hits her, flinching and raising a hand to shade her face. Wearing the barest of little black dresses and her eyes shimmering with fever, she looks raw, brutalized and helplessly exposed. And now she's going to sing us a song, an anthem to hedonism, about how life is a cabaret, old chum. She might as well be inviting you to hell.

title: Bibelots of the Romanovs: Diamonds Are a Czar's Best Friend
description: Warning: Take sunglasses when you visit ''Jewels of the Romanovs: Treasures of the Russian Imperial Court,'' the lavish traveling show that opens today at the Brooklyn Museum of Art. The glare thrown off by these high-carat rocks is no respecter of retinas.

title: SINCLAIR BROADCAST TO SELL 3 STATIONS TO CENTENNIAL
description: Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. said yesterday that it would sell three New Orleans radio stations to the closely held Centennial Broadcasting for $16 million to comply with Federal limits on ownership of outlets in a single market. Centennial, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., is buying WBYU-AM, WRNO-FM and KMEZ-FM. The first two stations came with Sinclair's acquisition of 24 radio stations from the Heritage Media Corporation in 1997. After the pending acquisitions and divestitures are completed, Sinclair, based in Baltimore, will own or program four FM stations and two AM stations in New Orleans.

title: Nena Goodman, 88, Painter and Arts Patron
description: Nena Manach Goodman, an artist, patron of the arts and philanthropist, died yesterday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. She was 88 and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Lounges Attracted To Fashion Week
description: Fashion Week, the six-day runway ritual that draws designers with fall and winter collections to present, begins in 12 days. This explains all the recent lounge and restaurant openings, for being ready for Fashion Week can make a place hot.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Adolph Gottlieb

title: Counselor Made Victim Of 'Megan's Law' Prank
description: Hunterdon County prosecutors are trying to determine who sent dozens of phony ''Megan's Law'' notices to residents of a Readington Township housing development, wrongly accusing a high school guidance counselor of being a convicted sex offender.

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; White House Logs
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Strikes Limits on City Workers' Speech to the News Media
description: Regulations prohibiting workers in two New York City agencies from talking with reporters without their agency's permission are unconstitutional, a Federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

title: Yonkers Chooses a Developer To Revive Decaying Waterfront
description: Decades after city leaders first considered revitalizing the crumbling waterfront here, city and state officials announced today that a developer had been chosen to turn a rubble-strewn parcel of land along the Hudson River into an enclave of shops, offices and homes.

title: West New York Officer Admits Taking Bribes
description: A fifth former West New York police officer pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal extortion charges, admitting his role in what prosecutors have called one of the largest cases of police corruption in state history.

title: Times Executive Gets Newly Created Job
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that Charles E. Shelton had been appointed to the new position of vice president for work force development in the human resources department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIEVES, CESAR ANTONIO, JR.
description: NIEVES-Cesar Antonio, Jr. on March 14, 1998. Husband, father, grandfather, son, brother and great friend. Dear, brave and full of life, his grace and caring touched all he knew. Love, Bernie

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; No Blind Loyalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, HARRY L.
description: LEVIN-Harry L. On Wednesday, March 18, of Sugar Hill, N.H. (formerly of Newton, MA). Partner of Florence Rosenberg. Father of Jonathan and Jamie Dwork Levin of Newton, Steven and Marjorie Levin and Nancy Levin, all of Los Angeles. Step-father of Barbara and Rick Prose of ME, Kay and Didier Bourgine of France, and Kabba and Raje Anand of Hawaii. Favorite grandfather of Alex, Josh and Ben, and Ramoda, Sophie, and Celeste, Tristan and Lucas. Son of the late Anna and Samuel Levin. Brother of George and Melvin Levin and Janice Feffer. Services at the Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA, on Friday, March 20 at 2:30 PM. Memorial observance at the home of Jonathan and Jamie Levin through Sunday. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to NARAL or a charity of one's choice. For information, call Levine Chapel at 617-277-8300.

title: Reed Selects Option No. 2
description: Rick Reed awoke yesterday in Port St. Lucie, Fla., planning to pitch against the Los Angeles Dodgers' Albuquerque Class AAA team. A steady rain left the Mets' right-hander with a lesser option: a simulated game against an assortment of Mets' minor leaguers -- with Manager Bobby Valentine as home plate umpire.

title: Misunderstanding Sparked Indonesian Violence : Anatomy of a Price 'Riot'
description: PASURUAN, Indonesia  Until a few weeks ago, this small provincial town was best known for its sugar mills. But following reports of wide-scale looting and frenzied anti-Chinese violence last month, Pasuruan became a symbol of Indonesia's explosive potential for racial strife and civil unrest.

title: Hideo Shima, a Designer of Japan's Bullet Train, Is Dead at 96
description: Hideo Shima, a designer and driving force behind the building of the first bullet train, a symbol of the postwar re-emergence of Japan as a technological and economic power, died of a stroke yesterday in a hospital in Tokyo. He was 96.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELL'OREFICE, MAESTRO LUIGI EDUARDO
description: DELL'OREFICE-Maestro Luigi Eduardo. March 18, 1998. Beloved husband of Lina, loving son of the late Eva and Maestro Antonio Dell'Orefice, grand nephew of composer Giuseppe Dell'Orefice. Reposing Saturday and Sunday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 at Frank E. Campbell, 1077 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday 10 A.M., at Blessed Sacrament Church, 152 W. 71 Street. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, L.I.

title: French Lite
description: French restaurants come in two major flavors: formal French, where the food is about as dressed up as you can imagine, and casual French, like these 12 restaurants, where the food is more relaxed, even if the prices are not. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Reunited but Disjointed, Nets Do Enough to Win
description: The Nets looked like a new team tonight, in more ways than one.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: On My Mind; The Tory With Juice
description: The journalistic sense of mission to visit London that seizes American columnists each springtime can be fulfilled only with commitment to specific duties. Walks in parks alive with daffodils must be undertaken; also seeing a couple of plays, dinner at an excellent club, and breakfast at the Ritz.

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; A Rare Act of Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrity's Son: Big Connections And Addictions; Ordeal of Moyers Family Underlies a TV Documentary
description: William Cope Moyers was graced by fortune, with good looks, wit and social privilege inherited from celebrity parents. His father, Bill Moyers, is one of television's most trusted journalists and a former press secretary to Lyndon B. Johnson. His mother, Judith Davidson Moyers, presides over the family production company, Public Affairs Television, and juggles an array of corporate boards and trusteeships.

title: Turkey Sentences 5 Officers in Journalist's Death
description: In the second major human rights verdict delivered in Turkey this month, a provincial court sentenced five police officers to seven-and-a-half-year jail terms today for beating a journalist to death. Human rights advocates said the sentences were far too light.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POCZIK, REGINA
description: POCZIK-Regina. It is with tears and profound sorrow that we mark the passing of Reggie, our first class lady, whose warmth, devotion to her family, dignity, grace and courage throughout, made all of us who knew her feel special and realize she was special. What she imparted to each of us will keep her alive in our memories. To Donald, her husband, and our friend and partner, and Evan and Susan, her children, we extend our heartfelt sympathy. We are truly there for you. Your extended family, The Partners-All of Us

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLANATHAN, RICHARD B.K.
description: MCLANATHAN-Richard B.K., 82, of Phippsburg, Maine. A member of the Society of Fellows at Harvard and the American Academy in Rome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HILDA G.
description: SCHWARTZ-Hilda G. Retired Supreme Court Justice on Mar. 18, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Herman N. Schwartz. Loving mother of John M. Schwartz. Devoted sister of Edith Smolen and the late Rose Weisman, Dr. Joseph A. Gaines and Mary Princer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81 St, Saturday 6-9PM. Funeral service Sunday, March 22, 11:30AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65 St.

title: Fidelity Investments to Close 3 of Its Most Popular Funds
description: Fidelity Investments said yesterday that it planned to close three of its largest and best-performing mutual funds -- the Growth and Income, Contrafund and Low-Priced Stock funds -- to new retail investors after April 3.

title: 2 Business Districts Violated Wage Laws, Judge Rules
description: A Federal judge has ruled that two major business improvement districts in midtown Manhattan violated minimum wage laws by paying homeless people whom they recruited to work in custodial, security, office and laundry jobs $1 to $1.50 an hour.

title: A Wildcatter On the Tame Side; Replacing Roughnecks With Computers
description: Designed for the world's hungriest, damn-the-expense devourers of data, the Auspex NS7000 computer server, costing more than $1 million, can store the equivalent of a million 400-page novels for instant access. The first one in this area went to NASA in 1995 for guiding space shuttles into the heavens. The next year, another was installed, at the Zilkha Energy Company, for exploring under the Gulf of Mexico, miles into the earth's crust.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIERRA, MARCEL
description: SIERRA-Marcel. A brave, warm, wonderful friend and neighbor. He will be deeply missed by Muriel, Inez, Betty and our families.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column yesterday, about writers who have been signed up for a new Random House series, ''The Library of Contemporary Thought,'' misstated a given name. The writer is Edwin Schlossberg, not Robert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKMAN, HANNAH
description: DRUCKMAN-Hannah. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Loving mother of Eleanor, William and the late Barbara. Adoring grandmother of David Lerner and Emily Druckman. Cherished sister of Judith Weber and Arthur Abraham. Devoted aunt and loving friend. Service Sun, 12:15 at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her memory to Hospice of Central Pennsylvania.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.

title: Of a Powerful Will to Die Amid a Reality Full of Life
description: ''Taste of Cherry'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 27. The film -- in Farsi with English subtitles -- opens today in Manhattan.

title: A Goody-Eight-Shoes Idyll Of Tiny Tiffs and Tragedies
description: The Beals, the glowing smiley-faced clan who inhabit M. Night Shyamalan's insufferable family comedy ''Wide Awake,'' are the kind of fantastically wholesome goody-goods that Hollywood loves to invent to make us all feel terrible about our own less than idyllic upbringings.

title: Deal of the Day
description: Demand for Internet-related stocks continues to expand. Shares of Exodus Communications Inc., an Internet service provider, skyrocketed in their first day of trading. The offering, underwritten by Goldman Sachs, was priced late Wednesday at $15, and shares began trading yesterday at $24.75. While revenues have been growing rapidly, to $12.4 million last year, Exodus has continued to pile up losses, including $25.3 million last year, and its prospectus says the company expects to continue losing money for the foreseeable future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, JACOB
description: EPSTEIN-Jacob. A dear friend and fellow music lover joins family members and countless friends of all ages in noting the passing of an extraordinary human being. I will sorely miss his keen wit, long-standing commitment to dignity and respect for all human beings, and profound and unquenchable interest in the world around him. It was with a deep sense of loss but also a quiet joy that I learned of Jacob's recent departure from this transitory life to rejoin, Ruth, his beloved wife, companion, comrade & sole-mate. Both were once-in-a-life-time friends who deeply enriched the lives of all who knew them. Jacob was lovingly cared for by Ruth's grandniece, for whom he had the greatest affection and held in the highest esteem. I will cherish his friendship & his memory forever. Karalenne Gayle

title: Unlikely Tangles of Bodies In a Context of the Absurd
description: The first image in David Parker's ''On the Tip of My Tongue'' is of upended bottoms, skirts falling around them like petals on a flower. One is large and cushiony, straining against its pinkish tights and framed by two smaller, leaner bottoms. Beyond is a forest of sharply angling legs, feet encased in six gleaming pink toe shoes.

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; G.O.P.'s Powerful Fringe
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, JOEL M.
description: KAUFMAN-Joel M., on March 18th, 1998 in Deerfield Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Rochelle. Loving father of Sherry Padva (Ira) and Debra Goodman (Alan). Much loved and special grandfather to Jason, Amy and Brandon. Cherished brother of Libby Ladin and the late Albert Kaufman and Fanny Casher. Adored uncle and great-uncle. Much respected entrepreneur and loyal friend to many. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Garlick Funeral Home, Unionport Road, Bronx, NY, 718-892-9400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDING, J. WILLIAM, M.D.
description: FIELDING-J. William, M.D.. The Board of Trustees, Medical Board and Administration of St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Center acknowledge with sadness the passing of J. William Fielding, M.D., former Chairman of the Dept of Orthopedics. Dr. Fielding was a beloved and revered colleague who exemplified the finest traditions of medical excellence. He will be sorely missed. To his wife Doris, the entire Fielding family and all who loved him, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington, Chairman, Board of Trustees Ronald C. Ablow, M.D., President Richard P. Fried, M.D., President, Medical Board

title: A New Spray for Chickens Helps Control Salmonella
description: A new technique significantly reduces salmonella in chickens by providing protection that, before factory farming, was naturally transferred from a mother hen to her chicks, scientists announced yesterday.

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; Fidelity Above All?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INNOVATIVE VALVE TECHNOLOGIES INC., Houston, a provider of maintenance services for industrial valves, agreed to acquire the closely held IPS Holding Ltd., of Downers Grove, Ill., a pipe repair services company, for undisclosed terms.

title: Metro Business; Bank for New Air Terminal
description: First Union Bank and Travelex, a money exchange service, have been selected as the first retail and service tenants in the new terminal being built at Kennedy International Airport.

title: A Master's First Shots
description: The early work of the photographer Paul Strand (1890-1976) is the subject of a thought-provoking exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where ''Paul Strand Circa 1916'' brings together some 60 pictures made between 1911, when the artist was barely past his student years, and 1917.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEALY, ROSABEL (NEE POULSON)
description: HEALY-Rosabel (nee Poulson). On March 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jerome. Loving mother of Patricia Mucci, Jerome F. Healy and Barbara Hoffman. Dear sister of George Poulson. Also survived by five grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Visiting Friday (today) 2-5 and 7-9PM at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont. Mass Saturday 9:30AM, St. Mary's Star of the Sea, City Island.

title: Young Paul Strand: Impressionable, Experimental
description: Was there ever a time in American art when so many conflicting impulses and imperatives converged as in the first two decades of this century?

title: Black Youths' Rate of Suicide Rising Sharply, Studies Find
description: Suicide among black teen-agers, once quite rare, has increased dramatically over the last two decades, a troubling rise that might reflect the strain some black families feel in making the transition to middle-class life, according to a study released today by the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNTON, ERNEST A.
description: LYNTON-Ernest A. Age 71. Died peacefully at home on Wednesday, March 18. Survived by his wife Carla, two sons and their families: David and Jeanette, their children Ashley, Jared, Rachel and Aubrey, in Alpine, UT; Eric and Aviva, their children Liran, Adi and Tal, in Kfar Hanassi, Israel; also survived by the Lynton family in New York; and the Kaufmann family in Lausanne and the U.K. There will be gatherings at home on the evenings of Friday, March 20, Saturday, March 21, and on Sunday, March 22, from 6-9 PM. Funeral service will be held on Monday, March 23, at 10 A.M., at Temple Israel, Longwood Avenue and the Riverway, Boston. Instead of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to: Children's Defense Fund, 25 E Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20001; or Marlboro Music, 135 South 18th Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19103.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, NENA
description: GOODMAN-Nena. On March 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Andrew Goodman. Devoted mother of Vivien G. Malloy, Mary Ann Quinson, Edwin A. Goodman and Pamela Lichty. Loving grandmother of Andrew T., Deborah Malloy Winkler, Kenneth H., Mark L. and Vivien C. Malloy; Geoffrey, Luke, Adam and Joshua Taylor; Sara and Thea Goodman; Will and Simone Lichty. Great grandmother of Courtney and Caitlin, Connor, Maggie, Kenneth Jr., Shane Malloy; James, John and Alexandra Taylor. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84 St., Monday 10 A.M. Those desiring may send flowers or contributions in her memory may be made to National Jewish Center, Immunology and Respiratory Medicine, 1400 Jackson St., Denver, CO 80206; or the International Rescue Committee, 122 East 42nd Street, 12 Flr, New York, NY 10017; or The Alcoholism Council of Greater NY, 352 Park Avenue South, 8th Floor, NY, NY 10010.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about efforts by the Federal Government to assure that its computers continue operating properly in the year 2000 misstated the time in which the Government expects to spend $4.7 billion on solving the software problem. It began in the 1996 fiscal year and will continue until the 2000 year.

title: Auction Ends 5-Year Dream in 5 Minutes
description: It was over in just five minutes. Yolanda Garcia, who had fought for five years to restore the old Bronx County Courthouse, a hulking monument to the city's abandonment of her neighborhood, was simply outbid.

title: Last of the British Blue Bloods?
description: IN nine decades of building automobiles, Rolls-Royce Motor Cars has used only nine all-new bodies. The latest of these, for a car that seems likely to be the last Rolls built under British ownership, made its United States debut Wednesday evening at a reception in New York attended by Prince Philip.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Gerald Monroe

title: Someone Else Gets to Play Tallulah's Best Role, Herself
description: Of all the crazy schemes. Tallulah Bankhead impersonated by . . . a woman?

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; Plenty of Information
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Campaign for Speaker

title: Observer; So They Sent In the Clowns
description: What a circus! What a farce!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEPIS, JEANNE
description: PEPIS-Jeanne. On March 16, 1998. Loving mother of Tara. Beloved daughter of Henry and Jean Pfister. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., Friday. Mass St. Joseph's Church, Garden City 9:45 A.M. Saturday.

title: AXA's Profit Soared In 2d Half of '97
description: AXA S.A., the big French insurer, indicated yesterday that its second-half profit almost quadrupled amid gains in foreign operations and a turnaround at UAP, the French insurer it acquired last year. Profit rose to 3.7 billion francs ($607 million) in the half from 1 billion francs a year earlier. The results were better than expected. Full-year profit doubled to 7.9 billion francs, the company said.

title: Capturing the City At a Vanishing Point
description: It is the nature of cities to change and the nature of city dwellers to regret the sacrifices made along the way, even in the name of progress. Our cities are extensions of ourselves, and their streets open up to memory like family albums of all the lives lived in them. The past of city and self tends to seem ever more important and precious as time and memory threaten to bury it.

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; Risky Legal Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Lyonnais Profits Jumped in 2d Half of '97
description: Credit Lyonnais S.A., the French state-owned bank, indicated yesterday that its profit rose more than threefold in the second half. The company, France's third-largest listed retail bank, made an implied profit of 460 million francs ($75 million) in the second half compared with 135 million francs in the second half of 1996. For all of 1997, profit was 1.06 billion francs, up from 202 million a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMUTTER, CELIA
description: PERLMUTTER-Celia. On March 18, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Martin Perlmutter. Services Friday 12 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAATA, MARY
description: FLAATA-Mary. The Auxiliary of Lenox Hill Hospital notes with sadness the loss of our longtime member and dedicated volunteer. The entire Lenox Hill Hospital community will sorely miss her. The Auxiliary of Lenox Hill Hospital

title: Better Pay vs. Job Stability in Wage Debate
description: The Democrats today formally introduced President Clinton's plan to increase the minimum wage, drawing praise from unions but raising concerns even among supporters that the proposed new level, $6.15 an hour, might cost jobs.

title: BBC and Discovery to Develop Programming Together
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation and Discovery Communications Inc. signed a deal yesterday under which they would form a $565 million alliance to create new programs and new cable channels around the world.

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; Careless Candor
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Modernists, Along With Hymns, Jazz and Percussion
description: Most pianists would never consider playing the program that Eliza Garth presented on Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall with gnarly works by five contemporary composers: four living Americans, all of whom were present, and one dead German master. But to Ms. Garth, contemporary music is as lucid and communicative as any older music, and her fine pianistic skills and palpable engagement pull you in. This was a challenging yet exhilarating evening.

title: Raising Safer Chickens
description: The Government has approved a technique that uses naturally occurring microbes to reduce salmonella in chickens. The technique involves spraying chicks with bacteria; if successful, it could also reduce the use of antibiotics in chickens, which scientists say has contributed to an increase in drug-resistant bacteria.

title: Ivana's Boy Toy (for the Record, He's a Prince)
description: IT'S a smart man who is skeptical of his coverage in the press, and this perhaps explains the face Roffredo Gaetani di Laurenzana dell'Aquila d'Aragona Lovatelli is making as he translates some Italian clippings.

title: Prices Paid By Consumers Up Just 0.1%
description: Inflation remained subdued last month, thanks in large part to falling energy prices.

title: Residential Real Estate; 6 Historic Buildings Getting New Life
description: Six small 18th- and 19th-century commercial buildings in the South Street Seaport Historic District -- long abandoned and crumbling -- are being reborn as apartment buildings in a move that extends the recent pattern of office building conversions downtown into a new area and a different building type.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, GERTRUDE ASPELL
description: WRIGHT-Gertrude Aspell, 89. Of Delray Beach, FL and Edgartown MA. Died March 14, 1998. Widow of Frank C. Wright, Jr., she leaves two daughters, Gill of Perrysburg, OH., Gail of NY and Middleburg, VA., and two grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, ESTELLE
description: LEWIS-Estelle. On March 19, 1998 in Hollywood, FL. Beloved mother of Linda Lindenbaum. Adored grandmother of Erica Tishman and Laurie Lindenbaum Horne, loving great-grandmother of Adam, Stuart and Julia Tishman and Sarah Horne. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society. Funeral services private.

title: Clinton Lawyer's Strategy
description: President Clinton's lawyer in the Paula Corbin Jones sexual misconduct suit said that he would not raise evidence in court of Ms. Jones's past sexual conduct. Page A19.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Robert Greene

title: Steinbrenner Discussed Selling a Piece of Yankees
description: George Steinbrenner said today that he had discussed selling a portion of the Yankees to Cablevision Systems Corporation, the television and sports company that already owns the Knicks and Rangers. Mr. Steinbrenner said no deal had been struck, and he insisted this afternoon that he would never completely let go of the legendary baseball franchise.

title: A marketing star's decision to move on leaves Coca-Cola facing 'Life After Sergio.'
description: SERGIO ZYMAN, the marketing executive widely credited with shaking awake a slumbering, hidebound Coca-Cola Company and teaching it to sing a more youthful tune, has resigned. Now Madison Avenue and the soft drink industry must face ''Life After Sergio,'' which sounds like a spicy soap opera but could be a tamer version of what has gone before.

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; Spare the First Family
description: To the Editor:

title: How Drug Baron Set Up Shop Under a Mexican Governor's Not-So-Watchful Eye
description: Little by little over the last year, Mexicans have learned how one of the country's most powerful drug traffickers turned Morelos, the state south of Mexico City, into a base of operations.

title: Portrait Of a Candidate As Casanova
description: A long time ago in a galaxy far far away there was a sweet-talking Presidential candidate, a Southern governor who felt our pain. And created some of it, since his idealism and political infighting skills were not easily reconciled. Expediency carried him through crisis after crisis, offering the electorate a lesson in how to turn moral compromise into campaign advantage.

title: Schoolgirls Make Alligators Look Like Ingenues
description: Lucky Blue Bay, Fla. The weather is sunny, the mansions are big and the scenery is especially nice at the local high school. That's where Mr. Dillon, as in Matt, is around to provide guidance counseling and coach the sailing team. And Mr. Bacon, as in Kevin, is the police detective in charge of delivering a guest lecture on sex crimes. His talk comes in handy, since Blue Bay High School also has a well-developed Lolita squad.

title: Budapest Journal; Hungarian Fingerprints All Over the 20th Century
description: He was a man of brilliant and diverse intellectual energy who discovered the nuclear chain reaction, went on to help develop the atom bomb and then tirelessly campaigned against it.

title: Buying Yanks Would Bolster Cablevision's Empire
description: Whatever the Cablevision Systems chairman, Charles Dolan, says or does not say for public consumption, there is no doubt on Wall Street that he would love to add the Yankees to his empire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADICOFF, ESTHER
description: ADICOFF-Esther. Beloved wife of the late Aaron (Harry) Adicoff. Loving aunt, cousin and friend. Services Friday 11AM at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Cedar Park-Bethel, Paramus, NJ.

title: Man in the News: Atal Bihari Vajpayee; Sworn In as India's Leader, Ambiguity in His Wake
description: When Atal Bihari Vajpayee was sworn in today as the 16th Prime Minister of India since independence 50 years ago, many onlookers outside the presidential palace thought he looked curiously uncomfortable. His first words as Prime Minister were certainly more solemn than cheerful. ''I have a pledge to redeem, and a promise to fulfill,'' he said.

title: Q&A/ Richard Stallman : Why Software Should Be Free and Shared
description: Richard Stallman developed the free software operating system called GNU, which is currently used by an estimated five million people. Principal author of several GNU programs, Mr. Stallman, 45, was awarded a MacArthur Foundation Fellowship in 1990, and received an honorary doctorate from the Royal Institute of Technology in Sweden. He is currently a researcher in residence at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Massachusetts, where he recently met with Ken Shulman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREMNITZER, JOHN
description: KREMNITZER-John. On March 19, 1998. Devoted husband of Susan. Beloved father of Ronald and the late Carol. Cherished grandfather of Jordana, Corin, Kathryn and Ben. Services Friday 10 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. May his memory be blessed.

title: Loving Life, Facing Death
description: Robert Capa stories: In 1945, he was photographing an American corporal manning a machine gun on the balcony of an apartment building overlooking the Zeppelin Bridge in Leipzig, which the United States Army had just fought its way across. Capa, having caught up with the advancing troops, figured that the view from the balcony ''could be the last picture of the war for my camera.'' He arrived at the apartment in time to snap the corporal reloading his gun when a German sniper in the street fired a bullet through the soldier's neck, killing him.

title: Cone Is Tapped by Torre To Pitch Home Opener
description: Joe Torre, the manager of the Yankees, determined promptly that Andy Pettitte would pitch opening day, on April 1 against Anaheim, and David Wells would throw the next day. Having made those decisions, Torre then had to decide which starter would line up as No. 4 in his rotation, for that pitcher would start the Yankees' home opener, on April 10, before a crowd of some 56,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDRON, MARIE COOPER
description: WALDRON-Marie Cooper. March 16, 1998, age 95. Lover of books, dance, art, antiques, animals and life from Greenwich Village to Woodstock, NY. Gentle, steadfast and fair-minded friend to many generations, she'll be missed by all who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, CRAIG
description: WILLIAMS-Craig. The Systems and Technology Department of The New York Times extends their deepest sympathy to Craig Williams' family on his passing. Always a cheerful friend and coworker who was optimistic and courageous, no matter how serious his ailments were. We think of Craig with tender memories and his parting leaves a void in our hearts. All of us in the Systems and Technology Department will miss his bright smile and enchanting laughter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEBAN, JULIAN MILTON
description: KLEBAN-Julian Milton. Died on March 19th, 1998 at the age of 92. Beloved father of Toby Levine of Potomac, MD and the late Edward Kleban, devoted husband of the late Sylvia Kandel Kleban. Loving father-in-law of Andrew Levine. Adoring grandfather of Caren Pelletier and Amy Levine and grandfather-in-law of Michael Pelletier. Cherished cousin and keeper of the Kleban family tree. Remembered by all who knew him as a sweet, kind and generous man who had a rare gift for friendship with people from all walks of life and a song for everyone. Graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School and New York Law School. Member of the Bronx County Bar Association, New York State Bar Association, and former president of the Jewish Lawyer's Guild. Services Friday, March 20, 1 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Misler Jewish Senior Day Program, 1801 East Jefferson St, Rockville, Maryland 20852.

title: Damron in Lead As Rain Halts Play
description: Robert Damron has lived at Bay Hill Club and Lodge in Orlando, Fla., for 19 years. His home is adjacent to the 10th green. And when asked, Damron estimated he had played the golf course at Bay Hill well over 1,000 times.

title: Carolina Applies Dominating Defense
description: North Carolina kept coming and coming at Michigan State whenever it was necessary tonight. If it was not Shammond Williams, it was Ed Cota. If it was not Antawn Jamison, it was Vince Carter. The Tar Heels were pushing and prodding and doing just what they needed to keep putting the Spartans in perilous positions.

title: NATO Debate: From Big Risk To Sure Thing
description: When President Clinton called for NATO to expand into the former Soviet bloc by 1999, the idea was considered a stunning gamble that could either unite and stabilize Europe or create a dangerous new post-cold-war dividing line. Expecting a fierce fight, the Administration took the unusual step of opening a special State Department office to sell the proposal.

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; The Gentleman's Denial
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLOY, HELEN (NEE MURPHY)
description: MALLOY-Helen (nee Murphy). Age 88. Native of Dromore, County Mayo, Ireland. Loving wife of the late William. Beloved mother of Lillian Carney and William Malloy. Fond sister of Josie Farragher in Ireland. Dear grandmother of Deborah O'Heihr, Susan Carney, Kathleen Schier, Jennifer Malloy, and the late Kevin Carney; and five great grandchildren. Family will receive friends Friday, 2-5 and 7-9PM at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Church of the Visitation, Saturday, March 21 at 11 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Leading Indexes Continue To Climb to Record Levels
description: The stock market's leading indexes rose to record highs again yesterday despite new earnings warnings from several companies. Investors, it appears, are continuing to focus on what good news there is while ignoring -- or discounting -- any negative vibrations.

title: Smoking Budgets in Washington
description: After two months of soap-opera diversions, Congress has returned to the familiar task of squabbling over how to spend money that does not exist. President Clinton and the Democrats want to apply funds from a tobacco settlement to hire teachers, build classrooms and expand health coverage. Republicans reject that approach but are divided over the alternatives. Whichever side prevails, the budget makers are courting trouble by counting on a tobacco settlement, and that may cripple their ability to craft one that does not give too much away to the industry.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: ''Come back next month and have the ravioli again,'' says Jorge Rodriguez, the chef and owner of Chimichurri Grill. ''My mother will be here then, and hers are much better than mine.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the architect Daniel Libeskind's design for a Jewish Museum in Berlin misidentified the historical period to be covered by the old Berlin Museum after the extension. It is the period up to the Second Reich, not the First. The article also misstated the start of the Second Reich. It was 1871, not 1870.

title: Choreography of Contrasts: One's Huge, the Other Isn't
description: ''Stretch Marks'' commanded attention when it didn't belabor the obvious. The collaboratively choreographed program that Heidi Latsky and Lawrence Goldhuber danced on Tuesday night at Playhouse 91 began with solos from a new full-evening piece called ''I Hate Modern Dance.''

title: A Judicial Mugging
description: Judge Frederica Massiah-Jackson of the Pennsylvania state courts, who would have been the first black woman to serve as a Federal district judge in Philadelphia, withdrew her nomination this week to avoid near-certain rejection by the Senate. She had been subjected to what Senator Arlen Specter called ''water torture'' in an unfair process that is bound to have a chilling effect on judicial independence.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Business Day yesterday about a long-distance telephone service offered by I-Link Inc. for 4.9 cents a minute included an outdated reference to the company's headquarters location. It is Draper, Utah, no longer St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Airport Gets Tourists Off To Bad Start
description: IF you care at all about this city and how it is viewed from outside, then you have to feel a twinge of pain when you hear about a gratuitous bit of New York nastiness inflicted on an unsuspecting visitor. Civility, after all, is a virtue that many cherished long before they'd ever heard the name Giuliani.

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; Supreme Hindsight
description: To the Editor:

title: Is the Explosion-Noisy Base a C.I.A. Spy School? What Base?
description: Nine miles out of Hertford, a town as tranquil as an old dog on a porch, the road ends at a sign that says Harvey Point Defense Testing Activity.

title: Encore Performance by Elvis Leaves Fans All Shook Up
description: The King's not dead.

title: Underdogs Meet for Shot At Yet Another Upset
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament has always had its share of teams that produce spectacular upsets. The Midwest Regional semifinal here has two of those teams, and they are matched against each other on Friday night.

title: UConn Makes Great, Late Escape to Face Carolina
description: Connecticut can smell, taste and feel the Final Four. It is that close for UConn after it survived, barely survived, because Richard Hamilton made an off-balance, eight-foot shot at the buzzer to catapult his team to a 75-74 triumph tonight over Washington.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cablevision Official Offers To Buy a Stake in Yankees

title: Kodak Cuts Chairman's Pay to $2 Million
description: The pay of the chairman and chief executive of the Eastman Kodak Company, George M. C. Fisher, was cut in half last year to $2 million, as the photo company withheld his bonus after a disappointing 1997 performance.

title: EASTERN UTILITIES ASSOCIATES IN TALKS TO SELL A UNIT
description: Eastern Utilities Associates said yesterday that it was in discussions to sell its EUA Cogenex Corporation contracting unit to an undisclosed buyer by the middle of the year. EUA Cogenex, based in Lowell, Mass., provides economic analysis, engineering and design services and financing. It also implements energy programs. As of last month, it managed more than $300 million in project investments. Eastern Utilities, a Boston-based energy-services company, also said it would buy back up to 3 million shares, or 14.7 percent of its 20.4 million shares outstanding. Its shares closed at $26.125. up $1 each.

title: Sunbeam Stock Falls 9.4% on Lower Projections for Revenue
description: The Sunbeam Corporation warned Wall Street yesterday that because of a decrease in orders from some large retailers it might not meet sales estimates for the first quarter.

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lennon Steps Out On His Own
description: ''Hi, we're the Electric Blanket Band,'' began the aspiring pop stylist with the dyed-blond hair and Clark Kent-style eyeglasses on the Mercury Lounge stage early Wednesday night. If he hadn't added the next phrase -- ''I'm Sean Lennon'' -- few would have recognized him as the progeny of a rock legend. Unless, of course, they could see his diminutive mother dancing in a corner.

title: A Mocking TV Spot Draws Angry Responses
description: Under pressure from angry New Jerseyans, officials of Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America have discontinued a television advertisement that portrayed the New Jersey Turnpike and the city of Newark as befouled by industrial pollution.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Raves Not Certain, Even From Family
description: The party after the screening for ''No Looking Back,'' the medium-budget film by ED BURNS (who made ''The Brothers McMullen'' in 1995 on a shoestring), was like a pleasantly large, pleasantly noisy family reunion. Aunts, uncles, cousins, childhood friends and Mr. Burns's doorman were on the guest list.

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; Comparison to Hill
description: To the Editor:

title: Questioning Character, but Not a Presidency; No Big Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Float Like a Butterfly, Sting Like a Proteus?
description: MORE THAN A CHAMPION

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOTT, PETER GEORGE
description: MOTT-Peter George. June 13, 1947 to March 20, 1997. Together we found Truth. Forever One. W.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSON, DOROTHY (DOSSIE)
description: GERSON-Dorothy (Dossie). Formerly of Closter, New Jersey, on March 18, 1998. Beloved wife of Sy. Devoted mother of Betsy Densen and Anthony Gerson. Adoring grandmother of Matthew and David Densen, and April Gerson. At her request, there will be no funeral. Friends are invited to visit on Sunday March 22 and Monday March 23 at 52 Knoll Road, Tenafly, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations in Dossie's name to a favorite charity or Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind, Smithtown, NY would be appreciated.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: LIPTON CHAMPIONSHIPS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ERNEST
description: WEISS-Ernest. Beloved husband of Margaret, beloved father of Stanley Weiss, D.D.S., and Esther Bolkin. Beloved grandfather of Jonathan, Daniel and David Weiss; David, Michael and Jennifer Bolkin. May they be comforted among the mourners in Zion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, RUTH V., M.D.
description: JOSEPH-Ruth V., M.D. Beloved mother, dear sister. Devoted grandmother of Peter and Michael. Dedicated physcian over 60 years. A one of a kind woman, ahead of her time. Rest in Peace

title: Park Slope Arrogance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABRANCHE, GEORGE M.L.
description: LaBRANCHE-George M.L. III. Age 72. Born in New York City on November 11, 1925. Died March 17 after a valiant struggle against cancer. George joined the Marine Corps in 1942 at the age of 17 and later fought in the battle of Iwo Jima. He retired as the President of Roy B. Rendle Company, a Boston marine construction contractor. He is survived by his wife Patricia Munro LaBranche of Marblehead, MA., and Amagansett, N.Y.; a daughter, Eugenie Damon of Darien, CT; a son, George IV of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y.; a daughter, Nicole LaBranche of New York; and 10 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City, Friday, April 3, 1998, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th Street, New York, New York 10003.

title: A Uniform Solution For N.Y. Schools?; 1950's Sensibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Lotto Winner Guilty in a Killing, Cleared in 2d
description: In a split verdict today, a jury here found that a man who had won millions in the state lottery acted in self-defense when he shot and killed his former lover outside her Chappaqua home, but found him guilty of second-degree murder in the death of her father-in-law during the same gun battle.

title: Cassell Takes a Seat, And Nets Take a Loss
description: Sam Cassell walked off the court as the Nets headed to the bench for a timeout with 1 minute 16 seconds remaining in tonight's game against Indiana. He walked away from his teammates toward the end of the bench, muttering, ''I'm done.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday, with a television review of an A&E program about Jews and Hollywood, misidentified the man shown with the producer Jack Warner in a 1930's photo. It was his father, Benjamin, not his brother.

title: Uniform Business Gears Up to Supply Public-School Children
description: In the wake of the New York City Board of Education's decision to require uniforms for elementary-school children, manufacturers of the signature plaid skirts and navy vests and the stores that sell them are giddily expecting a surge in business and are gearing up for the competition.

title: Big Band, Big Premiere, Big Tour, Big Marsalis
description: Wynton Marsalis and the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra have spent the last several months touring the world, and on Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, over several hours of technically perfect playing, it showed. Mr. Marsalis and the orchestra, who will be performing again tonight as part of Jazz at Lincoln Center, were completely at ease moving through difficult music; the sharp juxtapositions Mr. Marsalis throws around in his pieces were never forced, and horn and percussion riffs were tossed in the air with the precision of a piece of industrial equipment stamping out a metal part. And at least one musician nodded off to sleep.

title: A Bigger, Slower, Aimless NATO; Balancing Act
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: Lady Enniskillen, 80, Journalist and Diplomat
description: The Dowager Countess of Enniskillen, formerly Nancy MacLennon, an American journalist and consular officer, died on Feb. 24 at Kinloch House, her home in Amulree, Perthshire, north of Edinburgh. She was 80.

title: A Bigger, Slower, Aimless NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Geography Redux: Where You Live Is What You Are
description: Pick up a geography textbook from the first half of this century and you can discover a simple rule-of-thumb explanation for the varying fates of the human race: the weather.

title: 1998 N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST -- Duke Rolls On, but Valparaiso's Magic Runs Out; Rhode Island Defeats the Pesky Crusaders
description: They came back for a curtain call and a group hug.

title: You Want to Be a Star? Then Get in Line
description: ''And now you want to be an actor,'' said Michael Kahan. It could have been a question or a statement.

title: Lott Puts Off Vote On Adding to NATO
description: An hour after President Clinton urged Senate approval of NATO's expansion, the majority leader, Trent Lott, put off action. Mr. Lott said he was frustrated by a filibuster on a bill to set up education savings accounts. Approval had been expected as early as next week for adding three nations to NATO.

title: Connecticut's Women Still a Rugged Match
description: The University of Connecticut women's basketball team insists that the constant pressure it is under to excel has now been compounded by injury, illness and a lack of depth.

title: Brawley Plaintiff's Day Is Moved to Monday
description: The much-anticipated testimony of Steven A. Pagones, the man who is seeking redress in the Tawana Brawley defamation case, was put off again yesterday. He is expected to take the stand on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKASHOK, LILLIAN G.
description: LUKASHOK-Lillian G. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Martin and the late E. David. Wonderful grandmother to Bill and Janet and devoted greatgrandmother to David and Owen. Fond sister of Frances Horowitz and the late Meyer Ginsburg. Funeral service Monday, 11:15AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: HARNISCHFEGER ACQUIRES HORSBURGH & SCOTT
description: Harnischfeger Industries said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held Horsburgh & Scott for about $40 million cash to expand its mining-equipment lines. Horsburgh, a Cleveland-based manufacturer of custom-engineered gear and replacement parts for mining and industrial equipment, has annual sales of $60 million and 250 employees. Harnischfeger, a Milwaukee-based maker of equipment for the paper, pulp and mining industries, had sales of $634.3 million for its first quarter ended Jan. 31. Horsburgh will be run by Harnischfeger's P&H Mining Equipment unit. Harnischfeger rose 37.5 cents, to $33.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Voluntarily, C.I.A. Director Reveals Intelligence Budget
