description: For the first time, the Director of Central Intelligence voluntarily disclosed today how much money the United States was currently spending on secret intelligence activities.

title: New York's Winter That Wasn't Inches Toward a Record
description: The winter of 1997-98, possibly the most snowless on record, left town yesterday.

title: ITOCHU AND TOSHIBA SELL TIME WARNER SHARES
description: The Itochu Corporation and the Toshiba Corporation sold a third of their stakes in Time Warner Inc. for a total of about $620.5 million, taking advantage of the gains in the shares of the entertainment and media company to raise cash. The Japanese companies sold the shares to Citicorp at an average of $67.89 each. Time Warner, meanwhile, said it plans to buy back the 9.14 million shares from a Citicorp affiliate at the same price, plus a financing charge, within the next two years. Itochu and Toshiba each acquired stakes of about 3 percent in Time Warner in 1995. The sale represents about 29 percent of their combined holdings. Shares of the New York-based Time Warner rose 62.5 cents each, to $73.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Pharaoh, Too, Looked Askance at Swine; Kosher Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the auction of John F. Kennedy memorabilia misattributed a quotation from a seller. It was Charles Stone, not Atwater Bradley, who said: ''She called me her fishmonger. I'd rather sell these and have the money go to my grandson's college education.'' Mr. Stone was referring to notes of thanks he received from Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis for delivering fish on Martha's Vineyard; he sold the notes outside the auction.

title: Scully Signs Off World Series Radio
description: Vin Scully will no longer call the World Series on network radio, concluding a chapter in a sportscasting career that began in Brooklyn nearly a half century ago. Scully will still call Dodgers' games and would announce a Dodgers World Series on local Los Angeles radio.

title: Head of Financial Control Board for District of Columbia Resigns Under Fire
description: After months of public criticism about his management style, Andrew F. Brimmer said today that he would step down in June as chairman of the control board that has restored the financial stability of the District of Columbia over the last three years.

title: About New York; From Queens, A Dialogue In Good Faith
description: JOHN GOLDSTEIN joined eight Jewish and Roman Catholic friends sitting in a circle in his living room, where they talked about the Vatican's recent document on the Holocaust. ''Why did it take nearly 60 years?'' asked Anita Weisbord, who fled Austria for England in 1939. Mr. Goldstein, the Catholic son of a mixed marriage, mentioned that a book he had just read detailed how church leaders in Europe were neither silent nor complicit in the face of genocide.

title: Yale Loses Top Scorer And Game to Princeton
description: Yale not only lost a game to Princeton tonight at the semifinals of the Eastern College Athletic Conference tournament, but also lost its leading scorer, Jeff Hamilton.

title: Drug Distributors to Fight Foe of Deal
description: The McKesson Corporation and the Amerisource Health Corporation have decided to fight the Federal Trade Commission's attempt to block their merger, which would combine the nation's No. 1 and No. 4 drug wholesalers.

title: Oxford Plans to Transfer Medicaid Patients
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said yesterday that it intended to transfer its 41,000 Medicaid members in New Jersey to Amerigroup Corporation when Oxford exits the program in the state on July 1.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERKOTTER, PAUL
description: OBERKOTTER-Paul. Age 93, Mar. 16 suddenly at his apartment in Manhattan. Survived by his daughter Mildred L. Oberkotter of Palo Alto, CA; his daughter-in-law, Joyce Oberkotter widow of his son Robert of Newport, NH; three grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. Burial will be private and a memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. For those caring to contribute in his memory it is suggested that they consider the Alexander Graham Bell Assn for the Deaf, 3417 Volta Place, Wash., D.C. 20007; any of the Option Oral Deaf Schools or a charity of their own choosing.

title: Sports of The Times; Tournament Breathes Life Into a Game
description: SHORTLY after Duke's convincing victory last night over Syracuse, Roshown McLeod, Duke's senior forward, and Chris Carrawell sat in the Blue Devils' locker room. McLeod tried to be diplomatic: yes, it would be nice to play Kentucky, he said, when asked about a possible matchup with the Wildcats on Sunday.

title: Gore's Earth Channel Would Offer the Big Picture; Poetry in Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore's Earth Channel Would Offer the Big Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ERNEST
description: WEISS-Ernest. Beloved husband of Margaret, beloved father of Stanley Weiss, D.D.S., and Esther Bolkin. Beloved grandfather of Jonathan, Daniel and David Weiss; David, Michael and Jennifer Bolkin. May they be comforted among the mourners in Zion.

title: TIMES MIRROR ADDING RECYCLER CLASSIFIEDS
description: The Times Mirror Company agreed yesterday to acquire the Los Angeles-area publications of Recycler Classifieds, a publisher of classified ads. The two companies, along with DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, formed a new company, Target Media Partners, to operate the remaining publications owned by Recycler and their local publishers. The companies said the acquisition of Recycler Classifieds by Times Mirror and the joint investments in Target Media totaled more than $200 million. Recycler, based in Los Angeles, is majority owned by DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, a unit of the investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. Recycler's Los Angeles operations include 24 publications with average weekly circulation of more than 400,000.

title: Turkish Premier Confronts Military Over Islam
description: After surviving an attempt by religious conservatives to bring down his Government this week, Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz is confronting an even more powerful group: the military commanders who effectively put him into office last year, and the military is pushing back.

title: Wild Energy, and Lots of It, as the Essence
description: Jimi Hendrix must have heeded a cosmic revelation when he named one of his ensembles the Band of Gypsies. He did not know of Taraf de Haidouks; its 11 fiddlers, accordionists and rhythm musicians did not play together outside their Romanian village before 1991. But the vibrant and oppressed community to which Taraf belongs more than superficially resembles African-American musicians like Mr. Hendrix. In Europe, Gypsies invented rock-and-roll attitude.

title: Fugitive Cuban Athletes Are Said to Reach Safety
description: The journey of four Cuban baseball players and a coach who fled their country on a small boat and then seemed to vanish took a puzzling turn yesterday with a swirl of vague, unconfirmed reports that they had washed ashore in the Dominican Republic, weakened but alive after nine days at sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, ESTELLE
description: LEWIS-Estelle. On March 19, 1998 in Hollywood, FL. Beloved mother of Linda Lindenbaum. Adored grandmother of Erica Tishman and Laurie Lindenbaum Horne, loving great-grandmother of Adam, Stuart and Julia Tishman and Sarah Horne. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society. Funeral services private.

title: Times Appoints Head of Circulation Dept.
description: Richard H. Gilman, senior vice president for operations at The New York Times, has been appointed head of the paper's circulation department. The appointment of Mr. Gilman, was announced yesterday by Janet L. Robinson, president and general manager of The Times.

title: Taking the Pope's Cue on Cuba
description: The Helms-Burton law limits President Clinton's power to modify the American economic embargo on Cuba. But yesterday Mr. Clinton made good use of his executive authority to help religious and charitable groups, as well as Cuban-Americans, deliver more humanitarian aid to Cuba's people. Any easing of the outdated and increasingly counterproductive embargo is welcome, especially in humanitarian areas. Relief from abroad helps the independent sectors emerging in Cuban society distance themselves from the Castro Government.

title: Guidelines Govern Use Of Megan's Law Notices
description: ''Megan's Law'' notices can be sent home with schoolchildren as long as the notices are contained in sealed envelopes and parents are required to sign for their receipts, according to guidelines issued yesterday by the State Attorney General's office. The guidelines, intended for school superintendents and county prosecutors, also permit school officials to notify high-school students directly about convicted sex offenders who live nearby.

title: On Impatient Gardeners
description: To northern gardeners, this time of year is full of anxious pleasure. Even as they daydream about the botanical joys of June and July, ordinary mortals find themselves nearly defeated by the gardening deadlines that pass so swiftly in March. Extraordinary mortals -- whose seeds arrived two months ago, whose windows are now full of seedlings and who are ready to sow peas and carrots the instant the soil thaws -- will suffer torments of their own when the perfections they are planning fail, somehow, to germinate or to blossom. A garden, it seems, is just a way of mapping the strengths and weaknesses of your personality onto the soil. It would be too much to bear if nature did not temper a gardener's limitations with her own unsolicited abundance.

title: A Uniform Solution For N.Y. Schools?; Truly a Distraction
description: To the Editor:

title: Disappointing Raises Set for Japan's Workers
description: On its face, the annual ritual of wage negotiations that took place this week is one more sign of the depths of Japan's economic distress.

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP
description: L.P.G.A. PHOENIX

title: CUNY Delays Vote on Limits To Offering Remediation
description: Three days before the trustees of the City University of New York were to decide on a sweeping overhaul of remedial education, a divided board said yesterday that it would postpone the vote.

title: Devils Are Swept Away By an Unexpected Rush
description: Mike Dunham made his first start in goal in almost a month and pulled his groin. But the injury was the least of the Devils' problems against the Washington Capitals tonight.

title: Owners Give Blessing To Media Marriage
description: By voting so overwhelmingly on Thursday to let Rupert Murdoch's Fox Group take possession of the Los Angeles Dodgers, major league baseball owners may have opened their clubhouse door even wider to less controversial media companies like Cablevision Systems, which has had discussions with George Steinbrenner about buying all or part of the Yankees.

title: Flowers Acknowledges Earning $500,000 From Scandal
description: Gennifer Flowers says that she probably earned $500,000 by capitalizing on her reputed affair with President Clinton but that with better timing, or perhaps better luck, she could easily have been a millionaire.

title: Clinton Asserts Privilege to Bar Query to Aides
description: President Clinton today took the extraordinary step of formally invoking both executive privilege and attorney-client privilege to block grand jury testimony of senior White House aides in the Monica S. Lewinsky inquiry, lawyers involved in the case said.

title: The East Side's Old Fort
description: Across the country, National Guard armories tend to be unromantic places, painted in dull shades of gray and green, filled with jeeps and trucks and rifles. There is usually a bureaucratic colonel and staff to run the place, and once a month it fills with Guardsmen. They drill and sweep, paint and polish and go back home, leaving the armory spic and span. But this is New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELL'OREFICE, MAESTRO LUIGI EDUARDO
description: DELL'OREFICE-Maestro Luigi Eduardo. March 18, 1998. Beloved husband of Lina, loving son of the late Eva and Maestro Antonio Dell'Orefice, grand nephew of composer Giuseppe Dell'Orefice. Reposing Saturday and Sunday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 at Frank E. Campbell, 1077 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday 10 A.M., at Blessed Sacrament Church, 152 W. 71 Street. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HILDA G.
description: SCHWARTZ-Hilda G. Retired Supreme Court Justice on Mar. 18, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Herman N. Schwartz. Loving mother of John M. Schwartz. Devoted sister of Edith Smolen and the late Rose Weisman, Dr. Joseph A. Gaines and Mary Princer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81 St, Saturday 6-9PM. Funeral service Sunday, March 22, 11:30AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65 St.

title: Journal; The Liars' Club
description: So many women who may be lying on TV, so little time. How else to explain the scant attention paid this week to the unmasking of the Beardstown Ladies, a gang of Middle American grandmas caught in the biggest media hoax since Joe Klein denied writing ''Primary Colors''?

title: Europe Joins America in Golden Rush To the Market
description: LONDON  Whether it's New York or London, Frankfurt or Madrid, stock markets seem to go in only one direction these days.

title: Clothes Don't Make the Child
description: The New York City Board of Education made a big mistake when it voted this week to order all students in city elementary schools to wear uniforms, starting in 1999. The board shouldn't be making these decisions; the individual schools should, as they have been doing already.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESLIN, MICHAEL T.
description: BRESLIN-Michael T. Of NYC, suddenly on March 19, 1998 at age 57. Survived by his wife Janice (nee Pacifico), his mother Alice and eleven siblings. Reposing on Saturday 7-9 P.M., and Sunday 2-4 and 79 PM at Meserole Funeral Home, Inwood, Long Island. Mass on Monday 10 A.M., at Our Lady of Good Counsel RC Church, Inwood.

title: Excerpts From Arguments Filed by Clinton Seeking Dismissal of Suit
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's arguments in support of his motion to dismiss Paula Corbin Jones's lawsuit against him. They are in response to papers filed by Ms. Jones's lawyers on March 13, arguing that the suit should proceed. The President's motion to dismiss the suit was filed on Feb. 17. These arguments were made public today by lawyers for the President.

title: Op-Art
Guinea Pigs in Peril in Central Park
description: A worker in Central Park saw the villain in the gathering dusk of Thursday evening. Standing on the edge of the Conservatory Garden at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, the culprit opened some cages and little animals scurried forth, scrambling wildly about.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a new minimum-wage bill in Congress misstated the views of two labor economists, Alan Krueger at Princeton and David Card at the University of California at Berkeley. They do not favor the bill; they have taken no position.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERNANDEZ, CINDY MARIE
description: HERNANDEZ-Cindy Marie. Beloved daughter of Harry and Rosemarie. Devoted sister of Jennifer Rolon and Mark. Dearest aunt to Jessica. Resposing at A. Ribustello & Son, 811 Morris Park Ave., Bronx. Funeral Mass, Saint Clare's Church, Monday, 10:30AM.

title: ZURICH INSURANCE GROUP ADDS REST OF KEMPER
description: Zurich Insurance Group said yesterday that it had acquired the remaining 20 percent of the Kemper Corporation from the investment group Insurance Partners, making Kemper a full subsidiary. The sale price was not disclosed. Kemper, which has its headquarters in Long Grove, Ill., consists of three companies: the Federal Kemper Life Assurance Company, the Kemper Investors Life Insurance Company and the Zurich Life Insurance Company of America, with combined assets of more than $14 billion.

title: Boeing to Cut 8,200 Jobs By Year 2000
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 8,200 jobs by the turn of the century as it consolidates its North American operations in the wake of two recent multibillion-dollar acquisitions that have transformed it into the world's largest military and civilian aerospace company.

title: A Uniform Solution For N.Y. Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 3 about Samuel Eilenberg, a mathematician at Columbia University, misidentified a university at which he taught earlier. A reader's letter dated Feb. 11 points out that it was Indiana University, not the University of Indiana. This correction was delayed by an editing error.

title: The Dow Tops 8,900 to End Solid Week
description: Investors paid some attention to bad news yesterday, but not much.

title: Safir's Libel Lawsuit
description: To the Editor:

title: Crew Imposes His Nominee On a Board
description: If there was one swatch of New York City that epitomized the shift in power that decentralization brought to the public school system 30 years ago, it was the neighboring Brooklyn communities of Ocean Hill and Brownsville.

title: Suharto Aide Concedes Plan On Currency Is Impractical
description: Indonesia's Finance Minister acknowledged today that a plan favored by President Suharto to peg the currency to the dollar was not realistic.

title: Hot-Hitting Spehr Catches Mets' Eye
description: ''The Mendoza Line'' is major league jargon that is used in reference to a batting average hovering around the .200 mark. Tim Spehr knows that line well, but something strange is happening this spring. Spehr, the 31-year-old Mets handyman, went into tonight's game against the St. Louis Cardinals hitting a team-leading .545 in 22 at-bats, with 3 home runs and 6 runs batted in.

title: Lazard Is Overtaken At Open Pairs
description: For 3,000 players, today is the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring National Championships, which will last for 10 days. But for 56 players, it is the end of the North American Open Pair Championship, which began at the local level in the fall. The winners, in a close finish Thursday night, were Ron Sukoneck of Annandale, Va., and Bill Cole of Beltsville, Md.

title: Defying Pressure, Tokyo Scrimps on Budget
description: Japan's lower house of Parliament passed the nation's budget today, approving a $600 billion plan that could squeeze money out of the economy just as it is careening toward recession.

title: Top Teams Stay on Top
description: Defending champion Iowa and top-ranked Oklahoma State suffered costly upsets, but each still advanced three individuals into the finals at the N.C.A.A. Division I wrestling championships last night in Cleveland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, MARION
description: ALEXANDER-Marion. On March 19, 1998. Loving sister of Raymond and sister-in-law of Joan. Cherished aunt and great-aunt. Services Tuesday, 11:45, ''Gutterman's Funeral Home'' (Riverside building), 331 Amsterdam Avenue, corner of 76 Street, NYC. Visitation Monday night 7 PM-9 PM.

title: Zippy Arizona Will Clash With the Might of Utah
description: Fight or flight?

title: Whitman Resists Adding Miles to 65-M.P.H. Test
description: Three state lawmakers have asked the Department of Transportation to expand its test of a new 65-mile-per-hour speed limit to include 300 more miles of highway in the northern half of the state. But Gov. Christine Todd Whitman responded yesterday that she wanted to stick to the original plan of 400 miles of roads.

title: President's Team Demands Dismissal of Jones Lawsuit
description: With a welter of documents and a tone of angry combat, President Clinton's lawyer today demanded the dismissal of Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct suit against the President on the grounds that it amounts to ''little more than a web of deceit and distortions.''

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN STRENGTHENS. The dollar fell for the first time this week against the yen, which rose after Japan's central bank sold dollars to defend its currency. The dollar cost 130.41 yen in New York, down from 130.70.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Austere Japan Budget Stirs Recession Fear

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, CHARLES
description: RICH-Charles. Born in Hungary. Baptized Catholic, March 19, 1933. Beloved friend of the Jesuit community. Reposing at The Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Rd. Visitation Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial, Murray Weigel Hall Chapel, Monday, 11:30AM. For information contact Farenga Brothers Inc. Directors

title: Copenhagen Journal; Unsolved in Denmark: Little Mermaid Caper
description: The Little Mermaid lost her head when someone sawed it off the other day, and therein lies a tale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASIN, GLICKMAN, EDYTHE. (TIBBY)
description: CHASIN - GLICKMAN - Edythe. (Tibby). Passed away peacefully at the age of ninety-two at her home in Florida in the devoted care of Mary Peters. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Chasin and David Glickman. Devoted mother of Arthur Chasin, Suzanne Wajntal and Barbara Scotch. Loving grandmother of four and greatgrandmother of nine. Graveside service will be on Sunday, March 22, 1998 at 12:45, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI. Tibby's generosity of spirit and deed and loyalty to her family along with her sharp sense of humor will be missed by those who loved her dearly. Shiva will observed at the home of Barbara Scotch, 300 E. 51 Street, NYC on Sunday, 5-10 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, JOSEPH E., M.D.
description: SNYDER-Joseph E., M.D., age 80. Of Holmes Beach, FL, formerly of River Edge, NJ, died March 16 in Bradenton, Florida. Survived by his wife, June (Wilke) Snyder; two sons, Robert E., Richard A., five grandchildren. Beginning in 1947, Dr. Snyder was Assistant Vice President of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and Director of the Vanderbilt Clinic in New York City. He retired in 1980 as Director of Medical Affairs for Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. Graduate of the University of Nebraska and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. Life Member of the American Cancer Society.

title: 1998 N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: SOUTH -- Duke Rolls On, but Valparaiso's Magic Runs Out; Blue Devils Use Defense To Stifle Syracuse Rally
description: Sometimes the shots do not fall for Duke. The Blue Devils make a lazy pass here and there and every once in a while turn the ball over. Full-court trapping pressure can make them, like any team, hesitant. Sometimes an opponent can outmuscle them for a rebound.

title: George Hecht, Manufacturer, Inventor and Civic Patron, 90
description: George Hecht, a retired electronics manufacturer, inventor and major supporter of Cooper Union and many civic causes, died on March 9 at Astoria General Hospital in Queens. He was 90 and lived in Astoria.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARNES, EDWARD
description: PARNES-Edward, age 92 on March 19, 1998. Beloved husband of Harriet (Novich) Parnes. Loving father of Jane and Raymond Epstein, and Kate and Andrew Parnes. Grandfather of Kevin, Christy, Ryan, Daniel, and Devyn. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Saturday 7-9PM. Services and interment private.

title: Lott Abruptly Postpones Senate Action on NATO Expansion
description: An hour after President Clinton urged the Senate today to the expansion of NATO, the majority leader, Trent Lott, abruptly postponed action on the measure, partly in frustration over a Democratic filibuster on other legislation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, SAMUEL
description: WALLACH-Samuel. Left us at the age of 98. Sound of mind and humor. He lived to a maturation of loving wisdom. He assessed the world's troubles with sympathy and hope, and entertained us with high spirits and poetry. We are more for him having been here. Devoted husband to the late Blanche. Father of: Alfred, Richard and Samoa Joan. Grandfather of Pamela, Jennifer, Jodie, Clifford, Joshua and David. Visit at Syosset, Saturday and Sunday; Forest Hills Sunday afternoon. Scarsdale Saturday after 4pm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIGHTSTONE, PEARL (NEE WEISBERG)
description: LIGHTSTONE-Pearl (nee Weisberg). Of West Palm Beach, FL. Thursday, March 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Charles; devoted mother of Ronald and Nancy Lightstone and Laurel and Mel Gebroe; dear sister of Ann Kornfeld; loving grandmother of Dana Lightstone, Alan and Robyn Gebroe and Linda Gebroe; adoring great-grandmother of Eric and Emily Gebroe. Graveside service Sun, March 22, 12:30 P.M. in King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, N.J.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It looks like a perfectly good profession. They see a lot of actors in their living rooms. And TV looks so easy.''

title: Columbia Graduate Student Found Fatally Injured
description: The police are trying to determine wheth er a 26-year-old Columbia University gradu ate student who died last night was the victim of a homicide.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BECKER, MURRY C.
description: BECKER-Murry C. We miss you more each day. Your memory serves as our inspiration and guidance. Your children and grandchildren

title: Bruins No Match For 'Cats; Duke Next
description: Teams that reach the Round of 16 are supposed to be sweet.

title: Scientists Brace for Changes In Path of Human Evolution
description: For years, molecular biologists and geneticists have trod gingerly around the most explosive topic of the new reproductive biology: purposely making genetic changes in people that would persist for generation after generation.

title: Cormier Resigns As Fairfield Coach
description: Paul Cormier resigned yesterday as Fairfield University basketball coach to accept the newly created position of associate athletic director.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Chief Offers Aid to Iraqis Facing Ouster
description: R. James Woolsey Jr., a former Director of Central Intelligence, said today that he wants to defend six Iraqis who fought with the C.I.A. against Saddam Hussein and now face deportation as threats to American national security.

title: Hewlett-Packard Plans Rival Version of Java
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company will release its own version of Sun Microsystems Inc.'s Java software, putting its stamp on the technology that aims to let programs run on any operating system.

title: Cliff Barker, 77, a Kentucky Basketball Star
description: Cliff Barker, who helped the University of Kentucky win two National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball titles a half century ago and then coached and played in the National Basketball Association, died on Tuesday at his winter home in Satsuma, Fla. He was 77.

title: The Red-Hot Poker and the Frosty Quip: 52 Years Later, They're Still Dueling
description: It was October 1946, and the philosopher Karl Popper was presenting a paper called ''Methods in Philosophy'' at the Moral Science Club at King's College, Cambridge. Suddenly, Ludwig Wittgenstein, the eminence grise of Cambridge philosophy and no fan of Popper's theories, picked up a poker and brandished it threateningly before stalking out in a huff.

title: Maria Shriver Secretly Buys 2 Kennedy Family Diaries
description: John F. Kennedy's children battled this week's auction of 600 Camelot mementos with lawyers and blunt press statements; his niece used her pocketbook.

title: 2 Mormons From the U.S. Are Abducted In Russia
description: Two American Mormon missionaries have been kidnapped in Russia in a case that has stirred fears that foreigners are increasingly becoming the prey of extortionists in this country.

title: MYCOGEN IS REPORTED TO WIN IN MONSANTO SUIT
description: The Mycogen Corporation, an agribusiness company, said yesterday that a superior court jury in San Diego had awarded it $174.9 million in damages in a breach of contract suit against the Monsanto Company. Mycogen said that Monsanto had delayed fulfilling terms of option agreements to license crop enhancement technology to Mycogen. Mycogen said the award represented compensation for lost profits and market share for its seed business caused by what it said was a lack of access to Monsanto insect resistance technology called bacillus thuringiensis, for corn, and glyphosate herbicide tolerance technology, for corn, cotton and canola, for which Mycogen holds license options. A judge ruled that Monsanto had breached the agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, NORMAN
description: FEINBERG-Norman, 76. A generous, caring man with a special warmth and wisdom. He passed away suddenly on Wednesday, March 18. He will always be cherished by his loving wife and best friend Lois, their children Barney, Robert and Ellen and their spouses Tracy, Ruth and Ken. His greatest joy came from sharing himself and his time with family and friends. ''Papa Norman'' loved his grandchildren Eric, Lauren, Phoebe, Aaron, Sydney and Joelle. An ''Amici'' for life, Norman truly made this world a better place. His warm, loving smile will always be remembered. Memorial service Sunday, March 22, 1:30PM, North Country Reform Temple, Glen Cove.

title: A Uniform Solution For N.Y. Schools?; Creativity Will Conquer
description: To the Editor:

title: After Battering by Casinos, Dog Racing Returns to Bridgeport
description: When the Shoreline Star Greyhound Park and Simulcast Complex opened here about two and a half years ago, it was hailed by industry experts and officials here as the best new dog track in the country, one that could help save both a dying industry and Connecticut's largest city.

title: Pharaoh, Too, Looked Askance at Swine
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; The Cultural Revolution
description: China may soon let out a few dissidents to appease the U.S. before President Clinton's June visit. This should be taken with a grain of salt, because more dissidents can just be arrested. Fortunately, though, the dissidents are not the only agents of change here. In fact, they aren't even the most important ones. The most important ones are those whom the Government doesn't know, and can't arrest, but who represent powerful trends that, over time, will force the Chinese Government to either loosen its grip or risk instability.

title: Task Force Urges Increase In Police Pay
description: A majority of a task force on the Police Department and community relations established by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani after the beating of Abner Louima last summer favors a pay raise for the police, an official who is familiar with the panel's conclusions said yesterday.

title: A Quiet Return To Finish Up Some Business
description: Dennis O'Connor's ''Unfinished Business,'' performed at the Kitchen on Thursday night, is like a small, many-faceted jewel whose color changes subtly when seen from each new angle. Returning to the New York stage after three years abroad, Mr. O'Connor is as strong a performer as ever. But he seems newly serene, and ''Unfinished Business'' is a work of haunting calmness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEENAN, EDWARD
description: KEENAN-Edward. On Thursday, March 19, 1998, in Blue Bell, PA. Edward F., Jr. Age 62 yrs. Beloved husband of Elinor (Thulin) Keenan. Son of the late Edward F. and Mabel (Cororan) Keenan. Father of Edward F. III, Michael J., Kevin P., Kenneth P. Keenan, Maureen E. Clegg. nine grandchildren. Brother of Kathleen Knapp, Joan Sullivan, 3 nieces, 3 nephews. Viewing will be held on Sun. March 22, 1998, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM for relatives and friends from Emil J. Ciavarelli Family Funeral Homes, Inc., 516 Fayette Street, Conshohocken, PA. There will be a funeral Mass on Tuesday, March 24, 1998 at 10 AM in St. Edward The Confessor R.C. Church, New Fairfield, CT. Interment Mountain View Cemetery, New Fairfield, Connecticut.

title: Among Young Of Immigrants, Outlook Rises
description: A multiyear survey that is the largest ever of the children of immigrants -- who now account for almost 1 in 5 American children -- found that they overwhelmingly prefer English to their parents' native tongues and have higher grades and steeply lower school dropout rates than other American children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, GEORGE D. III
description: ROBERTS-George D. III in New York on March 17, 1998. Survived by his children, Janet R. Capinera and George D. IV of Watertown, CT, and Peter E. of Savannah, GA; sister Janet Dwyer of Wayne, NJ; brother Ronald E. of Greensboro, NC and friend, Denise Melato of NY. Burial in Hillside Cemetery, Torrington, CT., on April 18.

title: Germans Cut Labor Costs With a Harsh Export: Jobs
description: It would be hard to find a more vivid example of the revival of German industry than the renowned sports car manufacturer Porsche AG. Six years after the company came perilously close to bankruptcy, sales and profits are booming and its snappy new two-seater, the Boxster, is a hit.

title: G.M. Pulls Out the Stops in Fight for Market Share
description: Surf through prime time television and you can count on many shows having one thing in common: they'll be interrupted by a lot of advertisements for General Motors' cars and trucks.

title: Point Guards Face Off In Carolina-Connecticut
description: When the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament brackets were announced on March 8, Khalid El-Amin of Connecticut immediately turned to his coach, Jim Calhoun, and expressed excitement about the possibility of opposing North Carolina and point guard Ed Cota. Calhoun put his fingers on his lips to quiet El-Amin and reminded him that the Huskies had to make it to the Eastern Regional final to have that chance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMOWITZ, ROSE
description: ABRAMOWITZ-Rose. Devoted wife of the late Paul, beloved mother of Bernard and Sharon, adored grandmother of David, Mark, Melissa and Philip. Services held privately on Sunday.

title: Search for Truth Must First Tackle Uncertainties in Law; Then Comes Politics
description: Moments after Kathleen E. Willey told her story last Sunday on the CBS News program ''60 Minutes,'' President Clinton's lawyer, Robert S. Bennett, said the country would soon learn whether the President was lying in his denials of her accusation, or whether she was doing so.

title: The Knicks Rediscover Their Fire
description: It was Charles Oakley's last plunge of the night, a tumble directly into the cameras lining the blue baseline. It made for a picture worth framing for the Knicks.

title: Tornado Kills 13 in Northeast Georgia
description: An early morning tornado tore an 11-mile gulch through rural northeast Georgia today, destroying homes and schools, killing 13 people and injuring scores more.

title: Peter Feller, 78, Set Builder on Broadway
description: Peter L. Feller, a Tony Award-winning builder of sets for Broadway shows, died on March 13 at Holmes Regional Hospital in Melbourne, Fla. He was 78 and lived in Melbourne.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARIAS, HERNANDO
description: ARIAS-Hernando. 3/21/94. Remembered today, missed everyday. Cuca

title: Fleury Scores 2 As Flames Top Isles
description: FLAMES 4, ISLANDERS 1

title: Allies in Milk Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: What Is the True Measure of a Lost Book?
description: For more than three hours yesterday, Jean Ashton, director of the rare book and manuscript collection at Columbia University, sat on the witness stand, pulling on white gloves as she carefully handled old manuscripts, scrolls and a letter written by George Washington.

title: Challenger Of Visa Bias Wins Job Back
description: The State Department has been ordered to reinstate a visa officer who was dismissed because he refused to follow orders to screen visa applicants at the United States Consulate in Sao Paulo, Brazil, because of their physical appearance, national origins and, possibly, race.

title: Once Again, Police Raid the Wrong Apartment
description: Seeking drug dealers, the police came to the Fulton family's Bronx apartment Wednesday night with a battering ram. But after barging inside with their guns drawn, the officers instead found a grandmother, her daughter and her 6-year-old grandson watching television.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FORD MOTOR CO., Dearborn, Mich., plans to invest $900 million at its plant in Genk, Belgium, in the next three years for the production of new-model Mondeo cars and Transit vans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, BENEDICT
description: GINSBERG-Benedict. 1908-1998. Mr. and Mrs Herbert R. Weissberg and Family mourn the passing of the greatest lawyer and loyal friend for more than forty years. We will miss him every day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINCUS, JOAN T.
description: PINCUS-Joan T. Of Yonkers, NY. Corporate attorney and civic activist. Beloved wife of Sherman. Devoted mother of Harlan & Judith. Loving grandmother of Matthew Freud. Sister of Allan Turkheimer. Services Sunday 12:30 P.M., at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers. Contributions to Joan Pincus Scholarship in Political Science at Hunter College, C/O Sandra Radinsky, Director of Development, 695 Park Ave., New York, New York 10021.

title: Nashville Clinic Offers Case Study of Chronic Gap in Black and White Health
description: For most of her 65 years, Verna Pugh never went to doctors. But inexplicably, she has lost 44 of her 169 pounds in just a few months, and that has brought her to the Meharry Medical College's health clinic here on a winter afternoon.

title: Medical Care Claimants
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKMAN, HANNAH
description: DRUCKMAN-Hannah. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Loving mother of Eleanor, William and the late Barbara. Adoring grandmother of David Lerner and Emily Druckman. Cherished sister of Judith Weber and Arthur Abraham. Devoted aunt and loving friend. Service Sun, 12:15 at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her memory to Hospice of Central Pennsylvania.

title: Grass Roots Showing
description: The latest stop in Michelle Shocked's rambles around the United States is New Orleans, and she has begun to go native. On Monday night at CBGB, she led a band steeped in funk and the blues, and she sang about Louisiana subjects from the chemical pollution around Lake Charles to the jubilant funeral of a boy shot dead in a New Orleans housing project. She has also absorbed something more: the spirit of music as a communal event, where bringing pleasure to a roomful of listeners is more important than promoting songs or CD's.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER SURGES. A late rally came on speculation that the investor Warren E. Buffett, who has large silver holdings, foresees a big use for the metal in fuel-cell batteries. May contracts jumped 24.5 cents an ounce, to $6.135.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEXTER, LEO
description: HEXTER-Leo. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Paulette Katzenstein on the loss of her beloved father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Police Arrest Suspect In Slaying of Teen-Ager
description: A group of Queens narcotics detectives made an arrest in a three-month-old homicide case yesterday after they drove past a street corner in Jamaica and spotted a man suspected of fatally shooting a teen-ager in December, the police said.

title: Jets Make an Offer For Patriots' Martin
description: The rivalry and gamesmanship between the Jets and New England -- not to mention the feud between Coach Bill Parcells and the Patriots' owner, Bob Kraft -- continued yesterday when the Jets made a startling six-year, $36 million contract offer to Curtis Martin, one of the National Football League's most productive running backs.

title: Another Short Day Leaves Woods in Front
description: Tiger Woods played only seven holes today, but that was enough to take the lead. Completing his first round, which was suspended because of rain on Thursday, Woods birdied four of the seven holes for an eight-under-par 64 and a one-stroke lead at the Bay Hill Invitational.

title: Christian Broadcasting Network to Pay Fine for Its Political Efforts in 1988
description: The Christian Broadcasting Network has agreed to pay a substantial fine to the Internal Revenue Service for its involvement in the 1988 Presidential election, a Federal official said tonight.

title: A Dark Tale, Youthfully Executed
description: The city's two productions of ''Les Contes d'Hoffmann,'' put in near proximity this season, constitute a controlled experiment of sorts. The Metropolitan Opera's well-fed production returned recently with considerable success. The New York City Opera's skinnier, more light-footed version played on Thursday night.

title: Without Any Headache, LaFontaine Pays a Visit
description: There were some encouraging signs for the Rangers this morning as Pat LaFontaine, the veteran center who sustained a head injury during last Monday's game against Ottawa, felt well enough to visit teammates at the team's Playland practice facility.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCASKEY, LYDIA
description: McCASKEY-Lydia. On March 18, 1998 Lydia was suddenly taken away from her husband George, daughter Pamela and many other close family members and friends who loved her dearly. We must all cherish the 65 wonderful years we had with her, but sadly, we will all miss her terribly. Visitation will be held at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc., 1380 New York Avenue, Huntington Station, Long Island, N.Y. Sunday 7-10PM and Monday 2-5 and 7-10PM. Religious service will be held Monday, 8PM. Prayers will be offered Tuesday, 10AM followed by an entombment at Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIERRA, MARCELINO F.
description: SIERRA-Marcelino F., PhD. The administration, faculty, staff and students of the State University of New York Health Science Center at Brooklyn mourn the untimely passing of our colleague, Marcelino F. Sierra, PhD, Associate Professor of Pathology and Director of Clinical Microbiology at University Hospital of Brooklyn and Kings County Hospital Center. His intellect, professionalism and warmth will long be missed. Our condolences go to his wife, Dr. Lorraine Clarke, and all family members and friends. Eugene B. Feigelson, MD Interim President

title: From Highflier to Downer; Transformation Plans at Hoechst Are Losing Thrust
description: Until recently at least, Jurgen Dormann came as close as any German business executive to being a Wall Street darling.

title: A Bigger, Slower, Aimless NATO; Lessons of World Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From the Cross-Examination of Kathleen Willey in the Paula Jones Case
description: Following are excerpts from a deposition of Kathleen E. Willey, a former White House volunteer, given on Jan. 10 in the sexual harassment case of Paula Corbin Jones against President Clinton. Ms. Willey was questioned by Robert S. Bennett, the President's lawyer, and Ms. Jones's lawyer, Donovan Campbell Jr. These excerpts were made public today by lawyers for the President.

title: Killer of Hasidic Student Won't Talk in Court
description: The gunman convicted of firing into a van full of Hasidic students on the Brooklyn Bridge in 1994, killing a teen-ager, refused to answer most questions yesterday after being called to testify in a civil suit.

title: LIFE BY DESIGN; Smart Machines, and Why We Fear Them
description: The cultural definition of artificial intelligence or A.I., as it is known -- goes something like this: ''A.I. is the science of how to get machines to do the things they do in the movies.'' No wonder the subject makes some people nervous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, NENA
description: GOODMAN-Nena. On March 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Andrew Goodman. Devoted mother of Vivien G. Malloy, Mary Ann Quinson, Edwin A. Goodman and Pamela Lichty. Loving grandmother of Andrew T., Deborah Malloy Winkler, Kenneth H., Mark L. and Vivien C. Malloy; Geoffrey, Luke, Adam and Joshua Taylor; Sara and Thea Goodman; Will and Simone Lichty. Great grandmother of Courtney and Caitlin, Connor, Maggie, Kenneth Jr., Shane Malloy; James, John and Alexandra Taylor. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84 St., Monday 10 A.M. Those desiring may send flowers or contributions in her memory may be made to National Jewish Center, Immunology and Respiratory Medicine, 1400 Jackson St., Denver, CO 80206; or the International Rescue Committee, 122 East 42nd Street, 12 Flr, New York, NY 10017; or The Alcoholism Council of Greater NY, 352 Park Avenue South, 8th Floor, NY, NY 10010.

title: DEPUY TO BUY ACROMED, SPINAL IMPLANT MAKER
description: DePuy Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the privately held Acromed Corporation, a Cleveland spinal implant company, in a transaction valued at $325 million. It earned $122.8 million on sales of $770.2 million in 1997. Acromed, which makes devices to support damaged and diseased spines, reported sales of $90 million in the year ended June 30. DePuy said the combined company would be the world's second-largest spinal implant company. Shares of DePuy, a Warsaw, Ind., maker of orthopedic devices and supplies, rose $1.8125, to $30. The acquisition should begin adding to DePuy's earnings per share in 1999.

title: Did the Envoy of a Queen Really Dress in Drag?
description: Until Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appeared in spangled pink gown, platinum-blond wig and lipstick at the Inner Circle parody show last year, only one high New York official had ever been accused of transvestism: Edward Hyde, Viscount Cornbury, first cousin to Queen Anne and Royal Governor of the colonies of New York and New Jersey from 1702 to 1708.

title: A Threat to Indian Sovereignty
description: Senator Slade Gorton has once again declared war on the Indians. Having failed last year to undermine the concept of Indian sovereignty with a sneaky amendment to an appropriations bill, the Washington State Republican has now offered a freestanding bill, erroneously labeled the ''American Indian Equal Justice Act,'' that is a reprise of last year's rider. The bill would, among other things, deprive Indian tribes of their sovereign immunity against civil lawsuits.

title: INSIDE
description: Dow Rises by 103, Capping a Big Week

title: Simply Living His Life, Trying to Be Honest And Solve Some Crimes
description: One of the many strengths of Walter Mosley's mystery novels is that his hero, Easy Rawlins, is an anti-detective, negotiating the blind alleys and smoky back rooms of Los Angeles not so much as a solver of cases but as an illuminator of the moral ambiguities of the post-World War II era. Socrates Fortlow, the primary character in a collection of Mosley short stories, follows a similar path across the burned-out, paved-over landscape of contemporary South-Central Los Angeles, but in the film ''Always Outnumbered,'' he's portrayed in such compelling fashion by Laurence Fishburne that he becomes something other than just an Easy Rawlins for a less romantic time.

title: CLINTON HESITATES TO PUNISH NATIONS FOR IRAN OIL DEALS
description: The Clinton Administration is backing away from imposing sanctions on foreign energy companies that are investing in Iran, despite a law signed with great fanfare by President Clinton in 1996, senior American officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, ANNE V. (NEE FOWLER)
description: MCMAHON-Anne V. (nee Fowler). On March 18, 1998, Anne V. McMahon passed away unexpectedly. Beloved wife of Roger F. McMahon who predeceased her in 1956. Beloved mother of Roger, Jr., John (deceased), Harry, Mary Thomas and Katherine Zaremba, Gerard and Michael Albert McMahon. Loving grandmother to Rosemary, James, Patrick, Roger, Sean, Megan, Gerard, Brian, Kerry Ann McMahon, Amy McQuade, Jack and Jayne Zaremba, William, Elizabeth, Heather, and Kenneth Thomas. Beloved great-grandmother of Ryan and Jason McMahon and Kelly Anne Thomas. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Pkwy & Northern Boulevard, Little Neck, NY on Satuday 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-5; 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered in St. Anastasia R.C. Church, Monday at 9:45 AM. Interment Private.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Tuesday about ''The Gershwins and Their World,'' a four-day program of panels and performances at the Library of Congress, misidentified the director of a concert version of the Vincent Youmans musical ''Great Day!'' on Sunday. The director was Lainie Munro. (Aaron Gandy was the music director.)

title: Text of Court Filing by Clinton To Strike Jones Materials
description: Following is the text of President Clinton's motion to strike materials from Paula Corbin Jones's lawsuit against him. The materials were filed by her lawyers on March 13, in response to a motion to dismiss her suit filed by Mr. Clinton on Feb. 17. The motion was made public today by lawyers for the President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, DONALD
description: JOYCE-Donald. On Tuesday, March 10, 1998, age 45, of cancer. Musician, organist, choir director, teacher. A service will be held on Saturday, March 28, at 1 P.M., at the Church of the Holy Apostles, 9th Ave at 28th St., NYC 10001. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made either to the Organ Fund at the above church or to the Donald Joyce Scholarship Fund at the Copland School of Music, Queens College, Flushing, N.Y. 11367.

title: The Morgan Curtails Access to a Trove Of Pynchon Letters
description: A trove of Thomas Pynchon letters -- the most highly prized item in the Carter Burden collection of American literature given last month to the Pierpont Morgan Library by the Burden family -- will not be open to scholars during Mr. Pynchon's lifetime, it was announced yesterday.

title: Beliefs
description: The Nazis' slaughter of six million European Jews is hardly a topic that can be addressed with utter calm. And the opening and closing sections of the Vatican's document reflecting on Christian complicity in the Holocaust are admirably passionate in describing this singular evil and condemning the anti-Semitism that drove it.

title: SHARES OF WAYNE BANCORP RISE AS IT SEEKS BUYER
description: The shares of Wayne Bancorp Inc. jumped yesterday as it said it would seek a buyer for the company, after a proxy vote showed ''a substantial number of stockholders'' supported a sale. The stock of the savings institution, which is based in Wayne, N.J., rose $4.25 a share, to $28.75, in Nasdaq trading yesterday. At its current price, the company has a market capitalization of about $58 million. Wayne Bancorp hired the New York investment bank Sandler O'Neill & Partners to help find a buyer.

title: Hernandez Can't Hide First-Day Emotions
description: Orlando Hernandez has told the harrowing story of his flight from Cuba in a leaky boat dozens of times since last December, when he and seven others went ashore on the Anguilla Cay. When the pitcher was asked to recount the journey today, after completing his deal with the Yankees, Hernandez's eyes filled with tears.

title: Yanks' Edge: Will to Spend
description: Only George Steinbrenner knows for sure how much he is worth, and whatever the value of his portfolio, it presumably is less than those of the giant corporations slowly buying into baseball. But if Steinbrenner does not have the deepest corporate pockets, he remains the most formidable spender in the game.

title: Jheri Redding Is Dead at 91; A Hair Products Entrepreneur
description: Jheri Redding, an Illinois farm boy who founded four hair care products companies, revolutionized the economics of the hair salon industry and changed the way much larger companies market shampoos, died on Sunday at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 91.

title: Schlumberger Sets Big Russian Oil Alliance
description: Schlumberger Ltd. plans to announce next Tuesday that it will form a five-year strategic alliance with the AO Yuksi Oil Company, Russia's largest oil producer, Yuksi said yesterday. Schlumberger would take over and manage some of the Russian oilfields to make them more productive.

title: Pharaoh, Too, Looked Askance at Swine
description: To the Editor:

title: Hope Dims in Effort to Save Sign of the Dove Building
description: It looks as if the wrecking ball will soon fall on the northwest corner of Third Avenue and 65th Street, where construction of a 31-story condominium tower has been delayed since early this month.

title: Ideas & Trends: Feeding Frenzy; It's Good. No, It's Bad. No, It's Good. Really. I Think.
description: THERE'S an old saw about the weather that might apply just as well to new information about healthy living: If you don't like it, wait a minute.

title: Musical Out of Age of Innocence
description: THE musical reflects upon a vanished past, the dawning of a new century in the land of opportunity. A strange new syncopated sound is evolving, but it doesn't silence the mounting rage against segregation and sexism -- the anarchist Emma Goldman is among the cast of characters -- or the turbulence wrought by immigration issues, which intensify bigotry, ethnic hate and alienation.

title: Sunday, March 22, 1998; AIEEE!
description: *''Teletubbies,'' the British children's-television phenom, hits the United States next month. *The Tubbies are four furry creatures with rubbery faces, antennae and TV's in their tummies. Tinky Winky is purple, Dipsy is green, Laa-Laa is yellow and Po (pictured) is red. *They're aimed at 1-year-olds, were conceived in the hometown of William Shakespeare and talk baby talk. Many critics hate them. The Daily Telegraph said the show has caused ''widespread indignation.''*The Sun revealed that Laa-Laa was played by a ''shaven-headed hippie who lives alongside squatters.'' *America is just another fallen domino, after the U.K., South Africa, Australia and New Zealand. *It's estimated that the Tubbies made $80 million last year. Among the merchandise: masks, dolls and a CD called Teletubbies Say 'Eh-Oh.'

title: Runner Wear With Legs
description: ON a recent Friday morning on Astor Place, the most stylish women on the street were Suzanne Ethier and Nathalie Fuz. They were loping toward the gym, dressed in vintage track pants with wide side stripes, vintage T-shirts (Ms. Fuz's read, I SPIKE LIKE A GIRL ) and vintage sneakers. Actually, the ones Ms. Fuz wore were Spanish skateboard shoes called Dr. Termans -- a loose anagram for Doc Martens.

title: Commercial Property/Newark's Slow Office Revival; Investors Buying Big, Mostly Vacant Buildings
description: BETTING that Newark's slow commercial revival is about to turn a corner, investors are buying some of the big, old and mostly vacant downtown office buildings.

title: A Place in Midtown For One-Stop Eating
description: Facing the brutal competition in the midtown restaurant market, John Calo opened a catch-all last month: a takeout lunch place, a bar-lounge and a formal restaurant, all in one 2,100-square-foot space. He calls it Calo & Company, at 18 East 41st Street, between Madison and Fifth Avenues.

title: Does Vatican Holocaust Report Go Far Enough?; Blame Isn't Particular
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: Trusting Rosy Scenarios; One's Extremist Is Another's Winner
description: THE loudest hurrahs for Peter Fitzgerald, the new Republican nominee for the Senate from Illinois, came not from within his party but from Democrats who think he is so conservative he will be a pushover against Senator Carol Moseley-Braun in November.

title: March 15-21; Clothes Make the Student
description: Children learn many things as they wend their grueling way from kindergarten to sixth grade: reading, math, a bit of history -- and which clothes are seriously cool.

title: Seeking Solace In the Music Of Maturity
description: SONGWRITERS on their way up write about what they want: attention, romance, justice, satisfaction. And then, if they stay around long enough, they end up writing about all that they've lost. Baby boomers' rock icons, who were born during World War II, are now reaching their mid-50's. And as they do, they are turning to reflections and elegies, facing others' mortality and their own.

title: Reliving San Juan Hill And a Time of Turmoil
description: LONG before Vietnam, the Spanish-American War drove a wedge into the hearts and souls of Americans. To commemorate the war's centenary, ''Militant Metropolis'' will open Wednesday at the New-York Historical Society.

title: Once Again, A Joe Can Go To Joe's Again
description: Before there was Joe Namath, Joey Heatherton or even Joe McCarthy, there was Joe Stanziani, a World War I veteran who opened one of Greenwich Village's first pizzerias in 1933 at the corner of West 10th and Fourth Streets. With its red-and-white tablecloths, Neapolitan nautical prints and Venetian blinds (which were usually drawn), Joe Stanziani's became a prototype for the red-sauce spaghetti joints that once seemed to be on nearly every block of the city.

title: March 15-21; The Resurrection of Rosty
description: If a Chicago television station saw a shred of satire in putting Dan Rostenkowski -- the fallen former chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee -- on the air as a political pundit last week, nobody let on.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: LOVING CHLOE

title: From Silver to Strap Hinges, Bargains Worth Lining Up For
description: The true rummager does not fret over the loss of a chic velour warm-up jacket forgotten at choir practice. Even with a Saks Fifth Avenue label, it cost only $5 at a church rummage sale.

title: Portrait of The Artist as A Focus Group
description: In ''Portrait of the Artist as a Focus Group,'' Michiko Kakutani deftly points out the dangers of confusing ''market demands for authentic artistic and political vision'' (March 1). However, there is another distinction to be made. Art and entertainment, while not mutually exclusive, are not the same. Art calls to and awakens the sleeping, hungry child in each of us. Entertainment feeds it Froot Loops. The danger lies in diminishing the appetite for anything more substantive.

title: Michelin Stars Giving Off More Light in France
description: The traditionally conservative Michelin guide, celebrating its 100th year and a new, leaner look for its mascot, Bibendum, has been generous with stars in France and Switzerland this year.

title: Without Zoning: Bethlehem Ponders Need for Change
description: COUNTRY chic hasn't arrived in Bethlehem. Sure, there are several people from show business living in town, but they are ''very low key,'' points out Doris B. Nicholls, chairwoman of the Historic District Commission. Christine Baranski, who appears in the television sitcom ''Cybill'' and her husband, Matthew Cowles, a director and soap opera actor, live in Bethlehem as does Kathleen Ankers, a set designer. But celebrities haven't flocked to Bethlehem to buy houses as they have elsewhere in Litchfield County. And one has to go elsewhere to patronize elegantly refurbished inns, expensive restaurants and trendy shops.

title: Hollywood Studio Puts Manhattan Ave. Under Martial Law
description: At twilight, purveyors and purchasers of kielbasa and other Polish staples do business on Manhattan Avenue, and teen-agers on in-line skates gossip in Polish next to old men with Old World faces. Yet many store signs above their heads carry not Polish lettering but Arabic.

title: '. . . And Thanks to My Fans for Forgetting My Early Television Roles'
description: THE first time you see Helen Hunt as Carol, the frazzled waitress and single mother in ''As Good as It Gets,'' one thing is clear: this is not Jamie Buchman. Jamie, the casually chic urban professional that Ms. Hunt plays on the NBC sitcom ''Mad About You,'' would not be caught dead in that dismal Brooklyn apartment, for one thing, or in most of Carol's clothes. And she would never have the nerve to tell off Jack Nicholson.

title: INSIDE
description: Suspect in Student's Slaying

title: Liberties; Change of Hart
description: When you see Gary Hart on the street in Washington, he seems like a ghost. He's grayer, and he has a rueful look around the mouth and eyes that sets him apart in this capital of false bonhomie.

title: Stanford Plans to Keep Up the Rough Stuff
description: After their bruising game against Purdue on Friday night, Stanford's players woke up with an assortment of bumps and scrapes. Stanford Coach Mike Montgomery said he was particularly concerned about forward Mark Madsen.

title: A Troubling Legacy of Conversions
description: HARDLY anyone would argue with the suggestion that now is a good time to be a co-op shareholder selling an apartment. Hardly anyone, that is, but someone whose apartment is in a building in which a majority of the units are still owned by the original sponsor.

title: Yankee Rookie Listens To Mom
description: Charlene Bush can't remember the poem she once read in a drama class, but its title and message remain with her: ''Be Somebody.'' While the fifth of her eight children was growing up, she would recite these two words to him. Be somebody.

title: From a Home Start, a Business Mushrooms
description: WHAT does it take for executives to quit high-paying jobs for the unknown? In the case of Adele and Noel Zeller, it was a desire to become entrepreneurs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, GERTRUDE ASPELL
description: WRIGHT-Gertrude Aspell, 89. Of Delray Beach, FL and Edgartown MA. Died March 14, 1998. Widow of Frank C. Wright, Jr., she leaves two daughters, Gill of Perrysburg, OH., Gail of NY and Middleburg, VA., and two grandchildren.

title: TV Time for Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Irabu Has Tendinitis, and May Miss First Start
description: The Yankees won their seventh straight exhibition game today, 17-1, over Kansas City. They have outscored their opponents by 31-1 in the last three games. They are averaging more than six runs a game. But now they have a problem.

title: Handyman Seeks a Financial Blueprint
description: DARRIN SCHOEN'S friends call him ''the Specialist.'' A 20-something construction manager, he can fix anything: tune cars, clear drains, repair masonry. When it comes to fixing his finances, though, Mr. Schoen doesn't know the stock market from a circular saw.

title: Men's Edition?
description: So what was this? The men's edition of the Magazine? On the cover, you refer to ''the Incubator, where young men. . . hope to grab their billion-dollar slices of Silicon Valley's new world,'' even though the story includes a woman. The table of contents lists an article on ''An Illustrated Man'' and a column about a ''Nowhere Man,'' as well as a story about the ''Little Men'' of the Princeton basketball team. Another story, ''How to Manufacture a Best Seller,'' turns out to be about ''three guys named John.'' Where were the female human beings? In an article about little girls' clothing called ''Pink Makes You Think''! Yeah, well, ignoring half your readers makes you sink.

title: Elizabeth Byrd, F. S. von Stade 3d
description: Elizabeth Sims Byrd, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Byrd of Hendersonville, N.C., was married on Friday to Francis Skiddy von Stade 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip R. von Stade of Locust Valley, N.Y. The Rev. Andrew Mead performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Lenders Laud the Value of Home Sweet Equity
description: DURING the recent stampede for mortgage refinancings, home equity loans -- consumers' solution for everything from high-interest credit card debt to college tuition -- were temporarily left behind. Now banks that want to keep the market going strong are promoting the loans aggressively.

title: Handgun Renewals
description: Under the recently enacted count Handgun Record-Keeping Accountability Act, all pistol licenses must be registered by April 1, 2000, and all permits must be renewed every five years thereafter to reflect changes in an owner's status or address.

title: How to Manufacture A Best Seller
description: I think ''How to Manufacture Depression'' should have been the title of Michael Maren's article, since that is what reading it produced (How to Manufacture a Best Seller, March 1). For years I have strived to perfect my skill, become emotionally involved with my subject matter and been driven to create compelling prose, only to discover that all I needed was a fiction doctor and a P.R. package. Whatever happened to taking simple pleasure in the act of writing?

title: The World; Clinton's Spotlight Now Turns to Africa
description: FOR millennia, Africa has largely remained a mystery to the outside world, marked perhaps more by its isolation than by any other feature.

title: Appearances; Scarlet Fever
description: After iridescent blue lips, fingernails that looked hammered and eyes painted in tones of old bruises, the fashion forward among us are dismayed to learn that pink and red are the big shades for spring. Glowing cheeks, lips bright as a baby's -- is our imagination so impoverished that we have to fall back on pretty?

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Willey Cited Effort to Put Incident in Past
description: Kathleen E. Willey, a former White House employee who claimed that President Clinton had made an unwanted sexual advance on her, has said in a sworn deposition that in a second meeting alone with Mr. Clinton in the Oval Office less than two weeks later she told him that the earlier incident should be forgotten.

title: Does Vatican Holocaust Report Go Far Enough?; A Crafted Statement
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNOWER, BERNARD
description: SNOWER-Bernard. Park East Synagogue and Day School mourn the passing of Bernard Snower, beloved uncle of our devoted Rabbi Arthur and Elisabeth Schneier. Sincere condolences to Bernard's wife Kitty, children Lillian and Dennis, and the entire family. Rabbi Fred Hyman, Ass't. Rabbi Michael Scharf, President Julius H. Gewirtz, Chairman Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEENAN, EDWARD
description: KEENAN-Edward. On Thursday, March 19, 1998, in Blue Bell, PA. Edward F., Jr. Age 62 yrs. Beloved husband of Elinor (Thulin) Keenan. Son of the late Edward F. and Mabel (Cororan) Keenan. Father of Edward F. III, Michael J., Kevin P., Kenneth P. Keenan, Maureen E. Clegg. nine grandchildren. Brother of Kathleen Knapp, Joan Sullivan, 3 nieces, 3 nephews. Viewing will be held on Sun. March 22, 1998, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM for relatives and friends from Emil J. Ciavarelli Family Funeral Homes, Inc., 516 Fayette Street, Conshohocken, PA. There will be a funeral Mass on Tuesday, March 24, 1998 at 10 AM in St. Edward The Confessor R.C. Church, New Fairfield, CT. Interment Mountain View Cemetery, New Fairfield, Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYDEN, MILTON
description: HAYDEN-Milton. On March 20, 1998 at age 61. Devoted husband of Marsha. Beloved father of Jodi, Scott and Lauren. Cherished grandfather of Tali and son-in-law of Joel and Gertrude Wiener. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: A Senator's Old Speech Holds Truths for Today
description: The words were meant for a different age, for a time when the Senate was controlled by a different party and when the main issues were Communism, civil rights and tax cuts and not NATO expansion, tobacco regulation and Social Security.

title: The View From/Bridgeport; Bit of Scenery? Need It Yesterday?
description: LATE in the summer of 1995, a fire devastated the show-business complex of Atlas Scenic Studio Ltd. in Bridgeport. Six of seven enormous buildings housing a wealth of wood, paint and some finished theater sets burned to the ground. Damages: about $2 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINCUS, JOAN T.
description: PINCUS-Joan T. Of Yonkers, NY. Corporate attorney and civic activist. Beloved wife of Sherman. Devoted mother of Harlan & Judith. Loving grandmother of Matthew Freud. Sister of Allan Turkheimer. Services Sunday 12:30 P.M., at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers. Contributions to Joan Pincus Scholarship in Political Science at Hunter College, C/O Sandra Radinsky, Director of Development, 695 Park Ave., New York, New York 10021.

title: Colleen Finn, Sean McDonald
description: Colleen Anne Finn, the daughter of Kathleen Haley of New York and James J. Finn of Middletown, N.J., was married yesterday to Sean Patrick McDonald, a son of Mary Ann McDonald of Lindenhurst, N.Y., and the late Laurence J. McDonald. The Rev. Eugene J. Prior performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HILDA G.
description: SCHWARTZ-Hilda G. Retired Supreme Court Justice on Mar. 18, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Herman N. Schwartz. Loving mother of John M. Schwartz. Devoted sister of Edith Smolen and the late Rose Weisman, Dr. Joseph A. Gaines and Mary Princer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81 St, Saturday 6-9PM. Funeral service Sunday, March 22, 11:30AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65 St.

title: Heavy Load of Beckett In a Rickety Vehicle
description: IF Didi, Gogo, Pozzo and Lucky are variations on everyman, it must be every playwright's dream to create a Godot of his own. Steve Tesich, who died in 1996 at 53, trod the Beckettian landscape in his penultimate play, ''On the Open Road,'' only to come up against a dead end. Still, there is the occasional stimulating stopover during his futile meanderings and boundless musings.

title: Kay Caffarra, Howard Epstein
description: Kay Ann Caffarra, a daughter of Jeanette and Edward Caffarra of West Orange, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Howard Scott Epstein, a son of Sheila Shor of Englishtown, N.J., and Arthur Epstein of North Andover, Mass. The Rev. Gerald Marchand will perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Lourdes in West Orange.

title: A San Francisco Treat
description: The best design is the kind that makes you look twice. How else would you see all the small, careful decisions that went into what looks like a single, authoritative one? Take this San Francisco house, which was designed by its owners, Richard Beard and Michael Booth. What strikes you first is its lanky, unassuming elegance. Its outside is the product of perfectly ordinary elements -- weathered-cedar siding and double-hung windows. But the windows are overscaled, making the narrow, three-story front seem taller than it really is, and setting the house apart from its densely packed neighbors on the hillside street.

title: Welcome to Your Closet: Employers Cut Costs With Smaller Offices
description: WHEN Karen Berman starts her new job this week as director of marketing and sales at Tempest Software in New York, she will be sitting in a tidy cubicle no bigger than the average bathroom. Not that she minds.

title: Dance; Daring and Driven to Succeed, Come What May
description: A FEW weeks ago Eliot Feld sat in his rehearsal studio near Union Square and cued the music for his newest dance, ''Simon Sez.'' As the rhythm kicked in and the choreographer looked on, three young dancers began to erect a scaffold as part of the piece. They hammered and climbed until the frame rose into a skylight's deep recess. In the end, only their ballet slippers remained visible.

title: Silent Year That Spoke Volumes For Reed
description: Keep your mouth shut, do what you are told and good things will happen to you. That has always been Rick Reed's thinking, and he has never wavered from it, even while he was bouncing around the minor leagues for the first 11 years of his career.

title: Don't Pan Decency
description: To the Editor:

title: Au Courant Cafes Touting Healthy Eating
description: TASTE is often the great divide between food that is good for you and food that is good. The bright, airy, upbeat Planet Cafes, in Great Neck (482-7717) and Woodbury (364-2910), are trying to bridge that gap. The two very 90's cafes, which bill themselves as ''healthy eateries,'' succeed some, but not all, of the time with their yogurt-dipped, no-fat-or-sugar-added, baked not fried, low-calorie-and-cholesterol fare.

title: Sports of The Times; The Bracket That Is Set Up for Revenge
description: TWO seasons ago, everyone figured the insatiable beast had been satisfied.

title: Lisa Truitt, Douglas Jehl
description: Lisa Marie Truitt, a supervising producer at National Geographic Television in Washington, was married yesterday to Douglas Duncan Jehl, the Cairo bureau chief of The New York Times. The Rev. Charles C. Anker, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Wayfarer in Carmel, Calif.

title: Outgrowing Your Parents at 8
description: If I had my way, I would have had Gary fixed when he was younger,'' Charity Blazek says, referring to her son. A solid, no-nonsense woman, she is sitting in the cramped living room of the apartment Gary shares with his wife and two children. ''They still did it back then. But the doctors told me that he was too old -- he was 10 or so -- and he would resent it.'' Gary Blazek, 45 years old and mentally retarded, nods in agreement.

title: Working on Civil Side Of County Bias Cases
description: IN an effort to free the county government of discrimination and unfair practices, County Executive Andrew J. Spano has directed Kathie E. Davidson, recently appointed Deputy County Attorney, to achieve on the civil side what the District Attorney's Office has done in criminal bias matters.

title: Lights, Camera, Web
description: The movie ''Cherry,'' filmed in Manhattan and Hoboken, N.J., doesn't have a chance of winning an Oscar tomorrow night (it's not finished, let alone nominated). But film buffs can learn a lot about the current state of independent film making by visiting the Making Cherry Home Page.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC; One Label's Strategy: Make It New, but Make it Pay
description: THE collapse of the classical-record industry, at least as it once functioned, has been widely reported. And it is a fact. In an oversaturated market, the number of successful new recordings of standard repertory is now limited to those few recordings of pure interpretive genius that can somehow stand out from the hundreds of recordings of the same pieces that preceded them.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Mara's Opposition to Labor Deal Could Swing the Vote
description: He is one of the most respected men in the National Football League. His calm demeanor conceals a fierce competitor who fights to keep the game healthy. Who is he? Well, he's not Commissioner Paul Tagliabue or a high-profile player.

title: The New York Hangover Is Not a Violent Outfit
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline yesterday about President Clinton's legal action in the Paula Jones lawsuit referred incorrectly in some copies to his lawyer Robert S. Bennett's description of the suit as ''garbage.'' Mr. Bennett used the word in a news conference, not in court papers.

title: Bernice Davidson Dies at 70; Curator at the Frick Collection
description: Bernice F. Davidson, a historian of Italian Renaissance art who served as research curator at the Frick Collection for more than four decades, died at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx on Feb. 24. She was 70 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Gas Station Goes To Make Way For High-Rise
description: The transition was startling. For years, the Mobil filling station at the southeast corner of First Avenue and 90th Street was a thriving corner of Islam. Pakistani station attendants would pray in corners on musallahs, or prayer mats, while South Asian cabdrivers -- mostly Pakistani, Indian and Bangladeshi -- used the station as a dispenser of coffee, gasoline and neighborly gossip.

title: Easy Rewiring Would Make Taxi Riders Buckle Up
description: To the Editor:

title: B. Santangelo, An Educator And Writer, 80
description: Betty L. Santangelo, a retired teacher and school administrator who was long active in Italian-American and other civic affairs, died on March 15 at the home of a daughter in Manhasset, N.Y. She was 80 and formerly lived in the Bronx.

title: Blacks Seek Focus on Africa Policy
description: The scene outside was pure Denver: a March blizzard. But inside City Hall, Mayor Wellington E. Webb was talking about Africa -- human rights, trade expansion, and debt relief.

title: For Albanian Immigrants, Kosovo Crisis Is Close to Home
description: For the last three weeks, Vehbi Bajrami, the editor of Illyria, an Albanian-American weekly newspaper, has been working until midnight, trying to get the latest news on the strife in the Serbian province Kosovo, where 90 percent of the population is ethnic Albanian. Since early March, an estimated 80 Kosovo Albanians, including women and children, have been killed in clashes with the Serbian police.

title: Rapid-Fire Inspections Planned for Iraq Sites
description: As Iraq and the United Nations position themselves for a critical test of the agreement that averted an American military attack in February, the head of the commission disarming Iraq says that he plans rapid-fire inspections of previously off-limits Presidential properties to determine what buildings will get spot inspections later -- with much less notice.

title: V. Galvani, 89, Designer of A-Bomb Trigger
description: Vincent J. Galvani, a chemical engineer who was in charge of designing the trigger mechanism for the first atomic bomb during World War II, died on Wednesday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Preservation Group Lists Top 10 Endangered Sites
description: Each year, Preservation New Jersey, a nonprofit advocacy organization, names 10 sites, or types of sites, that are the most likely to disappear if action is not taken. This year's, released last week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNTON, ERNEST A.
description: LYNTON-Ernest A. Age 71. Died peacefully at home on Wednesday, March 18. Survived by his wife Carla, two sons and their families: David and Jeanette, their children Ashley, Jared, Rachel and Aubrey, in Alpine, UT; Eric and Aviva, their children Liran, Adi and Tal, in Kfar Hanassi, Israel; also survived by the Lynton family in New York; and the Kaufmann family in Lausanne and the U.K. There will be gatherings at home on the evenings of Friday, March 20, Saturday, March 21, and on Sunday, March 22, from 6-9 PM. Funeral service will be held on Monday, March 23, at 10 A.M., at Temple Israel, Longwood Avenue and the Riverway, Boston. Instead of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to: Children's Defense Fund, 25 E Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20001; or Marlboro Music, 135 South 18th Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19103.

title: Fortune Society Gets Castle
