description: The castlelike building at 140th Street and Riverside Drive has stood empty for 18 years, as various plans to develop it have fallen by the wayside. Built as a Roman Catholic boarding school in 1910, it later served as a yeshiva. It has been used to shoot movies, including ''Basketball Diaries'' and ''Search and Destroy.''

title: Reviewing Census Data, Essex Counts Blessings as Well as People
description: Few jaws dropped over last week's Census Bureau report showing that Essex County is not sharing in the general population increases of its suburban neighbors, and, indeed, has lost more people than any other New Jersey county. The cause was simply the march of history, demographerssay.

title: 2 Women Receive Art Grants From Unknown Female Donor
description: ONE artist, Nancy Davidson, works in a TriBeCa studio, forming giant weather balloons into voluptuous visual puns. The other, Mary Lucier, based in Chelsea, edits mixed-media video installations late into the night. Both are teachers at Purchase College, and they have regularly looked to grants to support their expensive, highly acclaimed art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISKIN, ZELDA ''PEGGY'' GROSSMAN
description: DISKIN-Zelda ''Peggy'' Grossman. Mother of Marilyn Blanchard, grandmother of Dana Lieberman Hofstetter. Graveside service 11 AM, Monday, Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ.

title: A Professional Sorority, in the Most Creative Sense of the Word
description: IN September 1985, Rosalind Bloom and several female friends, who had recently finished their studies at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts and Moore College of Art and Design in Philadelphia, decided to form a group to share ideas about art. Assemblage, as the sisterhood came to call itself, was thus established.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERGENTIME, CHARLOTTE (LIEF)
description: MERGENTIME-Charlotte (Lief). died March 21, 1998. Devoted and beloved wife of Lester Troob and the late Lloyd Mergentime. Loving mother of Toni Levi and Lois Mergentime and mother-in-law John Slotwinski. Proud grandmother of Rebecca Levi and Kate Slotwinski. Dear sister of Marilyn Lief Kramberg and sister-in-law of Hal Kramberg. Cherished aunt of Steven, Kenneth and Ross Kramberg and Donald and Kenneth Morgan. Caring stepmother of Andrew, Charles and Daniel Troob. Inspiring teacher, author, founder of Reading Help Program of NYC School Volunteers. Funeral service Monday, March 23, 1998, 12 noon, at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Winter? Or How It Used to Be Known
description: THOSE who might have thought that the winter a year ago was the winter that wasn't can now readjust their thinking. The season that just drew to a more or less blase close was the real thing, the bona fide winter that wasn't, according to meteorological records.

title: Young Survivor Is Major Witness as Death Penalty Trial Opens in 2 Killings
description: Dalkeith McIntosh's road to his murder trial in Dutchess County Court here, and a possible death sentence, began on an August afternoon in Poughkeepsie two years ago.

title: When Hoop Dreams Became a Nightmare
description: When New York City was the hub of college basketball, fans crowded smoky old Madison Square Garden to watch powerhouse teams from the City College of New York, New York University and Long Island University. The Knicks were subservient to the college game; they fled uptown to the 69th Street Armory on Saturday nights.

title: Far From Vienna, A Lipizzaner Home
description: THIS summer Pam Capozzola, an artist, and her 12-year-old daughter Eva of Westhampton Beach will saddle and gently break their filly, Guiseppina. Since her birth 18 months ago, Guiseppina has been part of the baby herd at Rolling Green Farm in Manorville, where she has been given the freedom to prance about the field.

title: Television; An Old Hand's View of TV News: Not Good
description: ON March 22, 1948, a brash and inquisitive young man named Don Hewitt -- we can be sure he was brash and inquisitive, even then -- walked into CBS News's offices, at 15 Vanderbilt Avenue, above Grand Central Terminal in New York. Then 25, he had just quit his $100-a-week job writing captions for Acme Newspictures, a renowned worldwide photo service, to take $80 a week and join a fledgling enterprise scorned by most serious journalists.

title: An Island Tale: Past, Present and Future
description: About a month ago, a raised traffic triangle at the confusing intersection of Jane Street, Eighth Avenue and West Fourth Street suddenly appeared, surrounded by two layers of S-shaped bicycle racks to prevent anyone from standing on it. Some residents found it to be a strange and hostile construction (photo at right).

title: An Endangered Act
description: Of all the environmental statutes born in the early 1970's, the Endangered Species Act has been the most contentious, setting developers who think it infringes on property rights against conservationists who see it as an indispensable legal weapon against the destruction of threatened species and their habitat. As it happens, the act is celebrating its 25th anniversary, and is also up for legislative renewal. Congress's task is to make the act less adversarial while giving even greater protection to threatened species.

title: Restoration Murder
description: AN INSTANCE OF THE FINGERPOST By Iain Pears. 692 pp. New York: Riverhead Books. $27.

title: Profile of a Midwife Omitted Joys of Home Birth
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Grandpa Calder's Legacy in the Family
description: Alexander (Sandy) Rower, a grandson of Alexander Calder, takes a photograph off his corkboard. It's of three young men in a vaulted hall of the Miro Foundation in Barcelona, Spain. At Mr. Rower's elbow are Joan Punyet Miro and Manus Sweeney, one the grandson of the artist, the other the grandson of the eminent critic and curator James Johnson Sweeney.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Machine Beauty

title: Debate Centers On Definition Of Harassment
description: Over the last two months, the sexual accusations involving President Clinton have unleashed a torrent of debate about sexual harassment, and where to draw the legal line between behavior that is uncouth and that which is grounds for a lawsuit.

title: Green Enough for Envy
description: FORGET coffee. The real passion around Puget Sound is gardening -- which only stands to reason in a mild, moist maritime climate that combines the best of Japan and the British Isles.

title: The Nation; Looking Back At Jackson Hole
description: SINCE the start of the 1970's, an obscure group of economists and health specialists had been flogging notions of universal medical care to the deaf ears of legislators and Presidents.

title: How to Manufacture A Best Seller
description: Michael Maren states that ''MEG,'' the first of a two-book, $2 million dollar deal, was ''last year's multimillion-dollar flop.'' By whose definition?

title: Respecting the Root
description: SOON the trees will leaf out, providing summer-long bowers of cooling shade. Meanwhile, those who are cleaning up from winter's ravages have been raking the lawn. This activity often reveals how well, or not well, the tree roots are behaving. In many cases, they are scarring edges of the lawn, pushing up sidewalks and in some cases making a real nuisance of themselves. Yet with all their massiveness, roots form an essential part of any tree's life.

title: Charity Roast
description: The benefit was a $1,000-a-plate event that Alfred would have paid $50,000 a plate to skip. Poking at his overcooked salmon, he glumly contemplated the rest of the spring charity season: so many good causes, so many wretched meals. Tonight's dinner was for children with a gallbladder disease whose details did not go well with salmon. Alfred didn't mind when the kids were wheeled out to meekly thank the assembled millionaires, but why were they allowed to stay? Alfred did not dine with his own children, and they were healthy.

title: Cassell Dismisses Sitdown In Indiana
description: Sam Cassell was himself again today, laughing with teammates, smiling at questions that he knew were embarrassing to him and to the Nets.

title: JUSTIN TIME
description: Last year, while the spotlights were focused on Tiger Woods and hordes of new fans who had never been to a tournament turned out to watch him play, an unassuming young man from Texas was quietly commanding the attention and respect of longtime golf enthusiasts. Under conditions that daunted many of his more experienced colleagues, Justin Leonard walked off with the British Open, and his performance on the final day of the PGA, a duel to the finish with his friend Davis Love 3d (the winner), offered an object lesson in the art of hanging tough; with Woods, Love and others, he went to Spain and played on the American team for the Ryder Cup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWLER, WILLIAM R.
description: BOWLER-William R. Age 83. Died peacefully at home on Thursday, March 19, 1998. Beloved husband of Adele. Devoted father of William, Howard, David, Carolyn and Meredyth. Loving grandfather. His warmth, generosity and insight will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held at Wave Hill, Riverdale, NY, at 11 AM, Monday, March 30. In lieu of flowers, donations made in his memory to the Fortune Society, 39 West 19 St., New York, NY 10011, or Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter, 237 East 77 St., New York, NY 10021, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, JOEL M.
description: KAUFMAN-Joel M. Beloved and most wonderful brother of your sister, Libby Ladin. Adored uncle of Ellen (Paul), Jay, and Sally (Urie), and all the six grandnieces Abby, Evie, Jennifer, Iolanthe, Savitri and Noa.

title: Where the Silk Road Took a Detour
description: IN the mid 1980's, as political unrest spread throughout Asia, a wealth of medieval silk tapestries, brocades and embroideries were brought out of Tibet and sold in the West. Most were small squares of cloth, fragments used for centuries in Tibetan monasteries to cover books or sutras. Some larger pieces came from wall hangings or clothing -- boots, a child's suit and a purse.

title: UConn Gets Last Laugh As It Moves to Final 8
description: The University of Connecticut may never fret again about being snubbed in the seedings of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about a juggling club at the Ridge Street School in Rye Brook misstated the telephone number. It is 939-7146.

title: Innocent Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mission: A Political Role for Everyone
description: IN a world in which politics increasingly is viewed by the lay person as an us-versus-them proposition, there is an experiment in democracy in Winsted designed to put the people back in the process.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: March 15-21; McKinney Gets a Demotion
description: Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney, once the Army's top enlisted soldier, was sentenced to a one-grade reduction in pay and a reprimand for his conviction on a single count of obstruction of justice stemming from a court-martial in which he was cleared of sexually harassing six servicewomen.

title: Strong Stuff
description: Shortly after 9 o'clock on the morning of Dec. 3, 1997, the 14 members of the Governor's Task Force on Driving While Intoxicated and Vehicular Homicide took their seats in a hearing room in the Louisiana State Capitol Building in Baton Rouge. The issue before them: whether the state should add a provision to Louisiana's drinking law that would prohibit 18- to 20-year-olds from entering bars. The law currently allows them into bars, even while it prohibits them from buying or drinking alcohol. The law is widely flouted, however, and most of the task-force members -- highway officials, state legislators, local sheriffs, a representative from Mothers Against Drunk Driving (MADD) -- were united on the need to change what they saw as a loophole. The loophole, they believed, was encouraging college students to spend their nights carousing rather than studying. They also felt it was contributing to the carnage on the state's highways. In 1995, Louisiana had 883 traffic fatalities, of which slightly more than half were alcohol-related -- the third highest rate in the country.

title: Kay Coltoff, 61; Aided Others With Breast Cancer
description: Kay Coltoff, a social worker and educator who used her own illness to make things easier for breast cancer survivors, died on March 5 at her home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. She was 61 and had been a professional-development counselor at Hunter College.

title: VIEWPOINT; The Euro Can Complement the Dollar
description: NOW that Germany, France and Italy have all passed the key budgetary test for European monetary union, the creation of the euro at the beginning of 1999 seems virtually guaranteed. Naturally, the birth of this new currency is raising questions about the future role of the dollar. Its outlook is no academic matter.

title: Starks's Start Reveals Club's Urgency
description: It is enough of a risk to delicately prod a team that seems one nudge from becoming rubble without putting a potential wrecking ball on the floor.

title: Respecting the Root, Foundation of the Tree
description: SOON the trees will leaf out, providing summer-long bowers of cooling shade. Meanwhile, those who are cleaning up from winter's ravages have been raking the lawn. This activity often reveals how well, or not well, the tree roots are behaving. In many cases, they are scarring edges of the lawn, pushing up sidewalks and in some cases making a real nuisance of themselves. Yet with all their massiveness, roots form an essential part of any tree's life.

title: Sisterhood Is Historical
description: A CENTURY OF WOMEN

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: STENDHAL

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Missile Crisis Revisited

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKASHOK, LILLIAN G.
description: LUKASHOK-Lillian G. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Martin and the late E. David. Wonderful grandmother to Bill and Janet and devoted greatgrandmother to David and Owen. Fond sister of Frances Horowitz and the late Meyer Ginsburg. Funeral service Monday, 11:15AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Fancy Shelter for Dogs Is Deemed Fit for Homeless Humans
description: In a twist in dealing with homelessness, an animal shelter is volunteering to provide overnight lodging for homeless adults alongside the dogs.

title: Habitats/Manhattan; When Being a Lawyer Is a 2-Edged Sword
description: ALISON MAREK and Charles J. Glasser Jr. did not so much leave New York as take a short sabbatical to Maine. But when they returned to the city in December after a year and a half in Portland, life had changed. Not only were they different -- no longer students willing to accept a bohemian existence in Greenwich Village -- they were viewed differently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADSEN, VIGGO HOLM
description: MADSEN-Viggo Holm, longtime resident of Albertson, New York died at Doniphan, Missouri, March 20, 1998, after a long illness, at the age of 72. A well-known artist and art educator, he taught art at Roslyn High School for 22 years and was Adjunct Professor of Art at Nassau Community College for 28 years. His prints were exhibited widely in this country and Europe. He is survived by his widow, Lois, son Kirk and daughter Karen and three grandchildren. Memorial gifts may be made to Anderson University, 1100 East 5th Street, Anderson, Indiana 46015 to be used for needy art students.

title: Streetscapes/William Van Alen; An Architect Called the 'Ziegfeld of His Profession'
description: THE Art Deco Chrysler Building at 42d Street and Lexington Avenue is a touchstone for New York City architecture. Yet its architect, William Van Alen, remains little known.

title: Guiding Spirits
description: JANE DOHERTY gets one call a week, sometimes more, especially in spring and fall, when, she said, ''spirit activity is at its peak.''

title: Utah Upsets Defending Champion Arizona, and It's Not Even Close
description: Andre Miller walked through the corridors of the Arrowhead Pond today, wearing a smile and a slightly askew baseball hat that made him appear like an aging member of Our Gang. Protruding from underneath the hat was a piece of twine, snipped only moments earlier from the the basket at the east end of the arena.

title: Oscar Doesn't Live Here Anymore
description: ''CHAPTER ONE: He adored New York City. He idolized it all out of proportion. Uh, no. Make that: He romanticized it all out of proportion. Yeah. To him, no matter what the season was, this was still a town that existed in black and white and pulsated to the great tunes of George Gershwin. Uh, no. Let me start this over again.

title: THOSE FABULOUS FEMBLES
description: Ruling Palm Beach society wasn't enough. Behind the walls of Mal de Mer, the Fembles were setting new styles--in resort wear as in the art of living. Glimpses from a fictional family album, 1924 to 1934.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASIN, GLICKMAN, EDYTHE
description: CHASIN - GLICKMAN - Edythe. (Tibby). Passed away peacefully at the age of ninety-two at her home in Florida in the devoted care of Mary Peters. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Chasin and David Glickman. Devoted mother of Arthur Chasin, Suzanne Wajntal and Barbara Scotch. Loving grandmother of four and greatgrandmother of nine. Graveside service will be on Sunday, March 22, 1998 at 12:45, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI. Tibby's generosity of spirit and deed and loyalty to her family along with her sharp sense of humor will be missed by those who loved her dearly. Shiva will observed at the home of Barbara Scotch, 300 E. 51 Street, NYC on Sunday, 5-10 PM.

title: Only Their Hairdressers (And the World) Know
description: ANNA WINTOUR, the editor of Vogue, which has given both Ivana Trump and Lisa-Marie Presley radical makeovers to reintroduce them to a quizzical public, may have put it best: ''If you're going to make accusations against the President, you had better have a good hairdresser.''

title: Groups Ask Permission To Revive Hemp Farms
description: A coalition of agricultural, commercial and environmental groups is pushing the Clinton Administration to overturn the prohibition on cultivation of all Cannabis strains so those that lack the intoxicating properties of marijuana can again be grown.

title: LEISURE CLASS
description: Relaxed. Playful. Carefree. As winter's rigors thaw, spring allows a certain unwinding that men's wear designers have taken to the limit this season. Suits with sandals? Drawstring pants? Sheer shirts? If some -- or all -- of the above are not for you, take heart. There is a strong alternative in the form of casual resort wear inspired by the sporty looks of Palm Beach and Miami in their glory days. Defined by a truly sophisticated sense of style, these jaunty classics are neither extreme nor boring, but are simply one of the best looks for spring and summer weekends, or even for weekdays at the office, where standards for men's style have relaxed considerably in recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, ESTELLE
description: LEWIS-Estelle. On March 19, 1998 in Hollywood, FL. Beloved mother of Linda Lindenbaum. Adored grandmother of Erica Tishman and Laurie Lindenbaum Horne, loving great-grandmother of Adam, Stuart and Julia Tishman and Sarah Horne. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society. Funeral services private.

title: Images of an Economy Devouring the Poor
description: THE video welcoming visitors to Houston on the hotel channel confides that the man who built the Astrodome had a copy of it at home and one bedroom dedicated to P. T. Barnum, another with a bed resting on a calliope. The city's attractions are sometimes unique. Fotofest is one. It's the only international biennial gathering of photographers, curators, critics and exhibitions -- 70 shows this year -- in this country.

title: Tomatoes? Farmers Consider Growing Jersey Echinacea
description: Medicinal herbs and natural products that can help fight disease or just make a person feel better are all the rage now, and the New Jersey Farm Bureau is encouraging local farmers to cash in.

title: Backtalk; Athletes Taught at Home Find Niche in Public
description: Six years ago, Tom Sanders bought some reversible basketball jerseys, loaded up a van of 14-year-olds and begged small Christian schools and reformatories to give his guys a game. One of the players was his son. All of players were schooled at home, and together they learned about teamwork over 14 games.

title: The Primal Bug And Its Rituals
description: LOVE it? Loathe it? Laugh at it? This much is certain: The New Beetle is a memory machine. Judging by the people who gave thumbs-up signs on the road or stopped to chat in parking lots, it brings back the warm and fuzzy past.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: California Agency Ponders Bypassing Health Groups
description: The state of California is considering circumventing its long-entrenched health maintenance organizations and contracting directly with groups of physicians and hospitals for medical care for its 1,024,000 employees, a state health benefits official told a weekend meeting of physicians and health system executives.

title: Big Macs to Go
description: Golden Arches East

title: Bigger Amounts May Bring Bigger Risks
description: PERHAPS the most aggressively promoted deal in home equity now is the ''125 percent'' loan, a financial product that seems to defy the usual laws of collateral.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHACTER, CHARLES BANKS
description: SHACTER-Charles Banks. Happy Birthday, precious Dad and Papa. You are guardian angel to us all. Love, Carol

title: No Krantz, Koontz or Coffee Bars
description: GABI FRIEDMAN stood transfixed before a towering wall of books. Clutching a work of feminist history and the essays of Walter Benjamin, she explained why she had come from New Haven, where she is studying law, to Labyrinth Books on Morningside Heights. ''I heard about this place up at Yale,'' said Ms. Friedman, 28. ''People were saying there is finally a good bookstore in New York.''

title: Are You Game?
description: It's true that the drag-name game, which combines the name of one's first pet with one's mother's maiden name, forces us to break frame and assume new and challenging identities (''Are You Game?'' by Guy Trebay, March 1). My own is Pepito Kravetz, a moniker that crosses almost every boundary and suggests a person who just wants to have fun and maybe an antacid. As a 5-year-old, I played the game on my own pet. Deeply disappointed that my black cat wasn't a she, I coped by naming him Marilyn Midnight, unwittingly giving new meaning to the phrase, ''Look what the cat dragged in.''

title: War of the Paintbrushes; Near the Metropolitan, Police Confiscate Art Daily
description: For Zhang Wei, the plaza outside the Metropolitan Museum of Art has always been sacred space.

title: A Family's Journey, Literal and Otherwise
description: AS the only black family on Dean Street in Brooklyn in 1950, the Crumps had to leave $10 for the postman to get mail in the morning ''like white folks do.'' Where was the promised land for ''colored folks from the country''?

title: Rachel Abrams and Ian Pear
description: TWO summers ago, Rachel Schulder Abrams and Ian Daniel Pear set off across the country in a rented Winnebago they nicknamed the Chariot of Fire.

title: Out of Servitude, Deaf Mexicans Languish in Limbo of Motel
description: Eight months after they walked into a police station seeking relief from bosses who kept them as virtual slaves, 48 deaf Mexican men and women are still being held by Federal authorities in a motel in Queens while the case they set in motion winds through the courts.

title: A Dutch Latecomer's Moment Of Possible Transformations
description: Mike Van Diem likes to dwell on his anxieties about movie making to explain why, at 39, his career as a director is only just getting under way. Yet in his first feature film, this slim good-natured Dutchman showed anything but insecurity. He took on the challenge of adapting a classic Dutch novel, Ferdinand Bordewijk's ''Character,'' then raised the stakes by altering the plot to suit his needs. At the very least, he risked upsetting Bordewijk fans.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 22, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Providing an Accompaniment For Unaccompanied Bach
description: SO, what's the deal with Yo-Yo Ma these days? A dispassionate observer might assume that Mr. Ma, as the most bankable star at Sony Classical, is contractually bound to lend his lush cello sound to any project the crossover-obsessed label can dream up: jazzy duets with Bobby McFerrin, faux-Appalachian fiddle tunes with Mark O'Connor, a Piazzolla tango album and Tan Dun's symphonic celebration of Hong Kong's reabsorption into China are among his latest outings. Such an observer might be surprised to learn that most of these ventures were initiated not by Sony but by Mr. Ma.

title: Canines on Line At a Web Site Store
description: You won't be able to bring your schnauzer to the Dog Lovers Bookshop starting April 1, because it will exist only in cyberspace. The owners, Margot Rosenberg and Bern Marcowitz, will close the store at 9 West 31st Street, just west of Fifth Avenue. They are expanding their on-line store, at http://www.dogbooks.com, which they opened in 1996. ''It was very difficult to maintain both things, and something's got to give,'' Mr. Marcowitz said.

title: Nowhere Man
description: Lowenthal's quest for ''connection'' with his Jewish roots at Al Ghriba fell only a few miles short. I recently visited the nearby village of Hara Kebira, where I encountered a poor but thriving Jewish community with more than a dozen active synogagues, a bustling yeshiva and residents who greeted me warmly in Hebrew.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a day-old sports page appeared in some copies yesterday in place of page C3, which carried articles about the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@ nytimes.com. (Include a postal return address.)

title: Some Natural-Fiber Floor Coverings
description: MENTION soft floor coverings and most people think of carpets or rugs made of fibers like wool, cotton, silk, or synthetics like rayon or acrylic. Now, however, soft floor coverings made from natural grass and plant fibers are gaining in popularity. Called ''natural-fiber'' floor coverings, they are typically woven from coir, jute, rush, seagrass or sisal fibers (note: Many manufacturers and decorators use the term ''natural-fiber'' only for grasses and plant fibers, although, strictly speaking wool, cotton, and silk should also be included).

title: William M. Haenszel, 87; Tracked U.S. Cancer Cases
description: William M. Haenszel, an epidemiologist at the National Cancer Institute who set up the first national system to track cases of cancer and their possible causes, died on March 13 at his home in Wheaton, Ill. He was 87.

title: Cherylyn Carr, Frederic Pratt
description: Cherylyn Carr, a staff lawyer for cable television and new media at ABC Inc. in Manhattan, and Frederic Pratt, a senior staff lawyer at the Legal Aid Society in Brooklyn, were married yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Florence Pert, a Dutch Reformed minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Word for Word / Dr. Spock; Time to Change the Baby Advice: Evolution of a Child-Care Icon
description: DR. BENJAMIN SPOCK died last week at 94, just as his publisher, Pocket Books, was putting the final touches on a new edition of ''Baby and Child Care,'' the how-to manual whose phenomenal success placed him in the pantheon of one-name global icons like Einstein and Elvis. Like the 1946 original and the revisions of 1957, 1968, 1976, 1985 and 1992, the seventh edition, due out May 2 and co-written by Dr. Steven J. Parker, tries to keep up with the times, discussing pornographic Web sites, gay parents and bonded resin to fight tooth decay. But the book's optimistic credo (''Trust yourself. You know more than you think you do.'') has not changed, and a comparison of the oldest and newest editions shows that many passages have passed through the generations virtually intact.

title: For the Defense of a President, a Street Fighter
description: Robert S. Bennett, the President's lawyer, smiles proudly in confirming that when he was a strapping Brooklyn lad over four decades ago, he knocked on the door of a boy who had bullied his younger brother, Bill, and summarily decked him with a punch.

title: Artists Working Like Artists On Quilts
description: IN a sort of new renaissance, historic quilts -- documents of fabrics, designs and customs of the past -- have been adapted as a medium of contemporary design.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Eugene O'Neill's play ''Ah, Wilderness!'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center referred incorrectly to an Oscar Wilde character in ''The Importance of Being Earnest.'' It is Lady Bracknell's daughter, Gwendolyn, who likes to read her diary when she travels, not Lady Bracknell.

title: The Positives and Negatives of a Pro League in Progress
description: Major League Soccer seems to have two developments working for it and two working against it as the league's third season gets under way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUMARKIN, CAROLYN KUNST
description: TUMARKIN-Carolyn Kunst. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Beloved mother and grandmother. An active civic and human rights leader and advocate, she will be missed. Services Monday, 11 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Public Radio Offers Substance, Not Style
description: To the Editor:

title: 15 Hate Groups in Region, Monitoring Organization Says
description: Last summer in Smithtown, on Long Island, a hooded man calling himself Reverend Frank announced that he was New York State's first Ku Klux Klan Grand Dragon in decades. About the same time, a librarian in Berlin, N.J., found printed diatribes from a different anti-Semitic and anti-black group tucked into history books dealing with Adolf Hitler. In Connecticut, fliers from a white supremacist organization were posted in the West Haven City Hall.

title: INSIDE
description: MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 5/

title: The Other Side Of Parsonage Allowances
description: To the Editor:

title: Q. & A.
description: Board Can Set Rules On Its Own

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAKIN, JEANETTE
description: WAKIN-Jeanette. Distinguished scholar, superb teacher, and beloved colleague. The students, faculty, and staff of Columbia University's School of General Studies and Religion Department mourn her loss. Her legacy will endure through the students she trained with such care and affection.

title: Reds Are Following The Cleveland Plan
description: The Cincinnati Reds will open the season with one of the five lowest payrolls in the major leagues. They also will open the season picked by many to finish last in their division.

title: 'Remaking Eden'
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Another Day in Paradise By Eddie Little. Viking. $22.95.

title: In an Ancient Capital, a Trove of Pebbles, Artfully Arranged
description: Of all the world's classical art forms, the mosaic is among those that maintain the greatest hold on the human imagination. One of the best places in the world to see the heights to which this art soared in its Golden Age is the Hatay Archeological Museum in Antakya, a provincial town in southern Turkey that, in the days when it was known as Antioch, was one of the world's most important cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRESSLER, REBA
description: DRESSLER-Reba. Beloved wife of the late Sidney Dressler, passed away on March 18. Cherished and devoted mother of Leonard and Juliette Dressler and Phyllis and Efrom Lebow, and dear sister of Mortimer Chrein. She was adored by her grandchildren and great grandchildren. We will all miss her very much.

title: Galina Ulanova Is Dead at 88; A Revered Bolshoi Ballerina
description: Galina Ulanova, whose uncanny blend of unabashed emotionalism and lyrical restraint made her one of the greatest dancers of the 20th century, died here today. She was 88.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE MAN WHO STOLE

title: U.S. Is Waffling on Religious Freedom in China
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Deals In West Village
description: DROVERS TAP ROOM +

title: 'But Darling, It's You'
description: THE Oscars are here, and Hollywood is in full frivolous bloom. Wolfgang Puck is engaged in all-night souffle-making sessions at Spago. Experts who specialize in plucking famous eyebrows are booked around the clock in their suites at the Four Seasons hotel. And the boulevards of Beverly Hills are humming at high pitch with talk of Hollywood's most important power game: who's wearing what.

title: The High-Technology Toll: E-Z'er, But Is It Smarter?
description: When New Jersey awarded a $488 million contract to a Nebraska-based company this month to install and operate the electronic toll system, E-Z Pass, on the state's toll roads, state Transportation Commissioner John J. Haley Jr. billed it as a ''customer service initiative.''

title: Victoria Winter, Jonathan Dienst
description: Victoria Jean Winter, a lawyer, and Jonathan Dienst, a television news reporter, both in New York, were married last evening by Cantor Dan Rous at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Big Start Poses Challenge for a Focused Fund
description: IT was the most successful mutual fund launch in history -- if you believe that bigger is indeed better. Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter introduced its Competitive Edge Fund ''Best Ideas'' Portfolio on March 9, after an initial public offering that raised $1.3 billion from the firm's customers.

title: A Ski Area Without the Extremes
description: WITH the white peaks of the Wasatch Mountains rising behind him, Onno Wieringa, manager of the Alta Ski Lifts Company, stood in the middle of the road leading to this venerable resort and politely, but firmly, stopped every car trying to get in.

title: The Nation: Pride and Prejudice; The South's History Rises, Again and Again
description: LIKE an anthology of short stories threaded by a common theme, a confluence of events in Mississippi last week provided a poignant test of William Faulkner's wry observation that ''the past is never dead; it's not even past.''

title: Sunday View; The Hills Are Alive Again, and It's Quite O.K.
description: GIVE in, cry uncle. It's time to admit that ''The Sound of Music'' is a de facto classic. When the show originally opened in New York in 1959, the critics were dismayed to find that Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d had turned their backs on the modern American musical they pioneered. Instead of producing something as experimental (for them) as ''Allegro,'' a 1947 flop, they came up with an operetta so sugar-frosted that its Nazis would not have looked out of place as tiny attendants on a wedding cake.

title: Giants Standing Tall: Chagall and Courbet
description: Chagall

title: Q&A/Michael W. Hovey; Pursuit of Peaceful Resolution to Conflict
description: WHEN Michael W. Hovey's number came up for the draft, he felt he did not want to fight in Vietnam so he joined the Navy. Then after visiting a museum in Nagasaki a few years later and seeing evidence of how devastating the atomic bomb was he knew he could not fight in Vietnam or anywhere else.

title: Cameras Won't Help Many Abused Women
description: To the Editor:

title: El Nino's Wrath Felt In California Parks, Too
description: The recent El Nino-generated storms that caused flooding and mudslides across California did not spare the state's natural attractions. In fact, some parks suffered so much damage from rain that they have had to be closed or extensively repaired.

title: Blade Runner
description: The Ultimate Rush

title: For Iraq, U.N. Plans Rapid-Fire Searches
description: With another crucial test looming between Iraq and the United Nations, the head of the commission disarming Iraq said he plans rapid-fire inspections of previously off-limits Presidential properties. That will determine which buildings will get spot inspections later, with less notice. And the new procedures could set off a new conflict.

title: Introduction
description: Many readers of Michael Lewis's article on Silicon Valley applauded the tech revolution, but criticized both ''the greed'' that propels it and the exclusion of women from much of it. The March 1 issue also drew fire for a preponderance of articles emphasizing men.

title: Standing Up for Adam Purple; The City Turns On Its Living Treasures
description: To the Editor:

title: Journeys of Le Cocktail
description: LIKE any genuine form of cultural expression, the cocktail is complex. It's a purely American invention, born of necessity, inspiration and sheer playfulness. A little like jazz, it subverted the European traditions that nourished it and laid down a new, flexible set of rules, which, in a further paradox, captured the European imagination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, ANNE
description: SUSSMAN-Anne, on March 17th, 1998, of Boca Raton, Fla. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Joan and Ronald Berkley, Madeline and Robert Kaplan. Cherished grandmother of Gordon and Janet, Glenn and Aymie, Gayle, Peter, Larry and Janine, Jeffrey and Jenifer. Also survived by eight adoring great-grandchildren. Services were held Friday.

title: Pupsterity Served
description: Fernanda Gilligan, a student at Skidmore College, isn't ready to own a puppy. So at Christmas her stepfather-to-be, Kirk Henckels, master of Tattoo, a beloved 12-year-old Jack Russell terrier, gave Ms. Gilligan an unusual gift: futures on Tattoo's pups.

title: Rutgers Slows It Down, To No Avail, Against Vols
description: As her team awaited top-ranked Tennessee tonight, C. Vivian Stringer had a decision to make about the Lady Vols' preference for drag-strip basketball. Should Rutgers play with its feet on the accelerator, or on the brakes? Should it play with checkered-flag abandon, or with crossing-guard caution?

title: At the Ramparts of the 'Year 2000 Problem'
description: IT'S hardly news that the end of the world is only a couple of years away. People have been predicting the Apocalypse in the year 2000, ever since it so annoyingly failed to happen in the year 1000.

title: Africa Enduring Rebirth Awaits Clinton's Arrival
description: On Sunday, when President Clinton begins the longest foreign trip of his Presidency, a 12-day visit to sub-Saharan Africa, he will be touring a region very different from the one last traveled by an American President when Jimmy Carter came to this country 20 years ago.

title: Warming Up For Oscars With Tales Of Hoffman
description: THERE were no envelopes, no naked male statuettes and no weirdly choreographed musical interludes. But the American Museum of the Moving Image's salute to Dustin Hoffman on Thursday night did have a few things in common with the Academy Award ceremonies: Tom Cruise was wearing a tuxedo, there were a lot of film clips, and the evening seemed to go on forever.

title: Wow, Man, It's Like a Flashback
description: FROM the disco 70's, through the junk-bond 80's and into the cigar-chomping 90's, a long, strange trip it has surely been. But there are still a few outposts where flower power prevails and tie-dyed T-shirts are always in style.

title: At Giants Stadium, Renovations From the Ground Up
description: TO every sport, there is a season, but maintenance goes on year-round.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/City Island; A Waterside Village, Part of the Bronx
description: ON a gray day recently, the talk on City Island, the half-mile-long marine village off Pelham Bay Park in the north Bronx was of an approaching storm. The last big storm, in 1992, damaged scores of small boats, knocked tree limbs through the roofs of several houses and submerged the island's only link to the mainland, the bridge to the park.

title: Sports of The Times; Commissioner of the People Shouts: 'We're No. 4 1/2! We're No. 4 1/2!'
description: THIS is the way a sports event should feel: People should congregate in urban bars and cafes, just outside the gates, drinking their vino or their cerveza or their espresso. They should enter through common portals, elbow to elbow, arguing and exulting together, the $2 patron and the $1 patron.

title: Little Buyers
description: At allowance time, when Maxine Meade hands her 10-year-old daughter, Louise, her weekly $20, there's only one store where Louise wants to go: Marsha D. D. ''I guess the days of going to the Gap are over,'' said Mrs. Meade, who lives on the Upper East Side.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 2 about romances between South Koreans and foreigners misstated the nationality of former President Syngman Rhee's wife, Francesca. A reader's E-mail message on Wednesday pointed out that she was Austrian, not American.

title: The Little Creepy Crawlers That Will Eat You In the Night
description: What about the young women who dream about entrepeneurship? As encouraging as Lewis's cover story is to those who aspire to find funds and riches in Silicon Valley, and despite his mention of Barbara Hayes-Roth, where are the opportunities for women? While reporting reality is important, so is asking important questions about the future.

title: After Attack, Guatemala Steps Up Security Efforts
description: ALARMED that the widely publicized rape and robbery of a group of American college students in January is scaring away foreign tourists and hampering efforts to rebuild the economy, the Guatemalan Government has begun a wide-ranging campaign to improve security for foreign visitors.

title: The Group
description: PRIDE By Lorene Cary. 321 pp.New York: Nan A. Talese/ Doubleday. $23.95.

title: A New Baseball Strategy: Latin-American Bargains
description: Sandy Alomar Jr. hits a home run that wins last summer's All-Star Game. Edgar Renteria drives in the winning run in the 11th inning of the seventh game of the World Series last October. Pedro Martinez is voted the National League's best pitcher for 1997, later becoming the highest-paid player in baseball history.

title: WINDOW DRESSING
description: As distinct as fingerprints are to individuals, each of Manhattan's top men's stores has its own unique image. The emphasis may vary from season to season -- gray may give way to brown, stripes may yield to plaids -- but there is always a certain continuity in the style of each store. Here, in typical New York settings, we present the way eight stores see themselves this season. If the way you see yourself coincides with the look of a particular store, this may be a good way to get started on your spring wardrobe.

title: Changing Fortunes: Hubris and Humility as U.S. Waxes and Asia Wanes
description: Judging from today's economic landscape, it must have been a few million years ago when a Japanese member of Parliament named Shintaro Ishihara offered a few pointers for the West.

title: Number of Concussions Has the N.H.L. in a Search for Answers
description: During a National Hockey League game last week between the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim and the Philadelphia Flyers, a boy in the audience got his 15 seconds of fame on national television. A camera for the ESPN2 cable network showed him holding two plastic hockey-player dolls. One figure was a miniature replica of Eric Lindros, the big, tough captain of the Flyers who plays an aggressive, collision-based style. The other was of Paul Kariya, the smallish captain of the Ducks, whose playing style features swift skating and smooth moves.

title: Bradi Harrison and David Nathan
description: Bradi Lynn Harrison, the director of beauty advertising at Town & Country magazine in New York, was married last evening to David Lawrence Nathan, the New York regional promotion director for Universal Records. Rabbi Cory Weiss performed the ceremony at the Union League Club in New York.

title: Mounds of Petunias, Minus the Pinching
description: WERE it not for the pinching, petunias would have everything going for them.

title: Scudder's European Emissary
description: FOR Carol L. Franklin, Park Avenue has it all over Ouagadougou. As a young woman, Ms. Franklin toyed with the notion of a career in the Foreign Service. During high school, she spent a year as an exchange student in Nicaragua. At Smith College, she majored in French literature, spending her junior year in Paris studying at the Sorbonne and l'Institut d'Etudes Politiques.

title: Meet the (New) Beetles
description: IT is a head turner, a traffic stopper, a conversation starter. Or, as Joseph Castagna, a mortgage banker, said when he saw one in a 7-Eleven parking lot in Manorville, N.Y., ''It's like the old one on hormones.''

title: Going for the California Look In Design Tiles
description: Tiles: A Refined Selection, opened its fourth store three weeks ago, venturing into midtown at 227 East 59th Street between Second and Third Avenues, around the corner from the Decoration and Design Building. The owner, Bruce Levitt, has tended to open stores in neighborhoods with many design companies.

title: Emergency, With a Co-Star
description: WHEN the nonstop chiming began at 7:45 P.M. on that December Saturday in my room at the Tawaraya Inn in Kyoto, I assumed that once again my travel alarm was going off at the wrong time. As I slid open a lightweight screen and began to scramble for the clock, the phone rang. A high voice on the other end was animated verging on polite panic. Knowing no Japanese, I could not discern a word. The urgency alone was enough to get me to run into the hallway. Besides, what had earlier been an enticing grilling smell from the kitchen had grown too strong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTMAN, HELEN
description: WALTMAN - Helen. Beloved mother of Stephen and Gillian Waltman and Toni Somerstein. Adored grandmother of Scott Somerstein, Belinda and Michael Waltman. She was a great lady.

title: A Funny Thing Happened
description: LAUGHING MATTERS

title: In Westbury, Report Card Concerns
description: LOUISE QUIJANO, a 10th grader at Westbury High School, is not concerned about having to pass the English Regents examination next year to receive her high school diploma. Even though last year 26 percent of the students at Westbury who took the English Regents passed with scores of 65 or higher, Louise is confident, she said, that with her teachers' help she will be well prepared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, NORMAN
description: FEINBERG-Norman. His lifelong friends and their families mourn the wrenching loss of one who has been a true brother to all of us. The memory of his loving kindness, friendship and caring will sustain us and we shall miss him every day of our lives. The Amici

title: Does Vatican Holocaust Report Go Far Enough?; Infallible Popes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sequel at Purchase
description: DO concertgoers ever wonder what happened to the duck that was swallowed alive by the wolf in ''Peter and the Wolf,'' the fairy tale by Prokofiev? Or if Peter had any second thoughts about depleting the wildlife population?

title: Bowling for Dollars
description: ASKED how Atlantic City Hilton executives had snatched away the Bowl-for-Kids Executive Challenge trophy from the Showboat casino team last year, John (King Pin) Licciardello did not hesitate. Hilton's star bowler, who supervises data processing for the casino, attributed the stunning upset to the coconut head.

title: The View From/Chappaqua; Long Past School Age And Immersed in Music
description: IT had to be one of if not the most -- esoteric Sunday afternoon gatherings in the county. On a blustery, soaking day, a small group of adults all past school age voluntarily left their homes and drove through wind and rain to gather at the Amadeus Conservatory of Music here. Dressed in blue jeans or skirts with many wearing interesting handmade jewelry pieces, they earnestly addressed no less a topic than ''Music and the Intellect.''

title: Meals for the Elderly: A Growing Need
description: THE setting was the Pawcatuck Neighborhood Center, and the stuffed cabbage, mashed potatoes and carrots were served in plastic-covered containers. But for the 57 elderly from the Stonington area, gathered for lunch and bingo, the event was reminiscent of a family get-together.

title: Without Conductors, G Trains Stand for 'Ghost,' Critics Say
description: William E. Chambers had planned to spend his retirement writing mystery novels. Instead, he spends most of it writing letters -- to city agencies, politicians, anyone who will pay attention, and those who won't. A lifetime Greenpoint resident, he and his wife, Marie, have become full-time activists. They are fighting the Transit Authority's decision to allow ''one-person train operation'' on the G line, Greenpoint's main subway connection to other boroughs.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Using a Reverse Mortgage to Purchase a New Home
description: EARLIER this year, Robert H. Nicklas, a 72-year-old retired tax lawyer, sold his three-bedroom Tudor in Hempstead to move to Seaford in southern Delaware with his companion and one-time business partner, Constance Driscoll.

title: Sunday, March 22, 1998; WILL RUN FOR CASH
description: Tom Rawles, a candidate in the Arizona Republican gubernatorial primary, came up with a bold plan to reform campaign financing: he decided to pay himself to run. An attorney, Rawles put himself on the payroll of his own campaign at $4,000 a month. Justification for this radical departure from standard practice? Rawles argued that ''if you're not independently wealthy, it's almost impossible to run for office anymore -- unless of course you're the incumbent and the taxpayers are paying you.'' Nice talk, but apparently that's all it was. Earlier this month, Rawles dropped out, acknowledging that he couldn't win. One bright spot: he'd already collected $36,000 in salary. Not bad for a guy who never collected a vote.

title: The Nuke Of the 90's
description: Although Roger Altman's apocalyptic metaphor strikes me as a bit too vivid, his arguments are fundamentally correct (''The Nuke of the 90's,'' March 1). The viability of the Asian economy and the long-term stability of the international marketplace are tied tightly to the International Monetary Fund. In Asia, continued hemorrhaging would harm U.S. interests, not the least of which is maintaining export markets for American goods and agricultural products.

title: Does Vatican Holocaust Report Go Far Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rachel Horowitz, Gregory Weiss
description: Rachel Hope Horowitz, a daughter of Janet and Leonard I. Horowitz of Westport, Conn., was married last evening to Gregory Nathaniel Weiss, the son of Caren and Roger J. Weiss of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: What Public? Whose Use?
description: IF it were just a question of public relations, it would be no contest. On one side of Columbia Place is a casino belonging to Donald Trump. On the other are Vera Coking, a widow in a three-story building that she ran for decades as a boarding house; Clare and Vincent Sabatini, proprietors of a little Italian restaurant, and Peter Banin, a gold merchant who tends his shop into the wee hours, just himself and a small gray cat named Junior.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Blueprints, Models? A Virtual Image Does the Trick
description: A LONG wooded, winding Stillwater Road, a few discreet signs point the way to a builder's open house at Westover Woods, a new development of 27 high-end homes in Stamford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLAMOWITZ, BEATRICE
description: SCHLAMOWITZ-Beatrice, R.N. Dearly beloved wife of the late Dr. Isadore, cherished mother of Margery Strauss, Kathryn Venet, Daniel Venet and his wife, Claudia. Loving stepmother of Frances (Steve) Grodzinsky, Merry Burke, (John), and Patty (Larry) Eckstein. Adoring Baba of Casey and Arleigh Venet, Mark Grodzinsky, Rachel Feldgoise (Stephan), Jason and Julia Eckstein and Julian Burke. Mrs. Schlamowitz made many contributions while employed as a researcher and developer for Ayerst Labs and Sterling Drug Co., and was highly regarded as a technical consultant for medical programs on television for many years. Her loving nature, helpfulness and kind counsel to all in need will be deeply missed. Interment private.

title: Judge Is Expected to Try to Reclaim Former State Senate Seat for Republicans
description: Christopher J. Mega used to be a New York State Assemblyman and Senator, but has been out of the political arena for the last five years. As the presiding judge of New York State's Court of Claims, he cannot so much as publicly utter a politically oriented thought, lest he violate judicial guidelines on ethics.

title: 'Grace and Glorie' in Nyack
description: EONS before Neil Simon unwittingly came up with a title that defined a genre, the odd-couple play was a prescribed convention in how-to manuals for playwrights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCASKEY, LYDIA
description: McCASKEY-Lydia. On March 18, 1998 Lydia was suddenly taken away from her husband George, daughter Pamela and many other close family members and friends who loved her dearly. We must all cherish the 65 wonderful years we had with her, but sadly, we will all miss her terribly. Visitation will be held at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc., 1380 New York Avenue, Huntington Station, Long Island, N.Y. Sunday 7-10PM and Monday 2-5 and 7-10PM. Religious service will be held Monday, 8PM. Prayers will be offered Tuesday, 10AM followed by an entombment at Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: Downside of Central Location
description: When not corralling crowds at parades or protests, the New York City Police Department's 6,200 barricades are stored at Pier 40 in Manhattan. But the pier is included in plans for the new Hudson River Park, which means the police will have to find a new place to store their blue wooden sawhorses and metal barriers. In their search, though, they've run into a barrier of their own.

title: Not So Jolly Now, a Giant Agency Retools
description: NO advertising agency has ever had a culture or tradition quite like that of the Leo Burnett Company, since the 1930's the sculptor of a Mount Rushmore of American brand icons.

title: Floors, the Natural Way
description: MENTION soft floor coverings and most people think of carpets or rugs made of fibers like wool, cotton, silk or synthetics like rayon or acrylic. Now, however, soft floor coverings made from natural grass and plant fibers are gaining in popularity. Called natural-fiber floor coverings, they are typically woven from coir, jute, rush, seagrass or sisal fibers (note: Many manufacturers and decorators use the term ''"natural-fiber''" only for grasses and plant fibers, although, strictly speaking wool, cotton, and silk should also be included in this category).

title: Q and A
description: Ballooning Over Tuscany

title: Marian Morrill, William Fisher 3d
description: Marian Jane Morrill and William Edward Fisher 3d were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York. The Rev. Philip Channing Ellsworth, an Episcopal priest, officiated, and the Rev. Kevin McGrath, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Hardwood
description: A MARCH

title: On the Shoulders of Giants
description: The Ascent of Science By Brian L. Silver. Illustrated. 534 pp. New York: A Solomon Press Book/ Oxford University Press. $35.

title: Cheryl Rothman, E. A. Feuerstein
description: Cheryl Joy Rothman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry I. Rothman of New York, is to be married today to Edward Abraham Feuerstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Feuerstein of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Mordechai Willig is to officiate at the Westchester Marriott in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Talks to End Korea Conflict Hit Another Impasse
description: A week of talks aimed at creating a framework for peace on the tense Korean peninsula ended in an impasse today with the United States and North Korea blaming each other for the failure.

title: The Cutting Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: A Germanic Touch

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLATBUSH

title: Royal Blue Collars
description: FOR a quarter-century, the message from the job market has been loud and clear. Avoid traditional blue-collar work. Go to college. Scramble for a foothold in the service industry elite, where unions and seniority mean little and adaptability is the most prized talent. If you are really ambitious and prepared to risk your life savings, start your own business.

title: Standing Up for Adam Purple; The City Turns On Its Living Treasures
description: To the Editor:

title: Four California Mayors Ask Clinton to Stop Marijuana Club Suit
description: The Mayors of four California cities have written to President Clinton, urging him to halt a Federal lawsuit that threatens to close clubs that distribute marijuana for medical use.

title: March 15-21; Presidential Counterpunches In the Paula Jones Case
description: President Clinton's lawyers and public relations staff spent the week fighting back against the legal team seeking to prove he sexually harassed Paula Jones at an Arkansas hotel in 1991.

title: Middle Eastern Dishes in Mamaroneck
description: TURQUOISE is a witty name for this terrific little restaurant with walls as blue as the Mediterranean and Middle Eastern offerings done with a decidedly Turkish spin. Expect simple char-grilled meats, savory rice and vegetables galore in a myriad of forms from blatant rough cuts to indescribably delicious smoothness. And it seems that diners are more than ready for the haunting flavors this kitchen dishes up. On weekends, even with confirmed reservations, diners might have long waits as serving staff and kitchen struggle to supply the nonstop demand. Dining very early or during the week makes sense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEXTER, LEO
description: HEXTER-Leo. The entire staff of Modern International Corporation deeply mourn the passing of Leo Hexter, March 18, 1998, a devoted and respected Vice President for many years. Our condolences to his dear wife Martha and to all his children and grandchildren. Modern International Corporation Daniel Stern, President Henry Stern, Chairman

title: Houston Historic Area
description: To the Editor:

title: The Little Creepy Crawlers That Will Eat You In the Night
description: So this is the Brave New World of Silicon Valley! (''The Little Creepy Crawlers That Will Eat You in the Night,'' by Michael Lewis, March 1). A bunch of aging, well-educated, rich, powerful white men looking for younger men with their own interests to spend their money on. This is new?

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the International Datebook listing on March 8 for the Virginia Waterfront International Arts Festival, which begins on April 23, misstated the information telephone number. It is (757) 664-6492.

title: Building Clinic Offers Skills to Women
description: UNDETERRED by dreary weather and in some cases undaunted by not knowing the difference between a soffit and a header, 30 women braved a steady drizzle on a recent Sunday afternoon to learn how to install windows and doors and shingle a roof on a garden shed at the Home Depot here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXELRAD, AMELIA (MILLIE)
description: AXELRAD-Amelia (Millie). At age 95 on March 16, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Sol Axelrad, M.D., loving aunt of Edith Gelfand, and devoted friend of Frances Grabarz. A long-time resident of Woodhaven, New York, she was active in the Women's Auxiliary of the Queens County Medical Society. Her later years were spent in Highlands, NJ and St Thomas, VI. Her cheerful countenance will always be remembered.

title: CASINOS INCREASE THEIR DONATIONS TO U.S. CAMPAIGNS
description: Confronted by a rising concern about the pervasive growth of casinos and by the threat that a national commission studying gambling could recommend new regulations and taxes, casino operators and other gambling interests have more than quadrupled their contributions to Federal candidates and political parties since 1991.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Summer Dance Workshop

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN WYCK, DOROTHY
description: VAN WYCK-Dorothy. On March 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Halsey Allen Van Wyck. Devoted mother of Susan Van Wyck Sack and mother-in-law of A. Albert Sack. Grandmother of Carter Van Wyck Sack and A. Albert Sack VI of Bermuda. Services private to be held in Bermuda.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: SPACE

title: How Serial Refinancings Can Rob Equity
description: FOR Ormond and Rosie Jackson, an elderly couple in Brooklyn living on Social Security, the problem started in 1990, when a salesman knocked on the door saying he could have the windows on their home repaired for payments of $43 a month over 15 years. Six years later, the Jacksons had amassed $88,000 in new debt, seen the equity in their home melt away, paid tens of thousands of dollars in fees and been served with foreclosure papers by their lender.

title: What's Doing In; Norfolk
description: Spring has come early to Norfolk. Thanks to a mild winter and the wettest February on record, the camellias, tulip magnolias and Bradford pears have all blossomed ahead of schedule. Even the azaleas are poised for an early debut.

title: Sunday, March 22, 1998: CRAFTSMANSHIP; Cutting Edge
description: This summer Jim Jackson, Queen Elizabeth's expert on armor, will travel to tiny Lockesburg, Ark. (population 608), to study blade-making techniques for a week under a rural bladesmith named Jerry Fisk. As Jackson knows, Fisk is the man to see: operating in a huge carpeted workshop on his country property, Fisk, a bearded, craggy 44-year-old, has used his meticulous skills to build a reputation as one of the finest makers of decorative weapons in the world. He forges swords, knives, sabers, daggers (like the $8,000 ''Arkansas Dagger'' pictured), axes and myriad other sharp objects for royalty, celebrities, millionaires and anyone else who can afford him. His clients and fans include the Sultan of Brunei, Swiss industrialists and Bo Derek, who is talking to Fisk about creating a ''special knife.''

title: Corrections
description: The Choice Tables column on March 8, about Asian restaurants in Washington, misspelled both names of the writer mentioned in a diner's overheard conversation at Asia Nora. He is the beat poet Allen Ginsberg.

title: Back to the Good Old, Free-Spending Days
description: CALL it in-your-face flouting of political correctness (culinary branch) or a trip down Nostalgia Lane, but Morton's of Chicago adds a new level of big-city professionalism (and prices) to Stamford's dining scene.

title: Despite Efforts To Organize, Union Rosters Have Declined
description: With the A.F.L.-C.I.O. focusing on recruiting more workers, the labor leaders gathered here for the federation's winter meeting were stunned and stumped by the latest news on union membership.

title: At Top of Its Season, Asparagus Is Ready for the Pot
description: THIN as a pencil or thick as a cigar, asparagus is now at the height of its season. It can be steamed, boiled, grilled or roasted, and it can be cut up for pasta, sauteed and stir-fried.

title: So There
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Light of Falling Stars

title: She's the Captain of Her Own Hockey Team
description: GIVE her a breakaway, and, yes, a little extra body contact, and Naomi Yoshii of Mineola is in hockey heaven. Miss Yoshii loves to play roller hockey. She is perhaps the only woman who plays competitive roller hockey against all men on Long Island. And she is captain of her team.

title: As Jordan's Troubles Grow, Uneasy Lies Its Crown
description: These are uneasy times in Jordan.

title: Fifth Graders' Letters Await Mayor's Answer
description: AT 8:30 A.M., we stoked up on egg and cheese sandwiches at the White Castle on Atlantic Avenue. ''I always eat at least three,'' Arlene Schulman said. ''You need a lot of energy for these fifth graders. They are so smart. You'll see.''

title: AIDING CONSUMERS IS NOW THE THRUST OF ANTITRUST PUSH
description: When the Government challenged the proposed mergers of the nation's four largest drug wholesalers earlier this month, the pronouncements from the Federal Trade Commission did not follow the script that trustbusters used for much of the last century, decrying the power of big, monopolistic businesses.

title: Not Sexual Assault
description: To the Editor:

title: Sometimes, Safeguards Protect Nobody
description: When the boss owns most of the stock, he wins. No matter what the auditors say. And no matter what the other directors think.

title: Now, the Oscar for Ghostly Longevity . . .
description: At Leo Burnett, it seems impossible to avoid the presence of Leo himself. It is as if the salty former copywriter were standing just around the next corner, puffing a cigarette, scanning ad copy, about to let loose with a wisecrack.

title: Former Boyfriend Arrested in Killing Of a Law Student Near Columbia
description: The police said last night they had arrested a 23-year-old former boyfriend in connection with the death of a Columbia University law student who was found with her throat slashed in her university apartment on Friday.

title: An Unclear Picture in Long Island Attack
description: Over the last three weeks, 26 witnesses have been asked to describe what they saw in the early morning hours of May 26, 1996, when a black man was nearly bludgeoned to death by a white man in a racially charged brawl outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub, but no clear picture of the attacker has emerged.

title: Posters on a Fence Are a Draw, Not an Eyesore
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, CRAIG M.
description: WILLIAMS-Craig M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Craig M. Williams, associated with The Times from 1971.

title: Columbia Sweeps The Coast Guard
description: Columbia's men's heavyweight crew won its opening race of the 1998 rowing season, sweeping a dual regatta against the United States Coast Guard Academy yesterday in New York to retain the O'Hara Cup for the fourth consecutive year. The trophy was inaugurated in 1984 to honor Jim O'Hara, who served as boatman to Columbia's crews from 1960 until 1983. O'Hara presented the trophy yesterday to the Columbia varsity and then surprised them by pulling individual medals from his pocket, which he bestowed on the eight oarsmen and the coxswain.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Men's Fashions/Magazine Part 2

title: Government Called A Shoreham Victim
description: NINE years after the demise of Shoreham, a new analysis of America's largest dead-end industrial project has identified a victim beyond the obvious ones, the customers and shareholders of the Long Island Lighting Company and taxpayers around the United States, who will share a waste of more than $5 billion on the reactor.

title: When Sherman White Threw It All Away
description: Sherman White is 69 years old with what he calls a ''hole in my heart.'' Emotionally, not medically, emotionally. But that emotional hole has been there for nearly 50 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESLER, RICHARD MILES, SR.
description: CHESLER-Richard Miles, Sr. 69. Of Shady Side, MD, died of cancer at Anne Arundel Medical Center on March 18, 1998. Mr. Chesler's immediate survivors are his wife Alice, three daughters, Deborah Poteet, Diane Pounsberry, and Denise Chesler, two sons, Richard, Jr. and Donald, 9 grandchildren, mother Ruth Davis, sister Caryl Veth, 3 brothers Robert Chesler, Sidney and Charles Davis. Shalom, Dick. Family and friends wish you a painless, joyful journey on the the sea of eternity.

title: When the Trailer Lot Next Door Becomes Nightmare Alley
description: A treble and bass clef adorn the window bars of James and Pamela Weekes's home on East 37th Street, and a tiny sign outside reads ''House of Music,'' a reference to the music lessons Mr. Weekes offers. It might as well say House of Plagues.

title: BENEFITS
description: Mr. Kamen's Opus

title: Medicine in America, Spanning 150 Years
description: AS a concept, art for art's sake seems to have been superseded by art that illustrates or preaches. Whether this is the will of artists or art educators is a moot point, but there is no doubt that, like the squeaky wheel, the show promoting a blameless cause is the one most likely to get the Federal, state or corporate grease. A current example is ''Say Ahh! Examining America's Health,'' which has nothing to do with art but is nonetheless on view at the Hudson River Museum here.

title: Custody Disputes Taking Heavy Toll On the Children
description: THOSE who would find it a harbinger of better times for families that the United States is experiencing its lowest divorce rate in a decade may be discomfited to learn that Long Island does not follow the national trend. Although the number of divorces in Suffolk County has held fairly steady over the past seven years, Nassau County recorded 48 percent more divorces in 1997 than in 1990 despite no growth in population.

title: Rallying the Troops
description: Presentations: They're showtime for some people, the bane of many others. How have they gone for you? And what moments next to the overhead projector would you most like to forget? Or remember? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHNEIDER, LORRAINE CONHEIM
description: SCHNEIDER-Lorraine Conheim. February 17th, 1955. In ever loving memory. Sister, Marilyn

title: What It Takes to Fashion a Broadway Musical
description: IT is another busy Sunday with recitals, choral concerts, children's programs and a visiting orchestra to hear. First off the mark at 2 o'clock is the classical guitarist Tom Schuttenheim playing Bach, Villa-Lobos and some of his own compositions at the Westport Women's Club.

title: Lillian Vernon Moving
description: After five years in a 41,000-square-foot building in downtown New Rochelle, the Lillian Vernon Corporation, the mail order company, will move to larger quarters along Playland Parkway in Rye this summer, David C. Hochberg, a spokesman for the company, said.

title: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?
description: THERE are two commonly held beliefs about today's New York. No. 1: Things are good. No. 2: Everyone agrees about No. 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILLMAN, ISRAEL E.
description: STILLMAN-Israel E. Ned died in Florida March 19, 1998. Graduate of Boys High and NYU. Active in the millinery industry and synagogue. Loving husband of Frances and Julia, partner of Bea, devoted father of Barbara and Bill Cohen, David and Enid Stillman. Adored and adoring grandfather of Meri, Jimbob, Leslie, Steven and Matthew. Special Poppi-Poppi of Danielle and Samantha. Survived by sister Ethel. He taught us how to live and love with an open heart. Graveside services are at Old Montefiore Cemetery, Queens at 2 P.M., on Monday.

title: Chicago's Jordan-Jackson-Pippen Triangle
description: He is becoming more vocal all the time, detailing his team's plight to anyone who will listen. Either Michael Jordan feels eternally wronged by the management of the Chicago Bulls, or he is up to something more productive, something that might lay the groundwork for his guaranteed return next season.

title: Fire Department Out
description: It began as an experiment two years ago to hire the first private fire department in the Northeast. But it ended in defeat early this month, when Rye Brook handed traveling papers to Rural Metro of Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Confessions of a Former Child
description: Dear Genius

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on March 3 about mating behavior by a species of bird, the European oystercatcher, and its implications for human mating strategies, misstated the religious affiliation of Elizabeth Joseph, who has extolled the benefits of polygamy. She considers herself a Protestant; she is not a Mormon.

title: March 15-21; The Capital's No. 2 Topic
description: When President Clinton agreed with the Republican leadership last spring on a plan to eliminate the Federal deficit, it seemed to bring an end to years of bitterly partisan budget wars. But as Congress moved ahead last week on its tax and spending plans, it immediately became clear that the battle goes on.

title: Hali Browne and Eric London
description: Hali Beth Browne and Eric Damon London were married in Washington last evening by Rabbi Kenneth S. Weiss at the Washington Hebrew Congregation.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday on living in Pawling, N.Y., misspelled the middle name of a television talk-show host who recently purchased a home there. She is Sally Jessy Raphael.

title: Sunday, March 22, 1998: MOVIES; Danger! Your Script Will Not Be Optioned!
description: April brings with it ''Lost in Space,'' the big-screen version of the cheesy 1960's TV series about those cosmic castaways, the Robinson family. For Bill Mumy, who played the precocious young son, Will, the movie is a reminder of a missed opportunity: he once wrote his own ''Lost in Space'' script, a 1980 teleplay called ''The Epilogue.'' It never got filmed because the late Irwin Allen, the show's creator, wouldn't sign on. ''He was really rude,'' recalls Mumy, 44, now an actor based in Los Angeles. (He has a recurring role on ''Babylon 5.'') ''He was making feature films, and the last words he said were, 'If at any future time I want to do ''Lost in Space,'' it will be because I want to, not you.' '' Mumy has been asked by a producer to update the script for a CD-ROM version of his story; meanwhile, here's what he originally had in mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORGANSKI, PROFESSOR ABRAMO FIMO KENNETH
description: ORGANSKI-Professor Abramo Fimo Kenneth. Political scientist and educator, died on March 6 of a heart attack. Dr. Organski was born in Rome in 1923, where he attended the Ginnasio Liceo Torquato Tasso. He came to the United States with his parents Menasce and Anna (Feinstein) Organski and his brother Guido in 1939 as his family fled the anti-Jewish laws of the Mussolini regime. He settled in New York where he became an American citizen in 1944. He served with the American armed forces from 1943 to 1945 and then went on to earn a BA (1947), MA (1948) and Ph.D. (1951) from New York University. After teaching at Brooklyn College from 1952-1964, he joined the faculty of the University of Michigan. At the time of his death, he was professor of political science and Senior Research Scientist in the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan. He was also Chairman of the Board of Decision Insights, New York, NY. His books included ''World Politics; Population and World Power'', coauthored with his first wife Katherine Davis Fox; ''Birth, Death and Taxes'' written with several of his students; ''Stages of Political Development; The War Ledger'' written with Jacek Kugler; and ''The 36 Billion Dollar Bargain.'' Dr. Organski's honors included the Distinguished Faculty Achievement Award by the University of Michigan, a lifetime achievement award by the Conflict Processes Section of the American Political Science Association, and the Cavalieri dela Republica by the government of Italy. In addition to his intellectual depth and orginality, Kenneth Organski will be remembered for his zest for life, love of language, human warmth and gift for friendship. He was a devoted husband, father and grandfather and will be deeply mourned by his wife, Patricia Joan Bard; his daughter, Elizabeth Anna Organski-Horn and her husband, Steven Horn of Whitmore Lake, MI; his son, Eric Fox Organski of Savannah, GA; his grandson, Steve Horn, Jr; his brother, Guido Organschi of Litchfield, CT; and by generations of devoted students. A memorial service will be held on April 18 at 4 PM in East Hall at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, MI. Memorial contributions may be made to the A.F.K. Organski Fund, Center for Political Studies, University of Michigan.

title: Postnuptials
description: Who says bridesmaids' dresses have only one shining moment? At Serafina, 29 East 19th Street, Mary Greenhill, 27 (far right), Lisa McAtee, 28 (right), and Victoria Hadden, 28, design and sell bridesmaids' dresses fashionable and versatile enough to be worn again.
