title: Self-Censorship or Kid-Sensitivity?
description: Barbara Nitke was fussing with the slide projector when she learned that her show would not go on.

title: Amid Talk of a Sale, Kaufmann Fund Falters
description: THE managers of the storied Kaufmann Fund appear ready to cash out of their $6 billion money management firm, and perhaps not a moment too soon. Performance has been lagging lately and assets leaching steadily.

title: The Art of Swimming Against the Tide
description: ''BUY when blood is in the streets.'' No one takes that investing adage more to heart than a contrarian like Anthony M. Gallea.

title: Why Bold Documentaries Get Few Oscars
description: THERE'S no such thing as a safe Oscar bet, except the excellent chance that ''Men in Black'' will trounce ''Mrs. Brown'' in the Best Makeup category tomorrow evening. But it looks as if this year's Academy Awards mean smooth sailing for a certain seafaring legend, a sign that much is right with the movie world. This year, as Hollywood rediscovered its inner storyteller the nominations took a turn for the traditional. They did that so consistently that voters must have found themselves with considerable hairsplitting to do.

title: March 15-21; U.S. to Ease Cuban Curbs
description: Pressed by Pope John Paul II to be generous toward Cuba, President Clinton announced a softening of American restrictions. He reversed a ban on direct humanitarian flights to Cuba, allowed Cuban-Americans to send $1,200 a year to their relatives and simplified licensing for the sale of pharmaceuticals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARNES, EDWARD
description: PARNES-Edward, age 92 on March 19, 1998. Beloved husband of Harriet (Novich) Parnes. Loving father of Jane and Raymond Epstein, and Kate and Andrew Parnes. Grandfather of Kevin, Christy, Ryan, Daniel, and Devyn. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Saturday 7-9PM. Services and interment private.

title: Corrections

title: Corrections

title: Chaya Goldstein, Michael Roth
description: Chaya Sarah Goldstein, a daughter of Seema E. Goldstein and Rabbi Jacob Z. Goldstein of Brooklyn, is to be married this afternoon to Michael Danny Roth, the son of Julie and Leslie Roth of Melbourne, Australia.

title: Do Grannies Know Best, Despite a Fiscal Slip-Up?
description: BETTY SINNOCK brought together the 16 women who founded the Beardstown Business and Professional Women's Investment Club in 1983. It turns out, though, that Mrs. Sinnock may have made her greatest contribution to the Beardstown Ladies, as the famous stock-picking group became known, with an embarrassing accounting error more than a decade later.

description: DANCYGER-Marvin Lee. March 21, 1918 to March 17, 1998. Beloved husband of Goldie. Loving father of Deanna and Barry Moskowitz, Ellen and Richard Cole, Mitchel and Gale Dancyger, Bonnie and David Swerdloff. Adoring grandfather of 10. Services were held.

title: Ups and Downs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISELIN, SARAH (SALLY) C.
description: ISELIN-Sarah (Sally) C. Writer, editor and photographer. Wife of the late Lewis Iselin, and mother of Edith Byron and Sarah Iselin. Died at her home in New York March 18 at age 82. Services will be private.

title: 3 Suspects Are Arrested In Westchester Drug Raid
description: Three people were arrested and 21 kilograms of cocaine with an estimated street value of more than $3 million was seized yesterday after an early morning raid on a house in Mount Vernon, prosecutors said.

title: So Somebody Can Sing Schubert After All
description: LAST year, much hoopla attended the 200th anniversary of Schubert's birth, including the release of several recordings meant to honor the occasion. Among them were disks featuring such acclaimed singers as Renee Fleming, Thomas Hampson, Anne Sofie von Otter and Bo Skovhus.

title: Editorial Observer; The Tet Offensive and the Scent of Memory
description: I live outside a village in Columbia County called Austerlitz. Perhaps one day that name will bring to my mind only the tiny post office there or the bare picnic ground near the town hall. But for now whenever I say or write Austerlitz, I also hear the echo of the names of other places -- Jena, Borodino, Waterloo. Like the European town from which my town took its name, those were the sites of Napoleonic battles almost 200 years ago. From some names and even some dates, the scent of war cannot be expunged, from Verdun, for instance, and Gettysburg, from June 6 and Dec. 7. That is true, too, of Tet, the Vietnamese name for the Chinese Lunar New Year, and of two places with which it was first and forever linked 30 years ago, Khe Sanh and Hue.

title: Carolina Snaps UConn In the Crucial Minutes
description: Every time North Carolina needed a critical basket in the last six minutes tonight, someone scored. Every time the Tar Heels needed to stop Connecticut, they did. Every time the Huskies scared the best team in college basketball, the Tar Heels treated them like little brothers. It worked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROOB, CHARLOTTE (LIEF)
description: TROOB-Charlotte (Lief). Please see notice today under Charlotte Mergentime.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; I'm a Stay-at-Home Mom. Please Hold the Applause.
description: I GAVE birth to a beautiful, healthy baby boy on Nov. 7. My original plan had been to return to work after taking three months of leave, but my boss decided that he didn't want me back.

title: Caught in Their Acts
description: Aiding the UJA-Federation, an American museum and a Russian orchestra; a fashion side-show in Paris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLIAM, BEVERLY J.
description: GILLIAM-Beverly J. Died on February 14, three weeks after her 70th birthday. She was the Evening Director of Library Services at Hunter College until her retirement in 1991. Ms. Gilliam grew up in New York City's Washington Heights. She was graduated from City College and received a Master's Degree in Library Science from Columbia University. Her career began in 1953 as a librarian with the U.S. Occupation Team in Asia. She spent four years setting up and managing American libraries in Korea and Japan. This was followed by eight years in London, England as Area Librarian for the U.S. Air Force (7500th Group). Upon returning to the US in the mid 1960s, Ms Gilliam became the Math and Physics Librarian at Rockefeller University and later the librarian for Lenox Hill Hospital School of Nursing. She joined the staff of Hunter College in 1980. For the last five years, her time was divided between New York City and Seattle, Washington. She also maintained an extensive schedule of world travel. She was preceded in death by sister, Dolores Gilliam Ward in 1959, mother Mary F. Gilliam in 1980 & father, Reginald E. Gilliam, Sr. in 1994. She is survived by her brother & sister-in-law, Reginald, Jr. and Arlene Gilliam of Vienna, Virginia and many friends throughout the world. Ms. Gilliam requested that anyone so desiring, make contributions to the American Cancer Society.

title: A Vietnam-Era Boat That Evokes Cinematic, and Real, Memories
description: With their machine guns mounted fore and aft, grenade launchers, M-16's and 12-gauge shotguns, the Navy's 31-foot P.B.R.'s (for patrol boat, river) were known as miniature battleships to the sailors who stood a one-in-four chance of becoming casualties on board, said Bob Wilson, 62, who commanded river patrol boats in Vietnam from 1967 to 1970. Moviegoers know the boat as Martin Sheen's ferry upriver into Cambodia to terminate Marlon Brando's command in Francis Ford Coppola's 1979 film ''Apocalypse Now.''

title: Crime
description: Spring comes to Boston in Robert B. Parker's new Spenser mystery, SUDDEN MISCHIEF (Putnam, $22.95), bringing the ducks and the tulips and the swan boats, along with a crisis in the private eye's idyllic relationship with the annoyingly perfect Susan Silverman. The first cracks appear when Susan asks her lover to rescue her ex-husband from a multiple sexual harassment suit -- a boon that would test any knight's mettle. Spenser does the noble thing and disproves the bogus charges against Brad Sterling, a fund-raiser for charities that never see a dime from the gala events he stages and a charming rat with women. But instead of thanking her hero for his selfless efforts on behalf of this clown, Susan snaps and snarls at him and goes into an interminably dull analysis of her attraction to ''inappropriate men.''

title: The Nation; A Scandal's Road Kill Undergoes an Autopsy
description: ON a rare sunny morning last week, on a quiet street of bungalows, Andrew J. and Kathy Bleiler opened their curtains for the first time in two months; for the first time, in fact, since telling their humiliating secret on national television.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: YOU GOT TO DANCE WITH THEM WHAT BRUNG YOU Politics in the Clinton Years. By Molly Ivins. Random House, $23.

title: QUICK BITE/Middletown; Savory Selections From a Bountiful Indian Buffet
description: ''I miss my lunch stops along East Sixth Street,'' said Rick, a customs broker who recently moved from Manhattan to the New Jersey Shore. What he was longing for, specifically, were the samosas, the tandoori chicken, the sag panir and the other goodies he would enjoy on the block of restaurants informally known as Indian Row.

title: Vivian Einstein, R. A. Rosenberg
description: Vivian Einstein, a daughter of Charlotte Einstein of Morristown, N.J., and the late Theodore Einstein, was married last evening to Richard Alex Rosenberg, a son of Sylvia and Kenneth Rosenberg of Westwood, Mass. Rabbi Robert Scheinberg performed the ceremony at the New York Academy of Sciences in New York.

title: Effort to Bar A Candidate Fuels Crisis In Paraguay
description: Fearing that a general who tried to seize power two years ago could win the presidential election in May, the governing party here is maneuvering to bar his candidacy, plunging this country into the worst political crisis of its fledgling democracy.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: No Laughing Matter The Life and Times of Flann O'Brien. By Anthony Cronin. Fromm International, $29.95.

title: Modern Japanese Perception in Prints
description: A SHOW called ''Modern Japanese Prints,'' at the Connecticut Graphic Arts Center in Norwalk, surveys a style that had to go on the road before it could be appreciated in its own country. All the 31 works come under the rubric Sosaku Hanga (Creative Print).

title: Corrections
description: The table of contents on Feb. 15 omitted two credits for the photograph on the cover, which showed a model's shaved head painted in compartments representing different memories. The lettering on the head was hand-painted by Christoph Niemann; the makeup was by Jane Choi.

title: DIARY
description: MARKETS

title: March 15-21; Netanyahu Spars With Briton
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, evidently had two goals on his visit to Israel. One was to present a new European initiative to advance the peace talks, the other was to demonstrate European disapproval of the rapid expansion of Jewish settlements in the West Bank by visiting the planned new neighborhood of Har Homa in southeastern Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, SYDNEY T.
description: STEWART-Sydney T., Ph.D. We mourn deeply the death of our colleauge Sydney T. Stewart, Ph.D., training psychoanalyst, man of letters and connoisseurship, who survived Bataan prison camps to give his gifts of thoughtfulness and wisdom to others. Harriet I. Basseches, Ph.D. President The New York Freudian Society

title: Corrections
description: The Good Eating column last Sunday included an erroneous rating for the restaurant Il Valentino. It received two stars from The New York Times on June 20, 1997, not one.

title: HIGH VISIBILITY
description: The sharp city suit is taking flight. In contrast to the season's casual mood, these elegant styles give high visibility throughout the day and into the night. The fabrics are distinguished by a subtle sheen and, in some cases, even a certain iridescence. They range from blends of mohair, silk or synthetics, to wool sharkskin. Colors cover a palette from mid-tones to darker shades of blue, worn to best effect with brightly hued dress shirts and ties. For ultimate impact, choose a truly colorful dress shirt, like yellow, green, rose or even purple, and pair it with a closely matched iridescent tie. To showcase our suits' high-flying style, we photographed them among the classic airplanes of the Pima Air & Space Museum in Tucson, Ariz.

title: Through Maori Eyes
description: MANY visitors to New Zealand, whose two main islands are the largest in Polynesia, see its vast fjords, soaring mountains and untouched beaches. Then there are the sheepshearing, bungee jumping and thrilling helicopter rides. After visiting a number of Polynesian islands, my husband, Joe, and I wanted to see New Zealand through Maori eyes. The Maori, New Zealanders of Polynesian descent, once were close to extinction. Today, they're experiencing a remarkable cultural renaissance.

title: Communications Unit Gives Local Awards
description: THERE were a record number of entries for this year's Clarion Awards, which are given by the Westchester Chapter of the Association of Women in Communications.

title: Joshua Tree, Alight With Mystery
description: SOME people go to the desert to play golf. Others go to tan. Although I have been known to acquire a tan in the desert, that's not why I go there. I go for the rocks in the shape of Billy Martin.

title: New Method To Veil Data Could Upstage Export Policy
description: One of the nation's leading computer scientists has proposed a novel technique for scrambling data that could circumvent Government export policies aimed at limiting the foreign sale of encryption technology.

title: A 36-Hole Showdown For Woods, Els and Love
description: Sunday's final threesome at the Bay Hill Invitational will feature the following three players: Tiger Woods, Davis Love 3d and Ernie Els.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, CLARA B.
description: MAYER-Clara B. On March 12, 1998. Devoted wife of Seymour, beloved mother of Marjorie and Martin Diamond, cherished grandmother of Caryn and Ned. Private services were at graveside.

title: Asparagus: It's Time
description: THIN as a pencil or thick as a cigar, asparagus is now at the height of its season. It can be steamed, boiled, grilled or roasted, and it can be cut up for pasta, sauteed and stir-fried.

title: Scribble, Scribble
description: ''Once...long ago...in the dark of the night..., a wondrous thing happened to all things that write.''

title: Too Many Arms to Twist
description: The Clinton Administration's frenetic diplomatic activity in recent weeks in and around Serbia's Kosovo region provides a fresh example of floundering in today's international environment. Senior Administration officials have made public threats that, if carried out, could embroil the United States in an ethnic war with slight if any relevance to American security.

title: For Metropolitan Phoenix, 6 Golf Courses a Year
description: IF all of the fairways and greens in this hot, cactus-studded metropolis -- 165 golf courses, in all -- were placed in a straight line, the swath of grass and sand traps would stretch hundreds of miles across the Sonoran Desert.

title: Last 3 Leo House Tenants Look for Last-Minute Rescue
description: After five years of fighting to keep their low-rent apartments in the heart of Chelsea, the three remaining tenants at the Leo House Annex have finally lost their legal battle and anxiously await eviction. Unless, that is, John Cardinal O'Connor issues a last-minute reprieve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERGER, CAROL LEE
description: WEINBERGER-Carol Lee. Of Bayonne, New Jersey. Beloved wife of Stanton, devoted mother of Debra and Dr. Steven Levine, Dr. Joel and Rosalie, dear sister of Jerome and Kathy Shainberg. For information contact ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PILMAR, HOWARD
description: PILMAR-Howard. Today on the second anniversary of your death, we want you and the world to know how much we miss you and promise that justice will soon prevail. Dad, Carol and Heather

title: Way Outback
description: OYSTER By Janette Turner Hospital. 400 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25.95.

title: Corrections
description: A quotation in the In Brief column on March 8, about a lawsuit filed by a homosexual who had been expelled from the Boy Scouts, misidentified the judge whose ruling was quoted. It was Judge James M. Havey of the Appellate Division of Superior Court, not Judge Patrick J. McGann of Superior Court, who wrote that the Boy Scouts' action had violated the state's anti-discrimination law. (Judge McGann had issued the earlier ruling that was overturned by the appeals court.)

title: A la Carte
description: Nobody Knows the Truffles I've Seen

title: Who Pays For Mistakes In Making Electricity?
description: LEGISLATION to deregulate the electricity industry is giving a repeat performance in the General Assembly this year, following a humiliating final act in last year's session -- the parliamentary equivalent of getting the hook. Some observers are saying the new bill, with careful reworking and attention to its previous shortcomings, is now ready for prime time; others are not so sure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDING, DR. JOSEPH WILLIAM
description: FIELDING-Dr. Joseph William. At Port Huron, MI, March 18, 1998, at age 75. He graduated from the University of Toronto Medical School '46. Former Chief of Orthopaedic Surgery of St. Luke's/Roosevelt Hospital in New York City and past President of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgery. Dr. Fielding served on many medical and surgical committees and boards. He was an internationally renowned researcher and educator. Bill enjoyed photography, opera and classical music, ballet, the study of ancient civilizations and travel. He was a whistler extraordinaire. Bill married Doris Alma Toogood, his wife of 48 years, in Toronto, January 21, 1950. He is survived by his wife, his children Pamela, Bruce, Deborah and Victoria, and eight grandchildren. He was predeceased by his son Cameron Alec, brother John, and three grandchildren. Friends called at the Turner and Porter Yorke Chapel, 2357 Bloor St. West, Toronto, on Friday. Funeral Service was held in the chapel on Saturday, March 21, 1998, at 3 PM. Private interment Park Lawn Cemetery. If desired, donations may be made to the Orthopaedic Research Education Foundation.

title: The Fonda Who Came In From the Cold
description: There is something delicious about the resurrection of Peter Fonda's career. It's a story with symmetry, closure; the hero makes peace with his demons and gets his just desserts. Something that happens only in the movies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a visit to Albania by Strobe Talbott of the State Department misstated his title and the former position of an Albanian political figure, Sali Berisha. Mr. Talbott is Deputy Secretary of State, not Deputy Assistant Secretary. Mr. Berisha is a former President, not a former Prime Minister.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Megan Golden, Peter Neiman
description: Megan Ruth Golden and Peter Gillies Neiman were married yesterday at the Water's Edge restaurant in Long Island City, Queens. Judge John M. Walker Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit officiated.

title: Mixed Reactions to Student Scores in Math and Reading
description: RESPONDING last week to New Rochelle's scores on the state's report cards for middle schools, the district's Superintendent, Linda E. Kelly, expressed a measure of pride and disappointment.

title: A Temporary Haven On the Journey of Life
description: PROJECT RETURN, a group home for teen-age girls in Westport, seeks to rescue its inhabitants from unsafe situations while reinventing the traditional home.

title: It's Not Your Mother's VW
description: THE bull's-eye of Volkswagen's target market for the New Beetle is a place like Ann Arbor, home of the University of Michigan and tens of thousands of young, well-educated trend setters. So how do students, soon to be gainfully employed and ready to release their pent-up consumer demand, describe the car?

title: How to Manufacture A Best Seller
description: I was vastly amused to discover in Maren's article that not only has HarperCollins paid $2 million for a mere idea, it has paid that egregious sum for an idea already well published and well reviewed here and abroad. The joke is on them. The novel is ''The Aleph Solution,'' by Sandor Frankel and Webster Mews, published by Stein & Day in 1978. Its central character is a terrorist who seeks to hold the world hostage by re-enacting the Biblical plagues. How much more grateful a reader I would be if publishers were as eager to advance $200,000 each to 10 deserving writers who would provide me with original works.

title: At the Casinos
description: Atlantic City Hilton

title: A Tale From the Machine Age, for Any Age
description: FIRST, you hear the amplified clamor of an antiseptic office. The typist types. The bookkeeper at the adding machine adds. The switchboard operator yammers. But no one, not even the clerk who sorts mail, is quiet. ''You're always late,'' their overlapping voices shout at the secretary.

title: Abigail Alperstein, J. M. Ruttenberg
description: Abigail Lena Alta Alperstein, a daughter of Sara Alperstein and Dr. Gerald Alperstein of New York, is to be married today to Jonathan Michael Ruttenberg, a son of Sara and Edward Ruttenberg of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Reuven Landman will officiate at the Holiday Inn in Bethesda, Md.

title: Introducing 'New World' Composers
description: THE New York Philharmonic's annual season is one of the longest of any symphony orchestra, and it can seem at times like a 17-inning baseball game. This spring, fortunately, some of the well-known stars, like Beethoven, Brahms and Mahler, will sit down in the late innings and let some interesting bench-warmers into the game.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the On the Towns listings on Feb. 22 misidentified the actor who starred with Greta Garbo in the 1927 film ''Flesh and the Devil.'' He was John Gilbert.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: MUSEUM

title: Smithsonian Tours Adds Weekend Trips
description: The Smithsonian Institution is adding weekend packages to its 20-year-old Study Tours travel program. These four American Snapshots are excursions to Amelia Island, Fla.; Holmes County, Ohio; southeast Wisconsin, and Puget Sound, Wash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUMARKIN, CAROLYN
description: TUMARKIN-Carolyn. The Women's Campaign of the American Jewish Committee mourns the loss of its esteemed Board member, Carolyn Tumarkin, who served with dedication for over 40 years. Our deepest condolences to her sister Teddy Slote, also a devoted member of the Board, and her entire family. Ruth R. Goddard Honorary Chairman Janine Behrman Chairman

title: In Rome, Innovative Or Forever Classic
description: AS the Eternal City blasts and hammers its way to the next millennium, with construction everywhere in preparation for the Holy Year here in 2000, many residents are thinking it best to stay indoors. Fortunately, it is still safe to go out to eat. Recently I surveyed a number of establishments, both new and known, with my companion, Franco Filippi, and occasional friends. We found little reason to change our minds on the known, and were delighted to find some interesting new comers, two of them elegant hotel restaurants, a category once spurned by food-lovers. Our other ''winners'' include two unbeatable classics and one new charmer that defies categorization.

title: F.Y.I.
description: A Brooklyn Treat

title: Less to Celebrate at This Gold Rush Anniversary
description: For more than a century, the Gold Rush of 1849 defined the Golden State, capturing in its rush for riches the eternal optimism that drew generations of adventurers to California.

title: Go for the Burn
description: When Eric Torres yells ''fire!'' (or ''10-75'' in firefighter-speak) at the Crunch gym on Lafayette Street, it isn't the aerobics studio that's burning. It's calories. Mr. Torres (above, in hat), a 33-year-old firefighter for Ladder Company 34 in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, leads a workout called Firefighter Training, which he invented -- it's the first of its kind in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEVINE, CHARLES PATRICK
description: DEVINE - Charles Patrick. 1953-1997. One year ago, you held me tightly, and kissed me farewell. You fought so hard to stay with me and told me so. You slipped away in the comfort of my loving arms and were freed of pain and suffering. H. P., and serenity never left our side. A most treasured memory is of us dancing in snowy Lake Placid to our song: ''Hold me, thrill me, kiss me, make me...if we ever say adieu, kiss me.'' Words can't describe how much I miss you. My beloved husband and hero. Charlie, I'll always hold you. Your biggest fan, Lystra

title: Sunday, March 22, 1998: QUESTIONS FOR:; Ted Rall
description: Ted Rall is a writer and cartoonist (above: a self-portrait). His new book is Revenge of the Latchkey Kids.

title: U.S. and Georgia in Deal To Improve Juvenile Prisons
description: Attorney General Janet Reno and Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia reached an unusual agreement on juvenile prisons last week under which the state pledged to spend millions of dollars and institute sweeping changes to improve what Justice Department investigators have called ''egregious,'' ''abusive'' and ''grossly substandard'' conditions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMM, EVERARD M.C.
description: STAMM-Everard M.C. Madeleine his wife, Kenneth his son, Christine his daughter-in-law, Caroline and Margaux, his granddaughters saddly announce that Everard the kindest, ''gentle gentleman'', died on March 4, 1998 in the south of France. Born in England, he lived in Manhattan before retiring to Westport, Connecticut. A private service was held in the south of France. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to your favorite charity in care of Kenneth Stamm, 17A Indian Hill Road, Westport, CT. 06880.

Adoring grandfather of Lauren and Jason. Brother of Richard (Irma). Devoted Uncle to Nieces and Nephews. Memorial services at a later date. Contributions to the Rose Y, 30 Oakley Ave, Mt. Vernon, NY 10550

title: Politicians and Public Figures Model to Benefit the Arts
description: THOSE who like seeing politicians in ultra-chic clothing should be at Nordstrom in White Plains next Sunday night.

title: David Kaufman, Marjorie Greenspan
description: Marjorie Lynn Greenspan, a managing director of marketing at Towneley Capital Management in Manhattan, was married last evening to Dr. David Mark Kaufman, a urologist in Manhattan. Rabbi Ramie Arian performed the ceremony at Estherwood, a historic house on the grounds of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Chefs' Conversational Entree
description: THE SETTING -- An upstairs room at the four-star restaurant Le Cirque 2000, where owners of other well-known Manhattan restaurants were drinking wine, picking at caviar and quail eggs and quietly giving out their secret reservation phone numbers. The official occasion: a party for Wine Spectator magazine's special issue on New York: a guide to restaurants, shopping and hotels.

title: 'The Schoolhouse, Then the Home'
description: To the Editor:

title: China Tweaks the Reins, and Hong Kong's Media Bridle
description: A dispute over press freedom has erupted here, interrupting Hong Kong's otherwise peaceful return to Chinese rule and temporarily upstaging even the Asian financial crisis.

title: Arts Leaders Lobby for Dollars in Washington
description: PERFORMANCE ART of the most democratic kind reached the paneled offices of Congress recently, as arts advocates from around the United States lobbied for increased funds for the National Endowment for the Arts. A cautious mood of optimism prevailed, as arts proponents set their sights on the 1999 Federal budget.

title: Q&A: Allegra Pacheco; Lawyer From L.I. Fights for Palestinians
description: AT the age of 32, Allegra Pacheco, a Jewish woman who grew up in Dix Hills, is quickly gaining recognition in Israel as a defense lawyer for Palestinians and their families who claim to have been wronged by Israeli authorities. In January, Ms. Pacheco won first prize in France at an international competition of human rights lawyers for her presentation of an argument against Israel's use of administrative detention. Ms. Pacheco is a 1990 graduate of the Columbia University Law School who moved to Jerusalem four years ago to practice law. She worked for various Palestinian human rights organizations before recently setting up her own law practice in Bethlehem. She was interviewed in Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONHEIM, PHILLIP
description: CONHEIM-Phillip. February 21st, 1944. In ever loving memory. Daughter, Marilyn

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: VARIETY is the spice of film fare this week: a wise portrait of a British predator, a glittering revamp of a Broadway musical, a searching social satire and a vest pocket thriller that became an instant classic.

title: Favorite Sons
description: To the Editor:

title: Yonkers Lawsuit
description: The state has appealed last month's Federal Court ruling that would force the state to help Yonkers pay for part of the city's housing integration effort, Raymond P. Fitzpatrick Jr. of Birmingham, Ala., outside counsel for Yonkers, said last week.

title: Mystery of Missing Baseball Players From Cuba Is Deepening
description: Four Cuban baseball players and a coach thought to have come ashore in the Dominican Republic after leaving Cuba nearly two weeks ago have still not been found, and some of those trying to pin down the group's whereabouts are considering the possibility that they never landed here.

title: ALTERNATIVE ROCK
description: Spartan outerwear and sportswear to match

title: Our Towns; Marching Peacefully To Prison
description: THERE are so many details to take care of before going off to prison. On Friday, Dan and Doris Sage were fretting that they might not make it to the post office before they report to Federal prison tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELL'OREFICE, LUIGI EDUARDO
description: DELL'OREFICE-Luigi Eduardo. Beloved Maestrissimo. May the angels accompany you as you have accompanied us. The gratitude and love of all your students ''mille e tre'' and two. Ira and Linda

title: Wasatch Rewards Bailey With Victory in the Gotham
description: For most of the year, the jockey Jerry Bailey makes his home and his living in New York, but he heads south for the winter along with many of the horses who will figure in the coming Triple Crown races.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Stalin's War
description: Yevgeny Khaldei beat the odds against his survival many times. He was a poor Ukrainian Jew who became the top Soviet photographer of World War II, then endured neglect and outbreaks of Russian anti-Semitism during the subsequent decades. He even lived long enough to outlast his own obscurity. Before he died last year at the age of 80, two American museums had devoted exhibits to his work, and his images were made available to collectors via the Internet. WITNESS TO HISTORY: The Photographs of Yevgeny Khaldei (Aperture, $40), with a biographical essay by Alexander and Alice Nakhimovsky, who teach computer science and Russian, respectively, at Colgate, that focuses on Khaldei's record of World War II, the pinnacle of his professional career. He covered the war from arctic Russia south through eastern and central Europe and back to Berlin, creating images of epic sweep and surreal destruction: a reindeer stands frozen amid exploding stones and rubble; an airplane hangs perilously from the facade of an apartment building; weary soldiers move through vast landscapes. His most widely reproduced image, of Russian soldiers raising the hammer and sickle over Germany's Reichstag, was inspired by Joe Rosenthal's photo of marines raising the Stars and Stripes at Iwo Jima. A model of enterprise, if not of journalistic scruples, Khaldei managed a quick trip back from the front to Moscow, where he persuaded a tailor friend to construct three Soviet flags out of purloined red tablecloths. After photographing soldiers and flags at two other Berlin locations, he found the composition he had been seeking on the roof of the Reichstag. However much some of his photos may have been orchestrated, they effectively convey the brutal strangeness of war. Rosemary Ranck

title: Lives; The Good Neighbor
description: My friends all warned me about first-floor apartments. They told me nightmare stories about thundering footsteps and stereo noise from above, wailing babies, squeaky bedsprings. But as soon as I saw the street-level studio in Park Slope, I was a goner. The apartment, at the rear of a small, saggy building, had a tiny deck and a little fenced-in square of mud that the management-company rep called a garden.I could already see the beds of marigolds that I would plant, the morning glories that would wind up the fence posts and the neat little lawn I'd trim with my Kmart weed whacker.

title: Portobello Roe
description: America is predicated on the notion that bigger is always better. Historically, a large person signified power; later, big houses and big cars said the same thing. From the first Thanksgiving onward, big food has been equated with good food. And while big people have fallen out of favor, the big food they feasted on continues to be celebrated.

title: The Concert Stage Meets the Back Lot
description: Things worked out so well for Frank Sinatra after his first movie-acting role (''Higher and Higher,'' 1943) that pop singers have been trying their luck at film careers ever since, with varying degrees of success. Here are a few of those stars and how things worked out. ANITA GATES

title: March 15-21; Still Bunkmates
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen plunged -- gingerly -- into the debate over whether the nation's armed services should put male and female recruits through boot camp together. Largely following the lead of the service chiefs, he rejected recommendations by a committee he appointed to have the Army, Navy and Air Force segregate men and women for much of basic training, the way the Marine Corps does it now.

title: Harlee Abrams, Jeffrey Richmond
description: Harlee Maurajen Abrams, a daughter of Elaine Abrams and Dr. Stuart Abrams of Stamford, Conn., was married there last evening to Dr. Jeffrey Howard Richmond, the son of Marjorie Richmond and Dr. Stephen Richmond of Rockville Centre, N.Y. Rabbi Joshua Hammerman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOX, JOAN DARRACH FOX
description: KNOX-Joan Darrach Fox, 65. Of Monticello, FL., died Thursday, March 12. A native of NYC and former resident of Sarasota, FL., and Greenwich, CT. She was a watercolor artist whose work has been displayed nationally and internationally. She was a humanitarian and environmentalist. She is survived by a son, Robert Knox of Monticello, FL, a daughter Ellen Knox Ward, of Saudi Arabia, a brother Kerry Fox of Fullerton, CA., and two grandchildren. Memorial services will be announced and held in May in Florida.

title: Sports of The Times; From the Olympics to the Collegiate Championships to 2002 and Beyond
description: SOMEONE had to stay home and do the domestic chores. Someone had to build on the foundation of women's hockey where it really counted, in the schools. That's what Brandy Fisher's friend, the Olympian Chris Bailey, told her when Fisher didn't survive a painful national team roster cut. Likewise her coach, Karen Kay, who didn't make it either.

title: Do Preferred Shares Close the Door?
description: An investor has brought a lawsuit challenging a recent move by Gabelli Equity Trust to offer preferred shares. The suit, on behalf of all shareholders entitled to vote at the annual meeting last year, was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan and seeks to rescind a 1997 vote that allowed the shares to be issued.

title: The Amistad, in Multimedia Rendering
description: THE more one learns about the Amistad episode, the more it captures the imagination. The true story of a group of Africans kidnapped by slave traders in 1839 and of their rebellion aboard the Spanish ship Amistad, has -- during the past decade -- been the subject of scholarly books, novels, exhibitions and documentaries, not to mention Steven Spielberg's movie. Yet each exposure reveals new facets of the tale, new characters well known in their day who had been all but forgotten in our century.

title: Jodi Fragin, Bruce Falbaum
description: Jodi Lee Fragin and Bruce Alan Falbaum were married last evening by Rabbi David Geffen at Temple Israel in Scranton, Pa.

title: The Nuke Of the 90's
description: Although a favorite of economic pundits, Roger Altman's argument that globalization exposes economies to greater risks makes little sense. Just as investors reduce their risks by diversifying their portfolios, economies reduce their risks by diversifying their customer bases and sources of supplies. A global economy permits greater diversification.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Sometimes a street fighter is called for.''

title: Just Let 'Em Carry Grocery Bags
description: To the Editor:

title: Conciliator Who Changed a Dress Code
description: The man who would clothe New York City's half-million elementary schoolchildren in uniforms has never worn one himself, having missed the national trend toward such dress codes in public school by about 30 years.

title: March 15-21; Virtual Elvis
description: Elvis is alive. True believers know that. Even as the decades melt away, they hold out for a glorious, hip-swiveling Second Coming. No ersatz Elvis for them!

title: PERIPHERALS
description: The difference between a man who's just dressed and a well-dressed man is in his choice of accessories. Here is where he defines his individual style elegant businessman, modern minimalist, sporty activist or a combination of all three. The signature looks of this season include English-style shoes for business, sandals for play, iridescent ties, modernist-style watches, suede belts with brushed metal buckles, streamlined sneakers and messenger-style bags. Put them all together, they spell: Spring '98.

title: As Pre-K Programs Expand, a Successful One Is Canceled
description: Albert Nalle and his wife, Amy Paulsen, live with their two daughters in a building the family owns far west on 21st Street. Four years ago, after making the rounds of private nursery schools, Mr. and Ms. Paulsen decided to send their older daughter to the pre-kindergarten program at Public School 11, on 21st Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. ''We thought it was better,'' Mr. Nalle said. ''It had more space, was well staffed and had lots of toys. And the pre-K room opened right up onto their own playground.'' He became an active parent in the school, and, he said, his faith in public schools was restored.

title: Americana
description: SOMETHING great is about to happen at American Fare, a serious but informal restaurant that opened last May. You can tell after sampling the appetizers, which are almost as good as they sound -- and they sound wonderful. Listen to a few from a recent menu: a bitter-greens bisque brightened with Madeira and edible nasturtium blossoms; buttery paillards of salmon dripping cream and Dijon mustard, and a risotto with roasted pumpkin and acorn squash that is slightly overcooked but delicious.

title: Controlling Unruly Classrooms
description: What steps would you propose to control unruly classrooms?

title: Queens West Pioneers Are Getting Company
description: WE were looking for a place we could afford,'' said Linda DiBrita. A 30-year-old who works for a bank and plans to start a business as a quilt maker, she and her husband, Anthony, a lawyer, had been renting in a brownstone in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn last year when they decided they needed more space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ALFRED G.
description: COHEN-Alfred G. 85. Died March 15, 1998. He was the president of Macon Umbrella Corp., located in Brooklyn, NY. Mr. Cohen pioneered in the use of aluminum in the construction of the garden umbrella, winning awards from his national trade association. He was instrumental in the formation of the Association of the National Summer Furniture Manufacturers and was an officer of the Association for many years. He was also an active member of the committee that built the Israel Center of Hillcrest Manor in Queens. Mr. Cohen leaves behind his beloved wife of 60 years, Mildred; his children, Michael Cohen, Ellen Masters and Marilyn Cohen Savryn; and his grandchildren, Marc and Caryn Masters and Sophia and Penny Savryn. Family man, friend and businessman, Al was loved and respected and will be dearly missed. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or the Boys Club of New York.

title: Public Radio Offers Substance, Not Style
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: A Student Center for Sarah Lawrence; Combining Old and New
description: Until recently, students at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers didn't have a real student center. But they had their beloved Pub, a rambling fieldstone building that offered little more than a snack bar, seating for 70, and a room with a pool table.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; Losing Houses, Losing Myself
description: THERE are certain buildings around us that resonate so strongly with character that people begin almost to identify with them. To those who know the steady feel of such places, losing one can take a bit of the sustaining joy out of daily life.

title: Playing Down the Rock-Star Image on Screen
description: THE married British playwright is in love with a young actress and feels guilty. A boyishly handsome American movie star volunteers to seduce the playwright's wife, just to help out (''At least she'd get her confidence back,'' the American says). The playwright takes him up on his offer. In fact, the wife is not the only character who ends up in bed with this brash, apparently irresistible young man, played by Jon Bon Jovi.

title: Sunday, March 22, 1998: MOVIES; Oscar Cop
description: Scott Miller has won hundreds of Oscars, all of them in court. As Legal Rights Coordinator for the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, which awards the Oscars tomorrow night, Miller enforces the Byzantine rule book that dictates legal use of the statuette's name and image. The rule manual is tremendous, roughly the size of a Bible, moans one studio adman, who struggles with its many edicts. For example: the commandment that only Best Picture-winning films can have Oscar's image on videocassette packages, a single, preapproved likeness no taller than an inch.

title: Sponsorship Unites Port With a Disabled Athlete
description: It was an unusual alliance: a disabled sailor from Miami and the Maritime Association of the Port of New York/New Jersey. But in sponsoring David Schroeder in international yacht racing, the maritime group saw something intangible but positive for both sides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPOCK, DR. BENJAMIN
description: SPOCK-Dr. Benjamin. With admiration and thanks from a grateful parent. Geraldine L. Boone

title: On Iona Campus, Students' Euphoria Turns Into Heartbreak
description: THE ''whoop'' nine days ago that thundered out of Rice Hall, a residential dormitory on Iona College's campus here, sounded as if the movie ''Animal House'' was being remade. But inside, at midday, no toga party raged. Instead, more than 200 Iona students, faculty members and workers cheered, stomped and groaned to the big-screen image of their team playing Syracuse University in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in Lexington, Ky.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 1 about the Academy Award categories for best original dramatic score and best original musical or comedy score misidentified the music supervisor for the 1997 film ''My Best Friend's Wedding.'' She is Bonnie Greenberg, not Lisa Brown.

title: Classical Music; A Composer Who Actually Earns a Living Composing
description: FORGET the Beethovenian model of the composer: wild-eyed, hair askew, struggling with recalcitrant material, shaking a fist at the gods. And the Romantic myth of the composer as bohemian, starving in a lonely garret, knowing that recognition will come only after death.

title: IN THE SALON WITH: Yancy Butler; As Tough As Nails? Well . . .
description: A MANICURE and a swipe of polish on neatly filed nails are about the only fashion fixes these days for Yancy Butler. But Ms. Butler, the raspy-voiced actress who plays Anne-Marie Kersey, the embattled police officer on the CBS-TV drama ''Brooklyn South,'' finds them harder to get.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Flesh Wounds By Mick Cochrane. Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $21.95.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Things That Got Away
description: On a dazzling autumn morning, Mark Random, the narrator of the title story in Dabney Stuart's delightful collection, THE WAY TO COBBS CREEK (University of Missouri, paper, $16.95), is standing knee-deep in the Connecticut River when he hooks a ''gorgeous'' brown trout, then inexplicably lets it slide out of his grasp. But maybe this isn't so surprising, since Mark seems to have let much in life slip away -- marriages, children, jobs. Now ''nearing the bogey of middle age,'' he is lost in his memories, trying to come to terms with his distant, hard-drinking father and thinking about ''making my manhood my own -- you know, catching it.'' Fishing serves as both primary setting and central metaphor for Mark's struggle. As his last name suggests, there is a haphazard quality to his ruminations, and the story, composed of a series of vignettes from his life, moves back and forth through time, sometimes in a confusing fashion. Yet Stuart's lush and lyrical prose propels the reader onward. Scene after scene is described with remarkable attention to detail, slowly and subtly building in emotional intensity. The three other stories in this collection are equally strong, and each concerns a character who has had an influence on Mark's life. The final one, about Willy Parole, a handyman who worked for Mark's grandparents, features a gleeful abundance of appropriately colorful language. ''No one would ever know how long he could have sustained his prodigious capacity for pleasure and recuperation,'' Stuart writes, describing Willy's father, Phoenix, a legendary drunk who died at 35, ''and his legend had no fitting cap, no ecstatic expiration at the moment of climax among a bevy of his doves.'' What's memorable in these stories is not the climax but the prose that's encountered along the way. Maggie Garb

title: Backtalk; New Sign Of Spring: Murdoch
description: Like a tall dog who attacks a bear to remind himself he is still a tall dog, Ted Turner took a run at Rupert Murdoch last week, barking and nipping just enough to make himself felt but not unwelcome, then he retreated into the pack. As expected, the bear was then declared king of the jungle.

title: Lunchtime in Paris
description: In Paris, women are lunching in Edwardian-style Dior necklaces that fill the necklines of their low-cut suit jackets. The fashion was first seen in the first decade of this century when Queen Alexandra of Britain wore jewelry during the day that most women saved for evening wear. The romantic, over-the-top look of John Galliano for Dior has set this current revival of Edwardian opulence in motion. His talent is like a glamorous tornado, striking the uniformed minimalist style of the computer age.

title: Pasta Are the Stars in a Welcome Return
description: IT is homecoming in Port Washington. Romantico is back. Yesteryear's loyal regulars, flashing smiles and giving hugs, are flocking here. The warmth flows both ways. It takes no more than the drop of a menu for one of the owners to gush about his love for Long Islanders.

title: The Hidden Half of Central Park
description: COUNTRY, PARK, & CITY

title: Developmentally Disabled Want Institutions Closed
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, SUE G.
description: GREENBERG-Sue G. On March 21, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin; loving mother of Carolyn. Her life was devoted to her family and to the many organizations to which she was dedicated. Services Monday, 12 noon, at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street.

title: Sand Trap
description: THE ROAD TO UBAR

title: Trips for Those Going Solo
description: A YOUNG friend -- she is real but her name is legion -- asks what sort of trip she could take by herself where she would not be marching off and on a bus all day long, or end up at a table by herself in a hotel dining room. Her recent relationship just broke up and she is not really looking for someone particular, but she wants to get away and meet some new people. She said she would pay a single supplement to get some privacy.

title: Of Ideas, A Table Of Plenty
description: IT is easy to understand why the director Cara Caldwell Watson was drawn to the content of ''Wenceslas Square'' by Larry Shue. But where is style? Where is the essence? Where's the play?

title: Three Big Musicals, Three Fates
description: I believe in the power of St. Lazarus.

title: Dinosaurs and Friends Head for Philadelphia
description: New York has the Unisphere, Seattle the Space Needle. Philadelphia is getting a Nuerosaurus -- for a month, anyway.

title: Woodlands and roses, for all of Seattle
description: As an avid gardener, I am constantly poking around Seattle's public gardens. Here are two of my favorites:

title: POSTINGS: On-the-Spot Answers to Nagging Questions; Co-op, Condo Expo at Hilton
description: If your co-op or condominium is grappling with a water or sewer question, including billing problems, it could get an on-the-spot answer at the Co-op and Condo Expo to be held March 31 from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the New York Hilton on Avenue of the Americas and 53d Street.

title: Sports Betting Ring
description: A yearlong joint investigation has led to the seizure of $200,000 in cash and the arrest of six men on charges related to alleged sports gambling activities in Chubby's Deli in Eastchester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALMENSON, EDITH
description: CALMENSON-Edith. On March 18, 1998. Dearest wife of Kermit, mother of Stephanie and Michael, sister of Evelyn and Estelle.

title: Purists Beware: Jazz Is Making Peace With Rock
description: JAZZ prides itself on being a high art, but since the days of Tin Pan Alley, it has lifted material from music intended for the masses -- the show tunes of composers like George Gershwin, Cole Porter and Jerome Kern. From Art Tatum to Sonny Rollins, jazz musicians have taken American popular songs into the laboratory of improvisation, proving their staying power as standards. Today, a new generation of jazz musicians is attempting a similar experiment with a different sort of pop: the rock and rhythm-and-blues of the last three decades. And although jazz musicians have occasionally dabbled with the tunes of Lennon and McCartney and the like, the breadth of today's work -- and its inclusion of rock -- is striking. Jazz musicians are riffing on everything from James Brown to Nirvana, and their interpretive approaches vary just as widely.

title: Teaching My Daughter The World Is Open
description: Your article ''What to Teach Our Daughters'' [March 1] prompted much discussion among mothers in my community, especially those of us who would fall within the author's ''strange breed of woman'' known as ''soccer Moms.'' The author seemingly looks at the decision whether or not to stay at home and raise one's children as an all-or-nothing proposition -- and, unfortunately, she is missing what is probably the most important aspect of that decision. Most stay-at-home moms (which is in itself an oxymoron since we rarely seem to be home at all and are anything but the robotic-like drones she conjures up) I know are well-educated women who left, temporarily, very exciting and rewarding careers. Many of us (myself included) are fortunate enough to achieve a wonderful balance by working part-time to keep our careers afloat during the children's younger years and to keep a sense of ourselves. But what the author fails to discuss is the fact that most women (I am not referring to those who must work due to economic factors) make a deliberate, conscious decision to raise their children because they want to! It's something that comes so naturally to many, if not most, women -- that old maternal instinct kicks in from the first wail in the delivery room, and the thought of having a stranger care for and guide that precious child through its childhood is completely incompatible with everything you've ever dreamed of. This is not to say that women who chose to work are doing anything wrong. It's just that I don't believe that we have to ''teach'' our daughters that they must make a decision between having a career and having an identity. One can take a break from a carreer and still be a successful and fulfilled woman. It's all in how you look at it and how you prioritize.

title: Lifting the Veil
description: In Search of

title: Park Service Considering Developing Water Gap Trails
description: Though millions pass through the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area each year, not many get out of their cars to walk around. That is partly because there are only half a dozen officially designated trails and some other unofficial ones. The National Park System is considering developing a more extensive system and plans to hold meetings next week to present its ideas and get comments.

title: This Order Feeds Chaos Among Rivals in Kosovo
description: The Device Convent, with its thick wooden doors, chilly stone chapel, rows of wooden beehives and thick white marble cemetery crosses, has always served as a barometer in times of war.

title: Ideas & Trends; Step Right Up and See Grass Grow and Paint Dry
description: IT is 2:07 A.M., and not much is happening in the icy gloom of a Nordic night in Kotka, Finland. A few street lights glow faintly along a two-lane highway that bends across a snowy plain into town. But for at least 20 minutes, nothing stirs on this forlorn road.

title: LOCKER GROOM
description: To deal with the tensions of handling high-end properties, the New York City real estate broker Daniel Stoiano gets to the gym every day. He has his program down pat, moving through a full aerobic and weight-resistance workout in 45 minutes. Then he heads for the locker room and his equally well-organized grooming routine. Snugly stored in Stoiano's gym bag is a collection of compact aluminum bottles in which he keeps a conditioning shampoo that does not dry out his hair, nonirritating soap and oil-free moisturizer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, FREDERICK T.
description: ZIMMERMAN-Frederick T. Distinguished physician, father and friend, age 95, on March 12, 1998. Survived by daughter, Mary Louise Schwarz; grandchildren, Kurt A., Holly Rae and her husband, Jeffrey Hardy. Expressions of remembrance should be directed to Leonard J. Lucas Funeral Home, Shamokin, PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAATA, MARY S.
description: FLAATA-Mary S., 85. On March 18, 1998. Beloved mother of Joni Chadkin and Kirsti Madeo. Beloved sister of Marcella Waldman. Beloved grandmother of Helen and Francesca Madeo. Memorial services will be held in New York City in April.

title: Correction
description: An article on March 1 about Russian immigrants settling on the East End misspelled the names of several new residents. They are Alla Kouznetsova, Alex Kouznetsov, Ivan Brativnyk and Maja Brativnyk.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on March 1 about vandalism at the Bayside Cemetery in Queens misstated its location. It is in Ozone Park, not South Ozone Park.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Feminists and the Clinton Question
description: If all the sexual allegations now swirling around the White House turn out to be true, President Clinton may be a candidate for sex addiction therapy. But feminists will still have been right to resist pressure by the right wing and the media to call for his resignation or impeachment. The pressure came from another case of the double standard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, NENA
description: GOODMAN-Nena. On March 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Andrew Goodman. Devoted mother of Vivien G. Malloy, Mary Ann Quinson, Edwin A. Goodman and Pamela Lichty. Loving grandmother of Andrew T., Deborah Malloy Winkler, Kenneth H., Mark L. and Vivien C. Malloy; Geoffrey, Luke, Adam and Joshua Taylor; Sara and Thea Goodman; Will and Simone Lichty. Great grandmother of Courtney and Caitlin, Connor, Maggie, Kenneth Jr., Shane Malloy; James, John and Alexandra Taylor. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84 St., Monday 10 A.M. Those desiring may send flowers or contributions in her memory may be made to National Jewish Center, Immunology and Respiratory Medicine, 1400 Jackson St., Denver, CO 80206; or the International Rescue Committee, 122 East 42nd Street, 12 Flr, New York, NY 10017; or The Alcoholism Council of Greater NY, 352 Park Avenue South, 8th Floor, NY, NY 10010.

title: Standing Up for Adam Purple; The City Turns On Its Living Treasures
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: Princeton's Nude Run Is Undone by Weather
description: In ancient Rome, naked young men ran in circles around Palatine Hill as part of a fertility ritual. Nowadays at Princeton University, the first snowfall of the year brings the Nude Olympics, in which naked young people of both sexes run around the university's Holder courtyard for no clearly discernible reason.

title: Goodwill Games Call World's Athletes to Nassau
description: WITH the completion of a $30 million swimming and diving center in Eisenhower Park this month, Long Island takes a big plunge into international aquatics competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARROW, VICTOR
description: SHARROW-Victor. Died March 11, 1998. Age 79. Survived by his wife Naomi Sharrow and two children Loralee Sheridan, Newport Beach, CA, and Joel, Garrison, NY, and four grandchildren.

title: No-Show Snow's Budget Impact
description: THIS has been one of the least snowy winters on record in Connecticut, a meteorological anomaly that comes only two seasons after the all-time snowiest. The 1995-1996 season caused huge deficits in municipal snow plowing budgets, but anyone hoping for equally large surpluses in those accounts this year will be disappointed.

title: Baseball's Real Tradition
description: When media tycoon Rupert Murdoch bought the Los Angeles Dodgers from the descendants of Walter O'Malley last Thursday, there was much wringing of hands over the fact that the era of family ownership in Major League Baseball had finally ended, and that a new era of exclusively corporate ownership was at hand. Yet before too many tears are shed, let one truth be known. Baseball owners break fans' hearts, and that aspect of the game is not likely to change. It was Walter O'Malley who brought grief to Brooklyn, Horace Stoneham who silenced the old Polo Grounds, Clark Griffith who transported the Washington Senators to Minneapolis. Let us also not forget the wandering Athletics and the peripatetic Braves.

title: Rachel Rodin, Joshua Wolman
description: Rachel Beth Rodin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Rodin of Chevy Chase, Md., was married last evening to Joshua Philip Wolman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Wolman of Chestnut Hill, Mass. Rabbi Mindy A. Portnoy officiated at the Willard Hotel in Washington.

title: Slow Escalators, Short Fuses
description: With nerves frayed and jaws set in anger, merchants along Roosevelt Avenue near Main Street are bracing for five additional months of fewer customers and lower profits because of delays in installing subway escalators.

title: Young Swimmers Ready to Make Impact
description: BRENDAN NELIGAN will take about 15 minutes to swim 1,650 yards in his next race. And now he can make it home even quicker.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the On the Towns pages last Sunday for the percussionist Evelyn Glennie's concerts with the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra this Thursday through Sunday misstated the telephone number for tickets. It is (800) 255-3476.

title: Dear Shareholder: The Dog Ate Our Earnings
description: THREE years ago it was O. J. Simpson's fault. In 1996, the Summer Olympic Games were blamed. Just last fall the fingers were pointed at Diana, Princess of Wales, of all people. When companies lose money, seemingly nothing is safe from taking the blame, except, maybe, the companies themselves.

title: Taking Work Home With Them
description: Sure, they sell their handbags to department stores like Bloomingdale's and Macy's. But Cherie Christmas, 35, and her husband, Yakob Assayag, 42, partners in Maxx New York, seem especially fond of their smaller customers, the specialty stores that carry their wares.

title: Flying Solo: Women Shun a Package Deal With Men
description: To survive alone or to thrive together, that is the millennial question that the men's and women's tennis tours, two separate businesses with little but a sport in common, will have to answer this week during the coed Lipton Championships.

title: A Time-Lapse Portrait of Princeton and Its Inhabitants
description: WHEN a Civil War veteran named Royal Hill Rose opened his photography studio in Princeton in 1873, the medium was just emerging from its infancy. But it grew up considerably in the 78 years and three generations that the studio remained in the Rose family. By the time the studio closed in 1951, photography was a part of daily life.

title: Huskies Just Can't Beat Tar Heels' Experience
description: Different place, different circumstances. Same result.

title: For Krzyzewski and Duke, Another Step in Restoration
description: Mike Krzyzewski has coached in big games, coached big-time players and coached against them. He has been in big places and in big arenas and has confronted huge odds and won. He has been through so much. He is a warrior, a survivor.

title: Philharmonic Debut for a Tribute to L.I.
description: WHEN Agnes de Mille said, ''The truest expression of a people is in its music,'' she might have thought of Dana Perna of Syosset. This weekend Mr. Perna will have his symphonic voice heard at the premiere of his ''Three Places on Long Island''by the Long Island Philharmonic under the baton of David Lockington at Tilles Center.

title: Let's Make a Deal
description: SINGING INTO THE PIANO

title: Rangers Arise From Torpor Too Late to Catch Red Wings
description: Of the 20 players in Ranger uniforms yesterday, only five were with the team when it won the Stanley Cup so long ago, in 1994. Perhaps they could tell the other 15 what it was like back then to blend talent, desire and good fortune to make a championship season.

title: Don't Blame Modernists for the Empty Seats
description: SERMONS on the decline of music come oddly from the lips of a Lloyd Webber, but Julian, the cellist brother of the composer of ''Cats'' and the like, took the opportunity of a platform at the World Economic Forum last month in Davos, Switzerland, to express his views on the eclipse of classical music in the West. Fewer people are attending concerts; fewer classical CD's are being sold; fewer students in the United States and Europe are studying at music schools. And why? Because, Mr. Lloyd Webber is reported to have said, ''for 40 years of madness . . . classical music turned its back on audiences.''

title: PULSE; Falling in Step
description: For a sneaker that was once looked upon by the fashion-conscious as the Volvo of running shoes, New Balance is making big strides. Drab, gray-on-gray New Balances are suddenly emblems of low-profile, retro coolness. And a new candy-colored line is raising the hip quotient further. Previously sold only in Paris, London and Tokyo, the colorful sneakers -- in purple, red, orange, acid green or powder blue suede -- are showing up on New York streets. They recently arrived at Active Wearhouse, 514 Broadway (Spring Street), where brisk sales were reported last week, despite the $150 price tag. And New Balance plans to make a limited number available in six to eight weeks across the country in stores to be announced later.

title: March 15-21; Fate of 5 Athletes From Cuba Is in Doubt
description: Four baseball players and a coach were reported to have fled Cuba in a flimsy boat on March 10, and at first they were feared to have drowned at sea. But on Friday a Miami television station, WTVJ, reported having been told by a relative that the four had reached the Dominican Republic the day before -- ''barely alive.''

title: Tigers Take High Road
description: PRINCETON 5, CLARKSON 4

title: Q&A/Guy R. Mazza; Counsel for Keeping Utility Bills Down
description: THE Office of Consumer Counsel represents customers of the state's five regulated utilities -- gas, electric, cable, water and telephone. The name doesn't ring bells with most people, but it probably should. The Consumer Counsel's primary task is to keep those monthly bills reasonable.

title: 3 Men Accused of Killing Brooklyn Father
description: An unemployed Brooklyn man found dead in his ransacked apartment on Wednesday afternoon had been tied up, beaten, asphyxiated and then urinated on by a former roommate and two accomplices who wanted to steal his stereo, the police said yesterday.

title: Devils' Friendship With Power Play Is Quickly Restored
description: The Devils' power play, slowed since Doug Gilmour's knee surgery eight games ago, had come up empty on 20 chances in four games. But tonight the team scored two power-play goals that proved the key in a 3-2 victory over the Washington Capitals.

title: Investing in Future, States Spend More on Preschool Classes
description: State lawmakers across the country are beginning to recognize what first-grade teachers like Roseann DeLuca have long known: Children who attend full-day kindergarten and preschool are far better prepared to succeed in school than those who do not.

title: The Other Side Of Parsonage Allowances
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report article on Feb. 22, about the Haghia Sophia in Istanbul, misstated the names of the organization and program that placed it on an endangered sites list, and of their spokeswoman. The group is the World Monuments Fund, which runs the World Monuments Watch (not the World Monument Fund and World Monument Watch). The spokeswoman is Anne Edgar, not Anne Edwards.

title: Exploring Strategies To Financing Child Care
description: WHEN President Clinton visited the region recently, he stopped at a day-care center in Connecticut, posing with toddlers while making a public push for Congress to act on his $21.7 billion child care proposal. The plan would provide tax breaks and subsidies to help working families pay for child care. The proposal would also increase the number of after-school programs, promote early learning and improve safety and quality of the programs.

title: Get Out the Chromosomal Map
description: Mendel's Dwarf

title: UP AND COMING: Robin Tunney; A Young 'Best Actress' Takes the Plunge in 'Niagara, Niagara'
description: ROBIN TUNNEY is game. ''If something scares you, it's probably a good thing,'' she said. And in ''Niagara, Niagara,'' a small-budget drama that opened on Friday, the 25-year-old actress has taken an artistic risk not unlike going over the falls in a barrel.

title: Miss Edmunds, Mr. Bennett
description: Elizabeth Margaret Edmunds and Mark Joseph Bennett were married yesterday in Cedarhurst, N.Y. Msgr. John Bugman, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Joachim's Church.

title: We're Doomed! Story at 11, Facts Tomorrow
description: WITH the unending hysteria about sexual activity in Washington, the recent shocker from the astronomy beat, accompanied as it was by screaming front pages and gravely emoting television anchors, was shaping up as a grand diversion. In my mind, headlines were spinning like the ones in movies from the 1930's:

title: Style; Bread and Circuses
description: At the Hard Rock Cafe, for the price of a hamburger, the customer gains admission to a museum of music memorabilia. The food is beside the point. It's the privilege of eating beneath Jimi Hendrix's guitar that has made the place a destination. There are now 85 Hard Rock Cafes in 29 countries, and in the wake of their success any number of other restaurants-as-theme-parks have sprung up -- among them, the All Star Cafe (a mecca for sports fans) and the Fashion Cafe (for supermodel wannabes). As marketing concepts go, this one looked to be harmless enough -- a novelty business that targeted a particular field of interest. It is only lately that these ventures have emerged as part of a larger trend, now that other restaurants, including some with serious menus and superior ratings, are striving to provide amusement.

title: March 15-21; A Vatican Apology to Jews
description: Eleven years after it was first promised, the Vatican issued a document on the role of the Catholic church during the Holocaust that left many observers wondering why it had taken so long.

title: On Language; Retronym Watch
description: Used to be, your partner was the guy you were in business with. Now the word needs modification. We have life partners, people in a state of permanent cohabitation, straight or gay, connoting a more equal relationship than companion or live-in boy- or girlfriend.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; First Phase Begun on a Hoboken Riverfront Project
description: UNTIL recently all that could be seen up and down this city's prized mile-long riverfront were the ghosts of its industrial past. Now, adjacent to a new three-acre riverfront park, 20 derelict acres at the northern end of the waterfront that were once home to the Bethlehem Steel Shipyard are being transformed into a mixed-use enclave of 1,160 residences called The Shipyard.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 22, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Nowhere Man
description: I began reading with considerable excitement Michael Lowenthal's essay on his encounter with the Djerban Jewish community and visit to Al Ghriba, the legendary synogague on this Tunisian island (''Nowhere Man,'' March 1). That excitement quickly turned to dismay when I realized he was using the space to reconfirm his own cynicism and rootlessness at the expense of a place that has special meaning for many of us.

title: The Other Ellis Island
description: Mention Ellis Island, and many people think only of the main hall on the north side, lovingly and expensively restored a decade ago and reopened in 1990 as a wonderful museum. It's understandable why that part of the island gets all the attention. That main hall was the immigrant experience; just about everyone landing on the island had to pass through it. What better place to teach millions of tourists a year about the hardships, hopes and indeed the raw courage of those who left everything in the old country to build a new life from scratch.

title: SOAPBOX; Missing the Point
description: ON a rainy Thursday night in mid-October, a national cable television audience watched the Syracuse University football team crush an overmatched and undermanned Rutgers Scarlet Knights squad 50-3 in a half-filled Rutgers Stadium.

title: Silent Hotels / Building Boom Goes Bust : 5-Star Luxury at Bargain Prices
description: SURABAJA, Indonesia  Welcome to the executive suite at the five-star Hotel Majapahit, a celebration of marble, Oriental rugs and gold plate.

title: Military Gets Main Use of Big Computers
description: At a time when the demand for supercomputers among American scientists far outstrips availability, the Federal Government is rapidly shifting its spending for the fastest and most powerful machines to weapons research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, EMANUEL
description: ROSENTHAL-Emanuel on March 22, 1998. Cherished uncle of Harold Rosenthal and Beth Rosenthal Finkel. Adored great-uncle. Graveside services 2 PM at Mt. Hebron.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERKOTTER, PAUL
description: OBERKOTTER-Paul. The National Center for Disability Services mourns the passing of Paul Oberkotter, a dear friend and supporter of programs for children and adults with disabilities. His efforts leave a lasting legacy that will improve the lives of countless future generations. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. The National Center for Disability Services expresses their heartfelt condolences to his daughter Mildred, grandchildren, greatgrandchildren, family and friends. Edmund L. Cortez, President and CEO The Board of Directors, National Center for Disability Services

title: Belfast Journal; The Chain This Catholic Wears Speaks Volumes
description: There is no greater citadel of Protestant power here than the domed and columned Belfast City Hall, and as a Roman Catholic, Alban Maginness was wary of even going near it.

title: For ABC, the Academy Awards show means a badly needed big audience.
description: FOR ABC, which is broadcasting tonight's Academy Awards show, the stars seem to be in perfect alignment.

title: Sports of The Times; Duke-Kentucky II: A Sequel to Remember
description: SEQUELS are very rarely as good as the original. As Kentucky Coach Tubby Smith said on Friday when he was asked about the classic 1992 Duke-Kentucky game: the stars have to be right.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CADENA, ISABEL
description: CADENA-Isabel. 3/15/83. Beloved Mommy-15 long years. I miss you more than ever. Rest in heavenly peace. With eternal love, Judy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, JUDITH
description: TUCKER-Judith. All her friends and people in the bridge world whose lives she touched are deeply saddened and mourn the passing of our beloved Judy Tucker. Memorial service Wednesday, April 1, 5 PM, Honors Bridge Club, 115 East 57th St., NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUMARKIN, CAROLYN KUNST
description: TUMARKIN-Carolyn Kunst. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Beloved mother and grandmother. An active civic and human rights leader and advocate, she will be missed. Services Monday, 11 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: INSIDE
description: Charge in Student's Killing

title: Princeton, Yale Set for Tourney
description: Princeton's first trip to the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament will begin Friday in Ann Arbor, Mich., where the Tigers will play Michigan in a first-round West Regional game.

title: Cendant Is Expected to Get Miami Insurer for $3.1 Billion
description: Henry R. Silverman, the chief executive of the Cendant Corporation, is expected to announce today that his company is buying a little-known Miami insurance company for $3.1 billion in cash and stock, ending nearly eight weeks of corporate combat with Maurice R. Greenberg, the chief executive of the American International Group, one of the country's biggest insurers.

title: Don't You Wish You Could Get Buttered Popcorn in Civics Class?
description: Mike Nichols, the director of ''Primary Colors,'' and the studio executives involved in the film have insisted all along that their movie about a Southern governor's political ascendancy is not really about Bill Clinton.

title: Yugoslavs Try to Outwit Albright Over Sanctions
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, may have made just enough concessions over the conflict in Kosovo Province to confound Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's efforts to intensify Western sanctions against him, American and European officials said today.

title: For Connecticut, Next Season Has Begun
description: Your team was not supposed to be challenging for the Final Four this season. Not really. Just get the players acquainted with the free-spirited, chunky point guard, watch the team mature around him and his skinny sidekick, snag a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and battle valiantly before vanishing. Then get your developing team ready for next season and the true, splashy unveiling.

title: How a Child Learns to Read; Classroom Experts
description: To the Editor:

title: Fortune Bucks Critics And Covers Its Parent
description: It is a delicate business when a publication covers its parent company. When the news is negative, it is particularly sticky. When the news is positive, it has the potential to get downright gooey.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Monday with an article about Republican gains in the South misstated the party affiliations of several states' governors and senators and the makeup of their Congressional delegations in 1980 and 1990. A corrected version appears today on page A12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TASCHEREAU, JULIA ELIZABETH
description: TASCHEREAU-Julia Elizabeth. On Monday, March 16, 1998. Loving mother of Elizabeth Combier and Julia Danger. Cherished grandmother of Julie, Sari, Michael, Healani, Elise and Marielle. Memorial service on Tuesday, March 24, at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 8 PM.

title: Forget About the Next Star; Look for What's Different
description: The line to see the seminal New York rock band Sonic Youth spilled outside the club La Zona Rosa here on Thursday, winding along Fourth Street in a motley, traffic-blocking mess of teen-agers and music industry drones. Though the club was already full, the crowd was reluctant to leave. The occasion was the South by Southwest convention, which in 12 years has changed from a showcase for local acts to the reigning meet-and-greet of the rock business.

title: Essay; U.S. Versus Clinton
description: By defiantly asserting that he and his aides are above the criminal law -- the essence of his claim last Friday of ''executive privilege'' -- Bill Clinton has increased the likelihood of their indictment and his impeachment.

title: Club Med Appears Headed for Publicis
description: Club Mediterranee S. A. in Paris, the struggling resort operator, is expected to announce today that it will consolidate its worldwide advertising account at Publicis S. A. in Paris, according to executives who have been told of the company's plans. Billings on the account, which Publicis handled from 1992 to 1995, were not disclosed.

title: Unsealing History
description: To the Editor:

title: Using a Key That Still Works; Smith Corona's Future Rests in Putting Its Name on Other Products
description: For people who remember it at all, the name Smith Corona conjures up but one thing: typewriters. These were the manuals they hauled off to college, the portable electrics they typed their resumes on. These were the products that made Smith Corona a titan of this working-class town.
