title: False Starts Aside, Virtual Reality Finds New Roles
description: While virtual reality has played a leading role in science fiction and popular culture since it was introduced in the 1980's, it has had little impact in the business arena. But the languishing technology may finally reach the spotlight now that Sun Microsystems Inc. has acquired the rights to many of virtual reality's defining elements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRIE, STANLEY R.
description: CURRIE-Stanley R. The Board of Directors of the Seligman Group of Mutual Funds and Tri-Continental Corporation have learned with profound regret of the death on March 16 of Stanley R. Currie, a member of the Board from 1971 until his retirement in 1993. Mr. Currie served the Seligman Funds and Tri-Continental Corporation with distinction for many years as the Director of Research. We extend our sincere condolences to the Currie family. Seligman Group of Mutual Funds Tri-Continental Corporation

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Feb. 20 with an article about the fifth time the death penalty was being sought in Brooklyn misstated the number of times that capital punishment has been sought in Erie County. It is once, not twice.

title: Hilton Hotels and Circus Circus Call Off Merger Talks
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation and Circus Circus Enterprises have called off merger talks that would have created the world's largest casino company, industry officials said today.

title: What the Elephant Forgot
description: A friend of mine recently ran for office on the ticket of a right-of-center political party. He'd call me late at night, after finishing a hard day of campaigning, and burst into a self-mocking parody of the speeches he had been embarrassing himself by making from dawn to dusk. ''Let me say how sickened I am by the evils of child abuse! I yield to no one in my condemnation of the illegal trade in puppies! We must move ahead, while leaving nobody behind!''

title: Rice Survives Christ the King
description: Rice (22-4), ranked 18th in the nation, survived a scare yesterday and defeated Christ the King, 75-72, in the Catholic High School Athletic Association final in front of 2,700 at Fordham University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, VIOLA WERTHEIM, M.D.
description: BERNARD-Viola Wertheim, M.D. On March 21, 1998. Daughter of the late Jacob and Emma Wertheim. Beloved aunt of Joan Wofford and David Whittlesey. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

title: City's Public Toilets
description: To the Editor:

title: Dismantling of Arizona Will Follow Its Devastating Loss
description: In the span of 40 minutes, the time it took Utah to dismantle Arizona by 76-51 on Saturday, the Wildcats went from a team seemingly on the verge of repeating as collegiate basketball champion to one of the nation's biggest question marks for next season.

title: After 5 Years as Runners-Up, A Pair Takes the Top Honor
description: The most remarkable string of successes in the history of bridge ended here on Saturday, but in a positive fashion. In each of the last five National Championships, two top European players, Tony Forrester of Britain and Geir Helgemo of Norway, have finished second in a major national pairs championship. This time, in the Open Pairs, which began the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, they ended their streak by winning, and did so in convincing fashion, a board and a half ahead of their nearest rivals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMANUS, PHILIP F.
description: McMANUS-Philip F. Formerly of Rockville Centre, NY, on March 20, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth (nee Stouges). Loving and devoted father of George D., Philip F., Deirdre Soehner, Elizabeth Craig, and Bridget McManus. Adored grandfather of 14. Dear brother of Ruth Honerkamp and the late John J. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, Tuesday, 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral mass St. Agnes Cathedral Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Cross, Brooklyn, NY. Memorial contributions may be sent to Catholic Charities, Diocese of Rockville Centre, 50 No. Park Avenue, RVC, NY 11570.

title: The Psychic Dyspepsia In O'Neill's Tragic Journey
description: A meal is eaten, a whisky bottle drained, a foghorn sounded. Virtually nothing of real consequence occurs in ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' and yet, in its way, it is one of the bloodiest plays ever written.

title: Taking In the Sites; Finding Business Ethics on and About the Internet
description: The World Wide Web is not exactly a haven for good business ethics. It can be a lawless place filled with unscrupulous operators pushing get-rich-quick schemes and other scams.

title: How the New York Media Cover the New York Media: Intently
description: In a city where books merge into screenplays, where the news jumps from headlines onto the Broadway stage and magazines appear in cyberspace before they make it to the newsstand, it should come as no surprise that one of the hottest topics for the media in New York is, well, the media.

title: An Ambiguous E-Mail Trail in Torture Case
description: Just hours after prosecutors claim that he kidnapped and tortured a 20-year-old Barnard College student whom he had met on the Internet, Oliver Jovanovic sat down and typed her a computer message.

title: Witty Wins Another 1,000
description: The world record-holder and Olympic silver medalist Chris Witty won her second straight World Cup final 1,000-meter speed-skating race yesterday in her hometown of West Allis, Wis.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Mets Send Pulsipher Down, Despite Impressive Spring
description: Bill Pulsipher wanted more than anything to travel north with the Mets for opening day. But today he was sent to Class AAA Norfolk, where he will pitch an opening day of a sort he never wanted.

title: Putting the Elderly On the Couch
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutilation Seen as Risk For the Girls Of Immigrants
description: More than 160,000 girls and women in immigrant communities in the United States may have been victims of the traditional practice of genital mutilation or are at risk of being subjected to it, according to a report to be published today by a New York State Congresswoman active in a campaign to prosecute practitioners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSHAN, SARAH DAVIS
description: BUSHAN-Sarah Davis. The Auxiliary of Montefiore Medical Center is deeply saddened by the passing of Sarah Davis, a devoted member of the Auxiliary and a volunteer for over 40 years. We will miss her devotion to the Information and Referral Service. We extend our deepest sympathy to her son, Hank Davis. The Auxiliary of MMC Ruth Sapporta, President Mary D. Goldsmith, Secretary

title: Political Memo; In Election Year, Pataki Steers to Right
description: As the year began, Gov. George E. Pataki seemed to be avoiding strife, resting on his popularity in hopes of cruising to re-election in November. After three years of battling to cut budgets, he proposed a large spending increase and embraced Democratic programs like prekindergarten education, leaving Democrats little to quarrel with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWBURGER, STANLEY W.
description: NEWBURGER-Stanley W. March 19, 1998, at age 81. Professor of philosophy at SUNY New Paltz. Previously taught at Columbia where he received his Ph.D. A gentle, intelligent, generous man-deeply curious about the world-he will be much missed by his family and friends.

title: 3 BIG OIL NATIONS JOIN TO ANNOUNCE A PRODUCTION CUT
description: Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico, in a surprising show of cooperation, said yesterday that they would cut their crude oil production and that they had received pledges from other countries to make similar reductions in a move that is expected to reverse the sharp decline in oil prices.

title: Giving Something Back
description: The announcement of a $10 million gift to Brooklyn Technical High School from the school's alumni is a heartening development not only for one of the city's premier high schools, but also as an indication that business leaders are finding public schools worthy of investment. Leonard Riggio, chairman of Barnes & Noble booksellers, and John Catsimatidis, chairman of the Red Apple supermarket chain, both graduates of Brooklyn Tech, are leading a fund-raising campaign that has already brought in $2 million. The total amount, to be raised over five years, will create an endowment that may generate $800,000 a year for new equipment, teacher training, and curriculum expansion.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, RUTH
description: SIEGEL-Ruth. 86, died March 20, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Hyman Siegel; loving mother of Anita, Roy and Robert; grandmother of three. Funeral services Fort Lauderdale, FL.

title: A Defenseman Falls, and So Do the Rangers, in Overtime
description: At the end of a scrappy and entertaining mess of a hockey game tonight, Wayne Gretzky set another of his many records. He was showered, dressed and out of the locker room in a New York Ranger minute, stalking tight-lipped and visibly angry to the team bus for the long ride home in the dead of night.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about a gathering of the women who had accused Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney of sexual misconduct referred incorrectly to the type of uniform worn by most of them. It was the class A uniform, the military equivalent of a business suit -- not the dress uniform, equivalent to formal wear.

title: California Admissions
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Auction Bills and Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and the auction of two-year notes tomorrow and five-year notes on Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Friday in the ''On Stage and Off'' column of Weekend about the actor Brian Cox and his one-man show, ''St. Nicholas,'' at Primary Stages, misidentified the London theater where he first appeared in the play. It was the Bush Theater, not the Royal Court.

title: Yankees' Rotation Rounds Into Shape
description: More than a month ago, Joe Torre waved an unlit cigar with his right hand, like a professor wielding a pointer, and explained why he thought his starting pitchers presented the greatest unknown for what looked to be a great Yankees team.

title: Religious Right, Frustrated, Trying New Tactic on G.O.P.
description: Early in March, Paul Weyrich, the godfather of social conservatives, summoned about 25 prominent leaders from the religious and political right for a secret meeting in his office here overlooking the rail yards behind Union Station.

title: New Needs for Retirement Complexes' Oldest
description: When Herman and Annette Adelson moved to the Kings Point retirement community 20 years ago, they were happy to pay extra for a condominium on the second floor. The upstairs apartments offered breezes, better views of the golf course and, important to transplanted Northerners, fewer bugs.

title: Singer Pares Her Vision Of Love, Lost and Found
description: Some songwriters seem to emerge fully formed, with a gift for distilling stories and emotions into a few words and a shapely melody. Others improve as they go, and Shawn Colvin, who performed at Irving Plaza on Thursday night, is one of them. After winning two top 1997 Grammy Awards for her song ''Sunny Came Home,'' about an unhappy wife with visions of arson, she is touring as a solo performer.

title: Benjamin Bowden, 91, Auto and Bicycle Designer
description: Benjamin Bowden, an industrial designer who created a futuristic bicycle that became an expensive collector's item, died on March 6 in Lake Worth, Fla. He was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUHAUS, ELLEN
description: NEUHAUS-Ellen. On March 21, 1998, the 71st anniversiary of her marriage to her beloved late husband, Dr. Fritz Neuhaus. Born in Berlin, Germany, July 25, 1905, she was a refugee from Nazi Germany and a longtime resident of NYC and Miami Beach, FL. She is survived by her devoted children Dr. Robert P. Newhouse and his wife Mary of NYC, and Block Island, RI, and Marian Nachman of Greenwich, CT. Loving grandmother of Alisa Newhouse Smith of Los Angeles, Sarah Newhouse of Watertown, MA, Andrea Newhouse of NYC, Alex Nachman of Boston, MA, and Juliet Nachman of Oregon, and great-grandmother of Olivia Taylor Smith and Jules Haskell Smith of Los Angeles. Funeral services will be private.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Hilton Hotels Ends Bid To Acquire Circus Circus

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOKARZEL, YEMNA HELEN
description: MOKARZEL-Yemna Helen. Died 1/2/98. Happy birthday dearest sister, aunt, friend, we miss you. Your vibrancy, good humor, knowledge of news, especially family news, we remember your faithful devotion to volunteer work almost all your life including years at Convent of Mary Reparatrix in charge of making Communion wafers for churches until they had to move. Then at Society of the Blind on West 23rd St. We remember you at the end peacefully looking forward to going to heaven. Sisters, Nieces, Nephews

title: How a Child Learns to Read; Most Effective Mix
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball's Game of Deception In the Search for Latin Talent
description: Earlier this month, Yovanny Jimenez, a young outfielder in the Dominican Republic who said he had been promised $40,000 last August to sign a contract with the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, filed a formal complaint with his country's baseball commissioner. The Devil Rays, he said, had reneged on their commitment and were offering to pay him only $15,000.

title: Admitting Error at a Weapons Plant; Belatedly, Energy Department Deals With Leaks of Nuclear Waste
description: For almost 50 years, managers at the nuclear weapons plant with the nation's largest concentration of radioactive waste, in Hanford, Wash., steadfastly maintained that leaks from underground tanks were insignificant because the radioactive material would be trapped by the surrounding soil. But they now admit that they were wrong.

title: Holocaust Document; Open the Files
description: To the Editor:

title: Elvis Lives? Well, His Musicians of the 70's Do
description: It was deja vu all over again. It was ''Elvis: The Concert,'' the touring oddity that projects Presley on a 24-foot video screen, backed up by his musicians from the 1970's in person: his rock band and two gospel vocal groups, the Sweet Inspirations and J. D. Sumner and the Stamps, along with strings and brass led by his longtime conductor, Joe Guercio. The show came to Radio City Music Hall last weekend.

title: Court to Weigh Whether H.I.V. Is a Disability
description: A Supreme Court case about discrimination against people who carry the virus that causes AIDS offers the Justices a surprisingly blank slate on which to write an opinion with major implications not only for the law on the disease itself but also for disability rights law in general.

title: Campaign Finance Charades
description: Newt Gingrich has a plan to snooker Americans yearning for a cleanup of their corrupt election finance system. Last year, at the height of the disclosures of fund-raising abuses, the Speaker of the House promised to let lawmakers debate and vote on various reforms. He has not kept his word. Worse, he has scheduled a vote on sham legislation dressed up to look like reform, with no chance for members to vote on the real thing. The moment has arrived for Republicans and Democrats who say they want change to stand up to the Speaker and demand it.

title: One Street, Two Names and an Identity Crisis; A Proposal to Ease Confusion Touches Off a Fierce Feud Among Neighbors in Queens
description: At New York City's eastern frontier, dividing the Cape Cods and Tudor homes of Queens from the Cape Cods and Tudor homes of Long Island, there is a commercial strip dotted with old standbys like the Bellerose Old-Fashioned Butcher, new arrivals like the Indian beauty shop, and boarded-up storefronts waiting for another chance.

title: Ashland Picks Lowe for Valvoline
description: The Valvoline Company in Lexington, Ky., a division of Ashland Inc., has named Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York to handle its national account, with billings estimated at $25 million.

title: How a Child Learns to Read; Volunteers Are Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Six In Lake Give Daly an 18
description: Things happen to John Daly, and today's final round at the Bay Hill Invitational brought another bizarre chapter in his career.

title: Political Briefing; Death Penalty Support Declines After Execution
description: When Karla Faye Tucker was put to death in a Texas prison last month for killing two people with a pickax, her execution set off an intense debate, in the state and nationwide, about capital punishment.

title: For Lockheed, A Showdown Over Merger
description: As the Lockheed Martin Corporation and the Government head toward a showdown over the company's $8.3 billion acquisition of the Northrop Grumman Corporation, Lockheed's options are clearly unappealing.

title: Abroad at Home; Justice Or Publicity?
description: ''Legal Trials are not like Elections, to be won through the meeting-hall, the radio and the newspapers.'' -- Justice Hugo L. Black, 1941

title: Metro Matters; A New Video By Sex Shops Is a Shocker!
description: WHAT if the owners of New York City's myriad sex shops, topless joints and triple-X arcades all pooled their resources to make one jaw-dropping video about the scandalous conduct of the Giuliani administration?

title: Military Mischief in Indonesia
description: American military training for Indonesia's notoriously brutal anti-riot troops is a dangerous idea that was expressly prohibited by Congress on human rights grounds years ago. But such training has been going on, quietly, since 1992. The Pentagon cynically sidestepped Congressional objections by moving the Indonesian training from the military education program, where it was prohibited, to a different bureaucratic pocket.

title: Putting the Elderly On the Couch
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHACTER, CHARLES
description: SHACTER-Charles. March 23. Happy Birthday, Papa. Miss you, love you, always.

title: Nigerians Pin High Hopes on Pope's Visit
description: Mixing stout doses of the spiritual and the political in a country bracing for critical elections, Pope John Paul II beatified Nigeria's first candidate for sainthood and presided over Mass today for as many as one million people in this overwhelmingly Roman Catholic city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, IDA
description: MITCHELL-Ida. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Devoted mother of the late Carole Morris. Loving grandmother of Patricia and John Murphy, and Doreen Morris. Great-grandmother of Sean, Kerri, Jessica and Jason. Graveside services today, 1 PM, at Mt. Eden Cemetery, 20 Commerce St., Hawthorne, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFEE, SYLVIA S.
description: JAFFEE-Sylvia S. Died March 21, 1998, age 82. Long time resident of Manhattan. Beloved sister, aunt and friend to many. Executive secretary to former Board of Education Presidents Moss and Shapiro. Enlisted and served in the WACS during World War II. Long time employee at Plum Point Resort in New York. Champion of the artsChannel 13, The Met, Lincoln Center, etc. As per her wishes cremation with no service. Contributions can be made to Hospice and American Cancer Care Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLDEN, CHARLES STUART, III
description: HOLDEN-Charles Stuart, III. Of Bronxville, NY, on March 20, 1998. Son of Charles Stuart and Mary Patricia O'Donnell Holden. Brother of the late Nancy Jean Holden. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 7 to 9 PM, Monday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Tuesday, March 24, at 10 AM.

title: A Murder? No, a Universe On the Edge of Oblivion
description: SOLIBO MAGNIFICENT

title: New Jersey Man Denies Killing Columbia Student, His Lawyer Says
description: With sagging shoulders and an expressionless face, Edmund Ko, 23, a former associate buyer for Macy's in Herald Square, was charged yesterday with second-degree murder in the throat slashing of his former girlfriend, a Columbia Law School student named Hyeseung Lynda Hong.

title: Young & Rubicam Fills 2 Top Posts
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York has named two executives to top posts as preparations continue for an initial public offering.

title: Yankee Lineup Leaves No Breathers for Foes
description: A pair of scouts sat behind home plate at an exhibition game last week, watching the Yankees' carousel of sluggers bludgeon the Toronto Blue Jays. ''There's just no end to it,'' one scout said to the other. ''You get toward the end of the lineup and there's Chili Davis, and Darryl Strawberry looks great, and it's just one tough out after another.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIER, DR. MORTON
description: FIER-Dr. Morton. Of Ridgewood, New Jersey. Beloved husband of Ricki; cherished son of Freda; devoted father of Ian, Carl and Claudia; father-in-law of Layne and Rachel; brother of Leonard; loving grandfather of Hannah, Samantha and Daniel. He was an attending psychiatrist for more than 35 years at Hackensack University Medical Center, beloved by his patients, colleagues and students alike. He was a gifted Professor of Psychiatry. We will miss and love him forever. Contributions may be made to the Morton Fier Memorial Fund, c/o Arthur Middleton, M.D. For information, ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 1-800-522-0588.

title: All Too Soon, New F.C.C. Chief Finds Warm Welcome Is Cooling
description: The honeymoon is over for William E. Kennard, if there ever was one.

title: Political Briefing; California Conservatives Again Target Justices
description: Back in 1986, California conservatives caught the nation's attention when, dissatisfied with law-and-order decisions handed down by the state's Supreme Court, they orchestrated a campaign that resulted in three justices being voted off the bench, including Chief Justice Rose Elizabeth Bird.

title: How a Child Learns to Read
description: To the Editor:

title: Hoosier Hysteria
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Cryovac, Duncan, S.C., part of W. R. Grace & Co., to Fitzgerald & Co., Atlanta, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle worldwide trade advertising for the maker of plastic packaging, which had been handled by various local agencies. Billings were estimated at $8 million.

title: Kentucky Gets Revenge After a Wait Of Six Years
description: At halftime, no one could beat Kentucky in its mad dash to simply get off the floor.

title: Coca-Cola's roster of agencies could be downsized when a marketing executive leaves.
description: FOR Madison Avenue, the countdown to change at the Coca-Cola Company is under way.

title: On a Spring Day, Winter Shows Up, With Snow
description: After just one day on the job, spring took a break yesterday and surprised New Yorkers who awoke to a storm that dropped five inches of snow -- the most in the city in more than two years.

title: Nine Cuban Defectors Are Found in the Bahamas After 17 Hours at Sea
description: Four Cuban baseball players and a coach were safely under lock and key in a Bahamian detention center here tonight, confounding earlier reports that they were either lost at sea or washed up on a Dominican Republic beach.

title: State Moving to Stop Deportation of Some Major Drug Offenders
description: The Pataki administration is moving to disqualify most drug offenders from a program that speeds up deportation of illegal immigrants convicted of nonviolent crimes, officials said. The proposed changes followed published reports that several major drug traffickers had been paroled and deported long before completing even their minimum sentences.

title: A rather benign declaration on the Internet is treated as a revolutionary manifesto.
description: HOW neurotic is the Internet?

title: Auriemma Sees UConn-Tennessee Rematch Ahead
description: If basketball were a Broadway show, the University of Connecticut women's team's initial steps in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament could have been taken from ''Man of La Mancha.'' For the Huskies, who were without the star guard Shea Ralph all season, and then were denied the talents of the all-American Nykesha Sales in the post-season, seemed destined to tilt at windmills in battles they could not win.

title: Endowment Nominee's Broad View Of the Arts; Moving Beyond Country Music To a Political Stage
description: ''I have a soft spot for Webb's car,'' Bill Ivey said as he peered wistfully over at the silver-dollar-studded 1962 Pontiac convertible with tooled leather seats, pistols for door handles, horseshoes for pedals, and huge steer horns mounted on the front bumper. It was owned by the honky-tonk singer Webb Pierce, and ''he was still driving it around when I first came to town,'' Mr. Ivey said.

title: A Motley Crew of Women Share a Friend's Pregnancy
description: The story is an old one. A young, unmarried woman becomes pregnant and goes away until the baby is born. Her options, however, are modern: She can have an abortion. She can keep the child and rear it alone. She can keep the child and rear it with her friend and former teacher, Kate, a lesbian, even though Caroline, the mother-to-be, isn't gay. Or she can give the child up for adoption, which is her stated plan.

title: Israel Tries to Hush Clinton on Peace Proposal
description: The Israeli Cabinet defiantly warned the United States today against making public a new peace initiative, declaring that a reported American demand for withdrawal from 13 percent of the West Bank was ''unacceptable.''

title: Explicit Photos Touch Off a Debate at Rutgers
description: The series of sadomasochistic sex photographs were an afterthought, added as a biographical footnote to the retrospective of paintings and sculptures by Copy Berg now on display in the Robeson Student Center gallery at Rutgers University here.

title: Works of the Imagination In a Gershwin Celebration
description: New York Theater Ballet, an attractive company directed by Diana Byer, celebrated the centennial of George Gershwin's birth with a choreography competition. From 85 entries, all relating to Gershwin, judges chose four winners, which were danced on Friday night on a program called ''Legends and Visionaries'' at the Kaye Playhouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONEY, VIRGINIA M.
description: MALONEY-Virginia M. Died Saturday morning, March 21, at home after a five year battle with oral cancer. Ginny, the daughter of the late James and Mary Robinson and brother of Donald, also deceased, was born in Stamford, CT, and grew up in Rye, NY. She was an honor graduate of both Good Counsel Academy and College of White Plains. She is survived by her husband, Robert G. Maloney and by her children, Maura of Kingston, TN, Sheila of Gold Hill, CO, Eileen Triplett of Hyannis, MA, Sean of Seattle, WA, Deirdre Cutler of Bedford, NY, Donal of Denver, CO, and Robert J.F.K. of Park Ridge, NJ., Thomas and Siobhan predeceased her. Her loving grandchildren are Rebecca, Erin, Leah, and Siobhan Hengemuhle, Elizabeth and Christopher Triplett, and Shaynna, Brendan, and Wesley Cutler. Virginia was a mild mannered person but demonstrated her inner strengths by raising a challenging brood, overcoming earlier difficulities and enduring extensive medical treatments. May she rest in peace. Ginny's wake will be at Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc., 155 Kinderkamack Road in Park Ridge, Tuesday, 7 to 9, Wednesday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. The funeral mass will be at 10 AM, Thursday, March 26, at Our Lady of Mercy RC Church in Park Ridge. Final resting place will be St. Mary's Cemetery in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to Covenant House, 347 West 17 St., NY, NY 10011-5002.

title: Candidates Use Conference To Court the Hispanic Vote
description: Amid workshops on subjects like immigration, welfare reform and the status of Puerto Rico, there was the unmistakable, ever-present undertone of election-year politics during a statewide gathering of Hispanic elected officials here.

title: Holocaust Document
description: To the Editor:

title: The More Things Change . . .
description: Federal Census figures released last week show modest net changes in population for the New York metropolitan region. But hidden in those relatively static figures are enormous flows of people: 1.07 million New Yorkers left the city, for example, while 677,000 foreigners moved in.

title: Nets' Playoff Hopes Set Back Two Pegs
description: Chris Webber stalked around the floor today, flexing his muscles and making faces at no one in particular, while his Washington teammates danced off the court and the Nets, expressionless, walked to the locker room. He put his finger to his throat, held it there for a moment and then ripped it across his neck.

title: Marie-Louise von Franz, 83, A Jungian Legend, Is Dead
description: Once upon a time in a faraway land, where princes once vied and heroes died, where questers set out and there were trolls and the stories seemed to come straight from the stone, a child of the aristocracy was born.

title: Jack R. Howard, 87, Broadcasting Executive
description: Jack R. Howard, a newspaper heir who became a pioneer in broadcasting, died yesterday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 87.

title: Putting the Elderly On the Couch
description: To the Editor:

title: Box Office: Top Gauge For Films
description: The movie industry concerns itself with many things, from artistic expression and storytelling to deal-making. But the business is nearly unanimous on one basic measure of success that supersedes all else: ticket sales.

title: Ugandans Hope Trip Will Aid Democracy and Trade
description: Charles Katongole, a taxi driver by trade, swung the pickax into the earth at the main traffic circle outside this hot and humid capital with a purpose today. Sweat drenched his face and body.

title: 1954 Murder Still Roiling Both Sides In Cleveland
description: More than four decades after Dr. Sam Sheppard was convicted of murdering his wife, his case still rivets this city. And just as the United States Supreme Court ruled that his original trial was prejudiced by media pressure, his supporters believe that politics is now preventing his exoneration.

title: Dramatic Victories Fill In the Final Four
description: The field for the men's basketball Final Four was completed yesterday in two down-to-the-wire games. Kentucky came from 18 points behind to defeat Duke, 86-84, in the South Regional and went a long way toward banishing the ghosts of the last-second shot by Duke's Christian Laettner that eliminated the Wildcats from the tournament six years ago.

title: Republicans Criticize Clinton On Executive Privilege Claim
description: Leading Republican lawmakers clipped on their microphones in television studios around town today to attack President Clinton for formally invoking executive privilege to block grand jury testimony of senior White House aides in the Monica S. Lewinsky inquiry.

title: Political Briefing; Missouri May Spare Inmate Organ Donors
description: Whatever Texans think about capital punishment, a Missouri legislator has his own special take on the issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, DONALD
description: JOYCE-Donald. On Tuesday, March 10, 1998, age 45, of cancer. Musician, organist, choir director, teacher. A service will be held on Saturday, March 28, at 1 P.M., at the Church of the Holy Apostles, 9th Ave at 28th St., NYC 10001. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made either to the Organ Fund at the above church or to the Donald Joyce Scholarship Fund at the Copland School of Music, Queens College, Flushing, N.Y. 11367.

title: White House Drug and AIDS Advisers Differ on Needle Exchange
description: The debate over the propriety of handing out sterile syringes to people who inject illegal drugs, to reduce the spread of AIDS, has reached the White House, where President Clinton's two main policy advisers on the issue have staked out opposing positions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILGRAY, RABBI ALBERT
description: BILGRAY-Rabbi Albert. Of Tucson. We extend sympathy to families of daughter Betty Brenner, son Dave, and brother-in-law Rabbi Mordecai Waxman. Families of David Belgray and Alice Bilgrei Weinbaum

title: Offerings of Equity Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIDMAN, IRVING
description: DAVIDMAN-Irving. Remembered on his 29th yahrzeit, 25 Adar, by his sons Joe and Lenny Davidman

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Sports of The Times; At the End of the Road Familiar Bugbear Sits
description: THIS wasn't for publication -- after all, he didn't need the information being tacked to a rival's bulletin board for added motivation -- but a member of the Chicago Bulls, in Deep Throat mode, whispered recently that the only obstacles standing in the way of them winning yet another National Basketball Association championship were: ''Utah, Utah and Utah.''

title: Political Briefing; George C. Wallace Jr. Runs as a Republican
description: When it comes to politics, the Wallaces of Alabama have been a lot of things. But they have always been Democrats when running in their home state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, MARGOLIN, EVA
description: BRENNER - MARGOLIN - Eva. Died on March 21, 1998 in Netanya, Israel, where she resided since October 7, 1973, formerly of Borough Park, Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Brenner and beloved wife of Elkin Margolin. Devoted mother of Helyn (z''l) and Seymour Reich of NYC, Rabbi Reeve Brenner of Bethesda, MD and Dr. Joyce Rosman Brenner of Netanya, and Roberta and Alan Zuckerman of Providence, RI. Loving grandmother of Keith and Audrey Reich, Leslie and Dana Goldfarb, Jaime and Avi Amiram, Neeva and Gabriel Kleiman, Nurete Brenner, Noga and Alon Brenner-Samia, Gregory and Michelle Zuckerman, Ezra and Lisa Sivan (Zuckerman), and Shara Zuckerman. Adoring great grandmother. Burial in Netanya on March 22.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MORTON
description: GOLDSTEIN-Morton. On March 20, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice, loving father of Aileen and Barbara, fond brother of George and Ruth. Passed on suddenly and will be greatly missed. Donations to Bnai Zion and USCJ kindly requested.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMERLING, RABBI SAMUEL
description: SMERLING-Rabbi Samuel. We mourn the passing of Rabbi Samuel Smerling and extend our sincere condolences to his bereaved family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The I.J. Morris Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, SUE G.
description: GREENBERG-Sue G. On March 21, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin; loving mother of Carolyn. Her life was devoted to her family and to the many organizations to which she was dedicated. Services Monday, 12 noon, at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZFELD, SYLVIA
description: HERZFELD-Sylvia. March 21, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Leon. Beloved mother of Jeffrey (Suzie) and Sandy (Ricki). Adoring grandmother of Michael, Leah, Sam and the late Lisa. Services Monday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Economic Scene column in Business Day on Thursday misstated Bulgaria's economic performance for 1996 and 1997. Economic output declined by 10.9 percent in 1996 and by 8 percent in 1997. It did not rise by 19 percent over the two years.

title: Political Briefing; Annual Ribald Roast Is Followed by Rebuttal
description: Every spring for a dozen years, the whim would hit and Vincent F. Callahan Jr. would rise from his seat in the Virginia House of Delegates and deliver himself of a ribald roast, singeing other members of the oldest legislative body in the Western Hemisphere with locker-room jokes about everything from bestiality to menstrual cycles.

title: Hundreds Are Arrested In Series of Drug Sweeps
description: Responding to a recent outbreak of violent, drug-related crimes, the Jersey City Police Department has raided open-air drug markets in the city seven times since February, the police said Friday. The series of raids has resulted in more than 370 arrests.

title: Patents; Here's an invention that can help spend a Federal income tax refund before it's actually received.
description: PAYING taxes is never easy, but that has not stopped some inventors from trying to improve the experience. Perhaps the only welcome aspect of tax season is the prospect of a refund from the Internal Revenue Service. But Ross Longfield, an inventor from Far Hills, N.J., did not want to wait for the check to arrive in the mail. Instead, he has patented a system for using an instant tax refund as the collateral for a credit card or loan.

title: Els Turns a Showdown Into a Solo Performance
description: Ernie Els never expected today's victory to come so easily.

title: Most Dropped From Welfare Don't Get Jobs
description: A vast majority of people who have dropped off New York State's rapidly shrinking welfare rolls have not obtained legitimate jobs, a state survey indicates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOLAZNICK, IDA
description: ZOLAZNICK-Ida. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with sorrow the passing of Ida Zolaznick, who was a beloved member of the Hebrew Home community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Zolaznick and Lustgarten families. The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman Daniel A. Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: Knicks Give Malone and Stockton 6 Periods to Win
description: This resembled the halcyon days, when the Knicks would exchange baskets with another finals contender like two groggy kids in a pillow fight and leave everyone fantasizing about a seven-game series in June.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The Governor's Race Begins
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross's official announcement that she is pursuing the Democratic gubernatorial nomination seems to have filled out the field of candidates who want to run against Gov. George Pataki in November. Some party members are already bemoaning the weakness of their options. But in New York, it is always difficult to find strong opponents for a well-positioned incumbent. We prefer to see this particular glass as half full. All five of the announced contenders have impressive resumes. The impoverished, disorganized state Democratic Party is probably fortunate to have this many credible candidates ready to make such a challenging run.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Clinton Packs Up His Care and Woe To Trot the Globe
description: President Clinton left the country today. And you had better get used to it.

title: What Scouts Value
description: To the Editor:

title: Emotion on the Faces Speaks Louder Than Words
description: ''We didn't need dialogue in those days,'' Gloria Swanson's forgotten silent-movie queen says to William Holden's unemployed screenwriter in ''Sunset Boulevard.'' ''We had faces then!''

title: Stanford Wins In a Single Mad Minute
description: Thank goodness for videotape. Otherwise, Stanford might never know how it pulled off a stunning 79-77 victory over Rhode Island in the final of the Midwest Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament at the Kiel Center this afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISELIN, SARAH (SALLY) C.
description: ISELIN-Sarah (Sally) C. Writer, editor and photographer. Wife of the late Lewis Iselin, and mother of Edith Byron and Sarah Iselin. Died at her home in New York March 18 at age 82. Services will be private.

title: In the South, a Changing Lineup
description: A chart last Monday with an article about Republican gains in the South misstated party affiliations of several states' governors and senators and the makeup of their House delegations in 1980 and 1990. Correct data appear below.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIDENMAN, JAMES W.
description: WEIDENMAN-James W. On February 18, 1998, of Syosset, NY. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Loving father of Leslie, Meredith, Keith, Lauren and Darren. Cherished grandfather of Kate Christie. Visiting on Friday (March 27), at the Beney Funeral Home of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Rd., 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass Saturday, 9 AM, at St. Dominic's R.C. Chapel, Oyster Bay, NY. Donations to Nature Conservancy (LI Chapter), American Cancer Society or the World Wildlife Fund, would be appreciated.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Foreign travel does a lot for a President under siege in terms of his own psyche. Every President enjoys traveling in foreign countries because it makes him feel like a President again.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONNER, BEATRICE (NEE KATZ)
description: KONNER-Beatrice (nee Katz). Formerly of Hackensack, NJ, died March 17 in Portland, OR. Beloved wife of the late Abner Konner. Greatly mourned by her son and his wife, Michael and Claire; granddaughters, Nancy Truax, Judith and Margaret Konner; greatgrandsons, Jack and Alex Truax; brother, Herbert Katz; sister, Muriel Glaser; nieces and nephew.

title: What Price the Playoffs? For Knicks, a Draft Pick
description: As the Knicks plod through the season's final weeks, they may have to decide what is more important: the playoffs or a good young player.

title: World Medical Community Frets Over Unregulated Medicine Sales on Web
description: The unregulated atmosphere of the World Wide Web may be a boon to the First Amendment, but the international medical community might argue that freedom has its limits.

title: Putting the Elderly On the Couch
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall St. Journal Joins Life-Style Bandwagon With New Section
description: Since 1889, The Wall Street Journal has helped its readers make money. On Friday, it brought out a new section to tell them how to spend it.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Monday about the emerging field of cyberspace law misidentified the publication that carried an article titled ''Cyberspace and the Law of the Horse,'' by Judge Frank Esterbrook of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in which he argues against the idea that the Internet creates a need for a new legal discipline. The publication was the University of Chicago Legal Forum, not the University of Chicago Law Review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENDROFF, ROSE
description: WENDROFF-Rose. On March 21, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Louis; beloved mother of Paula and Bernard, Alan and Rosanna. Loving sister of Rachel and Max and the late Ada and Samuel. Adored grandmother of Barry, Jill, Wendy, Dale, Andrew and Wayne and loving great-grandmother. A charitable, gentle, elegant, dignified, good-humored woman. A very special lady.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOCKSTADER, FREDERICK
description: DOCKSTADER-Frederick. Author and former director of the Museum of the American Indian in New York. Survived by his wife of 47 years, Alice Dockstader died March 21 after a short illness.

title: SAMSONITE DISCUSSES SELLING 50% STAKE TO PAY DIVIDEND
description: The Samsonite Corporation said yesterday that it was in talks to sell a 50 percent equity stake to unnamed investors and use the proceeds to pay a $30-a-share dividend to stockholders, including Apollo Advisors L.P., which is headed by Leon Black, a Samsonite director. Samsonite, the Denver-based luggage company, said that if it did not sell the equity stake, it would recapitalize with $600 million in bank loans and pay shareholders a $12.50 dividend. Samsonite's stock has fallen 40 percent in the last 12 months, cutting the value of Apollo's 36 percent stake to about $215.3 million. The stock fell an additional $2.0625 a share yesterday, to $30.3125.

title: Mr. Yeltsin's Latest Surprise
description: Russia's President, Boris Yeltsin, is turning the abrupt dismissal of top government officials into his trademark governing style. Yesterday Mr. Yeltsin, only recently returned to work from a severe respiratory infection, surprised Russia and the world by dismissing his Prime Minister, Viktor Chernomyrdin, along with his entire Cabinet. Mr. Yeltsin's achievements over the years have been impressive. But his increasingly mercurial leadership, marked by erratic pronouncements, frequent health crises and sudden removal of top aides, now threatens to undermine Russia's political stability and the confidence of foreign governments and investors.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Ian McEwen; A Novelist Wraps Ideas Inside Intoxicating Plots
description: The British novelist Ian McEwen is a careful person. He is careful in the way he makes salad dressing, using fancy olive oil (a gift from his Italian publisher) and mixing the ingredients until a precise consistency is achieved. He is careful in the way he places smoked salmon, in neatly spaced rectangles, on its serving plate.

title: Raise the Bar at City University
description: To the Editor:

title: Crew of Airliner Received Warning Just Before Guam Crash
description: In the final minute before Korean Airlines Flight 801 crashed on a hillside in Guam last Aug. 6, a mechanical voice in the cockpit gave the crew members information that they were making a fatal mistake, according to data released today by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, NENA
description: GOODMAN-Nena. The American Jewish Committee notes with profound sadness the death of Nena Goodman, a woman of warmth and caring, the widow of Andrew Goodman, a devoted AJC member and officer. We send our heartfelt condolences to her son, Edwin, and the rest of the grieving family. Robert S. Rifkind, President David A. Harris, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEDOLSKY, MILTON
description: PEDOLSKY-Milton. Formerly of Port Washington, NY. Loving to, and dearly loved by, his late wife, Beverly; son, Richard; daughter-inlaw, Cecillia; grandson, Isak; daughter, Andrea; Nicholas; and many wonderful friends. He will be greatly missed. Memorial service April 7, 4 PM, at Cooper Union, Peter Cooper Suite, 7 E. 7th St., NYC. Should friends desire, memorial contributions may be made to Friends and Relatives of Institutionalized Aged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JEAN
description: GOLDMAN-Jean. We mourn the passing of the mother of our esteemed member Beverly Schachar and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: Thou Shalt Go Forth Fearlessly
description: There was probably some good reason for putting that appalling photograph of a woman and a man simultaneously giving an open-mouthed kiss to the same apple on the biographical program for ''Va Yomer. Va Yelech.'' But it conveys all the wrong ideas about this powerful, sophisticated show from the Cameri Theater of Tel Aviv.

title: BASEBALL: SPRING TRAINING
description: WHITE SOX

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, BETTY (NEE MAYER)
description: JORDAN-Betty (nee Mayer). Passed away March 23, 1998. Survived by William Murrell, mother of Barbara Noriega and Shoshana (Susan) Benmosche, grandmother of Cristina Noriega, Diana Targia, and Antony Graf, great-grandmother of Andrew, sister of Marjorie Mayer Curnan, and Benjamin H. Mayer.

title: ULTRA PAC SOARS ON NEWS OF COMPANY'S IMPENDING SALE
description: The Ivex Packaging Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Ultra Pac Inc., a maker of plastic containers and packaging for the food industry, for about $63.6 million in cash. Shares of Ultra Pac more than doubled after the announcement, rising $8.3125, to $15. Ivex, a plastic and paper packaging company based in Lincolnshire, Ill., said it would begin the $15.50-a-share tender offer on Thursday for all of Ultra Pac's shares outstanding. Ultra Pac, based in Rogers, Minn., had 1997 sales of $62.1 million. Ivex had sales of $538.5 million in 1997; its shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $22.375.

title: An Empire With Modest Beginnings
description: In 1923, Bennett Cerf and Donald Klopfer, the founders of Random House, set up shop as the Modern Library in a tiny ninth-floor office at 73 West 45th Street, with their desks facing each other and sharing a secretary. From that grew the immense enterprise that is now being acquired by Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany.

title: Several Big Deals Near for Sun's Java Language
description: Sun Microsystems Inc.'s Java programming language is suddenly enjoying new momentum outside the personal computer industry, and the company is planning to announce several new deals with consumer electronics manufacturers over the next few weeks.

title: Blame the Messenger for Making the Flu So Awful
description: BARBRA STREISAND, Michael Jordan, Elvis Stojko and millions of others both famous and obscure who were attacked by the influenza virus this winter may take little comfort in such information, but scientists at the National Institutes of Health believe they have discovered what makes a flu sufferer so miserable.

title: U.S. Seeks to Block Merger
description: The Justice Department filed suit to block Lockheed Martin's planned acquisition of Northrop Grumman, contending that a combination of the military contractors posed a threat to the nation's defense. Page D1.

title: Parolee Accused of Crime Spree in Brooklyn
description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn man on parole for felony drug and weapons convictions cut off an electronic tracking bracelet he was required to wear and set out on a crime spree with various accomplices that included at least four robberies and three shootings over five days, the police said.

title: Hively Agency Shuts Down
description: The Hively Agency in Houston has closed. It liquidated after an 11-month effort to reorganize under Chapter 11 Federal bankruptcy protection.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Pushing the Speed Limit In Mahler's Fifth

title: U.S. Is No Model For Europe's Jobless
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISQUITH, MOSES
description: ISQUITH-Moses. Beloved husband of Clara. Devoted father of Rantch and Lenore. Adored grandfather of Jennifer and David. Brother of Santley, Murray and Jack. He was the recipient of The Purple Heart, African Campaign Ribbon with two Battle Stars, Good Conduct Ribbon, Combat Infantry Badge and Expert Marksmanship Medal during World War II. Services Tuesday March 24, 11 AM, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Living 'Normally,' for Opera, Refugees and 2 Children
description: When Barbara Hendricks opens the door of her home in this blissful Swiss city, she appears so tiny across the small courtyard that she could be an adolescent sent to usher in guests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, ALLEN
description: CAMERON-Allen. Of Essex, CT., March 20, age 86. Husband of Ruth I. Cameron, Father of Suzanne Schutz of Greenwich, CT., and Laurie Larkin of Claremont, CA; Brother of F. Morton Cameron and Sister Donalda Cameron both of San Diego, California, and Grandfather of 3. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Friends of the Valley Railroad Co of Connecticut Valley, P.O. Box 452, Essex, Connecticut 06426.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Insights Into the Familiar, With Energy and Playfulness

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD JUMPS 2.5 PERCENT. Prices of gold and other precious metals surged in tandem with the rebound in oil prices. In New York, gold for April delivery rose $7.30 an ounce, to $299.50, the biggest one-day gain in two months.

title: For Indians, Sovereignty Is a Two-Edged Sword; Broken Legal System
description: To the Editor:

title: Tennessee Rally Rescues A Shot at Another Title
description: Those who withheld judgment on whether Tennessee was the greatest women's college basketball team ever did so in part because the Lady Vols had won their games by an average of 30 points this season and had seldom been tested.

title: For Indians, Sovereignty Is a Two-Edged Sword
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, THOMAS
description: KELLY-Thomas. We are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of Tom Kelly, a loyal and devoted member of our organization. He will surely be missed by all of us. Our deepest sympathy goes out to his family. Friends and Co-Workers at Dorby Frocks and Miss Dorby

title: 4 Who Would Succeed Chernomyrdin
description: Here are brief sketches of the people most often mentioned as Boris N. Yeltsin's next Prime Minister.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about assessing the value of rare manuscripts at a Manhattan trial misstated the number of rare books in Columbia University's collection. It is 500,000, not 500.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about the popularity of acting careers for young people misspelled the surname of the director of the drama division at the Juilliard School. He is Michael Kahn, not Kahan.

title: Prosecution Says Man's Prints Are on Bar Used in a Beating
description: A partial palm print found on a steel club that the police say was used in the nearly fatal beating of a 23-year-old man outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub two years ago matches the defendant's hand, a witness testified today.

title: Saving the Sound
description: Long Island Sound may someday turn out to be an environmental success story rivaling the steady restoration of the Hudson River. But it will require a greater effort by New York City and other communities to clean up their discharges. Yesterday Connecticut joined a Federal suit filed by conservationists to force the city to reduce its discharges of nitrogen-rich waste water into the sound. New York State has filed a similar lawsuit, charging that at least four of the city's 16 waste treatment plants exceed discharge limits. Nitrogen pollution creates algae blooms, which in turn pollute the water, foul beaches and threaten the marine food chain.

title: Chirac Acts to Thwart Far-Right's Push for Power
description: French politics have been turned upside down by maneuvering that put the far-right National Front party of Jean-Marie Le Pen closer than it has ever been before to exercising political power on a national scale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMTER, FLORENCE (JILL) F.
description: SAMTER-Florence (Jill) F. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Thomas, Stephen and Hilary. Adored and cherished grandmother of Todd, Jonathan, Alison and Alexis. Services private.

title: Oil Price Rises 13% on Pledges Of Supply Cuts
description: The price of crude oil rose 13 percent yesterday in world petroleum markets, the biggest one-day surge since the Persian Gulf war more than seven years ago, in reaction to weekend promises by producing nations to reduce their exports.

title: Foreign Affairs; What if . . .?
description: The U.S. and Israel are heading for a fateful week. President Clinton has indicated to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that the U.S. wants to present to Israel and the Palestinians a compromise proposal that it believes can break the deadlock between them. If they both accept it, that would be ideal. But if not, the U.S. would have to explain publicly who is holding up the peace process.

title: In Spring, Birds Return to the Salton Sea and Die in Droves
description: FROM its shore, the Salton Sea appears disorientingly vast as it bends over the horizon and vanishes into a barrier of mountains that jut through the Colorado Desert. Gulls, herons, and pelicans skim the briny water against a majestic backdrop of sagebrush, sandstone and glorious blue sky.

title: NBC Signs Deal to Keep 'Mad About You' for Another Season
description: NBC concluded a deal yesterday that would bring the hit comedy ''Mad About You'' back to the network for another season, averting an additional blow to the network that will already lose the most popular comedy in television, ''Seinfeld,'' next season.

title: Defense in Sexual Torture Case Says Court Let the Accuser Lie
description: Defense lawyers for Oliver Jovanovic, the graduate student accused of kidnapping and sexually abusing a woman he met on the Internet, claimed yesterday that the judge and prosecutors had allowed the accuser to lie on the stand.

title: Law in the Clinton Era; A Feminist Dilemma
description: The feminist movement has been called to judge whether President Clinton is worthy of its allegiance. These are not the first Clinton supporters to feel squeezed between their principles and an alliance with the President. Welfare advocates and environmentalists have faced similar conflicts.

title: Ex-Perot Executive To Lead Cybersafe
description: James Cannavino, a former I.B.M. executive and former chief executive of Perot Systems, will become chairman and chief executive of Cybersafe, an Issaquah, Wash., company that makes corporate network security products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCENEANY, MARY
description: McENEANY-Mary. On March 22, 1998. Native of County Monaghan, Ireland. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Loving mother of Sr. Mary Carmel O.P., Kathleen Singer, Edward J. and Sr. Barbara McEneany O.P. Cherished grandmother of Susan, James, John, Brian and great-grandmother of four. Dear sister of Catherine and Patrick McKenna. Family will receive friends at Williams Funeral Home Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232nd St., Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Nicholas of Tolentine Church, on Wednesday 10:30 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Sisters of St. Dominic Retirement Fund, 496 Western Highway, Blauvelt, N.Y. 10913 will be appreciated.

title: Stanford Is a Surprise at a Familiar Party
description: Stanford was not supposed to be physical enough for a tough inside battle with Purdue in the Midwest Regional semifinal. But in the end, the Boilermakers were the ones picking themselves up off the floor.

title: A Visit From Oscar Is Overdue
description: AND for best picture in the field of New York movie, a nonexistent Oscar category begging to be created, the envelope, please.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, FRANKLIN H., JR.
description: NICHOLS-Franklin H., Jr. Of Guilford, CT, formerly of Greenwich, CT. Husband of Joy (Hallock) Nichols and the late Louise (Newell) Nichols. Services Thurs., March 26, 11 AM, Trinity Episcopal Church, 1109 Main Street, Branford, CT.

title: Church's Loss Near Yellowstone Will Become Wildlife's Gain
description: A few years ago a controversial religious sect called the Church Universal and Triumphant had grand plans for a self-sufficient New Age community that could survive what its leader claimed was a coming nuclear holocaust.

title: People
description: * Peter Vezmar, chief financial officer at Leap Group, Chicago, resigned, the agency company said, to pursue other opportunities.

title: Into Africa
description: Africa is the Rodney Dangerfield of continents; the world seems to pay it scant heed and shows it less respect.

title: Sitter Is Charged in Scalding of a Baby Girl
description: A 27-year-old woman baby-sitting her cousin's 2-year-old daughter in the University Heights section of the Bronx inflicted second-degree burns over half the child's body by dipping her in scalding water early yesterday, the police said. The police charged the baby sitter, Cedena Whitley, with attempted murder, first-degree assault and endangering the welfare of a child.

title: 'Titanic' Ties Record With 11 Oscars, Including Best Picture
description: ''Titanic,'' the James Cameron epic about a tragic love affair aboard the doomed ocean liner, glided triumphantly through the 70th annual Academy Awards tonight, winning 11 accolades, including best picture and the top director Oscars for Mr. Cameron. The film's honors tied it with ''Ben-Hur'' for the most ever.

title: Relentless Jamison Is the Tar Heels' Leader
description: The pin was given to Antawn Jamison by a friend, and he wears it everywhere as a reminder, a touchstone amid the swirl of a college career that has exceeded his loftiest expectations.

title: Insurgent Is Elected President Of a Municipal Union Local
description: In what reformers say may be the first of many developments to shake up District Council 37, the giant union of municipal workers, an insurgent has defeated Louis Albano, the longtime president of the 6,600-member local representing city engineers and architects.

title: When Everything's Normal, And All of It Is Absurd
description: An alarm rings. A prayer is said. Teeth are brushed. A new day begins. A happy day. A day like all days, ''no better; no worse; no change.'' Except for the fact that the earth is slowly burying us, reclaiming us, as it were, for itself.

title: YELTSIN DISMISSES HIS ENTIRE CABINET IN SHOW OF POWER
description: Demonstrating once again his enormous power and his mercurial nature, President Boris N. Yeltsin astonished the nation today by dismissing his entire Cabinet, including his loyal and dedicated aide, Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin.

title: Allergy Season Is Off to Early Start
description: FOR some 40 million Americans with nasal allergies, the legacy of El Nino is expected to last well beyond the mild temperatures that graced the North and the torrential rains that afflicted the South and West this winter.

title: Why Not Require Uniforms in All Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: When a College Team Betrayed a City
description: ''Say it ain't so, Beavers!'' Such might have been the cry of a million or two New Yorkers to the 1949-51 City College of New York basketball team that plunged from glory to shame in the blink of a season. But the producers of ''City Dump: The Story of the 1951 C.C.N.Y. Basketball Scandal'' recognize that the story is not just about the erring ways of a few young men who found they could make a little money without, as they must have rationalized, hurting anybody, but also about all those who were deeply hurt.

title: F. Cecil Brenner, 79, Scientist Who Devised Tire Ratings
description: F. Cecil Brenner, a scientist and regulator whose legacy can be found on nearly every tire on the road, died on Thursday at Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington. He was 79.

title: A Shade of Difference
description: FOR a plant protein that was dismissed by skeptics in the 1950's, phytochrome has come a long way. Because of it, growers who want the best and biggest tomatoes, strawberries and other crops need to be as fussy as an artist over the color of the plastic mulch they put in their fields.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Woolworth stock has been strong, but will Nike sales at the company's Foot Locker unit hurt?
description: DOTH the Woolworth Corporation protest a bit too much?

title: Budget Groundwork Finishes Early in Albany
description: In an era when state budgets have been enacted two, three or four months late, today represented a dubious milestone. For the first time in five years, the complex positioning that precedes serious budget talks ended before the end of the fiscal year on March 31.

title: Ultra-Positional Gem Helps Benjamin Win in Bermuda
description: Three players tied for first place in the Bermuda Open Tournament, which was held Feb. 6 to 8: the grandmasters Joel Benjamin of Manhattan and Alexander Ivanov of Brookline, Mass., and the international master Daniel Fridman of Latvia. Each scored 4 1/2- 1/2 in the five-round Swiss-system competition, and each was awarded $800. In addition, Benjamin won a blitz playoff and captured an all-expenses return in next year's event.

title: Going Organic, Clumsily
description: After more than five years of deliberations, the Agriculture Department has released its proposal on how to regulate the labeling of organic foods. Unfortunately, the plan will make it harder, not easier, for the consumer to distinguish between organic and conventionally produced food.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, VIOLA WERTHEIM, M.D.
description: BERNARD-Viola Wertheim, M.D. On March 21, 1998. Daughter of the late Jacob and Emma Wertheim. Beloved aunt of Joan Wofford and David Whittlesey. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Trade Deadline Sneaks Up On Islanders and Rangers
description: With the playoffs a long shot for the Rangers and a near impossibility for the Islanders, there are many deals to be considered by the general managers of both teams as today's 3 P.M. trade deadline approaches.

title: Opus Benefit Delayed
description: ''Michael Kamen's Opus,'' the benefit concert that was to have taken place tonight at Carnegie Hall, has been postponed. The event, a celebration of the music of Mr. Kamen, a film composer, was to benefit Mr. Holland's Opus Foundation, an organization established by Mr. Kamen to provide musical instruments to schoolchildren. Spokesmen for the event said the concert would be rescheduled for the summer. Tickets, they said, are refundable where purchased or will be honored for the rescheduled concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUMARKIN, CAROLYN
description: TUMARKIN - Carolyn. The Trustees and staff of The Jewish Museum note with sorrow the death of Carolyn Tumarkin, mother of Curator Susan Goodman. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Joan Rosenbaum, Director Robert J. Hurst, Chairman Philip A. Laskawy, President

title: Betsy King Reaches $6 Million
description: Betsy King became the first L.P.G.A. player to reach $6 million in career earnings after finishing tied for 30th in last weekend's Standard Register Ping Classic in Phoenix.

title: Kirshenbaum Bond And Hartz Separate
description: The Hartz Mountain Corporation, the maker of pet products, and its agency of seven months, Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York, said yesterday that they had parted ways. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. The account has been moved in-house as Hartz decides whether to undertake a review.

title: Raise the Bar at City University; Stop Blaming Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: QUEEN SAND TO BUY INTEREST IN OIL WELLS FROM MORGAN
description: Queen Sand Resources Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy oil and natural gas royalties and overriding royalty interests from the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York for $150 million. Queen Sand, based in Dallas, operates oil and gas properties. Morgan Guaranty is a unit of J. P. Morgan & Company. The deal will include stakes in more than 530 wells with estimated proved reserves of 127.7 billion cubic feet of natural gas and 3.7 million barrels of oil. The royalty and overriding interests range from 2 percent to 80 percent. Queen estimates that after the deal closes, it will have daily net production of 35 million cubic feet of natural gas and 1,850 barrels of oil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERBER, MOLLIE
description: GERBER-Mollie. On Mar. 23, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Arlene Greenberg, Linda (Austin) Gelzer and Harold (Dee Dee) Gerber. Cherished grandmother of Andrea, Jeff, Margie, Alan, Ellen, Janlori, Jimmy, Nancy, Michael, Dee Dee, Jane, David, Steven, Jill, Leslie and David. Adored great-grandmother of Eric, Rachel, Philip, Amanda, Maya, Hannah, Kali, Gabrielle, Toby and Adam. Services Wed. 12 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTENTHAL, IRVING
description: BERTENTHAL-Irving. Age 93. Father of Muriel Weisel, Doris Sklar and husband Samuel, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Beloved by all. Shiva will be observed through Sunday morning March 29th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, ELEANOR GREENBURG
description: GOULD-Eleanor Greenburg. On March 23, 1998, age 84. She is survived by her husband of 61 years, Milton S. Gould, by her children Patricia Booth, Judson and Jonathan, by her grandchildren Eliza, Alexander, Olivia, Eleanor, and Oliver, and by her brother Robert D. Greenburg. Her life was a blessing upon her family and upon her myriad friends of all ages. Family will be receiving Wednesday from 1 P.M. with service to follow at 2 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1077 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: No More Goofiness
description: After being honored at a benefit for the American Museum of the Moving Image at the Waldorf-Astoria, DUSTIN HOFFMAN and his wife, LISA, wandered off with BARRY LEVINSON, the director, and MICHAEL OVITZ, former president of the Walt Disney Company.

title: Casualty of the Abortion Debate; A Doctor, Aiming at Conciliation, Instead Loses a Post
description: ''I'm not a rabble rouser,'' Dr. David N. Mesches said the other day, and until recently few could possibly have disputed that.

title: Goals, Goals, Goals
description: MAJOR LEAGUE SOCCER

title: The Reformers Did It. No, Blame the Bankers.
description: Ever since President Boris N. Yeltsin was re-elected in 1996, the battle for Russia has been portrayed as a bitter struggle between a small group of tycoons who bankrolled his campaign in exchange for insider privileges, and the band of economic reformers he appointed to rein in those powerful bankers and businessmen.

title: Arch Coal to Buy An ARCO Unit
description: Arch Coal Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the Atlantic Richfield Company's American coal operations for about $1.14 billion.

title: Raise the Bar at City University; A Wiser Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: Dwellings in All Sizes; Of Greed and Need
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael Reardon, 60, Dies; A Bartender to the Famous
description: Michael Reardon, bartender to famous writers, mayors, journalists, stockbrokers, seamen, singers or any guy who dropped in off the street over the course of 30 years at the Lion's Head, a legendary species of New York bar that became extinct because people just didn't drink anymore the way they used to, died on Sunday in Fall River, Mass. He was 60.

title: At the Hospital, a New Doctor Is In
description: ANYONE who has been a patient or a visitor on an ordinary medical ward in an American hospital knows the usual routine. During the day a steady parade of residents, nurses, aides, students, therapists, nutritionists and social workers marches in and out of the room, but the doctor responsible for a patient's welfare is not among them.

title: Commerce Missions Disgusted Cabinet Official, Court Is Told
description: Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown became disgusted with the Clinton White House for pampering businessmen who were big donors to the Democratic Party and then trying to hide the evidence of special favors, a close associate of the late Secretary testified today.

title: Auto Insurance Panel Agrees on a Few Changes
description: A committee overhauling the state's automobile insurance laws agreed yesterday to measures that would crack down on insurance fraud and provide low-cost policies, officials said. But with only a week before Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's March 31 deadline to introduce such legislation, the committee has yet to address controversial proposals to reduce premiums in urban areas and to limit drivers' ability to sue for pain and suffering.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Overturning of Late-Term Abortion Ban Is Let Stand
description: Over a sharply worded dissent by three Justices, the Supreme Court today turned down the first case to reach it involving a ban on a method of late-term abortion.

title: BASEBALL: The Bounds of Retaliation; Players Count On the Beanball, as Long as It Is Done Properly
description: The knockdown pitch is as ingrained in the tradition of baseball as the glove or the bat, but actual deployment carries certain responsibilities. When Cleveland's Jaret Wright whipped a fastball near the head of second baseman Luis Sojo in an exhibition game on March 2, none of the Yankees contested the pitcher's right -- his duty, to some -- to retaliate for earlier pitches that had hit his teammates.

title: Increase in Oil Prices Sends Most Market Gauges Lower
description: A jump in oil prices reverberated through financial markets yesterday, leaving stocks generally lower, precious metals higher and the bond market unchanged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, RUTH S.
description: FISCHER-Ruth S. Mommy-Nana, the years you lived in our home and the love you gave to all of us will be treasured memories that we will hold in our hearts forever. We all loved every moment we shared, and we will love you with all our hearts forever and ever. Your memory and good deeds will live on forever through our family and future family generations. With all our love, Leslie and Bob, Justin, Brandon and Blake

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARADIES, LYLA
description: PARADIES-Lyla. Age 74 years, of Plattekill, NY died Monday, March 23, 1998, at her residence. She is survived by two daughters, Louise W. Harrison of Setauket, NY and Lynne Harrison of Queens, NY. She was a member of the Art Association of Queens, NY and a former member of St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Forest Hills, NY. A Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, March 25, 1998 at the Copeland Funeral Home, Inc. 162 so. Putt Crs. Rd., New Paltz, NY with visitation form 10 AM-11 AM.

title: Elf Aquitaine Buys Stake in AO Yuksi Oil
description: The French energy company Elf Aquitaine said yesterday that it had acquired a 5 percent stake in the AO Yuksi Oil Company, Russia's largest oil producer, for $528 million. Elf said that the investment was part of a strategic alliance between the two companies for the development of oil and gas activities in Russia as well as for trading and distribution of crude oil and refined petroleum products.

title: German Media Giant Will Buy Random House for $1.4 Billion
description: Bertelsmann A.G., the German media conglomerate, yesterday struck an estimated $1.4 billion agreement to buy the shiny crown jewel of American publishing, Random House, in a deal that will solidify its claim that it is the world's largest English-language publisher of trade books.

title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian: Renegade Ringleader
description: JERRY TARKANIAN, who needs about 60 minutes to build an ethically challenged college basketball program, was offering his standard defense yesterday, the thin-plated armor of political correctness.

title: Plan Is Seen For New Class Of Officers
description: A task force established by the Mayor after the reported beating of Abner Louima will recommend that the New York City Police Department create a new class of higher-paid, more highly decorated community patrol officers and appoint a monitor to audit how effectively brutality complaints are investigated, according to several members of the panel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKASHOK, LILLIAN G.
description: LUKASHOK-Lillian G. The Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Lillian G. Lukashok. A longtime supporter of UJA-Federation, she dedicated her life to philanthropy and leadership in many communal organizations. She was a friend of the entire Jewish community. Our condolences go to her son, Martin; her sister, Frances Horowitz; her grandchildren; her great-grandchildren; and her entire family. May you be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Susan K. Stern, Vice Chair, Campaign & Chair, Women's Campaign Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Specialists Report Rise In Adoptions That Fail
description: Rick and Jennifer made their way from Houston to a Siberian orphanage in January to adopt a 4-year-old boy and a girl of 5. But once the new family settled back in Texas, the children became aggressive and self-destructive. The boy put plastic bags over his head; the girl gave herself bloody noses. Within a month, they were hospitalized for psychiatric evaluation and given anti-psychotic drugs.

title: Paying Tribute to a Pianist, With Music, of Course
description: The pianist Marian McPartland is one of these invaluable jazz figures, a musician who has spent a good portion of her career in the service of the music. For nearly 20 years, she has produced ''Marian McPartland's Piano Jazz,'' a show from National Public Radio (Thursday night at 7 on WBG0, 88.3 F.M.) on which she has played duets with both the known and the unknown. All that activity has kept her playing fresh. At 80, she is seemingly as comfortable with a modal tune or a piece by John Coltrane as she is with the standards of her youth.

title: Washington Listened, But Moscow Didn't Call
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin did not call. Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin did not call. No top American officials in Washington heard from their Russian counterparts today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Survival Roulette
description: After the first release of captive-bred lemurs in Madagascar occurred in November, researchers were relieved to see them exhibit the right survival instincts, even though they had been raised at the Duke University Primate Center. But one of the five black and white ruffed lemurs became prey this month, apparently for another endangered animal, a grim reminder that despite precautions, the fate of a released animal can be survival roulette.

title: U.S. Moves To Block Deal For Northrop
description: The Justice Department filed suit today to block the Lockheed Martin Corporation's planned acquisition of the Northrop Grumman Corporation, contending that a combination of these two leading military contractors posed a threat to the nation's defense.

title: The new 'I [Love] NY' commercials do without the Governor.
description: THE custodians of the ''I [Love] NY'' campaign seem to have decided that Governors, tall and rugged-looking as they may be, are perhaps not actually scenic wonders.

title: Baerga Fixes Leg Woes, Getting Balance at Plate
description: Balance, Carlos Baerga said today, is the key to hitting. Now, Baerga is doing something about a problem that has kept him off balance: his right leg is shorter than his left.

title: On My Mind; Love, America and Britain
description: The young man was taking his examination to enter the Foreign Office. His inquisitors threw him a hardball: ''What do you think are the most important things in the world?''

title: Lessons From in the Ring And Inside a Prison Cell
description: The trainer whispers something to the fighter in turquoise trunks shortly before the bell rings to begin the round, and the fighter nods, in time-honored tradition. This is no ordinary trainer, however, and this just may be no ordinary fighter, either. They are father and son, one a former convict and the other a potential world champion.

title: Law in the Clinton Era; The Abuse of Privilege, Again
