description: Even if it is a time-buying tactic, President Clinton's decision to invoke executive privilege in the Monica Lewinsky investigation cannot be lightly regarded as one more legal maneuver in an unpleasant case that has seen no shortage of posturing by all sides. Mr. Clinton's attempt to block grand jury testimony by two important White House aides, Bruce Lindsey and Sidney Blumenthal, is an alarming attempt to extend Presidential power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, JACK ROHE
description: HOWARD-Jack Rohe. On March 22, 1998. Husband of the late Barbara Balfe Howard and the late Eleanor Harris Howard. Father of Pamela Howard Gumprecht and Michael Balfe Howard. Brother of Jane Howard Perkins. Grandfather of Eliza Howard, Esme Howard, Matthew Beatty Howard, Cassie Mei Howard, Jack Rohe Howard-Potter, Ian Nicholas Gumprecht and Christopher Balfe Gumprecht. Contributions in his memory may be made to Phillips Exeter Academy, 20 Main St., Exeter, NH 03833-2460 and the Scripps Howard Foundation, 312 Walnut Street, Cincinnati, Ohio 45212.

title: Myths of Redemption Amid a Legacy of Loss
description: THE ANTELOPE WIFE

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODBART, ESTELLE NELSON
description: RODBART-Estelle Nelson. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Louis S. Nelson, and Nathan Rodbart, cherished mother of Harriet (Robert) Levy, Dr. Irwin Nelson (Myrna), and the late Myra B. Ruskin, devoted sister of Miriam Levine, loving grandmother and great grandmother. Graveside services will be held Wednesday, March 25 at 1 P.M. at The Washington Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Inquiry Now at President's Pace
description: President Clinton's decision late last week to invoke executive privilege in the Monica S. Lewinsky investigation was both an effort to protect the Presidency and to slow the independent counsel's criminal inquiry, say lawyers in the investigation, White House officials and independent analysts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the baby boom generation's buying of luxury estate houses in suburban neighborhoods referred to the baby boom years incompletely. They began in 1946, not 1954, and lasted until 1964.

title: Today's Arts Pages
description: To accommodate late news of the Academy Awards, the Arts pages have been moved today to section C, starting on C9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIDEN, STELLA GOLDBERGER
description: HEIDEN - Stella Goldberger. Passed away on March 22, 1998. Born June 21, 1903. Married to the late Dr. Lionel Heiden. Beloved ''Aunt'' Stella to dozens, piano and music teacher to hundreds, degrees from Damrosch-Juilliard and Columbia University. Taught at Horace Mann, Julia Richman, and Washington Irving. Avid sailor and swimmer. Board member of Bloomingdale House of Music, Secretary of the UFT Retired Teachers Chapter for 25 years. Funeral service at Gramercy Chapel, 1 PM on March 24th. Donations to Bloomingdale House of Music. We will miss her.

title: CUNY Board Fails to Approve Bid to Allow Remedial Cuts
description: The heightened political sensitivity surrounding the status of remedial classes at the City University of New York was evident yesterday as the board narrowly failed to pass a resolution that would have allowed individual colleges to abolish remedial classes.

title: INSIDE
description: Abortion Ruling Is Upheld

title: Host Pulls the Plug
description: No cable? No party.

title: Learning Jazz Through Byron's Poetic Mix
description: THE public school kids rustling in their seats at the Brooklyn Academy of Music had no idea what to expect, except that their teachers wanted them to hear some music that was probably good for them. It didn't matter, anyway, because the Field Trip Rule was in effect: anything you do on a field trip, anything at all, is automatically better than being in school.

title: BOOK DEAL: THE BUYER -- Hansel & Gretel Inc.; Bertelsmann's Journey From Fairy Tales to Multimedia
description: Bertelsmann A.G. has come a long ways from selling books of Christian music and stories by the Brothers Grimm.

title: At Start of Tough Campaign, D'Amato Runs From G.O.P.
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato wears a pink ribbon on his lapel these days, a reminder of his concern about breast cancer. He denounces abuses by health maintenance organizations and banks. He backs spending for mass transit and lines up with environmentalists. And he preaches tolerance, standing up for the right of immigrants to get food stamps one day and urging an end to the military's ban on declared homosexuals the next.

title: 'Planning Our Future,' Newhouse Brothers Say
description: With the pending sale of Random House to Bertelsmann A.G., the powerful Newhouse family appears to be streamlining and getting its house in order.

title: New Suburbs, New Alignments
description: Not so long ago, American cities banded together to protect their interests against the booming suburbs. At annual meetings, city officials talked of ''the urban agenda'' and plotted ways to preserve their housing subsidies, money for new immigrants and welfare grants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, ALICE
description: WRIGHT-Alice. Age 95. On March 22, 1998 of 509 East 78 Street, Apt 4G, N.Y., N.Y. Graveside service Wednesday, 11 A.M., at Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, N.Y. Inquiries Roslyn Heights Funeral Home, Inc., 516-621-4545.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSS, JOSEPH R.
description: POSS-Joseph R. Age seventy-one, of chronic leukemia on March 22nd, 1998. Former employee in the Accounting Department of Pepsico for 40 years, a graduate of NYU School of Commerce and an active member of St. Peter's Church in Citicorp. Survivors include brother Fred, niece Susan Rooney, nephews Fred and Paul Poss and Joe's companion William Gentz. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, 2-5, 7-9 P.M., with service Wednesday 11:30 AM. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Peter's, Wednesday, April 29 at 6 P.M. Memorials are suggested for various programs at St. Peter's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLENBERG, MARY
description: ELLENBERG-Mary. We express our deepest sympathy to Maggie's family on her untimely passing. CAMP NYDA Junior Division

title: He Accuses Special Prosecutor of 'Trying to Torture' His Daughter : Lewinsky's Father Rips Into Starr
description: WASHINGTON  Monica Lewinsky's father vented anger and frustration Monday over the way that the investigation of his daughter's relationship to President Bill Clinton has dominated and disrupted the lives of his family and her friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, JEROME A.
description: GREENBAUM-Jerome A. Age 72, of Woodcliff Lake, NJ, Saturday, March 21, 1998. Beloved father of Suzanne Schoenfeld, Gary, Adam and Daniel. Cherished brother of Bertha Schachter. Founder and President for 48 years of Carbon Steel Products Corp. of Elizabeth, New Jersey. Services were held at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Why Not Require Uniforms in All Schools?; True Individuality
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENKES, BETTE S. (NEE KAPLAN)
description: MENKES-Bette S. (nee Kaplan). Of Fort Lee, N.J. Formerly of Teaneck, New Jersey. Beloved wife of the late Sherwood Bradford. Devoted mother of Holly and Alan Freedman, Laurie and Jeffrey Hollman, Jill and Robb Kushner and the late Peter K. Menkes. Loving grandmother of John and Michael Freedman, David and Richard Hollman, Matthew and Liz Kushner. Services were held at Gutterman - Musicant, Hacken sack, N.J., Sunday. Contributions to Peter K. Menkes Memorial Fund, C/O Teaneck Public Library, Teaneck, New Jersey 07666. The family will sit shiva at their respective homes on Tuesday.

title: Paterson Man Is Accused Of Setting Squatter Afire
description: A Paterson man was arrested yesterday and charged with killing a squatter by dousing him with gasoline and setting him on fire as he slept in an abandoned factory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, SEYMOUR L.
description: KATZ-Seymour L. Loving and beloved husband of Rose for 58 years. Caring and devoted father of Steven and his wife Susan, and Herbert and his wife Linda. Cherished and loving grandfather of Naomi and Aviva, and Jonathan, David and Marlee. Dear brother of Esther and Sylvia. He was gentle and charismatic. A pioneer in the movement to free Soviet Jews. A loyal son of his people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZFELD, SYLVIA
description: HERZFELD-Sylvia. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member and extends it condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Alan S. Roth, President

title: S.E.C. Studies Whether Mutual Funds Pass Along Merger Benefits
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a study of whether mutual funds are passing along to investors the benefits of a recent wave of fund company mergers, particularly in the form of lower fees, the commission's top mutual fund regulator said yesterday.

title: Kunming Journal; Riding the Rattling Minibus, a China in Miniature
description: Ma Hong had a big voice for such a small body.

title: Per-Pupil Spending Rises By 4.6 Percent in State
description: Per pupil spending in New Jersey schools, already 70 percent higher than the national average, increased 4.6 percent for the current school year, with more than half of the money going to teachers' salaries, the State Department of Education said yesterday.

title: N.C. State Stops UConn Short of Final Four
description: The University of Connecticut women had visions of a championship showdown with the No. 1 Tennessee Vols dancing in their heads, only to lose control of the dream, which ended among the tall pines of North Carolina State.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, FREDERICK HARPER, JR.
description: WALSH-Frederick Harper, Jr., 82. Of Hobe Sound, FL., died Friday, March 13, 1998. A native of Bronx, New York, he had lived in Hobe Sound for 18 years, prior to that he had resided in Port Washington and Manhasset, L.I. New York for 33 years. Before retirement, he was an advertising Sales Manager for Fawcett Publications and Hearst Corporation in NYC. Survivors include his wife of 55 years, Dorothy Walsh, of Hobe Sound, Florida, three sons, Frederick H. Walsh, III of Greenlawn, NY, Jay L. Walsh of Anchorage, Kentucky, and Glenn A. Walsh, of Byron, Georgia, two daughters, Georgia Miller of New Haven, Conn., and Suzanne Desposati, of Hobe Sound, Florida, and fourteen grandchildren. Those who wish may contribute to Bethel Lutheran Church, S.E. Federal Highway, Hobe Sound, Florida, 33455.

title: A Pennsylvania Town Mourns Its Sons and Daughters
description: Their faces alone said that this was not a typical Monday. All day, students here at Line Mountain High School in central Pennsylvania walked somberly to and from their classrooms, painfully aware that many of their friends were gone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMERLING, RABBI SAMUEL
description: SMERLING-Rabbi Samuel. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. Ordained in 1949, he served as a chaplain in the United States Army after which he served pulpits in New Jersey and New York, most recently the Rosedale Jewish Center (NY). We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Pearl, and children Arthur, Reva, and all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Seymour L. Essrog, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, MAXINE L. (MCKETTRICK)
description: WILSON-Maxine L. (McKettrick). Age 89, on March 22, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Isaiah Herbert ''Bud'' Wilson. Lovingly remembered by daughter Lynda Mae Wilson Laurence; grandson Matthew James Wilson Laurence and son-in-law Judge Kenneth Laurence, all of Lexington, MA. Private burial with interment at Westview Cemetery in Lexington. Visitors welcome at the Laurence home, 11 John Poulter Road, Lexington, evenings during the coming week. Contributions in Maxine's memory may be made to the Schepens Eye Research Institute for Macular Degeneration, 20 Staniford Street, Boston, MA 02114-2500, Tel: 617-723-6078.

title: California Justices Allow Scouts To Bar Gay and Atheist Members
description: The California Supreme Court ruled today that the Boy Scouts of America can exclude homosexuals, agnostics and atheists from its ranks because it is a private membership group not covered by the state's civil rights law.

title: British Aerospace Sells Its Orion Stake
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said yesterday that it had sold its 26 percent stake in Orion Network Systems Inc., an international satellite communications company based in Rockville, Md., for $143 million cash. British Aerospace said that it would realize a profit of $54 million before taxes on the sale, the proceeds of which will be used ''for general corporate purposes.''

title: A Fairy Tale Becomes a Wintry Spectacle
description: ''The Snow Maiden,'' Ben Stevenson's latest premiere for the Houston Ballet, is a gamble won on risky terrain, the icy slopes of ersatz Romanticism.

title: Giuliani Tells City's Drivers To Slow Down Or Pay Up
description: A month after vowing to make New York into a more civil city, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday announced that an important strategy toward that goal would begin today: speed enforcement.

title: Key Phase of Belfast Talks Begins With 2 Sides at Odds
description: The make-or-break phase of negotiations on the political future of Northern Ireland began today with Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders still sharply divided on how to end the sectarian warfare in this predominantly Protestant British province.

title: Great Universal Stores Sues Merger Rival
description: Great Universal Stores P.L.C., Britain's largest home shopping company, has filed a countersuit against American Business Information Inc., contending the United States company interfered with its $831 million bid for the Metromail Corporation, a direct marketer. Great Universal Stores said its suit, filed in the Delaware Chancery Court, sought an injunction against American Business from interfering with its bid or ''substantial'' damages if an injunction was denied.

title: Sampras Double-Faults and Is Defeated
description: It was sacrilege of a sort: Pete Sampras, the world's No. 1 player and a player deservedly feared for his serving prowess, double-faulting on his own match point, in what turned out to be a losing third-round encounter with Wayne Ferreira today at the Lipton Championships.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bertelsmann of Germany Buying Random House

title: 'Good Morning' Names 2d New Anchor
description: The other anchor dropped yesterday at ABC's ''Good Morning America,'' when Kevin Newman was named to replace Charles Gibson, who has been co-anchor for the last 11 years and is said to be eager to move on to a new role. In September, Lisa McRee took over the other co-anchor job from Joan Lunden, who had held it for 17 years.

title: CREATIVE COMPUTERS STOCK FALLS 22% ON STORE CLOSINGS
description: The shares of Creative Computers Inc. fell 22 percent yesterday after the company said it had closed six of its seven stores, dismissing about 150 people, to focus on selling through its catalogue and the Internet. The company, which sells personal computers and computer products, also warned that it would have a first-quarter loss after taking an unspecified charge for costs related to the closings. It will shut three Elek-Tek stores in Chicago and three Creative Computer stores in Southern California. Shares of the company, which is based in Torrance, Calif., fell $2.375 yesterday, to $8.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, I. STANTON
description: JACKSON-I. Stanton, 92. Of Gilford, NH., formerly of NYC. At home March 14, 1998. Widower of Gertrude Van Brunt Jackson who died in 1989. Survived by nephew, Dr. George V.B. Cochran of Ossining, NY. There are no calling hours. Private graveside service will be held in Pine Grove Cemetery, Gilford, in spring. Donations may be made in lieu of flowers to charity of one's choice. Contact Wilkinson-Beane Funeral Home, Laconia, N.H. for arrangements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUHAUS, ELLEN
description: NEUHAUS-Ellen. On March 21, 1998, the 71st anniversary of her marriage to her beloved late husband, Dr. Fritz Neuhaus. Born in Berlin, Germany, July 25, 1905, she was a refugee from Nazi Germany and a longtime resident of NYC and Miami Beach, FL. She is survived by her devoted children Dr. Robert P. Newhouse and his wife Mary of NYC, and Block Island, RI, and Marian Nachman of Greenwich, CT. Loving grandmother of Alisa Newhouse Smith of Los Angeles, Sarah Newhouse of Watertown, MA., Andrea Newhouse of NYC, Alex Nachman of Boston, MA, and Juliet Nachman of Oregon, and great-grandmother of Olivia Taylor Smith and Jules Haskell Smith of Los Angeles. Funeral services will be private.

title: Seeking White Candidate For Mostly Black Council
description: Democratic officials in predominantly black Mount Vernon said yesterday that they are deliberately seeking a white candidate to fill a vacancy on the otherwise all-black City Council.

title: Scientist at Work: Stephen W. Hawking; Sailing A Wheelchair To the End Of Time
description: OUT of a crumpled, voiceless body in a wheelchair, the mind of Stephen W. Hawking soars and summons expression by pressing a finger and thumb to a small control box in his lap. Slowly, one word or letter at a time, sentences appear on the lower half of a compact computer screen attached to the chair. He is forming an answer to a question about the consuming quest of some of the world's most brilliant scientists, himself very much included, to find a ''theory of everything'' to explain all phenomena in space-time, especially the first split second of cosmic creation in the Big Bang.

title: Dwellings in All Sizes
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic's Notebook; Tracing the Look of Alienation
description: Everyone watched the Academy Awards last night. Everyone has seen ''Titanic.'' Everyone is on the Internet. Everyone wears the same 15 or so designer labels. So why is it that the more consumers have in common, the more isolated they feel and the more disconnected they feel from the culture and from one another?

title: Running Late? Researchers Blame Aging Brain
description: CAN March be almost over? Didn't they play the Super Bowl just last week? It sometimes seems that with each passing year, the days and weeks zip by more quickly.

title: Cendant Says It Will Buy Miami Insurer
description: The Cendant Corporation formally announced today that it had reached an agreement to buy American Bankers Insurance Group Inc. for $67 a share in stock and cash, or $3.1 billion, making it one of the leading direct marketers of insurance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, HERBERT
description: MENDELSON-Herbert. Thanks for the integral part you played in our success. For 38 years you were always there to guide us. Without you, who knows where we would have been. Gould Investors LP

title: Goldman, Sachs Reports Record Earnings of $1.022 Billion
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, the last big investment banking partnership on Wall Street, said yesterday that it had earned a record $1.022 billion before taxes for the three months that ended on Feb. 28, benefiting from some of the most favorable financial market conditions in years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, PHILIP
description: GREENBERG-Philip, 83 of Woodstock, NY, formerly of Jackson Heights, died March 19, 1998. Husband of the late Evelyn, father of Leslie and Robert, grandfather of Justin and Gavin, brother of Rabbi Sidney Greenberg and Sara Aboff, dear friend and companion of Shirley Fink. Former ''tie-coon'' extraordinaire, a lover of life and people, happy and always productive-he lived fully to the very end. Richer for having known him, he leaves behind a large family of relatives and friends and a long trail of smiles... Contributions may be made to the Woodstock Jewish Congregation Building Fund.

title: BAGHDAD ARRESTS A GERM SPECIALIST
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Court Fight Doesn't Save Residency Requirement
description: The United States Supreme Court yesterday declined to hear an appeal of an appellate ruling that struck down the North Bergen Township's residency requirement for municipal employees as discriminatory.

title: Battery Park City to Give Middle-Income Renters a Break
description: The Battery Park City Authority, hoping to attract more middle-class people to the neighborhood it oversees, is doing something almost unheard of in the hot Manhattan real estate market: providing subsidies to families with annual household incomes as high as $108,000.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HERSEY, JOHN
description: HERSEY-John. June 17, 1914-March 24, 1993. Forever in my heart. B.

title: Players Foresee Release As Other Refugees Wait
description: Four Cuban baseball players being held in a detention center here negotiated with sports agents today and were told they could expect to be released after just a few days in custody. Meanwhile, more than 100 other Cuban refugees locked up with them, who have been held for months in the bare-bones compound, began a hunger strike to protest their plight.

title: Tough Tactics In One Battle Over Animals In the Lab
description: ALAN STAPLE, the president of a New Jersey company that conducts animal tests for other companies, was attending a conference in England last May when he was jolted awake by a telephone call at 3 A.M. from his company's vice president.

title: Cash Retires
description: Pat Cash, a former Wimbledon champion, said yesterday that he was retiring from tennis after 16 years as a professional.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUSS, MOLLY
description: YUSS-Molly. Age 95. Devoted mother of Marcia Grey, Irene Tuft and Shirley Elias. Loving grandmother of Michael, Mia, David, Carrie and Susan. Great grandmother of Zachary. Services Wednesday, 10 A.M., ''Weinstein-West End Funeral Chapel'', 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Record Total Inches Even Higher
description: A Guyanese-born livery cab driver paralyzed by a robber's bullet. An elderly Holocaust survivor forced into a homeless shelter after a fire destroyed her apartment. A family of Russian immigrants struggling to feed themselves after the household breadwinner suffered a heart attack.

title: Jet-Lagged Armadillos
description: To the Editor:

title: By Design; Small Touches That Add Up
description: Finishing touches on the European runways for fall included capelets covering the shoulders, tiny shrugs that were little more than long sleeves joined by fabric across the back, and circlets of fur worn either around the neck or falling off one shoulder.

title: PLAINS IN $420 MILLION DEAL FOR 3 GOODYEAR BUSINESSES
description: Plains Resources Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the oil pipeline unit of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and two other Goodyear businesses for $420 million in cash. Plains said it would buy Goodyear's All American Pipeline System, which connects oilfields in California with West Texas, as well as the Celeron Gathering Corporation and the Celeron Trading and Transportation Company. The deal ends Goodyear's diversification attempt. Goodyear, the big North American tire maker, spent $1.6 billion building All American in 1983 and will report a $35 million loss on the sale. Shares of the Houston-based Plains rose $2.125 yesterday, to $17.8125. Goodyear fell 93.75 cents, to $73.5625.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERMAIN, LAWRENCE
description: GERMAIN-Lawrence. In loving memory of my dear husband who passed away March 24, 1991. No words were ever written No smile could ever hide The heartache and the loneliness That are hidden deep inside There's a lonely feeling in my heart An ache I can't explain There's a picture of my Lawrence Locked in a silver frame. We met and loved in time too short And very long ago But I have not forgotten you And how I love you so. I remember the day I met you And the day God made you mine I remember the day I lost you And will til the end of time. We made our vows as man and wife Til death us do part And when God came and took you Lawrence My whole world just fell apart. Along the road to yesterday That leads me straight to you Are memories of happy days Together we once knew. I dream of a beautiful garden By the gate my Lawrence stands One day that gate will open And Lawrence will take my hand. I cannot write a letter Your hand I cannot touch So Dear Lord, take this message To the husband I love so much.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORREST, GERALD (JERRY)
description: FORREST-Gerald (Jerry). Best husband of Loretta. Best father to Salli, Pamela and Mitch. Best friend, best dressed, best dancer, ...the best of everything. For shiva information call Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 516-487-9600.

title: Mitsubishi to Merge Petroleum Product Units
description: The Mitsubishi Corporation and the Mitsubishi Oil Company will merge petroleum product sales units in July and cut staff to reduce operation costs, an official at Mitsubishi Oil said yesterday. By combining sales operations of subsidiaries in the Nagoya and Fukuoka regions, the companies hope to cut combined annual operation costs by about 1 billion yen ($7.7 million) in the first year, said Takahisa Iwanaga, a Mitsubishi Oil spokesman.

title: The Movable Feast
description: Why is this night different from all others?

title: The Auction Wave
description: Another yacht owner is hoping to cash in on a Kennedy connection. The Marlin, a 52-foot vessel that belonged to the Kennedy family from 1952 to 1970, is scheduled to be auctioned by Christie's on April 25.

title: Throngs Greet Call by Clinton For New Africa
description: Be fore the largest crowd he has ever addressed a whooping and clapping throng estimated by the Government here at more than half a million -- President Clinton opened his 12-day tour of Africa today by pledging more American interest and aid while calling for a deeper African commitment to democracy and free markets.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is time for Americans to put a new Africa on our map.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HOSPITALITY PROPERTIES TRUST, Newton, Mass., a real estate investment trust, bought 15 Summerfield Suites hotels for about $240 million from affiliates of Summerfield Hotel Corp.

title: More Interest Payments on Awards Are Urged to Speed Up Court Cases
description: Seeking to crack down on defense lawyers who stall personal injury cases in the courts, New York's Chief Judge proposed today that their clients pay retroactive interest on lawsuit awards in cases that drag on for more than a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZOG, RUTH S.
description: HERZOG-Ruth S. Age 94, beloved wife, mother, grandmother, and great grandmother. Dearie to all. An elegant lady of a bygone era.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Bloody Clues in Apartment Where Student Was Killed
description: The police said last night that they had found a man's blood-soaked clothes at the apartment of a slain Columbia University law student and were seeking to determine whether the clothes were those of her former boyfriend charged in the killing.

title: Gateway Dismisses D.M.B.& B.
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications has been dismissed by Gateway 2000 Inc., a personal computer company, after handling its worldwide account for one year. Billings were estimated at $50 million to $70 million.

title: Hotel Company in Talks to Buy Four Seasons
description: Strategic Hotel Capital Inc. is close to a deal to buy the Four Seasons Hotel, New York's tallest hotel and a symbol of the city's economic fortunes, for more than $350 million, according to real estate executives.

title: Toothpaste a Hazard? Just Ask the F.D.A.
description: It was a routine purchase of that most benign of products, toothpaste, at a Duane Reade drugstore in Manhattan. So Laura Cheek, mother of a 22-month-old daughter, did a double take when she read the new message on the tube of Colgate that she had just pulled off the shelf:

title: Mexico Playing Unfamiliar Role in World Oil Politics
description: Mexican officials are traveling in unfamiliar territory, side by side with Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, leading the way in cutting oil exports to bolster world petroleum prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLACHTER, HELEN C. (NEE CYMROT)
description: SCHLACHTER-Helen C. (nee Cymrot). Of Royal Palm Beach, formerly of Bethpage, NY. Passed away on March 19th. Beloved wife of the late Fenimore (Monte), loving mother of David and Barbara Schlachter, of Merrick, NY, and Moshe and Marilyn Berger, of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. Devoted grandmother of Aliza, Natan, Oren, Yaakov, Jason, and Rebecca. Survived by cherished sisters, Dorothy Cymroth and Sadye Silver and brother Ben Cymroth. The warm and beautiful memories she created will always be with her loving family and very special friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, HOWARD P.
description: PECK-Howard P. On March 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Nikki Peck. Loving father of James M., Andrew J. and Theodore S. Peck. Adoring grandfather of Alissa D. and Adam R. Peck. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, March 24, at 11:30 AM. Interment private.

title: Chief Executive Named at Chiron
description: After a search of more than a year, the Chiron Corporation said today that it had picked Sean Lance, a former top executive of Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., to be president and chief executive.

title: Overcoming Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Spot in Playoffs at Risk On Knicks' Trip West
description: On paper, it is the self-esteem swing, a chance for the Knicks to recapture some of their game and ego and gain some ground in the Eastern Conference playoff race: Golden State (14-53) tonight. The Clippers (15-52) in Los Angeles on Wednesday. And Vancouver, another team with 15 victories, on Friday.

title: SERVICO TO ACQUIRE IMPAC HOTEL GROUP IN STOCK DEAL
description: Servico Inc. will buy the closely held Impac Hotel Group for $111.8 million in stock, based on yesterday's closing price, adding upscale hotels and creating the nation's largest independent hotel owner and operator, with several brands, including Marriott. The combined company will be called Lodgian. Servico shareholders will get one Lodgian share for each Servico share held, while Impac's holders will get six million shares. The Atlanta-based Impac owns or manages 55 hotels. Lodgian, which will be based in Atlanta, will own or manage 140 hotels with 26,698 rooms in 35 states and Canada. Shares of Servico, of West Palm Beach, Fla., rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $18.625.

title: Bidders for CIC Narrowed to 3 Banks
description: The French Government narrowed the number of bidders for Compagnie Financiere de CIC to three banks -- Societe Generale S.A., Credit Mutuel, and ABN AMRO Holding -- yesterday after examining bids from five companies. The Finance Ministry did not say why the preliminary offers of two other banks -- Banque Nationale de Paris and Credit Commercial de France -- have now been eliminated.

title: Rap Producer Testifies on Fatal Stampede at City College
description: In 1991, Puffy Combs was a largely unknown rap promoter whose celebrity basketball game became forever linked to a horrible event: the stampede that killed nine people at City College.

title: KODAK TO INVEST $1 BILLION IN CHINA FOR MANUFACTURING
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would invest more than $1 billion in China in the next several years to make film and paper. Noting that fewer than one Chinese household in 10 own a camera, Kodak said that China offered more potential for photography than any other market in the world. ''By the year 2000, most Kodak products sold in China will be made in China,'' said Kodak's chief executive, George M. C. Fisher. Kodak will invest about $380 million to capitalize two established Chinese companies and more than $700 million in the next two to five years to upgrade technology, improve manufacturing capacity and expand distribution and marketing.

title: Connecticut Sues New York City Over Pollution in Sound
description: Seeking to burnish his image with an attack on his neighbor, Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut announced today that his state would join a lawsuit accusing New York City of illegally polluting Long Island Sound with poorly treated sewage.

title: Raise the Bar at City University; Worthless Diplomas
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CERTNER, JOEL
description: CERTNER-Joel. In loving memory of our beloved Joel, who would have been 53 today. Mother, Naomi and Jerry

title: U.S. Is No Model For Europe's Jobless; Beyond Basic Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: Deflected Pact: N.B.A. Owners Reopening Labor Agreement
description: Fed up with an economic climate that they contend is too favorable for the players, the National Basketball Association owners voted overwhelmingly yesterday to void the final three years of the collective bargaining agreement with the players' union.

title: Method or Madness? Lewinsky's Lawyer Baffles Washington Establishment
description: Back in the days before he became as familiar a television fixture as ''Seinfeld'' reruns, William H. Ginsburg once observed, ''A trial is not a game, but it is theater.''

title: N.F.L. Has a New Pact; Cleveland Back in Fold
description: National Football League owners insured labor peace through the year 2003 by ratifying the new labor deal with their players today. But because of a passionate speech against the extension by the Giants' co-owner, Wellington Mara, things were much closer than expected.

title: Corrections
description: Because of broadcasters' schedule changes, two highlight listings for today in the Television section on Sunday were outdated. ''The Jesus Conspiracy'' has been replaced by ''The Nine Steps to Financial Freedom with Suze Orman,'' from 9 to 11 P.M on Channel 13. ''Jonathan Pond's Tax Party'' has been replaced by ''The Polish Americans,'' from 8 to 9:30 P.M. on Channel 21.

title: Deal for Equipment Maker
description: Tomkins P.L.C. agreed today to acquire Schrader-Bridgeport, a privately held transportation equipment maker, for $:112 million, or $186.9 million. Tomkins, an industrial management company based here, will also assume debt of about $:41 million, or $68.4 million. Schrader-Bridgeport, which had 1997 sales of $175.9 million, manufactures fluid-control components and systems, transportation wheel valves and related products. It has 1,500 employees and operates in the United States, Brazil, Mexico, France, Northern Ireland and India.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Upholds Key Aspect of Sex Shop Law
description: A Federal appeals court has removed another obstacle to the Giuliani administration's efforts to enforce a zoning law that bans X-rated businesses from residential neighborhoods, ruling that the law neither violates the First Amendment nor discriminates against women.

title: A Toast to a First
description: ''Looks like NASA,'' ALAN ALDA said as he walked in, but it was not Mission Control, only a television control room on West 42d Street.

title: Patterns
description: Fashion Lets G.M. Drive

title: Utility Is Fined $55,000 For Reactor Violation
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission fined Public Service Electric and Gas $55,000 yesterday for violating standard operating procedures at the company's Hope Creek nuclear reactor in Lower Alloways Creek Township.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about preparations for President Clinton's visit to Africa misspelled the surname of Ghana's President. He is Jerry Rawlings, not Rawlins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANCHEZ, ROBERT
description: SANCHEZ-Robert. On March 21, 1998. Employee of NYC District Attorney's Office, beloved husband of Marta (nee Arriaga), loving father of Robert Jr, dear son of Aurora LaPorte, dear brother of Junior. Reposing at Riverdale Funeral Home, 5044 Broadway at 214 St, New York City, on Tuesday 2-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Jude Church, NYC on Wednesday 10 A.M. Interment at Saint Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Bookends by the Visiting Angelenos
description: The Los Angeles Philharmonic's weekend in New York, two concerts at Avery Fisher Hall, stationed composers with large appetites at its beginning and at its end. Friday night, it was Magnus Lindberg's ''Fresco,'' on Sunday afternoon the Mahler Third Symphony. In both pieces, form is an afterthought, a way of keeping some kind of order in a relentless outpouring of new ideas and musical developments that no amount of restraint or temperance could possibly slow down. Sonata form is replaced by the esthetic principles of ''And furthermore . . .'' or ''Did I forget to mention . . .?''

title: To Coaches, This Final Four Also Counts as a Reward
description: Before the National Collegiate Athletic Association began its post-season basketball tournament, and long before it started to generate huge television dollars, there was a National Invitation Tournament in Madison Square Garden. Now the N.C.A.A.'s high-profile tournament has spawned March Madness, and the mad part of that nickname could refer to teams angry that they were bypassed for the N.C.A.A. tournament and had to settle for the N.I.T.

title: U.S. Is No Model For Europe's Jobless; Struggling to Survive
description: To the Editor:

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Love Triangle of Sorts, With Daredevils and Pots

title: Pink and Purple Germs
description: Q. What do doctors mean when they talk about gram-negative bacteria?

title: Packer's Analysis Lifts Game to Higher Level
description: CBS's Billy Packer says a lot. He is a fast-talking chatterbox of analysis and opinion, all delivered in a straightforward style. He manufactures no silly nicknames or categories. He never screams. His language is English.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITTLEMAN, FANNIE C.
description: GITTLEMAN-Fannie C. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Isaac F. Gittleman, devoted mother of Maryann and Dr. Alvin Harris, and Ephros and Seymour Manello. Cherished grandmother of Patricia, Jonathan, Danielle, and Sarah. She was dignified, elegant, concerned, involved and will be greatly missed. Donations to the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, Inc., 138 So. Oxford St, Brooklyn, NY 11217 would be appreciated. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, Long Island.

title: From Birth to Manhood, the Tale of Afro Jo, Black Everyman
description: Plenty of rewards lie in wait for audiences at ''Hip 2: Birth of the Boom.'' It's an ambitious little show, grappling with big ideas, energized by a multitalented cast and alight with wide-ranging song, exciting dancing and some genuinely funny comedy. At the same time, ''Hip 2'' is a long-winded journey to an unsurprising insight that leaves the impression that the parts are better than the whole.

title: Low-Cost Portables With Personality
description: THE most personal thing remaining in the world of personal computing is the portable computer. With ''desktop'' machines so bland that we typically hide them under the desk, choosing a favorite screen saver or cartoon assistant is about as personal as things get. That makes the notebook machine the last bastion of individuality. Screens, keyboards, pointing devices and the size, shape and color of the machines themselves march to the beat of a different tinny speaker.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK GAINS. The mark rallied to end higher after traders concluded that a Cabinet shake-up in Russia could help economic relations with Germany. The dollar cost 1.8256 marks in New York, down from 1.8302 Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZUR, GRACE (HARTMAN)
description: MAZUR-Grace (Hartman). Ethel Fishman and family mourn the passing of a most delightful and courageous woman. Died March 20, 1998. She will be missed.

title: Greg MacGregor Former Times Reporter, 85
description: Greg MacGregor, a foreign correspondent who reported on the Korean War as well as economic and political developments in Southeast Asia during a 17-year career at The New York Times, died on Sunday in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTFELD, PAULINE
description: ALTFELD-Pauline. Mar. 23, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Murray. Cherished mother of Esther and Joel Silver and Arlene and Jay Goldberg. Beloved sister of Rae and Irving. Loving grandmother of Larry, Caryn, Deborah and Tony, and Erica. Great grandmother of Shoshana. A paragon of loyalty and strength. Service Wednesday, 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Felcor Suite Agrees to Purchase Bristol's Hotels
description: Felcor Suite Hotels Inc. agreed today to buy the Bristol Hotel Company's hotel properties for almost $1.2 billion in stock and the assumption of $700 million of debt, making it the largest owner of Holiday Inns and expanding it beyond all-suite hotels.

title: Metro Business; Reject Bank Merger, New York Tells Fed
description: The New York Banking Department has said that the Federal Reserve Board should oppose the $33 billion merger of Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation, citing poor handling of accounts of Jews after World War II.

title: Israel's Darkest Secrets
description: In televised remarks last week, Ariel Sharon, a senior minister in the Israeli Government, warned that Israel would eventually assassinate Khaled Meshal, the leader of the Muslim fundamentalist group Hamas. Mr. Meshal has already survived one assassination attempt, six months ago when Israeli agents sprayed him with poison in Amman, Jordan.

title: Bloody Sweatshirt Tied to Suspect's Lover
description: The blood-soaked black sweatshirt found in the apartment of a slain Columbia Law School student belonged to the girlfriend of the suspect, Edmund Ko, investigators said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEBSTER, JOHN BANCROFT
description: WEBSTER-John Bancroft. Sept. 22, 1916-March 25, 1997. Remembered every day with love. Your wife, Sula

title: NETWORK ASSOCIATES AGREES TO BUY A SOFTWARE MAKER
description: Network Associates Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Magic Solutions, a privately held software company, for $110 million. Magic Solutions develops help-desk software, which gives employees guidance on how to use their computers. Help-desk software can also be used externally to assist customers with products. Magic Solutions, based in Paramus, N.J., will be integrated with Network Associates' service-desk unit. Network Associates, based in Santa Clara, Calif., changed its name from McAfee Associates in December. It had 1997 revenues of $612.2 million.

title: Lakes Are Born Great, 5 Sniff, So Upstart Is Ousted
description: Whoops! Lake Champlain may not be a Great Lake after all.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AVX CORP., Myrtle Beach, S.C., a maker of electronic components, will buy the passive component business of France's state-owned military and electronics company, Thomson S.A. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTRAM, DAVID G.
description: BARTRAM-David G. March 18, 1998 in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. after an extended illness. Born in Indianapolis, IN., he moved to Terre Haute and attended Indiana State University. During WWII, Bartram served the U.S. Navy in Norfolk, VA. before developing an accounting firm back in TerreHaute which was later acquired by Ernst & Ernst. He was assigned partner to Washington, DC., then in NYC. In 1969, Bartram became a partner in the investment firm Paine Webber Jackson & Curtis. He helped incorporate the firm and retired in 1980 as Financial VP/Treasurer. Received a distinguished alumni award from ISU in 1972. Served as treasurer of the Tax Institute of America and governor/President of Greenwich Country Club. Until 1980, Bartrams lived in Greenwich, CT then moved to Ponte Vedra, Fl. where Bartram was director of the Ponte Vedra Community Assoc. and a member of The Ponte Vedra Club. He is survived by his wife Ethel, daughter Clare B. Cerri (Atlanta) and grandchildren, David, Katie and Steven. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the schoolbuilding funds of: St. Paul's Catholic Church, 224 N. 5th St., Jacksonville Beach, FL 32250 or Our Lady Star of the Sea, 545 A1A North, Ponte Vedra Bch, FL 32082. Memorial service pending.

title: Filmmakers' Off-Screen Drama; They Fight to Regain Money Entrusted to Nonprofit Sponsor
description: Claire Panke has spent six years trying to make her first documentary film. She never imagined it would be as hard as it has been. As she puts it, climbing Mount Everest naked would seem easy in comparison to making an independent film.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Enabling Bad Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia Reported to Agree to Sell Heavy Weapons to Yugoslavia
description: In a move that could threaten the delicate peace in the Balkans, Russia has agreed in principle to sell Yugoslavia tanks, attack helicopters, ground-to-air missiles, MIG-29's and spare parts, American officials report.

title: Ecuador Native Receives Life Term, Not Death
description: Carlos Cevallos, who was convicted in November on a capital murder charge, will not face the death penalty, a judge has ruled, after a protest by his native country of Ecuador, where capital punishment was outlawed in 1906.

title: Former Chief of Carpenters' Union Convicted of Stealing Funds
description: Frederick W. Devine, who campaigned against corruption to become one of the state's most powerful construction union leaders in the early 1990's, was convicted yesterday in Manhattan on charges that he stole more than $50,000 from a fund earmarked to create jobs for unemployed carpenters.

title: Fictional Bookshop Touches a Nerve
description: In a city that seems to be in perpetual mourning for the passing of bookstores, a sign for Fox & Sons Books in Chelsea has prompted more than a few double takes. Sorry, book lovers: It's not a bookstore, but a set for the NORA EPHRON film ''You've Got Mail.'' (The TOM HANKS character owns a large bookstore chain, which is a threat to the small bookshop for children owned by the MEG RYAN character.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOROSS, HELEN
description: MOROSS-Helen. On March 23, 1998. Beloved mother of Sonya Bregman and Gladys Cutler. Loving grandmother of Sheryl and Gary Bregman. Funeral services Wednesday, 11 AM, at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. For further information contact John J. Fox Funeral Home 914-834-0144

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: That's the Official Name of Its Crackdown on Illegal Immigrants : Malaysia to Indonesians:Go Away
description: KUALA LUMPU  The Malaysian Navy has launched a small fleet. The police have descended almost nightly on squatter villages, arresting those without working papers. And trawler captains convicted of ferrying illegal immigrants have been sentenced to three years in prison and six lashes with a rattan cane.

title: Off the Menu
description: Chefs on the Move

title: Real Estate; Trade Associations Form Electricity Supply Deals
description: As property managers and owners in New York and Westchester Counties prepare for the April 1 changes in state regulations that will allow them to choose their supplier of electricity, a group of real estate trade associations has announced an agreement with two of the new power suppliers.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC PLANS TO BUY SPANDEX FOR $183 MILLION
description: Gerber Scientific Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Spandex P.L.C. of Britain for about $:109 million ($183 million) in cash. Gerber, based in South Windsor, Conn., a supplier of automated systems for graphics and sign making, said it was offering 325 pence in cash for each share of Spandex. Gerber said the offer had been unanimously recommended by the directors of Spandex and that it had received acceptances totaling 54.5 percent of the total shares. Gerber's chairman, George M. Gentile, said the acquisition of Spandex, a supplier of equipment and materials to the sign and graphics industry, would help it exploit opportunities in the speciality graphics market.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; The Decline of Punditry
description: To the Editor:

title: In California, a Distant Mirror on Korea
description: Bong Koo Cho was once one of the wealthiest industrialists and biggest landowners in South Korea. He lived in a 14,500-square-foot mansion and owned five or six cars.

title: In London, the Sun Still Rises on the Flavors of Empire
description: MY, but the English love their curry. They always have.

title: Tourism Plan Cites Cultural Attractions
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced a 10-year tourism master plan yesterday that would emphasize the state's cultural and rural attractions, partly through overseas advertisements.

title: Label Unit for Mail-Well
description: The office-supplies maker Mail-Well Inc. has agreed to acquire the International Paper Company's label unit. Terms were not disclosed. Mail-Well, based here, is a paper and envelope-printing concern. International Paper's label unit, based in Bowling Green, Ky., had annual sales of about $30 million last year. It supplies paper labels to the beverage, food and household products industries.

title: IN UGANDA, CLINTON EXPRESSES REGRET ON SLAVERY IN U.S.
description: President Clinton expressed regret today for the role of the United States in African slavery, as he reeled off a list of errors in American policy toward this continent that included turning to ruthless dictators as allies during the cold war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALVIN, JOSEPH E.
description: GALVIN-Joseph E. Of East Northport, Long Island, March 23, 1998. Husband of Doris. Father of Christine, Roger and Claudia. Loving grandfather of Emily, Eric, Kate and Molly. Veteran of W.W. II Submarine Service, retired deputy chief, NYC Fire Dept., teacher, and devoted marathon runner. Donations to NYC Firefighters Burn Center, c/o Ladder 61/Engine 66, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx NY 10475

title: Little Lumps, Lots Of Comfort
description: WHILE risotto could easily win the award for the most cliched dish of the decade, a similar rice dish has hung back in the shadows, mostly unnoticed by New York's dining cognoscenti.

title: TV Program Chiefs Seek To Call Halt To Sniping
description: The heads of the entertainment divisions at each of the four big broadcast networks held a private, unpublicized meeting last week to discuss ways to curtail some of the internecine sniping that many believe has helped damage the image of network television and to present a unified front against growing attempts by the cable television industry to eat into advertising revenue controlled by the networks.

title: Judge Rejects Challenge to Lilco Takeover
description: In a ruling that clears a hurdle for Governor Pataki's plan to take over part of the Long Island Lighting Company, a judge today dismissed a court challenge filed by the Suffolk County Legislature. An appeal is expected.

title: American Palates Awaken To the Bold Tastes of India; As the latest fusion star, creative Indian cuisine vies with its Asian rivals.
description: THE soup may look familiar enough -- at least at first. It's a tomato soup, after all, and it's served with croutons. But the croutons are made of the Indian bread called nan, and the dish is spiked with roasted cumin and coriander seeds, and soothed with yogurt. It's Western comfort food married to Indian spice.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Quest for Notoriety
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about a musical at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center misstated the work's title. The musical, which runs through Sunday, is titled ''Birth of the Boom,'' not ''Hip 2: Birth of the Boom.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, DONALD
description: JOYCE-Donald. On Tuesday, March 10, 1998, age 45, of cancer. Musician, organist, choir director, teacher. A service will be held on Saturday, March 28, at 1 P.M., at the Church of the Holy Apostles, 9th Ave at 28th St., NYC 10001. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made either to the Organ Fund at the above church or to the Donald Joyce Scholarship Fund at the Copland School of Music, Queens College, Flushing, N.Y. 11367.

title: 5 Are Killed at School; Boys, 11 and 13, Are Held
description: A 13-year-old boy, who reportedly vowed to kill all the girls who had broken up with him, and his 11-year-old cousin opened fire on students outside a middle school here this afternoon, killing four girls and a teacher and wounding 11 other people, the authorities said.

title: Campbell Campaign Wins Top Honors
description: A campaign for Swanson Broth, marketed by the Campbell Soup Company in Camden, N.J., took top honors yesterday at the Advertising Research Foundation's fifth annual David Ogilvy Award ceremony for excellence in research.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Accepting Rejection
description: To the Editor:

title: Americans Are Warned Not to Stay at 2 Hotels Linked to Tripoli : U.S. Plays Anti-Libya Card in Prague
description: PRAGUE  Two of Prague's top hotels have been blacklisted by the U.S. government because they have been purchased by a company with purported links to the government of Libya, and American travelers have been warned that they could face criminal penalties if they stay at them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERBER, MOLLIE
description: GERBER-Mollie. On Mar. 23, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Arlene Greenberg, Linda (Austin) Gelzer and Harold (Dee Dee) Gerber. Cherished grandmother of Andrea, Jeff, Margie, Alan, Ellen, Janlori, Jimmy, Nancy, Michael, Dee Dee, Jane, David, Steven, Jill, Leslie and David. Adored great-grandmother of Eric, Rachel, Philip, Amanda, Maya, Hannah, Kali, Gabrielle, Toby and Adam. Services Wed. 12 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, MARION
description: ROSENBERG-Marion. Beloved wife and mother. Survived by husband, four children and five grandchildren. Services today 12 noon at Parkside Funeral CHapel, Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue

title: Sports of The Times; N.F.L. Scores Touchdown For History
description: A DELIGHTFUL case of swift justice is taking place in sports. How often can you say that these days?

title: G.O.P. Donor Won New York Contract As His Gifts Soared
description: In March 1997, a construction company owned by one of the biggest financial backers of Gov. George E. Pataki and the New York Republican State Committee learned that it was on the verge of losing the competition for a contract to repair the Queens-Midtown Tunnel that was worth as much as $100 million.

title: McKay Gives the Devils Everything They Need
description: Lou Lamoriello spent much of the day on the phone talking to general managers from around the league. But he was not impressed by what they had to offer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDHAGEN, ROSALIE
description: GOLDHAGEN-Rosalie. On March 23rd, 1998, in her 71st year of Lauderhill, FL. Dear mother of Keith, Jerry and Robert Goldhagen. Adored grandmother of Scott, Lindsay and Samantha. Loving sister of Dr. Lewis Berman. Graveside services today, March 25, 1 PM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Donations may be made in Rosalie's name to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLACHTER, HELEN C. (NEE CYMROT)
description: SCHLACHTER-Helen C. (nee Cymrot). Of Royal Palm Beach, formerly of Bethpage, NY. Passed away on March 19th. Beloved wife of the late Fenimore (Monte), loving mother of David and Barbara Schlachter, of Merrick, NY, and Moshe and Marilyn Berger, of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. Devoted grandmother of Aliza, Natan, Oren, Yaakov, Jason, and Rebecca. Survived by cherished sisters, Dorothy Cymrot and Sadye Silver and brother Ben Cymrot. The warm and beautiful memories she created will always be with her loving family and very special friends.

title: The Chef
description: ASPARAGUS comes into season soon, and it's the sort of ingredient that really should be eaten in its prime -- from late April through May. This dish is a good example of how to use all the parts of a vegetable, something that home cooks do not always do.

title: Amending Tobacco's Sweet Deal
description: The tobacco industry is waging a fierce campaign to win Congressional approval for the agreement it reached with 40 state attorneys general last summer. The industry's desperate pitch is a good indication that the settlement is good for the tobacco industry and not good for everyone else. The deal would give the industry what it desires most -- protection from future class-action lawsuits and other legal shields, with relatively little impact on future profits. Senator John McCain, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, now has the tough job of producing better tobacco legislation that can meet public health goals, give the states their expected payoff and persuade the industry to accept voluntary advertising controls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARTORIUS, JOHN MANFRED
description: SARTORIUS-John Manfred. Of Quogue, NY formerly of Tenafly, NJ, died on March 23, 1998 after a long illness in his 78th year. He is survived by his devoted wife Nancy, four sons, John, Jr., Peter, David and Scott, a brother Robert Sartorius. He was predeceased by his first wife, Frances Cauchois Sartorius in 1973. Mr. Sartorius graduated from the Hill School and Princeton University Class of 1942. He served as a 1st Lieutenant in the U.S. Army in Europe during World War II and was awarded the Bronze Star. He retired from Union Carbide in 1980 as a product Manager. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Southampton Care Center or the Southampton Hospital would be appreciated. Funeral Mass will be 10 AM Monday March 30, at the Church of the Immaculate Conception Westhampton Beach, New York

title: A Strange Fan Eludes Police
description: A fan acting strangely and thought to be carrying a gun as he watched from the stands caused so much concern for Yankee officials this afternoon that the police were called to the team's minor league complex, which is about a mile from Legends Field. A police spokesman said tonight that the police could not locate the man, who was last seen walking away from the complex.

title: U.S. Ties Unaffected, Russian Tells Albright
description: Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia said today that his country's foreign policy would remain unchanged despite this week's political turmoil in Moscow.

title: Witness Interrogated In Internet Kidnapping
description: Defense lawyers sought to chip away again yesterday at the accusations against Oliver Jovanovic, the Columbia University graduate student who has been charged with kidnapping a young woman he met on the Internet.

title: TV Notes; Skating Fans' Revenge
description: If you've ever wanted to throttle the Russian figure skating judge -- or any judge who gave a ludicrous score to your favorite skater -- then Friday should be your special night.

title: Domingo in a Once-Censored Verdi Work
description: If there is buried treasure in Verdi's output, it is probably lying there in ''Stiffelio,'' which was the last opera he wrote before ''Rigoletto'' and which did not have much chance before 1993, when the Met staged what was effectively the world premiere. In Verdi's time the work was done only in censored versions, and after 1857 it vanished altogether, much of the music going into ''Aroldo.'' Modern musicologists restored the score, and now we are waiting for modern productions to make it work.

title: Chirac Puts Regional Allies on Spot After Deals With Far Right
description: President Jacques Chirac's dramatic television appeal on Monday night to fellow conservatives to renounce support from the far-right National Front in newly elected regional assemblies increased pressure today on five maverick regional leaders to resign because they had accepted votes from the Front to win their posts.

title: Museum in Los Angeles Losing Director
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles announced yesterday that Richard Koshalek, its director since 1980, would resign. But rather than leave the museum altogether, Mr. Koshalek is to become a consultant for five years beginning in the summer of 1999.

title: Sips; Mellow Infusions to End the Evening Nicely
description: SEEN LIPPERT, the chef at Across the Street on East 91st Street, learned to make herbal-infusion teas from Alice Waters, her boss at Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif. During her 11 years of cooking there, Ms. Lippert said, a pot of ginger and hot red pepper flakes was always steeping on the stove in the kitchen.

title: TELUS IS IN TALKS WITH AT&T OVER POSSIBLE DEAL
description: The Telus Corporation, a Canadian local phone company, said yesterday that it was in talks with the AT&T Corporation about a possible business combination. Analysts said the talks could involve the merger of Telus with the AT&T Canada Long Distance Services Company or its purchase of the majority stake in AT&T Canada owned by three Canadian banks. AT&T owns a one-third voting stake in AT&T Canada. Telus, of Edmonton, Alberta, provides telecommunications services. The portion of AT&T Canada owned by the banks is worth about $704 million. The Royal Bank of Canada, the Bank of Nova Scotia and the Toronto Dominion Bank gained two-thirds voting control of AT&T Canada when they reorganized its debt in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, VIOLA, M.D.
description: BERNARD-Viola, M.D. The staff and leaders of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services and its Child Development Center mourn the passing of Viola Bernard, M.D., a longtime friend and colleague of CDC whose many contributions enriched the Center's work. We extend our deepest sympathy to Dr. Bernard's family. Joseph S. Kaplan, President, JBFCS Alan B. Siskind, PhD, Executive Vice President JBFCS Renee S. Ward, Chairperson, CDC Alice Kross Frankel, M.D., Director, CDC

title: A Soupcon of Ego
description: So it's not Thursday night at 9 o'clock. The soup's the same.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZFELD, SYLVIA
description: HERZFELD-Sylvia. A member of long standing of the Woodmere Club. She will be missed. Board of Governors Mgr, Staff Woodmere Club

title: Hitachi Cuts Jobs in Texas
description: Hitachi Ltd. of Japan said today that it would immediately cut 200 manufacturing jobs at its semiconductor plant here in response to market volatility for memory chips. Hitachi said the reduction would involve a shift in focus to other types of chips. It said it had experienced ''substantial'' losses from a glut of D-RAM, or dynamic random access memory, chips. It expects employment at the Texas plant to be about 500 workers after the revamping takes place.

title: 2d Person Is Named in Arms Case Involving New Jersey Man
description: Offering new details of what the Government says was a plot to illegally supply missile parts to Iran, a Federal grand jury said today that a Northvale, N.J., military equipment purveyor who was arrested this month had a co-conspirator in Singapore.

title: Two Units of Newell Change Agencies
description: Two units of the Newell Company have changed agencies.

title: Outside 'Help' on Issues Raises G.O.P. Fears of Voter Backlash
description: Republicans are bracing for an unexpected consequence of the efforts by outside interest groups to swamp local elections with advertising campaigns: the costly commercials, intended to help Republicans, can backfire -- and may even help Democrats.

title: Wine Talk; Price Chaos on Restaurant Lists
description: IT is time for a significant celebration, an elegant dinner with wine. Not just any wine, either, but Chateau Petrus. You might do it at Lespinasse, in the St. Regis Hotel. They have the rare 1982 Petrus. At $5,000 a bottle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVICK, RONALD E.
description: LEVICK-Ronald E. On March 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Judith H. Loving father of Jill H. Levick and Stephen M. Levick. Cherished grandfather of Sarah and Hannah Levick. Devoted brother of David L. Levick. Service Wednesday, March 25, 1998, 9:45 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: With Revenue From Oil Reduced, Mexico Again Cuts Its Budget
description: Mexico tightened its belt today for the second time in 1998 because of weak oil prices, cutting $1.05 billion from the budget.

title: Life Term in Attacks
description: John J. Royster, who was convicted of murdering one woman and brutally assaulting two others in Manhattan in 1996, was sentenced to life in prison without possibility of parole.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Eating Well column last May 21 reported on the presence of genetically engineered ingredients in some commercial food products, including three Frito-Lay snack foods and two baby formulas, from Similac and Carnation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, PAULINE STELLA
description: LAZAR - Pauline Stella. Ten months old. Died March 19, 1998. Our precious baby. Daughter of Annie-B and Paul Lazar. Sister of Jack Lazar. Contributions to Infant and Child Learning Center, 450 Clarkson Avenue, Box 1203, Brooklyn, New York 11203, earmarked for Pauline Lazar's Baby Library.

title: Judge Storms Off Bench as Brawley Trial Erupts Again
description: The judge in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial stormed off the bench today in the middle of a shouting match with several members of the defense team that was perhaps the most heated episode the jurors have yet seen.

title: Old Sitcoms as Telling Time Capsules
description: The first episode ever of ''The Mary Tyler More Show'' includes one of the touchstone scenes in sitcom history. Mary Richards, while being interviewed for a job at WJM-TV, is told by Lou Grant: ''You know what? You've got spunk.'' And while Mary is looking pleased for two seconds, fans are getting ready to recite the next line along with Mr. Grant: ''I hate spunk.''

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 13 about Maynard A. Amerine, a plant physiologist who helped revive the California wine industry after Prohibition, misidentified the location of his home town, St. Helena, Calif. It is in Napa County, not Sonoma.

title: U.S. and I.M.F. Delay Funds for Indonesia
description: The United States and the International Monetary Fund have agreed to delay billions of dollars in aid to Indonesia until President Suharto begins to act on a revised plan for economic reform being negotiated in Jakarta, according to American and I.M.F. officials.

title: Istanbul Journal; Armenians Among the Turks: A Happier Chapter
description: When the Armenian Patriarch of Istanbul, Karekin II, died this month, his funeral produced a scene that some foreigners found surprising. More than 1,000 Turkish citizens of Armenian background, together with senior diplomats and Government officials, crowded the stately cathedral where a Mass was celebrated in Armenian for the repose of his soul.

title: Move Over, Big Bird: A New Blue Dog's in Town
description: For the latest generation of toddler television watchers, Big Bird and Barney are no longer the biggest celebrities on the playground. They have a scrappy new rival, in the shape of a bright blue computer-generated dog named Blue.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Are Passes O.K. Now?
description: To the Editor:

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Prelude to Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Organizations Oppose Coverage Cuts
description: A day after a committee overhauling the state's auto insurance laws agreed to let insurers offer low-cost policies with sharply reduced medical coverage, a coalition of health organizations criticized the proposal yesterday as unsound.

title: New York Police Hit the Streets In a Crackdown on Speeders
description: Police officers deployed hand-held radar guns on Manhattan's Upper East Side. They lurked in unmarked cruisers parked near the Lincoln Tunnel. They sat astride horses in Chelsea. And they made their presence known on usual raceways like Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn and Queens Boulevard.

title: Under Fire, President Quits
description: Takashi Kitaoka, president of the beleaguered Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, resigned today, capping a year in which the electronics company's longstanding position as an also-ran finally caught up with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONANT, FRANCES TOWNE
description: CONANT-Frances Towne. Of Darien, CT., on March 23, 1998. Wife of Frank E. Conant. Mother of F. Scott Conant. Mother-in-law of Lynn Conant. Grandmother of F. Scott Conant Jr. and Amy Olsen. Great grandmother of Megan McCormick. Memorial services at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, CT., on Saturday, May 9, 1998 at 11:00 A.M. Interment will be at the church. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Post 53Ambulance, P.O. Box 2066, Darien, Connecticut 06820.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Signs and Portents; What Does Parcells's Pursuit of Martin Really Mean?
description: Behind closed doors at the National Football League owners meetings, many in the league are asking: What is Jets Coach Bill Parcells thinking?

title: State Leaders Reach Accord On Amount They Can Spend
description: In a break with tradition that could lessen Gov. George E. Pataki's influence over the state budget, legislative leaders of both parties reached agreement today on roughly how much money is available to spend, and said the state's first-ever budget conference committee would meet Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, SISTER ANTOINE
description: CAMPBELL-Sister Antoine. The entire Marymount School community mourns the death of Sister Antoine Campbell, RSHM, a beloved educator and friend. She served our students, parents and alumnae for more than forty years as a dedicated Teacher of Latin and speech, Headmistress, and Director Alumnae Relations. In addition to her sincere fondness for each student, she will be lovingly remembered for her quiet humor and gentle elegance. Her legacy lives on at Marymount through the alumnae established Sister Antoine Campbell Faculty Endowment Fund and the commencement award given each year to the graduate who exemplifies her values of kindness, generosity and genuine concern for others. She will remain in our hearts and minds as a woman of faith who served her God and shared her gifts with others. A memorial service will be held at Marymount School, 1026 Fifth Avenue, New York, New York, Thursday, April 23 at 6 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, SAMUEL
description: SOLOMON-Samuel. On March 24, 1998. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving father of Stephen and Regina. Cherished grandfather of Todd and Lisa. Dear brother of Lillian Goldberg, Rose Fromer, Jack Solomon, Sarah Dershowitz and the late Ben. Services Wednesday, 12:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRANTZ, MAX
description: KRANTZ-Max. At 93. Cherished husband, for 68 years, of Miriam (nee Osofsky). Adored father of Joan Simon Crespi and Ellen Parker. Father-in-law of Donald Parker, the late Lewis Simon and the late Ralph Crespi. Devoted grandfather to Suzi and Mark Simon, Karen and Brian Buher, Diane and Douglas Simon, Ellen and Daniel Parker, Felicia van Bork and Alan Parker. Proud and loving ''Poppa'' to Andrew, Michael, Jesse, Erica, Emma, Hannah, Eli, Russell and Chandler. Brother of the late Rose Levy and Irving Krantz. Services Thursday, March 26, 1998, 12 Noon at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 312 Coney Island Avenue, Bklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDER, MATTHEW
description: LEDER-Matthew. Age 37. Of Westwood, N.J. On March 23, 1998. Survived by his loving parents Dr. Robert and Barbara and his devoted brothers Richard and Michael. Charitable contributions may be made to General Scholarship Fund of New York University. Services today, 10 A.M., Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rte 4 East, Paramus, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCKMAN, LEO
description: LUCKMAN-Leo. On March 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Leona. Devoted father of Helene Spiewak and Peter Luckman. Dear brother of Blanche Fleischer and Sid Luckman, All-American Football Star, Columbia University and Hall of Fame Chicago Bears. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. President of Tri-Borough Transportation Corporation for 60 years. Graduate of Syracuse University, Phi Beta Kappa, Captain and First Team All-American Soccer 1931 and 32 season. Private services will be held March 25.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about a musical at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center misstated the work's title. The musical, which runs through Sunday, is titled ''Birth of the Boom,'' not ''Hip 2: Birth of the Boom.''

title: City Hall Loses Political King From Queens
description: BY this time next week, the corridors of City Hall will seem a lot less boisterous and maybe a touch less fun. By this time next week, Kevin McCabe will have left the building.

title: A Literary Reunion
description: The $1.4 billion deal for Bertelsmann A.G. to buy Random House will put NAN and GAY TALESE back under the same umbrella. The same corporate umbrella, that is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONTHEIMER, CARL G.
description: SONTHEIMER-Carl G. Age 83, engineer and co-founder with his wife, Shirley of Cuisinarts, Inc., died on March 23 in Greenwich, Connecticut. The cause of death was respiratory failure. He was a native New Yorker and received much of his early education at a lycee in Paris before continuing his studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he obtained the degree of Bachelor of Science in Physics. He founded several research and development companies before retiring in 1969. Bored with retirement, with his wife, Mr. Sontheimer founded Cuisinarts, the company which introduced the food processor to the United States. He held 56 U.S. patents in the microwave and food processor fields, and was a Chevalier of the French Legion of Honor. He is survived by his wife, Shirley, of Greenwich, CT; two sons, Peter and Henry of Gettysburg, PA; two daughters Katherine Rovine of Elkins Park, PA; and Barbara Young of Monroe, CT., and ten grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

title: Food Stuff
description: Chocolate Dinosaurs, Straight Out of an Exhibition

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Defenders of Adultery
description: To the Editor:

title: Indians Are Latest to Disrupt Race Panel
description: The idea was to bring order and civility to often raucous meetings of President Clinton's advisory board on race. A small group of citizens, screened to weed out extremists and eccentrics, were picked to join the board and its chairman, John Hope Franklin, on stage for what was to be a measured discussion of racial stereotyping, while an audience was supposed to listen respectfully.

title: Liberties; Sinners and Spinners on the Equator
description: Jesse Jackson smiled contentedly as he got off Air Force One and sauntered along the crooked red carpet on the tarmac at the airport in Ghana.

title: A Mere Flirtation For Great Champlain
description: After a short-lived brush with greatness, Lake Champlain will remain what it always has been to those who frequent the shores of Lakes Huron, Ontario, Michigan, Erie and Superior: a relatively small body of water that straddles Vermont and New York. Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, included Lake Champlain among the Great Lakes to try to direct Federal money from a national sea-grant program to his home state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ADELE GLADSTONE
description: COHEN-Adele Gladstone. On March 23, 1998. Graduate Brooklyn College of Pharmacy 1937. Chief Pharmacist at Kew Gardens Hospital. First woman member of the NYS Pharmaceutical Society. Secretary of the College Alumni Association and a Coordinator of the Continuing Education Program. Driving force of the Richmond Hill Leisure Club until her illness in 1996. Despite her being a polio survivor of the 1917 polio epidemic, she strived to accomplish and excel in any endeavor and never refused to assist in any task. After the death of her husband, Simon in 1989, she became Secretary as well as Events Coordinator for the Leisure Club. Her enjoyment of people was only equaled by her love of animals and had four Pekingese over the years which became her trademark. She is survived by her daughter, Glenna G. Levine and her beloved sister, Ruth G. Stateman. It is requested that donations be made to the American Lung Association.

title: Nichols Apologizes for His Role in Bombing
description: Terry L. Nichols, who was convicted of conspiracy in the Oklahoma City bombing, has sent a letter of apology to the judge who will sentence him in the 1995 bombing that killed 168 people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, ELEANOR GREENBURG
description: GOULD-Eleanor Greenburg. On March 23, 1998, age 84. She is survived by her husband of 61 years, Milton S. Gould, by her children Patricia Booth, Judson and Jonathan, by her grandchildren Eliza, Alexander, Olivia, Eleanor, and Oliver, and by her brother Robert D. Greenburg. Her life was a blessing upon her family and upon her myriad friends of all ages. Family will be receiving Wednesday from 1 P.M. with service to follow at 2 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Remaindered
description: In a sense, there is no news in the news announced Monday that Bertelsmann A.G. will purchase Random House, the pre-eminent American publishing company. The pending acquisition is business as usual in the publishing world, except, perhaps, for the fact that Bertelsmann A.G. is a German media conglomerate.

title: Middlebury Makes It Four Straight Titles
description: Without consulting Coach Bill Beaney, it is difficult to comprehend how a small college like Middlebury in Vermont can win an unprecedented four straight national championships in a sport as money-minded and competitive as hockey. The entrance requirements are stiff - average Scholastic Achievement Tests of 1,330 - and the annual cost of about $30,000 occasionally eased by a grant based on family need. There are no athletic scholarships.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; A Breach of Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about problems faced by the most elderly at retirement communities misidentifed a couple who moved 25 years ago to the Kings Point community in Delray Beach, Fla. They were Honey and Mike Shapiro, not Herman and Annette Adelson.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Aid to Indonesia Delayed, But U.S. Sends In Food

title: Accounts
description: * Ground Zero, Santa Monica, Calif., was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at more than $10 million. One was Activision Inc., Santa Monica, the interactive entertainment software company, previously handled by Rubin Postaer & Associates, Santa Monica.
