The other was the Genesee Brewing Company, Rochester, previously handled by Pedone & Partners, New York.

title: James Ellroy Prowls His Inner L.A.
description: For all its sinuendo, the real city of Los Angeles can't beat the landscape of James Ellroy's writing for dark, seamy secrets and devious passions. It's a landscape of which Mr. Ellroy, the author of ''L.A. Confidential'' and assorted other cult classics like ''The Black Dahlia,'' now provides a guided tour. Camera-ready and terrifically articulate about his work, he cruises through the documentary ''James Ellroy: Demon Dog of American Crime Fiction'' in a Cadillac convertible, discussing the real-life underpinnings of his stories and the brutal events that shaped his world view.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIERSTEAD, LAPID, LOIS
description: KIERSTEAD - LAPID - Lois. On Monday, March 23, 1998 of Chatham, N.J. formerly of Boston, MA and N.Y.C., N.Y. Beloved wife of Remon Lapid. Devoted mother of Jessica Lapid. Cherished daughter of William and Ruth Kierstead. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, N.J. on Wednesday, March 25, 1998, at 1 P.M. Interment B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, PAUL
description: CAMPBELL-Paul. In Trappe, Maryland, March 11, 1998, formerly of Greenwich, Ct. Retired investment banker and past Commodore of the Storm Trysail Club and past Commodore of Indian Harbor Yacht Club; 52 year member of the New York Yacht Club; U.S. Navy Veteran of WWII. Beloved husband of Julia Willets, father of Paul Campbell, Jr. of Boston and Melanie Sharp Bolster of Ireland and Gordie Villalon of St. James City, Fla. 5 grandchildren. Service of Remembrance Friday, March 27th at 2 P.M., in Christ Episcopal Church, Greenwich, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JEAN
description: GOLDMAN-Jean. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved mother of Beverly Schachar, YU Guardian with her husband, Henry Schachar, member of the Board of Directors of YU's Sy Syms School of Business and of the Board of Trustees of our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Study Finds No Big Rise in School Crime
description: Just last week, in response to President Clinton's request for a report on school safety, the National Center for Education Statistics released its first survey on crime in the public schools, finding that more than half the schools had experienced some crime during the 1996-97 school year, but only 1 in 10 had a serious violent crime like rape, robbery, or fights with a weapon.

title: Hingis Escapes One Williams, and Will Face the Other
description: She was on the ropes; she was off the ropes. Never convinced that the upper hand belongs to anyone but herself, Martina Hingis refused to be knocked down and out by the two match points her adversary, 16-year-old Serena Williams, intended to clobber her with in their tense, two-hour quarterfinal this afternoon at the Lipton Championships.

title: Yankees' Erdos Is Lucky to Be Alive
description: Moments after Brian Cashman traded Andy Fox for pitchers Todd Erdos and Marty Janzen earlier this month, he stopped a reporter. You ought to know about Erdos and his medical history, said Cashman, the Yankees' general manager, in the way someone might recommend a good suspense movie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTOG, LOTTE
description: HARTOG-Lotte. On March 23, 1998 at home. Beloved wife of Joseph, mother of Thomas J. Smith and grandmother of Damon Eric Smith and Colin Thomas Smith. Also leaving Elzelien Hartog, Anne Marie Hartog, Fay Le vin and John Hartog. Services will be private.

title: Test Kitchen; The Tandoor, Fully Domesticated
description: FOODS cooked in a tandoor oven can be seductively good -- irresistible flatbreads like nan and poori, for example, or succulent charred meats like chicken tikka. But you usually have to go to an Indian restaurant to find them. The intense heat chars the outside and cooks so quickly that food remains juicy: you can't get these results with a conventional oven or even a backyard grill.

title: Familiar Pains on Oscar Night
description: The reunion of former acting award recipients at the Academy Awards show on Monday was fascinating, particularly for people who watch the ceremonies to see how veteran movie stars are aging, and which of the younger ones are showing signs of eating disorders. But the parade of past winners also demonstrated how many less-than-stellar performers in forgettable films have grabbed the prize over the years. When Jack Nicholson won his third Oscar for ''As Good as It Gets,'' some commentators noted that only three other performers had been honored that often. Most of them did not mention that one was Walter Brennan.

title: A Goodbye Look: Rangers Trade 5 Players at Deadline
description: The Rangers began their spring cleaning at yesterday's National Hockey League trade deadline, shedding three players from their major league roster and two minor leaguers who had played with them earlier in the season. Despite his statement to the contrary, the moves indicated that Neil Smith, the Rangers' president and general manager, is losing faith in the team's ability to make the eighth and final playoff berth in the Eastern Conference this season and has begun to rebuild.

title: Piece of Penn Station's Past Is Found in Salvage
description: Maybe it was the sunflower behind her ear. Or the silky folds of her robe. Or the gentle waves in her hair.

title: J. Walter Thompson Shuffles Executives
description: The J. Walter Thompson Worldwide unit of WPP Group shuffled three top executives in North America yesterday.

title: Microsoft Expects to Beat Earnings Targets
description: With its sales continuing to power ahead, the Microsoft Corporation announced late yesterday that its profits in the current quarter would exceed Wall Street's forecast by about 9 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUSON, SYDNEY
description: GRUSON-Sydney. A memorial gathering to celebrate the life of Sydney Gruson, a former executive of The New York Times Company, who died on March 8, will be held at 11 A.M., March 26 in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Those attending are asked to use the museum's main entrance at 82nd Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Finding the Meaning Under the Beauty
description: When a singer has a voice as rich, even and warmly beautiful as the German baritone Matthias Goerne's, it must be hard not to simply show it off, to make each song a demonstration of velvety legato phrasing and creamy tone.

title: TV Notes; An Oscar Night To Remember
description: Riding the record number of awards for the most popular movie of this (or many another) year, ABC got a titanic performance out of the Academy Awards on Monday night, drawing the biggest audience ever for the annual special.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, LEON H.
description: COHEN-Leon H. Beloved husband of Patricia and devoted father of Donald, loving grandfather of Erin. Services today, 1 P.M., Gutterman's Chapel, Woodbury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIAN, MARY DIANE
description: HARRIAN-Mary Diane. Age 70. Of New York, NY. Died of cancer March 23, 1998. Beloved daughter of Dr. Yervant Harrian and Dr. Pauline Goodian. Ms. Harrian retired in 1997 as a librarian at the New York Public Library. She was a graduate of Columbia University and New York University. She was a member of the Armenian General Benevolent Union and a parishioner of St. Cross Armenian Apostolic Church, Washington Hts, NY. Ms. Harrian and her parents were devoted to the promotion of Armenian culture, history and rights. Funeral service will be held 10 A.M., on Friday, March 27, at Flynn Memorial Funeral Home, 325 South Broadway, Yonkers, New York, with interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: A New Model for Africa: Good Leaders Above All
description: When President Clinton walks into a conference with East African leaders here on Wednesday afternoon, he will do what American Presidents usually do in the third world. He will preach the virtues of free markets, democracy and civil liberties.

title: Malaysia Cuts Forecast For Growth This Year
description: The economy of Malaysia will probably expand only 2 to 3 percent this year, the country's Finance Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, said yesterday.

title: As Life Unfolds at a Housing Project
description: ''Public Housing'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 4, 1997. The film opens today at the Walter Reade Theater, at Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, SEYMOUR L.
description: KATZ-Seymour L. Loving and beloved husband of Rose for 58 years. Caring and devoted father of Steven and his wife Susan, and Herbert and his wife Linda. Cherished and loving grandfather of Naomi and Aviva, and Jonathan, David and Marlee. Dear brother of Esther and Sylvia. He was gentle and charismatic. A pioneer in the movement to free Soviet Jews. A loyal son of his people.

title: Antonio Ribeiro, 69; Portuguese Cardinal Backed Democracy
description: Antonio Cardinal Ribeiro of Lisbon, who helped maneuver the Roman Catholic Church into a pro-democracy stance after Portugal's right-wing dictatorship was overthrown in 1974, died today at Santo Antonio Hospital in suburban Lisbon. He was 69.

title: Bell Is Challenged On Access to Markets
description: A coalition of long distance telephone companies, including MCI, Sprint and AT&T, accused Bell Atlantic yesterday of hindering their efforts to compete in the local calling market by limiting access to existing phone networks. Bell Atlantic still controls 99.69 percent of the state's local calling market, even though the market was deregulated in 1996, said Al Smith, a vice president of AT&T.

title: Finance Chief In the Senate Unveils Bill Curbing I.R.S.
description: The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee unveiled his long-awaited bill today to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service, proposing to go further than a version passed by the House last year in reining in the agency's powers and granting oversight authority to an independent board.

title: What We Can Do for Africa
description: During his tour of Africa, President Clinton should ask to visit a United States processing center for refugees. He'd have to make a detour, though. On a continent with 3.5 million refugees, the United States has only one such site, in Nairobi, Kenya. This outpost, which handles 5,000 or so people a year, is the sole commitment the world's only superpower has made to the problem of African refugees.

title: To Go; Southern Cooking, but Lighter
description: IN an old Redd Foxx routine, the comedian ridiculed those healthy eaters who'd given up what he considered the pleasures of life: fried chicken, ribs, neck bones and gravy, pigs' feet. ''You're gonna look awfully silly laying up in the hospital dying of nothing,'' he concluded.

title: Seikaly Putting In Extra Time
description: The rest of his teammates had already left the court, heading for the locker room to partake of a birthday cake for David Vaughn and rush to nearby Teterboro Airport. But Rony Seikaly remained behind, working about a half-hour on the court and then retreating to the corner of the Nets' practice facility where he began a weight-lifting regimen with Rich Dalatri, the Nets' strength and conditioning coach.

title: Rebels Take On Managed Care
description: Some doctors in California and New York are banding together in associations of ''independent'' doctors to challenge the dominance of managed care. They are rebelling because of what they see as harmful interference in the way they practice medicine and because they resent the lower fees paid by managed care companies.

title: Montana Writers' Sessions Teach Language of the Land
description: Like the old Federal Writers' Project of the Great Depression, which provided jobs for unemployed authors, Gallatin Writers Inc. of Bozeman, Mont., puts writers in harness to help uplift a depressed area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, K.B.
description: WEISSMAN-K.B. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound regret at the loss of K.B. Weissman of Palm Beach, FL. A life trustee of the ATS Board of Regents and an alternate member of the International Board of Governors of the Technion, he was fervent in his support of excellence in scientific education and research. Mr. Weissman and his wife, Edna, became Technion Guardians, having reached the highest level of commitment and vision for the ATS and the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology. They generously contributed to many vital Technion programs including student dormitories, the Greater Palm Beach Industrial Robotics Center, scholarships and faculty recruitment funds, and gave freely of time and energy in the leadership of the Palm Beach Chapter. In recognition of his efforts on behalf of the university, K.B. was awarded an honorary fellowship from the Technion in 1997, and had the K.B. Weissman Boulevard named on the Technion campus. K.B. had a keen mind and great wisdom, and served as mentor, advisor and strategist in our organization. We feel Mr. Weissman's loss with profound sorrow and extend our heartfelt condolences to Edna and the entire Weissman family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Irving A. Shepard President Ben Z. Sosewitz Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom Executive Vice President Sam B. Topf, Chairman Southern Region Richard P. Zaretsky, President Palm Beach Chapter Albert G. Effrat, Director Southern Region Ileane Rayman-Kaufman, Assistant Director Palm Beach Chapter

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, LEONARD W.
description: KATZ-Leonard W. Born July 24, 1913, died March 24, 1998. Beloved husband of Mildred Hill Katz. Beloved father of John W. Katz of D.C., Laura L. Katz of Baltimore. Stepfather of Tony Hill of Berkeley, CA., and Polly Hill Landess of New York. Also survived by one grand-daughter and five grandsons. In mourning at home.

title: DONALDSON, LUFKIN UNIT TO PAY $437 MILLION FOR INSILCO
description: The Insilco Corporation agreed to be acquired by a buyout fund run by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., a unit of the Equitable Companies, for about $437 million including assumed debt, the companies said yesterday. Insilco, based in Columbus, Ohio, makes computer connectors and industrial components and had 1997 revenue of $530 million. Under the deal, DLJ Merchant Banking Partners II will acquire about 90 percent of Insilco's common shares. Insilco shareholders will receive about $44.50 a share, consisting of $42.98 in cash and 0.03419 share of the surviving entity. Insilco shares rose 37.50 cents, to $43.3750. Shares of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette jumped $2, to $87.625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IANNOLI, VINCENT
description: IANNOLI-Vincent. Age 73. Mar. 17, 1998 in Conroe, TX. after a long illness. A resident of New York City for many years, he was interred March 21 in a family plot in Saint Ann Cemetery, Cranston, R.I. following a Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Providence. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated Saturday, April 18, 11 A.M., at The Church of Saint John the Evangelist, 348 East 55 Street, New York City.

title: Hidden Evidence Claimed in King Slaying
description: The lawyer for James Earl Ray maintained today that a retired F.B.I. agent concealed evidence he collected in the initial search of Mr. Ray's car 30 years ago, and that the long-hidden papers provide verification of Mr. Ray's assertion that he was set up to take the blame for the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Nearsighted Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Sets Limit On the Shield Of Bankruptcy
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal bankruptcy law, which generally offers people a fresh start by erasing their debts, does not excuse the obligation to pay damage judgments stemming from acts of fraud.

title: Hapless Warriors No Match For Knicks
description: This was not a show of unfurled might by the Knicks, nor an example of how their urgent desire to land a playoff spot had driven them to finally win their first game on the road in five attempts.

title: 2 Most Serious Charges Are Dropped in Lighting of Firecrackers at City Hall
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office dropped the two most serious charges against a man who lighted a string of firecrackers on the steps of City Hall last month and has agreed to drop the remaining three charges if he stays out of trouble for the next six months.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Gossip and Pieties
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic's Notebook; A Metaphysical Scamp on Broadway, Opening April 1
description: During rehearsals of his first play, ''The Bald Soprano,'' in Paris in 1950, Eugene Ionesco was overcome by seeing actors play characters who had emerged from his imagination. As he later wrote, ''To incarnate phantasms, to give them life, is a prodigious, irreplaceable adventure.''

title: AMERITECH PLANS TO ELIMINATE $3 BILLION IN EXPENSES
description: The chairman and chief executive of the Ameritech Corporation, Richard C. Notebaert, said yesterday that his telecommunications company would eliminate $3 billion in expenses through 2002 in a bid to sustain at least 10 percent annual earnings growth. Mr. Notebaert, speaking in New York at a meeting with securities analysts, said Ameritech also expected to increase annual revenue in the ''high single digits.'' Mr. Notebaert said he was ''not uncomfortable'' with analysts' earnings estimates for 1998; the company is expected to earn $2.34 a share, according to I.B.E.S. International.

title: Life Sentence and No Parole In a Murder and 2 Beatings
description: John Royster, who was convicted this month of murdering one woman and brutally assaulting two others in 1996, was sentenced yesterday to life in prison without possibility of parole by a judge who called him ''an incurably violent and dangerous monster.''

title: HOCKEY; Some Faces Change, but Result Is the Same for Islanders
description: For all the changes the Islanders made to their roster over the last two days, they did little to change their fortunes in the standing.

title: Through Sad Haze, A Glimpse of Beauty; Homeless Man's Past Emerges: A Black Pioneer in the Ballet
description: He said that his name was Arthur Bell and that he had once been a dancer. Now he could hardly stand.

title: SPX Reports Holder Support On Echlin Bid
description: The SPX Corporation, the Michigan-based automobile part and tool maker engaged in a testy $3 billion takeover battle for Echlin Inc., said yesterday that it had enough support from Echlin shareholders to request a special meeting to vote on whether to oust Echlin's board of directors.

title: Albert Wolff, Last of Ness's Men, Dies at 95
description: Albert Wolff, believed to have been the last survivor of the Untouchables, the band of reputedly incorruptible Federal agents under Eliot Ness who waged war against Al Capone in Prohibition-era Chicago, died on Saturday at the Cedar Village nursing home in Mason, Ohio. He was 95.

title: Tape Shows Crew's Confusion in Guam Crash
description: As Korean Airlines Flight 801 approached Guam last Aug. 6, the captain told his crew that a radio beacon that would have led them to the right spot on the ground was not working.

title: Crude Oil Gives Up Some of Monday's Big Gain
description: Crude oil fell almost 4 percent yesterday on doubts that oil exporters would honor an agreement to cut production that had sent prices soaring the day before, in their biggest rise in seven years.

title: In Legal Limbo, Central Americans Are Rallying for Residency
description: Sometime this afternoon, Guillermo Turcios, 38, plans to stand with hundreds of Guatemalan and Salvadoran immigrants in front of the Capitol building in Washington to demand that he and others like him, refugees from Central American wars in the 1980's, be granted a legal status in the United States.

title: In Speech on Mideast, Mayor Takes Shot at White House
description: In his second trip here in less than two weeks, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani waded into the volatile waters of Middle East politics today, criticizing the Clinton Administration's handling of the stalled peace process between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Niagara Mohawk is doing well on Wall St., but it now must contend with a mortifying state report.
description: TALK about adding insult to injury. In January, just as the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation was struggling to restore power to the last of 300,000 customers in upstate New York after a brutal ice storm, the state's Public Service Commission blasted the company's management for failing to respond adequately to widespread ethical problems and repeated failures of internal controls, some continuing for more than a decade.

title: BOEING WILL BE 5 PLANES SHORT OF FIRST-QUARTER GOAL
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it would miss its delivery goals for the first quarter by five planes, as production bottlenecks on its 737 assembly line persist. A total of 110 aircraft will be delivered in the first quarter, Boeing said in its monthly production update. Last month, the Seattle-based company said it would deliver 115 planes in the quarter. The company, the world's largest aircraft maker, reassured investors last month that the assembly-line problems were being solved. The update shows that Boeing may have difficulty in meeting its goal to make 42 jetliners a month by the second quarter, one short of its original goal of 43. About 53 of the updated 737 jets are being delayed because of modifications to meet regulatory requirements.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: At Harvard, a Politically Emblematic Debate on Grapes
description: It has become a litmus test of campus politics at Harvard University: did you support ending the grape boycott?

title: Williams Spends a Day In the Florida Sunshine
description: Ted Williams took his hands off the walker and danced a little jig.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Presidential Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Patients' Lives on the Line In Battle Over Transplants
description: For two years and one month, Mindy Ervin has waited in uneasy limbo for a new liver. Too well to be ushered to the top of the transplant list, yet so sick that she has already planned her own funeral, she spends her days in bed, hoping the telephone will ring with news of an available organ.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I've been in this for a long time. This is the worst thing I had ever seen.''

title: Business Travel; T.W.A. overhauls its frequent-flier program in a move aimed at luring more corporate passengers.
description: IN a major overhaul of its frequent-flier program, Trans World Airlines is lowering its mileage requirement to 15,000 miles for a free ticket for travel between most cities no more than 750 miles apart -- between New York and Boston, for example, or between Chicago and St. Louis or Kansas City, Mo., and St. Louis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOCKSTADER, FREDERICK J.
description: DOCKSTADER-Frederick J. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Huntington Free Library and Reading Room mourn the death of friend and colleague, Frederick J. Dockstader. A trustee of the library for almost 30 years, we will remember him for his unwavering support of the library, his significant contribution to Native American studies, and his sunny disposition. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Alice.

title: Allied Textile Ends Talks and Shares Fall
description: The shares of the Allied Textile Companies fell as much as 15 percent yesterday after the company said it had ended takeover talks in the absence of a formal offer. Shares in the company, a British yarn, fabrics and carpet maker, fell 25 pence, to 156.5. The company said it was continuing a review of its business ''for the enhancement of shareholder value.'' It will make a further announcement ''in due course.''

title: The Imagined Life of a Film Pioneer
description: NOSFERATU

title: I2 TECHNOLOGIES TO ACQUIRE ONTARIO SOFTWARE COMPANY
description: I2 Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Intertrans Logistics Solutions for $97 million in stock. Intertrans, based in Markham, Ontario, provides logistics and supply chain management software. I2 Technologies, based in Irving, Tex., provides planning and other business software. It had revenue of $200.7 million in 1997. I2 Technologies said it would exchange 1.66 million of its shares for all of the shares of Intertrans Logistics. Shares of I2 rose $2.59375, to $61.28125.

title: $25 and Under; A French Bistro With an Italian Personality
description: JEAN COCTEAU once described the French as Italians in a bad mood. If he had eaten at Velli, Jean-Claude Iacovelli's new place on West Houston Street, he might have described the restaurant as a Frenchman in a good mood.

title: The Pop Life; The Best Disks You Can't Buy
description: With obscure albums of prophecies by the mid-century psychic Griswell and songs by Tina Louise of ''Gilligan's Island'' fame new on the CD market, it would seem as though record labels have scraped their vaults dry. But there are a lot of important albums that have yet to be reissued on CD.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOGUT, MINNIE (MICKEY)
description: KOGUT-Minnie (Mickey). March 23, 1998. Beloved and missed by all; especially by her husband Alvin and sons Alexander and Richard. Adored by daughters-in-law Jackie and Nicole and her granddaughters Deborah and Danielle.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Selective Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Random House Sale Shakes Up Literary World
description: The announcement hit the luncheon of the Women's Media Group Monday like a shelf of tumbling books: Random House would be purchased by the German media conglomerate, Bertelsmann A.G..

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Amorphous Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a sports picture from Reuters on March 13 misidentified a University of Richmond player celebrating victory in the first round of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament. The player, at the left, was Jarod Stevenson, not Nick Patrick.

title: The Minimalist; Meuniere and Its Many Variations
description: TRADITIONALLY, the term ''meuniere'' has a specific meaning, usually referring to fillets of sole that are floured and sauteed quickly, then finished with lemon juice, parsley and browned butter.

title: As the Panthers Lose Money, Their Fans Enrich Huizenga
description: H. Wayne Huizenga cannot make money in the sports business. Or so he has claimed.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Thomas vs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: Railroad Banning Traffic
description: The Union Pacific Railroad said today that it would bar most freight traffic to Mexico in an attempt to ease a yearlong backlog that has clogged its already overburdened rail system.

title: Jakarta Dissident Questions U.S. Military Aid
description: Indonesia's best-known opposition leader has challenged President Clinton to explain why United States special-operations soldiers are training members of the Indonesian military.

title: Why Washington and the World Largely Failed to Act to Head Off the Blood Bath
description: Nearly four years ago, Rwanda and its neighbors dissolved into genocidal violence, and today President Clinton is expected to say the world should have responded sooner to head off the killings.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Environment of Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: Prices of Treasuries Little Changed After Day of Fluctuation
description: After fluctuating through the day yesterday, prices of long-term Treasury securities ended slightly higher, helped by healthy investor interest in a monthly Treasury auction, a modest retreat in oil prices and some weakness in weekly retail sales data.

title: Temptation; Summer's Sweet Taste Captured for March In Some Bright Small Tomatoes
description: PRODUCE snobs alert: there is a tomato on the market, here in March, that actually tastes like a tomato. And, ahem, more painful news: it comes in a plastic net sack.

title: New Searle Drug Goes to Burnett
description: The G. D. Searle pharmaceutical business unit of the Monsanto Corporation has named the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago to handle a new worldwide assignment, the introduction of Celebra, an arthritis therapy now under clinical study. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $30 million or more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAL, WILLIAM F.
description: DIAL-William F. 72. Of Westbury, New York, on March 21, at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn after a brief illness. Husband of 47 years of Carolyn Thomasson Dial, father of Stephen F. Dial, Sarah D. Primrose, Paul L. Dial, William G. Dial and Nora C. Dial, grandfather of Michael J. Dial, Brigid R. Dial and Landon G. Primrose, father-in-law of John A. Primrose and Greta L. Bucher, brother of Ruby Johnson, Matilda Stein and Marion Longbotham. Services will be held on Thursday, March 26, from 4 to 6 PM at William M. Donohue, 293 Castle Ave, Westbury. Interment will take place Saturday, March 28, 3 P.M., at Pleasant View Memory Gardens, Kearneysville, W.V.

title: Daihatsu to End Thai Operations
description: The Daihatsu Motor Company has stopped production in Thailand and will close its sales outlets there at the end of this month, becoming the first Japanese auto maker to pull out of the economically troubled Southeast Asian country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, HERBERT L.
description: MENDELSON-Herbert L. On March 23, 1998 of streptococcus A infection. Treasured husband of Joan, cherished father of Susan and Barry Stein, Billy and Carole and Clifford and Tammy, proud grandfather of Benjamin and Noa, Sophie and Michael and Amanda and Annie, devoted son of Ralph (and Edna), adored brother of Myra Waldman and brother-inlaw of Arthur and Susan Resnick, caring uncle of Steven and Bobby (and Amy) Scher and Ben Resnick, and beloved cousin of Marilyn Marber. Herb was a senior partner of Herrick, Feinstein LLP where he practiced law for fortythree years. Herb assisted many organizations with his time, abilities and resources. He served as a member of the board of directors of ALYN Hospital for Handicapped Children in Israel, as Chairman of the Greater New York Campaign Cabinet of UJA/Federation, as Chairman of the North Shore Long Island UJA/Federation Campaign Cabinet, and as Head of the UJA Long Island Country Club Mission Program. Herb was also a board member of The Daniel Heumann Fund for Spinal Cord Research, was Chairman of the Glen Oaks Country Club Charity Committee and a board member of the Sigma Alpha Mu Fraternity. At Syracuse University, Herb was selected as the MVP of its lacrosse team and as All American goalie in soccer. The funeral service will be on Wednesday, March 25, 1998, 10:00 AM at Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in Herb's memory may be made to ALYN Hospital for Handicapped Children in Israel, 19 West 44th Street, New York, NY 10036.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHARNEY, DR. ELLIOT
description: CHARNEY-Dr. Elliot. March 25, 1997. We miss you and love you. Sy and Joan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, ELI
description: GINSBURG-Eli. Survived by his wife, Suzan, daughters Ellen, Lynn and Amy and sisters Pat Rudnick and Shirley Engel. Worked fifty years in the magazine publishing industry holding various circulation and marketing positions. Past President of READ and Board Member of the 25 year Club. Family man, friend and baseball ''maven.'' Services will be on March 25, 1998 Temple B'Nai Shalom, 1:30 P.M., East Brunswick, NJ. Rest In Peace.

title: TCI Plans Linkups to Offer Financial Services Via Cable
description: Tele-Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would link up with the BankAmerica Corporation and Intuit Inc. to let customers invest, shop for mortgages or pay bills through their cable television hookups.

title: Japan's Vehicle Output Fails to Rise Again
description: Japan's vehicle production failed to rise in February for the fifth consecutive month as plunging sales at home and in the rest of Asia offset rising exports to the United States and Europe, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said yesterday. The nation's vehicle output was unchanged in February from the same month in 1997 at 933,192 units.

title: Clinton's Lawyers Seek Broader Ruling on Privilege
description: President Clinton's lawyers appeared before a Federal judge behind closed doors today to argue for a broad definition of executive privilege that would shield internal White House discussions on how to respond to sex-and-perjury accusations involving a former intern, Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Minnesota Will Meet Penn State for the Title
description: All season long, Fresno State has been plagued by substance-abuse problems and physical assaults that have left it with only seven scholarship players. That thin roster and an undisciplined offense made a difference last night as Minnesota beat Fresno State by 91-89 in overtime in the semifinals of the 61st annual National Invitation Tournament.

title: Hampton Goes In Search of Job
description: The Giants have given Rodney Hampton, the team's career-leading rusher, permission to seek employment with another team.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Credibility Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: In Mount Vernon, Black Woman Is Rejected for Sake of Diversity
description: Three years ago, Karen Watts-Cave lost a bid for the City Council here by just 105 votes. So, when she learned that the woman who had defeated her was leaving, Ms. Watts-Cave quickly sent a note to her party chairman asking to replace her.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the political strategy of the religious right referred incorrectly to Rich DeVos, co-founder of the Amway Corporation, who helped pay for the Family Research Council's headquarters in Washington. He is not ''the late''; he is 72 and lives in Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNIG, ESTHER
description: HORNIG-Esther. Died at 93, March 21. Devoted wife of the late Harry. Beloved mother of Audrey Denburg, Judy and Jerry Loving grandmother of Mady, Joan and George, Ruth and Robert, Amy and Dean, Mathew and Robin. Proud great-grandmother of Max, Leo, Emily, Benjamin, Justin, Natalie, Russell, Maxwell, Julia, Jessica. Cherished sister of Julius, Lynn and Sadie Yanuck, Lillian and Joseph Kushner. Graveside service at Mount Lebanon, March 25 at 10:30 A.M.

title: Company Owner Guilty Of Abandoning Waste
description: A Bloomfield man convicted of dumping cyanide from his electroplating company into the Passaic Valley sewage system in 1991 pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of abandoning 5,000 gallons of toxic wastewater at the company's defunct plant in Newark, the State Attorney General, Peter G. Verniero, announced.

title: REGIONS FINANCIAL PLANS TO ACQUIRE VILLAGE BANKSHARES
description: The Regions Financial Corporation signed a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire Village Bankshares Inc. of Tampa, Fla., for $55 million in stock. Regions said it would issue 1.34 common shares for each share of Village Bankshares. Village Bankshares holds Village Bank of Florida, which operates nine offices and had total assets of $199 million at Dec. 31. Regions Financial said it had also signed a definitive agreement to acquire Etowah Bank of Canton, Ga. In January, Regions, based in Birmingham, Ala., agreed to exchange 3.3127 common shares for each Etowah Bank common share in a transaction valued at $117 million. Under the definitive agreement, Regions said it would issue 3.20 shares for each Etowah share.

title: Who Won and for What
description: These are the winners of the 70th annual Academy Awards, presented on Monday night at the Shrine Auditorium by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

title: Are Feminists Right to Stand by Clinton?; Not 'Consenting'
description: To the Editor:

title: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE PAID CHAIRMAN $3.85 MILLION IN 1997
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company paid its chairman and chief executive, Reuben Mark, $3.85 million last year, up 44 percent from 1996, and awarded him 2.6 million stock options after a directors' compensation committee study found his pay ranked below that of comparable executives. Mr. Mark, 59, received $1.12 million in salary, a $2.72 million bonus and $3.38 million in restricted stock, as well as 2.6 million options with strike prices ranging from $68.6125 to $106.0375, or 10 percent to 70 percent over the price of the stock when the options were granted. They are the only stock options he will receive until 2003, the New York-based company said. It makes Colgate toothpaste and Hill's Science Diet pet foods. Mr. Mark had a gain of $18.2 million last year from exercising older options and still holds $148.6 million in other options.

title: New Proposal By Netanyahu For West Bank
description: After months of stalemate and under increasing pressure from the Clinton Administration, the Prime Minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, has sent President Clinton a compromise offer on an Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank.

title: INSIDE
description: Blue Dog Nips Purple Dino

title: Calendar
description: Whimsy With Sound

title: Eating Well; U.S. Proposal on Organic Food Gets a Grass-Roots Review
description: THE organic food industry has organized an impressive grass-roots campaign -- employing Web sites, public meetings, enclosures in telephone bills and even information printed on the backs of milk cartons -- that has already convinced the Agriculture Department that substantial changes must be made in the proposed Federal regulations for organically grown food.

title: A Medical Resistance Movement; As Independence Fades, Doctors Fight Care Plans
description: When Barry G. Chaiken started out as an ophthalmologist in Manhattan 15 years ago, he saw patients in managed care plans, though he was not crazy about the idea. He did not last long. After he had to ask three people to authorize a laser procedure for a patient, he quit. He could not abide the idea of his medical judgment being questioned.

title: Roche Profit Up 9.7% Before Charge in 2d Half
description: Roche Holding A.G., the world's sixth-biggest drug maker, indicated yesterday that its profit before a charge rose 9.7 percent in the second half of 1997. Roche's second-half income before a charge of 6.3 billion Swiss francs ($4.3 billion), rose to 1.849 billion francs, from 1.686 billion francs a year earlier. For the full year, Roche posted a loss of 2.03 billion francs, the biggest in its history.

title: Serbs Renew Crackdown on Albanian Villages in Kosovo
description: The Serbian police, ignoring calls by Washington to end a crackdown against armed Albanian separatists in Kosovo province that has left more than 80 dead, renewed counterinsurgency action today against villages near the Albanian border.

title: Jones to Join CBS
description: Brent Jones, the former San Francisco 49ers tight end, yesterday was the first analyst hired by CBS Sports for the network's revived ''N.F.L. Today'' pre-game studio show. He will join the host, Jim Nantz, and two other analysts, who will be named within the next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSHAN, SARAH DAVIS
description: BUSHAN-Sarah Davis. Montefiore Medical Center mourns the passing of Sarah Davis, a devoted volunteer and highly respected member of the Auxiliary for more than four decades. She will be missed by all who knew her and by those she served through her dedicated efforts on behalf of the Information and Referral Service. Our condolences are extended to her beloved son, Hank Davis. Spencer Foreman, M.D., Pres. Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Audit Finds Child Agency Usually Does A Good Job
description: Despite criticism that it has repeatedly failed to protect children in its care, New York City's child welfare agency properly investigates a vast majority of complaints of abuse and neglect of foster children, an audit released yesterday by the City Comptroller's office said.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK RETREATS. The mark fell on data from Germany that showed falling import prices and lower inflation, diminishing the possibility of higher interest rates. In New York the dollar cost 1.8278 marks, up from 1.8256.

title: The Presidency and the World
description: For Americans accustomed to the idea of a diminished Presidency, the sight of Bill Clinton addressing a cheering crowd of half a million people in Ghana and being effusively welcomed in Uganda must seem a wonder. It suggests that the majesty of the American Presidency has never been greater even though this President is engulfed by troubles in Washington.

title: How Open a Door?; Ending Remedial Classes at CUNY Could Drastically Change Its Mission
description: Like a summer storm, one of the fiercest battles over public higher education has suddenly blown up in New York City.

title: Matsushita's Management Gets U.S.-Style Changes
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, one of Japan's most conservatively run corporations, outlined a number of Western-style management changes today that illustrate how deeply the concepts of accountability have infiltrated the Japanese business establishment.

title: A Carrot-and-Stick Plan for Indonesia Aid
description: The United States and the International Monetary Fund have agreed to further delay the payment of billions of dollars in aid to Indonesia until President Suharto begins to act on a revised plan for economic reform, American and I.M.F. officials say.

title: Nasdaq Market Index Posts Its First Close Above 1,800
description: Several major stock market indexes climbed to highs yesterday as investors used the previous day's selloff as an opportunity to buy stocks at lower prices. The gains pushed the Nasdaq composite index, a leading technology barometer, to its first close above 1,800.

title: TV Notes; Where the Girls Are
description: Another night of broadcast television has begun to achieve some of that ''must-see'' cachet that NBC established on Thursdays with ''Seinfeld'' and ''E.R.'' -- at least with the MTV-and-Internet generation.

title: The Head and the Heart of Utah
description: They might not be the best, but they certainly are the brightest. Few expected the University of Utah to advance this far in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, not to the Final Four, certainly not the first season after losing the best player in the school's history.

title: Young, Disaffected and Constantly Tired, After Tiananmen Square
description: Qi Lei has decided to commit suicide. He's a struggling, constantly tired young performance artist who lives with his sister and her husband. (''Life is a major strain on me,'' he says. ''At day's end, I'm completely exhausted.'') And the idea of taking his own life is the only thing that excites him. (''I'm more and more attracted by the power of it,'' he tells friends.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERKOTTER, PAUL
description: OBERKOTTER-Paul. The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff and Administration of the Hospital for Special Surgery mourn with profound sorrow the death of Paul Oberkotter, a loyal friend and benefactor of the Hospital for many years. Mr. Oberkotter's generous support of the Hospital's work is inspirational to us all and we shall always be grateful to him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his daughter, Mildred, daughter-inlaw, Joyce, and the entire Oberkotter family. Richard L. Menschel Winfield P. Jones Co-Chairmen of the Board of Trustees John R. Ahearn John R. Reynolds Co-Chief Executive Officers Russell F. Warren, MD Surgeon-in-Chief Philip D. Wilson, Jr., MD Surgeon-in-Chief Emeritus

title: Enmeshed by Hasidic Rules
description: It's sure to be an uphill battle for ''A Price Above Rubies'' to find an audience, since this is a story of life among New York's Hasidic Jews that doesn't especially aim to please. But it tells the engrossing tale of a shy, appealing heroine with a yen for love and freedom, and it also features a good deal of jewelry. By some lights, that makes it a solid women's picture for sure.

title: Journal; The Religious Right Goes Hollywood
description: You know the religious right is in meltdown when Jerry Falwell and Ralph Reed lend a helping hand to Dreamworks, the Clinton Administration's favorite movie studio.

title: Pratt Worries About His Spot With Mets
description: With Todd Hundley likely out until at least June, Todd Pratt came into camp this spring confident that he could be the Mets' opening day catcher next Tuesday. But confidence is not a word that describes Pratt's state of mind right now. Dazed and confused is more like it.

title: Settlement Is Discussed In Crown Heights Strife
description: Talks are under way in a late effort to settle the suit that Hasidic residents of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, have brought against the city over its handling of a 1991 racial disturbances, court records indicate.

title: Restaurants; Where Steak Is Both King and Jester
description: KURT VONNEGUT JR. does not seem happy. The author has been hanging around the entryway of Sparks with the actor Albert Finney and about 20 other hopeful diners. The maitre d'hotel does not seem in the least concerned that we are squashed into an uncomfortable crowd, and he is brusque with those of us who ask when our tables will be ready. After about 20 minutes, Mr. Vonnegut's party leaves, and as I watch the men walk through the door, I find myself wondering if there is another restaurant in America where people of such stature would be kept cooling their heels.

title: After Yeltsin Shake-Up, Business as Usual
description: The Kremlin was calm and quite businesslike today as President Boris N. Yeltsin set about showing that his Government could press on even though he had dismissed his entire Cabinet on Monday.

title: MANY GREEN CARDS DELAYED BY 'BUGS' IN A NEW MACHINE
description: The Federal Government has delayed issuing tens of thousands of residency permits for immigrants because a new machine designed to produce fraudproof green cards has been dysfunctional since it was installed last summer.

title: About New York; Wall St. Horde Gives Mongols Feel of Action
description: MONDAY, the Mongols hit Manhattan, descending first on the New York Stock Exchange. They strode past the clerks and brokers who stood on Broad Street smoking their morning cigarettes. They skipped the line of tourists waiting to enter the building, eliciting suspicious whispers before they passed through the revolving doors and metal detectors. Their progress was smooth, until an alert guard slowed them down.

title: In Oscars for 'Titanic,' An Omen of More Power For Big-Budget Directors
description: In accepting his Academy Award for directing ''Titanic,'' James Cameron raised his arm and said with glee, ''I'm king of the world.''

title: Nasdaq Short Sales Up 5.6%, But Intel's Position Declines
description: As stock market indexes have continued to set new records, there has been a slight increase in the number of investors prepared to bet that share prices may decline.

title: On Dogma of Big Is Good, an Agnostic
description: WHEN the world of high technology seems to be moving too fast, when computers and other modern tools seem too hard to use and when the arrogance of technology companies brings us to the edge of a psychotic state, it is time for a few soothing minutes with Dr. Donald A. Norman. In the technological revolution, Dr. Norman is on our side, the side of the humans.

title: Zions to Buy Sumitomo California Bank
description: The Zions Bancorporation said yesterday that it would buy Sumitomo Bank Ltd.'s California bank for about $546 million in cash to expand into the state's growing Asian immigrant banking market.

title: Trade Group Is Opposing Bank Measure
description: The American Bankers Association, the Washington trade group that represents the nation's largest banks, said yesterday that it opposed a bill intended to break down barriers that separate the banking, insurance and securities businesses.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Tuesday reported the arrest of an Iraqi scientist who worked on the country's biological warfare program. The article included two paragraphs of background material that should have been attributed to The Washington Post, about a paper written by the scientist in 1983. The omission resulted from an inadvertent deletion of the credit from an on-line research file at The Times.

title: Promising Computer Beauty
description: IF you ask Robert Savi, the operative question when buying a new computer is not how much RAM to choose, or how large a hard drive to get. No. The crucial decision is: maple or red oak? Unless you can afford to step up to zebrawood or Mexican cocobolo.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Death in a Middle School
description: The statistics about school violence offer no solace in understanding the shooting in Jonesboro, Ark., that killed four students and a teacher and wounded 10 others. Data gathered around the nation show that the incidence of violence in schools has remained relatively stable over the past two decades, and that the deaths this week are a horrific aberration. But the attack carried out by a 13-year-old boy and his 11-year-old cousin at Westside Middle School grips the heart because the same deadly scenario has played out no less than five times in other school settings in the past two and a half years.

title: Public Eye; Sport Utility Toasting
description: RUGGED, retro, British and expensive, the Dualit professional toaster has a bulldog look. Essentially unchanged for a half century, the Dualit ($359 for the four-slot model, $269 for two slots) resembles a Land Rover -- the original 1948 Land Rover, the one on which Joy Adamson's lions draped themselves. There's the same combination of curves and lines, the same rugged metal surface (though the toaster comes in colors like sea green, yellow and blue as well as chrome) and the same utilitarian shape -- the same look right down to the slotted grill.

title: Star Spotting
description: It wasn't enough that BOB MERRILL, a trumpeter and band leader, saw MERYL STREEP in the airport when he arrived in the Virgin Islands.

title: A Win by Trump! No, by Tenants!; Battle of the 80's Ends, With Glad-Handing All Around
description: Tenants vs. Trump was the classic battle of the 1980's. A group of entrenched tenants in rent-regulated apartments overlooking Central Park vowed not to budge when Donald J. Trump announced his plans to tear down their building. In an opening salvo, Mr. Trump labeled them ''millionaires in mink coats, driving Rolls-Royces.''

title: The Old Give-to-Get Code
description: Sometimes the knot of politics, business and government has a bad odor to it in this state, whatever the protests of innocence or coincidence from everyone involved. Such is the case of one of Gov. George Pataki's big donors, Angelo Silveri, and his company's $100 million contract to revamp the Queens-Midtown Tunnel. In the first round of bids for the lucrative job, Mr. Silveri's firm, Silverite Construction, was rejected by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority as not having the necessary prior experience to do the work. Shortly after Mr. Silveri protested the decision to the M.T.A., his company won the contract on a second round of bids. And oh, yes, about the same time the M.T.A. was changing its mind about the Silverite proposal, the New York Republican State Committee received about $100,000 in contributions from people and companies linked to Mr. Silveri and his construction firm.

title: Bringing the Visual World of the Web to the Blind
description: CURTIS CHONG has been using the World Wide Web for three years to look up topics like music, fund-raising and medical research. He also uses it as a way to teach and encourage other blind people to get on the Web.

title: The Price of Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; You're All Fired!
description: Bored? Depressed? Stumbling and coughing a lot? Fearful your public is tiring of you, but unwilling to gamble on vigorous reforms? Take the Yeltsin Cure: grab world headlines by firing your whole Cabinet, and then hire most of them back.

title: Guess Who Was There First
description: FOR nearly two decades, the Internet was mainly the province of computer scientists, physicists, biologists and other researchers at a few dozen universities around the country. By all rights, these first settlers should be incensed at the influx of 20- and 30-somethings. They should look in horror upon the parvenus and interlopers who have moved in and made themselves at home.

title: The Man Who Created 'Peter Pan'
description: In ''The Man Who Was Peter Pan'' the playwright Allan Knee has performed an extraordinary act of imagination: he has removed Freud from the world, and it is an astonishingly different place for that. And the 42d Street Workshop has found six actors who make that world -- the turn-of-the-century London that was home to Sir James Barrie, the four Davies boys who inspired his play ''Peter Pan'' and their mother -- natural, affecting and distinctly odd.

title: Agency Orders Investigation Of 1997 Tunnel Contract
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority ordered an inquiry yesterday into a $97 million contract to repair the Queens-Midtown Tunnel, responding to a report that contributors connected to the winning bidder had given $100,000 to the New York Republican State Committee about the time that the authority awarded the project.

title: An Executive Whose Dream Is More Of Everything
description: At the end of a wide-ranging interview one day last week, Leonard A. Lauder, the chairman of the Whitney Museum of American Art, leaned across the table in the museum's newly restored boardroom and said, ''You didn't ask me about my fantasy.''

title: A Need for Information
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a British novelist and his latest work, ''Enduring Love,'' misspelled his surname. He is Ian McEwan, not McEwen.

title: Times Are A-Changin' For a Fatherless Child
description: THE RICH MAN'S TABLE

title: Mother of Lewinsky Must Testify Further
description: Marcia Lewis, Monica S. Lewinsky's mother, failed yesterday in her effort to get excused from further testimony before a Federal grand jury. Ms. Lewis's appearance last month before the grand jury provoked sympathy from millions of Americans and criticism of the prosecutorial tactics of the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr.

title: Little News Fails to Slow TV Reports
description: By now viewers of the all-news channels must know that once past the terrible facts and heartbreaking pictures, they will find few real answers to the questions everyone wants answered about killings of the young by the young, in Kentucky, in Mississippi and now in Arkansas.

title: Currents: Los Angeles; California Dreamers Awake to Reality
description: CALL Los Angeles Prototype City. That bang! bang! bang! is the sound of new chairs and tables, beds and sofas taking shape on the assembly line.

title: Schumer Withdraws From Upstate Straw Poll in Senate Bid
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer withdrew yesterday from a Democratic Party straw poll this weekend intended to measure the upstate support for Senate candidates. The move came in the face of what was shaping up to be a defeat for the Brooklyn Democrat in a part of the state where he is not well known.

title: Iomega Chief Resigns After A Warning Of New Loss
description: A week after warning of a loss for the current quarter, the Iomega Corporation said yesterday that its president and chief executive, Kim B. Edwards, had resigned.

title: Brother of 'Megan's Law' Killer Charged With Sexual Assault
description: The brother of Jesse K. Timmendequas, the man who raped and murdered 7-year-old Megan Kanka in 1994, was arrested yesterday afternoon on charges that he sexually assaulted two girls in a North Brunswick home, prosecutors said.

title: Pataki and Judge Offer Plan on Child Support
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and New York's Chief Judge, Judith S. Kaye, proposed legislation today that would allow state and local social service agencies to issue child support orders, potentially speeding the process for thousands of parents who now must rely on the state's overburdened court system.

title: Calendar; Landmarks and Antiques
description: Preserving New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, ELIZABETH B.
description: CLARK-Elizabeth B. On March 25, 1998. Mother of Bruce Clark, mother-in-law of Deborah Clark and grandmother of Samantha Ann and Andrew Bruce. Mass 10 A.M., Friday, Immaculate Conception Church, N. Broadway, Irvington, N.Y. Visiting Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford, (Saw Mill Exit 17), Dobbs Ferry, NY Thursday between 7 and 9 P.M.

title: Cutting Congestion, and Taxes
description: One manifestation of America's devotion to driving is a Federal tax rule that makes an employer-provided parking space a tax-free benefit, now worth up to $175 a month. This is far more generous than the nontaxable benefit for using mass transit or van pools, which is only $65 a month and governed by more restrictive rules that limit the number of people who would find it an attractive option. The disparity retards efforts to promote mass transit as the best road to cleaner air, less congestion, more efficient energy use and economic growth in metropolitan America.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENBERG, JERRY
description: GREENBERG-Jerry. For my brother, with love.

title: A Forest in Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: Garden Notebook; The Hellebore, Beloved and Hardy, Like a Rose in Snow
description: HELLEBORES, known as Christmas and Lenten roses, are generating a lot of heat these days. It is not only that they are as promiscuous as ever, what with species mixing it up with each other and dropping highly varied hybrid seedlings before one can say ''Helleborus orientalis subspecies abchasicus.'' It is also that, in the last five years, gardeners and breeders have been fighting over and spending money on the hellebore, which loves shade and blooms in the winter, even in the Northeast.

title: Workers of the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Resales Soar by 8.7% As Slowdown Proves Elusive
description: Home resales rose at a record pace in February and factories continued to receive orders for big-ticket items at healthy rates, signs of strength that confounded predictions of slowing economic growth.

title: Reading Eliot Feld: Behind a New Name, A Troupe Is Redefined
description: Eliot Feld changed the name of his company last year from Feld Ballets/NY to Ballet Tech, which is also the name of the school he founded. When the troupe opened a five-week season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, the program's title page listed the company as Feld Ballet Tech, albeit with Mr. Feld's name printed in smaller letters and at right angles to the other words.

title: Nightmare, Delusion and Psychosis, for Fun
description: DON'T take your sanity for granted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMERFORD, ROSE M.
description: COMERFORD-Rose M. Of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn and Point Lookout, New York, on March 24, 1998. Practicing psychotherapist, graduate of Fordham University, NYU School of Social Work and Washington Square Institute. Beloved and devoted wife of late Frank Comerford. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Joellin, Michael and Andrianne, Frank and Maura, Patrice, Elizabeth and William Spinelli, Maria and James Corcoran, K.C. and Justin Fauci, Christina & Pete Lekkas, Timothy & Mary. Cherished grandmother of eleven loving grandchildren. Reposing Andrew Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305-79 Street, Bklyn, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday 11AM, at St. Malachy's RC Church, Manhattan. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Child Abuse Prevention Program, Inc., 7 Hanover Square, 8th Floor, New York, NY 10004. (212)344-1902.

title: Metro Matters; Budget Panel Offers Touch Of the Comical
description: IT is said that men who have lived sequestered from the sun stumble at first in the light, groping with their hands, until their eyes become adjusted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVICK, RONALD E.
description: LEVICK-Ronald E. Sixty years of friendship. Oh Ron, what a void has been created. Cliff Barr

title: Jets Get Martin, but the Deal Is Under Scrutiny
description: The New England Patriots said today that they would not match the six-year, $36 million offer sheet the Jets made to running back Curtis Martin, meaning that the Jets get Martin and the Patriots get the Jets' first- and third-round picks in this year's draft.

title: Status of Har Homa
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Doctor Is Charged With Falsifying Credentials
description: The name tag he wore in the emergency room at Brooklyn Hospital Center read ''Dr. Timothy McNamee,'' but the man in the white coat apparently did not have a license to practice medicine or the right to perform complex medical procedures like opening a patient's chest to do heart massage.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Academy Awards referred incorrectly in some copies to the impromptu song performed by the director Stanley Donen after he received an honorary Oscar. The title is ''Cheek to Cheek,'' not ''Heaven.''

title: Russian Continues Her March
description: She is as imperious as they come, and then some. Anna Kournikova, a Russian 16-year-old who, for the moment, is just another princess in Martina Hingis's court, continued her rampage at the Lipton Championships today by strutting into the semifinals with a 6-4, 2-6, 6-2 demotion of second-seeded Lindsay Davenport.

title: Guns for All Ages
description: The images are hauntingly familiar. Emergency medical technicians rush the wounded to ambulances. Body bags containing the dead are taken to morgues. Families stand entwined in circles of grief.

title: Levin May Get A Big Payout From Options
description: The directors of Time Warner Inc. yesterday disclosed new stock options for the company's chairman, Gerald M. Levin, that they said created ''powerful incentives'' for him to increase value for shareholders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARTORIUS, JOHN M.
description: SARTORIUS-John M. Of Quogue, New York, formerly of Tenafly, New Jersey, died on March 23, 1998 after a long illness in his 78th year. He is survived by his devoted wife Nancy, four sons, John, Jr., Peter, David and Scott, a sister Beverly VanderPoel, a brother Robert Sartorius. He was predeceased by his first wife, Frances Cauchois Sartorius in 1973. Mr. Sartorius graduated from the Hill School and Princeton University Class of 1942. He served as a 1st Lieutenant in the U.S. Army in Europe during World War II and was awarded the Bronze Star. He retired from Union Carbide in 1980 as a product Manager. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Southampton Care Center or the Southampton Hospital would be appreciated. Funeral Mass will be 10 AM Monday, March 30, at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Westhampton Beach, New York.

title: A Touchy South Africa Takes Pains Not to Kowtow
description: President Clinton is spending 11 days on this continent, but he is really making two different trips: one to Africa and one to South Africa.

title: Release the King Files
description: Nearly 30 years after the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., public opinion polls show that a vast majority of Americans believe that a still unrevealed conspiracy was behind his death. The King family has called for a new trial for his convicted killer, James Earl Ray, and various new theories are swirling. Just yesterday, the Federal Bureau of Investigation cast doubt on a retired agent's claim that he possessed papers that could be relevant to the case.

title: On Line, Universities Link To Alumni and Their Wallets
description: COLLEGE students used to say their goodbyes at graduation and hope to catch up at five-year intervals ever after. But now colleges are offering alumni services like lifelong personal E-mail accounts, home pages for each graduating class and regional alumni newsgroups on the Internet, making it easier than ever for former students to keep in touch -- and for college fund-raisers to find them.

title: Arts Prizes Announced
description: The winners of the fourth annual CalArts/Alpert Awards are Jeanne C. Finley (film), Joanna Haigood (dance), Danny Hoch (theater), Roni Horn (visual arts) and Pamela Z (music.) The awards, which carry a $50,000 cash prize for each winner, were established by the Herb Alpert Foundation and the California Institute of the Arts to encourage mid-career artists to take new risks and enable them to reach wider audiences. The awards are to be presented on May 16 at the foundation in Santa Monica.

title: UNISYS REACHES PACT WITH HEWLETT FOR PC PRODUCTION
description: The Unisys Corporation said it had agreed to a deal for the Hewlett-Packard Company to supply Unisys with personal computers and entry-level servers as part of a plan by Unisys to quit producing PC's and concentrate on high-end servers. No financial terms were disclosed. Unisys, of Blue Bell, Pa., announced in January that it was seeking a partner to produce its PC's and low-end servers. Unisys took a charge of about $127 million for its PC operations as part of a broader set of $1.1 billion in restructuring charges. Under the deal, which remains tentative, Unisys plans to sell under its brand name built-to-order notebook, desktop and Intel-based entry-level server computers from Hewlett-Packard.

title: Bill Further Limits Class-Action Lawsuits
description: Aggrieved investors are likely to face further limits on their ability to sue companies using class-action lawsuits under a bill that was endorsed yesterday by Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, ARNOLD
description: GOLD-Arnold. On March 23, 1998, age 75, passed away as the result of a stroke. Beloved father of Sidney, brother of Eleanor Sterman and Uncle of Judith Kornbluh. Funeral services, Thursday, March 26, 11 A.M., at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to New York Artists' Equity.

title: Finding Hidden Senders in All That E-Mail Gobbledygook
description: BY now, most of America has enough experience with electronic mail to realize that it is often not what it seems. Spoofs and pranks are easy to pull off. Most E-mail programs make it as easy to claim a false name as it is to write a false return address on a paper envelope.

title: Keeping Bookmarks In a Place That's Safe
description: Q. How can I permanently save the bookmarks that I use with my Netscape browser? I want to back them up so the site-address part (and not just the title of the site) is retained if they get corrupted. I have been a victim of corrupted bookmarks too often.

title: Camden Asks New Jersey To Take Over School System
description: Saying that local educators have failed for decades to improve this city's public schools, Mayor Milton Milan has taken the unusual step of asking the state to seize control of the school system.

title: Mayor to Raise Pay of Officers On City Beats
description: Insisting that he had not yet read two reports issued by his own Task Force on Police/Community Relations, the panel he created after the Abner Louima beating, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani embraced the essence of one of its major recommendations yesterday, announcing pay increases for thousands of patrol officers who choose to remain on the beat in city neighborhoods.

title: Free Throws by Houston Salvage Knicks' Victory
description: This was not the Jazz. This was the Clippers. And yet the pressure was just as great as Allan Houston stepped to the free-throw line with the game on the line.

title: Annan Is Stern But Friendly On Israel Visit
description: Delivering what he called ''the most difficult message'' of his visit here, Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations today accused Israel of a chain of ''provocative acts'' that he said contributed to a crisis in Israeli-Arab relations.

title: Residential Resales
description: Manhattan

title: Tests With Anthrax Raise Fears That American Vaccine Can Be Defeated
description: Biological warfare experts are concerned that countries like Iraq may be able to create forms of anthrax that can overcome the vaccine now being given to American troops in the Persian Gulf.

title: Jersey City State College To Become a University
description: Increasingly in New Jersey's higher education circles, it seems, the term ''college'' no longer makes the grade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORBIN, LILLIAN M.
description: KORBIN-Lillian M. Died Saturday, March 21, 1998. Lillian, wife of the late Theodore R. Korbin, was born in Springfield, MA., and spent the majority of her life in the Bx., N.Y. She is survived by her nephews Gerald C. McDonald, Robert T. McDonald, and John R. McDonald and several grandnieces and grandnephews. Calling hours Friday, March 27, 2-5 and 7-9 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, March 28, 9:45 AM at the Church of St. Phillip Neri, Bronx.

title: TEL-SAVE SEES A STRONG CHANCE IT WILL STAY INDEPENDENT
description: Tel-Save Holdings Inc., the long-distance telephone service provider that last month hired Salomon Smith Barney for advice on a possible sale, said yesterday that there was a ''strong possibility'' it would remain independent. The company's chairman, Daniel Borislow, said that because of the success of a recent marketing initiative with America Online and the company's value compared with its peers, ''any talk of a takeover will have to start with the first digit of a takeover price being a 3,'' referring to a price of $30 a share. Yesterday, Tel-Save shares fell $2.96875, to $24. The company's deal with America Online is expected to generate about 500,000 telephone lines by the end of the current quarter. Mr. Borislow said Tel-Save, which is based in New Hope, Pa., would make a final determination on its future by April 15.

title: Replay Turned Down by N.F.L.
description: National Football League owners once again decided not to bring back instant replay, rejecting it by a vote of 21-9, and now even its most energetic supporters say they are through trying to resurrect it.

title: Metro Business; Caldor Plans Final Sales
description: The Caldor Corporation, the Norwalk, Conn., discount retailer, is hiring Gordon Brothers Retail Partners to conduct going-out-of-business sales at 11 stores Caldor is closing to help it return to profitability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTER, LISL
description: POTTER-Lisl. March 24, 1998. Of Somers, NY. Formerly of Pound Ridge and Scarsdale, NY. Beloved wife of Georges. Loving mother of Barbara Potter, Andrea Kirshoff and Tina Potter. Devoted grandmother of Joey, David, Jack and Maddy Kirshoff. Mother-in-law of Steven Kirshoff, James Taylor and Carl Prinzi. Services and interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Rangers Let Biggest Game Slip Away
description: In perhaps their most important game of the season, the Rangers did what they have done the most this season: they lost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIN, MICHAEL L.
description: HEIN-Michael L., 55. Investment banker for CAPMAC, died March 25 at Lenox Hill Hospital. Father of Ethan Hein, Molly Hein, step father of Daniel Righini, also leaves his former wife Karen Hein and her husband Ralph Dell. Funeral service Mar. 29 at the Community Church of Whitingham, VT, 2 PM, burial to follow in Jacksonville Village Cemetery in Jacksonville, VT. Calling hours Saturday March 28, 6-8 PM at the Covey & Allen Funeral Home, 44 Main Street, Wilmington, VT. 05363. Memorials to Whitingham Historical Society in care of funeral home.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You need to dance, but dance slowly.''

title: Facing Grown-Up Problems; Can a New Chief Find a Solution for Toys 'R' Us?
description: The last time Arlene Blankenship was in a Toys ''R'' Us store, during the holiday season, she left with two things: ''The Lost World: Jurassic Park'' games for her grandsons and the notion that there had to be an easier way to play Santa.

title: Arts Abroad; The Ideal Martyr: Oscar Wilde Has the Last Laugh
description: Nearly 100 years after his death and vilification, Oscar Wilde is suddenly and somewhat surprisingly back in everyone's good graces here, and the object of apparently endless fascination.

title: Net's a Natural for Fantasy Baseball
description: FOR baseball fans, spring is a season of seduction. The siren song of off-season trades and Grapefruit League statistics stirs irresistible hope for championship glory. And then there's the bandwidth drain.

title: Is That Machine After Your Job?; Measure of Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Blacks on a Brooklyn Street: Both Cynics and Optimists Speak Out
description: Far from Africa but so deeply connected to his roots that he considers himself African (no hyphenated ethnic label for him), a vegetable and fruit vendor from Brooklyn pondered the question for a moment and replied with a shrug: ''I haven't really thought about it. I'm not into politics, you know,''

title: Bashful City Employee Is Reinstated to His Job
description: A city employee dismissed after he did not urinate for a random drug test because a police officer was looking over his shoulder has been reinstated after a state appeals court ruling that the test's conditions were unconstitutional.

title: The Price of Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: As He Waits for Holyfield, Lewis Gets Set for Briggs
description: Lennox Lewis makes Shannon Briggs sound like a last-minute prom date.

title: Puerto Rico Statehood; Let Us Vote, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: High Court Hears 2 Sex-Harassment Liability Cases
description: Having painted the broad outlines of sexual harassment law with striking unanimity over the last decade, the Supreme Court moved on today to the challenging task of filling in the details.

title: Yiddish Teacher, 85, Dies After Apparent Assault
description: An 85-year-old Yiddish teacher whom family and friends described as indomitable died Tuesday after she was apparently assaulted in a purse-snatching in her Queens neighborhood, the police said yesterday.

title: Underprepared Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: French Bank Offers To Buy Rest of Natexis
description: The French banking company group Caisse Centrale des Banques Populaires offered yesterday to acquire the 75 percent of the banking company Natexis S.A. that it does not already own. Banques Populaires bid 440 francs a share for the Natexis stake, or about 7.2 billion francs ($1.17 billion).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, TRUDY
description: SCHWARTZ-Trudy. Wife of Sol, mother of Deah Schwartz, Sheila Cooperman and Carol Stock, sister of Arthur Ashendorff, daughter or Alice Ashendorff, beloved Granny of Jacqueline, Rebecca and Stephanie Cooperman and Zachary Filler. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 11:30 AM Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A background article and a chart on Tuesday about Bertelsmann A.G.'s agreement to buy Random House referred imprecisely to the American publisher's origins. Random House traces them to 1925, when Bennett Cerf and Donald Klopfer acquired another publisher, the Modern Library. The name Random House first appeared in 1927, not 1925. Mr. Cerf and Mr. Klopfer did not set up shop as the Modern Library in 1923.

title: In the Race for the Fastest Chip, Just Don't Blink
description: THE past week went fast, and faster. Steve Jobs, the acting chief executive of Apple Computer, showed off what is now the fastest personal computer on the planet, a 300-megahertz version of the G3 PowerPC Macintosh. Then, to top it off, Mr. Jobs demonstrated a 400-MHz prototype that used a new copper (instead of aluminum) wiring scheme on the chip. Apple has not wasted any time capitalizing on its speed advantage over Intel Pentium-based machines, with new advertisements that show a Pentium II chip strapped to the back of a snail and one of Intel's bunny-suited chip technicians being toasted to ashes by the speed of Apple's rival PowerPC chips.

title: Experts Note Access to Guns and Lack of Ties to Adults
description: The shootings in Jonesboro, Ark., on Tuesday -- coming only a few months after multiple shootings at schools in West Paducah, Ky., and Pearl, Miss., -- have galvanized public concern about school violence, and left parents, psychiatrists and politicians alike wondering what prompts youngsters to open fire on their classmates.

title: Critics Say U.S. Ignored C.I.A. Warnings of Genocide in Rwanda
description: When President Clinton confessed today that ''people like me'' failed to see the storm of mass killings that swept Rwanda in 1994, he acknowledged a bitter truth for the first time.

title: At Internet Torture Trial, Defense Builds Case on a Beat Novel
description: Lawyers for a man accused of kidnapping and sexually abusing a woman he met over the Internet used the writings of William S. Burroughs yesterday in an attempt to cast the woman's story as a fantasy drawn in part from the pages of a novel.

title: New Approach Lanes For E-Z Pass Drivers
description: E-Z Pass is getting even easier.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Buffett Likes Silver; Soros, a Silver Mine
description: Long before Warren E. Buffett made his well-publicized bet on silver, George Soros bought a big stake in a silver mine.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PANETTA, AMEDEO
description: PANETTA-Amedeo. July 31, 1918-March 26, 1994. Dear Amedeo, I'll always love you. V.I.

title: Executive Changes
description: ADVANTA CORP., Spring House, Pa., named Olaf Olafsson president, filling a position that has been vacant since David Brooks left the company a year ago.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a Critic's Notebook article about the playwright Eugene Ionesco misidentified the play scheduled to open on April 1 at the Golden Theater on Broadway. It is ''The Chairs,'' not ''The Bald Soprano.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, MORTON
