description: STERN-Morton. Husband of the late Betty and the late Thelma. Devoted father of Joseph Stern and the late Barbara Scheinfeld. Step father of Robert Lipsky and Marilyn Natiss. Dear brother of Jack Stein. Cherished grandfather of Lester, Judith, Bonnie and Stacey. Loving great grandfather of Carlyn, Bret, Alexandra, Samantha, Timothy and Brian. Services today 10 A.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, L.I.

title: The Price of Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY MEXICAN MILITARY AIDS DRUG TRAFFIC
description: For a year the Clinton Administration has presented the stunning arrest of Mexico's drug-enforcement chief as proof of that Government's strong will to fight corruption. But now United States analysts have concluded that the case shows much wider military involvement with drug traffickers than the Mexican authorities have acknowledged.

title: Spots for Adults Appeal to Children
description: Of the 10 commercials most frequently named by children as their favorites in a survey, two were for products not aimed at them: beer and motor vehicles.

title: Show Me the Mummy! Internet Offers a Home to Archeology
description: THE archeologist Heinrich Schliemann used Homer as his guide when he excavated Troy, and he published his findings in books. When Howard Carter unearthed the tomb of Tutankhamen in 1922, the world learned of his discovery through a spectacular scoop by The Times of London in a dispatch sent ''by runner from the Valley of the Kings.'' The paleontologist Richard E. Leakey drew widespread attention to humankind's African origins with a series of popular television documentaries.

title: Korean Airlines Faults Crew's Actions in Crash on Guam
description: Korean Airlines, point by point, faulted the performance of its crew in the minutes before the crash of Flight 801 on Guam last August. But five hours of testimony today did not establish why the three fairly seasoned officers brought the Boeing 747 down into the jungle, four miles short of the runway; in fact, a top executive of the airline quickly disposed of one of the investigator's leading theories.

title: Lions and Gophers And Big Ten, Oh My
description: Larry Brown is the starting tight end on Georgia's football team and a post player on its basketball team. Jarrett Stephens, once a high school all-state tight end in Michigan, is a post player on Penn State's basketball team.

title: Justice Dept. Belatedly Finds New Defense of Line Item Veto
description: The Clinton Administration has found a new argument in its effort to preserve the line item veto, asserting that those who seek an immediate ruling on its constitutionality must be individual people, not corporations or local governments like the City of New York.

title: The Price of Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Bell Atlantic Is Seeking to End Rate Freeze on Pay Phones
description: One of the few financial breaks that comes with living or working in New York -- the 25-cent local pay phone call -- may soon end.

title: Fossil Reveals a 113-Million-Year-Old Secret: the Inside Story of Dinosaurs
description: The fossil of a baby dinosaur has come to light in which details of soft anatomy never seen before in any dinosaur are preserved. Scientists expect the fossil, which was found in Italy, to yield important information about the anatomy of dinosaurs in general.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALABRESE, JOHN
description: CALABRESE-John. On March 25, 1998 of Wayne, NJ. Devoted husband of Alice and dear father of Patrick and Kelly. A mass will be offered Saturday April 4, 1998 at 10:00AM, at St. Mary's RC Church, 17 Pompton Ave, Pompton Lakes, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions in John's memory to the John Calabrese Cancer Fund, C/O 25 Chopin Drive, Wayne, N.J. 07470 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOROSS, HELEN
description: MOROSS-Helen. On March 23, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Herbert L. Moross, loving mother of Sonya Bregman and Gladys Cutler, devoted grandmother of Sheryl and Gary Bregman. Funeral service was held Wednesday at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: U.N. Tells Iraq Of Inspections At Key Sites
description: The chief United Nations arms inspector for Iraq told the Government of Saddam Hussein today that inspections of eight previously forbidden presidential properties would begin on Thursday morning under the direction of an American expert whom the Iraqis have tried to sideline.

title: Swiss Banks Face Deadline And Sanctions
description: More than a year after the investigations of Nazi gold began to taint Switzerland's reputation, its banks are fighting the threat of politically damaging sanctions across the United States and a lobbying effort by New York State to block the merger of two giant Swiss financial institutions.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Saving or Not Saving a Maple

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABKIN, SYLVIA
description: RABKIN-Sylvia. March 24, 1998. Beloved daughter of the late Morris and Sarah. Adored sister of the late William, Louis, George, Matilda and Anna. Loving aunt of Marilyn, Rosalind, Francine, Betty, Norman, Martin, Richard and Grace. Cherished great aunt. Service on Thursday, 11:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Germany's Postal Service Acquiring Stake in DHL
description: Deutsche Post A.G., Germany's state postal service, said yesterday that it would buy 22.5 percent of DHL International Ltd. in a sale estimated at $500 million. Terms of the purchase from the estate of the DHL co-founder Larry Lee Hillblom were not disclosed. Deutsche Post joins the airlines Deutsche Lufthansa and Japan Airlines in owning DHL International.

title: Echlin Loses Effort to End Hostile SPX Bid
description: Legislators in Connecticut defeated a bill yesterday that would have helped Echlin Inc., an auto parts maker based in the state, repel a hostile $3 billion bid from a smaller rival, the SPX Corporation.

title: A Media-Ready Mayor's Mansion
description: NEW YORK CITY has Gracie Mansion. Detroit has Manoogian Mansion. Los Angeles has Getty House. And come the millennium, Denver's Mayor will have Cableland.

title: A Plausible Israeli Peace Proposal
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's proposal for Israeli withdrawals from a further 10.5 percent to 12 percent of the West Bank does not go as far as Israel should. But given the frozen state of the Middle East peace effort, it should be treated as a serious offer. Its double-digit numbers cross a psychological barrier for Israelis and Palestinians. More important, Israel's willingness to turn over contiguous territory, rather than isolated enclaves, shows Palestinians that a final peace agreement can leave them with the makings of a viable state. Mr. Netanyahu reasonably links his offer to improved Palestinian security measures.

title: Coca-Cola prepares a summertime pitch for teen-agers that may be its most aggressive ever.
description: SUMMER is just around the corner. And along with the hissing of sprinklers and the chirping of crickets must come the roar of marketing's heavy artillery as Coca-Cola and Pepsi battle for consumer loyalty during the hottest, thirstiest months on the calendar.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL RISES 3.5 PERCENT. Crude oil surged on OPEC's call for an emergency meeting Monday, suggesting it will seek deeper production cuts than those already pledged. Crude for May delivery cost $16.48 a barrel, up 56 cents.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by Reuters in Business Day on Tuesday about the fourth-quarter loss reported by Donna Karan International Inc. misstated predictions of the company's performance. Analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation estimated that the company would report a loss of $3.64 a share, not $2.03 a share.

title: First Death Under an Assisted-Suicide Law
description: While doctors, religious leaders and politicians continue to debate the ethics of allowing physicians to help terminally ill patients kill themselves, the issue took a sharp turn from the abstract today when the first known legal assisted suicide was announced in Oregon.

title: Is That Machine After Your Job?; Ask the Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: And Then There Were Seven
description: In 1960, having bought Alfred A. Knopf and some other companies, Random House's founder, Bennett Cerf, was exultant. ''Within the next few years,'' he said, ''some five or six great publishing combines will dominate the publishing scene, much the way that a handful of companies today dominate steel, automobile and other truly big industries.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, LENORE HELEN
description: ROSENBERG-Lenore Helen. Of East 79 St, Manhattan. Friend and devoted employee of Dr. William Horowitz, 5th Avenue, Manhattan. Loyal friend of Helen Dym and Mary Schimpf. Died on March 20. Interred at Mt. Richmond Cemetery, Staten Island. We will miss you and remember you always.

title: Arkansas Law May Bar Stiff Prosecution of Boys
description: The two young boys used to tease 12-year-old Erica Swindle about her glasses. She thought they were mean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDEL, ESTELLE L. BECKER
description: MENDEL-Estelle L. Becker. Eighty-five years old of North Miami Beach, Florida. Formerly of Staten Island, New York. Died in North Miami Beach, Florida on March 25, 1998. She was the devoted mother of Mrs. Linda F. Lewis (Alan) of Jupiter, Florida and Dr. Jaqueline H. Becker of New York City. She is also survived by her dear grandchildren, Barbara K. Schoor-Greenwell (Stephen) and Debra G. Schoor and several nieces and nephews. Mrs. Becker Mendel was the young widow of the late Benjamin J. Becker. She was an active member of the Pythian Sisters, Hadassah, The City of Hope and while a resident of Staten Island, a member of the Sisterhood of Temple Tiffereth Israel. Funeral services will be held at the Menorah Chapel, 2145 Richmond Avenue, Staten Island, New York on Friday, March 27, 1998, at 10 A.M.

title: Victim of Beating on L.I. Describes Life in Its Wake
description: With several long, jagged scars clearly visible on his head, Shane Daniels came face to face today for the first time with the man accused of nearly bludgeoning him to death outside a Long Island nightclub nearly two years ago.

title: No Tilley Cover At New Yorker
description: Eustace Tilley, The New Yorker magazine's favorite cover boy, has undergone a stunning metamorphosis. After 69 years as a monocled, top-hatted Regency dandy in pursuit of a butterfly, he became a pimply punk rocker in 1994. Since then, he has been pictured as a woman in a low-cut dress and a detective.

title: Nurses Get New Role in Patient Protection
description: Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest health maintenance organization, agreed today to let its Northern California nurses' union appoint ''quality liaison'' nurses to serve as watchdogs at each of the organization's hospitals in the region and to force prompt attention to abuses and oversights in the care of patients.

title: Belfast Talks Kept on Course By Ducking Issue of I.R.A. Guilt
description: In statements clearly designed to keep the Northern Ireland peace talks on track, British authorities said today that they had no evidence that several recent bombings were the work of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Lewinsky's Bookstore Purchases Are Now Subject of a Subpoena
description: The independent prosecutor investigating President Clinton's relationship with a former White House intern has subpoenaed the records of a Washington bookstore for information about what the young woman bought there.

title: Time for Congress To Act on NATO; Russians Are Reacting
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTON, WILLIAM D.
description: ALTON-William D. On March 23, 1998. Smart, sweet, loving, remembered. Zohra

title: Is That Machine After Your Job?; Insulting the Narcissist
description: To the Editor:

title: Erin Go Rah: Exalting Ireland's Musical Traditions
description: The members of Solas wore the customary color of Ireland Tuesday night during their crowd-pleasing set at Tramps: purple. Admittedly, this custom may be one the five-member ensemble originated. Sexy in leather pants and jackets, tie-dye and flashy earrings, the group looked more like a hippie-influenced rock band than America's most lauded purveyors of Irish traditional music. Yet Solas exalted that much-sentimentalized isle's musical artistry without either softening it up or setting it in Blarney stone.

title: MONSANTO TO SELL EYEGLASS LENS UNIT FOR $100 MILLION
description: The Monsanto Company agreed yesterday to sell its Orcolite eyeglass lens unit to BMC Industries for $100 million in cash. BMC Industries, which is based in Minneapolis, makes eyeglass lenses and aperture masks for color picture tubes for television sets and computer monitors. It will make Orcolite part of its ophthalmic lens business. Orcolite, of Azusa, Calif., had estimated 1997 sales of $34 million. Monsanto, based in St. Louis, has already shed its chemical units and said earlier this year that it wanted to dispose of products that do not relate to its life sciences business. It also plans to sell its Solaris lawn-and-garden products unit.

title: London Journal; Wanted: Big City Mayor. And Big Names Apply.
description: The names in play are Glenda Jackson, Jeffrey Archer and Richard Branson, and there's not a movie, a novel or a high flying balloon in sight.

title: Foes of Abortion Split Sharply Over Campaign Finance Bill
description: The National Right to Life Committee and Senator John McCain are usually allies, joined in their opposition to abortion. But in an odd twist in the battle over campaign financing that shows how important the current system is to interest groups, the committee has been challenging the Senator, even belittling any Presidential ambitions he holds.

title: A Move From 'Our Crowd' to Mass Media
description: SERENA ALTSCHUL grew up on Fifth Avenue, with four older siblings who went as expected to Harvard, Yale, Columbia and Barnard. Her great-uncle was Gov. Herbert H. Lehman of New York. Her great-grandmother, Hattie Lehman Goodhart, is in the first sentence of ''Our Crowd,'' Stephen Birmingham's chronicle of New York's German-Jewish aristocracy, as an arbiter of people one visited, and people one didn't. Her father, Arthur G. Altschul, briefly covered the United Nations for The New York Times in the late 1940's, then fed the Altschul fortunes for a half-century on Wall Street. Her mother, Siri von Reis, is a Harvard-educated ethnobotanist, half-Finnish and half-Swedish, who is now a full-time poet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, BETSEY CUSHING
description: WHITNEY-Betsey Cushing. It is with profound sadness that we note the passing of this dedicated and generous benefactor. Mrs. Whitney gave wholeheartedly to fulfill a dream shared by thousands-the creation of a hospital on Long Island's North Shore. During its early years of growth, she continued to devote her energy to the betterment of the institution and the community. This exceptional woman will always be remembered as one of those who set the groundwork for the development of one of the largest health care systems in the country. Mrs. Whitney's title of Honorary Chairman of the Board at the time of her passing symbolized her family's long-time dedication, spirit and commitment to North Shore University Hospital. The entire hospital family will sorely miss this great lady. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her family. John S.T. Gallagher & David R. Dantzker, M.D., Co-Presidents, CEOs Administration and Employees North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Uganda Could Be Model For 'New' Africa's Goals
description: Winston Churchill called this lush, landlocked country ''the pearl of Africa.'' Idi Amin turned it into a charnel house. Now it is a display window for an African renaissance.

title: 2 Are Hurt in Subway Attacks At Upper West Side Stations
description: Two commuters were stabbed at subway stations on the Upper West Side during yesterday morning's rush hour by a mugger who fled into Central Park, the police said.

title: Tennessee Redefining the Women's Game
description: When the University of Tennessee found itself trailing North Carolina by 12 points with seven and a half minutes remaining on Monday night, Coach Pat Summitt gathered her Lady Volunteers and launched a blistering tirade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACHT, ANITA BRIM
description: SCHACHT-Anita Brim. Much loved wife of the late Jack, mother of Diane, sister of Miriam and Gloria, and aunt to Jonathan, Michael, Linda, and Jennifer, on Wednesday, March 25, 1998. Social worker, sculptor, traveler, and free spirit, she will forever live in our hearts. Services at Park WestRiverside, Fri., March 27, 9:45 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the World Wildlife Fund or the Nature Conservancy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 11 Countries Are Cleared To Join Euro Currency

title: Plan to Commemorate A 'Forgotten War'
description: On a landscaped lot along the boardwalk next to the city's Brighton Park, a memorial to the state's 133,000 Korean War veterans, including the 808 who died in action, will be erected by June 2000, the 50th anniversary of the beginning of the conflict, officials announced yesterday.

title: Critics Say a Lilco Takeover Would Greatly Enrich Its Chief
description: The Long Island Lighting Company's chairman would receive a windfall that might exceed $10 million as a result of Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to take over part of the utility, foes of the deal charged today.

title: Design Notebook; From Latin Memories, Tropical Modernism
description: EVERY summer, Madeleine Sanchez, now a 38-year-old architect, would visit her grandmother's small turquoise and ocher house in Cayey, P.R. She was often awakened in the middle of the night by the moonlight, which streamed in through cracks in the wooden planks that made up the small hand-built casita where her grandmother lived and died.

title: A Chance to Wear Your Heart On Your Sleeve -- or Bosom
description: A CRESCENT brooch covered with diamonds and rubies, and priced at $500,000, might not seem to need more glitz. But with a little help from technology, the rubies do much more than glitter -- they pulsate, glowing each time the heart beneath them beats.

title: F.C.C. Chief Backs Off on Rules for Free Air Time for Candidates
description: Faced with threats to cut his agency's budget, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission yesterday backed away from his plan to start developing rules immediately that would require broadcasters to give free time for political advertising to candidates for Federal office.

title: C. G. Sontheimer, Cuisinart Backer, Dies at 83
description: Carl G. Sontheimer, a creative electronics engineer and successful entrepreneur who made his most visible contribution to the American economy -- and American kitchens -- after his retirement, died on Monday at a hospital near his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 83 and known as the man who revolutionized American cooking by bringing the Cuisinart to the United States.

title: Time for Congress To Act on NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Interview With the Spammer
description: IF YOU think the junk E-mail clogging your In box is causing you problems, try being the poor spammer. That's the person we should really feel sorry for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRUPE, SANTO W. ESQ.
description: CRUPE-Santo W. Esq., March 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Isabelle (nee Tuzio). Devoted father of Dorothy Tomasulo, William Santo and Peter James. Loving grandfather of Christine Ayers, William Santo Jr. and Elizabeth Crupe, and Stephen and Anthony Tomasulo. Born in Albany, New York, he was a graduate of Columbia College and St. John's Law School. He practiced law in New York City for almost 50 years. An Army veteran of W.W. II, he served as a military governor in Italy, attaining the rank of captain. He also served as a judge advocate in the U.S. Army Reserves, retiring as lieutenant colonel in 1964. Reposing at Ralph Aievoli & Son, Inc., 1275 65 Street, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, IRVING
description: GOLDBERG-Irving. Beloved husband of the late Pearl. Adored father of Barbara Bloomenstein and Martin, Arthur & Hedy, and Herb. Loving grandfather of Adam and Julie, Jill and Alan, Marc and Charina, Shari, Mia, Mindy and David, and Sari. Greatgrandfather of Leah-Perle, Stefan, Allison, Zachary and Lindsay. Brother of Louis. Founder and Honorary President of Utopia Jewish Center. Services Friday, 10AM, at Utopia Jewish Center, 65th Avenue and Utopia Parkway.

title: New Jersey Man Accused In Plot to Bilk Churches
description: Prosecutors in Manhattan have charged a New Jersey man with impersonating a disabled motorist in order to steal money from clergy members around the country.

title: Lehman Reports Rise in Earnings
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose 30 percent in the latest quarter, exceeding expectations, led by fees from advising on corporate mergers and other investment banking services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, HELEN
description: SCHINDLER-Helen. On March 24th, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Herbert, loving aunt of Peter, Marianne and family, and Susan and Gary. Dear cousin of Molly. Graveside service Thursday 1 PM, Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, New York.

title: Too Many Temptations
description: To the Editor:

title: CLINTON DECLARES U.S., WITH WORLD, FAILED RWANDANS
description: President Clinton came here today to talk to scarred and mutilated survivors of the 1994 genocide in Rwanda and to acknowledge that the world could have protected them, though it did not.

title: Violinist Takes Sibelius for a Dynamic Ride
description: There is a degree to which the differences between insight and eccentricity, brilliant showmanship and cheap trickery, and originality and perversity are matters of a listener's disposition and flexibility. For this listener, Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg's account of the Sibelius Violin Concerto with the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening was off the meter in terms of idiosyncratic posturing (both physical and musical), pointless effects and sheer violence to the score.

title: Town Recalls 4 Carefree Little Girls, Preoccupied by Things of Youth
description: ''Sweet.'' ''Polite.'' ''Loved 'Titanic.' ''

title: Power Deregulation: Shadow, Substance and Politics
description: The Clinton Administration presented guidelines yesterday as to how it would like to see the utility industry deregulated, including an innovative way for consumers to easily compare deals offered by rival sellers of power. But it's unclear whether the proposals will help expedite the process of dismantling the economy's last major regulated monopoly.

title: A Healthy Olazabal Returns to Form
description: Few people ask Jose Maria Olazabal about his health anymore. His golf game is strong. The pain in his feet, which threatened his career two years ago, has subsided. And as he prepared for the Players Championship, which begins Thursday at the Tournament Players Club at the Sawgrass Stadium Course, Olazabal was enjoying his return to form as one of the world's top players.

title: Guess Who's Going On Line
description: THE E-mail was brief, but for the loose group of Webheads who subscribe to a list where it was posted recently, no further explanation was required. They could identify.

title: Female Bonding Over Cigars
description: ''If you want to play the boys' game,'' STAR JONES was saying, ''you've got to smoke their cigars, drink their Scotch and play their golf.''

title: Turf; A Family Leapfrogs Its Way Into a Mansion (Luck Helps)
description: THIS is the saga of a hard-working, very smart, very personable couple who started out with a $45,000 one-bedroom wreck and within a decade and a half managed to buy one of New York City's few remaining mansions to live in with their sons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, VIOLA W., M.D.
description: BERNARD-Viola W., M.D. Louise Wise Services for Children and Families deeply mourns the loss of our distinguished Honorary Board Member, Dr. Viola Bernard. She was our esteemed colleague, teacher and friend. Dr. Bernard served on the Board for fifty years and was our Chief Psychiatric Consultant for nearly forty years. Her dedication and concern for the needs of children in crisis formed the foundation of Louise Wise Services' mission. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Glenna R. Michaels, President Carl Mazza, Acting Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWIGG, SMITH, LAILA
description: TWIGG-SMITH-Laila. The Board of Trustees and staff at the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sadness the passing of our beloved friend and member of the Museum's National and Painting & Sculpture Committees, Laila Twigg-Smith. She will be warmly remembered for her steadfast support of American artists and her dedication to furthering the welfare and progress of contemporary American art. We extend our deepest condolences to her son, Cade. Flora M. Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Gilbert C. Maurer, President David A. Ross, Director

title: Metro Business; Tenants for 55 Broad Street
description: Three food retailers have signed agreements to occupy the ground floor of 55 Broad Street, a building in lower Manhattan that is noted for its high-speed computer connections and preference for new-media tenants.

title: U.S. Fails to Get Firmer Yugoslav Sanctions
description: The United States failed to obtain backing today for new sanctions to punish Yugoslavia for its violent crackdown in Kosovo Province, but Washington did receive a promise from Moscow that Russia would support a United Nations resolution for a comprehensive arms embargo on the Government of President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Union Pacific Halts Some Traffic to Mexico
description: As shippers see it, this is the Union Pacific campaign to repeal the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Leniency Possible if Nichols Helps Inquiry
description: A Federal judge who will sentence Terry L. Nichols in the Oklahoma City bombing said today that he would consider some leniency if Mr. Nichols helped the Government learn more about the conspiracy.

title: Rare Sibelius Tone Poems
description: Finnish music, particularly that of Sibelius, has invaded New York's musical life this season, and both audiences and ensembles appear to have capitulated without complaint.

title: Prophecy Is Retracted as God Fails to Appear
description: After God did not appear on television as predicted, a religious leader said today that his second prophecy -- that God would soon appear in this Dallas suburb -- should be treated as ''nonsense.''

title: Albany's Open Budget Talks Make History in Fits and Starts
description: The Legislature today convened the first conference committee in history on a state budget, a mechanism long taken for granted in Congress and other state capitals, but hailed here as a stunning sign of openness and change that had lawmakers grasping for new synonyms for ''historic.''

title: Yoshii Is Waiting for Mets' Decision
description: His English is still in its formative stages. But that did not prevent the Japanese newcomer from conveying how he felt.

title: Is That Machine After Your Job?; Institutional Change
description: To the Editor:

title: To Telecom Industry's Delight, Mobile Phones Are Talk of Finland's Towns
description: HELSINKI  For a people reputed to be taciturn, the Finns are doing a lot of talking these days  on mobile phones.

title: Six Leaders In East Africa Agree to Build Democracies
description: After a three-hour meeting at a lakeside hotel here, President Clinton secured a commitment from six East African leaders today to work toward building more democratic governments in their countries and to prevent genocide in this strife-torn region.

title: Bridge; Partnerships Come and Go
description: One great partnership ended at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here this week while another was revived. Bob Hamman and Bob Wolff, who have won nine world titles as partners in the last 26 years, played their last session together on Tuesday night when their team, the top-seeded group led by Nick Nickell, was upset in the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAR, GEORGE A.
description: HAAR-George A. On March 25, 1998, of Cliffside Park and West End, NJ, formerly of Fairlawn, NJ, of an intracerebral hemorrhage. Adored husband of Arline (nee Goldberg), loving and devoted father of Geoffrey and Jane, Robert and Beth, Gary and Natalie, and Marc (deceased). Cherished granfather of Alison, Joshua, Jonathan, Jamie, Justin, Adam, and Marc, beloved brother of Frances Yeston and Murray Haar. George was CEO of JH Haar & Sons, of Kearny, NJ. George was a member of The Board of Overseers of the Rabbinical School of The Jewish Theological Seminary, member of the Chancellors Counsel of The Jewish Theological Seminary, member of the Board of Directors of The Fort Lee Jewish Center, Co-Chairman of Religious Affairs Committee of The Fort Lee Jewish Center, Past President of The Fairlawn Jewish Center, Past Present of The Mens Progress Clus, Past Master of Beth-El Masonic Lodge, member of The Fort Lee Jewish Center, Fairlawn Jewish Center, Temple Beth-El, Oakhurst, NJ. He endowed many scholarships for Camp Ramah in the Berkshires. He was a major contributor to the Gerard Berman Day School. He supported The Solomon Schecter Day School in Bergen County, The Founders Circle of Hadassah, endowed the Marc Steven Haar Retreat at The Rabbinical & Cantoral School of The Jewish Theological Seminary, he was a member of The Board of Directors of The Federation of North Jersey to The Jewish Museum. Funeral service will be Thursday, March 26th at 12 noon at The Fairlawn Jewish Center, 1010 Norman Avenue, Fairlawn. Contributions in George's memory may be made to The Marc Steven Haar Foundation, 849 Newark Turnpike, P.O. Box 524, Kearny, New Jersey 07032.

title: Stunned Residents Find Solace in Act of Heroism
description: Just back from lunch in the cafeteria of the Westside Middle School in Jonesboro, Ark., Shannon Wright was calling her sixth-grade English class to order when the fire alarm sounded early Tuesday afternoon.

title: FSI WORKERS ASKED TO TAKE OFF 10 DAYS TO CUT COSTS
description: FSI International Inc. of Chaska, Minn., said yesterday that it had asked all employees to take 10 furlough days sometime during the fiscal year ending in August to cut costs. FSI, whose products are used to make semiconductors, computer-chip modules and flat-panel displays, also said that it had cut its capital spending plans for 1998 to less than $10 million from as much as $15 million. FSI reported that in the fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28, sales fell to $124.3 million from $127.1 million in the quarter a year ago because of weakness in the microelectronics market and order delays.

title: Teen-Age Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, NORMAN
description: LEVINE-Norman. Beloved husband of Mary. Proud and adoring father of Judith Levine, Alice and Richard Baxter, Susan and Laurence Rosen and grandfather of Raphael, Jonah, Elie, Gwendolyn and Sarah. Services today, 12:30 at United Hebrew Community, 201 East Broadway, New York City.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN RALLIES. The yen rose on rumors that Japan's central bank would sell dollars and on reports of unexpected increases in Japanese Government spending. In New York, the dollar cost 128.73 yen, down from 130.28.

title: Puerto Rico Statehood
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A background article and a chart on Tuesday about Bertelsmann A.G.'s agreement to buy Random House referred imprecisely to the American publisher's origins. Random House traces them to 1925, when Bennett Cerf and Donald Klopfer acquired another publisher, the Modern Library. The name Random House first appeared in 1927, not 1925. Mr. Cerf and Mr. Klopfer did not set up shop as the Modern Library in 1923.

title: Credibility of Brawley Case Witness Attacked
description: A witness in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial who had testified that he thought Ms. Brawley fabricated her story endured a withering cross-examination today after jurors were shown a televised interview in which he characterized the Rev. Al Sharpton with an expletive.

title: Is This Terrapins' Season?
description: Will this season see Maryland gain the summit of a national lacrosse championship, which has eluded the Terrapins for so long? Coach Dick Edell knows what it is like to come close and miss. Last May 26 in the Terrapins' Byrd Stadium, they lost to Princeton, 19-7, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I final. In the 1995 final at the same stadium, Maryland lost to Syracuse, 13-9.

title: Remarks by Packers' White Draw Criticism in Wisconsin
description: Reggie White, the star defensive lineman of the Green Bay Packers, drew sharp criticism from some state legislators today after his remarks concerning a range of racial and ethnic groups in an off-the-cuff talk before the State Assembly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, REV. JAMES LAWRENCE BASIL
description: WILLIAMS-Rev. James Lawrence Basil, a retired Episcopal clergyman, died Mar. 21, 1998, in Palm Beach, FL. He was 84. He is survived by a daughter, actress Judith Barcroft Washam of N.Y., NY, and a son, Ian R.D. Williams, a lawyer in White Post, VA., and four grandchildren, Ian Washam, Amy Washam, Ashton Williams and Anne Williams. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church in Upperville, VA., at 3:00 PM on Saturday, March 28, 1998. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made to the Bethel Memorial Association, P.O. Box 109, Millwood, VA. 22646.

title: APRIA HEALTHCARE SHARES PLUNGE AS A PACT FALTERS
description: The shares of Apria Healthcare Group fell after it said that an investor group had pulled out of an agreement to provide it with $172 million in new financing. Apria said late on Tuesday that it was suing the group, headed by Joseph Littlejohn & Levy, contending that it had refused to meet the terms of a recapitalization agreement. The company lost $273 million last year. Like other home health care providers, it has been hurt as health insurers and the Federal Government have cut fees. Shares of Apria, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., fell $2.3125, to $8.875.

title: Only the Early and the Rare
description: When large groups of wind players get together, it must be hard to stop them from playing Mozart. But the Chamber Music Society imaginatively resisted that natural tendency on Sunday afternoon and had its own wind soloists join the Ensemble Wien-Berlin, a quintet made up largely of past and present members of the Vienna and Berlin Philharmonics, in early Beethoven and a rare work by Georges Enesco.

title: Making Books; Much Rumbling About a Merger
description: News of the imminent merger of Random House with Bantam Doubleday Dell stunned everybody in the very staid book publishing world on Monday for about 15 minutes before self-interest took over and everyone started asking, ''What's in it for me?'' Or, more precisely, ''What's not in it for me?''

title: Giuliani Sues To Block Police Board
description: In the continuing battle inside City Hall over how the city should investigate police corruption, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sued the City Council yesterday to prevent the creation of an independent police review board.

title: Strong Home Sales Report Pushes Price of 30-Year Issue Down
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday after a stronger-than-expected home sales report for February raised investors' concerns about how long the Federal Reserve could refrain from raising interest rates.

title: Sports of The Times; Great One Not Enough For Rangers
description: IT'S one of the oldest truths in sports:

title: Corrections
description: A chart with the stock tables in Business Day on Thursdays, showing the ratio of put options to call options on the Standard & Poor's 100-stock index, has carried erroneous figures for the last four weeks. A corrected version appears today on page D8.

title: RAYOVAC TO CLOSE 2 PLANTS AND EXPAND BATTERY OUTPUT
description: The Rayovac Corporation said yesterday that it would close two plants, consolidate operations at three sites and expand output of alkaline batteries, which make up 90 percent of the market. Rayovac, based in Madison, Wis., makes batteries used in flashlights, toys and portable electronic devices. Its shares rose $1.1875, to $22.1875. Rayovac said it would consolidate its manufacturing and packaging at three plants in Wisconsin, closing one Wisconsin plant and one in Britain. It expects to eliminate 60 jobs and has hired a service to help dismissed employees find work. The moves will cost $9.5 million initially.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, K.B.
description: WEISSMAN-K.B. A devoted and loyal Trustee of the Optometric Center of NY & of SUNY College of Optometry, K.B. Weissman was a staunch advocate of care for the needy and underprivileged. For more than 3 decades, Ben constantly proselytized for better care for children, particularly those who were poor and who lacked access to professional services. Always interested in young people who were students and future professionals, he helped countless hundreds through his generosity and unfailing commitment to their needs. The Board of Trustees of the Optometric Center of New York, of which he was for many years an officer and former president, extend to the members of the Weissman family, indeed, to his multitude of friends and colleagues, profound condolences on this unhappy occasion. He lived a long, productive and fruitful life by understanding, by giving and by loyalty. Dr. Alden N. Haffner, President, SUNY College of Optometry Mr. Thomas A. Farrell, President, Board of Trustees, Optometric Center of New York

title: Official Stamps of Approval for the Euro Plan
description: The European Commission officially recommended today that 11 countries, including Italy, be allowed to join Europe's new single currency plan next year.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Metro Business; Columbia University Debt Rating Is Raised
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday that it had upgraded Columbia University's debt rating one notch from AA+ to AAA because the school has become more competitive, expanded its endowment, and maintained its reputation as a major research center.

title: Latino Culture Whirls Onto Center Stage; Even as They Capture the Spotlight, Performers Question Their Identity
description: On a recent evening in the heart of Broadway, the infectious polyrhythms of salsa wafted over the knots of exhilarated theatergoers emerging from ''Freak,'' the one-man show by John Leguizamo, a Colombian-American actor who has been packing the Cort Theater.

title: Chess Rivals That Coach as They Vanquish
description: WHEN the world chess champion Garry Kasparov lost a six-game match to I.B.M.'s Deep Blue computer last year, it was not the first time he had been bested by a silicon-powered opponent. Three years earlier, he had been knocked out of an elimination tournament by Genius 2, a software program that ran on an ordinary PC and was widely available in computer stores.

title: ASCEND SHARES GAIN ON CONTRACT WITH BRITISH TELECOM
description: Ascend Communications Inc. of Alameda, Calif., said yesterday that it had signed a contract with British Telecom P.L.C. and expected to sell more networking equipment to the telecommunications giant. Ascend shares rose $1.4375, to $36.25, in trading of almost 16.1 million shares. The company, whose switches and remote access concentrators link computers to corporate networks and the Internet, said it had sold British Telecom 50 of its MAX 4000 switches. It did not disclose the value of the order. The market for that equipment is worth around $1 billion a year and is expected to double in the next few years as phone companies and Internet service providers expand networks.

title: Betsey Cushing Whitney Is Dead at 89
description: Betsey Cushing Roosevelt Whitney, the widow of John Hay (Jock) Whitney, the first wife of James Roosevelt and the last of the three glamorous Cushing sisters of Boston, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y. She was 89.

title: Irabu May Still Be a Puzzle, But Yankees Are Fit to Go
description: Life is good for Joe Torre. The Yankees' manager is healthy, his lineup is producing runs at a shocking rate and the Cuban defector Orlando Hernandez looks great. Torre's only real worry is whether his No. 5 starter, Hideki Irabu, will be ready to pitch the first week of the season.

title: E. V. Lipman Sr., 87, Manager In Long Career at Ocean Spray
description: Edward V. Lipman Sr., whose career at Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc. spanned 51 years, died on March 13 at his home in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 87.

title: Personal Shopper; The Wonders of Whatnots
description: THE Victorians called them whatnots. They are still popular for displaying this, that and whatnot, without taking up table space. And they don't have to hang at picture height. Lower on the wall, they make small end tables, night stands or perches for phones.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FALCO, LOUIS
description: FALCO-Louis, 1993. Your love, courage & inspiration are forever in our hearts. Appreciation for the legacy you leave behind in dance, theatre and art is ever present. God Bless You Always.

title: Free the Bartenders?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEIMSIDER, GERTRUDE
description: LEIMSIDER-Gertrude. It is one year since we lost our mother and best friend. You are in our thoughts, our hearts, and our souls. Love, Jeffrey, Shelly and Elaine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, JACK M.
description: GRAY-Jack M. Age 68, on March 18, in Spartanburg, S.C. Formerly of NYC. Beloved husband of Mary Gray, and loving father of Patricia and Jonathan. He will be greatly missed. Services private.

title: Hartford Moves To Limit Funds For Campaigns
description: While Congress has faltered in overhauling campaign finance laws, Democratic and Republican state legislative leaders here are moving rapidly to make Connecticut one of two states to end a practice by which national political parties funnel millions of dollars into state races.

title: One Suspect, 13, 'Had a Lot of Killing to Do' : Deadly School Attack Stuns Arkansas City
description: Residents of the small Arkansas city of Jonesboro were struggling Wednesday with the shock of the bloody ambush killings of four young students and a teacher by a 13-year-old boy and his 11-year-old cousin outside a middle school.

title: Pleased Yet Wary, U.S. Offers Gestures Of Support for Iran
description: After five years of demonizing Iran, the Clinton Administration is searching for small gestures of reconciliation and is responding, however slowly, to the leadership of President Mohammad Khatami of Iran.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUSON, SYDNEY
description: GRUSON-Sydney. A memorial gathering to celebrate the life of Sydney Gruson, a former executive of The New York Times Company, who died on March 8, will be held at 11 A.M., March 26 in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Those attending are asked to use the museum's main entrance at 82nd Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: New Moves at Architecture Magazine
description: ARCHITECTURE magazine has announced the appointment of Reed Kroloff, 37, as editor in chief. And on April 6, the magazine, which has a circulation of 85,000, will also move its editorial offices to the Viacom Building on Times Square from the Dupont Circle neighborhood in Washington. Both announcements were made by Stephen Donohue, Architecture's publisher.

title: This Time All Women, No Spiders
description: Entering the Intar theater for Manuel Puig's ''Mystery of the Rose Bouquet,'' the audience encounters a woman asleep in a hospital bed. As the play begins, a nurse arrives, changes the flowers in a vase and is about to filch some sleeping pills from a night stand when the patient awakes. It is quickly established that the woman, identified only as the Patient, has been depressed since the death of her grandson 14 months ago and has been hospitalized for a nervous condition. We soon learn, of course, that she is as strong as a horse.

title: His Parents' Pain Inspires Cota
description: Sometime on Saturday night, Ed Cota will temporarily divert his attention from North Carolina's pre-game drills to gaze into the throng of fans at the Alamodome in San Antonio and locate his stepfather's wheelchair. It is a warm yet tragic sight that Cota has turned into supreme motivation. There is nothing in basketball that can faze Cota once he thinks about what the man he calls Dad encounters every day. The experience has also defined the son.

title: Is That Machine After Your Job?
description: To the Editor:

title: Settlement Closer in Suit On Crown Heights Melee
description: Major progress has been made in efforts to settle a suit that Hasidic residents of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, have brought against the city over its handling of the 1991 racial disturbances there, lawyers and community leaders said yesterday.

title: Monica Lewinsky's Mother Fails in Bid to End Testimony
description: Marcia Lewis, Monica S. Lewinsky's mother, whose painful ordeal before a Federal grand jury last month provoked sympathy from millions of Americans and criticism of the prosecutorial tactics of the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr, failed today in a plea to be excused from further testimony.

title: Record Momentum Wanes, With Dow Retreating 31.64
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, having charged to record after record for weeks now, stumbled yesterday.

title: A Grieving, Shattered Town Asks, Who Are These Boys?
description: As a town tries to comprehend how two boys could decide to shoot their classmates, law-enforcement authorities are trying to understand how they could have carried out such an attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, HERBERT
description: MENDELSON-Herbert. My first friend, my friend for life. It is impossible for me to accept your untimely death. You were always there for my needs. What pleasure and joy you took in my successes. What wisdom and support you gave me when my life was not so kind. Was there anyone smarter with advice and direction about life? In 40 years of friendship there was not a single harsh thought between us. I am going to miss the dialogue we had; our golf games, the banter, the drinks we shared and the never ending shtick between us. Herbie, I am going to miss you very much. To Joanie and your family, my love and my thoughts are with you. Don Zacharia Christina Zacharia

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHR, DONALD
description: MOHR-Donald. Temple Beth Torah, Westbury, New York, mourns the loss of our beloved member. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Esther and children Ian and Pamela. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Michael Katz Ivan Ziegler, Pres.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LEAR CORP., Southfield, Mich., a maker of automobile seats and interior systems, agreed to acquire two A. W. Chapman units of the British auto parts maker Rodd Group Ltd. Terms were not disclosed.

title: INSIDE
description: Reprieve for Yugoslavia

title: Hobbled Van Horn Handles Coleman
description: Late in the third quarter, Keith Van Horn emerged from a crowd under the basket, limping badly, and John Calipari's heart sank. Van Horn hobbled to the bench, and then to the locker room. As he walked through the tunnel, the Nets began to wonder if he was taking their playoff hopes with him.

title: Japan Banks Grant Indonesians Debt Delay
description: Ten of Japan's biggest banks have agreed to a plan to allow Indonesian companies to delay the repayment of the principal on their loans for six months, according to an official from one of the Japanese banks. Under the plan, the central bank, Bank Indonesia, will subsidize the exchange rate for companies with foreign debts, the official said.

title: Economic Scene; In the economy's success, don't forget somy lucky breaks.
description: NO ONE can argue with a straight face that the American economy is damaged or even threatened by what happened to oil this week. Sure, the producing countries announced that they intended to cut production. And in response, oil prices jumped for a day. They might even go a bit higher. But oil is still remarkably cheap, clearly a break for the national economy.

title: PSA Peugeot Shares Rise On Outlook for Profit
description: Shares of PSA Peugeot Citroen jumped yesterday after the company, France's biggest car maker, said it would report a profit this year and pay a dividend after losing 2.77 billion francs ($454 million) in 1997. Shares climbed 97 francs, to 1,070.

title: NCO GROUP TO ACQUIRE FCA INTERNATIONAL FOR $68 MILLION
description: NCO Group Inc., an accounts receivable management company in Fort Washington, Pa., agreed to buy FCA International Ltd. for $68 million. FCA provides accounts receivable management services through its offices in the United States, Canada and Britain. ''The combined company will be a dominant force in the United States and Canadian markets, and the European presence will allow us to provide a wider array of services,'' said Michael J. Barrist, NCO chairman and chief executive. Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd., which holds about 27 percent of FCA shares, has agreed to sell its shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLANSKY, RUTH
description: KAPLANSKY-Ruth. Family and friends mourn the passing of a righteous and devoted wife, cherished mother and loving grandmother who dedicated her life to her family. She was a pillar of strength and demonstrated committment to life each and every day. She is survived by a loving husband of 59 years, Phillip. Beloved mother of Melvin, Alan and Steven, daughter-in-law Joanne, grandmother of Jonathan, Mandy, Harris and Marin. A loyal retired public servant of the City of New York will remain in our hearts forever. Shiva will be held at the family home in Queens. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Simon Wiesenthal Center, 9760 W Pico Blvd, L.A., CA 90035.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREWSTER, MARY SANFORD
description: BREWSTER-Mary Sanford. LaGrange, NY, Wednesday, March 25, 1998. Mother of King Smith Brewster, John Sanford Brewster, Joy Sprague Brewster, Sharon (Sari) Brewster Tietjen, grandmother of 8, great grandmother of 4. Private funeral services will be held for family members. Burial will also be private. There will be no calling hours. Memorials may be made to Thompson House, PO Box 514, Rhinebeck, NY 12572.

title: Helms Vows To Make War On U.N. Court
description: A day after President Clinton, moved by his meeting with survivors of the frenzy of killing in Rwanda, endorsed a permanent international criminal court to deal with such crimes, Senator Jesse Helms vowed that the tribunal would be ''dead on arrival'' in the Senate unless Washington wields veto power over it.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Balancing Costs and Benefits of Highway Improvements
description: AMONG the throng of lobbyists on the $214 billion transportation bill making its way through Congress, those representing road builders argue that the bill should pass because every $100 million spent on safer roads will save 145 lives over 10 years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the grand jury investigation of Monica S. Lewinsky's activities referred incorrectly to Jodie Torkelson, a witness who appeared before it on Wednesday. She is a senior adviser at the Voice of America, no longer the White House director of management and administration.

title: Treasury Prices Fall on Concern in Advance of Fed Meeting
description: Treasury securities prices were lower yesterday, weighed down by new supply and market uneasiness ahead of next week's Federal Reserve meeting on monetary policy.

title: A Store Owner Pleads Guilty To Transporting Fetuses Illegally
description: The owner of a SoHo boutique specializing in the sale of animal and human bones pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to illegally selling remains of endangered species and transporting human fetuses.

title: New Video Releases
description: Mr. Bean

title: Intel's Chief Steps Down After 11 Years
description: Andrew S. Grove, a founding father of the personal computer industry, is stepping aside as the chief executive of the Intel Corporation, the company announced yesterday.

title: G.O.P. Defections Delay House Vote On Campaign Bill
description: House Republican leaders today decided to put off a vote on campaign finance legislation after days of behind-the-scenes maneuvering left them short of the support they needed to kill a bipartisan plan to rewrite the nation's fund-raising rules.

title: Fiery Uprising Kills 8 Detainees in Camp And a Police Officer : Crackdown In Malaysia Sets Off Riot By Illegals
description: SEMENYIH, Malaysia  Nine people were killed Thursday as hundreds of illegal Indonesian immigrants rebelled at a detention camp here hours before they were to be deported across the Strait of Malacca.

title: Sports of The Times; Every Wager Only Hastens Next Scandal
description: IT sure is terrible about gambling on college basketball. I was thinking about that yesterday while waiting in line to buy the newspapers. The man in front of me was taking many minutes to select a wad of lottery tickets that I'm not sure he could really afford.

title: Paul Oberkotter, 93, Top U.P.S. Executive
description: Paul Oberkotter, a former chief executive of the United Parcel Service, died on March 16 at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, IRA, PH.D.
description: KATZ-Ira, Ph.D. Friends and colleagues mourn the passing of Dr. Ira Katz, age 64, on March 24 in West Long Branch, NJ. Our friend was retired as Vice President and Director of Research and Development for International Flavors & Fragrances, where he was employed for 30 years. He was the beloved husband of Loretta and a devoted father to Andrew, Eric and Barbara. He was the loving brother of Barry Katz and Elaine Snyder and was blessed with two grandsons, Alexander and Jason. Services are March 27 at 10 am at the Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Funeral Chapel in Ocean Township, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Congregation B'nai Sholom, 213 Lenox Ave, Long Branch, NJ 07740 or the Muscular Dystrophy Association, 1049 Broadway, West Long Branch, NJ 07764. This extraordinary man will be dearly missed by all who knew him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ROSE KEATS (NEE KUMMEL)
description: MILLER-Rose Keats (nee Kummel). Of Verona, N.J. On March 26, 1998. Beloved wife of Dr. Herbert Miller. Devoted mother of Philip Keats, Robert Keats, Elizabeth Ann Keats and Anthony Keats. Dear sister of Eugene Kummel and Bertram Kummel. Loving grandmother of Daniel, Andrew, Matthew and Sandra. Funeral services at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, South Orange Ave, Short Hills, New Jersey, 1:30PM on Friday, March 27. Interment B'nai Abraham Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Rose Kummel Keats Miller Scholarship Fund, Smith College, Attn Development Office, Northampton, MA. 01063.

title: Japanese Party Backs $124 Billion Economic Plan
description: After hemming and hawing and hinting for weeks, the dominant Liberal Democratic Party today approved a package valued at $124 billion intended to spur the foundering Japanese economy and reduce the risk that Japan will set off a global economic slowdown.

title: JOHNS MANVILLE DIVESTING ITSELF OF LAST MINE INTEREST
description: The Johns Manville Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its royalty on the Stillwater Mining Complex in Montana to the Franco-Nevada Mining Corporation for $36 million. Johns Manville, the Denver-based maker of insulation and building products, said the 5 percent Stillwater royalty was its last mining interest. In 1995, Johns Manville sold its majority stake in Stillwater, which produces platinum and related metals. The Stillwater mine is expected to produce about 500,000 ounces of platinum and palladium this year. Franco-Nevada, based in Toronto, said the mine is the only significant source of platinum group metals outside of South Africa and Russia.

title: Democrats, for a Second Time, Block Tax Break for School Costs
description: For the second time in a week, Senate Democrats succeeded in blocking action on a cornerstone Republican education proposal that would offer tax breaks for public and private school costs.

title: Morgan Stanley's Income Increases 21% in Quarter
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company said yesterday that net income for the quarter ended Feb. 28 increased 21 percent, to $691 million, or $1.10 a fully diluted share.

title: Top Conservative Jumps Parties to Take On Quebec Separatists
description: Canada's long struggle to stay united took an unusual turn today as one of the country's most prominent politicians switched parties so he could spearhead an effort to defeat Quebec separatists in coming provincial elections.

title: Winded Larceny Suspect No Match for Marathoner
description: After 72 marathons, running after a shoplifting suspect was a challenge Tom Hart could not resist. But it was not much of a race.

title: AMERICOLD TO ACQUIRE FREEZER SERVICES FOR $112 MILLION
description: Vornado Realty Trust said its Americold Corporation unit had agreed to buy the assets of the closely held Freezer Services Inc. for $112 million in cash to expand in the Midwest. It will also assume $22 million in debt. Americold, which provides services and refrigerated warehouse space to the frozen food industry, is owned jointly by two real estate investment trusts, Vornado and the Crescent Real Estate Equities Company. Vornado said Americold would acquire nine cold-storage warehouses in central United States markets not now served by the company. Americold, based in Portland, Ore., reported sales of $310 million in 1997. It has 49 warehouses in 17 states. Vornado, based in Saddle Brook, N.J., owns 60 percent of the venture.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PHARMACEUTICAL RESOURCES INC., Spring Valley, N.Y., said Lipha Americas, a unit of the German pharmaceutical company Merck K.G.a.A., would buy 10.4 million newly issued Pharmaceutical Resources shares for $2 a share in cash.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: New Top Executive For Mesa Air Group
description: Mesa Air Group Inc. named a former airline executive, Jonathan Ornstein, to succeed its founder, Larry Risley, as chief executive on May 1.

title: Could School Shooting Have Been Prevented?; Hold Gun Owners Liable
description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: 'Titanic' vs. 'Ben-Hur'; Tragedy as Stowaway
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cow Town That Acquired High Culture
description: This is the Mile High City, right? Right. Its National Football League champion Broncos play in Mile High Stadium, right? Right. So Denver must be cradled in the beautiful Rocky Mountains, right?

title: Simplicity In Bronze
description: ''Han bronzes are the Cinderella of the Chinese art world,'' said Michael Goedhuis, a London dealer who is exhibiting 11 bronzes from one tomb in southwest China at the Asian Art Fair. The fair opens today at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, and runs through Wednesday. (Review, page 40.)

title: Take Bach, Add a Twist Of Brazil
description: Villa-Lobos's ''Bachiana Brasiliera'' No. 5 contains one of the most famous melodies in the world yet is rarely performed in concert, mostly because of the difficulty of getting a soprano and eight cellists together in the right place at the right time. On Wednesday evening they were there, at the 92d Street Y, for a concert that was neatly planned to culminate in the Villa-Lobos piece.

title: $48 Million Is Pledged For Foster Care System
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced a plan yesterday to overhaul the state's foster care system through the use of $48 million in state and Federal money over the next three years.

title: At Last, Ex-Prosecutor Addresses Accusers in Brawley Case
description: Addressing his accusers under oath, and in public, for the first time since they branded him a rapist more than a decade ago, Steven A. Pagones took the witness stand in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial today and stated over and over again that he never attacked Ms. Brawley.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jenifer Kobylarz

title: GIULIANI DISMISSES POLICE PROPOSALS BY HIS TASK FORCE
description: With a tone of voice veering from annoyance to sarcasm, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday caustically dismissed most of the recommendations of a task force he appointed last summer to examine relations between New York City's residents and its Police Department, saying that the panel had failed to recognize the department's recent success in reducing crime.

title: Could School Shooting Have Been Prevented?
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Animals and Animal Designs in Chinese Art'

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Holding On To the Dream

title: Close, but Keeping Her Distance
description: Documentary photography is like sharpshooting. What counts is not just what is shot, but how, where, with what weapon and at what distance. Every photographer, Inge Morath explained, has an innate sense of distance. Robert Capa once said, ''If your pictures aren't good enough, you aren't close enough.'' Henri Cartier-Bresson liked four meters between himself and his subjects, she said. Her own favorite distance is four meters, too, ''but sometimes closer and sometimes farther.'' One thing she is certain of: ''I don't zoom.''

title: Crafting Genes Is About Ego, Not Science
description: To the Editor:

title: In the 1800's, a Touch of Class and Crass in Wood
description: Among rich and trendy New Yorkers in the early 1800's, one of the most droppable names in furniture was Charles-Honore Lannuier (1779-1819). A French-born cabinetmaker, he came to the city in 1803 with the flair and gall to pit himself against the titan of the trade, Duncan Phyfe (1768-1854).

title: Lockheed Martin Previews Court Strategy
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation previewed today the strategy that it will probably use to fight the Government's suit to kill the aerospace giant's $12 billion acquisition of the Northrop Grumman Corporation.

title: Genetic Testing Falls Short of Public Embrace
description: If ever there was a perfect person to test for a newly discovered colon cancer gene, it was a 50-year-old Maryland woman named Candace. Colon cancer was in her family: her mother died of it three years ago, at age 82. And a test showed that her brother had inherited the colon cancer gene. That meant Candace might have it, too.

title: Ambition, Manipulation And a Misguided Mother
description: THE PAGE TURNER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESIBIA, EDWARD J.
description: DESIBIA-Edward J., 82. Of 2 South View Drive, Keene, NH died Tuesday at Lee Memorial Hospital in Fort Myers, FL. He was born in New York City, August 12, 1915, the son of John and Grace (Antonucci) Desibia, was raised there and then lived most of his life in River Edge, NJ before moving to Pompton Lakes, NJ for several years & Keene in 1991. Mr. Desibia was employed from 1945 to 1980 as a chauffeur for the New York Times. He was an active member of St. Peters Church in River Edge and was a fourth degree Knights of Columbus. He was a US Marine veteran of World War II serving in the South Pacific and Okinawa. Survivors include his wife of 51 years, Anita (Cipriani) Desibia of Keene, one son, John E. Desibia of Warwick, NY, two daughters, Deborah A. McMahon of Walpole and Phyllis Thrower of Belleview, NE, one sister, Mary Gangi of Bronx, NY, ten grandchildren, seven great grandchildren, nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be conducted at a later date. Burial will be in Friedsam Cemetery in Chesterfield, NH. There will be no calling hours. Contributions may be made in his memory to the NH Heart Fund, 20 Merrimack St, Suite 1, Manchester, NH 03101.

title: No. 50, as in Seasons, Has Seen Them All
description: He played against Mickey Mantle and with Jackie Robinson, Sandy Koufax and the 1962 Mets, managed Dave Winfield and Carl Yastrzemski, watched Bucky Dent's fly ball hit the net above the Green Monster at Fenway Park. And he was there when Charlie Hayes caught the pop-up to end the 1996 World Series.

title: Residential Real Estate; New East Harlem Co-op Is Priced for Wide Range
description: A vacant block along Madison Avenue in East Harlem from 123d to 124th Streets is coming back to life as a cooperative apartment complex designed to be affordable to people with low to upper-middle incomes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLORFEINE, MYRTLE
description: CLORFEINE-Myrtle. Of NY and FL, on Tuesday, March 24. She inspired her family and friends with her indomitable energy and spirit. She will be remembered with great love by her children Susan Grossman and Steve, son-in-law Bernie, grandchildren Jeffrey, Julie, Stacy, their spouses, greatgrandchildren Matthew, Daniel, Michael, Sophie, Josh and Jordan.

title: Dresdner Says '97 Profit Will Be Hard to Sustain
description: Dresdner Bank A.G., Germany's second-largest bank, said yesterday that it would have a difficult time increasing profit growth this year from 1997's 6.8 percent rise amid increasing competition before European currency union. Dresdner's 1997 profit rose to 1.69 billion marks ($920 million) from 1.58 billion a year earlier. (Bloomberg News)

title: St. Petersburg Journal; Russian Woman Sails Solo in a Sea of Cadets
description: Except for peeling paint, little has changed at the Frunze Naval Academy since it was founded by Peter the Great in 1715.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, DONALD
description: JOYCE-Donald. On Tuesday, March 10, 1998, age 45, of cancer. Musician, organist, choir director, teacher. A service will be held on Saturday, March 28, at 1 P.M., at the Church of the Holy Apostles, 9th Ave at 28th St., NYC 10001. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made either to the Organ Fund at the above church or to the Donald Joyce Scholarship Fund at the Copland School of Music, Queens College, Flushing, N.Y. 11367.

title: Sobering News Amid Tourney's Hype
description: From the lobbies of downtown hotels to the steps along the Riverwalk to the Alamodome, the hysteria of the Final Four shifted today to discussions about fixing games after two former Northwestern basketball players were indicted on gambling charges.

title: Ben Bagley, 64; Produced Off Broadway Hits
description: Ben Bagley, who produced several hit Off Broadway revues and a much-admired series of recordings of obscure Broadway songs, died on Saturday at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 64.

title: Senators Ask Microsoft to Ease Data Release
description: In a sign of increasing Congressional scrutiny of the Microsoft Corporation, the Senate Judicary Committee formally asked it yesterday to allow business partners to provide information to the committee without notifying the software maker.

title: Campaign Reform Law; Voting With Shares
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Germs That Are Worth Catching

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURKEVICH, JOHN
description: TURKEVICH-John. The Rev. Professor. Age 91, of Princton University. On March 25, 1998. Husband of the late Ludmilla. Father of Marina T. Naumann and Tamara T. Skvir. Brother of Anthony and Nicholas and grandfather of four. Funeral will be held Sunday, March 29, 7:30 PM, St. Vladimir's Church, Stanton Adeline Street, Trenton, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the United Parkinson Foundation, 833 W. Wash Blvd., Chicago, Illinois 60607.

title: Campaign Reform Law
description: To the Editor:

title: White Rejects Criticism for Remarks
description: Reggie White did not back off yesterday from his remarks in the Wisconsin State Legislature on Wednesday that left some legislators cringing and some activists criticizing him.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday Thurs about ''Mystery of the Rose Bouquet'' at the Intar Hispanic American Arts Center misspelled the surname of a star. She is Doris DiFarnecio, as shown in the credits listing, not DeFarnecio.

title: Bid-Rigging Case Engulfs an Elite Who Built the Interiors of Offices
description: Addressing the elite of New York City's interior construction industry at an awards breakfast earlier this year, Dennis M. Cahill, the publisher of Interiors magazine, made a little joke that hit painfully close to home. He said he would understand if anyone had to leave early to talk with a lawyer about indictments or subpoenas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, SYLVIA GOLD ROTHENBERG
description: ROTHENBERG-Sylvia Gold Rothenberg, age eighty-one. Of Bal Harbour, Florida, passed away on March 24, 1998. Born in New York, Mrs. Rothenberg was a long-time resident of Jersey City, N.J., before moving to Florida. With her husband Artie, she was an active partner in their business which was named for her, the ''Sylvette Shops''. Mrs. Rothenberg was a member of Temple Beth El in Jersey City, the Crestmont Country Club in West Orange, NJ, Hadassah, and the Brandeis University Women's Book Club. Locally she was a Founder of Mount Sinai Medical Center, served on the Board of the Bal Harbour Towers, and was a member of Westview Country Club. Mrs. Rothenberg is survived by her beloved husband Artie to whom she was married for sixtyfour years, children Lois Weiss, Dr. Kenneth Rothenberg, Dr. Trisha Roth, brother and sisters, Artie Gold, Shirley Batherman, Rose Schindelheim, Irma Marantz, Madeline Kesselman, Hermine Gewirtz, Janice Feinson, twelve grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Funeral Services will be held at 11:00 A.M., Friday, March 27, 1998 at the Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 1920 Alton Road, Miami Beach, Florida (305) 531-1151. Donations in Mrs. Rothenberg's memory may be made to a charity of choice.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Crisis in Asia Contributes To Fall in Corporate Profits

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the financier George Soros's investment in a silver mining company referred incorrectly to the financing of the CPM Group, a precious metals research consultant. Financing from silver miners and users goes to sponsor CPM's annual silver survey; the consulting group itself is not directly financed by the industry.

title: Determined to Find Healing In a Good and Decent Place
description: This is a place that has learned to cherish a slow day.

title: PPG DISCLOSES TALKS ON SALE OF 2 EUROPEAN UNITS
description: PPG Industries said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its European automotive and flat glass units to focus on its more profitable North American glass business and other product lines. PPG, based in Pittsburgh, did not disclose the names of interested buyers. Combined, the units have 2,750 employees and $450 million in annual revenue, amounting to about 21 percent of the company's total glass sales of $2.1 billion. PPG said the units, based in France and Italy, were profitable but inconsistent. Earlier this year, the company said it would shutter an unprofitable Georgia plant and sell its stakes in two Chinese ventures amid an oversupply of specialty glass.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about F. Cecil Brenner, a scientist and regulator who developed the national tire safety and performance rating system, cited his educational background incompletely. In addition to a master's degree in chemistry, he received a doctorate in polymer chemistry from Polytechnic University in Brooklyn.

title: M.T.A. Approves Sale of a Bronx Bus Depot to The Post for a Printing Plant
description: Over the protests of officials, community leaders and environmentalists, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to sell a bus depot in the South Bronx to the state, making it available to The New York Post for a printing plant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANCHEZ, JUAN D., SR.
description: SANCHEZ-Juan D., Sr. Of North Brunswick, NJ on March 26, 1998. Retired international banker for Citibank. Husband of Rose Bruno Sanchez, father of Juan D. (Jack) Jr. of North Brunswick, NJ and Eileen Coleman of Pembroke Pines, FL. Also survived by four grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Monday 9:45 AM from the Selover Funeral Home, 555 Georges Rd., North Brunswick, NJ, followed by 10:30 AM mass at Our Lady of Peace RC Church, North Brunswick. Burial in St. Peter's Cemetery, New Brunswick, NJ. Visitation Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When you hear people say, 'It isn't supposed to happen here,' what they're saying is, 'This is not the atmosphere that breeds this sort of violence.' ''

title: On My Mind; Murdered in the Park
description: Every night, after work as a secretary in a Manhattan office, a slender young woman in her 20's took the subway to the Mosholu Parkway station in the Bronx, nearly the end of the line.

title: All Calder, High and Low
description: More than two-thirds of the way through the National Gallery of Art's lavish survey of Alexander Calder's prolific career, a small, little-known work stands out, as much for oddness as visual merit. ''Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man,'' made by the American sculptor in 1947, when he was 49 and well established, is a bright red, upright, three-legged stabile, just under a yard tall. In the prolific flow of Calder's quirky, jovial, yet essentially formalist art, this self-portrait strikes a darker, more personal note.

title: Republicans in a Bind
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, K.B.
description: WEISSMAN-K.B. It is with deep sorrow that we extend our condolences to Edna and Alan on the passing of their dear husband and father. Goodbye dear brother-inlaw. Rest in peace. Mitzi and Fred

title: At Minnesota Public Radio, a Deal Way Above Average
description: Who says good works never pay?

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Stars of Stage And Screen

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEVON, RENEE S.
description: ZEVON-Renee S. On March 25, 1998, age 50. With profound sadness, we mark the passing of our beloved and compassionate friend and mentor. Renee touched us for too short a time, but ever so deeply, with her senses of humanity and of humor and with her zest for life. She was the great communicator and we will miss her terribly. Our greatest love and deepest sympathy to Richard, Elizabeth, Amanda and Michael. Stephanie Mudick David Gottlieb

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Stephen Pace

title: Law Enforcers Link North Korea to Drug Trade : A Pyongyang Connection?
description: BANGKOK  International narcotics specialists and U.S. drug-enforcement officials are increasingly concerned that North Korea may be involved in illegal drug transactions to gain hard currency for its depleted Treasury.

title: A First in Brawley Case
description: Steven A. Pagones, accused of raping Tawana Brawley more than a decade ago and now suing three of her former advisers for defamation of character, addressed his accusers in public for the first time. ''I've never seen Tawana Brawley in my life, except on television,'' he said.

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'Meet the Deedles'

title: Hingis Falls To Surging Williams
description: The 2,000 beads framed her joyful face like a white plastic halo. The fists were in the air with index fingers raised like punctuation marks. The legs performed a modified, modernized hustle step. This was the unsubtle way that Venus Williams, who uses Muhammad Ali as a role model for championship behavior, chose to celebrate today after mowing down the undisputed champion of women's tennis, Martina Hingis, at the Lipton Championships.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Mary Heilmann

title: Battling Gets Nasty as Vote Nears on a Drunken Driving Bill
description: Supporters of tougher drunken driving legislation fanned out across Capitol Hill today, papering Congressional offices with highway crash statistics, searing tales of devastated families and photographs of dead children, smiling and fresh-faced for eternity.

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'Barney's Great Adventure' 'The Movie'

title: From the 60's, Paper Dreams That Reflect the Modern City
description: Celebration, the neo-traditional Florida town created by the Disney Company, is not favored by smart people. But this should not discourage other entertainment companies from getting into the housing business. On the contrary. Virgin Records, for example, could probably build some spectacular neighborhoods. Or so you may think while touring the show at the Thread Waxing Space on the work of Archigram, the British group of architectural visionaries that flourished from 1961-74.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORBIN, LILLIAN M.
description: KORBIN-Lillian M. Died Saturday, March 21, 1998. Lillian, wife of the late Theodore R. Korbin, was born in Springfield, MA., and spent the majority of her life in the Bx., N.Y. She is survived by her nephews Gerald C. McDonald, Robert T. McDonald, and John R. McDonald and several grandnieces and grandnephews. Calling hours Friday, March 27, 2-5 and 7-9 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, March 28, 9:45 AM at the Church of St. Phillip Neri, Bronx.

title: Crafting Genes Is About Ego, Not Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, VIOLA
description: BERNARD-Viola. On March 21, 1998. Viola was one of our most distinguished faculty members. She showed us how the sensitivity and subtlety of a clinician could be brought to bear on problems of the public health. Her strong ethical sense, her personal generosity and her caring involvement, even when she was unwell, were examples to us all. We will miss her greatly. David Shaffer, M.D., on behalf of the staff and faculty of the Division of Child Psychiatry Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, N.Y.

title: State Reports on Film Sponsor's Deficit
