description: An initial review of the financial records of Media Network, once the country's largest nonprofit corporation devoted to fiscal sponsorship of independent films, has determined that the defunct corporation's revenues dropped sharply in 1997 and that its operating deficit ballooned.

title: Could School Shooting Have Been Prevented?; Proper Parenting
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL RISES AGAIN. After a 3.5 percent gain Wednesday, oil rose 2.1 percent to a seven-week high after Norway said it might join other exporters in cutting output. Crude for May delivery rose 35 cents, to $16.83 a barrel in New York.

title: Accounts
description: -- Bates USA West, Irvine, Calif., part of Cordiant Communications Group, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $9 million to $11 million: Wham-O Inc., Torrance, Calif., to handle advertising for the toy company under its new ownership, and Outback Mountainboards, Seattle, to handle advertising for the maker of skateboards, snowboards and surfboards, which had been handled in-house.

title: Stray Signals May Have Had Role in Jet Crash
description: The Boeing 747 that crashed on Guam last August probably picked up stray radio signals that misled the crew into thinking that a navigation beacon was functioning, a senior Federal Aviation Administration expert on navigation testified today.

title: Council Sees More Revenue For the City Than Giuliani
description: Drawing the lines for the battle over the next city budget, City Council leaders predicted yesterday that over the next year and a half, the city would have nearly $1.4 billion more in revenue than was projected by Mayor Rudolph. W. Giuliani.

title: Boston's Defensive Line Goes On the Offensive
description: BRUINS 4, FLYERS 2

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRULL, ALEXANDER
description: STRULL-Alexander, on March 25, 1998. Devoted husband of Ruth (nee Lipetz). Loving father of Judith Strull of Newton, Mass., and Linda Berman of Edina, Minn. Adoring grandfather of Rebecca and Daniel.Dear brother of Arthur, Bob, Sylvia and Pearl.

title: Asian Fair Is Freshened, But Basics Are Honored
description: Markets may crumble; politicians may tumble; but the International Asian Art Fair is here to stay. Or at least that's the impression conveyed by the robust and lavish gathering of some 60 dealers from Europe, Japan, China and the United States, who have set up shop in the Seventh Regiment Armory for a six-day run beginning today.

title: Russia's Deadly Expertise
description: You just got back from your business trip to Europe a few days ago, and this morning you're not feeling well. You've developed a fever and a severe headache, and aspirin doesn't help. Your doctor diagnoses the flu and sends you home to rest. But your condition worsens; by evening, you've developed a nasty cough and you're spitting up some blood. Your doctor changes his diagnosis to pneumonia and prescribes antibiotics, but it's too late. Your cough rapidly worsens, and the next evening you die -- but not before realizing that your family and the friends who stopped by while you were ill have developed fevers and headaches.

title: Catholic-Jewish Panel Meets on Holocaust Document and Agrees to Dig Deeper
description: In sessions that were described as intense, frank and at times profoundly religious, Jewish and Catholic leaders met this week in the wake of the Vatican's much-criticized statement on the Holocaust. They agreed that together, they would dig deeper into the historical record of the period, a move described by a leading American rabbi as ''a significant step.''

title: New Jersey Tackles Geographical Limits For Auto Insurance
description: State lawmakers trying to revamp New Jersey's auto insurance system took up one of the more politically sensitive issues today: redrawing the geographic boundaries used by insurance companies to help set rates.

title: Lo, a Blink From a Green-Eyed Monster
description: Does Iago have a thing for Desdemona? There is the hint of hateful love in Randolph Curtis Rand's fairly faithful production of ''Othello'' at the Salon Theater. Even as he goads Othello into murder, Iago, played here by Al Benditt, contorts his features at the suggestion of revenge on Desdemona for her trumped-up affair with Cassio.

title: Not Knicks Seats, But Not Bad
description: Some fashion designers will be experimenting with color during Fashion Week, which begins on Monday -- not in fabrics, but on the traditionally white walls at the end of their runways. ADAM JANOVIC, who is supplying the paint, maintains that when he suggested a dab of something bright here or a splash of something subdued there, all he really wanted was passes to the shows.

title: United Way Reorganizes
description: In the first move toward an expected wave of consolidations, eight large United Ways in California agreed yesterday to merge back-office operations this year and, later, to coordinate their marketing.

title: Columbia/HCA Names 3 Outside Directors
description: As part of an effort to reshape itself in the wake of a huge Federal investigation, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation named three new outside directors yesterday.

title: Moyers Finds Hope in the Battle Against Addiction
description: If there is such an anomaly as an Enlightenment televangelist, it is Bill Moyers, who brings to his documentaries a preacher's zeal for spreading the gospel of progress. Never has this spirit been more impassioned than in his new series, ''Moyers on Addiction: Close to Home,'' which finds him bearing the good news that addiction can be beaten if society learns to treat it as a disease, not as a moral failing.

title: Defense Lawyer Doubles As Avenging Ghost? O.K.
description: You could spend weeks rewatching Raoul Ruiz's delightful metaphysical comedy ''Genealogies of a Crime,'' and trying to arrange its jigsaw pieces into a coherent puzzle, and perhaps they would all fit. Then again, perhaps they wouldn't. In any case, overanalyzing the ingredients of this labyrinthine fantasy by the Chilean-born French director would be to risk underappreciating its cinematic whimsy. The story of a lawyer named Solange (Catherine Deneuve) who imagines herself the murder victim of the young man she is defending is a droll mock-philosophical inquiry that refuses to take itself too seriously while finding a hundred different ways to ask, what if?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KABAT, DARWIN F.
description: KABAT-Darwin F. Died March 25, 1998. Devoted husband of Henrietta ''Muchie''. Loving father of Richard, Jeff (Cindy) and Jacqueline Brodar. Adored grandfather of Ross, Larry, Andrew and Max. Services Friday, March 27th, 2PM at Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Contrasting Views of the Mayor's Task Force on Police and Community Relations
description: THE MAJORITY REPORT

title: Houston Is Trying to Fit Into Knick Starring Role
description: A burdensome but welcomed role has been thrust upon Allan Houston, one that seems to hang over his slumped shoulders like an oversized suit.

title: The Songs Of the Century
description: ''Finally on video! Pent-up cult demand. A classic,'' reads the recommendation in The Movie Monitor, a tip sheet that alerts dealers to coming titles. Not everyone might agree with that critical appraisal of Ralph Bakshi's ''American Pop,'' to be released on Tuesday by Columbia Tri-Star for the first time on tape. But it is certainly true that the animated film, which appeared in theaters in 1981, has taken a long time getting to the video shelf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, EDNA R.
description: LEVY-Edna R. On March 26, 1998. Retired New York City teacher, P.S. 19M. Beloved wife of the late Seymour W. Levy, cherished mother of Jane Levy, Elizabeth Kaplan, and son-in-law Nathan Kaplan, devoted grandmother of Jonathan, Alexander and Caroline Kaplan. Eldest sister of Olga Menkes and Amalia Pearlman, loving sister-in-law of Clarice Fiestal. Services Sunday, March 29th, 10 A.M., at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: INSIDE
description: Marine Flight Crew Charged

title: In Arkansas Jail, One Boy Cries And the Other Studies the Bible
description: The older boy calmly asked for a Bible and a minister this morning, the local sheriff said, while the younger one cried and pleaded that he ''wants his mama, and he wants to go home now.'' Both asked if they could trade their lunch of corn bread, white beans and baked chicken for a pizza. They were told no.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDBERG, ELAN
description: GOLDBERG-Elan. You are our strength and inspiration and we will love and miss you forever. Mom and Dad

title: In Mixed Day, Dow and S.& P. 500 Dip as Nasdaq Rises
description: The stock market was mixed yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drifting lower while technology stocks and smaller-company stocks sent their key indexes to new highs.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Ex-Northwestern Players Charged in Point-Shaving
description: Federal prosecutors today announced the indictments of two former Northwestern basketball players on charges they took bribes to fix Big Ten games during the 1994-95 season.

title: Metro Business; Tishman Takes Over Site
description: Tishman Speyer Properties, the New York-based development company, said yesterday that it has signed a contract to buy the financial interests of the Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh in the Queens West development on the East River in Long Island City.

title: Torrid Minnesota Wins Title In N.I.T.
description: At first, for much of the time, the basketball was tentative, disorganized and downright sloppy, not what you would expect to see in the final of the 61st annual National Invitation Tournament in Madison Square Garden. Then, Lewis and Clark and friends went on a shooting expedition and led Minnesota (20-15) to a 79-72 victory last night over Penn State (19-13).

title: Metro Business; Old Navy to Open Store on 34th Street
description: Less than a year after the collapse of a deal for a huge Old Navy store at a prominent site on West 34th Street, the clothing chain and the property owner have worked out their differences and construction is scheduled to start this summer, the broker involved in the deal said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORWIN, JOAN
description: CORWIN-Joan. Prayers go out to our sister-in-law, aunt, and friend, Corey Corwin Shafran and her family on the death of their mother, Joan. Eve, Billie, Annah, Andrew, Sammy, Molly, Joshua, Jenny and Kirsten

title: A Tale of Biblical Heft That Plays to the Crowd
description: Handel was both an incomparable genius and a regular Mr. Show Biz. Far from canceling each other out, these qualities combine in bracing ways, at least in Handel's best works, like the 1738 oratorio ''Saul,'' which received an engaging and stylistically informed performance on Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by the Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra, based in San Francisco, and its founding music director, the British conductor Nicholas McGegan.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen rose for a second day after Japan's ruling party approved a $124 billion plan to invigorate the economy. In New York, the dollar cost 128.29 yen, down from 128.73.

title: Catholic Hospital Merger
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEAVY, WILLIAM T., M.D.
description: KEAVY-William T., M.D. The Lenox Hill Hospital family expresses it sorrow at the passing of William T. Keavy, M.D., a distinguished member of our Plastic Surgery staff for twenty-seven years. Dr. Keavy was nationally and internationally renowned for his exceptional skill as a plastic and reconstructive surgeon. Throughout his remarkable career, his deep commitment to his patients and to Lenox Hill Hospital was unwavering. A devoted & gifted educator who took great pleasure in sharing his knowledge and love of surgery with young physicians, Dr. Keavy impressed all who knew him with his kindness, compassion and integrity. Lenox Hill Hospital honors the memory of this truly remarkable physician who exemplified the highest standards of his profession. We extend our deep sympathies to his family and friends. James S. Marcus, Chairman, Board of Trustees Gladys George President and CEO Stephen A. Obstbaum, M.D., President, Medical Board Norman H. Schulman, M.D. Chief, Section of Plastic Surgery

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: When I find myself the only non-Japanese person in a sushi bar, I am almost always of two minds. On the one hand, I feel that I have chosen the right restaurant. On the other, I can't help noticing that the man next to me, the one having the genial chat with the sushi chef, is clearly being offered superior slices of toro. I notice that his hamachi has been more expertly trimmed than mine too.

title: The Ebb and Flow of Reform; Mr. Gingrich Retreats
description: In a brazen repudiation of his own promises, Newt Gingrich has yanked campaign finance reform from the House agenda. The Speaker's action yesterday came after a frantic but fruitless effort by his aides to round up the votes to block genuine reform legislation on the House floor. Mr. Gingrich's allies are now reportedly plotting to reschedule consideration of reform bills next month, but only under rules requiring a two-thirds vote for approval. These desperation tactics are an abuse of power reminiscent of conduct Mr. Gingrich himself deplored for years.

title: Clinton Seeks A Partnership With Africans
description: With President Nelson Mandela as his escort, President Clinton appeared before Parliament here today to describe a ''common promise'' in the American and South African experiences with race and revolution.

title: Isles Overcome Injuries To Surprise Penguins
description: Reeling from recent trades and injuries, the revamped Islanders came up with one of the more surprising victories of their season tonight.

title: Tax Writers Back Limits on Real Estate Trusts
description: The top tax writers in Congress endorsed a version today of President Clinton's proposal to limit the tax benefits of a type of real estate investment trust.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'The Circle Comes Round'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWIGG, SMITH, LAILA
description: TWIGG-SMITH-Laila. Jay Johnson and Alan Wanzenberg, and the entire staff of Jed Johnson & Associates, Inc., and Alan Wanzenberg Architects, P.C. deeply mourn the death of their friend, Laila. Her great passion for life and enthusiasm for art and all things beautiful will be incredibly missed. Her tremendous contribution to the creation of Twin Farms will always be remembered. Our sincerest condolences to her son Cade, and to all her friends, in particular Janet.

title: Miles to Go, and Worlds Apart
description: This year's New Directors/New Films series begins on a fine footing with the two warmly comic, tenderhearted road movies that are tonight's opening features. Not often are the series's first two films as sweetly harmonious as these. Though ''Smoke Signals'' is set in the American West, and the French film ''Western'' unfolds in Brittany, these films share a surprising amount of common ground. Each is a whimsical buddy story; each has a beguiling intimacy, with an emphasis on food, drink and the longing for family connections. Each, for all its seductive coziness, is about travelers who feel like foreigners wherever they go.

title: Largest German Utility Reports Strong Profit
description: Veba A.G., Germany's largest utility, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose a greater-than-expected 16 percent as a stronger dollar and cost-cutting helped increase earnings from oil, transport and trading. Net income rose to 1.43 billion marks ($781 million) from 1.23 billion.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Life With Father, but Think Dickens and Kafka
description: While ''Character'' received this year's Academy Award in the ever-perplexing best foreign film category, it is not the rare film from the Netherlands made with a light touch. (Neither was ''Antonia's Line,'' the Dutch winner two years ago.) Using somber hues, blunt acting and a stark visual style offset by sweeping camera work, it adapts a popular 1938 Dutch novel about a young man's lifelong struggle with a father whose cruel authority borders on the Kafkaesque. The story is long and episodic, but its larger trajectory is not always evident. Something important seems lost in translation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, NENA
description: GOODMAN-Nena. The directors, trustees, staff, and patients of National Jewish Medical and Research Center in Denver wish to express our deepest sympathy to the family of Nena Goodman, who passed away March 19. Mrs. Goodman was the widow of Andrew Goodman. Andrew Goodman's father, Edwin, began the Goodman family's decades-long involvement with National Jewish. Andrew Goodman, who passed away in 1993, chaired the National Jewish Council of National Trustees from 1965-1983. The Goodman building at National Jewish was named in his honor. Andrew and Nena Goodman's son, Edwin A. Goodman, is currently a National Jewish trustee. Nena was a most gracious, kind, and generous friend to National Jewish. Robert L. Mettler, Chairman Council of National Trustees Lynn M. Taussig, M.D., President and CEO

title: Corporations' Profits Fell In 4th Quarter
description: The Asian financial crisis contributed to the first drop in corporate profits in more than a year despite a healthy rate of growth in the economy as a whole, the Commerce Department said today.

title: NCI BUILDING SYSTEMS IN $550 MILLION DEAL FOR RIVAL
description: The metal-building manufacturer NCI Building Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Metal Building Components Inc. from the British industrial company BTR P.L.C. for $550 million. NCI, based in Houston, makes metal building systems, components and roll-up doors. It had annual sales of $407.8 million in 1997. Metal Building, also based in Houston, had revenue last year of $408 million and shareholder's equity of $200 million. Metal Building was the principal remaining unit in the current phase of BTR's divestment program. Last fall, BTR said it would sell noncore assets and concentrate on engineering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRY, LILLIAN PERELMAN
description: BERRY-Lillian Perelman. Beloved wife of George. Devoted mother of JoAnn Perelman Werbel and Cherie Bloom. Loving grandmother of Lee, Julian Perelman and Jeffrey Michael Sachs, Jason and Mark Bloom; great grandmother of Julia and Katherine. Dear sister of Michael and Ben Yaffee, Bernice Rosenstein. Service and interment were held privately.

title: Brookhaven Lab Plans to Clean Up Contaminated Ground Water
description: Brookhaven National Laboratory will start a decadelong project this year to pump out and clean nearly two billion gallons of ground water near a residential neighborhood to remove a toxic contaminant measuring as much as 1,028 times the safe level for drinking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, IRVIN
description: HOROWITZ-Irvin. On March 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Muriel. Loving father of Stuart and Ilene. Cherished grandfather of Elizabeth, Sharon, Amy and ALexander. Service today 11:30 A.M., at ''Riverside-Nassau North'', 55 North Station Plaza (opp LIRR), Great Neck.

title: Love Invades a Proper English Life
description: Medical alert: a certain palsy, thought to have been wiped out decades ago, has resurfaced at the Criterion Center Stage Right. The affliction, which was epidemic in London theaters of the mid-century, arises when strong feelings clash with good breeding, and its victims can always be identified by one conspicuous symptom. That is the twitching stiff upper lip.

title: The March Backward Continues For Rangers
description: Perhaps it is best for the Rangers and their fans that this horrible season ends horridly. Tonight's embarrassing defeat was their fourth loss in their last four games in their backward march from playoff contention.

title: Crafting Genes Is About Ego, Not Science
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 White House Aides Appear Before Starr's Grand Jury
description: Prosecutors brought two mid-level White House aides before a Federal grand jury today, apparently in an effort to learn more about Monica S. Lewinsky's job history at the White House and her visits with President Clinton.

title: Senate Fails to Reverse Ruling That Mexico Is Fighting Drugs
description: The Senate upheld tonight the Clinton Administration's decision last month to certify that the Mexican Government is ''fully cooperating'' with the United States in the fight against drug trafficking.

title: Hilda Morley, 81; Wrote Poetry Shaped by Abstract Expressionism
description: Hilda Morley, an American poet who gained wider recognition late in life, decades after she first published her imagist free verse, died on Monday at Royal Free Hospital in Hampstead, London. A former resident of Sag Harbor, N.Y., she was 81 and had moved to London last year to continue work on a biography of her late husband, the avant-garde composer Stefan Wolpe.

title: Martin Is a Jet All the Way, Parcells Says
description: Bill Parcells said today that Curtis Martin would remain a Jet, and that the team had violated no National Football League rules in luring the star running back from the New England Patriots.

title: Plan Ratified for Mall at L.I.R.R. Terminal
description: After a last-minute dispute with City Hall was resolved, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday approved the renovation of Brooklyn's busiest rail terminal, the combined Long Island Rail Road and subway station at Atlantic Avenue and Flatbush Avenue, and the construction of a large shopping mall above it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROLLINS, JUDITH COLEMAN
description: ROLLINS-Judith Coleman, 57, died March 20th of breast cancer. Educated at Bennington College, Bank Street College and Harvard University. She was the Director of Day Care for New York State, Metropolitan Regional Office. Survivors: children Malikkah and Khari, mother Ruth, brother Jerry. Services will be held March 31st at 2 P.M., at Riverside Church.

title: Church Is Destroyed When Wall Collapses
description: The rear wall of a five-story building in East Harlem crumbled yesterday, destroying a first-floor church and causing 29 people to be evacuated from an adjoining apartment building, the authorities said. No injuries were reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOXER, SARAH
description: BOXER-Sarah. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother, grandmother, great grandmother, sister and aunt. Services at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey, 1:00 P.M., Sunday.

title: COLONEL'S INTERNATIONAL SEEKS MERGER WITH DURAKON
description: Colonel's International Inc. said yesterday that it had proposed a merger with Durakon Industries that it said would make the two companies, which are automotive parts suppliers, more competitive. Colonel's, based in Milan, Mich., said if the companies agreed, Colonel's would offer Durakon holders one share of its own stock for each share of Durakon. Durakon makes light-truck accessories. Colonel's makes automotive and light-truck parts. Colonel's rose $1.25 a share on the Nasdaq stock market, to $9.25, and Durakon, based in Lapeer, Mich., rose 25 cents, to $8.875, before trading in the two issues was halted.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Campaign Reform Law; Unfair to Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Sweaty and Spiritual
description: We've been practicing the tai chi game of push-hands for under a minute when I shove hard at Master Chen's shoulder. It's like leaning against a door with exceptionally well-oiled hinges -- as he bends away there's no resistance, and I nearly stumble forward. ''Good,'' laughs Master Chen, and then he straightens instantly and with a jolt sends me reeling backward. ''But you have to be careful when they come back.''

title: Asylum Pitch: Persecution Or a Curveball
description: HOW improvident it was of Abdirizak Mumin Ibrahim not to learn to play baseball while growing up in Somalia.

title: On Tour With Clinton: Business, Business, Business
description: President Clinton is the undisputed star of the American troupe touring Africa, but there are supporting acts, too.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Bell Canada in Phone Deal
description: Bell Canada International Inc. said today that it had acquired a 68.4 percent stake in the Colombian cellular phone operator Occidente y Caribe Cellular S.A. for about $302.3 million. Bell Canada International said the move would give it more than 50 percent of Colombia's cellular subscribers. Bell Canada International, a unit of BCE Inc., Canada's largest telecommunications company, owns and operates telecommunications systems outside Canada, primarily in Latin America and the Asia Pacific region, concentrating on the wireless sector.

title: Reduce and Stir
description: DAVID GLASS, a baker in Hartford, Conn., is such a SOPHIA LOREN fan that last year he named a new almond cake for her.

title: Could School Shooting Have Been Prevented?; Misogynist Tendencies
description: To the Editor:

title: Continental Gets Brazilian Partner
description: Continental Airlines Inc. and the Brazilian carrier Viaco Aerea Sao Paulo S.A. agreed today to work together to offer flights between the United States and Brazil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADREANI, SERGIO
description: ADREANI-Sergio. Formerly of Manhattan. Died March 25 in Chicago, Illinois. Beloved son of Adele and the late Peter Luigi. Dear brother of Walter (Dee). Fond uncle of Paul, Marc and Lisa. Visitation will be held Friday between 3 and 9 P.M., at Haben Funeral Home, 8057 Niles Center Road, Skokie, Illinois. Funeral Mass on Saturday, 9:30 A.M., at St. Peter Catholic Church, Skokie, Illinois. Entombment St. Joseph Cemetery, River Grove, Illinois. Funeral Home information at 847-673-6111.

title: Guns and Responsibility
description: The schoolyard massacre in Jonesboro, Ark., on Tuesday has prompted talk about the Southern gun culture and how it may have contributed to the tragedy. Yet the societal sickness the shootings exemplify -- children with easy access to guns and ammunition -- is not confined to any one region of the country.

title: Bernard Meltzer, Dispenser Of Advice on Radio, Dies at 81
description: Bernard Meltzer, the folksy foggy-voiced radio personality who built a huge following in the 20 years that he dispensed advice over WOR-AM in New York on virtually every known problem and every conceivable subject, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Manhattan. He was 81 and widely regarded as the father of ''expert talk radio.''

title: 2 Jailed Boys Meet With Juvenile Judge : After the Mayhem, Jonesboro Fights 'Disbelief'
description: Children accompanied by grave and ashen-faced parents returned Thursday to Westside Middle School in Jonesboro, Arkansas, struggling to make sense of the shooting deaths of four classmates and a teacher by two boys aged 11 and 13.

title: Crowding the Runway; Art, Money and Egos Collide During Fashion Week
description: Fern Mallis sits in her midtown office, scrutinizing a large piece of cardboard. It is not a glamorous object, not the stuff that draws drooling camera crews from ''Entertainment Tonight.'' But the giant white board leaning against a wall at the offices of Seventh on Sixth is fashion week's most sacred object: the schedule of all the shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, IRVING
description: GOLDBERG-Irving. Utopia Jewish Center announces with deep regret the passing of one of our founding fathers, Irving Goldberg, ''Mr. Utopia''. May the Almighty comfort the family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Solomon Goldman, Rabbi Henry Major, President

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: MEN
description: MICHIGAN

title: Blue Collars And Miseries By the Sea
description: The cinematography of ''No Looking Back,'' Edward Burns's moody third film, so richly evokes an aching blue-collar melancholy that nothing the characters say and do seems quite as authentic as the drab, wind-scoured place they call home.

title: 2 New Yorkers Among 13 Kidnapped in Colombia
description: Two New York City men who are avid bird-watchers in Central Park and had traveled to Colombia to pursue their hobby were among at least 13 people kidnapped by guerrillas near Bogota on Monday, the Colombian news media reported.

title: $200,000 Bail in Assault Case for Brother of 'Megan's Law' Killer
description: Nine months after his brother Jesse was convicted of murdering Megan Kanka in 1994 and sentenced to death, Paul Timmendequas was brought to court in manacles today to answer charges that he had molested a 15-year-old relative in her bed and sexually assaulted a friend's 12-year-old stepdaughter.

title: Dutch Bar Claim to Art Taken by Nazis
description: The Government of the Netherlands Wednesday rejected a claim by the American heirs of a Jewish art collector to paintings that were acquired by Hermann Goring after the German occupation of the Netherlands in 1940 and that ended up on display in Dutch museums after World War II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEAVY, WILLIAM, M.D.
description: KEAVY-William, M.D. The Lenox Hill Hospital Alumni Association has lost a treasured colleague and friend. Dr. William Keavy, a member of the Section of Plastic Surgery for over 30 years, and an active member of the LHH Alumni Association, was of a spirit that knew only how to give to others. He will be deeply missed by his family, his friends and his colleagues. Peter Bruno, M.D., President LHH Alumni Association Peter Baiocco, M.D., Secretary LHH Alumni Association

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, BERNARD C.
description: MELTZER-Bernard C. On March 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Meredith. Father of Melinda Jacobs, Cynthia Weller, Lesley Silverstein and Michael Meltzer. Grandfather of eight. Brother of Rae Fieldman and Dora Glatter. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday, March 27 at 9:45 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to The National Tuberous Sclerosis Association, 8000 Corporate Drive, Suite 120, Landover, MD 20785.

title: Travels With Kale, Salt and Prosciutto
description: The Four Seasons restaurant does not usually use ingredients that arrive the way these did: in suitcases carried by a visiting chef.

title: Building Linked to Drugs Seized by U.S. Marshals
description: A team of Federal marshals seized control of a 26-unit rooming house yesterday, saying that the building had served as a drug supermarket for the last three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAR, GEORGE
description: HAAR-George. The Jewish Community Center of Fort Lee is profoundly saddened and deeply mourns the passing of an esteemed member of it's Board of Trustees and Co-Chairman of its Ritual Committee. He was a very generous benefactor and guiding light to our Synagogue. George led by example and set the standard for all to follow. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Arline; his children Geoffrey and Jane, Dr. Robert and Beth, Gary and Natalie; his seven grandchildren; his brother Murray and sister Frances. He was a fine, dignified gentleman and leader who will be sorely missed. Steven Kolitch, President Irving Spielman, Rabbi Paul Zim, Cantor Larry Trope, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNTER, EDWARD BRIAN SR.
description: HUNTER-Edward Brian Sr. A distinguished patent attorney with Nolte, Nolte and Hunter in Jericho, L.I. Passed away Wednesday, March 25, 1998 in Thornwood, NY. Survived by wife Loretta, six children, five grandchildren and one sister. Reposing at the Maher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY (914) 769-2044 Saturday and Sunday 2-4PM and 7-9PM. Mass Monday 10:30 AM, at Holy Innocents Church, Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: Another independent turnover: The acclaimed Arnold agency signs a deal with Snyder.
description: FOR the third time in less than two months, a well-regarded, creatively focused independent agency is being acquired as the frenetic Madison Avenue takeover spree keeps going and going and going.

title: 3 Community School Boards Resist Mandatory Uniforms
description: In a direct challenge to the authority of the central Board of Education, three community school boards are resisting the board's policy requiring elementary school children to wear uniforms by the fall of 1999.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, BETSEY CUSHING
description: WHITNEY-Betsey Cushing. We mourn the death of our beloved mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother, Betsey Cushing Whitney, who died on March 25, 1998. Her sense of humor, her determination and her courage will be with us always. Our thanks to all who have communicated their love and support. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held on April 25 at 11AM, Christ Church, Northern Boulevard, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, contributions to North Shore University Hospital and New York Hospital.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., named Mark Begor chief financial officer of its NBC television network unit effective immediately, succeeding Warren Jenson, who is leaving to become chief financial officer of Delta Air Lines Inc.

title: Eviction Left Guinea Pigs on the Run
description: In a city that has had envious success in solving its serious crimes, this one was one of the more benign: Several dozen South American guinea pigs had been illegally released in Central Park, a strange land where they would surely meet their death.

title: The Ebb and Flow of Reform; Connecticut Moves Forward
description: The Connecticut Legislature's bipartisan drive to close loopholes in the state's campaign finance laws could not have come at a better time. The duplicity and evasion that have characterized Congress's attempts to dodge this issue may be leading some voters to fear the cause is hopeless. But Connecticut is demonstrating that at least some politicians can rise above narrow self-interest.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: McDonald's Alters System For Kitchens
description: In an attempt to freshen its business, the McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that it was switching to a high-tech kitchen system that would eliminate warmed-over burgers and fries.

title: Of the Voluptuous And the Dead
description: Some experts blame the mild winter. Others say it is fate. But whatever the reason, after a blockbuster fall when the estates of big-name collectors like Victor and Sally Ganz and Evelyn Sharp were sold at auction, no equally important collectors have either died or decided to sell their works over the last six months, leaving auction house experts scrambling for property to sell.

title: Jokes, Skits And a Deft Way With Makeup
description: The bloke in the dark eyeliner and blue hard-candy nail polish is back, with even more on his mind than last time. Taxidermy, the Oscars, Queen Victoria, kites, Kathleen Willey, paganism, ''Hawaii Five-0,'' puberty, Steve McQueen, dinosaurs, Easter eggs: Eddie Izzard is not your ordinary topic-surfing comic in black vinyl pants and Chinese housecoat. He is a human search engine.

title: Shielding Young Suspects Is No Longer Automatic
description: News organizations once were quick to withhold the names of young people who had been charged with crimes, but this week's shootings at an Arkansas middle school showed that self-imposed rule is now gone. Today, journalists say they increasingly weigh practical considerations in making such decisions.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Julian Trigo

title: U.S. Orders Sickest to Be Given Priority on Donated Organs
description: Stepping into one of the thorniest issues in medicine, the Clinton Administration today ordered the private network that distributes donated organs to replace its current system with one that gives priority to the sickest patients, no matter where in the country they live.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENWALD, DOROTHY B.
description: ROSENWALD-Dorothy B. The life of Dorothy B. Rosenwald, who passed away January 24, 1998, will be celebrated at a memorial service March 30, at 5 PM, at the home of Pat and Ben Heller, 42 East 74 St. Speakers will include the family and close friends.

title: Moving Ideas: Having the Life of Her Time
description: Victoria Marks made the passage of time her choreographic theme on Wednesday night at Dance Theater Workshop.

title: Woman, 35, Faces Charge Of Rape of Boy
description: A 35-year-old Harlem woman who the police said had a year-long affair with a 14-year-old boy was arrested yesterday and charged with statutory rape.

title: Intel Is Replacing Westinghouse As Sponsor of Science Contest
description: When Westinghouse began a contest in 1942 to identify the nation's budding teen-age scientists, the company's name was a synonym for innovation, one that would soon be emblazoned on refrigerators in millions of homes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 20 about a Presidential town hall meeting on race relations to be broadcast by the sports cable channel ESPN misstated the scheduled date. It is April 14, not April 1.

title: Crafting Genes Is About Ego, Not Science
description: To the Editor:

title: New AT&T Chairman Got Big Stock Deal
description: When C. Michael Armstrong agreed to join the AT&T Corporation as chairman last fall, the company granted him stock and stock equivalents now valued at more than $22 million, according to documents AT&T submitted yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: WPP Group Buys 2 Specialist Agencies
description: WPP Group, which owns agencies including the J. Walter Thompson Company and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, has acquired two agencies specializing in consulting on high-technology marketing. Terms were not disclosed.

title: State's Top Court Rejects a Rent Rollback for Some Elderly Poor
description: The state's highest court rejected a bid today to roll back rents for thousands of low-income elderly people in New York City.

title: 'Titanic' vs. 'Ben-Hur'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Floor Generals Attack Off the Dribble
description: Kentucky, Stanford, North Carolina and Utah each arrive at the Final Four with rebounding might, with sharp shooters and with a defensive will that paved the way. Now at this exciting precipice, with each team one victory away from the national championship game, every basketball element from floor balance to setting hard screens illuminates. Every pass, every shot, every possession at this point means so much.

title: An Unlikely Eagle and a Leader to Match
description: For Glen Day, it was the shot of the day and one of the most exciting shots of his career.

title: Brokerage Firm Settles Price-Rigging Suit
description: BancAmerica Robertson Stephens & Company has agreed to pay $17 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that accused it of colluding with 36 other brokerage firms to rig securities prices on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Unions Are Battling Drives in 21 States to Curtail Sharply Their Political War Chests
description: Upset by organized labor's growing political clout, conservatives in California and 20 other states are pushing ballot initiatives or state legislation that could greatly reduce labor's political war chest.

title: Disease Control Agency Urges Wider Use of H.I.V. Blood Tests
description: Concerned that an estimated 250,000 Americans do not know they are infected with the AIDS virus, Federal health officials yesterday urged wider use of blood tests, particularly of a little-used test that can provide results in an hour or less.

title: Ta-Ta, Los Angeles, And Hello, London
description: Grey Advertising sent the top executive of its Los Angeles office to head its office in London yesterday. Steve Blamer, executive vice president and managing director in Los Angeles, will become managing director and chief executive in London. Mr. Blamer, 41, will succeed Nigel Sharrocks, who left Grey in September. In Los Angeles, Jeff Alperin, 44, president of the office, will assume Mr. Blamer's responsibilities.

title: Mayor Plans To Apologize On '91 Melee
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would apologize on the city's behalf for its handling of the 1991 racial disturbances in Crown Heights as part of a financial settlement that community leaders say they are hammering out with the city in their lawsuit over the violence.

title: Take a Number, Please: One Very Busy Confessional
description: ''The Proposition'' offers a cautionary lesson for actors everywhere: if you're handed a dead screenplay, don't fool yourself into thinking your Stanislavskian technique or sizzling star quality can breathe life into it. Dead words make for dead performances, no matter how many tricks you hold up your sleeve.

title: Could School Shooting Have Been Prevented?; Blame Gun Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Stock Options That Raise Investors' Ire
description: When a company with a falling stock decides to lower the price at which its executives can buy shares, many investors become infuriated. The practice -- known as stock option repricing -- is widely denounced as a giveaway to managers who may be to blame for the poor performance in the first place.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIS, JOSEPH J.
description: DAVIS-Joseph J. June 13, 1950March 28, 1993. Love never ends. Your love and beautiful music are with us always. Your family, Mary, friends and students

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Hopelessly Devoted: 'Grease' Is the Word
description: Twenty years before he ran for President, svelte John Travolta was shaking his snake hips through the giddy screen version of ''Grease.'' Now the fake 50's musical that won't go away is back all over again, as Paramount reissues the black leather chestnut in honor of its birthday.

title: CAMPBELL SETS $253 MILLION CHARGE AGAINST EARNINGS
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that it would take a third-quarter charge of $253 million, resulting in a loss, as the company, the world's largest soup maker, sheds businesses and cuts costs. The charge of 55 cents a diluted share will cover costs from next week's spinoff of Vlasic Foods International Inc., the maker of Vlasic pickles and Swanson frozen foods. Campbell said it might close factories and dismiss workers as part of a plan to reduce annual costs by as much $150 million. Since September 1996, the company has sold unprofitable businesses and used the money to buy back stock.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Off the Menu column of the Dining section on Wednesday mar 25 about chefs' assignments in Manhattan misstated Fernando Saralegui's role in the restaurant Alva in the Flatiron District. He is a partner only; the chef is Aaron Bashy.

title: Nestle's Earnings Rose 4.2% in 2d Half of 1997
description: Nestle S.A. indicated yesterday that its second-half 1997 earnings rose 4.2 percent, as the company cut costs and increased profit in North and South America. Nestle, the world's largest food and beverage maker, raised second-half net income to 2.115 billion Swiss francs ($1.44 billion) from 2.03 billion francs a year earlier. Nestle shares fell 37 francs, to 2,788 francs. Full-year earnings rose 17.8 percent, to a record 4.005 billion francs from 3.401 billion francs. (Bloomberg News)

title: Memo From Moscow; Yeltsin the Improviser, Bathing in New Limelight
description: Nothing gives Boris N. Yeltsin more pleasure than playing dice with his little piece of the universe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREWS, LOUISE EVANS
description: ANDREWS-Louise Evans. Of Centerport, New York, March 23, 1998. (3rd generation graduate of Smith College and her daughters, 4th generation graduates.) Wife of Stephen P. Andrews. Mother of Jonathan B. Andrews, Elizabeth P. Andrews, Sarah K. Andrews, Myra L. Sobel. Daughter of David Evans. Sister of Daryl Platt and Sarah Kingston. Five grandchildren. Private services will be held.

title: Jailing Journalists in Latin America
description: Reporters in Latin America are still dodging bullets. Of 26 journalists killed worldwide in 1997, 10 were in Latin America, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists. But an arrest warrant is a more common danger. Government officials are bringing criminal charges against journalists who report on official crime and corruption, giving intimidation a legal veneer.

title: Senate Backs I.M.F. Funds, And Girds for Fight in House
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund, setting up a fight with the House, which has attached a divisive anti-abortion provision to the financing measure.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: SWISS BANKS PLAN RESTITUTION FUND FOR NAZIS' VICTIMS
description: Switzerland's three major banks reversed themselves today and agreed to negotiate a global settlement with Holocaust victims, pledging to set up a compensation fund in the United States to make restitution more than a half-century after World War II ended.

title: Arkansas Unfazed by Long Odds of Facing Tennessee
description: Many assume that the outcome of the 17th National Collegiate Athletic Association's women's Final Four is a foregone conclusion. Borrowing a chant, if not its intent, from Rutgers, the theme of the day is unmistakable: ''Tennessee, Tennessee, Tennessee.''

title: A Night of Understatement
description: At Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, Joan Baez remarked that she was often asked about the difference between current songwriters and songwriters ''of yore.'' She joked that the current generation of folk-based songwriters was better at business and guitar-tuning than hers had been. But their songs suggested something more: a turn toward subtlety and indirection that Ms. Baez is still getting used to.

title: New and Seldom Heard
description: Conventional wisdom holds that audiences, having been burned by new music in past decades, are reluctant to give contemporary composers a chance. That may be so, but the New York Philharmonic program that David Zinman conducted on Wednesday evening -- and that he is repeating tonight and tomorrow evening -- suggests that listener prejudices may not be limited to modern works.

title: Adobe Profit Falls More Than Expected
description: Adobe Systems Inc. said today that its first-quarter earnings fell 50 percent, a bigger decline than analysts expected, on weak sales in Asia and North America and declining sales of Macintosh products.

title: Pratt Finally Gets Word And He's Off to Norfolk
description: Todd Pratt could see it coming. And today, he finally received the words he did not want to hear.

title: Bank Robbery as Boyish Fun
description: The director of ''Slacker'' and ''Dazed and Confused'' has moved on to his first big-budget, elaborately costumed picture, and the immediate question is: Why? The answer becomes most apparent just when ''The Newton Boys,'' Richard Linklater's film about America's most unsung and fiscally successful band of Prohibition-era bank robbers, is over. At the end of this sometimes old-hat story about young guns, Mr. Linklater suddenly includes real glimpses of the real Newtons beside the closing credits. They lived to ripe old ages and, in the case of one brother, to a jovial appearance with Johnny Carson on ''The Tonight Show.'' One of them, at 77, was nabbed robbing one last bank.

title: Observer; Those Fetching Guys
description: Juliet Capulet, they say, was 14 years old when she lost her heart to Romeo Montague. According to the 1996 movie about that affair, Romeo looked exactly like Leonardo DiCaprio, the romantic lead in ''Titanic.''

title: Moviefone Leaves Ryan Drossman
description: Ryan Drossman & Partners in New York and the agency's first client -- Moviefone Inc. -- said yesterday that they would part ways after almost eight years. As a result, the Moviefone account has been placed in review.

title: Low on Cash, Thai Concern Will Sell China Assets
description: It was only a year ago that Dhanin Chearavanont, chairman of the Thai conglomerate Charoen Pokphand, was dispensing wisdom about how to succeed in China, where he had become, by many estimates, the largest and most influential foreign investor.

title: Moroccan and Middle Eastern
description: Morocco may be a continent away from Iran, but the two countries and most of those in between share a pool of culinary ingredients and cooking techniques. From there, the cuisines stream off in many directions. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Dreamers of Thoroughbred Glory Mine Florida
description: Dennis G. Madonna, a 39-year-old general contractor from Pennsylvania, walked around horse stalls at the Ocala Breeders' Sales Company here this week with a trainer and two veterinarians in tow. Tired of losing money with four racehorses, he came to an auction of thoroughbreds determined to find a winner, if not of the Kentucky Derby, at least high-stakes races.

title: McRooms No More; Holiday Inn Finds Predictability Isn't Enough Today
description: The first Holiday Inn, built 46 years ago between a lumberyard and a two-lane highway in suburban Memphis, had a 53-foot-high sign in front with flashing green lights to lure passing motorists.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Victim's Friends Testify About Hamptons Beating
description: The lawyer for a man accused in the near-fatal beating of a man outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub two years ago called as the first defense witnesses yesterday two brothers who told the police that the attacker was a tall man with spiked blond hair.

title: Pepsico Names New Chief Financial Officer
description: Pepsico Inc. said today that Michael D. White would become its senior vice president and chief financial officer, replacing Karl M. von der Heyden, who will remain vice chairman.

title: Marines Charge Crew of Plane In Gondola Accident in Italy
description: All four men aboard a Marine Corps jet that severed a gondola cable in Italy last month, plunging 20 people more than 300 feet to their deaths, have been charged with negligent homicide and involuntary manslaughter, a Defense Department official said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNEY, JEANETTE
description: CHARNEY-Jeanette. Died on Thursday, March 26th, 1998. Jeanette Charney of Hollywood, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Elaine (Nevin) Gibson of Springfield, Virginia and the late Leonard and (Judith) Charney. Five grandchildren, Marlo (David) Sims, Seth Davis, Cathy, Johanna and Joanne Lamstein. Graveside services will be held on Friday, March 27 at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, New Jersey, 1 P.M. Information Danzansky-Goldberg Memorial Chapel, Inc, 301-340-1400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, PEARL
description: COOPER-Pearl. On March 26, 1998. Beloved wife for 58 years to George. Adored mother of Elizabeth and Irwin Feiner, Leslie and Bob Gruber, and Barbara Cooper. Loving grandmother of Steven, Scott, Andrea and Andrew, Andrew, Richard and Alan, Jason and David. She was our family matriarch and will be missed tremendously by all. Services on Sunday, March 29 at 1:30 PM, Blvd Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY.

title: He Used to Wrangle Mayors. Now, Students.
description: THE Giuliani administration simply refuses to comment on the coming departure of Raymond D. Horton from the helm of the Citizens Budget Commission.

title: Devils Take Off Gloves And Pound Avalanche
description: Claude Lemieux advised his Colorado Avalanche teammates to have patience. He said the Devils feast on opponents' frustration. He told them to execute their scoring chances because there were not going to be many. And do not let them take a lead.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Andrew Bush

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, HERBERT L.
description: MENDELSON-Herbert L. Friend, lawyer and man of principle and character. We will miss you. Our deepest condolences to Joan, Susan and Barry, Billy and Carole and Clifford and Tami. N. Richard and Carol Kalikow

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM FALLS. Palladium dropped 4.4 percent on optimism that Russia, the metal's top producer, would soon resume exports after an extended delay. June-delivery contracts settled at $258.70 an ounce, down $12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, LUCY
description: GREENBERG-Lucy. On March 25, 1998. Devoted mother of Mary and Amy. Beloved grandmother of Robert, Elizabeth, Josh, Katie, Sean, Jennifer, and greatgrandmother of Samantha. Service was held Friday at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Family receiving at the home of Mary and Dana Johnston through Wednesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSHEL, HANNAH
description: MANSHEL-Hannah. Entered into rest on March 26th, Hannah (Jacobson), of New Rochelle, NY. Beloved wife of Ernest Manshel. Devoted mother of Marsha Amir of Phoenix, AZ, David Manshel of Maynard, MA., and Stephen Manshel of Aurora, CO. Dear daughter of the late Dr. Moritz Jacobson and Charlotte Marcuse Jacobson. Loving sister of Eva Loew of Hampton, CT, and the late Dr. Lou Jacobson. Cherished grandmother of Toby Amir, Karen Amir, Alexander Manshel, Jeffrey Manshel, Brandton Manshel and Andrew Manshel. Memorial services at New England Baptist Hospital Chapel on Friday, March 27 at 3 P.M. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy in her memory may be donated to the Hannah Manshel Memorial Fund, C/O New England Baptist Hospital, 125 Parker HIll Avenue, Boston, MA 02120. Mrs. Manshel was an educator and administrator at the New York School for the Deaf where she established a pre-school program for deaf children. A consultant in the field, she attended many international conferences and was active in international foreign exchange programs. She also served for many years on the Board of Trustees of the New England Baptist Hospital. For information contact Stanetsky Memorial Chapels, Brookline, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORCZYNER, HARRY
description: TORCZYNER-Harry. Order of Leopold, Belgium, in his 88th year, son of the late Numa and Rachel Torczyner, precious husband of Marcelle Siva, adored father of Evelyn Musher Shechter and Denise Wiseman, respected fatherin-law of Samuel Shechter and Sam Wiseman, doting grandfather of Joshua and Shira Musher, Naomi Shechter, Rafi Musher, and Danielle Diller, proud great grandfather of Shoshana Rachel and Jeremy Max Musher, loving brother of Jacques and Berthe Torczyner. Service Sunday 2PM, at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

title: COLONIAL BANCGROUP TO GET COMMERCIAL NATIONAL BANK
description: Colonial Bancgroup said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Commercial National Bank, a Florida banking company, for $28.5 million in stock. Colonial Bancgroup, based in Montgomery, Ala., is a banking company with 227 offices in Alabama, Florida, Georgia and Tennessee as of last month. Its parent, CNB Holding, had assets of $83.3 million as of Dec. 31. Commercial National, based in Daytona Beach, Fla., has four offices in the Daytona Beach area. Colonial's shares slid 12.5 cents, to $35.875, on the Big Board.

title: Poisoning the Wells of Knowledge
description: Not one of the many bookstores in this bookish town still has a shelf for literary criticism. Yet more of it is being published than ever before, by university presses that say such works often sell no more than 500 copies each.

title: U.S. May Fight Satellite-TV License Sale
description: Federal regulators are said to be leaning toward challenging a plan by a venture of the MCI Communications Corporation and the News Corporation to sell a valuable satellite television license to Primestar Partners L.P.

title: U.S. Lawyers Are Examining Tunnel Deal
description: Two teams of Federal prosecutors have begun separate investigations into a decision by state officials to award a $97 million contract to repair the Queens-Midtown Tunnel to a company that is owned by one of the biggest financial supporters of Gov. George E. Pataki and the New York Republican State Committee.

title: Agent Expects Visas From Costa Rica
description: The four Cuban players and one coach who defected to the Bahamas last weekend will receive visas to Costa Rica within a week, their agent, Joe Cubas, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPLAN, JOAN PLATOFF, PHD
description: CHAPLAN-Joan Platoff, PhD, of Englewood, NJ, Los Angeles, CA and Seattle, WA on Tuesday, March 24, 1998. Joan graduated from Vassar College. She worked in radio and television in NY for many years. She then received a masters in Early Childhood Education from Bank Street College and a PhD from NYU. She worked to set up Head Start in NYC and was a consultant to many early childhood centers. She had a great mind that was matched by a great heart. She was married for thirty years and was a proud and wonderful mother. She will be remembered with great love by her husband Abraham, her daughters Connie and Catie, her stepdaughters Janet, Margaret, Rebecca, Sandra and their spouses and children, her nephews John and David and their spouses and children, and many other family members and friends. Donations may be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center.

title: Perez Retires, Rejecting Demotion
description: Cleveland Indians pitcher Melido Perez retired rather than accept a demotion to minor league camp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, HELEN
description: KRAMER-Helen. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Louis Kramer. Devoted mother of Paul, Susan Kane and Jonathan. Loving grandmother, aunt and friend. Services on Sunday 11 A.M., at Temple Emanu El, Rumsey Road, Yonkers. Contributions to Alzheimers Association or Mental Health Association. For information call Weinstein Memorial 914-793-3800.

title: Torre Decides to Keep 3-Way Mix in Left Field
description: Faced with a difficult decision on who will play left field and when, Yankees Manager Joe Torre handled his choice like a deft politician. He decided to not decide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIPPERT, WERNER
description: ZIPPERT-Werner, 94. Died on March 25, 1998 at the Greene County Nursing Home in Eutaw, AL. Beloved husband of the late Helen Zippert. Devoted uncle of John Zippert. Also survived by grand and great-nieces and nephews. Graveside service will be held at 2 PM, Sunday, March 29, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIS, JOSEPH J.
description: DAVIS-Joseph J. June 13, 1950March 28, 1993. Love never ends. Your love and beautiful music are with us always. Your family, Mary, friends and students

title: A Fracture Sidelines Williams For Season
description: Jayson Williams walked off the court midway through the fourth quarter tonight and did not stop at the bench. He went directly to the hospital.

title: A Bidding War Sends Metromail Shares Up
description: The bidding war for Metromail Inc., a direct marketing company, heated up yesterday, and Metromail's shares rose amid expectations that both suitors might offer even more.

title: Sultriness May Sell, but a Cigar Is Still a Cigar
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEAVY, WILLIAM T., M.D.
description: KEAVY-William T., M.D., age 62, an internationally renowned reconstructive and plastic surgeon, died March 26, 1998 in Lenox Hill Hospital. Dr. Keavy was born in Bridgeport, CT., and resided in Westport, CT., and Central Park South, NYC. He was a graduate of Fairfield Preparatory School, Fairfield University, and Georgetown University. He received a law degree from Fordham University and his medical degree from Marquette University. He was on the Staff at Lenox Hill Hospital, and Doctors Hospital both in NYC, and St. Joseph's Hospital Stamford. He was a member of the Section of Plastic Surgery for over thirty years, and an active member of LHH Alumni Association. A devoted and gifted educator who took great pleasure in sharing his knowledge and love of surgery with young physicians. Dr. Keavy impressed all who knew him with his kindness, compassion and integrity. He will be deeply missed by his family, his friends and his colleagues. Survivors include his mother: Irene Burns Keavy, of Westport, and many cousins. Friends are invited to attend the funeral on Monday at 11:00 a.m. in St. Luke's Church, 49 N. Turkey Road, Westport, CT, interment in St. Michael's Cemetery, Stratford, Connecticut. Friends may call on Sunday from 4 to 8 P.M., at the Cyril F. Mullins Funeral Home 399 White Plains Road, Trumbull, CT. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Dr. William T. Keavy Scholarship Fund at Fairfield Preparatory School, North Benson Road, Fairfield, CT.

title: The Tar Heels Are Favored, But It's No Slam Dunk
description: The North Carolina players stared inside their lockers at pictures of the Alamodome all season. The Stanford players signed a poster before the season to affirm their goal of waltzing here. The Kentucky players remembered the sting of succumbing in the national championship game last season. The Utah players figured they would be watching the Final Four on television.

title: State to Study Sales Tactics In Home Sales
description: State officials have begun a preliminary inquiry into accusations from residents of an affluent Brooklyn neighborhood that real estate brokers are using racial and ethnic scare tactics to persuade them to sell their homes.

title: Gretzky Drops Hint That Future Is Now
description: By analyzing the Rangers' problems with unusually blunt words this week, Wayne Gretzky has forced his bosses to confront a coming crisis. Do they bring him back next season with a new cast of high-salaried veterans acquired through free agency or through trades? Or, by rebuilding with youth, do they dare Gretzky to retire or to demand a trade before his 20th National Hockey League season?

title: Don't Turn Back the Clock on Sex Harassment; What the Law Says
description: To the Editor:

title: Hip-Hop Idol Is the Pride Of a People; Young Haitian-Americans Get Help Against Stigma
description: Nelust Wyclef Jean, a member of the hip-hop group the Fugees, strolled onto the basketball court in the Springfield Gardens High School gymnasium in Queens, grabbed a microphone and delivered a few lines from ''Gone Till November,'' a hit from his latest album.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Shaolin Temple Journal; Where Zen and Kung Fu Got Off to a Flying Start
description: As you stroll through the nicely restored Shaolin Monastery complex you are apt to be startled when a teen-age boy in a sweatsuit suddenly thrusts a foot into the sky, or another practices the fine art of hanging from a tree by his toes.

title: Rapee, 82, and Team Score Upset in Vanderbilt Contest
description: A bridge miracle came a step closer in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here Thursday. George Rapee, 82, of Manhattan, who won his first Vanderbilt in 1946 and the first of his three world team titles in 1951, scored an upset to advance to the semifinals. If he wins two more matches, he will be by far the oldest winner in the event's 69-year history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRANE, LILLIAN
description: KRANE-Lillian. Age 74. Devoted wife for 50 years. Loving mother to her three children and three grandchildren. Her remains are to be laid to rest on March 30, 1998.

title: The Long-Ago Dance
description: It is always interesting to stand wherever crowds gather in New York City and imagine the robust arc of memory that gives shape to all those lives, connecting them to the unmapped geography of the past. Sometimes, on the other hand, you hear the story of a single life that captures in itself the fragility of memory, the delicacy of the very thing from which our personal narratives are constructed. That kind of story belongs to Arthur Bell.

title: General Retires After Sex Accusation by Woman
description: The Army let its deputy inspector general retire honorably last month, even though he stood accused by a subordinate's wife of coercing her into sexual relations, military officials said today.

title: Hip-Hopping To Miami
description: It's a long way from Harlem to Miami, but longer still aboard the ramshackle bus carrying the characters in ''Ride'' toward what they hope is a rendezvous with hip-hop destiny.

title: Carolina's Favored, But It's No Slam Dunk
description: The North Carolina players stared inside their lockers at pictures of the Alamodome all season. The Stanford players signed a poster before the season to affirm their goal of waltzing here. The Kentucky players remembered the sting of succumbing in the national championship game last season. The Utah players figured they would be watching the Final Four on television.

title: Don't Turn Back the Clock on Sex Harassment; Lack of Enforcement
description: To the Editor:

title: Prime Lending Rates Lowered in Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong banks cut their prime lending rates one-quarter point, to 10 percent, yesterday in a move to increase demand for loans as their borrowing costs hover near eight-month lows. The prime lending rate had risen to 10.25 percent from 8.75 in October after the Hong Kong central bank drove up interbank lending rates to shore up the local dollar as Asian currencies tumbled.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's sale of a bus depot in the South Bronx misstated the position held by C. Virginia Fields. She is the Borough President of Manhattan, not the Bronx.

title: Sultriness May Sell, but a Cigar Is Still a Cigar
description: To the Editor:

title: An Unpleasant Accident And a Menage a Trois
description: Thanks to the strong, heartfelt performances of its three main actors, Ricardo Franco's weepy drama, ''The Lucky Star,'' manages to keep its head above the soapsuds for about two-thirds of its length. After that, this Spanish film, which New Directors/New Films is showing at the Museum of Modern Art tonight at 9:30 and tomorrow at noon, succumbs to its own mawkish tendencies. During the protracted death scene that ends the film, you want to slap its face and shout, ''Snap out of it!''

title: Stanford Is Determined Not to Be Left Behind
description: The provincial thinking here is that Kentucky (33-4) is the race horse and Stanford (30-4) is the mule. After 40 minutes of play in the Alamodome on Saturday, Kentucky will be breathing easy and Stanford will be panting. Stanford's players' tongues will be hanging and their feet aching from trying to keep pace with the quick Wildcats.

title: SUN IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE PLANT FROM ALLIED SIGNAL
description: The Sun Company agreed yesterday to acquire a Philadelphia phenol plant from Allied Signal Inc. for $185 million to expand its production of chemicals used for making nylon, plywood and plastics. Sun, a petroleum and petrochemical refiner-marketer with 1997 sales of $10.5 billion, said Allied Signal's facility, which is near Sun's headquarters in Philadelphia, is one of North America's largest producers of phenol, used in making plastics like those in compact disks. Sun intends to begin a plant expansion -- announced earlier by Allied Signal -- to increase the facility's phenol production by 8 percent. Sun said it would pay the $185 million in installments over four years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGE, LESLIE M.
description: PAGE-Leslie M. Of Southampton, New York. On March 27th, 1998. Beloved husband of Lucy. Loving father of Calla Page Clay, Jay Jarvis and Chips Chapman Page. Dear brother of Jarvis and Chauncey Page. Also survived by four grandchildren. Reposing Sunday from 2-4 PM only, the Brockett Funeral Home, Inc, 203 Hampton Road, Southampton. Interment Southampton Cemetery. Memorial donations to St. John's Episcopal Church, Southampton, New York, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, IRVIN
description: HOROWITZ-Irvin. We note with sorrow the sudden passing of a loyal member and dear friend. We extend our sincerest condolences to his family. Hilary Chilton Auxiliary President North Shore University Hospital/ Manhasset

title: Life Sentence for a Man Who Killed His Mother
description: A 19-year-old man who was convicted of fatally shooting his mother in their driveway, then blaming the crime on a masked gunman, was sentenced yesterday to life in prison, Somerset County prosecutors said.

title: Mayoral Ingratitude
description: After the Haitian immigrant Abner Louima was beaten and tortured in a Brooklyn precinct house bathroom last August, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani wisely organized a citizens' task force to study police brutality in New York City. It was a quick and useful way to cool tempers on the streets and calm growing fears that as the crime rate went down, the rate of police brutality was going up.

title: SHARES OF ONCOR RETREAT AS SURVIVAL IS DOUBTED
description: The shares of Oncor Inc. fell 55 percent yesterday to a nine-year low after the company received an audit report saying its accountants doubt its survival as a going concern because of dwindling cash reserves. The gene-based test maker's shares fell $2, to $1.625, in trading of 1.5 million shares. The company received a ''going concern'' report -- which occurs when cash reserves are less than the losses in the last year -- for the year ended Dec. 31 from Arthur Andersen L.L.P., its independent public accountant. The company, based in Gaithersburg, Md., said it had been able to finance its operating losses in the past and it expects to continue doing so.

title: Baseball, Ever Evolving
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Income and Spending Were Up Strongly in February
description: Personal income and spending grew robustly in February, an indication that American consumers will continue to spur economic growth.

title: Russia's New Prime Minister
description: Americans unfamiliar with Russia's new Prime Minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, are not alone. Most Russians barely know him either. In another of his improvisational governing decisions, President Boris Yeltsin has selected a young, largely untested politician to lead the Russian Government. Mr. Kiriyenko is at least considered to be a democrat and a reformer, but it is far from clear whether he has the leadership skills and fortitude to manage a fractious Government and country.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHESTNEY, SELMA
description: CHESTNEY-Selma. March 28, 1958. In loving memory. Doris and Ed Klein Mimi and Bill Konig

title: House G.O.P. Shifts on Campaign Bills
description: Abruptly shifting gears, the House Republican leadership announced today that it would take up four campaign finance bills on Monday -- but not the main bipartisan bill, which would not be allowed to the floor.

title: Tokyo Girls Play It Safe
description: If you're pining to see a contemporary cinematic variation on the kind of minimalist dance pioneered by the Judson Dance Theater in the 1960's, Sharon Lockhart's rigorously structured film, ''Goshogaoka,'' is your dish of tea. The 63-minute movie, which New Directors/New Films is presenting at the Museum of Modern Art this afternoon at 4:30 and tomorrow at 6:30 P.M., is a detached, methodical deconstruction of the body language of basketball that invites you to supply whatever interpretation you want. If you're not inclined to read multiple meanings into its choreographed groupings, it also invites you to doze off.

title: In Facing Lewis, Briggs Takes a Big Step
description: It was a close decision. Even Shannon Briggs seemed genuinely surprised when it was announced that he had eked out a 12-round decision against the popular 48-year-old George Foreman. But what followed was even more stunning to Briggs.

title: Con Artists Prey on Elderly Homeowners
description: They are unsettling signs of spring: con artists claiming to be home improvement contractors, preying on unsuspecting homeowners, particularly the elderly.

title: Impotence Drug Expected to Be A Popular Pill
description: Viagra, Pfizer Inc.'s new treatment for impotence, could have the fastest takeoff, measured in prescriptions written, in drug history. As the only pill for impotence in a sexually active culture, Viagra sales could soar to several billion dollars annually in a year or two, securities analysts said yesterday.

title: Senators Agree On Forcing Up Cigarette Price
description: After a week of day and night negotiations on tobacco legislation, leading senators have agreed to drive up the price of a pack of cigarettes by $1.10 over the next five years, almost double what the cigarette manufacturers accepted in a settlement they reached last June with state attorneys general.

title: I Shop, Ergo I Am: The Mall As Society's Mirror; Scholars Say Where, What and How People Buy Is Changing, and Not for the Better
description: In certain academic circles, ''shop till you drop'' is considered a civic act. If you follow cultural studies -- the academic scrutiny of ordinary activities like eating fast food, buying a house in the suburbs, watching television and taking vacations at Disneyland -- you will know that shopping is not just a matter of going to a store and paying for your purchase.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Fall for Third Day On Fears of Weaker Profits

title: Threatening Parliament, Yeltsin Names Neophyte Premier
description: Acting both impulsively and combatively, President Boris N. Yeltsin today named Sergei Kiriyenko, a little-known 35-year-old technocrat, as Russia's new Prime Minister and warned that he would disband Parliament if it rejected the nomination.

title: I.R.S. Urges Jerseyans To Claim Tax Credit
description: In response to reports by the state that nearly 70,000 eligible families in New Jersey failed to apply for the Earned Income Tax Credit last year, the Internal Revenue Service has opened five of its regional offices on Saturdays to encourage taxpayers to claim the credit.

title: Murder Suspect Casts Suspicion on Girlfriend
description: Edmund Ko, the man charged with slashing a Columbia Law School student to death, has denied his guilt and said that his girlfriend might be the killer, Mr. Ko's lawyer said in court yesterday.

title: Arkansas City Begins Burying Its Young Dead
description: A man in blue jeans stood in the foyer of the packed Farmers Union funeral home, his arms wrapped tightly around a little girl, as family, neighbors and classmates said goodbye to 12-year-old Paige Ann Herring in the first of two funerals this day.

title: Presiding Over the President: Judge Wright's Big Moment
description: Before Jones v. Clinton, Judge Susan Webber Wright's biggest trial was the Whitewater case of two bankers accused of concealing withdrawals from Bill Clinton's campaign account. When they were acquitted, however, another judge heard the verdict; Judge Wright had decided to honor a prior commitment to attend a conference and take her daughter to Walt Disney World.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the New York news media's coverage of the media misstated the given name of a reporter for Daily Variety. She is Jennifer Nix, not Jessica.

title: DOVER DOWNS IS GETTING GRAND PRIX ASSOCIATION
description: Dover Downs Entertainment Inc. agreed to buy Grand Prix Association of Long Beach Inc. for about $88 million in stock, cash and options, expanding its operation of motor-sports events throughout the United States. Dover will exchange 0.63 share of its common stock for each share of Grand Prix. The stock portion of the transaction is valued at $73.1 million, based on Dover Downs' closing price on Thursday. Dover will also pay $10.5 million in cash and $4 million to buy Grand Prix options. The purchase will make Dover Downs the owner and operator of 15 major Indy and Nascar motor sports events and a number of other races.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORWIN, JOAN
description: CORWIN-Joan. Prayers go out to our sister-in-law, aunt, and friend, Corey Corwin Shafran and her family on the death of their mother, Joan. Eve, Billie, Annah, Andrew, Sammy, Molly, Joshua, Jenny and Kirsten

title: Jury Clears Gun Makers Of Culpability In a Shooting
description: In the first case of its kind to go to trial, a Federal jury in Brooklyn cleared seven firearms manufacturers and their owners yesterday of culpability in a 1994 shooting attack on a van full of Hasidic students on the Brooklyn Bridge that left one dead and two others wounded.

title: Tricon Chairman Got $3.1 Million in '97
description: Tricon Global Restaurants Inc. paid its chairman and chief executive, Andrall Pearson, $3.1 million last year, as the operator of KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut restaurants was spun off from Pepsico Inc.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS. The yen fell sharply on disappointment over Japan's economic stimulus package and on a Standard & Poor's rating downgrade of four big Japanese banks. In New York, the dollar cost 130.33 yen, up from 128.29.

title: Undersized Knicks Hang On In Overtime
description: Part of this journey for the Knicks was to avoid slipping up as they ducked in and out of cities with teams searching for crawl space at the bottom of the Western Conference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KABAT, DARWIN
description: KABAT-Darwin. We mourn the passing of our former partner and dear friend. We will miss him and his example. We extend our condolences to our partner Jeff, and the Kabat family. David Levine, Arthur Goodman Charles Goodman & Co., Ltd.

title: Guam Crash Discloses Vulnerability in the U.S.
description: Accidents like the Korean Airlines crash on Guam, in which a Boeing 747 slammed into a hillside, are more characteristic of Asia or Latin America than of the United States. But three days of hearings here on that crash last August, which killed 228 people, demonstrated that this country is vulnerable, too.

title: Janzen Produces on Demanding Day
description: Difficult situations do not easily intimidate Lee Janzen.

title: Confession to Dozens Of Killings for Mercy
description: A hospital worker who told investigators he was acting out of mercy has confessed to killing 40 to 50 unconscious patients since 1989 at a hospital in Glendale, Calif., the authorities said last night.
