title: From Mandela, a Gentle Admonishment
description: President Nelson Mandela of South Africa praised President Clinton and some of his policies today as Mr. Clinton stood beside him in the midday sun, but he stoutly defended his right to remain friendly with nations the United States considers rogues, like Libya, Iran and Cuba.

title: A Wife Trapped in Tradition's Painful Grasp
description: The calculating monster who pulls the strings in Dariush Mehrjui's heartbreaking film, ''Leila,'' is an imperious mother-in-law (Jamileh Sheikhi) whose selfishness and pride put her in the same elite league with some of Hollywood's most formidable gorgons. On learning that her daughter-in-law is infertile, this termagant who is obsessed with having a male grandchild to carry on the family line systematically undermines the marriage of her only son, Reza (Ali Mosaffa). For the Iranian filmmaker, the situation illustrates the brutal clash between modernity and Islamic tradition in contemporary Iran. The movie, which has screenings tomorrow and Monday, is one of the most gripping and beautifully acted selections in this year's New Directors/New Films series.

title: Rice Holds Off Schenectady to Gain Final
description: Rice, a boys Catholic high school from Manhattan, and Christ the King, a girls Catholic school from Queens, advanced impressively to their respective Class A finals tonight at the New York State Federation championships.

title: TIDEWATER PLANNING A BUYBACK OF ITS STOCK
description: Tidewater Inc. plans to buy back as much as $200 million of its stock, which has fallen more than 30 percent from last November's record, because that is the best use of the company's ''substantial positive cash flow'' from operating oil-service boats. Tidewater already has bought back 3.3 million shares, at a total cost of $149.8 million, since December 1996 under a buyback program that will expire March 31. The company has 59.4 million shares outstanding. Tidewater shares have fallen recently amid growing concern that oil companies will cut back on exploration spending because of low oil prices. Tidewater shares slipped 56.25 cents, to $45.0625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock hit a record $69.625 in November.

title: Sultriness May Sell, but a Cigar Is Still a Cigar
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Turn Back the Clock on Sex Harassment; Unmentionable Values
description: To the Editor:

title: A Better Death in Oregon
description: Since 1990 Dr. Jack Kevorkian has been helping people to kill themselves in motel rooms, in the backs of cars and in other hidden spots in Michigan. More than 100 of them, hooked up to his homemade machinery, are dead today, successful in suicide because of him. Whether they would do it again is something we cannot know. They wanted to do it then. They had their reasons, and they had only to persuade themselves and Dr. Kevorkian. There was no system to insure that decisions to speed death were made with care, and with adequate safeguards for the patients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VINING, DONALD
description: VINING-Donald. Age 80. On January 24, 1998. Author of'' A Gay Diary'' and other works. Predeceased by life partner of fortythree years Richmond Purinton. Service at the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center, 208 West 13 St, NYC, Sunday, April 5th, 2 PM. Donations may be made to the Center or the Lincoln Center Performing Arts Library.

title: About New York; Nuns Pray A TV Parish Won't Perish
description: WHEN Sister Mary Dowd goes to work at the Maura Clarke-Ita Ford Center in Brooklyn, she passes a multicolored mural that proclaims, ''Reach for the Stars.'' It's a good motto for the immigrant women who come to her training center in Bushwick to learn English or how to become home health aides as they seek to get off welfare and onto somebody's payroll.

title: Napoleon's Dead, but the Battles Rage On
description: Welcome to the new Napoleonic Wars. This time, the battlefields are in France and the United States, where aficionados of Napoleon Bonaparte are slugging it out over how best to preserve the legacy of the little corporal and Emperor of France, the subject of 250,000 history books so far and for many simply the greatest soldier the world has seen.

title: Beloved Mother Dies, And Her Daughter Falls Into Darkness
description: A wild, heartbreaking young actress named Samantha Morton plays the central role in Carine Adler's ''Under the Skin'' with incredible abandon. This 20-year-old newcomer stars as Iris, the younger of two English sisters whose mother (Rita Tushingham) rather wishfully named them for flowers. And it is pregnant, matronly Rose (Claire Rushbrook, Brenda Blethyn's sulky daughter in ''Secrets and Lies'') whom their mother clearly favors. That makes life all the more excruciating for Iris when, with little warning, their adored mother dies.

title: For Russian Premier, A Youthful Neophyte
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin picked a little-known technocrat, only 35 years old, as Russia's Prime Minister and said he would disband Parliament if it rejected the nomination.

title: Those Backwater Folks, Happily Dispensable
description: In 1994, when the City Center Encores series started bringing back rarely heard musicals in lively concert productions, the focus was on snappy songfests from the long-gone pre-book days of the Broadway musical.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, BETSEY CUSHING.
description: WHITNEY-Betsey Cushing. We mourn the death of our beloved mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother, Betsey Cushing Whitney, who died on March 25, 1998. Her sense of humor, her determination and her courage will be with us always. Our thanks to all who have communicated their love and support. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held on April 25 at 11AM, Christ Church, Northern Boulevard, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, contributions to North Shore University Hospital and New York Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, BARBARA P.
description: HOCHBERG-Barbara P. The officers, trustees and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee express their deep sorrow at the loss of Barbara Hochberg, devoted member of the JDC Board and beloved wife to Larry. She was deeply dedicated to meeting the needs of World Jewry and of the State of Israel with a special concern for children. She was also involved since the earliest days in the struggle to free Soviet Jewry. Barbara, who was Chairman of the Board of the Jewish Federation of Chicago, served as Chair of the JDC Ralph I. Goldman Fellowship Committee as well as Co-Chair of the JDC Israel Area Committee. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family. Jonathan W. Kolker, President Michael Schneider, Exec VP Ambassador Milton A. Wolf, Chairman of the Board

title: Religion Journal; Issues of Sexuality Split The Presbyterians Again
description: Fifteen years ago, two Presbyterian denominations (one northern, the other southern, separated from each other since the Civil War) re-united to create a national religious body, the Presbyterian Church (USA). In celebration, members joined to march in a parade down Peachtree Street in Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTON, FREDERICK SAMUEL, III
description: MORTON-Frederick Samuel, III, 77, a long time resident of Charlottesville and retired University professor, died on Sunday, March 22nd, at the University of Virginia Hospital after a brief illness. He was the widower of the former Margaret Elizabeth Burke and, previously, of the former Elsie Anna Koeppl. He is survived by his children, Marshall Nay of Richmond, Virginia, Frederick Samuel IV of Christiansburg, Virginia, Elsie Ann of Austin, Texas, Shan Morton Giordano of Norwalk, CT., and James Burke of Hanover Co, VA.; his brother, Eugene Daniel of Greenwich, Connecticut, and six grandchildren. Mr. Morton was a graduate of Davidson College, attended Harvard Law School and graduated from Harvard Business School with distinction, earning Master's and Doctoral degrees; he went to teach on the faculty of Davidson College before joining the faculty of the Darden School in 1957. At Darden he initiated the Division of Executive Programs and for many years served as its director. During 1964-65 he served on the faculty of I.M.E.D.E. in Lausanne, Switzerland. He retired from Darden as Professor Emeritus in 1989. Prior to and subsequent to his retirement from the Darden School, Mr. Morton was active as a consultant and professional director to several corporations. Mr. Morton, a paratrooper and glider officer in World War II, was captured, missing in action & subsequently escaped and was awarded two purple hearts among the several decorations he earned during that conflict. In lieu of flowers the family suggests contributions to the Frederick S. Morton Award Fund of the Darden School Foundation, PO Box 6550, Charlottesville, Virginia 22906.

title: Grossberg's Lawyers Argue to Stay on Case
description: Lawyers for Amy S. Grossberg, the Wyckoff teen-ager accused of killing her newborn son, argued yesterday that they should not be dismissed from the case. They accused the prosecution of seeking to stifle a fair and ardent defense.

title: Israel's Majority Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: The Routs Over, Tennessee Will Play La. Tech for Title
description: The script was written earlier this week, when the Final Four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's women's basketball tournament was determined. The underdogs Arkansas and North Carolina State, who rode a string of improbable upsets to reach the national semifinals, inevitably fell tonight to the traditional powerhouses Tennessee and Louisiana Tech.

title: A Road Warrior of Innovators; Tires a Slow-Growth Industry? Don't Tell Goodyear's Chief
description: How is this for a corporate nightmare:

title: Israel's Majority Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: The Routs Over, Tennessee Will Play La. Tech for Title
description: The script was written earlier this week, when the Final Four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's women's basketball tournament was determined. The underdogs Arkansas and North Carolina State, who rode a string of improbable upsets to reach the national semifinals, inevitably fell tonight to the traditional powerhouses Tennessee and Louisiana Tech.

title: Major Indexes Close Lower For Third Consecutive Day
description: Rising investor concern about corporate profits pushed major stock market indexes lower for the third day in a row.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Odds Against History
description: What if the bookmakers in London and Las Vegas gave odds for international relations the way they do for boxing? What if you could bet on whether Bill Clinton will finish his term or whether Boris Yeltsin will stay sober? It could be kind of interesting. Well, here's a bet I would like to see some bookie lay odds for. It's the late-20th-century daily double: Will Zhu and Bibi make history despite themselves?

title: Dinkins Faults Giuliani on Crown Heights Lawsuit
description: Former Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday accused the current Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, of seeking to ''reap short-term political benefits'' by moving to settle a lawsuit with Hasidic residents over the 1991 violence in Crown Heights and apologizing on the city's behalf.

title: Sports of The Times; Broadway Awaits A Star
description: FINALLY, there was a crowd that cracked the cool veneer of Chamique Holdsclaw, that persuaded her to reach for something rehearsed, as opposed to her trademark ability to spontaneously create.

title: Silicon Graphics Projects Loss and Big Revenue Drop
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. said today that it expected to report a significant quarterly loss and a 23 percent drop in revenue because of declining demand for the company's work stations and supercomputers.

title: Honors Are in Sight for Devils, But Lemaire Is Focusing on Cup
description: New Jersey Coach Jacques Lemaire believes that success breeds success, but he is not so sure the philosophy applies to a dominating National Hockey League regular season begetting a playoff run to the Stanley Cup.

title: Black Bears Off Limits To Hunters This Year
description: Black bears roaming the forests of New Jersey can breathe a collective sigh of relief. The state's Fish and Game Council voted yesterday not to have a bear hunting season this year.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Antiques column of Weekend on March 6 about the European Fine Art Fair in Maastricht, the Netherlands, misstated the price of an Attic amphora, circa 520 B.C., from the William Randolph Hearst collection, offered at the fair by Royal-Athena Galleries of Manhattan. It was $215,000, not $875,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, STANLEY
description: ANDERSON-Stanley, Piscataway, NJ, on 3/27/98. Husband of Edith (Greenburg) Bank Anderson. Father of Charlotte Linzer, Larry, and Rick Anderson. Grandfather of Kevin and Talia. Funeral Sunday, 12:30PM, at Crabiel Parkwest Funeral Chapel, 239 Livingston Ave., New Brunswick, New Jersey.

title: The Starks Experiment Has Early Success
description: John Starks has been a hit of caffeine for the Knicks' starting lineup.

title: Defense in Brawley Case Disputes Ex-Prosecutor's Records
description: Lawyers at the Tawana Brawley defamation trial waged an occasionally caustic battle today over Steven A. Pagones's detailed account of the five-day period during which Ms. Brawley claimed she was abducted and raped.

title: Giuliani Sneers, and Even Friends Bridle
description: When he created a task force last summer to examine relations between the city's residents and the Police Department, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed a couple of civil-rights advocates known for criticizing his administration. But he also named a healthy number of people to the panel who made no secret of their admiration for their Mayor.

title: Don't Turn Back the Clock on Sex Harassment
description: To the Editor:

title: China Turns Blind Eye to Pirated Disks
description: In the downtown area of almost every major Chinese city, the signs are now prominently displayed on store windows: open advertisements for pirated video compact disks of Hollywood movies that sell for less than $2 each.

title: INSIDE
description: Yeltsin Picks Young Premier

title: A Nerve-Racking Time For Mets on the Bubble
description: It is an unpleasant rite of spring for a certain few individuals, a time when the normal clubhouse routine is turned upside down.

title: Don't Turn Back the Clock on Sex Harassment; As Policy Flounders
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Arrested in 1982 Brooklyn Slaying
description: The case could not have been colder if it had been buried six feet under. And that's about where the unsolved murder of Donald Holloman was: under 15 years of paper work in the metal cabinets at the 82d Precinct station house in Brooklyn.

title: India's Confident Leader Faces a Key Vote Today
description: Despite the inherent fragility of their 19-party coalition, a week in office has been enough for the Hindu nationalists who lead India's new Government to fend off threats of a repetition of their humiliation in 1996, when the nationalists' first bid to govern collapsed in 13 days.

title: Lawmaker Sees Hope Of Erasing Arts Losses
description: New York State may be about to restore aid to the arts to a level not seen in nearly a decade, State Senator Roy M. Goodman told cultural officials and artists yesterday at a gathering at Lincoln Center.

title: Up Against the Wall, Images of Human Graffiti
description: In ''Simon Sez,'' a fresh and clever ensemble work that he has choreographed for his company, Ballet Tech, Eliot Feld looks back to his roots as a dancer.

title: Worker Confesses to Killing Up to 50 Hospital Patients
description: A hospital worker who told investigators that he was acting out of mercy has confessed to killing 40 to 50 unconscious patients from 1989 to last summer at a hospital in nearby Glendale, the authorities said tonight.

title: SUMMIT BANK TO TAKE OVER CALIFORNIA SECURITY BANK
description: The Summit Bank Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held California Security Bank of San Jose, Calif., which has $40 million in assets. Terms of the all-cash deal were not disclosed. Summit, an Atlanta-based banking company and parent of Summit National Bank, said the deal would bring its total assets to about $225 million. Shares of Summit rose $1.1875, to $23..625 on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the first woman to attend the Frunze Naval Academy in St. Petersburg, Russia, referred incorrectly in some editions to the American military college that Shannon Faulkner attended briefly. It is The Citadel, not the Virginia Military Institute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTYNSKI, JERRY S.
description: BARTYNSKI-Jerry S., 73. Of Jamesburg, New Jersey, on March 26, 1998. Retired president of Independent Components Corporation and president of Corona Air Equipment, Corp., he is survived by sons Walter and Robert, and daughters-in-law Barbara and Daphne, and grandchildren Steven, Sara, Andrew, and Ryan. Viewing on Sunday 7-9 P.M., funeral, on Monday at 10:30 A.M., Rezem Funeral Home, 457 Cranbury Road, East Brunswick, NJ, 08816. He will be deeply missed by all that knew him. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: MATRIX CAPITAL ENDS PLAN TO BUY LEADER MORTGAGE
description: The Matrix Capital Corporation said yesterday that it had terminated its plan to buy the Leader Mortgage Company. Matrix, an S.& L. holding company, said, based upon its review of Leader, the companies were unable to come to a definitive agreement. In February, Matrix said it planned to acquire Leader, a closely held Ohio-based mortgage banking company, for $32 million. Matrix, based in Denver, had total assets of $607.2 million as of Dec. 31. Matrix's shares slid 31.25 cents yesterday, to $27, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Clinton Comment on Slavery Draws a Republican's Ire
description: Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, one of the top Republican leaders in the House, castigated President Clinton today for expressing regret about America's role in the slave trade, portraying the President as an aging hippie who betrayed the United States during the Vietnam War and is doing so again.

title: David Powers, 85, Aide to John Kennedy, Dies
description: David F. Powers, whose loyalty, sense of humor and contacts throughout Boston's Irish community made him a close friend and aide to John F. Kennedy and a fixture at the Kennedy White House, died today at the Symmes Medical Center in Arlington, Mass. He was 85.

title: Israel's Majority Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Bank to Add Capital to 3 Affiliates
description: The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi plans to provide 190 billion yen, or $1.47 billion, in additional capital to its three nonbank affiliates, the newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported yesterday. The Diamond Mortgage Company will receive 120 billion yen, and Diamond Factors Ltd. and the Diamond Home Credit Company will receive 50 billion yen and 20 billion yen, respectively.

title: U.S. Warns Travelers as 2 New Yorkers Are Held in Colombia
description: The State Department yesterday strengthened its advisory cautioning Americans against traveling to Colombia, where two New York City bird-watchers and two other Americans were reported to have been kidnapped by rebels.

title: Baseball, Ever Evolving; Full Media Circle
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Turn Back the Clock on Sex Harassment; Hypocrisy on the Right
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Some say he is too young and too inexperienced. I categorically disagree. Professionalism and energy are not defined by one's date of birth.''

title: Turkish Generals Demand Curbs on Islamic Fundamentalists
description: Asserting once again that they will not tolerate civilian leaders who compromise with fundamentalism, Turkish generals demanded today that Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz crack down on what they say is spreading religious extremism.

title: Woman Testifies in a Reopened Rape Case
description: A Korean immigrant who claimed that she was raped by her employer last October testified before a Queens grand jury this week in a case that has raised questions about how prosecutors handle the rape complaints of women who do not speak English.

title: At the Heart of Report on Police, Some Modest Proposals
description: The heart of the one-inch-thick report by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's task force on police-community relations lies in its 13-page summary: a compilation of nearly 100 proposals -- most of them modest, specific and within the Mayor's discretion -- that the panel said could help soothe longstanding tensions between the largely white police force and the much more diverse population of New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HALPERN, JOEL A.
description: HALPERN-Joel A. 17 years since your tragic fatal accident. Our thoughts are of you, with you, and shall be so forever. Mother & Dad

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the ''On Stage and Off'' column of Weekend yesterday about Laila Robins, who plays Shakespeare's daughter in the new Broadway play ''The Herbal Bed,'' misstated the starting date for previews. It was last night; it is not next Thursday.

title: Catching an Inside View Of Summitt and the Vols
description: Eavesdropping is a guilty pleasure that viewers can indulge in ''A Cinderella Season: The Lady Vols Fight Back,'' an HBO documentary about the 1996-97 Tennessee women's basketball team that struggled most of the season to a 29-10 record. This season's edition is 37-0 and seemingly headed for a third consecutive national championship. The common bond is Coach Pat Summitt.

title: Telling Connected Tales With 6 Director-Writers
description: A scruffily handsome young filmmaker (David La Haye) walks into a Montreal coffee place and downs one espresso after another while madly scribbling words (''cinema, hostages, Cambodia, time dragging'') in his notebook. Later we learn that he's almost unbearably nervous about going on a television talk show to discuss his film.

title: Prosecutors Dusting Off Old Tactic Against Gotti
description: Turning to a strategy that helped them convict his father five years ago, Federal prosecutors in the case of John A. Gotti have suggested that they may move to disqualify his two lawyers.

title: Redwoods Still Inspire Sturdiest of Defenders
description: Enduring a cold and wet El Nino winter, Julia Hill has lived for three months on a small plywood platform here, perched in an ancient redwood 180 feet above a paint slash marking the tree for logging.

title: HUGE MARKET SEEN
description: After months of eager anticipation by patients, doctors and investors, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved the first pill for male impotence.

title: Ahead of His Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a sexual harassment case before the Supreme Court misstated the surname of a lawyer who argued it. He was Terry L. Weldon, not Wilson.

title: Jaded See South Africa As 'Flavor of the Month'
description: It could be argued that Michael Jackson got a more enthusiastic reception when he arrived in South Africa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, PEARL
description: COOPER-Pearl. On March 26, 1998. Beloved wife for 58 years to George. Adored mother of Elizabeth and Irwin Feiner, Leslie and Bob Gruber, and Barbara Cooper. Loving grandmother of Steven, Scott, Andrea and Andrew, Andrew, Richard and Alan, Jason and David. She was our family matriarch and will be missed tremendously by all. Services on Sunday, March 29 at 1:30 PM, Blvd Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, SEYMOUR
description: SCHECHTER - Seymour. On March 27, 1998. Beloved husband of Corinne. Loving father of Roger and Justin Schechter, and Sharon Levine. Adoring grandfather of Brendan and Mara Schechter, Briana and Samara Levine. Dear brother of Lillian Turock and Alex Slater. Service Sunday 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSMAN, ALBERT
description: OSMAN-Albert, 87. Of Pembroke Pines, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, passed away March 27, 1998. Beloved husband of Beatrice; loving father of Norman Osman, Gayle Osman Lopata, and Iris (Steven) Meier; dear brother of Robert (Bella) and Martin. Services Sunday at Levitt Weinstein Memorial Chapels, 1-800-343-5400

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, LEONA F.
description: BLUM-Leona F. On March 25, beloved wife of the late Arthur, devoted sister of James and Jeanne Bary, Carol Fahy and the late Dorothea Subkoff, loving mother of Richard and Clair, Micheal, David and Reva, grandmother of Michael and Monique, Adam, Amy, Andrew, Rachel and Jennifer, and great-grandmother of Jacob. She will be greatly missed by her family and many caring friends.

title: Third Inquiry Affirms Others: Ray Alone Was King's Killer
description: Findings released today from the third official investigation into the 1968 assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. have once again ruled out everyone but James Earl Ray in the killing of the civil rights leader.

title: Rios Moves Within a Match of Being No. 1
description: Their red flags waving, the South Americans in the stands chanted happily this afternoon at the Lipton Championships as the moody little man who would be king, Marcelo Rios of Chile, moved within one victory of snatching the world No. 1 ranking away from Pete Sampras.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Stance Toward Nigeria And Its Ruler Seems to Shift
description: President Clinton appeared today to signal a change in American policy toward Nigeria, Africa's most populous country.

title: Immortal Words, Immortal Royalties? Even Mickey Mouse Joins the Fray
description: Should Shakespeare have gotten royalties for ''West Side Story,'' since it was based on ''Romeo and Juliet''? Or what about ''Jesus Christ Superstar''? Did the Apostles lose out because the New Testament was not under the protection of United States copyright laws?

title: Kulik Withdraws With Back Injury
description: Ilya Kulik of Russia, the men's Olympic figure skating champion, said yesterday that he was withdrawing from next week's world championships in Minneapolis because of a recurring back injury.

title: Disney Can Use Park Meadow Closed to Public
description: Sheep Meadow, the rolling brilliant-green lawn in Central Park, may be closed to lollers, loungers and people-watchers from late fall to mid-April each year, but a $105,000 fee has opened it to the Walt Disney Company tomorrow for a commercial it plans to film there.

title: SYCAMORE PARTNERS AGREES TO ADD MEGO FINANCIAL
description: Sycamore Partners L.L.C. agreed yesterday to acquire the Mego Financial Corporation, a developer of time-share vacation properties, for about $120 million. Sycamore is a newly formed entity that will be financed by the New York based investment firm Blackacre Capital Group L.P. Mego, based in Las Vegas, Nev., has developed properties under the banner of Ramada Vacation Suites in five states. It had revenue of $67.5 million for the year ended Aug. 31. Under the agreement, Sycamore will pay $6 for each Mego share, less an expected adjustment in the range of 25 cents to 29 cents a share relating to the valuation of a receivable held by Mego. Mego has about 21 million shares outstanding.

title: 3 Boys Accused of Sexual Attack on Girl at School
description: Three 16-year-old boys forced a 14-year-old girl down to the basement of Lafayette High School in Brooklyn during the school day on Thursday and began sexually assaulting her, but fled when they heard a safety officer approaching, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALIN, ROBERT C.
description: MALIN-Robert C. On March 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Donna Spencer Malin, beloved son of Jacob (Jack) and Mollie Malin, beloved father of Judd Malin, Stephanie Malin Sherman. Dear brother of Herbert Malin. Funeral services Sunday in Temple Beth-El, 350 Roxbury Rd, Stamford, CT at 2 PM. Burial Beth-El Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to Temple Beth-El or the UJF of Stamford or the American Heart Association are appreciated.

title: Journal; Lord Of the Flies
description: Why did they do it?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRANSCRYPT INTERNATIONAL INC., Lincoln, Neb., an information-security company, said it had to delay filing its annual 10-K form with the Securities and Exchange Commission because its finances were still being audited. The company's stock plunged more than 39 percent.

title: Ferdinand Porsche, Creator of the Sports Car That Bore His Name, Is Dead at 88
description: Ferdinand Porsche, creator of the German sports car that bore his family name and son of the legendary engineer who designed the Volkswagen Beetle, died yesterday at his family's vacation home in the Austrian resort town of Zell am See. He was 88.

title: Legislators Reject Rowland's Tax Rebate, Favoring Other Measures
description: The State Legislature's tax-writing committee today rejected Gov. John G. Rowland's income-tax cut and rebate proposals, opting instead to approve a half-dozen other measures that include steps to provide more property-tax relief and to remove some sales taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSHEY, MARGARET
description: BUSHEY-Margaret. On March 27, 1998, after a long illness, in Mineola, NY. Beloved wife of Harold. Loving mother of Pat and Gary, Jeannetta and Lauren. Proud grandmother of Brendan and Lindsay. Wake at Cassidy Funeral Home, Mineola, NY, Sunday and Monday. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the L.I. Alzheimer's Foundation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: Crime and Punishment, Juvenile Division
description: After a tragedy like the one in Jonesboro, Ark., this week, Americans cry out for vengeance, for justice, for change! We want quick solutions, whether it is to a Mississippi flood, teen-age pregnancy, or children throwing children out of windows or blasting them with shotguns in schoolyards.

title: Tracing Crayola To Peekskill Roots
description: MENTION Crayolas to Kirk Moldoff and he will share the happy memories of how, in his youth, they helped shape the artistic abilities that later led him to become a medical illustrator.

title: PULSE; Story Line
description: What story do your clothes tell about you? If you're Jane Mayle, an owner of Phare, a men's and women's boutique that opened two weeks ago on suddenly stylish Elizabeth Street, they say that you're a well-dressed, well-traveled woman who dreams of being an Anna Magnani-esque gypsy. Such is the look invoked by the clothes: lace-and-velvet-trimmed camisoles and cardigans; button-down dresses, and loose, tailored pants, some of which sold out the first week.

title: Allure of 'Titanic,' Minus Ice, Is Packing Cruise Ship Cabins
description: After they marry in September, Colleen Murphy of New York and John Brady of Parlin, N.J., had planned to fly to Fiji or Paris on their honeymoon. But about six weeks ago the young couple -- she is 27, he 32 -- saw ''Titanic.'' They quickly changed their plans and booked their first cruise, a 12-day Mediterranean trip aboard the Norwegian Cruise Line's venerable Norway.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: PLAYING TO THE CAMERA

title: Students Who Make the Grade and Make Money
description: FOR most college students, the chance to manage real money is as rare as a professor who never assigns homework. But then there is the University of Northern Colorado.

title: 'Upscale' Music School Teaches All Sorts
description: To the Editor:

title: At End of the Road Trip, Knicks Hit a Brick Wall
description: The Knicks thought they had escaped embarrassment by making their way through a West Coast trip without losing to a team that was beneath them. All they had left was to play Seattle tonight. Even though it seemed only natural for the Knicks to struggle against a team with the talent and size of the Sonics at Key Arena, they did not expect to completely unravel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, PHILIP
description: GREENBERG - Philip, 83. Of Woodstock, NY, formerly of Jackson Heights, died March 19, 1998. Husband of the late Evelyn, father of Leslie and Robert, grandfather of Justin and Gavin, brother of Rabbi Sidney Greenberg and Sara Aboff, dear friend and companion of Shirley Fink. Former ''tie-coon'' extraordinaire, a lover of life and people, happy and always productive-he lived fully to the very end. Richer for having known him, he leaves behind a large family of relatives and friends and a long trail of smiles... Contributions may be made to the Woodstock Jewish Congregation Building Fund.

title: Our Medicine Chest
description: SAY Michigan and the automobile business comes to mind. To think of Texas is to think of the oil industry. And North Carolina still means big tobacco.

title: Ancient Troy Meets Modern Troubles In a Poet's Drama
description: HOPE and history can rhyme, declares the Chorus in ''The Cure at Troy,'' the Irish poet Seamus Heaney's sole play, once the longed-for ''tidal wave of justice'' rises up. It is no accident that ideas of amity and concord suffuse Mr. Heaney's drama based on Sophocles' rarely seen Greek tragedy ''Philoctetes.'' Modern political events spurred him to write his version of the fifth-century B.C. work.

title: Unsolicited Gift From Norwich
description: The members of the Society of the Founders of Norwich read with great interest the article about Montville's Mohegan Tribe's quest for the return of sacred objects. (''Mohegans Seeking Return of Objects Sacred to Tribe,'' Feb. 8).

title: Dow's Robust Run Draws Reappraisal
description: FOR many who are paid to forecast moves in the stock market, the outlook for 1998 seemed clear: the year would provide a reality check for investors, with Asia's problems and a slowing domestic economy crimping corporate profits and making double-digit percentage gains in broad market averages highly unlikely.

title: Habitats/Morris Township, N.J.; For a New Jersey Couple, No More Stately Mansion
description: FOR 30 years, Walter and Babette Bergner have lived in a stately re-creation of a New Orleans mansion, a New Jersey home that is a testament to craftsmanship.

title: This Singer Took a Song's Advice (da-da-da-Da)
description: Sixteen years ago, Earl (Speedo) Carroll, the lead singer of the Cadillacs, a doo-wop group that was big in the 50's, followed the dictates of one of that era's songs: ''Get a job.'' He had come to Public School 87 on West 78th Street for high school equivalency classes when he found out a custodial job was available there. He took it to tide him over when show business was slow, and, as he said, ''fell in love with the teenie-weenies.''

title: Wear It And Read It
description: Models, editors and designers taking a break from the runway action this week at New York's fall fashion shows will be able to brush up on their sartorial history. Kinsey Marable & Company, a seller of rare books, has set up a kiosk at the Seventh on Sixth shows in the tents in Bryant Park, with out-of-print books on fashion and style.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GODNICK, AUDREY
description: GODNICK-Audrey. On March 31, 1996. Two years ago. There will never be another like you.

title: DON'T TREAD ON MY TOQUE
description: Prompted by E. coli and salmonella fears, the California Legislature has restricted restaurants' use of raw foods. One regulatory victim is the Caesar salad. The statute dictates that its raw-egg-based dressing must be prepared tableside, under the diner's gaze. If the dressing is mixed out of sight, a ''pasteurized egg product'' should be substituted. But there's a loophole: if a diner specifically requests a raw egg, it's O.K. to whip it up backstage. Chefs, predictably, are howling about Big Brother seizing their whisks, so Carole Migden, a San Francisco Assemblywoman, has introduced a bill that would allow a restaurant to tell diners that raw ingredients will be used and let them swallow the outcome.

title: VIEWPOINT; A Corporate Future Built With New Blocks
description: THE recurring themes at the World Economic Forum, which concluded in Davos, Switzerland, early last month, clearly illustrated the extent to which the tectonic plates of business are shifting in unimaginable ways.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Get Real About Productivity
description: To the Editor:

title: Symphonies That Unfold as if Outside the Boundaries of Time
description: IF the questing, careening, troubled symphonies of Mahler continue to enthrall modern listeners because the music seems so powerfully to reflect where we are, in the collective psychology of our time, perhaps the aspiring and doggedly affirmative symphonies of Bruckner evoke a place where we would like to be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTON, BILL
description: ALTON-Bill. From Second City to Lincoln Center; a full and gifted life. Playhouse 90 and Candid Camera. Cannes Film Festival and Clio Awards. U. of Chicago, Bennington, Sarah Lawrence. Actor. Director. Teacher. A kind soul, dedicated to creating a safe place to act. Faithful to his belief that all stories-even the angry and bitter ones-are love stories. We love you, Bill. Thanks. It's ''eleven o'clock in Grovers Corners-You get a good rest, too. Good night.'' Bill Kern and Mariye Inouye

title: Manhattan Strength Lifts All Boroughs
description: DONALD PIERRE could not find the home he wanted for the price he could pay in his old neighborhood, Crown Heights, Brooklyn -- the one that would work for his growing family and bring in a bit of rental income.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In England, it is extraordinarily easy to start a company and extraordinarily difficult to open a bank account. In France, it's easy to open a bank account and a nightmare to start a company.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEIGER, HARRIETTE V.
description: ZEIGER-Harriette V. Died suddenly but peacefully in her home on March 26, 1998. She leaves behind her son R. Anthony Zeiger; her daughter Nancy Sylvor; her two grandchildren, Jeffrey and Andrew Zeiger; her beloved cousin Norman Rubin and her dearest friend, Ellen Rosenthal DeSario. She remained so vigorous in mind, body and spirit until the moment she left us, that now it must be time for her to rest. Go with love, dear one, but this world is a little darker for your leaving it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, SAM ''NAT.''
description: STEINBERG-Sam ''Nat.'' Of Miami Beach, FL, formerly of Williamsburg, Brooklyn. On March 27, 1998, age 95. Husband of May. He was predeceased by his first wife, Ethel. Foster father of Ernest and Herta Gottschalk and grandfather of Mark and Mathew Steinberg. Member of Knesset Israel of Miami Beach and Young Israel of Willliamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Appetite for Talent, Fed With Flexibility
description: WHEN Lisa Benne left her job as a seller of medical diagnostic equipment two years ago to join the Essential Data Corporation, a Stamford consulting firm, little did she expect to get breakfast at the office every morning, not to mention massages and other eclectic thank-you's, courtesy of her boss.

title: Business Class As a Way of Life
description: In an issue devoted primarily to air travel, I was quite disturbed to see that the only coverage of flight attendants included the image on the cover and the portrayal of some of us as easy pickups for business travelers (''The Cheating Kind,'' by Eric Konigsberg). What bothers me most about your in-depth reporting regarding the joys and maladies of the frequent flier is your exclusion of us.

title: Our Towns; Nothing Can Stop The Waves
description: AS surely as the day dawned bright and May-like, Joe Cerce knew he would be risking the wrath of his neighbors, not to mention the police.

title: One-Stop Luxury
description: Nightclubs have long been hip to the power of a discreet front door. Now, fashion and accessories designers are catching on. The understated facade of the town house at 22 East 72d Street conceals salon boutiques catering to those who wear embroidered velvet slippers with black tie. Mish New York, the jeweler, and Stubbs & Wootton, the party-slipper purveyor, opened as the Drawing Room on the third floor last spring; the resort-wear designer Steven Stolman moved in one floor up this month. They are no strangers to the Southampton, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., social set, some of whom looked right at home at Mr. Stolman's opening party.

title: Business Class As a Way of Life
description: So the members of the new business class aren't having their real needs met, lead lives full of stress, can't find a feeling of community and have a hard time meeting their family obligations. How, exactly, does that make them different from other Americans? The only difference I can come up with is that the rest of us don't have $7,000-a-month apartments in Hong Kong or $590 Prada weekend bags as compensation.

title: Trackers
description: THE HUNT CLUB By Bret Lott. 243 pp. New York: Villard Books. $23.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Plus-Size Model
description: VENUS OF WILLENDORF, where have you gone?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORCINO, NORMA FRANKS
description: FORCINO-Norma Franks. Age 59, died peacefully at home on March 27, 1998, with her loving family at her side after a courageous struggle with ovarian cancer. Throughout, she maintined her humor, wit and dignity, and gave us all inspiration and strength. She was a compassionate nurse who received her RN from NY Medical College's Flower and Fifth Avenue School of Nursing, and her masters in nursing from Marymount Manhattan College. She will be dearly remembered by all those she touched at both NYU's Skin and Cancer Center, and her father and brother's private practice where she worked until shortly before her death. She was adored by her two children Frank Forcino of NYC and Lydia Plachy of Montana, and their spouses Grace and Milan, three loving grandchildren Michael, Milan and Lydia. She is also survived by her beloved mother and father Dr. and Mrs. Andrew G. Franks, Sr., her cherished sister Joy Catapano, her devoted brother and sister-in-law, Drs. Andrew and Linda Franks, Jr. and her many nieces and nephews, all of NYC. Friends are invited to a prayer service on Monday, March 30, between 10 AM and 10:30 AM, at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. (20th St.), NYC, followed by Mass at R.C. Church of the Epiphany, 22nd St. and 2nd Ave., at 11 AM. Interment services will be private.

title: The Death of a Brilliant Surgeon Who Lived in the Fast Lane
description: HIS was a death that has evoked the legend and the mystery of a James Dean.

title: Delta to Tighten Rule On Carry-On Baggage
description: Delta Air Lines says it is making a new effort to restrict the amount of baggage and other personal belongings that passengers carry into its cabins.

title: 1998 BASEBALL PREVIEW: Boom Times; This Season Promises New Teams, Worse Pitching and Better Hitting
description: Listening to Tom Kelly, the longest-running manager in the major leagues, explain it, the phenomenon becomes simple to understand. Professor Kelly, who manages the Minnesota Twins when he is not sharing the fruits of his dozen years on the job, dissected the difficulty teams face every time the majors expand.

title: Clinton's Rwanda Apology Wasn't So Candid; Acting Too Late
description: To the Editor:

title: 19,368 Tickets Written In Police Crackdown
description: A three-day crackdown on speeders and other driving scofflaws last week netted more than double the usual number of moving-violation citations, the police said yesterday.

title: March 22-28; Not a Great Move
description: Great no more.

title: Mortal Combat
description: IN THE COUNTRY OF ILLNESS

title: How Cartel Tried to Buy Bank Group In Mexico
description: In the last two weeks, a scandal surrounding a bank that was almost taken over by narcotics traffickers has revealed how far drug money-laundering has reached into the upper echelons of Mexico's financial system.

title: The View From/Stevenson Dam; How to Fix or Replace an Aging Bridge Over the Housatonic?
description: IN the early 1900's, traveling Route 34 between the small towns of Monroe and Oxford meant crossing the Housatonic River west of Derby on a single-lane, wooden suspension bridge. By 1919, when the Connecticut Light and Power Company finished building the Stevenson Dam across the river, topped with a long, two-lane, concrete arch bridge, the landscape changed dramatically.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Forest Hills, Queens; Town and Country Close to Midtown
description: A MOSAIC-TILE mural on the front facade of the Greenpoint Bank at 71st Road and Queens Boulevard shows Forest Hills in the foreground, the towers of Manhattan in the far distance, and an amorphous sea of houses and apartment buildings in between.

title: The World; Democracy in China: Fear, Loathing, Halting Steps
description: AS China struggles to become a more modern nation, it is only a matter of time before the leadership concedes that in a modern state, leaders are elected, not self-selected.

title: Ya Gotta Relieve, and if Mets Do, There's Hope
description: Adequate starting pitching and above-average defense. Little speed and few marquee names. And maybe not enough hitting, at least until catcher Todd Hundley returns in midseason from elbow surgery.

title: Dole, Still at Watergate, Plays Offense
description: After Republicans burglarized the Watergate in 1972, a hometown reporter sheepishly asked Senator Bob Dole whether he had hidden the break-in tools in his one-bedroom apartment in the complex. (He said he had not.)

title: Blue Notes (Or Pink)
description: People have been shaking their booties at the Village Vanguard since 1935. But it wasn't until recently that baby bootees and jazz formed an unlikely combo. ''We sell these adorable baby bootees, even though we are a jazz club and not a gift shop,'' said Lorraine Gordon, the owner of the club, at 178 Seventh Avenue South (11th Street). The bootees (above) are by Charles Hacskaylo, the president of Pine Hosiery Mills in Star, N.C. He sent 100 pairs as a token of his love for jazz and the club. At $5 a pair, they soon sold out. Now, Mrs. Gordon is on her second reorder. ''I have given them to some of the musicians who have babies,'' she said. ''I even gave a pair to my old friend Ruth Brown, as a joke, since it was she who taught me the meaning of booty.'' MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Down by the Bay
description: If there's something worth saving -- from the Battleship New Jersey to the lives of people with cancer -- Trenton has probably authorized a license plate promoting the cause. The latest way for vehicle owners to do a good deed is to buy a Baymen's Heritage plate and help support the Barnegat Bay Decoy and Baymen's Museum and the future Tucker Seaport Project in Ocean County.

title: Buying A House in Foreclosure
description: THE classified newspaper advertisements at first seem unbelievable. Is it really possible to buy that foreclosed house in Larchmont, N.Y., or Upper Saddle River, N.J., or Greenwich, Conn., for only the amount the owners owe on their mortgage, plus late charges and lawyers' fees?

title: Vanguard's Index Killer
description: ASK John J. Nagorniak, manager of the Vanguard Growth and Income fund, how he manages to beat his rival funds year after year and he deadpans: ''We consistently bore the opposition to death.'' Such is the life of a quantitative fund manager.

title: In a Maine Outpost, A Master of Sound Has Built a Mecca
description: WHEN Bob Ludwig left the New York mastering studio Masterdisk in 1993 to start his own studio in this sleepy seaside town, he figured he would lose half his clients. He was wrong. Five years after opening Gateway Mastering Studios -- housed in a building tucked beneath a parking garage -- Mr. Ludwig and his staff have all the work they can handle.

title: The Money Man for Inspirations
description: IT SUITS an intellect that careens in a hundred directions, this painting in the conference room at the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation. It's a trompe l'oeil that shows two shelves of books from the late 20th century. The man who chose them for the painter is Scott McVay, the foundation's executive director, who from time to time whirls around to point to the works that animated the passions he is spinning out.

title: In Philadelphia Transit Talks, Uncertainty Rules
description: Despite its cherished reputation as the City of Brotherly Love, Philadelphia is accustomed to nasty labor disputes, and the latest one has been irritating people here for nearly two weeks.

title: When Life After Death Is the Company's Lot
description: THERE'S no good time to get bad news, but some times are worse than others. Nicole Maxwell was the humand resources director for Barrington International Hospitality Inc., an upstart hotel-management company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., eight months pregnant - and had moved the previous day to a new house in a new neighborhood - when the word came: The plane carrying her boss and father, Barry L. Conrad, on a United States trade mission to the former Yugoslavia was missing.

title: A Romantic Moment That Reverberates
description: ON the streets of Paris in 1950, two dreamy people, among oblivious strangers, stopped for one stolen kiss, an instinctual response to the impulse of love. It took a great photographer, Robert Doisneau, to implant that kiss in time and memory. Virtually everyone has seen the picture -- on posters, on postcards, on calendars, even on pillow cases.

title: Where AIDS Means Help
description: THE most emotional piece of public art in town stands in the office of the South Jersey AIDS Alliance on Gordon Alley: a mural, roughly seven tall by eight feet wide, of empty prescription drug bottles and vials. The names on the labels have been crossed out. You don't have to know what the drugs were for, how many of those who took them have since died, or how many still survive as clients of this nonprofit organization to be overcome by the wall's emotional statement.

title: Clinton's Rwanda Apology Wasn't So Candid; Try Debt Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: Secularism And Islam
description: When a squad of new young commando officers assembled for their diplomas on Friday at a military base in Kayseri, the regional commander, Gen. Seyfettin Seymen, told them they must be ready not just to fight wars, but also to suppress religious extremism.

title: Paddling Among Baja's Islands
description: THE Baja Peninsula is a contradictory land of heat and cold, sea and desert. The cactuses are often more widely separated than trees on a New York street and when the sun is up almost nothing moves. Even the rattlesnakes sleep in the shade of rocks, waiting for the night to relieve the heat as the temperatures fall 30 degrees or more soon after the sun drops. It is a land of spines and barbs, of tumbled seaside rocks sharp as hatchets. Life begins at the water's edge.

title: When Life After Death Is the Company's Lot
description: THERE'S no good time to get bad news, but some times are worse than others. Nicole Maxwell was the human resources director for Barrington International Hospitality Inc., an upstart hotel-management company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., eight months pregnant -- and had moved the previous day to a new house in a new neighborhood -- when the word came: The plane carrying her boss and father, Barry L. Conrad, on a United States trade mission to the former Yugoslavia was missing.

title: Fighting AIDS, Drop by Drop
description: A Hell's Kitchen bar on the side of the angels? Could be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, FREDERICK MYERS, DD
description: MORRIS-Frederick Myers, DD, STD. 92, husband of the late Dorothy Quincy (Hastings) Morris, died March 27, 1998, in Bloomfield, CT. He was born in Los Angeles in 1906, son of Lewis G. and Ruth (Myers) Morris. Dr. Morris served as Rector of St. Thomas Church, New York for 18 years from 1954 to 1972. He is survived by three daughters, Dorothy Curtiss, Ruth Keitt, and Elizabeth Lenerville; and 15 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the convenience of the family in Bloomfield, CT. Burial to take place at All Saints Cemetery, Morris, NY. Memorial donations may be made to the Community Fund of Duncaster, 40 Loeffler Rd., Bloomfield, CT 06002.

title: Living In Princeton Borough
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Desert Meets the Sea
description: AT the southernmost tip of the Baja California peninsula, where the Gulf of California meets the Pacific Ocean, is the fast-growing resort region of Los Cabos. Long a mecca for big-game fishermen, Los Cabos is about as far as one can go in Baja -- it's more than 700 miles from the California border and at the bottom of a landmass known for an austere desert beauty. Yet burgeoning tourism is rapidly changing this corner of Mexico.

title: Troubleshooting and Repairing Soffits
description: SOFFITS are the narrow strip of ceiling material (either wood or metal) that covers the underside of the roof eaves. This rather innocuous area is often ignored by homeowners until rot or decay develops. This is usually caused by leaks in the roof that drip down and collect in the eaves and on the soffit boards. Homeowners should inspect the soffits every spring because decay is an indication of even greater damage in the roof.

title: Margaret Asbury, Daniel Vasquez
description: Margaret Anne Asbury, a daughter of David J. Mooney of Exeter, N.H., and the late Frances A. Mooney, was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel Abad Vasquez, the son of Dr. Lutgarda A. Vasquez and Dr. Gil T. Vasquez of Brooklyn. The Rev. Celestino V. Pascual, a Roman Catholic priest who is a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: Paul Robeson's Life and Legacy
description: In a year filled with centennials, another important anniversary is about to be celebrated: that of the birth of Paul Robeson.

title: Few Blushes at Oscars of Makeup
description: THE SETTING -- The CEW Beauty Awards, known as the Oscars of the beauty industry. Fifteen hundred people from the beauty and cosmetics world gathered in a Waldorf-Astoria ballroom to receive awards for their products from Cosmetics Executive Women, the industry trade group. Among the honorees: Mascara Flash from Christian Dior, Skin-So-Soft Bug Guard (Avon) and Pore Perfect Deep Cleansing Nose Strips (Biore).

title: On the Fourth Attempt, An Eastern Team Wins
description: NEW HAMPSHIRE 7, WISCONSIN 4

title: Retail Center Is Proposed In East Harlem
description: Amid intense government efforts to lure commercial development to the blighted manufacturing areas of Harlem and the South Bronx, city and state officials will announce a plan today to replace an abandoned East Harlem wire factory with a three-block-long shopping complex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, PAULINE
description: BLOOM-Pauline. At age 95. Loving aunt of Shonna, Barry and Joel Levine, Judith Pearlman, and Dr. Kenneth Robinson. Services private.

title: A Dreamy Sojourn in Helsinki
description: IN the Helsinki Airport, at the start of a long winter weekend in the Finnish capital, I got an interesting piece of advice from the immigration agent who stamped my passport: ''You don't get much vacation in America. You should strike.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: PULSE; Designer.com
description: New Yorkers on the prowl for discount fashions may take sample sales in SoHo for granted. But for bargain hunters in the Midwest or in countries like Bulgaria, the search is not nearly as easy. Now, some of them are turning to the Internet. Piece Unique, an on-line catalogue, sells women's clothes and accessories by names like Armani, Ungaro and Issey Miyake at a discount. A printed Ungaro set (left) is $350, about half the retail price, said Catherine Leroy, who founded the site -- www.pieceunique.com -- last June. Ms. Leroy, a French photojournalist who lives in Los Angeles, buys the items from sources like designers and retailers. Many, she said, were once worn by actresses or models, so sizes are small: 4 to 8. But a classified section has more options, including vintage items. (A 1950's crocodile Hermes handbag just sold for $3,400.) The reach is global, with clients from Japan, Argentina and Eastern Europe -- reflecting her philosophy that fashion is a ''common tribal language.''CINNAMON BRUNMIER

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: WAS IT SOMETHING I SAID?

title: From Wild Talk and Friendship To Five Deaths in a Schoolyard
description: The sun was beginning to shine brightly early Tuesday over the scrub pines and oak trees surrounding the neat red-brick house on a knoll here when Andrew Golden and Mitchell Johnson, as quietly as they could, broke a single pane of glass on the basement door, reached through, released two locks and slipped inside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORUT, FLORENCE (NEE BOYLE)
description: BORUT-Florence (nee Boyle). Of Rockville Centre, NY, on March 27, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Phillip M. Loving and devoted mother of James R., Phyllis Gallagher, Richard, Robert and the late Phillip. Adored grandmother of twelve and great-grandmother of one. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Ave., Rockville Centre, today 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral, Monday, 10 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY.

title: The World: Dueling Mullahs; Iran's Gladhander Takes on the Leader
description: ON ''Clean Air Day'' last month, Iran's President, Mohammed Khatami, took public transportation to work. Accompanied by his chador-clad wife, Mr. Khatami got into a communal taxi, then a bus, then another taxi, rather than use a gas-guzzling limousine. The next day, most of Teheran's newspapers ran front-page photographs of him chatting to a fellow passenger -- a woman -- on the bus.

description: Barney's Great Adventure

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: CRUISE

title: Now! Just 15 Weeks: Big Stars in a Big Hurry
description: WHEN Gregory Mosher, the director and sometime producer, was crunching numbers and trying to decide whether to bring John Leguizamo's one-man show ''Freak'' to Broadway after its successful Off Broadway engagement, he already knew it would be a limited run. It had to be.

title: The Reality Is Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURMAN, HERMAN JOSEPH, M.D.
description: BURMAN-Herman Joseph, M.D. 7/14/1898-3/30/1988. A graduate of Fordham University and Tufts Medical School, Dr. Burman was Director of the Department of Otolaryngology and Bronchoesophagology at Harlem Hospital and was a consultant at several New York City hospitals. He held several academic appointments at area medical schools including Columbia University, New York Medical College and Polyclinic Medical School. He was the author of ''Textbook of Diseases of the Nose and Throat,'' as well as numerous medical journal articles. A Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, a Diplomate of the American Board of Otolaryngology and a Fellow of the American Academy of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology, he was also a member of many other professional organizations. ''A soft answer turneth away wrath.''

title: The Cheating Kind
description: ''The Cheating Kind'' (by Eric Konigsberg, March 8) sounds like an apologia for President Clinton. Are you sure it wasn't written by Dick Morris? It is amazing that the so-called cheaters' comments are so similar to those that have been spinning around in the news recently:

title: INSIDE
description: Lawyers Accuse Clinton Of Obstructing Justice

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, MURIEL
description: FUCHS-Muriel. On March 23, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Paul Fuchs. Beloved mother of Emily and the late Edward. Adored Nana of Lyle and Jared. Cherished mother-in-law of Charlie. Services were held March 26 in Great Neck with interment in Atlanta, GA.

title: A New Pollster
description: Manhattanville College recently joined the ranks of other academic institutions as a political pollster. The college president, Richard A. Berman, who described polling as a ''great way of teaching analysis to students,'' said that as an institution of higher learning, Manhattanville was an ideal place to raise issues and ''focus the debate.''

title: On Hearing Her Sing, Gershwin Made 'Porgy' 'Porgy and Bess'
description: IN his tragically short life, George Gershwin knew only one Bess, and this bittersweet fact has framed Anne Wiggins Brown's life. She was that Bess in the original production of Gershwin's operatic masterwork based on Dorothy and DuBose Heyward's theatrical adaptation of Heyward's novel ''Porgy.''

title: Ms. McCormick And Mr. Baruch
description: Karen Margaret McCormick and Gregory Mark Baruch were married yesterday in Washington. The Rev. Joseph Lacey officiated and Rabbi Arthur Blecher took part in the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church.

title: Use It to Educate
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Savior or 'Slumlord'?
description: For 20 years Banana Kelly, a pioneer grassroots housing group in the South Bronx, has built and rehabilitated town houses and apartment buildings on acre after acre of burned-out rubble. Its chairwoman, Yolanda Rivera, has been honored at the White House and at the United Nations, and has become a well-known symbol of local revival.

title: Got a Police Problem? Keep It to Yourself.
description: THE story of Melva Max, the Chelsea restaurant owner arrested and strip-searched after flagging down a police car last October, has lost its dark hilarity. Acting with unusual speed, the Civilian Complaint Review Board recently decided that Ms. Max's allegations that the night-shift sergeant in the car and his driver had used excessive force were unfounded. According to the official letter sent to Ms. Max, this ''means that the acts complained of did not occur.'' The letter did not deal with the larger issues of false arrest and abuse of authority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, HARRIET
description: ROSENBERG-Harriet. Formerly of Valley Stream, LI. Passed away on March 22, 1998 in Raleigh, NC. Beloved wife of the late Sam. Mrs. Rosenberg is survived by her son Steven, his wife Kathleen and her daughter Pearl McKnight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, SELMA (NEE HALPERT)
description: ROTH-Selma (nee Halpert). On Tuesday, March 17th, 1998. Of Palm Beach, Florida. Formerly of Massapequa, New York. Beloved wife of A. Sidney. Loving mother of Jonathan of Westport, CT, Peter of Rochester, NY and Leslie Silverstein of Andover, MA. Dear sister of I. Lawrence. Devoted grandmother of David, Michael, Jamie, Scott and Brett. Donations may be made in her memory to B'nai Brith, 1640 Rhode Island Ave N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036.

title: Sports of The Times; Kentucky's Newton Has Come Full Circle
description: AS the Kentucky Wildcats took the Alamodome floor on Friday for the final practice before their Final Four game against Stanford, C. M. Newton sat courtside and took in the atmosphere. Tubby Smith, the Wildcats' first-year head coach, came over and shook his hand. Newton, Kentucky's athletic director, wished Smith luck -- and blessings. A day later, an overtime victory over tall, tough Stanford completed Kentucky's improbable run to the national championship game.

title: Tied Up in Knots In the Race for a Shoe
description: WHEN you have spent countless hours calling Kissimmee, Fla., Dry Ridge, Ky., and Pigeon Forge, Tenn., in search of silver shoes, you are most definitely a fashion obsessive. I know. For months, I have been driven to find Nike Air Max Metallics (Code No. 104096-061) in my size.

title: Urban and Rural, Rise and Fall
description: YOU can't keep a good museum down. The Yale Center for British Art in New Haven is undergoing renovation, and consequently will have no exhibitions during 1998. Until last year, however, the center's director, Patrick McCaughey, was the director of the Wadsworth Atheneum. Largely due to this link, 43 paintings from the 18th and 19th centuries were taken to Hartford to form an absorbing exhibition, ''Canaletto to Constable, Paintings of Town and Country From the Yale Center for British Art.''

title: The Happy Medium
description: Other Powers

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Indian Artists Exhibit at Restaurant
description: PAINTINGS by Dipali Bhattacharya depict the landscapes and cityscapes of present-day India, setting dreamy flower scenes against the street life of Calcutta. Yusuf Arakkal revels in both abstraction and figure painting, his large canvases warm with the tones of the earth. Both artists say contemporary Indian painting is flourishing, at once liberated from and inextricably entwined with its ancient traditions.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Their Inward Parts
description: At first, there seems to be no trace of a smile in Francis Bacon's ''Study of Henrietta Moraes Laughing'' (1969), one of many portraits of Moraes that Bacon (1909-92) painted over the years. All one sees is a distorted face with eyelids closed over deep-set eyes, the face in shades of white, ocher and black, overlaid in patches with marks in red and magenta like bloody fingerprints. Yet in the mangled lower half of the face (where violent white brushstrokes and superimposed volumes compete for attention and hint at turmoil), the viewer eventually can distinguish what may be a row of pearly white teeth; to their left, perhaps, is Moraes's restrained smile a moment before (or after) laughter; to their right, an ominous black patch, like a bullet hole. With 233 color reproductions illustrating Bacon's variations on a theme -- series of three (or two) studies for a portrait or self-portrait, single portraits and studies, diptychs portraying different subjects, as well as details of all of the above -- BACON: Portraits and Self-Portraits (Thames and Hudson, $60), by France Borel, a Belgian art historian, provides ample opportunity to examine the ways the artist had of delving into his subjects -- friends, lovers, admirers and himself. Most of these approaches appear violent, involving painterly renditions of flayed skin; cheekbones, jaws and necks defined by savage brushstrokes; hollowed eye sockets; torn ears; extreme dislocation of features, all in a riot of spurting colors, except for one constant: the portraits' solid background. Again and again, Bacon returned to the same subjects -- Moraes, George Dyer, Isabel Rawsthorne, Lucian Freud, Peter Beard and Muriel Belcher -- in an effort to capture and convey their inner turmoils, secrets, beauty and mortality. He directed the same relentless attention to his own features (his ample cheeks, his squarish jaw) with the same purpose. In one series from 1967, his face seems to be sucking itself in; in a 1979 study, the contours of his eyes and lips, and the line that joins his nostril to the corner of his mouth, are ghoulish, drawn in purple on a bluish-white face; and in a 1980 series, bloody marks cover large areas of his emaciated self-portrait. In his introduction, Milan Kundera writes that Bacon was in search of an ''infinitely fragile self shivering in a body.'' As this book makes clear, Bacon's search never ended. Christine Schwartz Hartley

title: Business Class As a Way of Life
description: I have just read ''The New Business Class,'' by Pico Iyer, and found it compelling. I skimmed the rest of the issue and have placed it in my computer bag. It looks so good, I want to save it for later this week -- when I have four hours to kill on a coast-to-coast flight.

title: Biggest Sender Of Junk Mail On Internet Agrees to Stop
description: In a consent decree that represents a turning point in the escalating war against Internet junk E-mail, or ''spam,'' the company most responsible for stuffing millions of E-mail boxes with unsolicited advertisements has agreed to pay $2 million to settle the last of several lawsuits brought against it by Internet service providers.

title: Culture Zone; Information, Please
description: Watch a few television dramas and you can become an expert on summary-judgment hearings (''The Practice''), motions to suppress evidence (''Law and Order''), fractured fibulae (''E.R.'') or Rasmussen's encephalitis (''Chicago Hope''). Pick a novel from the best-seller list and you can learn to act like a noble lawyer (John Grisham's ''Street Lawyer'') or a crooked lawyer (John Grisham's ''Partner''). Go to the movies and Will Hunting (Matt Damon in ''Good Will Hunting'') will prove complex mathematical theories so fast even Robin Williams can't keep up, but then Will is exceptional. In this era of information overload, only a certified genius is allowed to stay so far ahead of the audience.

title: Correction
description: A photo caption accompanying a March 15 article about owners' resistance to higher liability rates for sport utility vehicles incorrectly identified the model of the vehicle driven by David Gregorino, an opponent of higher rates. Mr. Gregorino drives a Chevrolet Tahoe, not a Chevrolet Suburban.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Kissing the Beehive

title: Smart Looks, and Tasty American Food
description: LAURA'S is just what Oyster Bay needs and its residents know it. They have taken this newly opened American restaurant to their hearts and made it an instant hit. Even midweek evenings find nearly every table filled; on Saturdays there are crowds waiting in the bar.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, GERTRUDE ASPELL
description: WRIGHT-Gertrude Aspell, 89. Of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of NYC, died at her home March 14 after a long illness. Active in many civic and social groups, she served on boards & committees of YWCA Residences, the Cosmopolitan Club and the China Institute. She is predeceased by her husband, Frank C. Wright, Jr. (1982); survivors include a sister Hope A. Young of NY, NY; daughters Gill W. Bentley, Perrysburg, OH., and Gail W. Goltra, Middleburg, VA, and NY, NY; two grandchildren and two step-grandchildren. Memorial services are scheduled 5PM, April 25, The Barr Terrace, Delray Beach, FL and 11 A.M., June 20, at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Edgartown, MA. In lieu of flowers, those planning an expression of sympathy are asked to consider: Delray Beach Gift Tree Program, Delray Beach, FL; The Martha's Vineyard Preservation Trust, Inc, Edgartown, MA; or Hospice by the sea, Boca Raton, FL.

title: Versailles Treasures Travel to Mississippi
description: The Sun King goes to Mississippi: Approximately 150 objects from Versailles will be on display in Jackson, beginning April 1, including a re-creation of a royal bedchamber with fabrics from the late 17th century, the famous ''Portrait of Louis XIV'' (1702) by Hyacinthe Rigaud and a specially commissioned 10-ton copy of Bernini's equestrian statue of the king (1680). ''Splendors of Versailles'' runs through Aug. 31 at the Mississippi Arts Pavilion. Jackson will be the only stop for the show.

title: Glimpse of a Warm, Witty Past
description: MILTON BOND, a self-taught artist who was born in Bridgeport and lives in Stratford, is celebrating his 80th birthday with an exhibition at the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport.

title: Killings Illuminate Culture of White Supremacists
description: When William Mueller, his wife and her little girl vanished from their home in the wooded Ozark mountains of northwest Arkansas, his mother-in-law feared that they had gone underground with one of the white separatist groups that Mr. Mueller admired. But the truth was worse.

title: Q&A/Gayle King; On Television, for News and Talk, Too
description: SINCE last September, Gayle King has added to her celebrity as co-anchor of WFSB's 5:30 P.M. news and Oprah Winfrey's best friend. That's because Ms. King, 43 years old, is also seen weekdays on 205 television stations as the host of ''The Gayle King Show,'' a half-hour production by Eyemark Entertainment done as a companion to the ''Martha Stewart Living'' show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, MILDRED E.
description: HILL-Mildred E., born July 23, 1903, died March 26, 1998 in Lakewood, NJ. A social worker and graduate of Barnard College, she reorganized and became president and head worker in 1934 of The Neighborhood House of The City of New York, a settlement house begun in 1910 which she continued to lead for nearly forty years, until it merged with St. Matthew's and St. Timothy's Neighborhood Center. Miss Hill's tutoring and social services programs continue at the Neighborhood Center for the benefit of the upper West Side community. Miss Hill is survived by her nephew, David Hill of Creedmoor, NC and her niece, Virginia Senne of Mancos, CO. A memorial service will be announced later. Gifts can be sent to St. Matthew's and St. Timothy'sNeighborhood Center, 26 West 84 St., NY, NY 10024.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rydex Is Bulking Up With Sector Offerings
description: The battle for sector fund assets is about to heat up. The Rydex Series Trust, whose arsenal of 8 index-based funds has become increasingly popular with market-timing and other investors, is introducing 14 no-load sector funds.

title: When the Warning Is More Like a Speed Bump
description: From a 1990 California training videotape, ''Questioning 'Outside Miranda','' by Devallis Rutledge, assistant district attorney, Orange County:

title: Backtalk; Really Radical Realignment
description: You want radical realignment? Put first base down the left-field line.

title: L.I. Sound Benefiting From Rise In Support
description: STANDING along the wind-whipped shores of Long Island Sound earlier this month, Gov. George E. Pataki waxed poetic about the once foul estuary, describing it as potentially one of the major environmental comeback stories of the decade. Other New York politicians, too, took bows that stormy morning as millions of dollars from the state's Clean Water, Clean Air Bond Act came to their constituencies for projects in the Sound.

title: Dangers in Peru
description: To the Editor: The article on Arequipa (''Altar to Altar in a Peruvian City of White,'' Dec. 14) was terrific -- the place sounds fascinating. But readers should know that two American visitors were mugged there last July, just a block or two off the main plaza.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORCZYNER, HARRY
description: TORCZYNER-Harry. Order of Leopold, Belgium, in his 88th year, son of the late Numa and Rachel Torczyner, precious husband of Marcelle Siva, adored father of Evelyn Musher Shechter and Denise Wiseman, respected fatherin-law of Samuel Shechter and Sam Wiseman, doting grandfather of Joshua and Shira Musher, Naomi Shechter, Rafi Musher, and Danielle Diller, proud great grandfather of Shoshana Rachel and Jeremy Max Musher, loving brother of Jacques and Berthe Torczyner. Service Sunday 2PM, at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

description: Sara Weaver is the oldest daughter of Randy Weaver, a onetime white separatist whose wife and son were killed during an 11-day standoff with the F.B.I. at Ruby Ridge, Idaho, in 1992.

description: The New York City Department of Environmental Protection has announced revised regulations governing fishing and boating permits at reservoirs that supply city dwellers with their drinking water.

description: WITH foreign travel setting new records almost every year, many more people are at risk from malaria, hepatitis-B and who knows what else.

description: School financing has dominated the education debate for more than a year, leaving another troublesome topic -- state takeover of failing districts -- neglected by politicians and education officials.
