description: Jayson Williams was seated in a restaurant just a few hours after he had walked off the court during the Nets' 82-76 loss to the Boston Celtics with a fractured right thumb on Friday night, and a little less time since he had his forearm in a hard cast.

title: BENEFITS
description: Authors Converge

title: A.L. Central
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. In the East, the Yankees are picked to finish in second place.

title: Indonesian Students Keep Protests Well Within the Pale
description: They chant, ''Reform or death!'' They stage tea-only hunger strikes. They burn the President in effigy. But they are usually careful not to leave the grounds of their campuses, where the gates are ringed by armed police officers.

title: Here's the Windup, and the Pitch. But Can the Diamondbacks Score?
description: Jerry colangelo, managing general partner of the Arizona Diamondbacks, is a tall, plain-spoken man with the aquiline nose of a Roman emperor. On this cold afternoon in late February he is sitting in the third-base stands of his expansion team's spring-training park in Tucson, Ariz., watching the team play its first-ever intrasquad game.

title: Beef, Ostriches and Turtles Moving to West Side
description: The Ottomanelli brothers have learned that good meat pays: they opened another butcher shop, at 395 Amsterdam Avenue at 79th Street, two weeks ago. ''People said, 'why don't you move to the West Side?' '' said Joseph Peter Ottomanelli, 51, the president. ''We were bursting at the seams on the East Side; we said it would be nice.'' Their butcher shops are noted for their in-house aged beef, fowl and exotic game, including ostrich and turtle. Last year, they even ordered alligator meat for a customer.

title: Parents' Lawsuit
description: In a class-action lawsuit brought on behalf of autistic children in the state, four parents have sued the state, Westchester County and New York City on charges that the defendants failed to provide appropriate treatment for their children as required by law.

title: Daniel Massey, a Stage Actor With Great Range, Dies at 64
description: Daniel Massey, a stylish and versatile actor who performed with equal ease in plays by Shaw, Wilde and Pinter as well as in Broadway musicals and was for many years an important member of the Royal Shakespeare Company and the Royal National Theater, died on Wednesday in a London hospital. He was 64.

title: Insurance Relief, Under Your Nose
description: ALL eyes are on the state Assembly in the expectation that it will pull a legislative rabbit out of its hat and give New Jersey drivers a reduction of at least 10 percent in their annual auto insurance premiums -- infamously the highest in the nation -- without reducing the level of coverage.

title: Grumblings Over the Rise of Dividend Fees
description: FOR nearly a quarter century, the Gillette Company invited its stockholders to plow their dividends back into additional shares of the shaving and toiletries giant. And whether the amounts were large or meager, this process cost them not a penny in commissions.

title: Cincinnati Fund Looks No Farther Than Its Backyard
description: CINCINNATI'S dated nickname -- Queen of the West -- says a lot: it has been a long time since the city that invented air mail (by balloon), professional baseball and Ivory soap made waves as a driver of innovation and growth. In fact, Mark Twain remarked, ''If the world would end, I would come to Cincinnati for everything happens here 10 years later.''

title: A.L. East
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. In the East, the Yankees are picked to finish in second place.

title: Mall Has Plenty to Eat, but Nothing Much Left to Buy
description: When Lundy Brothers restaurant on Emmons Avenue reopened in December 1995, prompting memories of family lobster feasts, the only problem was getting a weekend reservation. Once billed as America's largest restaurant, seating 2,400, the new Lundy's was scaled down to seat 800. The rest of its 42,000-square-foot tile-roofed stucco building was filled six months later by a Japanese restaurant, Momoyama, and a shopping mall, called Lundy's Landing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROONEY, ANNE E. (NEE DAVIDSON)
description: ROONEY-Anne E. (nee Davidson) on March 27, 1998. Retired NYC public school teacher. Beloved wife of the late John; devoted mother of Paul K., Elizabeth Garbarino and the late John P. Cherished grandmother of six and one great grandchild. Reposing at McNulty Funeral Home, 3006 Middletown Rd., Bronx, NY today 2-5 and 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10:15 AM, St. Helena's Church. Interment St. Raymond's.

title: F.D.A. Is Investigating Use of a Dangerous Fingernail Adhesive
description: In the aftermath of a fraud scheme that resulted in Florida's revoking the licenses of 1,700 manicurists last year, officials here and in other states are investigating the use of a restricted chemical that is blamed for severe fingernail damage and other health problems.

title: At This Animal Shelter, It's the Humans Who Are Fighting
description: The word shelter usually implies haven, but the Tinton Falls animal shelter, in Monmouth County, was anything but, according to 15 people who were banned from volunteer work there last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEBALD, CECILLE ROSNER
description: HEBALD-Cecille Rosner, 82. Born in New York City, died in Rome, Italy February 7, 1998. Beloved wife of renowned sculptor Milton Hebald, mother of Los Angeles architect Margo Hebald Heymann, grandmother of Lara Hebald Embry and Sergei Hebald Heymann; all who miss her with deep sorrow.

title: Maid of Honor
description: The Fiery Pantheon

title: Tennessee, La. Tech: Legacies Of Success
description: Like old money versus new, Louisiana Tech and Tennessee represent different dynasties in women's college basketball.

title: Streetscapes/The Little Red School House at 196 Bleecker Street; Progressive Education in a Onetime Mission Church
description: ONLY the annex of The Little Red School House is red, and now the whole thing is getting bigger. The school's picturesque, Italian-style facade at 196 Bleecker Street, at Sixth Avenue, was built as a mission church in 1920, but was taken over by the progressive school in 1932. Later the school bought the old row houses at 200-202 Bleecker Street, where it now plans a $1 million expansion.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC; At the Met, Some Are Sure to Boo the New
description: FORGET about the fat lady. These days, the opera ain't over till the audience sings. The recent opening night of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Lohengrin,'' which has its final performance on Thursday evening, ended with banshee shrieks of apparently homicidal intent aimed at the director, Robert Wilson.

title: Boston Has a Message for the Bronx: Watch Out for Garciaparra
description: Nomar Garciaparra, the embodiment of a Gold Glove shortstop and Silver Slugger, did more for the precious metals market last year than did the famed financier Warren Buffett.

title: Clinton Commemorates the Struggle to End Apartheid
description: President Clinton commemorated the moral courage of the long struggle against apartheid here today, but he also turned his attention to the gritty, complex tasks of state-building, crime-fighting and economic development that have succeeded it.

title: The Nation; Who? Me a Mason? Britain Sees Threat
description: FREEMASONRY, the mysterious and ritualistic fraternal society that began in Britain more than 350 years ago, has only one secret left -- its membership list -- and now the Government is trying to make it public.

title: Israeli Arabs March Home, To a Place They Can't Live In
description: Viewed from a distance through the thick haze of a sandstorm, the marchers with their upheld sheets of red and green paper seemed to merge with the flowering fields of the Galilee.

title: In a Battle of Teen Angst, Williams Settles Down to Overcome Kournikova
description: Girls will be girls, even globe-trotting millionaire girls who have been designated as the future of their sport. And since these two could not make up their minds which one was going to squeeze the juvenile errors from her game and play tennis worthy of a Lipton Championships crown and its $235,000 payday, the 17-year-old Venus Williams and the 16-year-old Anna Kournikova pushed their final-round match into a third set.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, LEONARD W.
description: KATZ-Leonard W. Born July 24, 1913, died March 24, 1998. Beloved husband of Mildred Hill Katz. Beloved father of John W. Katz of D.C., Laura L. Katz of Baltimore. Stepfather of Tony Hill of Berkeley, CA., and Polly Hill Landess of New York. Also survived by one grand-daughter and five grandsons. In mourning at home.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about living in the City Island section of the Bronx misstated the length of the island. It is a mile and a half, not half a mile.

title: Packing (the Schedule) for the Weekend
description: WE arrived Friday morning and left Monday afternoon, yet in three and a half days, we managed to experience the quintessence of London, piecing together a mini-vacation with the sweep and swagger of a 10-day tour. We saw three plays, visited two art galleries, cruised an outdoor antiques market, enjoyed a chamber music concert, dined in four memorable restaurants, shopped for our grandsons and walked our feet to a frazzle. In extolling this jam-packed adventure, I'm not saying more is always better, but when you're on a tight schedule, more is the point. And in our case, more turned out to be marvelous indeed.

title: Thousands March in France to Protest Far-Right Push for Power
description: Tens of thousands of people took to the streets of Paris and other cities today to protest power-sharing deals in regional parliaments with the far-right National Front.

title: Sentimental Favorite Ousted in Bridge Play
description: A sentimental favorite in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals was ousted from the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championships here last night by the narrowest of margins.

title: N.L. East
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. In the East, the Mets are picked to finish in second place.

title: A.L. West
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. In the East, the Yankees are picked to finish in second place.

title: Wendy Lashin, Todd Sinett
description: Wendy Jennifer Lashin, a daughter of Judith and Arnold Lashin of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Todd Alexander Sinett, the son of Annette Sinett and Dr. Sheldon Sinett of Merrick, N.Y. Cantor Robert Abelson officiated at the Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, BETSEY CUSHING
description: WHITNEY-Betsey Cushing. We mourn the death of our beloved mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother, Betsey Cushing Whitney, who died on March 25, 1998. Her sense of humor, her determination and her courage will be with us always. Our thanks to all who have communicated their love and support. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held on April 25 at 11AM, Christ Church, Northern Boulevard, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, contributions to North Shore University Hospital and New York Hospital.

title: Oil Jumps, but Users May Be Safe
description: THE price of crude oil took a large jump last week after several leading producer nations said they would cut output. But while the stocks of oil companies moved up on the news, the stocks of airlines and trucking companies took a hit.

title: Scouting Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Health Care Provider And the Bottom Line
description: I am writing in response to Dr. Elaine Fox's letter entitled ''When the Bottom Line Affects Health Care'' [Mar. 8].

title: Reason for Dramatic Drop In Crime Puzzles the Experts
description: Crime has declined dramatically for six years, but new studies prepared for a national conference of academic experts on crime suggest that criminologists are no closer now to understanding the reasons than when the downturn was first detected.

title: Michelle Silverman, Kenneth Beckman
description: Michelle Faye Silverman, a daughter of Wendy Schreiber of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Norman H. Silverman, was married last evening to Dr. Kenneth Alan Beckman, a son of Charlotte and Phillip Beckman of Columbus, Ohio. Rabbi Robert Lennick officiated at the Doral Arrowood Resort in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: Christ the King Keeps Title
description: CHRIST THE KING 70, CORCORAN 62

title: Hey Kids, It's Showtime!
description: GOTHAM'S great fashion houses are humming in anticipation of their biggest week of the year, the showing of the fall women's collections. Chaos grows with every Concorde load of buyers and editors who arrive, tired and a bit cranky from weeks of shows in Europe.

title: In Sheet Metal, From Apprentice To Company Owner
description: LUCKY is how Joseph Massaro describes himself. ''I've always been lucky,'' Mr. Massaro said in discussing the career that took him from apprentice to owner of the Elmsford Sheet Metal Works, the largest privately owned sheet metal company in the six counties north of New York City.

title: 3 New Books Focus On National Parks
description: Those heading for the national parks this summer have three new books to help plan their visits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, PHILIP
description: DAVIS-Philip. The lawyer who established the precedent that a purchasor of a ticket on the New York Central Railroad is contractually entitled to a seat, died March 26, 1998 in Basking Ridge, NJ at the age of 90. Mr. Davis was born January 10, 1908 and worked from the age of 12 when his father died. He graduated from Fordham Law School in 1929 and opened his own office for the practice of law in November 1930. He continued to practice law in New York City until October 17, 1997 when he suffered a stroke. During law school, Mr. Davis worked as the chief usher at the Mark Strand Theatre. In 1937, Mr. Davis purchased a ticket to travel on the New York Central Railroad from Albany to N.Y. The train did not have sufficient seats for some of the ticketholders and Mr. Davis filed suit seeking recovery of $47.80. In 1937, Mr. Davis won a decision from the New York Court of Appeals holding that a ticketholder is entitled to a seat and that the railroad had an obligation to add additional cars to accommodate all of the passengers. In 1973, Mr. Davis sued the Penn Central Railroad for $1.80 because he was not provided with a seat on a trip from Grand Central Station to North White Plains. Relying on his prior precedent, he won a judgment against Penn Central Railroad for $1.80 plus $10 for discomfort. Mr. Davis became a Mason on December 6, 1934 and served as Grand Master of Pacific Lodge No. 233 in 1942. He was also president of Rehoboth Lodge No. 38 of B'nai B'rith in 1941. He was an active and devoted alumnus of Fordham Law School & organized reunions of the Class of 1929 every five years from 1934 through 1994. Mr. Davis organized a group called ''The Strand Alumni'' comprised of the ushers at the Mark Strand Theatre from 1926-1930 which met every five years from 1935 on. Mr. Davis is survived by his wife, Miriam, his son, Jed Davis; his daughter, Helen Davis Chaitman; by his grandchildren, Jennifer Chaitman, Alison Davis Curry, Larissa Rose, Aglaia Davis, and Rhadamanthus Davis; and by his great-grandchild, Emma Davis Curry. A memorial service will be held by his family at the Princeton Club, 15 West 43rd Street, on May 2, 1998 at noon.

title: Kofi Annan's Next Test
description: A few minutes before noon on sunday, Feb. 22, three black Mercedes sedans pulled into the U-shaped driveway of the Baghdad villa in which the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, and his staff had been quartered since their arrival in Iraq two days earlier. These were not the same drivers who had taken Annan to his repeated negotiating sessions at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; these were Saddam Hussein's personal drivers, among the very few people permitted to know the Iraqi President's whereabouts. They had come to take the Secretary General to his climactic negotiating session with Saddam. Annan was told that he could take no more than three aides and his bodyguard. He was not told where he was going. He didn't seem fazed;

title: Remaindering Baghdad
description: I traveled to Baghdad in mid-February, not as an Indian writer but in the course of my ''other life'' as a United Nations official. The world was largely focused on two dramas at the time, both involving (in very different ways) issues of access to presidential sites -- the Monica Lewinsky investigation in Washington and the crisis over United Nations weapons inspections in Iraq. I had nothing whatsoever to do with America's internal affairs (if the dreadful pun can be forgiven), but the other crisis took me to the Iraqi capital, at very short notice, with an advance team to prepare the visit of the Secretary General of the United Nations. The necessary groundwork completed, there was just enough time away from United Nations business to catch a few glimpses of Baghdad before the political negotiations began.

title: Rome
description: Church bells, flower stalls bursting with color, markets offering fresh strawberries and asparagus, sidewalk dining, Baroque churches, Roman ruins.

title: Now, 24-Track Dream Factories for 'Indie' Musicians
description: MOUNTAIN MIKE OEHLER lives in an underground sod house in Bonners Ferry, Idaho, near Ruby Ridge and the Canadian border, so he didn't exactly feel at home in the 24-track, digitally mastered Manhattan sound studio the very first time.

title: Dangerous Inertia in Japan
description: Japan is sinking ever deeper into economic stagnation and confusion of purpose. Every day brings fresh news of another anemic financial rescue effort or an embarrassing disclosure of corruption or suicide in elite circles, including the Finance Ministry. Yet Japan is not just another Asian country in trouble. With an economy twice as large as the rest of Asia's, Japan's health is crucial to recovery in the region and stability throughout the world. It cannot afford to muddle along.

title: Editorial Observer; Why Comics Are as Important as Shakespeare
description: People who write for a living routinely credit heavyweights like Faulkner, Hemingway and Proust with showing them the way. In my case much of the credit goes to comic books. Between 5th and 11th grade, I read almost nothing else. Instead of trashing ''The Flash,'' ''Green Lantern'' and ''The Fantastic Four,'' my English teacher nudged me toward books that bore no resemblance to ''Silas Marner'' or that deadly dull ''Heart of Darkness.'' Comics and fantasy paved the way for science-fiction novels like ''The War of the Worlds'' and ''Fahrenheit 451'' and eventually for mythology, most notably the ''Iliad.''

title: F.Y.I.
description: A Secret Passageway?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHMAN, JULIUS
description: FISHMAN-Julius. March 26, 1980. We know that you are always there to guide us and take pride in our accomplishments. We miss your voice, your smile, and your love. We have been blessed to have had you as part of our lives. AnnaMae, children and grandchildren

title: A Mini-Medical School, Minus Scalpels and Stethoscopes
description: While other teenagers might devote their Wednesday evenings to watching ''Beverly Hills, 90210'' on television, or eating pizza with friends, Heather Snook, 17, would much rather sit in a darkened auditorium at a medical school here, listening to a doctor expound on such topics as ''Vogelstein's Genetic Model for Colorectal Tumorigenesis.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOWITZ, WILLIAM
description: LEBOWITZ-William. On March 28, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Bertha. Loving mother of Elliot and the late Buddy. Dear brother of Dorothy Weinstein. Devoted grandfather of Dr. Mark, Gary, Sharon Becker, Scott, Bennett, Andrew, Eric. Great-grandfather of Rachel and Alex, Danny, Jake and Joseph Becker. Service Sunday at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Security Stepped Up At U.S. Airports
description: AIRLINE passengers may not notice, but Government officials say that steps taken since the beginning of the year have made travel more secure.

title: Who Said London Is Backward? The French. Now They Flock There.
description: For most of the last 50 years, the French have felt superior to the British. London was the capital of an empire in decline, a quaint but backward place where prospects were bleak and unthinkable things like fish and chips wrapped in newspaper passed for haute cuisine.

title: Clinton Accused of Obstruction for Withholding Willey Letters
description: Saying that President Clinton had failed to provide them with correspondence from Kathleen E. Willey, lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones filed papers today accusing President Clinton of obstruction of justice. Mr. Clinton's lawyers quickly made the letters public after Ms. Willey, in a televised interview, accused Mr. Clinton of sexual misconduct.

title: Dear Woody, Have We Got News for You
description: WOODY ALLEN built his career playing neurotic schlemiels who aspire to be someone else (like Humphrey Bogart in ''Play It Again, Sam''), victims of mistaken identity (the nebbish taken for a guerrilla leader in ''Bananas''), assorted misfits and, in the case of ''Zelig,'' a chameleon-like cipher. In short, the typical Woody Allen hero is a walking identity crisis.

title: A Soprano Who Can Relate to the Yankee in Emmeline
description: AMERICAN opera singers, whose stock in trade is a culture once removed, are often obliged to make imaginative leaps to the parched streets of Seville or the leafy banks of the Rhine. Rarely are they required to conjure up anything like a dingy New England mill town.

title: Snooze Alarm
description: THE HOUSE OF SLEEP

title: Monkey Business
description: To the Editor: While I enjoyed Joan Mellen's article on Cobblers Cove in Barbados (''Barbados Retreat, English Country Style,'' Jan. 11), I hope she was not taking her readers for a bunch of monkeys.

title: Word & Image; Lies to Live By
description: ''Save social security first,'' Bill Clinton exclaimed with the thundering-herd scandal hunters at his heels. And thus, the polls record, he first saved himself.

title: Blue-Collar Work Buoyed by Boom In the Economy
description: FROM a mild winter that barely slowed construction and into the spring, builders and blue-collar workers have been hitting pay dirt on former farms in the Hamptons, a hot spot for second homes fueled by Wall Street money and low mortgage rates.

title: My Dead Giants
description: When Andre the Giant died in his sleep five years ago, he left many fond fans and inspiration for ''My Giant,'' the Billy Crystal buddy comedy in theaters next month. Though colorful in life, in death Andre doesn't rate a mention on the A-list of Gary Will, a pro-wrestling historian in Waterloo, Ontario, who maintains a Web site devoted to the final exits of grapplers. ''I didn't set out to compile a list of dead wrestlers,'' Will says. ''In the early 90's, I was researching pro-wrestling history, and I got a lot of death information.'' His work led to ''Wrestling Title Histories,'' the bible of the sport. Will's favorite deaths resemble their victims' lives -- theatrical, often brutal and rarely dignified. Here's a look.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, GARETTA
description: LYONS-Garetta. Of Smithtown, NY, died Friday, March 27, at the age of 93. Widow of Leverett Lyons, mother of the late Ann Litz, grandmother of Leverett Litz and sister of Richard B. Smith, Edward H. L. Smith, W. Wickham Smith and DuBois T. Smith. The family will be at home at Judges Lane, Smithtown, from 3-5 PM, and 7-9 PM, on both Sunday, March 29, and Monday, March 30. Funeral service will be held Wednesday, April 1, at 1 PM, at the Smithtown Presbyterian Church. The interment will follow at the St. James Espiscopal Church Cemetery, St. James, NY.

title: Nina Lesser and Stephen Sheng
description: AMONG some friends and family members, Nina Beth Lesser and Stephen Ke-Wen Sheng are known as the 24-hour couple. As the bride's father, Larry Lesser, put it, ''They work together, they live together and they're never out of sync with one another.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture on March 8 with an article about living in Princeton Borough was published in error. It showed three houses on Battle Road in Princeton Township, just over the border with Princeton Borough.

title: Amelia Levin and Eliot Relles
description: Amelia Levin, the daughter of Raquel and Lear Levin of New York, was married last evening to Eliot Leland Relles, the son of Roslyn Rolan of Fort Lee, N.J., and David Relles of Middletown, N.J. Rabbi Robert Levine performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: Neighbors Say 'Enough'
description: When Boys Town opened its first New York center for troubled adolescents, in Park Slope in 1990, neighbors were against the idea. This weekend, Boys Town is opening its second nonsecure detention center in the city, in Baychester, and the reception has been much the same.

title: Amy McLean, Jared Sprole
description: Amy Lynn McLean, a daughter of Rebecca Holden Deckard and Dr. Jary Lynn McLean, both of Wichita, Kan., was married yesterday to Jared Knapp Sprole, a son of Katherine Thompson Blakeslee and Frank Jared Sprole, both of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Carla Bailey performed the ceremony at the United Church of Christ at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H.

title: Long Treatment Ends For Boy From Turkey
description: IT was called a breakout party, and if it sounds a bit like celebrating a prison escape, that is probably what it felt like for Salmon Hassan, 4. He was celebrating his release from four weeks of isolation, and -- hopefully -- the end of a harrowing treatment for a rare but aggressive form of cancer.

title: THEATER: SUNDAY VIEW; At the Heart of a Spellbinding 'Cabaret,' a Star
description: BERLIN, 1929-1930: the Weimar Republic is tottering; the Nazis maneuver for power in their attempts to discredit the Communists, who also want to pick up the pieces when the Government collapses; petit-bourgeois Germans go about their daily lives without acknowledging the intrigue, corruption and hysteria that lie just beneath the surface; adventuring English and American tourists flock to the German capital for cheap, anything-goes fun-and-games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, STEPHEN SAMUEL
description: GLASS-Stephen Samuel. 70. Passed away March 27, 1998 at home. Beloved husband to Aileen (nee Harris). Loving father to Linda and Jeffry Schwartz and Kenneth and Heidi Glass. Adoring Poppy to Melissa Schwartz, Jared and Brandon Glass. Brother of Nancy Pines. Graduate of USNA, Class of '49. President of Trident Manager, Inc. Member of L.I.G.A. and M.G.A. Services Sunday 12:45 PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: 'Don't Dare Get Near Me,' Janzen Seems to Say
description: Whenever Lee Janzen faced a challenge today, it only seemed to increase his determination.

title: Isles Fall With 4 Seconds Left
description: There are deflating losses, and then there are really deflating losses.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Life in a Lighthouse

title: Sharon B. Kroll, Michael D. Cohen
description: Sharon Beth Kroll, the daughter of Leon Kroll of Highland Park, N.J., and the late Ruth Yucht Kroll, was married last evening to Michael David Cohen, the son of Dr. and Mrs. David M. Cohen of Atlanta. Rabbi Yakov R. Hilsenrath officiated in the ballroom at the Equitable Center in New York.

title: Miles Davis's Mid-60's Quintet Reverberates Inside Jazz's Head
description: MILES DAVIS'S second great quintet -- Wayne Shorter on saxophone, Herbie Hancock on piano, Ron Carter on bass and Tony Williams on drums -- left behind four of the more perfect albums in acoustic jazz history. The records -- ''Miles Smiles,'' ''E.S.P,'' ''Sorcerer'' and ''Nefertiti'' -- brought jazz to an extraordinary level of interaction, changing the parameters for group improvisation. Then in 1967, everything changed: Davis and the group started playing with electric instruments and pop textures, and the albums receded into history, albeit beautiful history.

title: DIARY
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 15 about the summer dance season in Europe misidentified the company performing at the Harrogate International Festival. It is the Stars of American Ballet, which features dancers from the New York City Ballet and several other American companies, not the entire City Ballet company.

title: Show Looks at Revolution and the Hudson
description: WASHINGTON, Clinton and psychological warfare sound like contemporary references. But in ''Defending the Hudson 1775-1783,'' an exhibition at the Rockefeller State Park Preserve here, the names refer to Gen. George Washington, British Maj. Gen. Henry Clinton and 18th-century warfare, and they have more emotional than physical impact -- all key elements during the American Revolution centered on the Hudson River.

title: N.L. Central
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. In the East, the Mets are picked to finish in second place.

title: FILM; A Giant Denied His Rightful Stature In Film
description: THE American titan that was Paul Robeson -- all-America football player; singing, film and theater star; outspoken pioneer for racial and economic justice -- has been grossly underhonored, until now. For the centennial of his birth, on April 9, half a dozen cities are planning major events, and half a dozen documentaries on his life are nearing completion. Even the Grammys deigned to give him a ''lifetime achievement'' award this year.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on March 15 about Exile, a lounge, misstated the name of the country where the owner, John Barounis, said he found his inspiration on a recent visit. It was the Czech Republic, not Czechoslovakia.

title: Help for Student Grief
description: SOMEHOW the vast auditorium at the Saunders Trade and Technical High School here seemed dwarfed by the sorrow that 10 students haltingly shared with a visitor. Nearly every student sitting around the table on the stage had experienced the death of a parent. Some had lost both parents and had also gone through the pain of the death of a grandparent or a close friend.

title: Pianist Offers Spring Concert at Caramoor
description: NOT too long ago, Caramoor meant only summer music, and while the annual festival is still the jewel in the crown of Westchester's warm-weather listening, the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts now emulates Vivaldi with concerts in each of the four seasons. Today at 3 P.M. in the Music Room, the Israeli-born pianist Yael Weiss plays Schubert, Brahms, Schumann and Martinu to usher in what Paul Rosenblum, the center's general manager, describes as a ''spectacular'' spring. ''Part of our mission is to introduce the most exciting emerging stars to our audiences,'' he said. ''Ms. Weiss is certainly in that firmament.''

title: One Nation, After All?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERBST, DANIEL L.
description: HERBST-Daniel L. Age 69, of Larchmont, NY, died March 23, 1998, at his home of a heart attack. Born in Brooklyn, and a graduate of Brooklyn College, Mr. Herbst was a sales and marketing executive in the hospital supply business most of his career. He was a U.S. Army captain during the Korean War and was awarded a silver star, two bronze stars and two purple hearts. He was an avid swimmer and sailor, a certified scuba instructor, member of the University Club of Larchmont, and a volunteer for the Elissa Tall Ships Program in Galveston, TX.

title: State Comptroller Faults Development Agency
description: A state comptroller's audit has criticized the Department of Economic Development for failing to measure whether its economic development zones are succeeding, but a spokeswoman for the agency says a system to do so is nearly complete.

title: Rolling The Dice On Expensive I.P.O.'s
description: This is a tale of two companies with much in common. Neither has ever earned a dime of profits, but both have big plans. And when each went public last week, insiders decided it was a good time to take some profits.

title: Word Scratcher
description: SOLIBO MAGNIFICENT By Patrick Chamoiseau. Translated by Rose-Myriam Rejouis and Val Vinokurov. 190 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $23.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: On an Oasis of Ice, Common Denominators
description: IT'S 1:20 on a recent Wednesday afternoon and Darryn Tilden, a pilot for Delta Air Lines, has just come off the ice at Chelsea Piers' Sky Rink. Leaning on his two hockey sticks, breathing heavily and dripping sweat, he says that most players at these noontime pickup hockey games are just out for ''a good relaxing lunchtime skate.''

title: Q and A
description: Finding an A.T.M.

title: March 22-28; Cuban Ball Players Pop Up
description: Like a high pop fly lost in the sun, the flight of four Cuban baseball players and their coach in a small fishing vessel caused alarm and confusion about their whereabouts until they floated safely into view on a remote Bahamian island. They said they had still been in Cuba when the Miami rumor mill had them lost at sea or washed ashore in the Dominican Republic the week before. They were at sea for 17 hours in all. Sports agents quickly gathered at the Nassau detention camp where the defectors were housed, presumably a short stopover until some country grants them political asylum and eventual passage to major league contracts. JON NORDHEIMER

title: A Life on Art's Barricades
description: Clement Greenberg

title: Micheline Wolf, Peter Schwartz
description: Micheline L. Wolf, the editorial manager at Seventeen magazine in New York, was married last evening to Peter Jay Schwartz, a talent agent with the Agency Group in New York, an international music booking agency. Rabbi Bruce Block performed the ceremony at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Police Tactics Chipping Away at Suspects' Rights
description: The warnings have become a familiar background noise, droning in the American imagination. Courtesy of TV detectives like Kojak, Sipowicz and Pembleton, millions know that if they find themselves in police custody and ask for a lawyer or insist on their right to remain silent, the interrogation is supposed to come to a screeching halt.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BING, ILSE
description: BING-Ilse. The life of Ilse Bing, who passed away March 10, 1998, will be celebrated at a memorial service on April 2 at 3 P.M., at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, ROY EDWARD
description: ANDERSON-Roy Edward. On March 28, 1998. Beloved husband of Mary Chapman. Service and interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRAYER, MARY JANE
description: DRAYER-Mary Jane. On March 30, it will be fifty years since you left. You are always in my thoughts and, most often, in my expressions and sense of being. For all the times I didn't say I love you, Mom, I say it now. Sleep well and tell God I thank Him for making Mary Jane my mother. See you soon. Sonny

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGSNER, CELESTE
description: LANGSNER-Celeste. On March 27, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Herman. Beloved mother of Alan (Hilary). Loving stepmother of Franklin (Elaine). Cherished grandmother of Lauren, Stephen, Sandra and Nancy. Funeral service Sunday, 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILLELEA, MARGARET M.
description: KILLELEA-Margaret M. Of Flushing, NY. Retired Assistant Principal, Bayside High School. Loving aunt of James K. Reposing at the M.A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY, Monday, 4-8 PM. Mass St. Andrew Avellino R.C. Church, 10:15 AM, Tuesday. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a Himalayan mountain, with an article about Vice President Al Gore's notion of a space camera trained on the Earth, misidentified the peak. It was Ama Dablam, not Everest.

title: Tough Competition for Pencil, Calculator
description: MATHEMATICS may not have the same following as basketball and football, but the competition is no less intense when the state's 85 high school teams compete with numbers.

title: County Seeks To Reduce Health Risks For Minorities
description: COINCIDENTAL with two highly publicized studies that found minority groups at greater risk of certain health problems than whites, two committees of the County Board of Legislators have begun hearings to find ways to close the health gap between whites and nonwhites.

title: Explorers in the Natural World
description: '' 'Let us go,' we said, 'into the Sea of Cortez, realizing that we become forever a part of it; that our rubber boots slogging through a flat of eelgrass, that the rocks we turn over in a tide pool, make us truly and permanently a factor in the ecology of the region. We shall take something away from it, but we shall leave something too.' ''

title: Ethnic Cuisine In Midtown
description: ARTUSI** [Rating: Two Stars]

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Hard Men in Trouble
description: THE LAST VOYAGE: And Other Stories (Harvill/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, paper, $15), a collection of work from the early 1930's by the prolific Irish-born writer James Hanley, serves as a gripping introduction to both his dark vision of humanity and his unusual, stripped-down prose. Here are two stories of the sea (Hanley's trademark), another about soldiers at war and yet another about a disillusioned former sailor struggling for recognition, as well as a bizarre, haunting portrait of a man on death row. In Hanley's fiction, working-class men of action face crises and decisions -- some simple, some complex -- that will forever alter their existence. In every story, time is brutally compressed; similarly, any unnecessary detail is washed out of the language. What's left are stark feelings, what one story describes as the ''full orchestra of the emotions -- anger, dejection, sorrow.'' Sometimes excruciating, these elemental human reactions are nevertheless always on carefully controlled display. In the final story, ''Narrative,'' chance plays a key role as a party of men is chosen to join a doomed ship, sailing in wartime and bound for parts unknown. The strangest story, ''A Passion Before Death,'' is a tightly written evocation of the moments in which a man faces execution, his last wish one of sexual desire that can be expressed only toward his burly warders. In contrast, ''The German Prisoner'' details the more generalized brutality and futile hatred engendered by the trench warfare of World War I. Each story explores the fine line between sanity and madness; thanks to Hanley's skill, each also reveals ''the terrible power of words.'' Erik Burns

title: A Therapist Brings Out Homicidal Tendencies
description: ''VOICES in the Dark,'' at the George Street Playhouse here, could be the first play in a new genre: the whodunit or, more precisely, the who'll do it, that may have you rooting for the villain.

title: Expert on Board
description: To the Editor: Having been privileged to be a guest lecturer on six international cruises, I want to compliment William Grimes's article ''Wanted: Expertise (or Celebrity), Plus Pep'' (Feb. 1).

title: What's Organic?
description: To the Editor:

title: Neighborly Combo: Maternity, Yoga and Litigation
description: Twelve years ago, Peggy Levine, an exercise instructor, opened her small fitness studio for women on West 92d Street, between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway. It was not a great block; crack sales were brisk in those days. But to Ms. Levine, who had rented spaces in the West 80's, only to lose them to larger businesses, the more northerly location was fine. For the next decade, she built her business, which features gentle exercises for women who were pregnant, postnatal or far from childbirth, as well as baby-sitting.

title: Singing and Dancing the Praises of Portuguese Culture Around the World
description: NO atlas or dictionary is needed for a good time at New Jersey Performing Arts Center's lively festival of Portuguese music and dance, or at the associated art and food events. But it wouldn't hurt the curious to have one or the other handy, for tracing Portugal's cultural connections with Europe, Africa and South America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAGOVIN, SANFORD A.
description: RAGOVIN-Sanford A., D.D.S. Beloved husband of Ann. Loving father of Helene and Marc. Dear brother of Nada. Services today at 11:30 AM at ''Parkside Chapel'', Queens Blvd. and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Staff Rounds Into Shape
description: Al Leiter is ready. And so, apparently, are the Mets.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Edward Dmytryk's MURDER MY SWEET (1944), from Raymond Chandler's ''Farewell My Lovely,'' compounded the flow of granite-hard detective movies that belately followed the success of Dashiell Hammett's ''Maltese Falcon'' in 1941. A harshly intriguing tale of blackmail and homicide, it spotlights Dick Powell as a California sleuth -- a new image for the vocalist, who is entirely credible in the role. So are Claire Trevor, Anne Shirley, Otto Kruger and Mike Mazurki. -- Tuesday at 11:30 A.M. on AMC.

title: Russian Politician Is Too Wily for Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: VIVA PEEP!
description: Can freedom be found in a cramped glass-partitioned Times Square ''fantasy booth''? Yes, says Ronnie Larsen, whose play ''Ronnie Larsen's Peep Show'' (which opens this week at the Actor's Playhouse) chronicles the triumphs and travails of four sex workers and their faithful customers. Larsen, a playwright who was once briefly a prostitute, is quite upset about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's efforts to crack down on the sex industry. The play tries to show that the peep world can provide warmth. ''It's liberating to get what you want,'' Larsen says. ''A girl at Show World told me about a nuclear-plant worker who made her wear a hazardous-materials suit. Who knows why he couldn't ask his wife to do that, but he couldn't.''

title: March 22-28; Asked and Answered
description: At a hearing on tobacco legislation, Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, was questioning Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers about the extent to which an increase in cigarette prices would lead to a reduction in teen-age smoking. This exchange occurred:

title: Fashions
description: This season, couture came down from its lofty catwalk; At Balmain, Dior, Gaultier, Chanel and Valentino, designers presented their collections at close range. The operatic proceedings and the aloof glamour were gone, replaced by extravagance of a different kind - straightforward, sophisticated, sublime.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Hello, Sugar

title: In Horse Country, Lifting Riders From Wheelchair to Saddle
description: In the hills of Hunterdon County is a 12-acre horse farm near Oldwick that looks pretty much like any of the numerous farms and riding stables in New Jersey's horse country. But the 60 adults and children who ride at the Somerset Hills Handicapped Riding Center once or twice a week want more than a bit of fun or exercise. They want to improve the quality of their lives and expand the activities in which they can engage the rest of their week.

title: Spice Island
description: INHERITANCE

title: Helen M. Perez, Daniel J. Boyd
description: Helen Maribel Perez, a daughter of Miledys Nivar and Domingo Perez, both of New York, was married yesterday to Daniel James Boyd, a son of Lillian C. Bruins of Virginia Beach, Va., and Cather A. Boyd of Bayshore, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. John I. Snyder performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Babylon, N.Y.

title: Food Co-op Ate Its Spinach, and Now Is Bursting Its Seams
description: Barry Smith, a founder of the Flatbush Food Co-op and its general manager for 21 years, remembers a time in the 1970's when New York had 20 food cooperatives. Some were small home-based buying clubs. Others operated in storefronts.

title: POSTINGS: Project Dims Office-Building Prospects; New Stores For 42d Street
description: A new store-construction project has started on 42d Street near the Avenue of the Americas, signaling that prospects for office development on a key Manhattan site -- the largely assembled 40,000 square feet of land on the west side of the avenue between 42d and 43d Street -- have receded.

title: The Famous Discuss Faith
description: One is at ease before crowds; the other is shy. One prays regularly; the other confesses to praying scarcely enough.

title: Record Free Fall Would Be Monument to Huizenga's Greed
description: ZERO and 162. That's what I want for the Florida Marlins this year.

title: The Smoker's Bubble
description: Tavern owners in California are coming up with creative ways around the statewide ban on smoking in bars, which went into effect Jan. 1. Barley & Hopps, a brew pub and restaurant on the edge of Silicon Valley, has devised an elaborate (and legal) solution -- a sealed-off room-within-a-room reserved for smokers.

title: Who Wants Justice?
description: For the last two months Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel and former Federal appellate judge, has been doing the job that Attorney General Janet Reno and the United States Court of Appeals directed him to do: investigate allegations of perjury and obstruction of justice related to Monica Lewinsky.

title: South Africa's Bitter Pill for World's Drug Makers
description: AMERICANS who need to visit a doctor here notice it right away: the price of the appointment is a pleasant surprise, far less than it would be in the United States. But the prescription afterward is a shock -- sometimes double the charge for the doctor's time.

title: Once Widowed in India, Twice Scorned
description: Govind Dasi has only a vague sense of the passing years, but this much she knows: She was married at 12 in her native village outside Calcutta, widowed at 14 when her teen-age husband died of tuberculosis, then forced to work as an unpaid servant for her mother-in-law for about 30 years.

title: Lewis Gets No Glory Points In Knocking Out Briggs
description: Lennox Lewis had wanted to win impressively against Shannon Briggs here tonight, the better to draw out Evander Holyfield for a possible heavyweight unification bout. He thought he could do it with a first-round knockout. But he had to put in a little bit of overtime.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; When There's No More Space for the Overflow
description: FROM the outside, the three-story structure on Van Brunt Avenue in Englewood, not far from Route 4, looks like any other office building. But inside, instead of office space, there is a vast collection of cubicles used by families as second attics and by businesses as extra supply closets.

title: A Group Home on Your Block?
description: What would be your reaction if a group home for the mentally disabled were planned for your block?

title: Miss Johnston And Mr. Smith
description: Elizabeth Sheridan Johnston and Douglas Wayne Smith were married yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Mendham, N.J. Msgr. Kenneth Lasch performed the ceremony.

title: School Aid: State Has Promises To Keep
description: MAYOR NANCY VALENTINE of Ansonia says the state has put her city in a bind. Rising school enrollment and state mandates are increasing the cost of public education but the state won't pay what it promised. Instead, the money comes out of Ansonia's property tax revenue.

title: These Are Two Ladies Who Really Lunch
description: ''Excuse me, but aren't you the two fat ladies?'' That line could earn a well-deserved slap in the face in any other situation, but in Virgil's restaurant in midtown Manhattan, sharing a late lunch with Jennifer Paterson and Clarissa Dickson Wright, it is delivered in a tone approaching reverence.

title: A Voice That Pleads For Home
description: MARYAM MURSAL was Somalia's first female pop star. Then, after recording a political song with its criticisms too thinly veiled, she was banned from performing; she became Somalia's first female cabdriver. And in 1991, as Somalia's civil war devastated Mogadishu, she decided to leave the country. With her five children, she walked and hitchhiked across the Horn of Africa, through Kenya and Ethiopia and back through Somalia to Djibouti, where she was given asylum by the Danish Embassy. Clearly, she has earned the title of her new album, ''The Journey'' (Real World), which is far and away the funkiest album ever connected to Denmark, where Mursal now lives.

title: In a Week, Snow and Heat
description: Last Sunday, New Yorkers were braving blustery winds and trudging through five inches of snow, wondering if spring would ever arrive. Yesterday, they were digging out their Bermuda shorts, lathering themselves with sunscreen and flocking to rooftops and parks.

title: The Problem Isn't Guns, but Easy Access to Them; Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Stepping Out of a Rut
description: NOWHERE has the fashion gulf between the sexes been more evident than in the shoe department. Even in fashion-forward stores, men's footwear has traditionally been a far cry from the sensual extremes reached in women's designs.

title: Q&A: Bill Ayres; In Forefront of Fighting World Hunger
description: BOTH body and soul need nourishment in order for man to survive.'' So says Bill Ayres, and he's taken to these tasks quite diligently. As co-founder and executive director of World Hunger Year in Manhattan, Mr. Ayres is working to eliminate world hunger. As a former priest and host of ''The Bill Ayres Show,'' a call in radio program that airs Sundays at midnight on WPLJ (95.5 FM), he also dishes up plenty of food for thought.

title: The Whitney's Search for a Mission
description: IT'S hard to say precisely when, but several years ago the Whitney Museum of American Art pretty much slipped off the radar screen. Arguing about it had been a cherished pastime, then people seemed to stop talking, or really caring, about it as they once had.

title: White Plains Shoe-In
description: In White Plains, the athletic footwear retailer Foot Locker will fill part of the space vacated by Woolworth last year. Foot Locker, a Woolworth division, will open on Mamaroneck Avenue across from a building once occupied by Macy's, where Tishman Speyer Properties and Loews Theaters are planning a 24-screen, 5,200-seat theater.

title: March 22-28; 'Titanic' Meets Its Fate
description: In the end, the Hollywood establishment had no choice.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGART, HANNAH
description: BOGART-Hannah. On March 27, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Murray Lloyd and Brenda (Jerry) Melissaratos. Cherished grandmother of David and Jenna. Services Monday, 10 AM at Schwartz Bros.Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd. at 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

title: Man Called 'Consummate Predator' Is Charged in Widow's Death
description: A Queens man described by the police as a ''consummate predator'' has been charged with the murder and robbery of an 85-year-old widow who died last week after being pushed to the ground during a purse-snatching in Kew Gardens Hills, the police said yesterday.

title: New York Concert Life as He Might Have Shaped It
description: ONE hundred years ago -- on March 28, 1898 -- an event occurred that changed the course of New York City's cultural life. This was the death of Anton Seidl at the age of 47.

title: Maurice Sagoff, 88, a Master Of Terse Verses on Literature
description: Maurice Sagoff, a reformed journalist who made a late-life name for himself abbreviating great literature into terse humorous verse, died on March 18 at a hospital near his home in Acton, Mass. He was 88 and the author of ''Shrinklits: 70 of the World's Towering Classics Cut Down to Size.''

title: Down to the Final 2: Kentucky and Utah
description: Utah stunned North Carolina, 65-59, to advance to the final of the men's N.C.A.A. Division I basketball tournament. In Monday's final, Utah will take on Kentucky, which narrowly avoided an upset of its own in an 86-85 overtime victory over Stanford.

title: Erica Golden, M. J. Greenberg
description: Erica Milli Golden and Michael Jay Greenberg were married last evening by Rabbi David Wirtschafter at the Crescent, a catering business in Bayville, N.Y.

title: Why Not Look in the Gift Horse's Mouth?
description: WHO doesn't love it when department stores hand out mystery gifts? Shoppers searching for cologne or lipstick get the fun of a secret prize, a pretty box concealing a tote bag or an umbrella. Of course, no matter how nice the present, no reasonable person buys something they don't want so they can get a gift with a value they can't judge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, TRINA MARSHALL
description: NORTON-Trina Marshall, 84. On Wednesday, March 25th, 1998. She is survived by son, Nathaniel R. Norton of Charlotte, VT., and son Marshall L. and wife Mia Norton of Richmond, VA. and six grandchildren. Services will be Monday at St. Mary's Episcopal Church on River Road at 12:00 Noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the John Jay Homestead Foundation, Katonah, NY 10536.

title: A Friendship That Ended The Clutter
description: Imagine being entrusted with another's cherished heirlooms, only to discover that they are a pair of seven-foot naked dolls, male and female, and ''anatomically correct,'' as they say. Imagine having to drag them down Lexington Avenue to be cleaned, as passers-by stare at the spectacle. And after a nearly 20-block trip to the New York Doll Hospital, imagine having to drag them back when it turns out to be too expensive to bother.

title: The World; Singing the Cartel Blues
description: IN the glory days of OPEC a quarter-century ago, a decision to cut oil production and raise the price of the world's lifeblood commodity invariably shook markets around the globe. There would be endless speculation about what it all meant for Mideast peace, the North-South power games between the industrialized nations and the under-industrialized, America's inflation rates, Japan's growth prospects and the price of plastic garbage bags.

title: March 22-28; A Papal Plea in Nigeria To Free Political Detainees
description: Fresh from Cuba, where he succeeded in obtaining the release of dozens of political detainees, Pope John Paul II flew to Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, and one of its most grievous abusers of human rights, in a bid to duplicate his feat. Vatican officials spoke of not humiliating Nigeria's military regime by emphasizing the political status of those detained -- such as Moshood K. O. Abiola, the presumed winner of the country's 1992 elections, or Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, the only Nigerian military leader to hand over power to civilians. Instead, they discreetly presented a list of about 60 prisoners to Nigeria's ordinarily reclusive leader, Gen. Sani Abacha, who seemed frankly delighted to be receiving a rare visit from such a prominent actor on the world stage.

title: Stage Named for Elaine Steinbeck
description: EVERY summer, Elaine Steinbeck greets the Japanese tourists who come to her Bluff Point Lane, Sag Harbor, home to see the small eight-sided outbuilding where her husband, John, wrote ''Travels With Charley.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: An Auction With a Big-Screen Plot: Drugs and Diamonds, Agents and Arrests
description: It wasn't quite the Maltese Falcon, but there was a treasure of gems: 33 colored diamonds, the largest a marquise-cut, intense blue stone weighing more than three carats. There was no Humphrey Bogart, but there were Federal agents and a manhunt. There was no Peter Lorre or Sydney Greenstreet. But there was Stephen Jenks of Largo (no Key), Fla.

title: Ex-Premier Of Russia Plans to Run For President
description: Russia's recently dismissed Prime Minister announced today that he would run for President in 2000, adding a new twist to a week of political back-stabbing and backroom maneuvering.

title: REPUBLICANS HOLD AN EDGE IN KEEPING CONTROL OF HOUSE
description: As Republicans struggle to retain the narrowest House majority held by any party in the last half century, they may benefit in this year's midterm elections from something of a political security blanket: Incumbents around the nation are savoring high popularity ratings, and the sturdy economy and dearth of contentious issues has left many challengers with no foothold.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHASHIN, SIMON, H. LOUISE
description: CHASHIN-SIMON-H. Louise, M.D. Darling daughter and loving sister, we miss you and love you every day,. but today, all the more so, because it's your birthday. Rest in peace, dear. Mama, Bruce and Zesel

title: The Joys of Jerry's
description: I UNDERSTAND why people like Jerry's. The fried shrimp alone are worth the drive down Paterson Avenue, and the knotty-pine dining room radiates its own kind of 50's warmth. The bar, the servers in their black-and-white polyester uniforms and the popularity of drinks served with maraschino cherries (rather than Perrier) set the stage. Lucy and Desi could show up, and it wouldn't surprise you.

title: Suki Dixon and David Keen
description: Susannah Mary Dixon and David Nicholas Keen were married last evening at the Stamford (Conn.) Museum and Nature Center. Rabbi Robert B. Lennick performed the ceremony.

title: Candidate Scores an Upset In Straw Poll for Governor
description: A vote today by upstate Democratic leaders further muddied the race for the Democratic nomination for governor as Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, the front-runner in the polls, did poorly, and a little-known former state official, James L. Larocca, ran away with the contest.

title: Conversations/Zoilamerica Narvaez; A Victim of Sexual Abuse In a Prison of Political Ideals
description: SHE may be the only woman to ever publicly accuse a former president of incest. Her husband has confided that he remained devoted to that president for years, despite knowing the identity of his wife's tormentor.

title: Room Service
description: If Robert Packard had been able to pronounce the simple and melodious word ''kahvalti'' while in Ankara, he would have been presented with the typical Turkish breakfast: robust toast with dark, flavorful honey; creamy white cheese; black olives; a wedge of juicy tomato in season, and hot tea served in a small glass, sugar cubes on the side.

title: Is Your Rent Controlled?
description: In more than 12 years of studying housing in New York, Douglas P. Hillstrom, the executive director of the New York City Rent Guidelines Board, has decided at least one thing. ''Real estate in New York is totally insane,'' he said. But a Web site, he reasoned, might introduce some sanity.

title: A Suitcase Full of Guilt
description: Both my husband and I travel for business (''A Suitcase Full of Guilt,'' by Diane K. Shah, March 8). Our experiences are tediously similar, with one odd exception. When my husband travels, his associates greet him with a breezy, ''How's the family?'' At the parallel moment in collegial chitchat, I am asked, ''Who's watching the baby?'' If our experience is at all typical, it is good news for women who like to travel light. One needn't stuff guilt into an overburdened suitcase. It will be provided upon arrival.

title: Commercial Property; Companies Seek High-Profile Street-Level Presence
description: IN late 1995, when the Intertech Corporation of Washington bought the 33-story building at 1500 Broadway, on the east side of Times Square between 43d and 44th Streets, its executive vice president, Orna Shulman, decided there had to be a better use for the ground-floor space than the chain restaurant, two-screen cinema and small shops that were there.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 29, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Interpreting Domains And Life With Wires
description: Domain

title: Air War: Money Now vs. Room for Students Later
description: On West 61st Street between Amsterdam and West End Avenues there is an elementary school, a post office and not much else. But big plans are afoot, and at least one school official is worried.

title: The Computer Age Began in a Barn
description: IN 1948, 20-year-old William B. Wenning of Stamford, fresh out of a two-year technical college in New York City, was looking for a job. An acquaintance suggested he try Remington Rand.

title: Time for Crackdown: Enforce Dead Time
description: TO help fans come to see Babe Ruth hit home runs, baseball once got rid of its dead ball. Now, to help its fans stay awake, baseball is hoping to get rid of its dead time.

title: Puzzling Over Productivity
description: ''America's Treadmill Economy'' (March 8), Louis Uchitelle's article about productivity and the pressure on companies to increase quality as they fight to hang onto customers, drew a large response from readers. All the letters discuss -- and illustrate -- the divergence over what is or should be measured, and how.

title: Backtalk; Scandals And Crime? You Bet!
description: Why not?

title: Room Service
description: To the Editor: Of course, there are more important things to concern ourselves with than morning room service, but indeed the niceties of civilization must be counted.

title: National News Briefs; Gingrich Announces He Will Seek Re-election
description: Speaker of the House of Representatives Newt Gingrich will run for re-election to his Georgia House seat, and -- if Republicans retain a majority in the House -- will run for re-election as Speaker, he announced here tonight.

title: A Chronicle Faces Death and Celebrates Life
description: NEIL GREENBERG'S newly completed trilogy, like a serial novel choreographically reimagined for the age of AIDS, chronicles four years in the life of his company, Dance by Neil Greenberg. A dancer goes to Australia. A baby is born. A choreographer falls in love. But what resonates most deeply in the work is a battering series of losses -- a brother, a mother, a father, an ex-lover, a litany of dear friends.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Vatican Peace Offering Reopens War Wounds
description: WHEN the Vatican issued its long-awaited statement on the Holocaust two weeks ago, its authors declared that the future of Jewish-Christian relations demanded that the past be remembered. Quoting a line from a prayer by Pope John Paul II, the document stated that ''there is no future without memory.''

title: Berkshire Outpaces Buffett
description: QUESTION: What has outperformed, by a large margin, the value of investments made by Warren E. Buffett?

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Folk Art in Old Lyme

title: Corrections
description: A map on March 1 with an article about the Miraval spa in Arizona included outdated information on a national park. The area shown east of Tucson is part of Saguaro National Park East; it is no longer Saguaro National Monument.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, RICHARD SAMUEL
description: FELDMAN-Richard Samuel. Former Vice President, Crescent News Distributors, Garden City Park. Cherished friend, beloved father of Frank and Nancy. Your keen, mercurial mind, your penetrating wisdom, your humor, and your love will live in our hearts forever. Services were held March 26 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 516-487-9600.

title: Turkish Fare, Good Service, Modest Prices
description: THE new Golden Kebab in Garden City, billed as Mediterranean, is actually part of a small but growing Turkish enclave in Nassau-Suffolk. Until recently, Turkish restaurants avoided Long Island, perhaps because less-than-mainstream ethnic spots have not enjoyed great popularity here. That's true even though Turkish food is very similar to Greek fare, with a few distinctive dishes thrown in.

title: He's Consistent
description: To the Editor:

title: Sorry, I Can't Help You: Phone Number Hell
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUDELMAN, BEATRICE
description: YOUDELMAN - Beatrice. On March 20, 1998, originally of NYC. Cherished and devoted mother of Carol and Barry Widensky and the late Matthew. Widow of Herbert Youdelman. Adored grandmother of Chad, Bradley and Ian. Terrific aunt and friend. Loved by all who were fortunate enough to know her in her lifetime. Her memory will inspire others to count their blessings, not their misfortunes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMERFORD, ROSE M.
description: COMERFORD-Rose M. Of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn and Point Lookout, New York, on March 24, 1998. Practicing psychotherapist, graduate of Fordham University, NYU School of Social Work and Washington Square Institute. Beloved and devoted wife of late Frank Comerford. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Joellin, Michael and Andrianne, Frank and Maura, Patrice, Elizabeth and William Spinelli, Maria and James Corcoran, K.C. and Justin Fauci, Christina & Pete Lekkas, Timothy & Mary. Cherished grandmother of eleven loving grandchildren. Reposing Andrew Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305-79 Street, Bklyn, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday 11AM, at St. Malachy's RC Church, Manhattan. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Child Abuse Prevention Program, Inc., 7 Hanover Square, 8th Floor, New York, NY 10004. (212)344-1902.

title: April Off Norway
description: To the Editor: Sarah Ferrell's ''Scenic Days and Nights Off Norway'' (Feb. 1) depicts the charms of a June vacation on the cruise the Norwegians call Hurtigruten and market as ''the world's most beautiful voyage.'' The same trip is very different but equally wonderful in late April, which is when my wife and I went two years ago.

title: Now They All Want To Be in Cleveland
description: When the city of Cleveland lost its football team after the Browns bolted to Baltimore, fans along Lake Erie talked about being abandoned. How times have changed.

title: Helping Artists Cope When They Flounder
description: ''I AM like a shrink,'' said Caroll Michels, with a kind laugh. Since 1978, she has been surrendering her living-room couch to countless artists seeking emotional support and practical guidance on their careers.

title: The View From/Elmsford; Slapstick or Satire? Club for the Funny Bone
description: THE Amazing Johnathan was at Bananas, doing his shtick, a combination of the utterly childish stuff kids used to hurl at one another in grade school (''Why don't we press your face in some dough and make idiot cookies'') and the utterly unprintable. Johnathan (the only name he will reveal), clad in black and with a deliberately demented look on his face, also did magic tricks, some amazing enough to draw mystified oohs and aahs, others flubbed on purpose.

title: The Widow's Run
description: The sun is dazzling and a whispery breeze buoys the star-spangled banners outside the American Legion Hall in Palm Springs, Calif., as Col. Lewis Millett, a Korean War hero and Medal of Honor winner, announces his withdrawal from the race for the United States House of Representatives and pledges his allegiance to someone else.

title: Putting Another Spin On the Triangle
description: THE most notable stage and screen variations on the theme of three-cornered love can still be called modern. Consider Noel Coward's ''Design for Living'' (the 1930's), Francois Truffaut's ''Jules et Jim'' (the 1960's) and Harold Pinter's ''Betrayal'' (the 1970's). None emanate from the puritanical sexual mores of America where the publicity of scandal is more important than the privacy of lives.

title: Hamptons Rental: 3 Bedrooms, School Vu
description: RENTING out one's house in the Hamptons in July and August is usually an easy feat. Except if the house is owned by a school district. What do you charge when it's a school board doing the charging? Too little and the taxpayers could be mad. Too much and the public might grow angry.

title: The World: Bertelsmann Swallows Random House; American Pop Culture, Foreign-Owned
description: IT may not have been quite as shocking as when Tina Brown of the London Tatler and Vanity Fair became editor of The New Yorker, but the book industry got quite a jolt last week when the German media conglomerate Bertelsmann AG announced a deal to buy Random House and become the largest American book publisher.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Guidelines Aim at Keeping a Horse-Farm Feeling
description: THE PenMor Farms development on Route 25A here still looks very much like the thoroughbred horse farm it once was, down to the steel-and-chrome horse sculpture that had always stood at the entrance and still does.

title: Taxpayers, Defeated by Schedule D, Surrender to the Experts
description: ISELOTTE LOEWENSTEIN, a financial district secretary who operated her own dress shop for 27 years, never used to be intimidated by her Federal income tax return.

title: Laura Danford, Paul Mandel
description: Laura Ellen Danford and Paul David Mandel were married last evening in Dexter Hall at the New-York Historical Society in New York. Rabbi Seth Bernstein performed the ceremony.

title: Stephen Biehle, Kimberly Conway
description: Kimberly Jeanne Conway and Stephen Frank Biehle were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York. The Rev. Jeremiah P. O'Neill performed the ceremony.

title: Gretzky Says He's Staying As Rangers Hold Auditions
description: With Wayne Gretzky insisting today that he wishes to remain a Ranger next season, there are at least 19 other questions about the other bodies who will wear the Blue Shirt in 1998-99. Among them: will Aleksei Kovalev, Gretzky's linemate, continue to blossom as a scorer, as he did again today with two more goals in a 2-2 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins?

title: Paige Gaskins, John Rustum
description: Mary Paige Gaskins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larry D. Gaskins of Williamsburg, Va., was married there yesterday to John Patrick Rustum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Rustum of Maplewood, N.J. The Rev. W. Clay Macaulay performed the ceremony with the Rev. Patrick Golden, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Williamsburg Presbyterian Church.

title: World News Briefs; South Korea Eases Curbs On Investment in North
description: The Government will allow business travel and visits by elderly people to North Korea in a bid to expand economic cooperation, a top presidential assistant said today. The move reverses previous policy.

title: Therapist's Confessed Role in Deaths May Be Difficult to Prove
description: Months of detailed investigation will be needed to substantiate the claim of a former respiratory therapist that he sped the deaths of 40 to 50 seriously ill patients out of mercy over the past several years at a hospital in nearby Glendale, Calif., the authorities said today.

title: The New Combination Lock
description: Don Zimmer's seemingly expandable eyes are widening. In his 50th year of professional baseball, Zimmer is stumped.

title: Lawyers, Clean House
description: To the Editor:

title: MUTUAL FUNDS; Returns that Don't Rely on Power and Light
description: ON the menu of investment options, utilities funds have long been, well, meatloaf: safe and boring. But investors who think they are buying the stock market's equivalent of comfort food might be in for some heartburn if they look at what's inside their utilities funds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVNER, FLORENCE
description: RIVNER-Florence. Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mother of Alyson and Randi. Cherished grandmother of Samantha. Dear sister of Yvette. Services ''BoulevardRiverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30 P.M., Sunday.

title: One Nation, After All?
description: To the Editor:

title: All Fashion, Almost All the Time
description: FARRAH SUMMERFORD, fashion's latest Venus, was waxing chatty on a question that has long perplexed civilians: Why do models insist on stalking the runways wearing stormy scowls? The subject of a recent mini-profile on E! Entertainment Television, Ms. Summerford gazed at the camera and let viewers in on the secret. Those vinegary expressions, she confided, were nothing more than a badge of insecurity.

title: Quick Bite/Englewood; Pasta for di Pasqua, or Anytime
description: Here comes Peter Cottontail, along with everything else people think about when planning their Easter celebrations: colored eggs, fancy bonnets and, of course, pasta.

title: Reading Suggestion About Group Homes
description: I read Andrea Kannapell's article ''Into the Outside World'' (March 15) with great interest as I had just completed Lotte Moise's book, ''Barbara and Fred, Grownups Now,'' which I heartily recommend to anyone faced with developmental disabilities.

title: A Magical Ground Cover Called Epimedium
description: FEW plants earn the designation ''perfect,'' but epimediums come close. They are attractive, elegant in appearance and trouble-free.

title: Almighty Dollars
description: GOD IS MY BROKER

title: Beauty Becomes Them
description: A week to celebrate grand opera, grand art from Asia, community service and community education.

title: The Problem Isn't Guns, but Easy Access to Them; No Need for Nostalgia
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Trash Tabloid' Mentality Not Only Publishers' Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: On Language; Paine In the Neck
description: A button man in the gotcha! Gang, Jerome B. Agel of New York, was browsing through Safire's New Political Dictionary and let out a whoop: there, in the entry on ''United States of America,'' was the assertion ''coinage attributed to pamphleteer Thomas Paine.''

title: Die Euro Ist Gut!
description: Polls show that the German people don't much like the idea of discarding the mark for the euro, the European Union's common currency, which is set to be introduced in most of the 15 E.U. member nations next year.

title: P. R. Bauble Of the Week
description: When Food and Wine magazine names the country's best new chefs at a party on April 6, the guests might be in hard hats, mailed with an invitation on a blueprint. And why not? The hors d'oeuvres will go round in Grand Central Terminal, under reconstruction.

title: A Pearl Beyond Price
description: IT was easier to spot Barbara Bertozzi Castelli, the wife of the legendary diminutive art dealer Leo Castelli, than Mr. Castelli himself on Thursday night, when the National Arts Club awarded him its Centennial Medal of Honor. The dapper dealer sat at a table not far from the podium, where Richard Oldenburg of Sotheby's; Kirk Varnedoe of the Museum of Modern Art; David Ross, the departing director of the Whitney Museum; Milton Esterow, the editor of Art News, and the artist James Rosenquist all painted glowing pictures of the man who personifies contemporary art history.

title: Fresh Parsley, Watercress and Scallions Add Greenery to Dishes
description: IT has felt like spring for months and, finally, the season has arrived. And the appetite is more than ready for food that is richly herbaceous yet sturdy enough to satisfy when a chill lingers in the air.

title: Arabs' Ordeal in Israeli Jails Scars Children, U.N. Is Told
description: In his third annual report on human rights violations against Palestinians, a United Nations independent investigator says that a large number of children in Gaza and the West Bank are suffering because of violent treatment of their fathers.

title: Ideas & Trends: Issues of Self-Interest; Suddenly, Nonprofit Work Gets Profitable
description: THE idea that the private sector can teach the public sector a lot has wide appeal in this country. Peter Drucker and other management gurus have long argued that universities, hospitals, charities and governments could all benefit by becoming more efficient, more focused, more entrepreneurial -- in short, more businesslike.

title: Suffolk Sheriff Says Overcrowded Jails Need Double Bunks
description: DESPITE statistics showing that major crimes have sharply declined during the last five years, inmate populations remain high at county jails in Nassau and Suffolk.

title: PLUS: ROWING -- THE BOAT RACE; Cambridge Crew Smashes a Record
description: It was all Light Blue on the River Thames yesterday, as Cambridge University set a record-breaking pace in defeating the Dark Blues of Oxford in the 144th rowing of The Boat Race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, MARGARET L.
description: BERGER-Margaret L. March 25, 1998. Beloved wife of Dr. Adolph R. Berger. Devoted daughter of the late Charles J. Liebman and the late Aline Meyer Liebman. Loving sister of the late Charles J. Liebman Jr. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, March 30, 11 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street, NYC.

title: When This Fight Started, the Subway Fare Was 60 Cents
description: In 1981, Carmine Santa Maria led the fight against Mayor Edward I. Koch when Mr. Koch closed the doors of Public School 248 and gave the keys to the Transit Authority, which turned it into a school for motormen, conductors, engineers and other employees, complete with an old subway car on the playground. Seventeen years later, Mr. Santa Maria is still fighting to have P.S. 248, at 86th Street and West 13th Street, become an elementary school once again.

title: INSIDE
description: ASSAULT ON 9000 /Page 4/

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Breaking of the American Social Compact

title: For Avid Collectors, Corkscrews' Charm Is Out of the Bottle
description: FOR more than 300 years, inventors have tried to come up with the perfect corkscrew. And yet, from the bent nail to the space-age cork puller with a Teflon-coated screw, none has achieved the precise combination of delicacy, strength and handiness needed to draw corks without occasionally breaking one. Still, the long march toward refinement has gone on, with the ordinary corkscrew taking extraordinarily diverse forms.

title: A Reluctant Realist
description: DIPLOMACY FOR THE NEXT CENTURY By Abba Eban. 191 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $24.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column on March 8 about the arched and pedimented church facade on the east side of 402 East 90th Street in Manhattan misstated the building's current name and use. It is a condominium, not a co-op, and it is called River East Plaza, not East River Plaza.

title: Acts That Failed
description: Presentations: They're showtime for some people, the bane of many others. How have they gone for you? And what moments next to the overhead projector would you most like to forget?
