Or remember? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Overseer, Seeing End to Mob Power, Backs Vote in Union Local
description: Concluding that a New Jersey teamsters local is no longer influenced by the mob, a court-appointed overseer will recommend that the local hold elections for the first time in a decade.

title: Trapped Inside James Baldwin
description: JAMES BALDWIN

title: The Common Touch
description: GETTING AWAY WITH MURDER How Politics Is Destroying the Criminal Justice System. By Susan Estrich. 161 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $19.95.

title: Court Dismisses Professor's Suit Against Cornell
description: A New York State court has dismissed the last of eight claims in a $1.5 million lawsuit against Cornell University brought by a psychology professor who challenged the university's procedures in finding him guilty of sexually harassing four female students.

title: SING IT
description: * Starting Tuesday, baseball's opening day, we'll be hearing a lot of ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' -- 2,430 renditions this season, and that's just in the major leagues. * Among active players, Eddie Murray has heard it the most: 3,026 times. * Phil Margo intends to spend $200,000 on road expenses in 1998 so that his band, the Tokens (who sang ''The Lion Sleeps Tonight''), can sing the anthem in every major-league park in one season -- a potential record. * Jamie Lynn Bence, a 10-year-old singer from Hartland, Wis., is only five teams shy of completing her anthem tour. ''This isn't one of those 'parent pushing the child' type things,'' says Rod Beaudoin, her manager. ''This is stuff Jamie wants to do.'' * Put off by overemotive singers during the 1985 World Series, a Missouri state legislator introduced a resolution requiring ''traditional'' anthem singing. It went nowhere.

title: Twisting and Bobbing Into the Spotlight
description: AT first you can't figure out the gait: one leg goes up, the shoulder twists, an arm turns, the head bobs. It's as if a three-legged camel were perambulating the stage. This, of course, is Cripple Billy in ''The Cripple of Inishmaan,'' Martin McDonagh's other play, the one opening on April 7 at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, directed by Jerry Zaks.

title: SPENDING IT; Health Insurance Remains At Home for Many Students
description: WHEN Olia Urinyuk, a sophomore at the University of California at Santa Barbara, was diagnosed with a hormonal imbalance, she required treatment beyond the traditional primary care offered by the campus's student health service.

title: And Now for That Other Season Opener: The Trout
description: Although much of March has been cold, wet and nasty, a gentle winter has set the stage for better-than-usual stream conditions for the April 1 opening of New York State's trout season.

title: Wrong Way on Social Security
description: Proposals from archconservatives to chip away at a gargantuan Government program like Social Security shock no one. But when an influential moderate like Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan proposes to divert Social Security taxes into private retirement accounts, a flawed idea gains ominous support. Mr. Moynihan's rationale is complex. But it is also misleading and unwise.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Mr. Nice Guy

title: Catch of the Day: Companionship, and Maybe Even a Fish or Two
description: Everyone knows that people who fish like to tell stories: about their favorite fishing hole, about the biggest fish they've ever caught, about the one that got away.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A FINE SILVER THREAD.

title: Trophy Properties Top the Recovery in Chicago
description: THE recovery of the downtown commercial real estate market in major urban centers in the mid-90's has led in Chicago to new ownership at some of the city's choicest office properties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, PARKOFF, RUTH
description: TAYLOR-PARKOFF-Ruth. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a highly respected member of the community, a dedicated Zionist and supporter of Jewish institutions here and in Israel, beloved wife of Norm Taylor and mother of A. Richard (and Debra) Parkoff and David (and Linda) Parkoff. A. Richard Parkoff, a member of the Board of Directors of Yeshiva College, and his wife Debra are YU Guardians who established the Abraham Parkoff Scholarship Fund at our James Striar School of General Jewish Studies. Dedicated leaders of YU, they were honored by the University with the prestigious Heritage Award. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to grandchildren and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Q. & A.
description: Appraising Vacant L.I. Land

title: Adam Ratner and Shari Gelber
description: Shari Ellen Gelber, a daughter of Carol and Jules Gelber of Scarsdale, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Adam Jonathan Ratner, the son of Dr. Ellise Delphin of Tenafly, N.J., and Stephen Ratner of New York. Jonathan Malamy, a rabbinical student, officiated with Rabbi Lisa Gelber, a sister of the bride, at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Where Rain Falls Rarely On the Plain
description: Spring rain in Paris brings out that fashion capital's practical side. The newest raincoat, far right, is an instant status symbol: one of Marc Jacobs's first designs for Louis Vuitton, in the company's monogrammed fabric. Other coats come from classic houses like Hermes, Gucci. Chanel, Jaeger and Burberry. Students on the Left Bank favor coats in camouflage prints. Even all-weather beige coats have distinctive shaping, including aggressive shoulder padding, bottom left. Beige seems to be the color of choice, too, for French-bulldog-wear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, LEONARD JOHN
description: ROBBINS-Leonard John. In Manhattan at the age of 95. A graduate of Jesus College, Cambridge University, and New York Law School, he was a senior partner of Ladas & Parry. A member of the New York Bar Association, he was an internationally renowned patent attorney. Also an accomplished artist, and a proud member of the Century Association. Beloved husband of 66 years of Ann Roe Robbins. Loving father to Susan Morrison, Jennifer Manocherian and Victoria Cowal. Grandfather of eleven, great grandfather of eleven. He will be sorely missed.

title: Remembering Paul Robeson, in His Jersey Days and Beyond
description: Actor, musician, athlete, lawyer, outspoken advocate of civil rights and left-wing causes, Paul Robeson was a renaissance man for his time, even if that time's racism and terror of Communism overshadowed his achievements. He was also a New Jerseyan by birth, and many communities are planning observances of the 100th anniversary of his birth on April 9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONS, JAMES D.
description: SIMONS-James D. On March 27, 1998 after a long illness. Beloved son of Anna Lee Berini. Loving father of Janet and Joyce. Adoring grandfather of Scott. Dear brother of John. Writer and historian. Family will receive Sunday 7-9 PM. Service Monday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory to the American Revolution Round Table, 14 Beverly Rd., Port Washington, NY 10150 or the American Cancer Society.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: AT HIS SIDE: The Last Years of Isaac Babel

title: Business Class As a Way of Life
description: A lot of my fellow road warriors join me in saying thank you for noticing the life style of some of us (''Business Class as a Way of Life,'' A Special Issue, March 8). It is a difficult life style, but one that is getting easier with E-mail and cellular phones that can follow you. In the early 80's, when businessmen like myself would go into mainland China or Russia or even Mexico, it was as if we were going into outer space. No one could find us. I knew that a new era had begun the day I was driving in a rural area in the state of Jalisco, Mexico, and my cellular phone rang. It was a friend in Europe calling from his cellular phone and it sounded as if he were next door.

title: March 22-28; When I Want Advice, I'll Tell You What It Is.
description: Last summer, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed a commission to study how to improve the sometimes tense relations between New York City's residents and its police officers. On Thursday, he stunned members of the task force by belittling their recommendations. Created shortly after the alleged torture of a Haitian immigrant inside a Brooklyn police stationhouse last August, the task force recommended higher pay and a residency requirement for officers.

title: Her Ideas Won't Fade
description: To the Editor:

title: March 22-28; Swiss Seek Settlement Of Nazi Gold Suits
description: For most of the time that Jewish groups have been laying siege to Swiss banks for the way they helped the Nazis and hindered Holocaust survivors, the banks have repeated a mantra: Show us documentation that your family deposited assets during the war, and we'll turn it over. Otherwise, go away.

title: March 22-28; College Athletes Charged With Rigging Games
description: It was an ignominious coincidence. On the eve of college basketball's biggest weekend of the year, the Final Four championships, a Federal grand jury handed up an indictment charging that college basketball players had taken bribes to fix Big Ten basketball games in 1995.

title: A Two-Way Commitment
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Symposium Series and an Exhibition; On Preservation And Landmarks
description: Starting Tuesday and continuing through May, the New-York Historical Society, at 77th Street and Central Park West, will present six free symposiums on the present and future direction of landmark preservation.

title: World News Briefs; Peace Talks on Schedule Despite Killing in Ulster
description: British and Irish officials said today that an outbreak of violence in Northern Ireland would not delay the resumption of peace talks on Monday.

title: Sports of The Times; Teams That Represent Basketball, Not Gender
description: THEY have been to the women's Final Four a combined 26 times and won seven national titles. They have statewide support and news media coverage, pack their arenas and dwarf the success of their school's men's teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, PEARL S.
description: WEISS-Pearl S. Of Sarasota, FL, formerly of Larchmont, NY, on March 28, 1998. Wife of the late Harold (Pat). Mother of Anne Schiff and Martha Grinberg. Grandmother of five.

title: Corrections
description: A review on March 8 about ''For the People: What the Constitution Really Says About Your Rights,'' by Akhil Reed Amar and Alan Hirsch, misstated the number of amendments to the Constitution. There are 27, not 26; the 27th, ratified in 1992, limits the power of Congress to raise its own pay.

title: Laurie Baskin Steven Fadem
description: Laurie Beth Baskin and Steven Scott Fadem were married last evening by Rabbi William Kaufman at Temple Beth El in Fall River, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, RUTH S.
description: FISCHER-Ruth S. Mommy-Nana, the years you lived in our home and the love you gave to all of us will be treasured memories that we will hold in our hearts forever. We all loved every moment we shared, and we will love you with all our hearts forever and ever. Your memory and good deeds will live on forever through our family and future family generations. With all our love, Leslie and Bob, Justin, Brandon and Blake

title: Go West: New Sport Brutes Square Off on the Utah Buttes
description: MONUMENT VALLEY, that collection of impossibly beautiful buttes, mesas, canyons and valleys in southeast Utah and northeast Arizona, is an excellent place to test the mettle of sport utility vehicles. There are great roads, good roads, bad roads, rocky roads, dirt roads and no roads, with natural wonders waiting no matter which route you take.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, JEANETTE
description: WEINSTEIN-Jeanette. 85 years young. Wife of the late Ted, sister of Yetta. Mother of Ed (Julie) and Richard (Catherine). Nana of Evan, Jennifer, Shayna and Faith.

title: Spending Proposal
description: The Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services, which provides services to 32 central and southern school districts in the county, has proposed a $4.5 million administrative budget for 1998-99, up from $4.3 million this year. But because the board has reduced costs and found new sources of revenues, the cost to the districts will actually drop, Vincent T. Beni, the district Superintendent, said.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: A Rat's Tale

title: Eight Schools Named Among the Best
description: EIGHT of the county's high schools have been named among the 100 best public high schools in the United States, according to the March 30 issue of Newsweek magazine.

title: A Complex Artist Of Simple Bearing
description: THE era of Soviet ballet that Galina Ulanova symbolized so completely died at least two decades before her own death at 88 on March 21 in Moscow.

title: Lady Liberty Isn't the Only City Worker With a Torch
description: It's a short walk from Community Board 4's office on West 42d Street to the nightclub Don't Tell Mama on West 46th, but it's far enough for Jessica Greer to change from mild-mannered district manager to sultry cabaret singer in a red satin dress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, MARION
description: GOLDMAN-Marion. Of Rego Park on March 27, 1998. Beloved wife and lifelong companion of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Seymour and David. Loving mother-in-law of Suzanne. Dear sister and best friend of Laura and Jeannette. Sister-in-law of Norman. Adored grandmother of Lorin Michelle, Evan Daniel, Brian Seth and Diana Beth. Cherished aunt of Adrianne, Arlene and Phyllis. Esteemed President of the Sisterhood of Rego Park Jewish Center. A woman of valour. Her goodness, radiance and love will live forever in the hearts of all who loved her and all whose lives she touched. Services on Sunday, March 29, 1998, 2 PM at ''Parkside Chapel'', Queens Blvd. at 66th Avenue.

title: Hunger Strikers Back an Albanian Who Defrauded Thousands
description: In this destitute country where court cases are generally decided by the biggest bribe and where a banking system is a foreign concept, there seems to be no end to the power of the swindler.

title: Women Say Seduction Was Mask for Swindle
description: Joy desperately wanted a man in her life.

title: Harrowing Ride Comes To an Uneventful End
description: Millions of dollars worth of Yankees talent went through a harrowing experience late Friday, when a bus carrying the team's players rocked heavily as it went over a curb in Mexico.

title: Five Ethnic Festivals Lose Their Weekends
description: Five of the 10 ethnic festivals usually held in the spring and fall at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel Township will not take place this year, and some organizers are balking at a single festival that would celebrate the five displaced ethnic groups together.

title: Forces From the Soul of a Dyed-in-the-Wool (Or Is It Fake Fur?) Romantic
description: AVANT-GARDISTS proclaim that art must be forward-looking, but sometimes it moves forward by looking backward. Alison Weld could be an example. A dyed-in-the-wool romantic, she disclaims all connection with the conceptual gamesmanship and irony of so much recent art. Instead, her elective soul mates would be artists like Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Franz Kline and their followers, ''action painters'' slugging it out with a loaded brush and an empty canvas in the cold-water flats of the existentialist 1950's.

title: Claris Ramos, R.A. Sukkar Jr.
description: Claris Ramos and Richard A. Sukkar Jr. were married yesterday in Austin, Tex. The Rev. Larry Mattingly performed the ceremony at La Iglesia Catolica de Cristo Rey.

title: March 22-28; Yeltsin Makes It Clear Who the Boss Is
description: Even for a man who long ago made the high wire his home, it was quite a week for Boris N. Yeltsin. After a bout of illness and months of vague and inconsistent statements, he appeared in the Kremlin Monday to announce that he had dismissed his entire government. The main victim was Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, his steadfast Prime Minister. He then appointed himself in Mr. Chernomyrdin's place but was informed that the Constitution wouldn't allow it. So he appointed a 35-year-old political neophyte, Sergei Kiriyenko, who heard the news about a half hour before the rest of the country did.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; The Evolution of Lawn Guyland
description: MY fourth-grade teacher, Mrs. Cornell, was the first to tell me about the glacier that created Long Island. The pile of debris-laden ice halted on a southward journey from New England, melted and left its rough edge of solid materials, much as a broom consolidates a little ridge of sweepings. From Brooklyn to Suffolk, the glacial ridge in Bay Ridge, Jamaica Estates, Lake Success and Dix Hills is one of the unifying features of our Long Island. Some of it is used as a right-of-way for parkways that traverse the line separating the city from Lawn Guyland.

title: National News Briefs; $271 Billion Roads Bill Draws Clinton's Wrath
description: The six-year, $271 billion highway bill pending in the House is drawing fire from President Clinton, who calls it a threat to ''both our fiscal discipline and our commitment to education and other critical investments in our future.''

title: Marcia Landesman, Oren Sauberman
description: Marcia Lynn Landesman, the daughter of Debby and Charles Landesman of Hillsdale, N.J., was married last evening to Oren Sauberman, a son of Hadasa and Simon Sauberman of Pomona, N.Y. Rabbi Andrew Ungar officiated at Temple Emanuel in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: The Movie That First Noticed TV's Grip on Politics
description: HEGEL saw the ritual reading of the daily newspaper as the secular equivalent of morning prayer. If so, the great televised media events that periodically transfix Americans must be something akin to religious festivals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORWIN, JOAN
description: CORWIN-Joan. Prayers go out to our sister-in-law, aunt, and friend, Corey Corwin Shafran and her family on the death of their mother, Joan. Eve, Billie, Annah, Andrew, Sammy, Molly, Joshua, Jenny and Kirsten

title: All Schools Need Charter Schools' Leeway
description: To the Editor:

title: N.L. West
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. In the East, the Mets are picked to finish in second place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDLOW, ALDEN R., JR.
description: LUDLOW-Alden R., Jr. Of Lawrence, NY on March 26, 1998 at age 86. Husband of the late Mabel Whitman Ludlow. Son of the late Alden Rodney Ludlow and Alician Gamble Ludlow. Brother of the late Alicia Ludlow Cavanagh. He is survived by his sons Alden R. Ludlow, III and Eben W. Ludlow and grandsons Alden R. Ludlow, IV and Sayre H. Ludlow. Mr. Ludlow was a graduate of the Greenvale School, St. Paul's School and Yale University, Phi Beta Kappa, Class of 1934. During World War II he served as a Major in the Army Air Corps in North Africa and Italy and was awarded The Bronze Star. He retired in 1969 as Vice President, Managing Director of U.S. Industrial Chemicals Co. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the American Cancer Society. A memorial service will be held at the Trinity-St. John's Church, Hewlett, LI, NY on Saturday, April 18 at noon.

title: When the Auctioneer Himself Is a Charitable Donation of Sorts
description: ALL it takes is a hot room, good items and a little luck. And when you've got all that going for you, it's magic, said Leighton Strader, off-hours auctioneer.

title: Indian-Italian Eating At Modest Prices
description: Although Indian-Continental fusion cuisine is now popular, not all of it is expensive. Ajid Saha (pronounced SHA-ha) opened his modest Kiran Continental and Indian Cuisine at 401 West 53d Street at Ninth Avenue last month.

title: The World: Sorry About That; Africa Gets the Clinton Treatment
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON has had precious little to offer in terms of new financial help during his 12-day tour of Africa. But he has been dispensing regret by the shovelful.

title: A Pair of Programs Of String Quartets
description: BEETHOVEN is the link between two string quartet programs this week. Today at 4, in the Congregational Church of Wilton, the Brentano Quartet plays works by Haydn and Bartok as well as by Beethoven (the number to call for more information is 203-762-8076). On Friday at 8 in Crowell Hall at Wesleyan University, Beethoven's Opus 18 No. 2 is the centerpiece of the Manhattan Quartet's program, which also lists Shostakovich and, with Okon Hwang, professor at Eastern Connecticut State University, Schumann's Piano Quintet.

title: Corrections
description: The Cyberscout column on March 15, about cybercafes, where travelers can connect to the Internet and get something to eat or drink, misstated the number of such places listed in the book ''Cybercafes: A Worldwide Guide for Travelers.'' It is more than 530, not more than 350.

title: Lawsuit Charges Landlord Had No Vacancies -- for Blacks
description: In spring 1996, the Open Housing Center, a nonprofit fair-housing organization in Manhattan, received an anonymous telephone call about a Bay Ridge realtor.

title: Still a Bilingual Guy, But Without Muppets
description: AN entire generation of Americans will proudly tell you that ''Sesame Street,'' which begins its 30th season this year, taught them to read and count. But for John Williams, that statement is particularly close to the truth. In the early days of the show, Mr. Williams was better known as John John, the little boy whose memory for numbers and letters, recited with Grover and Kermit and other Muppets, was matched only by his impossibly plump cheeks.

title: Out of Context
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Everyone Has a Story,' As One Reporter Proves
description: David Johnson is not a man of original ideas. If he were, he says, he would be a novelist, not a newspaper reporter living on a remote ranch. But his one inspiration has caught on in this slightly obscure corner of the world.

title: Scenic Path in Wales For Hikers and Bikers
description: Cyclists and hikers in Wales can experience the varied landscapes of the country -- from the national parks of Snowdonia and Brecon Beacons to the industrial valleys of South Wales -- on the Welsh National Cycle route, part of a 6,500-mile network being developed by a civil engineering charity, Sustrans. The Welsh stretch, called the Lon Las Cymru, runs for 288 miles along abandoned railway lines, country tracks and quiet back roads, from Holyhead in the north to Cardiff and Chepstow in the south. It is expected to be finished by the year 2000, with sculptures and artwork by local artists along the way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVECHILD, LESLIE M.
description: EVECHILD-Leslie M. Floral and jewelry designer and loving daughter of Evelyn and Ed Smiler. Passed away in Cabrini Hospice on March 27, 1998.

title: K. Rations
description: THE CASTLE

title: Corrections
description: A brief review of ''Charles A. Lindbergh: A Human Hero,'' by James Cross Giblin, in the Times Book Review on March 15 misstated the month of Lindbergh's nonstop flight from New York to Paris. It was May 1927, not April.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Radclyffe Hall

title: Babies Aloft
description: To the Editor: Your article on air travel with babies, ''Having Second Thoughts in the Air'' (Jan. 4) was timely.

title: Rough Sailing for South Street Seaport
description: THEY came by the thousands on that bright day in July 1983, eager to take part in the event: the opening of the Fulton Market Building, which was built above the still-operating Fulton Fish Market and was to be the centerpiece of the long-awaited rehabilitation of the South Street Seaport.

title: Collage of Memories and More On Civilians in World War II
description: I HAVE forgotten the name of the movie but not William Holden's performance in it. He is cast as the captain of a merchant ship who, while shaving, learns that the United States has entered World War II and, without missing a stroke, says, ''Which side are we on?''

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: The Disease That Does Not Discriminate
description: In the dark years when Maia Szalavitz was chasing heroin, the young red-headed New Yorker landed briefly in jail. On her release, she hurried back to her apartment and ground up some opiates that a police search had overlooked. ''And I injected them,'' she confessed to Bill Moyers. ''I mean, how irrational can you get? You've just been arrested for this stuff, and then what do you do but as soon as you go home, you do this?''

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: Puzzling Over Productivity
description: ''America's Treadmill Economy'' (March 8), Louis Uchitelle's article about productivity and the pressure on companies to increase quality as they fight to hang onto customers, drew a large response from readers. All the letters discuss -- and illustrate -- the divergence over what is or should be measured, and how.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 29, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, VICTOR CHARLES
description: BELL-Victor Charles. 96, lifelong Manhattan resident with distinguished naval and civilian careers, died March 5 at the home of his daughter Mrs. Wendy Walsh of Hackensack. Investment banker, industrialist and combat veteran of WWI and WWII, serving in the Mediterranean and on Guadalcanal. Business partner of Walter Chrysler, Jr., in Sonora Radio, Moto-Meter Gauge and Equipment Company, and Electric Auto-Lite. President and Chairman of General Aviation Equipment Company, manufacturer of WWII bomber controls and the support spar for Howard Hughes' Flying Boat, ''Spruce Goose.'' Drafted portion of the original FDIC Charter. Former member of Metropolitan and Wings Clubs. Survived by six children, four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

title: Legislation: Breast Exams, Insurance Disclosure
description: State lawmakers are considering a bill that would make New Jersey the first state in the nation to require public schools to teach breast self-examination in health education classes.

title: Food; Lagoon Struck
description: If a city could have an astrological sign, Venice would be Pisces, two fish swimming in opposite directions. In fact, if you lose yourself in a canal or on one of the city's narrow, winding streets, you begin to believe that only a fish could find its way out.

title: The Nation: Spin Cycle; Round and Round in the Search for Meaning
description: ALMOST from the moment the bullets stopped flying outside Westside Middle School in Jonesboro, Ark., the explanations and analysis began whizzing by.

title: Puzzling Over Productivity
description: ''America's Treadmill Economy'' (March 8), Louis Uchitelle's article about productivity and the pressure on companies to increase quality as they fight to hang onto customers, drew a large response from readers. All the letters discuss -- and illustrate -- the divergence over what is or should be measured, and how.

title: Arthur Link, 77, Editor of Wilson Papers, Dies
description: Arthur Stanley Link, whose prodigious 35-year effort editing the papers of Woodrow Wilson set the standard for the presentation of historical documents, died of lung cancer on Thursday at the Bermuda Village Health Center in Advance, N.C. He was 77 and widely regarded as the foremost authority on the 28th President.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Hawthorne Motel Owner Razing It to Build Anew
description: DIRECTLY opposite the exit to this hamlet off the Saw Mill River Parkway, a 50's-style motel sits unobtrusively on a hill overlooking heavily trafficked Route 9A. For 42 years, it's been a part of the landscape, often the first thing motorists see when they come into Hawthorne.

title: Prep School for CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ANNETTE ROSE (NEE GOLDBERG)
description: COHEN-Annette Rose (nee Goldberg). March 24, 1959. In cherished and loving memory of a dearly beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Sadly missed, always in our hearts. Lucille, Richard Jay, Hope and daughters, Lindsey and Ashley

title: Child Watch, Another View
description: How sad that Linda Pearce Prestley, whose job is the State Child Advocate, sees no alternatives for the most vulnerable children besides substandard foster care and warehousing them in institutions. (''Child Watch: Of Access and Orphanages,'' Q&A, Feb. 22.0

title: Sorry, I Can't Help You: Phone Number Hell
description: To the Editor:

title: Challenging Ireland's Demons With a Laugh
description: THE Irish are such obsessive conversationalists that if they were not funny, they would probably be at one another's throats. On second thought, of course, they have been at one another's throats a fair bit, but they have still retained their sense of humor. Unsurprisingly, given the successive traumas of Irish history, it is a dark sense of humor. But it has also proved immensely useful: in the pub and in literature, it has permitted the Irish both to mock and to celebrate their Irishness. Now, in Neil Jordan's new film, ''The Butcher Boy,'' which opens on Friday, humor has become the ultimate instrument of survival.

title: A Lyrical Reading of Bartok's Quartets
description: SOMETIMES nice guys, or dolls, finish first, not because of divine justice but because their very niceness masks a fierce ambition.

title: March 22-28; Some Are More Prepared To Be Scouts Than Others
description: As everyone knows, Boys Scouts are supposed to be prepared, and also brave, clean and reverent, but the California Supreme Court ruled that young men who are gay, agnostic or atheist can be denied the right to join. In a pair of unanimous rulings, the court held that the Scouts are a private membership organization, not covered by the state's 40-year-old civil rights law, and so are free to set membership policies as they see fit. The ruling did not turn on any question of Federal law, so it cannot be appealed, but similar challenges to the Scouts' membership policies are pending in other states, and a New Jersey state appeals court recently ruled in favor of a gay Scoutmaster's efforts to stay in the organization. TODD S. PURDUM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERMAN, DR. SIDNEY
description: LERMAN-Dr. Sidney, 70, died on March 18th, 1998, of complications from Crohn's Disease. A distinguished ophthalmologist, acclaimed throughout his profession for his work in many areas of eye research, Dr. Lerman, a native of Montreal, graduated from McGill University with honors and from McGill Medical School. He held university appointments in ophthalmology and biochemistry and directed departments of experimental ophthalmology at the University of Rochester Medical School, McGill University Medical School, Emory University Medical School, the Georgia Institute of Technology, and New York Medical College. He was widely published in scientific journals and wrote numerous books, some of which became standards in their field. He served on the editorial boards of scientific journals as well as on the boards of directors of biochemical and photobiologic societies & was a frequent lecturer on topics related to his research. He is survived by his wife, Lynn F. Lerman of NY; daughter, Lora Rachel Helyar of Encino, CA; son, Mark J. Lerman of Providence, RI; sister, Bella Linden of NY; twin brother, Dr. Bernard Lerman of Atlanta, GA; two grandchildren, Samuel Helyar and Rae Lerman; and nieces and nephews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALEY, JOAN LAWTON
description: PALEY-Joan Lawton. Of Lauderdale By The Sea passed away after a long illness on March 27, 1998. Joan was born in Pawtucket, Rhode Island and educated at Brown University and Albany Law School. She practiced law in Washington, DC and in New York City. She was a Supervisory Attorney for the National Labor Relations Board and later an associate in the law firm of Berman, Paley, Goldstein & Kannry, LLP in New York City. Before moving to Florida, Joan lived in Larchmont, NY and was a past president of the Scarsdale Woman's Club and a past president of the Scarsdale Congregational Church Woman's Guild. She was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and several other honorary societies. She is survived by her husband David, sister Maureen McGarry, her stepdaughter Staci and two grandchildren Christopher and Aletha Buchal. A memorial service will be held at the First Congregational Church, 2501 N.E. 30th Street, Fort Lauderdale, Florida 32757 on Palm Sunday, April 5, 1998, at 12:30 PM.

title: Wipeouts
description: VIRUSES, PLAGUES,

title: Our Memories, Our Selves
description: Stephen S. Hall's article ''Our Memories, Our Selves'' (Feb. 15) credited a New York University film student with writing a screenplay and coining the name Bleach to identify memory-suppressing drugs. ''Bleach'' is the name of my screenplay and film, which was recently shown at the 1998 Sundance Film Festival. The term is used in a futuristic setting to identify a particular memory-suppressing drug on the street.

title: Puzzling Over Productivity
description: ''America's Treadmill Economy'' (March 8), Louis Uchitelle's article about productivity and the pressure on companies to increase quality as they fight to hang onto customers, drew a large response from readers. All the letters discuss -- and illustrate -- the divergence over what is or should be measured, and how.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, PEARL
description: COOPER-Pearl. On March 26, 1998. Beloved wife for 58 years to George. Adored mother of Elizabeth and Irwin Feiner, Leslie and Bob Gruber, and Barbara Cooper. Loving grandmother of Steven, Scott, Andrea and Andrew, Andrew, Richard and Alan, Jason and David. She was our family matriarch and will be missed tremendously by all. Services on Sunday, March 29 at 1:30 PM, Blvd Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY.

title: TELEVISION; Muppets Succeed Where Politicians Haven't
description: WE are rehearsing a scene about a Palestinian rooster and a Palestinian girl monster struggling to overcome their fear of a giant Israeli porcupine.

title: Bike Haters Love This Park
description: Riverbank State Park, between the Hudson River and the Henry Hudson Parkway in West Harlem, has almost all the amenities. It has a large softball field, an Olympic-size track, an indoor swimming pool, a skating rink, four basketball courts and four tennis courts, even a community greenhouse. It has nearly everything, except a welcoming attitude toward cyclists.

title: $42 Million for Black Colleges
description: The United Negro College Fund said last week that it had been awarded a $42 million grant for a three-year program to assist historically black colleges and universities with construction needs, student financial aid and faculty assistance.

title: Fly Back to Idlewild: Enjoy the Holding Pattern
description: Idlewild, the 1960's customized jet lounge at 145 East Houston Street between Eldridge and Forsyth Streets, is about to board. Jim Chu, Eric Rasmussen and Rob Lumerman plan to open this concept lounge on Saturday. The exterior suggests a fuselage; the entrance hall is like an airplane ramp, and the interior sports the windows of a Boeing 727. Cocktail menus are in the seat pockets.

title: SOAPBOX; A Case of Mistaken Identity
description: IT was one of the few bitterly cold days of last winter. The wind was tossing debris in Central Park, and the litter from the street was swirling around me. Tree branches were cracking and falling.

title: Q&A/Stuart Kessler; From a Tax Man, Thoughts on Old Image
description: ON various levels the Federal tax code and the Internal Revenue Service have been under attack. Last year, Congress held hearings on reported I.R.S. abuse. Earlier this month, Vice President Al Gore called for a friendlier I.R.S. There is talk of eliminating the income tax entirely and replacing it with a national sales tax, and seemingly everyone decries how complicated the tax code is.

title: VIEWPOINT; Get It Right, Mr. Levitt
description: THE widening stream of information from the corporate board room has been a key factor propelling the record bull market of much of the last decade, leading to greater transparency and greater confidence among investors. Yet the Securities and Exchange Commission still has not come to grips with the issue of just when this information truly becomes public, despite repeated requests to do so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARTORIUS, JOHN M.
description: SARTORIUS-John M. Of Quogue, New York, formerly of Tenafly, New Jersey, died on March 23, 1998 after a long illness in his 78th year. He is survived by his devoted wife Nancy, four sons, John, Jr., Peter, David and Scott, a sister Beverly VanderPoel, a brother Robert Sartorius. He was predeceased by his first wife, Frances Cauchois Sartorius in 1973. Mr. Sartorius graduated from the Hill School and Princeton University Class of 1942. He served as a 1st Lieutenant in the U.S. Army in Europe during World War II and was awarded the Bronze Star. He retired from Union Carbide in 1980 as a product Manager. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Southampton Care Center or the Southampton Hospital would be appreciated. Funeral Mass will be 10 AM Monday, March 30, at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Westhampton Beach, New York.

title: Funerals End for Jonesboro, but Not Questions
description: Today, as this city buried the last of its dead, killed in an almost unspeakable act, people stared into the unsettling prospect of moving on.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: HIGH HOLIDAY SUTRA

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: FIRST LOVE and LOOK FOR MY OBITUARY By Elena Garro. Curbstone, paper, $11.95.

title: Stanford Pushes Wildcats To the Brink in Overtime
description: What more could Stanford have done?

title: Liberties; Some Vexing Matters
description: When Bill Clinton meets with a foreign leader, he takes on some of the other leader's coloration. With Helmut Kohl, the President looks the satisfied, well-fed burgher. With Boris Yeltsin, the President exudes a ruddy bonhomie. With Nelson Mandela, Mr. Clinton ingratiates himself by standing a bit straighter, holding himself with a bit more dignity.

title: The Cheapest Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Class As a Way of Life
description: The stories you chose to tell paint the ''brave new world'' of business travel as a place where traveling salesmen blithely engage in extramarital affairs while their poor, unsuspecting wives wait at home; where traveling women are universally burdened by guilt over abandoning their children. Even the fictional characters in your fashion spread were stereotypes. The female perfume executive (the only minority traveler in the entire issue, by the way) has a chaste blind date, while the male rock-and-roll lawyer trolls for ''girls'' at bars and art galleries. If you had looked a little harder, surely you could have also found women on the road who cheat on their poor, unsuspecting husbands and traveling men longing to spend more time with their families.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Newton Boys

title: Style; Up From Ready-to-Wear
description: Flashback: Sometime in the 1960's, Susan Kaposta, recently of Shreveport, La. -- daughter of an Air Force pilot, art appreciation student at the Sorbonne -- is slipped a coveted invitation to the Chanel couture show at 31 rue Cambon by a family friend. ''It was sheer magic,'' she recalls. ''A woman would announce 'No. 10' and describe the fabric and there was quite a hush, you know? And up the stairs sat Mademoiselle, smoking and watching the reaction. One portly woman told me as I was leaving -- I was very thin back then -- she said to me, 'Darling, you're the only one who could wear the darn things.' Which was true. But of course I couldn't afford it.'' Yet.

title: Detours Amid the Squalls
description: After experiencing everything from treacherous wind changes to flying fish to turbulent squalls, nearly every yacht in the Whitbread Round the World Race changed positions between Wednesday and Friday. And on-board reports made life in a washing machine sound desirable to what several yachts were going through as they neared the Bahamas in the final stages of Leg 6.

title: Axels and Arias?
description: Beaver Creek, Colo., has figured out a way to mix skating and sonatas. The Vilar Center for the Arts opened last month beneath a skating rink in that ski town. Acoustical-isolating springs were used in all the theater's walls and ceiling to keep out the noise from above. The theater also includes a 2,250-square-foot art gallery. Information on Vilar Center events: (970) 748-1394.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESIBIA, EDWARD J.
description: DESIBIA-Edward J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Edward J. Desibia, associated with The Times from 1957, until retiring in 1980.

title: Time for Lolita's Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Shutout Moves Brodeur Toward Mark for Victories
description: There is the game-day ritual of suiting up left side to right. There is the tendency to ignore the word ''optional'' attached to off-day practices. Then there is the videotape, which every 10 days or so Martin Brodeur studies of every puck shot on his goal.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Eighth Graders' Project of Devising Show
description: GALLERY 2 at the Hudson River Museum was tantalizingly empty, with the exception of an azure-clothed table circled by a half-dozen eighth graders. The challenge facing them was to concoct a show for the gallery. Their subject was ''On the Home Front,'' a tribute to World War II. They had already decided to re-create the interior of a house, circa 1940's Westchester.

title: It's Over When It's Over, Until We Meet Again
description: ''IT ain't over till the fat lady sings,'' is a saying often incorrectly attributed to Yogi Berra.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about state report cards for middle schools and high schools referred incorrectly to the reading performance at Pleasantville Middle School. It scored in the second-highest group, not the lowest.

title: Oh, That Brazen, Raucous, Glorious Hibiscus
description: ON the subject of hibiscus, there is little room for neutrality. Some gardeners adore it, some hate it, and a few profess to admire the tropical varieties while despising the hardy perennial types. Hibiscus inspires opinion.

title: The Unseen Presence, the Overheard Secret
description: LISTEN to the prolific Richard Greenberg talking about his playwriting technique: ''I take a lot of images, ideas -- scraps -- that are probably by themselves too thin to make a play of, and they come together suddenly and seem to fall into place.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, STEVEN GLENN
description: SCHULMAN-Steven Glenn. Beloved husband of Laura. Devoted father of Matthew and Stephanie. Adored son of Marlene and Jerry. Cherished brother of Mindy and Jon, Jeffrey and Diane. Darling son-in-law of Esther and Herman Ching. Brother-in-law of Norton. Dear uncle of Melissa, Amanda and Carly. Private family services at Union Field Cemetery.

title: Questing for New Definitions of Contemporary Art
description: WHEN I was a child in the 1940's, the idea that an art museum could be the target of controversy was like imagining a 300-pound ballerina as the lead in ''Swan Lake.'' Yet today, just 50 years later, contemporary-art museums have become nearly synonymous with pitched battles over the nature, value and financing of art. The International Center of Photography, the Studio Museum in Harlem, Dance Theater Workshop, El Museo del Barrio, the Kitchen and Franklin Furnace, to name a handful in Manhattan alone, are arts organizations that have taken enormous risks to change the cultural landscape for the better. Controversy is endemic to them, because sparking disagreement and debate is exactly what the art of our own time does best and most valuably: it encourages independent thinking.

title: Holy Axmen!
description: THE BARBARIAN CONVERSION

title: Three Cuisines Fuse in Croton-on-Hudson
description: FICUS trees strung with pinpoints of golden light stand sentry, marking the entrance to this romantic beauty of a new restaurant. Except for the soaring side room (the one we prefer), the space itself lacks grandeur, but the decor does a brilliant job of imparting the feel of far-away baronial splendor, easy to imagine in the unsteady glow from dozens of pillar candles reflecting on the polished wood floor and in huge ornate mirrors.

title: Stylish Spot, Small Menu and No Airs
description: TIME was, not all that long ago, when restaurants were either very fancy (and priced accordingly) or about at the fast-food level, with few tolerable choices in between. But today one can have a pleasant casual meal with good, sometimes very good, food at affordable prices. The level of restaurant cooking has improved considerably in the past 5 to 10 years.

title: Two Plans Aimed at Better Education
description: A FIVE-YEAR half-billion-dollar education package that includes more than 20 proposals to improve the quality of education in urban centers was recently approved by the State Board of Education.

title: How Boyhood Friend Aided Pope With Israel
description: Jerzy Kluger says the first memory he shares with Karol Wojtyla, the man who is now Pope John Paul II, is of being chased around the square in their home town in Poland by an irate policeman. They were only 4 or 5 years old and had tried to pluck the policeman's sword from its sheath while he dozed on a bench.

title: Mystery Behind a Public Death; Feeling Unwelcome, Russian Wanted to Go Home
description: Trained as an engineer in Russia, Michael Kurchak mopped floors and cleaned toilets in America. He slept in a small room at the private Hasidic academy where he worked in Monroe, N.Y., hoarding his weekly $184 janitor's check, telling at least one student that he would soon be going home.

title: Report Points to Next Battle at CUNY
description: In yet another attack on the embattled City University of New York, a new study charges that most of CUNY's senior colleges are denying their students a proper academic grounding by not requiring core courses in basic areas like mathematics, science, history and literature.

title: San Diego to Celebrate Balboa Park in Bloom
description: San Diego, known for its mild spring weather and spectacular blooms, is holding ''Buds n' Blooms! A Floral Fiesta in Balboa Park'' throughout April.

title: The Deerslayer
description: HEART OF HOME People, Wildlife, Place. By Ted Kerasote. 250 pp. New York: Villard Books. $23.

title: Lust at the Top: the Prequel
description: By the time the Monica Lewinsky drama has run its course, there will probably be more people who can identify Warren Harding's mistresses than the causes of World War I. Americans generally have little interest in history, but whenever the nation's moral bearings seem particularly shaky, we turn hopefully to the past, looking for evidence that the present social disarray is merely part of an old pattern rather than evidence of some long, irrevocable slide into spiritual decay. It's nothing, we yearn to tell ourselves. This has happened before, and we got over it.

title: Lives; Multiple Exposure
description: Consider how hard it is to be the other James Barron. He and I live in the same neighborhood, but he gets all my calls. No wonder: his number is in the book; mine is nonpublished. So when my sources let their fingers do the walking, it's his machine that does the answering. ''I have a great story for you,'' more than one caller has confided, hinting at a stop-the-presses scoop that I could turn into something big at The New York Times, where I've been a reporter for 19 years, ''but I don't dare risk calling your office.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANDY, RUSSELL H., JR.
description: TANDY-Russell H., Jr. Age 79, of Juno Beach, FL, and Westfield, NJ, on March 25, 1998. Prominent member of the insurance and banking communities with Flynn, Harrison & Conroy, Marsh and McLennan, Lloyd's of London, and Bankers Trust Company. Loyal graduate of Columbia University (Delta Psi) and Fordham Law School. Active member of Baltusrol and Echo Lake Country Clubs, the University Club, Jupiter Island Club, Hobe Sound Yacht Club. Longtime vestryman at St. Paul's Church, Westfield, and Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island. Artillery captain in WWII Pacific; President of Westfield SAR. Survived by wife of 56 years, the former Mildred Ficken; brother John; sons Russell III, Spencer, and David; six grandchildren; three great-grandchildren. Service to be held at Christ Memorial Chapel, Sunday, March 29, at 4 PM. Donations may be sent to Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island, FL 33455.

title: Setting the Tone for Togetherness
description: THOSE idyllic family vacations: Mom and Dad enjoy a romantic respite from a life of take-out; the kids hang out with Grandpa, who breaks them in on the quiet joys of fishing and eating those grand old specialties of Grandma, who in the golden years is reverting to her own mother's cooking. Calling Norman Rockwell . . .

title: Dogs Tie Up Drug Traffic At the Tunnels
description: For years, government agents have used dogs to detect drugs in ships, planes and cargo at points of entry like airports and seaports. Now, drug-sniffing dogs are working at points of entry between New Jersey and New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHORR, MARIA GRANDY
description: SCHORR-Maria Grandy. Beloved wife of Seymour; devoted daughter of Frances Grandy; adored mother of Allegra and Richard Fitch, Lydia and Bruce Silverman. Cherished grandmother of Zachary, Julia and Evan. Dear niece of Jeanne Hurst. Services Monday, 10 AM, at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 312 Coney Island Ave. at Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

title: After Clinton's Trek: Fear of a Crushing Embrace?
description: One of the central themes of President Clinton's trip to Africa is partnership, which is widely welcomed here as a break with the paternalism of the past.

title: Tennessee Routs Louisiana Tech for Its Third Consecutive Title
description: It may be time to rename the women's version of March Madness the Tennessee Waltz. Or, for the latest victim of perhaps the most versatile and mercilessly proficient team ever, the March Massacre, as the Tennessee Lady Vols continue to rewrite history without mercy or flaw.

title: Jose Guzman Ends Career
description: Pitcher Jose Guzman has ended his comeback attempt with the Texas Rangers, announcing his retirement yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MANY, JULIUS
description: MANY-Julius. March 30, 1971. Always remembered. The Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOUTRY, DIDIER, DDA
description: BOUTRY-Didier, DDA, 53. Died March 28, 1998, at Cabrini of AIDS. Former private chef to Mrs. Mary Lasker, executive chef Marsh & McLennan companies, painter, raconteur, beloved companion of the late Wolfgang Tippner and dear friend. We will miss you. Patrick Turner and George Slowik Peter and Frankie McGrattan Robert Strahan, Tracy Thomas

title: Two Brothers Indicted In Thefts at Banks
description: Two brothers from Staten Island have been indicted on charges of stealing $3,600 from a bank in New Jersey and trying to steal from two other banks in 1994 and 1995, Federal prosecutors announced on Friday.

title: Accounts
description: * Legoland California, Carlsbad, Calif., to Asher & Partners, Los Angeles, as the first agency to handle advertising for the theme park, scheduled to open in spring 1999. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Corrections
description: A standalone chart last Monday headed ''Keeping Track: The More Things Change . . . ,'' showing population shifts in the New York region as a result of domestic and international migration, omitted a time label. The shifts took place from 1990 to 1997.

title: Equal Work, Less-Equal Perks; Microsoft Leads the Way in Filling Jobs With 'Permatemps'
description: They hold high-prestige, high-technology jobs at Microsoft's plush campus. They often do the same work as the Microsoft Corporation's permanent employees, developing CD-ROM's, designing World Wide Web sites and writing software manuals. Yet they do not qualify for Microsoft's coveted stock options, and their health and vacation benefits are pale imitations of those enjoyed by regular Microsoft workers.

title: Man to Man, Utah Is Pesky
description: Once energetic Utah takes the court against exciting Kentucky on Monday night at the Alamodome, a scene that occurs on playgrounds millions of times a day will also happen in the national championship game: every player will pick up a man on defense. The stakes are much higher here than on the blacktop, obviously, and both teams are much more serious about their defense.

title: As Giants Merge, Small Publishers Prosper
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Refine Methods So Potent, Even the Innocent Have Confessed
description: The victim was a taxi driver, a 45-year-old father of two. The Nassau County police proudly announced the arrest of Robert Moore, who had confessed to being with two acquaintances as they robbed and killed the cabby. Prosecutors said they might seek the death penalty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, MAJOR GENERAL ROBERT
description: SOLOMON - Major General Robert, U.S. Army (ret). The West Point Jewish Chapel Fund mourns the loss of a colleague and ardent longtime supporter. ''General Bob'' was outstanding among many military and civilian leaders who helped make the Jewish Chapel at the United States Military Academy at West Point a reality. We remember him with everlasting gratitude. West Point Jewish Chapel Fund Louis Gross, President

title: Doing It the Hard Way, Leonard Wins Again
description: For Justin Leonard, it was another extraordinary comeback and another extraordinary victory.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: OVERHEARD by Velma Grusd, one of the crowd coming out of a recent performance of ''Rent.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDLOW, ALDEN R., JR.
description: LUDLOW-Alden R., Jr. Of Lawrence, NY on March 26, 1998 at age 86. Husband of the late Mabel Whitman Ludlow. Son of the late Alden Rodney Ludlow and Alician Gamble Ludlow. Brother of the late Alicia Ludlow Cavanagh. He is survived by his sons Alden R. Ludlow, III and Eben W. Ludlow and grandsons Alden R. Ludlow, IV and Sayre H. Ludlow. Mr. Ludlow was a graduate of the Greenvale School, St. Paul's School and Yale University, Phi Beta Kappa, Class of 1934. During World War II he served as a Major in the Army Air Corps in North Africa and Italy and was awarded The Bronze Star. He retired in 1969 as Vice President, Managing Director of U.S. Industrial Chemicals Co. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the American Cancer Society. A memorial service will be held at the Trinity-St. John's Church, Hewlett, LI, NY on Saturday, April 18 at noon.

title: Political Briefing; California Is Trying For Early-Bird Vote
description: Back in the 1996 Presidential election, California sought to increase its political clout as the nation's most delegate-rich state by bumping up its primary date by more than two months, to the last Tuesday in March from the long-accustomed first Tuesday in June. So many states had moved up their primary dates over the years, the thinking went, that the nomination often was already sewn up by the time the Golden State's primary rolled around.

title: ARMS CONTRACTORS SPEND TO PROMOTE AN EXPANDED NATO
description: American arms manufacturers, who stand to gain billions of dollars in sales of weapons, communication systems and other military equipment if the Senate approves NATO expansion, have made enormous investments in lobbyists and campaign contributions to promote their cause in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIPP, GITA
description: RIPP-Gita. It is with great sadness that we note the passing of Gita Ripp (nee Kahan), beloved mother, sister, aunt and grandmother, on Sunday, March 29, 1998. She was a granddaughter of the philanthropist Chaim Kahan. Born in Baku, Russia, in 1909, she lived in Russia, Germany, France and the United States. She devoted her life to others. In lieu of flowers, contributions to DOROT Programs for the Elderly (171 W. 85th St., NYC 10024) in Gita's memory will be warmly appreciated. She is survived by her sister Lily Feiler, her sons Paul and Victor Ripp, her daughters-in-law Eleanor and Nancy, her grandchildren Daniel, Peter, Jonathan, Alexandra and a large family in Israel. Services will be held 10 AM, Tuesday, March 31, 1998, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Though Evans Lost His Coach, He Has Gained a Shot at a Title
description: Manhattan College had been good for Heshimu Evans. His first two basketball seasons there, in 1994-95 and 1995-96, were exciting and productive. But then his basketball world seemed to crash around him: the coach, Fran Fraschilla, was leaving for St. John's and Fraschilla was the primary reason Evans had signed with Manhattan.

title: 'St. Matthew Passion' From a Group Worthy of Its Name
description: Since last encountered, the music program of the Church of the Ascension on lower Fifth Avenue, directed by Dennis Keene, has made a name for itself, literally. Voices of Ascension, it is called in its various recordings for Delos and in concert, as in a performance of Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion'' on Wednesday evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARK, BERNARD S., D.D.S.
description: STARK-Bernard S., D.D.S. Age 80, of New York and Arizona, on March 29. Survived by wife Janessa (Land), daughter Ellen North (David), daughter Laurie (Randy Lang), grandsons Alex and Scott, granddaughter Jessica. Services in Tucson, AZ; memorial in New York at later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREALY, MARY V. SHEA
description: GREALY-Mary V. Shea. Of Bronxville, formerly of Crestwood, NY, on March 28, 1998. Wife of the late Francis P. Grealy. Mother of Francis, Jr., Philip, Neil, William and Margaret. Grandmother of eight. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 24 and 7-9 PM, Monday and Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial Annunciation Church, Crestwood, on Wednesday, April 1, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, NY.

title: No Way Out, At Work Or at Play
description: The Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble is made up of young people from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center, the school of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. So it can be called that troupe's second company. But Sylvia Waters, its director, has made it a first-rate group in its own right. It certainly looked assured in a program of old and recent works on Friday night at Davis Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISMAN, DOOLEY
description: REISMAN-Dooley. Cherished and special friend. Your absence in our lives will be overwhelming because your presence was so great. Carol and Noel Hecht Arlene and Howard Jacobs Dedee and Stephen Lovell

title: Albany's More Open Budgeting
description: Like a third-world country experimenting with self-government, New York State has begun opening its infamously secret budget process to the public. Last Thursday, the Legislature convened its first budget conference committee ever. Before an astonished audience of Albany hands, the lawmakers brazenly discussed how much money to make available for schools, tax cuts and other programs previously put together behind closed doors. It was awkward, self-conscious and more than a little scripted. But it was a big step in the right direction.

title: Pataki and D'Amato Meet Kin of Crown Heights Victim
description: Against a backdrop of new tensions between the Mayor and his predecessor over the 1991 racial disturbances in Crown Heights, Gov. George E. Pataki and United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato met yesterday with the parents and brother of a Hasidic man who was stabbed to death in the unrest.

title: Misreading Sexual Harassment Law
description: In the debate surrounding the investigation of President Clinton, some feminists have painted the rest of us into a corner. Defending the President, they have argued that what he is accused of doing is not sexual harassment. This distorts the law and trivializes women's experiences.

title: On Impeachment Process, House G.O.P. Leaders Consider Timing and Bipartisanship
description: Facing perhaps their most momentous decision since taking control of the House, its Republican leaders are quietly working to insure that if they must consider President Clinton's impeachment, the inquiry does not rebound out of their control and endanger their majority.

title: Oil-Rich Neighbor Eclipsing Armenia
description: Yerablur Cemetery has two identities.

title: Sports of The Times; Holdsclaw and Vols Change Their Game
description: THIS is what Michael Jordan had to say two months ago when he met Chamique Holdsclaw for the first time.

title: Republicans Handle Impeachment Gently
description: Republicans in the House of Representatives are quietly working to insure that if they must consider President Clinton's impeachment, the inquiry does not get out of their control and endanger their majority.

title: A Repeat Vanderbilt Victory Is the First in Over 20 Years
description: The Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship ended on Saturday night with a victory for Richard Schwartz of East Elmhurst, Queens; Mark Lair of Canyon, Tex.; Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash.; Bob Goldman of Highland Village, Tex.; Chip Martel of Davis, Calif., and Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif. Schwartz won the Vanderbilt a year ago with a slightly different team, the first repeat victory in more than 20 years. The Schwartz team will have a very different look next year, for Soloway, Martel and Stansby will be switching their allegiances.

title: Organic Farmers, Unite
description: To the Editor:

title: Flotsam and Jetsam of the California State of Mind
description: On Jan. 24, 1848, James Marshall discovered a gold nugget at Sutter's Fort near Coloma, Calif. His timing was good. The word had yet to spread when, nine days later, the Mexican-American War was settled by the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo. A new border was drawn at the Rio Grande and, in exchange for $18 million the United States received the territory now comprising parts of Wyoming and Colorado, and all of Utah, Nevada, New Mexico and California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISMAN, JULIA ORNSTEIN
description: REISMAN-Julia Ornstein. March 28, 1998, at home. Beautiful wife and loving companion of Sy. Wonderful mother of Nancy, Richard, Jodi and Kenny. Loving daughter of Miriam and Albert. Devoted sister of Steve and the late Robert. Cherished daughter-in-law of Sylvia and Willie. Beloved mother-inlaw of Eric and Steven. Loyal and caring sister-in-law, aunt, friend. Dooley lived her life with compassion, integrity, grace and dignity and gave us all inspiration and strength. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Dooley's memory may be made to the Duke Brain Tumor Research Fund, Duke Medical Center, Durham, NC.

title: Electronic Party Music's Future Is Now
description: The machine-human interface was buzzing and thumping last week in New York City, with a mini-invasion of European bands that mix live and computerized music. Solex, from Amsterdam, was at Windows on the World on Tuesday; the Propellerheads, from Bath, England, were at Irving Plaza on Wednesday, and Junkie XL, also from Amsterdam, was at the Cooler on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERN, HELEN
description: KERN-Helen. Beloved mother and mother-in-law of Rene and Elinor Weidenfeld and Jinette and Rolf David. Also survived by four loving grandchildren and one great-grandson. Funeral services Monday, 11:30 AM, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels (Queens Blvd. & 76th Rd.).

title: Professional Wrestling Cuts Good Guys From the Script
description: Henry Simard grew up watching professional wrestling, and he still loves it. He drove from his home in Billerica, Mass., today to attend Wrestlemania XIV, billed as the championship of the World Wrestling Federation.

title: Updates/Media and Technology; 26 Journalists Were Killed Last Year
description: Despite reduced hostilities in the Balkans and in the former Soviet republics in 1997, the number of journalists killed worldwide because of their work remained unchanged at 26 from the toll the year before, while the number in prison declined sharply, according to the annual report of the Committee to Protect Journalists released last week in Washington.

title: Christians and the Lion Kings; Party of Lincoln?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, ROY EDWARD
description: ANDERSON-Roy Edward. On March 28, 1998. Beloved husband of Mary Chapman. Service and interment private.

title: Bronx Man Is Charged With Murdering Stepson, 8, for Refusing to Do a Chore
description: An 8-year-old boy described as so gentle he would cry at the slightest roughhousing was beaten and strangled in his Bronx apartment on Saturday night, and the police said his stepfather had killed him after he refused to empty a cat's litter box.

title: Media; Newhouse's Legacy Lives In Publisher
description: The house of Random looms over the East River and New York's literary landscape like a skyscraper in hard cover -- the best seller in consumer trade publishing with an estimated $1.2 billion in annual revenues and a corporate collection of more than 60 Pulitzer Prizes and other major awards.

title: Study Criticizes Illinois's Rules For Legislators
description: In the Illinois State Capitol, in Springfield, farmer-legislators write the agriculture laws. Doctor-legislators propose the laws on H.M.O.'s. The beer-distributor-legislator sponsors a law limiting beer sales over the Internet.

title: Lovers Still Bickering, In War And Peace
description: ''Boys, apes, braggarts, jacks, milksops!'' The insults are flung in the heat of rage, but the fellows at whom they're directed, though officers and gentlemen all, deserve every one of these slurs in Cheek by Jowl's probing new production of ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' now at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: This Week's Treasury Auction Is Confined to Regular Bill Sales
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Sports of The Times; In the Realm of Phantom Sport, the Best Punch Tyson Never Threw
description: MIKE TYSON couldn't escape. As the ''Enforcer,'' alias the referee in Wrestlemania XIV, he was minding his own business last night as Shawn Michaels and Stone Cold Steve Austin pulled their punches. Suddenly, a haunting chant erupted that was not in the World Wrestling Federation script.

title: Aggression Meets Ritual In a World Full of Anxiety
description: Ohad Naharin's choreography for the Batsheva Dance Company of Israel is predicated on extremes. Raw and elegant, violent and tender, his dances are sometimes obscure but always powerful.

title: Connecticut Examines Use of Restraint Holds on Psychiatric Patients After Death of Boy, 11
description: Four days into his stay at a psychiatric hospital in Portland, Conn., 11-year-old Andrew McClain, a mildly retarded child in foster care, was brought to a padded ''time-out'' room.

title: A New Radio Network Announces Its Arrival With Casey Kasem's Top 40
description: The smooth-voiced disk jockey Casey Kasem has built a career out of the ''American Top 40,'' a radio program on which he plays the most popular songs on the air each week and dedicates songs requested by listeners. His 28-year-old countdown formula is one of radio's most recognized devices -- copied by others and even parodied in film.

title: For Fairness in Organ Transplants
description: Secretary Donna Shalala of the Department of Health and Human Services wants to give gravely ill patients the same shot at a life-saving liver transplant whether they live in downtown Pittsburgh or rural Mississippi. Survival, she rightly says, should not be an accident of geography. Yet the private organization that coordinates the organ transplant program for the department -- United Network for Organ Sharing -- rejects her sensible idea. Part of its objection flows from a seeming misunderstanding of Ms. Shalala's intention. But UNOS's resistance also reflects its defense of small transplant centers around the country whose autonomy and income would be undermined by the Secretary's plan.

title: If Parents Testify, Bonds Are Broken; Starr Off the Rails
description: To the Editor:

title: Poppies, Fiddlenecks and Fairy Dusters Lure the Admiring Flocks
description: If there is a rainbow amid the driving rains of El Nino, it can be found here in the vivid wildflowers that are not only blooming earlier and longer and in more colors than usual but are also attracting droves of tourists.

title: Port Authority Reports Rise in Volume of Cargo
description: The volume of goods shipped by sea through ports controlled by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey rose 4.5 percent in 1997, the agency has reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEGLEY, EVELYN M.
description: BEGLEY-Evelyn M. Of Venice, FL, formerly of Ft. Salonga, NY. Native of Cloone, County Leitrim, Ireland. Beloved wife of John. Devoted mother of John, Dermot M., Deidre M., Neil P. and Oona E. Grandmother of six. Sister of Mona Walters, Rita Williams, Noreen Charles and Paul Cooney. Reposing Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, Northport, LI, 7-9 PM Monday and 2-5 and 7-9 PM Tuesday. Mass Wednesday 11 AM St. Philip Neri Church, Northport. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Donations to American Cancer Society in her memory appreciated.

title: Christians and the Lion Kings
description: To the Editor:

title: The Plot to Bury Reform
description: Newt Gingrich has selected today as the moment to line up his firing squad and kill campaign finance reform in Congress this year. Yet the House Speaker may be surprised. Republicans and Democrats who favor reform are so outraged over Mr. Gingrich's broken promises and heavy-handed tactics that they could seize the moment and force him to back down. Whether the reformers succeed depends on their ability to hold together and find ways to get genuine reform to the floor, where a majority of members appear ready to vote for it.

title: U.S. to Improve Satellite Navigation System
description: The Government plans to upgrade the Global Positioning System in the next few years to make hand-held navigation instruments up to 10 times more accurate, a White House official said this weekend.

title: Lady Vols Win 3d Straight Title
description: The Tennessee Lady Vols finished a perfect season last night, becoming the first team to win three straight National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championships with a 93-75 defeat of Louisiana Tech in Kansas City, Mo. It is the sixth championship over all for the Lady Vols and Coach Pat Summitt.

title: Taipei Journal; The Mayor Won't Abide Licensed Licentiousness
description: Six hard ladder-back chairs sat empty against the custard yellow wall, next to a curtain of red velveteen that hung more like a shroud than an invitation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THEURER, JOHN J. (JACK)
description: THEURER-John J. (Jack). Of Jericho, LI. Suddenly on March 28, 1998. Age 64. Beloved husband of the late Barbara. Loving father of Eve R. Finger (Carl) and Michael S. Visiting Dodge-Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, Monday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass St. Paul the Apostle R.C. Church, Brookville, NY, Tuesday, 9:45 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. Donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The bottom line is Americans as a general rule think that when they elect a President, he's elected for four years.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBMAN, GERTRUDE
description: GRUBMAN - Gertrude. Beloved wife of the late Sam Krauss and the late Sidney Grubman. Devoted mother of Gloria and Norman Samuels, and the late Elaine Topper. Loving grandmother and greatgrandmother of Stephen and Emily, Jonathan and Margaret, David, Steven, Mia, and Anna. Services Tuesday, 12:30 PM, ''BoulevardRiverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACHMUTH, JOSEPH
description: RACHMUTH-Joseph. Brooklyn. Died March 21, 1998. Respected educator, advocate animal support groups. Survivors: sister, Jean (Jack); nephews Howard, Allen, Randy (Tamar) their baby, Miriam; and dear cat, Boy.

title: Small Satellite Phones: An Expensive Gamble
description: Alex Lesser, a former New York lawyer whose practice now has him based in the expanses of this resource-rich and entrepreneur-filled Central Asia nation, has some choices if he wants to phone his uranium mining clients in London, Toronto or Perth, Australia.

title: Sports of The Times; One More Game And Thrills Of a Lifetime
description: UTAH Coach Rick Majerus was into his funny-man routine yesterday, telling one-liner after one-liner. Informed that Coach Smith said he wished he were as funny as Majerus, he paused quizzically and asked, ''You mean Coach Dean Smith?''

title: Updates/Media and Technology; British Cable Operator In Talks to Acquire Rival
description: Telewest Communications P.L.C., Britain's second-largest cable television company, said it is in talks that might lead to a takeover bid worth $1.12 billion for a rival, General Cable P.L.C.

title: Abroad at Home; Punishing the Past
description: In 1967 the apartheid Government of South Africa passed a Terrorism Act that defined hostile words as ''terrorism.'' An ingenious provision said the act should be deemed to have come into effect in 1962, so that things said and done in the previous five years were retroactively made criminal. And people were prosecuted for past acts.

title: Dean E. McHenry, Dies at 87; Developed U.C. Santa Cruz
description: Dean E. McHenry, an academic pioneer who turned his vision of a campus with a redwoods vista, a Pacific view and a no-fault grading system into a counterculture magnet and an educational gem, died on March 17 at a hospital in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 87 and the founding chancellor of the University of California at Santa Cruz.

title: El Nino Finally Meets Its Meteorological Match: El Spring
description: El Nino has led the United States on a not-always-merry weather chase this year. But scientists say that the peak of its influence has passed and that its effects on North America are being progressively weakened by an even more powerful climatic force, the seasonal change known as spring.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Friday, about the acquisition of Arnold Communications by Snyder Communications, misspelled the name of a company that had previously expressed interest in Arnold. It is Cyrk Inc., not Cryk.

title: Political Briefing; Las Vegas Isn't Game To Pull Plug on Slots
description: Not counting those in casinos and bars, there are something like 2,500 slot machines scattered around Las Vegas, Nev., 25 percent more than there were four years ago. The whizzing, whirring, flashing, now-and-again jingling contraptions can be found in coin laundries, convenience stores, doughnut shops, even car washes.

title: A Lead but No Time for Cayard
description: Paul Cayard, the captain of the Whitbread Round the World race leader EF Language, had been on land for only about 30 minutes today after 15 days at sea, but he clearly was antsy.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of the Arts section on Thursday about a concert given in Budapest to honor the memory of the conductor Georg Solti reversed the attributions of two compositions. ''Psalmus Hungaricus'' is by Kodaly, and Serenade by Leo Weiner.

title: Debate Erupts Over Whether Clinton Legally Withheld Letters
description: Accusations that President Clinton failed to provide lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones with correspondence from Kathleen E. Willey set off partisan sparring today between Republican and Democratic lawmakers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Diageo to Sell Dewar's To Bacardi for $1.94 Billion

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORCINO, NORMA FRANKS
description: FORCINO-Norma Franks. Age 59, died peacefully at home on March 27, 1998, with her loving family at her side after a courageous struggle with ovarian cancer. Throughout, she maintined her humor, wit and dignity, and gave us all inspiration and strength. She was a compassionate nurse who received her RN from NY Medical College's Flower and Fifth Avenue School of Nursing, and her masters in nursing from Marymount Manhattan College. She will be dearly remembered by all those she touched at both NYU's Skin and Cancer Center, and her father and brother's private practice where she worked until shortly before her death. She was adored by her two children Frank Forcino of NYC and Lydia Plachy of Montana, and their spouses Grace and Milan, three loving grandchildren Michael, Milan and Lydia. She is also survived by her beloved mother and father Dr. and Mrs. Andrew G. Franks, Sr., her cherished sister Joy Catapano, her devoted brother and sister-in-law, Drs. Andrew and Linda Franks, Jr. and her many nieces and nephews, all of NYC. Friends are invited to a prayer service on Monday, March 30, between 10 AM and 10:30 AM, at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. (20th St.), NYC, followed by Mass at R.C. Church of the Epiphany, 22nd St. and 2nd Ave., at 11 AM. Interment services will be private.

title: Fight Vowed on Bid to Lift Cap on Pay Phone Calls
description: Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco vowed yesterday to fight the Bell Atlantic Corporation's attempts to be allowed to raise the price of a pay phone call in the state.

title: Corrections
description: A corporate symbol with the International Briefs column of in Business Day on Tuesday, with a report about a merger of units of the Mitsubishi Corporation and the Mitsubishi Oil Company, was published in error. It was the logo of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd., which has no operating relationship with the Mitsubishi Corporation or the Mitsubishi Oil Company.

title: MetroStars Regroup After Loss on Road
description: The faces told the story after the MetroStars opened their season Saturday night by giving up two late goals to lose by 3-2 to the Los Angeles Galaxy at the Rose Bowl.

title: Corrections
