description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Jerzy Kluger, a childhood friend of Pope John Paul II who later served as his informal intermediary with Israel, referred incorrectly in some copies to the Nazi camp where Mr. Kluger's grandmother died. It was Belzec; his sister and his mother died at Auschwitz.

title: A Market for Organs
description: To the Editor:

title: Watt and Arabian Headed to Finland
description: Sarah Watt of Schomberg, Ontario, and her mount, Arabian, earned a trip to the World Cup final in Helsinki, Finland, next month and a starting spot in next Saturday's Budweiser American Invitational Grand Prix by winning the $50,000 Grand Prix of Florida yesterday afternoon in Tampa. The pair was charged with four faults in 37.62 seconds.

title: Torre's Big Plan Is to 'Stay Out Of the Way'
description: The Yankees look extraordinary, and at one point this spring, George Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner, asked Joe Torre whether an American League manager has ever gone undefeated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUDE, LILLIAN
description: BRAUDE-Lillian. The President, Board of Trustees and staff of Guild Hall mourn the loss of Lillian Braude, devoted wife of distinguished poet/publisher Michael Braude. Lillian Braude was a distinguished longtime Trustee, patron and devoted Museum Committee and Hays Poetry Committee member who fostered this cultural center's commitment to literature and education. Her pathbreaking Poets and Artists Exhibition held at Guild Hall Museum was a landmark in the development of Guild Hall's interdisciplinary approach to the arts. Her warmth, vision, intellect and commitment are irreplaceable. We extend our deepest sympathy to her daughter Judy Kay and her grandchildren Adam and Rachel. Henry Korn, President Melville Straus, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, REGINA
description: COLLINS-Regina. On March 29, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence M. Strauss and the late Albert Collins. Loving mother of Lawrence Strauss and Marjorie Power; adoring grandmother of Lawrence C., Michael and Jeremy Strauss and Erik Power. Dear sister of Julian Rothbaum. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers an act of kindness in her memory, or contributions to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Touring Iraq's Presidential Sites
description: New arrangements for inspecting Iraq's presidential sites are working relatively well. There have been only minor disputes over ground rules between United Nations inspectors and Iraqi officials. But these preliminary visits, which Iraq has had plenty of time to prepare for, are not the real test of the agreement negotiated last month by United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan. That will come when U.N. investigators return later for surprise follow-up inspections, looking for evidence of prohibited weapons or sensitive documents describing Iraq's germ and chemical warfare programs.

title: Just Another Sports Scandal
description: There is a nasty kind of justice in the fact that a scandal is rocking college sports just as the N.C.A.A.'s biggest money-making venture, the men's basketball tournament, reaches a climax. Prosecutors have indicted two former members of the Northwestern University basketball team and charged them with having taken bribes from gamblers to fix the outcomes of games during the 1994-95 season.

title: Nets May Have Some Hope, But Need Seikaly's Help
description: The Nets held a clinic after practice at Continental Arena today, giving children of their sponsors an opportunity to get on the floor with the players. But the children missed out on Jayson Williams, who was home with the fractured right thumb he sustained Friday night.

title: Metropolitan Life Will Name A New Chief Executive Today
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company will announce today that it has named Robert H. Benmosche as chairman and chief executive of the company, succeeding Harry P. Kamen, who is retiring after serving as Met Life's chief executive since the spring of 1993.

title: Van Horn, Not Looking Back, Will Root for Utes From Afar
description: Nets Coach John Calipari offered to provide a private plane for Keith Van Horn to fly to San Antonio to see his former Utah teammates play for the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship, then get him back for Tuesday night's game with Atlanta.

title: Mets' Trade Opens Spot For Yoshii
description: All Juan Acevedo wanted this spring was a chance to pitch in somebody's rotation. All Masato Yoshii could think about was winning the Mets' fifth-starter slot. All General Manager Steve Phillips had to do, then, was find someone who wanted to make a deal for Acevedo to open up room for Yoshii.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, GARETTA
description: LYONS-Garetta. Of Smithtown, NY, died Friday, March 27, at the age of 93. Widow of Leverett Lyons, mother of the late Ann Litz, grandmother of Leverett Litz and sister of Richard B. Smith, Edward H. L. Smith, W. Wickham Smith and DuBois T. Smith. The family will be at home at Judges Lane, Smithtown, from 3-5 PM, and 7-9 PM, on both Sunday, March 29, and Monday, March 30. Funeral service will be held Wednesday, April 1, at 1 PM, at the Smithtown Presbyterian Church. The interment will follow at the St. James Espiscopal Church Cemetery, St. James, NY.

title: Aides Say Pataki Is Unhappy With CUNY Leader He Chose
description: Thirteen tumultuous months after Gov. George E. Pataki picked a little-known English professor with powerful political connections as chairwoman of the City University of New York's board of trustees, he has already soured on her, aides to the Governor say.

title: Though Lewis Won, the Heavyweight Division Did Not
description: There were a lot of interested parties at ringside for the Lennox Lewis-Shannon Briggs heavyweight championship fight at the Atlantic City Convention Center on Saturday night. Unfortunately, what they saw was not very interesting and painted an even bleaker picture of the future of the heavyweight division.

title: No Ultimatum for Israel, Albright Assures U.S. Jewish Groups
description: As a White House envoy announced today that he would return from the Middle East to brief President Clinton on the reaction to new peace proposals, leaders of American Jewish groups said they were assured by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright that the United States would not present Israel with an ultimatum for a withdrawal from the West Bank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, EVA
description: STRAUSS-Eva. Born Stuttgart, Germany, 1905, died March 28. Daughter of Adolph and Martha Kops. Devoted and beloved wife of the late Julius Strauss. Mother of the late Rosemary Strauss. Lovingly remembered by her children Peter and Laura, and her grandchildren Carolyn Strauss, Mimi Friedman, Diana Strauss, and Michael Norwood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, BERNARD N.
description: KLEIN-Bernard N. On March 28, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Tedra. Loving father of Jonathan and Barbara. Cherished grandfather of Deborah, Melissa, David, Benjamin, Avram and greatgrandfather of Zachary and Rebecca. Dear brother of Edward. Graveside services Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at Riverside Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POCHODA, PEARL
description: POCHODA-Pearl. Died March 26, 1998. Beloved wife of Samuel. Mother of Philip, Daniel and Ralph. Grandmother of Ivy. Adored friend of many. Funeral service will be Wednesday, April 1 at Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Funeral Chapel, Manalapan, N.J.

title: If Parents Testify, Bonds Are Broken
description: To the Editor:

title: Segue From Comic to Tragic
description: Dan Froot simply played his saxophone in the opening number of ''Froot Alone,'' presented on Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop. Mr. Froot did embellish the number, ''Loop,'' with vocal high jinks. But that was no preparation for what was to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAEL, KENNETH S.
description: MICHAEL-Kenneth S. Age 72. Husband of Jenny; father of Naomi and Aaron Mandelbaum, Jacob and Rochel Leah Michael, Daniel and Miriam Michael, Sheera and Michael Moffson. Adored ''Opa'' of Yossi, Esti, Avi Mandelbaum; Sori, Dina, Shoshana, Moshe, Simcha, Yehuda Leib, Aaron, Yisroel Meir, Chana Michael; Ari, Joshua, Michal Michael; Racquel, Daniella, Alexander Moffson. Passed away peacefully at home with his loving family. Funeral services were held at Ohav-Zedek Synagogue. Shiva will be observed at his home in New York.

title: Political Notes; Her Victory Was Expected, But Not the Slim Margin
description: The Democratic candidate's victory in last week's special election for a vacant Assembly seat representing southeast Queens was widely expected. But what was unexpected to many was how thin the margin of victory was for Pauline R. Cummings, who ran in her first political campaign.

title: INSIDE
description: 'Permatemps' Proliferate

title: Painful Detours on the Road Paved With Good Intentions
description: Bob and Liz actually did what other good hippies only talked about in the early 70's. They moved to a farm, without electricity, a telephone, a car or, God forbid, a television, and began living off the land in complete simplicity. Eleven years later, they're so successful at this that an enthusiastic young author is including them in her first book and photographing Bob admiring his home-grown beans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKIN, DAVID B.
description: ELKIN-David B. Beloved husband to Margot Turitz Elkin, loving father of Charlotte and Sam Elkin, cherished brother of Ethel Elkin and devoted son-in-law to Zitha Turitz. David was an economist, former Vice President of W. R. Grace and Co, adjunct professor, and economic consultant. He grew up in the Bronx, later lived in Manhattan, and settled in White Plains. His intelligence, vast knowledge, political conscience, wry humor and sensitivity will be deeply missed. Memorial service to be held Tuesday. Contributions to Fund for Parkinson's Research, University of Medicine and Dentistry of NJ, New Brunswick, NJ 08903.

title: In Battle of Two Best, Devils Finish Second Best
description: This was not how a preview of a possible Stanley Cup final series was supposed to play out. The Devils and the Dallas Stars were supposed to play a muscular chess game. They have the best records in the National Hockey League, great defenses and great goalies.

title: On-line sellers learn how to get packages from cyberspace to consumers.
description: Speak the words ''electronic commerce'' and in most circles, the starry-eyed vision that comes to mind is of a sophisticated new computer system for selling goods to millions of on-line consumers without the costly overhead of a storefront. Win-win, retail revolution, etc.

title: U.S. Facing Lightning Technology Shifts in Microsoft Case
description: In its pursuit of the Microsoft Corporation, the Justice Department is breathing hard -- just to keep up, let alone catch the company red-handed with the kind of evidence it needs to bring a broader antitrust case.

title: A Family's Tales of China As a Path to Theater Fame; A Troupe Honors a Playwright and His Parents
description: It was a great event in the life of a small theater company, a first night in a brand-new space. It was a great night for a playwright whose newest play is about to open a continent away. And it was a great night for the playwright's family, particularly his immigrant parents, who saw their legacy engraved in stone. Indeed, more than anything, this is a family story.

title: U.S. Need Not Fear a World Criminal Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Fortunes Improve for Upstate Cities That Symbolized Decline
description: For years, there was no greater cliche of urban decline than this old industrial city on the Hudson River. Often described as the most financially distressed city in the country, it earned municipal notoriety five years ago when its officials used a maneuver that amounted to a mortgage on City Hall to try to close a deficit.

title: Christians and the Lion Kings; Thankful Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, EDYTHE
description: GREEN-Edythe. On March 28, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Loving mother of Lynn and Alan. Dear sister of Florence, Charlotte and Debby. Adoring grandmother of Adam and Anthony-James. Family will receive Monday, 7-9 PM. Service Tuesday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to the Sussman Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center, 16th St. and 1st Avenue, NYC 10003.

title: As Giants Merge, Small Publishers Prosper
description: To the Editor:

title: Kicking and Screaming, Baby Boomers Begin to Talk About Aging
description: It was a workshop to get baby boomers to talk about what was billed as ''the A word'' -- aging.

title: A Market for Organs
description: To the Editor:

title: Winners and Losers in Acquisition of Dow Jones Markets
description: For Bridge Information Systems, the laggard in the hotly competitive business of providing Wall Street with desktop financial data, this month's $510 million purchase of Dow Jones Markets was critical.

title: An Improvisation Impresses Even the One Who Sang It
description: The singer Brian McKnight finished a long, unaccompanied vocal line, working a word over with melismas and sudden jumps into the falsetto range, and then turned to his band and said, ''Wow.''

title: Volkswagen in Spain Names Bates to Account
description: SEAT, the Spanish operation of Volkswagen A. G., has named Bates Worldwide to handle European advertising, with billings estimated at more than $150 million. Those duties had been divided between Casadevall Pedreno & PRG in Barcelona, which handled the account in Spain, and Wilkens International, part of True North Communications, which handled the account elsewhere in Europe.

title: Perfect Road to Derby For Event of the Year
description: Event of the Year stretched his winning streak to four yesterday when he won the $600,000 Jim Beam Stakes at Turfway Park by five lengths. He heads for the Kentucky Derby with a perfect record, just as his sire, Seattle Slew, did 21 years ago.

title: James L. Hymes Jr., 84, Author And Specialist on Child-Rearing
description: James Lee Hymes Jr., a national authority on early education who taught generations of parents and teachers how to raise and teach preschoolers and first graders, died on March 6 at El Camino Hospital in Cupertino, Calif. He was 84 and lived in the Cupertino retirement community of the Forum at Rancho San Antonio.

title: Moynihan Backs Vallone In Primary for Governor
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the elder statesman of New York Democrats, will endorse the New York City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, for governor on Monday, giving Mr. Vallone the imprimatur of someone who is popular in all regions of the state and with voters of all parties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOWITZ, WILLIAM
description: LEBOWITZ-William. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, and its Men's Club mourn the passing of their senior member and former vice president of the Congregation and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Reporter's Notebook; Africa Presents Clinton With a Raft of Distractions
description: President Clinton seemed to have every reason to fear that his embarrassing troubles back home -- ''the current situation,'' as some White House officials delicately refer to it -- would trail him to Africa, during the 12-day trip that brought him here today for two days of relaxing among the big game of the Kalahari Desert.

title: Khmer Rouge Factions Battle Each Other in the Jungle
description: The remnants of Cambodia's Communist Khmer Rouge movement have turned their guns on each other and the jungle stronghold that has withstood repeated Government offensives is now torn by factional fighting.

title: The da Vinci of Data
description: It is well past noon and the 286 Manhattan office workers have been kept in their chairs all morning with another four hours to go. Still, they're hooting in guilty laughter as they stare at the confident emcee, who is striding around in front of a large pair of screens.

title: Knicks Hope to Shake Off Seattle Blowout
description: The Knicks seemed to accept their debacle in Seattle as if it were nothing more than a stain on a couch cushion. Flip it over and it disappears.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VINING, DONALD
description: VINING-Donald. Age 80. On January 24, 1998. Author of'' A Gay Diary'' and other works. Predeceased by life partner of fortythree years Richmond Purinton. Service at the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center, 208 West 13 St, NYC, Sunday, April 5th, 2 PM. Donations may be made to the Center or the Lincoln Center Performing Arts Library.

title: Surprise! B.C., Not B.U., Advances to Final Four
description: One Boston team survived and the other did not yesterday at the East Regional event of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's hockey tournament in Albany.

title: Report Mandela Calls Hoax Links Ex-Guerrilla to Coup Plot
description: The mystery surrounding the arrest of a former anti-apartheid guerrilla who is a Government official deepened today. President Nelson Mandela said he had received a report linking the former guerrilla, several army generals and the President's former wife, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, to a plot to overthrow the Government.

title: A New Debate on the Fate (And State) of Puerto Rico
description: On a stone set on a pedestal in Guanica, a small town in southwestern Puerto Rico, a plaque commemorates ''the landing of the American troops under Gen. Nelson A. Miles on Guanica Beach, July 25, 1898.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, STEVEN
description: SCHULMAN-Steven. After a heroic battle, Steven is finally at peace. He'll always shine down on us all with his inspiration, warmth and wit. Our hearts go out to his wonderful family. Nancy and Allen Susan and Clive Ellen and John

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Political Briefing; In Washington State, Death Be Not Death
description: Washington State builders felt that State Senator James West wasn't supportive enough of their causes, especially given that he is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. So the other day the Building Industry Association ran an ad in The Seattle Times that was sharply critical of the powerful Spokane Republican's stands on industry bills, some of which went down to defeat.

title: Mattiace's Bid Unravels at 17th Hole
description: It would have been a touching story if Len Mattiace had won the Players Championship.

title: Christians and the Lion Kings; Victory on Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Williams Rages, Quietly, Amid Contract Impasse
description: Bernie Williams usually faces his locker as he plays his guitar in the Yankees' clubhouse, staring forward, everything and everyone left behind him.

title: A Stoplight Vigil: When Prayers Halt Traffic
description: Joel Valdez, a 5-foot-8 altar boy hoisting an 8-foot crucifix, led the congregation as the double front doors of St. Barbara's Roman Catholic Church burst open just after noon yesterday. All 900 parishioners rushed into Central Avenue in Bushwick, Brooklyn, as if they were late for a fire drill. Or a good game on television.

title: Diageo May Sell Dewar's To Bacardi for $1.9 Billion
description: Seeking to become a bigger and more diversified player in the intensely competitive liquor business, the Bacardi Corporation plans to buy Dewar's Scotch, now owned by Diageo P.L.C., a person close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: For $19.95, Slate Sees Who Its Friends Are
description: It is a clear, shining day in Washington, a world away from the Seattle rain. The budding cherry blossoms hint at spring. And Michael Kinsley, the editor and creator of Microsoft's on-line magazine Slate, is pacing the bare parquet floors of a one-bedroom apartment, considering whether to rent it.

title: Sony Plans To License Sun's Java
description: The Sony Corporation, the consumer electronics giant, said Friday that it planned to license a version of Sun Microsystems Inc.'s Java programming language to be used to develop interactive applications for digital set-top television boxes.

title: Stock Offerings Expected This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Far-Right Furor Has French Conservatives Crumbling
description: Three years ago, when Jacques Chirac was elected President on a promise to bring ''profound change'' to dispirited, unemployment-plagued France, the mainstream parties of his conservative coalition looked likely to govern the country well into the next century.

title: Corrections
description: Three small charts last Monday with an article about the debate over renaming a thoroughfare in Bellerose, Queens, referred incorrectly to the racial breakdown of three communities in census figures. Hispanic residents are counted in the census as an ethnic group, not a race, and were already included in the charts' white, black and Asian categories. The charts mistakenly added a Hispanic category, resulting in percentages that totaled well over 100 for each community.

title: Eight Young Protesters Who Changed the South
description: THE CHILDREN

title: Patents; It's spring, and some inventions are aimed at helping baseball players improve their form.
description: ASPIRING baseball players have a lot to remember in addition to keeping their eyes on the ball. This season brings a number of new inventions whose purpose is to help players practice their form with Pavlovian precision.

title: Essay; Here Comes 'Paycheck Protection'
description: The Supreme Court decided the issue a decade ago: union members have the right to claim refunds of portions of their dues not spent on collective bargaining. If your union leader wants to contribute to a bill legalizing marijuana, and you're against pot smoking, you can get back from the union that part of your dues that went to support what you oppose.

title: Rios Dismantles Agassi and Seizes No. 1 Ranking
description: Marcelo Rios, the terminally crafty left-hander who may be the most gifted grouch to manhandle a racquet since John McEnroe ranted and raved his way to the top, leapfrogged to the No. 1 ranking in the world this afternoon with a slick, smart, straight-set demolition of Andre Agassi in the final of the Lipton Championships.

title: Har Homa Is Settlement
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRECHER, SYLVIA
description: BRECHER-Sylvia. Your astounding spirit and strength amaze me. Always upbeat when we spoke, you listened, you advised and, more important, you cared. You will be missed. Your nephew Hank

title: Rameau Without the Spectacle
description: Any opportunity to hear Rameau's stage music will draw the kind of big crowd that showed up at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday night. Promised was a rare sighting of the opera ''Zoroastre,'' the attraction fattened by promises of period-instrument style as practiced by William Christie and Les Arts Florissants from France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORWIN, JOAN
description: CORWIN-Joan. Prayers go out to our sister-in-law, aunt, and friend, Corey Corwin Shafran and her family on the death of their mother, Joan. Eve, Billie, Annah, Andrew, Sammy, Molly, Joshua, Jenny and Kirsten

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEK, JOSEPH
description: SOBEK-Joseph. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of Joe Sobek, for many years the tennis pro at Fairview. On behalf of all Fairview members, we wish to express our deepest condolences to his wife Nancy and family. Andrew J. Frankel, President Judith Weil, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORCZYNER, HARRY
description: TORCZYNER - Harry. Distin guished friend, advisor and counselor for Annals of Scholarship, an international journal on Art Practices and the Human Sciences in a Global Culture. Heartfelt sympathy to his family. Marie-Rose Logan, Editor and the Editorial Board

title: Miller Tells His Orioles: Think Small on Offense
description: Ray Miller introduced himself as the Baltimore Orioles' new manager by warning his players that he might be detrimental to their hitting statistics. Miller wasn't new to the team -- he was pitching coach last year -- but he was the new manager, replacing Davey Johnson, an established winner.

title: As Giants Merge, Small Publishers Prosper
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONS, JAMES D.
description: SIMONS-James D. On March 27, 1998 after a long illness. Beloved son of Anna Lee Berini. Loving father of Janet and Joyce. Adoring grandfather of Scott. Dear brother of John. Writer and historian. Family will receive Sunday 7-9 PM. Service Monday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory to the American Revolution Round Table, 14 Beverly Rd., Port Washington, NY 10150 or the American Cancer Society.

title: If Parents Testify, Bonds Are Broken; Privilege Claim
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; 'Waltons' Star Sells Himself on 2 Coasts
description: Ralph Waite is on the road more than Willy Loman -- because Ralph Waite is Willy Loman.

title: Lake's Fleeting Greatness Graces a Faded City; Wave of Welcome Publicity for Plattsgurgh
description: As the ferry made its way from Vermont to New York, across the choppy waters of Lake Champlain, Kirk Polhemus, a deckhand, issued a judgment heard over and over these days in the North Country. ''It may not be a great lake,'' he said, ''but it's the best lake.''

title: People
description: * Jean Robaire, creative director, and Sally Hogshead, copywriter, at Martin Creative Los Angeles, which was closed by the Martin Agency unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., opened Robaire & Hogshead, Los Angeles, where each is a creative partner.

title: Glickman, Shut Out of 1936 Games, Is Honored at Last
description: The United States Olympic Committee presented the broadcaster and former sprinter Marty Glickman with a plaque today in lieu of the gold medal it prevented him from competing for 62 years ago.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Law Firms Are Turning to Technology to Manage Information Explosion
description: In the not-so-distant past, case-book-laden lawyers crowded law firm libraries, a secretary sat stationed outside nearly every office door and messengers frequented the corridors.

title: Beverley Cross, 66, Playwright and Librettist
description: Beverley Cross, the playwright, librettist and writer who devoted himself in equal measure to his own career and to that of the great love of his life, Dame Maggie Smith, died here on March 20. He was 66.

title: Money replaces lush images of the good life with a pointed pitch: 'You need this magazine.'
description: MONEY, the longtime leader in the competitive category of personal finance publications, is replacing smooth, glossy sales spiels centered on lush images of the good life with pitches that are as pointed as, well, the rivalry in the category.

title: Metro Matters; Of Rudeness And Courtesy, Yada, Yada
description: ''I think that's recommendation 9B. So that's a good change. We can change it from 'affairs' to 'relations.' ''

title: A Silent Witness in Cigarette Trials
description: Behind the walls of a handsome brownstone in this city's historic heart lives a man whose career has tracked the fortunes of the cigarette business and its dark contradictions.

title: A Visitor Is Dazzled By His Own Stardom
description: Alan Cumming is an alien of extraordinary ability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LOUIS
description: GROSS-Louis. Age 59, of Arlington, MA, on March 26, after a seven year fight against lymphoma and melanoma. Beloved husband of Patricia Hollander Gross. Loving brother of Lillian Ratner of Great Neck, LI, NY, and Jacob Gross of NYC. He was a graduate of the University of Chicago and had worked as a computer programmer for MITRE, Lincoln Laboratry, Intermetrics, Prime and Digitial Equipment Corp., and was active in the Arlington Civil Rights Committee, the New Jewish Agenda, Temple Emanuel and Havurat Shalom Community. Services at Temple Emanuel, 101 West Forest St., Lowell, MA, on Tuesday, March 31, at 10 AM. Following burial in Arlington, the family will return to Havurat Shalom Community, 113 College Ave., Somerville, MA, until 5 PM. Memorial donations may be made to Temple Emanuel or Havurat Shalom or to New Jewish Agenda, PO Box 390787, Cambridge, MA 02139.

title: Carat North America Has Acquired Freeman
description: Carat North America, the media services agency owned by Aegis Group P.L.C., has acquired Freeman Associates in Newton, Mass., which specializes in media planning and buying for high-technology companies. Terms were not disclosed.

title: HEALTH INSURANCE IS G.O.P. INITIATIVE FOR ELECTION YEAR
description: House Republican leaders are drafting an election-year bill that would create new tax breaks to help people who receive no health benefits from their employers in buying health insurance.

title: A Final Chapter in '91 Crown Hts. Killing
description: More than a year after he was convicted of civil rights violations in the stabbing death of a Hasidic scholar during the 1991 violence in Crown Heights, Lemrick Nelson Jr. is to be sentenced today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: African Spirits on the Streets of Havana
description: If respect were truly doled out for musical complexity, then Los Munequitos de Matanzas, a percussion, vocal and dance group from Cuba, would be mightier than it already is. The group, which played three sold-out concerts over the weekend, first at Hostos Community College in the Bronx on Thursday night then two more concerts at Symphony Space in Manhattan on Friday and Saturday, uses a few percussionists and a handful of singers to make music that is as complex as any in the popular arena.

title: Powerful New Encryption Standard Delayed by a Weakness
description: A Government standards group has delayed the adoption of a new data scrambling standard for protecting the world's most sensitive financial transactions, including most banks' electronic funds transfers, after the discovery by two computer scientists of a weakness that could allow the code to be cracked.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINER, MICHAEL
description: WEINER-Michael. March 31, 1995. Three years without you Feeling your presence and Sustained by memories. Betsy, Conna, and Tracy

title: Rabosky to Join Ammirati Puris
description: Steve Rabosky, a well-known creative director, will join Ammirati Puris Lintas in the new position of executive vice president and creative director for worldwide brands.

title: Exiled Leader's Return to Test Cambodian Democracy
description: Cambodia's battered democracy began its severest test today as Norodom Ranariddh returned from exile to run for re-election as Prime Minister against the man who ousted him in a coup nine months ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN OSS, ANNE ELISE (NEE BURNETT)
description: van OSS-Anne Elise (nee Burnett). Formerly of Lawrenceville, New Jersey. Died March 26, 1998 in Newtown, PA. of emphysema. She is survived by her husband of fifty years, Hendrik van Oss, her three children Alex, Hendrik Gilbert and Elise and by her brother Gilbert Burnett. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to charity. A memorial gathering will take place at Pennswood Village, Newtown, PA., on April 18, 1998 at 2:30 P.M.

title: Flawed Organ Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  URDANG, LENORE
description: URDANG-Lenore. The Board of Governors and Members of Bocaire Country Club, record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Mon., March 30, 1998. She will be missed. Services will be held Wednesday, April 1, 1:30 P.M., at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, 7240 N. Federal Highway, Boca Raton, Florida. Melvin Michaelson, President

title: A Sober Test for the House
description: An intense legislative battle culminates this week in the House over sensible legislation to establish a national standard for drunken driving. Medical and traffic safety experts agree that at a blood alcohol level of .08 percent, a driver's ability to steer, brake and make critical judgments is significantly impaired. The measure, which recently cleared the Senate, would require the 35 states that still set a .10 threshold for drunken driving to adopt a stricter .08 standard within three years or lose some of their highway construction aid.

title: Science Watch; The Fantastic Voyager
description: Going where no spacecraft has gone before, Voyager 1 recently broke the distance record held by Pioneer 10. And now, nearly 21 years after its launching, it is hurtling outward at 39,000 miles an hour.

title: Sports of The Times; King and His Courts: Promoter Pleads Case
description: IN proclaiming Evander Holyfield's heavyweight title defense against Henry Akinwande at Madison Square Garden on June 6, Don King shouted the significance of the date.

title: A Competent CBS Needed McGuire
description: Throughout Jim Nantz's and Billy Packer's call of Kentucky's 78-69 victory over Utah last night, the only thing missing was Al McGuire. Nantz and Packer did their jobs more than adequately: Nantz set the table for Packer, who adroitly analyzed the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game as if he were the 11th player on the floor.

title: Japan, to Revitalize Economy, Prepares to Reshape Its Markets
description: In one of its most ambitious undertakings, the Japanese Government plans this week to set in motion a far-reaching program that it hopes will infuse the country's financial landscape with the prowess of its manufacturing industries.

title: New Means To Make Men Feel Younger
description: After spending much of their research budgets focusing on cures for fatal and chronic illnesses, pharmaceutical companies now see a vast opportunity in offering new drugs aimed at easing the various ailments and complaints of aging baby boomers, while often making them feel young again.

title: Ex-F.C.C. Chief to Face the Bells Yet Again
description: When Reed E. Hundt was chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, he had a reputation as a tenacious foe of the local Bell companies.

title: Ramos Is Eager To Return
description: Tab Ramos looks fit and trim. His appearance, however, belies what he must be feeling.

title: Once Seen As a Political Beacon, Senegal Backslides
description: When Leopold Sedar Senghor, the poet who was this country's first President, voluntarily resigned from politics in 1980 after more than 20 years in office, the gesture shocked this region. His peers were still reeling from his gradual introduction of multiparty politics, starting in 1976, which broke with a near-uniform pattern of one-party rule in West Africa.

title: UNIVERSAL FOREST TO BUY STRUCTURAL SUPPORTS MAKER
description: Universal Forest Products Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Shoffner Industries for $90.7 million in cash and stock to become the largest United States supplier of structural products for roofs and floors in houses. The closely held Shoffner is based in Burlington, N.C., and has 14 facilities in 7 Eastern states and sales of $90 million in 1997. Including the Shoffner purchase, Universal Products has spent about $137 million in the last few months to buy four companies to enter the market for structural supports in home building, a spokesman said. Universal Forest, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., had net income of $17 million, or 97 cents a share, on revenue of $1.1 billion.

title: In Publishing, Bigger Is Better
description: To judge by all the wailing last week, you would have thought that the announced purchase of Random House by Bertelsmann A.G., the German media conglomerate, signaled the end of the civilized world. Why is it so hard to see that this deal could revitalize the entire industry, benefiting publishers, writers and readers alike?

title: A Young Bride Adrift in a Harsh and Exotic World
description: THE HACIENDA

title: Science Watch; As Good as Your Words?
description: NEW psychology research has turned up a kernel of truth to the childish taunt ''I'm rubber, you're glue -- what you say bounces off me and sticks to you.''

title: Silent on Sudanese War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NANNI, LOUIS F.
description: NANNI-Louis F. March 29, 1998. Loving husband of the late Ethel. Owner and proprietor of Nanni's Restaurant and Nanni Il Valletto, Institutions of Italian Cuisine. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him, especially his longtime and loyal staff. Friends may call Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Yeltsin Says He Won't Run For Another Term in 2000
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that he would not run for re-election in 2000, throwing the door open to a bevy of would-be successors.

title: 2 Executives Dismissed by Salomon Over Pornography
description: Salomon Smith Barney, the brokerage subsidiary of the Travelers Group Inc., dismissed two executives on Friday after concluding that they had used the company's electronic equipment to transmit pornography.

title: For Trinidad, the Wait Between Bouts Is Agony
description: Felix Trinidad was dancing around the ring at the empty Wilfredo Gomez Arena, jabbing at an imaginary opponent as he honed his footwork. Trinidad moved left, danced right and looked comfortable in this setting, with no boxer in front of him.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture credits on the Arts and Ideas page on Saturday with an article about scholars' changing view of shopping misspelled the photo agency's name. It is Corbis-Bettmann, not Bettman.

title: Scientists Find New Ways To Break Into the Brain
description: DRUG companies working on promising new treatments for brain disorders like Alzheimer's disease, tumors and depression are learning a hard lesson: it is easier to make a medicine that will act on the brain than it is to make one that will get into the brain.

title: LaFontaine Packs It In, And So Do the Rangers
description: They lost a top player, then lost to a team at the bottom of the league. It was that kind of day for the Rangers, the lowest point in a season full of lows.

title: Post-Communist Russia Plumbs Its Soul, in Vain, for New Vision
description: Russia is in search of a ''national idea'' that can define its essence and inspire its citizens. But so far the struggle for a post-Soviet identity has been a grandiose exercise in conflict and confusion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISMAN, DOOLEY
description: REISMAN-Dooley. Your courage and strength were an inspiration to all of us. We will always remember your beautiful smile, warmth and vitality. You will be in our hearts always. Sue and Bob Rahn

title: A Wildcat on the Bench Hits Big
description: After the national championship had been decided, after Cameron Mills had entered late and scored 8 huge points for Kentucky during the decisive moments, moments that swung the game Kentucky's way for good, Mills recalled the early days. He is a senior, and it is over now. But he will take with him a glittering championship ring, a constant reminder of Kentucky's 78-69 victory over Utah last night in the Alamodome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAEL, KENNETH
description: MICHAEL-Kenneth. We mourn the passing of Kenneth Michael, devoted friend and benefactor, son of our unforgettable first president, Rosi Michael, and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Jenny and to the whole family. RE'UTH Rosa Strygler, President Ursula Merkin, Chairman

title: Glitches Galore Cropping Up In Full Audit of Government
description: It seemed like a good idea at the time: a comprehensive audit of the entire Federal Government, the first in two centuries. After all, many in Congress argued when it commissioned the audit in 1994, if Microsoft and General Motors have to get auditors to bless their financial statements, why not the Government?

title: Bringing Back a Taste Of Brooklyn: Rheingold
description: Like the Volkswagen Beetle and bell-bottoms, some things never really go away.

title: When Lawmakers Waffle, and Sometimes Before, Voters Turn to the Ballot Measure
description: Twenty years ago this June, angry California voters unleashed the revolution of Proposition 13, the ballot initiative that capped local property tax rates, cutting $5 billion in taxes statewide -- a feat the politicians had contended was impossible.

title: Following Gary Hart
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORTON, EILEEN M.
description: LORTON-Eileen M. Dear sister of Margaret Rothberg, Madeline and the late Therese Lorton. Reposing John J. Fox and Sons Inc, 201st Street and the Grand Concourse, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Philip Neri Church, Wednesday 10 A.M.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Intel's takeover of the former Westinghouse science competition misidentified the part of a computer that displays the ''Intel Inside'' slogan. It is the case, not the hard drive; the reference is to the computer's central processing chip.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the March 22 Television section on March 22 about the HBO documentary ''City Dump: The Story of the 1951 C.C.N.Y. Basketball Scandal'' misidentified the place where the New York Knicks played most of their home games. It was the 69th Street Regiment Armory, at 25th Street, not the uptown 69th Street Armory. The same article also misidentified the college attended by that the novelist author Avery Corman, who is interviewed on the program. It was attended. He graduated from New York University, not City College.

title: Reality Shapes an Editor's Fashionable Life
description: ELEVEN days ago Liz Tilberis had one of her periodic blood tests to screen for cancer, but yesterday morning, just before the fashion show by Carolina Herrera, the designer, in Bryant Park, she was shoving whatever the results might be from her mind. ''Can I be honest with you?'' Ms. Tilberis, the editor of Harper's Bazaar, said sheepishly. ''I haven't called the doctor yet. You start to put it off.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GODNICK, AUDREY
description: GODNICK-Audrey. On March 31, 1996. Two years ago. There will never be another like you.

title: Wrangling Over the Federal Budget Outlives a Dying Deficit
description: Last year's balanced budget agreement was supposed to make it all so simple. After years of bitter partisan warfare over taxes and spending, President Clinton and the Republican leadership in Congress agreed on a five-year plan that gave both sides most of what they wanted, with enough left over to eliminate the Federal deficit.

title: Exploring Rap and Race In a Jangle of Cultures
description: Flip Dog, the incredibly famous rap artist, has sold 275 billion albums. Anyway, that's what he tells Jay Leno on ''The Tonight Show,'' along with some other intriguing statistics, like the number of women waiting to please him back in his hotel room (149). Flip Dog, by the way, really is black, he says, contrary to appearances. The small dark spot on his arm is his true color; the rest of his skin is a birthmark.

title: Judge Orders East Haven to Develop Plan for Minority Hiring
description: In what is believed to be the first ruling of its kind in Connecticut, a Federal judge has ordered this New Haven suburb to revise its hiring practices to end a perception of job discrimination among blacks and other minorities.

title: Two Airlines to Tighten Rules on Seat Belts
description: American Airlines and United Airlines, the two largest airlines in the United States, said today that they would require passengers to keep their seat belts buckled whenever they are seated.

title: Metro Business; Former Times Plant Leased
description: The cavernous building in Carlstadt, N.J., that until recently housed some of the printing presses of The New York Times will soon become a very large wine cellar. Sort of.

title: Discovery and a Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Warner in South Africa TV Venture
description: Beating six other strong entrants, a consortium backed by the media giant Time Warner Inc. won the license today to build a new television network here.

title: Florida Puts to Death First Woman in 150 Years
description: A 54-year-old woman convicted of poisoning her husband with arsenic died in the electric chair today in Starke, Fla., becoming the first woman in Florida to be executed since the days of slavery.

title: U.S. Effort Fails To End Impasse In the Mideast
description: The American mediator for the Middle East, Dennis B. Ross, concluded a four-day round of shuttle diplomacy in the area today, apparently without breaking the year-old deadlock in Israeli-Palestinian negotiations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, TIMOTHY C.
description: BURKE-Timothy C. on March 27, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Michael Burke. Devoted mother of Doreen Sorrell and Michele Majer. Loving grandmother of William, Edmund and Spencer. Member of Colonial Dames of America and D.A.R. Memorial service at St. Jean the Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave at 76th Street, Thursday, 11 AM. Intermnent private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to God's Love We Deliver,. 166 Avenue of the Americas, NYC, 10013.

title: A Pianist Who Shows His Passions' Depth
description: Next week, the pianist Andras Schiff settles into a glamorous two-week residency with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall. But on Sunday afternoon, he slipped into town through a side door, giving a recital in the modest Peoples' Symphony Concerts at Town Hall.

title: Defense in Brawley Case Demands 1988 Grand Jury Records
description: A lawyer for the State Attorney General and defense lawyers in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial argued today over the defendants' rights to information from a 1988 state grand jury investigation that could, if released, expand the trial's scope and lengthen its duration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, PARKOFF, RUTH
description: TAYLOR-PARKOFF-Ruth. In loving memory of a beautiful gracious lady, our dear Aunt Ruth. Horbar and Ruchman families.

title: Words Come First For Aging Rocker
description: Even when all he has to do is read -- no singing, no wild gyrating on a stage -- DAVID BOWIE believes in rehearsing. Yesterday the 51-year-old rock star, who has morphed from late-70's androgyny to 90's money management (as Britain's richest rock star, he has much to manage), tried out the lines he is to read at an appearance tonight with MATTHEW COLLINGS, a writer and art critic. Mr. Bowie knew the material: he is also a partner in 21 Publishing Limited, the art-book publishing house that issued Mr. Collings's most recent book.

title: An Intricate Dance With Iran
description: The United States and Iran are engaged in the delicate business of trying to repair a broken relationship. Reconciliation will not be easy, and may prove impossible if Iran does not end its support of terrorism and its effort to develop nuclear weapons. But the initial signs are promising and should be pursued.

title: A Mother, Her Baby And a Disarming Guest
description: Francois Ozon's ''See the Sea'' is set at the Ile d'Yeu, a French beach community, and filmed so precisely that it seems to observe every grain of sand. Discreetly terrifying in the way that only a tranquil, sunlit setting can be, the island is the backdrop for an insinuating two-character story. An Englishwoman named Sasha (Sasha Hails) is seen spending time in privileged isolation with her baby daughter, as the camera carefully records the simple rhythm of her days. Then a rude, sullen backpacker named Tatiana (Marina de Van) appears and announces her intention to camp in Sasha's yard. ''See the Sea,'' which is brief and expertly chilling, watches an uneasy rapport develop between these two.

title: Review/Fashion; Evoking Street-Smart Understatement
description: Of the surfeit of celebrities packed into Donatella Versace's Versus show, the one who has most in common with the designer is Lil' Kim. The steamy rapper, who attended the event on Saturday night in a black leather corset and diamonds, best exemplifies what Ms. Versace and her late brother stand for.

title: Good Riddance, Virginity: A Girl's Quest
description: ''The First Time,'' a German coming-of-age film about a 15-year-old girl on the brink of losing her virginity, doesn't say much that hasn't been said many times before. But it has the novel trick of imagining Johnny Depp as a sort of fairy godfather to Fili (Lavinia Wilson), the teen-ager at the center of the story. Fili keeps a Depp shrine and composes audiotapes to send to her idol, and the film has a Depp look-alike who returns the favor. None too convincingly done in Mr. Depp's more flamboyant screen costumes, this shadowy figure turns up occasionally to masquerade as Don Juan DeMarco or do the dancing potatoes trick from ''Benny and Joon.''

title: CBS Considers Manhattan and Jersey City for New Studios
description: In what may shape up as the next trans-Hudson battle for big business, the CBS television network is considering several sites in Manhattan -- and one in Jersey City -- for a new broadcasting center to replace its 35-year-old studios on West 57th Street, near 11th Avenue, according to several people involved in the negotiations.

title: Flawed Organ Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Down With the Ferry (But It's Free)
description: COINCIDENCES tend to be suspect in this hard-boiled city, and Staten Islanders, who take pride in not being a part of the main, rank among the more suspicious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKIN, DAVID B.
description: ELKIN-David B. Beloved husband to Margot Turitz Elkin, loving father of Charlotte and Sam Elkin, cherished brother of Ethel Elkin and devoted son-in-law to Zitha Turitz. David was an economist, former Vice President of W. R. Grace and Co, adjunct professor, and economic consultant. He grew up in the Bronx, later lived in Manhattan, and settled in White Plains. His intelligence, vast knowledge, political conscience, wry humor and sensitivity will be deeply missed. Memorial service to be held Tuesday. Contributions to Fund for Parkinson's Research, University of Medicine and Dentistry of N.J., New Brunswick, New Jersey 08903.

title: Fund Investors Are Returning To Riskier Bets
description: After several months of more cautious and conservative investing, mutual fund shareholders and managers are growing bold again.

title: DECAUX OF FRANCE UNIT OFFERS HIGHER BID FOR MORE GROUP
description: A unit of the privately owned French advertising company Decaux S.A. offered $:475 million ($799 million) in cash for More Group P.L.C., outbidding Clear Channel Communications Inc. of San Antonio. Decaux's 1,110-pence-a-share offer is 8 percent higher than Clear Channel's 1,030-pence-a-share offer. Decaux said on Friday that it was considering a rival bid to that of Clear Channel. Clear Channel responded with a statement that suggested it was considering another bid. Its shares fell $1, to $97.125. Clear Channel, which owns radio and television stations throughout the United States, made the offer as part of an effort to enter the international advertising market.

title: To Save Mayan Artifacts From Looters, a Form of Protective Custody
description: To get to this remote Mayan ruin deep in the heart of northern Guatemala, a visitor must drive south for an hour and a half on a dirt road from the Flores Airport, ride a motor boat up La Pasion River for close to an hour and climb for 20 minutes or so up a steep, narrow path through the jungle to the first clearing. There the flat, round Temple of the Wind sits, crowned by a platform where Mayan dancers performed ritual ceremonies some 1,200 years ago. A little further on are more temples and many tall, carved limestone tablets known as stelae. Here and there, stone steps run up the side of a mound, signaling that another building in this still largely unexcavated city lies below.

title: World War I Museum's New Drive on the Home Front
description: Two weeks after World War I ended on Nov. 11, 1918, a group of Kansas City civic leaders decided to create a memorial to those who had served. A fund drive was held, and in less than two weeks it raised $2 million, then a substantial sum.

title: Topics of The Times; The Best Team Ever
description: It was a massacre, but unlike most blowouts, it was fun to watch. The Tennessee Lady Vols not only destroyed Louisiana Tech to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship, but they did so with a verve that raised women's basketball to new heights of excitement.

title: A Social Security Feeding Frenzy?; Time to Privatize
description: To the Editor:

title: A Social Security Feeding Frenzy?
description: To the Editor:

title: ENSIGN RESOURCE TO BUY OIL AND GAS SERVICE COMPANY
description: Ensign Resource Service Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Artisan Corporation, a Canadian oil and gas service company, for $225 million (Canadian), or $159 million (United States), in cash and stock. Ensign Resource, based in Calgary, Alberta, is an oil and gas contract-drilling and well-servicing company. The combined company will have a total of 182 drilling rigs in Canada and the United States, and 115 service rigs in Canada. Under the agreement, Ensign will pay $10.50 (Canadian) cash, or 0.3415 of one of its shares, for each of Artisan's shares outstanding, or a combination of cash and Ensign shares. Artisan is also based in Calgary.

title: BDO Seidman Faces a $77 Million Lawsuit
description: The former accountant for A. R. Baron & Company is being sued for $77 million for failing to uncover a stock-fraud scheme at the defunct brokerage firm.

title: Treasury Prices Dip in Defensive Trading
description: The prices of Treasury securities were lower yesterday, amid defensive trading ahead of today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's committee on monetary policy, at which the course of interest rates in the months ahead may be determined.

title: Daiwa Bank Doubles Bad Loan Write-Offs
description: Daiwa Bank Ltd., Japan's ninth-largest commercial lender, said yesterday that it was writing-off twice as much in bad loans as it had forecast earlier, using money it had set aside to cover stock losses. The Osaka-based bank is the latest in a wave of Japanese lenders to announce it is increasing its disposal of bad debt, as Japanese banks are pushed to speed write-offs by new government standards on assessing loans.

title: In Congress and Outside, a Digging In of Heels on Tobacco Liability
description: In the Congressional cauldron that is shaping tobacco legislation, one issue is vital to cigarette makers and to their enemies: how much legal protection should the Government give cigarette producers and at what price?

title: Ndiaye Withdraws Slur Charge
description: A dispute involving the allegation of racial comments took another twist today when North Carolina's Makhtar Ndiaye withdrew his claim that Utah's Britton Johnsen had used epithets toward him during the semifinal game on Saturday night. But Ndiaye denied Johnsen's accusations that he had spit on him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POCHAPIN, ANNE
description: POCHAPIN-Anne. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved mother of our dear friend, Rita Rosen. Mrs. Pochapin was a member of our Society of Founders. Her concern for others will live in perpetuity in the good works of her daughter, Rita, and son-in-law, Philip. Benefactors of our medical school and Guardians of our University, Rita and Phil are esteemed members of the Einstein Board of Overseers, who have established the Philip and Rita Rosen Department of Communications and Public Affairs at our institution. To Rita, Phil and the entire family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Burton P. Resnick, Chairperson Board of Overseers Albert Einstein College of Medicine Dr. Dominick P. Purpura, Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Britain Moves to Combat 'Millennium Bug'
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair announced today an accelerated program to forestall the catastrophic essential service lapses, business losses and communications blackouts that he said could be caused by the year 2000 computer date change crisis known as the Millennium Bug.

title: Telescope Will Offer X-Ray View Of Cosmos
description: Astronomers looking skyward know that some of the most violent, calamitous occurrences in the universe are happening all around, but no one can see them. Stars are exploding and collapsing, giant clouds of super-hot gases are expanding and gravity-intense black holes are devouring everything in their vicinity -- all outside the limits of human sight.

title: Don't Blame Guns For School Attack; Combustible Brew
description: To the Editor:

title: Discovery and a Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Lady Vols' Outlook? Brighter Than Ever
description: It can now be etched in stone, at least as much as anything can be. The University of Tennessee, 39-0 and winner of an unprecedented three consecutive national championships, is home to the best women's college basketball team ever.

title: Wild Things: Elephants and Tigers and Aerialists, oh My!
description: Moves that Michael Jordan can only dream of.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKLE, JOEL
description: FINKLE-Joel. Of New York City and Palm Beach, Florida, on March 29, 1998. Son of the late Benjamin and Hinda Finkle. Brother of Ann Odel and Edith Horwitt and the late Celia David and Mary Pollen. He is survived by his cherished wife Maria, loving daughter Joan Swirsky and son Jonathan Finkle, grandchildren, Seth, David and Karen, and great-grandson, Julian and brother-in-law Walter Weil. He was predeceased by his son Zachary Dan. In his lifetime, the vast scope of his charities addressed the needs of Jewish people throughout the world. He provided inspiration, leadership, and substance to every cause to which he devoted his formidable energy, and embodied vitality, optimism, and joie-de-Vivre in his everyday life. Funeral services were held on Monday, Fifth Avenue Synagogue. Shiva will be observed at 930 Fifth Avenue until Sunday A.M., April 4th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the Maria and Joel Finkle Center for counseling at Bar Ilan University, 91 Fifth Avenue, New York, New York 10003.

title: MAIN ELECTION BILL DIES IN THE HOUSE
description: The House held its campaign finance debate tonight but approved only two minor changes in the law. The main bipartisan bill for a thorough overhaul -- a measure that had apparently commanded majority support -- was never allowed onto the floor for a vote.

title: Nets View Playoffs, Using All The Angles
description: For much of the last month, John Calipari has tried to keep the Nets from watching the scoreboard, wishing that they would keep their minds on their performance. But with 11 games left and Jayson Williams sidelined for the rest of the regular season, Calipari has opened his mind to other ways into the playoffs.

title: For Haydn, Some Tricks With Silence And Bluster
description: Listening to a Haydn string quartet is to be in the presence of prototype and perfected model simultaneously. Haydn, in other words, invented the form as we have come to use it and was arguably its most satisfying practitioner. The Lindsay String Quartet from Britain came to Weill Recital Hall on Friday night with four examples drawn from Haydn's long and various quartet-writing career.

title: Hilda G. Schwartz, 90, Retired New York Justice
description: Hilda Ginsburg Schwartz, a retired justice of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan, who was a mentor and role model for many female lawyers, died on March 18 at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 90 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: For an Old Beer, A New Life
description: In the days before neighborhood bars gave way to microbreweries, Rheingold Extra Dry Lager Beer was the brew of choice for New Yorkers. The most popular beer in the region from the 1940's to the 60's, it was the official beer of the New York Mets, and its advertisements featured the likes of John Wayne, the Marx Brothers and Jackie Robinson.

title: Edmund Asbury Gullion, 85, Wide-Ranging Career Envoy
description: Edmund Asbury Gullion, one of the country's most accomplished career ambassadors and former dean of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University, where he trained the next generation of Foreign Officers, died in his sleep the night of March 17 at his home in Winchester, Mass. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POKRESS, YALE B.
description: POKRESS-Yale B. Of Middletown, New Jersey, formerly of New York City, NY on March 29, 1998. Loving husband of Jean Pokress. Devoted father of Gail Hartley & the late Michael Lloyd Pokress. Brother of Dr. Murray Pokress. Retired Lt. Colonel of the U.S. Army. A well respected veteran in the toy industry and a self made investor in the Wall Street jungle. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the VNA of Central Jersey, 141 Bodman Place, Red Bank, N.J. 07701. A private memorial service will be held.

title: Whitman to Streamline Operation of Programs
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced yesterday that the state government would be reorganized to streamline the administration of some programs.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWITZER, ANNA ASHLEY LAMAR
description: SWITZER-Anna Ashley Lamar. Died on Friday, March 27th, 1998 after a brief illness at her home in Pensacola, Florida. She was 97. She was a daughter of Caroline Law Varnedoe and Charles Wilbur Lamar and the widow of VADM Wendell Gray Switzer, USN. Mrs. Switzer was born in Valdosta, GA September 11, 1900, and moved with her family to Pensacola in 1903 where her father, a banker, soon founded what would become Lamar Outdoor Advertising. She married in 1924 and traveled extensively during her husband's 45year Naval career. When they retired in Pensacola, Mrs. Switzer continued her close association with the Navy, and became a community and political activist. Mrs. Switzer was the first woman named to the Naval Aviation Museum Foundation Board and in 1992 was awarded the Dorothy M. Flatley Award presented by the USS Yorktown CV-10 Association to ''the woman who has come closest to exemplifying Dorothy Flatley's incredible 55 years of inspirational support as a carrier aviator's wife, mother, and grandmother.'' Mrs. Switzer was predeceased by her sons LTJG Wendell Gray Switzer, Jr. in 1955 and LCDR John Lamar Switzer in 1959 who were both killed in Naval aviation accidents. Her husband died in 1970. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law Ann Lamar (DeeDee) and Kevin Patrick Reilly of Baton Rouge, LA., & Pensacola, her sister, Mrs. George W. (Mary Lee) Anderson of Washington, DC, 7 grandchildren and 13 great grandchildren. Funeral services were held Monday, March 30 at 11:00 AM in the First Presbyterian Church in Pensacola. Burial will be in Arlington National Cemetery Monday, April 6, at 2 PM with her grandnephew, the Rev. Lupton P. Abshire of Georgetown Christ Church, officiating. Demaines Funeral Home, Alexandria, VA.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROTH, MURRAY
description: ROTH-Murray. March 30, 1997. Forever remembered and cherished, dear Murray. We miss you and think of you all the time. Oh, how we miss you. Pam, Dawn and Catherine

title: Deputy Sheriff Accused Of Abusing Girl, 6
description: A New York City deputy sheriff was arrested yesterday on charges that he sexually abused his girlfriend's 6-year-old daughter, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFFER, LILA
description: SCHAEFFER-Lila. Beloved wife of Morris, loving mother of Peter and Anne, Amy and Brian Clinch, cherished grandmother of Matthew, Lee, Max, Erin, Neil and Sam. Dear sister of Gilbert Birnbaum. Services Wednesday, April 1, at 1 PM at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd. at 76 Road, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Health Industry Seeks Congressional Relief
description: Hurt by a series of investigations and large penalties under a Federal fraud statute, the hospital industry is waging a battle on Capitol Hill to make it more difficult for prosecutors to bring such cases against health care providers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROOB, MARTIN
description: GROOB-Martin. Great Neck Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife and to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Dale Polakoff Dr. Ephraim Wolf, Rabbi Emeritus David Werber, President

title: Moving Into the Lead Late, Anand Triumphs at Linares
description: With the three top-ranked players in the world -- Garry Kasparov, Vladimir Kramnik and Viswanathan Anand -- entered in the Linares Supertournament in Spain, it was not expected that an outsider would be threatening to win the event right through the eighth round. But the almost-hero, Alexei Shirov of Spain, faltered and lost in Rounds 9 and 13, dropping back into second place with a 7-5 score. And Anand, with a critical victory over Veselin Topalov in Round 13, grasped the lead and held it with a last-round draw against Kramnik that gave him 7 1/2-4 1/2.

title: GREAT UNIVERSAL WINS BID TO ACQUIRE METROMAIL
description: Great Universal Stores P.L.C. of Britain won a battle yesterday to acquire the Metromail Corporation, a direct marketing company, for $905 million, after a rival bidder failed to provide proof that it had the necessary financing. Metromail said late yesterday that its board had affirmed approval for Great Universal's bid and ended an auction of the company. Earlier, the rival bidder, American Business Information Inc., said it could not meet a deadline set by Metromail for the submission of additional documents. American Business on Saturday raised its offer to $37.48 a share, or about $980 million, compared with Great Universal's offer of $34.50 a share.

title: Bellville Journal; University Insists That Tuition Be Paid . . . or Else
description: It has become an annual ritual at virtually all of the universities once set aside for blacks under apartheid. With the start of the academic year each February come the student demonstrations. Campuses are vandalized, hostages taken, tires burned in the streets and officials blocked from their offices.

title: Texaco Stock Buyback
description: Texaco Inc. said today that it would buy back up to $1 billion of its common stock. The buyback, which will take place over an unspecified time, represents about 3.1 percent of Texaco's 522.2 million basic shares on average as of Dec. 31. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing shares outstanding. The oil and gas giant said it recently completed a two-year buyback of stock valued at $650 million. The stock closed today at $60.9375, up 81.25 cents.

title: Discovery and a Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINGERET, HAROLD
description: FINGERET-Harold Beloved husband of Ilene. Devoted father of Matthew Fingeret and Sheryl Winkler. Loving grandfather of Jacob, Jared and Danielle. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' corner of Park and Passaic Streets, Hackensack, N.J. on Wednesday, April 1, 1998 at 10am. For info 1-800-522-0588.

title: Don't Blame Guns For School Attack
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, STEVEN GLENN
description: SCHULMAN-Steven Glenn. In Loving Memory, Aunt Maxie, Uncle Stanley and Uncle Edwin.

title: Triton Energy Weighs Sales
description: Triton Energy Ltd. said today that it was considering the sale of interests in South America and Southeast Asia. Triton, an oil and natural gas company based here, had revenue of $149.5 million in 1997. The company said it had retained independent advisers to aid in the sale of its interests in gas fields discovered in the Gulf of Thailand and two oilfields in Colombia.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DOREL INDUSTRIES, Montreal, a manufacturer of ready-to-assemble and metal folding furniture, will purchase Ameriwood Industries International Corp., Grand Rapids, Mich., also a furniture maker, for $9.625 a share, or $41.1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, ELLIOTT
description: GORDON-Elliott, 64. Chairperson of Associate Degree Program of Pratt Manhattan. Survived by his wife Barbara, sons Dr. Cameron Gordon of Manhattan and Tony Gordon of Fort Myers, FL. Visiting hours April 2nd, 6-8 PM, Dimicelli Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations to Bide-A-Wee Home, 410 E. 38 St., NYC 10016 are appreciated.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Introduce Bill To Lower Car Insurance Rates
description: The State Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, introduced a bill tonight that he said would reduce auto insurance rates by 15 percent for most drivers. But the insurance industry is skeptical of the projected savings, and legislative leaders in the Assembly have not agreed to all of the measure's provisions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, JEANETTE
description: TUCKER - Jeanette. Beloved mother of Michael and Harry. Cherished grandmother of Adam, Eric and David. Loving sister of Ruth Garfinkel. Services were held Sunday at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLMERT, MORDECHAI
description: OLMERT-Mordechai. We extend sincerest condolences to Ehud Olmert, Mayor of Jerusalem, on the loss of his beloved father. Mayor Olmert and Shaara Zedek Medical Center have shared a long-standing partnership dedicated to providing the people of Jerusalem with state-of-the-art-medical care. May Mayor Olmert and brothers Ami, Yirmi and Yussi, and the entire family, be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Stuart Tauber, Exec. Dir.

title: SENATE IS OFFERED SWEEPING MEASURE TO FIGHT SMOKING
description: With bipartisan support, Senator John McCain today offered a comprehensive tobacco bill that could form the basis of ground-breaking legislation meant to sharply reduce the number of Americans who smoke.

title: A Social Security Feeding Frenzy?; Stay Out of the Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, REGINA
description: COLLINS-Regina. On March 29, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence M. Strauss and the late Albert Collins. Loving mother of Lawrence Strauss and Marjorie Power; adoring grandmother of Lawrence C., Michael and Jeremy Strauss and Erik Power. Dear sister of Julian Rothbaum. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers an act of kindness in her memory, or contributions to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: New Tack Promising On Winter Depression
description: NOW that spring has begun and those plagued by winter depression are emerging from their annual doldrums, new studies suggest that a few tiny doses of the hormone melatonin each afternoon might have helped to keep their demons of darkness at bay all winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASSEF, MORTON
description: ASSEF-Morton. Age 72, died Mar. 30, 1998. Beloved son of the late Jennie Lassef. Devoted brother of Sylvia (Bibby) and Philip Korn, loving uncle of Richard Korn and Naomi and Dr. Stephen Syken and adored grand uncle of Shayna and Jenna Syken. Service Wednesday April 1, noon at Schwartz Brothers Forest Hills. Donations in his memory may be made to New York Primary Care Health Foundation, POB 234491, 307 East Shore Rd, Great Neck, New York 11023.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULBRETH, MARVIN K.
description: CULBRETH-Marvin K. Age 72. Interior designer and illustrator died in Danbury Hospital on the 27th of March. Calling hours Wednesday between 6 and 8 P.M., at Kane Funeral, 41 Catoonah Street, Ridgefield, CT. Contributions in his memory may be made to High Watch Farm, P.O. Box 607, Kent, Connecticut 06757.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HETTLING, LILLIAN BASSEIN
description: HETTLING-Lillian Bassein. Formerly of Croton-On-Hudson, New York, died in Virginia Sunday, March 29, 1998. She was born in 1906, in the Bronx, NY, to Leon ''Elbe'' & Lizzy Goldberg Bassein. Lillian was the wife of the late Frederick E. Hettling, and is survived by 2 daughters, and 3 grandchildren. Those who knew her are invited to a gathering in her memory Friday, April 3, 1998 at 2 P.M. at The Tarrytown Hilton, 445 South Broadway, Tarrytown, New York.

title: Chancellor Takes Over Magnet School
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has taken over a Staten Island magnet school that he found rife with internal dissent and political favoritism in admissions decisions, problems exposed earlier this month by an independent investigator.

title: Facing Up to the Realities of Sleep Deprivation
description: WAKE UP! This is National Sleep Awareness Week and judging from a national survey, Americans remain woefully ignorant about sleep, its critical role in their lives and the hazards of not getting enough of it.

title: Topics of The Times; Play Ball
description: Call us crazy, but we think this could be a truly interesting baseball season. For one thing, the commissioner's office has instructed umpires to enforce new procedures aimed at speeding up play. Pitchers will not be allowed to dawdle, and between-inning breaks will be shortened. As long as the basic rules and rhythms of the game are not sacrificed in the rush, this will be an improvement. The average length of games in the American League increased from 2 hours 30 minutes in 1977 to about 3 hours in 1997. That is too much dead time, especially for younger fans.

title: Don't Blame Guns For School Attack; A Health Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Republican Budget Feuds
description: Republicans in Congress have developed a habit of fighting with each other more than with the White House. Now their feuding threatens passage of emergency spending for disaster relief and for American forces in Bosnia and the Persian Gulf.

title: Reader's Digest Will Feature Zippier Image With May Issue
description: Starting with the May issue, Reader's Digest is tossing away its old look -- the bland but useful listing of the articles on the cover -- and taking on a zippier new image, complete with color photography inside and out, a modernized typeface and a table of contents that does not appear until page 2.

title: School Boards Crank Up the Budget Pitch
description: First, back in December, they asked focus groups to come in to help plot strategy. Then they brought in computer-generated pie charts and graphs and a parent-made video showing wholesome scenes like science labs, cheerleading practice and graduating seniors triumphantly tossing their mortarboards in the air, to the sentimental strains of a Barbra Streisand song.

title: Ecstatic He's Not, but Holyfield Will Face Akinwande
description: Henry Akinwande is not the kind of opponent who sets Evander Holyfield's competitive fires ablaze. But Akinwande is a chore Holyfield must complete, sort of like taking out the garbage, if Holyfield is to reach his ultimate goal of unifying the heavyweight championship.

title: Her Shopping Lists Can't Be Bought
description: Thirteen letters from Jacqueline Kennedy to a saleswoman at Bergdorf Goodman have been withdrawn from a Sotheby's auction because of a family squabble -- not among Kennedys but among relatives of the saleswoman, Marita O'Connor, who died in 1974.

title: Supreme Court Considers if Disabilities Act Covers H.I.V. Case
description: The Supreme Court took up its first case under the Americans With Disabilities Act today, and the argument over whether the law covers people who have H.I.V. but who show no symptoms of disease served mainly to underscore the statute's complexities.

title: Git Along, Li'l Fashion Plates; A Rocky Mountain Upstart Wages Jeans Shootout in Wrangler Corral
description: Britt Bockius is a heeler, the cowboy responsible for lassoing the back legs of a steer during a team roping contest. But moments before he mounted his horse at a rodeo here the other morning, dressed in a new style of jeans and shirt, he spoke not of the perils of doing battle in the ring, but of fashion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEARD, WENDY STEDMAN (WILLIAMS)
description: SHEARD-Wendy Stedman (Williams). Friends and colleagues mourn the passing of Wendy Sheard, age 62, on March 25th in Stony Creek, CT. She was the beloved wife of Michael and a devoted mother and stepmother to Amanda (Bourque), Tony (Stedman), Paul, Russell and Craig Sheard. She was the loving sister of Jill Williams and was blessed with seven grandchildren, Emma, Laura, Zoe, Keegan Sheard, Julia, Maddie, and Katie Bourque. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Connecticut Hospice, 61 Burban Drive, Branford, CT 06405.

title: Kentucky Rally Earns a 7th Title
description: Kentucky, no stranger to cutting the nets down in championship games, snipped away again last night after capturing its second N.C.A.A. title in the last three years and its seventh in history with a 78-69 comeback victory over Utah at the Alamodome in San Antonio.

title: Metro Business; Vornado Buys Hotel Stake
description: Vornado Realty Trust of Saddle Brook, N.J., says it has doubled its stake in the Hotel Pennsylvania in Manhattan to 80 percent by buying one of its partner's interests for $70 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: Pay-for-Play Back on the Air But This Rendition Is Legal
description: In January, a radio station in Portland, Ore., and a record label in Los Angeles struck an unusual arrangement. The record company, Flip/ Interscope, agreed to pay the radio station, KUFO-FM, about $5,000 to play a song by one of the label's emerging acts 50 times during five weeks. The song, ''Counterfeit,'' is by Limp Bizkit, a hip-hop-influenced heavy-metal band whose music the station had initially considered a little too hard for its audience.

title: A Social Security Feeding Frenzy?; 'Fixes' That Failed
description: To the Editor:

title: CUNY Sees Financial Losses in Limiting Remedial Classes
description: Cutting back remedial courses at the City University of New York could cost the university hundreds of millions of dollars in tuition revenue if remedial students are not allowed to register at its colleges, the university's chief fiscal officer told trustees yesterday.

title: 'Einstein Ring' Caused by Space Warping Is Found
description: AN array of six radiotelescopes scattered across Britain, working cooperatively with the Hubble Space Telescope, has captured the first image ever recorded of an unbroken ''Einstein ring,'' a circle of light created by the gravitational warping of space between a very distant galaxy and the earth.

title: People
