description: * Jordan H. Rednor, executive vice president at Draft Worldwide, New York, part of the Interpublic Group , was promoted to president and chief operating officer, succeeding Dan Ginsburg, who retires June 1.

title: When the Doctor and Patient Need Couple's Therapy
description: IT was a lot like an ordinary blind date. The man and the woman were strangers, set up by a mutual acquaintance. He showed up at her place at the appointed time, they spent about an hour together, then she walked him to the door.

title: Hong Kong Rulings Stir Fears Over Law System
description: Hong Kong's legal system is one vestige of British colonial rule that most people here have fought to preserve. But a series of government rulings in recent weeks have stirred fears that the rule of law is being eroded as Hong Kong is absorbed into China.

title: MATTEL BIDS FOR BLUEBIRD TOYS, MAKER OF ETCH-A-SKETCH
description: The toy maker Mattel Inc. said yesterday that it had offered $:46 million, or $77.4 million, to acquire Bluebird Toys P.L.C. of Britain. The bid tops an earlier unsolicited offer of $:42 million by Guinness Peat Group P.L.C., a British investment company. Mattel, of El Segundo, Calif., offered 111 pence a share for Bluebird, which makes toys like Polly Pocket and Etch-A-Sketch. Guinness Peat had offered 101 pence. Mattel said that the offer reflected the company's confidence in Bluebird's brands. Mattel's stock slipped 43.75 cents, to $39.25.

title: Republican Lawmaker Is Caught in the Middle
description: Representative Christopher Shays, Republican of Connecticut, was on his way to a news conference to criticize his party for blocking what he saw as true change in campaign finance rules.

title: Problems at DFS Cause Shares of LVMH to Fall
description: LVMH shares fell yesterday after its duty-free unit, DFS Group Ltd., said it was negotiating a two-month delay in payments to all its 5,000 suppliers to offset slowing sales in Asia. Shares of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., the maker of luxury goods, fell 27 francs, to 1,288 French francs.

title: The International National Pastime
description: If you go to a Mets game this season you might see a Japanese pitcher (Masato Yoshii) wind up and deliver the ball to a Dominican catcher (Albert Castillo). An African-American might hit that pitch to a Venezuelan third baseman (Edgardo Alfonzo), who will throw the ball to a Puerto Rican second baseman (Carlos Baerga), who will relay it to a white first baseman from Washington State (John Olerud) to complete a perfect double play.

title: Saudis End Inquiry in Blast That Killed 19 U.S. Airmen
description: The Saudi Arabian Government said today that it had completed its investigation into the June 1996 terrorist bombing there that left 19 American airmen dead but would not immediately release the results of the inquiry. The announcement caught the Clinton Administration by surprise and led to new fears that the culprits might never be brought to justice.

title: Whitney Heir Gives Museums Art
description: Betsey Cushing Roosevelt Whitney, the New York socialite and philanthropist who with her husband amassed one of the nation's great private art collections, has bequeathed 15 major works by Picasso, van Gogh, Matisse, Toulouse-Lautrec and other masters to the National Gallery of Art in Washington and the Museum of Modern Art in New York. The gifts are estimated to be worth $300 million.

title: Irabu Wins, but Many Questions Remain
description: Hideki Irabu pitched well enough today to dominate a college team. Only time will tell whether Irabu's stuff, diminished by elbow tendinitis, is good enough to beat a major league team.

title: BMW of Germany Will Buy Rolls-Royce
description: Rolls-Royce, Britain's legendary manufacturer of hand-burnished luxury automobiles and a cherished symbol of national pride, is about to be sold to the German car company BMW.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK PLUMMETS. The mark fell after senior Bundesbank officials questioned the stability of Europe's planned single currency. In New York, the dollar cost 1.8474 marks, up 1.1 percent from 1.8266 and the highest since Aug. 12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBER, YETTA R.
description: SILBER-Yetta R. On March 29, 1998. Loving mother of Alan and Fred Gorelick and devoted stepmother of Dr. Stanley Silber. Adored mother-in-law of Anita Sapirman and Jan Fogelman. Cherished grandmother of Jamie, Brett and Samantha. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERCE, REV. MICHAEL G., S.J.
description: PIERCE-Rev. Michael G., S.J. Of Boston. On March 28, 1998. A highly respected administrator and director of development who provided for the training of young Jesuits in formation and the care of the elderly and infirm members of the Society of Jesus. Reposing at Campion Center, 319 Concord Road, Weston, Massachusetts. Visiting hours Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9. Concelebrated funeral Mass in the Chapel of the Holy Spirit, Campion Center, on Wednesday, April 1st. at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Reverend Michael G. Pierce, S.J. Fund, P.O. Box 799, Back Bay Annex, Boston, MA. 02117-0799.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, EVA
description: STRAUSS-Eva. Born Stuttgart, Germany, 1905, died March 28. Daughter of Adolph and Martha Kops. Devoted and beloved wife of the late Julius Strauss. Mother of the late Rosemary Strauss. Lovingly remembered by her children Peter and Laura, and her grandchildren Carolyn Strauss, Mimi Friedman, Diana Strauss, and Michael Norwood.

title: Crispin Porter Gets Cunard Account
description: Cunard Line Ltd. said yesterday that it had named Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami to handle its worldwide account, with billings estimated at $11 million. The account had been handled for four years by Bates Worldwide in New York, a unit of the Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C., which resigned earlier this year.

title: Science Watch; A New Medical Record
description: A 1543 medical textbook by the anatomist Andreas Vesalius set a record this month for the highest auction price ever paid for a medical book, the auction house Christie's of New York said.

title: UNION PLANTERS TO BUY SOME CALIFORNIA FEDERAL ASSETS
description: The Union Planters Corporation agreed yesterday to buy California Federal Bank's Florida branches for $110 million, adding $1.5 billion of deposits. Gerald J. Ford, chief executive of California Federal, which is a subsidiary of First Nationwide Holdings Inc., said that the sale would increase the closely held bank's tangible book value by about 10 percent, or by 55 to 60 cents a share. Last month, Golden State Bancorp agreed to merge with California Federal to create the third-largest United States thrift institution. Union Planters, a Memphis-based bank, agreed to buy Magna Group Inc. of St. Louis for $2.2 billion, increasing the bank's assets to $28 billion, from $18 billion. Union Planters' stock fell 68.75 cents a share, to $61.875.

title: Marchers at State House Criticize Charter Schools
description: Two days before the State Board of Education is expected to rule on the fate of 14 charter schools, a coalition of parents, teachers and administrators held a rally yesterday criticizing the state-financed privately run schools as a drain on public education.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with a Film Festival review of ''Under the Skin'' misstated the surname of the star. She is Samantha Morton, as the review said, not Moore.

title: Fears of Increasing Inflation Send Market Gauges Lower
description: Fears of rising inflation and Asian economic woes pushed major stock market gauges lower yesterday for the fourth straight day.

title: Sports of The Times; Sheppard Answers The Call
description: YOU don't stump John B. McLendon Jr. on basketball questions very often. With his 83d birthday next Sunday, McLendon, a pioneer and Hall of Fame coach, has forgotten more basketball than most coaches ever learn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHORR, MARIA GRANDY
description: SCHORR-Maria Grandy. The Juilliard School mourns the loss of Maria Grandy, distinguished member of the Dance Faculty for the past ten years. A teacher remarkable for her dedication and spirit, she was noted for her ability to inspire great progress in her students. She believed that the dancer's training should be all encompassing, involving all disciplines of the School. She will be missed by her students and colleagues alike, who found her boundless energy and enthusiasm a daily source of pleasure. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her entire family. Mary Rodgers Guettel Chairman, Board of Trustees Joseph W. Polisi President Benjamin Harkarvy Director, Dance Division

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Don't Blame Guns For School Attack; What's a Life Worth?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSWEENEY, WILLIAM
description: McSWEENEY-William, 93, native of Kilkee, County Clare, Ireland. National Life Member AOH. Beloved husband of the late Kathleen (nee Marrinan). Cherished father of Elizabeth O'Flynn, John and Patrick McSweeney, and Kathleen O'Neill. Devoted father in law of Denis O'Flynn, Claudine McSweeney, Eileen McSweeney, and William O'Neill. Loving grandfather of 14 grandchildren and 5 great grandchildren. FamIly will receive friends Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9PM at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial at St.John's R.C. Church (Kingsbridge) Thursday at 10:45 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GHERARDI, DR. LINDA BUCH
description: GHERARDI-Dr. Linda Buch. March 31, 1996. Two years since you left us. We love you so. You are deeply remembered and sorely missed by all. Your loving family

title: Pieter Bruegel & Sons, Painters; A Rare Chance to Compare Three Members of a Flemish Dynasty
description: A Bruegel can be quickly spotted as a Bruegel, but which Bruegel? At least in reproduction, who can tell if a landscape crowded with round-faced peasants at work and play is by Pieter Bruegel the Elder or by one of his sons, Pieter Breughel the Younger or Jan Brueghel the Elder? (Yes, they all spelled their surname differently.) Only by hanging them side by side can one truly distinguish the renderings of 16th-century village life in the Low Countries. But how often can this be done?

title: Patterns
description: Who's Dressing the Stars?

title: Among the Mountains and Cracking Ice, Meditation With an Edge
description: The Nancy Meehan Dance Company, founded in 1970, avoids all isms. Ms. Meehan's choreography is not for every taste, but its refinement is a relief from the slickness in many other modern-dance troupes.

title: Kentucky Turns Comeback Into Its 2d Title in 3 Years
description: The giddy Kentucky Wildcats stood on a makeshift podium, which was appropriately draped in blue, as in Kentucky blue. The players wore new white T-shirts and new white hats that naturally designated them as the new national champions after they rallied to squash Utah, 78-69, tonight at the Alamodome.

title: Foreign Affairs; Gulf Of Tonkin II
description: Despite all the predictions that NATO expansion would sail through the Senate like a slam-dunk, the Senate is likely to adjourn this week without a ratification vote. True, the delay is largely due to the refusal by the majority leader, Trent Lott, to let NATO expansion come up for a vote while Democrats were filibustering a Republican education bill. But it is also true that the more the Senate debates the NATO issue, the more senators actually focus on it, and the more they ask the central question to which the Clinton team has never given a satisfactory answer: ''Why are we doing this now?''

title: New Bill Cracks Down On Delinquent Loans
description: Architects, veterinarians and other professionals who default on government-backed student loans could lose their licenses under a bill approved yesterday by the State Senate.

title: On My Mind; Saddam's Sanitation Squad
description: The U.N. inspectors entered the room in one of Saddam Hussein's ''palaces.'' What was in this room? What was its function? the inspectors asked the Iraqi monitors crowding around them.

title: Metro Business; Bank of New York Is to Relocate Offices
description: The Bank of New York Corporation has agreed to lease 300,000 square feet of space in 100 Church Street and will move about 1,300 employees there beginning on June 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORCZYNER, HARRY
description: TORCZYNER-Harry. Ariel United Israel Institute and American Friends of Ariel-Midrasha mourn the passing of Harry Torczyner, father of our devoted friend, supporter and ardent volunteer worker Evi Musher Shechter, wife of our former President and Chairman Board of Governors, Samuel D. Shechter. We express our sincere and heartfelt condolences to Evi and to the entire family. Rabbi Shear-Yashuv Cohen, Chancellor Natalio S. Fridman, Pres. Lawrence A. Kobrin, Chairman Board of Governors Michael D. Jaspan, Treasurer

title: Packing Shea For Today; Then What?
description: There is little chance of a sellout. But the Mets are hoping that when Bobby Jones throws the first pitch of the season to Philadelphia Phillies center fielder Doug Glanville this afternoon, Shea Stadium will have more than 50,000 people on hand.

title: Joseph Sobek, the Inventor Of Racquetball, Dies at 79
description: Almost a half-century ago, Joe Sobek, frustrated that he could not find an indoor racquet sport he liked, designed a new racquet, found a ball of the right size and spring, and invented racquetball. Last Friday, he died at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut at age 79.

title: By Design; Mood-Enhancing Sunglasses
description: To the arsenal of available mood enhancers -- St. Johnswort, lavender bath oil and a brisk walk around the block -- add the latest in sunglasses: wraparound, preferably in a modified cat's-eye shape or a sort of tapered rectangle, and in color.

title: For the Gray Wolf, Blue Skies at Last
description: Reversing a legacy of trapping, hunting and poisoning that eradicated from the wild one of the Southwest's most enduring symbols, Federal biologists announced today that they had released nearly a dozen wolves from chain-link pens into the remote ponderosa forests and meadows here in the White Mountains of eastern Arizona.

title: Unseparated, by Time or Tyranny; A Family Bond Forged in the Fire of the Holocaust
description: By January 1945, the two women had endured months of hunger, cold, lice, the fatigue of digging trenches, the capricious savagery of their Nazi guards and the steady deaths of women around them. But Pepi Deutsch made sure that her daughter, Clara, got to celebrate her 17th birthday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about efforts by American military contractors to lobby the Senate in favor of NATO expansion referred imprecisely to the relationship between the arms industry and the U.S. Committee to Expand NATO. While the committee has the political support of the industry, its by-laws forbid it to accept corporate contributions.

title: Another Lazard Executive Exits
description: Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities said yesterday that it had hired Gerald Rosenfeld, former head of investment banking at the Lazard Freres & Company, to head a $600 million private equity fund.

title: Nurses Strike Maimonides Center In Deadlock Over Cuts in Benefits
description: Six hundred nurses went on strike yesterday at Maimonides Medical Center, demonstrating in force outside Brooklyn's second-largest hospital in an angry picket line that reverberated with cries of strong-arm management tactics.

title: South Korea Wraps Up Bank Debt Extension
description: South Korea wrapped up a $21.8 billion bank debt extension with creditors, paving the way for a swift return to international capital markets. Some 123 international banks agreed to extend 97 percent of eligible foreign debt for up to three years, removing the threat of default.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AKESON, THOMAS F.
description: AKESON-Thomas F. On March 29, 1998 of Dix Hills, NY in his 64th Year. Beloved Husband of June M. (nee Bach). Devoted Father and Best Friend of Thomas C. and Scott M. Dear Brother of John W. Akeson, St. Petersburg, FL, Robert A. Akeson, St. James, NY, and Kenneth W. Akeson, Garden City, NY. Also Survived by Several nieces and nephews. Vice President of Marketing Services for Cotton Incorporated. Reposing Moloney's Hauppauge Funeral Home, 840 Wheeler Road (Rte 111), Hauppauge, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 9:45 AM at St. Matthew's R.C. Church, Dix Hills, NY. Interment following St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Visitng Tuesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. In Lieu of flowers the family requests donations be make to Make a Wish Foundation or the Leukemia Society of America.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the On Stage and Off column in Weekend on Friday about New York stage appearances by movie and television stars referred incompletely to the producers of ''Twelfth Night,'' starring Helen Hunt, at Lincoln Center this summer. It is a production of the Lincoln Center Theater in association with the Lincoln Center Festival, not of the festival alone.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have all been living in a protected environment, like a society of young children. But from now on, only those who think for themselves and act by themselves will survive. And it is a big question whether everyone who belonged to that society can grow up and become an adult.''

title: Early Equinox
description: Q. Our sixth-grade class charted the number of daylight hours based on the times of sunrise and sunset listed in the weather report. We were surprised to find that in New York City on March 17, there were exactly 12 hours of daylight, with sunrise at 6:05 A.M. and sunset at 6:05 P.M. That was three days before March 20, the spring equinox. Shouldn't that be the day with 12 hours of daylight?

title: Just What Is This Language Called Java?
description: THESE are heady times for the programming language called Java. Amid the annual Java One conference for software developers in San Francisco last week, Sun Microsystems Inc., Java's proud parent, won a preliminary injunction against the Microsoft Corporation prohibiting it from claiming its products are officially ''Java Compatible.'' Before that, the Hewlett-Packard Company announced that it was developing its own potentially incompatible version of Java for devices like printers.

title: KNOWLEDGE UNIVERSE TO ACQUIRE CHILDREN'S DISCOVERY
description: Children's Discovery Centers of America Inc., a provider of child care and preschool programs, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by closely held Knowledge Universe L.L.C. for as much as $99.1 million in cash, as Knowledge Universe expands its educational services to children from infancy through eighth grade. Under the agreement, Knowledge Beginnings L.L.C., a unit of Knowledge Universe, will pay $12.25 a share for Children's Discovery. The shares of Children's Discovery Centers, based in San Rafael, Calif., rose $1.875 each, to $12. Knowledge Universe is based in Burlingame, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRIMMINS, VIOLET ROTHWELL
description: CRIMMINS-Violet Rothwell. Of Darien, CT, March 29, 1998. Wife of the late Robert Crimmins. Mother of Sally Thorne, Anne Crimmins, & Susan Crimmins. Grandmother of four. At her request, there will be no services. Donations in her memory may be made to Hospice Care, Inc. 1029 East Main Street, Stamford, Connecticut 06902.

title: Barkley Fined for Outburst
description: The National Basketball Association fined forward Charles Barkley of the Rockets $10,000 yesterday for calling Referee Jack Nies gutless after being ejected from a game against the Orlando Magic.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: ARCHERY

title: An Assassin Of Malcolm X Gets Islam Post
description: Muhammad Abdul Aziz, who was Norman 3X Butler in the turbulent 1960's when he and two other Black Muslims were convicted of assassinating Malcolm X, has been named by Louis Farrakhan as chief of security for the Harlem mosque once headed by the civil rights leader, Nation of Islam officials said yesterday.

title: Why Live in Russia? Maybe Mammoths Were the Lure
description: FOR as long as humans have lived here, near Moscow where the soil is poor, the winds are harsh and the winters are brutal legends -- people have asked a simple, compelling question: What kind of a migratory mania could have brought people to this place?

title: Seton Hall's Kaba Earns An Award for Courage
description: Seton Hall's Jacky Kaba has not seen his parents and four brothers since 1990 and has not spoken to them since Christmas. He does not know whether they are still alive because a civil war in Liberia has been going on since 1989, with the death toll at 150,000. Kaba studies pictures of dead bodies from Liberia on the Internet, hoping he does not spot members of his family.

title: 2 Developers Bid Top Dollar For What's Left in Times Sq.
description: Outbidding a dozen other developers, Mortimer B. Zuckerman and George Klein have won the rights to buy the last two development sites in Times Square, but at a price that vastly exceeds that of similar buildings in the booming, neon-encrusted neighborhood, said real estate executives and a top state official.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Low earnings notwithstanding, 3Com stock still has believers.
description: WALL STREET lowered earnings estimates for the 3Com Corporation last week after the company reported earnings well below stock analysts' estimates for the second consecutive quarter.

title: INSIDE
description: Saudi Attack Unresolved

title: Ewing's Return Is Looking More Likely, but When?
description: He ran and shot well today, sailing through the routine basketball drills with energy to spare. Patrick Ewing continues to show signs that he is on his way toward participating in a full-contact practice with his teammates, leaving only one pertinent question:

title: Agency Faults Safety Reports Filed by F.A.A.
description: Federal Aviation Administration inspectors so seldom cite airlines for breaking safety rules that they are probably forgiving many violations on the spot, the General Accounting Office said today in a scathing review of the agency's ability to find problems and recognize trends.

title: Court to Rule If Death Ends Confidentiality Right for Client
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide what happens to the attorney-client privilege after the client dies.

title: With Warmth and Lyricism, A Love Song to the Violin
description: Holding the first composer's chair at Carnegie Hall these past three years has probably brought Ellen Taaffe Zwilich more firmly into the spotlight than winning the Pulitzer Prize did in 1983. In her official capacity, Ms. Zwilich advises Carnegie on contemporary music and directs a series of composer spotlight concerts that has ranged freely through contemporary styles, including avant-garde approaches outside Carnegie's usual purview. But from a composer's point of view, surely the most valuable aspect of the job is the profile it gives one's works. Older scores by Ms. Zwilich have been revived for Carnegie programs, and there are regular commissions for works meant to have their premieres at the hall.

title: Oblivious to Attention or Pressure
description: At one point last Friday night in Philadelphia, three former rookies of the year were on the court at the same time. But it was the future rookie of the year who was creating the stir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, ETHEL
description: MEYERS-Ethel, 96, in Miami, FL. on March 28, 1998. Wife of the late Harry, mother of Rosalie (Fred) Lichtblau and the late Robert. Rest in peace.

title: Malcolm X Assassin Now Mosque Official
description: Muhammad Abdul Aziz, one of three men convicted of assassinating Malcolm X, has been named by Louis Farrakhan as chief of security for the Harlem mosque once headed by the civil rights leader, Nation of Islam officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEGER, LOUIS
description: KRIEGER-Louis. Fifty year resident of Elmont, New York, beloved husband of Barbara, father of David and Lenore, grandfather of Sari, Daniel and Alexander, died on Sunday, March 29, 1998. Service will be held on Tuesday, March 31, 3 P.M., at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: Appealing for Asylum, 12 Crash Into UN's Offices in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR  In a desperate attempt to avoid being sent back to Indonesia, 12 asylum seekers crashed a truck through the gates of a United Nations office here Monday as Malaysia deported nearly 1,500 more illegal immigrants.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japan Plans for Big Bang, A Financial Overhaul

title: Swiss Seek to Narrow List of Holocaust Funds to Be Recovered
description: After agreeing last week to begin negotiations to settle Holocaust-era financial disputes, Switzerland's leading banks are seeking to limit the focus to accounts left untouched since the Second World War.

title: Kennelly Picks New Manager in Attempt to Refocus Campaign
description: Representative Barbara B. Kennelly sought yesterday to steer her drifting campaign for Connecticut governor, hiring a new manager and announcing an agenda that includes tougher standards for students and tax cuts for homeowners.

title: Last Rites for a 'Plywood Palace' That Was a Rock of Science
description: There was a wake here on Friday, and more than 200 mourners gathered to mark the passing and celebrate, not a person, but an unusual building. The mourners were mostly scientists who had worked in the building, ''the plywood palace,'' as it has been called for 50 years, a building that was midwife to a great array of discoveries in fields as varied as radar and frog vision.

title: What's New: Two Teams What's Old: Top Teams
description: As part of the opening game ceremonies at Pro Player Stadium Tuesday, the Florida Marlins will raise the World Series championship flag. Maybe they should fly it at half-staff in memory of half the World Series team that is no longer there.

title: New Leader Takes Over Organization Of 800 Rabbis
description: The New York Board of Rabbis, which represents 800 rabbis from congregations around the New York metropolitan area, last night installed as its president Marc Schneier, an Orthodox rabbi who can trace his rabbinical roots back 18 generations.

title: 2 Strong Antagonists Hold Ulster's Fate
description: As Roman Catholic and Protestant leaders met here today with a deadline of 11 days for finding a settlement of Northern Ireland's 29 years of sectarian warfare, two skilled, powerful and antagonistic politicians will determine whether the talks lead to peace, or to more violence.

title: The fast-paced world of telecommunications means swift turnover in agencies.
description: THE ringing sound that executives along Madison Avenue keep hearing isn't a sign of stress or a symptom of tinnitus. It's a signal from telecommunications clients, who are calling more frequently to change agencies.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: American League

title: Bill Limits Time Fathers Can Object to Adoption
description: The State Senate approved a bill yesterday that sets a limit of 120 days after the birth of a child for a father to contest an adoption.

title: Clinton Asks For Sanctions In Jones Case
description: President Clinton moved for contempt sanctions against Paula Corbin Jones's legal team today, saying that it released a flood of false and salacious accusations over the weekend that violated the court's guidelines and tainted potential jurors.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC WILL BUY CECORR FOR $190 MILLION
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Cecorr Inc., a corrugated-sheets producer, for about $190 million in cash and stock. Georgia-Pacific, based in Atlanta, is a maker of pulp and paper products with 1997 sales of $3.22 billion. Cecorr, a closely held company based in Indianapolis, operates 11 sheet feeder plants, a corrugating medium paper mill, and several specialty operations and support service groups. It has annual sales of $282 million. Under the agreement, expected to close this spring, Georgia-Pacific will also assume $86 million of Cecorr's debt.

title: Hilton Casinos' Head Was Paid $1 Million
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation's head of gambling operations, Arthur Goldberg, received a salary almost twice as large as that of the company's chief executive, Stephen Bollenbach, last year.

title: Norway Pledges to Take Part In Worldwide Oil Supply Cuts
description: An emerging coalition of oil-exporting countries seeking to reduce production and raise prices was significantly strengthened yesterday when Norway, a major exporter, said it would cut its output as much as 100,000 barrels a day.

title: Nordstrom Names Fallon McElligott
description: Nordstrom Inc. said yesterday that it had named Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis as the first agency to handle a branding assignment for the fashion specialty department store chain. Though billings have not been determined, trade publications estimated them at $20 million to $30 million.

title: He'll No Longer Be Home Alone
description: Having outgrown his role as a round-mouthed youngster in the ''Home Alone'' films, MACAULAY CULKIN has asked to play a different part: husband. Mr. Culkin, 17, is engaged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAHEY, EUGENE E.
description: VAHEY-Eugene E. On March 29, 1998. Husband of Carole A. (nee Dickinson). Father of Mary, Hugh, Deborah, Doris, Katherine, Patricia, Eileen, Thomas and the late Michael. Grandfather of Michael, William, Katherine and Andrew. Brother of Catherine. Friend of Carolanne Travell. Reposing at the Walter B. CookeKennedy F.H., 117 W. 72nd St on Mon. 7-9 and Tues. 2-5 & 7-9. Funeral Wed. 9:30 a.m. Mass of Christian Burial Ascension R.C. Church 10 a.m. 221 W. 107th St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations in Gene's memory may be made to American Heart Association.

title: Imperial Chemical to Buy Acheson Industries
description: Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Acheson Industries for $560 million. Acheson, based in Port Huron, Mich., makes specialty chemicals for the electronics and computer industries. It had sales of $189 million last year. Imperial Chemical, based in London, makes petrochemicals, polymers and general industrial chemicals. It had revenue of $18.6 billion in 1997.
